title: Mathematical Metaphors in Art
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Many Ways Seen to Ease Property Tax
description: The State Property Tax Commission, created by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman after her narrow re-election victory last fall, has agreed on dozens of recommendations intended to lower real estate taxes in New Jersey.

title: Tracy Stallard Is 61 And Keeping Quiet
description: If Tracy Stallard had called yesterday, we could have wished him a happy 61st birthday. And asked him about Roger Maris's 61st home run.

title: Radioactive 'Seeds' Check Cancers In Prostate
description: PATIENTS with prostate cancer may be able to avoid radical surgery and subsequent incontinence and impotence with radioactive ''seeds,'' no bigger than grains of rice, that are strategically implanted in the prostate, says a Seattle doctor who has monitored 152 cancer patients over the last decade.

title: Elliott Is Charged With D.W.I. and Speeding
description: Jumbo Elliott, the Jets' left tackle and a key player in the team's fortunes, was arrested at 5 A.M. Sunday not far from his Nassau County home, and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol as well as speeding at 80 miles per hour, 25 m.p.h. over the speed limit. He was held for three hours and then released on his own recognizance and a court date was set in Hempstead, N.Y., for next Tuesday. That is a day off for players who open the season on Sunday in San Francisco.

title: Taking a Political Detour, Unions Shift Into Neutral
description: About this time in election years, the political gears of New York's powerful labor unions begin turning -- grinding out mailings, setting up phone banks, organizing rallies and issuing endorsements. In statewide elections, those blessings are usually bestowed on Democrats.

title: Wieden to End McCann Alliance
description: Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., said yesterday that it would dissolve an alliance with McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising on its shared Nike Inc. account in Japan and open its own office there.

title: Two Pitchers Get Tests
description: Jeff Nelson and Darren Holmes, who are on the disabled list because of back trouble, each pitched an inning for the Yankees' Class A affiliate in Tampa, Fla., last night. Holmes allowed a hit and struck out three in one scoreless inning. Nelson surrendered a run, a hit and a walk and struck out two. Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, said both said they felt fine afterward, but how they feel the day after they pitch will be more important. Nelson and Holmes are scheduled to pitch for Tampa again tomorrow, before being activated Friday, barring setbacks.

title: Losses Pile Up On Wall Street As Markets Keep Eroding
description: Wall Street is starting to count the cost of the recent turmoil in financial markets.

title: A Bitter Airline Strike
description: It is hard to imagine a less sympathetic union than one made up of high-salaried pilots. Northwest Airlines, in a move to exploit that vulnerability, has launched a large advertising campaign denouncing the pilots, saying they get a lot of money for very little work. The pilots have their own, smaller campaign blasting management as being greedy.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's like childbirth. It's not easy when you're going through it, but after the pains your whole life is better. The party's not over for me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, ABRAHAM N.
description: GORDON-Abraham N. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the father of our Member, Florence Wassner, and extends to her and the family our heartfelt condolences.

title: Nuclear-Disaster Pills
description: To the Editor:

title: New Generation of American Men Finds Ways to Win
description: Following in the sneakerprints of Pete Sampras, Andre Agassi, Jim Courier and Michael Chang has the potential to be a very thankless task. But yesterday at the United States Open, several members of the latest, if probably not greatest, generation of American men's tennis players managed to prosper at the expense of visitors from foreign lands.

title: CAMBRIDGE TECHNOLOGY AGREES TO ACQUIRE EXCELL DATA
description: Cambridge Technology Partners Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Excell Data Corporation, a closely held information technology-consulting and software concern, for $60.1 million in stock, Cambridge, based in Cambridge, Mass., provides consulting and software-development services. Excell, based in Bellevue, Wash., integrates systems based on Microsoft technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERR, ALICE
description: SCHERR-Alice. Of Palm Beach, Fla. and previouly Great Neck. Died peacefully at her home on Sunday. Beloved wife of the late Percy. Loving mother to Ellen, to Richard and Ellie, and Kenneth. Adored nanny to Nicole and Ross and to Michael and Jonathan. We will all remember your dignified beauty and love of life.

title: A Bossa Nova Princess Blending Shyness and Fizz
description: ''Brazilfest '98,'' a condensed program at the Damrosch Park Band Shell on Sunday night, was pure Rio suavity, most of it borne on the broad shoulders of Antonio Carlos Jobim, with replications of original arrangements of his songs. The singer Bebel Gilberto, daughter of Joao Gilberto, performed, as well as the young singers Patricia Marx and Carol Saboya and the light-classical chamber music group Quinteto D'Elas.

title: Francisco Salveron, MacArthur's Aide, Dies at 88
description: Francisco Salveron, a Philippine-born Army orderly whose devotion to Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur in World War II gave him a front-row role in MacArthur's historic return to the Philippines, died on Aug. 23 at his home in Bladensburg, Md. He was 88.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the exhibition ''Ahab's Wife,'' which is at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center on Staten Island through Oct. 4, misstated the center's telephone number. It is (718) 448-2500.

title: After Break From Past, Lucic Wins
description: Mirjana Lucic, who said last week that she had left her father/coach, Marinko, because he physically abused her and tampered with her prize money, did not let her family problems interfere with her United States Open assignment.

title: Union Pacific to Limit Traffic on Its Tracks
description: The Union Pacific Corporation, still recovering from some of the worst congestion in the industry's history, announced a plan today to improve and, in some cases, ration its service.

title: Missile Test by North Korea: Dark Omen for Washington
description: North Korea's test today of a medium-range missile able to reach targets in Japan represents a technological breakthrough that has raised new fears of the spread of ballistic missiles, Administration officials and arms control experts said.

title: Restoring Hearing, After Too Much Noise
description: THE world is awash with noise, an endless banging, ringing, thumping and clanging that not only annoys but also steals. The deafening din slowly takes away the hearing of many and, in cases of enormous assault, can result in deafness within days.

title: Nuclear-Disaster Pills
description: To the Editor:

title: Phone Companies Create Traffic Jam on Road to Internet
description: THE next high hurdle for the personal computer industry is keeping many a chip maker and computer manufacturer awake at night, because after 15 years of building ever faster and more powerful machines, the wizards of silicon increasingly find themselves at the mercy of local phone companies.

title: When Lightning Strikes, Lives Are Changed
description: George McBay never saw it coming. The 51-year-old industrial roofer said he was six stories high, helping lower a large metal pipe down to a worker on the ground below when he heard a large, ''explosion-like'' boom and felt ''like I had just been through a B-52 bombing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, PHILIP F.
description: COHEN-Philip F. Founder of Oceana Publications. On August 29, 1998. Husband of Fay. Father of David Cohen, Anne Cohen, and Karen Schnabel. Visiting 11 am until noon prior to funeral at 12 noon, Wednesday, at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (Saw Mill Exit 17), Dobbs Ferry, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory to The Foundation for the Community Hospital at Dobbs Ferry, 128 Ashford, Dobbs Ferry, NY 10522, preferred.

title: Is Global Collapse At Hand?
description: There can be little doubt that world financial markets are now in full-blown crisis. With yet another black Monday taking the Dow down 513 points yesterday, a sense of despair and desperation has set in. Global currency contagion has run rampant, from Thailand to Russia and all too many points in between. The International Monetary Fund seems to be out of bullets. Investors are stripping risk from their portfolios.

title: 'Titanic,' the Promotion, Lands at Video Stores
description: It is not often that the release of a video generates a promotional blitz, but when the video is that of the highest-grossing movie of all time, it is a sure bet that video stores will make the biggest splash possible to draw in as much money as possible.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERARD, FRED N.
description: GERARD-Fred N. 1930-1997. Still disbelieving, we cherish you more than words can say. Your children, Daniele and Gregory

title: McCaughey Ross and Husband Meet on Campaign's Future
description: Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the investment banker who has been financing the gubernatorial campaign of his wife, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, held a formal meeting with Ms. McCaughey Ross last night to discuss the future of the campaign amid indications that he has grown reluctant to give the campaign carte blanche, people close to the campaign said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRECHER, ALBERT
description: BRECHER-Albert. On August 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Diane. Devoted father of Leslie and Gary Stern and Donna and Andrew Goldberg. Cherished grandfather of Jessica Haley Stern. Loving brother of Lillian Sternberg. Services Wednesday, 12 Noon, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: The Rise of the Stylist: A Double-Edged Sword
description: Several years ago, about the worst epithet a fashion insider could fling at Ralph Lauren in the face of his undeniable success was to describe him as a stylist. To call a designer a stylist -- the implication being that one's talent is not in creating clothes, but in presenting them -- is no longer a barb. The wall between the two is crumbling, as more stylists become the creative forces behind collections and more successful collections resemble the work of a good stylist.

title: Piazza Gives Dodgers a Parting Shot
description: Had he chosen to, Mike Piazza could have sat out the Mets' 8-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight. The All-Star catcher had taken a foul ball off his right shoulder in the first inning of Sunday night's loss and then removed himself from the game after the inning was over. His shoulder was still smarting when he came to the ball park today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAM, MURRAY
description: FLAM-Murray. On August 30, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Robin and Neil, Lisa & William, Gary and Annalea. Cherished grandfather of Gabriel, Daniel, Jennifer, Patrick and Jonathon. Dear brother of Sylvia and Albert. Services Wednesday, 12:30 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting hours Tuesday 7-9 PM.

title: North Korea Test-Fires a Missile Off Japan's North
description: SEOUL  North Korea test-fired its longest-range ballistic missile to date into waters off northern Japan on Monday in a show of strength that analysts believed was designed to impress its own starving people as much as the rest of the world.

title: I.R.A. Denies Link to Bombing in Northern Ireland and Rejects Calls for Disarmament
description: The Irish Republican Army, which has observed a cease-fire for 13 months, made a rare public statement today, denying any connection to a bombing that killed 28 people two weeks ago in Omagh, Northern Ireland.

title: Senate Panel Finds Insufficient Evidence to Tie Iraqi Gas to Illnesses
description: A Senate committee has concluded that while the Government failed many veterans of the Persian Gulf war there is insufficient evidence to conclude that exposure to Iraqi nerve gas caused the illnesses reported by thousands of American soldiers.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO BUY NORTHLAND UNIT
description: The Associates First Capital Corporation, America's largest consumer finance company, said yesterday that it would buy the insurance business of the privately held Northland Company of Mendota Heights, Minn., to improve its insurance sales. Associates, based in Dallas, is rumored to be paying almost $700 million for the company, or about twice book value, but terms were not disclosed by the companies. The unit sells trucking and other commercial property-casualty insurance through independent agents. Associates, which was spun off by the Ford Motor Company this year, already sells such coverage through its 100 commercial branch offices. Its stock fell $5.75 a share yesterday, to $59.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Plan to Demolish a Century-Old Church Splits a Parish
description: When parishioners at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church learned several months ago that their Bishop intended to demolish their 100-year-old church and replace it with a larger one, they responded with both relief and anguish.

title: 53 Years Later, Lawsuit Is Filed on Behalf of Hitler's Slave Labor
description: Encouraged by their success in persuading Swiss banks to repay victims of the Holocaust, lawyers in the United States and Germany are suing Germany's biggest industrial companies on behalf of workers forced into slave labor during Hitler's regime.

title: Bush's Achievement
description: To the Editor:

title: Female Refs Debut In Blaze of Red Cards
description: The league sent two women -- Sandra Hunt and Nancy Lay -- onto the field over the weekend as referees and they, in turn, sent off three players with red cards.

title: For Aging Ocean Explorer, a New Life at New Depths
description: THE sea has millions of dark secrets. And now, a famous explorer is to illuminate more of them.

title: Celebrating Parker In His Own Spirit
description: Staging a Charlie Parker Jazz Festival worthy of its name is a difficult job, but the sixth annual edition of the concert, at a packed Tompkins Square Park on Sunday afternoon, did the trick in a way that was neither curatorially exact nor some sort of seance. The great saxophonist's style of harmony, phrasing, composition, tone, choice of repertory and bravado are part of the modern jazz player's kit and that was the conceptual starting point for all four acts. The audience was a rare example of a jazz-concert crowd that was full of musicians, laughing at musical jokes, cooing at references.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS SURGES. Speculation that a storm in the Gulf of Mexico could disrupt natural gas production pushed prices up almost 7 percent. Gas for October delivery rose to $1.775 for a million British thermal units from $1.664.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRONSTEIN, MELVIN
description: BRONSTEIN-Melvin, M.D. A unique man, so dearly missed by his wife and children. Remembered warmly by all who knew him. Know you'll be watching over Wendy's wedding. Your loving family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARVER, MARIE
description: CARVER-Marie (nee Frega), died at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center, on August 30, 1998, after a brief illness. Mrs. Carver was predeceased by her beloved husband, William and her fond companion, Charles Dreitlein. She is survived by her dear cousin, Sophie Walsh and her devoted brother-in-law, Gino Bagnasco. Marie Carver was for many years Executive Secretary and Personal Assistant to Jack Wrather, Chairman of the Board of Wrather Corporation and Muzak Corporation. She also assisted Mr. Wrather's wife, the noted actress Ronita Granville. During her years with The Wrather's she worked on such shows as ''Lassie'' and ''Sgt. Preston of the Yukon''. In later years, she joined Worldvision Enterprises, Inc. as Executive Secretary and Special Assistant to the Chairman of the Board, Kevin O'Sullivan. During her tenure at Worldvision, Mrs. Carver was involved with the development of such Television Presentations as ''Holocaust'', ''Little House on the Prairie'', Freedom Road'', ''The Love Boat'', ''Mod Squad'', Barnaby Jones'', and many others. Kevin O'Sullivan stated, 'Marie Carver as a remarkable talented woman. She not only was of great professional assistance to me, but she was a true friend. My family and I will miss her deeply'. Funeral from McCorry Brothers Funeral Home, 780 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, N.J., on Wednesday, September 2, at 9:00 A.M. Mass of the Resurrection will be at Epiphany Church, Knox Avenue, Cliffside Park, at 9:45 A.M. Burial to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y. Visitation on Tuesday, September 1, from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Too Much Faith in the Fed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Congress (Monica) Has Month (Monica) to Set Spending (Monica)
description: With only five weeks left on the legislative calendar, Capitol Hill is girding for a chaotic if unproductive end-of-session dominated by Monica Lewinsky.

title: Reporter at The Times to Receive Award for Decades of Journalism
description: A reporter for The New York Times has won the 1998 John Chancellor Award for Excellence in Journalism, the Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania plans to announce today.

title: First TV Ads From Ferraro Lead Senate Race Into the Final Heat
description: After 10 months of running a curiously quiescent campaign for United States Senate, Geraldine A. Ferraro turned up the volume yesterday with her first two television advertisements, while her opponents for the Democratic nomination, Mark Green and Charles E. Schumer, spent the day touting their records on social issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ERWIN
description: GREENBERG - Erwin. Beloved husband of the late Marjorie and Florence. Loving father of Jessica and Ellen and James Tilzer. Devoted grandfather of Katherine, Andrew, Brian & Lisa. Wonderful stepfather and step-grandfather. Memorial service to be held on Wednesday at 11 AM at Temple Beth El, 220 South Bedford Road, Chappaqua, New York.

title: Smith Injured When Thrown
description: Mike Smith, the leading rider at Saratoga this summer, was hospitalized yesterday after he was flipped during the ninth race.

title: Persistence vs. Stalking
description: To the Editor:

title: Omnipoint Starts New Fee Plans
description: Omnipoint Communications said today that it would introduce new pricing plans for its wireless customers that eliminate certain monthly fees for customers who prepay.

title: A Theory: Too Cold, Too Hot, Then Just Right for Animals
description: THE first animals on earth may have been shocked into existence by the evolutionary one-two punch of a climatic episode so cold that the oceans froze -- snowball earth -- followed by one of the hottest periods in earth history, according to a new hypothesis based largely on studies of carbon atoms in ancient sediments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKER, JACK
description: SCHENKER-Jack. On August 30, 1998 of North Palm Beach, FL, formerly of N.Y.C. A former partner of Newmark & Company Real Estate. Beloved husband of Leonore (Mandell). Loving father and stepfather of Susan Schulman, James and Richard Mandell and Margery Sugarman. Cherished grandfather of Andrew and Amy. Service on Wednesday 11 A.M., at Menorah Gardens and Funeral Chapel, 9321 Memorial Park Road, West Palm Beach, FL. 33412. 561-627-2277

title: Hong Kong Shifts Gears, This Time Trying Reverse
description: The Hong Kong government continued to play cat-and-mouse today -- abruptly withdrawing from the stock market after it had feverishly intervened last week. Without the government to prop up shares, Hong Kong's market promptly plunged 7.1 percent.

title: School Work, Homework And Good Works in Chicago
description: To instill a sense of civic duty in teen-agers, the Chicago public school system has become the largest district in the nation to require students to perform community service to receive a high school diploma.

title: Applications Keep Pace For New Charter Schools
description: Despite past complaints that privately run charter schools siphon money from public schools but are not as accountable, 35 applications to establish charter schools in 1999 have been received from parent, teacher and civic groups, state officials said yesterday. The total is nearly as many as the 37 applications submitted in each of the program's first two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BRUNT, ROBERT ERNEST
description: Van BRUNT-Robert Ernest. On August 29, at age 87 in Columbia, SC. Formerly of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. and Sarasota, FL. Beloved husband of the late Gladys Strongin, father of Vincent of Columbia, SC and Peter of Chevy Chase, MD. Dear father-in-law of Marjorie J.; devoted grandfather of Edward R. and Zachary J. of Columbia, SC; brother of Edwin D. of Somers, NY and Albert D. of NYC and East Hampton, NY. Loving companion of Janet Cohen of Longboat Key, FL. Retired VP of Consolidated Insurance Companies of Brooklyn, NY; taught at College of Insurance in NYC. Served in the US 7th Army in North Africa and France in WW II. Contributions in his memory can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, Development Division, 919 North Michigan Ave. Suite 1000, Chicago, IL 60611.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAPOPORT, PORTER GRACE
description: RAPOPORT-Porter Grace. We love you and miss you. Miriam, Ellen and Steve

title: Investors Take Flight
description: For most of the past decade, the individual American investor has been a bulwark against panic in world financial markets. When money managers got scared and started selling, it was individuals who bought, believing that all declines, like the 1987 crash, were buying opportunities.

title: Rumors of the Death of Bears Were, It Seems, Exaggerated
description: As they surveyed their outsized stock market gains over the last three years, some investors may have thought to wonder, on occasion and in an idle sort of way, just what a bear market felt like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAHLER, REBECCA
description: ZAHLER-Rebecca. Loving mother of Bernard Zahler, Vivian Lerer, Gloria Kestenbaum. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Shiva at 550 B. 129 Street, Belle Harbor, until Sunday morning.

title: BASEBALL: Homers Come With Patience; Neck and Neck With McGwire, Sosa Is Knocking Them Out
description: Sammy Sosa is in the batting cage at Wrigley Field, and his coaches are talking hitting. They use a strange vocabulary, with talk of tap stepping and loading up, of quiet hands and early feet. They are all code words for patience.

title: North Korean Missile Is Fired Across Japan
description: North Korea fired a ballistic missile over Japan, which called the firing ''extremely dangerous.''

title: Global Vigilante
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, JUDITH S.
description: STEWART-Judith S. On August 17, 1998. Retired NYC Principal of Marta Valle J.H.S. #

title: DOW OFF 6% IN WAVE OF SELLING, ERASING MARKET'S GAINS FOR '98; PRESSURE FOR RATE CUT LIKELY
description: Waves of selling by investors large and small engulfed the stock market yesterday.

title: VIACOM TO BUY BACK AS MUCH AS $1.75 BILLION OF ITS STOCK
description: The media giant Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back up to $1.75 billion of securities. Viacom said it would repurchase one or more classes of equity securities over an unspecified time, beginning immediately. Viacom's class B shares, the most commonly traded of Viacom's securities, closed at $49.75, down $4.375 in yesterday's rout on the American Stock Exchange. The class A shares were also down $4.375 each, to $49.125. Viacom, based in New York, is an entertainment and publishing company whose operations include the Blockbuster video-rental chain, MTV Networks, Paramount Pictures, Showtime and Simon & Schuster.

title: In Russia's Parliament: Name-Calling, Pleading, Urgency, but No Premier
description: Following are excerpts from statements today by Russian political leaders in the debate over the nomination of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to be Prime Minister, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Viagra's fast climb to iconic status makes it a natural for a variety of campaigns.
description: MADISON AVENUE is answering in the affirmative when asked ''Am I blue?'' -- not a reference to Wall Street but to a certain little pill.

title: Backyard Bugs
description: Q. How many insects and other arthropods might you find in a Northeastern backyard?

title: Stockholm Journal; In Years Since Palme Killing, a Loss of Innocence
description: The site is so modestly marked that it is easy to miss. Perhaps appropriately, one must bow one's head to see it.

title: Nothing Becomes a Man More Than a Woman's Face
description: A TIMELESS movie scene some of us wish we could forget: Leonardo DiCaprio climbing to the bowsprit of the ''Titanic'' and crowing, ''I'm the king of the world!''

title: Latin America Is Buffeted, but Seems Stronger Than in '94
description: The demons of financial crisis are haunting Latin America again, unleashed by tumult in Russia, Japan and, now, the United States. Markets and currencies across the region are sinking as panicky investors retreat to the safe haven of American Treasury bonds and dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SOSLER, CAROLYN ATLAS
description: SOSLER-Carolyn Atlas. April 10, 1940-September 1, 1993. ''The world breaks everyone and afterward many are strong at the broken places. But those that will not break it kills. It kills the very good and the very gentle and the very brave.'' Hemingway. You are always with us. Pop, Neil, Andree

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONEMAN, EDNA
description: STONEMAN-Edna. In Los Gatos, CA, August 30, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Milton Stoneman. Loving mother of Rita Norton and the late Ronald Stoneman, and mother-in-law of Kent Norton. Devoted grandmother of Marcy and Daniel Norton. Dear sister of Alexander Lurkis and beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Memorial services to be announced. For information Oak Hill Funeral Home, 1-408-297-2447.

title: Market Is No Longer Staunch Clinton Ally
description: He had good reasons to go to Russia, President Clinton told a friendly audience in an elementary school gymnasium in Virginia shortly before noon today. ''We have learned the hard way,'' he said, ''that problems that develop beyond our borders sooner or later find their way to our doorstep.''

title: Credit Suisse Selling Reinsurance Business
description: Credit Suisse Group said yesterday that it had agreed to sell the reinsurance business of its Winterthur Insurance Company unit to the Bermuda-based Partnerre Ltd. for 1.125 billion Swiss francs ($750 million). Credit Suisse said that the sale was another step in the strategy of having Winterthur concentrate on its core insurance business, and that proceeds from the deal would be reinvested in Winterthur's primary insurance operations in Western and Eastern Europe and in Asia.

title: THE MARKET TURMOIL: DEJA VU -- The Shadow of Black Monday; Wall St. Has Come a Long Way Since '87, Hasn't It?
description: In the stock market, the sky is falling -- again.

title: The Market Turmoil
description: ECHOES OF 1987 -- For many, yesterday's market plunge revived memories of Black Monday. But there are differences. Page C1.

title: More Latin Strongmen?
description: To the Editor:

title: BINKS SAMES TO SELL SOME ASSETS TO ILLINOIS TOOL
description: The Binks Sames Corporation, a maker of industrial spray-painting equipment based in Franklin Park, Ill., agreed yesterday to sell certain assets and product lines to Illinois Tool Works Inc. for $80 million. Illinois Tool, based in Glenview, Ill., will also assume about $26 million of debt. Illinois Tool will purchase assets that include a leased manufacturing plant in Longmont, Colo. and the Poly-Craft Systems division in Cottage Grove, Ore. International operations in Britain, Belgium, Germany, Australia and Canada are included in the sale. Binks shares fell $2.50, to $25.125, on the American Stock Exchange. Illinois Tool shares fell $3.50, to $48.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Volatility in Stocks Likely To Slow Merger Agreements
description: The recent volatility in stock prices is likely to slow this year's flurry of mergers and acquisitions, analysts said yesterday.

title: Tax Takes a Holiday for Some Back-to-School Shoppers
description: In a back-to-school gift to shoppers and retailers, the fourth tax-free shopping week in the last two years begins today in New York State, with state sales taxes eliminated on all clothing and shoes costing less than $500.

title: Queens Rivals to Meet Again in Primary for Assembly
description: When Pauline R. Cummings was selected by Queens Democratic Party leaders as their candidate in a special election for an Assembly seat five months ago, she was backed by the party's elected officials in that borough.

title: By Design; Longer for Fall
description: Spring's pleated skirt has grown longer for fall, its hem reaching anywhere from below the knee to the floor. Just keep in mind that those ankle-length and longer skirts are cut to fit tall women.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 2 of Dr. Edward F. Edinger, a leading American interpreter of the psychoanalytical theories of Carl Jung, referred to Dr. Edinger's marital status incorrectly. He and Frances McCarthy were not divorced but were still married when she died in 1995; at his death, Dr. Edinger was not married to his companion, Dianne D. Cordic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CICCOTELLI, EMIL A.
description: CICCOTELLI-Emil A. Retired Deputy Chief NYPD on August 30, 1998. Dearest husband of Lorraine (nee Reeber). Beloved father of Thomas E., Michael P., Emil A., Jr., James T., Peter M., Richard T. Ciccotelli and Jeanmarie A. Dool. Also survived by his 15 grandchildren and two brothers. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10:30 AM at St. Barnabas Church. Interment following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. The family will be present Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Ave., Yonkers, NY.

title: Weinke Passes First Test at Age 26
description: Florida State came here tonight, to the Kickoff Classic, lugging lofty expectations and saddled with high anxiety. Much of it centered on the team's 26-year-old sophomore quarterback, Chris Weinke.

title: Metro Business; Big Cinema Planned For Jamaica Center
description: National Amusements, the Massachusetts-based parent company of Viacom Inc., has announced plans to develop a 15-screen, 3,200-seat movie theater complex at Jamaica Center in Queens.

title: Mexican Stocks Fall Sharply Over Interest Rate Concerns
description: Mexican stocks tumbled for the eighth day out of nine as traders dumped securities on concerns rising interest rates will stall the consumer spending engine that's been driving economic growth.

title: INSIDE
description: Student Service in Chicago

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIZZA, CARMELO
description: ZIZZA-Carmelo. On August 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Gregoria nee (Mazzarino). Loving father of Agata DiBartolo, Antonino, Maria DiBartolo and Salvatore. Devoted grandfather of 9 & great grandfather of 3. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Sons, 1305 79 Street, Bklyn, N.Y. Funeral mass Thurs., 9:20AM at St. Mary Mother of Jesus Church. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: People
description: * Kevin C. Clark, vice chairman at Modem Media.Poppe Tyson, Westport, Conn., part of True North Communications, resigned, to pursue what he described as ''new ventures within the Internet marketplace.'' There are no plans for a successor to Mr. Clark, who had been chairman and chief executive of Poppe Tyson before that agency was merged with Modem Media.

title: Too Much Faith in the Fed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sprewell Refiles Suit Against N.B.A.
description: Thirty days after Latrell Sprewell's lawsuit against the National Basketball Association and the Golden State Warriors was dismissed on procedural grounds, his lawyers amended and refiled their complaint yesterday. Charging that the league had destroyed evidence while investigating Sprewell's assault on Coach P.J. Carlesimo, the suit asks that Sprewell pay a fine of no more than $1 million for his actions last December.

title: Russia on the Verge
description: Boris Yeltsin's hastily arranged deal with the Communists last weekend was troubling, but Sunday night's sudden collapse of their bargain could prove even worse. Its first negative consequence was yesterday's parliamentary rebuff to Mr. Yeltsin's nominee for prime minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin. Russia is left without a government at a moment when urgent action is needed to check the country's vertiginous financial free fall. A prolonged vacuum in Moscow could fracture the geographically sprawling Russian Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, HENNI
description: FRIEDLANDER-HENNI. January 1, 1927-September 1, 1991 you are with us always. The wound heals but the scar remains. Everyone misses you.

title: U.S. OPEN: A Mother's Diary; Defeat Comes Without Despair
description: Samantha Stevenson's diary of her 17-year-old daughter Alexandra's season, leading up to her first appearance in the main draw of a Grand Slam tournament, appeared on the Perspective page in SportsSunday. Here is her description of Alexandra's first-round match yesterday at the United States Open.

title: Some Think Time Is Right for a Market-Calming Rate Cut
description: As foreign and domestic investors fled to the safe harbor of the United States Treasury market yesterday, talk was growing of a market-calming interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.

title: Comets See Fast Start
description: The defending champion Comets and the brash Phoenix Mercury play for the Women's National Basketball Association championship tonight at the Compaq Center in Houston. Bring combat boots, not a laptop.

title: Abroad at Home; Weighing the Price
description: With its special power and responsibility in the world, the United States has to be free to act unilaterally in urgent circumstances. We cannot wait for international approval before responding to terrorism.

title: Misery Loves Cybercompany but Has Little Sympathy for Market Losers
description: Heavy Internet traffic slowed many on-line investment sites yesterday as fearful investors mobbed cyberspace, checking their stock prices and then sticking around to commiserate.

title: Metro Business; 2 Real Estate Firms Merge
description: In a transaction that is part of the continuing consolidation of the commercial real estate industry, the New York real estate services firm Douglas A. Edwards Inc. has been acquired by GVA Williams for an undisclosed price.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: P.T.A. Under Fire for Letting Advertiser Use Its Name
description: In a decision critics say is at odds with its own policy opposing commercialism in schools, the National P.T.A. has agreed to let its name and logo appear, for a fee, in back-to-school advertisements by a large office-supply chain.

title: Russian Legislators Reject Prime Minister Candidate
description: Russia's Parliament today emphatically rejected President Boris N. Yeltsin's choice for Prime Minister after a rancorous debate, leaving the nation virtually rudderless in the midst of its deepening economic crisis.

title: A Diva's Day, Rich With Love, Prayer And Politics
description: For a true diva, technique is irrelevant. Her performance is about a beloved sound, a celebrated personality and a repertory that magnifies them both. That was the kind of performance Nina Simone gave on Sunday afternoon at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

title: Carrefour Shares Surge On Bid for Rival Retailer
description: The shares of Carrefour S.A. surged yesterday in the first trading since it agreed on Friday to buy Comptoirs Modernes with a cash and stock bid valuing its domestic rival at 21 billion French francs ($3.5 billion). The shares gained 261 francs, to 3,460 francs. The shares of Comptoirs remain suspended until the French stock market authority issues a statement on the bid.

title: If You're a Man, Publish
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Tight-End Plans Back on Drawing Board
description: Coach Jim Fassel has been able to reshape many aspects of the Giants in two seasons. He has replaced eight starters. Only 10 reserve players predate his tenure with the team. His Giants are younger, faster and more confident.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: South Korea Cuts Bank Loan Rate
description: The South Korean central bank said today that it would cut its discount rate to 3 percent from 5 percent.

title: Accounts
description: * Gingiss International Inc., Addison, Ill., to Rosen Group, Chicago, to handle advertising for the tuxedo and formal wear retailer, which had been handled by Columbian Advertising, Chicago. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: LASALLE PARTNERS TO BUY BUSINESSES FROM LEND LEASE
description: LaSalle Partners Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the real estate management-services unit and the United States retail-property management business of the Lend Lease Corporation of Australia for $180 million, plus additional payments of up to $77.5 million. LaSalle, based in Chicago, is a real estate services company that had revenues of $224.8 million last year. Lend Lease is a property and financial-services group. Lend Lease's Atlanta-based real estate management services business, Compass Management and Leasing, has operations in the United States, Australia, Brazil and Britain. Under the agreement, LaSalle will make the additional payments over five years if the Lend Lease businesses meet certain profit targets. LaSalle shares rose 62.5 cents, to $34.5625.

title: Old Ideas for CUNY
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TENNEY, JOAN LUSK
description: TENNEY-Joan Lusk. Entered into eternal rest September 1, 1996. We both miss you terribly, but we know you're smiling down on us. Love always. Anne and Toby Unge

title: Decline in New-Home Sales Is a Bit Steeper Than Expected
description: Sales of new homes fell more than expected during July, a sign that the housing market may be settling down after its record growth in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAIN, PATRICIA ANN
description: CAIN-Patricia Ann. On August 29th, 1998 in Phoenix, AZ, formerly of Mineola, N.Y. Loving daughter of Cecilia (nee Dunn) and the late Edwin T. Cain. Dear sister of Jacqueline Maltzan, Robert J. and Edwin T. Jr. The family will receive friends at the Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 445 East Meadow Avenue, East Meadow, N.Y. on Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Friday 10 A.M. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: The Doctor's World; Dr. DeBakey at 90: Stringent Standards And a Steady Hand
description: DR. MICHAEL E. DeBAKEY moved like a dancer in a pas de deux, anticipating his surgical partner's every move during a quadruple bypass operation on a woman at the Methodist Hospital here recently. As Dr. DeBakey deftly manipulated scalpels, scissors and forceps for more than three hours, his hands never quivered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENS, ROY A.
description: STEPHENS-Roy A. The staff of the Department of Dermatology at North Shore Hospital regrets the loss of their esteemed colleague. He was a superb physician and teacher and a gifted dermatologist. He had a warm and friendly outlook on life and his sense of humor was legend. He will be sorely missed by his patients and colleagues. Our warmest sympathy is extended to his wife, Barbara, and his family. Eugene L. Bodian, M.D. Chief, Division of Dermatology

title: Leader's Loss In Panama Clouds Future Of the Canal
description: Politics here have been thrown into a free-for-all after Panamanians crushed President Ernesto Perez Balladares's hopes for a second term by a resounding margin of nearly 2 to 1.

title: Lots of Political Fireworks In Parliament but No Help
description: For a coun try that has not had a government for a week a week in which its currency plummeted and its banking system veered toward collapse -- there was a striking lack of urgency to the debate today in the Russian Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILDERS, MONSIGNOR JAMES G.
description: WILDERS-Monsignor James G. The trustees and staff of the Seamen's Church Institute (SCI) note with sorrow the death on Tuesday, August 25, 1998 of former Trustee, Msgr. James G. Wilders. Msgr. Wilders served the Institute with distinction from 1981 to 1993. He was actively involved in ministry to seafarers, serving as the Roman Catholic Chaplain at Manhattan's Passenger Ship Terminal. As such, he was instrumental in developing a spirit of cooperation among various church organizations serving the port. His was a true friend to seafarers.

title: The Muscle-Building Secret Is Out of the Bottle
description: AS baseball fans cheer on Mark McGwire's effort to capture the seasonal home run record set by Roger Maris in 1961, manufacturers of a dietary supplement called creatine are cheering wildly, too. The Cardinals' first baseman says he has been aided in his quest by the muscles and strength he acquired through creatine-supplemented workouts.

title: BREED TECHNOLOGIES SHARES FALL ON DISPUTE WITH S.E.C.
description: The shares of Breed Technologies Inc. fell 29 percent after the company said it would delay its earnings report for the fourth quarter and the 1998 fiscal year because of a dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Breed, the world's third-largest maker of automobile air bags, fell $3 a share, to $7.125 yesterday, on the New York Stock Exchange. Breed said the S.E.C. was ''disagreeing with certain aspects'' of $349.9 million in restructuring and other charges the company took in its second quarter. The company had been expected to report its earnings last Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, YAFFA
description: GORDON-Yaffa. The Yesihva University family mourns the passing of a highly respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of Isidore Gordon; and mother of Yeshiva College Board member Nahum (and Barbara) Gordon, David (and Karen) Gordon, and Daniel (and Beatty) Gordon. We extend our heartfelt condolences to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire Gordon family, long-time supporters of YU and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Treasury Chief Seeks to Assure Jittery Investors
description: The sharp stock market selloff is likely to ripple through policy and politics, putting more pressure on the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates and threatening the air of prosperity that has been the foundation of President Clinton's political support, analysts and Government officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBARBIERI, JAMES EDWARD
description: DeBARBIERI-James Edward. 80, of Pearl River, NY, and Shin Pond, ME, died on August 28, 1998, of cardiac arrest near his home in Maine. He is survived by his wife of more than 50 years, Marie Therese DeBarbieri, four children, James Edward Jr, of Brklyn, NY, John M., of Phila, PA, Mariann E., of Petersham, MA, and Lydia Pomerantz, of West Palm Beach, FL, a sister, Anne Guallini, of NYC, a brother, Louis, of Emerson, NJ, and five grandchildren, Lily, Elizabeth, Nathaniel, Aaron, and Bartholomew. He was a decorated veteran of WWII, and served in the Far East. The funeral will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Helen Hayes Hospital For Rehabilitative Medicine, West Haverstraw, NY 10993.

title: Transportation Secretary Calls for Meeting in Pilots' Strike
description: At the request of President Clinton, Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater asked officials of Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots union today to meet with him in Washington on Tuesday.

title: A New Acid Test for Tokyo As It Tackles Banking Crisis
description: With markets crumbling at home and around the world, one of Japan's very large, very frail banks is turning into a critical test case for the Government in its effort to prop up the financial system here.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a dispute between Andersen Consulting and J. Baker, a large apparel retailer, referred to the status of the dispute incorrectly. As the article noted, J. Baker has not sued Andersen; the consulting firm has sought a court ruling in an effort to ward off a possible lawsuit by J. Baker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLE, MARGARET SHEEHAN
description: ENGLE-Margaret Sheehan. Died suddenly Sunday, August 30, she was 81. As Margaret Sheehan, she had a long career as an actress. She appeared on Broadway in ''Picnic'', and was a mainstay on the stock circuit with her late husband Dale Engle. She performed at prominent theaters such as the Alley Theater and the Shady Lane Playhouse. In WWII era, she toured the South Pacific and Japan with the USO. She also appeared in numerous films and most of the live television shows originating from New York, from ''The Defenders'' to ''Saturday Night Live''. A native of Springfield, MA, she is survived by her son, the actor Tod Engle and her granddaughter Sarah Dale Engle. Friends may call Wednesday, 2-5 & 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Funeral mass Thursday, St. Thomas Moore Church, 65 East 89 Street, 10AM. Interment in MA. She will be greatly missed, but her spirit, spunk, and unwavering support and love will inspire us and live on forever.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN GAINS. The dollar fell against the yen as United States stocks plunged. A rise of the Nikkei 225 stock average also pushed the yen up. In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 140.78 yen from 141.85.

title: War Rhythm to Draw People In
description: Soweto Street Beat, which performed at Lincoln Center Out of Doors on Friday afternoon at the Fountain Plaza, is a company of 10 savvy, sassy dancers and musicians whose idea of entertainment is disarmingly simple. Soweto Street Beat was founded in 1989 by Peter B. Ngcobo and Isabelle Doll Ngcobo, who hired and trained young men from the impoverished streets of Soweto. The dancers, now based in Atlanta, are high-powered and charismatic. On Friday, the performing in Ms. Ngcobo's ''Zulu Warrior'' was rhythmically complex and a joyous workout of nonstop bouncing and bounding, mostly in place and in formation, with the articulation of the bodies as minute and complex as beadwork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASO, RALPH G.
description: CASO-Ralph G. Sr., The Honorable former Nassau County Executive (1971-1978) of Merrick, NY on August 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Grace (nee Milone). Devoted father of Ralph Jr. of Independent Group Home for Living, Nesconset, New York & Jolisa Sagstetter of Wantagh, NY. Devoted fatherin-law of Donald G. Sagstetter. Cherished grandfather of Christina Grace and Donald Franz. Dear brother of Dr. George R. Caso, Sr. of Merrick. Fond brother-in-law of Virginia Caso & of Caroline Milone Giaquinto, Louis J. Milone, Vera Milone Ferme, all of Rockville Centre & John E. Milone of Roslyn Estates. Also survived by his many nieces and nephews. Reposing Thursday, September 3, 1998, 2-4:30 PM and 7-9 PM at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick. Funeral Mass Friday 10:45 AM at Cure of Ars R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Independent Group Home for Living, Inc. C/O Mr. Walter Stockton, P.O. Box 638, 62 Pine Street, East Moriches, NY 11940.

title: American Hubris Won't Help Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: The Crisis at Legal Aid
description: The quality of legal services for New York City's poor defendants continues to decline. The city has steadily reduced its contributions to the Legal Aid Society, the main nonprofit agency providing representation for indigent defendants, even as caseloads have grown. A recent report from a court-appointed committee shows how desperate the situation has become.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, PHYLLIS B.
description: CLARK-Phyllis B. Of Atlanta, on August 30, 1998. Beloved mother of Gail Claydon, Priscilla Kahale and Jonathan Clark. Cherished sister of Eileen Reid and Norma Daly. Also survived by six grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held Tuesday, 3-5 and 7-9 at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home Inc., 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Sta. Services will be held Wednesday, 10 AM at the Old First Church, Huntington Village. Interment at Locust Valley Cemetery. Donations may be made to The Society for Progressive Supra Nuclear Palsy Inc., Suite. 515, Woodholme Medical Building, 1838 Green Tree Road, Baltimore, MD. 21208.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Erase Gains in 1998 As the Dow Tumbles 6.37%

title: Strike Apparently Settled, Workers Return to U S West
description: With nonunion companies competing hungrily for telephone business in booming cities of the Rockies, U S West tentatively settled a two-week-old strike today, putting employees back to work at the region's Bell company.

title: Writing As Revenge
description: Biographers of writers often dream about their subjects. They have been known to have spectral communication with them, to adopt their prose style and move into their homes. It's impossible to write a biography without feeling that you have property rights to your subject's life. When the work is finished, a strange sense of bereavement and separation follows, as your subject is returned to the world. That subject was never yours, after all, but belongs to everybody.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZER, ANNETTE
description: LINZER-Annette. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Elliot Linzer on the loss of his beloved mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: After a Holiday, Gore Campaigns in Midwest
description: Back on the campaign trail in Illinois and Ohio after his two-week holiday in Hawaii, Vice President Al Gore turned to his companions this morning on Air Force Two and asked, ''Anything happen while I was gone?''

title: Japanese Stocks Recover From Early Drop
description: Stock prices cascaded around the region in response to the deep plunge on Wall Street, spreading anxiety over a possible global slowdown that could fan greater financial instability in Asia and quash any hopes for an economic recovery.

title: Hard Truth: Hatred Comes In All Colors
description: RAISING hypothetical ''what ifs'' is an often-pointless exercise, but every once in a while it is necessary, even unavoidable. So here goes.

title: BOEING MAY REPURCHASE UP TO 15 PERCENT OF ITS SHARES
description: The Boeing Company, the world's largest aircraft maker, said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of as much as 15 percent of its common stock in a bid to increase its share price, which is at its lowest level in more than three years. The stock repurchase would cost about $4.51 billion, based on yesterday's closing price of $30.9375, down $3 a share. The Seattle-based company has about 973 million common shares outstanding.

title: For Champions, The Real Tests Are Yet to Come
description: Start spreading the news: Pete Sampras is feeling historic, Martina Hingis is feeling acquisitive and Goran Ivanisevic is feeling that the turbocharged hardcourts at the United States Open are delivering his aces almost faster than he can send them across the net.

title: Bugs, Transformation and Subterfuge in a Reinvented Eden
description: Ever since cave painters began sketching horses, bison, elephants and the like, artists have wrestled with the relationship between man and nature. Fast-forward 20,000 years to the rural and maritime landscapes and the still-life oils of the post-Renaissance, and the question remained unchanged. How should art respond to nature?

title: Police Sergeant Stops Brooklyn Robbery 3 Days After Promotion
description: An armed robbery at a Brooklyn gas station was foiled yesterday by an off-duty police sergeant who witnessed the robbery, chased down the suspect and shot him once in the leg during a furious struggle before arresting him, the police said.

title: Hera's Wrath and Favor
description: To the Editor:

title: American Hubris Won't Help Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite a Rough Start, the Seminoles Display Talent Aplenty
description: Their mature quarterback looked as if he had been shagging baseballs in the minor leagues. Their junior wide receiver validated all the hopeful Heisman talk coming from Tallahassee. But ultimately it was a sure-footed field goal kicker who helped the Florida State Seminoles outlast Texas A&M, 23-14.

title: Foreign Bank Lending Shifts From Asia
description: Foreign banks more than doubled their lending to Russia in the first quarter of 1998 from the previous three months as they shifted funds from Asia, the Bank for International Settlements said here today.

title: ESSAY; Mathematical Metaphors Abound in Art and Fiction
description: AS a mathematician, I lately seem to find myself discussing the movies a lot. Copies of the Oscar-winning ''Good Will Hunting'' are now lining the shelves in the video store; Darren Aronofsky's ''Pi'' about a reclusive mathematician obsessed with patterns is becoming a cult classic. Friends, acquaintances, students all want to talk to me about these movies because they are ''all about math.'' Are they?

title: 'It's Disturbing, to Put It Mildly,' But Investors Say They'll Hold On
description: Gloom, fear, pain and queasiness. Around the nation, anxieties ran high yesterday as investors big and small watched the jagged lines fall and much of the year's profits evaporate in a breathtaking 512-point plunge on Wall Street. Many called it scary, but almost no one seemed ready to panic.

title: Beyond Personal Faults, The Power of the Office
description: In the eyes of many of his fellow leaders and ordinary people around the world, President Clinton has lost personal stature since investigations into his private life and his admission of an inappropriate relationship with a White House intern. But he has lost little of the authority and power conferred on him by the Presidency.

title: Not Your Grandfather's State Fair; Leaping Llamas and Low-Cal Jams in an Agrarian Bastion
description: Just next door to the display of the state's largest squash and only a flight of stairs above the room where assorted jams vied for glory, Kate Broderick struck a pose.

title: Covering and Covering the Clinton Story, Oh So Apologetically
description: Add yet another count to the accumulation of misdemeanors being assembled against President Clinton: He has incited a flurry of moralizing by television journalists, who have enrolled themselves among the victims. Yes, there is whining from reporters that they have been compelled to devote themselves to Monica S. Lewinsky when they are longing to cover Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Shell and Texaco Consider a Joint Venture
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that it was talking to several major oil companies, including Texaco Inc., about forming a joint refining and fuel-sales venture in Europe to cut costs and increase profits.

title: Chic by H.I.S. Names Spike DDB
description: Chic by H.I.S. Inc. in New York, which markets Chic Jeans, said yesterday that it had named Spike DDB in New York to handle its integrated marketing account, which had been handled in-house for the last 10 years. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PSS WORLD MEDICAL INC., Jacksonville, Fla., a distributor of medical supplies, said its Diagnostic Imaging Inc. unit had agreed to acquire Gilbert X-Ray Co. of Texas Inc., Dallas, a closely held imaging-distribution concern. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Tavern Owner Is Indicted In Inquiry Into the Police
description: As part of a Federal investigation into police corruption in northern New Jersey, a West New York man was indicted yesterday on charges that he bribed local police officials to allow his two bars to sell drinks after hours, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REQUENA, JOSE JUAN
description: REQUENA-Jose Juan. We mourn the loss of Mr. Requena who passed away August 30, 1998 in Valencia, Spain. He was a devoted father of Jose Juan Sanchez. He played a significant role in the foundation and growth of CMA Inc. Consultory & Advisory. His legacy of a high level of integrity, honesty and humanity shall remain with his family and all those that he touched. CMA Inc.

title: Dietary Supplement Found to Be Contaminated
description: RESEARCHERS at the Mayo Clinic are reporting that they have found a potentially dangerous contaminant in the popular dietary supplement 5-hydroxy-L-tryptophan, or 5-HTP, which is sold in drug and health-food stores as a remedy for insomnia, depression, anxiety, obesity, headaches, premenstrual syndrome and other ailments.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Kiss-and-Tell Tale Has Editors Abuzz

title: A Spectacular Tale In Its Mythic Home; 'Turandot' Enters the Forbidden City
description: In a giant courtyard of the Forbidden City, a woman's voice soars gloriously into the night sky.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Pollinating Tongue

title: Rangel Welcomes Marchers But Not Leader to Harlem
description: Navigating the treacherous political waters of the Million Youth March, United States Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem urged his constituents yesterday to welcome the young marchers, but he criticized the event's organizers and praised Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for his handling of the issue.

title: Patterns
description: Talks at Halston

title: At N.Y.U., the Clintons, Gore and a Mini-United Nations
description: In what is shaping up as a remarkable lineup of domestic and foreign leaders at New York University, President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton have agreed to lead a day of discussions on the global economy at a conference later this month, with guests including the prime ministers of Britain and Italy, the White House said yesterday.

title: GRADING THE SECRETARY: A special report.; Albright, a Bold Voice Abroad, Finds Her Role Limited at Home
description: With her bold public stands undermined by irresolution in the White House and her experience rendered less relevant by new economic crises, Madeleine K. Albright has had a tough 20 months as Secretary of State.

title: Too Much Faith in the Fed?
description: To the Editor:

title: HICKS, MUSE MAY BUY 35 PERCENT STAKE IN TRITON ENERGY
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the Dallas-based investment group, has agreed to buy as much as 35 percent of Triton Energy Ltd., an oil and natural gas explorer, which needs cash to develop foreign projects. Hicks, Muse will pay $130 million to Triton initially and will then invest up to $220 million more. Last week, the firm bought a 62 percent stake in the Fort Worth-based Coho Energy for $250 million, reflecting a new strategy to invest in the oil and gas industry's long-term prospects, said Roy Winnick, a Hicks, Muse spokesman. Shares of Triton, which is also based in Dallas, have fallen about 54 percent this year, partly because of oil prices that are near their lowest level in 10 years. The shares closed at $11.4375 yesterday, down $1.9375.

title: Columbia/HCA Staff Shift
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation named Scott L. Mercy chairman and chief executive of its America's Group, effective Tuesday. It said today that he would join the unit's president and chief operating officer, Jim Fleetwood, to form a leadership team in anticipation of a spinoff of the unit to form a new public company. America's Group includes 22 rural hospitals. Mr. Mercy had been president and chief executive of America Service Group Inc., a provider of health care services to correctional facilities.

title: Three Die in Capsizing of a Powerboat Off Shelter Island
description: A family's fishing trip off Shelter Island ended in tragedy today when their boat capsized, killing one man and two 7-year-old girls, both cousins, and injuring five others, the police said.

title: North Korea Fires Missile Over Japanese Territory
description: North Korea today fired a two-stage ballistic missile across Japan, which called the firing ''extremely dangerous.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD
description: SHEPPS-HOWARD. WE WERE TOGETHER WHEN YOU WERE BORN...WE WERE TOGETHER WHEN YOU DIED... WE WISH YOU WERE HERE.

title: Potentially, the Home Run Call of the Century
description: When Mark McGwire crushed his 53d home run last week in Pittsburgh, Joe Buck cringed. The St. Louis Cardinals' announcer -- who is also the lead baseball voice for Fox Sports -- was at home in St. Louis, watching with his wife, Ann.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NUSSBAUM, LEONARD
description: NUSSBAUM-Leonard. We always have and always will continue to love you. Joel, Bette, Brett, Jodi, Marlo and their families

title: Expertise at Maneuvering Helps Gulko Gain a Title
description: Every chess player beyond the neophyte stage gets caught up in the striving for perfection. After the game is over, no matter whether it was for a club championship or only a park bench struggle, the players replay it to see whether the winner should really have won or whether he was just lucky that his opponent failed to find a saving defense. When they get through, it often looks as though they had played a couple of dozen games, instead of just commenting on one. Indeed, after some tournament games the winner has suspected that his defeated opponent really needed the chance to show that he was the better player.

title: Moscow Mood: What if They Ascended a Summit and No One Cared
description: Russia's top network news program, ''Vremya,'' led off tonight with Parliament's rejection of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister, the ruble's continued wobbliness and the anniversary of Diana's death. Then it flagged fascinating plans by Muslim extremists for several villages in rural Dagestan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about a seminar on the sociology of jazz held at the annual conference of the American Sociological Association misstated the given name of a panelist from New York University. He is Scott Appelrouth, not Paul.

title: Williams Worries Only About the Series
description: All but one of the cubicles in the Yankees' clubhouse are identical: about four feet deep; a bar across the top from which to hang jerseys and workout gear and street clothes; several other drawers and shelves for gloves and shoes and personal items, and a chair in front.

title: Marines Face More Charges In Italy Case
description: The Marine Corps said today that the pilot and the navigator of a plane that struck a ski-lift cable in the Italian Alps, killing 20 people, were being charged with obstruction of justice because they had hidden or destroyed a videotape, apparently made during the flight.

title: State of Mississippi Seeks Agency
description: Mississippi, the first state to settle a claim against tobacco marketers, said yesterday that it was seeking an agency to handle an anti-smoking campaign. Billings for a two-year effort were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Austria Takes a Bridge Title
description: Austria won the World Women's Team Championship here this afternoon, defeating Germany in the final by 85 imps to capture the Louis Vuitton McConnell Cup. The winners were Maria Erhart, Sylvia Terraneo, Doris Fischer and Terry Weigkricht. Two American teams, led by Carol Sanders and Nadine Wood, tied for third and fourth to win bronze medals.

title: Redskins Hope 2 Bookends Fit in Trophy Case
description: The Redskins reviewed their 8-7-1 season from a year ago and found a hole in their hearts. A hole smack in the middle of their defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLAY, JENNIFER TRUSLOW
description: MACLAY-Jennifer Truslow. Of Charlottesville, VA. Formerly of Wilton, CT. Died in a car accident on August 28 in Charlottesville. She is survived by her sister, Susan Finnis of Cheshire, England & four children, Michael Truslow of Charlottesville, Sara Truslow Hardin of N.Y., Elizabeth Salvatore of Lucas, TX, and John Truslow of Oyster Bay, N.Y., as well as 11 grandchildren. Services will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Wilton, CT., on Thursday, September 3rd at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Wilton Library Association, Wilton, CT.

title: Too Much Faith in the Fed?
description: To the Editor:

title: Backpack in F.B.I. Office Prompts an Evacuation
description: A backpack full of dirty laundry left in an Federal Bureau of Investigation office in Newark yesterday prompted the evacuation of a 26-story building and nearby Pennsylvania Station for 90 minutes by officials who feared the pack might have contained a bomb.

title: An Editor Who Cared for Issues, Not Clothes
description: RUTH WHITNEY, who steered Glamour Magazine and influenced several generations of women through the three most important decades in American feminism, absolutely hates one of the signal words of the feminist movement.

title: Apple TV Spot Wins Emmy Award
description: A commercial for Apple Computer Inc. in Cupertino, Calif., won the Emmy Award for outstanding television commercials at the annual competition sponsored by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences.

title: Genocide With Spin Control: Kurtz Wasn't Fiction
description: KING LEOPOLD'S GHOST

title: From Japan, a Securities Firm With a Spiel of Radical Change
description: Yoshinari Hara, president and chief executive of Daiwa Securities, is on a mission to New York this week to sell ratings agencies, financial institutions and investors on the merits of a purely Japanese securities firm.

title: Accounting Firms Facing More Pressure From S.E.C.
description: Concerned about the millions of dollars of consulting that the Big Five accounting firms now do at some of the companies they audit, the Securities and Exchange Commission wants auditors to meet annually with company directors to explain why the consulting services have not harmed the accountants' independence.

title: Sosa Takes Wood's Curtain Call
description: Sammy Sosa took two bows tonight at Wrigley Field, one for himself and one for Kerry Wood. After his 55th home run, a three-run drive in the third inning that tied him with Mark McGwire for the major league lead, Sosa stepped out of the dugout to tip his cap. The ovation lasted more than a minute.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMS MERNS, STEPHEN
description: SYMS MERNS-Stephen. With broken heart and loving affection, my sad goodbye. Lynn Syms

title: Chancellor Set to Acquire Whiteco Unit
description: Just days after announcing a deal that would make it the largest chain of radio stations in the country, the Chancellor Media Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the nation's largest privately held billboard company for $930 million.

title: Blues Present And Past
description: The British blues movement of the mid-1960's was one of rock's transitional phases. As British musicians emulated American blues, they polished their guitar techniques, roughed up their singing and learned new perspectives on irony and emotional extremes. They also alerted American listeners to music that had been ignored. By the end of the decade, blues ideas had made their way into psychedelia and heavy metal, while genuine American blues musicians had revitalized their careers on the rock circuit. Still, some diehard British musicians had become blues purists, clinging determinedly to their adopted music.

title: Auction of Kia Canceled After Low Bids
description: The auction of two South Korean auto makers was canceled tonight because none of the four initial bids met the sellers' minimum price.

title: No Bail for Man Accused Of Faking His Drowning
description: A man who the authorities believe faked his drowning to avoid criminal charges was ordered held without bail yesterday while investigators prepare a report on his risk of fleeing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AKPATA, TOKS
description: AKPATA-Toks. Gone from our sight. Forever in our hearts Mom, Reggie, family and friends

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILLS, RUTH FIFE
description: SILLS-Ruth Fife. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Ruth Fife Sills. Our sympathies are extended to her husband, Nathaniel L. Sills, and her children, Lawrence and Susan, Arthur and Sarah, Peter and Susan, and to her brother, Bernard Fife. The Sills and Fife families have always been heartfelt supporters of UJA-Federation. We offer our deepest condolences to the entire family and all those whose lives she has enriched with her presence. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, ROBERT A.
description: PHILLIPS-Robert A. 87 of Lynbrook, LI. Peacefully in his sleep on August 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Regina. Loving father of Robert A., Jr. and Margaret M. Longto. Father-in-law of Chikee Phillips and Frank J. Longto. Dear grandfather of Brian and Kathleen Phillips. Survived by his twin brother James of Melbourne, Florida, devoted Uncle of James N. King and many other nieces and nephews. Veteran of US Navy WWII and US Army Korean Conflict. Retired from Irving Trust Company. Memorial mass 9:45 AM, Thursday at Saint Raymond's R.C. Church of East Rockaway, LI. In lieu of flowers, family would appreciate contributions to the Make-A-Wish Foundation or The American Heart Association.

title: Sports of The Times; The Slugger Behind The Serve
description: JUST when men's tennis finds itself a qualitative also-ran to the more charismatic and poignant women's game, who should show up, fittingly enough, to kick off the United States Open yesterday in Arthur Ashe Stadium but Goran Ivanisevic, the power-serving human sleeping pill.

title: Muslims on Trial in France
description: A trial of 138 suspected supporters of Islamic insurgents in Algeria, rounded up in police raids four years ago, started today in a prison south of Paris.

title: Loans Aren't a Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF THE MENU
description: More Breakfast?

title: In Wealthy Greenwich, There's Plenty of Money Left
description: Sheltered by a canopy at the residents-only beach in this wealthy town of stone walls and private lanes, a club of 37 investors gathered glumly around picnic tables for an emergency meeting on Monday evening to deal with the day's stock market rout. The early line: Dump the equities. Stop the losses.

title: Business Travel; Fliers are coping with the Northwest strike, but things could get much tougher after Labor Day.
description: THE pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines has not caused tremendous disruption so far for business travelers, since many carriers are temporarily increasing service at Northwest's primary hubs at Wayne County Metropolitan Airport in Detroit and Minneapolis/St. Paul International Airport.

title: Wondolleck Team Takes U.S. Title
description: A three-woman team that was led by Stephanie Wondolleck of San Francisco won the United States women's sailing championship last week on the Fern Ridge Reservoir near Eugene, Ore.

title: Metro Business; State Helping Library
description: The state has committed $1.75 million toward the $70 million renovation of the New York Public Library's landmark building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. The money will help pay for a major upgrading of technology services in the main library, with new public computer work stations, fiber optic and copper cables and a technology center.

title: Clinton Tells Moscow Crowd That Future Won't Be Easy
description: President Clinton delivered a sober lecture to Russian leaders and the Russian people today about the hard realities of capitalism and the price of international support for relief from Russia's current financial crisis.

title: Manufacturing In 3-Month Fall
description: Manufacturing activity contracted for the third consecutive month in August, suggesting that the economic turmoil in emerging markets was taking a toll on factory orders.

title: Is It Morning in Indonesia Or the End of an Eclipse?
description: At a time when investors seem ready to hang black crepe over the global economy, Indonesia's Finance Minister is guardedly optimistic about one of the world's bleakest economies.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''People here are so rich, they're still rich.''

title: Lewinsky Issue Inspires Theme for G.O.P. Ads
description: In the first indication that the Republican Party intends to make President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky a central campaign issue, the party today introduced a multimillion-dollar advertising drive in which a leading message will be ethics.

title: Home Run King? Let Fans Argue
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweepstakes Could Face Restrictions
description: Lawmakers and law-enforcement officials proposed a series of tough measures today to reduce what they described as deception and fraud in the nation's multibillion-dollar sweepstakes industry.

title: Home Run King? Let Fans Argue
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Options for Russia: Populist Path Seems Most Likely but Dangerous
description: Plan A, a $23.6 billion program courtesy of the International Monetary Fund, failed in less than four weeks. Plan B, a devaluation and debt moratorium cobbled together by young Russian reformers, collapsed within days. Neither prevented investors from fleeing or citizens from turning every ruble they have into dollars.

title: Blue-Ribbon Wines
description: A 1997 Johannisberg riesling made by Chateau LaFayette Reneau, a boutique winery in Hector, N.Y., on the southeastern side of Seneca Lake, has been chosen as the No. 1 wine in New York State.

title: In Other Sections
description: RUSSIAN OPTIONS -- Without a bailout, what is left? Some Western economists are considering measures that once would have been dismissed as extreme. Page A10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAIN, ARTHUR B.
description: KAIN-Arthur B. Age 84, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Lynbrook, NY. Beloved husband of Esther for 60 years. Brother of Norman, devoted father of Stephen, Karen and Steven Bachmann, Janet and Edward Greenberg, adored grandfather of Seth Kain, Jill Karp, Jennifer Sweetwood, Michael Bachmann, Amy Bachmann, and Jonathan Greenberg. Loving greatgrandfather of Alexander Kain. He was a graduate of NYU, Class of 1935, a dedicated and respected CPA, past-president of Congregation Beth David, Lynbrook, NY, a kind and gentle man, he will be missed by all. Services Thursday, 12:00 noon at Gutterman's, 175 North Longbeach Road, Rockville Centre, New York. In lieu of flowers, family requests contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Getting It All Together: 9 Vast Serra Works
description: Richard Serra's newest sculptures are nothing if not weighty.

title: How Sweet It Is: A Moderate Indulgence
description: WHAT do Sauternes, Tokay, trockenbeerenauslese, vendange tardive, Dolce and Eisrebe have in common? They are some of the world's finest wines, and they are all sweet. Beyond that, few wine drinkers know much about them (except for Sauternes): where they come from, how they are made or even what they taste like.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER SURGES. Copper prices, which had been at 11-year lows, jumped 6 percent as a stronger yen and a rise in United States stocks raised optimism on demand. December copper rose 4.55 cents, to 75.90 cents a pound

title: Crisis Batters Emerging Economy, Sending Rand to New Lows
description: In the 1980's, the apartheid Government was obsessed with fear that it would be overrun by Communist-backed black guerrillas, and it presented the Soviet Union as a vast menace that justified brutal oppression.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEPHENS, ROY, M.D.
description: STEPHENS-Roy, M.D. We are saddened by the loss of our esteemed friend and colleague whose devotion to, and leadership of our society were an inspiration to all. Roy's boundless energy, enthusiasm and humor were greatly valued by all his colleagues and patients. We will sorely miss our friend whose contributions to this society were invaluable. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Barbara and entire family. The Long Island Dermatological Society

title: Wrestling With War And Love; Raw Pain, Relived Tim O'Brien's Way
description: Tim O'Brien entered the Mystic Lake Casino with the agitated assurance of a man who belonged there. He pulled a wad of $100 bills from his tennis shorts, strode to the $200-minimum-bet blackjack table and within minutes, maybe three cigarettes into a long night, was playing with $2,000 of the casino's money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, ENOCH
description: WALDMAN-Enoch, August 29, 1998. Cherished husband of Leah. Adored father, grandfather, great grandfather, brother. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be to B'nai B'rith.

title: McGwire's 57th Sets N.L. Record
description: At the end, Mark McGwire felt overwhelmed with all the bearhugs from his teammates and the fans' cheers throbbing in his ears.

title: Lewinsky Questioned Again in a Secret Meeting, Lawyers Say
description: In a secret meeting with prosecutors last week, Monica S. Lewinsky answered more questions under oath that were intended to highlight any discrepancies between her grand jury testimony and the sworn testimony given by President Clinton, two lawyers familiar with the inquiry said today.

title: BASKETBALL; Comets Hold On To Title
description: So much for Coach Cheryl Miller's prediction of an upset by her Phoenix Mercury. Although Miller got the dogfight she wanted, the Houston Comets, behind Cynthia Cooper, won their second consecutive Women's National Basketball Association title tonight.

title: As Stocks Shudder, Rivals Assail Pataki's Spending
description: The challengers in the Governor's race yesterday pounced on the recent bad news from Wall Street, charging that Gov. George E. Pataki has made the state's finances so precarious that the stock market sell-off, if it resumes, will mean budget cuts next year.

title: The Patroness Who Made Tchaikovsky Tchaikovsky
description: Every year, more Americans attend arts events than sports events. So somebody is making money, yet artists themselves continue to struggle.
