As evidence, just take a walk through SoHo and note how many former artists' lofts have become doctors' condos. Given the moralizing that has strangled government financing of the arts, and the fickleness of many private foundations, things look pretty bad. It's enough to make an artist want to return to the days of private patronage.

title: THE CHEF
description: IT happens every September, if you're lucky enough to have a garden. The irrational exuberance of spring -- marked by serious overplanting of fruits and vegetables -- inevitably ends in the glut of late summer. For some people it's tomatoes or zucchini. For me it's corn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAITMAN, GERALD
description: WAITMAN-Gerald. The leadership and staff of Israel Bonds extend its heartfelt condolences to Dr. Albert Waitman and his wife, Batsheva Waitman, Chairman of our New York Woman's Division, on the untimely death of his beloved brother Gerald. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, EDWARD JAMES
description: KAUFMAN-Edward James. Practicing attorney since 1940; served in the U.S. Army as a Second Lieutenant in World War II. Cherished husband of Charlene for 42 years. Survived by his utmost dedicated children, Cindy and Larry Kohn and Jill and Ralph Betesh. Adored by his precious grandchildren, Remi Lane, Garrett Jerome, Adam Cole and Lexi Erin. He will be forever in our hearts, forever in our minds; he will be missed by all who knew him. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 12:30 PM, Wednesday.

title: Rafter Survives Scare In Starting Title Defense
description: Even when Patrick Rafter is having a perfect day, hair or otherwise, he sweats like a condemned man. Rivulets and rivers of the stuff stream from his body as he chases after his serve, screeches to a stop and braces himself for the passing shot that will try to elude his volley. Or cut through him like a laser. It's a dangerous way to make a living, but it's the way Rafter learned to play back on the Australian anthills, and he has refused to modify it.

title: Keep the Seat Belts Buckled, But It's O.K. to Loosen Them
description: The smoke from the stock market shootout of the last five trading days finally began to clear yesterday. As the Dow Jones industrial average rallied to close up 288.36 points, or 3.8 percent, investors began to ask: Where do we go from here?

title: Pete Watrous, 82, American Diplomat
description: Livingston Day (Pete) Watrous, a career diplomat who specialized in Latin America, died yesterday at his home in Nantucket, Mass. He was 82.

title: European Stocks Stumble Lightly
description: With a nervous eye on every tremor from Wall Street, European stocks slumped, seesawed and stumbled through a day of trading today.

title: Chicago Offers A Sweet Home In Risky Times
description: There are few winners in a stock market selloff. But among those who are managing, and even thriving, in the recent volatility, are investors and traders who have looked to Chicago.

title: President Clinton Lectures on Russia's Future
description: With markets crashing, banks shuddering and the Government imploding, Russians may not feel the urgent need for a lecture from President Clinton about economic reform. Despite the worthiness of his message about how Russia must ultimately follow ''the fundamental economic imperatives of the global market'' to flourish, the President's talk yesterday to young leaders in Moscow still sounded a little like the rich man giving a pep talk to the poor folk under the bridge: Yes, it's cold and gloomy down there, I know, and yes, it's painful now, but I promise it will be better in the long run.

title: Bargain-Hunters Drive Stocks Back Up as Volume Sets Record
description: The stock market yesterday regained more than half of the value it lost on Monday as trading volume set a record.

title: Fight Corruption First
description: To the Editor:

title: Summit Meeting Teeters On Edge of Self-Parody
description: As President and Mrs. Clinton prepared to retire tonight at the Marriott Hotel near the banks of the Moscow River, a car pulled over not far from the hotel entrance. The doors opened, and Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the ultranationalist who controls a bloc of seats in Russia's Parliament, climbed out.

title: Bread Salad, Easy as Toast
description: BREAD salad is a traditional way of making good use of stale bread. Like many old-fashioned preparations for salvaging food before it goes bad (count pickles and jam among these), it has an appeal of its own. This is especially true at this time of year, when good tomatoes -- an ingredient in bread salads -- are plentiful.

title: Not Just Another Patty: Burgers of the World
description: THERE is nothing more American, or more straightforwardly delicious, than a perfectly grilled hamburger. But at this point in the grilling season, even the most patriotic of backyard cooks could be forgiven for wanting to introduce a little variety to the menu.

title: In Business Day
description: RUSSIAN RIPPLES -- The number of Western financial companies reporting heavy losses on their Russian business is growing. Page C1.

title: Koch Returns To the Streets He Rescued
description: EDWARD I. KOCH stood on the corner of Mapes Avenue and East 178th Street, a Bronx neighborhood he first visited 15 years ago to survey the desolation wrought by years of abandonment, arson and anarchy. On Monday, he savored the sight of new homes on the side streets, packed stores on Tremont Avenue and a sparkling new community center.

title: A Good Year for A French Stew
description: WHAT'S more daunting? The long list of ingredients in a typical recipe for ratatouille or the vowel-clogged French word itself? Actually, the preparation and the pronunciation share the same rule: keep the components distinct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APONTE, JOHN
description: APONTE-John. The officers, members and teams of the Long Island Midweek Baseball League, mourn the untimely passing, on August 31, 1998, of Board Member and friend, John Aponte. His sportsmanship, competitiveness and sense of humor exemplified the ideals of our League and all of Men's Senior Baseball. His wise counsel and dedication will be missed. Heartfelt condolences to his wife Maureen and family.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HACKER, LOIS
description: HACKER-Lois 2/17/30-9/2/97 My darling mother, I feel your loss in my heart always Your loving daughter, An

title: Clark and Wells Meet Again
description: David Wells and Al Clark were on the field together at Yankee Stadium last night, Wells pitching for the Yankees and Clark umpiring at second base. They are the central figures in an investigation by Major League Baseball into an allegation that Clark sold baseballs from Wells's perfect game against Minnesota on May 17.

title: Airline and Pilots to Weigh New Talks
description: The heads of Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots union met for almost five hours today with the Transportation Secretary but agreed only to consider returning to the bargaining table.

title: Taiwan Chief Sees Separate Identity
description: Resisting pressure to forge closer ties with mainland China, President Lee Teng-hui says he is seeking to break out of the isolation imposed by Beijing.

title: Straddling a Line Between Political Worlds
description: WHATEVER this weekend's rally for black youths turns out to be -- a peaceable protest, a thunderhead of rage and malevolence, a forgettable fizzle -- it will take place on David A. Paterson's doorstep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBIN, SCHATTNER, LENORE
description: TOBIN-SCHATTNER-Lenore. The ''leading lady'' of the theatre party industry for over thirty years, passed away on September 1st. Survived by her sister, Jane Muccio, and her surrogate children, Patricia and Ronald Lee; and grandchildren Alison, Gillian, David, Stephanie and Christopher Lee; and her cousin, Kay Blick and her family. Remember her by contributing to the Actors' Fund of America, 1501 Broadway, New York, New York 10036 (whose nursing home took such wonderful care of Lenore in her final years).

title: Guard Was Peacemaker In Shootout, Lawyer Says
description: The lawyer for an off-duty prison guard accused of killing a school bus driver during an argument said yesterday that his client had merely happened upon a gun battle and had tried to stop it.

title: The Market Turmoil
description: STEADY AT FED -- While the slump has raised hopes that the Federal Reserve may lower interest rates, many economists are skeptical. Page C1.

title: Finally, a Match for Wilson
description: When Mark McGwire hit his 56th and 57th home runs for St. Louis last night, he ended Hack Wilson's 68-year reign as the National League season champion, one of the oldest records in the books. Before this season is finished, Sammy Sosa will most likely pass Wilson's mark, too.

title: Giants' Offense Reveals Thin Line
description: It is a simple difference of opinion. The members of the Giants' offensive line scoff at talk of their preseason problems, promising that they will be ready when the regular season begins Sunday.

title: Disguised at Rest Stop, Police Catch Fugitive in Shootout
description: In a huge undercover sting that involved state troopers posing as diners at the Walt Whitman Service Plaza, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and troopers exchanged gunfire with a heavily armed fugitive today before charging him with shooting a Camden police officer in 1997.

title: U.S. to Send Russia Alerts About Missiles
description: Now that the nuclear standoff with the Soviet Union is over, the United States has found a new use for its warning systems -- alerting the Russians about missile launchings around the world. President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin plan to sign an accord to share data about the launching of ballistic missiles and space payloads.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, ERWIN
description: GREENBERG-Erwin. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Erwin Greenberg. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Florence, and their family. Morton West, President Daniel Amster, Secretary

title: INSIDE
description: City Reaches Terms on Rally

title: Improving Security in the Schools
description: A draft proposal to give New York City's Police Department significant new control over security in the schools offers a compromise to a long-running disagreement between Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. In earlier years, the Mayor has pushed for more police in the schools and more control over school security matters. Dr. Crew has resisted sending more armed officers into schools and has long argued that educators cannot be cut out of school security decisions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRUN, JOSEPH W.
description: HEILBRUN-Joseph W. Of Boca Raton, FL. formerly of N.Y.C. passed away August 30, 1998. He is survived by his children Nanette (Robert) Saraga and Michele Heilbrun and grandchildren Brittany and Andrew Saraga. Funeral service will be 12 noon Wednesday, September 2, 1998 at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street at Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Wellwood. Mr. Heilbrun was deeply loved and will be greatly missed.

title: An Alaska Trek Makes Elders of the Aging
description: Martha Wroe made up her mind years ago that there were two things she would never do when she got old. ''I was not going to be one of those old ladies clutching their purses to them wherever they went,'' she said. Nor was she going to be the sort of traveler who viewed the world from the safety of a cruise ship.

title: CALENDAR
description: Lessons From Ismail Merchant

title: Move to Reassure Investors With Share Buyback Plans
description: A day after the Dow tumbled 512 points, companies large and small tried to reassure investors yesterday by announcing plans to buy back shares.

title: For Some, Texas Town Is Too Popular as Waste Disposal Site
description: Lupe Bustamante cradled a gallon of milk under her arm in the dim and sparsely stocked Guerra General Store on the main street of this dusty outpost, population 600, and wondered why the whole world seemed to want to dump on her tiny town.

title: It's a Nightmare for Most Shareholders, but a Dream Come True for Short-Sellers
description: Not everyone is lamenting the stock market's steep selloff. While many investors are still licking their wounds, even after yesterday's rally, some are celebrating. They may have stayed on the sidelines with cash, for example, immune to the damage in the last few weeks, or made astute bets in the Treasury market and racked up some gains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMS MERNS, STEPHEN
description: SYMS MERNS-Stephen. ''Gone is the joy of our hearts, our dancing has turned into mourning'' (Lamentations 5:15). Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the tragic and untimely passing of Stephen Syms Merns, son of cherished members of our extended family, Sy Syms and Ruth Merns. We pray that Stephen's family will find some measure of comfort knowing that the major scholarship endowment, established by Sy Syms, Chai Founder of Boys Town, will indeed provide the gift of life to disadvantaged Israeli youth by offering them hope and opportunity. ''Never again shall your sun set ....and ended shall be the days of your mourning'' (Isaiah 60:20). Our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Vice Chairman Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Executive Vice President

title: Even After 7-Run Inning, Mets Fall Out of Wild-Card Lead
description: Mike Piazza could not save the Mets from falling out of the National League wild-card lead for the first time since Aug. 17.

title: Malaysia Imposes Controls On Trading in Its Currency
description: Taking an enormous gamble to halt the slide in Malaysia's currency and stock markets, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad imposed controls on the sale of the currency today and said the nation would introduce a fixed exchange rate.

title: Asia Fears Crisis It Exported May Be Headed Back Again
description: After being battered by tumbling currencies and stock markets for more than a year, Asian investors are now looking fearfully at the turmoil on Wall Street and wondering whether they are going to be hit yet again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINFIELD, SEYMOUR L.
description: LINFIELD-Seymour L. On August 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Babette. Loving father of Michael, Jeffrey and the late Judith. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth, Jessica and Rachel. Dear brother of Jordan, Hadassah and David. Services Wednesday 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: U.S.A. T.M.I.
description: I was lolling at home yesterday morning, watching Howie Mandel, a talk-show host, ask Rosie O'Donnell, another talk-show host who was his guest, about her summer vacation.

title: Congo Exile Group Emerges To Seek Ouster of President
description: A new factor in the Congo war emerged here today when a group of Congolese exiles called for the ouster of President Laurent Kabila's embattled Government.

title: Japan by the Bowlful, Con Brio
description: FINDING a reasonably priced restaurant in midtown is almost always a compromise, which is a polite way of saying that if the food is cheap, it's usually not very good, the restaurant's not very comfortable and the service is not very polite. Then, along comes Ya Bowl to prove that even this rule has its exceptions.

title: Metro Business; New Generator Planned
description: The AES Corporation of Arlington, Va., the nation's largest developer of power plants, plans to build a power plant near Hartford that will cost as much as $300 million, greatly increasing its presence in the New England electricity market.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Straphanger Gets a Film Role

title: Couple Are Attacked by 3 Men in Central Park
description: A Manhattan couple strolling through Central Park on Monday night were attacked by three men who robbed the man and sexually assaulted the woman, the police said yesterday.

title: Mahoney Is Rehired To Raise Money
description: Brian Mahoney, dismissed as basketball coach two years ago, was rehired yesterday by St. John's. He will work for the university's Office of Institutional Advancement as a fund-raiser involved in development and alumnni relations.

title: The Global Search for an Economic Parachute
description: Europe and the United States today shunted aside a call from Japan for an emergency meeting of the world's largest economies to deal with Russia's economic crisis.

title: Two Men Are Attacked In Gay-Bashing Incidents
description: One man was beaten and another was stabbed in separate incidents in Greenwich Village late Monday and early yesterday by a group of men who carried out the attacks because they thought their victims were gay, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, HELEN F.
description: KATZ-Helen F. Beloved wife of the late Morris M. Katz, loving mother of Lewis J. Katz, devoted grandmother of Evan H. Katz, dear sister of Sidney L. and Myron M. & the late doctor Abraham H. Fineman, Elva Novick & Monroe Fineman. Services on Wednesday 1:30PM, at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel 114-03 Queens Blvd. Corner of 76th Road.

title: Chernomyrdin, Still Unapproved, Plans to Appoint Acting Cabinet
description: While anxiety over Russia's deepening economic crisis spread, Acting Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin said today that he would form an acting cabinet without waiting for parliamentary approval.

title: Ralph G. Caso, 80, Is Dead; Led Nassau County in 1970's
description: Ralph G. Caso, who during his eight years as Nassau County Executive in the 1970's led efforts to build housing for the elderly, construct the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum and expand the county park system, died on Monday. He was 80.

title: Today's Hustings: a Phone Room and Lists of Donors
description: The Democratic primary in New York is two weeks away, but G. Oliver Koppell, a candidate for attorney general, has become something of a recluse lately, often shunning the campaign trail in favor of a tiny office that has the feel of a bookie's hideaway. By sequestering himself for hours on end, he believes that he can win the race: all he needs is an assistant with a sturdy dialing finger, a few phones, and lists -- lots and lots of lists -- of potential political contributors.

title: Tepid Debut For Stern Show
description: A station manager in Lubbock, Tex., disliked what he saw of ''The Howard Stern Radio Show,'' the newest entry to Saturday late-night television, strongly enough to drop the show on Monday, after its first two weeks on the air.

title: Hard-Charging Bulls and Red Flags
description: No bull market in American history has been so avidly tracked as that of the 1990's. For eight years, we have watched this expanding balloon with a sense of collective wonder, transfixed by our unending prosperity.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN STRENGTHENS. The dollar plunged to an 11-week low against the yen in Asian trading before recovering later as United States stocks rose. In New York, the dollar traded at 139.25 yen, down from 140.78 yen on Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Monday's sharp drop in stocks misstated the closing figure for the Standard & Poor's 500 index in some copies. It was 957.28, not 958.53.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VERITAS SOFTWARE CORP., Mountain View, Calif., which makes software to protect data, will acquire Telebackup Systems Inc., Calgary, Alberta, for $84.5 million in stock to add products for portable computers.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about the effect of the market turmoil on mergers and acquisitions misstated the outlook in some copies. As the article noted, the turmoil is likely (not unlikely) to slow deals.

title: Doctor Charged With Assaulting Girlfriend
description: A gynecology doctor at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center was charged with assault last night for injecting his girlfriend with an unknown substance while she was unconscious, the police said.

title: Tender Biscotti With Crumble, Not C-C-Crunch
description: SOME biscotti are so rock hard that it is reasonable to fear chipping a tooth, and some are so cakey that they are like a sponge in your mouth. But when you bite down on cornmeal almond biscotti from Once Upon a Tart, an unusual thing happens. The hard, coarse, twice-baked cookie shatters into a thousand tiny, incredibly flavored crumbs. The sensation is strange and fantastic.

title: DELTA DROPS PLANS TO LINK FLIGHTS WITH UNITED
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., after failing to reach an agreement with its pilots, dropped plans yesterday to link its routes with those of the UAL Corporation's United Airlines. The plan had been the cornerstone of a marketing partnership announced in April. Delta's decision yesterday came two weeks after its board refused to grant voting rights to the member of the board representing the pilots' union. The pilots said they would not support linking flights with United -- a practice known as code-sharing -- without voting rights like those that United pilots have on UAL's board. UAL shares rose $2.6875, to $63, while Delta's climbed $1.9375, to $103.8125. Northwest, the fourth-largest United States airline, set off a wave of airline pairings this year after it agreed in January to buy a controlling stake in Continental, the fifth largest, and said the airlines would sell tickets on each other's flights.

title: Sports of The Times; Graf Takes Next Step In Comeback
description: AT the distinctly non-regal hour of 11 o'clock in the morning, there was a pitty-pat of applause as Steffi Graf returned from a year in the tennis netherworld. One discreet little sign was taped in front of the two expensive box seats. It said, ''Steffi Queen of the Courts/ Kids Take Notes.''

title: Harlem Rally To Take Place, With Limits
description: Complying with a Federal court order, city officials and organizers of the rally billed as the Million Youth March briefly put aside weeks of vitriol last night to hammer out conditions for the event, which will take place on Saturday as organizers had hoped but in a much smaller swath of Harlem and for a much shorter time.

title: North Korea Draws Anger With Test Of a Missile
description: Congressional leaders, already angered at reports that North Korea may be building a new underground nuclear weapons plant, responded today to the firing of a new medium-range missile across Japan on Monday with threats to cut off all food aid and other assistance to the North Koreans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, JACK V. M.D.
description: LISMAN-Jack V. M.D. Age 81. Died on August 30, 1998. Survived by his wife of 54 years Sylvia; children Richard and Lee Lisman, Jane and Robert J. Katz; sister Leona Rothstein; four grandchildren, Hilary, Bogert, Cyrena L. Fink and James and Emily Katz, and great-granddaughter Brigitte J. Fink. Distinguished staff member and past Chief of the Division of Opthalmic Plastic Surgery at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital. Private services were held Tuesday, September 1 in Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to NYU School of Medicine or The Orbital Disease Foundation (635 Park Avenue NYC 10021)

title: N.Y.U. Says, 'No, Thanks' To Star Role In a Sitcom
description: Felicity Porter makes a very last-minute decision about where to go to college. On graduation day, when Ben Covington, the cute boy she has loved from afar in high school, writes something nice in her yearbook, Felicity decides to forget the pre-med program at Stanford (her parents' idea, anyway) and follow Ben to New York City. In the first episode of ''Felicity,'' the WB mini-network's new drama series, viewers will see the title character gazing at the application form. The letterhead says ''University of New York.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYPOL, ARTHUR
description: SAYPOL-Arthur. Age 90 on September 1, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Mildred. Loving father of Mary Goldblatt & Bruce Saypol. Cherished grandfather of Amy and Mark Holtzer, Julie and Frank Kern, Joshua Saypol, Benjamin Saypol, the late Andrew Goldblatt and great grandfather of Sarah, Talya, Jacob and Noah Holtzer & Melanie and Adam Kern. Devoted brother of George and the late Julian and Irving. Graveside service 1 P.M., Thursday, September 3, 1998 at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKER, JACK
description: SCHENKER-Jack. The Partners of Newmark & Company, Real Estate, Inc, mourn the passing of our former Partner, Jack Schenker. Jack was a true gentleman and a loyal an trusted partner, and will be missed by all of us. Our condolences go out to his wife, Lee, his daughter, Susan, his grandchildren, and the rest of his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LOUGHLIN, JEAN M. (GALLANT)
description: O'LOUGHLIN-Jean M. (Gallant). Of Floral Park, NY, died September 1, 1998. She was predeceased by her husband, Joseph M. O'Loughlin, also of Floral Park. She is survived by five children, Anne, Jean, Noreen, Joellyn and Martin; four grandchildren; and six siblings, Marie Johnson, Francis Gallant, Raymond Gallant, Robert Gallant, Kevin Gallant and James Gallant. Wake at Dalton Funeral Home, Floral Park, New York, Wednesday, September 2. Funeral mass at Our Lady of Victory R.C. Church, Thursday, September 3, at 10:30 A.M. Family requests donations made to Covenant House, New York, in lieu of flowers.

title: Another Itty Bitty Reno Step
description: By authorizing a narrowly defined investigation of whether Harold Ickes committed perjury in Senate testimony about the 1996 election campaign, Attorney General Janet Reno is trying to buy some time and relieve the intense Congressional pressure for an unfettered inquiry into President Clinton's fund-raising. The House and Senate Judiciary Committees, which will interview Ms. Reno today, will not be satisfied with this latest baby step. But they may regard the Ickes inquiry as a sign that Ms. Reno is beginning to yield to the righteous demands from Congress and her own Justice Department that she appoint an independent counsel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDELL, SOL
description: BEDELL-Sol. Died peacefully on August 31 in his 80th year. A native of New York City where he worked as a social worker, he relocated to Philmont, N.Y. in 1983 where he was active in the mental health movement. In 1991 he retired to Spring Hill, FL. to spend his years continuing his volunteer service to troubled youths. He leaves behind wife Doris, three wonderful children and their families, and four grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, THERESA
description: STEIN-Theresa. On August 30th. Beloved wife of the late George J. Devoted mother of Michael and Mary Ellen and Robert and Susan. Adored grandmother of Gary and Doris, Lauren, Douglas and Anissa, Matthew, and Rachel. Loving great-grandmother of Jessica. Private family service held on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, MARILYN
description: GREENBERG-Marilyn. The Officers, Trustees, congregants and clergy of The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourn the passing of Marilyn Greenberg, beloved wife of Rabbi Emeritus David Greenberg, and mother of Rachel, Ruth, Ethan, Adam and Susannah. We extend deepest condolences to Rabbi Greenberg and his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Cantor Debra Stein-Davidson Joseph Oppenheimer, President

title: U.S. to Use Its Missile Warning System to Alert Russians to Launchings Worldwide
description: During the frigid days of the cold war, American satellites watched for the fiery launchings of Soviet missiles, a sign that the United States might soon be under nuclear attack.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Stocks Need Time

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Valley of Plenty: A Rebirth For the Hudson; Three and a Half Hours to France, by Car
description: AS Route 9 shoots southward from Saratoga Springs, N.Y., the grand Victorian mansions of the old spa yield to the familiar outposts of American road culture. There are gas stations and convenience stores, a vegetable stand, a lawn-ornament emporium, a drive-in barbecue joint with picnic tables, and the rusticated cabins of the Thorobred Motel. It takes a sharp eye to pick out, on the left, the silver diner with the small rooftop sign: Chez Sophie Bistro.

title: Rebound on Wall Street
description: The American stock market bounced back yesterday, encouraging investors around the world and reducing the pressure on central bankers to lower interest rates here and in Europe. Perhaps markets will now pause to see just how far Asia's economic woes will spread.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIDER, BERTHA (NEE SAMPSON)
description: REIDER-Bertha (nee Sampson). On August 31. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Gerhard Schauer. Devoted mother of Paulette McLeod and the late Andrew Schauer. Dear sister of Dr. Louis Sampson and the late Joseph Sampson. Loving grandmother of Gabriel, Gideon and Eve. Also survived by many nieces & nephews. Services Wed. 12:15PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARNOW, JEANNETTE ABELOW
description: JARNOW-Jeannette Abelow. August 31, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Alfred Jarnow, loving mother of Alfred Jarnow Jr, and Betsy Potter, cherished grandmother of Jesse, Daniel and Liza. She will be deeply missed. She was an accredited author as well as Professor Emeritus & Chair of The Business Merchandising Department at The Fashion Institute of Technology. Services Thursday, Sept. 3, 2 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Long Island Childrens Museum, Garden City, L.I., The FIT Scholarship Fund, or a charity of your choice.

title: Tyson Is Facing New Concerns
description: A traffic accident in a Maryland suburb near Washington on Monday has created potential problems for Mike Tyson and could negatively affect his appeal to the Nevada State Athletic Commission to restore his boxing license.

title: Fewer Delays Than Selloff In October '97
description: Market Plunge 2.0, it seems, may be quite an upgrade for Internet stock brokers. It was only last October when the first billion-share trading day on the New York Stock Exchange tested Wall Street, as many of the new Internet trading services failed. Customers found that their brokers' Web sites had ground to a halt and phone lines were clogged.

title: Mallon and Jones On U.S. Team
description: Both Meg Mallon and Rosie Jones will return to familiar ground as members of the United States Solheim Cup team later this month.

title: Home Run King? Let Fans Argue
description: To the Editor:

title: Housing the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, MENDEL
description: BERKOWITZ-Mendel. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Margit and father of Ivan (and Francesca) Berkowitz, member, Yeshiva College Board of Directors; and Gila Berkowitz Levine (and Arvin). Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Berkowitz are YC Fellows. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Federal Court Upholds County's Smoking Law
description: For the second time in four weeks, a Federal court has ruled in favor of Suffolk County in a lawsuit challenging the county's ban on smoking in all areas of restaurants, including their bars.

title: Albert Bela Bauer, City Architect, 99
description: Albert Bela Bauer, who oversaw the construction of public buildings in New York as city architect for 30 years and prompted Mayor Robert F. Wagner's 1965 executive order providing for the use of art to adorn them, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 99 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELWIG, EDWARD P.
description: HELWIG-Edward P. Age 95. On August 30, 1998. At home in Larchmont, N.Y. Columbia 1924. Realtor with Cross & Brown. Mourned by wife Christine, daughters Christa Patterson & Marymina Wallis, five grandchildren and eight greatgrandchildren. Donations to Columbia College or Country Dance and Song Society.

title: A Magazine Catching Up With Opera's New Gloss
description: True opera fans have never turned to Opera News, the leading magazine on opera in the United States, for glossy picture layouts and puffy life-style pieces. It's not that opera fans aren't interested in the latest gossip about, say, which singer is in disfavor at La Scala or which young baritone is courting which promising soprano. And Opera News is a pretty good source for such tidbits.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the first executions under Palestinian self-rule referred incorrectly to the human rights group B'Tselem, which condemned them. It is Israeli, not Palestinian.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the first page of Business Day showing the 1998 performance of four major indexes gave incorrect figures for one, the Russell 2000. It closed on Monday at 337.95, down 31.2 percent from its peak of 491.41 on April 21.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Markets Bounce Back On Record-Setting Volume

title: Feeling Lost? Actually, This May Be the Place
description: WHEN you arrive at Church Street between Franklin and White in search of 2 Seven 7, you are presented with a number of choices. There is a restaurant on the corner, lights aglow, but its sign says ''Arqua.'' There is a set of black french doors set off by tall columns that looks like the entrance to a boutique under renovation. There are two shuttered shops. And there is, in fact, a door marked ''277.''

title: A Stray Bullet Kills a Man Riding Home With His Wife
description: A 55-year-old Bronx man driving home with his wife from their night-shift jobs was struck in the neck and killed by a stray bullet just three blocks from their co-op yesterday morning when a gunfight broke out on the street, the police said.

title: Despite Wall Street's problems, many on Madison Avenue are upbeat about consumers.
description: ADVERTISERS, agencies and the media are warily optimistic that the free-spending ways of American consumers, which have fueled more than three years of solid growth on Madison Avenue, will survive the wild gyrations on Wall Street relatively intact.

title: Malaysia Clamps Down On Currency Trading
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia effectively turned its back on the free market Tuesday, becoming the first Southeast Asian country hit by the regional economic crisis to clamp down on currency trading.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Business Digest yesterday referred erroneously in some copies to an article about the cancellation of an auction for two South Korean auto makers. The article became ready for copies printed later. Readers wishing copies of the article may write to Business Day, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1474. E-mail: bizday@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLARD, JEROME
description: MILLARD - Jerome. Beloved brother and brother-in-law. A sweet, kind, smart man, always full of humor, liked and respected by all who knew him. We will miss him and remember him lovingly. Walter and Eda Millard Marion and Herb Edelstein

title: Special Counsel's Duty Is to Report, Not to Judge
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, GERTRUDE
description: STEIN-Gertrude, 91. Beloved sister, sister-in-law, aunt and greataunt. Deceased 8/31 in Northport, FL. Thought to be the first woman graduate of City College Night School. Inspirational NYC public school teacher. Active Temple founder. Mother to us all. We will treasure her memory. Funeral 9/4, 1:30 PM, Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Call 201-843-9090 for info.

title: Metro Business; Empty Stores Getting Fewer and Costlier
description: Manhattan's inventory of stores available for rent dropped to 1,665 from 1,742 during the first six months of this year, triggering an increase in rents for primary retail space throughout the city, a leasing agency reported yesterday.

title: Two Electric Suppliers In Britain to Merge
description: Southern Electric P.L.C., a British utility, said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Scottish Hydro-Electric P.L.C., creating one of Britain's largest electricity suppliers. The all-stock merger will create a company with a market capitalization of $:4.87 billion ($8.13 billion) and with distribution networks serving 3.3 million customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWBURGER, FRANK L., JR.
description: NEWBURGER-Frank L., Jr., 89 who resided in Elkins Park, PA, died on Sunday after a long illness. Mr. Newburger was a Partner of Newburger, Loeb & Company, Newburger & Company, and a Senior Vice President and Director of Advest Group, Inc. Mr. Newburger was President of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, as were his father and brother. He was also a member of the Board of Governors of the New York Stock Exchange, in addition to having served as Chairman of its Regional Firms Advisory Committee for several years. During World War II, Mr. Newburger was on active Army duty with the University of Pennsylvania Hospital Unit (20th General Hospital), serving in the CBI Theatre, and retiring with the rank of Major. He was a graduate of Cornell University and a longtime member of the Cornell Council, of which he was an Emeritus member in his later years. Mr. Newburger is survived by his wife, Jane B. Newburger, son Frank L. Newburger, III, daughter-in-law Carol Palmer Newburger, grandson Charles N. Charnas, granddaughters Joann C. Nasson, Dory Newburger and Dana Newburger, stepsons Michael, Peter and John Lederer. Services will be held on Thursday at 1 P.M. at Reform Congregation Keneseth Israel in Elkins Park, with burial in Mount Sinai Cemetery.

title: Democrats For Senate Seeking Out Safe Ground
description: With the Democratic primary for United States Senate still a race in search of some sizzle, Representative Charles E. Schumer focused on a trademark issue yesterday, proposing anticrime measures to stem illegal interstate gun sales.

title: Pentagon and C.I.A. Defend Sudan Missile Attack
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen and the Director of Central Intelligence, George J. Tenet, told 42 senators at a classified briefing today that they are convinced that the United States has strong evidence to justify its attack on a suspected chemical-weapons site in the Sudan, according to a person who attended the closed-door meeting.

title: U.S. Faults Depositions of Microsoft Executives
description: In a court document made public today, the Justice Department accused top executives of the the Microsoft Corporation, including its chairman, William H. Gates, of ''an astonishing lack of recall'' when they were questioned under oath for the Government's antitrust suit against the software giant.

title: DOW CHEMICAL TO EXPAND OWNERSHIP OF MYCOGEN TO 100%
description: The stock of the Mycogen Corporation soared 37 percent yesterday as the Dow Chemical Company, the world's fifth-largest chemical company, said it would buy the 32 percent of Mycogen it did not already own for $322 million. The purchase will help Dow compete in the market for genetically engineered crops. Mycogen, which is based in San Diego, rose $7.50 a share, to $27.50, in Nasdaq trading. Dow Agrosciences, a Dow Chemical subsidiary, will make a tender offer at $28 a share for the remaining stake of Mycogen, a seed developer. The offer tops Dow's offer of $20.50 a share made in April.

title: Sinn Fein Calls Violence in Northern Ireland 'a Thing of the Past'
description: Gerry Adams said today that his party, Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, now considered violence in Northern Ireland to be ''a thing of the past.''

title: The Price of Cleveland's Heart
description: Bart Wolstein has built country clubs, strip malls, Kmarts and offices. They made him fabulously rich, but the thrills are past. Now when Wolstein, the son of a Minsk cloth cutter, thinks of what he must do, one thing remains: buying the Cleveland Browns.

title: Police Say Panel Withheld Findings Against 108 Officers
description: Raising new questions about New York City's ability to root out police brutality and misconduct, officials acknowledged yesterday that more than 100 cases of police misconduct were deemed credible by the independent agency that monitors the police but were never forwarded to the Police Department so it could discipline the officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ATLAS, THEODORE
description: ATLAS-Theodore, 85. Of Bal Harbour, Florida. Formerly of New York City. Passed away Monday, August 31, 1998 following a stroke. Devoted husband of his late wife Lillian, devoted father of Robert of Rockville, MD., and David of Red Bank, NJ, sadly mourned by his grandchildren Lauren, Brian, Anthony, Shira and Etai and loving brother Martin of Brooklyn and his dvoted nurse and friend Pancia Gerald. Mr. Atlas, a retired tax accountant, was a long time active volunteer for the Shul of Bal Harbour. Graveside services to be held 1:15PM, Thursday, September 3, at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, N.J. The cemetery can be contacted for further information at 201-262-1100.

title: Activist Arm-Twisting
description: The Rev. Michael Pfleger says that Jerry Springer broke his promise, and Father Pfleger and his band of activists in Chicago are not going to let him off the hook.

title: Home Run King? Let Fans Argue
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, ALFRED
description: FISHER-Alfred. On September 1, 1998. Beloved husband of Evelyn, devoted father of Dr. Howard, Tina, Esq., and the late Gary. Dear brother of Shirley Natke, Olivia Spitz and Diana Reich. Cherished grandfather of Shani, Bari and Rebecca. Loving father-in-law of Lori and Minda. Services Wednesday, 1PM at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: 5 Big Lenders Report Losses From Russia
description: Ripples from Russia's economic crisis are rapidly spreading through other financial markets, as Citicorp, Bankers Trust, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Barclays and Nomura Securities yesterday joined the growing list of companies reporting heavy losses on their Russian business.

title: Charles Haskell, 55; Redid Bold Adventures
description: Charles T. Haskell, an environmentalist and adventurer who recreated perilous historic expeditions in South America and Africa with descendants of famous explorers, died on Aug. 18 at a hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C., near his family home. He was 55.

title: Chrysler Sales Break a Record for August
description: Sales of Chrysler cars and trucks rose 3.5 percent in August, setting a record for the month, though they were off from the blistering pace of the spring.

title: Pilots on Strike at Air Canada as Talks Fail
description: Pilots for Air Canada, Canada's largest airline, went on strike today after failing to agree to a new contract, setting the stage for hundreds of canceled flights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACLAY, JENNIFER TRUSLOW
description: MACLAY-Jennifer Truslow. Of Charlottesville, VA. Formerly of Wilton, CT. Died in a car accident on August 28 in Charlottesville. She is survived by her sister, Susan Finnis of Cheshire, England & four children, Michael Truslow of Charlottesville, Sara Truslow Hardin of N.Y., Elizabeth Salvatore of Lucas, TX, and John Truslow of Oyster Bay, N.Y., as well as 11 grandchildren. Services will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, Wilton, CT., on Thursday, September 3rd at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Wilton Library Association, Wilton, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRIGHT, JACK
description: BRIGHT-Jack. Died in Florida. Loving husband of 56 years of Edna ''Honey''. Adored father of Lois Elsinger and Lynn Jacobson. Beloved grandfather of Jessica, Todd, Andrew, Brett. Retired executive of Alexander's Department Stores. Services were held September 1st.

title: The Secrets of the Universe as Decoded by the Unhinged
description: Poor, dumb astronomers, the wigged-out letter writers all seem to be saying. ''I know something about life that others don't seem to know,'' confides one deranged correspondent. Another scolds, ''You cannot comprehend on account of your scientific education!''

title: So Far, Luxury Goods Hold Their Luster
description: The $400 ashtrays are still selling at Versace's on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. So are the ties, which start at $120. When customers are spooked by sell-offs in the stock market, sales of these gewgaws tend to fall off, managers said. After all, even if one can't live without a $5,000 evening gown, one can put off the $400 ashtray.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS BUYS FRENCH PACKAGED-MEAT CONCERN
description: Smithfield Foods Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Societe Bretonne de Salaisons, a French packaged-meat company. Financial terms were not disclosed. Societe Bretonne de Salaisons, based in Brest, France, has annual sales of about $115 million and employs about 500 workers. Smithfield, based in Smithfield, Va., said Societe Bretonne would provide the platform for expansion of its European business. In addition to curing ham and bacon, Societe Bretonne also makes fresh sausage and pates. Smithfield said that three-quarters of Societe Bretonne's sales are to French retail grocery chains, with the remainder to food-service companies and for export.

title: GHANAIAN MINING COMPANY TO BUY SAMAX GOLD OF CANADA
description: The Ashanti Goldfields Company, a mining company based in Accra, Ghana, agreed to buy Samax Gold Inc., based in Toronto, for $177.5 million (Canadian) in stock. The purchase will give Ashanti control of Samax's Kukuluma gold property in Tanzania, which abuts Ashanti property there. The deal is worth about $114 million (United States). Ashanti, the world's 12th-largest gold producer last year, is offering to pay $7.94 (Canadian) in cash for each Samax share. Samax shareholders will also have the option to take shares in an Ashanti subsidiary worth $7.10 (United States) each.

title: West Isn't to Blame For Russia's Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHTMAN, FRANCES SIMMONS
description: LEICHTMAN-Frances Simmons. Of Boynton Beach, FL on August 31, 1998. Former Senior Vice President of Alexander's department stores. Beloved wife of Paul Leichtman; loving mother of Gail Macht-Martin and Alvin Martin, and Jane Freeman and Stuart Freeman. Devoted and generous grandmother of Hilary Macht, Timothy Macht, David Freeman and his wife Gail Freeman, and Todd Ewan; great grandmother of Michael Freeman. Dear sister of ''E'' Lipman, Dorothy Simmons and the late Alfred E. Simmons, Rose Greenberger and Allen Simmons. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, September 2, 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, ELIZABETH (NEE LANSKY)
description: LEVINE-Elizabeth (nee Lansky). Age 86, beloved wife of George, beloved mother of Lisa Ann, beloved grandmother of Devin and devoted friend to Mary. Services Thursday 12 noon at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to City Meals On Wheels, would be appreciated.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: For Two Shops, More Room For Chocolate and Pastries

title: Panel Head Accuses Clinton Backers of Smear Tactics
description: Representative Dan Burton, whose committee has been investigating fund-raising abuses in the re-election campaign of President Clinton, said this week that a national magazine planned to publish a ''scandal story'' about him at the behest of Mr. Clinton's supporters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASO, RALPH G
description: CASO-Ralph G. Sr., The Honorable former Nassau County Executive (1971-1978) of Merrick, NY on August 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Grace (nee Milone). Devoted father of Ralph Jr. of Independent Group Home for Living, Nesconset, New York & Jolisa Sagstetter of Wantagh, NY. Devoted fatherin-law of Donald G. Sagstetter. Cherished grandfather of Christina Grace and Donald Franz. Dear brother of Dr. George R. Caso, Sr. of Merrick. Fond brother-in-law of Virginia Caso & of Caroline Milone Giaquinto, Louis J. Milone, Vera Milone Ferme, all of Rockville Centre & John E. Milone of Roslyn Estates. Also survived by his many nieces and nephews. Reposing Thursday, September 3, 1998, 2-4:30 PM and 7-9 PM at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Avenue, Merrick. Funeral Mass Friday 10:45 AM at Cure of Ars R.C. Church. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Independent Group Home for Living, Inc. C/O Mr. Walter Stockton, P.O. Box 638, 62 Pine Street, East Moriches, NY 11940.

title: Italy Wins Bridge Title by 79
description: The bridge team representing Italy won the Vivendi Rosenblum world championship title here this afternoon, defeating Brazil by the large margin of 79 imps. The winners were Andrea Buratti, Massimo Lanzarotti, Alfredo Versace and Lorenzo Lauria, with Antonio Sementa and Francesco Angelini playing supporting roles.

title: Detroit Papers Ordered to Rehire Strikers and Pay Back Wages
description: Ruling that two Detroit newspapers had not bargained in good faith, the National Labor Relations Board yesterday ordered them to rehire hundreds of reporters, drivers, pressmen and other workers who went on strike three years ago and to give them millions of dollars in back wages.

title: Three Rappers Who Flip and Roll With the Punches
description: The Black Eyed Peas stood on the cliff's edge of a problem during the first of two shows Sunday night at S.O.B.'s, but whirled away and gracefully made it into an opportunity. A few songs in, the trio of rappers realized they needed one more microphone onstage, to accommodate Kym Hill, the singer accompanying them. ''I need a mike,'' murmured Ms. Hill, and the show lost pace as she waited.

title: Kellogg to Review Marketing Programs
description: The Kellogg Company said unexpectedly yesterday that it would begin a review that might result in adding an agency to the roster of shops handling its troubled American ready-to-eat cereal account.

title: Coast Guard Faces Suit Over Toxic Batteries It Dumped in Lakes and Rivers
description: The United States Coast Guard, responsible for policing the nation's navigable waterways, has for decades dumped toxic batteries into rivers and lakes and has only half-heartedly tried to clean up its mess, say environmentalists and anglers who are behind a Federal lawsuit intended to force the service to retrieve the batteries.

title: Teachers Imported From Spain To Teach Spanish in the Bronx
description: It may seem odd, in a city with more than a million households in which Spanish is spoken, that the Board of Education has gone all the way to Spain to find people to teach Spanish.

title: DURA AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY TOWER'S AUTO HINGE BUSINESS
description: Dura Automotive Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Tower Automotive Inc.'s auto-hinge business for an undisclosed amount. Dura, which is based in Minneapolis, plans to expand its product line. Tower's hinge business, with about $50 million in annual revenue, has two plants in the Detroit area and supplies major auto companies. Tower, which is based in Grand Rapids, Mich., said it planned to concentrate on its chassis and suspension business. Dura Automotive's products include parking brake systems, latches and jacks.

title: Mistakes Hobble Venezuelan Economy, Experts Say
description: With investment holdings flying out of this country, international market analysts widely agree that Venezuela's economy has been crippled by an overvalued currency, government interference in monetary policy and irresponsible spending that relies too heavily on oil revenues.

title: Cancers From Nuclear Tests Are Seen as Too Hard to Trace
description: There is no good way to find the tens of thousands of Americans who may have received enough radiation from atmospheric nuclear tests to raise their chances of cancer significantly, an advisory panel said today.

title: Pushing for the Tale of a Tiny Boy
description: Mark Steven Johnson, a screenwriter best known for his hit pictures ''Grumpy Old Men'' and ''Grumpier Old Men,'' recalls the months he spent traipsing from studio to studio to pitch the idea of adapting a portion of the John Irving novel ''A Prayer for Owen Meany.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALNIG, LAWRENCE R.
description: MALNIG-Lawrence R. Age 81, of Ridgefield, NJ, died on August 31, 1998. Devoted husband of Laura (nee Itteilag) of Ridgefield. Beloved father of Julie Malnig of New York City and Anita Malnig of San Francisco, CA. Loving brother of Yolanda De Augustinis of Brooklyn, New York. Loving grandfather of Tomas Kaufman of San Francisco, CA. For further information, please call Blackley Funeral Home, Ridgefield, New Jersey at (201) 945-5032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ALBERT
description: SCHWARTZ-Albert. On September 1, 1998. Devoted husband to the late Jyle who was his love and companion for over 65 years. Loving and adoring father to Jack and Ellen, Toby Maranga, Louis and Jane. Proud grandfather to Lauren and Michael Lynfield, Randi and Seth Salwen, Lee and Joann Stahl, Harrison and Lindsay Schwartz, Deborah and Barry Johnson, Mark Weinberg. Loving and proud great-grandpa to Gabrielle and Shoshana Lynfield, Kelsea Johnson. Devoted brother to Fanny Slotnick and Rose Rosenberg. Service Wednesday, 12 noon at Kirschenbaum Bros., 1700 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

title: An Injured Smith to Miss 3 to 4 Months
description: Mike Smith, the leading rider at Saratoga this summer and the regular jockey on the star colt Coronado's Quest, fractured two vertebrae in his upper back in a spill he took Monday. He will not ride for three or four months.

title: Breakaway States
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKET TURMOIL: POLICY -- Reading the Fed's Tea Leaves; Some Doubt Lower Rates Will Follow Market Plunge
description: When faced with a Latin America that could no longer pay its debts during the summer of 1982, the Federal Reserve cast aside its tight-money policy and cut interest rates. When faced with a stomach-churning stock market drop in October 1987, the Fed acted quickly to pump more money into the system.

title: Home Run Chase On the Air
description: The Sammy Sosa-Mark McGwire home run extravaganza will get extra national exposure with yesterday's decisions by Fox, ESPN, the Fox Sports Net and FX.

title: STOCK JUMPS AFTER FIRSTPLUS REPORTS IT MAY BE ACQUIRED
description: Shares of Firstplus Financial Group Inc. jumped yesterday after the company, a mortgage lender, said it was talking with potential buyers about being purchased. Dallas-based Firstplus, which specializes in loans of as much as 125 percent of a home's value, said on Monday that the discussions came after ''a lengthy review'' and informal discussions with potential buyers. Its stock rose $4.4375 a share, to $27.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said interested parties could include large credit card or finance companies or banks. The company hired Bear, Stearns & Company and Carpenter & Associates to advise it on the transaction.

title: What Anti-Semitism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSON, ARTHUR
description: CASSON-Arthur. Beloved husband of Iris. Loving father of Paula Joseph & Shari Reisch. Loving grandfather of Jordan, Nathan, Brandon and Troy. Dear brother of Harvey, Charlotte and Henry. Services at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island at 11:30AM Thursday.

title: The Year of the Black Auteur, Soulfully and Seductively
description: Soul music, urban music, rhythm-and-blues: the vast field of pop played by predominantly black artists for a black-based audience is where the curious should wander to find excitement now. With the spotlight on talents like Lauryn Hill, RZA of Wu Tang Clan, Missy Elliott and her partner Timbaland and Canibus and category-busters like Chocolate Genius and Eagle-Eye Cherry making waves, there's good reason to call 1998 the year of the rhythm-and-blues auteur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOSI, LAURENCE A. JR.
description: TOSI-Laurence A. Jr., 63. Of Rye Beach, N.H., on August 30, 1998. Husband of Dyanne. Visiting hours Wednesday 7-9 PM & Thursday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. in the family residence, Rye Beach. Funeral mass Friday, 11 A.M., St. Theresa Church, Rye Beach. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, MARILYN JEAN
description: WARREN-Marilyn Jean. Of Bronxville. On September 1, 1998. Wife of John J. Warren. Daughter of William F. Kadlec Sr., sister of William F. Kadlec Jr. and Alice Fennell. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M. Wednesday & Thursday. Service at St. Luke's Lutheran Church, New Rochelle, Friday, September 4 at 11 A.M.

title: S.A.T. Scores Decline Even as Grades Rise
description: Calling it evidence of persistent grade inflation in American high schools, College Board officials said yesterday that more college-bound students had A averages than a decade ago but that they scored lower on their S.A.T. exams.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 20 about the growth of stock market signs in Times Square misstated the type of sign put up in 1904 for Trimble's Whiskey. It was electric, not neon.

title: Tough Opening Games Create Jittery Coaches
description: Coach Bobby Bowden learned that right now, this edition of the Florida State Seminoles would be a 30-point underdog against his 1993 national championship team. And Nebraska's Frank Solich got a lesson in medicine, after preseason injuries made his secondary vulnerable and a ligament tear complicated his quarterback situation.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Assembling Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza Puzzle
description: It took 15 years, from when the first plans were drawn up in 1983 until tenants started moving in earlier this year, to turn Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza from a concept into a reality. But now it is there, its front on Adams Street in the borough's downtown district and complete with 820,000 square feet of Class A office space, a 376-room Marriott hotel that began receiving guests in July, and 1,100 underground parking spaces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISE, GORDON JAMES
description: WISE-Gordon James. On August 31, 1998. Loving husband of Barbara Wise. Father of Janet Lang, Margaret Auer, Diana Reock, Andrea Reed, Evelyn Auer. Stepfather of Laura Drons, Betsy Whitmore & Peter Whitmore. Brother of Winifred Cort, Janet Renz and Marion Wise. Grandfather of fifteen. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. James the Less, Crane Road, Scarsdale, N.Y., Thursday at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Church of St. James the Less, Crane Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Russian Woes Increase Doubts Over U.S. Money for I.M.F.
description: The current economic turbulence has widened the gulf dividing Republicans over whether to approve new financing for the International Monetary Fund.

title: Canadian Real Estate Deal
description: The Fortress Investment Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Trizec Hahn Corporation's portfolio of Canadian office and industrial real estate assets for about $54 million. Fortress, a real estate concern based in New York, said the portfolio consisted of about 1.3 million square feet leased long term, primarily to the Bell Canada unit of BCE Inc. The assets are in southern Ontario. Trizec Hahn, based in Toronto, is a real estate holding company.

title: Judge Rules Against Mall In Dispute Over Leaflets
description: A state judge has ruled that the owners of a Secaucus shopping mall cannot force organizations to carry costly liability insurance in order to distribute leaflets.

title: Serenity From Vietnam by Way of Paris
description: ''I DON'T feel like fighting anymore,'' Antoine Nguyen said a couple of months ago. ''I was in Vietnam, and that was enough.''

title: Dialing for Dollars
description: G. Oliver Koppell, a candidate in the Democratic primary for state attorney general, trying to persuade a lawyer over the phone to give a campaign donation.

title: Reno Orders Inquiry Into Ickes's Testimony Before Senate
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today ordered an investigation into whether Harold M. Ickes, a former deputy White House chief of staff, committed perjury last year when he testified before a Senate committee examining Democratic campaign fund-raising abuses.

title: Too Nice, Too Perfect To Come True Again
description: In the history of major league baseball, no pitcher has ever pitched two perfect games, so who could have thought last night that David Wells would pitch his second one in three and a half months? The Oakland A's, that's who.

title: Lingering Summer Hits
description: This summer has proved unusually fertile ground for new shows; two might reasonably be labeled hits.

title: Angola Delays Unity Move And Peace Prospects Dim
description: Even as Angolan troops are busy propping up the neighboring Government of Congo, prospects for peace in Angola seem to be diminishing.

title: Young Jets to Get Look At the Legendary 49ers
description: The San Francisco 49ers, the Jets' season-opening opponent on Sunday, have produced 15 straight seasons with at least 10 victories. In the late 1980's, when Jets who are now 23 or 24 were first turning into teen-agers, the 49ers reeled off back-to-back Super Bowl victories, giving them four for the decade.

title: A Protein Is Said to Predict Prostate Cancer's Virulence
description: Researchers at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York have found that a protein seems to predict which prostate cancers are likely to be deadly and warrant aggressive treatment and which can be controlled with less treatment or perhaps none at all.

title: School Sign-Up Plan Praised
description: A week before New York City's 1.1 million public-school children are to descend on their new classrooms, their principals opened their doors yesterday to register students new to the city, the school system and, in some instances, the country.

title: James A. Washington Jr., 83, Judge and Dean of Law School
description: James Aaron Washington Jr., a retired District of Columbia judge and Howard University law dean who helped to formulate the Supreme Court case that resulted in the 1954 decision against school segregation, died on Saturday in his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 83.

title: In a Word, a Novel That's Fraught
description: THE MUSEUM GUARD

title: Home Run King? Let Fans Argue
description: To the Editor:

title: Poorest New Jersey Districts Race to Be Ready for Preschoolers
description: Just a few days before the start of the new school year, the Superintendent in Phillipsburg, N.J., learned that two of his special-education teachers were quitting. Then, after the bombings at two embassies overseas, he and his elementary school principal had to negotiate with the Department of Defense about increasing security at temporary classrooms they were leasing in an old armory.

title: Old Wage Plan for Cabbies Gets Another Look
description: Taxi executives, worried that the city wants to modify or eliminate the cab-leasing system that has become an economic linchpin of the industry, proposed a pilot program yesterday under which 100 cabbies would work on commission, as most did until the 1980's.

title: Zedillo Tells Mexico Painful Economic Policies Are Farsighted
description: President Ernesto Zedillo tonight made his first major statement about the effects of the world financial crisis on Mexico. Mr. Zedillo acknowledged that plunging oil prices had forced painful budget cuts and urging Mexicans to be patient and work hard to help the country continue to grow.

title: Telefonica's Profit Rises 15% in Quarter
description: Telefonica S.A., Spain's biggest telecommunications company, had an implied quarterly profit that was 15 percent higher as booming revenue from Latin America offset the effect of competition on its Spanish business. Telefonica's profit in the second quarter rose to 65.3 billion pesetas ($438 million), as extrapolated from a 16 percent increase in first-half net, to 98.11 billion pesetas.

title: Home Run King? Let Fans Argue
description: To the Editor:

title: Wells Waltzes With Pitching Immortality
description: David Wells had been in this magical situation before, not so very long ago. Wells was looking so powerful and so much in control on the mound. His fastball was zooming past the Oakland batters, his curveball was dancing all the way toward home and virtually every pitch he unleashed was slithering into the strike zone. Wells was, well, perfect.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: After a Strenuous Victory, the Agony of Recovery
description: Jonas Bjorkman had just finished his first-round victory over Cedric Pioline in five sets yesterday, but as Bjorkman remained standing to avoid cramping inside the men's locker room, his workday was far from over.

title: Mediterranean Nights
description: OVER the years, Paula Wolfert seems to have settled into her role as a tireless correspondent reporting on the Mediterranean's complex culinary cultures. Her latest dispatch is ''Mediterranean Grains and Greens'' (HarperCollins, $27.50), her sixth cookbook.

title: Hoechst and Mobil Call Off Joint Venture
description: Hoechst A.G., Germany's third-largest drug and chemical maker, and the Mobil Corporation, the second-largest United States oil company, said yesterday that they had abandoned plans to form a joint venture to make plastic film after failing to agree on terms. The venture would have combined the Mobil Chemical Company's films division and Hoechst's Trespaphan unit that makes oriented polypropylene. It would have had annual sales of about $1 billion, the companies said in March, when they signed a letter of intent.

title: Treasuries Register Sharpest Loss in More Than 4 Months
description: With the stock market having rebounded from Monday's decline, Treasury securities posted their sharpest loss in more than four months yesterday. Volume was heavy, as flows of capital from equity markets into United States Government debt eased.

title: Valley of Plenty: A Rebirth For the Hudson; How Farmers Capture The Culinary Heart Of the City
description: AT 2 o'clock on a Friday afternoon, the orchards at Locust Grove Farm were enjoying a siesta in the hot midday sun. Not a farmer was in sight, so I headed to the top of a bluff overlooking the farm and the Hudson River and knocked on the door of an old yellow house.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Oh, What a Tangled Web!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Heavy Weather: Hurricane Bonnie a Big Draw
description: In addition to taking its toll on the Atlantic Coast States, Hurricane Bonnie did a number on the Internet server of Weather.com, the Web site of the Weather Channel cable network.

title: Giuliani and Vallone Battle Over Charter Lawsuit
description: The legal battle between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, over Yankee Stadium and the Mayor's Charter commission devolved yesterday into a skirmish over where a lawsuit filed by the Speaker should be heard.

title: PHOTOBITION OF BRITAIN TO BUY KATZ DIGITAL IN CASH DEAL
description: Katz Digital Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by Photobition Group P.L.C., Britain's leading supplier of graphic services and products to the exhibition, display and media industries, for $50 million in cash. Photobition will pay about $47 million for Katz's stock, vested options, warrants and other convertible securities, based on a price of about $8.78 a share, while holders of unvested options will receive about $3 million. Shares of Katz rose $2.375, to $7.3125. Katz provides digital printing and prepress services for advertising and marketing companies in New York and surrounding states.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Women in Be-Bop
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMS MERNS, STEPHEN
description: SYMS MERNS-Stephen. We are deeply saddened and shockecd beyond comprehension at the passing of our beloved associate, Stephen. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to the entire family. Stanley Blacker

title: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; Lots of On-Screen Options And a Band to Back You Up
description: PLAY GUITAR WITH ROSS BOLTON(Play Music Inc.; $49.95; Windows 95, 98 and NT.)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For brokerage stocks, once darlings, regaining favor depends on hints from a fickle market.
description: THE shares of Wall Street brokerage firms have been battered in recent weeks, in some cases falling more than 40 percent, suddenly becoming pariahs after months, even years, when they were among the market's darlings.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Generations of Hollyhocks

title: Livent Ledger Woes, Scene II: New Hire Replaces Impresario
description: In their first major move since disclosing serious accounting problems and suspending two company executives, officials of the theater production company Livent Inc. announced yesterday that they had hired Todd Haimes, the artistic director of the Roundabout Theater Company, as their artistic director.

title: Campaign Inquiry Wouldn't Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISMAN, ABRAHAM, M.D.
description: REISMAN-Abraham, M.D. Beloved husband of Marian. Devoted father of Judy Reisman Toof, Richard Reisman, & Joan Cooper. Loving grandfather of Amy, Steven and Daniel. Service 11 A.M., Thursday at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, SOL
description: RABINOWITZ-Sol. On September 2, 1998. Husband of Elizabeth. Father of Robert Rabinowitz and Toby Becker. Grandfather and great grandfather. Services Friday 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about ''The Museum Guard'' included several references to the author by his given name rather than his surname. He is Howard Norman.

title: Tough Civics Lessons Ahead
description: They say Vermont is a rather insulated state, but it's not, I'm afraid, insulated quite enough. So, like every other middle school teacher in the country, I know that as school resumes I'll have no chance of avoiding an avalanche of difficult questions and smart remarks from my students regarding the President of the United States.

title: Honda to Sell Stake In Venture to Partner
description: The Honda Motor Company plans to sell its 51 percent stake in Kinetic Honda Motor Ltd. to its joint venture partner, Kinetic Engineering Ltd., based in Bombay, India, for $8.1 million. A joint statement said Honda would continue to provide technical support to Kinetic Honda. Kinetic Honda will continue using Honda's network for exporting its vehicles under the Honda name, the statement said.

title: Magnet Plan Suggested to Desegregate School
description: In a new chapter in the bitter, 13-year feud over desegregating Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood, a committee of the New Jersey Board of Education proposed today that the community work to correct the imbalance itself by creating a special magnet school in hopes that it would lure white students from nearby towns.

title: Calling on Technology to Build a Better Handcuff
description: AS many police officers will admit, there is no such thing as a pick-proof handcuff. The engineers and law enforcement officials who work at developing one are simply outnumbered by the convicts who spend many hours a day figuring out how to outwit their restraints.

title: Changing Bank Regulation
description: The Senate Banking Committee today takes up the financial services regulatory reform bill, which passed the House earlier this year by a one-vote margin. It is good legislation that sets up fair rules as banks, insurers and brokerage firms expand into each other's business. But two provisions in the House-passed bill need to be changed.

title: Lower East Side on Jersey Shore; In Bradley Beach, Chinese and Italians Find Harmony
description: Family after family, they flocked to this tiny, tranquil Jersey Shore town from Mulberry Street in Little Italy, Italian-Americans hungry for a summer escape from urban congestion.

title: Does the Internet Bring Us Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Shipbuilder Reports 94% Slide in Earnings
description: Kvaerner A.S.A., Europe's largest shipbuilder, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit slid a greater-than-expected 94 percent, dragged down by write-downs, interest payments and a slump in shipbuilding profit. Kvaerner said it would merge divisions to become more efficient as profit fell to 26 million Norwegian kroner, or $3.4 million, from 440 million kroner in the period a year earlier. Analysts forecast profit of 224 million kroner and were surprised by the 178 million kroner write-down.

title: Sleeveless Dress Turns Costly
description: Sleevelessness has its disadvantages. Venus Williams has been fined $100 for refusing to display a WTA Tour logo on the ensemble she wore during her first-round victory at the United States Open, and yesterday the Tour's chief executive officer, Bart MacGuire, made it clear that the fines would continue to be levied unless Williams and her sponsor, Reebok, rethink their position. If Williams goes logo-less into her second round match today, the fine escalates to $500, and it could skyrocket to as much as $25,000 for the third round.

title: Review Board Criticizes Police on Discipline
description: The independent agency responsible for investigating complaints of police misconduct gave an unusually blunt critique of the Police Department's disciplinary system yesterday, charging in a report that the department is slow to act when the agency finds reason to believe that an officer is guilty and deserves punishment.

title: Microsoft Acts as a Muse, But Not One to Its Liking
description: An attempt to dominate world markets. High-lee intrigue. Manipulation of the justice system. Executives talking about ''killing'' competitors.

title: Robert Stern to Be Yale's Architecture Dean
description: Robert A. M. Stern, who has designed notable buildings for Berlin, Battery Park City and the Walt Disney Company, is expected to be named today as the new Dean of the Yale School of Architecture. He will replace Fred Koetter, who has been dean for the past five and a half years and who will return to private practice while remaining a part-time adjunct professor.

title: Does the Internet Bring Us Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Street Shopping'
description: To the Editor:

title: Main Street Investors Take the Bear by the Horns
description: During these pogo stick days on Wall Street, Stanley Walker, a retired mechanic with a good chunk of his life savings in the stock market, has thought once or twice about his boyhood in the Depression years.

title: Malaysian Chief Ousts Deputy Who Opposed Him on Economy
description: In a swift and politically brutal move, Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, today dismissed his deputy and heir apparent, Anwar Ibrahim, who had opposed his insular and free-spending economic policies.

title: BASEBALL -- It's Sosa's Day, but Night Belongs to McGwire; Sosa Blasts 56th Homer, Helped by Many Friends
description: Sammy Sosa responded to Mark McGwire, or at least to Barbara Reichert. ''We need just one run, Sammy, hit me one,'' she yelled today from the first row in the right-field bleachers at Wrigley Field.

title: We Still Need Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: Commuters Take Up Digital Arms to Battle Traffic Snarls
description: IT'S 8 A.M. in Seattle, and a commuter looks down at his watch. The digital pager display tells him that there has been an accident on his preferred route to work, so he considers an alternative. What about taking a bus?

title: 2 WPP Group Units In Joint Venture
description: Two divisions of the Commonhealth unit of WPP Group P.L.C. -- Learning Systems in Wayne, N.J., and the Hill & Knowlton Health and Pharmaceutical Practice -- are teaming up to form a joint venture in London called Health Learning Systems. The new unit, specializing in medical-education programs and professional relations, will be headed by Martin Godfrey, 42, chief executive of Hill & Knowlton's European Health and Pharmaceutical Practice in London, as managing director. The joint venture will have 86 employees and work for clients like Glaxo Wellcome and Schering-Plough.

title: Do-It-Yourself Travel With a Load of Guilt
description: I HAVE avoided taking infants on airplanes ever since the mashed peas incident of 1990. On a nonstop flight from Phoenix to New York, my 11-month-old daughter smeared a handful into the hair of a sleeping woman in the row ahead. The next three hours were as suspenseful as any Hitchcock movie; what if the passenger woke?

title: Relax. Stocks Rarely Steer the Economy.
description: Are plunging stock prices a harbinger of economic crisis? Paul Samuelson, the Nobel laureate in economics, once quipped that stock market declines had anticipated nine of the previous five recessions.

title: Coasters That Have The Life Span Of a Drink
description: ''I've always wanted to design great, affordable things for the home,'' Keith Carollo said. ''Paper seemed like a good place to start. It's inexpensive and disposable.'' Mr. Carollo's company, Fred Flare, has created 3.5-inch-square Mint Moxie coasters (above) out of thick, slightly textured card stock. In packs of 12 for $5, at Eclectic Home, 224 Eighth Avenue (21st Street), and the Whitney Museum Store, 943 Madison Avenue (74th Street). RIMA SUQI

title: USWeb to Buy CKS Group
description: The USWeb Corporation in Santa Clara, Calif., which provides Internet services, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire CKS Group Inc., an integrated marketing communications agency company in Cupertino, Calif., for stock worth $21.66 a share, or $344.4 million, and will combine the two under the name Reinvent Communications Inc.

title: Overcoming, Not Just Surviving
description: ALONE, with a magazine and her private thoughts. That's how Monica Seles spent the time before she was summoned onto the Arthur Ashe Stadium court yesterday afternoon. In the bustling players' lounge, she stretched herself out by the window in two facing chairs, draped a towel across her ankles, and remained in that detached position longer than most 24-year-olds could.

title: Poughkeepsie Man Linked to Slayings Of Eight Women
