description: Police investigators wearing face masks and white jump suits found the bodies of two women and the decaying remains of others yesterday in a ramshackle green house a block from Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Public Defender of a High-Profile Private Life
description: I'M worried about myself,'' said Lanny Davis, the ubiquitous former White House aide who may well defend Bill Clinton until the last independent counsel dies. Normally you can find Mr. Davis in Washington -- or in an NBC studio, actually, where he spent more than 17 straight hours as a pro-Clinton talking head on the day of the President's Monica Lewinsky speech. But on Tuesday Mr. Davis got off the air long enough for coffee at the Royalton Hotel on West 44th Street, before he hurried over to Simon & Schuster to work out a book contract about his years in the First Bunker.

title: Disposables for That Last Bash of Summer
description: The endless summer will soon end. But there is time for one last splash this weekend with Cocktail Cats and Sur la Table, two series of vividly colored napkins, bowls and plates. They were designed by Hilton McConnico, best known for his expensive 1986 Daum crystal wineglasses with cactus-shape pate de verre stems, now in the permanent design collection of the Museum of Decorative Arts in Paris. ''There's nothing worse than a boring plate,'' Mr. McConnico said from his atelier on the outskirts of Paris. The cocktail napkins are $3.50 for 20; dinner napkins, $7.50 for 40, and dinner plates, $4.75 for 8. The paper goods, made by Caspari, are at Kate's Paperie, 561 Broadway (Prince Street). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Overbite, Underbite, Megabyte: Dentistry Gets an Upgrade
description: TECHNOLOGY has always been the dentist's stock in trade. From high-speed drills to X-rays, the men and women who pull and preserve teeth have often turned to technology to take their practice one more step beyond the image of the torture chamber. It's no surprise then, that dentists are going digital.

title: I.B.M. WINS $3 BILLION CONTRACT OUTSIDE U.S.
description: I.B.M. won a $3 billion, 10-year contract to provide computer support to Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. in its biggest service contract outside the United States. I.B.M. will maintain the computer network and billing system for Cable and Wireless, Britain's No. 1 cable company. The partnership will involve the transfer of 1,000 Cable and Wireless staff to I.B.M.'s Global Services unit and create up to 400 new jobs. Global Services is I.B.M.'s fastest-growing business. Shares of I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., rose $2.5625, to $120.50.

title: Many Sites To Confess One's Sins
description: THE Internet may be the world's largest confessional. Its paradoxical combination of anonymity and intimacy provides fertile ground for admissions that might never be aired in ''real'' life. Even when real names are known, the medium -- a step removed from physical contact and thus, perhaps, from perceived consequences -- somehow evokes a closed-curtain, hush-toned closeness that draws people out in occasionally astonishing ways.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BURNETT, ALTON R.
description: BURNETT-Alton R. 9/3/05-5/7/90. We love you and miss you always. The Family

title: Imaging in Orthodontics; Straighter Teeth in Mere Moments, at Least on Screen
description: FIFTEEN-YEAR-OLD Monica Tantlinger can see the future. She even has a computer printout of it.

title: Telnet: Old Friend Offers High Speed
description: YOU log onto the Internet one day, and it's blazingly fast; no more World Wide Wait. Pulling up Web pages is instantaneous. Your E-mail soars by more quickly than you can read it. Information is at your fingertips with hardly a pause.

title: Cleaned-Up Computers
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen Drury, 80, Novelist; Wrote 'Advise and Consent'
description: Allen Drury, the quintessential Washington novelist and author of ''Advise and Consent,'' died yesterday at St. Mary's Medical Center in San Francisco. He was 80 and lived in Tiburon, Calif.

title: Campaign Inquiry Wouldn't Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Reno in Reverse Gear: New Outlook or Tactical Move?
description: Buffeted for 18 months by Republicans in Congress over her refusal to allow an independent counsel to examine how Democrats financed President Clinton's re-election, Attorney General Janet Reno has abruptly reversed herself, opening two preliminary inquiries in a week that could lead to the appointment of an outside prosecutor.

title: Schumer in the Stretch
description: Internal polls are starting to show Representative Charles Schumer neck and neck with -- or even slightly ahead of -- Geraldine Ferraro in the three-way Democratic primary race for the U.S. Senate, with Public Advocate Mark Green trailing.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: First Lady Draws Cheers at Women's Conference in Belfast
description: Introduced by a 16-year-old student as ''a role model for young women around the world,'' Hillary Rodham Clinton told a cheering gathering of women in Belfast tonight that it was their ''courage and strength'' that had secured the new Northern Ireland peace settlement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, GEORGE
description: DEUTSCH-George. In his 90th year, on September 1. Founder Deutsch Wicker. Beloved husband & best friend of Miriam for 64 years. Loving father of Karyn & Denny Michaels & Roger (Teddi). Caring grandfather of Danny, Michael, Beth & Jennifer Frient. Great grandfather of Tyler & Amanda Frient. Service Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows today, 10:15 AM.

title: The First Rock Opera (No, Not 'Tommy')
description: With the lyric ''From number three there came the cry, 'S. F. Sorrow is born,'' the British band the Pretty Things entered the rock-and-roll history books in 1968 with what is generally acknowledged as the first rock opera. But for a work of such importance -- among the most interesting and ambitious albums of the 60's -- ''S. F. Sorrow'' has remained unjustly obscure.

title: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; A Well-Paced Music Tutorial
description: GUITAR 101/THE FENDER METHOD(G-Vox Interactive Music; $39.99; Macintosh and Windows 95.)

title: Classes, Exhibitions And Tours
description: Into Their Homes

title: The Firewall: Doubts About a Tactic to Contain Chaos
description: Inside the Treasury Department, some of the strategists desperately seeking to contain spreading outbreaks of financial chaos once called their approach the ''firewall strategy.''

title: For 3 Drug Makers, F.D.A. Makes Their Day
description: Yesterday was a boon for investors in three makers of cancer drugs.

title: Finding Something Nice to Say About Microsoft's Operations
description: Richard McKenzie and William Shughart don't believe that there should be the Microsoft logo under the word ''monopoly'' in the dictionary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENBERG, JACK (YANEK)
description: LEVENBERG-Jack (Yanek). On September 1, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Kate. Loving father of Lora Rogers (Joseph) and Eileen Lichtenstein (Allan). Cherished grandfather, great grandfather and uncle. Dear brother-inlaw. We celebrate a life devoted to family and friends. He was a wonderful man. Services Thursday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Slow but Still Working
description: To the Editor:

title: On-Line Delivery
description: To the Editor:

title: Python Modern
description: Inspired by a pair of vintage snakeskin candlesticks at an antiques show, the interior designers Peter Salgado and Kip Saucier of SSD created the Ramon table lamp, which has a paper shade and a base covered in natural python.

title: The Unnatural Art of the Pool
description: THE reverence most people feel for the sight and sound of water in the garden doesn't necessarily extend to the swimming pool. What seems the essence of serenity in the contemplative setting of the Alhambra, or in Hockney's aquamarine acrylics, turns garish when suburbia's acrylic-tinted pools are viewed from the air.

title: A House Suitable for Barbie, Ken and Daughter
description: Call it a case study for a modern Hudson River country home -- in Manhattan. Liberty House, designed by Dennis Wedlick, is based on preferences from the readers of Country Home magazine. The house has no closets -- ''No reader mentioned them,'' Mr. Wedlick said -- no kitchen per se and no living room. The 2,500-square-foot experimental house was built in eight sections in Pennsylvania, then trucked to the yacht harbor at the World Financial Center. The grand hallway is 22 feet high but only 11 feet 9 inches wide. ''Well, 13 feet 9 inches was the factory capacity,'' Mr. Wedlick said. There are ballet barres for hanging clothes, with lots of storage -- ''I'm a basket person,'' said Mary Emmerling, the creative director of Country Home, who decorated the house and nicotine-stained the hall. Salvage supplied huge doors, a mantel and a wooden spiral stair for an imaginary teen-age daughter's two-story ''apartment.'' ''We weren't concerned with resale,'' Mr. Wedlick said. ''Resale is the death of architecture.'' Extras include a gift-wrapping area and a satellite dish. The house is open Saturday through Oct. 8; hours from the World Financial Plaza events line, (212) 945-0505; admission, $5. LINDA LEE

title: Gastineau Arrested
description: Mark Gastineau, the 41-year-old former Jets defensive lineman, was arrested yesterday and charged with assault involving an incident on Aug. 25 with a woman the police say is his girlfriend, the police said.

title: Total Posts Flat Profit For First Half of 1998
description: Total S.A., the French energy company, said yesterday that its first-half net profit was virtually unchanged from the period a year earlier as increased oil production, a stronger dollar and better refining margins helped it offset lower prices for crude oil. Total said its first-half net income eased to 3.97 billion French francs, or $675 million, from 3.98 billion francs a year earlier. Sales fell by 14 percent, to 82.3 billion francs, or $14 billion.

title: Criminals Have Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: RENT-WAY IN $231 MILLION DEAL FOR HOME CHOICE HOLDINGS
description: Rent-Way Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Home Choice Holdings Inc. for $13.60 a share in stock, a total of $231 million, plus about $70 million in debt, making Rent-Way the second-largest company in the United States rent-to-own market. Rent-Way, with revenue of $88 million in 1997, will exchange 0.588 share for each Home Choice share. Rent-Way, based in Erie, Pa., is expanding through acquisitions, after buying Champion Rentals Inc. in January. Its shares fell 62.5 cents, to $22.50, while Home Choice dropped $1.3125 a share, to $11.375. Rent-Way and Home Choice, which is based in Mesquite, Tex., rent consumer merchandise like major appliances weekly and monthly.

title: When the Novelists Become the Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Question Suspect About Rapes and Slaying
description: A man detectives described as a homeless drifter was being questioned last night in connection with a series of rapes and a slaying in the Bronx earlier this year, the police said. The police were questioning John Price, 38, about the April 22 death of Pam Watson, 33, who was pregnant when she was strangled at the Twin Parks West Houses in Tremont, said Detective Robert Samuel, a police spokesman.

title: CLINTON DEFENDS HIS TV ADMISSION ON LEWINSKY CASE
description: Directly questioned for the first time in public about the Monica Lewinsky matter since his televised admission two weeks ago, President Clinton said at a Kremlin news conference today that he believed he had expressed ''profound regret'' to those who had been hurt by his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky.

title: Hedge Funds Registering Huge Losses
description: The roiling of global markets continues to claim its victims among the most sophisticated money managers, the people who manage hedge funds. While some of these managers escaped and even profited from the damage done by falling stock markets and the rush to safer investments, many are telling their investors that their funds have racked up huge losses.

title: BASEBALL -- It's Sosa's Day, but Night Belongs to McGwire; Crunch Times: MCGwire Smacks Nos. 58 and 59
description: Soaring to heights that only Babe Ruth and Roger Maris have reached, Mark McGwire, this baseball era's most awesome slugger, hit two more home runs last night, Nos. 58 and 59, and catapulted himself only two swings away from Maris's 37-year-old record of 61.

title: With Barely a Whimper, Yanks Fail to Win 100th
description: The Yankees talked casually about winning their 100th game of the regular season because they have long expected to do it and because they have almost a month to get the one victory necessary to reach the lofty total. Like every other milestone this relaxed team has conquered, the Yankees treated the pursuit in a businesslike fashion. There is no need to get too excited, they stressed.

title: Anti-Gay Bias Is Cited In Latest Village Beating
description: In the third such attack in Greenwich Village this week, a man was beaten early yesterday by a group of men because they thought he was gay, the police said.

title: The Little Can That Could
description: IT'S the garbage can that got glamour. Since its introduction two years ago, the Umbra company's Garbo can, in black, white and translucent colors, has moved from a best seller at such humble retailers as Linens and Things and Bed, Bath and Beyond to become a celebrity of the design world. It has been celebrated in the Italian design press from Domus to Interni, the Milan-based magazine on whose current cover it appears, and this fall it will get its own ads in Vogue.

title: Mets Offer Reynoso Support In a Much-Needed Victory
description: The last thing the Mets could have afforded was a second consecutive loss here tonight. Not after the Cubs and Giants had both won earlier today. And not with a four-game extended weekend series coming up against the first-place Braves, against whom the Mets are 0-5 this season.

title: Shop Classes for All
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Prices Mostly Dip as Financial Turmoil Eases
description: Prices of most Treasury securities slipped slightly yesterday, as stock markets worldwide stabilized and the dollar weakened in currency trading, lessening the flight into Government securities that has been an almost daily occurrence lately.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS TUMBLES. Natural gas prices fell 7.5 percent after Hurricane Earl veered away from rigs off Texas and Louisiana, easing supply worries. October natural gas fell 13.4 cents, to $1.652 for 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Corrections
description: A headline and a picture caption yesterday about ''Felicity,'' a new series on the WB Television Network that is set at the fictional University of New York, characterized the series incorrectly. It is a drama, not a situation comedy.

title: Hong Kong Restricts Short Sales of Some Stocks
description: The Hong Kong government bolstered the stock market again today by suspending short-selling of shares in a number of companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, MENDEL
description: BERKOWITZ-Mendel. The Board of Directors, Officers and employees of PolyVision Corporation mourn the passing of Mr. Mendel Berkowitz, beloved father of our Board member, Mr. Ivan Berkowitz. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Berkowitz family. Steven S. Elbaum Chairman Joseph Menniti Chief Executive Officer

title: Kentucky Makes Sure Calumet's Trophies Will Be Staying
description: A grass-roots campaign in Kentucky to save Calumet Farm's racing trophies from being dispersed to help pay the farm's debt was declared a success today when no other bidders surfaced to meet the home-state bid of $2.7 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, DENA
description: LEVITT-Dena. Beloved mother of Dan Levitt, died at Mount Sinai Hospital on September 1. She was 82. Dena was the widow of the playwright Saul Levitt and had a distinguished career as a documentary film editor. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 St, NYC 10019-3984.

title: Victims' Kin Have Bittersweet Memories
description: In the fall of 1996, Catherine A. Marsh, a longtime prostitute and drug addict, repeatedly begged her mother to let her come home.

title: Where Mies Could Towel Off
description: ''WE wanted clean, simple, serene,'' the owner said. ''We wanted to feel the air, the wind.''

title: U.S. Notes Gaps in Data About Drug Plant but Defends Attack; Sudan Envoy Is Angry
description: When the United States launched cruise missiles against a factory in the Sudan on Aug. 20, it was unaware that the plant made medicines, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today.

title: Rongcheng Journal; As Floods Rage, Bitter Choices Over What to Save
description: Xiao Renbai, director of this beleaguered town along the overflowing Yangtze River, stood before an encampment of blue tents inhabited by 800 sorry-looking people who weeks before were told to flee for their lives.

title: Hard Rock, With Cellos And Corsets
description: In a world of rock bands, Rasputina is unique for its combination of lineup -- three female cellists and a male drummer -- and costumes. At Shine on Tuesday night, the three women wore corsets; two had elaborate lacy dresses, while the third proudly displayed tattoos and a pierced lip.

title: Desperately Seeking Susan OR Suzie NOT Sushi
description: IF the World Wide Web ever adopted a theme song, it could do worse than picking ''I Still Haven't Found What I'm Looking For.'' Searching the Web is the most popular on-line activity -- and often the most frustrating. In June, more than half of the top 10 most-visited domains were Web search sites, according to an Internet metering service, Media Metrix. But how many of the people visiting those sites found what they were looking for right away?

title: Campaign Inquiry Wouldn't Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Connecticut Allows Telephone Merger
description: As striking phone workers picketed outside, state regulators in New Britain, Conn., gave final approval yesterday to a merger between the Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation of New Haven, the independently owned local phone company, and SBC Communications, the telecommunications giant based in San Antonio.

title: Name Your Cyberpoison, Whether Worm or Virus
description: Q. Do a computer virus and a computer worm differ?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RAALTE, RUTH
description: VAN RAALTE-Ruth. On September 1, 1998. Beloved wife of Tom for 52 years. Sister of Harold and Jay Eliasberg. Loving mother of Tom (Zealie) Jr, Peter and Peggy. Mother-in-law of Susan and Henia. Devoted grandmother of Wendy, Andrew, Pierson, Ferris, Jessica, Zoe and Ethan. Step grandmother of Molly and Mischa. Memorial service at Ethical Culture Society, 7 Saxon Wood Road, White Plains, NY Sunday, September 13, at 2PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Phelps Hospice, 701 North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, New York 10591.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STOLBOF, BERNARD
description: STOLBOF-Bernard. Of Syosset, NY. Passed away on September 2, 1998, at age 70. He is survived by his wife Betty. Children Paul, Edward, Jesse and Daniel and four grandchildren. Retired from the House of Seagram where he worked for 35 years. He had a history of Parkinson Disease and died of pneumonia. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Avenue, Miami, Florida 33136.

title: Russia's Retreat From the West
description: The only certainty in Russia's present crisis is that it marks the end of an era -- the Yeltsin years for sure and quite probably the end of the theory, widely trumpeted just a decade ago, that market democracy has triumphed as a universal ideal.

title: Intern's Return Was Weighed, Lawyers Say
description: President Clinton told the grand jury investigating his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky that he was troubled by her transfer out of the White House and discussed bringing her back in the summer of last year, lawyers familiar with his testimony said.

title: An Island, Entire of Itself
description: Laura Rosen has a day job as an archivist with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. On her own time, she has carted her grandfather's Rolleiflex and other cameras for three years to spots like the Battery, Fort Tryon Park (above) and Riverside South to make a 160-page book, ''Manhattan Shores: An Expedition Around the Island's Edge'' (Thames and Hudson, $35). The black-and-white images capture water, fishing, bridges and derelict boats. In stores this month. LINDA LEE

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Hints at Offer To Russia of Financial Aid

title: Accounts
description: * Nature's Best Inc., Hauppauge, N.Y., to McCaffery Ratner Gottlieb & Lane, New York, to handle advertising for the marketer of nutritional supplements, which had been handled by Berenter Greenhouse & Webster, New York. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: CANADIAN DOLLAR RISES. Canada's currency edged higher for a second day, as expectations grew that the fall in commodity prices may have hit a low point. The Canadian dollar rose to 64.89 United States cents from 64.86.

title: Going Back in Time With Kitchen Clocks
description: TIMEPIECES are an essential part of the kitchen, whether for the one who is rushing out to punch a clock or the one who is watching the clock while punching bread dough. Despite the array of digital gadgets, the majority of kitchen clocks this fall are defiantly retro. From a 1920's reproduction French clock to a 50's-style square inspired by a classic General Electric model, they are analog; that is to say, they have hands. While new clocks run on batteries, you will know an original by its electrical cord.

title: When the Novelists Become the Characters
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Dismisses Adviser's 1990 Guilty Plea
description: A New York judge has dismissed the 1990 guilty plea of Donald C. Carter, an adviser in high-profile corporate takeovers in the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPHAM, GRACE W.C.
description: LAPHAM-Grace W.C. Passed away Wednesday, September 2. She is survived by her three children, Thomas, Stephen, and Anne Codey, & by eight grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at Manhasset Meeting House on Saturday, September 5th at 10 AM. Family requests donation be made to the Camp Fund of the Family Service Association in lieu of flowers.

title: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; Good Program for Beginners, Though Short on Notation
description: EMEDIA GUITAR METHODVolumes 1 and 2(eMedia Corporation; $59.95; Macintosh and Windows 3.1 and 95.)

title: Chang Is Unseeded, but Optimistic
description: In 1996, Michael Chang played in the final of the United States Open in Louis Armstrong Stadium. That stadium, now sliced nearly in half and overshadowed by one named for Arthur Ashe, is no longer the center of attention at this tournament.

title: Drugs to Fight Breast Cancer Near Approval
description: An advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration voted unanimously yesterday to recommend approval of the drug tamoxifen to reduce women's risk of developing breast cancer.

title: League of Conservation Voters to Endorse Pataki
description: The New York League of Conservation Voters, a political action group that focuses on environmental issues, has decided to back Gov. George E. Pataki in his re-election bid this fall, the organization's leader said yesterday.

title: At Third-World Meeting, Hopes for Congo Peace Rise and Fall
description: Hopes for a cease-fire in Congo were quickly raised and as quickly dashed here today.

title: Port Authority Drops Secret Plan for Police Patronage
description: Facing fierce criticism that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is transforming its police force into a patronage mill, the agency's chairman said yesterday that he would scuttle a secret plan to allow commissioners to influence hiring in the Port Authority Police Department.

title: Cary Middlecoff, 77, Dentist Who Became Top Pro Golfer
description: Dr. Cary Middlecoff, who abandoned dentistry to play professional golf and won more prize money than Ben Hogan, Sam Snead or anyone else in the storied 1950's era, died Tuesday at the Allen Morgan Health Center in Memphis. He was 77.

title: Junior Jones Likes His Chances
description: Junior Jones does not have a problem traveling to Tijuana, Mexico, to meet Erik Morales in his hometown for his World Boxing Council superbantamweight title on Sept. 12.

title: For Sale at Last in China: Dream Homes, but No Sink
description: BUYING a home is a relatively new phenomenon in China, and so is serious home furnishing. Even in Shanghai, the nation's most affluent and modern-minded city, the decor in most apartments still ranges from spartan to dowdy to just plain tasteless.

title: Styles of the Ming Dynasty
description: Those who think the 20th century invented life style should take themselves back 400 years to the Ming Dynasty, when Chinese scholar-esthetes led lives as connoisseurs and collectors in rooms so studiously enhanced by the subtleties of taste that a present-day stylist would have wept with failure. Christie's, in conjunction with a Chinese furniture and fine-art auction on Sept. 16 (picture from catalogue above), is sponsoring a seminar, ''From Elegant Mansions: Life Style of the Ming Gentleman,'' on Sept. 12 and 13. It will investigate the integration of art, architecture and interior and garden design that produced the refinement of classical Chinese houses. Speakers will include Soren Edgren of the Chinese Rare Book Project at Princeton University and Philip Hu of the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University. There will also be field trips. The fee is $495; information: (212) 702-1390. WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: Abbie Hoffman and Hey, His Turbulent Times
description: STEAL THIS DREAM

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Memoir of a Life Serving the Law

title: So Many Lewinsky Questions and So Little Opportunity
description: The two reporters who questioned President Clinton on the Lewinsky matter today at the Kremlin both said they had raised the matter because they were frustrated by the lack of opportunity to question Mr. Clinton about it since his speech to the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN DINA, ALFRED SR.
description: VAN DINA-Alfred Sr. Employee of The New York Times from 1967 to 1981. Beloved husband of the late Mary, devoted father of Alfred Jr., Ronald, Gary and Rosemary Davison. Loving grandfather of nine, cherished great grandfather of one. Visitation Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Franklin Funeral Home, 42 New Hyde Park Rd., Franklin Square. Funeral mass Friday, 10:30 AM at St. Catherine of Sienna RC Church. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Does the Internet Bring Us Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Inquiry Wouldn't Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Tribunal, in First Such Trial Verdict, Convicts Rwandan Ex-Mayor of Genocide
description: A United Nations tribunal investigating mass killings in Rwanda today handed down the first guilty verdict by an international court for the crime of genocide, and for the first time defined rape as genocidal.

title: OP-ART; DisNY City: The Eisner Empire Takes Manhattan
A Former General Fights for Seattle's Schools and for His Life
description: Seattle made an unusual choice three years ago when it tapped John Henry Stanford as superintendent of public schools. He had no background in school administration, but the former Army general and director of logistics in the Persian Gulf war did bring a Patton-style intensity to his crusade to improve public education here.

title: Procter & Gamble to Revamp Products
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the world's No. 2 maker of consumer goods, said today that it would reorganize along product lines, rather than geographic regions, to improve sales and speed the introduction of new products.

title: Market Frailty Isn't Mexican, Official Says
description: Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria runs an economy that is growing vigorously, with most exports surging and thousands of new jobs opening every day. But ask him whether the Mexican stock market will rise or plunge tomorrow and he shakes his head in bewilderment.

title: HORSESHOE GAMING TO ACQUIRE EMPRESS FOR $600 MILLION
description: Horseshoe Gaming L.L.C. has agreed to acquire Empress Entertainment Inc., a closely held operator of riverboat casinos in Indiana and Illinois, for about $600 million, including assumed debt. The agreement will help Horseshoe in its efforts to expand its gaming operations to Midwestern states. Horseshoe, based in Las Vegas, Nev., now has gambling operations in Louisiana and Tunica, Miss. It had six-month revenue of $225.4 million as of June 30. Empress, based in Joliet, Ill., owns two riverboat casinos. The acquisition, combined with Horseshoe's casinos, will give Horseshoe estimated annual revenue of more than $800 million this year.

title: Strange Things Happening? Blame Your Biorhythms
description: YOU oversleep and walk in late and un-ironed for your Big Meeting, plus you're limping from tripping over the curb on the way in. Mama said there'd be days like this, and now she can call up a Web-based biorhythm calculator on her laptop and warn you ahead of time -- all in good fun, of course.

title: SIEBE OF BRITAIN TO SELL AMERICAN UNIT FOR $229 MILLION
description: The British engineering group Siebe P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its industrial-safety products business to Norcross Safety Products L.L.C. for $:136.9 million (about $229 million). The business, North Safety Products, based in Cranston, R.I., had annual sales of $:111.3 million and operating profit of $:16.5 million, as of April 4. Siebe recently put the business up for sale along with several other noncore companies in its industrial-equipment division as part of a strategic plan to concentrate on controls and automation. Norcross, based in Rock Island, Ill., manufactures protective footwear for firefighters and industrial users.

title: MARKEL OFFERS $121 MILLION FOR AN INSURANCE PROVIDER
description: The Markel Corporation has offered $18 a share, a total of about $121 million, for Gryphon Holdings Inc., a provider of commercial property and casualty insurance. Markel, a company in Glen Allen, Va., that writes professional liability insurance, said it would pay $15.50 in cash and $2.50 in notes for the shares of Gryphon it does not already own. The stock of the New York-based Gryphon, which provides liability insurance for architects and engineers, rose $2.75, to $14.25. Markel's stock soared $8.4375 each, to $151.9375. The offer was made in a letter included in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday. Markel said an all-cash offer for Gryphon was also possible.

title: Metro Business; Brokerage Faces Lawsuit
description: A Wall Street brokerage firm was accused of sexual harassment and discrimination against female employees in a lawsuit filed yesterday by the New York State Attorney General's office.

title: Wall St. Jitters and The Deal
description: ABOUT to buy a place to live, and the stock market's roller coaster ride is giving you indigestion? (And a smaller nest egg?) Or perhaps you're the victim of mid-deal panic? To close or not to close, that is the question.

title: Possible Censure of President Is Roiling the Democrats in Congress
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, a Democrat, said today that he had been contemplating calling for the censure of President Clinton. But, he said, Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, called him on Monday and implored him to hold off making any comment at least until the President had returned from his trip to Russia and Ireland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAIN, ARTHUR B.
description: KAIN-Arthur B. Age 84, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Lynbrook, NY. Beloved husband of Esther for 60 years. Brother of Norman, devoted father of Stephen, Karen and Steven Bachmann, Janet and Edward Greenberg, adored grandfather of Seth Kain, Jill Karp, Jennifer Sweetwood, Michael Bachmann, Amy Bachmann, and Jonathan Greenberg. Loving greatgrandfather of Alexander Kain. He was a graduate of NYU, Class of 1935, a dedicated and respected CPA, past-president of Congregation Beth David, Lynbrook, NY, a kind and gentle man, he will be missed by all. Services Thursday, 12:00 noon at Gutterman's, 175 North Longbeach Road, Rockville Centre, New York. In lieu of flowers, family requests contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Giants-Redskins Rivalry Vibrant After 66 Years
description: Giants safety Percy Ellsworth today offered this summary of the appeal and importance of Sunday's season-opening game with the Washington Redskins:

title: Wielding a Voice Full of Character And Ripe With Love
description: The singer Freddy Cole stands at a crossroads between cabaret, jazz and blues, and that flexibility does him favors: as the brother of Nat (King) Cole, with a voice whose phrasing recalls the famous singer, he does well to escape from further categorization. Completely aside from that, as a deep-voiced singer of jazz love songs he embodies a vanishing esthetic: he's one of the few male jazz singers these days who is still at the height of his powers and can be taken seriously.

title: Real Help for Drivers In Remaining Awake
description: Sleepy drivers can cruise along the highway with the window wide open, pinching or slapping themselves, chewing gum or tuning the radio to a call-in host whose politics they detest, but none of that will keep them awake, the A.A.A. Foundation for Traffic Safety and a prominent sleep researcher said today.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK; Coaxing a Staten Island Walden Back to Idyllic Splendor
description: THE six teen-agers who worked on the new Eib's Pond Community Park on Staten Island this summer did not spend their childhoods catching tadpoles. Even though they live nearby, few had ventured very far into the 17 wetland acres, which were fenced with metal guard rails and filled with the rusted hulks of more than 20 abandoned cars. The park borders some of Staten Island's highest-density and lowest-income housing, and is within walking distance for thousands in the Clifton area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, YAFFA
description: GORDON-Yaffa. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Yaffa Gordon, beloved wife of Isidore and mother of Nahum, David and Daniel, distinguished supporters of NJOP for almost a decade. Sincere condolences to the family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Aug. 21 about Jeanine Tesori's music for the Lincoln Center Theater's recent production of ''Twelfth Night'' referred incorrectly to the Playwrights Horizons' staging of Ms. Tesori's 1997 musical ''Violet.'' It was a fully mounted production, not a workshop.

title: The Secret Power in Big Rap; Bryan Turner Makes Rap Records but Escapes the Criticism
description: When the pioneering gangsta rap group N.W.A was looking for its first record deal, it found a distributor in Priority Records, which released an album so obscene it prompted a letter of complaint from the F.B.I. When Ice-T left Warner Brothers Records after police groups and the company's shareholders objected to his song ''Cop Killer,'' he found a new home at Priority. When Suge Knight, the imprisoned head of Death Row Records, who is known for his pugnacious business tactics, was looking for his first deal, Priority gave it to him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRURY, ALLEN
description: DRURY-Allen. September 2, 1918September 2, 1998. Reporter, author, Pulitzer Prize winner, beloved member of our family. The world owes you so much. We miss you. Anne and Buzz, Kenneth, Kevin and Valerie and Alethea, Anson, and Daya. Funeral services Friday, September 4 Morrison's Funeral Chapel, Vintage Lane, St. Helena, Calif. in the Napa Valley. Donations in lieu of flowers. The charity will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, GABE
description: LEVENTHAL-Gabe. Loving husband of 58 years of Muriel. Beloved father of Stuart and Bruce. Proud grandfather of Andrew, Caroline, Alexander, Nicole, and Scott. Devoted brother to Harold. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. Family graveside service Thursday, September 3, 1PM, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Girl in Custody Battle Is Reported to Be Dead
description: A 10-year-old Dover girl who was the subject of an international custody battle died of malnutrition in Nigeria last fall after her father returned to the United States without her and her sister, who is still missing, the State Department said yesterday.

title: Denials and Delays on H.M.O. Claims Said to Hurt Doctors
description: A group of doctors and consumer advocates said today that the company that processes claims of more than half the state's 2.3 million health maintenance organization subscribers has endangered the solvency of doctors and hospitals by denying claims and delaying payments.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing Russia's creditors misstated the percentage of debt owed to international capital markets. It is 25 percent, not 15.

title: California Wildfire Leaves Area in Ruin
description: A wildfire started by lightning and driven by 40 mile-an-hour winds left little but blackened barren hills and the pungent smell of smoke after burning 34 homes and 6,000 acres near here on Monday and Tuesday.

title: In Other Sections
description: MAIN STREET IS CALM -- Despite this week's market jitters, there are few signs of concern in one Iowa town. Page A18.

title: Welfare Overhaul Initiatives Focus on Fathers
description: They are young, poor and hard beyond their years, with resumes that often list jails, not jobs. Their earnings have spent decades in decline, and so has their likelihood to marry. Yet there is a growing sense that the nation's ambitious welfare overhaul cannot succeed without them.

title: INSIDE
description: Market Takes a Breath

title: Internet Child Pornography Operation Is Raided in U.S. and Abroad
description: The police in 22 states and a dozen countries late Tuesday and early today swept down on scores of homes belonging to young and old, professional people and factory workers, all suspected of belonging to a huge Internet club trafficking in child pornography.

title: Roiled Market Takes a Breath As Dow Slips
description: After two days of a frenzied selloff and a partial recovery, stock prices were broadly mixed yesterday in comparatively sluggish trading. But few analysts were prepared to predict that the reverberations from the market's recent steep slide had ended.

title: For Korda, It's Game, Match, Open, and Out
description: There will be no more cartoonish scissors kicks, no reprisal of last year's epic United States Open dethroning of top-ranked Pete Sampras, no encores to the Grand Slam breakthrough he made last winter when he won the Australian Open at the ripe old age of 29.

title: In Gubernatorial Debate, Democrats Sound Like Allies
description: With remarkable unanimity, the Democratic candidates for governor attacked Gov. George E. Pataki on the state budget, job growth, education and campaign finance in a debate here tonight, treating one another more like chums than like adversaries.

title: Merrill Accord Gets Approval
description: A United States court gave final approval today to a settlement between Merrill Lynch & Company and about 2,800 female workers, paving the way for Merrill brokerage employees to take discrimination disputes to court.

title: Glen Cove Rushes to Save Ship It Agreed to Adopt
description: Volunteers rushed today to the rescue of the Regina Maris, a 90-year-old three-masted barkentine that became stuck in the mud at low tide and later filled with water, only a few boat lengths away from her new home here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTEI, ARIEL RENE, M.D.
description: MATTEI-Ariel Rene, M.D. Of Bronx, N.Y., on August 31, 1998. Beloved husband of Maria (nee Lopez de Jesus). Dear brother of Jose Antonio. Family will receive friends Friday 2-5, 7-9PM at John J. Fox & Sons Inc. 203 East 201 St., Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Ann Church, Saturday 9:30 AM. Interment: Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Man Arrested in Shooting Is Linked to Robberies
description: The fugitive arrested Tuesday after a shootout at a rest stop on the New Jersey Turnpike had gone there to rob an armored car and may be linked to six unsolved bank robberies in the Camden area, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Does the Internet Bring Us Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: Does the Internet Bring Us Down?
description: To the Editor:

title: Play That Stirred Outcry Prepares for Its Opening
description: About three months have passed since the Manhattan Theater Club decided not to produce ''Corpus Christi'' by Terrence McNally and then reversed itself after an outcry from artists and civil liberties organizations.

title: A Misguided Missile
description: North Korea is backing itself into a dangerous corner by showing off its ability to make and market advanced weapons. Just two weeks after American intelligence agencies noticed construction work on an underground complex suitable for developing nuclear bombs, North Korea fired a missile into the Pacific beyond Japan. At that range, the missile could reach American bases in the Tokyo and Okinawa regions. North Korea's reckless actions threaten the security of its Asian neighbors and undercut Washington's hopes of providing economic and humanitarian aid as a means to coax the North out of its traditional isolation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRUN, JOSEPH W.
description: HEILBRUN-Joseph W. The officers and the entire membership of The Young Man's Philanthropic League mourn the loss of our esteemed member. For 35 years, Joey, supported our philanthropy with compassion and dignity. We extend our condolences to his family. Stephen Dietz, Chairman Stanley Banks, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARTABEDIAN, ARA
description: VARTABEDIAN-Ara. On September 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Adele (nee DiGiovanni). Loving father of Janice Ziegler and Peter. Cherished grandfather of three and great-grandfather of one. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd (corner of 193 St). Visiting hours Thursday, 2-5 & 7-10 PM. Funeral service Friday 1 P.M., Armenian Church of the Holy Martyrs. Interment, Cedar Grove Cemetery.

title: Northwest Lays Off 27,000, Increasing Pressure on Strike
description: Northwest Airlines laid off more than half of its 51,000 workers yesterday, spreading the economic disruption created by a five-day-old strike of its pilots.

title: Uninspired MetroStars Lose Way
description: The MetroStars did not look like a playoff-bound team fighting for second place in the Eastern Conference tonight, not remotely.

title: No More Paper Chasing For One Business School
description: Applicants to the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology had better know their way around the World Wide Web. If not, the admissions staff will not be admitting them. In fact, the staff won't even look over their applications.

title: Quick Action by U.S. Banks Limits Damage
description: Although the Chase Manhattan Corporation and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette joined the chorus of financial services companies announcing losses on their business in Russia yesterday, investors may soon be able to breathe more easily about the Russian impact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEL, JAMES EDWARD
description: FRIEL-James Edward, 75. Died August 28, 1998. A Naples, Florida resident since 1983, coming from West Babylon, N.Y. Mr. Friel was a W.W. II veteran & worked for the New York Times as a dispatcher for 30 plus years. He is survived by his loving wife of 55 years, Beverly E. Friel, children Carol (James) Leuschner, James E. Friel, Steven (Laurie) Friel, Gerard (Maria) Friel, Lori (Martin) Gensler. Grandchildren Loren, Kelly, L.J., Chris, Keri Jean, Adam, Erica, Tara, Jesse, Gillian, Tyler & Brendon. Sister, Gertrude Wise. A Memorial Mass will be held on Thursday, September 3, 1998 at 3 P.M., at St. Peter's in Naples, Florida. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1000, Chicago, Illinois 60611. Phone 800-272-3900.

title: Lord Rothermere, Press Giant, Is Dead at 73
description: Viscount Rothermere, one of the last of Britain's great press barons, who helped transform The Daily Mail from a listless money loser to a highly successful newspaper aimed at Britain's growing middle class, died on Tuesday at St. Thomas's Hospital in London. He was 73 and had a heart attack, according to Vyvyan Harmsworth, the director of corporate affairs for The Daily Mail and General Holdings Ltd.

title: Nonperforming Loans Surge 11.8% in Korea
description: Nonperforming loans at South Korean banks surged 11.8 percent between March and June, accounting for almost a tenth of all bank loans and underscoring the fragile state of the nation's financial industry. Loans classified as nonperforming -- those that do not pay interest for six months or more -- rose by 3.08 trillion won, to 29.08 trillion won, or $21.4 billion, at Korea First Bank and 21 other commercial banks, the Office of Bank Supervision said.

title: Our Towns; Death at Stops Of Last Resort For Gamblers
description: THE clerk at the Golden Island cash-for-gold shop peered at the front door from behind bullet-proof glass for a long minute before buzzing in the small, solitary woman waiting outside. It was 2:30 in the afternoon.

title: Indonesia Keeps Troops in Rioting Province
description: After two days of riots and looting in a northern province, the Indonesian military halted its withdrawal of troops from the region today in an effort to restore order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWELL, FRANK
description: LOWELL-Frank. On September 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Carol. Loving father of Susan Greenleaf and Edward Lowell. Loving grandfather of Arlene, Jennifer, James, Chad and Jaime. Loving brother of Harold and the late Arnold. A short memorial service will be held at Brunswick Memorial Home, 454 Cranbury Rd., E. Brunswick, NJ on Sat., September 5th at 1PM. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the Hospice Memorial Fund, 253 Witherspoon St., Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: Bill Clinton's Shaken Friends
description: In an elegant turn of phrase, Michael Wines of The Times's Moscow bureau described the Clinton-Yeltsin summit meeting as an event teetering ''on the slippery brink of self-parody.'' The same could be said of President Clinton's claim at a Moscow press conference that he had adequately apologized for the Monica Lewinsky affair. That view is not widely held among Democrats in Congress or even within the White House staff, and Mr. Clinton's comments are a troubling sign that he is still relying on outdated reflexes in dealing with the Lewinsky crisis.

title: Clinton Visit On Eve of Vote Irks Democrats
description: A Manhattan fund-raising appearance by President Clinton scheduled for the night before the New York Democratic primary is stirring resentment among candidates and their aides, who are worried that Mr. Clinton will steal attention from their contests and undercut their fund-raising efforts.

title: America The Upholstered
description: THE Burlington Northern Railroad cuts through downtown Tupelo, Miss., twice, at both ends, east and west, which is a matter of about 10 blocks. The trailing wail and the crossings' clanging are as ubiquitous as the bug songs of the cicadas and crickets that pulse like a fever from the shade trees and the flowering crape myrtle.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CITADEL COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Tempe, Ariz., a radio station operator, said its Citadel Broadcasting unit had agreed to buy nine radio stations from Citywide Communications Inc. for $34 million.

title: Days Before Harlem Youth Rally, Little Effort to Draw Big Turnout
description: With just two days to go before Khallid Abdul Muhammad's planned youth rally in Harlem, the event's organizers have done little to draw a strong turnout despite their contention that people will be flooding into Harlem from around the nation.

title: The Election Commission Goes Astray
description: With limited resources and no shortage of serious campaign finance abuses to pursue, the Federal Election Commission has made the peculiar decision to target Forbes magazine for publishing columns written by Steve Forbes while campaigning for President in 1996. In doing so, the commission has managed to trespass on the First Amendment and call into question the agency's sense of priorities.

title: Too Plugged In
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTEX HOME-BUILDING UNIT TO ACQUIRE CARLTON HOMES
description: The Centex Real Estate Corporation home-building unit of the Centex Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Carlton Homes Inc. for $50 million. It also will assume debt of $34 million. Centex Real Estate, based in Dallas, is one of the nation's largest home builders, with operations in 53 markets in 19 states. Carlton Homes, a subsidiary of Carlton Inc., of Manalapan, N.J., builds single-family homes in central New Jersey. Carlton Inc. had revenue of $30.7 million in the six months ended May 31.

title: Provident hopes using a different name for disability insurance will increase its sales.
description: IF in marketing parlance a used car is pre-owned, toilet paper is bathroom tissue and the elderly are mature, why not bolster the image of a provider of individual disability insurance by describing its primary product as income protection plans?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PETERMAN, TOMMY DAVID
description: PETERMAN-Tommy David. September 3, 1992. In fond loving memory. Dougla

title: Adding Up the Pluses and Minuses of Buying or Leasing a PC
description: THE rapid pace of evolution in the personal computer industry guarantees that today's cutting-edge personal computer will be dull in about two years. And at the rate computer prices are falling, better and faster computers will be available in two years -- or two months, for that matter -- at lower prices.

title: A New Small Book Publisher, In More Ways Than One
description: What do you get when you cross the printing press with the Palm Pilot? The answer is Peanut Press, a fledgling publisher with a novel idea for presenting the printed word.

title: SEARS TO SELL AUTO PARTS UNIT'S CREDIT CARD PORTFOLIOS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company agreed yesterday to seek a buyer for the credit card portfolios of the auto parts business it is selling to the Advance Stores Company. Advance Stores, based in Roanoke, Va., announced last month that it would buy Western Auto from Sears and fold the auto parts business into its own operations. Sears will receive $175 million in cash and a 40 percent stake in the combined company. At Advance Auto's request, Sears will attempt to sell the unit's Parts America and Western Auto credit card portfolios to a third-party buyer, according to a quarterly report by Advance Stores filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Parts America is a segment of the Western Auto business.

title: What Price Preservation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rural Life Has Room For Angst
description: Beneath the picture-postcard scenes of pastoral America, writers, at least since Sherwood Anderson and Edgar Lee Masters, have discerned a depressing reality: Things are not as they seem amid the foliage. Tomorrow night, a television documentary maker confirms that civilization's discontents do not spare an upstate New York community despite the beauties of a snowy winter and the childhood frolickings of summer.

title: Elizabeth Man Charged In Gang-Related Deaths
description: An Elizabeth man who prosecutors contended was the leader of the New Jersey branch of the Latin Kings was arrested yesterday and charged with ordering the killings of two gang members who were found strangled in a park.

title: From Panama, to Wear or to Hang
description: It's not all fish (as in the 1996 panel above) that the Kuna Indians of Panama portray on their appliques, known as molas. There are also astronauts, Santa Clauses and Ninja Turtles. Kuna women use molas for blouses. Tourists turn them into pillows, wall hangings and quilts.

title: Testimony, Not Talks, For N.B.A.
description: In their economic game of chicken, neither the National Basketball Association team owners nor the players will blink. One month before training camps are scheduled to open and two months before the start of the regular season, the bargaining table is empty.

title: New Title on the Cutlass Edge of Software
description: WHEN your dramatic palette is limited, pirates are a fairly good bet. As long as you stick to the accepted ''Treasure Island'' ideas about how they're supposed to dress (earrings, tattoos, beards, rough-hewn prosthetic limbs) act (crude, jolly, brutal) and speak (''Yarrrr!!!!''), you can swashbuckle your way through a story without too much trouble. By its very nature, swashbuckling is a theater of broad gestures, and sword-fighting spectacles on the high seas can succeed on the basis of sheer kinetic energy. It worked when silent films made the transition to sound -- directors didn't really know what they were doing with dialogue, but Errol Flynn and Basil Rathbone sure looked great dueling on the mast. And audiences loved it.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The situation is worse than in 1917.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the release of the movie ''Titanic'' on videotape misidentified a store that violated the release date. It was not a Blockbuster branch.

title: Extra TV Coverage Planned
description: With Mark McGwire hitting two more home runs last night, to reach 59, and with Sammy Sosa at 56, Fox Sports accelerated its plans to broadcast their potential record-tying or record-breaking games.

title: Volvo May Buy Stake In Mexican Bus Maker
description: Volvo A.B., the world's second-largest bus maker, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy a stake in Mexicana de Autobuses S.A., Mexico's biggest bus maker, with its British partner, Henlys Group P.L.C., giving it access to the North American market. Volvo said yearlong talks with Masa's owners have recently become more intense, indicating a purchase could be imminent.

title: Dow Chemical Acquisition
description: The Dow Chemical Company, the fifth-largest United States chemical company, agreed today to buy a European synthetic rubber business from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in an effort to expand its own profitable rubber operations. The companies declined to disclose terms of the purchase or the revenue of the business. Dow Chemical will gain plants in Berre, France, and in Pernis, the Netherlands.

title: Ballots Counted And Foley Is Captain
description: His teammates are convinced that Glenn Foley is not only their quarterback but their leader, too. Today they elected him the offensive captain.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, JACK V. M.D.
description: LISMAN-Jack V. M.D. Age 84. Died on August 30, 1998. Survived by his wife of 54 years Sylvia; children Richard and Lee Lisman, Jane and Robert J. Katz; sister Leona Rothstein; four grandchildren, Hilary, Bogert, Cyrena L. Fink and James and Emily Katz, and great-granddaughter Brigitte J. Fink. Distinguished staff member and past Chief of the Division of Opthalmic Plastic Surgery at Manhattan Eye and Ear Hospital. Private services were held Tuesday, September 1st, in Hastings-onHudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to NYU School of Medicine or The Orbital Disease Foundation (635 Park Avenue, New York City 10021).

title: Sinn Fein Says It Will Try to Halt Arms
description: A day after declaring its commitment to end violence in Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said today that it would cooperate in finding ways to disarm paramilitary groups.

title: Scotland and South Africa Lead for 2 Final World Titles
description: With Italy and Austria already in possession of the major world titles here for open teams and women's teams, attention today focused on the final stages of the open pairs and women's pairs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELWIG, EDWARD P.
description: HELWIG-Edward P. Age 95. On August 30, 1998. At home in Larchmont, N.Y. Columbia 1924. Realtor with Cross & Brown. Mourned by wife Christine, daughters Christa Patterson & Marymina Wallis, five grandchildren and eight greatgrandchildren. Donations to Columbia College or Country Dance and Song Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOESTLER, ANNE WEHTER
description: KOESTLER-Anne Wehter. On September 2, 1998. Retired NYC school teacher, devotee of the opera and an avid theater goer. Devoted mother of Anthony and his wife, Laura. Loving grandmother of Lawrence and Craig. Family will receive friends Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC. Interment to follow Saturday A.M. at Mt. Wollaston Cemetery, Quincy, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLATT, WILLIAM
description: BLATT-William, 88, of Coral Springs, Florida, passed away September 2, 1998. Predeceased by loving wife, Ruth. Beloved father of Gloria (Neil) Schwartz; grandfather of Lisa (Vincent) Gerardi and Karen (Douglas) Landsman; and great-grandfather of Rachel Nicole Gerardi. Graveside services will be held on Thursday, Sept. 3 in Florida. For information contact Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapels, Tamarac, FL 954-523-5801.

title: It's the Same Old Style For New Devils Coach?
description: The playing surface at National Hockey League rinks will have different dimensions this season in an attempt to increase the goal-scoring and attacking excitement that have dwindled in recent years. The Devils will have a new head coach who is replacing the defensive-oriented one who helped stifle opposing attacks by perfecting the neutral-zone trap.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUFER, ANNIE
description: LAUFER-Annie. Died August 29, 1998, after a long illness. Eva Laufer Slone The Slone Family

title: GIANT INDUSTRIES CANCELS APRIL AGREEMENT TO BUY HOLLY
description: The Holly Corporation, the oil refiner, said yesterday that Giant Industries had canceled its agreement to acquire it for $168 million because of antitrust concerns from the Federal Trade Commission. Shares of the Dallas-based Holly Corporation fell $5.625, or 27 percent, to $15.25. Giant Industries, an oil refiner and gasoline marketer, agreed in April to swap 1.33 of its shares and $2.90 in cash for each Holly share. The oil-refining companies were unable to resolve the F.T.C. concerns. Giant was also concerned about a lawsuit against Holly.

title: And Still No Government: Ruble Sags and So Do Spirits
description: Russia struggled through another day without a Government; the ruble's value fell again; people had less money than ever, and spirits and fortunes sagged.

title: Northern Telecom Aided by Stock Fall
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. was able to trim $1.7 billion off its purchase of Bay Networks Inc. because of the stock market slide, its chief executive, John A. Roth, said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Circuits last Thursday with an article about flat-panel computer monitors misidentified a company that has replaced most of its conventional monitors with the new ones. It is Barclays Capital in Manhattan, not Barclays Bank.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS AID WILL RISE IF RUSSIA PRESSES REFORMS
description: President Clinton signaled today that the West would step up its aid to Russia if the Kremlin pressed ahead with tough economic reforms.

title: Computer-Driven Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Five-Day Event Begins Today
description: The Killington (Vt.) Stage Race, the most important bicycle stage race in the East, begins its five-day run today with a 3.4-mile time-trial prologue. The men's field of almost 800 professionals and amateurs includes George Hincapie, the United States road-racing champion; Norm Alvis, a five-time national champion, and Mike Engleman, both in their final race before retirement.

title: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; A Lighthearted Approach, But a Solid Information Base
description: GUITROPOLIS: AN ADVENTURE IN LEARNING TO PLAY THE GUITAR(Alfred Publishing; $49.95; Macintosh and Windows 3.1 and 95.)

title: LIBRARY/CD-ROM GUITAR COURSES; Picking and Strumming Lessons via Disk
description: TO play the guitar -- and to play it well -- do you have to learn music theory? According to Sabina Skalar, a developer of the eMedia guitar-education course reviewed below, the answer is no.

title: 4 Subway Stations to Close During Event
description: Transit officials have decided to close down four subway stations near the site of the rally planned for Saturday in Harlem, saying they are concerned that the No. 2 line cannot handle the crowds that may show up.

title: Roman Music Center Rises From the Ruins
description: Four years after winning his first commission to design a building in Rome, Renzo Piano watches as three concert halls, known collectively as the Rome Auditorium, arise on the northern outskirts of the city, and hopes that they will be ready by 1999, the eve of the new millennium.

title: Another Day in Spotlight for Champions
description: By the calendar, at least, yesterday should have been a normal day in school for a group of 12-year-olds from Toms River, N.J.

title: Voluntary Buyout Offer Extended by Bell Atlantic
description: Only weeks after agreeing to a new contract with its unionized workers, the Bell Atlantic Corporation has extended a voluntary buyout offer to some of its management employees.

title: Cambodian Power Struggle Heats Up Ominously
description: Part two: the protests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, ELEANOR
description: O'NEILL-Eleanor. Suddenly, on Sept. 1. Devoted wife of John, President Emeritus of Local 3, RWDSU-UFCW. Loving mother of Barbara. Beloved sister of Bernice Stacey. Viewing Thurs. 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, 34 Hempstead Ave., Lynbrook, NY. Funeral 11 A.M. Fri. Sept. 4 at Our Lady of Lourdes, 65 Wright Avenue, Malverne, N.Y.

title: Plane From J.F.K. Crashes Off Canada
description: A Swissair plane carrying 227 passengers and crew crashed late last night south of Halifax, Nova Scotia, while on a flight from Kennedy International Airport to Switzerland, Federal officials said.

title: American-Style Pay Moves Abroad; Importance of Stock Options Expands in a Global Economy
description: Rose Gerrit Huy was a fast-rising executive at Daimler-Benz A.G., the German industrial giant that makes Mercedes-Benz automobiles. A Harvard-educated economist, she was in charge of developing cars like the SLK roadster before she was promoted to head the company's finance and telecommunications subsidiary.

title: Campaign Inquiry Wouldn't Be Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ESTHER
description: BERGER-Esther. Beloved wife of the late Isidor. Mother of Walter and Sheindy, and Danny and Ruth. Sister of Rae Haimm. Grandmother and great grandmother. Shiva until Tuesday A.M. September 8th at 832 Fiske St., Woodmere. NY.

title: Investigating the Swissair Flight 111 Tragedy
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Face of an Actor, Shadow of a Spy
description: As paranoid as it sounds, David McCallum is absolutely certain he is being shadowed by a Russian agent.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Tiger in a Sea of Pussy Cats; Trinidad and Tobago Bids Goodbye to Oil, Hello to Gas
description: The flights coming in from the United States are so jam-packed with oil and chemical company executives hungry for a piece of the action here that reservations are hard to come by. Almost weekly, it seems, the Government has some natural gas find or new factory project at the booming Point Lisas Industrial Estate to announce.

title: Classical Guide and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Old Westbury to Be Model for New SUNY Standards
description: The Old Westbury campus of the State University of New York has had a reputation in recent years for having some of the weakest students and lowest graduation rates among SUNY's 64 colleges.

title: Contraception, Three Days After
description: In an important advance for women's health, the Food and Drug Administration has approved the marketing and sale of emergency contraceptive pills that women can take within three days after sex to prevent pregnancy.

title: Chemical Company Violated State Laws
description: In a rare criminal case prosecuted under the New Jersey Air Pollution Control Act, a Hawthorne chemical company pleaded guilty yesterday to violating state environmental regulations.

title: On 'Hate March,' Giuliani Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SLATER, DAVID
description: SLATER-David, 9/4/93. Dad, your wisdom is everlasting, Your loving daughter, Jani

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; AT&T and TCI Deal Is Scaring The Arbitragers
description: The chaotic stock market has sparked fears that the merger plans of some companies will fall apart and has created additional risk for traders who specialize in takeover stocks.

title: The Enduring Attraction Of Egypt
description: The Egyptian Revival style has been rearing its sphinxlike head for more than 2,000 years. And, like the sphinx, it maintains a mysterious allure.

title: On 'Hate March,' Giuliani Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: MOTIVEPOWER TO BUY YOUNG RADIATOR FOR $70.5 MILLION
description: Motivepower Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Young Radiator Company, a closely held maker of heat transfer products, for $70.5 million. Motivepower, based in Pittsburgh, makes locomotives and power-related components. It had sales of $305.9 million last year. Young Radiator, based in Racine, Wis., had sales of about $50 million last year. It makes radiators, air coolers, and heat exchange systems for locomotives, construction and mining vehicles, military vehicles and other markets.

title: Chernomyrdin Rallies Forces for Another Try at Confirmation
description: As Russia's political crisis heads for its next showdown, on Friday, Acting Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin rallied new forces today to try to stop the Communist-led lower house of Parliament from rejecting his nomination a second time.

title: Tanui to Compete In Chicago Marathon
description: Moses Tanui of Kenya, the 1998 Boston Marathon champion, will run in the Chicago Marathon on Oct. 11, race organizers announced yesterday.

title: TEMPLE-INLAND AGREES TO ACQUIRE 2 FIBERBOARD PLANTS
description: Temple-Inland Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two medium-density fiberboard plants from MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. for about $102 million. Temple-Inland, based in Diboll, Tex., makes paper, corrugated paper and building products. It had revenue of $1.9 billion in the six months ended June 30. MacMillan Bloedel, based in Vancouver, British Columbia, is a forest products company. It is selling the plants, in Pembroke, Ontario, and Clarion, Pa., as part of a revamping announced in January.

title: For Piazza and the Mets, The Countdown Now Begins
description: If the Mets end up winning the National League wild card playoff spot this season, they will certainly have earned it. And Mike Piazza, the All-Star catcher who has seemed unhappy at times with the Mets, will have enjoyed it.

title: Accounts
description: * 100 Black Men of America Inc., Atlanta, to Muse Cordero Chen & Partners, Atlanta, as the first agency to handle advertising for the organization. Billings have not been determined.

title: A List of Those Killed on Swissair Flight 111
description: Following is a list of the passengers and crew members killed in the crash of Swissair Flight 111, released by the airline. Two of the 215 passengers were not identified. The victims' ages and hometowns were provided by The Associated Press.

title: Immigrant Fights Off His Deportation
description: A week after he was told that the United States Government would no longer try to deport him to his native country, Jesus Collado, a Dominican immigrant who has lived in New York for 24 years, is facing new challenges: learning to live again without fear and paying the bills that have accumulated during his 16-month ordeal.

title: Just Deserts for Kanell: $9.5 Million for 3 Years
description: It made the Giants uncomfortable that the starting quarterback Danny Kanell was making the league's minimum salary of $216,000. It made Kanell uncomfortable that even backup quarterbacks make five times as much.

title: Latin America Tells I.M.F. Economies Are Sound
description: Fearful of being swept up in the financial turmoil that has devastated Asia and Russia, officials from nine Latin American nations said today that their economies were basically sound and should not be penalized indiscriminately by panicky investors.

title: Portraits of Victims
description: EXPERT ON VACCINES -- Dr. Mary Lou Clements-Mann, 51, was a leading researcher on AIDS vaccines and was considered an expert on the assessment of vaccines.

title: Whitman Campaigns For G.O.P. In Six States
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman begins a weeklong, six-state campaign swing in Montana on Friday. Along the way, she will raise money for fellow Republicans and try to bolster the campaigns of more than a dozen candidates, as well as her own standing within the party.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL SOARS. Petroleum prices rose to the highest levels in seven weeks as Nigerian and Russian shipments were delayed, which could reduce world inventories. Crude oil for October delivery rose $1, to $14.67 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLSTERLI, ANDREW
description: BOLSTERLI-Andrew. We extend heartfelt and profound condolences to Marianne and John Slade, our cherished and devoted friends and Benefactors, on the tragic and untimely passing of their beloved grandson. May the warm memories of this special person bring solace to Marianne and John, parents Hans and Barbara Bolsterli, and the entire family, and may they all be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratkzer, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: Senate Panel Delays Vote on Overhaul of Banking Laws
description: At the last minute today, the Senate Banking Committee postponed consideration of a bill to overhaul the nation's banking laws as an unexpected dispute emerged over banking services for low-income consumers.

title: In Berkshires, A Baseball Tip For the Bronx
description: SUMMER vacation in the Berkshires included, by custom, a family pilgrimage to Wahconah Park in Pittsfield, Mass., where the minor-league Pittsfield Mets set up shop from June to September. In case you wonder about the name, they are the New York-Penn League offspring of the better-known Mets of Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: State Trying to Coax 2 Exchanges From New York
description: State officials are involved in talks intended to woo the nation's second- and third-largest stock exchanges out of New York City and into a new home in New Jersey, an economic development official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLEMENTS, MANN, DR.
description: CLEMENTS - MANN - Dr. Mary Lou & MANN, Dr. Jonathan. Members of the Board of Directors, Scientific Advisory Committee, and staff of the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative (IAVI) mourn the tragic deaths of Dr. Mary Lou Clements-Mann and Dr. Jonathan Mann, pioneers in the global fight to end AIDS. A member of our Scientific Advisory Committee (SAC), Mary Lou was a cherished IAVI colleague and distinguished vaccine researcher who pressed for accelerated HIV vaccine developoment. Jonathan was a world renowned AIDS leader and an unyielding defender of human rights and the right to health care for people around the world. Their deaths leave a large void in the ranks of those working to control this global pandemic. We extend our deepest condolences to their families, friends and colleagues. Lee Smith, Chair Seth Berkley, M.D., President Jaap Goudsmit, M.D., Ph.D, Chair (SAC)

title: U.S. BANCORP IN DEAL FOR HIGH-YIELD BOND SPECIALIST
description: U.S. Bancorp, based in Minneapolis, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Libra Investments Inc., a privately held investment bank that specializes in high-yield bonds, for an undisclosed sum. Libra, based in Los Angeles, provides corporate finance and advisory services, securities research, and sales and trading of high-yield securities. It has 65 employees in Los Angeles and New York and plans to open a 30-person office in Minneapolis later this year. U.S. Bancorp, which has been investing in Libra funds for two years, has $74 billion in assets and about 1,000 branches in 17 states. U.S. Bancorp bought the investment bank Piper Jaffray for $730 million earlier this year.

title: Senate Candidates Stress Aid for the Young, Old and Ill
description: In a speech that her aides billed as a major policy address, Geraldine A. Ferraro said last night that government should help relieve some of the financial burden borne by families of the chronically ill, and she called for a comprehensive Federal regulation of the long-term-care industry.

title: Jeter's Season Not Wasted On Youth
description: Whenever Derek Jeter's name is announced, whenever he gets another pivotal hit or whenever he makes another slick fielding play, the reaction is much different than it is for other Yankees. For others at Yankee Stadium, there are roars. But for Jeter, there are squeals. They escalate as if Jeter were a singer with the Backstreet Boys.

title: Sports of The Times: A Sport Is Reborn -- The Home Run, America's Signature Feat, Invigorates Baseball; September's Aura Restored to Fans
description: MARK McGWIRE goes for No. 60 tonight in St. Louis. Goes for No. 61. Goes for No. 62. They are coming in bunches for the big boy. He's got his stroke down.

title: WEEKEND EXCURSION; At Monticello, Where Jeffersonian Genius Is Held Self-Evident
description: Nichole Wilder was arguing with her sister Samantha.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day

title: Minnesota Governor Asks Clinton to Halt Northwest Pilots' Strike
description: Abandoning his neutral stance in the pilots' strike against Northwest Airlines, Gov. Arne Carlson of Minnesota called on President Clinton yesterday to order the pilots back to work, but the White House stood firm against the idea.

title: With 'Titanic,' A Titanic Guide
description: ''Titanic,'' which was released on Tuesday, swamps all else on video this week.

title: The Sounds of Music: Whoosh, Buzz, Click . . .
description: Early in ''Modulations,'' a sprawling, informative documentary survey of electronic music, one of dozens of talking heads compares its invention to the splitting of the atom. The cutting up and reassembling of sound, he suggests, is the sonic equivalent of rearranging matter. Another pundit goes further by declaring that all sound modified by an electronic device, be it a microphone, a radio or a phonograph, is in fact electronic music.

title: A District's School Year Begins With a Strike
description: Just three and a half hours before the first day of school yesterday, teachers went on strike in the largest district in Monmouth County, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMITTO, ELIZABETH
description: COMITTO-Elizabeth. Of Bronxville, NY. On September 3, 1998. Wife of the late Grenardo. Beloved mother of Sandra DelPriore, Jaqueline Proios and G. Charles Comitto. Grandmother of four, great-grandmother of three. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville. Between the hours of 2-4 and 79PM Friday. Service at the funeral home, on Saturday, September 5 at 11 A.M. Interment in Warwick Cemetery, Warwick, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions to Brandywine Nursing Home.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It used to be when you went to eat in a hotel, you knew exactly what to expect: safe food in a bland environment. Almost every hotel in America served dishes to make the man from Kansas City feel as comfortable as the woman from Santa Fe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, JONATHAN AND MARY LOU CLEMENTS.
description: MANN-Jonathan and Mary Lou Clements. The public health community has been devastated by the loss of Drs. Jonathan Mann and Mary Lou Clements. They were extraordinary people who made untold contributions to people throughout the world in their work on AIDS, vaccine development and human rights. Their loss is an enormous tragedy and we will miss them greatly. The Association of Schools of Public Health and the deans and faculties of all US Schools of Public Health send heartfelt condolences to their families and their colleagues at Harvard, Hopkins and Allegheny Schools of Public Health. Allan Rosenfield, MD President ASPH Dean, Mailman School of Public Health Columbia University Michael Gemmell, Executive Director, ASPH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLASS, ANNETTE
description: GLASS-Annette. On September 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Linda Barnes and Eileen Avagliano. Cherished grandmother of Jacqueline Douglas, Jennifer Reeves, John V. Barnes III, Dana Blount and Mark Avagliano, and greatgrandmother of Lauren and Jack Reeves. Service Friday, 12:30PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Day Care in Court? Jury System Needs Refining; A Creaky Exemption
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, EDWARD J.
description: KAUFMAN-Edward J. To my best friend and a man that was better than a father to me. To all your family, I wish peace and love. Ira and Family

title: Whitman Unveils Plan To Patrol Public Schools
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a package of measures yesterday intended to deter violence among youths, including a recommendation that police officers patrol New Jersey's public schools.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Latin America Tells I.M.F. That Economies Are Sound

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, RABBI SENDER.
description: DEUTSCH-Rabbi Sender. The World Council of Orthodox Jewish Communities, has suffered the profound loss of its Senior Vice President and dynamic leader, editor of ''Der Yid'', who inspired a generation of the Chassidic community with his teachings and writings.
