We join in the sorrow of his devoted wife, sons, daughters and grandchildren in mourning his demise. May his bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Hertz Frankel, Vice President Eliezer (Louie) Kestenbaum, Chairman Executive Committee Rabbi Chaim M. Stauber, Executive Vice President

title: Fewer Primaries, Better Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror, Guilt and Blind Ambition in an Icy Heart of Darkness
description: THE VOYAGE OF THE NARWHAL

title: SENATE DEMOCRAT REBUKES CLINTON
description: Unleashing the swelling discontent among Democrats about President Clinton, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman denounced the President's conduct in the Lewinsky scandal today as ''disgraceful'' and ''immoral'' and said the issue carried deep moral consequences for the country.

title: A Timeless Fishing Village Is Transformed in a Moment
description: When Brendan Fitzgerald, a tourist from Massachusetts, arrived in Peggy's Cove earlier this week, it was still known mainly as the most visited, most admired old fishing village on Nova Scotia's craggy east coast -- necklaced by great white rocks, serenaded by crashing surf and crowned by a red-tipped lighthouse worth driving hours to see.

title: Ultimate Sports Goal Lures McGwire and Sosa and Fans
description: The pursuit of baseball's home run record took a day off yesterday, giving the contenders, Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa, and everyone else a chance to relax and take a few deep breaths before the most captivating and chronicled sports chase in recent decades resumes.

title: At Airports, Echoes of Earlier Crash
description: As relatives of passengers aboard Swissair Flight 111 filed into the Ramada Plaza Hotel at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and huddled in a private conference room to wrestle with their grief, the scene carried poignant echoes of July 1996, when families reeling from the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 gathered under the same roof.

title: In Summer's Popcorn Season, Appreciating the Champagne
description: As Hollywood's popcorn season fades into a filet mignon fall and the explosions of ''Deep Impact,'' ''Armageddon'' and ''Godzilla'' recede into distant background mutterings, what, if anything, have this summer's movies taught us about ourselves and our tastes in film? The most revealing lesson of the last two months -- one that is, I hope, not lost on Hollywood -- may be that popcorn doesn't have to rule the summer box office, notwithstanding the $100-million-plus gross of the tittery gross-out comedy ''There's Something About Mary.''

title: Big Board Votes to Abandon Mandatory Job-Bias Arbitration
description: The board of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to no longer require industry arbitration of job-discrimination claims, deciding that it will hear such claims only when they are submitted and after a dispute has arisen, according to executives at the exchange.

title: Rich Husband Cuts Campaign Support To McCaughey Ross
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross announced yesterday that her husband had withdrawn most of the financial backing for her gubernatorial candidacy, forcing her to scale back her campaign drastically and curtail the extensive round of television advertising that most politicians say is critical to her success in the primary.

title: W. L. Morgan, Finance Pioneer, Dies at 100
description: Walter L. Morgan, a pioneer of finance who founded an early mutual fund that sailed through the booms and busts of seven decades, died on Wednesday at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Pennsylvania. He was 100 and lived in Bryn Mawr.

title: Homer Rivalry Resumes, With a Shootout in Sight
description: Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa, separated by three home runs in their quest to break Roger Maris's record, take a bizarre coincidence into their games tonight as their spirited rivalry resumes.

title: North Koreans May Be Preparing Another Missile Test
description: North Korea may be preparing to test another missile, American and Japanese officials said today, even as North Korean diplomats met in New York to discuss their missile and nuclear programs with American officials.

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Minerva Bernardino, 91, Dominican Feminist
description: Minerva Bernardino, a major force behind the founding of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women and a pioneer among Latin American feminists, died on Aug. 29 in the Dominican Republic. She was 91.

title: Public and Private Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The President's relationship with Ms. Lewinsky not only contradicted the values he has publicly embraced over the last six years. It has, I fear, compromised his moral authority at a time when Americans of every political persuasion agree that the decline of the family is one of the most pressing problems we are facing.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNECK, SALLY ROOS.
description: SCHNECK-Sally Roos. On September 3, 1998. We celebrate your passion for living, you are truly missed. Devoted wife of Sidney, mother of Susan, Karen, Robert. Grandmother of Sophie, Sam, and daughter of Clara Gertrude. Private funeral. Memorial service, Sunday, September 6 at 11 A.M., Temple Beth El, Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Evanston-Northwestern Health Care, 2650 Ridge Ave, Evanston, IL. 60201, C/O Dr. Nicholas Vick, reference 3865 to support oncology research fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIMMELS, E. RICHARD JR.
description: RIMMELS-E. Richard Jr. Of Rock Hill & Hempstead, NY, September 2, 1998. Beloved husband of Agnes, father of Edward and Patricia, father-in-law of Jeffrey and Beth, grandfather of Stephanie. Senior partner of Montfort, Healy, McGuire & Salley & leading authority in insurance law, torts and civil appeals. Counsel to Fredrick A. Cook Society, Chancellor of the Diocese of the Resurrection, former president Wanaksink Lake Club, former chairman Cathedral School of St. Mary's, former editor-in-chief of The Nassau Lawyer. Repose will be at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, Garden City, N.Y. Friday, September 4, 1-3 PM and 7-9 PM. Service on Saturday, September 5, 9 AM at Fairchild Sons with interment to follow at Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to St. Stephan's A.C.C. of East Islip or the Make a Wish Foundation.

title: U.S. in Last Bridge Round
description: American players were among the leaders in two world championships here today.

title: Picking Up Varied Influences On the Road From Colombia
description: If asked, the members of Bloque could probably trace the rhythms of most of their songs back to specific regions of Colombia. Ivan Benavides, Bloque's lead singer, mentioned a few from the stage when the band performed at Fez on Wednesday night: a son negro, from Colombia's Pacific Coast, and one he jokingly described as a a neurotic cumbia.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABBOTT LABORATORIES LTD., Abbott Park, Ill., the medical products company, acquired 2 million common shares of the I-Stat Corp., Princeton, N.J., in connection with long-term sales, marketing and research agreements. It paid $22.7 million for the stake, which is 11.5 percent of I-Stat.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Roster of Victims Spans the Globe
description: The Swissair passenger list was a kaleidoscope of nations. Among the victims were a tireless battler against AIDS, researchers on the frontiers of science, and a contingent of United Nations workers making another commute between New York and Geneva.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, ELSIE N.
description: COHEN-Elsie N. On August 31. Wife of the late Samuel L. Cohen. Mother of Blossom (Albert) Block. Grandmother of James (Kim) and Sanford Block. Great grandmother of Steven and Kevin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZALUPO, VINCENT
description: MAZZALUPO - Vincent. Loving husband of Rosalie. Member of American Institute of Architects, he was an honorable man. Donations may be made in his memory to: Dicapo Opera Theater Vocal Competition Scholarship, 220 East 54 Street, New York 10022, Suite 11J, or Mazzalupo Architectural Fund, Pratt Institute Development Office, 200 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11205.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Janet Reno May Finally Get It
description: Attorney General Janet Reno is belatedly becoming more curious about the fund-raising abuses in President Clinton's re-election operation. This week Ms. Reno let it be known that she might ask for an independent counsel to examine the costly television ''issue'' ads directed by Mr. Clinton, and paid for by the Democrats' ''soft-money'' war chest, in a brazen effort to avoid Federal contribution and spending limits on his 1996 campaign. Whether Ms. Reno is seeing the light, as her people say, or feeling the heat from Congress, as we suspect, she is moving in the right direction. But she should get on with appointing an independent prosecutor to investigate all potential abuses, not just the limited range she has in mind.

title: Celebrating Life In 3 Languages
description: Some statements bear repeating. That principle is reflected in the title of the Na Zdorovye-L'Chaim-To Life Festival '98, which is the same spirited toast in Russian, Hebrew and English. (That's naz-dor-OV-ya le-CHAI-im.) And for good reason: The three-day festival, which will begin on Sunday in Battery Park, celebrates the flowering of Russian Jewish culture in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FURMAN, LUCILLE
description: FURMAN-Lucille. September 4, 1989. In fond and loving memory. Your Iris & Whitey

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the political standoff in Moscow used a word erroneously in a description of President Boris N. Yeltsin's news conference comment on the nomination of Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minster. The article should have said Mr. Yeltsin equivocated (not prevaricated) when asked about the possibility of a compromise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTS, PEGGY
description: ROBERTS-Peggy. Wife and best friend of Stanley. Dearest mother and best friend of Robin Stessel and the late Theodore. Adored grandmother of Jason and Sara Stessel. Devoted sister of Patsy Berkman and Anita Creazzo. Services Friday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Museums Built on the Passion to Collect . . . Anything
description: Hugh Francis Hicks is a 76-year-old dentist in downtown Baltimore, with an office on the parlor floor of an old brownstone diagonally across the street from the Walters Art Gallery. The other day, he took me into the building's basement to show me a collection he has been putting together for nearly 70 years. Dr. Hicks collects light bulbs. He has 60,000 of them.

title: Chief U.N. Inspector Reports More Interference by Iraq
description: The chief United Nations weapons inspector for Iraq said today that the Government of Saddam Hussein had gone beyond its decision to block surprise inspections and is now interfering with routine monitoring operations.

title: Lily Tomlin in Madison Ave. debut with Peter Lynch.
description: LILY TOMLIN, who once searched for signs of intelligent life in the universe, is joining Peter Lynch to help investors search for signs of intelligent life on Wall Street.

title: Residential Real Estate; Staten Island Co-op Project Is Priced for Moderate Incomes
description: Construction will start this month on 74 town house-style co-ops on Staten Island that are part of a new city program to provide housing that is affordable to people who earn as little as $30,000 a year.

title: REPUBLIC AGREES TO BUY CROSS-CONTINENT AUTO RETAILERS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it would acquire Cross-Continent Auto Retailers Inc., an owner of automobile dealerships, for $145 million in stock. News of the deal sent shares of Cross-Continent soaring 48 percent, or $3.0625, to $9.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., dropped 93.75 cents, to $15.875. Republic owns the nation's largest group of franchised automotive dealerships and operates the Autonation USA used-vehicle mega-store chain. The company, which is controlled by the billionaire financier H. Wayne Huizenga, has more than 300 dealerships in 18 states. Cross-Continent, based in Amarillo, Tex., has dealerships in Las Vegas, Denver, Oklahoma City and Amarillo.

title: Retailers' Sales Strong in August; Analysts Still Wary
description: American retailers reported relatively strong sales for August yesterday, but analysts warned that continued unease in the stock market and in the global economy could slow down retail sales for the rest of the year.

title: Pierce Gerety, 56, Official Who Helped African Refugees
description: Pierce Gerety, a Harvard-educated lawyer who briefly considered the priesthood but instead devoted his life to helping refugees trapped in the maelstroms of war and disaster around the world, died on Wednesday night in the crash of the Swissair jetliner off Nova Scotia. He would have been 57 next Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMAN, WALTER
description: NEUMAN-Walter. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: Cabaret
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Slugger's Bad Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Saratoga to Stage Stakes for Juveniles
description: Some of the most accomplished and most ambitious 2-year-old horses in the country will try to pass milestones on the road to juvenile championships in the next two days when Saratoga Race Course stages two Grade I stakes for beginners: the Spinaway today for fillies and the Hopeful tomorrow for colts.

title: John Mortimer, Times Executive, And Wife, Hilda, Die in Crash
description: John Mortimer, 75, a former senior vice president of The New York Times for personnel and industrial relations, and his wife of 22 years, Hilda, 69, died in the Swissair plane crash on Wednesday. They lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Airbus in Shift On 100-Seat Jet
description: Airbus Industrie said today that it had dropped a costly plan to develop a 100-seat jet together with Chinese companies, freeing it to develop its own model to rival the Boeing Company's two planes of that size.

title: Holyfield Says His Help Was Sought
description: Evander Holyfield said yesterday that he was approached by a member of the New Jersey State Athletic Control Board in July and urged to write a letter in support of Mike Tyson's getting a license to fight in New Jersey.

title: Development Claims a Harlem Sculpture
description: To some, the enormous skeletal structure along the Hudson River in Harlem was an eyesore that took up valuable space. To others, it was the perfect mix of art and utility, a sculpture that had been adopted by children who used it as a jungle gym.

title: Upstairs, Downstairs And Passion In the Halls
description: When Elisabeth (Sophie Marceau), a beautiful Swiss governess, meets Charles (Stephen Dillane), a handsome British aristocrat, for discreet late-night whoopee sessions at a picturesque little hotel on the north coast of France, she knows she is not supposed to feel any pleasure. Their carefully planned dates are just a business arrangement. In return for money to pay off her father's debts, she is to conceive and bear Charles the child that his wife, who has been lying in a vegetative state since being nearly killed in an unspeakable accident, cannot produce. But when the earth moves for Elisabeth on their third night together, you can be sure that somehow, somewhere, she and Charles will reunite, even though their deal calls for them never to meet again.

title: Fallon McElligott Hires Pair in London
description: A well-known British creative team has been hired as partners at the new office of the Minneapolis agency Fallon McElligott in London.

title: The Hallowed Ground Of Sports Car Racing
description: VERY form of racing has its spiritual home: Indianapolis for Indy cars, Charlotte for stock cars, Pomona for dragsters. And for a half-century, sports-car racing has had Watkins Glen, N.Y., host from 1961 to 1980 of the United States Grand Prix Formula One race. ''Part of the appeal of the race was the uniqueness of it,'' said Bob Kelly, who was the track's press chief from 1970 to 1980. ''You had this tiny town of 2,700 people in upstate New York hosting a race that was the focus of international attention.''

title: New Hollywood Studio Wrangles Over Project
description: It was the high-tech vision that was supposed to make the dream in Dreamworks come true, the first newly built Hollywood studio in nearly 60 years, nestled in a 1,000-acre tract amid the coastal wetlands where Howard Hughes built his giant seaplane, the Spruce Goose.

title: A Quirky Dealer With a Sharp Eye for Masters of the Offbeat
description: ''Julien Levy: Portrait of an Art Gallery'' at the Equitable Gallery, is the ideal end-of-summer show. It is a tumult of ideas, every one of which has been picked over for the occasion by two gifted and youthful enthusiasts, Ingrid Schaffner and Lisa Jacobs. There is a great deal to see, almost all of it is worth looking at, and none of it goes on for too long.

title: Gephardt Trumpets '98 Agenda Of His Party
description: Trying to instill optimism about the November elections, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the minority leader, arrived here today eager to snuff out talk of President Clinton's travails with a rousing chorus of hard-core Democratic philosophy.

title: The I.M.F. Could Save Your 401(k)
description: Until recently, the average American investor didn't see much reason to be concerned with the Russian financial crisis. But now that this crisis and the uncertainties in Asia have created turmoil in the United States stock market, investors have become wary of emerging markets. And the instability has also caused some to wonder whether we should continue to support the International Monetary Fund.

title: A Hard-Edged Zeal in Images of the Avant-Garde
description: Early modernist graphics are nothing if not upbeat. Embodying enthusiasm for the social and material possibilities of the new century in bold, insouciant, scientifically efficient new forms, they generated moods of almost utopian euphoria. Why then should the story told by ''Graphic Design in the Mechanical Age,'' a fascinating show at the Williams College Museum of Art here, be so depressing?

title: 3 State Troopers Wounded in Shootout
description: A man whose mobile home held an arsenal of firearms and explosives opened fire on three state troopers without warning today after two of them tried to question him about a neighbor's complaint of vandalism, state police said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a proposed acquisition by the Centex Real Estate Corporation misidentified the company being acquired. It is Calton Homes Inc., not Carlton Homes.

title: Two Former Stratton Officials Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: Two former principals of a defunct brokerage firm, Stratton Oakmont Inc., have been indicted in an international securities fraud and money laundering scheme that Federal prosecutors say tried to manipulate the stock of two small companies.

title: Japan Considers Nationalizing Some Banks
description: Japan is considering a trial step toward nationalizing troubled big banks.

title: Farm Studios Changes Its Name
description: The Farm Studios, a commercial production company in Hollywood, has changed its name to Farmland Studios after it ''unintentionally'' infringed the trademark of another creative production company, the Farm, which is based in New York. The company now known as Farmland Studios was formed last month by three commercial directors: Scott Gardenhour, Jeff Gorman and Gary Johns.

title: For Lieberman, 'Loyalty Is to the Public Interest'
description: Bill Clinton and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman go back a long way.

title: Digging for Meaning in Slavery's Wake
description: Maybe he just wanted to play the harmonica again. Whatever his reasons, and try as he might, the charismatic Ruben Santiago-Hudson cannot overcome the insurmountable obstacles imposed on him by ''Deep Down,'' a preachy mishmash of a drama about racism in rural Florida in the early days of the civil rights movement.

title: Slugger's Bad Example; Power Serves
description: To the Editor:

title: Sampras and Agassi Gain, but None Too Tidily
description: Just when it seemed that this 1998 United States Open was going to make a habit of parceling out the drama in tiny doses, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi received simultaneous scares yesterday. A pair of unintimidating but intriguing challengers summoned the audacity to trip up the former Open champions before they had even reached the third round.

title: On 'Hate March,' Giuliani Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: Number of Executions in China Seems to Decline, Rights Group Says
description: The number of criminals executed in China appears to have dropped significantly in the last year, since the passage of a new criminal law that restricts use of the death sentence, human rights monitors say. But they emphasize that China still executes far more people than any other nation.

title: INSIDE
description: More Korean Tests Feared

title: Stocks Take Broad Plunge; Dow Off 100
description: Stock prices headed broadly lower yesterday as investors continued to show nervousness about the effects of a possible global economic slowdown on the profits of American companies.

title: A Wry Defiance Behind Garish Colors and Tabloid Dramas
description: Multiculturalism is a complicated phenomenon, both sweet and bitter. During the last decade, artists and even whole cultures once excluded from mainstream consideration have gained admission, however tentative, to the contemporary art market controlled by the United States and Europe. But the terms of entry are often capricious and constricting.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 1
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, ARTHUR
description: WALTER-Arthur. Shelter Rock Jewish Center, Roslyn, NY mourns friend and founder, longtime and devoted Treasurer of our congregation. To Elisse, Alan and Abra our heartfelt condolences. We will miss Arthur and Shirley. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster Stanley Shanies, President

title: Lehman Expects Russian Turmoil to Help Cut Net by $60 Million
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that the financial turmoil in Russia and other developing countries would reduce its net income by $60 million for the three months ended on Aug. 31.

title: Day Care in Court? Jury System Needs Refining
description: To the Editor:

title: Fewer Primaries, Better Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: In O'Neill's First Play, Sparks to Light His Future
description: The good news down on Macdougal Street is that the Provincetown Playhouse has been thoroughly refurbished and is once again operating as a theater. It seems all the more fitting that the first productions in the spiffy and comfortable new space should be given to the works of Eugene O'Neill, whose early plays were staged there 80 years ago.

title: Empire State's Strength
description: To the Editor:

title: Bare Fists No Match for Sharp Claws
description: There are two villains to hate in ''Like It Is,'' and one is Roger Daltry, who looks fabulous.

title: CADENCE SAYS IT WILL PAY $260 MILLION FOR AMBIT DESIGN
description: Cadence Design Systems Inc., which makes software to speed the design of microprocessors, said yesterday that it would buy Ambit Design Systems Inc. for $260 million in cash to strengthen its technology offerings. The closely held Ambit makes tools for so-called system-on-a-chip technology, designed to put the functions of different computer chips on a single microprocessor. Cadence, based in San Jose, Calif., is seeking to expand its product line of tools associated with making system-on-a-chip technology. The technology is intended to make semiconductors more efficient. Cadence's stock rose $1.625 a share, to $22.50.

title: Judge May Change Lawyer in Embassy Bombings
description: The lawyer for one of two defendants charged in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya may be replaced today at a hearing in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: SOLUTIA SAYS IT WILL SELL PHOSPHOROUS CHEMICALS UNIT
description: Solutia Inc., the specialty chemical and fiber maker, said yesterday that it had decided to sell its phosphorous chemicals unit, allowing the company to focus on its more profitable businesses like nylon and shatterproof glass coatings. Solutia said the unit, which makes chemicals used in fire retardants, detergents and other products, contributed $370 million to Solutia's $2.97 billion in 1997 sales. Solutia, which is based in St. Louis, was spun off from the Monsanto Company last year. In July, Solutia said it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to help it evaluate alternatives for the unit. The company said it had had ''expressions of interest'' in the business and would pursue a sale.

title: The Pursuit of the Pursuers, Then and Now
description: It's not hard to imagine how Roger Maris would handle the news media if he were making his assault on Babe Ruth's record of 60 home runs in 1998. The shy, small-town man from Minnesota and North Dakota wearied of the pack of reporters who chronicled his 61-home run season in 1961. What if hundreds of reporters tailed him from city to city, many from cable television and radio outlets unheard of 37 years ago? What if a Howard Stern lackey taunted him with tawdry questions?

title: Vigilante Awarded Sprint Assignment
description: The consumer long-distance unit of the Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it had named Vigilante in New York as the first agency to handle its advertising aimed at black consumers.

title: Don't Expect Russia To Fend for Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLASS, ABRAHAM
description: KLASS-Abraham. Dearly beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of Richard Gropper, cherished grandfather of Daniel and Debbie. Dear brother of David and the late Dorothy and Ruth. Loving uncle of Joyce, David, Jeani, Barry and Stephanie. Services at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills, today at 12:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEURTEMATTE, JEANNE
description: HEURTEMATTE - Jeanne. Jeanne Heurtematte of Washington, DC and Saltaire, NY on September 1, 1998. Wife of Julio E. Heurtematte, Jr, mother of Darcy Heurtematte, stepmother of Douglas and Marc Heurtematte, sister of Patricia Connelly McAllister, daughter of Rita Gorman Connelly. Memorial mass at 10:30 A.M. on Wednesday, September 9, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, 8th and N Street, NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Children's National Medical Center, 111 Michigan Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20010-2970 or the National Bone Marrow Program, Minneapolis, MN 55485-8925.

title: Rough Rider, Easy Living
description: The house I would most love to go home to is Sagamore Hill. As an ardent visitor to museum-houses that offer glimpses of the personal daily lives of their revered occupants, I feel that Theodore Roosevelt's beloved estate in Oyster Bay on Long Island, more than any other, seems the perfect home in which to have grown up.

title: In Something Like a Debate, Kohl Defends While a Relaxed Schroder Taunts Him
description: In the closest thing to a televised presidential debate before elections this month, Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave a rambling defense today of his role as a statesman and the architect of German reunification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTA, ROMEO C.
description: SALTA-Romeo C. Aged 94, a pioneer of Northern Italian cuisine, passed away on August 31, 1998. Mr. Salta began his restaurant career in 1938 in Los Angeles, opening Chianti Restaurant, which became home to the most popular celebrities and business people. Following the shift of the entertainment industry to New York, Mr. Salta moved as well and in 1953 opened his world renowned restaurant on West 56th Street, which bore his name. Mr. Salta is survived by his wife Antoinette, his sons Salvatore, Romeo, and Remo, all of New York. Services and interment will be held in Italy. A Memorial Service will be held in New York at a later date. For information call Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries, particularly over the Labor Day weekend, and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECK, SHERMAN G.
description: BECK-Sherman G. Born in New York City, 1919. Graduate of Fieldston School and Carnegie Institute of Technology. Writer and director of documentary films. Survived by his daughter Linda, his former wife Jean, a brother Marcus and a sister Edith Kates. Services will be held at the First Unitarian Church of Miami, Saturday, October 3rd.

title: THE CHALLENGER: A special report.; A German Socialist Veers Toward the Center
description: Gerhard Schroder has changed with the times.

title: Fashion and Art: The Gown Was Gorgeous, but the Picture Was Divine
description: Richard Avedon's 1955 photograph of the model Dovima posing regally between two lively elephants may be overly familiar, but with its startling contrasts, it is an extraordinary image. It has less to do with beauty and the beast, and much more to do with Blakean ''Tiger, tiger, burning bright'' symmetry and the gall of a fashion photographer to have the mighty animals be a mere backdrop for a slender woman wearing an expensive evening dress.

title: Mircosoft Ordered to Provide More Antitrust Evidence
description: A Federal judge ordered the Microsoft Corporation today to give the Justice Department reams of new evidence that Government lawyers say will bolster their antitrust case against the software giant.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about CBS and its deal to broadcast National Football League games misstated the network's rank among 18-to-49-year-olds in prime time. It is fourth, not third, of the four big networks.

title: Shell and Texaco to Join Europe Refining and Sales
description: Royal Dutch/Shell and Texaco said yesterday that they would combine their refining and marketing businesses in Europe, a step that could further speed a trend toward cutting costs and capacity as the industry struggles with declining profit.

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 8.

title: Players Union Testifies at Hearing
description: Representatives of the players union addressed the N.B.A. lockout yesterday for the first time in more than a week, testifying before the arbitrator John D. Feerick in a Manhattan law office. The hearing will decide whether players with guaranteed contracts should be paid during the lockout imposed by owners on July 1. It is scheduled to continue today, next Tuesday and possibly next Wednesday.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Municipal Job Changes Proposed in Atlantic City
description: Mayor James Whelan has proposed several changes in the municipal government, including the creation of 44 new middle-management jobs, many for computer and technical experts.

title: President Named at Fidelity Investments
description: Fidelity Investments named James C. Curvey as president yesterday, shifting all operating responsibilities for the giant mutual fund and investment firm to him.

title: As Ruble Falls, Moscow Unravels Faster and Faster
description: The wasting disease now ravaging Russia's ruble and its banks has begun to infect everyday commerce in shops and groceries, with unsettling implications -- not just for ordinary citizens, but for the Russian Government, which rises and falls on their trust.

title: Scott Ellis Takes a New Roundabout Post
description: Scott Ellis, the Broadway director, has agreed to take the new position of associate artistic director of the Roundabout Theater Company, the theater announced on Wednesday.

title: 'On Stage and Off'
description: The ''On Stage and Off'' column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Pair Found Bound and Shot in Burned House
description: The charred bodies of a Staten Island couple who had been bound and shot execution-style were found by firefighters after a fast-moving blaze gutted their mansion early yesterday, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A note in the mutual funds table in Business Day yesterday misidentified the source of the data. The figures were supplied by Morningstar Inc., not Lipper Analytical Services.

title: Captain's Log: We're Back And, Boy, Are We Young
description: In the past, the future looked different. It was simpler than the present future, with brighter colors.

title: A Life's Work: Honoring Those Who Labored
description: ONE day last summer, Dr. Debra E. Bernhardt rode to the 17th story of 200 Park Avenue South, at 17th Street, and made her way to the roof. Stepping past the air-conditioning equipment and water pipes, she stood at the edge of the building and gazed down at what had become of Union Square, for so long the switchyard of labor organizing and radical agitation in New York City.

title: Hurricane Pounds Florida With Floods and Twisters
description: Hurricane Earl lashed Florida's Panhandle with winds of 80 miles an hour, crossing the coast in the darkness of the early morning hours and killing two people there and one in South Carolina.

title: Fewer Primaries, Better Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Terrorism Doubted in Crash, With 229 Aboard, Off Nova Scotia : No Hope of Swissair Jet Survivors
description: WASHINGTON  Canadian search and rescue teams found part of a Swiss airliner's fuselage in deep waters off a Nova Scotia fishing town on Thursday but held no hope that any of the 229 passengers and crew members aboard survived a desperate attempt to land at sea after smoke filled the cockpit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBUS, RICHARD L.
description: GARBUS-Richard L. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and former colleague. Rick was wise beyond his years, respected by his colleagues and clients, a great husband, fatheralways optimistic. He was a trusted and loyal friend. We will miss him. Our thoughts are with Peggy and their children. Stephen L. Solomon, Ivan W. Moskowitz, Richard M. Zuckerman Daniel Besdin, Jacob Inwald, and Joseph Vidulich

title: After 3 Violent Decades, Hope in Northern Ireland
description: If President Clinton visited Moscow at one of Russia's most trying moments, he came to Belfast at one of Northern Ireland's most promising.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions on Aug. 11 about Andrew Crispo, the art dealer who after stints in prison and in bankruptcy is opening a business, referred incorrectly to the sculpture shown. The work by Thomas Beckman, on display in Mr. Cris po's exhibition space in Greenwich Village, is made of wood, not dinosaur bones.

title: Medical Examiner Too Ill To Tape More Testimony
description: The Middlesex County Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Marvin Shuster, who is dying of cancer and is being allowed to testify by videotape in seven murder trials, has become too ill to continue the tapings, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: In Wake of Strikes, G.M. Posts August Sales Drop
description: Still struggling with the aftermath of two strikes, the General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that car and light-truck sales fell 36.4 percent in August. At the same time, the Ford Motor Company reported a stronger-than-expected 8.1 percent increase in sales.

title: Pressure Is on Jets' Hall, But Kicking Job Is His
description: It was a decision that Bill Parcells said ''will be wrong, whatever I do.''

title: Police Are Criticized as Poughkeepsie House Yields Corpses
description: A day after an unemployed school aide was arrested in the murder of one woman and was first suspected in the deaths of seven others, new questions arose today over how aggressively the police pursued complaints from at least two prostitutes who contended that they were assaulted by the suspect in the case.

title: WILLAMETTE PLANS TO SELL TIMBERLAND AND REDUCE DEBT
description: Willamette Industries said yesterday that it planned to sell about 117,000 acres of unneeded timberlands in the Northwest and use the proceeds to reduce debt and resume a $25 million stock buyback program. Willamette, the 10th-largest United States paper products company, could receive as much as $2,000 to $2,200 an acre for the timberlands, which are in southwestern Washington, analysts said. That would mean a potential selling price of more than $250 million. The stock buyback program, covering almost 1 percent of outstanding shares and authorized in 1995, had been inactive because of Willamette's high level of debt. Willamette is based in Portland, Ore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENTHAL, GABRIEL
description: LEVENTHAL-Gabriel. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member and dear friend, Gabriel Leventhal, and offers its heartfelt sympathy to his family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Eating Out
description: Japanese

title: A Royal Wedding, A Family Affair; Two Hasidic Dynasties Unite in Brooklyn Gala
description: There were 8,000 guests, not including those peering down from the rooftops. The police closed the streets in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to allow for a chuppa, or wedding canopy, and afterward the crowds squeezed so tightly into the reception hall that several people collapsed from heat exhaustion.

title: Silo Meets Satellite Dish In the New New England
description: There has never been a shortage of landscape in New England, nor, for that matter, of artists to romanticize it freely. But as industry, technology and suburbia have turned hamlets into towns and farmland into malls, the focus has drastically shifted. New takes on the old rural theme of human harmony with nature are showing up in the work of artists from the region. We've come a long way from the 19th-century vision of the Sublime, a view of America as a glorious, pristine land where nature connected man with God.

title: New Video Releases
description: Primary Colors

title: Clinton Promotes Accord In Ulster, With a Warning
description: On a rare sun-washed day marked by the fragile promise of peace and the wrenching remnants of hatred, President Clinton urged all parties in Northern Ireland today to seize this moment of optimism to secure lasting reconciliation.

title: G.O.P. Drops Effort to Remove Election Counsel
description: A Senate Republican agreed today to drop an effort to oust Lawrence M. Noble, the general counsel of the Federal Election Commission who has aggressively pursued accusations of campaign spending violations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERVING, T. CROSBY.
description: ERVING-T. Crosby. Formerly of Milton, MA. Survived by a stepson, Peter Newman and a stepdaughter, Lisa Newman. A memorial service will be held in St. Matthew's Church, 382 Cantitoe Street, Bedford, NY, on September 12 at 1PM. Burial will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, GERTRUDE DE LANCEY.
description: WALLACE-Gertrude de Lancey. Mother of Peter de L. and Helen W. Wallace, grandmother of Campbell Lloyd-, Peter Woodbridge, and Cornelia S. Wallace, died at home on September 1. Funeral service will be at St. Bartholomew's chapel, 50th Street & Park Avenue Friday, September 4, at 10:30 AM. Donations in her memory may be made to the Animal Medical Center, 510 East 62nd Street, New York, N.Y. 10021.

title: Stephen Syms Merns, 45, Retail Executive
description: Stephen Syms Merns, an apparel-chain executive and a philanthropist, died last Saturday during an outing to Columbia County in northern New York State. He was 45 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Metro Business; United Rentals Expands
description: United Rentals Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., the biggest equipment rental company in the United States, said it is expanding on the East Coast and has bought two rental businesses, with a combined annual revenue of $105 million.

title: Hull to Discuss Disputed Comments
description: Timothy Danson, the lawyer for Bobby Hull, said yesterday that the former hockey star would meet with Jewish and black groups at the offices of the Canadian Jewish Congress in Toronto on Sept. 17 to discuss the controversial and disputed remarks about race that were attributed to Hull in an article in a Moscow newspaper.

title: Excerpts From Senator Lieberman's Talk on President's Personal Conduct
description: Following are excerpts from a speech about the Clinton-Lewinsky episode that was delivered on the Senate floor today by Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service:

title: Experts Seek the Cause of Swissair Crash Fatal to 229
description: Scores of bodies and bits of debris were recovered from choppy seas off Nova Scotia yesterday as officials sought to determine why a Swissair jetliner bound from New York to Geneva fell into the Atlantic minutes short of an emergency landing in Halifax Wednesday night, apparently killing all 229 people on board.

title: Malaysian Reformer Hits Back After Ouster From Cabinet
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad personally took control of the economy early Friday, expelling his former deputy from the country's ruling political party and naming himself acting finance minister.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Noteworthy Bird Stops By for a Visit

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RISES. Germany's currency rose sharply on a report that the financier George Soros was dumping dollars. In New York, the mark traded at 1.7309 to the dollar, its highest level since Nov. 19, up from 1.7500.

title: New Campaigns For 2 Marketers
description: Two marketers are introducing the initial campaigns from their new agencies.

title: Focus on Finding Bodies, Not Flight Recorders
description: Although there are few clues as yet to the cause of the crash of Swissair Flight 111 on Wednesday night, the chairman of Canada's Transportation Safety Board said this evening that the plane disappeared from radar at ''7,000 or 8,000 or 9,000 feet,'' about 16 minutes after the pilot first alerted air controllers about smoke in the cockpit.

title: Candidate's Money Problems May Jeopardize Liberal Party
description: The financial problems hobbling the gubernatorial campaign of Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross are also threatening the viability of the New York State Liberal Party, which has staked its future on her candidacy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEEN, LEONARD W.
description: DEEN-Leonard W., 72. Of Bayside and Stone Ridge, NY, a Blake Scholar, author of ''Conversing in Paradise'', and a retired English professor at Queens College, died September 3, 1998. Husband of Rosemary Deen; father of Matthew, Mary Stella, John, Barbara Deen, and Catherine Piuggi. Memorial contributions may be made to the Leonard Deen Memorial Prize Fund, c/o Prof. Bette Weidman at Queens College, CUNY.

title: No Truce in Congo; Talks Are Planned
description: No cease-fire in the war in Congo was worked out today, but a summit meeting of the warring factions is to be held soon to discuss one, parties to the conflict said.

title: After Teen-Agers Play, Talk Is of Top 10 Futures
description: At age 18, Marat Safin does not often face someone younger than him in a men's tennis tournament. Yesterday was an exception, and when the final 125-mile-an-hour serve had been pummeled, Safin had given Taylor Dent, 17, a good sense of how much Dent needs to improve to be competitive in the higher reaches of professional tennis.

title: U.N. Arms Inspector Who Quit Is Told He Can't Make Policy
description: Senate Democrats mounted a careful counterattack today against the American who resigned in protest last month from the weapons inspection team in Iraq.

title: The 30-Year Treasury Price Moves Higher
description: Bonds continued to benefit from the turbulence in stocks yesterday, managing a modest gain.

title: RENO RENEWS LOOK AT SPENDING IN '96 BY THE DEMOCRATS
description: After two years of rejecting calls for an outside investigation of spending by the 1996 Clinton-Gore campaign, Attorney General Janet Reno has seized on a Federal Election Commission audit to reopen the Justice Department's review of whether an independent prosecutor should examine the issue.

title: On My Mind; The Days of September
description: In September of 1998, when it seemed that some Americans would lose money in the stock market and others might even lose jobs, America and its Government focused on nations they felt were to blame, and on what American policy should be toward them. Russia, Indonesia, Japan and so on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, SARA
description: ZUCKERMAN-Sara. Yeshiva University mourns the loss of a devoted mother, loving wife, and respected member of the Jewish community. We extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Dr. Matthew M. Zuckerman; her daughters, Linda (and Tommy) Sandel, Karen (and Gary) Fragin, and Nancy (and Jackie) Markovich; her sister, Ruth Shapiro; and her brother-in-law, Irwin Shapiro. The Shapiros are YU Benefactors and Irwin is a member of the Yeshiva University Board of Trustees, the boards of YU's Bernard Revel Graduate School, its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary, and High Schools. May the family members be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Jonathan Mann, AIDS Pioneer, Is Dead at 51
description: Dr. Jonathan Max Mann, a pioneer in the international campaign against AIDS and a founder of a movement to link health issues with those of human rights, died on Wednesday night alongside his wife, Dr. Mary Lou Clements-Mann, a vaccine scientist at Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health University, in the crash of Swissair Flight 111 off Nova Scotia. He was 51 and lived in Columbia, Md.

title: Soho Spacecraft to Study Sun Is Slowly Reviving From the Dead
description: The disabled Soho spacecraft is responding to commands and slowly recovering from a series of ground control errors that almost caused the loss of the valuable scientific observatory, officials said today.

title: List of 229 Was a Kaleidoscope of Nations
description: When Swissair Flight 111 plunged into the inky waters off Nova Scotia Wednesday night, it took an uncommon number of lives of dogged humanitarianism. It claimed a battler against the scourge of AIDS and researchers perched on the seemingly fathomless frontiers of science.

title: Mary Lou Clements-Mann, 51, An Expert on AIDS Vaccines
description: Dr. Mary Lou Clements-Mann, an epidemiologist and vaccine expert who headed the center for immunization research at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health in Baltimore, died with her husband in Wednesday night's plane crash off Nova Scotia.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Choices for the State Legislature
description: New York's State Legislature is mostly a closed shop, where incumbents are protected by a complex petitioning process and an unfair fund-raising system. But there are a few competitive primary contests in New York City on Sept. 15. Here are our recommendations in 10 races in overwhelmingly Democratic districts where nomination is tantamount to election.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHIFRIN, HILDA
description: SCHIFRIN-Hilda. I miss you and love you always. Lois

title: Let England Grieve
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies; The Allure Of Grandparents
description: Michael Douglas says he doesn't quite understand all those newspaper and magazine stories about the spate of summer movies in which an older man romances a younger woman. What's so unusual? he asked. ''It must have been a slow Monica week,'' he said with a laugh.

title: UNITED RENTALS TO BUY 2 MORE EQUIPMENT COMPANIES
description: United Rentals Inc., a company formed to consolidate the equipment-rental business, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Rental Tools and Equipment Company and McClinch Equipment Services Inc. The purchase price was not disclosed. The acquisitions would give United Rentals added revenue of $105 million, for total revenue of $850 million. United Rentals, based in Greenwich, Conn., has signed letters of intent to acquire 35 companies with 106 outlets and combined yearly revenue of $270 million. United was formed in September 1997 by former managers of United Waste Systems Inc.

title: Tans Fade, but It's an Endless Summer on Video
description: Frankie and Annette pouted and feuded and sang duets. Troy and Sandra fell in love and just seemed to get blonder. That's what you expect from movies with great beach scenes. Whenever the camera has turned to the seashore, either summer love or surfing has been almost certain to follow. With scant exceptions, like ''From Here to Eternity'' (with Burt Lancaster and Deborah Kerr, above), few of these movies are on anybody's list of classics. But when it's time to say goodbye to summer with some favorite videos, vistas of sand and sea, from Fort Lauderdale to St. Tropez, can make up for a lot of skimpy character development.

title: Woodson Of Ravens In Dispute On Testing
description: Rod Woodson of the Baltimore Ravens, a member of the National Football League's 75th anniversary team, violated the league's substance-abuse policy last month, refusing to take a second random drug test, according to executives from several teams.

title: One Swing Away
description: Mark McGwire of the St. Louis Cardinals and Sammy Sosa of the Chicago Cubs are closing in on baseball's record for home runs in a season, perhaps the most famous benchmark in sports. McGwire has 59 homers and Sosa 56, putting in jeopardy both Babe Ruth's mark of 60 in a 154-game season and Roger Maris's record of 61 in 162 games.

title: Spare Times
description: ON THE STREET

title: In Crash Landings, Ocean Surface Can Be Less Forgiving Than Runway
description: Experts on aviation accidents said yesterday that it was not surprising no one survived the impact when Swissair Flight 111 hit the Atlantic on Wednesday.

title: Sleepless Nights
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Just for Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Eloise O. Spaeth, 96, Collector And Supporter of American Art
description: Eloise O. Spaeth, an art collector and booster of American art in particular, died yesterday at her home in East Hampton, N.Y. She was 96.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS GAINS. Natural gas futures rose amid demand to refill storage that was depleted because of shutdowns caused by Hurricane Earl. Natural gas for October delivery rose 7.1 cents, to $1.783 for 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAPORTA, JESSIE
description: LAPORTA-Jessie. Suddenly on September 3, 1998. To my best friend, whose loyalty and friendship I will never forget. Love. Danielle Stockman

title: Top Of the Mountain
description: Allen Drury died on his 80th birthday Wednesday. He had a keen eye for newspaper cliches, so I refrain from calling him ''the father of the Washington novel.'' Still, his ''Advise and Consent'' is probably the best Washington novel there ever was, and its success inspired other reporters to produce a spate of novels in the same style, a couple of which were not bad.

title: For Clinton, Apology Is Test of Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Rwandan Premier Gets Life in Prison On Charges of Genocide in '94 Massacres
description: A United Nations tribunal sentenced a former Prime Minister of Rwanda to life in prison today for his part in the 1994 genocide there, despite his agreement to plead guilty and to testify against other high-ranking officials.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BELIEFS
description: Peter L. Berger is a contrarian, no doubt about it. A pre-eminent sociologist of religion, he has been undercutting conventional assumptions since ''The Noise of Solemn Assemblies,'' his 1961 book, cast a cold eye on the postwar religious revival still in full bloom.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Moody's May Lower China's Debt Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it might lower its debt ratings for China and Hong Kong. Moody's said its A3 credit rating for China might be cut because exports were slowing and direct investment in the country was declining. It also placed the nation's four biggest banks on review for a possible downgrading.

title: Murder Charges Dropped Against 2 Boys in Chicago
description: In an extraordinary turn of events in an equally extraordinary murder case, prosecutors today dropped charges against two boys, ages 7 and 8, who had been accused of killing an 11-year-old girl by hitting her with a rock and suffocating her so they could steal her bicycle.

title: Even Long Ago, A Loud Town
description: Car horns blare. Burglar alarms wail. Sirens scream. Subways squeal. Engines roar. Radios resound, and the city reverberates with noise. Welcome to New York, circa 1930.

title: David Craig, 75, Singing Instructor
description: David Craig, a singing teacher whose students included many stars of film and stage musicals, died on Aug. 28 at Tarzana Regional Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 75 and lived in Studio City, Calif.

title: Man Dressed As a Hasid Is Charged In Graffiti
description: For a week he was a busy man, the police said: He roamed through the predominantly Jewish neighborhood of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, leaving symbols of Nazi Germany in his wake.

title: Sosa Gains on McGwire
description: Sammy Sosa hit his 57th home run and Mark McGwire (0 for 3) stayed at 59 in baseball's race within a chase. SportsSaturday, page D1.

title: Hack Wilson's Lesson Still Valid
description: When he died, in Baltimore on Nov. 23, 1948, he was 48 years old, penniless, an alcoholic. He was also one of baseball's great players, who would later be voted into the Hall of Fame. This was Hack Wilson, whose National League record of 56 home runs in one season stood for 68 years, or until Mark McGwire drew even and passed him with two homers on Tuesday night.

title: Judge Urges a Charge Over a Disappearance
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge increased pressure on prosecutors yesterday to charge the lead suspects in the disappearance of an Upper East Side millionaire with murder by the end of the month.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Bombs, Fraud and Fashion Victims
description: Was a film ever more appropriately titled than ''Knock Off?''

title: Accidental Tourists Need Not Apply Here; It Takes Methodical Planning to Lure Visitors to Far Corner of Texas
description: The world surely is wide enough to hold a few more tourist attractions, and this city of 400,000 people has tried mightily to fill the bill.

title: CREW OF SWISS JET SEEMED IN CONTROL
description: As grieving families from several countries began to converge on this tiny fishing village today, officials looking for the cause of the crash of Swissair Flight 111 on Wednesday said it appeared that the crew was in control of the jet and making rational decisions about how to land the stricken plane until it abruptly disappeared from radar.

title: Catching No. 62 on Television
description: ESPN2 will televise tomorrow afternoon's Cincinnati Reds-St. Louis Cardinals game at 2 P.M. Eastern daylight time if Mark McGwire has not hit his 60th or 61st home run.

title: Emergency Landing In Newfoundland
description: A Royal Airlines Boeing 757 made an emergency landing in Newfoundland today after oil warning lights came on in the cockpit and the pilot smelled fumes, airline officials said.

title: Tokyo Prosecutors Raid NEC Offices
description: Japan's military contract-padding scandal spread yesterday to the NEC Corporation as Tokyo prosecutors raided the giant multinational electronics company. The search followed raids on Thursday at the Japanese Defense Agency and the Toyo Communication Equipment Company, an NEC affiliate, which resulted in the arrest of a senior defense official, the chairman and another executive of Toyo Communication and an NEC executive.

title: Health Benefits Assured In Domestic Violence
description: Health insurers cannot deny benefits for injuries caused by domestic violence under a bill signed into law yesterday by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEFALIDIS, NIKOS
description: KEFALIDIS-Nikos. Phipps Houses mourns the tragic loss of a special friend and business partner. Nikos' passion and quiet generosity and his devotion to his family, work and community will be missed and long remembered. We extend our sympathy to his family, to his wife, Laurie, & their children, Melanie, Elias and Marisa. Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, Chairman Ronay Menschel, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEFFER, SOLOMON
description: FEFFER-Solomon. The entire Jewish Theological Seminary family records with sorrow the passing of Solomon Feffer, a prominent scholar, revered teacher and beloved mentor who, through his dynamic career and magnetic personality, influenced generations of young Jews. Dr. Feffer founded the Rebecca and Israel Ivry Prozdor at JTS, a supplemental religious school program for elite high school youths, and was among the early leaders in the establishment of the Conservative Movement's Ramah summer camps. A longtime member of the JTS faculty, he also directed the language department at George Washington High School in New York, instituting the study of Hebrew there, and later became a professor of Hebrew language at Rutgers University. He is survived by his wife, Bessie; two sons, Amnon of Los Angeles and Jonathan of New York City; four grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing. Ismar Schorsch, Chancellor Gershon Kekst, Board Chairman

title: In Speech, Senator Hoped to 'Start a Process'
description: Like lots of other Americans, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut went on vacation with his family in mid-August. As it happened, the vacation began just after President Clinton admitted on national television to having an inappropriate relationship with a White House intern and to lying about it.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RISES. The yen rose to a nearly four-month high against the dollar after a jobless report offered scant evidence of an overheating American economy. In New York, the yen traded at 133.57 to the dollar, up from 134.70.

title: Did We Expect Too Much of Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Poland Pairs Take World Championship Titles
description: Amid some confusion, Poland and the United States captured major titles at the world championships here today. In the Societe Generale Open Pairs, a little-known Polish pair, Michael Kwiecien and Jacek Pszczola, surged to victory. The American pair of David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen, who had led throughout the day, barely held on to second position.

title: Reporter's Notebook; The Faces of Clinton: Weary to Somber to Vibrant
description: President Reagan's advisers were fond of saying that people never remember the words of a President, only the pictures.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREWDSON, FRANK, M.D.
description: CREWDSON-Frank, M.D. A dedicated, kind, scholarly clinician and teacher, he will be deeply missed by his colleagues and friends. The faculty of The Psychoanalytic Institute and the Department of Psychiatry at New York Medical College extend their heartfelt condolences to his wife, Carol, daughter Natasha, and sons Gregory and Michael. Joseph T. English, M.D. Professor and Chairman Myron L. Glucksman, M.D., Dir. The Psychoanalytic Institute, Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences New York Medical College

title: Think Tank; Odes to the Sporting Life and Death: Fans' and Players' Notes
description: AT THE BALL GAME

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, LAWRENCE
description: FOSTER-Lawrence. Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains, New York, records with sorrow the passing of our beloved Past President, and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark A. Hershey, President

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Labor Day

title: INTERNET'S IMAGE PROBLEM MAY DEPRESS USERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GREENSPAN HINTS THAT A RATE CUT ISN'T UNTHINKABLE
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, signaled today that the central bank was now less concerned about inflation as a threat to the American economy and was increasingly wary that the spreading global financial crisis could harm the United States.

title: Make the President Sit in the Corner, or Even 'Slap Him Silly'
description: America's children, some as young as 7, are aware that President Clinton was unfaithful to his wife, but they seem less interested in the sexual details of the White House scandal than the moral shortcomings of a man who would deceive and hurt his family.

title: Piazza Gives Leiter All the Help He Needs
description: Before the start of last night's game at Shea Stadium, fans flocked behind the Mets' dugout, waving signs wishing Mike Piazza a happy 30th birthday. The well-wishers were not totally selfless, because many of the signs also bore messages imploring the slugging catcher to stay in New York after this season.

title: Russians Defer A Vote, Buying Time for Talks
description: Hours after Russia's Acting Prime Minister finally laid out his program to pull the country out of its economic crisis, Parliament today put off a crucial vote on the new Government until Monday, buying more time for political negotiations.

title: Stanley Seiden, 76, Nederlander Leader
description: Stanley Seiden, an executive of the Nederlander theater organization, died on Aug. 27 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 76 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Civil Court Choices
description: Four Civil Court seats are being contested in New York City's Democratic primary on Sept. 15. The winners are almost certain to prevail in November's general election.

title: ANCHOR FINANCIAL SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE BAILEY FINANCIAL
description: The Anchor Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Bailey Financial Corporation for $56 million in stock. Anchor, based in Myrtle Beach, S.C., said the transaction, when completed late this year, would increase the banking company's total assets to $1.2 billion and expand its franchise to 34 offices in South and North Carolina. Bailey is the parent of M. S. Bailey & Son, Bankers and the Saluda County Bank in Clinton, S.C. Bailey has assets of $170 million.

title: For Clinton, Apology Is Test of Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: Things Change Stretches Saratoga Streak to Three
description: Nothing could be sweeter for a juvenile filly than to win at Saratoga, unless it is winning twice at Saratoga, or three times. And that is what Things Change achieved today when she won the 107th running of the Spinaway, casting the glow of tradition and promise on a career with a three-race winning streak.

title: Cleaning Up College Basketball
description: Jim Delany, commissioner of the Big Ten, recently announced a proposal for major reforms in N.C.A.A. Division I men's basketball, a sport that has witnessed far too many scandals involving recruiting and player behavior. These reforms will not be readily embraced by N.C.A.A. members and the National Basketball Association -- dramatic changes are always difficult to accept -- but they must be adopted if we are to cure the ills that afflict this sport.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISCHOF, LILLIAN E.
description: BISCHOF-Lillian E. Born in New York City, formerly of Lititz, PA. died Wednesday. She was a retired elementary school teacher in New York City. Her husband predeceased her in 1995. Survived by three daughters Beth Scholfield, Carol B. Wilson & Lynne McClure and brother William F. Ehret of Camillus, New York.

title: Dark Songs and a Smile In an Agile, Swedish Way
description: Eagle-Eye Cherry is a slender man, his fine bones lending him a foxy charm. Lightness makes for beauty in his music, too. The singer-songwriter, who is hoping his debut album, ''Desireless'' (The Work Group), will become the hit in the United States that it is in Europe, writes ballads whose rhythms carry their melodies like strings on balloons. And at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night, this buoyancy was the best aspect of his set.

title: KELLOGG IS CONSIDERING CUTTING SALARIED WORK FORCE
description: The Kellogg Company, the world's largest cereal maker, said yesterday that it might dismiss some of its 2,000 salaried employees in North America as it seeks to free up money for more advertising and promotions. The company, which makes Frosted Flakes and Rice Krispies, will review the work done by its headquarters staff and look at other administrative expenses. The three-month evaluation is aimed at helping Kellogg meet its goal of saving $100 million a year in costs. The review is the first major step by its new president and chief operating officer, Carlos Gutierrez, who took his post in June.

title: Neither Rain Nor Traffic Dampens Irish Warmth for Clinton
description: Harassed but smiling and even joking, President Clinton returned to Dublin today, as he promised he would on his first trip here in December 1995. But today's visit was very different.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Hints at Cut In Rates Amid Global Crisis

title: Coming Soon: The Bicoastal Primary
description: The California State Legislature voted this week to move its Presidential primary from June to the first Tuesday in March. If Gov. Pete Wilson signs the bill into law, it will virtually guarantee that the national Presidential primary system becomes a compressed melee in which nominations are awarded to the candidates with the most money and highest profile.

title: Leader For Irish Vows to Be Patient
description: Jarious Jackson has played on the punt return team, returned an onside kick for a touchdown and, in 28 minutes 41 seconds as Notre Dame's quarterback, managed four touchdown passes while completing 18 of 32 attempts. He has also been upbraided on national television by Lou Holtz, then the Fighting Irish coach, for capping a magnificent 21-yard run with a fumble in a game Notre Dame had already won.

title: A List of the 229 Passengers and Crew Killed on Flight 111
description: Following is a list of 215 passengers and 14 crew members killed in the crash of Swissair Flight 111, released by the airline. Ages and hometowns were provided by The Associated Press.

title: Hearings Resume On Players' Pay
description: The arbitrator John D. Feerick resumed hearings yesterday that will determine whether National Basketball Association players with guaranteed contracts will be paid during the lockout, which the owners imposed on July 1.

title: Enmity From School Strike Spreads to Town
description: Angry at the school board on the second day of the teachers' strike here, Joan Muso kept her two daughters home today. She said that no security checks had been completed on substitutes hired for $225 a day.

title: Four Crewmen Charged In Immigrant Smuggling
description: The four remaining crew members of a ship suspected of ferrying illegal Chinese immigrants to the United States were indicted yesterday in Federal court in Newark on conspiracy charges.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LOIS, HARRY JOSEPH
description: LOIS-Harry Joseph. 9/5/'58 to 9/21/'78. Today would have been Harry's 40th birthday. Rosemary, Luke and George Loi

title: One Year Later, Spirlea Defeats a Williams Sister
description: Irina Spirlea did last night what she could not do last year at the United States Open: beat a Williams.

title: Did We Expect Too Much of Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Speech
description: Following are excerpts from a speech last night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, at the Walter A. Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: On-Line Candor
description: To the Editor:

title: BOMBARDIER GETS $723 MILLION IN ORDERS FROM 2 AIRLINES
description: Bombardier Inc. has received orders totaling $723 million for its regional jets in a sign of growing demand for smaller planes serving less-traveled routes. Bombardier, based in Montreal, the third-largest maker of commercial aircraft, sold 12 of its new 70-passenger CRJ-700 planes and 15 of the CRJ-200, a 50-seat plane, to Atlantic Southeast Airlines for $575 million. In addition, the Midway Airlines Corporation ordered seven CRJ-200's for $148 million. Atlantic Southeast, a unit of ASA Holdings Inc., will use the planes to make longer flights from its hubs in Atlanta and Dallas-Fort Worth. Midway, based in Durham, N.C., will expand service from its Raleigh-Durham hub.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: What Drives Ken Starr?
description: With another special prosecutor, it could have turned out differently. But this one is the shadow Bill Clinton can't shake, and Kenneth Winston Starr's character has forever changed the President's destiny. A report by Michael Winerip.

title: Body Found Inside House Is Unexpected
description: Surprised law enforcement authorities revealed today that they had identified a woman they did not expect to find among the bodies investigators have unearthed from the tumbledown green home of an unemployed school aide and his family.

title: Water Is Safe
description: To the Editor:

title: Rail Services Acquisition
description: The Progress Rail Services Corporation will acquire most of the Kershaw Manufacturing Company of Montgomery, Ala., a maker of railway track and maintenance-of-way equipment. Terms were not disclosed. Progress, a supplier of railway equipment, is part of the Florida Progress Corporation.

title: Everybody Celebrates The Next One
description: EVERYBODY has been making a fuss over the natural, mechanical and pharmaceutical wonder of Mark McGwire's ever-thickening forearms.

title: Bring a Bowl
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Says Feminine Isn't Rowdy?
description: ''Step up to it,'' Rebecca Gates snarled into the microphone during her set at the Knitting Factory on Thursday night. She was singing a line from ''Love, the Lazee,'' a feisty song directed at a nervous lover. But her directive applied, for another reason. This bookish, smoky-voiced songwriter has been thrust into the ranks of artists trying to keep a feminine presence within aggressive rock, and she is stepping up to the task.

title: It's Official: Japan Is Still 'Slumping'
description: Japan's chief economic planner said yesterday that the economy had ''worsened further'' from last month and remained in a slump. ''At present there are no signs of a recovery in consumer spending,'' said Taichi Sakaiya, head of the Government's Economic Planning Agency. ''The Japanese economy is not anemic but has low blood pressure.''

title: The Web as Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Parcells Will Start Rookies Only if He Must (He Must)
description: While leading a Giants team on its way to the Super Bowl, Bill Parcells could virtually boast to his rookies: ''I don't need you.''

title: Dominicans' Favorite Son: Sammy Sosa, Home Run Hitter
description: These days, it is almost impossible to wander around Washington Heights without hearing the name Sosa on every block, in every store, in every apartment building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERETY, PIERCE
description: GERETY-Pierce. The Board of Directors and staff of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) are saddened by the tragic loss of Pierce on his flight to Geneva for the UN High Commission for Refugees. From 1980 to 1982 Pierce directed IRC's humanitarian work in Thailand for Cambodian refugees fleeing from the Khmer Rouge. Joining him in the effort was his wife, Marie de la Soudiere, who now directs IRC's program for children affected by armed conflict. When he finished his critical assignment for IRC, Pierce joined the United Nations where he continued his refugee work with the same outstanding courage, devotion, leadership and effectiveness that marked his years at IRC. The Gerety family has a distinguished history of service to the refugee cause. His father, Pierce J. Gerety, Sr., was an active IRC board member, & his brother Tom, President of Amherst College, is a current member. We will miss Pierce deeply. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Marie, and their three children, Sebastian, Pierce & Maeve, and all members of the Gerety family.

title: Payrolls Rose By 365,000 Last Month
description: Despite a sagging stock market and a growing trade deficit, America's labor market remains very solid.

title: TEXTRON OFFERS $326.5 MILLION FOR DAVID BROWN GROUP
description: Moving to expand its fluid and power systems operations, Textron Inc. has agreed to acquire the British engineering concern David Brown Group P.L.C. for $326.5 million, plus assumed debt. Textron, based in Providence, R.I., has interests in automotive, industrial and aircraft businesses. Last month, it agreed to sell its Avco Financial Services unit to Associated Capital of Dallas for $3.9 billion because the unit was not growing as quickly as its other businesses. David Brown, based in Huddersfield, England, makes industrial gears and mechanical and hydraulic transmission systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, PATRICK
description: BELL-Patrick. All of us at Tourneau mourn the tragic loss of our beloved Patrick, aboard Swissair Flight 111. He was a treasured member of our family. We extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to his parents, brothers and to all who cherished him.

title: And There It Goes: Chalk Up Another for Sosa
description: Sammy Sosa and Mark McGwire aren't giving Mark Grace much time to work out his etiquette problem.

title: In Maris's Proud Hometown, They Wait for an Era to End
description: If this had to be the baseball season when the home run record was smashed, Sandy Thiel had a small request: Please don't let it happen on her birthday, which is coming up in a few days. That, she says, would force her ''to remember it for the rest of my life.''

title: After Loss of Husband's Cash, McCaughey Ross Stays Upbeat, and Starts Fund-Raising
description: Her campaign account was $2.25 million lighter, a senior political aide was doubling as her driver and Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the wife of a millionaire and once the best-financed of the Democratic gubernatorial candidates, was yesterday facing a humbling task: calling people and asking for money to pay her campaign bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLSTERLI, ANDREW H.
description: BOLSTERLI-Andrew H. Of Geneva, Switzerland & New York City. Beloved son of Hans and Barbara Bolsterli, tragically perished on SwissAir flight 111, Wednesday, September 2nd, at the age of 25. Andrew is also survived by his sister Marina, his grandparents Mr. and Mrs. John H. Slade and his related families, Bolsterli, Weinberg, Wolf, Page, Slade and Gagnum. Andrew attended Trinity College in Hartford, Connecticut and the Culinary Institute Academy in San Francisco. He was currently employed by Restaurant Daniel in New York City. Andrew will live in our hearts forever.

title: Fido Should Get His Own Fountain
description: To the Editor:

title: Did We Expect Too Much of Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs; Two Commuter Airlines Given Tuesday Deadline
description: Secretary of Transportation Rodney E. Slater yesterday ordered two commuter airlines that suspended service last week because of the pilots strike at Northwest Airlines to resume flights to 17 small cities no later than Tuesday.

title: High School Athlete Died of Heart Disease
description: A freshman at Harrison High School died during a tackling drill at football practice on Wednesday because of heart disease, two weeks after a private doctor cleared him to play but advised the family to have him examined by a cardiologist, family members said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Political Briefing column on Aug. 15 misstated the involvement of the League of Conservation Voters in the Idaho Congressional campaign of Dan Williams. While the league has hired a full-time political consultant to promote Mr. Williams's candidacy and plans to spend $200,000 to promote his campaign, those actions are not directly connected to the Williams campaign. Under Federal law, the league must work independently, without coordination or contact with the candidate.

title: Russia's Desperate Economic Plan
description: Desperate political circumstances help explain the contradictory economic program proposed yesterday by Russia's Acting Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin. But it is hard to imagine how its successive phases of hyperinflationary expansion and ironclad austerity could possibly work. Russia needs daring economic boldness. But this plan comes dangerously close to incoherence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, WILLIAM
description: FUHRMANN-William. Enigmatic, loving loyal friend of Hunter, Jessica, Jimmy, Sarah, Andy, Jennifer, Denny and Lori. The silence is deafening. We will love you always and miss you forever.

title: Labor and the Left: Getting Cozy Again
description: Close partners through the first half of this century, organized labor and the intellectual left had an ugly breakup in the 1960's over Vietnam, integration and the vehemence of cold war anti-Communism.

title: When Rape Becomes Genocide
description: The guilty verdict the war crimes tribunal for Rwanda pronounced on Jean-Paul Akayesu this week marked the first judgment for the crime of genocide under international law.
