In making rape part of Mr. Akeyesu's genocide conviction, the decision also advances the world's legal treatment of rape and sexual violence.

title: For Clinton, Apology Is Test of Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tradition Remade in Brooklyn; West Indians Prepare a Lavish, and Popular, Pageant
description: A Brooklyn block lined with auto repair shops becomes an open-air rehearsal studio for three competing orchestras. As dusk falls on Parkside Avenue, quick, trained hands strike rows upon rows of carefully tuned oil barrels, mallets are beat on rusty tire irons, and the warm summer nights fill up with the syncopated sounds of calypso.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, ARTHUR J.
description: WEISBERG-Arthur J. Loving husband of the late Freda, adored father of Sidney Weisberg and Phyllis Rosenfield, their respective wife Elaine, and husband Ullman, and children Glen, Robert, Greg, Paul and Rick, and great grandchildren Danielle, Matthew, Stefan, Lukas, Zoe and Jacob. Private graveside service. In lieu of flowers please contribute to a cause of your choice.

title: ROYAL BANK OF SCOTLAND BUYS REST OF CITIZENS FINANCIAL
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland P.L.C. has purchased the remaining 23.5 percent of the bank holding company Citizens Financial Group Inc. it did not already own from the Bank of Ireland for $750 million. Citizens, based in Providence, R.I., is the third-largest bank in New England, with assets of $17 billion. Last month, the Bank of Ireland decided to exercise an option requiring Royal Bank to buy the stake. Under the agreement, Bank of Ireland will also receive $10 million to cover unrealized tax losses that resulted from Citizens' merger with First NH Bank in April 1996. Bank of Ireland is the parent company of First NH, and it received a 23.5 percent interest in the enlarged Citizens.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSTRIES, -- Honolulu, a utility company, said its HEI Power Corp., had paid $100 million for a 60 percent interest in a 206-megawatt coal-fired power plant under construction in China.

title: Katzenmoyer Plays; Ohio State Takes a Hit
description: ANDY KATZENMOYER is eligible to play; all's well in the world. All is certainly well in Columbus, Ohio, where Ohio State football is stronger than ever, now that Katzenmoyer and two teammates have been declared academically eligible to play in tonight's game at West Virginia.

title: $1 Million Offering for Ball To Aid Human Rights Case
description: A donor who asked to remain anonymous has offered to arrange payments totaling $1 million to the fan who catches the 62d home run ball by Mark McGwire or Sammy Sosa to help in the continuing search for justice in the 1980 murders of three American nuns and a lay worker in El Salvador.

title: Comedies of Manners, Laced With Morals
description: Alison Lurie is a transoceanic novelist, equally at home on both sides of the Atlantic, but with an even greater following in England than in the United States. Although she lives most of the year in Ithaca, N.Y., where she teaches children's literature at Cornell University, she keeps an apartment in London. She also has a home in Key West, Fla., the setting of her new novel, ''The Last Resort'' and, for her, a kind of neverland where fantasies are made real.

title: Labor and the Left: Getting Cozy Again; But Common Goals May Not Be Enough to Revive a Potent Alliance
description: For the last three decades, two groups that should be obvious bedfellows -- the labor movement and leftist intellectuals -- have far more often acted as enemies than as allies.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 22 about a 6-year-old boy in New Haven who died after signs of abuse misstated the number of disciplinary actions taken by New York City's Administration for Children's Services against caseworkers. Since December 1996, the workers dismissed for incompetence have totaled 26, not 1.

title: Massa Marittima Journal; Whatever's in the Lake, It's a Pain and a Puzzle
description: The crocodile that may eat Massa Marittima lives here.

title: Falling Prices For Oil Impede Iraq Aid Plan
description: Recent sharp drops in the price of oil have undermined a program under which Iraq can sell its oil to raise money for urgent civilian needs like food and medicine, the senior official in charge of the program told the Security Council today.

title: 12 Airmen Die As Two Copters Crash in Dark While Training
description: Two Air Force helicopters crashed early today on a nighttime training mission over a remote mountainous area in Nevada, killing all 12 crew members on both helicopters.

title: Court Bars Bells From Offering Long Distance
description: Dashing the main hope of the Bell local telephone giants for quick entry into the $80 billion long-distance business, a Federal appeals court in New Orleans reversed a lower court's decision yesterday that would have removed the main barrier between the Bells and the long-distance market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNETT, CARL F.
description: BURNETT-Carl F. of Schenectady, NY formerly of New York City. Died September 2, 1998. Husband of Frances Young Burnett. Father of Lawrence and Beverly Burnett. Grandfather of Naima. A memorial service will be held September 6th, St. Andrew's Church, Scotia, NY. Please send Memorial gifts to the Carl F. Burnett Scholarship, NYS Maritime College. For information Daly Funeral Home, 242 McClellan Street, Schenectady, New York 12304.

title: North Koreans Declare They Launched a Satellite, Not a Missile
description: North Korea said today that the purpose of its launching of a two-stage rocket on Monday was to carry a satellite into orbit, not to test a missile. It denounced Japan and other countries for jumping to the conclusion that it was launching a new class of missile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAZZALUPO, VINCENT
description: MAZZALUPO-Vincent, on September 3, 1998. Loving husband of Rosalie. Member of American Institute of Architects, he was an honorable man. Donations may be made in his memory to: Dicapo Opera Theater Vocal Competition Scholarship, 220 East 54 Street, New York 10022, Suite 11J, or Mazzalupo Architectural Fund, Pratt Institute Development Office, 200 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11205.

title: Irish Diaspora: The Pride Goes Along
description: Why, audiences may ask, would anyone want to get inside the head of a loud international soccer fan hanging around a German train station? As it turns out, that character, Eoin, an Irishman a long way from home, does have something worthwhile to say. But it takes him a long time and a lot of shouting to get there.

title: Priest in a Liberal Parish Loses His Job for Breaking Church Rules
description: When the Rev. James B. Callan says his last Mass at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church on Sunday, he can look back on a 22-year ministry that packed the pews on Sundays and created a battery of programs to help the poor, but that also moved so far from church rules regarding the roles of women, homosexuals and non-Catholics that he was removed from his job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JESSEN, ALBERT V., M.D.
description: JESSEN-Albert V., M.D. On September 3, 1998. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Garden City 2-5 and 7-9 PM Saturday and Sunday. Interment on Tuesday, at The Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Did We Expect Too Much of Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing Defendant Said to Claim Coercion
description: The former lawyer for a defendant charged in the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya said yesterday that his client was told by interrogators in Pakistan that the Government there wanted his confession in order to improve relations with the United States, which were damaged by Pakistan's test of nuclear weapons in May.

title: Despite Late Rally, Dow Ends a Bad Week 5.1% Lower
description: The stock market again flirted with the bears yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell below where it closed on Monday, the day of a 512-point plunge that shook up investors around the world.

title: Clinton Says He Is 'Very Sorry' After Senator's Harsh Criticism
description: Forced again on this five-day foreign trip to confront questions about the Lewinsky scandal, President Clinton said today that he ''basically'' agreed with Senator Joseph I. Lieberman who on Thursday criticized the President's conduct as ''immoral'' and ''disgraceful.''

title: Giants' First Option: Bigger Receivers
description: The Giants are the youngest team in the National Football League, just as they were last season. They will also return 20 of 22 starters from 1997.

title: INSIDE
description: Rwandan Leader Sentenced

title: Claims Processor Loses Contract With Blue Cross
description: Allied Specialty Services, a claims-processing company for four of New Jersey's largest health maintenance organizations, has been dropped by one of these managed care insurers, and its contract with another is being reviewed.

title: Huge Deployment Of Police Planned For Harlem Rally
description: Intent on preventing any outbreaks of violence, the Police Department plans to saturate the site of today's scheduled rally in Harlem with more than 250 officers along each of the six blocks set aside for the event.

title: Nomura Securities May Face Rating Cut
description: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest brokerage firm, may have its ratings cut by Moody's Investors Service on concerns about its profitability amid a nationwide recession and increasing competition brought about by Japan's ''Big Bang'' financial reforms. ''Stiff competition, deregulation and a deflating domestic economy pose significant problems for Nomura to solve for achieving sound and sustainable profitability levels,'' Moody's said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANOPOULOU, EUGENIA, PH.D.
description: SPANOPOULOU-Eugenia, Ph.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of Mount Sinai School of Medicine deeply mourn the tragic, untimely passing of our esteemed colleagues Eugenia Spanopoulou, Ph.D., and her beloved husband Andrew Hodtsev, Ph.D., along with their 18 month old son, Platon, in the crash of Swissair Flight 111 in Nova Scotia. An Assistant Professor in Mount Sinai's Derald H. Ruttenberg Cancer Center, Dr. Spanopoulou was a gifted researcher whose outstanding achievements led to her appointment last year as a Howard Hughes Medical Institute investigator, joining one of the Nation's most elite circles of scientists conducting cutting-edge work in cell biology, genetics, immunology, neuroscience and structural biology. Dr. Spanopoulou received her undergraduate degree in pharmacy from the University of Athens in 1983, her Master's degree in general biochemistry in 1984 from Chelsea College of the University of London, and her doctorate in molecular biology from Kings College of the University of London in 1990. She then worked as a postdoctoral fellow at Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Rockefeller University before joining Mount Sinai in 1995. Her research, which has appeared in numerous scientific publications, focused on the molecular mechanisms of the immune system and the potential role of those mechanisms in the onset of leukemia and lymphoma. Her husband was an immunologist who served as an instructor in the Ruttenberg Center. They were aboard the ill-fated flight en-route to her native Greece for their son's christening. They will be fondly remembered by all who knew them and their loss will be keenly felt. We extend our sincerest condolences to their families. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, MD, President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President

title: About New York; Youths' Voices Aren't Silent, Just Ignored
description: THE crossfire is an appropriate starting point for a discussion with the Rev. Dr. Anthony Nathaniel Lucas. Break the word down to its components and you have symbols of faith, suffering and redemption. Taken as one word, it is something that has touched Dr. Lucas's life when he has had to pray over the bodies of young people who died violently.

title: Work and Stress Lead to 'Depressive Reaction' : Norway Rallies Around Its Ailing Prime Minister
description: OSLO  When Kjell Magne Bondevik took over as prime minister of Norway last year, his ready smile and youthful vigor appeared to symbolize the sunny fortunes of this country's booming, oil-driven economy.

title: A Mostly Reliable Plane, But With Flaws in Its Past
description: The wide-body MD-11 built by McDonnell Douglas has been in service since 1990 and is widely regarded as safe and reliable, but Federal Aviation Administration records show that the plane has had a number of mechanical problems -- including some that posed fire hazards -- and several accidents.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Today's KEY GAMES

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think of it as the worst of everything in our culture. It's brutish. It's mean-spirited. And the guys look like they're heavy equipment stuck in the mud.''

title: Police Search Trailer Of Gunman Who Shot 3
description: State police here continued combing through the mobile home of a postal worker who opened fire on three state troopers on Thursday, trying to clear his trailer of numerous booby-trapped explosive devices and pipe bombs that the police discovered in the trailer after the shootings.

title: Reds Stump McGwire; It's 59 and Counting
description: When the Cincinnati Reds saw Mark McGwire in July, they walked him, then walked him again, walked him some more, and kept on walking him. With McGwire going into a three-game series with the Reds only two home runs away from Roger Maris's home run record, Jack McKeon, the Reds' manager, was asked whether he planned to have his pitchers repeat their July performance.

title: Treasuries Are A Bit Higher In Short Session
description: Treasury securities traded mostly higher in an abbreviated session yesterday, as a decline in stocks led nervous investors to seek safety in bonds.

title: Brokerage Firm Wins Approval For Electronic Futures Trading
description: Cantor Fitzgerald L.P. won approval today for the first computerized futures exchange in the United States, the latest in a global shift to electronic networks to replace the auction floors where traders shout orders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORREL, DR. NORMAN
description: MORREL-Dr. Norman. Temple Israel, Lawrence, New York mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends deepest sympathy to the bereaved family. Brooks R. Susman, Rabbi David M. Land, President

title: Moscow Plan: Spend Now, Save Later
description: As Viktor S. Chernomyrdin has battled to become Prime Minister, critics have wondered how he could placate the Communists and still take tough steps to rescue Russia from its deepening economic crisis.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about the United States Open tennis tournament misidentified Mary Joe Fernandez's opponent in the second round. She was Alexandra Fusai, not Anne Kremer.

title: When All You Need Is Love, For Starters
description: The Suffragette Sessions tour, which wound up its itinerary at Irving Plaza on Thursday night, can't avoid comparisons to the Lilith Fair. It was organized by the Indigo Girls, Amy Ray and Emily Saliers, who were part of Lilith this year; it was also a package tour of female musicians. But unlike Lilith, a day of performances by headliners and their bands, the Suffragette Sessions was one cooperative set in which all the women shared the stage, playing backup and singing harmony for one another. And the performers generally had the spotlight for two songs each, regardless of commercial status.

title: Analysts Warn of Dangers to Brazil's Economy
description: With Brazil's stock market in a nose dive and the Central Bank spending $1 billion a day to defend the currency, economists warned that despite the strengths of Brazil's economy, investor panic could plunge the region into decline.

title: Ferraro Offers Her Sharpest Criticism Yet of Clinton
description: On the first day of a three-day campaign swing in upstate New York, Geraldine A. Ferraro delivered her sharpest criticism yet of President Clinton's involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: H & R BLOCK SEEKS TO PURCHASE ACCOUNTING FIRM ASSETS
description: H & R Block Inc. said yesterday that it was buying the assets of the Chicago accounting firm Friedman Eisenstein Raemer & Schwartz L.L.P and three of its affiliates. Friedman Eisenstein Raemer & Schwartz has 28 partners and 175 full-time employees who provide accounting, tax and consulting services to individuals and small- to medium-sized businesses. The companies did not disclose terms of the transaction. Along with Friedman Eisenstein Raemer & Schwartz, H & R Block would get the assets of Practice Development Institute L.L.C., which publishes marketing newsletters and financial planning guides.

title: PARADE EVENTS: Caribbean Pride
description: These are some events connected to the West Indian American Day Carnival festivities:

title: F&M BANCORP PLANNING TO BUY MONOCACY BANCSHARES
description: F&M Bancorp, parent of Farmers and Mechanics National Bank, agreed yesterday to buy Monocacy Bancshares Inc. for $82.7 million in stock. F&M, based in Frederick, Md., which has total assets of about $1.07 billion, is buying Monocacy, parent of Taneytown Bank and Trust, to move into a contiguous region of Maryland, the bank said. F&M agreed to pay 2.22 million shares to purchase Monocacy, based in Taneytown, Md., and which has assets of $294 million. Based on yesterday's closing price, the purchase price would be $82.7 million, or about $45.97 a share. F&M's stock fell $1.75 a share yesterday, to $35.50. Monocacy closed unchanged at $32.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column on Aug. 18 about unfounded health scares referred incompletely to Government action on Alar, a chemical once used to make apples ripen uniformly. In May 1989, the Environmental Protection Agency announced steps to prohibit the use of Alar on apples and other foods, but allowed the chemical to stay on the market for at least 15 months. In the announcement, the agency said the chemical might pose an unacceptable risk of cancer in humans. Before the ban could take effect, the chemical's maker, Uniroyal, voluntarily removed it from the market. It is no longer used on food in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POHL, JOHN J., M.D.
description: POHL-John J., M.D. September 3, 1998, husband of Marilyn Eleanor Bennett Pohl, father of Mary Ellen (Pohl) Bork who is the wife of Judge Robert H. Bork, John B. and Thomas A. Pohl, brother of Arnold Pohl, M.D. and the late William Pohl, grandfather of Christopher J., Jeffrey J., Jennifer E., Timothy E., Katherine E., Jeanette E. and Matthew T. Pohl. Mass is at Saint Peter's Church, Troy, New York, September 5 today at 9:30 A.M.

title: Families' Last, Grim Task Is Just to Identify the Bodies
description: At first, whenever Janice Wallace closed her eyes, she could still see her big sister, Lori Moran, laughing and blowing kisses through the window of the taxi speeding toward Kennedy International Airport. For hours, she clung to that memory of Ms. Moran, a 34-year-old figure-skating coach who had planned to toast her third wedding anniversary in the French Alps.

title: Many Democrats Concur With Rebuke to Clinton
description: Congressional Democrats today began falling in line behind an influential Democratic senator who on Thursday excoriated President Clinton's behavior in the Lewinsky scandal as ''immoral'' and ''disgraceful'' from the floor of the Senate.

title: Of Those Boys of Autumn, Neither Beloved Nor Lauded
description: When the Pulitzer Prize-winning author David Maraniss decided several years ago to embark on a book about Vince Lombardi, legendary coach of the Green Bay Packers, he called his friend and fellow author Madeleine Blais to share the excitement.

title: BANKERS TRUST AGREES TO SELL INSURANCE BUSINESS
description: The Bankers Trust Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its insurance-products business to the RR Holding Company of Switzerland. Terms were not disclosed. Bankers Trust, based in New York, is one of the nation's largest banks, with assets of $172 billion. Its insurance unit provides risk and capital management products to insurers and reinsurers. RR Holding is a reinsurance company and unit of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the leveraged-buyout firm.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Aug. 26 about Vijay Singh's victory in the Professional Golfers' Association championship misidentified the language in which his given name means ''victory.'' It is Hindi. (Hindu is a religion, not a language.)

title: Robert Huebner, 84, Dies; Found Virus-Cancer Connections
description: Dr. Robert J. Huebner, whose genius as a medical detective in pursuit of viruses and other agents of disease became a major force in the battle against cancer, died on Aug. 26 at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Coatesville, Pa. He was 84.

title: Did We Expect Too Much of Russia?
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Win 100th as Torre Frets Middle Relief
description: The Yankees achieved their 100th victory tonight, the earliest date any team has reached that mark in the 20th century. They will continue to surpass or threaten other historical standards in the last three and a half weeks of the regular season.

title: Pioneer in Spotting Heart Disease Was Bound for Gene Conference
description: Dr. Roger Williams, a physician who pioneered the use of genetic data to identify people at risk for cholesterol-related heart disease, was among the 229 people who died in the crash of Swissair Flight 111 on Wednesday. He was 54.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SYMS MERNS, STEPHEN
description: SYMS MERNS-Stephen. The Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations extends its sincere condolences to our esteemed friend and supporter Sy Syms on the untimely passing of his beloved son. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mel Salberg, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: 6 Children Found Strangled After Mother Confesses to 911
description: A mother of six, living in poverty and estranged from her husband, called 911 on Thursday night, the police said, and made a shocking statement: she had killed her children.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Gentleman's Daughter

title: August 30-Sept. 5; Palestinians Execute 2
description: The first executions by the Palestinian Authority were hardly a paragon of justice. Only three days passed from the time members of the Abu Sultan family killed two brothers from the al-Khalidi clan to the time two Abu Sultan brothers were executed by firing squads in the Gaza police headquarters -- just time enough for some threatening protests in the streets, a quickie military trial and an O.K. from Yasir Arafat.

title: Glacier Hike
description: To the Editor: Timothy Egan's ''Alaskan Paradise Regained'' (Aug. 9) is a wonderful guide to Seward. There is, however, an on-shore attraction that rivals those at sea. Exit Glacier, part of Kenai Fjords National Park, is 12 miles from Seward. A trail, paved part way, leads close to the face of the glacier then rises along the edge. Here you can clearly see the blue ice caused by the densely packed snow's reflecting blue light.

title: Ronnee Hoffman, Karsten Pederson
description: Ronnee Jill Hoffman, the daughter of Sheila Hoffman and Dr. Lloyd R. Hoffman of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married last evening to Karsten Bjorn Pederson, a son of Rigmor and Ole Pederson of Farevejle, Denmark. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at Xaviar's, the restaurant in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Embassy Bombing Findings
description: Investigators in the embassy bombing in Tanzania say they have learned who transported the bomb and what it was made of. Page 14.

title: Q&A/Joy G. Dryfoos; Charting a Safe Course for Adolescence
description: AT 72, Joy G. Dryfoos, a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, still remembers her own crisis of identity as an adolescent. Years later, she watched her son as a teen-ager and wondered how he -- and the family -- would survive it. But they did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUGUST, ANNE
description: AUGUST-Anne. Beloved wife of Max. Mother of Joseph and Phyllis. Mother-in-law of Tsurah and grandmother of Luke and Marika. Shiva at August home in Woodstock.

title: Helped by a Flag, Vols Overcome McNabb
description: They don't do things the easy way up here at Syracuse. Right out of the gate, Coach Paul Pasqualoni wanted to see just what he had. No messing around. So he invited Tennessee, which is ranked 10th in the country, to the Carrier Dome to test his Orangemen, who are ranked 17th, in the season opener.

title: Still the Best Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLIN, GILDA AND RALPH
description: MALLIN-Gilda and Ralph. We sadly announce the tragic untimely death of our dear Gilda and Ralph Mallin, most loving parents of Michael and Martha, Danny, and Cindy and Philippe, adored grandparents of Melissa, Talya and Naomi. Beloved sister and brother-in-law to Carol and Phil, Bernie and Eva, and Elliott. They died together during the happiest days of their lives. Memorial service in NYC at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st St, on Thursday, September 10, at 10 AM. Memorial service in Boca Raton at Boca West Country Club, Monday, September 14, at 10 AM, in main clubhouse, Cyprus Room.

title: Mets' Phillips Makes Most of a Second Chance
description: When Tony Phillips rounded the bases in the eighth inning yesterday, after a two-run homer that capped a come-from-behind, 5-4 victory over the Atlanta Braves, he completed his trot with little flair. The veteran Phillips did not betray the emotion of the moment, but his Mets teammates could not help themselves. When he crossed home plate and headed to the dugout, they streamed out onto the steps to greet him and smother him in high-fives and handshakes.

title: Betsy Rosenberg, Jeffrey Eischen
description: Betsy Ann Rosenberg, the daughter of Donna D. Krieger of Wyckoff, N.J., and Richard K. Rosenberg of Denver, was married on Thursday to Jeffrey Dana Eischen, a son of Anne M. Goulet of Camillus, N.Y., and Dana E. Eischen of Ithaca, N.Y. Mayor Eileen Pilla of Tarrytown, N.Y., officiated there at Tappan Hill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORREL, NORMAN
description: MORREL-Norman, Dr. Beloved husband of Alice. Loving father of Andrew & Eva, Eric and Margery. Cherished grandfather of Veronica and Alexis. Dear brother of Dr. Melvin & Harriet Morrel. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'' Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, at 9:30 A.M. Sunday.

title: Free Willy: The Denouement
description: In Act I, Keiko the killer whale was found languishing in a tiny Mexico City amusement park in 1993, after his heart-tugging performance in the film ''Free Willy.'' In Act II, the privately funded Free Willy Keiko Foundation stepped in to bring the celebrity orca to the Oregon Coast Aquarium in 1996 for a cozy two-and-a-half-year recovery. Act III starts Sept. 9, when the foundation flies the world's biggest movie star to a sea pen in a protected bay of Iceland's remote Westmann Islands. There, Keiko will be reintroduced to the chilly waters he was captured from almost 20 years ago, in preparation for possible release into the wild. Then what? Well, various things could happen. Here's a look.

title: The Wasteland
description: AN EMPIRE WILDERNESS

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Looks Like a Bus, Acts Like a Subway
description: A bus system as speedy as a subway? It exists in the city of Curitiba in southern Brazil, which depends on a futuristic bus system to transport more than half its 2.3 million inhabitants every day.

title: Atoosa Behnegar and Ari Rubenstein
description: LIKE a French tulip, Atoosa Behnegar is tall and wiry, with skin so white it seems powdered, and wild black curly hair. She is 26, the senior fashion editor at Cosmopolitan magazine and looks like a cross between a runway model, an ''Addams Family'' character and a Shakespearean maiden from ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.''

title: Keep Economics Professors Out of Phone Deregulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Landlord Tells Doctors in the House It's Time to Go
description: When the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company built Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village in the mid-1940's, they created a self-contained community of 25,000 people, many of them families headed by returning war veterans. Stores ringed the red-brick complex and physicians, dentists and eye doctors occupied many of the buildings' ground-floor spaces.

title: Fiona Watt, Harold Neu
description: Fiona Shelford Watt and Harold Antonio Neu are to be married this afternoon by Robert Degnon, a Roman Catholic deacon, at Our Lady of Fatima Church in Wilmington, Vt.

title: Lives; Little Big Man
description: A few years ago I was finishing up an M.F.A. in creative writing when a dream job fell into my lap: $300 a week plus health care -- and it wouldn't aggravate my tendinitis. Baby-sitting. The setup was a little unusual -- the kid was 15 -- but that was Manhattan for you. A friend of mine baby-sat, more traditionally, for a 5-year-old while the maid and the cook were in the apartment.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTIMER, JOHN H.
description: MORTIMER-John H. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John H. Mortimer, associated with The Times from 1962, until retiring in 1983.

title: Ancient Evenings
description: COURTESANS & FISHCAKES The Consuming Passions of Classical Athens. By James N. Davidson. 372 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $25.95.

title: Correction
description: The Garden column on Aug. 23 about the plant Franklinia misstated the location of Twombly's Nursery. It is in Monroe, not Madison.

title: He's No Aaron
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Elizabeth Rudin, David Kaplan
description: Elizabeth Cara Rudin, the daughter of Susan and Ira Rudin of Belle Harbor, Queens, is to be married tonight to David Seth Kaplan, the son of Dr. Martin Kaplan of Lexington, Ky., and the late Hazel Kaplan. Rabbi David Lincoln is to perform the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: Led by Option, Irish Upset Michigan
description: They could not storm the courthouse over the summer. They could not overrun the National Collegiate Athletic Association for finding them in violation of rules. So the screaming, jumping Notre Dame faithful surged to the football field today for something they had not been part of in a while. A major upset: the Irish 36, No. 5 Michigan 20.

title: Many Think Kohl's Heir Would Run Better Race
description: In dire straits, a political party taps its most popular figure to lead the campaign to cling to power. Right?

title: Ms. Tillinghast, Mr. Dubitsky
description: Pamela Tillinghast, a daughter of Suzanne S. Tillinghast Bulkeley of Brookline, Mass., and the late Carlton W. Tillinghast, was married yesterday to Alexander Anatolievich Dubitsky, the son of Nina A. Dubitsky and Dr. Anatoly E. Dubitsky of Kiev, Ukraine. The Rev. Dr. David A. Usher, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of Christ in Mount Washington, Mass.

title: Mementos of a Moment and Its Movements
description: ''THERE'S more of everything,'' proclaims the slogan emblazoned across ''Watts 1963,'' a painting by Kerry James Marshall evoking the Nickerson Gardens housing project in Los Angeles, where he moved at age 8, in that politically and culturally momentous year. Those words are just one element in an elaborate interplay between realities and ideals in the 1995 painting's depiction of the project as a place of unexpected bliss. But they could also describe the modus operandi of an artist best known for grand, brilliantly realized canvases like this one, a visually and emotionally loaded meditation on black American life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANIELL, TATIANA (TANIA) LONG
description: DANIELL-Tatiana (Tania) Long. In Ottawa, on Friday, September 4, 1998. Widow of Francis Raymond Daniell, New York Times correspondent for 38 years in the U.S., Britain, Europe and Canada, deceased in 1969. Mother of Robert M. Gray, deceased in 1981. Herself, a newspaper correspondent first with the New York Herald Tribune, then for 25 years with the New York Times. Interment of cremated remains will be beside her husband in the Daniell family plot in the East Lawn Cemetery, East Haven, CT, USA.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, SIDNEY G.
description: EDWARDS-Sidney G. 91, of Bronxville, NY, died September 4, 1998. He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Juanita; his daughters, Melinda, Pamela Allara, and Roxanne; his son-in-law, Douglas Pirnie; his grandchildren, Mark and Ann Marie Allara, and his great-grandsons, Michael and Daniel Edwards Allara; and his sister, Mabel Barker of Oswego, KS. Born in Oswego, KS, Mr. Edwards graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Kansas University and received his LL.B. from Yale University Law School. He joined the New York firm now known as Debevoise, Plimpton in 1935 and retired as a senior partner in 1971. The funeral service will take place at the Scarsdale Congregational Church on Wednesday, September 9 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the United Way of Scarsdale-Edgemont or the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: Group Gives the Poor Clothes for the Office
description: DALLIANA TORRES was a woman on a mission. Like many other women spending a Saturday morning in pursuit of the perfect interview suit or office ensemble, Ms. Torres scanned the dress racks with an anxious if determined eye in her quest for an appropriate work wardrobe.

title: Generation Wallpaper; A tribe of newly affluent global nomads has a magazine to tell them who they are.
description: IF a tabloid television talk show decided to visit downtown Manhattan, Kelly Galligan and Ed Briggs -- proudly seated on a recently bought 1950's square-cornered sofa in their apartment -- would make ideal guests for an episode called ''We Traded the Grunge Life for an Eames Chair.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THEA, STANLEY
description: THEA-Stanley. Beloved husband of Frederica. Beloved father of Deborah and Donald. Cherished grandfather of Jackson. Funeral was private.

title: Editorial Observer; Japan's Prescription for Crisis: Be Timid! Be Timid! But Not Too Timid!
description: The frantic American efforts to get Japan to act boldly to cure its financial crisis remind me of the time my mother got sick in Japan and was rushed to the hospital, where the Japanese doctors' best attempts to reassure her went awry.

title: Jessica Greenfield and Paul Hummel
description: Jessica Anne Greenfield, the daughter of Harriet R. Greenfield of Newton, Mass., and Dr. Alan J. Greenfield of Boston, was married last evening to Paul Rudolf Hummel, a son of Margaret and Manfred Hummel of Underhill, Vt. Rabbi Wesley Odell officiated in the carriage house of the Museum of Transportation in Brookline, Mass.

title: On 'Live' Disks, Old Bands Keep Sounding Better
description: FANS of the rock singer Janis Joplin got an unexpected treat this summer when Columbia's Legacy series unearthed and issued a surprisingly strong 1968 live performance by Joplin and her original band, Big Brother and the Holding Company. It wasn't the singer's performance that was surprising. It was the band's. Though not without its charm, Big Brother was certainly no one's idea of a crack unit -- even by the loose standards of psychedelic San Francisco -- and the singer soon parted company with the group.

title: Scapegoating
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: OUT THERE: Duluth, Minn.; Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend
description: WHILE pampered millionaire ballplayers chased home-run records this summer, much of the upper Midwest was enthralled by a 5-foot, 8-inch, 140-pound pitcher with a shoulder-length ponytail and a uniform that read ''Duluth.'' Playing for about $1,000 a month, Ila Borders, the first woman ever to make the roster of a men's professional baseball team, electrified this chilly Minnesota town on Lake Superior.

title: August 30-Sept. 5; Airline Stalls State
description: While the Northwest Airlines pilots strike might have inconvenienced much of the country, most people probably made do with another airline or a delay. Not in North Dakota. There people were forced to do without the state's only major airline.

title: For Security, Safir Deploys A Small Army
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir left nothing to chance at the youth rally in Harlem yesterday, deploying thousands of officers in an overwhelming show of force that culminated when his forces stormed the stage and literally pulled the plug on the event.

title: Fatal Attractions
description: DEATH IN SUMMER

title: It's Only a Game. Or So You Thought.
description: The Duke of Wellington supposedly said that the battle of Waterloo was won ''on the playing fields of Eton.'' Indeed, many a valuable lesson is learned in games -- and that goes for business just as much as war. Some lessons may sting, but as these anecdotes demonstrate, they linger in the memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, DORA H.
description: WOLF-Dora H. November 27, 1902-September 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Joseph (deceased). Devoted mother of Howard (Arline), Seena (Fred) and Robert (deceased Syma). Cherished grandmother of Leslie, David, Debbie, Tracy, Shari. Great grandmother of Brian, Jeffrey, Michael, Joshua, Jeremy. Dear sister to Hilda and Bessie. She was truly a woman of valour. Services were held.

title: What Did Founders Expect From the Census?; Election by Sampling
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Newcomers Are Grounded by Turbulence
description: A PEEK at the Equity New Issue Calendar on a Bloomberg terminal last week read like a departure monitor at a fogged-in airport. ''Postponed.'' ''Delayed.'' ''Canceled.'' Indeed, as stocks struggled to climb back after Monday's selloff, not one company ventured onto the public markets last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEFALIDIS, NIKOS
description: KEFALIDIS-Nikos. The trustees, faculty and parents of All Souls School deeply regret the tragic death of the devoted husband of our Board President, Laurie Kefalidis, and the loving father of our graduates, Melanie, Elias, and Marisa. Nikos Kefalidis' generous support and wise counsel will be deeply missed. We extend our profound condolences to Laurie and to the entire family.

title: Antarctica's Summer Resort
description: AS we prepare to go ashore on South Georgia Island, a remote sliver of British territory 1,200 miles east of Cape Horn in the far southern Atlantic Ocean, it feels more like war than a holiday. Before the operation begins, we are summoned to a briefing in our ship's dining room. No one who misses it will be allowed into the Zodiacs.

title: What Do Thomas Jefferson and Tom Jones Have in Common?
description: Paul Graves didn't become interested in Wales because of his mother, who is of Italian heritage, or even because of Wales, where he spent part of his junior year abroad. The culture, the language and the taverns, where robust song would break out after a few pints of Brain's Brewery or Felinfoel's, captivated him immediately.

title: Seeds to Save, Seeds to Suppress
description: Save seed of heirloom vegetables and climbing vines like hyacinth bean. Pods of beans and peas left to dry on the vine give up their seed easily when rubbed gently. Store seed in labeled, airtight moisture-free containers like 35-millimeter film canisters.

title: The Primaries in New York; A Change in Endorsement Practice
description: For years, The New York Times has generally refrained from primary endorsements in major elections. We are altering that practice this year and anticipate doing so in the future. Primaries now often present the most critical and complicated choices that voters face in a campaign year. We feel readers have a right to see how we analyze these contests and which candidates we recommend.

title: Mapping the Trail Along the Aqueduct
description: IN 1842 when the old Croton Aqueduct first opened, two men actually traveled the length of the eight-and-a-half-foot-high masonry tunnel in a tiny rowboat. The trip, not for the claustrophobic, took 22 hours. These days, the tunnel is dry, but it is a historic landmark, and many people walk the land above it. Known as Old Croton Trailway State Park, it is a continuous 26.2-mile path, only 6 or so feet wide, which wends from Cortlandt to the Bronx border.

title: C.D.C. Warns of Flu In Alaska and Yukon
description: An investigation of a flu and pneumonia outbreak among travelers to Alaska and the Yukon Territory of Canada has identified 2,199 cases, including 71 of pneumonia. In summer, 70,000 tourists may visit the area each week, both on cruise ships and by land.

title: Penn State Answers Most of Its Questions
description: Penn State may get to celebrate Coach Joe Paterno's 300th victory next week, but No. 299 today will probably have a greater impact on the Nittany Lions' confidence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FIELDS, CAROL J.
description: FIELDS-Carol J. In memory of Carol J. Fields. There are more of us who miss you more each year. Love, The Family

title: Dealing With Bullies Before They Can Erupt
description: CINDY PIERCE LEE had planned to handle requests last year for 250 in-school programs dealing with conflict resolution, bullying, anger management and sexual harassment. But a rash of school shootings across the nation changed all that.

title: N.F.L. PREVIEW: The Battle for New York; Jets Are Relying on Martin For His Moves, and Makeup
description: There have been precious few times since 1968, the Jets' Age of Aquarius, when their fans could dream like this. But as the Jets headed to 3Com Park to open their 30th Super Bowl anniversary season today against the San Francisco 49ers, they brought many newfound clues in their search for lost glory.

title: Outwriting Disraeli?
description: To the Editor:

title: A.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: The Joys And Perils Of Betting On a Fall
description: MANY of the mutual funds that find themselves in good stead these days have something in common: big short positions.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Swimming, Boating And a Skyline View
description: Picture yourself floating on a lake, with white puffy clouds drifting overhead, silvery trout flitting beneath and sleek kayaks carving elegant wakes through the blue water. Slowly, you lift your head and gaze languidly up at . . . Fifth Avenue.

title: New Sports Bar With a D.J. and Food
description: Bellview might be considered a good name for a bar with French doors opening onto Bell Boulevard. And so it was when the Bellview Bar and Grill opened last month in Bayside, Queens, between 39th and 40th Streets.

title: Ms. Saroff, Dr. Singerman
description: Laurie Beth Saroff, a legislative counsel for the National League of Cities in Washington, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Richard Warren Singerman, the president of Bioquest, a biotechnology company in Washington. Rabbi Alvin Berkin is to perform the ceremony at the Tree of Life Synagogue in Pittsburgh.

title: Commercial Property/The Reuters Building at Times Square; A Corporate Headquarters Next to Bugs and Mickey
description: AS the next addition to the revival of Times Square, the Reuters building on the blockfront between 42d and 43d Streets on Seventh Avenue faces an unusual design challenge. It is intended to blend the dignity of a major corporate headquarters with a location that has Bugs Bunny and Mickey Mouse as its immediate neighbors.

title: Revenge of the Sissies
description: To the Editor:

title: Surf on Seventh
description: Seventh Avenue's going surfing. Designers, stylists and fashion executives are catching the surf craze, and not just by making beachy clothes. Camp Pascowitz, a family-run surf camp at San Onofre State Beach in California, counts movie executives and rock stars (Perry Farrell, Chris Isaak, Flea and his daughter) among its clientele. But now it is noticing an influx of would-be boarders from the East Coast, particularly the garment trade, said Izzy Pascowitz, the owner. ''We've had this huge draw of fashion people,'' he said. ''Editors, executives from Versace and Louis Vuitton, the marketing director of Hugo Boss.'' Stylish New Yorkers aren't the only ones who have realized that just looking like a surfer doesn't cut it anymore. Any day now the Pascowitzes are expecting the beach-blond Hanson family. ''They look like such surfers,'' Mr. Pascowitz said of the band, which is from Oklahoma. ''It's a pity they don't actually surf.''

title: August 30-Sept. 5; Reno Opens the Door To Campaign Inquiries
description: For two years, Attorney General Janet Reno resisted calls that she seek independent investigations of allegations that Democrats violated election funding laws in the 1996 campaign. Now she has opened the door.

title: Ex-Little Leaguers; The Boys of Summer Once Really Were Boys of Summer
description: PICTURES of the Little League champions from Toms River, N.J., standing proudly next to their Yankee counterparts during the National Anthem at Yankee Stadium last Tuesday did more than give the kids the second thrill of their lives in a week. They evoked the fact that the big leaguers once were Little Leaguers themselves, sporting baggy uniforms and major league dreams.

title: Courtney Murphy And John Hewson
description: Susan Courtney Murphy, a daughter of Martha-Reed and John Lacey Murphy of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to John Pritchard Hewson, a son of Jane Pritchard Bagby of Stevenson, Md., and the late Roswell Keach Hewson. The Rev. Pierre Baker, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with the Rev. Dr. L. Murdock Smith, an Episcopal priest, at St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church in Keene, N.H.

title: Ideas & Trends; Eat Your Heart Out
description: The North Pole has long since been reached. Astronauts have walked on the moon. The summit of Everest will soon need a traffic light. But until last month, no one had tossed a two-ton Caesar salad. Food: the final frontier. Somewhere out there, in the undiscovered country that lies beyond small, medium and large, someone is creating very big food. It might be a 10-foot-tall Godzilla made of 14,000 pieces of bread, or a quiche Lorraine with an eight-foot radius. It might be a dumping the size of a city dump, like the one unveiled in Bangkok last month, or a 21,000-egg omelet (those Thais again).

title: Political Briefing; California Ponders Question of the Month
description: If Gov. Pete Wilson signs a bill just sent to him by the California Legislature, the 2000 Presidential primary in the nation's most populous state will be held on March 7 instead of in early June, as in most years past. And if that happens, March 7, 2000, could turn out to be one dilly of a day in American politics.

title: Applause for Speech on Lieberman's Turf
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's hometown reacted with relief to his extraordinary rebuke of President Clinton on the floor of the Senate, with both Democrats and Republicans saying that he spoke for them, and that it was about time someone did.

title: Diane Goldberg, Michael Marcus
description: Diane Lesley Goldberg and Michael Roberts Marcus were married on Friday by Rabbi Connie Golden at Belvoir Terrace, a performing and fine arts summer camp for girls in Lenox, Mass.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Warning: This Restaurant May Be Hazardous
description: Los Angeles County has 20,000 eating places, New York City has 18,000 and each locale has a few million residents obsessed with one or another of them. New Yorkers who recall the last time they enjoyed a meal out, only to have suffered through a bout of food poisoning hours later, might appreciate the new, more stringent approach toward inspections taken by Los Angeles.

title: Foreign Expansion: Well-Planned Or Ill-Timed?
description: ARTHUR M. BLANK, the president of Home Depot, was brimming with optimism as he left Atlanta the other day on his way to visit his first store outside North America, a store that sits at the foot of the snow-capped Andes, flies the Chilean flag and houses a McDonald's franchise.

title: FILM; Restoring the Touch Of Genius to a Classic
description: Orson Welles (as Hank Quinlan, drunk): ''Read my future.''Marlene Dietrich (as Tana): ''You haven't got any.''Welles: ''Huh?''Dietrich: ''Your future's all used up. Why don't you go home?''-- A scene from ''Touch of Evil''

title: Study the Trees Closely, But Just Skim the Forest
description: PETER LYNCH has a thought about the global market meltdowns that have been a consuming nightmare for many investors over the last year. ''The world,'' he said last week, ''will be O.K.'' Next topic, please.

title: Ballet Company Director Announces He Is Leaving
description: Septime Webre, the artistic director of the American Repertory Ballet in Princeton and New Brunswick for the past five years, has resigned as of the end of the current season to direct the Washington Ballet.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Schools Expanding to Match Growth in Enrollment
description: WHEN children attending the Munsey Park and Shelter Rock elementary schools start classes Tuesday, they will be greeted by new classrooms and new upgrades to their buildings.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Inge Aicher-Scholl, 81, a German Whose Writing Inspired Pacifists
description: Inge Aicher-Scholl, who inspired a generation of pacifists in post-World War II Germany by writing about an anti-Nazi youth movement and the killing of her brother and sister, died on Friday. She was 81, and suffered from cancer.

title: Giving Teen-Agers a Chance to Play, a Chance to Mourn
description: Fun will be mixed with sadness at the Fairview Lake YMCA Camp in Stillwater Sept. 18 to 20, as the Karen Ann Quinlan Hospice conducts a camp for teen-agers learning how to cope with the loss of a loved one. Camp Connections, in the Sussex County hills, will house about 25 young people who have lost a parent, sibling, friend or anyone else close to them. The fee is $25 a camper. Information about the camp can be obtained at (973) 383-0115. Marlina Schetting, the director of social services for the Karen Ann Quinlan Hospice,talked about Camp Connections.

title: How the Knee Became the Back
description: Well, I did it playing soccer at the age of 42, but before you start muttering, Geez, what did she expect, let me tell you some of the other ways overenergetic baby boomers do it: playing tennis, playing basketball, playing volleyball, playing softball, downhill skiing, diving sideways for a Frisbee at the beach or making one rapid feint in the spur-of-the-moment touch-football game that seemed like such a good idea until the part with the writhing and the screaming and the panicky-faced people running for ice and a medic. Myself, I don't remember that part precisely. I do remember opening my eyes and perceiving that I was on my back. The central midfielder was looking down at me with an expression that alarmed me as much as the pain did.

title: China Mission
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano left yesterday on a trade mission to China to foster business, technology, educational, cultural and child-advocacy ties between Westchester and the world's largest country. He is leading an 18-member delegation, which includes business, government and education representatives from the county.

title: Shopping at Outlet Centers
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''A few months ago people were talking about seeing the light at the end of the tunnel. Now the only hope is keeping the world economy from total deterioration. And you get a sense that this is all now truly left to Adam Smith's invisible hand -- it's beyond any country's ability, any institution's ability, to control.''

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Notes From the Underground: Subways From Paradise
description: If the New York City subway system could die and go to heaven, it might find itself in London, where underground station assistants approach lost-looking passengers to ask if they need help, electronic boards post the number of minutes until the arrival of a train, and signs near escalators alert users to stand on the right. (Walkers are supposed to keep to the left.)

title: Monty Python, Woody Allen and Then Some
description: THE fall season of the New Jersey Film Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, opens on Friday with Barbara Kopple's documentary ''Wild Man Blues.'' Ms. Kopple is to answer questions after the screening of her film, which follows Woody Allen and his jazz band through an 18-city tour in Europe. The film offers a rare glimpse into Mr. Allen's private side, including his relationship with Soon-Yi Previn before their marriage last year.

title: No Threat to the New
description: To the Editor:

title: College Fund-Raising
description: In a successful fund-raising campaign, the College of New Rochelle has raised $19.5 million -- $1.5 million more than its goal, said Lenore Carpinelli, a spokeswoman for the college.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: PINDAR not only crushes grapes, it also crushes the competition.

title: Lisa Montgomery And James Hill
description: Lisa Louise Montgomery and James John Hill are to be married this afternoon by the Rev. Dr. F. Victor Metivier at the Chautauqua Institution, the cultural organization, in Chautauqua, N.Y.

title: Los Angeles Officer Is Held in Drug Theft in Unusual Graft Case
description: As a police officer in Los Angeles's busiest precinct, near downtown Los Angeles, Rafael Antonio Perez was responsible for investigating gang crimes and testifying against suspects in court.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town
description: NEW YORK, as New Yorkers will tell you, invented what it means to be a modern city. E. B. White wrote in ''Here Is New York,'' a 1949 essay, that the city is ''the concentrate of art and commerce and sport and religion and entertainment and finance.'' Most everything else, New Yorkers will not have to add, is from out of town.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERSON, BEATRICE (NEE MANDELBERG
description: BERSON-Beatrice (nee Mandelberg). Of Fair Lawn, NJ. On September 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Dudley J. Loving mother of Judith, of Miami Beach, Stuart of Mahwah, and Anita of New York City. Devoted grandmother of D. Jordan and Dana. Compassionate and generous friend.

title: Anthony Cullen, Joyce Yao
description: Joyce Jo-Lin Yao, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dick K. Yao of Denville, N.J., was married yesterday to Anthony Matthew Cullen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Cullen of Buck Hill Falls, Pa. The Rev. Daniel O'Shea, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Chapel at the Oak Knoll School of the Holy Child in Summit, N.J.

title: The Big City; Burgher Kings
description: This month the Museum of the City of New York will unveil a drawing, recently uncovered in an Austrian archive, that scholars believe is the oldest picture of the city. It's a view from Governor's Island of Manhattan's lower tip, where a tiny dock juts out near the spot where the Staten Island Ferry Terminal sits today. The drawing apparently dates from about 1650, when New Amsterdam was barely a quarter-century old and was inhabited by fewer than 800 people. The downtown skyline has changed a bit since then, but in some ways that town wasn't so different from Rudolph Giuliani's New York.

title: Oregano: From Garden Excess to Essential Ingredient
description: OREGANO threatens to take over the herb garden at this time of year (with mint as a close runner-up), spreading its roots wherever it can. I use it for pizza toppings, ragu sauce or with tomatoes and lamb, but I always have far more than I want. The leaves have a sharp, spicy taste, similar to marjoram, but I often pass them by in favor of basil.

title: MILITANT LEADER WAS A U.S. TARGET SINCE THE SPRING
description: United States intelligence officials drew up secret plans last spring for a covert raid to capture Osama bin Laden in Afghanistan, according to senior United States Government officials.

title: Ms. Liebman, Mr. Ruderman
description: Suzanne Jill Liebman, a daughter of Sandra and Jay Liebman of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married last evening to Stephen Howard Ruderman, a son of Charlotte Ruderman of Great Neck, N.Y., and the late Robert Ruderman. Rabbi Philip H. Berkowitz officiated at the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton.

title: Vintage Goodies, Including Bad Art
description: Disparate items like ice buckets and lamps share the selling floor with clothes, furniture and appurtenances from the 1930's to the 1970's at Honeymoon, a store that opened in the East Village this summer at 105 Avenue B, between Sixth and Seventh Streets.

title: Lynne Brady, Andrew Wagner
description: Lynne Candace Brady, a speech-language pathologist at the Spaulding Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston, was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Jay Wagner, a resident in internal medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. The Rev. Elizabeth Smith, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Pen Ryn Mansion in Bensalem, Pa.

title: Bid for New Office Headed to Board
description: IN his closing years in office, former Westchester County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke found that the Board of Legislators, even when controlled by his own Republican Party, was not going to rubber stamp his actions. In his first year in office, Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat and the current County Executive, is finding the same thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, GENEVIEVE KOLCZYNSKI
description: ROTH-Genevieve Kolczynski. 91, of Rockville Centre, New York passed away peacefully September 4, 1998 at her home of 63 years. Beloved wife of the late Arthur T. Roth, and loving mother of Donald Roth and Carol Madigan, she also leaves their spouses Trish Roth and Jay Madigan, five grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Friends may call at Macken Mortuary, 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre from 2-4 and 7-9 PM on Sunday and Monday. Entombment will be at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, following a Mass of the Resurrection at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre on Tuesday at 11 AM. The memory of her unfailing kindness, generosity and strength will be cherished by all who knew her.

title: In Minnesota, Due North
description: THE urge to strap on 10 pounds of gear and walk boldly through thickets of pine trees and mosquitoes is not something that often overcomes this suburban- and city-bred traveler. But in late summer the New York air coagulated into a steamy soup, and a wilder landscape began insisting its way into my daydreams: a steep trail marked by carefully stacked stones, an icy lake dotted with aluminum canoes, the rustle of leaves and invisible critters. Ruefully, I realized where my imagination was taking me -- to my Girl Scout sleepaway camp in New Jersey, circa 1966.

title: The Nation: Roll 'Em; Feeling Secure Is a Risky Business
description: AMERICANS who never fought a war or feared a depression could be forgiven for imagining a risk-free world. Living high and mighty, consuming more than their share of the world's food and fuel, feeling secure within their borders and even reasonably safe outside them, they could envision a boundless zone of security in which American money and power and culture and technology would insure some sort of peace.

title: From Miller Lite To the Making Of Movies Lite?
description: TAKING up a whole page in Daily Variety recently was a story about a young six-man Swedish advertising team known as Traktor that had been signed to direct a feature film in the United States. (Albeit a small one by Hollywood standards, a mere $10 million.) The article explained that Traktor's ''idiosyncratic sensibilities'' had been applied to some 200 commercials. The group, it seems, directs in pairs, giving it ''the good benefits of being four eyes,'' the piece went on to say.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Sending Students Out Into the World Well-Prepared . . .
description: WHO -- Jay Doolan, 51, Trenton, director of the Office of Standards and Professional Development in the state Department of Education. He is in charge of developing the practical guides that teachers will use to meet the core curriculum standards adopted by the Education Department in 1996.

title: Attorney General Candidate Is Assailed on Jail Management
description: Two Democratic candidates for state attorney general have criticized another candidate, State Senator Catherine M. Abate, asserting that she failed to root out brutality by guards at the Rikers Island jails while she was New York City's Commissioner of Correction in the early 1990's.

title: THE MARKETS IN TURMOIL: THE CLUB; Panic? No, Just a Search For Value in The Long Run
description: THE Pennsylvania Caveat Emptor Investment Club has its routine: Members convene on the first Wednesday of each month to review the club's stock holdings, analyze new companies and vote on new stock purchases.

title: Correction
description: The Garden column on Aug. 23 about the plant Franklinia misstated the location of Twombly's Nursery. It is in Monroe, not Madison.

title: Building a Spa, Despite Fire and Cancer
description: DE CAPRIO. In Fairfield County, at least, the name was associated with looking good way before Leonardo -- with a ''di'' spelling -- became a celluloid sensation. In fact, beauty has been Noel de Caprio's business for more than 40 years. And she needed no starpower, riding instead on the inspirations of fire, air, water, earth and heaven.

title: Citizen Tribute
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Baltimore's Downtown Neighborhood'' (Aug. 2) was very interesting, but despite the caption on the picture of the monument in Mount Vernon Square, I believe the first monument erected in this country to George Washington was built on July 4, 1827, on South Mountain, Md., by the citizens of Washington County. The rough stone structure still stands, adjacent to the Appalachian Trail. The monument has additional historic significance in that it was used as a signal station by Union troops throughout the Civil War, but most notably during the battle of Antietam. I was involved in its rehabilitation in 1995.

title: Q and A
description: London Architecture

title: Uniting Against Garbage Close to Home
description: The court-ordered deadline for closing the Fresh Kills landfill is still more than three years away, but three community groups in Brooklyn are already planning joint strategy against construction of waste-transfer stations in their neighborhoods.

title: Mishi Hosono, Adam Weintraub
description: Mishi Hosono and Adam Raphael Weintraub were married last evening by Rabbi Paul Swerdlow at the New York Hall of Science in Flushing, Queens.

title: Ms. Perera, Mr. Patterson
description: Katherine Thorne Perera, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Perera of Northampton, Mass., and Michael Ellmore Patterson Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Patterson of New York, were married yesterday in South Dennis, Mass. The Very Rev. James Munroe, the dean of Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral in Springfield, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of South Dennis.

title: Ms. Fisherman And Mr. Ruff
description: Jennifer Anne Fisherman and Michael Neal Ruff were married Thursday evening by Rabbi Robert Widom at the University Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWID, DOROTHY ZIES
description: SWID-Dorothy Zies. On September 3, 1998, of West Palm Beach. Loving wife of the late David. Loving step-mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt and great-aunt. Devoted high school math and physics teacher in the New York public school system, retired after 30 years. Services Tuesday, September 8, 10 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTINBAND, GERDA
description: MANTINBAND-Gerda. Widow of Prof. James Mantinband, died Wednesday, September 2, in Boulder, CO. Memorial service to be held on October 25. Friends are invited to send memories to be shared at the service to: Peggy Mantinband, 2990 Eagle Way #

title: Something's Fishy
description: MACKEREL BY MOONLIGHT

title: As Teachers, The Modest Are Often The Best
description: TEACHERS come in different shapes and sizes, and finding the right fit might sort out some of the educational controversies going on at the Tanglewood Festival up in Lenox, Mass. The troubles have been well rehearsed in these pages, and are not likely to go away when the season ends this weekend. Have Tanglewood's long-respected summer programs been emasculated by dismissals and resignations, or have they been reinvigorated by a new involvement on the part of the Boston Symphony and its music director, Seiji Ozawa?

title: Suit Due On School Financing
description: WHEN the county's schoolchildren return to their classrooms for the new academic year this week, they will be carrying more than new backpacks and supplies. Along with reams of lined paper and pens is their potential, as yet undiminished by difficult courses or unsympathetic teachers.

title: Miss Huntington And Mr. Ball
description: Elizabeth Gallagher Huntington, the daughter of Eleanor and Robert Hubbard Huntington of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Trevor Ball, the son of Jeanne MacIntyre of Winhall, Vt. The Rev. Michael O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Equinox Hotel in Manchester Village, Vt.

title: Cop Moms
description: It was 1951, and postwar booms in children and traffic were in uneasy juxtaposition. Concerned about safety in walking to school, members of the P.T.A. of Oakland Street School in Red Bank came up with the idea of posting mothers at especially dangerous intersections to guide children safely across. The P.T.A. president, Esther Long, and about 10 other ''cop moms,'' as they became known, became the first crossing guards in America -- at least, as far as she knew. So noteworthy was the development that the Encyclopedia Britannica published a photograph of her on the job at Pearl and Monmouth Streets under the ''Police'' entry in its 1952 yearbook. The school was closed about 20 years ago (it is now a restaurant), but crossing guards are commonplace, though now mainly paid. Esther Long Bragar, the founding cop mom, still lives in Red Bank. Her life has been uneventful, she says; ''my one claim to fame is that I was in the Encyclopedia Britannica.''

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; How About a Piece Of the Brooklyn Bridge?
description: Hey, buddy, want to buy a manhole cover? How about a park bench, parking meter or some other bite of the Big Apple? Boston, Chicago, San Diego and San Francisco all sell used, surplus and salvaged bits of themselves. Could there be gold in New York's municipal junk?

title: A School's Summer Pause Becomes Permanent
description: When the private Fielday School closed in late May for its traditional break between the school year and the start of its summer program, neither parents nor students suspected it would never reopen.

title: Trash Is Her Bag
description: Trash inspired Leah Singer to start her own newspaper. Working as a freelance graphic artist, she was captivated by Rubyliths -- orange acrylic masking films used by commercial artists to make silhouettes. She dug some out of a wastebasket and, she said, ''fell in love with them -- they were so strange.'' She collected silhouettes including a Buddha, a roller skater and a woman with a gun, and produced 1,000 copies of a 16-page all-graphics ''newspaper'' called Copy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REARDON, JAMES E.
description: REARDON-James E. Author of ''The Sweet LIfe of Jimmy Riley'' and ''Big Time Tommy Sloane'', died suddenly on August 17 in Deerfield Beach, FL at the age of 80. Formerly of NYC & Westport, CT. he was predeceased by his loving wife of 55 years Marjorie, and eldest son Michael. He is survived by his daughters Sheila, Valerie, Jane and Julie and son, James Jr., 13 grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. A memorial service is to be announced.

description: A Ved Mehta Reader

title: TO DIAL FOR: 'ELEMENTS,' FROM SPIEGEL
description: 87 pages; Rapid City, S.D.; (800) 778-5555

title: Justice First
description: WAR CRIMES

title: A Club's Heirloom: Benches on the Beach
description: THE benches are ordinary, as benches go: thick-planked wood painted bright blue and green. One hundred thirty of them, lined up in rows on the beach, glistening in the noonday sun.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Door to Nowhere

title: PEEP GALLERIES
description: * New York's 144 sex shops are staggering from Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's attack, but there's another outlet for adult entertainment: Manhattan's art world. * The Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea represents Andres Serrano's photograph series ''A History of Sex,'' which includes a naked woman fondling a stallion. * This year, the Jack Tilton Gallery in SoHo unveiled ''Self Portrait Porno Show,'' a live staging of a man and a woman engaging in raunchy sex. * On Sept. 12, Matthew Sandager rides the wave by presenting ''Eros Electronica,'' devoted to video artwork about sex. * Sample: ''Eros & Thanatos,'' by Grahame Weinbren, a one-minute edited video of Kinsey Institute footage of copulating animals. * Next up: the American Fine Arts Gallery on Wooster Street, which this week mounts an exhibit of nude photographs of Brooke Shields -- taken when she was 10.

title: Ms. Shaw, Mr. Williamson
description: Victoria Louise Shaw, a daughter of Marijane Shaw and Donald H. Shaw, both of Manhattan, is to be married this afternoon to James Gerard Williamson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Williamson of North Babylon, N.Y. Bishop Catherine S. Roskam, the Episcopal Suffragan of New York, is to perform the ceremony at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, MARTIN J.
description: CHAPMAN-Martin J. On September 4, 1998. Ret. Major World War II. Beloved husband of the late Felixia. Devoted father of Martin, Stephen, and Catherine Martinis. Dear grandfather of Patricia Dombroff, Christine & Philip Chapman. Great grandfather of two. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th St.) NYC, Sunday 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial at Epiphany RC Church, Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Making a Fight Against Cancer Fashionable
description: IT'S not every day that Donna Karan acts as a stylist for anyone but a runway model. But on an August afternoon on Terry Lane in East Hampton, Ms. Karan found herself at the home of Elizabeth Tilberis, the editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, counseling women on what to buy and how to wear it, and draping her sweaters over Hamptons-tan passers-by with the ardor of a SoHo street vendor. The event was a garage sale to benefit the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund, an organization presided over by Ms. Tilberis.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORTS: GREENWICH VILLAGE -- BUZZ; Viewing Downtown Through a Big Window
description: THE SETTING At the end of the aisle -- filled with dusty ceiling fans, fuzzy purple Barney slippers on sale for $6.99 and bright yellow back-to-school signs advertising notebooks and lunch boxes -- lies the KCafe, a cafeteria on the upper level of the Kmart store at 770 Broadway, near Eighth Street. On a recent afternoon, a few regulars gazed out the huge arched windows at the sweeping view of lower Manhattan.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: UPPER MANHATTAN

title: Julie Guttrich, Irving Barrett
description: Julie Anne Guttrich, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon L. Guttrich of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to Irving Berlin Barrett, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Barrett of New York. The Rev. Nigel Lyon Andrews, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Ned C. Watts Jr., a Methodist minister, at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHSON, MALVINA K.
description: MACHSON-Malvina K. On September 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Eddie. Loving mother of Laurie. She was loved and admired by her family and so many friends. Service Sunday, 1:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Not All the Best Asters Were Educated in Europe
description: IN the garden, as elsewhere, refinement is often viewed as a plus. Take New England and New York asters, for example. Among the first plants to catch the eyes of European settlers, they were sent abroad about 300 years ago and went to finishing school in the hands of British and German nurserymen.

title: As Ruble Withers, Russians Survive on Barter
description: Russia's currency may be tumbling. Its stock market may lie in ruins. But Yevgeny Shulman is used to operating without money.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 6, 1998
description: Weeks

title: As Banks Falter, Russians Search for Their Savings
description: With a bitter wind biting at his cheeks on this unusually cold but clear Saturday morning, Yevgeny Ushakov arrived at his local bank branch to find the doors closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCATURRO, ROSARIO
description: SCATURRO-Rosario. On September 4, 1998, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved husband of Frieda. Loving father of Charles and Catherine. Also survived by three grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Sunday and Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Mary's R.C. Church, Manhasset. Entombment St. Johns Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Coming Soon: 3 New Features
description: Later this month, Money & Business will publish a group of new features that invite readers' participation.

title: New Season of Events at Purchase College
description: HERE is a preview of events planned for the new season at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College.

title: They Got Game, And Laundry Too
description: Eight months before the W.N.B.A. ever played a game, the American Basketball League (A.B.L.) tipped off its first season of professional women's basketball in the United States. Unlike the W.N.B.A., the A.B.L. plays during basketball season, plays a longer season and pays all its players a living wage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLSTERLI, ANDREW
description: BOLSTERLI-Andrew. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York extend our deepest sympathies to John and Marianne Slade, our most cherished friends, on the sudden and tragic loss of their grandson, Andrew Bolsterli. May the memories of this special person bring comfort to John and Marianne; Andrew's parents, Hans and Barbara Bolsterli; his sister, Marina; and the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. VP

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARSALA, KATHRYN TERASE
description: MARSALA-Kathryn Terase. We miss your sense of humor, your good counsel and above all your friendship. We miss you. With love, Lila and Susa

title: SOAPBOX; Mega-Merger With Mini-Benefits
description: THIS summer marks the anniversary of the merger between Nynex and Bell Atlantic, a marriage that was hailed as a means of introducing new technology and lower prices. What the local consumer got instead was a mega-phone company that remains indifferent to innovation, intimidates competition and provides few economic benefits to the region's businesses and homeowners.

title: SOAPBOX; Back to Back to School
description: I WOULD never miss the first day of school. I consider it one of the perks of my job as director of special services, all the services not related to the general curriculum, like special education teachers, nurses, guidance counselors and so on. I try to avoid meetings, conferences, presentations or budget processing on that special morning.

title: BOOKEND; Slush!
description: From time to time, book publishers have their junior editors go through the piles of slush that arrive weekly. (Slush = unsolicited manuscripts.)

title: Casino Chief Is Leaving Behind More Than an Empty Chair
description: Help wanted: Casino Control Commissioner to head a five-member state regulatory board overseeing a dozen Atlantic City casino hotels, their 42,000 employees and 8,200 more in support industries that make up New Jersey's gambling industry.

title: Being White in Kenya
description: Rules of the Wild

title: A Guide to Cleaner Driving
description: MANY consumers want to know the size of a car's engine, its horsepower, how fast it races from 0 to 60 miles an hour. They're interested in the number of pockets, compartments and cup holders. But do they really care about the environmental impact of the vehicle they're thinking of buying?

title: Corrections
description: The Garden column on Aug. 23 about the plant Franklinia misstated the location of Twombly's Nursery. It is in Monroe, Conn., not Madison.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about Camp Helen Keller, a summer program for blind children in East Farmingdale, included the camp's erroneous account of the precedents for the employment of a blind counselor, Elizabeth Wurzer, this summer. She was not the first; that distinction belongs to Christine Faltz, who worked there in 1987.

title: Western Civ Fights Back
description: The Seekers

title: A Cast of Old Faces Are in New Places Up in the Booth
description: George Seifert was contemplating his career change, from coaching to neophyte studio analyst on CBS's revived ''The N.F.L. Today.''

title: Germany's Past
description: To the Editor: To ''What's Doing in Berlin'' by Eve Schaenen (Aug. 16) can be added a remarkably candid museum, called Topography of Terror, on the site where the Gestapo headquarters and its related institutions were once situated.

title: They Got Game, And Laundry Too
description: Thank you for your articles about women's basketball. As both the mother of a female high-school point guard and a gender-equity specialist, I support the W.N.B.A. because it affirms a girl's choice to be an athlete.

title: August 30-Sept. 5; Prosecutors Drop Murder Case Against 2 Children
description: A month ago, prosecutors in Chicago accused two boys, 7 and 8 years old, of having murdered an 11-year-old girl riding her bicycle in their neighborhood. The girl's body was found with evidence of having been sexually molested, and the police said the boys had confessed to attacking her.

title: On the Water, an Uneasy Mix; More Boats, but Few Rules, in Harbor and on Hudson
