description: Even on the only cloudy day last week, the waters in and around New York City teemed with boats of every description.

title: Saving Hospitals, But at What Cost?
description: Officials at both Winthrop and Catholic Health Services offered very cavalier answers to your reporter's queries about reproductive services in the two community hospitals that Winthrop and C.H.S. are taking over. Since Massapequa General and Mid-Island will have to operate under Catholic religious principles, there are many services they won't provide. Winthrop's John Broder said patients will be provided ''information'' about hospitals and doctors that offer the curtailed services. But with our limited choice of physicians because of managed care, patients won't always be able to find a doctor affiliated with a hospital still offering the services. And what if the patient is brought in with an emergency like a tubal pregnancy? Should her life be endangered while she is moved to a hospital that does therapeutic abortions? Women need services -- for contraception, infertility, sterilization and more -- not information about services.

title: Sell the Range Rover; It's Ford Time
description: SO, the long slide begins. This time, though, instead of being boiled in oil, like they were in 1987, investors look as though they will get a slow poaching. If 1989 was a head-on at 60 miles per hour, 1998 is more like running out of gas on the Garden State just after you enter the express lanes.

title: Elena Boley, David Leviss
description: Dr. Elena Boley, a second-year resident in internal medicine at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, is to be married this evening to David Jeffrey Leviss, an associate at Kramer, Levin, Naftalis & Frankel, a New York law firm. Rabbi Donald B. Rossoff is to officiate at the Luxury Collection Hotel in Washington.

title: Salt Air Still Lingers In Hull
description: THE secret of the North British croissant is safe. I managed to obtain a choice specimen in the port city of Hull, but before I could begin my researches it was seized as a deadly weapon at Manchester airport. In Hull, I was also seriously served a plate of lasagne with a side of french fries. On the other hand, it was in Hull that I drank the finest glass of beer I have ever tasted in my life.

title: A Compass for Those Choppy Seas
description: In reaching stomach-churning, sleep-depriving levels last week, the gyrations of the stock market seemed to restore meaning to an old Wall Street maxim:

title: The View From/Guilford; A Center for Women in All Their Aspects and Aspirations
description: QUILTING. Arthritis. Feng shui. Drumming. Safe homes for battered women. Grandparents raising grandchildren. Chinese cooking. All are huddled under one umbrella called the Women and Family Life Center -- a Guilford-based agency that opened less than a decade ago with a vision but not a red cent.

title: Nation Lacks plan to Deter Terrorism, Study Says
description: At a time of growing fear of terrorism within America's borders, senior state and local officials say the Ferderal Government still has no coherent system for deterring or responding to it.

title: Meanwhile, the Show Goes On in Oradell, Too
description: HOW often can theatergoers see a major musical in a major production and the very same show in a community theater less than 50 miles away? Never. Well, hardly ever.

title: Tania Long, 85, a Reporter For The Times in World War II
description: Tania Long, a war correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune and The New York Times who covered the London blitz and the Nuremburg trials, died Friday morning at her home in Ottawa. She was 85.

title: A Small-Town Mayor With Big-Time Dreams
description: THERE is much about the headaches of governance that Mayor Fred G. Wager is not at liberty to discuss because, at the moment, he is up to his neck in litigation. He needs to speak carefully. Still, he is steaming mad on behalf of his town, even if his shrug is good-natured when he says: ''You want to sue us? Get in line.''

title: Washington's New Salute to Compromise
description: BAD things happen to good architects. James Ingo Freed is the man who designed the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, one of the most powerful buildings of our time. It gives me no pleasure to report that Mr. Freed's most recent project, the Ronald Reagan Building, is a disappointing piece of work.

title: Kimberly Nuzum, Aaron Lippert
description: Kimberly Cramer Nuzum, a daughter of Dr. Margaret B. Nuzum and John M. Nuzum, both of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Aaron Matthew Lippert, the son of Reinehilde M. Lippert and Dr. Lawrence J. Lippert of Laurel Hollow, N.Y. The Rev. Peter Cullen, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at Grace Church in Brooklyn.

title: Inanimate Selves, Alternate Realities
description: ''AND the Lord God formed man of the dust of the ground, and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life; and man became a living soul,'' says the Book of Genesis. What God did is not so different from what puppeteers do, using humble materials to model their own images, and then breathing finite life into those figures.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 74th Yorktown Grange Fair

title: Warm Guiradelco Offers Taste of Philippines
description: THE young doctor from Huntington and his foodie friends were looking forward to a real adventure in eating. He excitedly told his patient, ''We've been to Chinese, Japanese, Indian and Thai restaurants, but Filipino? I didn't even know there was one on the Island.''

title: N.F.L. PREVIEW: The Battle for New York; Giants Put Faith in Kanell And His Quiet Confidence
description: Let it be known that Danny Kanell, the 24-year-old son of a Florida physician, the easy smiling, Bible-school attending quarterback who still lives at home with his parents in the off season, is not to be trusted.

title: Despite Reports to Contrary East Village Fight Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Morcine Scott, Craig Warren
description: Morcine Ann-Marie Scott, the daughter of Rema and Raphael Scott of Irvington, N.J., and Capt. Craig Frank Warren, a son of Patricia Warren and Dr. William C. Warren of Somerset, N.J., were married yesterday at the Glen Ridge (N.J.) Congregational Church. The Rev. Judith A. Vasile, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Shirley M. Roberts, an African Methodist Episcopal minister.

title: Support for Planned Children's Hospitals
description: IT was a parent's nightmare. When John and Brenda Fareri took their 13-year-old daughter, Maria, to the Westchester Medical Center here in September 1995 suffering from neck pain, a fever and spreading aches in her left arm and face, they were told she had rabies, a disease that is fatal by the time symptoms appear.

title: Arlene Yang and Jose Lau
description: Arlene Rae Yang, a daughter of Sue Pai Yang and Dr. Chung Shu Yang of Bridgewater, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Jose Antonio Lau Dan, a son of Maria Elena Dan de Lau and Antonio Lau of Tuxpan, Mexico. The Rev. Charles A. Sabella is to perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Martinsville, N.J.

title: Installing a Basement Sump Pump
description: HOMEOWNERS with leaky basements are often faced with deep puddles of water on the floor. Installing a sump pump in the basement can help, but it will not prevent water from entering the basement. It will only remove the water that collects.

title: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title: Guarding a Chemical Warehouse Just in Case
description: The waterfront warehouse in Williamsburg in which the Radiac Corporation processes chemical waste from medical research centers around the city may not have the visibility of the World Trade Center, but since the bombings of United States embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last month, it has captured the attention of the Police Department.

title: Runaway
description: TAKEN IN

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL: Sport Utilities With Training Wheels; '98 Isuzu Amigo: A Brawny Little Brute
description: MINI-SPORT utilities are for poseurs who covet the look, not the function. Face it: the real appeal of the wildly popular Subaru Forester, Toyota RAV4 and Honda CRV is comfort, splendid road manners and a great view of traffic.

title: The Beige and The Black
description: Michael Lind's premise that the white majority is giving way to a beige majority is compelling, but he proceeds to assume that beige Americans identify more with other beige, or white, rather than black, Americans (''The Beige and the Black,'' Aug. 16). Formulating identity is a complex issue, not to be reduced to how white, beige or black one is. In itself, categorizing people by color discounts cultural heritage and upbringing, perpetuating the perception of individuals exclusively by hue.

title: Family Challenges Party in Bronx
description: In the bustle of rush hour one recent afternoon, the Espada brothers took their political campaigns to the busy intersection of Westchester and Morrison Avenues in the Bronx, accompanied by a small army of supporters with bullhorns, bright red campaign placards and white T-shirts bearing the images of the brothers, Pedro Espada Jr. and Jose R. Espada.

title: Song Style From Era Gone By
description: GIVEN the indelible impact of Steven Spielberg's de-romanticizing of World War II in ''Saving Private Ryan,'' the retro gush of songs like ''Praise the Lord and Pass the Ammunition'' and ''Thank Your Lucky Stars and Stripes'' suddenly seems like a retaliatory, futile attempt to recapture rah-rah, good guys-bad guys patriotism.

title: A Few Surprises on Return Visits
description: IN restaurants, as in life, things change. Even the best establishments can go into a down cycle when an exceptional chef leaves or management coasts on its laurels. Conversely, an ordinary place sometimes improves with new chef, menu or ownership. Recent return visits to three restaurants produced a few surprises as noted below.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; The Art of Bringing Visitors to Science
description: For riders of Chicago's El and suburban trains, getting from downtown stations to the three science museums on the Lake Michigan shoreline was not exactly a leisurely task. They could wait around for the right city bus or hike the mile to the shore and face crossing major roadways.

title: Sports of The Times; Working With Youth In the Ashe Tradition
description: RODNEY HARMON grew up in Richmond, three houses away from tennis courts that, like the main court at the United States Open, are now named for Arthur Ashe. A life in tennis, though not likely, was at least a possibility.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE CONFER BUT DIFFER ON ECONOMIC CURES
description: The economic policy leaders of the world's two largest economies, the United States and Japan, spent hours here Friday night talking about the heightened risk of global recession and a further spread of the turmoil that has engulfed Asia, Russia and now Latin America. But they left this morning with no new plans, and an uneasy sense that Japan and the United States remain on different wavelengths about how quickly countries must act.

title: Taking a Look at a Naturalist's Life
description: IT takes patient observation, but beholding the inner workings of nature can be exhilarating -- from the detailed dances of honey bees to the complex interrelationships of ecological systems.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Weaving More Threads Into the Web
description: Adam L. Barsky, the director of the Mayor's Office of Operations, is proud of New York City's on-line efforts. ''We are really the model for the country when you look at what we've done with technology,'' Mr. Barsky said.

title: An Immigrant Artist At Home in Memory
description: MOODY, meticulously staged and filled with introspective symbolism, the room-size works of Ernesto Pujol have been fixtures on the international art circuit in recent years and, in the eyes of many, examples of installation art at its most evocative.

title: Saving Hospitals, But at What Cost?
description: A pro-abortion coalition group called Save Our Services, which includes the Civil Liberties Union and Planned Parenthood, among others, deplores one aspect of the takeover of Mid-Island Hospital and Massapequa General that will have no real impact on the communities that the two hospitals currently serve. Services will not be diminished. On the contrary. Bethpage and Massapequa area residents have won the health-care lottery whereby two failing hospitals with very limited facilities will be taken over by two long-established, state-of-the-art health-care providers that will enormously expand services, not restrict them!

title: The New York Times Business Best Sellers
description: HARDCOVER

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL: Sport Utilities With Training Wheels; '99 Kia Sportage: Not Ready for Prime Time
description: IT'S cheap, it's cute, and the top comes off. What's not to like?

title: Sports of The Times; For Aaron, There Was a Dreaded Difference
description: HE had 713 homers and Henry Aaron's season was over, but his worry wasn't.

title: They Had a Dream
description: OF ONE BLOOD

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUHLSTOCK, FRIEDA
description: MUHLSTOCK-Frieda. Beloved wife of the late George. Respected sister of Ruth Blei and the late George Livingston. Loving mother of Chuck and Stanley (Barbara). Devoted grandmother of Sharon, Todd and Mindy. Proud great grandmother of Dara Sheinker. Graveside services at Wellwood Cemetery, 11 AM, today.

title: Raising Money a Goal At Sarah Lawrence
description: THERE is a joke sometimes told here about Sarah Lawrence College that the prestigious institution has two sets of stationery, one listing its address correctly as the gritty city of Yonkers and the other with its assigned mailing address of Bronxville, an adjacent enclave of expensive Tudor-style houses. The Yonkers address is used for paying taxes and conducting other day-to-day business, the Bronxville address for recruiting and conducting public relations campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, TRUDE MICHEL
description: JAFFE-Trude Michel. On August 31, 1998 after a short illness. Wife of the late Herman J. Jaffe who died January 23, 1998. Senior Editor, crossword puzzles, Los Angeles Times Syndicate. She will be missed and fondly remembered by her family, which includes Herman's, and by her many friends. A memorial service will be held in New York at a later date. Donations in her memory made be made to American Ballet Theatre, 890 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

title: Green Is No Longer Underpaid
description: Only several days ago, the acrimony between Minnesota Vikings Coach Dennis Green and the team's new owner, Red McCombs, seemed thicker than cement. McCombs had rejected two contract proposals from Green's agent, Ray Anderson, with the latest rejection coming just last week. It increasingly looked as if Green was going to leave the Vikings at the end of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELFER, PETER
description: BELFER-PETER. 1946-1971. ''HE CHERISHED THE GIFT OF LIFE.'' JEAN AND IRA

title: An Even Exchange
description: In her essay on buying a gun for protection, Karla Kuban gave less than even treatment to a difficult decision. The odds that a gun in the home will be involved in the death or injury of a member of the household are substantially greater than the odds that it will be used to injure or kill an intruder. Homes with guns are almost three times as likely to be the scene of a homicide as those without.

title: Return to Yesterday, for Decor and Menu
description: THE Locust Valley Inn is yesterday. When it opened a quarter century ago, it was in the mainstream of Long Island restaurants. The decor defines cozy: brick walls, stained glass, stucco, wood beams and wrought-iron chandeliers. Today's headliners usually go for the crisp, airy look. Although most 1990's restaurants have limited choices that stress a specific cuisine or region, the inn's menu is encyclopedic. There is a world of possibilities vying for attention: seafood, steaks, chops, pastas, Italian favorites and a few German dishes.

title: Maddie Corman and Jace Alexander
description: Madeleine Cornman, the daughter of Michael Cornman of Irvington, N.Y., and the late Irene K. Cornman, is to be married this afternoon to Jason Edward Alexander, the son of the actress Jane Alexander of Carmel, N.Y., and Robert Alexander of La Jolla, Calif. Lawrence H. Ecker, Village Justice of Irvington, will officiate, with Ed Sherin, the bridegroom's stepfather, at the home of Mr. Sherin and Ms. Alexander.

title: August 30-Sept. 5; A Summit Trip Like No Other
description: When President Clinton met with President Boris N. Yeltsin in Moscow, the near collapse of Russia's economy was on his mind, but there wasn't much to be done beyond expressions of support if Russia stayed the course of reform.

title: Little-Known American Seeing Some Progress
description: Four American men reached the third round of this year's United States Open. There are the established stars, Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi. There is the potential star, Jan-Michael Gambill. And then there is Geoff Grant, a late-blooming graduate of Duke who has played tennis for precious little reward in a number of faraway places.

title: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title: The Finns Find Glitter In Russia's Shadow
description: FOUR years ago, Finland established a free-trade zone along its border to encourage business with Russia, hoping to revive a relationship that had all but collapsed along with the dissolution of the Soviet order.

title: LIPA Plan For Rebate Under Fire
description: TRUSTEES of the Long Island Power Authority will vote on Thursday on a plan for sending more than $160 million in payments to one million Long Island electric customers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: YOUR BLUE-EYED BOY

title: Racing Rebounds at Bridgeport Dog Track
description: WHEN the Shoreline Star Greyhound Park and Simulcast Complex closes down for the season next week, dog betting enthusiasts say they will miss it, but know their favorite greyhounds will be back at the starting gates next March.

title: For Aikman, a Mid-Career Crisis
description: It could have been first down or third down, a critical call or simply the continuation of an exacting drive toward the end zone. Troy Aikman, the Dallas Cowboys quarterback, would walk to the sideline last season and talk it over. Run or pass? Hit the middle or attack the outside? Remain in the pocket or try something on the run?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, JANE WYLIE
description: WILSON-Jane Wylie. 71. A retired literary agent died at her home in Manhattan on Friday, 4 September. The cause of death was a complication from emphysema. Ms. Wilson was a graduate of Barnard College Class of '49. Her career as an agent began at the William Morris Agency while working for Helen Strauss in the literary department. Jane later joined the late John Cushman in forming John Cushman Associates which became the JCA Literary Agency. She is survived by her brother, Dr. Dwight R. Wilson, Jr. also of Manhattan. A memorial service will be planned for a future date.

title: Cell Tower
description: His may be just a small village, but Mayor Joseph A. Lanza wants to have a big voice in whether the New York State Thruway Authority is allowed to build a 180-foot cellular phone tower -- the height of an 18-story building -- near a residential area of Mamaroneck.

title: 'Swingtime Canteen' At Bridgeport Theater
description: GIVEN the indelible impact of Steven Spielberg's de-romanticizing of World War II in ''Saving Private Ryan,'' the retro gush of songs like ''Praise the Lord and Pass the Ammunition'' and ''Thank Your Lucky Stars and Stripes'' seems like a retaliatory, futile attempt to recapture rah-rah, good guys-bad guys patriotism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, LEONARD
description: KLEINMAN-Leonard. We mourn the loss and warmly remember Len, a kind hearted friend and business associate of 25 years. We are saddened by the crash of Swissair #

title: Op-Art; Some Untouchable Ruthian Feats
Feeling Handcuffed, Many Stay Put
description: FOR many investors, the choice of whether to sell or hold fast as stocks swooned in the last two weeks felt like no choice at all: For better or worse, they said, they were handcuffed to the market by a need to avoid taking taxable gains or locking in devastating losses.

title: Frogs Hit the Charts
description: Cold-blooded they may be, but frogs have never been hotter. In May, alarm over frog populations caused Congress to form the Task Force for Amphibian Decline and Deformities. Now frogs are going from popular cause to radio sensation.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Murals in Stamford

title: Despite Reports to Contrary East Village Fight Goes On
description: To the Editor:

title: Robyn Cort, David Quattrone
description: Robyn Jill Cort, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Cort of Potomac, Md., was married last evening to David Charles Quattrone, the son of Anna R. Quattrone and Dr. Charles G. Quattrone of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Arthur Blecher officiated at the Carlton Hotel in Washington. The Rev. Michael Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Schools '98: Bar's Raised And Space Is Precious
description: AS students, teachers and administrators return for another school year on Long Island, the biggest concerns in many districts boil down to these: how to deal with the new, higher academic standards in effect in all districts this year, and where to put a larger student body spending more time in the classroom striving to make the grade.

title: Jocelyn Riseberg, Eric Scheirer
description: Jocelyn Courtenay Riseberg and Eric David Scheirer, Ph.D. candidates in media arts and sciences at the Media Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Cambridge, Mass., are to be married today. Rabbi Deanna Douglas is to officiate at the Four Seasons Hotel in Boston.

title: Rebecca Simons, Jonathan Fogel
description: Rebecca Simons, a daughter of Carol Simons and Lewis M. Simons of Washington, is to be married there today to Dr. Jonathan Tad Fogel, a son of Dolores G. Fogel and Dr. William M. Fogel of Richmond. Rabbi Jeffrey A. Wohlberg is to perform the ceremony at the Cosmos Club.

title: Puppeteers With a Hand in the Apartheid Protests
description: FOR Basil Jones and Adrian Kohler, forming the Handspring Puppet Company -- which on Wednesday helps lead off the International Festival of Puppet Theater in New York -- was partly artistic inspiration and partly draft-dodging. The inspiration part worked.

title: Our Towns; The Stories Beat a Path To This Space
description: SINCE this is my last column for ''Our Towns,'' a few answers to often-asked questions are in order.

title: Uses of Analysis
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, JOHN G.
description: O'NEILL-John G. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John G. O'Neill, associated with The Times from 1947, until retiring in 1994.

title: Correction
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about what is now the Bergdorf Goodman Building, misidentified the architects of the shops that were later combined to form the Bergdorf store. The firm was Buchman & Kahn, not Kahn & Jacobs.

title: Banco Popular to Open Site in New Rochelle
description: BANCO POPULAR, the largest bank of Hispanic origin in the United States, is bringing its mass-market popularity and bicultural appeal to Westchester.

title: 4-Wheel Drive With a Difference
description: Quick! Somebody call Dr. Love. Rollerboogie is alive and well and living in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx -- and anywhere else in the city with a good rink, a booming sound system and agile dancers on old-fashioned four-wheeled roller skates.

title: From Russia With Love
description: Possibly making up for lost time, and to rave American reviews, the Soviets sent us a towering, passionate, historical whopper in ALEXANDER NEVSKY (1938), about the the 13th-century routing of German invaders led by a valiant knight (Nikolai Cherkassov). The tall, statuesque actor made a majestic protagonist as his country's dedicated savior who inspired his warriors.

title: A Snapshot Survey of Graffiti On Line (The Train Line)
description: ''I'm a commuter,'' says Claude Noton, a 47-year-old technical writer from Trenton. He gets the Harrisburg Clocker Amtrak train at 8:26 every morning and rides it to Newark, where he switches to a PATH train and ends up on Wall Street and his day job as a technical writer for financial software manuals. Along the way, he casts an eye on the splotches of color that he sees flying past. ''It's graffiti,'' he says, ''and all summer it got bigger and bigger.''

title: When Russians Look Inward
description: After visiting Russia in the 1920's, the philosopher Bertrand Russell confided to a friend that, horrible though the Bolshevik dictatorship was, it seemed the best sort of system for that country. ''If you ask yourself how Dostoyevsky's characters should be governed, you will understand,'' Russell wrote.

title: King Hussein's Illness Shifts Spotlight to Prince
description: King Hussein has reigned for 45 years, more than twice as long as Ahmed Thneibat has been alive. But now the King is undergoing cancer treatment for the second time in six years, and Mr. Thneibat and other Jordanians are apprehensive about what is to come.

title: Winning the Drug War Isn't So Hard After All
description: Don't let rudolph giuliani fool you: methadone works. Since its introduction in the mid-1960's, studies have consistently shown that the synthetic narcotic cuts addicts' craving for heroin, enabling onetime street junkies to restart their lives. In so doing, methadone helps boost employment, inhibit the spread of H.I.V. and cut crime. That's why the New York City Mayor's recent attacks -- he denounced methadone as a chemical that's used to enslave people and promised to abolish it from the city over the next few years -- have left experts scratching their heads.

title: What to Do If Hurricane Heads North
description: FIRST, the good news: The 1998 hurricane season is nearly half over.

title: POSTINGS: $10 Million Conversion to Residences on Broadway; An 8-Story 1894 Loft Building Being Restored in SoHo
description: In 1910, the tenants of the eight-story building at 473-475 Broadway included manufacturers of lace, embroidery and rugs, with M. Hohner, the well-known harmonica manufacturer, on the sixth floor.

title: 1800 Gold Rush
description: To the Editor: Ann K. Ludwig recently wrote ''A Flash in the Pan Still Gleams'' (Aug. 16) on California's sesquicentennial celebration of the Gold Rush.

title: Vote of No Confidence in Northwest Strike
description: Northwest Airlines says that the only issue in the week-old strike by its 6,200 pilots is pay. The pilots counter that job security as well as money are the two big hurdles standing in the way of a settlement. But the real issue that has divided the two sides, leading to the longest airline strike since maintenance workers shut down Eastern Airlines in 1989, seems to be trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLA, WALTER
description: CELLA-Walter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter Cella, associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1972.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALKOVITZ, JOSEPH
description: PALKOVITZ-Joseph, Dr. The National Board of Hadassah, The Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the death of Dr. Joseph Palkovitz, beloved father of Judy and Harry Palkovitz of Pittsburgh, PA. May his memory be for a blessing. Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President Dr. Laura S. Schor, Nat'l Executive Director

title: Sosa Answers (Again), Hitting His 58th Homer
description: It's called a home run race, but the contestants are rooting for each other.

title: Rutgers Cuts Skid at 14 By 1 Point
description: Rutgers won a football game tonight.

title: Near Bridge, More Traffic Means Less Business
description: When the city's Department of Transportation changed the direction of traffic on the upper roadway of the Queensboro Bridge last month because of construction, it helped alleviate traffic on the Manhattan side of the bridge during the morning and evening rush.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STRAUSS, SIMON D.
description: STRAUSS-Simon D. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, September 9 at 3:30 P.M., at The Manhattan School of Music, West 122 Street and Claremont Avenue. Mr. Strauss died May 22, 1998.

title: Food; Unimpeachable Sauces
description: Gone are the days when a vegetable uneaten meant another brain cell absorbed by guilt. Today, vegetables are more pleasure than prescription. Where once they were used to frame a meal (or be a meal, for that matter), vegetables are now exploited for their flavor, as in vegetable sauces.

title: Al's Beach Books
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Big Stage for State Politics

title: Single Entendre
description: In a recent television profile, Sting argued that he was more than just a pretty face. ''Rock stars and footballers are supposed to be idiot savants,'' he trilled. ''We're not supposed to have read Proust.'' Monsieur Sting's erudition may indeed be staggering, but chances are idiot savant didn't come into his vocabulary by way of Swann. First coined by the British doctor J. Langdon Down (he of the famous syndrome) in 1887, the expression doesn't particularly benefit from a Gallic accent -- since it is virtually unknown in France.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: Goldstein-Engle Wins
description: Margie Goldstein-Engle of Wellington, Fla., rode Hidden Creek's Glory to first place and Concerto to second in the $50,000 Autumn Classic Grand Prix at the New Hope Farm in Port Jervis, N.Y., last night.

title: August 30-Sept. 5; Chinese Stranded by Floods
description: China has declared at least a temporary victory against its swollen rivers, but its authorities are facing a problem more daunting than this year's record-breaking floods: millions of refugees whose homes and belongings were literally washed away. They are a sad lot, now camping out in tents, schools, factories or at relatives' homes until they can began rebuilding their lives. It may not be soon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, SELMA K.
description: STARK-Selma K. On September 4. Beloved mother of Linda and Jessica, mother-in-law and friend to Ed Conroy, dedicated teacher, your pain has ended, rest in peace with your parents, Nettie and Ben Kessler. Services Monday, September 7, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBA, MAHMOUD
description: DIBA-Mahmoud. The Board of Trustees, the Staff and friends of the Brooklyn Museum of Art mourn the tragic death of Mahmoud Diba, beloved husband of our good friend and colleague, curator Layla Diba. A member of the Asian Art Council, he was a longtime friend of the Brooklyn Museum of Art. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Layla, their son, and to every member of the family. Robert S. Rubin, Chairman, Board of Trustees Arnold L. Lehman, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, COOKIE
description: ZUCKERMAN-Cookie. (nee Shreiber). AMIT is deeply grieved at the untimely passing of Cookie Shreiber Zuckerman, beloved daughter of our generous benefactor, Frances Shreiber Feder, z'l. A woman of noble spirit and character, she exemplified a long family tradition of magnanimous philanthrophy. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Evelyn Blachor, National Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: An Era of Grace
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Have Laptop, Will Track Each Blip in the Market
description: LIKE many other investors, Allen Page, 31, a packaging salesman in Pasadena, Calif., had a bad week last week. But if not for his cellular phone, his laptop, his Internet account and his pager-like device that receives stock prices, it could have been worse.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 23 in Part 2, Women's Fashions of The Times, misidentified the watch shown on page 68 at the far right. It was the Meisterstuck stainless-steel chronograph with calfskin strap from Montblanc, $1,750, not a stainless-steel chronograph from Baume & Mercier. Store information is available at (800) 388-4810.

title: Lucy Ramirez, Gerard Aguilar
description: Lucy Ramirez and Joseph Gerard Aguilar were married yesterday at St. Michael's Church in Chicago. The Rev. James Keena performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Hello, Dolly, Dolly, Dolly . . .
description: Clones and Clones

title: New Folk Art Collection On View in Santa Fe
description: Back in 1995, the Museum of International Folk Art in Santa Fe got a huge gift -- more than 2,500 textiles, ceramics and folk-art objects from all over the world collected by Lloyd E. Cotsen, the former chief executive of Neutrogena, and given jointly by him and the company. The museum immediately set to building more exhibition space. And now, for the first time, selections from the collection are on view in the new 8,775-square-foot Neutrogena wing.

title: Civil War Saga
description: The Whirlwind

title: The Cult of Joyce Maynard
description: Joyce Maynard wrote her first memoir, ''Looking Back,'' when she was 19; now, at 44, she has written her second, ''At Home in the World.'' In the 25 intervening years, Maynard bought a house, nearly had a nervous breakdown, lost her virginity to the soundtrack of ''Pippin,'' met Mary Tyler Moore and Muhammad Ali, was raped, got married, appeared on TV, had three children, emptied her breast milk into the Atlantic, planted a garden, went broke, had an abortion, clawed through a heap of garbage looking for a lost retainer, wrote three novels, watched her parents get divorced and die, got divorced herself, bought another house, got breast implants and took them out again, took tennis lessons, sold most of her possessions and moved from New Hampshire to California. Over the years, Maynard has related many of these events in her syndicated newspaper column (now defunct) and in articles for women's magazines. Oddly, she has been chastized severely, and often for imagining that any of them could possibly be interesting.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In:/Kingsbridge, the Bronx; A Place Convenient to Almost Everything
description: LIVING in Kingsbridge, you need never be a dreaded ''carpool mom.'' That's one of June M. Eisland's favorite expressions, but one of her least-favorite things.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Going Their Way, Going Your Way
description: For New York City taxi passengers, a ride in a cab is often a solitary experience and sometimes a pricey one. But in Madison, Wis., the Badger Cab Company offers a fairly affordable way to get to point B, along with company in the back seat.

title: Ring Funneled Drugs to Bermuda in Cruise Ships, U.S. Says
description: With the arrests of two cruise ship employees yesterday as their vessel docked in Manhattan, Federal law enforcement officials revealed the existence of an unusual drug ring that they said used luxury ocean liners to funnel cocaine, hashish and marijuana from New York City to the island of Bermuda.

title: Kerin Gleason, Andrew Zeilman
description: Kerin Amy Gleason, the daughter of Rela and Donald Gleason of Atherton, Calif., is to be married at her parents' house today to Andrew Todd Zeilman, a son of Jeanne and William Zeilman of Avon, Conn. Jerome Smith, a retired justice of the California Court of Appeals in San Francisco, will officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAUFFER, HAROLD M.
description: STAUFFER-Harold M. Of Weston, MA, formerly of New York. Past owner C. Stoler Casket Co, died September 3, 1998. Survived by wife Pearl, children Martin and Susanne, grandchildren Shelley Goodman and Marla Jenkins, great - granddaughter Rachel Goodman. Services in Newton, MA, September 8th. Donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Box E, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021, c/o Harold M. Stauffer Memorial Fund.

title: Art, on the Fence And in Competition
description: GOOD fences may make a good backdrop for art. For next Sunday's 48th Annual Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences Fence Show, the cast-iron fence of the Snug Harbor Cultural Center will support -- literally -- the visions of more than 80 local artists, in paintings, drawings and photos, all for sale.

title: The World: Inside the Mind of North Korea's 'Dear Leader'; First, Pay Attention. And Then Pay Up.
description: SO I finally got the world's attention! The United States and Japan thought they could ignore me and -- kersplash -- I send one missile shooting over Japan, and finally they look in my direction. Ha! Maybe I should do this more often!

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Qualifications
description: If you're looking for proof that being a bombshell in the 1950's and 60's was a ticket to a life of heartache and pain, BOMBSHELLS: Glamour Girls of a Lifetime (St. Martin's Griffin, paper, $19.95) is not the book for you. Of the 10 women Steve Sullivan profiles (there are also some fetching frontal views), six seem to have wound up modestly to deliriously happy. True, there was one suicide and quite a few divorces, and several of the women might be described as unfulfilled. The principal qualification for stardom in certain circles in the 50's was a bosom of jaw-dropping proportions. In contrast to today's bionic beauties, these women look engagingly real. Sometimes a little too real -- in a few shots it is apparent the subjects were not subsisting strictly on celery sticks. But only a cad would quibble. Although all the women had their moments, in some cases multiple moments, none became a star on the order of Marilyn Monroe or even Raquel Welch. But they made the most of what they had, and many of them seem to have had a good time in the process. The burlesque queen Jennie Lee, for example, was proud of what she did, performed until she was 50, and in her later years ran an exotic dancers' museum. ''It's been a lot of fun,'' she says. ''I had a good career and made lots of money. And anyway, how else could I travel the world like a millionaire without actually being one?'' To which all I can say is, lady, good for you. Ed Zotti

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Skip a Meal, Feed a Soul
description: If New Yorkers skipped lunch tomorrow, just think of the money (not to mention pounds) they would save. Then consider how far that money could go toward feeding the hungry.

title: Builder Specializes in Steel-Framed Houses
description: SWARMS of termites, carpenter ants, floods and now hurricanes. From coast to coast, this year's wacky weather has taken its toll on homeowners. Yet there is a building material that stands up to water, wind and termites: steel, stronger than wood, fire resistant and termite proof.

title: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLIN, RALPH
description: MALLIN-Ralph. The people of Tishman Realty & Construction Co., Inc., deeply mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Ralph Mallin, and his wife, Gilda, who were among the passengers on Swissair Flight 111. Ralph served as Mechanical/Electrical Engineer & Sr. Project Manager on several of Tishman's most important projects: The Merrill Lynch World Headquarters and J.P. Morgan World Headquarters in New York, and the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington, D.C. He was the consummate professional and a true gentleman, and we will miss him very much. Our deepest condolences to Ralph and Gilda's three children and their entire family.

title: Political Briefing; Democrats' Worry: Green, Green, Gone
description: With their appeal to hard-core environmentalists, counterculturists and other hard-left voters, Green Party candidates sometimes find themselves in position to swing elections or otherwise make political mischief. They seldom win office, but more than once they have kept others from winning, or come close to keeping others from winning, mainly Democrats who strayed too far to the right to hold the Green vote.

title: TV Series Didn't 'Fail'
description: To the Editor:

title: High Stakes and Antes in State Races
description: Not so long ago, State Senator Edward N. Warren ran for re-election every two years by handing out combs. Thousands of combs. Thousands of green combs (because Mr. Warren is from Greenville) with his name embossed in white type.

title: Focus on the Family In Jewish Arts Festival
description: ATTENTION, all Schwartz, Weinstein, Cohen, Rousso and Kelman families on Long Island: Operation Mishpaca is waiting to put you in touch with your roots.

title: The New Battle of Chile: Keeping Memory Alive
description: WHEN American film audiences last heard from the Chilean director Patricio Guzman, the year was 1978 and ''The Battle of Chile,'' his 190-minute documentary about the destruction of the elected government of the Socialist leader Salvador Allende Gossens, was appearing in theaters for the first time.

title: Dana Weller, John Siverd Jr.
description: Dana Michell Weller, a daughter of Francine and Jay Weller of Oakland, N.J., is to be married today to John C. Siverd Jr., a son of Nancy and John Siverd of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Joseph O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Rabbi Abraham Krantz at the Park Ridge (N.J.) Marriott Hotel.

title: Favorites Rush Through to the Fourth Round
description: The favorites at the United States Open, hustled through their paces by some tricky wind currents, took care of business with such dispatch yesterday that eighth-seeded Andre Agassi was not ready when he received the call for his third-round match with Davide Sanguinetti.

title: Installing a Basement Sump Pump
description: HOMEOWNERS with leaky basements are often faced with deep puddles of water on the floor. Installing a sump pump in the basement can help, but it will not prevent water from entering the basement. It will only remove the water that collects.

title: Uncovering the Real Deals In a Global Bargain Basement
description: EMERGING markets are on hold.

title: Tricky Eats
description: When Jason Rose, a political consultant based in Phoenix, decided to open a restaurant celebrating the First Amendment, it occurred to him to challenge diners' devotion to unfettered expression by naming it for that dastardly pol, Richard Nixon.

title: An Exclamation-Point End to Summer, in the Sky and Surf; Nerves, and Reverie, At 3,000 Feet and Falling
description: IT wasn't the voice of God, which I was half expecting. This one had a distinctly New York accent and it boomed from the radio strapped to my chest as I drifted 2,500 feet above East Moriches, dangling from a parachute.

title: Q&A;/Gordon Bruno; A Level Playing Field for All Students
description: WHEN it comes to education, Connecticut is an isolationist state, with 166 school districts for 169 towns. At the same time 85 percent of the state's minority-group children are concentrated in 14 of the 166 districts.

title: Inquiry Shows Jet Crew Went Silent Before Crash
description: The crew of the Swissair jet that crashed near here on Wednesday night had stopped responding to air traffic controllers about six minutes before the plane, an MD-11 with 229 people on board, hit the water, investigators said tonight.

title: Simply Recalling Mr. Maris
description: Roger Maris was not a subtle man but he might have appreciated some of the nuances of the current home run derby, particularly the controversy over Mark McGwire's use of testosterone-boosting pills and the second-banana status of Sammy Sosa. As a decent man, Maris would not have wished the Curse of the Bambino on the next home run king, although he would have appreciated having it finally lifted from his own crew-cut head.

title: Medevac Policies Prevent Big Bills
description: ''SICK people should always have medevac insurance,'' in the view of Dr. John W. Aldis, a medical officer in the United States Embassy in Beijing.

title: First Step for Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Lukas 2-Year-Olds Beaten in the Hopeful at Saratoga
description: For 94 years at Saratoga, they have called it the Hopeful because it was a career-building stakes for 2-year-olds whose owners were ''hopeful they had a colt of classic capabilities.'' And it was won by special colts named Man o' War and Secretariat and, last year, Favorite Trick, later voted Horse of the Year.

title: A Lady, She Wrote Music Nonetheless
description: SHOULD we cry for Amy Beach or not?

title: Mourners of Flight's Victims, Seeking Solace, Are Drawn to a Lighthouse
description: For as long as anyone here can remember, the red-and-white lighthouse that stands sentinel on the craggy shoreline has been a kind of landmark, because it was the first in Canada to double as a post office, used by the 60 residents of this tiny fishing village.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Forms of Devotion By Diane Schoemperlen. Viking, $24.95.

title: Shore Towns Give Summer Favorable Review
description: Bobby Dee, a k a Robert DiPeso, counted out the quarters for the players at the Gift Wheel at Bobby Dee's Casino (''Nobody leaves without a TV!'') on the Wildwood boardwalk and pronounced the summer of 1998 a good one.

title: A Kinder View Of West Side
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Lessons on Commissions and End Runs
description: WORLD-ALTERING events should be commemorated. The invention of the printing press, for instance. The discovery of the smallpox vaccine. The playing of the first college football game.

title: Regis Philbin Slept Here; Now Barbies Do
description: THE television viewing habits of Koji Soyama of Mineola consist mainly of watching The Weather Channel. ''I'm a landscaper,'' he said. ''I've got to know if I'm going to be working tomorrow.''

title: Great Men of Yesterday
description: To the Editor:

title: Rally in Harlem Ends in Clashes With the Police
description: As a black nationalist was concluding a youth rally in Harlem with an expletive-laced diatribe against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the police yesterday afternoon, police officers in riot gear stormed the stage, prompting a series of scuffles and tense standoffs to end what had been a peaceful event on an ugly note of violence.

title: The World; O.K., the Ruble's Junk. Not to Worry. Russians Get By.
description: IT'S already autumn in Russia, and as a pleasure drive along any country road outside the capital will reveal, the countryside is a riot of beautiful flowers. It is also a riot of Mickey Mouse beach towels, fresh and not-so-fresh fruit, various grades of motor oil, stuffed toys, bricks, pillows, used furniture, just-picked mushrooms and, in at least one instance, gravestones, available with your choice of inscription.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, WILLIAM
description: FUHRMANN-William. Age 40. Son of Helga, brother to Andrew, uncle to Oliver and friend to so many. Billy was a wanderlust who loved so much of what the world had to offer. He was also the quintessential New Yorker. The complexity and possibilities of the city mirrored his own life. He moved within its fabric, and embraced its energy with hope, wonderment and grace. We mourn the sudden, terrible loss of this loving, elegant human being in the tragic events of Swissair Flight 111, and offer our deepest love and thoughts to all who were touched by him. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be forthcoming. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hale House, City Harvest and the Starlight Foundation.

title: Dana Schwartz, Jeremy Bash
description: Dana Ruth Schwartz, the daughter of Francie and Stuart Schwartz of Montvale, N.J., is to be married this evening to Jeremy B. Bash, a son of Dr. Deborah Bash and Rabbi Marvin Bash of Arlington, Va. The bridegroom's father is to perform the ceremony at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington.

title: Robin Bass, Jason Nevins
description: Robin Alyse Bass and Jason Allan Nevins were married on Thursday by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein at the Fountainhead in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: PUTT AND SELL
description: Everybody knows business gets done on the golf course, but at Northern Illinois University in De Kalb, the art of fairway deals is part of the curriculum. Dan Weilbaker, director of the office of selling effectiveness, offers instruction (the next class starts this week) for businesspeople-golfers who want to swing and sell simultaneously. Among the tips: Chat about personal and company background on the first six holes. Shift to biz practices by the 8th. Go in for the kill on the last six, and close the deal on the 19th (the bar) and the 20th (the dinner date). One major question: Should the seller intentionally lose all the side bets? No. ''If the game is thrown, it sets up negative trust in the relationship,'' says the prof.

title: Shelter Operators to Get Bonuses for Finding Homes for the Homeless
description: New York City will pay $2.2 million in bonuses this fall to operators of homeless shelters who have moved an estimated 9,000 families and single adults out of the system and into permanent housing.

title: North Koreans Officially Inherit Another 'Great Leader'
description: North Korea today became the first Communist country to transfer government power within a family dynasty, as it formally anointed Marshal Kim Jong Il as its ''Great Leader'' and chairman of an expanded National Defense Commission.

title: While Pettitte Fumbles, Abbott Returns to Win
description: Baseball and Jim Abbott parted ways in spring training of 1997, his differences with the game irreconcilable. He had been an 18-game winner and he had thrown a no-hitter for the Yankees, but his ability had suddenly abandoned him and he was confused and hurt.

title: Fighting for the Lives of City Fish
description: Last Sunday, hundreds of rotting footlong fish floated on the surface of Eastchester Bay between City Island and Rodmans Neck in the Bronx.

title: Upgrades on American To Get Tougher in '99
description: A mile doesn't go as far as it used to.

title: Charter Schools in Search of Angels
description: THE state's 12 charter schools are beginning their second year, and their founders and supporters say they have learned some tough lessons about putting organizational autonomy and entrepreneurial spirit into public education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, EDWIN A.
description: MALLOY-Edwin A. On September 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Jennifer Combs and Timon. Loving grandfather of Meredith Combs. Dear brother of Howard Malloy and Tobene Rosenthal. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Service Wednesday, September 9, 2 PM, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: Offshore Hurricanes Swipe, Then Return Sand
description: What sand Hurricane Bonnie took away from the state's beaches, Danielle is giving back.

title: Yet Another Incarnation for a Beloved Monster
description: ROSE HOVICK had a dream, but she did not have a life. The dream was twice fulfilled, through her daughters. One, a vaudeville headliner at 6, a runaway at 12, came to be known as June Havoc, a star of the legitimate theater, film, radio and television. The other, Louise, four years older but relegated to the sidelines as unmarketable, became an inspired afterthought, molded by their mother into a bigger star, albeit an illegitimate one: not a thespian, but an ecdysiast, to be known forevermore as Gypsy Rose Lee.

title: What Did Founders Expect From the Census?
description: To the Editor:

title: Pilots Are Sometimes Unprepared for the Hazards of Operating a Smoky Plane
description: The only problem that the crew of Swissair Flight 111 reported to air controllers before the crash on Wednesday night was smoke in the cockpit, but smoke alone can bring a plane down, even if the fire that produced it does not disable crucial mechanical or electrical parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORAN, LORI
description: MORAN-Lori. Lori was a wonderfrul skating school director and competiive coach whose tragic loss with her husband, Michael Ditchkus, on Swissair Flight 111 will be felt deeply by the professional skating community. Her compassion and kindness will be forever remembered. Our hearts go out to both families. Denise Beaumont, Gioia Covo and other friends at Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, Manhattan

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about places to celebrate special occasions misidentified the restaurant shown. It was Stresa in Manhasset, not the West End Cafe in Carle Place.

title: Beyond Gravity, a Slow-Motion Dance for Art
description: AS the NASA KC-135 turbojet plunged sharply earthward, Kris Shapiro, a senior at the San Francisco Art Institute, floated weightless near the airplane's ceiling. Her orange ponytail fanned out above her. She and her dance partner, Elizabeth Albee Abascal, a junior, had shed the olive-drab flight suits that NASA required them to wear at takeoff. They bobbed around in sleeveless black unitards that, in Ms. Albee Abascal's case, revealed a tattoo on her right bicep.

title: Call to Arms for Lost Hispanic Arts Center
description: Last week was disheartening for Charas/El Bohio, the Hispanic community center and arts space that lost its city-owned building at auction in July. On Thursday, representatives of the new buyer toured the former schoolhouse on East Ninth Stret and Avenue B, measuring and videotaping every room as a handful of Charas's supporters, seething with anger, trailed behind. ''I feel like I'm being violated,'' said Armando Perez, the center's director, who helped convert the abandoned junior high school 19 years ago.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Ruins

title: Correction
description: An article on Aug. 16 comparing Broadway musicals and opera referred incorrectly to Placido Domingo's premiere performance in Gian-Carlo Menotti's ''Goya.'' He is not the only one of the Three Tenors who has sung in the premiere of an opera written for him; Jose Carreras sang in the premiere of Leonardo Balada's ''Cristobal Colon.''

title: August 30-Sept. 5; Optimism, For Once, in Ulster
description: Confidence in a more secure future has unexpectedly come to Northern Ireland scarcely three weeks after the most deadly episode in the conflicted province's bloody history.

title: The Great Makeup Caper
description: It was four o'clock, saturday afternoon. m.a.c., the face paint store on Spring Street in SoHo, was crammed with customers when the Makeup Gang made its move. ''Start at the end with base,'' advised Maya (The Brush) Roberts, a green-eyed brunette. They muscled in on a display counter. ''I need just a little under my eyes,'' said Rebekah (Glitter) Fisk, a green-eyed blonde, dipping a finger into a pot of concealer.

title: A Smash Hit: McGwire Clouts His 60th
description: First there was Babe Ruth, then Roger Maris, now Mark McGwire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEDERSEN, HOWARD NORGE
description: PEDERSEN-Howard Norge. Artist, 80. Died on September 4 at his home in Quogue. Mr. Pedersen worked with many leading decorators of the day, among them, Bill Pahlman, creating murals for hotels and such department stores as B. Altman & Bonwit Teller and in homes in Cuba and the Dominican Republic. Mr. Pedersen who was born and raised in Manhattan attended Pratt Institute. He also made vibrant landscapes and still lifes and designed needlepoint works which were on view at The Julie Artisans Gallery on Madison Avenue. He is survived by his brother Ernest of Bayside, a nephew Christopher Hoyt of Bothell, WA and five nieces: Hilary Jones of Smithtown; Susan Miraglia of Fort Lauderdale FL; Andrea Pedersen of Manhattan; Dana Pedersen Weber of Redding MA; and Victoria Pedersen of Manhattan.

title: In Eastchester, as French as It Can Be
description: MARKING the entrance to Jackie's Bistro, the crisp belled awning promises divertissement amid the gas stations, used car dealerships and hardware stores that dot this stretch of White Plains Road, and this charming little restaurant delivers the goods with style. Decor unabashedly celebrates French enthusiams. The tricolor and a soccer shirt demand tribute for the World Cup victory; roosters abound, as do pictures, news clippings and advertisements of French life. Stepping across this restaurant's threshold is like stepping into the past.

title: The Nation; Postcards From a What-Me-Worry Summer
description: SURE, Jamie Dimon, the co-chairman of Salomon Smith Barney, had to fly home from his August vacation in Europe when the market fell over 500 points last week. But after noodling with his Bloomberg terminal, and conferring with colleagues, he headed right back once the Dow regained some of its steadiness.

title: Explorations For Debris With Value
description: It may mark the wistful end of summer to some, but for the beachcombers who roam the sands armed with metal detectors and wire scoopers, life begins on Labor Day. For them, a walk on the shore is serious business, especially after the September and October storms that disinter the summer leavings.

title: August 30-Sept. 5; After All, Dear, It's Only Money
description: When Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross first announced that she would run for Governor of New York, Democrats took notice. She had just joined the Democratic Party, and she was still a relative newcomer to the business of politics, but she came with the promise of money -- courtesy of her husband, Wilbur Ross, who is an investment banker.

title: Shared Starting Position for Jets Player
description: IF the role of every professional football player is to be a starter when the season opens, then Dwayne Gordon will be halfway there this afternoon when the New York Jets begin the National Football League season in San Francisco.

title: A Hut for the Ages
description: To the casual observer, the surf shack at Windansea Beach in San Diego looks like ''just'' a surf shack, but to Vonn Marie May, a member of the San Diego Historical Site Board, ''it's a character-defining feature that illustrates an indigenous sport.'' The hut is a four-posted, thatch-roofed tiki job erected by pioneer surfers in 1946, and May is leading a campaign to have it added to the National Register of Historic Places.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 6, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Using the Horse To Hold a Mirror To the Human
description: EQUESTRIAN art may be as old as ancient Greece, but Bartabas, the founder and director of the Paris-based Zingaro Equestrian Theater, still likes to think he is doing something new. He may well be right. Carving a niche for himself somewhere between the classical dressage of, say, Vienna's legendary Spanish Riding School and the athletic antics of circus horses, the 41-year-old Frenchman has created an equestrian show that underlines the emotional power of horses.

title: New Categories For Bond Funds
description: Five new categories make their appearance today in the mutual fund tables to improve the identification of funds that specialize in emerging-markets bonds or in New York or California municipal bonds. The categories were devised by Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher that provides mutual fund data for The Times. Today's tables begin on page XX.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Island Justice

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPLEDGE, JANE E.
description: DEPLEDGE-Jane E. It is with great sorrow that the partners, counsel, associates and staff of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae L.L.P., mourn the untimely passing of our friend and colleague Jane E. Depledge, who along with her mother, father and brother did not survive the crash of Swissair Flight 111. Jane, an alumnus of Yale University, started with LeBoeuf as a summer associate in 1995, and joined the Firm in 1996 following her graduation from Columbia University School of Law, becoming an associate in our trusts & estates practice. We honor Jane's memory, the memories of her parents and brother and those of all who passed in this tragedy.

title: Lisa Peterson, Ronald Mitchell
description: Lisa Shell Peterson, a daughter of Dr. Juanita S. Peterson and Alonza J. Peterson of the Bronx, is to be married this afternoon to Ronald Dubois Mitchell, a son of E. Jeanne Genus of Treasure Beach, Jamaica, and Michael S. K. Mitchell of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. Marcus Lashley is to perform the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Pull Up a Seat; These Ballets Spin Stories
description: TODAY, when abstractions dominate many ballet repertories, it's tempting to proclaim plots unimportant. Dance is an art of movement, and the best story in the world cannot disguise unimaginative choreography. Nevertheless, should choreographers wish to tell tales, good stories can help make good choreography look even better. This is especially true of full-evening productions, which must sustain interest for several hours.

title: Seattle Symphony Gets a New Home (and View)
description: The Seattle Symphony has a new home this year, Benaroya Hall, the city's first space designed specifically for concert music performances. Gala celebrations and concerts will take place Sept. 12 to 20 to inaugurate the hall, with the regular season beginning Sept. 24.

title: Leadership Delayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Abramovitch And Mr. Simon
description: Ingrid Anne Abramovitch and Joel C. Simon are to be married this evening by Rabbi Barbara Borts at the Biosphere Museum in Montreal.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE HIDDEN POPE

title: Hanora Bellucco, Jeffrey Chapman
description: Hanora Ann Bellucco and Jeffrey James Chapman were married yesterday by the Rev. Andrew Flores at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Washingtonville, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAZAN, MARY (ELIAS
description: HAZAN-Mary (Elias). Beloved mother of Caroline (Leonard Freed) and the late Bernice (Irwin Rowe) and the late Mona (Stanley Faust). Dear sister of Lena Levy, Abe Elias, Ike Elias, Saul Elias and the late Sophie Confino. Loving grandmother of Marla, Jay, Jeff, Mara, Kenneth, Laurie, Tim, Robert, Deborah & the late David. Cherished great-grandmother of Kenny, Ryan and Daniel. Services and interment were held Tuesday, September 1st, 1998.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about a radio tower in Todt Hill, Staten Island, misidentified the tower pictured. It was a state police antenna, not the shorter transmission tower operated nearby by Highpoint Enterprises.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; A 'Frequent Flier' Plan For Broadway and Off?
description: It used to be that Broadway plays made their money in New York. But two-thirds of the $1.5 billion that Broadway plays took in last year was made on the road, said Jed Bernstein, the executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers. And most of the 140 theaters around the country that present Broadway productions, he said, sell subscriptions.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PASSING REMARKS

title: The Nation; Lonely Stands On Capitol Hill
description: SENATOR JOSEPH I. LIEBERMAN uncomfortably cast himself in one of the capital's classic roles on Thursday, going to the floor and demanding ''some measure of public rebuke'' for President Clinton, an old friend and ally. While it was early to talk of impeachment or resignation, he said, Mr. Clinton's conduct ''had diminished the office he holds'' and was ''reinforcing one of the worst messages being delivered by our popular culture, which is that values are fungible.''

title: When a Doctor Retires: Two Views
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRIMBLE, GREGORY K.
description: TRIMBLE-Gregory K. On September 5, 1998. Loving son of Billie P. and Howard K. Trimble. Dear brother of Carolyn Van Winkle and cherished uncle of Jason S. Van Winkle. The family will receive friends Monday, 3-5 PM, at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC. Interment Fairborn, OH. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: In Five Years, a Nobody Becomes Somebody
description: IN 1993, only one person in America could possibly have foreseen the day when Conan O'Brien would be so popular on late-night television that NBC would hand him an hour of prime time to celebrate his fifth anniversary on the air:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Round Rock

title: Anti-Sweatshop Group Targets Sears
description: A Sunset Park group that includes children of sweatshop workers is using the Sears store on Bedford Avenue in Flatbush to open a national campaign against the retail chain, which it says sells clothing made under abusive conditions.

title: Holiday Tomorrow -- Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: State Is in Forefront of Changing Drug Laws
description: AS state governments experiment with drug law reform, Connecticut is emerging as an innovator. The state was one of the first to allow needle-exchange programs, which offer intravenous drug users clean syringes in exchange for used ones. Such programs were started in Connecticut in 1988, after they were shown to be effective in slowing the spread of AIDS, said David D. Biklen, executive director of the Connecticut Law Revision Commission, which researches drug and substance-abuse issues and drug policy options, and makes recommendations to the General Assembly's public health committee.

title: Lucky Break? Not Quite
description: WAS she ever discouraged? Valorie Newman, a singer who begins a one-week engagement tomorrow night in Harrah's Atrium Lounge, can count the ways.

title: The Rape of the West
description: LASSO THE WIND

title: The Robust Charms Of a Yorkshire Port
description: ''OLD sailors never die,'' says a card pinned to an old fisherman's cottage, ''their float just stops bobbing.'' This, I guess, is saucy seaside whimsy. The incised legend ''Coroner'' above a nearby doorway in Whitby in northern England reveals a grittier seaside truth. On the rocky Yorkshire coast the Whitby lifeboat has been busy for generations. Whitby men lived from the sea, and often enough they died on it as well.

title: From Earth to the Moon and Back, for More Bows
description: DAVE SCOTT, one of 12 people who have walked on the moon, talks about movies and mini-series as if he were at the joy stick of a lunar lander maneuvering for a good place to set down. '' 'Apollo 13' was vertically integrated,'' he said. '' 'From the Earth to the Moon' was horizontal.''

title: Restored Memorial To Titanic Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 26 about weather forecasters misstated the historical rank of some extreme conditions in recent years. The errors were pointed out in a reader's letter received on Aug. 21.

title: It's a Plane, It's a Noise, It's a Bother and Then Some
description: Charlotte Russell has a wellspring of comparisons, none too pleasant, for the low-flying commercial airplanes that rattle the windows of the Washington Heights apartment where she has lived for 35 years.

title: Chasing the Great White Whalebone
description: THE hardy seamen who took up scrimshawing to pass the time during long voyages in search of whales more than a century ago would probably be dismayed to learn that their handiwork had been enlisted in the cause of feminism. But consider the evidence.

title: A Fright-Free Social Security Screenplay
description: The only sure bet about the next century is the eventual premiere of ''Friday the 13th, Part 65.'' The movie, scripted by a policy wonk, features retired baby boomers with ravenous appetites for more Social Security and Medicare. The previews for this thriller are already at a town meeting near you.

title: Asheville
description: The Blue Ridge Parkway, a 469-mile Federal scenic highway running between the Shenandoah National Park in Virginia and the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina, skirts the eastern side of Asheville, N.C., for about 12 miles. But all signs of the city's commerce and industry are obscured by hills and by walls of rhododendron bushes. Distracted drivers -- those with their eyes on autumn leaves, for instance -- can easily pass the five Asheville exits without realizing they have missed the largest city in western North Carolina.

title: DEALS AND DISCOUNTS
description: KENYA FARE SALE -- Sabena Belgian World Airlines has introduced a sale fare to Nairobi starting at $999 round trip from New York to help boost travel to the city following the bombing of the United States Embassy there last month. The fares, which are nonrefundable, are valid for travel from Tuesday through March 31, except for Dec. 12 to Jan. 11, when they are $200 higher. A Saturday stay is required; the maximum stay is one month. Departure taxes and fees of $60 are extra. The flights connect through Brussels. Reservations: (800) 955-2000. The United States Department of State lifted its travel warning on Kenya on Aug. 13.

title: A North Korean Satellite? U.S. Is Searching
description: The United States now believes it is possible that North Korea succeeded in putting a satellite into orbit when it fired a multistage rocket over Japan last Monday, officials said today, retreating from their initial assessment that the launching was a missile test alone.

title: Liberties; Landing The Big One
description: This is the sizzling book proposal that is about to land on the desk of the New York publisher Judith Regan.

title: A Cycle of Violence, on the Field and Off
description: Michael Strahan, the Giants' Pro Bowl defensive end, was chasing down Washington Redskins running back Terry Allen, his eyes locked on the target. Wide receiver Michael Westbrook, running in the opposite direction with a full head of steam, hit Strahan with a vicious crack-back block that knocked the nearly 285-pound Strahan off his feet. Then Westbrook stood over Strahan and celebrated, pointing a finger in his face.

title: Erica Sanders And Alec Foege
description: Erica Miller Sanders and Alec Michael Foege are to be married today at the Belvedere Country Inn in Rhinebeck, N.Y. Town Justice Kenneth J. Kremenick of Milan, N.Y., will officiate.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Q.: Where Do I Turn? A.: Check the Midblock Sign
description: Pity the New York motorist searching for a street off a three-lane road in heavy traffic or dim light. But now that New Yorkers know the ZIP code for Beverly Hills, here's something else to learn from that mini-city and the surrounding behemoth, Los Angeles: warning of streets ahead.

title: Private Life, Public Destiny
description: President Clinton has been sidling his way toward contrition, and at last reached an ''I'm sorry'' for his ''bad mistake.'' This is commendable, though the incremental approach impressed some as skating on the surface rather than plumbing any depths. It seemed facile, which brings to mind a passage from Book Six of Virgil's ''Aeneid'' that begins with the word ''facilis'' (easy). It says, roughly, this:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALLOVITZ, ELINORE KASS
description: SALLOVITZ-Elinore Kass. August 21, 1998. Beloved wife of Myron and mother of Joy Firshein, Karen and Linda Sallovitz. Loving sister of Seymour and Alby Kass and Sharon Silbert and grandmother of Jessica and Jenna Firshein. She was deeped loved and will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMDUR, EDNA
description: AMDUR-Edna. Died September 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Cecil. Mother of Robert. Sister of Phyllis Blumberg and the late Marvin Bloom. Devoted sister-inlaw, aunt and great aunt. Services private.

title: Ms. Perlmutter, Major Ferrari
description: Andrea H. Perlmutter, a daughter of Maida and Mickey Perlmutter of Livingston, N.J., is to be married this afternoon to Maj. John George Ferrari, a son of Loretta and George Ferrari of Plainview, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Morris, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate with Rabbi Hershel Jaffe at the Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y.

title: Sore Winner
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir may have ''fired more cops than the last two Commissioners combined,'' as he claims, but his commitment to rout out brutal cops is undermined by his own words (''Sore Winner,'' by Jeffrey Goldberg, Aug. 16).

title: Resentment Still Aimed At Chinese In Indonesia
description: More than three months after huge riots swept the city, the back lanes of Glodok, Jakarta's Chinatown, are still strewn with ash and bricks and bits of broken glass. Multi-story department stores are fire-blackened shells; small shops are rubble.

title: On the Rocks
description: PETE FORNATALE'S nasal tenor came in loud and clear last week, but not over the airwaves of WNEW (102.7-FM), where he spent a good chunk of his 35-year radio career. He was on the phone at his house in Nassau County.

title: An Exclamation-Point End to Summer, in the Sky and Surf; The Lure of the Waves, Even From a Hurricane
description: THERE are some things you can't get out of your blood, no matter how old you are.

title: Giuliani Skips an Event, but Has Plenty to Say About It
description: He seems to be everywhere, whether the news is good or bad. But while yesterday afternoon's rally in Harlem was being held, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went shopping for a suit.

title: Bending the Borders of Country
description: HER hair is a cool, dazzling silver. Her band is a blend of New Orleans funk, rootsy country and jagged, spooky rock with a drummer sporting Dennis Rodman hair. It's 95 outside, but she's wearing a black, ersatz patent-leather jacket, sipping hot chicken noodle soup and shivering in the air-conditioning at the Rockefeller Center studio where she's taping an appearance on ''Late Night With Conan O'Brien.''

title: Mixed Signals for Big-Ticket Buying
description: DON'T tell Chuck and Donna Gulland that last Monday's stock selloff was just one of those market dips of no lasting consequence. The couple were supposed to close last Tuesday on the sale of their home in Sunnyvale, Calif. ''We had everything we owned packed,'' said Mrs. Gulland, who expected to turn over the keys of her three-bedroom, two-bath home to Antonitta and Joseph Blazina of San Jose.

title: Political Briefing; It's Paula Jones, G.O.P. Fund-Raiser
description: The way Steve Arnold, a Republican from High Point, N.C., saw it, his campaign to win another term on the Guilford County Board of Commissioners needed a lift.

title: Valerie Gurney, Matthew Daniel
description: Dr. Valerie W. Gurney and Matthew Lorin Daniel are to be married this evening by Lawrence C. Brackley, a notary public, at the Pavilion, a private club in Portland, Me.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 8/

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column on Aug. 9 about Broadway referred incorrectly to a Dutch name for the street, Heere Wegh, and mistranslated it. Early references indicate that it was not the original name for Broadway but was preceded by Wagen Wegh (Wagon Way) and Brede Wegh (Broad Way). Heere Wegh means Gentlemen's Way, not Broad Way.

title: A Hot District In the East 20's
description: CAMPAGNA **

title: Ann Bonebakker, Charles Bonney 2d
description: Ann Allen Bonebakker, the daughter of Victoria and Erno Bonebakker of Portland, Me., was married yesterday at her parents' house on Chebeague Island in Maine to Charles Merrill Bonney 2d, the son of Sharon and Charles Bonney of Readfield, Me. The Rev. Donald G. Hodgson, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Word for Word/Books About Walking; Take a Hike! Can't You See I'm Reading?
description: WALKING seems simple: You take your right foot and place it ahead of your left. Then you take your left foot and place it ahead of your right. Locomotion ensues. You may wish to vary the starting foot. Left, right -- It's up to you.

title: G. E. Hangar
description: The Board of Legislators will conduct an environmental review of a revised plan by General Electric to build a hangar at the County Airport in Harrison, Legislator Michael B. Kaplowitz, Democrat of Somers, said.

title: Aryela Lerner, Pesach Lattin
description: Aryela Lerner, a daughter of Dr. Batya Lerner and Avrohom Z. Lerner of Brooklyn, is to be married this evening to Carlos Vernon Lattin, the son of Dr. Patricia Hopkins Lattin and Dr. Vernon E. Lattin, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Israel Belsky is to officiate in LaGuardia Hall at Brooklyn College, of which the bridegroom's father is the president.

title: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; House on Fifth, Tunnel Garage, a Brooklyn Office
description: The Tunnel Garage

title: MAKING IT WORK; Fence Artistry Taken to New Heights
description: EVER since 1653, when the Dutch built a wooden barrier at Wall Street to keep out the Algonquin Indians (and keep in the pigs), New Yorkers have been erecting barriers between themselves and their neighbors.

title: . .  and Bringing the Environment Into the Classroom
description: WHO -- Tanya Oznowich, 39, environmental education specialist for the state Department of Environmental Protection.

title: A Wethersfield Contest for Young Organists
description: NEXT weekend, the First Church of Christ in Wethersfield will be host to a national competition for young organists named in honor of Albert Schweitzer. On Saturday, the high school finalists will play from 9 A.M. to noon, those of college age from 2 to 5 P.M., with the winner in the latter division returning on Sunday at 4 P.M. to give a solo recital.

title: A Bit Older, a Bit Wiser, Seniors Will Counsel Sophomores
description: Shakeelah Gilyard stood on a chair in the community room of the North End Branch of the Newark Public Library, laughing nervously and leaning backward ever so tentatively. In an exercise to shore up trust among the group, several of Shakeelah's peers from Our Lady of Good Counsel High School knelt on the carpeted floor behind her, their hands and arms clasped, waiting to catch her in their human safety net.

title: A Peaceful Show of Unity, Until the Final Moments
description: Before the helicopter swooped over the crowd and the police in riot gear rushed the stage, thousands of peaceful people cheered, chanted and held their fists high as they echoed the call for black unity and youth empowerment yesterday.

title: An Even Exchange
description: I moved to Taos, N.M., from Manhattan in 1991 (Lives: ''An Even Exchange,'' by Karla Kuban, Aug. 16). I've suffered no acts of violence, vandalism or hostility. (In fact, it's a challenge to remember to lock my front door and car doors.) I've found that if I don't try to impose my expectations on this community, I am rewarded by a rich exchange with my fellow citizens.
