title: What Did Founders Expect From the Census?; Limits of a Head Count
description: To the Editor:

title: The Great Sluggers Tend to Come in Pairs
description: It had turned into a two-man race for the major league home run lead, and a dramatic pursuit by both players of the single-season home run record. Sound familiar?

title: The View From/Sleepy Hollow; Adventures in Kayaking on the Hudson
description: YOU'RE wearing the boat,'' Hubbard Marmaduke Jones 3d said succinctly. Mr. Jones, known to everyone as Bardy, is a partner in Hudson River Recreation, a new company based here that leads kayak trips, and he was talking to 15 people about to paddle down the Hudson. With the late afternoon sun glinting on the river and the waves slapping against the little stone launching ramp at Kingsland Point Park here, Mr. Jones gave a brief lecture to the novice adventurers:

title: Miss Mannarino, Mr. Consentino
description: Lynn Patricia Mannarino, the daughter of Patricia and Angelo Mannarino of Miami, is to be married this afternoon to Stephen Francis Consentino, the son of Sandra and Joseph Consentino of Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Tony Vetrano will perform the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Chapel in North Salem, N.Y.

title: An Exclamation-Point End to Summer, in the Sky and Surf; Taken to Unsettling Highs (and Lows) in a Glider
description: THE small gray biplane began moving with a lawn-mowerish burr down the grassy runway at Francis S. Gabreski Airport. The fat yellow nylon cord connecting the plane to the glider slithered on the ground, then stretched taut, and we were bumping along 200 feet behind.

title: Multiple Responses to a Single Shape And Works in a Multitude of Media
description: Ross Bleckner

title: From Garden Excess To Essential Ingredient
description: OREGANO threatens to take over the herb garden at this time of year. The leaves have a sharp, spicy taste, similar to that of marjoram, but I often pass them by in favor of basil.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Sunday Styles on July 5 compared apparel prices at ''outlet'' shopping centers near New York City with prices at department stores and boutiques in Manhattan. The article concluded that there was often no significant difference between prices at the outlets and sale prices at the Manhattan stores. But the headline, ''Bye Bye Bargains,'' suggested that the outlets offered no savings at all. That suggestion was not supported by the article.

title: Allison Elin, Brian Levin
description: Allison Paige Elin, a daughter of Jane Elin of Rye Brook, N.Y., and the late Allan Elin, is to be married this evening in Vail, Colo., to Brian Eric Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Levin of Englewood, Colo. Rabbi Jay Feder is to officiate at the Lodge at Vail.

title: Eron Friedlaender, Joel Portnoy
description: Dr. Eron Yael Friedlaender, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gary E. Friedlaender of Woodbridge, Conn., is to be married there this afternoon to Dr. Joel David Portnoy, the son of Jaclyn Portnoy and Lawrence F. Portnoy, both of Bethesda, Md. Rabbi Richard Eisenberg is to perform the ceremony at Congregation B'nai Jacob.

title: Emil Ciccotelli, Police Commander, Dies at 69
description: Deputy Chief Emil A. Ciccotelli, a longtime New York police commander who was an expert on organized crime and oversaw investigations of some sensational killings, died last Sunday at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital in the Bronx. He was 69.

title: END OF A GHETTO: A special report.; Razing the Slums to Rescue the Residents
description: In the final months of the Hole, anarchy was everywhere. The Hole, the most oppressive section of Chicago's notorious Robert Taylor Homes housing project, was coming down.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RANDALLS ISLAND; Besuboru for Early Risers
description: Hideki Irabu, Hideo Nomo and Masato Yoshii were probably still snoozing early last Sunday morning when Eiki Miura sprinted to the mound. As the sun came up over the outfield, Mr. Miura, 23, swung his arm for his first fastball amid a cacophony of cheers from his team, the Jokers. Their rivals, the Dreams, and the fans joined in: ''Gambare, gambare!'' (''Go for it!'')

title: Passion Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; The Hype and Hope of Reading to Baby
description: FOR baby's literary enlightenment, the hand that rocks the cradle should also be turning the pages of ''Good Night Moon'' or ''The Poky Little Puppy.''

title: An Ancient Music They Can Trot To
description: PANSORI, the music used in Zingaro's ''Eclipse,'' is narrative folk opera that has thrived in Korea for more than 500 years. The forerunner of the country's theatrical arts, its melodic roots can be traced to the ancient shamanist ritual music of the peninsula's southwestern region. Its repertory is derived from centuries-old folk tales, though new works have been created in recent years.

title: Taking the Kids
description: To the Editor: As a member of the obsolete Baby Sitter Generation, I gasp at travel articles by fond parents who deprive themselves of museums and concerts to accommodate the interest span of a youngster. Couldn't Grandma keep that 5- or 7-year old for a week or two? Parents who sacrifice immersion in the glorious Uffizi (''On Your Mark, Get Set, Duomo!'' Aug. 16) in favor of gelati and swimming could have stayed at home for a tenth of the money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAETH, ELOISE O'MARA
description: SPAETH-Eloise O'Mara. Of East Hampton, NY on September 4, 1998. Wife of the late Otto. Much beloved mother of Otto L. Spaeth, Jr.(Tony), Mary Louise Koon of St. Louis, and the late Marna Doherty and Deborah Shakespeare Green. Grandmother of sixteen. Great grandmother of 15. Mass of Christian Burial at Most Holy Trinity Church, Buell Lane, East Hampton on Friday, September 11 at 11 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 or to the Eloise Spaeth Collection Preservation Fund at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: POSTINGS: A Contract for Swingline Stapler Buildings; A Buyer Is Set For Queens Site
description: Two industrial buildings in Long Island City that are being vacated by a stapler manufacturer that used one of them for almost 50 years have found a buyer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPANOPOULOU, EUGENIA
description: SPANOPOULOU-Eugenia. The students, faculty, and staff of the Mount Sinai Graduate School of Biological Sciences mourn the tragic deaths of a stellar member of the faculty, Eugenia Spanopoulou, her husband Andrew Hodtsev, and their son Platon in the crash of Swissair 111. Eugenia was a brilliant young scientist whose sparkling creativity and personality enlivened and enriched our entire program. Her scientific accomplishments were already remarkable. She was also a marvelous mentor for her students. She energetically engaged in the work of developing their talents, careers and developing the new programs in which many of them were training. She thus influenced so many of us and fostered enhancements that will be part of the powerful legacy of a grievously shortened life. We extend our profound condolences to Eugenia and Andrew's families. Terry Ann Krulwich, Dean Mount Sinai Graduate School of Biological Sciences Sharon and Frederick A. Klingenstein-Nathan G. Kase, MD Professor

title: When a Doctor Retires: Two Views
description: To the Editor:

title: That's One Big Tomato, And It Wins a Prize
description: They didn't have to be pretty, just big. And the winner of the New Jersey Championship Tomato Contest last week was pretty big, all right. George Bucsko of Clifton took the grand prize with a 4.95-pound bumpy green tomato (bottom picture). His, like many other entries this year, was green, owing to the recent warm weather, which slowed the ripening process. Mr. Bucsko won $1,000 in gift certificates for Shoprite, sponsor of the contest.

title: The Man Behind the Mouth Behind Late-Show Host
description: AT 3:30 on a Thursday afternoon, Conan O'Brien is at his ''Late Night'' desk at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, rehearsing the show he'll tape two hours from now. He is talking to a photograph of President Clinton on a television monitor. In a corner of the studio, seated on a wooden stool, his head on a chin rest, Robert Smigel is doing Mr. Clinton's voice. On the monitor, only his mouth is seen, moving in the space where the President's mouth should be.

title: Denise Blate, Philippe Roederer
description: Denise Michele Blate, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth L. Blate of New York, and Philippe Louis Roederer, the son of Count and Countess Roederer of New York and Pornic, France, were married on Tuesday in Pornic. Dr. Philippe Boennec, Pornic's Mayor, officiated at the City Hall. Yesterday, the Rev. Michel Vaire performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of Notre Dame in La Garnache, France.

title: The Other Side Of Truck Driving
description: To the Editor:

title: Lapses of Photographic Memories
description: I may be the last person left in the world who takes snapshots on vacation and pastes them into a photo album. We have a treasure house of family history, a dozen formidable albums as big as medieval Bibles in which our holiday memories are lovingly preserved. The pictures have scarcely changed over the years. The main actors get a little older and grayer, but the prints are so small and fuzzy that it scarcely shows. Every vacation place looks exactly like every other. Photo albums give a reassuring sense of time standing still.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAM, WILLIAM TAYLOR
description: HAM-William Taylor, Jr., 89, of Richmond, died Wednesday, September 2, 1998. He is survived by his wife Jean Anderson Ham, two daughters, Christiana Ham Read, of New York, and Elsbeth Ham, of Richmond, a son-in-law Peter B. Read, Jr., two grandchildren, Rufus and Panthea Read. Mr. Ham was a veteran of the USMC from WW II. He retired from the Department of biophysics at MCV, after completing much research in the field of biophysics. He was the recipient of the 1990 Science Museum of Virginia's Lifetime Achievement Award, and the first annual ''George M. Wilkening Award'' in March of 1997.

title: House of a Different Color
description: On the outside, this is a typical late Victorian house, clad in cream-colored plaster on a small square in a stylish London neighborhood. You'd never guess that its grande-dame interior has recently been transformed from fusty to fabulous. But Jenny Armit, a decorator with a reputation for an exuberant use of color and an idiosyncratic style, knows that inside many a dowager beats the heart of a babe.

title: Cleaning Up, Throwing Out Without the Garage Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: Desalination Plant Goes to Work in Cape May
description: The first desalination plant in the Northeast began operating in Cape May last week, passing drinking water purity tests and satisfying hotel guests, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, TARA
description: NELSON-Tara. Sutton Place Synagogue extends heartfelt condolences to our members Sheila & Robert Nelson on the devastating loss of their cherished daughter. She was a shining star. Our sympathies to the family and to Dr. Edward Firouztale on the loss of his beloved. May their inspiring memories be a source of comfort. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Robert W. Berend, President

title: The Sound Of 1 Dog Barking
description: Q: I live in a co-op building and my bedroom is opposite a rental building that houses hearing-impaired tenants. One of the tenants owns two dogs, one of which is a constant barker. The barking usually begins before 7 A.M. and is a daily occurrence. I have complained to the owners of the building and was told that other than communicating with the tenant about this, there was nothing they could do. Is there some law that makes the landlord of this building responsible for alleviating this kind of problem? Is there an agency that would be responsive to such a complaint? . . . Sandy Berger, Manhattan.

title: Ms. Orlando, Mr. Munoz-Suarez
description: Susan Hamilton Orlando, the daughter of Janet and Geoffrey Orlando of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alejandro Munoz-Suarez, a son of Myriam Suarez and Isidoro Munoz, both of Miami. The Rev. Phillip Washburn performed the ceremony at the Scarsdale Congregational Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, C. DICKERMAN
description: WILLIAMS-C. Dickerman. Died peacefully in his 98th year, August 12, 1998 in Hamden, Connecticut. Devoted husband of the late Virginia Fain Williams, and father of Joan Williams Farr of NYC, Honor Williams Ishida of Tokyo, and Stephen F. Williams of Washington, D.C. Memorial service at 11 A.M., October 2, Church of the Redeemer, 185 Cold Spring Street (corner of Cold Spring & Whitney Avenue), New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Yale Law School.

title: Backtalk; Yes, Tyson Is a Menace; Get Him Back in the Ring
description: To those who have chronicled Mike Tyson for the past decade, it is not surprising that he has gone from ring rage to road rage. Last week's allegation that he punched one man in the chest and kicked another man in the groin following an auto accident in Gaithersburg, Md., fits right into the litany of Tyson's four-wheel and two wheel misdeeds and mishaps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VANDINA, ALFRED
description: VANDINA-Alfred Sr. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alfred VanDina Sr., associated with The Times from 1967, until retiring in 1981.

title: Hands-On Diplomacy
description: KENYANS, for the most part, threw the disk with terrific pizazz though with almost complete lack of control, a whirling and unwinding of arms and legs, the Frisbee launched to points unknown. The Chinese, in general, were far more reserved -- feet planted solidly, a brief turn at the waist and a snap of the wrist, the tosses crisp and precise. Greenlanders added guttural, tennis-player-like grunts to their throws; Bolivians, it seemed, were impervious to exhaustion. In Morocco, young boys, weaned irreparably on soccer, continually tried to stop the disk with their feet. Iranians, meanwhile, were able to rocket the Frisbee halfway across the desert yet could not have caught it any worse if they'd been blindfolded.

title: Withdrawal of Financing Renews Questions About Candidate's Spouse
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross's announcement that her husband, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., was withdrawing $2.25 million he had donated to her campaign for governor has raised a question that prominent Democrats have been asking all year: just how wealthy is Mr. Ross?

title: Hollywood Calling. No Thanks.
description: BO ZENGER called and I knew summer was over. The Bo Zengers of the world have the crispness of autumn in their voices, their words are ringed with school bells, they promise tests, they demand that you look as if you are really in attendance.

title: Hey New York: Listen Up! 12 Ideas From (Gasp) Out of Town; Dealing With Dog Waste: Cities Put Up Their Mitts
description: They are large enough to pick up a mess and opaque enough to hide it. And they're free at roadside and parkside dispensers in various places nationwide, including Cambridge, Mass., Newport, R.I., Westport, Conn., and, soon, Cincinnati. The degradable plastic bags, known as Mutt Mitts, are made by a Kentucky company called Intelligent Products, and some people say they can make a real difference in keeping streets and parks free of dog waste.

title: Going Under
description: SALT WATER

title: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title: Genevieve Field
description: Field is co-founder (with Rufus Griscom) of the on-line magazine Nerve and co-editor of the book Nerve: Literate Smut.

title: Handel's Undramatic Dramas Overtake the Present
description: HANDEL has changed. For pretty much two centuries after his death, in 1759, he was remembered primarily as a composer of oratorios, anthems, concertos, suites and sonatas: music that bolstered a gentlemanly image of magnificence and decisiveness. His operas, so much more pliant and equivocal in tone, were largely forgotten until the 1920's. In 1927 he finally made his debut as an opera composer in the United States, when Smith College staged ''Giulio Cesare,'' which remained for several decades the Handel opera of choice. Most of the others had to wait until after World War II for their first modern performances, and only in the last two decades have a good number of them begun to be regularly produced and recorded.

title: Twilight Times
description: The best portions of WILD STRAWBERRIES (1957), Ingmar Bergman's study of old age, are those of rueful irony, as a Stockholm professor reviews his life while accepting an honorary degree. This haunting story is perhaps the great filmmaker's least eccentric project, though the reminiscences range from thorny to bitter-sweet. As the elderly protagonist, Victor Sjostrom (above, with Bibi Andersson), is simply wonderful with his snowy mane and strong features. Bergman's old man remembers poignantly and shows us how to await the Reaper and how to accept all that has come before. Ingrid Thulin, Gunnar Bjornstrand and others of the Bergman company add substance and flavor. FRIDAY at 8 P.M. on TURNER CLASSIC MOVIES.

title: Clinton Trip Fails to Silence Doubt on His Domestic Clout
description: It has been a question from the start of President Clinton's five-day trip to Russia, Ireland and Northern Ireland this week: will his domestic troubles affect his ability to function abroad as the nation's leader?

title: AT THE CASINOS
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: An Exhibition That Equates Craftsmanship With Artistry
description: WITH ''Glass Houses'' and a show by Robert Berlind, the Neuberger Museum of Art at Purchase College here pays its respects to both craft and art while drawing attention, no doubt unwittingly, to the minefield that lurks between the two.

title: An 'Old Guy,' Phillips Can Still Belt It Out
description: In the clubhouse after yesterday's 5-4 victory over the Braves, John Franco, the Mets' closer who turns 38 in less than two weeks, put an arm around a grinning Tony Phillips, the 39-year-old left fielder and leadoff hitter, and said, ''Nice job; the old guys can still do it.''

title: Taking the Bus to School
description: Is it fair that the state does not provide money for busing students who live within two miles of school? Did you take a bus?

title: That Deflationary Feeling
description: ''Bear markets never happen when interest rates fall.'' This argument has been trotted out in the last few months by all manner of Wall Street strategists, perhaps to calm nervous investors as they watched their portfolios drift lower.

title: Sidewalk Snowball Fete
description: The lines formed as usual on a recent summer night outside Bond Street and Bowery Bar. What was unexpected was the action around the corner, on the patch of sidewalk in front of Guru, a flavored-snowball stand. On some Thursdays, Mary Frey, Guru's owner, hauls out a turntable and transforms this dark industrial stretch of Lafayette Street into a yard-style party, where players on the downtown scene like the Beastie Boys and Chloe Sevigny hang out, listen to dub music and help themselves to free pomegranate and coconut snowballs.

title: Janet Adams, Richard Hollyday
description: Janet Rives Adams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Tilley Adams of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Carmichael Hollyday 5th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hollyday Jr. of Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. James Billington performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford Village, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, PATRICK
description: BELL-Patrick. All of us at Tourneau mourn the tragic loss of our beloved Patrick, aboard Swissair Flight 111. He was a treasured member of our family. We extend our deepest heartfelt condolences to his parents, brothers and to all who cherished him.

title: For Parker Posey, a Zany Dance in the Sun
description: PARKER Posey's brand of zany acting and stylish wit, the main attraction of so many independent films in recent years, is now introducing New Yorkers to the Sundance Channel, an offshoot of Robert Redford's Sundance Institute and Sundance Film Festival that became part of Time Warner's cable offerings this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEL, JAMES E.
description: FRIEL-James E. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of James E. Friel, associated with The Times from 1952, until retiring in 1978.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Language of Sickness
description: Surgeons may play God with human lives, but their cloak of technical mastery and medical jargon hides a deep vulnerability. After all, they must stand humbly by at that terrible moment when, as Richard Selzer puts it, ''the humidity of life'' dissipates into arid nothingness. It's understandable, then, that while still a relatively young man, Selzer found that he, like a doctor he writes of in THE DOCTOR STORIES (Picador USA, $25), ''had grown tired of blood, of always having to be involved with blood.'' Yet for Selzer, giving up the scalpel for the pen didn't mean turning away from the hospital. In the introduction to this selection from three decades of his short fiction, he makes it clear that he has always seen language and medicine as intertwined: ''Take away metaphor from illness and there is left only the suffering.'' Not surprisingly, it is the language of sickness that Selzer puts on display with a surgeon's deliberate care: In ''Whither Thou Goest,'' a widow searches for the man who received her dead husband's heart in a transplant; in ''Angel, Tuning a Lute,'' the painter Luca Signorelli tries to resurrect his dead son by portraying the corpse, only to realize that ''there is something beyond technique and facility,'' that ''grace must season the painter's hand.'' The doctor's hand too, it would seem. Selzer's fiction is refreshingly old-fashioned: his prose is formal, his ironies straightforward. (In ''Luis,'' a street urchin is poisoned when the ''glowing disk'' he thinks will save his family turns out to be a radioactive part from a discarded medical instrument.) In his introductory essay, he says, ''I am averse to killing off my characters, and have done so only when there was no other way.'' Yet the string of corpses that connects ''The Doctor Stories'' suggests that in fiction, as well as in fact, the healer never has as much control as he may imagine. Tobin Harshaw

title: Even the Clintons Deserve Their Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Right-Wing Slant on Choosing the Right College
description: A new, frankly conservative guide to the nation's top 100 colleges excoriates Harvard University, sings the praise of the University of Dallas and criticizes many institutions for unchecked political correctness.

title: Rowing From Siberia to Brighton Beach
description: ONCE UPON

title: Saving Hospitals, But at What Cost?
description: The proposed sponsorship of Massapequa General and Mid-Island Hospital by Catholic Health Services and Winthrop South Nassau University Health System (''Saving Hospitals, but Not All Their Parts,'' Aug. 9) is not as simple as the proponents of the plan allow. Family planning and reproductive services would not be the only victims of this proposed association. If these community hospitals are forced to abide by Catholic directives, the loss of services will be far-ranging.

title: Correction
description: The On Politics column last Sunday, about property taxes, misstated the system for trash collection in the town of Essex Fells. Trash is collected by a private hauler from Belleville, T. Farese & Son. Homeowners pay the hauler directly; tax dollars are not involved.

title: Veteran of '87 Sees Less Cause for Alarm
description: AS the world's stock markets wobble wildly, Asian economies sink into recession, Russia slams the door on its creditors and American and foreign financial institutions make provisions for billions in losses, the Treasury and the Federal Reserve are hastily dusting off their primers on financial crisis management.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Customers Are Great Innovators
description: ''NO user-serviceable parts inside.'' This familiar warning label, alerting consumers to unmentionable perils lurking just beneath the Phillips screws, symbolizes everything that is wrong with today's company-customer relationships. By limiting user access, companies undermine their greatest source of competitive advantage.

title: The Nation: Who's Mr. Clean?; Washington Nervously Awaits New Deliveries of Dirty Laundry
description: EVERYBODY here is whispering about whispering about everybody else's sex life.

title: Julie Rosenbaum,Eric Skolnick
description: Julie Fay Rosenbaum, a daughter of Judith K. Rosenbaum and Richard Merrill Rosenbaum of Rochester, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Eric Dan Skolnick, a son of Irene R. Skolnick and Dr. M. Leon Skolnick of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Joshua Porush is to officiate at the Rochester Riverside Convention Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HODES, SHIRLEY
description: HODES-Shirley. Beloved wife of Bernard. Devoted mother of Margaret and Henry. A great Latin teacher and scholar, an accomplished cook, who brought love and light into so many people's lives. Passed away August 22, 1998 in Weston, CT. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: At Columbus Circle, A Circuitous Path To Columbus Centre
description: FOR most of this decade, Stephen M. Ross has been staring intently at the development opportunity of a lifetime -- right through the windows of his own office.

title: MOVIED THIS WEEK
description: A Japanese version of Shakespeare, urban suspense, , a macabre thriller and an excursion into American history furnish the highlights among films on television this week.

title: Engineering Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Insurance Alone Won't Make Children Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/100 John Street; A Theater Producer Sets His Next Act Downtown
description: RICHARD JAY-ALEXANDER is standing on the edge of Manhattan, and it seems inevitable that the lyrics to some great American musical are going through his head. This is a man who cannot visit Beekman Place without hearing ''Mame,'' look at Ellis Island without thinking ''Ragtime'' or eat a steak at Delmonico's without accompaniment from ''Hello, Dolly.''

title: 5 Teen-Agers Meet an Alien, and Then. . .
description: THEY don't trust anyone, over or under 30. They are convinced that there is a vast conspiracy against them, one that may include members of their own families. They believe that only they can save the world. And when threatened, they easily turn into a bunch of wild animals.

title: New Residential District Is Born in Chicago
description: A HANDFUL of developers are creating a new residential neighborhood in a former industrial area of this city, just blocks away from the Loop central business district.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: When Kenneth Starr was chosen to investigate Whitewater in 1994, the White House counsel, Abner Mikva, assured the Clintons that this was a fine selection. Mikva and Starr had known each other for years. During the 1980's, the two men served together on the Federal Appeals Court in Washington, and though they were on opposite ends of the political spectrum, the liberal Mikva and the conservative Starr were friends. Mikva and Starr socialized at each other's homes, dined out together with their wives. When Mikva thought of Starr, words like ''ethical,'' ''fair,'' ''decent'' came to mind. If Mikva saw a fault in the younger judge, it was that Starr was a little too much of an egghead, too pedantic, just not street-smart. This was brought home to Mikva one day during a near fistfight at the Federal courthouse. Starr, Mikva and Laurence Silberman were on a three-judge panel and, when they retired to the conference room, it turned out that Silberman was furious with Mikva over the case they had just heard. ''Silberman said to me, 'If you were 10 years younger, I'd punch you out!' '' Mikva recalls. ''I look over, and there was Ken, looking at the ceiling, wishing he was not there. He never said a word. I attributed it to the gentle son of a minister who didn't like controversy.''

title: David Jefferson and Dawn Comer
description: Dawn Renee Comer, the daughter of Dr. James P. Comer of North Haven, Conn., and the late Shirley A. Comer, was married on Martha's Vineyard yesterday to David Christopher Jefferson, the son of Jewel and Thomas Jefferson of Cambria Heights, Queens. The Rev. Frederick J. Streets, the Yale University chaplain, performed the ceremony at Trinity United Methodist Church in Oak Bluffs, Mass.

title: Sports of The Times; History Is Made, And Fan Survives
description: THE ball soared into the steamy ozone of the Mississippi River Valley, and eventually it came down. Mark McGwire has been so hot, so consistent, so productive, that it seemed -- dare one say it? -- almost anticlimactic when the big man tied Babe Ruth with his 60th home run.

title: Fox Airs 60th, Then . . . Oops
description: Fox Sports experienced no problem switching from the Braves-Mets game in time to show Mark McGwire's 60th home run yesterday, but it nearly missed showing McGwire's second at-bat.

title: Kelly Cowan, Robert Garner Jr.
description: Kelly Michelle Cowan, a television producer, and Robert Bryan Garner Jr., a television reporter, were married yesterday by the Rev. Bernard Powell at the Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church in Palm City, Fla.

title: In Chinatown, Preserving The Past or the Present?
description: MOST visitors to this city's teeming, colorful Chinatown would probably never notice Hang Ah Alley. A concrete corridor between a restaurant and a playground, it looks like nothing more than a broad, tidy sidewalk, spruced up with a few adolescent trees and several new wooden benches.

title: As the City Grows Safer, Crime Loosens Its Grip on the News
description: It was a slow news day in the depths of summer. Thirteen Ohio factory workers had won a $296 million lottery. The Hamptons were gearing up for a visit by the Clintons.

title: Wayward Sea Turtle Nests Far From Home
description: BILL FRISBIE was taking an early-morning stroll on Napeague Beach on Aug. 13 when he passed another man who warned him something very unusual was ahead: a huge sea turtle was digging a hole in the beach.

title: Seeing Nantucket
description: To the Editor: On our recent trip to Nantucket Island, we took Dirk Roggeveen's walking tour, and we believe that visitors should make this their first order of business. It would be a shame to miss the island's rich history and architectural beauty. As the whaling ''capital'' of the world, Nantucket had its share of colorful characters and played an important role in history (the Boston Tea Party) and literature (''Moby-Dick'').

title: After No. 62 Comes, the Race to the Homer Record Will Continue
description: A line on page 19 of the Elias Sports Bureau's ''Book of Baseball Records'' is certain to have a different entry in the 1999 edition than the name it lists in this year's copy. The question is what name will appear on the line next year. Will it be Mark McGwire or Sammy Sosa?

title: After the Fall
description: THE WORD ACCORDING TO EVE

title: Circles and Spheres, Outdoors and Outsize
description: ONE of the rewards of looking at a lot of art is now and then coming across an artist who makes vital work in a mode frequently regarded as dry. At the Stamford Museum's Nature Center, the artist is Jean Woodham, who makes abstract sculpture often with an eye toward placing a large piece outdoors.

title: Drop of Water, Dapple of Sun, a Happy Fern
description: THIS short story could begin, ''Once upon a time.'' The time was a cool, great-to-be-outdoors day and the place, an old established garden that was in dire need of care.

title: N.F.C. Scouting Reports
description: (Teams are listed in predicted order of finish)

title: A Labor-Friendly Fund Helps to Channel the Power of Unions
description: LABOR DAY is still seen largely as a blue-collar, big-shoulders kind of holiday, even though the overwhelming majority of its celebrants are largely disassociated from the principles of the organized work force.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Robert Wilson; Directing The Wind And Sky
description: IT was Robert Wilson's night to shine. But because both he and Isabella Rossellini were dressed in black as they greeted each arrival at a benefit party on Aug. 29 for the Watermill Center, it was Kitty Carlisle Hart who dazzled the eye.

title: Miss Mezzalingua And Mr. McKenna
description: Kristen Carmel Mezzalingua, a daughter of Kathleen and Daniel Mezzalingua of Fayetteville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Joseph McKenna, a son of Rita and George McKenna of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Richard B. Morrow, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Syracuse.

title: Wagging the Dog: The Early Years
description: EDWARD L. BERNAYS, who died three years ago at the age of 103, was a master of public relations -- the grand spinmeister of the century he spanned.

title: Miami Succumbs to Cuban Serenade
description: At a recent nightclub concert before a word-of-mouth audience of fewer than 200 people, the Cuban singer-songwriter Carlos Varela surveyed the room from the stage and said, ''This looks like a concert in Havana.''

title: Big Money Changes Everything for Once-Genteel Racing Crews
description: Behind the scenes in America's Cup preparations, prospective crew members are playing a tactical game that is far from the water. The race instead is for the cushiest crew positions on the most solvent teams. And personal friendships, long the mainstay of genteel yacht racing, are falling by the wayside.

title: Winning With Ease
description: Casual, comfortable dress has replaced the Ascot-style spectacle that the Hampton Classic horse show became on Grand Prix Sundays in the late 1980's and early 90's. This year, women among the 2,500 guests invited to the sponsors' luncheons opted for sundresses, billowing shirts over tank tops and straw hats. Even the men wore open-neck shirts, leaving their gold-button navy blazers at home. Unchanged were the elaborate decorations on many of the 188 tables for 10 in the V.I.P. tents.

title: Manhattan Mountaineer
description: HOW do you practice climbing a mountain when you live in New York City? I was to be a last-minute substitute on a climb of Mount Rainier in Washington, 14,410 vertical feet. The trip was two weeks away and I wasn't trained. The organizer suggested I hike up stairs at a pace I could keep up all day wearing a 50-pound backpack. I imagined the photo on my wall -- me, grinning at the snow-covered summit. But then I saw myself stuck, being rescued by an emergency helicopter.

title: This Season, the Time May Have Arrived for a New World Order
description: High hopes.

title: Ms. de Sa Pereira and Mr. Druckman
description: Vanessa Isabelle de Sa Pereira, a daughter of Chantal and Edward de Sa Pereira of Paris, is to be married this evening to Steven Edward Druckman, a son of Joan and Richard Druckman of Princeton Junction, N.J. Rabbi Sarah Reines will officiate at the Troutbeck Inn in Amenia, N.Y.

title: Amory Bradford, 85, Times General Manager
description: Amory H. Bradford, a former vice president and general manager of The New York Times who was the chief negotiator for the Publishers Association in the bruising 114-day New York newspaper strike in 1962-63, died Friday at his home in Edisto Beach, S.C. He was 85.

title: N.F.L. by the Numbers
description: 1-10 -- Bills' record in '97 when trailing at halftime (they were 5-0 when ahead at halftime).

title: Noreen Wu, Benjamin Fried
description: Noreen Huey-Lih Wu, a daughter of Liang and C. P. Wu of Holmdel, N.J., was married yesterday to Benjamin Cecil Fried, a son of Edith Fried and Prof. Albert Fried of Manhattan. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, officiated at Wave Hill in the Bronx.

title: A Lot Going On
description: The royals get the Wilson treatment.

title: The Nation: Confidence Counts; Everybody's Measuring Consumer Fears. Big Deal.
description: LAST week, as the stock market tumbled, President Clinton's political embarrassments deepened and Russia's financial crisis snowballed, the biggest fear suddenly became fear itself.

title: They Got Game, And Laundry Too
description: Not a big fan of professional sports but a frequent spectator at men's basketball games, I had the extreme pleasure of attending a recent New York Liberty game at Madison Square Garden (''Building a Team With a Whole New Game Plan,'' by Kirk Johnson, Aug. 16).

title: Demolition in the City, Open Space in Mind
description: IN an effort to clear away blight, reduce density and generally make their communities more livable, Connecticut's three largest cities are busily demolishing hundreds of buildings, including 19th-century houses and factory buildings.

title: The Primaries in New York; Mr. Schumer for the Senate Nomination
description: It seems appropriate to initiate a new endorsement practice with an enthusiastic recommendation. Happily, the Democratic race for the United States Senate nomination gives us that opportunity. In a contest that features three strong candidates, Representative Charles Schumer of Brooklyn is our preference. As noted above, this endorsement applies only to the Democratic primary. In November the primary winner will face Senator Alfonse D'Amato in the general election.

title: Warm, Ripe And Juicy: Fruit Picked By the Buyer
description: FEW things are so sublime as plucking a plump peach from the tree and biting into its sweet pulp, oozing with the essence of late summer. And what can compare with picking a big red apple from the branch, piercing its crisp skin and crunching through its tart white flesh, with the brisk autumn air tingling one's cheeks?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IMBARRATO, AURELIA CALIGIURI
description: IMBARRATO-Aurelia Caligiuri. September 2, 1917-August 28, 1992. You are in our hearts always. Valerie and Julia

title: Judy Lew, Jonathan Rollins
description: Judy Lew, the daughter of Jung Ja and Joseph Eun Sang Lew of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Jonathan Frederick Ashley Rollins, the son of Edwin Ashley Rollins of Brooklyn and the late Audre Geraldin Lorde. The Rev. Gail Burger, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: Romeo Salta, Dining Pioneer In Manhattan, Is Dead at 93
description: Romeo Salta, one of the first Manhattan restaurateurs to introduce fine Italian cuisine, died on Aug. 31 at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: A Roof Over Some Heads, For at Least a Little Longer
description: Faced with the prospect of 2,200 people becoming homeless this fall and winter, the Whitman administration decided last week that it would not hold fast to its 12-month time limit for some people who depend on the state's emergency housing assistance program.

title: Karen Fallowes, Andrew Ruffino
description: Karen Elizabeth Fallowes, a daughter of Victoria Bolker Fallowes and Russ F. Fallowes of Westfield, N.J., was married on Thursday to Andrew Arthur Ruffino, a son of Joan Ruffino of New Windsor, N.Y., and Dr. Anthony R. Ruffino of Salisbury Mills, N.Y.

title: Crime in Prague
description: To the Editor: On a recent six-day visit to Prague my wife and I were confronted by criminals on three occasions.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: PRECIOUS JEWELS OF TIBET

title: More Proof for the Dow Theory
description: ON Aug. 5, early in a frenzied month for the stock market, there were no apocalyptic headlines heralding the significance of the 299-point drop the previous day in the Dow Jones industrial average. But there should have been.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEURTEMATTE, JEANNE
description: HEURTEMATTE - Jeanne. Jeanne Heurtematte of Washington, DC and Saltaire, NY on September 1, 1998. Wife of Julio E. Heurtematte, Jr, mother of Darcy Heurtematte, stepmother of Douglas and Marc Heurtematte, sister of Patricia Connelly McAllister, daughter of Rita Gorman Connelly. Memorial mass at 10:30 A.M. on Wednesday, September 9, at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, 8th and N Street, NW, Washington, DC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Children's National Medical Center, 111 Michigan Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20010-2970 or the National Bone Marrow Program, Northwest 8925, POB 1450, Minneapolis, MN 55485-8925.

title: Dumping by the Coast Guard
description: Until the raising of the nation's environmental consciousness in the 1970's, many Americans treated their bays, rivers and streams as little more than open sewers into which trash, sewage and industrial waste could be cheaply and quickly dumped. Even so, it comes as something of a shock to be reminded that among the vandals was the official guardian of the nation's navigable waterways -- the United States Coast Guard.

title: Style; The Shrug Culture
description: When Monica Lewinsky appeared before a Federal grand jury in August to testify about her relationship with President Clinton, The New York Times described her as ''ending months of anticipation with a resigned shrug.'' Stepping from her car, she ''embraced a lawyer, shrugged and vanished inside.'' The weather in steamy Washington was perhaps too seasonable for a sweater, but Lewinksy's gesture, nonetheless, was right in style.

title: Sharissa Jones, Daniel Medwed
description: Sharissa Yvonne Jones, the daughter of Sharlane and Thomas Jones of Benkelman, Neb., is to be married this evening to Daniel Stern Medwed, a son of Mameve and Howard Medwed of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Michael Davis performed the ceremony at the United Methodist Church in Benkelman.

title: A Letter Comes. Wait's Over. You Finally Have a Teacher.
description: IF you're between 5 and 11 years old and go to the Watchung School in Montclair, The Letter was sent out last Friday.

title: Her Band, Herself, Made Over
description: SONGS, singers and songwriters have no fixed relationship. Some songs float free almost immediately to become pop standards or folky anthems as separate from individuals as ''My Funny Valentine'' or ''Blowin' in the Wind.'' Others mold themselves to interpreters' personalities, as ''My Way'' suited Frank Sinatra and later Sid Vicious. And certain songs are virtually inseparable from their originators; they are tied to a place, a sound, a life story. Smart pop stars use them to build myths.

title: What's for Lunch? Maybe a Few Bao Chi, Maybe a Couple of Quenepas
description: The scene is a familiar one. Mom and Dad are rushing to get ready for work. The children are stalling or excited, as the case may be, because it is the first day of another school year. One parent is trying to find a son's shoe; the other is packing a daughter's purple-and-pink lunch bag with a tuna sandwich or leftover fried chicken and Oreos.

title: DIARY
description: DRUGS

title: Can't Talk Just Now
description: To the Editor:

title: ART DEAL
description: Last year, when Nevada lawmakers approved a controversial tax break for buyers of $25,000 or more in art, they really had a single arts patron in mind: the casino mogul Steve Wynn, whose Mirage Resorts has bought $285 million in big-ticket paintings for its tony Bellagio hotel (set to open Oct. 15). In response, State Senator Ernie Adler wants the 1999 Legislature (Nevada pols meet biennially) to pass a ''poor man's art exemption.'' Buy $250 worth of local art and you'll pay just 2 percent sales tax instead of the customary 7. Adler also hopes that the tax break will liven up the market in a state that isn't exactly an arts hub. ''It's a nice thought,'' says Kathleen Nathan of the Smallworks Gallery in Las Vegas. ''It wouldn't turn things around, but it's a start.''

title: Take Me Back to the Ballgame!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAHMOUSH, ODETTE
description: TAHMOUSH - Odette. Beloved wife of the late Albert J. Tahmoush. Dear mother of Sandra Hansen, Cheryl Chicarelli, Susan Brown, and Laurel O'Neil. Grandmother of eight; great grandmother of one. Sister of Mary Bunai, Evelyn Abdelahad, and the late George Mousalam. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, September 9, 11 AM at Christ's Episcopal Church, 43 So. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY. Memorial contributions to U.S. Committee to UNICEF, Dept. 11251, 333 E. 38 St., NY NY 10016 or Doctors Without Borders USA, Inc., 6 E. 39 St., NY NY 10016 appreciated.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Opening Day Extremes: Redemption and Disappointment; Spectacular Finish Dooms Jets in OT
description: For four quarters today, for one game, for one season opener, the Jets showed they were equal to the National Football League's best.

title: As Demand for Teachers Exceeds Supply, Schools Sweeten Their Offers
description: In Baltimore this summer, prospective special-education teachers were in such demand that they were offered more money than the union contract requires: those with just a year's experience got the starting salaries of four-year veterans -- the equivalent of a $2,000 raise before ever putting chalk to blackboard. And like applicants in all other subject areas, they were also entitled to reduced-rate mortgages and low-interest $1,500 loans for relocation.

title: Living for Rice, Begging for Rice
description: It has become a ritual whenever a delivery truck arrives at the Cipinang rice market here. Young men clamber onto the truck to unload the sacks of rice, while women and children huddle next to the loading dock with crude brooms and dustpans.

title: RUSSIAN NOMINEE WARNS OF CHAOS IF HE IS REJECTED
description: On the night before Russia's Parliament is to vote again on whether he becomes Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin warned on national television that the nation has entered a fiscal nose dive and that further political squabbling could lead to social chaos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODY, PAUL
description: BRODY-Paul. On September 6, 1998 after a courageous battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Sybil and loving father of Jonathan, Ruth and Gary Zelman, and Sarah and Tom Janover. Adoring grandfather of Hannah, Ari, Joshua and Leah. We will miss him always and will remember him best at his favorite spot on Middlesex Beach.

title: Helping Kosovo's Displaced
description: The temperature in the Kosovo hills at night is now down to 40 degrees, and that means death is coming. Despite Slobodan Milosevic's repeated denials that Serbian forces are carrying out ethnic cleansing, many villages in Kosovo look like the worst parts of Bosnia, with shelled carcasses of houses and eerily empty streets. So far, relief groups say, some 200,000 to 400,000 people, almost all women, children and the elderly, have fled their homes and about a quarter of them have no homes to go back to. Some are with relatives in other parts of Kosovo and a few have gone to Montenegro, Albania and even Bosnia, but between 50,000 and 150,000 are living in the forests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANOV, ETHEL
description: BANOV-Ethel. Age 95. Much loved mother of Robert, widow of Jack Banov, sister of Richard E. Page. Passed away peacefully Saturday afternoon, September 5, 1998. She will always be missed. Graveside services will be private.

title: A Work Issue That Won't Go Away
description: One way to imagine you aren't growing older is to discover that old moral dilemmas have been recycled as new, as if decades had not passed. In the 1950's, for example, the big dispute was about whether a woman could hold a job and raise a family. Now, despite the fact that two-thirds of mothers do both, there has been a spate of reports on women who have faced the great ''either-or'' question, and done either or done or.

title: When Getting Older Doesn't Mean Slowing Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Software Makers Win a Round in Year 2000 Court Fight
description: In one of the first battles in what promises to be a long and titanic legal struggle over Year 2000 computer woes, the maker of the popular financial software Quicken has scored a knockdown. But ultimate victory for the company is far from certain in a lawsuit that tests just how active software companies must be in heading off problems their customers might suffer as a result of the so-called millennium bug.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: Irabu Is Spinning Out of the Rotation
description: Hideki Irabu was a Cy Young award candidate in May, a possible All-Star in June. Now he is in jeopardy of being dropped from the Yankees' rotation and, eventually, from their playoff roster.

title: Progress in Investigation of Embassy Blasts, Officials Say
description: Investigators have arrested two more suspects in the bombing of the United States Embassy here and have made significant progress in determining how the bomb was made and taken to the embassy, F.B.I. and local police officials say.

title: In Senate Race, 3 City Candidates Accentuate Upstate Ties
description: Before a dinner of pizza and beer in a back room at Pete's, an Italian restaurant and bar here in the northernmost reaches of New York State, Mark Green offered what has become his trademark serenade to voters outside of New York City as he pursues the Democratic nomination for United States Senate.

title: 3 Weeks to Judgment On the Mets' Season
description: There were 40,311 fans at Shea Stadium on a sun-drenched afternoon, 40,311 people who could have been frolicking in pools, relaxing on beaches or sitting in air-conditioned living rooms watching football. Actually, they might as well have been doing something else yesterday because John Smoltz emphatically brought the Mets back to reality in steering the Atlanta Braves to a 4-0 victory.

title: Clinton's Fate on Many Minds as Congress Returns to Work
description: The Democratic hand-wringing over President Clinton's personal behavior is intensifying as Congress returns to Washington this week for its final month of business.

title: Phnom Penh Journal; High-Minded Machiavelli, or Cambodia's Spoiler
description: ''Read this,'' said Sam Rainsy, leaving the room to dress for a political rally. ''A different point of view.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: I.R.A. Cannot Guarantee Disarmament, Adams Says
description: Gerry Adams, the leader of the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, said today that he could not guarantee that the I.R.A. would agree to disarm during the negotiations in the new Northern Ireland Assembly.

title: Finger Injury Sidelines Piazza
description: A hole was drilled in the fingernail of Mets catcher Mike Piazza's left index finger yesterday to drain fluid that had built up after Piazza was hit on the hand by a throw while breaking up a double play on Saturday night.

title: Holier Than Thou: Behind the Iranian-Afghan Rift
description: Although all-out war appears unlikely, the tens of thousands of Iranian troops deployed in a threatening buildup along the Afghan border have drawn attention to the hostility between two of the world's most conservative Islamic Governments.

title: Manchester United Gets Murdoch Bid
description: British Sky Broadcasting, Europe's second-biggest satellite broadcaster, is to buy England's Manchester United club for as much as $961.6 million, The Daily Telegraph reported in yesterday's editions, without citing sources.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUVILER, PAT
description: JUVILER-Pat. Rest in peace, after your courageous battle. Our sympathies to Michael, Dan, Mark and David. Ann and Bernie Jacobson

title: When Things Kept Silent Are Finally Said Aloud
description: Nothing is more lethal than family quarrels. Not only do they breed fury, grief and unforgiving righteousness, as anyone who has studied history or drama knows (Where do we begin? Euripides, Shakespeare, Lope de Vega?), family quarrels breed or mirror national and international ones. And artists -- who, if they are worth anything, tell all without flinching or fawning -- are often accused of betraying the family's, the race's or the nation's honor; telling secrets that render them less than implacably noble in their triumph or suffering.

title: Sports of The Times; The Understudy Stands His Ground Out on 'the Island'
description: AS the Giants' right cornerback, Conrad Hamilton was not only out there on what is known in pro football as ''the island,'' he was also out there as an understudy to the star. With Jason Sehorn awaiting knee surgery on Sept. 22, it was as if Hamilton had suddenly replaced Tom Hanks or Tom Cruise in a feature film.

title: For Men of a Certain Age, Three Roles to Savor
description: One set. Three characters. At least nine lives.

title: Northwest Strike Mediator Sends the Negotiators Home
description: After shuttling between negotiators for Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots for two days, a Federal mediator sent the two sides home yesterday and asked them to redouble their efforts to bring an end to the nine-day strike, which has grounded Northwest's nearly 1,700 daily flights.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It might not be time to crack out the champagne bottles, but it's probably time for a couple of cold beers on Labor Day to celebrate what's taken place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, EDWIN A.
description: MALLOY-Edwin A. On September 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Jennifer Combs and Timon. Loving grandfather of Meredith Combs. Dear brother of Howard Malloy and Tobene Rosenthal. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Service Wednesday, September 9, 2 PM, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street.

title: The Unknown Swiss Upsets Graf
description: Improbably, the first match point didn't belong to her, and neither did the second. When Steffi Graf, haughty but helpless in her unfamiliar moment of crisis in the Round of 16 at the United States Open, caved in and elbowed an awkward, errant backhand return beyond bounds, the match belonged instead to the upstart Patty Schnyder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, BILLY
description: FUHRMANN-Billy. Dear, dear friend to Jessica and Hunter. We will so miss your beautiful smile, delicious scent and hysterical laughing attacks. You touched us as individuals and as husband and wife. You brought us together and were a part of our family.

title: Rios, Once No. 1, Continues in His Slump
description: Only one small, agile left-hander played a match worth savoring in Arthur Ashe Stadium last night. That would be Patty Schnyder.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: As Irked Creditors Wait, Officials Squabble in Syracuse Bankruptcy
description: It is the sort of fight usually found on a playground, complete with glares, name-calling and a tussle over strawberry Twizzlers.

title: CHILDREN AND FAMILIES; Media Talk; High-Profile Authors Turn To Much Younger Readers
description: Several high-profile authors have recently written or agreed to write children's books, and Hyperion Books for Children has created a new imprint, Jump at the Sun. It will produce children's books with an African-American emphasis by authors like Toni Morrison and Bell Hooks.

title: House Chiefs Will Discuss Setting Rules On Starr Study
description: House Democratic and Republican leaders this week will try to resolve an increasingly contentious debate over exempting the Judiciary Committee from many House rules as the panel reviews President Clinton's conduct in the Lewinsky matter.

title: Big Marketers Join to Upgrade Internet Ads
description: Seven top marketers are joining the At Home Corporation, which operates the At Home Network Internet service, to create and test the larger, more elaborate types of on-line advertising that were the subject of a meeting last month on interactive marketing sponsored by the Procter & Gamble Company.

title: An Election Season Shadowed By Crises at Home and Abroad
description: As they take to the trail this Labor Day for the traditional opening of the fall campaigns, Republican and Democratic candidates say the Lewinsky matter, a jittery stock market and tumult abroad have thrust them into the most unsettled, and unpredictable, election season in years.

title: Virginia E. Rice, A Reader's Digest Editor, 53
description: Virginia E. Rice, a former head of the department at Reader's Digest that selected books to excerpt or condense, died on Aug. 19 at her home in Tucson, Ariz. She was 53. The cause of death was lung cancer, said Gary D. Yanker, her husband.

title: Bradley Carefully Weighs Presidential Run
description: In his Hall of Fame career with the New York Knicks, Bill Bradley lacked the insouciant grace of a natural athlete. Instead, his were the precise rhythms of a workaholic who had practiced every move, from his signature pull-up jumpers to his scoop shots and reverse dribbles, hundreds of thousands of times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANC, JOHN PATRICK
description: FRANC-John Patrick. Age 39. Beloved son of Kathleen and the late Gustave Franc, and brother of Michael, died on Friday, September 4, 1998. Wake at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, Monday, September 7, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th Street, Tuesday, September 8, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Rose's Home, 71 Jackson Street, New York, NY 10002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, JOHN PERRY
description: WALSH-John Perry. Died on Saturday evening, September 5, after a long and valiant battle with cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering in New York. A graduate of Yale, Class of 1950, a Captain in the United States Marine Corps, Mr. Walsh was President in the family apparel business, Florence Walsh, Inc., until his retirement in 1984. Beloved husband of Margo Grant Walsh. He is survived by his sister Elizabeth Walsh Sisk, one nephew and three nieces. Friends may call Tuesday, September 8, from 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Funeral mass will be Wednesday, September 9, 9:30 AM, at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church at 55th Street and 1st Ave., New York City. Interment will be private in the family plot in St. Joseph's Cemetery, Rhinecliff, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Solid Tumor Group, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, in the name of John Perry Walsh.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHIFF, DR. MILTON
description: SCHIFF-Dr. Milton. Age 88. Retired dentist in practice over 60 years. Former President and National Vice President of ZOA; President of the Men's Club of the Brooklyn Jewish Center and member of the Board of Trustees; Chairman for UJA; leader in Israeli Bond Drives. Survived by daughters, Naomi Myers, Ruth Seidenberg, Karen Shatz; grandchildren, Keith, Beth, Marc, Lauren, Ilana, Daniel; great - grandchildren, Jared, Benjamin, Rachel, Jack. Services Tuesday, 12:00, at Wein & Wein, 129 Engle, Englewood, NJ.

title: Woman Raped on Train That Had No Conductor
description: A 21-year-old woman was raped and robbed on a G train in Brooklyn late Saturday night, the police said yesterday. There was no conductor on the train because New York City Transit has been running weekend G trains without conductors since March, despite the objections of critics who warned that the trains would be more dangerous.

title: Malaysia Worries Over Mahathir's Succession
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Until recently, Malaysian officials had a stock response to businessmen asking why they should invest here instead of in other countries in the region. They would say that unlike many of its neighbors, Malaysia was stable. The country had a clear successor to Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, RAYMOND
description: FOX-Raymond. Age 92. Of North Miami Beach, FL. Formerly of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn. Died September 4, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Rosiland, father of Ethel (Joe) and Joyce (Robert), grandfather of Cheryl (Kenny), Michael, Andrew (Amy) and Karen. Great grandfather of Benjamin, Adina, and Jaret. We loved you, respected you and admired you. We will miss you. Services were held in Florida.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Sunday of Amory Bradford, a former vice president and general manager of The New York Times, referred incorrectly to the secret society he joined at Yale. It was Skull and Bones, not Skull and Crossbones.

title: Yes, the Tale of Esther As Modern-Day Thriller
description: THE GUN RUNNER'S DAUGHTER

title: Compressed Data; Time to Set The Millennium Clock
description: Budd Goldman, an inventor in Mineola, N.Y., has earned his living for two decades making tchotchkies. ''Toilet paper holders that look like the back of cars, masks over shower heads that looked like celebrities, a little black box that you pushed it and it cursed,'' Mr. Goldman said, describing a few of his greatest hits.

title: Metro Matters; When a Race Becomes A Riddle
description: WHAT is the sound of three hands clapping?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAETH, ELOISE O'MARA
description: SPAETH-Eloise O'Mara. Of East Hampton, NY on September 4, 1998. Wife of the late Otto. Much beloved mother of Otto L. Spaeth, Jr.(Tony), Mary Louise Koon of St. Louis, and the late Marna Doherty and Deborah Shakespeare Green. Grandmother of sixteen. Great grandmother of 15. Mass of Christian Burial at Most Holy Trinity Church, Buell Lane, East Hampton on Friday, September 11 at 11 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 or to the Eloise Spaeth Collection Preservation Fund at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: Media Talk; Two More Television Stations Drop Howard Stern's Show
description: Two more television stations, in Phoenix and in San Diego, dropped Howard Stern's late-night show from their schedules last week, joining a station in Lubbock, Tex., which did so last Monday.

title: Joy. Frustration. Motherhood.
description: The thing that got to my sister was not being able to give either job -- work or parenting -- a hundred percent. This was before she had her fourth child, when she was still a wage earner.

title: Unions, Growing Bolder, No Longer Shun Strikes
description: The recent strikes at Northwest Airlines, General Motors, Bell Atlantic and U S West represent the biggest surge in major walkouts in years and, industrial relations experts say, point to a new aggressiveness on the part of the nation's labor unions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPMAN, MARTIN J.
description: CHAPMAN-Martin J. On September 4, 1998. Ret. Major World War II. Beloved husband of the late Felixia. Devoted father of Martin, Stephen, and Catherine Martinis. Dear grandfather of Patricia Dombroff, Christine & Philip Chapman. Great grandfather of two. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th St.) NYC, Sunday 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial at Epiphany RC Church, Tuesday, 11 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Minor Victory for Intuit In Suit on Year 2000 Woes

title: Giants Still Must Run To Go the Extra Mile
description: BIG BLUE defense bailed out the offense again yesterday. Like big brother or big sister who keeps the bully at bay, the Giants' bruising defense swatted Washington back whenever it got a bit too close and the Giants escaped with a pleasant season-opening victory.

title: New Venture for C-Span: All Books, All Weekend
description: Expanding beyond its deadpan gavel-to-gavel coverage of Congress, C-Span is poised to bring similar unfiltered page-to-binding treatment of the publishing industry with the start on Saturday of Book TV, a regular weekend lit-a-thon of programs devoted to just books.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Media Talk; Hollywood Takes Break Over Labor Day Weekend
description: Movie addicts who were eager for a hot new film over the Labor Day weekend found slim pickings. But that was intentional on Hollywood's part. For film makers, the good news about Labor Day is the lack of competition; the bad news is the dearth of potential moviegoers.

title: How Top Pair Found Defeat In France
description: The world championships, which ended on Friday in Lille, France, brought victories to several countries. Italy won the Open Teams, after barely surviving a semifinal match against an American team. Austria won the Women's Teams, Poland the Open Pairs, the United States the Women's Pairs and Italy the Mixed Pairs.

title: Blue-Collar Greenwich
description: To the Editor:

title: Computer Wholesaler in Deal To Aid Its Custom-Order Sales
description: Ingram Micro Inc., the nation's largest wholesale distributor of computers, has signed a deal with PC Order.com Inc., a provider of electronic commerce technology, to create an on-line transaction system intended to let Ingram Micro deliver custom-built computers more efficiently to corporate customers.

title: A Wasteland, and Proud of It; E! Succeeds With Reruns and Short Attention Spans
description: As a new television season approaches, the broadcast networks are winding up an annual rite that involves spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing new series in hopes of finding the next ''Seinfeld'' or ''E.R.'' Though the chances of success are minuscule, the networks persist because the only way of attracting big audiences, and profits, is to come up with an original hit.

title: Penalties Costly To the Redskins
description: For two seasons, not much has gone right for the Washington Redskins when they face the Giants. A year ago, quarterback Gus Frerotte had to leave the game after head-butting a stadium wall, and later in the same game, Redskins receiver Michael Westbrook cost Washington a chance at victory when he drew a penalty for taking his helmet off.

title: INSIDE
description: Holding at 60 and 58

title: Perhaps Old Jerry Rice Met the New Jerry Rice
description: Right before halftime of yesterday's spectacular game between the Jets and the 49ers, San Francisco wide receiver Jerry Rice got into a scuffle with a Jets player. The two started pushing and shoving and Rice was not about to back down. Later, Rice could not remember what started the argument, but he did remember who broke it up. It was Keyshawn Johnson.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani and Organizers of Rally Clash Over Use of Force by Police
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stepped up his defense yesterday of police officers who stormed the stage at a youth rally in Harlem on Saturday, saying they had decided to move in only after the keynote speaker began urging the crowd to fight and even shoot police officers if provoked.

title: Editorial Observer; The Politics of Remedial Education at CUNY
description: Heavy-handed politics at the City University of New York has demoralized both faculty and administrators and led to a legal battle over an initiative that has made CUNY the first university of such historic importance to forbid remedial education on four-year campuses. A court ruling has blocked the plan, scheduled to phase in starting in 1999, pending a trial on whether trustees adopted the policy at a session that violated open-meeting laws.

title: Death Doesn't End Rule of Kim Il Sung, 'Eternal President'
description: North Korea announced today that it had revised its Constitution to make its late ''Great Leader,'' Kim Il Sung, the country's ''eternal President.''

title: In-House Competition From Web News Team
description: The next time Michael Jackson rumors start to swirl, word spreads of a Hollywood murder-suicide or Matt Damon changes his hair style, E! Entertainment will probably dispatch not one, but two teams of Hollywood news hounds.

title: Sprained Knee Sidelines Farrior
description: Jets linebacker James Farrior could be lost for up to a month, if not longer, after spraining his right knee. Chad Cascadden replaced him. Linebacker Bryan Cox produced consecutive sacks of Steve Young at pivotal moments in the fourth quarter, including one that pushed San Francisco out of field goal range with about nine minutes remaining.

title: Technology Start-Ups Suffer Market Jitters
description: After a month of hot and heavy flirting about a prospective merger, last Monday was going to be the day that CKS Group and USWeb finally got serious and set the price. Then the stock market started falling, dragging with it the already depressed shares of both companies.

title: El Paso, Feeling Gouged At Pump, Fights Back
description: A citizens movement to protest the high price of gasoline has become the hottest political issue in El Paso, drawing in Texas officials and entangling itself in a contentious proposal to open a pipeline from the Gulf Coast -- a kind of cavalry charging to the rescue.

title: Labor Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Nonaligned Movement Meets, Out of the Spotlight
description: Meanwhile, 6,200 miles to the south . . .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAHMOUSH, ALBERT J.
description: TAHMOUSH-Albert J. Of Naples, FL and Elmsford, NY. Beloved husband of the late Odette Tahmoush. Father of Sandra Hansen, Cheryl Chicarelli, Susan Brown, and Laurel O'Neil. Grandfather of eight; great grandfather of one. Memorial service will be held Wednesday, September 9, 11 AM at Christ's Episcopal Church, 43 So. Broadway, Tarrytown, NY. Memorial contributions to U.S. Committee to UNICEF, Dept. 11251, 333 E. 38 St., NY NY 10016 or Doctors Without Borders USA, Inc., 6 E. 39 St., NY NY 10016 appreciated.

title: The Strange Case of the Madman With a Quotation for Every Word
description: In 1879 when Prof. James Murray began the challenging assignment of editing the first edition of the Oxford English Dictionary, a project of unprecedented historical and cultural importance, the call went out for volunteers to supply quotations to illustrate definitions. The most prolific and faithful correspondent, represented by more than 10,000 entries, was Dr. William C. Minor, a surgeon residing in Crowthorne in the English countryside in Berkshire.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ESPOSITO, JOHN A..M 9
description: ESPOSITO-John A..m 9/97 I live for those who love me, for those who know me true; for the heaven that smiles above me and awaits my spirit, too; for the cause that lacks assistance, for the wrong that needs resistance, for the future in the distance, and the good that I can do. Daddy, you taught us more than you will ever know. We miss you so much. Love always, Annie, Tish and Thomas

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POWELL, MAXWELL M.
description: POWELL-Maxwell M. Five years and my heart is still aching. Send me a sign. I miss you so much. Susa

title: Memories of Silver Defies Her Medical Chart Again
description: They were two of the finest grass-racing fillies in the country, Memories of Silver and Auntie Mame, and they tangled in Saratoga's prestigious Diana Handicap today and toughed it out down the homestretch. But at the wire, with the long shot B.A. Valentine tucked in between them, Memories of Silver streaked home with her third straight victory and a perfect post-surgical record for 1998.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: Doonesbury's Dow
Sound of Steel in a Warm-Up for Carnival
description: Eleven orchestras, with hundreds of musicians, performed in Brooklyn on Saturday night, and there wasn't a music stand in sight. The orchestras were steel-drum bands, and their members -- adults, teen-agers and grade-school children -- played their elaborate arrangements from memory as they extended a magnificent 20th-century tradition. It was Panorama '98, the 31st annual steel-band showcase and competition presented by the West Indian-American Day Carnival Association on the grounds of the Brooklyn Museum of Art. The concert was part of the annual weekend of Caribbean shows that lead up to the Carnival parade on Labor Day.

title: Monsoon Hangs On, Swamping Bangladesh
description: For two months, the people of this village have been marooned on the tin roofs of their shacks, unwilling to abandon their homesteads even as the Jamuna River engulfed them in the longest-lasting flood in the history of this disaster-prone country.

title: Before the Next Long Weekend, Get Some Sleep
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Women and a Child Die in Bronx House Fire
description: Three people, including a mother and son, were killed yesterday in a fast-moving blaze in their wood-frame house in the Bronx, fire officials said.

title: Technology; At many computer companies, the most candid criticism emerges from employee E-mail forums.
description: WHEN managers blunder at certain high-technology companies, they are sure to read all about it -- not in the morning papers, but on their companies' internal computer networks, from their own subordinates, and often in language that would make a sailor blush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHURGIN, AUDREY
description: SCHURGIN-Audrey. The SAR Academy family notes with great sorrow the passing of our former Associate Principal. Condolences are extended to her dedicated and devoted husband Marvin, sons Jonathan and Paul, her father Simon Grishman, and to the entire family. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, September 8, at 12:30 PM at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th and Amsterdam. May the family find solace in her memory and be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack C. Bendheim, President Rabbi Joel Cohn, Principal Michael Schreck, Exec. Director

title: Witness Lists Suggest Moves By Microsoft And the U.S.
description: With the filing of witness lists on Friday night, the Government and the Microsoft Corporation offered the first glimpse of their courtroom strategies in the historic antitrust trial scheduled to begin later this month.

title: Voicing Anger at a Day Turned Upside Down
description: A home health care aide who works in Harlem spent two hours on Saturday trying to get home to the South Bronx. A woman trapped in front of her apartment on Malcolm X Boulevard was an hour late getting to work. And a Harlem woman trying to visit a shoe-repair shop was directed by the police through a circuitous maze of blue barricades, only to find the shop closed for the day.

title: Media Talk; High-Profile Authors Turn To Much Younger Readers
description: Several high-profile authors have recently written or agreed to write children's books, and Hyperion Books for Children has created a new imprint, Jump at the Sun. It will produce children's books with an African-American emphasis by authors like Toni Morrison and Bell Hooks.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Strike Zone Fools Mets, And Smoltz Dominates
description: Few hitters have a better idea of their strike zone than John Olerud. To see Olerud, the Mets' first baseman, argue a called strike is rare enough. To watch him toss his bat away and begin running to first base thinking he has walked, only to be called back, is rarer still.

title: Akira Kurosawa, Film Director, Is Dead at 88
description: Akira Kurosawa, who personified Japanese movies to most of the world and who grew into one of the handful of truly important directors that the cinema has produced, died yesterday at his home in Tokyo. He was 88.

title: Jazz Appetizers, Expertly Cooked
description: The last jazz festival of summer took place on Friday night at Summerstage in Central Park. For vague reasons, the co-producers of the Montreux Jazz Festival -- Claude Nobs, who founded it in 1967, and Quincy Jones, who became co-producer in 1991 -- decided to bring a mini-Montreux to New York.

title: When Getting Older Doesn't Mean Slowing Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Walking for Themes, Not Exercise; Tours Reveal the City Through a Variety of Prisms
description: Michael Kabac, walking-tour guide, gestured in the general direction of the bikers lounging across the street on St. Marks Place, then addressed the curious, and quite probably nervous, group of nine tourgoers before him. ''These are really neat people, you know?'' he said loudly, not that the bikers noticed. ''But they have more hair than you do. And as you can see -- they're out tonight.''

title: Quiet Day at Plate for McGwire
description: Two members of the St. Louis Cardinals smacked home runs in the eighth inning of their game against the Cincinnati Reds today, and even though Mark McGwire batted against John Hudek in that inning, he was not one of them. Fernando Tatis was.

title: Stallard Speaks Out: He Feels No Shame
description: Tracy Stallard, who seemed to be ducking telephone calls about his critical role in the home run record that the late Roger Maris is on the verge of losing, welcomed a call today to talk about that very subject. It enabled him, he said, to clear up any misimpression that might linger about his role.

title: U.S. Manufacturer Slowly Changes Course: Will Its A3XX Permit Airbus to Break Boeing's Hold on Jumbo Jet Market?
description: WASHINGTON  If you think of the mammoth Boeing Co. of Seattle not, say, as one big shiny 747 jumbo jet but as a fully loaded milelong oil tanker trying to shift course and outmaneuver a frigate in rough seas, you get a picture of the challenge facing the world's largest aircraft maker.

title: Labor Unions Show New Aggressiveness
description: Major strikes this summer indicate a new aggressiveness by the nation's labor unions, which, after several disasters, had generally shunned large-scale walkouts.

title: More Friendly Exchanges In Gubernatorial Debate
description: It is standard practice in politics to gang up on the front-runner. But for the second time in four days, the Democrats running for governor held a televised debate yesterday and the candidate recognized by his rivals as the leader, Peter F. Vallone, emerged largely unscathed.

title: Kirk O'Donnell, 52, Lobbyist And an Aide to a House Speaker
description: Kirk O'Donnell, a lawyer and lobbyist for a leading Washington law firm and the former chief aide to former Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., died on Saturday near his weekend home in Scituate, Mass. He was 52 and lived in Washington.

title: Compressed Data; Seeking Compromises On Internet Domain
description: With the Clinton Administration planning to end Federal financing for the management of Internet domain names on Sept. 30, the disparate forces struggling to constitute the global network's first legitimate governing body remain divided on issues trivial and profound.

title: Cashing In on a Programming Trend
