description: Mention HBO, and most people think adult thoughts. The pay-cable network is best known for sophisticated movies, R-rated comedy and big-time boxing, with the occasional provocative documentary thrown in. The words ''family fare'' definitely do not come to mind.

title: Bronx Mother Is Charged After Baby Drowns in Tub
description: A Bronx woman who the authorities said had a history of leaving her 6-month-old daughter unattended was arrested yesterday after the infant drowned while left alone in a bathtub, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELISCU, EDWARD
description: ELISCU-Edward. A memorial service will be held at the Alexandria Room of Edmond Town Hall, Newtown, Connecticut, on Sunday, September 13, 1998, 2-4:30 PM.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; An Insult to Harlem
description: In the end the ordinary people of Harlem proved to be smarter and far more responsible than either Khallid Muhammad or Rudolph Giuliani.

title: $200,000 Lost in an Investment Gone Bad
description: Sometimes it can be hard to have sympathy for the kinds of people who fall for securities schemes: the greedy, the gullible, the gamblers. But in the case of the Bennett Funding Group, lawyers say, most victims were careful, conservative people who thought they were putting their money somewhere safe.

title: Can the Global Economy Really Stabilize Itself?
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Opening Day Extremes: Redemption and Disappointment; Giants' Defense Washes Away Last Season's Bitter Taste
description: The Giants returned to Giants Stadium today, hosts again to an important game before a sellout crowd, with the ghost of their last game in the building an uninvited but insuppressible companion.

title: Director Tries Gentle Changes For the Frick
description: Samuel Sachs 2d, director of the Frick Collection, may work at a Chippendale desk in a paneled room built more than eight decades ago as the boudoir of Adelaide Childs Frick, but he spends his days looking toward the future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLSTERLI, ANDREW
description: BOLSTERLI-Andrew. The international leadership of the World Union for Progressive Judaism extends its profound condolences to dear friends John and Marianne Slade on the tragic loss of their grandson, Andrew Bolsterli, and to the entire Bolsterli family. Austin C. Beutel, President Rabbi Richard G. Hirsch, Exec Dir

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEROLLA, JOSEPH S.
description: MEROLLA-Joseph S. Age 46. On September 5, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Susan Spencer Merolla. Loving father of Spencer, Justin, and Jamie. Devoted son of Margaret and the late Joseph Merolla. Caring brother of the late Margaret Merolla. Dear son-inlaw of Rita Spencer and brotherin-law of Mark and Betsy Spencer. Loving uncle of Erica, Kristen, and Charles. Devoted friend of Ann, Harri, Steven, Roberta, Jerome, Mary, and many others. Family will receive friends at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY, on Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Augustine Church, Larchmont, NY, on Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment to follow at Mt. Vernon Cemetery, West Boylston, MA. Memorial contributions to United Hospital Hospice, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573 would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAHN, MALCOLM B.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCKENNA, JOHN J. ''JACK''
description: McKENNA-John J. ''Jack''. Of Ridgewood, N.J., died at home September 4, 1998. He was 67. He was Vice-President and Director, Sales Services for Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc., New York, New York. Beloved husband of Marie (Marone) and the late Dorothy ''Doe'' McKenna, who died in 1977. Loving father of Rita O'Connor, Annemarie Rigler, Carolan Sherman, Mary K. Guarente, Jacqueline O'Connor, Marianne Thomas, Daniel J. McKenna, and stepson Robert Marone. Devoted brother of Daniel J. McKenna & Sister M. Helen Theresa, OP, Dominicans of Sparkhill, NY, Gloria Cafferty, and the late Mary K. Cully, who died in 1995. Adoring grandfather of 21. Visiting will be Monday and Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9 pm at our Lady of Mt. Carmel RC Church, Ridgewood, NJ. Funeral mass Wednesday, 10AM at Mt. Carmel Church. Interment is to follow in Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah. No flowers, as donations to the Jack and Doe McKenna Memorial Scholarship Fund at Immaculate Heart Academy, 500 Van Emburgh Avenue, Washington Township, NJ 07675 are appreciated. title: Op-Art; The Post-Industrial Labor Day Parade
Looking to Doonesbury as an Economic Indicator
description: Has Doonesbury, the political comic strip by Garry Trudeau, become the latest sell signal?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEFALIDIS, NIKOS
description: KEFALIDIS-Nikos. Of Manhattan. On September 2, 1998, aboard Swissair 111. Best friend and beloved husband for 18 years of Laurie. Dearest and devoted father of Melanie (17), Elias (14) and Marisa (8). Loving son of Kerasia and Symeon Kefalidis of Alexandroupolis, Greece. Cherished brother of Chrysanthos Kefalidis of Athens and Efthimia Melidis of Alexandroupolis. Caring uncle of four nephews. Nikos spent the first nine years of his life with his family in Alexandroupolis, Greece, his birthplace. He then attended Anavryta College, a boarding school near Athens, as a scholarship student. He later studied at the University of Athens, graduating with a degree in economics. In 1970, he immigrated to the United States and became a U.S. citizen several years later. As founder and President of KLM Construction, Inc., he developed residential and commercial real estate projects throughout New York City. In 1989, he was instrumental in founding Beta Steel Corp., a privately held steel mill in Portage, Indiana, of which he was Chairman of the Board of Directors. In addition to his business ventures, Nikos was active in numerous community, political and religious organizations. He was appointed a member of the Democratic National Committee in 1994. He served on the Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Americas and as Vice President of the Board of Trustees of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York City. A Memorial Service will be held at The Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street (between 1st and 2nd Avenues) on Tuesday, September 8, 1998 at 6 PM, with His Eminence, Archbishop Iakovos presiding. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory either to The Greek Children's Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021, or to The Dalton School Scholarship Fund, 108 East 89th Street, NY, NY 10128.

title: A Newspaper and a Writer in a Philadelphia Story Full of Acrimony

Beasley Sr., a malpractice lawyer, was suing a major local institution -- often The Inquirer.

Loud jets flew overhead and louder fireworks popped and the band played on. The Ravens were ready to do something big to Pittsburgh.

It built the kind of strength that the Fighting Irish needed to wear down Michigan in the second half on Saturday and record the college football season's first major upset.

title: Silicon Valley Entrepreneur Takes High Tech to the High Seas

That is because Healtheon, an on-line service for the health care industry, is planning a widely anticipated public offering in late September.

description: Bill Bradley, the former United States Senator from New Jersey, has begun taking concrete steps toward running for the Democratic nomination for President in 2000. Page B6.

title: Fugue for Frequent Fliers; Transporting Most Instruments Requires a Virtuoso
description: Gordon Gottlieb laid out the Polaroid shots of the massive daiko drums he bought in Japan while touring Asia with the New York Philharmonic in July. He rattled off their dimensions: The biggest drum is 29 inches long and 90 inches in circumference with a head that is 24 inches across. Each was hand-crafted from a single piece of wood and took up to four years to make.

title: Frances Hamerstrom, Author And Biologist, Is Dead at 90
description: Frances Hamerstrom, who discovered a passion for observing nature as a young girl in Boston and pursued that passion throughout a life spent mostly in Wisconsin, died on Aug. 29 at Edgewater Haven, a nursing home in Port Edwards, Wis. She was 90.

title: Data Recorder Is Found, Raising Hopes for Clues to Swissair Crash
description: Divers found the flight data recorder of Swissair Flight 111 today on a rocky stretch of sea bottom littered with debris and three major pieces of wreckage of the MD-11. The discovery raised hopes that investigators would soon know why the plane crashed offshore here on Wednesday night, killing everyone aboard, after a pilot reported smoke in the cockpit.

title: More Jobs, Less Security
description: As America pauses for Labor Day, more people have jobs than ever before and the unemployment rate is close to its lowest level in a generation. At the same time, people are less likely to keep their jobs for long periods, and the level of layoffs is considerably higher than it was in earlier economic cycles. These facts are indicative of a vibrant, competitive economy that provides less security, for either workers or the companies that hire them, than the American economy seemed to offer in decades past.

title: Sports of The Times; A New Perspective Spurs Seles
description: THE wind swirled yesterday and blew her tennis shots this way and that. She broke four racquets -- count 'em, four racquets -- during her match. And Monica Seles, in white baseball cap and short, white dress, seeded sixth in the United States Open, was forced into a third set with unseeded Kimberly Po; the winner would go to the quarterfinals. It was not a terribly good day for Monica Seles, but, as she would be the first to admit, she has dealt with worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, MATTHEW THOMPSON
description: SCOTT - Matthew Thompson. Partner and Sr. Vice President of the sugar brokerage firm Czarnikow-Rionda, and principal of Darby Scott Ltd in New York, died on Swissair flight 111 at the age of 33. Mr. Scott was a graduate of Brown University, with a degree in Comparative Literature, and the Episcopal School in Alexandria, Va. A respected sugar trader and businesman, Mr. Scott helped his wife, Karen Darby Scott, found a couturier design company in 1994. Born in Columbia, S.A. Mr. Scott was fluent in English, Spanish and Portuguese. He was a member of the University Club and an enthusiastic athlete who played squash, soccer, tennis, and twice ran the New York Marathon. Matthew is survived by his wife, Karen who is known in the fashion world as Darby Scott, and their two year old son William. She is expecting their second child. He is also survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Scott of Englewood, NJ. Brothers, John W. and Robert A.T., and his sister Julia Leigh. Memorial services will be held on Friday, September 11 at 2 P.M., at Grace Church in N.Y., 802 Broadway at 10th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Concordia Language Villages, attention Christine Schulze at Concordia College, 901 South 8th Street, Moorehead, MN. 56562.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHURGIN, AUDREY
description: SCHURGIN-Audrey. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of our beloved Audrey Schurgin, former General Studies Principal. With her unique gift of recognizing individual strengths, her loving and nurturing encouragement, and her open arms and warm smile, she touched the lives of the students, faculty and entire SAR family and set the tone for what is truly the spirit of SAR. Loved by all who knew her, Audrey will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her adoring husband, sons, father and entire family. May she always watch over her ''Bubalas'' and may her memory be a blessing for us all. The SAR Academy Parent Teacher Council

Evocative as it is of the ghettoization of Jews in World War II, the photograph is notable for another element -- a black smudge in the lower right corner.

title: Quest for Frozen Pandemic Virus Yields Mixed Results
description: DIGGING in a cemetery on the Arctic island of Spitsbergen, Norway, medical scientists found the seven coffins they were looking for, but the coffins lay in shallow graves, which was not what they wanted to find. They had hoped they would be six feet deep, in permafrost, where the bodies would still be frozen and well preserved 80 years after dying in the terrible influenza pandemic of 1918.

title: The Political Crisis in Moscow
description: Russia has had more than its share of malevolent or inept political leaders over the years, but the latest Kremlin cast is setting a new standard for incompetence and self-absorption. With the country in an economic meltdown, the lower house of Parliament yesterday once again rejected President Boris Yeltsin's choice for prime minister, leaving the nation without a working Government. With the ruble's purchasing power tumbling and shortages of food and other vital commodities developing, Russia is rapidly slipping into conditions that breed unrest and demagogy.

title: Communists Still Seeking True Identity
description: Today might be one of those rare heady days for Russia's post-Soviet Communists, if only someone could say what a post-Soviet Communist is.

title: More of Her Life, and Love, to Look Back On

title: Arts in America; Bilingual Author Finds Something Gained in Translation
description: Her mother died 30 years ago, but for most of those years Rosario Ferre, one of Puerto Rico's leading writers, found that event impossible to deal with in her work. It was only when she began to write in English, Ms. Ferre says, that she felt distant enough to explore in her fiction a subject that had been taboo in her native Spanish.

title: Market Place; Buying Buffett at a Big Premium to the Sum of His Parts
description: It is well known that Warren E. Buffett is one of the world's smartest investors and one of the world's richest men. It is also well known that he did not get that way buying stocks at prices well above their asset values.

title: Can Social Behavior of Man Be Glimpsed in a Lowly Worm?
description: DOES behavior have a genetic basis? People may find the idea unwelcome, at least as applied to their own conduct, but genes that govern certain behaviors in animals are beginning to come to light, the most spectacular of them in an article in the current issue of Cell.

Lewinsky.

description: For the last few weeks, Bill Richardson has been trying to do two apparently unreconcilable jobs as the Clinton Administration's new Energy Secretary and the Government's representative to the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JOHN (HANS)
description: STRAUSS-John (Hans), 85. Died September 6, 1998. The family of Hans Strauss mourns the loss of their beloved husband and father. Born and raised in Vienna, Austria, Hans earned his Doctorate of Law from the University of Vienna in 1938. That same year, to escape Nazi persecution, he and his wife, Irma, emigrated to the U.S., settled in NYC and created a new life. He founded Atlas Traffic Consultants in 1958 and was its President until his retirement in 1978. His volunteer activities included teaching in an adult literacy program, FEGS, translating central synagogue archives. He was an avid stamp and coin collector. He satisfied his passion for journalism by writing and publishing stories, poems and articles in German and English. His lifelong love of language and learning never diminished. He was outspoken in his commitment and concern for those less fortunate. He leaves his wife of sixty years, Irma, his two daughters and their families, Susan, Sandy and Daniel Jacobs, Connie, Mark, & Michael Kolber, his brother, George Strauss, several cousins, nieces, nephews, and many valued friends. A service in his memory will be held Thursday, September 10, at 3 PM at Gutterman Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Broncos Have Plenty of Pop to Defeat the Patriots

title: Candidates Struggle To Stir Up Interest In New York Races

title: George H. Buchi, Organic Chemist, Dies at 77

He was 77 and lived in Cambridge, Mass., and Jackson, N.H.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, WILLIAM
description: FUHRMANN-William. New York Road Runners Club lost a wonderful friend in the tragic death of Bill Fuhrmann. We mourn the loss of this vital young man and offer our profound condolences to his family and colleagues. Allan Steinfeld, President Scott Lange, Exec. title: Editorial Observer; Agent Orange in Vietnam, 30 Years Later
description: Dr. Le Cao Dai, one of Vietnam's top experts on the health effects of Agent Orange, first encountered American military herbicides when he ran a field hospital for the North Vietnamese Army along the Ho Chi Minh Trail. American planes would fly low over the forest canopy and release a cloud of chemicals. Within days, the leaves would begin to fall, forcing Dr. Dai to move his hospital deeper into the forest for concealment. Only later did he come to believe that the spraying had done long-term health damage to Vietnamese soldiers and civilians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELSEN, QUARTARARO, DANIELLE
description: FELSEN-Quartararo-Danielle. Fly up Princess Bride on your cloud of white/You're a new angel now gliding towards the light/Our great love for you rides on your flight/ We know you'll gaze down from the height of all heights. Auntie Joan and Uncle Michael Her Spector-Rothschild cousins, Scott, Abbe, Alex, Jake, Adam, Marc, Karen, Charlie, Kellie, Marc, Jolie and Keith

title: Candidates for Schumer's Seat Try to Set Themselves Apart
description: In a debate in a Brooklyn elementary school auditorium last week, Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman of Sheepshead Bay told the audience about his authorship of more than 125 bills during his 18 years in the State Legislature. Noach Dear, a City Councilman from Brooklyn, told that same gathering of his attentiveness to the nitty-gritty of serving constituents, from repaving streets to installing traffic lights.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCOTT, MATTHEW THOMPSON
description: SCOTT-Matthew Thompson. Memorial services for Matthew Scott, 33, a passenger on Swissair flight 111 will be held Friday, September 11 at 2 P.M., at Grace Church in New York, Broadway and 10th Street (Manhattan). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Concordia Language Villages, Christine Schulze at Concordia College, 901 South 8th Street, Moorehead, MN. 56562.

title: A Hand From Above Helps Slipping Boston
description: Jeffrey Maier, the youngster who created a home run for the Yankees in the American League playoffs in 1996, apparently has a distant relative in cahoots with the Red Sox.

title: At State U., No Room at the Dorm For the Invited but Not Expected
description: So many more freshmen than had originally been expected showed up at the University of Maryland at College Park last month that dozens were sent to spend the semester at the local Quality Inn.

title: Art of the Deal Meets Science of Market Drop
description: It's that time of year: the children are back in school and Wall Street investment bankers have returned from a lazy holiday weekend at their Hampton estates, eager to do deals.

title: In Silicon Valley, Big Swings In Share Price Are Ho-Hum
description: With all due respect to Main Street investors who grew a bit faint when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 6.4 percent in a day last week, the young workers riding their stock options on Silicon Valley's roller coaster have a message: really, that's nothing.

title: Reformer Spared, for Now
description: In a gain for cleaner politics, Senate Republicans have dropped their effort to oust a top official at the Federal Election Commission who has been a vigorous foe of campaign fund-raising abuses. As a result, at least for now, Lawrence Noble, the commission's general counsel, will be able to continue his outstanding work trying to end the practice of using unregulated ''soft money'' raised by the national political parties for costly ad campaigns for candidates in clear violation of the election laws.

title: Proposal Would End Car Pool Lane Limits
description: State and Federal lawmakers from New Jersey are to announce a proposal today to open the state's car pool lanes to all passenger traffic, including solo drivers.

title: U.S. Designers Drop European Coattails
description: A revolution is taking place in the global order as American designers, long relegated to last place on the fashion calendar, get a jump this year.

title: Times Magazine Names Style Editor
description: Amy M. Spindler, the fashion critic for The New York Times, has been appointed style editor of The New York Times Magazine, effective next Monday.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILBRIDE, CHARLES J.
description: GILBRIDE-Charles J. On September 5, 1998. Of Ramsey, NJ. Formerly of Brooklyn. Husband of the late Caroline (O'Connor). Father of Charles P. Gilbride. Brother of Eileen Burke. Grandfather of Charles M. and Carey Gilbride. Mass celebrated September 10, 1998, at 10 AM at St. Paul's Church in Ramsey, NJ. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Visitation at Van Emburgh-Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Avenue, Ramsey, NJ, on Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM.

title: Software Deal Given Approval
description: Network Associates, a maker of anti-virus and security software, has received approval from Federal antitrust regulators to go ahead with its $130.2 million purchase of Cybermedia Inc., the company said Friday

title: Central Banker's Resignation Deepens Financial Chasm
description: Working for Russia's central bank has never been easy.

title: A Cleaner Harbor Lures Water Birds to New York
description: EACH year, 1,700 tankers bring 18 billion gallons of oil into New York Harbor. And each day huge barges carry 14,000 tons of garbage to the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island. The harbor, also heavily trafficked by container ships, gravel boats, tugs and pleasure craft, hardly seems a good place for fish-eating birds to settle and raise their families. Surely they would never choose to live among the flotsam and jetsam and just plain trash washing up on the shores, nor among wrecked ships and docks and long-abandoned buildings on islands that look nothing like a wildlife refuge. Surely elegant snowy egrets or black-crowned night herons would never call a place like that home.

title: Part Pit Bull, Part Teddy Bear, All Appetite
description: IN the course of an afternoon, Al Goldstein has his secretary book a prostitute as his dinner companion at Nobu, a chic downtown restaurant, and, for his cable television show, ''Midnight Blue,'' he tapes a vicious attack on New York magazine for leaving him out of its 30th-anniversary issue.

title: Untouched By a Promise To Reach Out
description: YOU may remember Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's exultant leap for the benefit of photographers when he won re-election last November. But a small wager says you have probably forgotten how the Mayor briefly tempered his joy with an uncharacteristic note of contrition.

title: No. 61 Leaves No Time For Poetry
description: Mark McGwire slugged his 61st home run with such ferocity yesterday that Jon Miller of ESPN could not muster a classic call. Miller was jolted out of a discussion of Roger Maris's family and the health woes that prevented Maris's widow, Pat, from attending the game when McGwire unleashed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Murdoch's BSkyB May Bid For British Soccer Team

title: Rushing a Vaccine
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; Polling Confirms It: Fritz Is Still First
description: One of the main worries that Democrats have about heading off further Republican gains in the Senate this fall is Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina. Hailing from a state that has been turning more Republican with each election, Senator Hollings, a moderate Democrat in his fourth decade in the Senate, only narrowly won re-election in 1992 and this year faces an even tougher challenger, Representative Bob Inglis, a hard-right conservative from Greenville.

title: Try Stronger Laws On Child Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing; A Tennessee Traveler Sees the Country
description: When Senator Fred Thompson was on ''Larry King Live'' the other night, Mr. King asked him whether he planned to run for President in 2000.

title: Led by Asia, Stocks Abroad Rise Sharply
description: Stock markets surged from Singapore to Seoul today in a powerful rally, fueled by a stronger Japanese yen and interventionist government policies in Hong Kong and Malaysia.

title: Giants Stiffen Defense After an Early Letdown
description: It was early in the second quarter on Sunday, and the Washington Redskins' offense was pushing the Giants' defense around, advancing down the field play after play.

title: Dark Skies, but Grand Totals, on Spa's Last Day
description: After six weeks of sunny weather, the Saratoga season ended in rain today. But it could not put a damper on the booming business of the 130th racing season here: an increase of 7.4 percent in attendance and 5.6 percent in betting at a time when the racing industry is searching for good omens in the face of widespread decline.

title: Congo Peace Talks Finish With Agreement Reported
description: A daylong summit meeting of African leaders seeking to negotiate a peace settlement for the Congo ended on an optimistic note today when the chairman of the group announced that all parties had agreed on ''what we intend to achieve in the Congo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARDI, BABAJAN
description: VARDI-Babajan. Passed away on September 4, 1998 on Long Island, N.Y. Beloved husband of Liza. Dear father of five children, Moshe (Karen), Joseph (Dalia), Miryam (Joseph), Ben (Elahe), and Esther (Jack). Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren. Funeral will be held in Jerusalem, Israel and Shiva will be held at 21 Clover Drive, Great Neck Estates, L.I. from Tuesday, September 8 at 3 P.M. until sundown Friday, resuming at sundown Saturday night.

title: Personal Health; Weighing the Pros and Cons of Hormone Therapy
description: MAKING an informed decision about whether to take replacement hormones during and after menopause is hard enough for women with no prior health problems. It is far more difficult for a woman who has had breast cancer or who has a strong family history of this most common cancer in women. Because estrogen can stimulate the growth of a breast cancer, women and their doctors are understandably reluctant to consider hormone replacement for someone at high risk of developing a new or recurrent cancer.

title: Goldman Staff To Discuss Stock Move
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has told its 11,500 employees worldwide to participate in a conference call early this morning in which leaders of the fabled investment firm are expected to discuss Goldman's planned offering of shares to the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, EUGENE
description: KRAMER-Eugene. On September 4, 1998. Loving husband of Florence, beloved father of Lenore, Robert and his wife Monique, and the late Douglas, and adoring grandpa to Liana and Matthew. Services today, 11:15, at Riverside Chapel, 180 W. 76th St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation, PO Box 61, Massapequa Park, NY 11762.

title: Few Teacher Vacancies as New York City Recruits 5,000 to Schools
description: After years of chronic difficulty attracting qualified teachers to the nation's largest school system, New York City education officials say they have hired 5,000 teachers in one of the most competitive hiring seasons in recent memory -- enough to fill virtually every classroom when the city's 1,100 public schools open tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROMET, DR. ROBERT YARMOUTH
description: GROMET-Dr. Robert Yarmouth. Sept. 6th, of Bay Harbor Island, Florida, formerly of Long Island, New York. Dr. Gromet practiced radiology since 1940, and had broad interests outside his field: world peace through world federalism, religion and poetry, and authored books in these three areas. Beloved husband of Eleanor (Potash) and the late Esther (Roth). Loving father of Gloria and Dr. Steven Sitzman of Lexington, MA, Rosalind and Dr. Martin Stark of Reston, VA., Dr. Matthew Gromet and Phyllis Schultz of Charlotte, NC, & stepdaughter, Anita Peckins of Suffern, New York. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Peter Sitzman, Andrew Stark and Daniel Gromet. Dear brother of Dr. Maurice Gromet of New York City, and the late Victor and Frederick. Burial in Miami, FL, Wednesday, September 9th. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to The Chautauqua Fund, Chautauqua Institution, Chautauqua, NY 14722. For further information, please call 305-761-8800.

title: Parcells Sees Good and Bad, But Dwells on the Ugly
description: A day after the Jets' agonizing 36-30 overtime loss to the San Francisco 49ers, Bill Parcells responded like a typical coach.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

description: NUEWEILER - Adrienne. Con dolences to Robert Robinson on the loss of Adrienne, dear and wonderful friend. The Board Shareholders, Employees and Neighbors of the Kenilworth.

title: Surprises In Early Qualifying
description: The World Cup finals seemed a lifetime away for some of Europe's most powerful nations as they misfired over the weekend in their opening qualifying matches for the 2000 European Championship.

title: McGwire Grabs Share of Maris's Mark
description: Combining impeccable timing with one deadly uppercut swing, Mark McGwire tied Major League Baseball's storied home run record today, smacking his 61st home run on his father's 61st birthday. The mighty right-handed-hitting first baseman needs to hit only one more home run in the St. Louis Cardinals' remaining 19 games to knock Roger Maris out of the record book and into baseball's bulging bank of statistical memories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILCOX, ALEX AND PETRA
description: WILCOX-Alex and Petra. We mourn the untimely passing of our friends Alex and Petra who did not survive the crash of Swissair Flight 111. We'll miss the love, laughter and intelligence you shared with us. Foie gras will never be the same. Benjamin Kriegler Vonda LePage

title: Full of Youthful Fire at 67, Korchnoi Keeps Winning
description: The year 1936 was the end of Emanuel Lasker's glorious career. He was 67, had held the world championship for 27 years, longer than anyone, and though still amazing in individual games, was taking sixth and seventh prizes in the strongest tournaments instead of first prize. He retired to the adulation of his fans, who called his achievement a ''biological miracle.''

title: BASEBALL: Goodbye, Ruth; Hello, Maris; And Now the Wait for No. 62.; A Family Celebration For a Historic Moment
description: Seconds after Mark McGwire's 61st homer was safely tucked in Section 281 in the left-field loge area at Busch Stadium, he focused on his faith and his family during his most memorable trot of the year. McGwire raised his finger to the sky, pointed behind home to his giddy father, and then touched the plate, lifted his 10-year-old son, Matthew, and gave the boy a bearhug.

title: Drugs Taint an Annual Round of Gay Revels
description: It began in the early stages of the AIDS epidemic as a relatively modest affair, a respite for the living and remembrance of the dead that was held in daylight, so that even the ill might be able to go, and was given a double-edged title resonant of grief.

title: Data Recorder Missed Swissair Flight's Final Minutes, Investigator Says
description: A preliminary examination of the flight data recorder from Swissair Flight 111 indicates that it stopped working about six minutes before the MD-11 plunged into the sea off Nova Scotia on Wednesday night, the chief investigator said tonight.

title: As Tension Rises in Cambodia, Troops Fire Into Crowds
description: Cambodia's post-election standoff erupted into turmoil and gunfire today as the leader, Hun Sen, ordered the arrest of his opponents and as security agents fired into crowds of protesters, killing at least one person.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: 4 Are Killed As Storms Lash The Northeast
description: Punishing thunderstorms and brutal hurricane-force winds wrought destruction across a broad area of upstate New York and around New York City yesterday, battering houses, toppling power lines, capsizing boats and causing at least three deaths.

title: Serving Beer but Making Waves
description: There are entirely too many colorfully crude blue-collar characters in ''Costello,'' and the show's star, Sue Costello, is one of them.

title: Giuliani as Usual
description: To hear Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani tell it yesterday, the largest and best Police Department in the country simply had to storm a stage at a Harlem youth rally on Saturday. The concluding speech of its chief organizer, a peripheral preacher of hate named Khallid Abdul Muhammad, was so inflammatory -- ''telling people to shoot and kill police officers'' -- that the riot police had no recourse but to slap down their face guards and seize the spotlight.

title: U.S. Eights Advance to Finals
description: The United States men's and women's eights qualified for the finals of the world championships at Cologne, Germany, yesterday.

title: Security Experts Assessing U.S. Embassies
description: Alarmed by evidence that terrorists are planning new attacks on American embassies, the Administration has dispatched counterterrorism experts to diplomatic missions around the world to determine if any are so vulnerable that they should be shuttered immediately, Administration officials say.

title: By Design; Shoes Like All Cats at Night
description: Never mind the gray flannel suit. This fall it's the gray flannel shoe. Grays can be difficult to match, but luckily the shoes in stores this season are available in as many shades of gray as the clothing. And gray is definitely the color of the season.

title: Man Dies After Falling Off Sport Fishing Boat
description: A Washington Township man on a fishing trip died after falling overboard on Sunday, the Coast Guard said yesterday.

title: Giving Screenplays a Sense of Reality
description: Robert Towne still recalls his fascination with movies as a young boy in the coastal town of San Pedro, Calif., and his yearning to write screenplays -- so he could correct all the wrong things he saw on the screen.

title: Greenspan's Words Taken For Golden
description: With markets tumbling and economies crumbling at an alarming pace, investors and governments around the world were looking for a lifeline from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, when he spoke in California on Friday night, and Mr. Greenspan gave it to them.

title: A Nomination for Governor
description: It is important that the Democratic Party pick a credible candidate to run for governor of New York this fall. Of the four people seeking the nomination, our preference is for City Council Speaker Peter Vallone. Running the state of New York requires the ability to lead and compromise, in equal measure. Mr. Vallone has proved in recent years that he can do both.

title: Political Briefing; Political Calendar
description: Primaries will be held today in Arizona, New Hampshire, Vermont and Wisconsin.

title: Where Young Viewers Go (and Ads Follow); The WB Network, With a Narrow Focus, Grows 20 Percent
description: One upstart network has made its name by appealing to teen-agers with shows like ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' starring a sexy high school misfit with supernatural powers, and ''Dawson's Creek,'' where teen-agers talk bluntly about masturbation and impotence and one boy loses his virginity to his over-30 English teacher.

title: Atlanta Rally Unburdened by Ills of Harlem's
description: Two days after a rally in Harlem ended in a brief skirmish with the police, black youths in Atlanta staged a sparsely attended but far less tense gathering today on the street where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born and is now entombed.

title: Sampras Keeps the Future in Its Place
description: When the sky went from gray to green to black yesterday afternoon, Pete Sampras looked up, registered moderate apprehension and played on. After all, the spotlights were eerily blazing inside Arthur Ashe Stadium, and he was scant serves away from taking a 6-4, 2-1 lead over Marat Safin in a match that eventually became a 6-4, 6-3, 6-2 rout and landed the four-time champion in the United States Open quarterfinals.

title: Inching Toward Justice in Rwanda
description: Not many people were happier than I was to learn last week that a United Nations tribunal had found Jean-Paul Akayesu, a former Mayor in Rwanda, guilty of genocide -- the first time such a tribunal had ever convicted someone of that crime.

title: Connecticut Senate Rivals Start TV Ad Campaigns Tonight, With No Party Mentioned
description: Connecticut's largely invisible United States Senate campaign will burst onto the state's airwaves on Tuesday, when television advertisements will begin pitting the incumbent's formidable political record against his challenger's compelling personal story.

title: Officer Is Injured When Reveler Grabs Gun
description: A man grabbed a police officer's gun at the West Indian American Day Carnival in Brooklyn yesterday, and a bullet grazed the officer's leg when the gun discharged.

title: Health Watch; Wanting to Lose
description: LITTLE about weight loss seems fair. Now new research underscores that sense: in a controlled study, the people who had the hardest time shedding pounds were those who did not like the way they looked, and who had lost weight -- and regained it -- many times.

title: Subway Rape Raises Concern About Reduced Train Crews
description: The news that a woman had been raped this weekend aboard a G train operated without a conductor shocked women riding the line yesterday -- but the assault was not the only source of their dismay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEFALIDIS, NIKOS
description: KEFALIDIS-Nikos. Of Manhattan. On September 2, 1998, aboard Swissair 111. Best friend and beloved husband for 18 years of Laurie. Dearest and devoted father of Melanie (17), Elias (14) and Marisa (8). Loving son of Kerasia and Symeon Kefalidis of Alexandroupolis, Greece. Cherished brother of Chrysanthos Kefalidis of Athens and Efthimia Melidis of Alexandroupolis. Caring uncle of four nephews. Nikos spent the first nine years of his life with his family in Alexandroupolis, Greece, his birthplace. He then attended Anavryta College, a boarding school near Athens, as a scholarship student. He later studied at the University of Athens, graduating with a degree in economics. In 1970, he immigrated to the United States and became a U.S. citizen several years later. As founder and President of KLM Construction, Inc., he developed residential and commercial real estate projects throughout New York City. In 1989, he was instrumental in founding Beta Steel Corp., a privately held steel mill in Portage, Indiana, of which he was Chairman of the Board of Directors. In addition to his business ventures, Nikos was active in numerous community, political and religious organizations. He was appointed a member of the Democratic National Committee in 1994. He served on the Archdiocesan Council of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Americas and as Vice President of the Board of Trustees of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York City. A Memorial Service will be held at The Cathedral, 319 East 74th Street (between 1st and 2nd Avenues) on Tuesday, September 8, 1998 at 6 PM, with His Eminence, Archbishop Iakovos presiding. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory either to The Greek Children's Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, NY, NY 10021, or to The Dalton School Scholarship Fund, 108 East 89th Street, New York, New York 10128.

title: Questions Surround Performance Enhancer
description: IN the 1940's, not long after the discovery and isolation of testosterone, the hormone in the body that can help build rock-hard muscles, it was learned that baseball players on the St. Louis Cardinals had loaded up on extra large doses of vitamins to try to enhance their performance. This led Paul de Kruif, a popular science writer of the day, to comment: ''We know how the St. Louis Cardinals have won championships supercharged by vitamins. It would be interesting to watch the productive power of an industry or a professional group that would try a systematic supercharge with testosterone.''

title: Try Stronger Laws On Child Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Getting to the Truth in Child Abuse Cases: New Methods
description: AFTER more than 12 years in prison, convicted of raping children at his family's suburban Boston day care center despite his avowals of innocence, Gerald Amirault says he is pinning his hopes on new science to get him out.

title: Who Invited You?
description: Labor Day is over. The phone has stopped ringing. You don't have to wonder, Should I pick it up? You don't have to wonder, Is is them?

title: Two Old Foes in Ulster Wars Speak Directly in First Meeting
description: Two of the bitterest perennial enemies in the war and peace in Northern Ireland spoke directly to each other for the first time today in a brief polite dialogue aimed at furthering the peace effort.

title: YELTSIN'S NOMINEE REJECTED 2D TIME; BANK CHIEF QUITS
description: Russia's Parliament again spurned President Boris N. Yeltsin's choice for Prime Minister today after last-minute negotiations between the Kremlin and a defiant Communist opposition broke down.

title: With a Mountain at Stake, Tiny Tribe and New Mexico Neighbors Do Battle
description: Rising 10,378 feet into the desert air, Sandia Mountain is more than a picturesque backdrop to Albuquerque, a city of more than 400,000 people. It is an escape valve for a booming Sunbelt city.

title: Correction
description: An article on Friday about the victims of the crash of Swissair Flight 111, and a passenger list, misspelled the surname of two passengers. They were Donald and Diane Sheer, not Scheer, of Norfolk, Mass.

title: Kfar Ruppin Journal; Air Force Seeking Dominion Over Fowl of the Air
description: Across northern Israel, spotters armed with binoculars and telescopes keep watch for a periodic incursion that has come to worry the country's air force as much as anything else.

title: Douglas C. Jones, 73, Conjurer Of Alternative American History
description: Douglas C. Jones, a writer who chronicled the mythology of the American West through fictional accounts of historic events, died on Aug. 30 at his home in Fayetteville, Ark. He was 73.

title: Hundley Is an Afterthought
description: Todd Hundley is unlikely to rejoin the Mets' regular lineup this year despite regaining his hitting stroke in the minor leagues, Manager Bobby Valentine indicated yesterday.

title: Executives Depart From 3 Agencies
description: Senior executives at three agencies are leaving.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, EDWIN A.
description: MALLOY-Edwin A. The Rabbis, Officers, Trustees and members of Congregation Emanu-El mourn the passing of our respected and revered Honorary President, Edwin A. Malloy. A man of impeccable character and uncompromising integrity, he spoke truth for truth alone was in his heart. His intellectual gifts were abundant and to all problems he brought wisdom and compassion. His almost three decades of devoted service on our Board and the shining years of his presidency yielded multiple blessings for our Congregation. He will be remembered with love and named with benediction. At the side of his beloved Susan, his wonderful children, Jennifer and Timon, and all the other members of the family, we weep at his death while thanking God for his life. Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Three Marketers Select Agencies
description: Three marketers have made decisions on their accounts.

title: Cool Reception Is a Step Up, The Mayor Says
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani walked for 13 blocks at the head of the West Indian American Day Carnival yesterday, he was greeted with boos and catcalls, signs blasting his handling of Saturday's rally in Harlem and a man on a bicycle who tried to ride into his entourage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUTTENBERG, LILLY S.
description: ROUTTENBERG-Lilly S., age 89, on September 7, 1998 in Clifton, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg. Loving mother of Ruth R. Seldin and Aryeh S. Routtenberg. Cherished grandmother of Alex, Yael, David and Noam. Devoted sister of Bernice Schneiderman. Services 11 AM, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: CLINTON'S LAWYER SEEKS EARLY LOOK AT STARR FINDINGS
description: President Clinton's private lawyer asked today that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent prosecutor, let him review at least a week in advance any report he submits to Congress, in a sign the White House is readying a defense against possible impeachment hearings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLIN, GILDA AND RALPH
description: MALLIN-Gilda and Ralph. We sadly announce the tragic untimely death of our dear Gilda and Ralph Mallin, most loving parents of Michael and Martha, Danny, & Cindy and Philippe, adored Gigi & Grandpa of Melissa, Talya and Naomi. Beloved sister & brotherin-law to Carol and Phil, Bernie and Eva, and Elliott. They died together during the happiest days of their lives. Memorial service in NYC at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 Street, on Thursday, September 10, at 10 AM. Memorial service in Boca Raton at Boca West Country Club, on Monday, September 14, at 10 A.M., in main clubhouse, Cypress Room.

title: Korea Bid Expected To Go to Rothschild
description: Creditors of the insolvent Halla Group, which owns Korea's biggest auto component manufacturer, appear likely to accept an offer by Rothschild Inc. to buy four of the group's companies for $1.8 billion, according to Korea Exchange Bank, one of Halla's biggest creditors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAETH, ELOISE O'MARA
description: SPAETH-Eloise O'Mara. Of East Hampton, NY on September 4, 1998. Wife of the late Otto. Much beloved mother of Otto L. Spaeth, Jr.(Tony), Mary Louise Koon of St. Louis, and the late Marna Doherty and Deborah Shakespeare Green. Grandmother of sixteen. Great grandmother of 15. Mass of Christian Burial at Most Holy Trinity Church, Buell Lane, East Hampton on Friday, September 11 at 11 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 or to the Eloise Spaeth Collection Preservation Fund at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: Poor Students, Too, Can Serve the Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, GERALD J.
description: MURPHY-Gerald J. Age 69, of Stonington, CT. Died suddenly at his home on Saturday. Survived by his beloved wife Anne, daughters Dianne and Bridia, son Matthew and two grandchildren Laura and Ryan. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Wednesday at 11:00AM at St. Mary Church in Stonington, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Mystic Art Association, 9 Water Street, Mystic, CT. 06355.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPF, GIBSON, NANCY
description: TOPF-GIBSON-Nancy. Born October 29, 1942. Died September 2, 1998. Nancy Topf-Gibson was a passenger on Swissair Flight 111 which was lost in the Atlantic Ocean with all passengers and crew while attempting an emergency landing near Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada. Nancy was a master teacher, dancer, and choreographer. As the innovator of Topf Technique, she created a natural developmental approach to movement using kinetic imaging and release and alignment principles. Nancy's technique of neuromuscular education re-patterns inhibited movement, develops creative freedom and heals chronic injuries. Working with professional dancers and many students Nancy strove to center each person's emotional, spiritual, and physical body. Nancy taught throughout the United States and internationally, and was en route to teach in Geneva. Nancy is survived by her husband, composer/ musician Jon Gibson of New York City; her son, Jeremy Gibson, a college student; her mother, Celia Topf Straus of Lauderhill, FL; by her sisters and their husbands, Bobbi and Robert H. Straus, Peggy and Murray Schwartz, Margie J. Topf & Stuart Rose; and numerous nieces and nephews. A Memorial Concert is being planned for early December in New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a fund established in support of her surviving family and sent to: Nancy Topf Memorial Fund, C/O Lynne Linehan, Vice President, The Cambridge Trust Company, 494 Boston Post Road, Weston, MA. 02493.

title: Valentine Goes to Mat and the Mets Return the Favor With Victory
description: The sight of Bobby Valentine and his coaching staff sprawled on their hands and knees on the infield tarp at Shea Stadium in the midst of a wild storm -- which the eventual winning pitcher, Greg McMichael, later described as akin to a typhoon -- was surreal enough.

title: Murdoch Reported to Have Bid $950 Million for Britain's Richest Soccer Club
description: Fresh from acquisitive forays into American sports, Rupert Murdoch is aiming at the richest stratum of British soccer with a reported $950 million bid for the fabled Manchester United club that would tighten his grip on televised sports in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHOCKEY, WILLIAM H.R. JR.
description: SHOCKEY-William H.R. Jr. 39. Of Rowayton, Conn. Husband of Kathleen Griffin Shockey. Father of William H.R. Shockey, III and Kelsy Griffin Shockey. Son of William and Susan Shockey. Brother of Suzanne Shockey and Ralf Shockey. Mr. Shockey was Vice President of Skott-Edwards, NYC. Services Thursday 10:30AM at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church, Westport, Conn. Interment Gate of Heaven cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Calling hours Wednesday 5-9 PM, at Christ and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: A New Twist on Air Mail For Unplugged Travelers
description: IN a few short years, E-mail has become the pulse of the workplace and a tool that is often most missed when an Internet connection is unavailable. A wireless E-mail service answers that need by enabling business travelers to send and receive electronic messages almost anywhere in the United States.

title: Williams Wins 2 (Well, Officially Just 1)
description: Venus Williams got credit for winning only one round yesterday at the United States Open, but those who managed to wait out the weather and return to their seats at Louis Armstrong Stadium know that Williams won two very different matches against Mary Pierce.

title: In Bellwether District, Clues to Lewinsky's Impact
description: Representative Ted Strickland sat in the back seat of the Ford Explorer, with its air-conditioner set up high, waiting for the start of the River Days parade, which has been the highlight of the Labor Day weekend in this Ohio River town as long as anyone can remember.

title: Is 'Chantilly Lace' the wrong song, and should yogurt makers go for the comic touch?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Is the Ruble Becoming Rubbish?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVANAVAGE, CATHERINE A.
description: LIVANAVAGE-Catherine A., 49 of Bedminster, NJ, died Sunday, September 6, 1998. Born in Brooklyn, NY, she was raised in upstate NY and lived in Basking Ridge and Far Hills moving to Bedminster 14 years ago. She was a supporter of the arts and many organizations that focused on the improvement of animal welfare. She was an avid equestrian and horse trainer, having donated much time to her enjoyment of the sport. She is the loving wife of Stephen, devoted mother and mother-in-law of James and Rachel Livanavage of Phoenix, AZ and Jennifer and Carl Lusins & cherished gramdmother of Alexander Lusins of Oneonta, NY, dear daughter of William and Lucille Burkert of Middletown, NY dear sister of Steven Burkert of Memphis TN, and giving friend to many animal and people friends. A memorial gathering will be held on Saturday, September 12 from 11AM to 2PM at the Livanavage residence, Ride the Clouds Farm, Bedminster, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to an animal charity of one's choice.

title: People
description: * Tim Spengler, deputy director for national television at Western International Media, Los Angeles, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to senior vice president and general manager, succeeding Bill Croasdale, who was named to the new position of office of the president.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYMAN, SEYMOUR ''SY,''
description: HAYMAN-Seymour ''Sy,'' age 83. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Jonathan and Valerie. Son of the late Louie and Ettie Hayman. Dear uncle of Ellen, Robert, Nicholas, Laura and Karen, & Joanne Larzik. Services on Wednesday, September 9th, at 12 PM, at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, New York.

title: More Police in the Village
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLIN, GILDA AND RALPH
description: MALLIN-Gilda and Ralph. We sadly announce the tragic untimely death of our dear Gilda and Ralph Mallin, most loving parents of Michael and Martha, Danny, & Cindy and Philippe, adored Gigi & Grandpa of Melissa, Talya and Naomi. Beloved sister & brotherin-law to Carol and Phil, Bernie and Eva, and Elliott. They died together during the happiest days of their lives. Memorial service in NYC at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 Street, on Thursday, September 10, at 10 AM. Memorial service in Boca Raton at Boca West Country Club, on Monday, September 14, at 10 A.M., in main clubhouse, Cypress Room.

title: A Long Way From Margaritaville
description: WAS it a mirage? In the sultry 95-degree heat, the fields shimmered along the highway leading west from Guadalajara, as if the hazy blue sky had tumbled to the earth and splashed over the hillsides.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about NASA's art program misstated the number of astronauts who have been to the moon twice. There are three, not one: James Lovell and Gene Cernan, in addition to John Young.

title: Patch of Desert Is Key to Mideast Talks' Next Step
description: Here is the parcel of land that has been mired in the most recent stalemate between the Israelis and the Palestinians: undulating dunes laced with scrub, starkly beautiful if desolate, and barren but for the lizards and an occasional Bedouin encampment.

title: IMPERIAL HOLLY TO BUY DIAMOND CRYSTAL SPECIALTY FOODS
description: The Imperial Holly Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Diamond Crystal Specialty Foods Inc. for $80 million in cash and $40 million in stock. It will also assume $33.9 million in debt. Imperial Holly can also purchase Diamond Crystal for cash alone, in which case the price will drop to $115 million. Diamond Crystal, based in Wilmington, Mass., manufactures nutritional dry mixes, sauces, seasonings, drink mixes and desserts. Imperial Holly, based in Sugar Land, Tex., processes and markets refined sugar. Imperial Holly plans to combine Diamond Crystal's operations with its Dixie Crystals Brands food-service unit. Dixie Crystals, based in Savannah, Ga., supplies sugar and non-sugar single service products.

title: Medicare Panacea Turns Patient; H.M.O's Now Must Treat Their Own Ills
description: Like thousands of other elderly Americans, Eugene DeLorenzo cannot find a Medicare health maintenance organization in his area.

title: A Table For Very Close Friends
description: NEW YORK is a perverse place. For years, restaurant owners have invested huge sums to get earsplitting acoustics, eye-popping interior design and the kind of bustling movement normally found on a trading floor. Now, they are installing tiny private rooms that let diners tune it all out.

title: Waiter, There's an Elbow in My Soup
description: ''SO, I don't know, what should I tell him?'' asked the young woman during dinner at Frank, a crowded little restaurant in the East Village, after telling the sad tale of her unhappy relationship.

title: Clobbering Prime Time
description: Besides knocking away at baseball's most magical record, Roger Maris's 61 home runs in a season, Mark McGwire managed to wreak havoc this week on plans by the Fox network to start up a couple of its most crucial programs in the fall television season.

title: Service for F. H. Knubel
description: George Rupp, president of Columbia University, will lead speakers at a memorial service this week for Frederick H. Knubel, director of public information at Columbia University. The service for Mr. Knubel, who died on Aug. 15, will begin at 2:30 P.M. on Friday in St. Paul's Chapel on the Morningside Heights campus at Broadway and 116th Street. Other speakers will be Michael I. Sovern, Chancellor Kent Professor of Law and president emeritus, and Joan Konner, publisher of Columbia Journalism Review. A reception will follow in the Faculty House.

title: Trouble in the Suburbs
description: President Clinton's visit to a Maryland school was to be a respite from political strife. But the reception wasn't all smiles. Page A20.

title: McGwire Does It!
description: With what seemed like the whole country in attendance, Mark McGwire of the St. Louis Cardinals drilled his 62d home run into the bleachers of Busch Stadium and into the history books last night, breaking Roger Maris's 37-year-old mark of 61 homers in a single season. It is possible that the man who has been shadowing McGwire all summer, Sammy Sosa of the Chicago Cubs, will overtake him before the season ends Sept. 27. Yet whatever happens, this was a joyful moment to be savored and celebrated, by McGwire and by anyone who loves sports and baseball in particular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEAVY, DORIS L.
description: LEAVY-Doris L. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Leavy. Loving mother of Barbara and Arthur Klauber and Jane Overman. Cherished grandmother of seven. Great-grandmother of thirteen. Services will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to UJA Federation, 130 East 59 Street, New York City 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMAS, JOHN P.
description: KAMAS-John P. On Sept. 7, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Stefania. Devoted father of Reverend Father John Kamas and Diane Williamson. Dear grandfather of Jason Williamson. Reposing at Hess-Miller Funeral Home, 64-19 Metropolitan Ave, Middle Village, Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Continued repose Thursday 5-9 at St. Jean the Baptiste Church, 76 St. & Lexington Avenue, Manhattan. Funeral mass will be held Friday at 10:30 AM. ''Krtil Funeral Home''

title: Man Held in Stabbing Dies in Jail Cell
description: An Atlantic City man being held for the stabbing death of his former girlfriend was found dead in his cell in the Atlantic County Jail over the weekend by a nurse and corrections officer making medical rounds, officials said yesterday.

title: A Leading Democrat's Theme: It's a Long, Long Time From Now Till November
description: Representative Martin Frost, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, finds himself facing two months of campaigning over uncertain ground for a party whose leader is up to his eyeballs in scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, GEORGE M.
description: SHAPIRO-George M. Died in his sleep on September 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Rita, devoted father of Karen Spector and the late Sanford Shapiro. His devotion to his family and his community was extraordinary. He had an outstanding career in law and public service beginning as Counsel to Governor Thomas E. Dewey. He then joined the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz and Mendelsohn (now Proskauer Rose LLP), eventually becoming head of its corporate department and long-time Managing Partner. He served as Chairman of the Board of the Park Avenue Synagogue, which named its new building in honor of him and his wife. Funeral services Thursday, September 10 at 10AM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street at Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Greyhound Unveils Its Plan To Serve the Disabled Fully
description: Greyhound Lines will formally announce plans on Wednesday that the company says will make all 4,000 stops on its nationwide bus system accessible to wheelchair users by October of next year. But groups representing those users said today that Greyhound planned to equip too few buses with lifts to deliver on the company's promises.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STRAUSS, SIMON D.
description: STRAUSS-Simon D. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, September 9 at 3:30 P.M., at The Manhattan School of Music, West 122 Street and Claremont Avenue. Mr. Strauss died May 22, 1998.

title: One Child, Many Influences
description: ''Do parents matter?'' ask the magazine covers, as controversy swirls around the new book ''The Nurture Assumption: Why Children Turn Out the Way They Do'' by Judith Rich Harris. The book apparently comes down heavily on the side of heredity and peers over parents as the major influences on children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, KENNETH
description: SIEGEL-Kenneth. An educator for 25 years in Brooklyn and beloved uncle, died 9/5/98 in Miami Beach, age 71. Private service.

title: Home Runs Become The Order Of the Day
description: While readying for the bottom of the seventh inning tonight, the Mets' players took their positions, and then, just like all the fans at Veterans Stadium, they turned toward center field and watched on the video screen as it displayed Mark McGwire's historic 62d home run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORBET, SANDRA
description: CORBET-Sandra. Of Manhattan died on September 7, 1998 of a stroke. Her beloved fiance, Steven Poster, Mother Betty Leibowitz, brothers Philip and Steven Leibowitz, her sister and brother inlaw Deborah and Robert Weingarten and nieces Shirelle, Meora, and Talia Weingarten and many relatives. We miss you so much. Sandy worked for thirty years as a commercial producer at such agencies as DMB&B, Y&R, Bozell, DDB Needham, Kirschenbaum and Bond. She also worked for Creative Artist Agency under the Coca Cola Campaign. She also produced theatre projects at MCC Theater and Shake-A-Leg. She also volunteered on the board of MCC Theater, Shake-A-Leg and was a member of Women in Film. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to MCC Theater in her name, 120 West 28th Street, NY, NY 10001. Services will be at 12:30 PM on September 9th at Riverside Memorial.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: As Ruble Crashes, Hangover Hurts a Lot
description: The music is still playing and the beer is still flowing, but three weeks into Russia's latest crisis, the good times at the Chesterfield Cafe -- a popular watering hole for Moscow's high-living young professionals -- are running out.

title: Beleaguered Illinois Senator Accuses a Critic of Racism
description: Senator Carol Moseley-Braun's re-election bid took an emotional turn when she angrily lost her composure during a Labor Day event and used a racial epithet to characterize herself as a target of racism.

title: Urgent Messages as Swissair Flight Systems Failed
description: As the pilots of Swissair Flight 111 were struggling to prepare their jumbo jet for an emergency landing Wednesday night, a series of vital operating systems on the plane were gradually breaking down, the chief investigator said this evening after a preliminary examination of the plane's flight data recorder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, PHILIP
description: BERKOWITZ-Philip. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its longtime distinguished member, beloved husband of Sabine Berkowitz. We fondly recall his commitment to his family, to Israel and the Jewish people. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Confronting Mr. Lott, Again
description: Trent Lott was gloating when campaign finance reform failed in the Senate last winter, despite the support of most Senators. But in a climate of public anxiety about ethics, the cause of cleaning up the election system was bound to return. Yesterday, emboldened by the House passing the Shays-Meehan ''soft money'' ban in August, John McCain of Arizona reintroduced campaign reform in the Senate. Now the Senate majority leader is again in the grotesque position of supporting a filibuster to thwart the majority's will. Again, the cause of reform depends on Republicans showing more sensitivity to voters than to Mr. Lott's campaign money addiction.

title: 3 Democrats in Race for Senate Strive to Rally Supporters
description: With Primary Day just a week away, the three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senate returned to their strengths yesterday, trying to rally key constituencies to counter what has been a lackluster campaign.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Aug. 29 about the changing role of the audience in political theater misstated the name of a theater institute at Harvard and the title of its leader. It is the Institute on the Arts and Civic Dialogue (not ''for'' Arts), and the writer and actress Anna Deveare Smith is its director, not artistic director.

title: Chief U.N. Arms Inspector Disturbed by Criticism of Ex-Inspector
description: Richard Butler, chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq, said today that he was disturbed by the Senate testimony of a former American inspector who resigned last month.

title: Court Is Asked To End Bias In Schools In Hartford
description: Two years after the Connecticut Supreme Court declared that Greater Hartford schools were racially segregated, representatives of the 17 families who originally filed the lawsuit were back in court today to ask a judge to impose specific goals for how quickly the state must reduce racial isolation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, PATRICK W.
description: BELL-Patrick W. Died September 2 on Swissair Flight in Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia. Executive Manager of Tourneau Time Machine, Madison Avenue, New York City. Son of William D. and Anita Bell of Carroll Valley, PA. (formerly of Takoma Park, MD, and Our Lady of Sorrows Parish). Brother of Daniel, Kevin and Michael Bell, uncle of Erin and Conor Bell. A memorial service will be held at 10:30 A.M., Friday, September 11, at Mount Saint Mary's College, Emmitsburg, MD. A reception will follow at the home of William and Anita Bell, 9 Grouse Trail, Carroll Valley, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, ANDRINE ADAMS
description: ROSS-Andrine Adams. On September 6, 1998 in NYC. Beloved wife of David A. Ross. Loving daughter of the late William W. and Anna Adams. Dear sister of Carole Adams and William C. Adams. Services to be held on Thursday, September 10 at 11AM Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to LSA Family Health Service, 426 East 119 Street, NY, NY 10035.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEFFER, ROSE
description: FEFFER-Rose, age 89. Beloved wife of the late Jack Feffer; much loved mother of Jane and Isabel and mother-in-law of Jerome and Edward; adored grandmother of Lisa, Ronald, Jon, Jillian, David, Halette, Jill and Barrett; greatgrandmother of Joshua, Corey and Jamie. We loved you dearly and will miss you. Services September 9, 11:30 AM at Bernheim, Apter and Goldsticker, 1600 Springfield Ave., Maplewood, NJ.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Gauges Soar As Investors Seem Hopeful

title: Campaign 'Reform' Limits Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, SARA
description: ZUCKERMAN - Sara. Heartfelt condolences to Board of Governors member Gary S. Fragin and Karen, to Linda & Tommy Sandel and to Dr. Matthew Zuckerman and families upon the passing of mother, wife and grandmother in Miami Beach. Hamakom Yenachemchem. Yeshivat Sha'alvim

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDWIN, M.D.
description: WEINSTEIN-Edwin, M.D. It is with great sorrow that The Mount Sinai Alumni mourns the passing of our distinguished friend and colleague. Dr. Weinstein, a pillar in the Department of Neurology at Mount Sinai for almost forty years, was a world recognized authority on Aphasia & communications disorders and has served as President of the Academy of Aphasia. In 1988, the Mount Sinai Alumni presented its most coveted award, the Jacobi Medallion, to Dr. Weinstein in acknowledgment of his profound professional achievements and his extraordinary service to the Medical Center and the Alumni. Our sincere condolences are extended to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D., Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treasurer

title: Microsoft Asks For Dismissal Of U.S. Suit
description: In a long, derisive court brief, the Microsoft Corporation asked a Federal judge today to dismiss the Government's antitrust suit, arguing that the Justice Department and 20 states were trying to ''distract the court from the fatal defects in their claims by slinging as much mud as they can.''

title: Lerner Wins Browns for $530 Million
description: Al Lerner, who helped Art Modell move the former Cleveland Browns to Baltimore in 1996, was chosen unanimously today by National Football League owners to buy the new Browns for $530 million, outdistancing his closest pursuer by $30 million.

title: EQUITY INNS CANCELS PLANNED ACQUISITION OF RFS
description: RFS Hotel Investors Inc. and Equity Inns Inc. have canceled plans for Equity to acquire RFS for $660 million. The deal was called off because stock in Equity Inns had fallen by last Friday to $10.50 a share, substantially below the minimum of $14 required by the merger agreement. In April, Equity Inns had agreed to exchange 1.5 of its shares for each RFS share. Equity Inns would also have assumed $330 million in RFS debt. Both companies are Memphis-based real estate investment trusts. RFS owns 64 extended-stay hotels, and Equity Inns owns 95 hotels.

title: Crusty Lamb Shanks That Stay Succulent
description: I'M often confused by the common wisdom of cooking. Why, for example, do so many recipes have you brown lamb shanks and other tough meats, when the braising for two or more hours after that to make them tender breaks down the lovely, crisp crust created by the browning? The simple truth is that browning creates complex flavors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHURGIN, AUDREY
description: SCHURGIN-Audrey. We mourn the loss of our unforgettable colleague, Audrey-our mentor, booster and friend with her welcoming smiles, enveloping hugs and upbeat vibrance. She spurred us to do only our best. Audrey's conviction that each child is a gem to be polished will forever guide us. We extend heartfelt sympathies to her family and thank them for letting us, too, bask in her warm special glow. The Teachers and Staff of SAR Academy

title: Poetic Justice for an Artist Ridiculed by the Nazis
description: Shortly before he left Germany for the United States in 1937, the artist Lyonel Feininger wrote to his son Lux, ''I feel 25 years younger now that I know I am going to a country where imagination in art and abstraction are not considered an absolute crime, as they are here.''

title: City Settles Prison Health Care Lawsuit
description: New York City's public hospital agency has agreed to pay $450,000 to settle a lawsuit in which St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan charged that the agency unfairly awarded a prison health-care contract to St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx last fall.

title: Nancy Topf, 55, a Choreographer and Teacher
description: Nancy Topf, a choreographer, dancer and teacher, died last Wednesday in the crash of Swissair Flight 111 off Nova Scotia. She was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEFALIDIS, NIKOS
description: KEFALIDIS-Nikos. Our partners, managers, and staff express our overwhelming loss of a dear friend. His generosity, caring, and accomplishments made him a unique human being who will never be replaced and whom we will never forget. We miss him deeply and want to express our heartfelt sympathy to the family he loved above all else in lifeLaurie, Melanie, Elias and Marissa. Roberta Bernhardt Bernhardt Karlitz Hayden & Decruze LLP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEAMAN, BERNARD
description: SEAMAN-Bernard. Artist, cartoonist whose work mainly appeared in the union and the labor press died September 7 at the age of 85. The cause was cancer according to his wife, Helen. Mr. Seaman served as Art Editor for the garment workers' union (ILGWU), the Seafarers Union (SIU), and the Electronic Workers (IUE). He contributed to many publications including PM, the New York Times, the Nation, & for many years was the editorial cartoonist for the AFL-CIO News. His cartoons were widely reprinted, both in the United States & Europe. The recipient of a number of awards, among them the Newspaper Guild Page One Award in 1952, Mr. Seaman designed and painted murals for union halls in Baltimore, New Orleans and other cities. Born in Stamford, CT he attended the public schools of New York City, City College, the Art Students League and the University of Alabama. Besides his wife, the former Helen Cook, he is survived by daughters Judith and Laura and three grandchildren. Services were private.

title: Improvising in Dancing Shoes
description: Art music forms have traditionally spent a good portion of their time pondering their relationship with dance. Jazz has been obsessed with its past as a popular dance form, and the vanguard of the Afro-Cuban tradition is as well, with experimentalists running their hands through the rich loam of the island's popular musical history. At S.O.B.'s on Monday night, Orlando (Maraca) Valle, a virtuoso flutist from Havana who spent time playing with Irakere, brought in his band Otra Vision, a group that wanders easily between street rumbas to hard bop and fusion; it's one of the few groups in the Latin jazz idiom that aspires to greatness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, MATTHEW THOMPSON
description: SCOTT - Matthew Thompson. Partner and Sr. Vice President of the sugar brokerage firm Czarnikow-Rionda, and principal of Darby Scott Ltd in New York, died on Swissair flight 111 at the age of 33. Mr. Scott was a graduate of Brown University, with a degree in Comparative Literature, and the Episcopal School in Alexandria, Va. A respected sugar trader and businesman, Mr. Scott helped his wife, Karen Darby Scott, found a couturier design company in 1994. Born in Columbia, S.A. Mr. Scott was fluent in English, Spanish and Portuguese. He was a member of the University Club and an enthusiastic athlete who played squash, soccer, tennis, and twice ran the New York Marathon. Matthew is survived by his wife, Karen who is known in the fashion world as Darby Scott, and their two year old son William. She is expecting their second child. He is also survived by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Scott of Englewood, NJ. Brothers, John W. and Robert A.T., and his sister Julia Leigh. Memorial services will be held on Friday, September 11 at 2 P.M., at Grace Church in N.Y., 802 Broadway at 10th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Concordia Language Villages, attention Christine Schulze at Concordia College, 901 South 8th Street, Moorehead, MN. 56562.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, JOHN. (HANS)
description: STRAUSS-John. (Hans) 85. Died September 6, 1998. The family of Hans Strauss mourns the loss of their beloved husband and father. Born and raised in Vienna, Austria, Hans earned his Doctorate of Law from the University of Vienna in 1938. That same year, to escape Nazi persecution, he and his wife, Irma, emigrated to the U.S., settled in NYC and created a new life. He founded Atlas Traffic Consultants in 1958 and was its President until his retirement in 1978. His volunteer activities included teaching in an adult literacy program, FEGS, translating Central Synagogue archives. He was an avid stamp and coin collector. He satisfied his passion for journalism by writing and publishing stories, poems and articles in German and English. His lifelong love of language and learning never diminished. He was outspoken in his commitment and concern for those less fortunate. He leaves his wife of sixty years, Irma, his two daughters and their families, Susan, Sandy and Daniel Jacobs, Connie, Mark, & Michael Kolber, his brother, George Strauss, several cousins, nieces, nephews, and many valued friends. A service in his memory will be held Thursday, September 10, at 3 PM at Gutterman Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: School Board Asks Judge to Dismiss Striking Teachers
description: With a New Jersey judge seemingly poised to start jailing striking teachers in Middletown Township at the urging of school officials, the school board abandoned that request today and instead asked that teachers lose their jobs if the walkout persists.

title: A Former Official Of Union Testifies
description: Simon Gourdine, the former executive director of the National Basketball Association players union, testified for four hours yesterday in arbitration hearings that will determine whether players with guaranteed contracts will be paid during the lockout imposed by team owners in July.

title: Cambodia Security Forces Tear Down Protesters' Tent City
description: Without warning, Cambodian troops ripped down a two-week-old protest campsite just after noon today and spent the rest of the day chasing stone-throwing mobs through the streets, flailing at them with sticks and firing automatic weapons in the air.

title: A Neglected Anti-Terror Weapon
description: The headlines make it sound as if we are making progress against terrorism: The United States is stepping up its security at embassies to protect against terrorist attacks. Two suspects in the bombings of our embassies in Kenya and Tanzania have been arrested and flown to New York. Osama bin Laden, the man suspected of being the mastermind of the bombings, has been indicted for terrorism crimes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROUTTENBERG, LILLY S.
description: ROUTTENBERG-Lilly S., age 89, on September 7, 1998 in Clifton, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg. Loving mother of Ruth R. Seldin, Aryeh Routtenberg and the late Naomi Routtenberg. Cherished grandmother of Alex, Yael, David and Noam. Devoted sister of Bernice Schneiderman. Services 11 AM, Wednesday, at ''The Riverside,'' W. 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: MET LIFE ANNOUNCES PLANS TO CUT 1,950 NONSALES JOBS
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company plans to cut 1,950 jobs, or up to 10 percent of its work force, in positions not related to sales. Met Life said yesterday that the planned reductions were part of its effort to lower overall expenses.
