The big New York-based mutual life-insurance concern said ''various factors, including normal attrition and organizational changes,'' would determine the actual number of jobs that would be eliminated. Details about the amount of money that would be saved by the cuts were not disclosed. In March, Met Life reported 1997 earnings of $1.2 billion after policyholder dividends, which amounted to $1.7 billion. Met Life now employs about 19,500 people at its administrative sites in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, CLARENCE HATFIELD
description: ARMSTRONG-Clarence Hatfield. Of the Bronx, NY on August 27th. Adopted son of Louis ''Satchmo'' Armstrong and husband of the late Evelyn Allen Armstrong. Visiting 3-4 PM and services at 4 PM Thursday, September 10, at McCall's Bronxwood Funeral Home, 4035 Bronxwood Avenue, Bronx.

title: Late Primary: Just Who Does It Hurt or Benefit?
description: When Robert Abrams won the New York Democratic primary for Senate six years ago, his candidacy was instantly debilitated by two political realities. The first was that a rancorous primary fight had left him short on both campaign funds and good will from voters. The second was that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato had five times as much money, an advantage the Republican incumbent demonstrated the morning after the primary with a flood of advertisements attacking his new Democratic opponent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANCHARD, PHYLLIS YVONNE
description: BLANCHARD-Phyllis Yvonne, 81. Of New York City, died September 7. Survived by two sons, Robert W. Blanchard and Scott A. Noll and four grandsons. A memorial service will be held 5:00PM, Thursday September 10, 1998 at the St. Timothy's and St. Matthew's Church, 26 West 84th Street, New York, NY. For information, contact the C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood, New Jersey.

title: A View on the Meaning of 'Merit' From 'The Shape of the River'
description: Following are excerpts from the study ''The Shape of the River: Long-Term Consequences of Considering Race in College and University Admissions,'' by William G. Bowen and Derek Bok, to be released today by Princeton University Press:

title: NatWest Announces Its Next Chairman
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said yesterday that it would appoint Sir David Rowland as chairman, effective next April. Sir David, 65, is credited with leading the recovery plan that turned around the Lloyd's of London insurance market after it had huge losses in the early 1990's. He was named a nonexecutive director of NatWest in February.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the contenders in New York's Democratic primary for the United States Senate reversed their positions on the death penalty in some copies. Geraldine A. Ferraro and Charles E. Schumer support the penalty; Mark Green opposes it.

title: A Fashion Groupie Finds the Perfect Niche
description: WHAT's a nice Mormon girl who grew up in Huntington Beach, Calif. -- home of shopping centers and surfers -- doing as the editor of Quest, the Manhattan society magazine that lovingly chronicles the 10021 set?

title: Pinstripes Could Be Short-Lived for Lowell
description: The visitors' locker room at Fenway Park is approximately the size of a large crate, with barely enough room for players to navigate from one end to the other. Nonetheless, six players promoted today from the Yankees' Class AAA affiliate stuffed themselves into corners and crannies, third baseman Mike Lowell among them.

title: After Violent Storms, Cleanup Begins
description: There was oak all over Oak Street today, literally. And at the intersection of Maple and Elm, the mammoth branch of a Norway maple that had once arched overhead, graceful and leafy, had been rendered so much cordwood and leaf piles at the curb in front of William Papirnik's house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAHMOUSH, ALBERT
description: TAHMOUSH-Albert. The Chairman of the Board, Directors and Employees of Reading Entertainment Inc. express their deepest sorrow over the tragic loss aboard Swissair Flight 111 of our beloved Director and his wife, Albert J. and Odette Tahmoush. Al faithfully served on Reading's Board of Director's since 1981. His insight, wisdom and clarity of thought were always inspirational. He was a consumate gentleman who displayed the utmost integrity and strength of character. His memory will forever be cherished and will continue to set a standard for all of us. We have been blessed to have had such a friend and mentor. We offer the Tahmoush family our most heartfelt sympathy.

title: Talks on a Cease-Fire in Congo End; Peace Gets Only Lip Service
description: Despite the official announcement on Monday night of a cease-fire agreement in Congo, the latest peace negotiations ended today much like the others in recent weeks -- with nothing more than a joint statement endorsing peace as an ultimate goal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAETH, ELOISE O'MARA
description: SPAETH-Eloise O'Mara. Of East Hampton, NY on September 4, 1998. Wife of the late Otto. Much beloved mother of Otto L. Spaeth, Jr.(Tony), Mary Louise Koon of St. Louis, and the late Marna Doherty and Deborah Shakespeare Green. Grandmother of sixteen. Great grandmother of 15. Mass of Christian Burial at Most Holy Trinity Church, Buell Lane, East Hampton on Friday, September 11 at 11 o'clock. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 or to the Eloise Spaeth Collection Preservation Fund at Guild Hall in East Hampton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, HELAINE
description: DAWSON-Helaine, 88. On September 5, 1998. Wonderful friend. Beloved sister of Phyllis Grunauer. Memorial service was held on Wednesday, September 8, 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, TILLIE
description: SOLOMON-Tillie. September 3, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mother of Dorine and Martin, and son-in-law Barry. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Services were held at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the increasing cost and competitiveness of state legislative elections misstated the party control of the Virginia Legislature. Republicans do not control both chambers; they control the Senate, and Democrats hold a narrow margin in the House of Delegates. There are 50 Democrats, 49 Republicans and 1 independent in that body, and the Speaker is a Democrat.

title: Security Flaws Left Embassy in Nairobi Open to Attack
description: The American Embassy here was an easy target for terrorists. Its perimeter was patrolled by unarmed guards earning about $100 a month. The embassy's parking lot, shared with a bank, had an exit lane protected by neither guards nor barricades.

title: Building an Empire
description: Larry Forgione, the chef and restaurateur, has not been an empire builder like some of his peers. But that is about to change. In the next two years, he will be opening three new restaurants and a cafe, and he is adding a market to An American Place. It was his recent break with Ark Restaurants, his former partner, that made it all possible, he said.

title: Glenn Bernbaum, a Solomon of Bistro Seating, Dies at 76
description: Glenn Bernbaum, the owner of Mortimer's restaurant, a favorite watering hole for Manhattan socialites, glitz folk and achievers since 1976, died late Monday night or early yesterday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: It's Got Squiggle Appeal
description: It could be the greatest television show on earth, but apparently having the word science in its title made children avoid it like, well, science. That's what the programmers at ABC decided about the zany but also educational show ''Science Court,'' which is about to start its second season on ABC's top-rated Saturday morning cartoon lineup.

title: Nikos Kefalidis, 55, a Real Estate Developer
description: Nikos Kefalidis, a real estate developer and founder of KLM Construction Inc., was among the 229 passengers who died on Swissair Flight 111 when it plunged into the sea off Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia, last Wednesday. He was 55 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paradox? What Paradox? The French Are Finally Getting Fat
description: I MARVEL each time I watch a certain farmer at our local market spoon rivers of thick, golden creme fraiche into large, fat glass jars for customers who tuck them into overflowing baskets. I can almost predict what these guilt-free shoppers will be having for Sunday lunch -- and it is never lo-cal. Yet, they don't seem to gain a pound. Americans, on the other hand, seem to pile on the ounces just thinking about buying cream.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANEVITZ, PAULINE
description: MANEVITZ-Pauline. Died September 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Hanania Manevitz. Devoted mother of Hon. Sharon Lauer Wolf, Sheila Manevitz Falik and Drs. Larry and Alan Manevitz. Cherished grandmother of Kehat and Hanania Falik, Zev, Shoul and Miriam Manevitz, Suzanne Lauer. Dearest sister of Madeline and Daniel Balk and the late Leon Balk. We will love you always and forever miss you. Memorial contributions may be sent to National Mental Health Education Foundation, C/O Alan Manevitz, M.D., 60 Sutton Place South, New York, New York 10022.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIGSBACH, MORRIS
description: KONIGSBACH-Morris. It is with deep sorrow that the Young Israel of Scarsdale mourns the passing of our dear member. Our heartfelt sympathies to Piri, Lily, Fred and the entire family. Jacob S. Rubenstein, Rabbi Joshua H. Klapper, President

title: Suspect Held in Colorado Shooting Rampage
description: A 17-year-old boy in police custody is the sole teen-age survivor and a suspect in a Labor Day shooting rampage that killed five other teen-agers and a woman, the authorities said today.

title: Liberties; View From the Limo
description: This is what Bill Clinton saw from the window of his limousine.

title: Brazil Plans Modest Steps to Spur Exports and Limit Spending
description: Caught between the urgency of stanching a near-hemorrhage of hard currency from the country and the demands of approaching presidential elections, the Brazilian Government announced modest measures today to stimulate exports and contain spending.

title: Sun and Microsystems Face Off at Hearing on '96 Java Pact
description: On the morning of March 12, 1996, after all-night negotiations to hammer out final details, principals from Sun Microsystems Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation signed a deal under which Sun licensed its promising Java technology to Microsoft.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Tenement House Setting For Dinner Parties

title: Out of Step on the Harlem March
description: Despite the vicious rhetoric of Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the so-called ''Million Youth March'' in Harlem last Saturday ended without serious violence, and with widespread praise for the restraint and courtesy of individual New York City police officers. But rightly or wrongly, the massive deployment of police and military-looking equipment focused the community's anger on City Hall rather than Mr. Muhammad. Harlem's officials said their constituents felt the Police Department's tactics were aimed more at intimidating the community than protecting it.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Using Different Strategy, Company Is Leasing Site
description: Sometimes less really can be more.

title: Apartheid Assassin Confesses Killings in Other Lands
description: One of the apartheid era's worst assassins began confessing to the Truth and Reconciliation Commission today about murders and bombings he and seven other colleagues committed outside South Africa.

title: Trying to Make Food Part of the Allure
description: A LAST-MINUTE call from the restaurant says it all: could we please send another photographer? The last one, it seems, caught a patron dining with a woman who was not his wife and the man is frantic. One if by Land, Two if by Sea has not been called New York's most romantic restaurant for nothing.

title: Exporters in China Are Left Wondering Where All the Russian Traders Went
description: Normally the Yabao Road market here is a bustling place, with more than 2,000 bountiful stalls crammed full of gaudy fur coats, bejeweled fuzzy sweaters, lavish blond wigs and formidable lacy bras -- reflecting the latest fashion trends not of Beijing, but of Moscow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, TARA
description: NELSON-Tara. The Milstein family and the Brokers and Staff of Douglas Elliman, offer their profound condolences to the family of Tara Nelson, who died in the crash of Swissair flight 111. Tara's many friends who knew her when she worked at Douglas Elliman remember her as an extremely professional, charming, warm and caring member of the group, cooperative and helpful to brokers, customers and staff alike. A loss so hard to comprehend. Our thoughts and prayers are with Tara's parents, our colleagues Bob and Sheila Nelson, in this time of incredible tragedy. Howard P. Milstein, Chairman The Brokers and Staff of Douglas Elliman

title: Police Defend Rally Tactics, Citing Attacks
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir yesterday offered a new explanation why his officers stormed the stage at the end of Saturday's youth rally in Harlem, saying that they did so only after they were pelted by bricks, bottles, metal barriers and other objects, many of them hurled from the speaking platform itself.

title: Business Travel; That old American Express standby, the check, will soon be out in that new currency, the euro.
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS said yesterday that it would print euro-denominated traveler's checks in time for sales to start on Jan. 1, 1999, the beginning of the European Monetary Union. While the euro becomes the official currency of the 11-nation euro-zone next Jan. 1, with national currency exchange rates fixed to the euro, the circulation of euro notes and coins will not begin until Jan. 1, 2002.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBA, MAHMOUD
description: DIBA-Mahmoud. The Board of Trustees of The Hagop Kevorkian Fund mourn the sudden and tragic loss of Mahmoud Diba, beloved husband of Layla and father of Ahmad. His warmth and concern for family and friends will be sorely missed. We extend our condolences to every member of his family. Ralph D. Minasian, President

title: Big Metropolis on Campus; New York Siren Song Lures More College Applications
description: New York hardly fits the usual image of College Town, U.S.A. And higher education will never dominate the local culture and economy the way it does in, say, Boston or Ann Arbor, Mich. But increasingly, New York is becoming the college applicant's destination of choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITWIN, CELIA
description: LITWIN-Celia. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Celia Litwin, and extends heartfelt condolences to her family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Martin Kay, President

title: Expert on Banking Mergers at Goldman, Sachs Plans to Retire
description: J. Christopher Flowers, a founder of Goldman, Sachs & Company's lucrative financial institutions merger practice, said yesterday that he was leaving the firm at the end of November. Mr. Flowers's retirement comes at a sensitive time for Goldman: The firm reaffirmed yesterday its intention to end its private partnership and issue shares to the public in November.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEILSON, ISABELLE
description: NEILSON-Isabelle. Age 87. On September 6, 1998 in South Paris, Maine, formerly of Carmel, N.Y. Ms Neilson was Confidential Assistant to Cabinet Secretary John W. Gardner during the Johnson administration. Dear aunt of Frank White. Visiting at Adams-Cordovano Funeral Home, Inc., 15 Church St., Carmel, NY off Route 6 on Friday from 9am-10am, funeral services directly following. Interment Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Campaign 'Reform' Limits Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Sunday about a magazine called Wallpaper and the people who buy the modernist furniture it promotes misstated the address of Ace Furniture in Manhattan. It is 269 Elizabeth Street, not 295.

title: Yeltsin's Silence Fuels Talk Of New Choices for Premier
description: The big news in Russia today was what did not happen.

title: More Democrats Rebuke Clinton and Call for Public Report
description: Two more Senate Democrats delivered stinging rebukes of President Clinton today, condemning what one called his ''dishonesty'' and the other his ''immoral'' behavior. The chorus of critics within the President's own party has gained volume as lawmakers return to Washington anticipating a report any day now from the independent counsel investigating Mr. Clinton.

title: Cheers and Jeers Greet Clinton in Suburbs
description: Standing on her sun-dappled lawn, Celia Winter politely dismissed President Clinton as ''a farce'' as his motorcade arrived from the White House on a mission of preaching education in this bastion of suburban values.

title: Clinton Sends Top Aide to Assess the Northwest Strike Deadlock
description: President Clinton dispatched one of his closest aides to Minneapolis yesterday to try to break the deadlock between Northwest Airlines and its striking pilots, which has grounded the carrier for 11 days and disrupted travel in the much of the Midwest and South.

title: Edward Robb Ellis Dies at 87; Diarist of 22 Million Words
description: Edward Robb Ellis, who in 1927 began keeping a diary to fend off the boredom of his small town Midwestern adolescence and emerged nearly 70 years later as the most prolific known diarist in the history of American letters, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Metaphysics Of a Home Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Report by Starr Against Clinton Expected Soon
description: Dismissing objections from the White House, Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent prosecutor, plans to deliver a report to Congress as early as the end of this week summarizing his eight-month inquiry into President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, allies of Mr. Starr said today.

title: Just Clearing the Wall, McGwire Claims the Record
description: Mark McGwire, the St. Louis Cardinals' Paul Bunyan with a bat, made the most out of the least tonight, setting Major League Baseball's home run record by hitting his 62d and shortest home run of the season.

title: New York School Year Begins Minus Usual Sense of Crisis
description: New York City's 1.1 million public school children begin trudging back to class today to a system less preoccupied with opening-day distractions than in any September in at least five years but facing new pressures to convert this moment of relative calm into lasting student achievement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, IRVING
description: COHEN-Irving. Dearest friend, you will be sadly missed but never forgotten. Anita and Fred Benjamin

title: Politicians' Easy Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Rises Sharply on Hope Inspired by Fed Chief
description: Stock prices continued their wild ride yesterday, but the vertiginous swings left investors cheering as the Dow Jones industrial average vaulted 380.53 points, or just less than 5 percent. Broader market averages also recorded hefty gains, partly reversing their recent steep declines.

title: Newsletter Points the Way to Rare Buys
description: SO you're a wine fanatic whose day is incomplete if it doesn't include a bottle of some rare California cabernet. Unfortunately, you have lots of incomplete days, because most shops don't carry them and those that do are always sold out.

title: Agassi Comes Up Short In Rally Against Kucera
description: They were shunted from one stadium to another, assigned a match schedule that shifted from day to night and back into day. They were ordered to start their Round of 16 tilt on a dark, damp court Monday night and finish it yesterday on a dry court that sparkled like an emerald. Forgive Andre Agassi and Karol Kucera for being so confused about their United States Open mission that they occasionally forgot how to play tennis and lapsed into a five-set comedy of unforced errors, 145 in all, that eventually cost this Grand Slam the continued services of its 1994 champion.

title: Chile Confronts Its Own History
description: Twenty-five years ago this week, on Sept. 11, 1973, the democratically elected Marxist President of Chile, Salvador Allende Gossens, died during a military coup as planes of the Chilean Air Force bombed La Moneda, the presidential palace in Santiago.

title: PENTACON BUYS ASI AEROSPACE GROUP FOR $86.4 MILLION
description: Pentacon Inc., a distributor of screws, bolts and other fasteners, purchased the closely held ASI Aerospace Group Inc. for $86.4 million in cash to expand in the aerospace-supply business. Pentacon, which is based in Houston, said it expected to bring its annual revenue to about $300 million with the acquisition of ASI, a supplier of fasteners and related components with offices in California and Texas. Pentacon had 1997 revenue of about $151 million. The acquisition broadens aerospace product lines for Pentacon, which supplies a number of industries. Pentacon has added about $118 million in revenue since it went public in March and promised to buy small parts distributors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENDRATH, BARBARA T.
description: EISENDRATH-Barbara T. Age 75. Died at home, September 7, 1998. Wife of the late David B. Eisendrath. Survived by her brother, Richard Forrest and sister-in-law Judith, their two daughters and two nephews. A true New Yorker, Barbara Eisendrath shared her intellectual enthusiasms and her joie de vivre with many friends, old and new. She will be remembered for her generosity, her wit, her interest in life, and her green thumb. Donations in her memory may be made to the ASPCA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEMITOFF, BETTY
description: NEMITOFF-Betty. Loving mother of Michael and daughter-in-law Ruth. Dear grandmother of Adam and Matthew. She taught silver/ gold jewelrymaking at the 92nd Street Y and was a freelance fashion illustrator. She was a very, very talented artist. She will be missed by all who knew her. Services Wednesday, 9:30AM, at Gramercy Chapels, 152 2nd Avenue, New York City.

title: The Metaphysics Of a Home Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Letters By Kendall and Starr
description: Following are excerpts from an exchange of letters between the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr and President Clinton's lawyer, David E. Kendall, about Mr. Kendall's request for an advance copy of any report Mr. Starr submits to Congress on his investigation of President Clinton:

title: CBS Ratings Strong In Return to Football
description: The first week of the National Football League season produced one clear ratings winner among the broadcast networks: CBS, which is paying $500 million annually to return to broadcasting the N.F.L. after a four-year hiatus.

title: Singing Of Byron, Yet Unborn
description: Peter Blegvad does not exactly fulfill the stereotype of the ''avant-rock titan'' although he is erudite and exceedingly tall and was billed that way at the Knitting Factory on Monday night. The phrase conjures images of wizards in psychedelic garb, more like the other participants of this four-day art-rock retrospective, like Daevid Allen, a founder of Gong, or Roy Harper, who sings of goblins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATTIMER, PRESTON DON AND NANCY BENNETT
description: LATTIMER-Preston Don and Nancy Bennett of New York City tragically died on SwissAir Flight 111 on September 2, 1998. Don Lattimer was Managing Director of Allen & Company. His wife of forty-two years, Nancy Bennett Lattimer, was a devoted wife, mother and grandmother. The Lattimers are survived by two sons, Mark of St. Petersburg, Florida, and William of Darien, Connecticut; two daughters, Elizabeth Lattimer Abshire of Camarillo, California and Amy of St. Petersburg, Florida; a sister, Helen Ruth Young, of Wellington, Ohio; and seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational United Church of Christ, 140 South Main Street, Wellington, Ohio on Friday, September 11th at 4:30 pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Nancy and Don Lattimer Scholarship Fund, c/o Mr. & Mrs. Walter Young, 238 Grand Ave., Wellington, OH 44090.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCOTT, MATTHEW THOMPSON
description: SCOTT-Matthew Thompson. Memorial services for Matthew Scott, 33, a passenger on Swissair flight 111 will be held Friday, September 11 at 2 P.M., at Grace Church in New York, Broadway and 10th Street (Manhattan). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Concordia Language Villages, Christine Schulze at Concordia College, 901 South 8th Street, Moorehead, MN. 56562.

title: Showdown at 60 Feet: Cone Outduels Martinez
description: David Cone donned a gracious choir boy smile Monday and said he was not quite good enough for Cy Young Award consideration. The mask came off tonight and he pitched his heart out against Boston's Pedro Martinez.

title: To focus on brand-building, 2 big marketers will consolidate portions of their accounts.
description: TWO giant advertisers said yesterday that they would consolidate portions of their accounts.

title: A Carnival? No Way
description: A haze of mystery has settled around ''The Roseanne Show,'' which arrives on Monday as the latest entry in the daytime television gabfest listings. No one, not even the star herself, has been able to say exactly what format her new show will follow -- foggery that is intended to generate curiosity about the show, no doubt, but that also arose from necessity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, CLIFFORD
description: THOMPSON-Clifford. Of Hartsdale, NY, on September 7, 1998. Former husband of Mary Lee Fuhr Baranger. Father of Robert Thompson. Funeral service Friday, 10 AM, at United Memorial Methodist Church, White Plains, NY. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Reposing at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York, Thursday evening, 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions to Art Students League of New York.

title: Pataki Signs Law Creating Hudson Park
description: Saying Manhattan's western waterfront has been an embarrassment since his days as a young lawyer on Wall Street, Gov. George E. Pataki signed a law yesterday to create a park nearly five miles long, from Battery Park City to 59th Street.

title: The Metaphysics Of a Home Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians' Easy Out
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: Free Wine With Lunch

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MIRIAM
description: GOLDSTEIN - Miriam. Beloved wife of Samuel, wonderful mother of Jeffrey and Debra, and Bonnie. Dear sister of Charlotte Katz, cherished grandmother of Alyssa and Danny. Service today 11 A.M. at The Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ.

title: No Room for Panic in the Game Plan
description: It would have been easy for Ray Sherman to fall into the trap, the one that grabs a new coach by the throat and makes him do things he does not want to do. The one that creates pressure to make a splash.

title: Vermont Vote Turns Fiction Into a Fact
description: Living out a scenario almost exactly like the script of the movie he starred in, Fred Tuttle, a 79-year-old retired dairy farmer and late-blooming movie actor with a campaign budget of $16 or so, unexpectedly won the Republican nomination for United States Senate in Vermont tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, MARION FRENCH
description: HAMMOND-Marion French, 90. On September 7, 1998, at Hightstown, New Jersey. She was the widow of Neill P. Overman, Ernest C. Johnson Jr., and Samuel Hammond. She is survived by her son Neill P. Overman Jr. of Stockton, N.J., her daughter Anne Overman Bunn of Short Hills, NJ, her sister Emily French Hazen, and several stepchildren, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A private graveside service will be held on Saturday, September 19.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: An Indian Kitchen In One Little Package
description: MADAME CURRY packaged Indian mixes are what foods like Rice-A-Roni should be. The recipes are authentic, the instructions are easy to follow and the quality of the ingredients is exceptional -- the fragrance of the spices practically leaps through the plastic.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Touting the Flavor Of the Big Apple

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNBAUM, GLENN
description: BERNBAUM - Glenn. I was shocked, a sharp feeling of loss overcame me when Mimi came back from that phone call and said Glenn is dead. How could it be? My mind replayed a scene with Glenn when the two of us were having lunch in my office and my secretary walked in saying Kennedy has been shot. Our lives had been closely intertwined. Glenn ran my business, the Custom Shop, for 17 years. One day he said: ''why can't I drink at my own bar?'' Then he said: ''I want to open a restaurant.'' Glenn really knew food and Glenn could cook. For him it would be a hobby and, crazy as it may sound, I encouraged him to go ahead. Glenn continued to run my business on a part-time basis (now from noon to 5 daily) for the next 3 years and with very good reason he was proud of Mortimer's Restaurant. We celebrated my 80th, 85th, and 90th birthdays there, and on each occasion, Glenn created a beautiful setting-a completely new Mortimer's-revealing his creative imagination. Glenn had become family and we shall miss him. Mimi and Mortimer Levitt

title: Hundley Remains On Outside
description: Todd Hundley arrived in the visitors' clubhouse at Veterans Stadium today not long after his Mets teammates and was met with enthusiastic greetings and high-fives. But being back with the team and actually feeling a part of it all are still drastically different stories.

title: The Metaphysics Of a Home Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARDI, BABAJAN
description: VARDI-Babajan. Passed away on September 4, 1998 on Long Island, N.Y. Beloved husband of Liza. Dear father of five children, Moshe (Karen), Joseph (Dalia), Miryam (Joseph), Ben (Elahe), and Esther (Jack). Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren. Funeral will be held in Jerusalem, Israel and Shiva will be held at 21 Clover Drive, Great Neck Estates, L.I. from Tuesday, September 8 at 3 P.M. until sundown Friday, resuming at sundown Saturday night.

title: Lieutenant Governor Starting TV Spots in Governor's Race
description: After a long delay, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross is to release her first major television advertisement today in a last-minute attempt to persuade Democratic primary voters that she is a formidable candidate despite the problems that have plagued her gubernatorial campaign.

title: Lapse in Communication At Newark Airport
description: Communication between pilots and air traffic controllers at Newark International Airport was cut off momentarily yesterday when the control tower's emergency generator failed during a power disruption, but the problem did not affect flights, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DONNELL, KIRK
description: O'DONNELL-Kirk. Formed a decade ago by a bi-partison group of New Yorkers, the ''Kirk O'Donnell Breakfast Club'' met regularly under his tutelage to hear a crosssection of views from Washington. Kirk was our mentor and guide to the mysteries and intricacies of American politics and government. He made politics and policy accessible and meaningful, and always joyous. We will miss his wit and wisdom, his twinkle and laugh, and his love of his noble craft of which he was one of our generation's most accomplished craftsmen. We were blessed to have learned from him. Our condolences to Kathryn, Holly and Brendan. Jay L. Kriegel, Chairman Robert E. Rubin, Tom Tisch, Vice Chairmen

title: Beyond the Homers, Maris Was a Complete Player
description: While everybody is cheering Mark McGwire, let us not overlook Roger Maris. For 37 years, in life and in death, Maris held one of sports's most important records, despite the sullen disapproval of many fans, who saw him as a one-trick imposter.

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: JACKSONVILLE

title: Hollywood Realities
description: To the Editor:

title: McGwire Is King, but Sosa Is Prince
description: Sammy Sosa actually wanted to weep after Mark McGwire made baseball history by lining his 62d homer to eclipse Roger Maris's illustrious 37-year-old record tonight. Sosa watched a delirious McGwire stumble around the bases during a historic trot and thought that, indeed, he would cry while witnessing the warm scene.

title: Promote Safe Sex, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Gray Delays Decision On Joining the Giants
description: The Giants attempted yesterday to sign the former Indianapolis Colts cornerback Carlton Gray, a player who could eventually unseat Conrad Hamilton as the starting right cornerback, but found themselves in competition for Gray's services with a handful of other National Football League teams.

title: Sports of The Times: A MIGHTY SWING, A GRAND RECORD; After 37 Years, McGwire Passes Maris
description: JUST keep belting the ball out of the park, early and often. This was the way to exorcise all the ghosts and the shadows, the doubts and the quibbles, the parenthetical clauses and the modifying phrases.

title: Districts Scramble for Rooms as Preschools Grow
description: The sprawling room in the Bronx was undergoing a transformation on Friday. A pre-kindergarten teacher unpacked dozens of wooden blocks, books and colorful puzzles in what used to be an office crammed with bulky desks, copiers and file cabinets, and painted institutional white.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, EDWIN A.
description: MALLOY-Edwin A. On September 5, 1998. Beloved husband of Susan. Devoted father of Jennifer Combs and Timon. Loving grandfather of Meredith Combs. Dear brother of Howard and Jospeh Malloy and Tobene Rosenthal. Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Service Wednesday, September 9, 2 PM, Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, The Solid Tumor Group.

title: PERKIN-ELMER MAY SELL ITS ANALYTICAL INSTRUMENT UNIT
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, one of the world's largest makers of biomedical and drug research equipment, said yesterday that it might sell or spin off its analytical instruments unit as it concentrated on its more profitable life-sciences business. The company, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., hired Warburg Dillon Read L.L.C. to advise it and expects to make a decision on the unit, which makes instruments that measure gases, liquids and solids, by early 1999. The unit could sell for about $610 million, analysts said. It accounted for about 40 percent of Perkin-Elmer's $1.5 billion revenue in the 1998 fiscal year. Perkin-Elmer's biology-related business makes equipment and software for such processes as analyzing human DNA. Perkin-Elmer's shares rose $1.75, to $57.75, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RENO ANNOUNCES AN INITIAL INQUIRY INTO CLINTON ADS
description: Advancing a pivotal step toward the possible appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate campaign finance abuses, Attorney General Janet Reno ordered a 90-day inquiry today into whether President Clinton circumvented Federal election laws in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIGATNER, FLORENCE
description: FIGATNER-Florence. On September 8, 1998. Beloved wife of Alan. Dear mother of Arlene, Maxine and Robert. Mother-in-law of Jonathan Pronesti and Lisa Figatner. Adored grandmother of Joseph, Ashley and Scott. Dear sister of Franklin and Roslyn, Marilyn and Murray. Services today 12:15 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: No Easy Route to Recovering Nazi Plunder
description: In the last six months there has been a notable change in the art world. It has nothing to do with exhibitions or acquisitions, but rather with the rhetoric surrounding potential claims for art plundered during World War II that later found its way, by various routes through dealers and collectors, into American museums.

title: McCaughey Ross Assails Vallone, Chief Party Rival, in TV Debate
description: The most heated exchange yet in the race for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination came last night in a televised debate, as Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross went on the offensive against her chief rival, Peter F. Vallone, blaming him for the ills of New York City's public schools.

title: Smoke and Mirrors, Rock-and-Roll; A Master Illusionist Fills Arenas With Magic
description: In the basement of the Magic Castle, a private magicians' club here, Franz Harary was performing a few new tricks for an audience of 50 colleagues and friends. He divided a woman into seven pieces, brought a fossilized lizard to life and attached the torso of one woman onto the legs of another. All that may sound complex, but Mr. Harary was full of apologies for its simplicity after the show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACHS, RAYMOND., SR.
description: SACHS-Raymond., Sr. Of Lutherville, MD, formerly of South Orange, NJ, on September 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Monica (nee Greeley) and brother of Catherine S. Phillips of Goshen, CT. Devoted father of Raymond, Jr. of Lewes, DE, Gregory of Summit, NJ, Margaret (Healey) of New Vernon, NJ and Elizabeth of Washington, DC. Survived by eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. The Mass of the Resurecction will be celebrated at 11:00 AM on Saturday, September 12 at Shrine of the Sacred Heart Church, Mt. Washington, Baltimore, MD. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Baltimore Serra Club Foundation, 320 North Cathedral St., Baltimore, MD, 21201.

title: New Venture For Ralph Nader
description: Ralph Nader has a new project, named Commercial Alert, meant to serve as an outlet and clearinghouse for consumer complaints about the increasing commercialism of American society.

title: Financial Unit Spun Off, British American Tobacco Rises 38%
description: Shares in the renamed British American Tobacco P.L.C. soared far ahead of the rest of London's lackluster stock market today in the first day's trading since the company sold its financial services arm to the Zurich Group.

title: 'Side Man' Is Moving To the John Golden
description: ''Side Man'' is moving on. Again.

title: About New York; Over a Bridge, The Real Life Of Nueva York
description: PICHONA ETLIS and three friends traveled from Argentina to New York for a quick getaway. They had already ridden the double-decker tour buses for one of those quickie pseudosurveys of the city. Downtown and uptown, they had shopped and dined, walked and watched. It was all nice, but was it real? Something was missing.

title: From Afghanistan, a Patchwork of Cuisines
description: THE food of mountainous Afghanistan is simple and satisfying, and much of it seems familiar, as well. The kebabs that are the specialty of this bright, pleasant restaurant, which opened just last month, resemble those found at Greek, Turkish and Middle Eastern restaurants. The rice and curries come from India, the dumplings may be Chinese and the yogurt may be Russian.

title: Jonsson to Re-Sign
description: Kenny Jonsson, the Islanders' best defenseman, will re-sign with the team today, according to a team official. Jonsson, a restricted free agent, has agreed in principle to a multiyear contract worth between $1.5 million and $2 million a season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNIN, JACK
description: KUNIN-Jack. Age 74. On September 5th. Beloved cousin of Eda Kunin and Florence Robinson. For information, call 212-222-1953.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Congo peace talks in Zimbabwe misidentified President Robert Mugabe's country. It is Zimbabwe, not Zambia.

title: Yale's Modernist Icon
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I would tell black youngsters to graduate from the schools magna cum laude and get one of those well-paying jobs to pay for all the therapy they'll need to remove that stigma.''

title: Fan's Collection Offers Cardboard Chronicle
description: Wendy Levy Jackson is a successful real estate broker, but you can't blame her for tuning in every night for the latest on Mark McGwire's quest to surpass Roger Maris as baseball's single-season home run king.

title: 3 Swedes Gain the Quarterfinals
description: When Bjorn Borg was gliding ruthlessly and quietly along the baseline, the United States Open was the brash and rambunctious place where Swedes could not win. But Mats Wilander broke the mold in 1988; Stefan Edberg grinded it into small pieces in 1991 and 1992 and now a new generation of Swedish men is doing more damage on the hardcourts of the National Tennis Center in Queens.

title: COLLEGES: FOOTBALL
description: SYRACUSE

title: Study Strongly Supports Affirmative Action in Admissions to Elite Colleges
description: A major new study of the records and experiences of tens of thousands of students over 20 years at the nation's elite colleges concludes that their affirmative action policies created the backbone of the black middle class and taught white classmates the value of integration.

title: German Regulators Oppose Pay-TV Deal
description: German antitrust authorities said yesterday that they would probably block a new plan by Bertelsmann A.G. and the Kirch group to raise their stakes in the country's largest pay-TV channel, because such a deal would give them a pay-TV monopoly. The German Federal Cartel Office said it would make a final decision by mid-October on the Bertelsmann-Kirch plan to buy a stake in the pay- TV channel Premiere from Canal Plus S.A. of France, raising their stakes to 50 percent each.

title: McDougal's Trial Begins With Chronicle of Finances
description: After months of delay, opening arguments began here today in the embezzlement trial of Susan H. McDougal, with a prosecutor telling jurors that President Clinton's onetime partner in the Whitewater deal stole more than $150,000 from the conductor Zubin Mehta and his wife in a ''crime of passion'' born of frustration at her financial reverses in Arkansas.

title: The Metaphysics Of a Home Run
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tale Out of Brittany
description: LE BERNARDIN has dazzled New York and changed the way Americans think about fish since the day it opened in the winter of 1986. The restaurant's achievement came not just from talent in the kitchen or the dining room. It took an unusual brother-sister act.

title: The Gloom Around Bill Clinton
description: Bill Clinton returned to work this week in a Washington unmistakably transformed since his hedged, much ridiculed confession to the nation last month about his relationship with Monica Lewinsky. With Democrats increasingly allergic to their leader and Republicans no longer treating impeachment proceedings as unthinkable, Mr. Clinton faces a rapid erosion of support that imperils his Presidency. As an astute politician and adroit card player, Mr. Clinton must by now realize that his incomplete explanations about Ms. Lewinsky are a losing hand.

title: The Jets Focus on Johnson And Foley
description: Bill Parcells will wring his hands this week, complain about a defense that collapsed in overtime against the San Francisco 49ers and growl about facing a Baltimore Ravens team on Sunday that crushed his team by 33-0 in the preseason. But Jets fans can take heart from that crushing loss to San Francisco: Glenn Foley and Keyshawn Johnson have found each other.

title: World News Briefs; 3-Cultures Foundation Opened by Shimon Peres
description: Former Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel inaugurated a foundation in Seville today to promote cooperation among Jews, Christians and Muslims. Mr. Peres said he hoped that the organization would help Bethlehem and Nazareth prepare to celebrate the millennium.

title: THE CHEF
description: FOR some years now, I have been using low, dry heat to add intense flavor to tomatoes or to make sweet root-vegetable chips. I simply put the vegetables in a very low oven and let them laze away as the moisture is slowly drawn out and the sugars become caramelized and profoundly sweet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LISMAN, JACK V. M.D.
description: LISMAN-Jack V. M.D. The Board of Directors, Administration and Medical Staff of Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital mourn the passsing of Dr. Jack Lisman on August 30, 1998. Dr. Lisman's prestigious career as a member of our medical staff span over 40 years starting with his appointment to the Department of Ophthalmalogy in April 1958. We extend our deepest sympathy to his entire family. Lindsay C. Herkness, III President, Board of Directors George A. Sarkar, Ph.D., J.D. Executive Director

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RISES. Copper prices surged on expectations that demand from European manufacturers would pick up. Copper for December delivery rose 1.85 cents, to 77.35 cents a pound -- its highest closing price since July 30.

title: Hingis Makes Quick Work Of Rival Seles In Quarterfinal
description: It's not that she is jaded: Martina Hingis delights in winning matches. Any matches, anywhere. But it takes a special occasion like last night's 6-4, 6-4 defeat of Monica Seles in their windblown United States Open quarterfinal to provoke the 17-year-old sophisticate to leap with joy as punctuation to a soul-satisfying victory.

title: Merrill Lynch's Overseas Loss Is $135 Million
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it lost $135 million in July and August from its business with Russia and other emerging markets, and was now preparing to cut costs after the recent turmoil in financial markets.

title: Clinton Aides Detail Strategy
description: The debate in President Clinton's inner circle about whether to challenge the right of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, to send a detailed impeachment report to Congress turned more on political considerations than on legal grounds, Presidential advisers said today.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Seasoning Cast Iron

title: INSIDE
description: Race Preferences Backed

title: METRIS TO BUY $1 BILLION IN CREDIT CARD LOANS FROM PNC
description: The Metris Companies, a credit card concern, agreed to buy $1 billion of credit card loans from the PNC Bank Corporation. Metris, based in St. Louis Park, Minn., is buying 518,000 accounts from customers who do not bank with PNC, which is based in Pittsburgh, and do not hold affinity cards from any of PNC's credit card partners. While the companies did not disclose terms of the acquisition, the average premium paid for credit card portfolios this year is 14 percent, according to R.K. Hammer Investment Bankers, credit card consultants. Metris shares rose $3.625 each, to $55.125, in Nasdaq trading. PNC shares rose $3.375 a share, to $46.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Trial to Determine Fate of Abortion Ban
description: A three-day trial to determine the fate of a state ban on a particular late-term abortion procedure is to begin today before a Federal judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, ANNA (NEWTA)
description: SHERMAN-Anna (Newta). On September 6th, 1998 at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Meir Sherman, Israel's first Economic Minister to the United States, first Chairman of the Board of Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York, & Managing Director of Paz Oil Company in Israel. Devoted sister to the late pianist Nadia Reisenberg Sherman, and the late theremin virtuoso Clara Rockmore. Survived by her son, Roniel, her granddaughters, Karen and Dina, nephews Alexander and Robert, & their families. Services on Friday, September 11, at 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Savoring a Borges Blend of Imaginings
description: COLLECTED FICTIONS

title: Grilling With the Mark of the Wild
description: GRILLING is such a familiar cooking technique for Americans that its particular effect on foods is often overlooked. Take, for instance, what grilling does to a steak. It browns and sears it in neat straight lines, so that you get crisp bites of a deep, caramelized flavor in between more tender parts untouched by the grill.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRION INC., Sanford, N.C., the air-cleaning equipment company, said its acquisition by McLeod Russell Holdings P.L.C. for about $53 million in cash had been postponed.

title: Artificial Turf Pops Up as No. 1 Foe
description: There were bandages everywhere in the Giants' locker room Monday morning. Big, thick white gauze wrapped around broad biceps and elastic dressings on puffy elbows, wrists and hands. Sunday, after all, had brought a tough game against the Giants' oldest rival, the Washington Redskins.

title: A Reluctant Home-Run Hitter, a Reluctant Hero
description: From the time he began playing baseball as an 8-year-old in Claremont, Calif., Mark McGwire has been a reluctant home run hitter and a reluctant hero. McGwire wanted to be a pitcher, not a hitter, and he remained on the mound until college. He has always wanted to avoid being the primary focus in a team sport.

title: I.B.M. to Introduce Disk Drive Of Tiny Size and Big Capacity
description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to announce today that it has developed an ultra-small, one-inch disk drive aimed at the explosively growing market for hand-held computers and consumer appliances like digital cameras and digital cellular telephones.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIPS. The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen, helped in part by a strong rally in United States stocks. In New York, the dollar settled at 132.10 yen, up from 131.82 yen on Monday but down from 133.57 on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPF, NANCY
description: TOPF-Nancy. Choreographer and educator of the highest order, whose imagination over the years helped to build the world's most extraordinary dance community. A single tragic moment only confirms the immense contribution she has made to our lives and creativity; she survives on our stages and in the hearts of her students. Our profound sympathies go out to her family and colleagues. The Artists, Staff and Board of Dance Theater Workshop

title: Researchers Report Success in Method To Pick Baby's Sex
description: With an announcement that is already producing applause and handwringing, doctors at a fertility center near Washington will report today that they can substantially stack the odds that a couple can have a baby of the sex they choose.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHN, BETTY L.
description: COHN-Betty L. October 4th, 1921September 9th, 1988. Lovingly remembered by sons Larry and Steve and their families

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Campaign 'Reform' Limits Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Tuscany Meets Mom
description: WHAT makes a pot roast Tuscan? Perhaps the rich gravy is made with Chianti, or olive oil is used to brown the brisket? Either way, the Tuscan pot roast ($13 a pound) at CAMPAGNA HOME -- is fabulous, lean and tender enough to melt in your mouth. And while it may be called Tuscan, it is equally Jewish, reflecting the formula that the chef, Mark Strausman, has used so well in Campagna, his restaurant just across the street, in the Flatiron district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDINGER, EDWARD J.
description: BALDINGER-Edward J. Of Staten Island, New York, on September 7, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Mary, loving father of Mary Molinelli, Bernard, Edward, and Mark Baldinger. Also survived by six grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. Funeral from Casey Funeral Home, 350 Slosson Avenue, Staten Island, New York, Friday. Funeral Mass Saint Ann's Church, 10 A.M. Private committal to follow. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: When Art Becomes A Metaphor For Identity
description: The art of the past is forever being reinterpreted in terms of the politics of the present. The most distinctive Armenian sculptures, for example, are heavy stone crosses called khatchkars. The Armenians, having been driven away or massacred by the Seljuk Turks, the Turkomans, the Arabs and others on and off since ancient times, developed khatchkars partly as a way to leave their mark in the land. Khatchkars are not easily moved. They suggest the enduring presence of the Christian faith in Armenia, even in the absence of the Armenians who erected them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLSTERLI, ANDREW
description: BOLSTERLI-Andrew. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion express our heartfelt condolences to John and Marianne Slade, beloved members of the HUC family, on the untimely and tragic death of their cherished grandson, Andrew. May his memory be a comfort to all those who mourn him, his dear parents and sister, family and friends. May God comfort them among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman President Dr. Alfred Gottschalk Chancellor Burton Lehman, Chair Board of Governors

title: Campaign 'Reform' Limits Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, JUAN
description: METZGER-Juan. September 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Joe, Tim and Jacqui, cherished grandfather of Jill, loving brother of Miriam. Service Thursday, September 10, 9:45 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Browning School, 52 East 62 Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The Bulls Stampede Back, Shoving Chicken Little Aside
description: Back to work. Back to school. Back to the bull market.

title: Consumer Borrowing in U.S. Surged in July
description: Borrowing by United States consumers grew at a faster-than-expected pace in July as auto and other personal loans surged, offsetting a drop in credit card debt, Federal Reserve figures showed today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENHEIM, HAROLD A.
description: LOEWENHEIM-Harold A. The New York Chapter CLU & CHFC, the NYS and the NYC Associations of Life Underwriters and GAMA of Greater New York mourn the passing of their highly esteemed and beloved Past President. He will be sorely missed.

title: Fair Game?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Royal Opera, Regrouping, Will Close For a Year
description: The Royal Opera House, buffeted in recent months by financial and management disasters that left it teetering on the brink of insolvency, announced today that it had worked out a radical solution to its problems. Starting in January, it said, it will close for almost a year, canceling all opera and most ballet performances until December 1999 to save money and put its affairs in order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWENHEIM, HAROLD
description: LOEWENHEIM - Harold. The Board of Directors, staff, and children and families of Interfaith Neighbors extend their heartfelt sympathy to Susan Loewenheim and family. We will all deeply miss Harold. He guided us, cheered us, counseled us and extended his hand during our darkest moments. With integrity and vision he helped to build our organization.

title: In Their Way, Clintons Have Been a Model Family
description: To the Editor:

title: Joint Document Management System for I.B.M. and Xerox
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Xerox Corporation, archcompetitors in the printer business, will jointly market an officewide document management system, comprising Xerox's Document Centre line of digital products that do triple duty as printers, copiers and scanners, and I.B.M.'s Lotus suite of document management software.

title: Why 6-Hour Batteries Conk Out in 40 Minutes
description: Q. The batteries for my Macintosh Powerbook 1400c seem to last for only about 40 minutes each, even though the user's manual says they can each last up to six hours. How can I get my Powerbook to run longer on battery power?

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Wolfgang Schauble, political heir to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in the Christian Democratic Union, misstated the number of ''grand coalitions'' of the leading parties that have governed Germany since World War II. The number is one (in 1966-69), not two.

title: Families of Slain Women Demand Bodies for Funerals
description: As court officers tried to silence them, anguished relatives of two of the eight women whose bodies were unearthed last week in a squalid family home here interrupted the arraignment of the murder suspect today, demanding that their kin be released for funerals without undergoing a new round of autopsies requested by defense lawyers.

title: Like Russia, Tea Room's in a Hole, But Era of Czars Is Coming Back
description: Russian Tea Room? Potemkin Village is more like it.

title: Philippoussis Is Ready To Move Up the Ranks
description: His fellow Australian John Newcombe was the first to call him Scud, and for much of his brief career, Mark Philippoussis has been true to that sobriquet. He has created plenty of sparks. He has received plenty of attention. And, despite some direct hits on important targets, he has performed below expectations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODFRIEND, GEORGE
description: GOODFRIEND-George. Passed away, New York. Former chairman of Holly Stores. Services and entombment will be on Friday, September 11, 10:30 AM, at Mount Nebo Cemetery, Miami, FL.

title: Lucent Licenses Its Software For Speech Recognition
description: Lucent Technologies, a major developer of industrial-strength speech-recognition technology, has turned its attention and expertise to the consumer desktop. The company, based in Murray Hill, N.J., announced recently that it was licensing software to developers who wanted to create speech-recognition programs for the Windows operating system.

title: How Fast Is Your System? That Depends on the Test
description: There are lies, damned lies and statistics. Then there are benchmarks.

title: If They're Running, They're Running Away
description: Democrats on Capitol Hill were spooked today by the arrival of Kenneth W. Starr's report and two van loads of evidence that some fear could topple President Clinton. That was especially true because many lawmakers were already frightened -- even panicked -- over how Mr. Clinton's denials and delays had let the crisis fester and escalate to the point that it threatens their own elections in just eight weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGDON, JAMES PHILLIP
description: LANGDON-James Phillip, 60. Of Lake Forest, IL, died Sept. 8, 1998. Husband of Lorna S. Langdon. Father of Donna Stearns & Denise Rancourt. Stepfather of Alexandra Greene, Shelley Patenaude and Stephen Briggs. Grandfather of ten. Brother of David, Barry and Geoffrey Langdon and Dorothy Brindley. Memorial service 11AM Saturday, Sept. 12 at The Church of the Holy Spirit, 400 E. Westminster, Lake Forest, IL. No visitation. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Children's Memorial Hospital, 2300 Children's Plaza, Box No 4, Chicago, IL. 60614 or to Covenant House, 346 West 17 Street, New York, New York 10011. Info-Wenban Funeral Home, Lake Forest, IL. (ph. 847-234-0022).

title: At Cincinnati, McGwire Pays His Debts and Thrills 51,969 Fans
description: Mark McGwire was reflective, he was folksy and he was surfer-boy cool on the day after he became the top home run hitter for a season in baseball history.

title: Giuliani Joins Attack on Parade Float
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani added his voice yesterday to the chorus of city officials who condemned a Labor Day parade in Queens that included a float of white men wearing blackface.

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: The Ferraro Record; Ferraro's Days in Congress: Reviews Are Mixed
description: From the moment Geraldine A. Ferraro entered the New York race for Senate, her opponents have questioned her skills and experience, suggesting that she was little more than a fading celebrity in search of an office.

title: Ally Doesn't Live Here Anymore: The New and Old McBeal Digs
description: When the second season of ''Ally McBeal'' begins on Monday, Ally may see dancing babies, but she won't acknowledge the transformation in her surroundings. Loyal viewers, however, will notice that it's a new apartment, a 3,400-square-foot, two-bedroom, one-bath apartment in Boston. Ally's move (not written into the show) is the result of the show's move to the new Raleigh Studios in Manhattan Beach, Calif., a large facility that allows for larger sets, much to the delight of the show's production designer, Peter Politanoff. ''The old layout was a traditional Beacon Hill apartment, and it wasn't terribly hip,'' he explained. ''I always wanted to take a bit more license with it.''

title: N.A.S.D. to Set Up Network To Report Data on Bonds
description: Seeking to shine a light into a long-dark corner of the financial markets, Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced measures yesterday to give investors more information about the prices and trading of corporate bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, GEORGE M.
description: SHAPIRO-George M. Died in his sleep on September 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Rita, devoted father of Karen Spector and the late Sanford Shapiro. His devotion to his family and his community was extraordinary. He had an outstanding career in law and public service beginning as Counsel to Governor Thomas E. Dewey. He then joined the law firm of Proskauer Rose Goetz and Mendelsohn (now Proskauer Rose LLP), eventually becoming head of its corporate department and long-time Managing Partner. He served as Chairman of the Board of the Park Avenue Synagogue, which named its new building in honor of him and his wife. Funeral services Thursday, September 10 at 10AM, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street at Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Metro Business; Insurer to Change Name
description: As part of an expansion plan to become a regional health care provider with a recognizable brand name, Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey is changing its name and that of its regional subsidiaries, the company said yesterday.

title: Greedy Colleges Tarnished Student Athletics
description: To the Editor:

title: Successful Searching
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Clinch the Division, And Now the Real Season Starts
description: Ball in hand, Jorge Posada waited on the mound for the Yankees' closer, Mariano Rivera, to jog in from the bullpen. With the Yankees three outs from a division title, the visitors' dugout was overflowing with players poised to run on the field and celebrate a summer of excellence. ''Let's finish this,'' Posada said to Rivera, pounding the ball into the pitcher's glove. ''Let's do this right now.''

title: 7 Projects Win Aga Khan Awards
description: Winners of the 1998 Aga Khan Award for Architecture were announced yesterday at a news conference at the Museum of Modern Art in New York. The seven recipients, chosen from 424 entries, are the restoration of Hebron's Old Town on the West Bank, the design of a leper hospital in Chopda Taluka in India, a new arts center in Lahore, Pakistan, a recreation center for the diplomatic quarter in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, the State Assembly of Madhya Pradesh in Bhopal, India, the Slum Networking Project of Indore City, India, and the Salinger Residence in Selangor, Malaysia.

title: Stoneware Pieces Of a Master Potter
description: Where would American pottery be without Charles Fergus Binns? An Englishman born in 1857, Binns worked for 25 years at the Royal Worcester Porcelain Works. In 1900, he founded the New York State College of Ceramics at Alfred University, sharing secret recipes for glaze and showing Americans new shapes, like the 1929 ovate vase above.

title: Why Should Russia Get Tough on Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Smart' Guns Can Check Identities Before Firing
description: IN May, a New York City police officer was killed when someone grabbed a .38-caliber revolver belonging to the officer's partner and shot him four times.

title: Clinton Signs Off on Digital Advance
description: DUBLIN  When President Bill Clinton applied his digital signature to a joint communique with Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland in Dublin on Friday, the two not only made a little bit of digital history, they also gave an unwitting lift to the cause of strong encryption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIX, THOMAS L., JR.
description: STIX-Thomas L., Jr. Beloved husband of Dorothy; devoted father of Stephen and Kimberly Stix, Carl and Diana Stix, and the late Julie Stix; loving grandfather of Robin & Benjamin. Services 12 noon Friday at Robert Schoem's Memorial Chapel, 150 Rte 4, Paramus, New Jersey. Memorial contributions to the Julie Stix Memorial Fund, Parkview School, 6200 Lake Street, Morton Grove, IL. 60053 would be appreciated.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Who Needs Flowers?

title: Who? The Democrat for What?; Barrage of Similar Ads Blurs Candidates and Messages
description: With a confusing blur of kindred images, matching promises and similar campaign slogans, Democrats running in next week's New York primaries have seized the state's airwaves, deluging viewers with back-to-back-to-back-to-back appeals that sometimes seem as indistinguishable as the candidates themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARDI, BABAJAN
description: VARDI-Babajan. Passed away on September 4, 1998 on Long Island, N.Y. Beloved husband of Liza. Dear father of five children, Moshe (Karen), Joseph (Dalia), Miryam (Joseph), Ben (Elahe), and Esther (Jack). Loving grandfather of 12 grandchildren. Funeral will be held in Jerusalem, Israel and Shiva will be held at 21 Clover Drive, Great Neck Estates, L.I. from Tuesday, September 8 at 3 P.M. until sundown Friday, resuming at sundown Saturday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCCHI, PAULINE
description: ROCCHI-Pauline. On Sept. 8, 1998. Ret. Chase Manhattan Bank, Sgt. with NYC Aux. Police and former officer of AARP. Devoted mother of Laura Taylor, Lydia GonzalezSawyer, Veronica Berrington, and the late Joseph Rocchi, Jr. Loving grandmother of seven. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St), NYC, Fri., 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service St. George's Church (at 17th St.) Sat., 9:45 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: The Loft, the Signature Space of SoHo, Hits the Road
description: Everyone wants to be an artist or at least to live in a place with tall ceilings and oversize windows. Laconia Lofts, above, a 99-unit building in the South End of Boston, may be the first new space for living and working built in New England in more than 75 years, said David Hacin, a Boston architect. ''In Boston, there is a real hunger for loft space,'' he said. The 180,000-square-foot building will provide 45 artist units for $100 a square foot; other units will sell for $200 a square foot. All unfinished lofts come with a simple kitchen and bath.

title: U.N. Keeps Sanctions on Iraq, Citing Its Balking of Monitors
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to deprive Iraq of any hope of having sanctions lifted until President Saddam Hussein resumes cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGAN, DR. IRVING H.
description: KAGAN-Dr. Irving H. 75. Of Boca Raton, FL and formerly of Huntington, LI, passed away on September 8, 1998. Mr. Kagan was the beloved husband of Terry Kagan.

title: Every Dog Has Its Data; The Web Has Pets the Way Pets Have Fleas, and There's No Leash Law
description: JUST what is the World Wide Web made of? Tips and tails and puppy-dog sales, if you know where to look.

title: THE MARKETS: Economic Scene; Twisting Controls on Currency and Capital
description: The International Monetary Fund, having bailed out Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and Russia over the last 15 months, is nearly out of money, and Congress is not yet rushing to its defense. But its job is far from complete.

title: Dignity Might Yet Survive
description: The delivery of Kenneth Starr's report to the House Judiciary Committee presents an opportunity for a statesmanlike example by the committee. The country is fortunate that the chairman is Henry Hyde and the ranking Democrat is John Conyers. Both are excellent lawyers and dedicated public servants, and there is a better-than-usual possibility that the Lewinsky matter will be concluded with a minimum of national embarrassment.

title: City Schools Face Only a Few Glitches on Opening Day; A Brand-New Building
description: The mood was unusual: enthusiasm from teen-agers on the opening day of school. But in a school system where half the buildings are more than 50 years old, their school, the Gateway to the Health and Sciences High School in Jamaica, Queens, was housed in one of only two brand new buildings to open this year.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN PRICES FALL. Corn futures retreated from Tuesday's gains, as expectations grew for large inventories and weaker demand, particularly from Japan. September corn fell 1.75 cent, to $1.985 a bushel.

title: Why Should Russia Get Tough on Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding the New Digital TV Shows
description: YOU'VE just decided to be not only the first on your block, but the first in your city to buy one of those new digital high-definition televisions. You don't mind taking out a second mortgage and building an extra room to house your new $10,000 HDTV because you're eager to watch all the new super-sharp wide-screen programs and the extra channels. But come Nov. 1, when digital programming begins, the question might be not just which shows to watch, but how in the world to find them all.

title: Pack a Vuitton; Paris Is Cheap
description: BORED to tears by endless cocktail-party speculation about whether the gyrating stock market will tarnish the value of $10 million Park Avenue apartments? Take that ennui right over to the Champs-Elysees and buy the same-size prewar palace for a (relative) chanson -- significantly less than it would cost in Manhattan.

title: Credit Suisse Sees Cuts in Profit in 2d Half
description: Credit Suisse Group, Switzerland's second-largest bank, said yesterday that its first-half profit rose by 36 percent but warned that its full-year results could be hurt by turmoil in world financial markets. The Zurich-based concern said first-half net income rose to 2.401 billion Swiss francs ($1.68 billion), from 1.767 billion a year earlier.

title: Making Books; A Monica Book As a Burden
description: The summer started with book publishers' oscillating around Monica Lewinsky and it ended the same way. In between, the country and maybe publishing have been afflicted with the newly identified disease T.M.I. (too much information). Despite that, the tutelaries of Ms. Lewinsky's interests have planted a report that she has turned down a mere $6 million advance. Not true; no such bid was ever made. Another publisher was said to have offered $2 million. This was denied, but publishing people have said that an offer in that neighborhood was made.

title: House Republicans to Push for Tax Cut Worth Up to $80 Billion
description: House Republican leaders challenged the heart of President Clinton's domestic policy strategy today, saying they would press for a tax cut worth up to $80 billion over five years and pay for it by dipping into projected Federal budget surpluses.

title: City Schools Face Only a Few Glitches on Opening Day; Less Congestion, but . . .
description: By 10 A.M., the hallways of Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, were clear and quiet. The fifth-floor resource room remained empty, and the only occupants of the lunchroom were cafeteria workers.

title: REPORT BY STARR SENT TO HOUSE; IMPEACHMENT PROCESS WEIGHED; CLINTON SEEKS PARTY'S SUPPORT
description: The Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, today sent to Congress a report that prosecutors said contained ''substantial and credible information that may constitute grounds for impeachment'' of President Clinton.

title: Unusual Characters Converge at Spiff
description: ENTER Spiff, and you find yourself in something like a 24-hour diner where all types of weird characters converge. This captivating on-line world unfolds at your direction at www.manipulation.com/ spiff/home/home.html.

title: NEW PRESIDENT, AN INSIDER, IS NAMED AT BANK OF NEW YORK
description: The Bank of New York Company yesterday named Gerald Hassell president and a member of the board. Mr. Hassell, 46, has been senior executive vice president and the chief commercial banking officer at the company, which has $63 billion in assets. He replaces Thomas A. Renyi as president. Analysts said that Mr. Renyi, who remains chairman and chief executive, helped build the securities processing business and that Mr. Hassell, who has been at the company since 1973, has extensive knowledge of the commercial bank.

title: Shopping Cacophony
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran President Will Not Bar Use of Force On Afghans
description: Despite American calls for restraint, Iran's President said today that his country would act ''in whichever way we see fit'' to resolve a potentially explosive dispute with the Taliban, the militant Islamic movement that controls most of neighboring Afghanistan.

title: Essay; Hang in There
description: Nervous-Nellie candidates, hand-wringing opinionmongers and parents doing a national slow burn should stop calling on President Clinton to resign. Quitting under 36 boxes of evidence is not The American Way.

title: Why Should Russia Get Tough on Taxes?
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebuking Ex-Arms Inspector, Albright Defends U.S. Role
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright hit back today at a former United Nations arms inspector and other critics who have accused her of trying to scuttle inspections of Iraq's weapons sites.

title: Marlins Move Close To a Sale
description: The Florida Marlins' president, Don Smiley, long favored by the team owner H. Wayne Huizenga to be his successor, withdrew his bid to buy the team today. That clears the way for John Henry -- a South Floridian and minority owner of the Yankees -- to possibly buy it.

title: So Much to Do, and Such a Little Organizer
description: The size of a credit card, the $229.95 Rex Pro PC Card Organizer, from Franklin Electronics Publishers, can carry 6,000 records, like contact information and ''to do'' lists. And, unlike previous Rex Pro versions, the information can either be entered directly into the device or downloaded from a desktop or laptop. (The Rex Pro actually doubles as a PC card, which means that it can be slipped directly into a laptop's PC card slot.) Next to the Rex Pro, the Palm Pilot looks like a mainframe.

title: Microsoft Serves Subpoenas On 5 Computer Companies
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had served subpoenas on five leading companies in the computer industry asking them to supply information that would show they engage in business practices similar to the practices at the heart of the Federal Government's antitrust suit against Microsoft.

title: Striking a Colorful Pose in the Digital Era of Photo Booths
description: FOR tourists in an foreign city, a reminder of home can often be more thrilling than the exotic allure of the unfamiliar. Or so it would seem, judging from the squeals of delight from a gaggle of six young Japanese women who spotted a pair of digital photo machines in downtown Manhattan.

title: A Somber Day in Washington
description: On Capitol Hill, tourists and civil servants pause when they sense history in the making. The television cameras showed scores of them watching as two black vans arrived on Capitol Hill yesterday with 36 boxes containing Kenneth Starr's report to Congress. The delivery may have signaled the beginning of a race. Can Bill Clinton apologize rapidly and completely enough to prevent the contents of those boxes from destroying his Presidency?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, SARAH
description: ZUCKERMAN-Sarah. The Mesivta of Long Beach marks with sorrow the loss of Mrs. Sarah ''Cookie'' Zuckerman, of blessed memory, mother of our dear friend Mrs. Gary Fragin. Her elegance and smile, reflective of her illustrious family's dedication to Torah, will long be remembered. Our heartfelt condolences to her beloved husband Matthew, her devoted children, Karen Fragin, Linda Sandel, Nancy Markovich and Ruthie Shapiro. To all her cherished grandchildren and the entire family, may you all be comforted and spared from further sorrow. HaRav Yitzchok Feigelstock Rosh HaYeshiva Rabbi Shlomo Lesin Executive Vice President

title: Release the Report
description: Not two minutes after the television networks breathlessly interrupted their soap operas and talk shows to report that Kenneth Starr had delivered his report and 36 boxes of material to the annex of the House of Representatives, my staff received the first official request from the press for a leaked copy.

title: Reading Aloud Is Good for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: In Their Way, Clintons Have Been a Model Family; Treatment of Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Mingling With Unlikely Neighbors
description: Three couples walk into a gated community. One is black and affluent; one is white and liberal; one is white and possibly mob-affiliated. Can they find happiness and true friendship in a Fox sitcom?

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Aug. 30 about criticism of the Federal Aviation Administration by the National Transportation Safety Board misidentified the company that a former aviation agency official said was not operating at the highest level of safety. The former official, Anthony Broderick, was referring to Comair, an airline, not Embraer, an airplane manufacturer.

title: Chinese Man's Release Ends A 5-Year Tale of Misfortune
description: In a reversal of fortune worthy of a Chinese poem about faith and perseverance, a Chinese man who had tried twice in the last five years to sneak into the United States walked out of an immigration jail a free man today after being cleared by officials to remain in this country indefinitely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODFREY, KALTER E.
description: GODFREY-Kalter E. On September 7, 1998. Survived by wife Eileen Godfrey, son Christopher, daughter Elise, two stepsons Jeffrey and Craig Scolaro and five grandchildren. Services private. Donations in his memory may be sent to The Carol Hirsch Godfrey Memorial Fund at the Cornell University Library.

title: City Schools Face Only a Few Glitches on Opening Day; Tradition, Starting Anew
description: Lots of people have claimed P.S. 6 in Manhattan as a home away from home over its 104-year history, but few can rival the claim that Joan Goldberg has staked to the place.

title: Successful Searching
description: To the Editor:
