title: Accounting Giant Hires Two Agencies
description: PricewaterhouseCoopers said yesterday that it had named two agencies to handle domestic and worldwide brand advertising jointly for the accounting firm, which was formed by the merger of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIDEL, CAROL H.
description: KRIDEL-Carol H., 78. September 8, at home. She was the widow of William J. Kridel. She is survived by her son, William J. Kridel, Jr, of London and New York, and by her daughter, Linda K. Smith, of Beloit, Wisconsin, and by three grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), Sunday, September 13 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Palliative Care Program, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029, or to The Collegiate School, 370 West End Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

title: Missouri Boy Meets New York; Guess Who Wins
description: FOR KINGS AND PLANETS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, EDWIN
description: MALLOY-Edwin. The Board of Directors of The Jewish Week mourns the loss of our fellow Board member and friend. We will miss his quiet strength and wise counsel. Our sincere condolences to his wife, Susan, and family. Richard Hirsch, President Lawrence Kobrin, Chairman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, GERTRUDE
description: FREEMAN-Gertrude. On September 8, 1998 Gertrude Freeman (nee Posner). Loving wife of the late Charles Freeman, beloved mother of Barbara Plasse of Baltimore, MD, and the late Arnold S. Freeman. Devoted mother-in-law of Dr. Jerome S. Plasse. Loving grandmother of Arnold Scott, Charles Lawrence, Keith Alexander, Sabina Dana and Victoria Elizabeth Plasse. Loving great grandmother of Jeffrey Connor and Alexandra Brooke Plasse. Loving sister of Bettye Fass of Tamarac, FL and the late Michael, Milton, Ralph, Arnold and Lillian Posner. Services and interment at Wellwood Cemetery, LI, NY on Thursday, September 10, 2 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be directed to any cancer, leukemia or heart association of your choice. Sol Levinson & Bros. Inc., 1-800-338-1701.

title: Calendar; Harvest Festival, Talks, Tours and Workshops
description: Harvest Fair

title: Moment of Conception
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, TARA
description: NELSON-Tara. Beloved daughter of Sheila & Robert; loving fiancee of Edward Firouztale; adoring sister of Judith & Jean-Paul Thibaud and niece of Laurie and Al Michel. We mourn the loss of this most wonderful & caring human being who was tragically taken from us by Swissair Flight 111. Recently returned to NYC from Mystic, CT., she was a dedicated naturopathic physician who devoted herself to helping others achieve a greater quality of life. She will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Memorial service at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51 St., NYC Sunday, September 13 at 3 P.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to Tara Nelson Fund, 2 Beekman Place, NY, NY 10022.

title: Lucas Varity of Britain Plans To Shift Headquarters to U.S.
description: Lucas Varity P.L.C., one of the world's largest makers of automotive brakes, said today that it would reorganize as an American company, and issue new shares, in an effort to move closer to its big customers and take advantage of lower borrowing costs.

title: Nelson Passes The First Test
description: Jeff Nelson accomplished the mission assigned to him Tuesday night, to retire Boston's Mike Stanley in the eighth inning.

title: Our Towns; The Clintons As Reminders Of Betrayal
description: JANIS ABRAHMS SPRING'S office has three green plush chairs arranged in a triangle. One is for the therapist, one for the ''unfaithful partner'' and one for the ''hurt partner,'' to use terminology developed by Dr. Spring during two decades of treating couples sundered by infidelity.

title: Giants Sign Gray; Hamilton's Role Shaky
description: Another week, another significant transaction. These are not your father's Giants.

title: Senate Revives Bill to Overhaul Laws on Financing Campaigns
description: The Senate today resurrected a bill to overhaul the nation's campaign finance laws, seven months after tossing it into the legislative dust bin.

title: Dell Breaks a Size Barrier For Screens for Portable PC's
description: Dell Computer has broken another barrier for screen size on portable PC's. The new Dell Inspiron 7000 features an active matrix screen that measures a full 15 inches.

title: Animal Health; Advice From Vets and Other Experts
description: Sure, there are Web sites to help you pick a puppy and a name for it, figure out its biorhythms and even learn to communicate telepathically with your cat, but the most important information available to pet owners on the Web is in the area of health care.

title: Report Says Immigrants Are Jailed With Convicts
description: Thousands of immigrants and political refugees are in United States jails, mixed with criminals and often treated as such, because the Immigration and Naturalization Service has no other place to hold them while they await deportation or a determination of their immigration status, according to a human rights report released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, VIRGINIA S.
description: MURPHY-Virginia S. On September 9, 1998. Aged 85. Beloved wife of the late Robert A Murphy. Devoted mother of Virginia D'Isidori, Robert A. Murphy Jr, Stephen V. Murphy and Raymond G. Murphy. Loving grandmother of Diane Hack, Justine Cody, Jennifer and Robert D'Isidori, Georgina and Annabel Murphy, Bryan and Gannon Murphy, and Nora, Brendan and Conor Murphy. Great grandmother of Daniel and Gabriel Hack and Barnes & Myles Murphy. Visiting hours at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York on September 11 from 3:00 to 5:00pm and 7:00 to 9:00pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, New York at 9:45am on Saturday, September 12, 1998. Interment immediately following at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The College of New Rochelle would be appreciated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Family of 'Rent' Creator Settles Suit Over Authorship
description: In the finale of a long-running legal drama, Lynn M. Thomson, the woman who had claimed partial authorship of the hit show ''Rent,'' has reached an out-of-court settlement with the estate of the musical's late creator, Jonathan Larson, whom she has sued twice.

title: High-Tech Dentistry
description: To the Editor:

title: Teacher Is Slain on Staten Island; Her Daughter and Son-In-Law Are Charged
description: A Staten Island woman who went back to school as an adult and became a special education teacher was slain the day before school started by her estranged son-in-law, with her daughter trying to cover up his role in the crime, the police said yesterday.

title: A Delicately Played Victory On the Way to Defeat in Lille
description: There would have been great rejoicing in Lille, France, last week if Sidney Lazard of New Orleans had captured the Vivendi Rosenblum world title. He has been a shining star and popular character in American bridge for nearly half a century, and he came very close to winning: his team lost in the semifinal to the eventual winner, Italy, by just 3 imps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLIN, GILDA AND RALPH
description: MALLIN-Gilda and Ralph. The National Board of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, mourns the tragic loss of Gilda Mallin, President of the Boca West Chapter of Hadassah, and of her beloved husband Ralph, who perished on SwissAir Flight 111. A Hadassah life member, Gilda celebrated her Bat Mitzvah at the 1995 National Convention in Miami; together the couple generously supported Hadassah. We extend our deepest condolences to their children and grandchildren. Marlene E. Post, Nat'l President Dr. Laura S. Schor, Nat'l Executive Director

title: Mutts by the Megabyte; Helping to Save a Few Good Doggies From Death Row
description: SAUCER-SIZE brown eyes gaze longingly from the computer screen. His name is Harry, and he was on Death Row. With that exaggerated underbite and those crossed eyes, he looks a little like a gargoyle, and he may be a biter. On the plus side, he's affectionate, neutered and housebroken. He just needs love -- who doesn't? -- but time wasn't on his side.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HYDROCHEM INDUSTRIAL SERVICES INC., Houston, agreed to acquire Valley Systems Inc., Canal Fulton, Ohio, an industrial cleaning company, for $29.8 million plus assumed debt and certain liabilities.

title: Reynoso Muzzles Phillies' Hitters
description: While Armando Reynoso was sidelined for more than a year, slowly working his way back from surgery on his elbow and shoulder, the Mets could not have expected much. Even Reynoso was unsure just what sort of pitcher he would be when he returned.

title: Leo Penn, 77, Stage Actor And a Director for Television
description: Leo Penn, an actor whose decade on the Hollywood blacklist in the 1940's and 50's stalled his career and eventually led him to direct, primarily in television, died on Saturday at St. John's Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 77 and lived in Malibu.

title: Appalachian Trail Sites Offer Virtual Walks on Wild Side
description: HIKING the entire Appalachian Trail is a daunting task. Walking 2,160 miles in the woods in six months while carrying a heavy pack can make one feel far removed from modern conveniences, like showers, television and computers.

title: Very Thorough Drug Index And Simple to Use, as Well
description: WWW.RXLIST.COM

title: A Long List of Clinical Trials
description: WWW.CENTERWATCH.COM

title: Tension Is at a Peak for Solheim Cup
description: Next week's Solheim Cup will put the women involved on golf's center stage, and players on both sides already feel the tension.

title: College Rankings Rankle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHALTAIN, VICTOR H.
description: CHALTAIN-Victor H. Of Bronxville, on September 8, 1998. Husband of Anne Tilghman Chaltain. Father of Victor H. Chaltain Jr., and Anne Tilghman Chaltain Jr. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 68 P.M. Friday. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, Saturday, September 12, at 10 A.M.

title: Airbus Receives $5 Billion Order
description: Airbus Industrie said today that it had received an airplane order from United Parcel Service of America Inc. with a value of as much as $5 billion, its first order from the giant package-delivery company.

title: For Wine Racks, It's Not a Bad Year
description: STORAGE meets sculpture. This fall, wine racks have reached the level of good industrial design, if not high art. They offer appealing display while solving a difficult storage problem. So what if the priciest wines should be kept cool and in the dark? Enophiles will be tempted to put these racks out in the open, perhaps filled with bottles of vin somewhat ordinaire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINREB, SAM
description: WEINREB-Sam. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne. Devoted father of Ann Bareish and Billy and Gwynne Weinreb. Cherished grandfather of Peri Bareish, Mark, Michael, Aisha, Ashley, and Sam Weinreb. Loving brother of Freddy, Ruthie and Annette. Services on Friday, 11 AM, at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Contributions can be made to the American Heart Association or to the Morse Geriatric Home in West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Assets Are Frozen on Insider Suspicions
description: A Federal judge in New York has frozen about $2 million in assets of unknown investors who regulators say may have used inside information to buy stock in USCS International Inc. before DST Systems Inc. announced plans to acquire the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSFELD, HERMAN
description: GROSSFELD-Herman. On September 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Elaine, father of Marsha and Steven, brother of Celia, Jerry, Janice and Fred, and grandfather of seven. He will be deeply missed.

title: Sosa, 0 for 3, Remains at 58
description: The Baseball Hall of Fame has a display case with Mark McGwire's bat, ball, jersey, spikes, everything but his socks and underwear. The question is, will Sammy Sosa still have his uniform when the season ends?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, NATHAN
description: GORDON-Nathan, 83. Former NBC Symphony violist, of Boca Raton, FL. Passed away Sept. 7, 1998. Mr. Gordon was the beloved husband of Marjorie, loving father of Peter Jon and father-in-law of Susan Barker, adored grandfather of Theodore and Joshua Gordon & Ian Schwartz. Memorial service will be at 5:30 P.M., on Thursday, September 17th, 1998 at ''The Riverside'', 180 West 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERTZER, ADELINE
description: SHERTZER - Adeline. Beloved mother of Ellen and Bette and grandmother of Elizabeth and Michael. Cherished by so many. A special woman, full of grace, peace and a special quality of listening. Funeral services will be at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, today at 11 AM. We will receive family and close friends at home on Saturday 8-10 P.M. and Sunday 2-8.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENBERG, ISABEL W.
description: ROSENBERG-Isabel W. Isabel deares

title: Call Letter Lore
description: THE nation's broadcasters use their call letters like vanity license plates. Call letters, a 19th-century invention, are still a quick way to give viewers a sense of the station's persona.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEFALIDIS, NIKOS
description: KEFALIDIS-Nikos. The principals and employees of Fairmont Insurance and Fairmont Financial Services express their profound sympathy on the tragic and untimely passing of Nikos Kefalidis. You were more than just another client, you were a true friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Laurie, and their children Melanie, Elias and Marisa. Charles Katz, Chairman Moishe Mishkowitz, President Lawrence A. Barth, Vice-President, Financial Services

title: Japan Lowers Overnight Rate Near Zero Level
description: In an attempt to lift Japan out of its worst recession since World War II, the nation's central bank said today that it would reduce an important interest rate to the extraordinarily low level of one-quarter of 1 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALCON, RICHARD C.
description: FALCON-Richard C. Sept. 1, 1998. Suddenly in Lake Panasoffkee FL. Richard worked as an advertising executive and was a resident of New York City for over thirty years. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, Sept. 12 at the Trinity Episcopal Church, 261 East Main St, Hamburg, New York, 3:30 P.M. Interment, in Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo, NY. Memorial contributions if desired may be sent to the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, 71 Symphony Circle, Buffalo, New York 14201.

title: Republican Missile Defense Bill Loses by One Vote in the Senate
description: For the second time in four months, the Senate today blocked a bill to require establishing a national defense against long-range missiles as soon as the technology was available.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCOTT, MATTHEW THOMPSON
description: SCOTT-Matthew Thompson Memorial services for Matthew Scott, 33, a passenger on Swissair flight 111 will be held Friday, September 11 at 2 P.M., at Grace Church in New York, Broadway and 10th Street (Manhattan). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Concordia Language Villages, Christine Schulze at Concordia College, 901 South 8th Street, Moorehead, MN. 56562.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVAGE, W. LEE
description: SAVAGE-W. Lee, age 69. The Board of Directors of Riverkeeper note with sadness the death on September 6 in Ossining, New York, of our honorary Director, a lover of the Hudson, a wise & witty artist, animator and film maker and a member of The National Academy of Design. We extend our condolences to his wife Karen, his children Peter, Will, Kate, Adam and Miranda and his stepdaughter Kristin.

title: Letter by Starr to House Accompanying the Report
description: Following is the letter accompanying the report and documentation sent today by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, to the House of Representatives:

title: Reading Aloud Is Good for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: It Takes a Pioneer to Save a Prairie
description: SOMETIME in autumn, after the nesting birds have migrated, the people of Prairie Crossing go for the burn. Equipped with water tanks and ''flappers'' -- special rubber mats for tamping down flames -- they leave quaint new houses named for Illinois settlers to partake in a novel suburban ritual: burning the prairie.

title: High-Tech Dentistry
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEDMAN, ROBERT H.
description: FREEDMAN-Robert H. On September 9, 1998. Of West Babylon, New York. Beloved husband of Estelle Freedman. Dear brother of Marjorie Freedman, Therese Freedman, Rosalie Fagelson and Richard Freedman. Funeral services today, Sept. 10, 1998, 12:30 PM at the George C. White Funeral Home, 364 East Main Street, Bay Shore, N.Y. Interment Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Beijing Dissident's Wife Is Hauled Away Near U.N. Rights Chief
description: Security agents dragged the wife of a jailed dissident through the lobby of the Hilton Hotel here this morning and detained her, moments before the visiting United Nations human rights commissioner gave a speech in a nearby room on democracy and freedom.

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Remarks
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's remarks to Democratic donors at a fund-raiser today for Lieut. Gov. Buddy Mackay, the Democratic candidate for governor, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, DR. ALFRED HENRY III
description: TAYLOR-Dr. Alfred Henry III of Pearl River, NY, died peacefully on September 6, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy E., loving father of Rise Taylor of Tronsoe, Norway and Linda Taylor of Pearl River. Funeral service to be held Saturday, September 12 at 3PM at Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church, Ehrhardt Road, Pearl River. Cremation private. Visiting at Saint Stephen's Episcopal Church, on Friday 7-9PM and Saturday 2-3PM. Memorials to the American Cancer Society, 255 Lafayette Avenue, Suffern, New York 10960.

title: Swissair's Web Site Inundated Following Crash of Flight 111
description: The headlines were chilling: ''Swissair jet crashes,'' ''No survivors from Swissair crash,'' ''Relatives en route to crash site.''

title: City Schools Face Only a Few Glitches on Opening Day; Opening-Day Jitters
description: Liz Phillips, the early childhood education coordinator at P.S. 321 in Park Slope, made the rounds early in the morning. She found Gina Ma, a new teacher from Teachers College at Columbia University, taking a breather in her classroom.

title: Clues Found to Fire's Location on Swiss Jet
description: Investigators said this evening that they had their first evidence of the location of a fire that apparently caused the crash of Swissair 111, which went down a few minutes after the pilots reported smoke in the cockpit.

title: Greedy Colleges Tarnished Student Athletics
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Procter & Gamble Warns Of Weaker Sales Abroad

title: Treasuries Post a Sharp Rise in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday, as the dollar surged in currency trading following an interest rate cut by the Bank of Japan. The 30-year Treasury bond soared 1 13/32, to 103 20/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.26 percent, from 5.36 percent on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOZES, JEAN, MAX
description: MOZES-Jean-Max, Chief Financial Officer of Czarnikow-Rionda, graduate of the Sorbonne in Paris, France, died on Swissair Flight 111 on September 2, 1998, at the age of 51. Jean-Max leaves his wife, Annie, his three children, Marina, Nathan and Julie, and his step-son, Jean-Marie Paras and wife Guillemette, and their daughter, Lucile. He is also survived by his mother, Betty Mozes of Cannes, France, and his sister, Danielle Berthoud & her family of Aix-en-Provence, France. He is missed by his many friends. A memorial service will be held on Friday, September 11 at 10:00 A.M., at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York, 7 West 83rd Street, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Community High School Emergency Fund, Fleet Bank, C/O John Rowland, Branch Manager, 85 Jefferson Avenue, Westwood, New Jersey 07675.

title: International Panel Closes Books on Gold Seized by Nazis in War
description: An international commission set up 52 years ago to return gold that Nazi Germany seized from central banks of countries it occupied closed its books and disbanded today after returning most of the last six tons to the original claimants.

title: Aliens Have Landed and Heads Will Roll
description: IF 3-D spectacles like Quake 2 and Unreal are the ''Armageddon'' and ''Deep Impact'' of the computer gaming world, Hedz is ''Trainspotting'' -- a highly idiosyncratic piece of work, shot through with a certain macabre wit, straight from the land of whisky and haggis.

title: Kurosawa's Gift
description: In his autobiography, the director Akira Kurosawa recalled the battles with his producer over the making of ''Rashomon.'' From the outset, the producer complained that audiences would never accept its story about four accounts of a rape and murder, with no hint of which one was correct. Many years later, however, when the film was hailed as one of the greatest of all times, Kurosawa caught that same producer taking full credit for its success. ''I had the feeling I was back in 'Rashomon' all over again,'' the director declared.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, M. ESTELLE
description: BURKE-M. Estelle. September 8, 1998. Beloved sister of Helen and the late Florence P. and Edmund. Fond sister-in-law of Dorothy Burke. Also survived by six nieces and nephews and 13 grand nieces & grand nephews. Visiting Friday 2-4, 7-9PM Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Saturday 9:30A.M. St. Patrick's, Brooklyn.

title: As Prologue, the Past Looks Like a Bad Bet
description: Twenty-four years ago the Watergate special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, gave Congress only raw evidence, not the kind of analysis lawmakers expect from the report that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, delivered today.

title: Ads for Alcohol And Cigarettes Are Restricted
description: The City Council today passed an ordinance that will virtually eliminate outdoor alcohol and tobacco advertising in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAFT, IONA
description: TAFT-Iona. On September 8, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Max. Dear mother of Juliette and Larry Wittlin, Shulamith (Taffy) & Bernie Davis. Adored grandmother of Robin Wittlin, Ellen and Doug Pellecchia, Peter and Robert Davis, great grandmother of Matthew. Services today 1 PM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIZO, MARCO
description: RIZO-Marco. Passed away on September 8, 1998. Cuban composer, concert pianist and Musical Director of the ''I Love Lucy'' show. He is survived by his sisters, Maria Rizo Burton and Vilma Rizo, his brother, Evelio, his son, Mark, nephews, Herbert Hernandez, Anthony Hernandez, & niece, Diana Hernandez. Friends may call Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-5PM and 7-9PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30AM at St. Paul the Apostle Church, West 60 Street and 9th Ave. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHER, GERTRUDE
description: ASHER-Gertrude. Aged 81. An educator and progressive, died September 5, after a short illness. She is survived by her son Robert, of Willimantic, Conn., her grandchildren Tanya Arenson & Samuel Arenson, her nephews Paul Stamler and Paul Steinberg, and her niece Jane Steinberg Zucker. A private service will be held in Los Angeles. Contributions may be sent to Environmental Support Center, 4420 Connecticut Avenue, NW, Washington, D.C. 20008-2301.

title: Races for Congress in New York City
description: One of the reasons New York City has an undistinguished Congressional delegation is that in most cases, Democratic incumbents enjoy virtual automatic lifetime tenure. Most of these one-party districts are not even holding perfunctory primaries, let alone serious races, on Sept. 15. Fortunately, there are a few exceptions.

title: Greedy Colleges Tarnished Student Athletics
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Data From F.D.A.
description: WWW.FDA.GOV/CDER/DRUG.HTM

title: A Quiet Move by Starr, Then a Dramatic Action
description: Quietly one day in July, Kenneth W. Starr filed a motion with a three-judge panel here seeking permission to send secret grand jury material to Congress. At the top of the motion was ''In re: Madison Guaranty Savings & Loan Association,'' the Arkansas bank related to the failed Whitewater land deal that was Mr. Starr's first investigative mission more than four years ago.

title: Troops Shoot at Mobs and Beat Protesters Again in Phnom Penh
description: Restless mobs milled about the capital today as opposition leaders who had stoked their anger said they were powerless to calm the crowds or prevent the violence that is eroding hopes for democracy and stability here.

title: FIRSTCITY SHARES FALL AS LOSS RESERVE RISE IS ANNOUNCED
description: The stock of the Firstcity Financial Corporation of Texas fell to an all-time low yesterday after the company, a mortgage lender, said it would add $10 million to $14 million to its loan loss reserves in the third quarter as low interest rates prompt borrowers to pay off loans faster than expected. While loan defaults are not rising, the company must make up for the lost revenue from borrowers who prepaid their higher-interest loans. Firstcity said it had canceled plans to sell preferred stock and would find other financing sources. Shares fell $2.625, to $13.625, after touching $12.625 earlier in the day.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Arts & Ideas on Aug. 29 about the changing role of the audience in political theater misstated the name of a theater institute at Harvard and the title of its leader, and a correction in this space yesterday misspelled her middle name. The organization is the Institute on the Arts and Civic Dialogue (not ''for'' Arts), and the title is director, not artistic director. The director is Anna Deavere Smith, not Deveare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELBLUM, OLGA KRAMER MARGOLIN
description: GELBLUM-Olga Kramer Margolin. In her 103rd year. Widowed by Elias Margolin in 1919. Loving wife of Jack (dec.). Beloved mother of Pearl Margolin Zimmerman, adored Nana of Margo and Ken Fuld and Jill and Ely Zimmerman. Great Nana to Margaret & Jeffrey Fuld, Elaine Fuld and Joseph DeMatteo, Caralyn and Steven Fuld and Joshua and Ben Zimmerman. Great, great Grandma to David DeMatteo. We know Nana's love, generosity and wisdom will be dearly missed by those of the Kramer, Margolin, and Zimmerman extended families. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Olga Margolin Gelblum Scholarship at Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14850. Service Thursday, 2:30pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Dolan Recounts  His Failed Bid
description: Lawrence Dolan said yesterday that his family's bid to acquire the new Cleveland Browns franchise was $5 million less than the $530 million from Al Lerner, which was accepted Tuesday night by the National Football League.

title: Berea Journal; A College of Few Parties And Fewer Complaints
description: Nobody calls Berea College a party school.

title: Driven a Gazelle Lately?; Eurasia Motor Leaves Its Dealers Waiting for Elusive Models
description: When Howard Patterson strode to the podium here last month, he was applauded wildly by several dozen car dealers, each of whom had paid from $25,000 to $60,000 to acquire a franchise for the fledgling Eurasia Motor Corporation of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Patterson, Eurasia's chief executive, had promised to deliver a line of vehicles called Gazelles, ranging from a $5,995 sedan to the $30,000 Avalanche, ''the largest sport utility vehicle ever produced.''

title: What Audubon's Parlor Never Looked Like
description: Can you squeeze big ideas into 8 feet by 8 feet? That's what 10 designers will try to do in ''Entertaining Thoughts,'' a showcase in small spaces at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum in Manhattan. Below is a sketch by Ron Wagner and Timothy Van Dam for ''Tea With Mr. Audubon,'' a parlor in the style of the early 19th century. Although Audubon (bust at left) painted North American birds, the stuffed peacock at right is not a native specimen. ''But it's one of the most fabulous, showy birds,'' Mr. Wagner said. The showcase will open on Sept. 18 and run through Sept. 27 at 421 East 61st Street. Information: (212) 980-9352. Admission is $10, and $8 for students and those older than 65.

title: Lusterware Is Back, In Bad Taste No More
description: Lusterware -- gleaming ceramics with metallic or iridescent overtones -- lingered from the last century into the present. ''It was the epitome of bad taste in the 1950's, for the same reason majolica was bad taste,'' said Terry Kovel, co-author of ''Kovels' Antiques and Collectibles Price List'' (Crown, $14.95).

title: With 15 Minutes' Notice, the Report Arrives
description: The much-anticipated report by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, arrived on a sun-splotched Capitol Hill today with all the warning of a bolt of lightning.

title: For $5, a Family Video Store Will Cut 2 'Titanic' Scenes
description: James Cameron won an Oscar for directing ''Titanic.'' Now Carol Biesinger, the owner of a video rental store in Utah, is winning business for making some creative cuts to the biggest-selling movie of all time.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The office has fulfilled its duty under the law. Responsibility for the information that we have transmitted today and for any further actions now lies with the Congress.''

title: In America; Simple Lessons in Humanity
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral was filled nearly to capacity for the prayer service that began at 10:30 yesterday morning. Close to 2,500 people were there. They came in very quietly. There were no surging throngs, just ordinary New Yorkers walking in from the bustle of Fifth Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIBBS, VIVIAN A.
description: HIBBS-Vivian A. Died of cancer at the Mt. Sinai Hospital on Monday evening September 7, 1998. Dr. Hibbs, born in Iowa City, IA. was an archaeologist, participating for several seasons in the excavations at Francolisa, near Naples, Italy. After graduating from Hunter College and receiving her doctorate from New York University's Institute of Fine Arts in 1979, she served as Curator of the Hispanic Society of America in New York City. Her dissertation, the Mendes Maze, was published by the Garland Press in 1985. A member of the Archaelogical Institute of America, the New York Academy of Sciences and the American Society for Hispanic Art Historical Studies, serving on its Executive Committee in past years. She is survived by her husband of 52 years, William, & a sister Margaret of Gulfport. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St., Friday, September 11, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. For further information, call 212-288-3500.

title: A Disney Tie-In With Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it would open 100 shops in Sears stores next month with the Walt Disney Company featuring sports clothes and accessories bearing the brand of Disney's ESPN sports television network. Sears and Disney plan to open the shops in the Sears men's sportswear departments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNBAUM, GLENN
description: BERNBAUM-Glenn. The patients and staff of the Center for Special Studies at the New York Presbyterian Hospital are shocked and saddened by the loss of our benefactor Glenn Bernbaum. Glenn was an intensely private man who downplayed his own contributions to the fight against AIDS. Yet his ability to rally some of the most powerful people in our community to the cause of the stigmatized and powerless was unique. That ability made a profound difference in the lives of thousands of New Yorkers with HIV. We will deeply miss his steadfast support and friendship. Jonathan L. Jacobs, M.D., Medical Director Samuel Merrick, M.D., Associate Medical Director Gerard Ilaria, Program Director

title: SCOUTING WITH: Joseph Holtzman; Guerrilla in the Midst
description: JOSEPH HOLTZMAN, the editor of Nest, the artsy new journal of decor and interiors, does have a few things in common with his editorial peers, the tough-as-nails sheltertrixes at House & Garden, Elle Decor and Architectural Digest.

title: Sports of The Times; 62 Swings That Lifted A Sport
description: AS Mark McGwire gave those moving and heartfelt hugs to the Maris children Tuesday night, embracing the magnificence of a 37-year-old record even as he'd broken it, I recalled a conversation last summer with Ken Griffey Jr. in which he speculated that the bar may have been raised too high for a baseball player to come across larger than life.

title: Loss of Communications At Airport Is Explained
description: A faulty fuel valve caused an emergency generator to fail at Newark International Airport on Tuesday, momentarily severing communication between air traffic controllers and 17 planes, a Federal official said yesterday.

title: Police Release Tape Showing Attack at Rally By Protesters
description: In an effort to demonstrate that police actions at Saturday's youth rally in Harlem were justified, Commissioner Howard W. Safir yesterday released portions of a police videotape of the rally showing that officers mounted the stage only after they were attacked by demonstrators hurling chairs and other debris.

title: Making Sense Of Sprawl
description: ''I LOVE sprawl!'' claimed Susan Nigra Snyder, a Philadelphia architect having lunch with a klatch of design academics at the University of Pennsylvania. As she expected, the eating stopped.

title: D'Amato Says He May Vote For Fund-Raising Changes
description: Under intense pressure from Democrats and government watchdog groups, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is running for re-election this year, has begun signaling a willingness to switch his vote and support legislation that would overhaul Federal campaign finance laws.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Electricity Forces A Change of Tune

title: Comprehensive Information That Can Be Hard to Find
description: WWW.IMS-HEALTH.COM

title: Big Banks to Merge In South Korea
description: Kookmin Bank said yesterday that it would merge with Korea Long-Term Credit Bankto create South Korea's biggest lender. The two banks have combined assets of about 100.6 trillion won ($73.9 billion) and 47 trillion won of loans. Terms of the merger are still under discussion.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; For Trading in Livent, an Indefinite Intermission
description: While Livent Inc. continues to sell tickets to its Broadway show ''Ragtime,'' the theater company's investors cannot sell their shares.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-19

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BASSEN, DR. E.J.
description: BASSEN-Dr. E.J. Forever and ever your loss is deeply felt by your wife, Lupe, and your family.

title: Reticent Novelist Talks Baseball, Not Books
description: WHEN the ball went over the fence Tuesday night -- and there is no longer any need to say which ball or which fence -- it shot into a dark utility space, perhaps the only gray area in the whole sunlit spectacle of this year's home-run daydream. Watching it go, feeling the old stirring once again, Don DeLillo briefly hoped the ball was truly lost somewhere in the darkness, perhaps rolling down history's drainpipe into lasting mystery.

title: PC Data Tries to Catch Up With Web Tracking Survey
description: Web surfing has become a spectator sport -- one that companies are willing to pay to observe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORTIMER, JOHN
description: MORTIMER-John. The Community Service Society of New York mourns the untimely death of its former Trustee who served with distinction from 1983-88. Mr. Mortimer brought his expertise in labor relations to his work as Chair of the Personnel Committee and as a member of numerous committees including the Search Committee to select a CEO. His generosity of spirit and contributions will long be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. David R. Jones, Esq, Pres/CEO Stephen R. Aiello, Ph.D., Chair Community Service Society of NY

title: President Appeals to Democrats With Pleas for Their Forgiveness
description: President Clinton pleaded today for forgiveness and another chance from his party's leaders and loyalists, rallying support even as prosecutors were preparing to give Congress the boxed results of their eight-month inquiry into his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Greedy Colleges Tarnished Student Athletics
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: A Few Bumps On the Road To No. 62; An Impromptu Embrace Turned McGwire Around
description: As he lay on the grass at Wrigley Field, stretching during pre-game exercises with his St. Louis teammates, Mark McGwire was not the happiest of baseball players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, DR. LEO
description: RICHMAN-Dr. Leo, 101. Of North Miami, FL, formerly of NYC. Passed away September 6. Dear brother of Joan Perlstein of NYC and the late Harry, James and Barbara Richman. Cherished uncle of Mae Gail (Hall) Esterman of Rochester, N.Y., and Robert (Marianita) Perlstein of Hastingson-Hudson, N.Y. Dr. Richman was a W.W. I Naval veteran and a graduate of Columbia University. Services were held in New York.

title: Girl Games: Plenty And Pink
description: WHAT a difference a few years can make.

title: Five Precious Pages Renew Wrangling Over Anne Frank
description: More than 50 years after they were written in a secret refuge from the Nazis, long-suppressed pages from the diary of Anne Frank have given her story a new twist and set off a furor over exploitation of one of history's top best sellers, only recently republished in a supposedly ''definitive'' edition.

title: Picasso's 'Weeping' Dora; Lover's Collection Helps Fill In the Portrait
description: Pablo Picasso's reputation for wrecking the lives of the women who loved him was in no small measure shaped by the way he treated Dora Maar, the Surrealist photographer who was his mistress and muse for nine years until he dropped her for the younger Francoise Gilot in 1944. The fact that he used her as the model for his ''Weeping Woman'' portraits only added to her aura of tragedy. He even persuaded himself that she was the weeping woman. ''I could never see her, never imagine her, except crying,'' he once remarked.

title: FBOP IN $111.6 MILLION DEAL FOR CALUMET BANCORP
description: The FBOP Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Calumet Bancorp for $111.6 million as it expands in its home state of Illinois. FBOP, a privately held bank based in Oak Park, has assets of $3.3 billion and offices in Illinois, California and Texas. Calumet, based in Dolton, Ill., is the holding company of Calumet Federal Savings and Loan Association, which has five offices and $492 million in assets. The deal, which values Calumet at $32 a share, was announced after the close of trading. Calumet ended yesterday at $26.50, down 50 cents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the investigation of the bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last month omitted the last two words of the name of an Islamic charity whose Nairobi manager was questioned by the F.B.I. It is the Mercy International Relief Agency. (A group with a similar name, Mercy International U.S.A., has not been linked to the bombings.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CREWDSON, FRANK ROY ''BIG D''
description: CREWDSON-Frank Roy ''Big D''. It is with great sadness that the Crewdson Family announces the death of Frank. He was born in Tenino, Washington in 1926 and he practiced psychoanalysis in New York for three decades. He will be buried in Becket, Massachusetts at a private ceremony. Frank was gentle, kind, warm, open, elegant, funny and supportive. He was a facilitator of young careers. We will miss him but know he lives on with us. We thank all the wonderful people who have filled our house with love & support. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Bargemusic in Brooklyn. ''Hope springs eternal''. Carole, Gregory, Michael and Natasha Crewdson

title: After Moves by Reno, Officials See New Prosecutor as Inevitable
description: After two years in which Attorney General Janet Reno resisted demands for the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate how the Democrats financed President Clinton's re-election campaign, Ms. Reno has started three separate inquiries, each of which could lead to an independent counsel.

title: Procter & Gamble Warns on Earnings and Details Changes
description: The Procter & Gamble Company warned yesterday that its first-quarter results would be weaker than expected because of flat sales in Europe and the financial crisis in Russia.

title: Dollar Rises Against Yen, Masking Recent Weakness
description: The dollar rose almost 4 percent against the Japanese yen yesterday after Japan's central bank announced a surprise cut in an important interest rate.

title: Company Has a Problem With Net's John Doe(s)
description: The Itex Corporation, an investment firm in Portland, Ore., last week filed an anti-defamation lawsuit in an Oregon court. There is just one catch: Itex is not exactly sure whom it filed the suit against.

title: Critic's Notebook; What Passes for News at 11 P.M.: High, Low and Sly
description: An acquaintance given to ending his day with the 11 o'clock news on Channel 2 called recently to draw my attention to some oddities he has encountered in the evening's chronicle of dire dispatches. My own subsequent week of viewing confirms his impression that what used to be a relatively sane assemblage of headlines shows signs of infection by experts. Whether other local-news purveyors are going in a similar direction requires separate investigation, but, for now, join me in a few highlights from CBS's Channel 2.

title: Reading Aloud Is Good for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Phil Goulding, 77, Pentagon Spokesman Caught in Vietnam Web
description: Phil G. Goulding, a Pentagon spokesman who unknowingly passed along encouraging but false reports about United States progress in the war in Vietnam and later wrote a book urging officials to press for accurate information from the military, died on Tuesday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 77 and also had a home in Brainardsville, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about testimony before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission in South Africa referred incorrectly to the day's sole witness. While the witness, Johan Coetzee, a former senior police official, told of having taken part in plotting a bombing, he has not confessed to any killings or been charged with any. The reference to assassins should have applied only to two witnesses in a group of eight applicants for amnesty whose hearings began on Tuesday.

title: De La Hoya Shows Dislike for Chavez
description: It was hard to tell whether Oscar De La Hoya was trying to talk up his rematch against Julio Cesar Chavez on Sept. 18 in Las Vegas, Nev., or whether he was sincere yesterday when he expressed disdain for Chavez during a telephone news conference from his training camp in Big Bear, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERKOWITZ, PHILIP
description: BERKOWITZ-Philip. We extend sincerest condolences to Sabine Berkowitz on the passing of her beloved husband. As Founders of the hospital they have played a vital role in ensuring state-of-the-art and compassionate medical care to the people of Israel. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratkzer, President Stuart Tauber, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HYMAN M.
description: WEISS-Hyman M. On September 9, 1998. Beloved husband to Edith for fifty-two years. Loving father to Janet and Eric Fader and Ellen and Derek Armitage. Cherished grandfather of Andrew and Evan Fader. Dearest brother-in-law to Donald and Marsha Schneider. Devoted uncle and great uncle. A kind and helpful friend to many. The service is Friday, at 12 noon at Riverdale-0n-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave., Bronx. Donations to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Gift From Kohl in an Election Year: Temporary Work for East's Jobless
description: Like many others in this small town in eastern Germany, Erika Tauber had been out of work since the textile factory here closed with the fall of Communism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAAC, HYMAN
description: ISAAC-Hyman. A prominent New Jersey lawyer & former president of the Union County Bar Association, died at age 88 on September 8, 1998. He was a loving gentleman who will be missed. He tried cases before the Federal District Courts in NJ and NY and handled appeals before the U.S. Supreme Court. He is survived by his wife, Frances, a sister, Cecilia Eisenberg of Elizabeth, N.J., two stepsons, Major Howard Holland of Durham, N.H., Richard Holland of Framingham, Massachusetts, five grandchildren, six great-grandchildren & two nieces. Services are today, 1 P.M., at Higgins and Bonner Funeral Home, Westfield, New Jersey.

title: Over the Hills and Into Valleys With Digital Television Signals
description: A coalition of companies involved in the advancement of digital television is touting a new technological breakthrough in the industry. A group of engineers last week successfully tested technology that will allow them to more efficiently redirect digital television signals into hard-to-reach geographic areas, like valleys and areas behind ridges and mountains.

title: Labor Board Orders Hearing on Doctor Union
description: Finding that the nature of medical practice has changed significantly in the era of managed care, the National Labor Relations Board has resuscitated faltering efforts to organize doctors by ordering for the first time a full hearing on a union's petition to represent physicians in private practice.

title: Aides Brace For Battle With Sense Of Gloom
description: With the delivery of the Whitewater independent counsel's report to Congress this afternoon, the struggle for President Clinton's political life reached a critical milepost whose gravity could be felt throughout the White House.

title: CORRECTIONAL PROPERTIES TO ADD PRISONS IN NEW MEXICO
description: Correctional Properties Trust said yesterday that it planned to acquire two New Mexico prisons under development by the Wackenhut Corrections Corporation for $75 million. One prison, in Hobbs, has 1,200 beds and is expandable to 2,200 beds. The other, in Santa Rosa, has 600 beds and is expandable to 1,200 beds. The prisons will be completed by Wackenhut late this year. Under the agreement, Correctional Properties will lease the facilities to Wackenhut, which will manage and operate them. Correctional Properties, a real estate investment trust, and Wackenhut, a unit of the Wackenhut Corporation, are both based in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.

title: After 'Coming Apart,' a Life Did Just That
description: The road to oblivion was an easy one for the filmmaker Milton Moses Ginsberg. ''Merely make a movie that's murder on the audience,'' he once wrote. ''It wasn't difficult for me. I positively aspired to the obscure, the pretentious and the boring.''

title: It's Been in the Family for Weeks
description: NOT since the 1920's has the New York region witnessed estate-building on the scale and pace of the late 1990's. These aren't the dinky 10,000-square-foot McMansions that are crowding the suburbs; they're serious turn-of-the-21st-century manor houses of 15,000, 25,000 and 40,000 square feet and more.

title: Places to Check Out the Pills for Your Ills
description: IF you are like most Americans, your medicine cabinet is packed with a pricey assortment of pills and potions, evidence that we, as a country, like to feel good. And some of the newer pills -- say, Viagra and Prozac -- can make even others feel good about you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLON, GENE
description: DELLON-Gene. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Gene Dellon, a generous supporter and valued member of our Plumbing and Heating Division. His devotion to the Jewish community has been embraced by his son, Scott, who has served as chair of this Division. We extend our sincerest condolences to Scott; Mr. Dellon's wife, Dolly; his daughter Robin; and his grandchildren, Brian and Kate. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Saul Klausner and Jack Weksler, Co-Chairs, Plumbing and Heating Division Stephen D. Solender, Exec. VP

title: Deciphering Pearl Jam's Messages
description: Though there were no light shows, fabulous clothes or extreme behavior, Pearl Jam's concert on Tuesday night at the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., had meta-messages galore. The band is touring behind its fifth and latest album, ''Yield,'' whose title has widely been interpreted as an uncomfortable capitulation to the irritations of major rock-band life. For Pearl Jam that means dropping a boycott and participating in Ticketmaster's stranglehold on the rock-concert business (the Continental Airlines Arena, as well as Madison Square Garden, where the band plays tonight and tomorrow, sells tickets through Ticketmaster), coughing up a video, talking to the press.

title: Mired in Recession, Japan Lowers a Rate
description: The Japanese central bank has lowered an important interest rate to the extraordinarily low level of one-quarter of 1 percent.

title: Bell Atlantic Ending Some Wireless Fees
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said today that its digital wireless phone customers will not pay long-distance or roaming charges, starting on Thursday, as the company tries to increase its number of customers.

title: INSIDE
description: A Sharp Decline in Stocks

title: Fresh Debate on 1802 Jefferson Letter
description: A renowned letter by Thomas Jefferson, which is the highlight of a traveling Library of Congress exhibition intended as a historical survey of religion and the founding of the nation, has been seized upon by conservative Christian leaders as support for their campaign for classroom prayer, taxpayer-financed vouchers for religious schools and posting the Ten Commandments in courtrooms.

title: Ushuaia Journal; A Key Factor in Politics: A Mother's Aching Heart
description: Like many mothers in Argentina, Graciela Fernandez Meijilde can remember the night years ago when the Argentine security forces knocked at the door.

title: Fate of Young Stars at Heart of Lockout
description: Two young stars whose future is at the heart of the dispute between the National Basketball Association and its players strolled into Madison Square Garden last night, locked out by the N.B.A. but ready to play.

title: Successful Searching
description: To the Editor:

title: A Change Lifts Nascar Truck Series
description: For two seasons, declining television ratings and slumping attendance plagued the Nascar Craftsman Truck Series, which was marked by predictable results and repeat winners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, JUAN
description: METZGER-Juan. The Board of the New York Society for the Deaf mourns the loss of its valued colleague and friend. Our thoughts are with his beloved family.

title: MEGO FINANCIAL CALLS OFF MERGER WITH SYCAMORE
description: The Mego Financial Corporation ended its proposed merger with Sycamore Partners L.L.C. and the Sycamore Acquisition Corporation yesterday, citing ''breaches'' of the agreement. The deal, which was announced in March, called for Sycamore to pay Mego $5.71 to $5.75 a share, or about $120 million, and to assume about $67.6 million in debt. In May, Mego said it was advised that Sycamore would proceed with the deal only if certain terms were changed, including a cut in the purchase price. Sycamore is a company backed by Blackacre Capital Group L.P., a real estate fund based in New York. Mego is a Las Vegas, Nev., developer of time-share properties and land parcels, with assets of about $178.3 million.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 2 about Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive for eight years in the 1970's, misstated the purpose of a county planning committee on which he served as co-chairman at his death. It is planning Nassau County's centennial in 1999, not its bicentennial.

title: Also King of Ratings and the T-Shirts
description: Mark McGwire's home run quest has been very good to Fox and ESPN.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, ANNA (NEWTA)
description: SHERMAN-Anna (Newta). On September 6th, 1998 at the age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Meir Sherman, Israel's first Economic Minister to the United States, first Chairman of the Board of Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York, & Managing Director of Paz Oil Company in Israel. Devoted sister to the late pianist Nadia Reisenberg Sherman, and the late theremin virtuoso Clara Rockmore. Survived by her son, Roniel, her granddaughters, Karen and Dina, nephews Alexander and Robert, & their families. Services on Friday, September 11, at 1:30 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Breast Cancer Rate Shows Decline Since '92
description: After a steady rise during the 1980's and early 90's in the number of New Jersey women who contracted breast cancer, the rate began to decline in 1992, the state reported yesterday.

title: PAPER COMPANY BUYING 45% OF PACKAGING PLANT IN CHINA
description: The Westvaco Corporation, a paper products maker with about $3 billion an annual sales, said yesterday that it planned to acquire a 45 percent stake in a packaging plant in Guangzhou, China, for about $25 million from the Shorewood Packaging Corporation to expand in China's consumer-goods market. Shorewood, a maker of folding cartons, will own the remaining 55 percent of the plant, which is scheduled to open within 30 days. Westvaco and Shorewood are based in New York. The investment will add to Westvaco's overseas operations, which account for about 25 percent of sales.

title: Parcells Gets Up Close and Personal
description: The Jets are down to five linebackers, Coach Bill Parcells is unhappy about tackling by two of them and he needs better production from his special teams. So he cornered some of the guilty parties today for private talks to impress on them the need to improve. ''I'm trying to do this in a nice, quiet, communicative way,'' Parcells said after he talked with each player, separately, in his office.

title: Arbitration Sides Wrap Up Hearing
description: An arbitration hearing to decide whether players with guaranteed contracts should be paid during the National Basketball Association lockout ended last night in Manhattan, with lawyers from the union and the owners delivering closing arguments before the arbitrator, John D. Feerick.

title: Bride Wins Lawsuit Over a Switch in Wedding Singers
description: Like many brides-to-be, Bridget Griffin spent a whole year planning the details of her wedding. And when it came to the entertainment, Ms. Griffin, 33, a marketing executive from Nanuet, N.Y., knew exactly what she wanted: a five-piece orchestra led by Paul Rich, a 20-something stockbroker and singer who promised to deliver a lively mix of pop hits, rhythm-and-blues and disco classics.

title: Bayonne Berth Favored For Historic Battleship
description: A day before a state commission is to vote on where to dock the U.S.S. New Jersey, the commission's chairman said he favored mooring the historic battleship in Bayonne rather than Jersey City or Camden.

title: Successful Searching
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Over Islander Ice Intensifies
description: Nassau Coliseum, home to the New York Islanders, is the oldest unrenovated arena in the National Hockey League -- and it shows. The ceiling hangs so low that some fans cannot see the ice, and many seats are broken. The Islanders say that the Coliseum, built in 1972, is one reason the team is near the bottom of the N.H.L. in attendance and is losing more than $11 million a year.

title: Press Curbed, Malaysians Go On-Line for News : Mahathir Caught in Web Of Internet Awareness
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysia's headlong rush into information technology is receiving strong support these days, although perhaps not among the crowd that Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad had intended when he launched a national Internet awareness program last year.

title: Glimmer of a West Bank Deal
description: The return of an American mediator to the Middle East yesterday after a four-month absence signals that the long stalemate between Israel and the Palestinians may be nearing an end. The two sides have made progress this summer on arranging the transfer of 13 percent more of the West Bank to full or partial Palestinian control. Though differences remain, particularly involving security matters, there is now a fair chance the American envoy, Dennis Ross, can help narrow the gap.

title: U.S. to Send North Korea Food Despite Missile Launching
description: The United States quietly agreed last weekend to send an unusually large shipment of emergency food aid to North Korea, despite the North's recent launching of a medium-range missile over Japan, officials who have been briefed on the talks between the two countries say.

title: Parents Step In, Rent's History
description: ELLIOT GOLD said it was time his son, Shawn, 24, a marketer at J. P. Morgan, got his own apartment.

title: Juan Metzger, 79, Is Dead; He Put the Fruit in Yogurt
description: Juan E. Metzger, the man credited with turning yogurt -- an obscure, highly acidic dairy product -- into a fruit-flavored staple in the diets of many Americans, died on Sunday at his home in New York. He was 79.

title: Reading Aloud Is Good for Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Digital Employees Tell of Threats by Gates Over Product
description: Five current and former employees of the Digital Equipment Corporation say that their company was forced to drop a planned Internet product last year under threats from the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, William H. Gates. The allegations appear to support the Government's contention that Microsoft routinely suppresses competition in any new market that might threaten its monopoly in personal computer operating systems.

title: Williams Marches Into Semis
description: On the same drafty Stadium Court where Patrick Rafter, the defending United States Open champion, used a panoramic display of aggression to attain the semifinals, Venus Williams, who aspires to be a defending Open champion, used a similar onslaught of power last night to blast her way into the semifinals.

title: Chicago Police Are Reviewing Juvenile Policy
description: After dropping murder charges in the case of two boys, ages 7 and 8, in the killing of an 11-year-old girl, Chicago police officials say they are taking a closer look at how they treat juvenile suspects.

title: Confronting Truths About File Storage
description: The other morning, as I groped for clothes in my bedroom closet, I settled for a mismatched pair of socks, leaned down to pick up a shoe -- and discovered two kittens sitting in my sneaker.

title: City Schools Face Only a Few Glitches on Opening Day; C Is for Construction
description: Leaders of the teachers' union were dismayed yesterday when they arrived at Public School 40 in Lower Manhattan and heard construction workers jackhammering concrete and debris rattling through a giant Slinky-like yellow trash chute.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: City Schools Face Only a Few Glitches on Opening Day
description: It was a day for fifth graders to learn how not to be fourth graders, for a beginning elementary teacher to chase away butterflies in the stomach and face 31 9-year-olds, for the Mayor and Schools Chancellor to go back to school and read to second graders, and for a group of high school students to marvel at their brand-new building.

title: Marketers are at the top of their windups as they prepare pitches for McGwire and Sosa.
description: THE race to cash in on Mark McGwire's 62d home run is already under way as marketers as disparate as the Walt Disney Company and a maker of baseball caps called Twins Enterprises scramble to celebrate his record.

title: House Fire Kills Woman; Power Failures Suspected
description: An elderly woman died in a house fire in central New Jersey last night, and authorities are investigating whether it may have been caused indirectly by the power failures that have left parts of the state in darkness since Monday's storms.

title: Profit Warning Pushes the Dow Down 155.76
description: Stocks slumped yesterday as several companies warned that third-quarter profits will be lower than expected and euphoria over possible interest-rate cuts seemed to dissipate.

title: A Theater Boom Is Born In Russian Film Industry
description: Five years ago, Raymond Markovich and Paul Heth carried reels of second-run American films on their laps and candy bars and popcorn bags in their luggage on flights from Los Angeles to Moscow, using their credit cards to finance a hotel movie theater here frequented by expatriates.

title: Russia's Communists Add To the Pressure on Yeltsin
description: As President Boris N. Yeltsin pondered for a second day over who would be his next Prime Minister, the Communists threatened today to pursue impeachment if he renominated Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.

title: MAYTAG SAYS 3D-QUARTER PROFIT WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: The Maytag Corporation, the No. 3 United States appliance seller, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings would beat estimates as strong demand for washing machines, Hoover vacuum cleaners and vending equipment pushes sales up as much as 20 percent. Maytag, based in Newton, Iowa, said its third-quarter profit would exceed 70 cents a share, the average estimate of six analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, which tracks earnings estimates. Sales are expected to surpass $1 billion, compared with $855.8 million a year earlier. Shares of Maytag shares rose $1.8125, to $46.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZENIOS, MARINO
description: ZENIOS-Marino, died on September 2nd, 1998 when Swissair Flight 111 crashed near Peggy's Cove, Nova Scotia. Marino was 33 years old. Marino was born in Athens, Greece and later spent the early years of his life in Port Elizabeth, South Africa. He later returned to Athens to study for his Bachelor of Science degree at Deree Collegethe American College of Greece. He was elected President of the Student Council and he graduated at the top of his class with the highest distinction. He came to the United States in 1987 to pursue his Master of Science degree in Industrial Administration (MBA) at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, PA. He launched his career in New York when he interned at the Union Bank of Switzerland (''UBS'') where after graduating with his MBA in 1989, he accepted a permanent position in UBS's Private Bank for the initial three years of his professional career. Marino spent his remaining seven years in the bank's Structured Finance Department where he was promoted various times ultimately to the position of Director holding key responsibilities in the asset securitization area of UBS's investment bank, Warburg Dillon Read. Marino will always be remembered for his intelligence, wit, sense of humor, thoughtfulness and compassion. He treated everyone with the same deference and affection and lived life celebrating every moment. He will be greatly missed by his family, friends and colleagues. His immediate relatives reside in Athens, Greece. He is survived by his parents, Elisabeth and Dominic Zenios, brother, Theo, sister-in-law, Polly, and nephews, Kyriaco and Faedon. A memorial tribute will be held for Marino on Tuesday, September 15th, in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to the American College of Greece, payable to Dominic Zenios.

title: MetroStars Are Limping Toward Playoffs
description: A season filled with promise for the MetroStars appears to be crumbling as the team gets ready for the Major League Soccer playoffs.

title: Recalling History by Pulling Strings
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERGAMENT, HENRY
description: PERGAMENT-Henry. On September 10, 1998. Most wonderful husband and father imaginable, you will be in our hearts forever. Memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 17 at 2:30 PM, at Plaza Memorial Funeral Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Abbott House for children, 914-591-7300.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCSEK, KEVIN
description: BUCSEK-Kevin. Son of John and Marlene, stepson of Jacob Kowalcheck. Passed away September 7. His life touched many and his memory shall touch many more. Services will be private.

title: Career Reborn, on a High Note
description: In one sense, it was a hard show to steal. Millennial Arts Productions' staging of ''Esther'' in May on the Lower East Side of Manhattan combined a Handel oratorio with a Racine play, using separate but interacting young casts of singers, actors and dancers. The dancers included Handel and Racine, as characters. Though admirable in its ambition, the production had a touch of the circus.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Circuits yesterday about prescription drug Web sites referred incorrectly to Lipha Pharmaceuticals. Lipha is a subsidiary of Merck K.G.a.A., a German company; it has no relationship to Merck & Company, an American drug manufacturer.

title: For Team and Olerud, Fatherhood Is First
description: John Olerud left the Mets late Wednesday night for New York to be with his wife, Kelly, who is expecting the couple's first child, and he did not appear in the Mets' 7-5 victory over the Phillies here tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAVERMAN, JUDY (NEE CADENA)
description: BRAVERMAN-Judy (nee Cadena). On September 10, 1998. Beloved wife of Irving. Adored mother of Hilary & Melissa. Cherished grandmother of Andrew, Christopher and Marcie. Dear sister of Nancy. We will miss your love, compassion and strength. You have gone to heaven but will live on in our hearts forever. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Friday, September 11, 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, September 12, 10 AM, at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55 Street. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to any breast cancer organization.

title: Officers and Firemen Wore Blackface on Float, Officials Say
description: Two New York City police officers and at least two city firefighters were apparently part of a group of men wearing blackface on a float in a Labor Day parade in Queens on Monday, city officials said last night.

description: MAASS-Richard, 79. Of Purchase, New York, died September 10, of cancer. Mr. Maass was born May 20, 1919 in Baltimore, Maryland to Arthur Leopold Maass and Selma Rosenheim Maass. He is survived by his devoted wife of 55 years, Dolly Lederer Maass, a brother Arthur Aaron Maass of Boston, sons Douglas O. of Sleepy Hollow, NY and R. Andrew of Jackson, Mississippi, four grandchildren, Aaron, Ethan and Kern Maass and Annie Maass Halpin, one great grandson Michael Andrew Halpin. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY, Monday, September 14, 1 P.M. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Purchase College (SUNY) Foundation Scholarship Fund.

She is not a daughter of Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the former Saudi Oil Minister.

title: New Jersey Signs 3 Free Agents
description: The Devils yesterday signed three of their free agents -- Denis Pederson, Sheldon Souray and Steve Brule -- and threatened to lock out two others who have not agreed to new contracts.

title: Students in Jakarta Continue Protests
description: Hundreds of students, ringed by soldiers, staged a noisy but peaceful demonstration today across from the Presidential Palace in the third day of protests aimed at President B. J. Habibie and his Cabinet.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Islanders Pack Up and Leave
description: One day after filing a Federal lawsuit alleging that Nassau Coliseum is too unsafe to play hockey in, the Islanders packed their office files, furniture and some memorabilia into a convoy of vans. About 60 administrative workers left and will relocate to office space in Manhattan.

title: Isabel Allende Is Chosen For the Gish Arts Award
description: Isabel Allende, the writer, is the recipient of the 1998 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, given annually for excellence in the arts. The award consists of a silver medallion and a cash stipend of about $200,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, SUSAN CUTLER.
description: ALDRICH-Susan Cutler. Of Barrytown, NY, died at home at Rokeby, September 9, 1998, in her 85th year. Widow of Richard Chanler Aldrich, daughter of the late John Wilson and Rosalind Fish Cutler. Survived by her children Richard and John Winthrop Aldrich, both of Barrytown, NY, and Rosalind Michahelles of Cambridge, MA; five beloved granddaughters; her brother John Wilson Cutler; and her sisters Patricia Rosalind Warner and Judith Bayard Shinkle. The funeral will be held at the Church of St John the Evangelist, Barrytown, New York at twelve noon, on Monday, September 14th. In place of flowers please make donations to a local animal shelter or a charity of your choice.

title: Searching for Romance, or at Least Sex
description: ''David Searching'' is the kind of movie in which people walk around Manhattan discussing the pros and cons of cappuccino in a can. In which the title character is asked what kind of man he's looking for and answers, ''Gilgamesh.'' The cast includes a batch of great people. If only it added up to something more than navel gazing.

title: Iran Holds Taliban Responsible for 9 Diplomats' Deaths
description: An angry Iran said tonight that it would hold the militant Taliban movement responsible for the deaths of nine Iranian diplomats whose bodies were recovered by the Taliban today in northern Afghanistan.

title: Recipe for Trouble: Falling Dominoes, Leadership Vacuum
description: Washington has been so distracted by President Clinton's troubles, by the slow-motion collapse of the Russian Government and by the continuing meltdown of Asia that few here have had time to consider what could set off the next wave of economic turmoil.

title: ART IN REVIEW

description: VOLKSWAGEN missed the mark on demand for yellow and silver Beetles. So instead of ''Drivers wanted,'' it's ''Cars wanted,'' and some would-be Beetle buyers are seeing red.

title: APS HOLDING TO SELL 142 BIG A AUTO PARTS STORES
description: The APS Holding Corporation, owner of the struggling Big A auto-parts chain, is selling 142 stores and 10 distribution centers for more than $100 million as part of its bankruptcy reorganization, officials said yesterday. The auto-parts distributor, based in Houston, filed for Chapter 11 under the United States Bankruptcy Code for protection from creditors in February. It is one of the largest auto-parts retailers in the United States. As part of its recovery plan, APS is selling nine distribution centers and 142 company-owned stores to General Parts Inc. and BWP Distributors Inc., which sell parts under the Carquest brand. Parts Source Inc., which operates Ace Auto Parts stores, is acquiring the other distribution center. The sales face approval by a bankruptcy judge.

title: Hispanic Agencies Hold Conference
description: The Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies is holding its fourth semiannual conference, which continues through Sunday at the Marriott Marquis Hotel in midtown Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEMPNER, IVAN, MD. 18 ELUL.
description: KEMPNER-Ivan, MD. 18 Elul. Loved, missed, remembered. Arline and their daughters Robbi, Juli and Lani.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 2
description: Game of the Week

title: Mindspring to Buy Sprynet
description: Mindspring Enterprises Inc. said today that it would buy Sprynet, an Internet service provider, from America Online Inc. for about $35 million to $45 million in cash. Mindspring, an Atlanta-based Internet service provider, said it had agreed to purchase Sprynet's subscriber base of about 180,000 customers as well as the customer support and network operations. Mindspring said the final purchase price would be determined by the number of subscribers who transfer.

title: Guide of Sorts To Just Who Is on Ballot
description: THE mail included a handy guide to Tuesday's Democratic primary that was prepared by the Citizens Union, an organization usually described as a good-government group. (How come you never hear about bad-government groups?) The booklet was indeed informative, especially about the sad state of voter interest in New York politics.

title: A Sign of the Past
description: For its 35th anniversary, the Ford Mustang has received a makeover that includes hints of the original pony car.

title: Four More Arrested In NEC Investigation
description: Four former and current officials of the NEC Corporation and an NEC affiliate, the Toyo Communication Equipment Company, were arrested yesterday in an overcharging and payback investigation involving the Defense Agency. Toyo Communication, a Japanese electronics maker, is suspected of overcharging the defense agency by 2.4 billion yen ($17.7 million) and then conspiring with top agency officials to minimize the amount repaid in return for offering jobs to retiring agency officials.

title: TRANSACTION NETWORK TO BUY AN AT&T PROCESSING UNIT
description: Transaction Network Services Inc. has agreed to buy the AT&T Corporation's credit-card processing unit, Transaction Access Service, for $64 million. Transaction Network Services, based in Reston, Va., provides data communications services for processors of transactions. The company had revenue of $63.3 million last year. Under the agreement, Transaction Network will perform AT&T's services under its 39 existing Transaction Access Service customer contracts. Transaction Network will also get some network hardware. The purchase would double Transaction Network's point-of-service transaction volume.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Out of the Closet And Into Print

title: YOUNG BROADCASTING SAYS IT'S NOT FOR SALE
description: The shares of Young Broadcasting Inc. plunged yesterday after the company, which owns a dozen television stations, said it was no longer for sale because it was unlikely to fetch a high enough price. Young, based in New York, fell $11.50, to $34.50, in Nasdaq trading. The company, whose stations reach 9 percent of all United States households, said it would continue to consider alternatives, including a possible merger or consolidation. Young's stations include its flagship KCAL in Los Angeles, the only independent VHF station in the city. Broadcast stocks are down as much as 50 percent since June 29, when Young announced that it had hired Lazard Freres & Company to explore options.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINN, JULIUS
description: WINN-Julius. Of Sarasota, FL. Husband of Catherine (and the late Rose). Beloved father of Stephen (Carol) and Joseph (Judy). Grandfather of Robin Winfree (Chris), Michael, Lindsay and Rachel. Brother of Estelle Smollet. Member of the firm of Siegel, Chalif & Winn.

title: Finishing First, Even When He Didn't
description: Though the link between the mercurial track star Steve Prefontaine, who died in 1975 at 24, and the veteran Hollywood screenwriter Robert Towne is not immediately obvious, Mr. Towne's Prefontaine biography is the most stirring and unmistakably personal film he has directed. In ''Without Limits,'' a writer famed for enriching screenplays (his own and others') with the gift of unruly, unpredictable life has taken on a curiously amorphous subject and invested it with deep, reflective power. And precisely because this sports story is not about winning, losing or even how you play the game, it becomes a broader parable than the viewer has any reason to expect. Its wisdom, and clearly Mr. Towne's, lies in the film's way of filtering a young man's headstrong nature through an older man's more rueful point of view.

title: Feuds Erupt in Congress Over Details of Release
description: As Congress prepared to make public the 445-page impeachment report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Democrats and Republicans began testily jockeying today over the details of releasing and reviewing the materials that could endanger the Clinton Presidency.

title: Brazil Sees Record Drop In Markets
description: Brazilian markets, caving in under the international financial crisis and the Government's failure over the last four years to make crucial changes, careered toward record losses today, with emergency measures over the last week proving futile to end the slide in investor confidence.

title: The Stonewall Crumbles
description: The House of Representatives' plan to release a large portion of Kenneth Starr's report is correct because it recognizes the need for the public to reach an informed decision about President Clinton's conduct in office and his political fate. House Speaker Newt Gingrich's call for decorous, fair debate is also encouraging and an affirmation of Congress's ability to avoid partisan warfare during times of national crisis.

title: Creditors to Write Off More of Kia's Debt
description: Creditors of the Kia Motors Corporation, the bankrupt South Korean auto maker, said yesterday that they would write off 2.9 trillion won ($2.1 billion) of the company's debt to make Kia more attractive in a second auction later this month. In the first auction earlier this month, the bids were either too low or contained conditions demanding additional debt write-off. The original bidders said they would submit new offers on Sept. 21. The four bidders are the Hyundai Motor Company, the Daewoo Motor Company, Samsung Motors Inc. and the Ford Motor Company.

title: Ad Sales Executive Named at The Times
