description: Denise F. Warren, who has spent the last 20 months as director for marketing, planning and research in the New York Times advertising department, will become vice president for advertising sales, the newspaper announced yesterday.

title: Republican Senators Join in Calls for '98 Tax Cut
description: Republican leaders in the Senate said today that they would join their counterparts in the House in pushing for a tax cut of up to $80 billion this year, despite unyielding opposition from the White House.

title: On Stage and Off; As Ever, Hope Has Its Moment
description: Less than 24 hours after Labor Day, the delirious spin of practice, previews and publicity stunts had begun on Broadway -- and the stages that lead there.

title: High Court To Hear Case On Sampling For Census
description: Acting with unusual speed in advance of its new term, the Supreme Court today agreed to hear the Clinton Administration's appeal of a ruling last month that barred the use of statistical sampling in the census for the year 2000.

title: Volkswagen to Create $12 Million Fund for Nazi-Era Laborers
description: Faced with a new lawsuit over the use of slave labor during World War II, Volkswagen A.G. is to announce plans on Friday to set up a fund of about $12 million to compensate surviving workers. It will be overseen by Shimon Peres, the former Prime Minister of Israel, according to people working with the company.

title: Objects of Wonder, Created to Be Used
description: ''Baule: African Art/Western Eyes,'' an exhibition at the Museum for African Art in SoHo, demonstrates how the uses and meanings of African objects are central to an understanding of their forms, no matter how beautiful those forms may be.

title: Albert Ready for Return to Work
description: On Monday at 11 P.M. Marv Albert will return to work, as host of the redesigned MSG SportsDesk, offering news, interviews and highlights. It will be exactly a year since he last worked, when he called a Giants-Ravens game for NBC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZ, HERMAN
description: SALZ-Herman. On September 10, 1998 at the age of 83. Husband of the late Sylvia. Beloved father of Alan, David and Barbara. Adored grandfather of Laurence and Lindsay. Brother of Charlotte Fischler and Marion Schiz. Graveside services Friday 11AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: D'Amato Votes Against Fund-Raising Changes
description: Brushing aside pressure from Democrats and government watchdog groups, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato voted today against legislation that would overhaul Federal campaign finance laws.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKO, MARY M. (NEE MCLOUGHLIN)
description: MOSKO-Mary M. (Nee McLoughlin), 78, of Middletown, NJ on Sept. 10, 1998. Wife of the late John. Mother of Andrew Mosko (Sally), Margaret C. Burris (James), Rita Bergers, Martha D'Adamo (Peter), Helen Lorri (Robert), Dorothy Mosko, Tess Scherer (Marty). Sister of Margaret Simmons, Theresa McLoughlin, Eileen Miedreich and the late John & Michael. Grandmother of seven. Funeral Monday 9:45 AM, the John F. Pfleger Funeral Home, 115 Tindall Rd, Middletown, New Jersey. Funeral Liturgy at St. Marys RC Church, New Monmouth at 10:30 AM. Visiting Sun 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Mother Theresa Missionaries, 335 East 145th St, Bronx, NY 10451.

title: Forstmann Cancels Plans to Sell Stakes
description: The leveraged buyout firm Forstmann Little & Company has canceled plans to sell or distribute its stakes in the General Instrument Corporation and two other companies because of plunging stock prices.

title: And What Have They Done With Their Lives?
description: BIRDS OF AMERICA

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; A Political Vacuum
description: To the Editor:

title: First Lady Backs President As He Appeals for Absolution
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton declared her pride and admiration for her husband tonight after President Clinton spent much of the day taking himself to the woodshed, offering emotional apologies to senators and Cabinet secretaries for misleading them over his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: INSIDE
description: Scientists May Have Found A Way to Eliminate E. Coli

title: Soaring Costs Delay Building of Federal Courthouse
description: Ever-rising construction costs, driven by the resumption of large-scale development in New York City, have delayed and may fundamentally alter plans for a new 18-story Federal courthouse in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Man Charged in Shooting At the Home of a Rapist
description: A Linden man has been charged with shooting at the home of a paroled rapist in June several days after the community was notified of his presence under ''Megan's Law.''

title: In a New Sign of Peace in Ulster, Troops Will Halt Belfast Patrols
description: British troops will stop patrolling the Belfast area this weekend and some paramilitary prisoners will be released in the next few days, officials said today.

title: Yanks Sought Extension On Knoblauch Contract
description: The Yankees considered extending the contract of Chuck Knoblauch at the time they traded for the second baseman in February, and according to a member of the organization, they tentatively reached an understanding to give Knoblauch a two-year, $18 million extension, beyond the three years and $18 million that still remain on his current contract. That extension would not be announced until after the Yankees finish their season.

title: No Maps, Compasses Or Faith
description: One morning Quentin wakes up and he's not in his bed. Or anybody else's. He's in an ugly, windowless 14-by-14-foot cube of a room, dressed in a drab uniform he has never seen. Soon he discovers that what he's in is a gigantic maze of interlocking cubes, that he has six other equally clueless souls for company and that since there's no food or water they had all better figure out how to get out of there fast. Unfortunately, as they soon learn, many of the surrounding rooms are booby-trapped in various clever ways. The first man who goes into one is quickly sliced and diced. Another man has his face burned off.

title: Tiny Boy With an Enormously Consuming Quest
description: ''Simon Birch,'' Mark Steven Johnson's insufferably precious ''reduction'' of John Irving's popular 1989 novel ''A Prayer for Owen Meany,'' might be described as the movie equivalent of a piece of stale angel food cake. Bite into it, and what you'll find is a nearly flavorless mixture of air and sugar and more sugar and a texture so parched that a mouthful is almost impossible to swallow without risk of choking.

title: McCaughey Ross Assails Vallone's Abortion Stance
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross made her harshest attack to date yesterday on her chief rival in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, Peter F. Vallone, calling his position on abortion rights ''a farce'' and questioning why he had not pressured New York City to enforce its law protecting women from harassment outside abortion clinics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALMER, SUSAN B.
description: PALMER-Susan B. On September 2, 1998. Devoted wife of F. Morgan Palmer. Loving mother of F. Morgan Palmer Jr. and Thomas P. F. Palmer. Contributions may be sent in her memory to The Church of The Holy Trinity Garden Fund, 316 E. 88 St, NY, NY 10128

title: Pettitte Wins His 16th, Struggling All the Way
description: When Joe Torre began answering questions about his playoff rotation a month ago, it seemed he would have to carefully pick three starters from a group of five. But with the post-season less than three weeks away, Torre, the Yankee manager, may find himself settling, or hoping, for mediocrity from his third starter.

title: Broker Accused of Theft Of Fees for Apartments
description: A real estate broker at a Brooklyn agency was arraigned in State Supreme Court in Queens yesterday on charges that she stole thousands of dollars from at least a dozen apartment hunters while operating without a license.

title: Baby Found Dead in Lot, and Mother Is Sought
description: The police were canvassing the streets of a Brooklyn neighborhood last night for the mother of a newborn baby found dead in a vacant courtyard yesterday.

title: Crash Investigators Focus on Electrical Part
description: Hampered by bad weather and other problems, investigators reported only slow progress today as they began their second week of work on the crash of Swissair Flight 111.

title: Objects of Wonder That Are Too Potent for Mere Display
description: In the third gallery of ''Baule: African Art/Western Eyes,'' an outstanding exhibition at the Museum for African Art in SoHo, an odd sight greets the visitor: a diorama centering on a life-size mannequin shrouded in bright African batik and wearing a female mask whose dark wood has touches of red at the eyes and mouth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FESSLER, DENNIS, EMMY.
description: FESSLER - DENNIS - Emmy. On September 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Laci Fessler and John Dennis. Loving mother of the late John Finder. Services on Friday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMARA, DAN GOODRICH, M.D.
description: MCNAMARA-Dan Goodrich, M.D. died at his home in Houston on September 9, 1998. He was born on October 19, 1922 in Waco, Texas to the late John Bolivar McNamara and Alice Battle McNamara. Dr. McNamara was a graduate of Baylor University and Baylor college of Medicine. He served his internship at The Medical Center in Jersey City, New Jersey and his residency in pediatrics at Hermann Hospital in Houston and the Children's Hospital in St. Louis, Missouri. He was a Fellow in Pediatric Cardiology at the Johns Hopkins Hospital under Dr. Helen Taussig. Dr. McNamara served in the military at the United States Naval Hospital in Quantico, Virginia. In 1954 he returned to Houston and joined the Department of Pediatrics at Baylor College of Medicine as an Assistant Professor and formed the Division of Pediatric Cardiology within the Department of Pediatrics. He was promoted to Professor in 1969 and at the time of his death was Emeritus Chief of Pediatric Cardiology at Texas Children's Hospital. Dr. McNamara established the standards and the environment which led to the current outstanding program in pediatric cardiology at Texas Children's Hospital. Dr McNamara was active as a Diplomate, Fellow and member in a number of professional boards and societies which include the American Board of Pediatrics, American Academy of Pediatrics, American College of Cardiology, American Pediatric Society, Beta chapter of Alpha Omega Alpha, Irish & American Pediatric Society, Association of European Pediatric Cardiologists, Cardiac Society of Australia & New Zealand, Harris County Medical Society and the American Medical Association. He seved as president of the American College of Cardiology (1981-1982); was a member of the Executive Committee of Texas Children's Hospital (1986-1988); and was Chief of Medical Department of Texas Children's Hospital (1986-1988). Dr McNamara trained an entire generation of physicians including more than thirty-five current heads of departments in repected hospitals and medical institutions around the world. He was an active member of Christ Church Cathedral for more than fifty years and served several terms on the Vestry. Dr. McNamara was a member of Houston Country Club and Texas Corinthian Yacht Club. Dr. McNamara received many honors during his distinguished career in medicine including the Distinguished Alumnus Award in 1981 from Baylor College of Medicine; Distinguished Alumnus Award from Baylor University; Distinguished Fellow Award form the American College of Cardiology in 1990; Founder's Award, Cardiology Section, American Academy of Pediatrics in 1990; The Arnold J. Rudolph Baylor Pediatric Award for Lifetime Excellence in Teaching in 1997; and Master of American College of Cardiology Award in 1990. Dr. McNamara authored and co-authored nearly three hundred articles and textbooks during his career and was an eminent consultant throughout his career with colleagues around the world. The prestigious teaching award in Pediatric Cardiology at Baylor College of Medicine was named for Dr. McNamara in 1997. Dr. McNamara is survived by a distinguished medical career which benefited countless patients, a multitude of friends who deeply respected his compassion for his fellow man and a devoted family, including his wife Kate Schweppe McNamara; brother John Bolivar McNamara and wife Nancy of Waco and his sister Alice McNamara Harwell of Waco. He was preceded in death by his brother Guy B. McNamara. Dr. McNamara is also survived by daughter Alice Goodrich McNamara of Austin, Texas; daughter Ann and husband David Duclos of Middlebury, Vermont; daughter Mary and husband Christian Tashjian of Woodstock, New York; son Dan G. McNamara, Jr and wife Joan of Austin, Texas; son Robert Weir McNamara and wife Judith of Forth Worth, Texas; step-children Kate Sharp Farris and husband Dr Glen Woody Farris; Dudley C. Sharp III and wife Jane; M.H. Palmer Moldawer and wife Susanna; and brother-in-law Dr. H. Irving Schweppe, Jr and wife Pauline. Dr. McNamara is also survived by twelve grandchildren. Doctor McNamara's family is deeply grateful for the superior care and devoted vigilance by Dr. Stanley Appel, Dr. William Spencer and Dr. Dennis Hamil. The family is at home at 3711 San Felipe in Houston. Memorial services will be at 10:30AM on Saturday, September 12, 1998 at Christ Church Cathedral, 1117 Texas Avenue in Houston with , The Very Reverend Walter H. Taylor and The Reverend Canon Betty C. Adam officiating. Interment will be at The Cathedral and the family will receive friends at 3711 San Felipe following the memorial service. Honorary Pallbearers will be the staff of the Department of Pediatric Cardiology at Baylor College of Medicine and Texas Children's Hospital. Pallbearers will be Captain David Adams of Key West, Florida; Mr. Edward Block of Key West, Florida; Dr. Timothy Bricker, Captain Earl Buckwalter of Key West, Florida; Dr. E Lillo Crain, Jr; Mr James A Elkins, Jr; Mr. Hal Foster; Mr. Wiley Hammersmith; Dr. Charles Mullins; Dr. Michael Nihill; Dr Joseph Reeves; Dr. Harvey Rosenthal; Dr. Thomas Vargo; Mr. F. Carrington Weems; Mr. Herbert Wells and Mr. David W. Wolkowsky of Key West, Florida. For those who wish, memorials may be sent in Dr. McNamara's honor to The Division of Pediatric Cardiology, 2-2280; Texas Children's Hospital, 6621 Fannnin, Houston, Texas 77030.

title: In a Black and White World, Brown Can Dazzle
description: The lights dimmed to darkness after the final bows. There was the sound of muted jangling church bells. Then the lights rose again to reveal, after two hours of horses and humans, three attitudinous white ducks strutting and flapping in the center ring as the audience left the theater.

title: WASSALL TOPS COOPER INDUSTRIES' OFFER FOR TLG
description: Wassall P.L.C. offered $:351 million ($582 million) to buy TLG P.L.C., a British maker of Thorn lighting products, exceeding an earlier bid of $:321 million from Cooper Industries of Houston. Wassall is asking for TLG to withdraw its recommendation that shareholders accept the Cooper offer, which was announced on Sept. 4. Wassall already owns 23.8 percent of TLG. TLG was spun off from Thorn EMI P.L.C. in 1993. The company issued shares on the London Stock Exchange in 1994. TLG's shares rose 8 pence yesterday, to $:177.5, above the offer price of $:175, suggesting investors expect a counterbid.

title: Ex-Treasurer Sentenced For Taking Kickbacks
description: The former treasurer of Essex County was sentenced to seven and a half years in prison yesterday for taking $125,000 in kickbacks to steer municipal bond deals to two Newark underwriting firms, Federal prosecutors said.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Spare Us the Details
description: To the Editor:

title: In Adventure Racing, Even a Little Is a Lot
description: After nearly four continuous days of racing in a multisport event called the Eco Challenge, the team that eventually won ran out of solid food in the mountains of British Columbia. Carrying 50-pound packs and operating on just two hours of sleep a day, the four ultralean members of Team Eco-Internet scavenged for berries and split a packet of carbohydrate gel every 90 minutes for the next three days -- a deficit of roughly 9,600 calories a day each.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HARSCO CORP., Harrisburg, Pa., a maker of gas-containment sytems, agreed to buy the high-pressure valve division of Amcast Industrial Corp., Dayton, Ohio, a metal fabricator, for an undisclosed price.

title: Leading Music Astray? Yes, Down a Path of Wonder
description: Has any composer of the 20th century become more of a lightning rod than Arnold Schoenberg? Listeners who object to the dissonances and melodic angularities of a particular style of contemporary music blame Schoenberg for leading music astray when he developed his 12-tone system in the 1920's. That view holds that in giving the 12 notes of the scale equal weight, and freeing them from conventional harmonic relationships, Schoenberg demolished what had until then been a universally comprehensible musical language. Entwined with that belief is the idea that Serialism, Schoenberg's system of deriving melodic and harmonic raw materials from tone rows -- carefully arranged series of notes -- robbed music of its expressivity and lyricism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARDIJAN, THOMAS A.
description: VARDIJAN-Thomas A. Of Manhattan. Formerly of Staten Island, on September 9, 1998. Husband of Junko. Son of Jennie Vardijan. Father of Elizabeth Miller, Amy and Katherine Vardijan. Brother of Jean Spooner, Barbara Ward, Patricia Harder and Peter Vardigan. Funeral service Matthew Funeral Home, 2508 Victory Blvd, Staten Island, Saturday 10:30am. Private cremation to follow. Friends may visit Friday 2-4, 7-9.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, REGINA A.
description: MEYER-Regina A. Of Forest Hills Gardens on Sept 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Francis J. Devoted mother of Marygene Anderson, William F. Meyer, Catherine M. Shore and Marjorie M. Healy. Also survived by 13 grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Reposing Glascott Funeral Home, 102-03 Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills. Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Saturday 9:15AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Joseph's College, 245 Clinton Avenue, Bklyn, New York 11205 appreciated.

title: Olde Discount And Officials Pay Big Fine
description: A discount brokerage firm and three of its executives, including its founder and chairman, agreed yesterday to pay $7 million in fines to settle Federal allegations of fraudulent sales practices and use of misleading advertising and promotional literature.

title: Musical Chairs in Moscow
description: If urbanity, longevity and familiarity with international issues were the qualities most needed for Russia's next prime minister, Yevgeny Primakov would be admirably suited for the job. Few officials are as well versed in Kremlin politics as Mr. Primakov, who has served in senior national security posts under every Russian leader going back to Leonid Brezhnev two decades ago. But since a commitment to democracy and reform are more essential for Russia's future, his selection yesterday by President Boris Yeltsin looks more like an act of desperation than an act of leadership.

title: Memphis Bank In Indiana Move
description: The First Chicago NBD Corporation, the Banc One Corporation and the Union Planters Corporation agreed this week that Union Planters would acquire 51 NBD Bank branches and associated deposits and loans in Indiana from First Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHONBERG, GEORGE
description: SCHONBERG-George. 5/26/22-9/11/95. Gone three years. So absent-so present. Love always, Doris

title: On My Mind; A Test for Presidents
description: At about 5:30 Wednesday evening, Saddam Hussein became the man who will first test Bill Clinton's remaining ability to preside over the United States Government and protect American national interests.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO PAY $556 MILLION FOR MORE OF DIBLO
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies agreed yesterday to pay $556 million for an additional 13.25 percent stake in Diblo . Anheuser-Busch said yesterday that the deal settled a dispute over the purchase price. After the sale, Anheuser-Busch will own 23.25 percent of Diblo and 35.12 percent of Diblo's parent company, Grupo Modelo. Grupo Modelo, a Mexican beer brewer and maker of Corona, will own the remaining 76.75 percent of Diblo. The additional investment will increase Anheuser-Busch's total holdings in Grupo Modelo and its subsidiaries to 50.2 percent. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest beer brewer, makes Budweiser and Michelob beers.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: In an Existentialist's Hell, Three Is Still a Crowd
description: Jean-Paul Sartre called his particular brand of existentialist drama the ''theater of situations,'' and there are few more terrifying situations in modern theater than the one he devised for ''No Exit,'' his searing 1944 play that is being revived by the Jean Cocteau Repertory.

title: Op-Art; Great Moments in American Automotive History
Sports of The Times; Farewell to Governor's Coach
description: EVERYBODY needs a mentor, and Michael Schwab found his on a hot July day in 1957.

title: In the Eye of a Hurricane, Awaiting the Final Blow
description: Bracing himself for a long, tough defense of President Clinton, the Senate Democratic minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, was the first to stand before open microphones and yearn for ''closure,'' the cliche word of modern tragedy and its wished-for ending by stricken participants.

title: Jaded Stick Figures Flirt to the Death
description: It should be hard to believe that sticks, rags and strings -- no more than can be carried in one hand -- could elicit so much emotion, laughter and curiosity, but the German puppeteer Frank Soehnle makes it easy to accept with his performance of ''Flamingo Bar,'' presented at La Mama by the Figuren Theater of Tubingen as part of the International Festival of Puppet Theater.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He is not our first choice, but he is the best choice among the alternatives.''

title: The 'New Jana' Is Enjoying the Ride
description: Jana Novotna, a Grand Slam singles champion, had just reached the semifinals of the United States Open without dropping a set, and now someone wanted to ask a question.

title: On Initial Focus Of the Inquiry, Mostly Silence
description: The report to Congress from the independent counsel, whose inquiry began four years ago with an examination of a complicated land deal called Whitewater and extended to investigations involving the White House travel office and the Administration's use of F.B.I. files, finds no offense by President Clinton in any of those areas that would merit impeachment, lawyers with knowledge of the report's content said today.

title: Philippoussis Wins in 5 Sets
description: Saying that it was a match that matured him, Mark Philippoussis of Australia advanced to his first Grand Slam semifinal last night with a 4-6, 6-3, 6-7 (3-7), 6-3, 7-6 (12-10) victory over Thomas Johansson of Sweden in the United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURZMANN, SAM
description: KURZMANN - Sam. Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Betty on the loss of her husband. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Charlie Feathers, 66, a Rockabilly Original
description: Charlie Feathers, one of the great original rockabilly singers, died on Aug. 29 at St. Francis Hospital in Memphis. He was 66 and lived in Memphis.

title: Former Hospital Druggist Sentenced in Theft
description: The former director of the pharmacy at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center was sentenced on Wednesday to one year and one day in prison for stealing about $58,000 worth of cancer-fighting drugs and other prescription medicines and selling them for cash, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; The Fire Inside Of Clemens
description: ON the Toronto scoreboard before the game against Detroit on June 3, the starting pitchers were listed along with their season records. For the Blue Jays, it read, ''Roger Clemens, 5 wins 6 losses, 3.50 earned run average.''

title: The Power of the Word In Darting Flames of Gold
description: Words are everywhere in Islamic art. Verses from the the Koran wind around the domes of mosques and fill the pages of books. Blessings are carved on tombstones and inscribed on lamps and bowls; charms are stitched into fabrics and written in henna on the palms of hands

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Hope Sandrow

title: Dancing Horses
description: Zingaro, the troupe that choreographs for humans and horses, is back in Manhattan for a two-month stay at Battery Park City. In ''Eclipse,'' the French equestrian company's new show, the horses are in great form, offering brilliantly improbable magic under the spell of Bartabas, the troupe's founder.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Fuji Bank Denies a Report of Big Losses
description: Fuji Bank said today that it currently had no actual losses from derivatives trading, denying recent rumors that it had lost large sums of money.

title: Primakov Well Known and Respected by U.S.
description: The Clinton Administration today welcomed the nomination of Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov as Russia's next Prime Minister, with officials describing him as a sure-footed survivor whose appointment could help defuse a political and economic crisis that had threatened to bring down President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: G.E. Introduces Faster Medical Scanner
description: Amid much hoopla, the General Electric Company introduced a medical scanner yesterday that it says captures images of the inner workings of a patient's body in seconds, not minutes.

title: Connecticut's Congressional Primary
description: In Connecticut's First Congressional District, the Democratic nomination is tantamount to election. History also suggests that once elected, an incumbent will stay put for a very long time. So this year's primary fight is an important one. Four candidates, all with considerable experience in state government, are running to succeed Representative Barbara Kennelly. The field includes Secretary of State Miles Rapoport, John Larson, the former president pro tem of the State Senate, Joe Suggs, a former State Treasurer and ex-Mayor of Bloomfield, and State Representative Jim McCavanagh.

title: Northwest and Pilots Union Gain Tentative Accord in Labor Fight
description: Negotiators for Northwest Airlines and its pilots union reached a tentative agreement yesterday to settle a 13-day strike that has disrupted travel in the Midwest and South.

title: Panel Asks Off-Duty Police Not to Mix Guns and Drinks
description: Shedding a spotlight on the abuse of alcohol by off-duty police officers, a mayoral commission urged the Police Department yesterday to prohibit officers from carrying their guns when they drink when not on the job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOBUE, JOSEPH
description: LOBUE-Joseph. Of N.Y.C. on September 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Ellen (nee Coffman). Devoted father of Joseph. Dear brother of Ann Harriman and Salvatore. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home 148 Dean Drive Tenafly, N.J. on Friday 3 to 5 & 7 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30AM St. Cecilia Church Englewood. Interment private. Memorials to American Cancer Society.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about small businesses in South Korea misstated the name of one such company. It is the Chang An Global Company, not Chang On.

title: First Lady Draws a Large Audience as the President Draws Religious Advice
description: President Clinton is seeking solace and forgiveness wherever he can find it, liberally spreading his contrition around to politicians and preachers alike. Hillary Rodham Clinton is dealing with her pain and her fury in private, but she betrayed a glimpse of her anger at a White House appearance today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNBAUM, GLENN
description: BERNBAUM-Glenn. Mr. Bernbaum-a dear funny, knowledgeable, man. I will miss our verbal jousts and you. Bruce Sobol

title: Treasury Yields Plummet on Expectations of Rate Cut by Fed
description: The prices of Treasury securities leaped yesterday, sending the yields on 10-year notes and 30-year bonds down to levels not seen since 1967. The decline shows that investors are betting that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates, a move that could help stabilize stock markets here and abroad.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Flanagan Trio Takes Care Of the Details
description: It's rare to look forward to bass solos in jazz. But in Tommy Flanagan's trio, a bass solo from Peter Washington initiates an attenuated routine on the music's lower level in which the pianist Mr. Flanagan plays hide-and-seek with the drummer Lewis Nash. They accompany Mr. Washington's improvisation separately in small, neat embellishments, then link up on a little riff; one or the other echoes the idea that was just played, expands on it, and it's wrapped up with a postlude. And this is all the background to what you're supposed to be listening to.

title: State Investigates Newark Power Failure
description: State regulators said yesterday that they were investigating whether Public Service Electric & Gas misled them about the cause of a power failure at Newark International Airport on Tuesday and whether laws governing excavation near the company's utility lines were violated.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Iran Issues Warning To Afghan Leaders
description: Iran said it would hold the militant Taliban movement that controls most of neighboring Afghanistan responsible for the deaths of nine Iranian diplomats whose bodies were recovered there yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Interest Rates Slide As Stock Prices Tumble

title: CNS and Real Media Name Agencies
description: Two companies named agencies yesterday for their accounts.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Thomas Demand

title: L.I. Power Authority Gives Final Approval to Rebates
description: For the one million customers of the old Long Island Lighting Company, the checks are almost in the mail.

title: A Jauntier, Less Reverential Gershwin
description: The music of George Gershwin is so encrusted with reverence nowadays that when singers perform his songs they sometimes lose sight of the jaunty, lighthearted spirit in which they were conceived. Their effervescence doesn't mean that these songs aren't exquisitely constructed little works of art. It does mean that finding their essence involves lightening up and rediscovering the ease, naturalness and pulsing fluency of songs that often have the feel of saucy musical banter.

title: Clinton Should Resign, 2 Religious Leaders Say
description: In a sign that President Clinton's approval among clergy members is eroding in the wake of the Monica Lewinsky scandal, two leading religious figures in New York -- one Protestant and one Jewish -- said in interviews yesterday that Mr. Clinton had lost his moral authority and ought to resign.

title: German Inflation Rate Reaches 8-Year Low
description: Consumer prices in Germany fell one-tenth of 1 percent in August and advanced eight-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, the Federal Statistics Office said yesterday, as the annual inflation rate hit its lowest level since reunification in 1990.

title: Little Drop in College Binge Drinking
description: A sequel to a landmark national study of binge drinking among college students has found that despite efforts at education and discipline, binge drinking around campuses dropped just slightly from 1993 to 1997, Harvard researchers said today.

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: The Schumer Record; Schumer Viewed as Relentless, Ambitious Legislator
description: When he decided 17 months ago to formally enter the Democratic primary for the United States Senate, Representative Charles E. Schumer brought with him ample reserves of the frenetic energy that has both irritated and impressed his Washington colleagues, a recurring role as vocal gadfly to the Republicans who have run the House of Representatives since 1994, and a substantial legislative record.

title: Leo Burnett Takes 10 Golden Marbles
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago won the most awards, 10, at the first presentation of the Golden Marble Awards for creative excellence in advertising to children.

title: Code Words For a Noted Sale
description: An 1889 self-portrait that van Gogh made as a 70th-birthday present for his mother, Anna Cornelia Carbent van Gogh, and that experts believe is the last self-portrait he painted before his death in 1890 will be sold at Christie's in New York on Nov. 19. It is estimated to bring $20 million to $25 million.

title: Leiter Cruises, but Mets Almost Blow a Bullpen Tire
description: The question put to Al Leiter after he had just picked up his 15th victory of the season was only half in jest. It was a question of location.

title: A Manic-Depressive Market Befuddles Even the Professionals
description: Investors in the stock market have to be ready for ups and downs. Everybody knows that. But who was prepared for the market's manic-depressive mood swings of the last few weeks? And what do the increasingly violent moves in stocks mean for the market over all?

title: Mexico's Central Bank Fails in Attempt to Prop Up Peso
description: The central bank waded into Mexican currency markets today in a dramatic new intervention, selling nearly $500 million in dollars and tightening cash in circulation in an unsuccessful effort to support the peso, which was pressured by new panic selling in the stock market.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; The Right to Evidence
description: To the Editor:

title: Hardy's Tess, Still at the Mercy of Men
description: Thomas Hardy, one of the last great Victorian novelists, didn't die until 1928, well into the age of movies. And as early as the 1870's his novels displayed qualities that seem ready-made for the screen: the picturesque rural backdrop, inspired by the Dorset countryside where he was born in 1840; drama so outsized it verges on melodrama; characters so complex, so trapped by fate and social convention that they still speak passionately to us today.

title: What's All the Talk About? (Hint: It's Not the Weather)
description: When Jazz (Troy Beyer), an advice columnist for a Miami newspaper, pitches her idea for a television show in which women talk frankly about their sex lives, the local station manager brusquely informs her that a description isn't enough; she must submit a sample program.

title: FIRST CONSULTING TO BUY INTEGRATED SYSTEMS CONSULTING
description: First Consulting GroupInc. agreed late on Wednesday to acquire Integrated Systems Consulting Group Inc. for stock valued at $123.8 million. First Consulting, based in Long Beach, Calif., said each outstanding Integrated Systems share would be exchanged at a rate of 0.77 for a First Consulting common share. First Consulting's stock fell $1.1875, to $16.25, while the stock of Integrated Systems, based in Wayne, Pa., gained 75 cents, to $11.125.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ABRAMS, LOUIS G.
description: ABRAMS-Louis G. Lovingly remembered, will never be forgotten. Libby E.

title: As Ruble Flip-Flops, Russians See a Trick
description: Russians, long accustomed to uncertainty, have a saying: ''Tomorrow's weather will be announced the day after tomorrow.''

title: House Panel Blocks New Funds for I.M.F.
description: Rejecting pleas by the Administration, a key House committee voted today against full financing for the International Monetary Fund.

title: A 150-Mile Voyage by Canal
description: ''Lock 25, Lock 25, Lock 25. This is the vessel Onondaga requesting westbound passage. Over.''

title: Moya Barrels Along on Confidence
description: Carlos Moya, the 1998 French Open champion, checked his confidence meter two weeks ago and experienced a rude awakening. It was empty. With the United States Open around the corner, he estimated his chances of survival to be next to none, especially if he let his thoughts wander to last year when he lost in the first round.

title: Metro Business; Nymagic Loses Two Chiefs
description: Nymagic Inc., an insurer based in New York, has fired its chairman, John N. Blackman Jr., saying that disagreements with his brother, the company's president, kept Nymagic from operating effectively. His brother, Mark W. Blackman, resigned.

title: EATING OUT
description: South American

title: The Arab-Jew Gulf, Seen Closed and Starkly Open
description: Before dawn today, a convoy of ambulances some with a red crescent on the side, some with the Star of David -- raced through southern Gaza to a hospital. In the aftermath of a bus accident, Palestinian and Israeli medics worked side by side to treat and transport about 50 injured Palestinian workers.

title: Beware The Bald Barber
description: Ever hear of intro-hair disorder?

title: Ankle Sprain Doesn't Slow Armstead's Resolve to Play
description: While his teammates ran through drills on different parts of the Meadowlands practice field today, Jessie Armstead stood behind them, limping as he lined up rows of padded obstacles, gingerly trying to push himself into motion, despite the pain in his sprained right ankle.

title: New Zealand Company Reports a Big Loss
description: Brierley Investments Ltd., New Zealand's fifth-largest public company, said yesterday that it had posted a loss for only the second time in its 37-year history after writing off 15 percent of its assets because of poor investments. The company took a charge of $1.19 billion (New Zealand), or $605 million (United States), mainly for investments made in the United States and Asia. For the year, Brierley lost $904 million (New Zealand), or $459 million (United States).

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Allies Cling To Results Of Surveys
description: Pointing to a diagram showing that most Americans think the country is on ''the right track,'' Mark Penn, the President's pollster, sought today to reassure gathered Democratic donors by inundating them with survey data.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Lesson on Accountability
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Aug. 18 about a performance of the Liturgy of St. John Chrysostom by Tchaikovsky at the Bard Music Festival in Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., misidentified a bass. He was Andre Papkov, not Nicholas Mokhoff.

title: Women Who Won in '92 Are Now Under Pressure
description: There is a grim joke current among Senators Barbara Boxer, Carol Moseley-Braun and Patty Murray, three of the celebrated winners of the Year of the Woman elections of 1992, when the notion that some male politicians ''just don't get it'' helped drive these women's victory campaigns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKERMAN, SARA
description: ZUCKERMAN-Sara. Young Israel of Harrison mourns the passing of Sara Zuckerman, beloved mother of its devoted member, Karen Fragin, and extends its heartfelt condolences to Karen and Gary and their children. Yaakov Bienenfeld, Rabbi Ed Leventhal, President

title: Walter Adams, 78, Expert on Corporate Power and Antitrust Issues, Dies
description: Walter Adams, an antitrust expert whose concerns about concentrations of corporate power helped shape Government policy for three decades, died Tuesday at his home in East Lansing, Mich., according to a statement from Michigan State University, where he taught for 46 years. He was 78 years old.

title: Burned Twice or Not, Williams Is a Keeper
description: On a depleted Jets defense that suddenly raises questions and will tax the brainpower of even the redoubtable defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick, who is devising schemes for Sunday's meeting with the Ravens, Kevin Williams is trying to make his way.

title: Classics of the 60's Revisited With the Composer's Vision
description: There is no better way to discern the essence of a song than to hear the composer perform it, backing himself on a piano or guitar without further accompaniment. Hearing Jimmy Webb, who wrote ''Up, Up and Away,'' ''MacArthur Park'' and ''Wichita Lineman,'' perform these 1960's hits stripped of glossy production, you have the sense that he is re-enacting the creative process that brought these songs into existence three decades ago.

title: Small Gems Amid the Biggies
description: Perusing video release schedules for the fall and winter, one finds an unusually large number of finely realized little films scattered among the more ham-fisted blockbusters. Parity may not be the word, but about a dozen critically praised and well-attended art-house movies are about to stage the same kind of modest breakout on videotape that they had during generally solid runs in theaters this spring and summer.

title: Knowing When to Hold 'em and Fold 'em but Just Not When to Run
description: Though John Dahl's ''Rounders'' finally adds up to less than meets the eye, what does meet the eye (and ear) is mischievously entertaining. Inspired by Martin Scorsese's brand of lowlife and aided by a splendid rogues' gallery of a cast, the director of ''The Last Seduction'' takes his audience behind closed doors and into the world of high-stakes poker, a demimonde captured with abundant local color. With settings that range from an Elks hall in Binghamton to a yuppie cigar bar to Russian Turkish Baths, Mr. Dahl's film has character in oversupply even if its actual characters are sometimes thin. Poker fever makes up for whatever the story lacks in everyday emotions.

title: Counsel Questions
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has just announced a 90-day preliminary investigation into whether President Clinton and others violated the criminal provisions of the Federal Election Campaign Act in 1996. If the conclusion is that they may well have, she will have to appoint an independent counsel. Fairness would require an independent investigation of both campaigns, for there was little difference in what they did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOZES, JEAN, MAX.
description: MOZES-Jean-Max. The officers and staff of Banca Commerciale Italiana mourn the tragic passing of Jean-Max Mozes. We are deeply saddened and much diminished by his loss, but so very grateful that he was a part of our lives. Giorgio Angelozzi Edward C. Bermant Claudio Marchiori

title: Criticism Is Undeserved, Residents Say
description: Nestled in the marshes of Jamaica Bay far from the bustle of the city, the island community of Broad Channel has 1,600 residents, one elementary school and a volunteer fire department with a long tradition of a festive Labor Day parade.

title: Japan May Launch a Satellite In Response to North Korea's
description: Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi said today that Japan might launch its own reconnaissance satellite, a move that would improve the country's military capacity and make it easier to monitor missile deployments in North Korea.

title: Koven Loses In Sculls Semifinals
description: Jamie Koven's attempt to defend his world championship in single sculls was undone by a loose screw yesterday in Cologne, Germany. He was eliminated in the semifinals after the screw popped out of his oarlock moments into his race on Lake Fuhlingen.

title: Heads Of Wood, Hearts Of Gold
description: Let's get serious. The puppets are back in town.

title: Georges Meyer, 67, French Store Executive
description: Georges Meyer, chairman and chief executive of Galeries Lafayette S.A., one of Europe's largest department store chains, died Tuesday afternoon at his home in Paris. He was 67.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNOV, ''TIPPI'' MILDRED MARSHALL CLARKE.
description: KRASNOV-''Tippi'' Mildred Marshall Clarke. Devoted and loyal wife of Robert. Loving mother of Jonathan. Died on Wednesday, September 9 in Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. She lived life to the fullest. She will be sorely missed by all those that loved her. Family will receive friends in the Harding Funeral Home, 210 Post Rd. East, Westport, Ct Friday from 7-9PM. Memorial Services will take place Saturday, 11AM in Norfield Congregational Church, 64 Norfield Rd., Weston, Ct. In lieu of flowers, please send Memorial Contributions to Weston Education Foundation, attention Liz Stokes, PO Box 1093, Weston, CT 06883.

title: Designer Looks Back With Pain and Pride
description: IN the 1960's, the clothing designer Stan Herman was hot and then he was not, and now, sitting in his little studio overlooking Bryant Park, his voice husky from walking pneumonia, he is theorizing about it.

title: Two Innocents Trapped In an Indifferent Reality
description: Some awfully familiar buttons are pushed in ''Digging to China,'' the story of a sweetly eccentric 10-year-old girl's friendship with a sweetly eccentric 30-year-old man who happens to be mentally disabled. Although there's nothing intrinsically false about the story of these two lonely misfits forming a deep emotional bond, which the outside world views with suspicion, the movie, directed by the actor Timothy Hutton (in his debut behind the camera) from a screenplay by Karen Janszen, is entirely predictable. The moment these two innocents share their first cuddly embrace you know somebody's going to get the wrong idea. You also know that sooner or later their idyll will be rudely shattered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHECTER, JOYCE
description: SHECTER-Joyce on September 8, of Stonybrook, NY, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of Abe, devoted sister of the late Sylvia Brill, and of the late Robert E. Wiener, loving aunt of Jeff Brill, Gail Wiener and Pam Wiener. Graveside service September 11, 11:15 A.M., at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Dow Falls About 250 Points As Foreign Markets Tumble
description: The drop in stock prices accelerated yesterday as worries increased about the Clinton Presidency and the global economy.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: City of Angels

title: Venator and Sports Authority Cancel Merger
description: Venator Group Inc. and Sports Authority Inc. announced yesterday that they were canceling the merger they had agreed to in May because Venator's stock had dropped 61 percent.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; No Attack on Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, IRVIN, D.
description: GLUCK-Irvin, D. 85. Died at home on September 10. Loving husband of Eleanor Soletsky Gluck. Father of Kathy Berkman and David Gluck. Father-in-law of Andrew Berkman and Mary Sessenden. Grandfather of Emily and Benjamin Berkman and Sofi Gluck. Brother of Midi Garth. Services on Sunday, September 13, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Contributions may be made to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, New York, 11590.

title: At the Movies; Spielberg Looks To the East
description: Steven Spielberg is known for his versatility and range of interests; he's done everything now from cuddly aliens to brutal war films. But his choice of subject matter for his next movie marks quite a new turn.

title: Middletown Township Teachers End Their Weeklong Strike
description: A bitter weeklong teachers' strike at the 17 schools in this sprawling central New Jersey suburb ended this morning about an hour before a court hearing in which a judge was to consider dismissing 800 striking teachers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOGELSON, MARTIN G.
description: FOGELSON-Martin G. Attorney at Law. Beloved husband of Arlene Wisan, dear son-in-law, nephew, cousin and friend. Services Friday, 11:30 AM, ''BoulevardRiverside Chapel'', 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bringing Out The Best
description: You didn't have to be a baseball fanatic to get swept up in the emotion of watching Mark McGwire's 62d home run clear the left-field wall at Busch Stadium the other night, or seeing him skip around the bases and hug his son at home plate. But surely the emotion that so many Americans felt at this moment was not just about a great record broken, by a nice guy. No, the whole way in which McGwire and Sammy Sosa have handled themselves, and the whole way in which baseball fans have responded -- giving the baseballs back for free -- is such a reminder of how much we need role models, how sorely they are missing now, and how much good they can actually do when they appear.

title: Reaping What They've Sown
description: All parents know that children have a talent for growing. What they may not realize is that their youngsters' gift may apply to plants as well as themselves. Adults will see just how green small thumbs can be at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden Harvest Fair, which plans to celebrate 250 young gardeners tomorrow. All have participated in the Children's Garden Program, growing vegetables at the botanical garden.

title: Yeltsin Bows to Pressure; Picks Compromise Figure
description: Bowing out of a confrontation with his emboldened opposition, President Boris N. Yeltsin today named Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov, architect of Russia's hard-line foreign policy, as his compromise candidate to lead a new Government as Prime Minister.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Educating Barbie'

title: Clinton Foe Admits Affair With Married Man
description: After criticizing President Clinton for the ''sordid spectacle'' of an extramarital affair and airing a campaign advertisement in which she says that ''personal conduct and integrity does matter,'' Representative Helen Chenoweth of Idaho admitted today that she had engaged in a long-term affair with a married man.

title: Foreign Policy Expert With Little Economics
description: In selecting Yevgeny M. Primakov for Prime Minister, President Boris N. Yeltsin has picked a wily diplomat and steely opponent of American dominance.

title: Web Sites Fear Busy Signals on Report
description: Distributing the Whitewater independent counsel's report on the World Wide Web on Friday might cause an electronic traffic jam that could leave many readers with the Internet's equivalent of a busy signal.

title: Rangers Interested in Deal for Penguins' Jagr
description: Seeking to add attacking power and return to the Stanley Cup playoffs, the Rangers are aiming high. They hope to trade with the Pittsburgh Penguins for Jaromir Jagr, the National Hockey League's reigning scoring champion.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Sidney Goodman

title: Semiconductor Giants' Outlook Is Upbeat
description: After warning investors in recent weeks that earnings would be hurt by economic turmoil in Asia and other markets, two giants of the semiconductor industry offered slightly more upbeat announcements today suggesting an improved outlook.

title: Not Giving Up on Campaign Reform
description: After two days of debate, a clear majority of 52 senators again demonstrated yesterday that they favor legislation to ban ''soft money'' and clean up the nation's corrupt election fund-raising system. Unfortunately, those 52 votes were not enough to shut down a filibuster engineered by Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader. As a result, John McCain of Arizona, the leading Republican sponsor of campaign reform, withdrew his bill and seems ready to give up this year. Abandoning the cause now would be a mistake. Campaign reform should be reintroduced again and again to dramatize its urgency and raise pressure on holdout senators.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Augustus, Not Aeneas
description: To the Editor:

title: JONES APPAREL PLANS TO PURCHASE SUN APPAREL
description: The Jones Apparel Group Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the clothing maker Sun Apparel Inc., which holds the license for Polo Jeans Company clothing, for $212 million in cash and stock. Jones, based in New York, which makes women's clothing for Ralph Lauren labels, is buying the closely held Sun for $125 million in cash and 4.8 million shares valued at about $87 million. It will also assume $232 million in debt. The purchase will add to Jones's substantial Ralph Lauren lines, which have been among its fastest-selling products this year.

title: Austria Moves Toward Returning Artworks Confiscated by Nazis
description: Senior ministers of the Austrian Government today sent a draft law on the restitution of art confiscated by the Nazis to Parliament and said they expected that some paintings, furniture and other objects would be returned to their rightful owners by the end of the year.

title: UTILICORP RAISES STAKE IN NEW ZEALAND POWER COMPANY
description: Utilicorp United Inc., the sixth-largest electric utility in the United States, said yesterday that it would pay $206 million to increase its stake in Power New Zealand Ltd., ending a four-year battle for control of the New Zealand electric company. Utilicorp, based in Kansas City, Mo., said its Utilicorp N.Z. Inc. subsidiary would increase its ownership of Power New Zealand to 78.6 percent from 37.5 percent. Utilicorp will buy shares from Mercury Energy Ltd., New Zealand's largest electricity retailer, and WEL Energy Group Ltd. In 1997, Utilicorp and Mercury agreed to drop competing hostile bids for Power New Zealand and submit a joint offer. But the two companies were not able to come to terms on creating a joint venture.

title: Raising Not Just the Decibel Level but Awareness for Tibet
description: As good causes go, surely Tibet ranks high among those who cherish liberty. Since the early 1950's, the country's nonviolent culture has been subjugated by China, which ended less than 40 years of Tibetan independence and reasserted claims of sovereignty that extended back several centuries. As a result, the Dalai Lama lives in exile in India with thousands of refugees. And Buddhist monks and nuns attest to imprisonment, torture, beatings, rapes and executions by the Chinese.

title: Eating and Hoping at the Concord; Kosher Hotel's Friends Await Bankruptcy Court Ruling
description: At the last meal of the season in the Concord Resort Hotel's 3,000-seat dining room, Table C-8, always the loudest, was even louder than usual.

title: It's a Whole New Ball Game; Get Over It, Scrooges
description: There's a plague in the land, and it's spreading. Scrooges are jumping out of the bushes, kicking Tiny Tim's crutches out from under him. In this case, the crutches are the bats of Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa, and the Scrooges are people who are already belittling their prodigious feats.

title: Rattling Montezuma's Halls
description: For Americans, the main significance of the Mexican-American War was the vast enlargement of the United States, an addition of 500,000 square miles of Western lands all the way from Kansas to the Pacific. Mexicans saw it differently, as a sheer land grab. Though ''The U.S.-Mexican War (1846-1848)'' celebrates American prowess, it also acknowledges the Mexican claims and what the expanding nation's takeover of the Western lands meant for the Indians in the way.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; How to Restore Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Opportunities In Chinese Furniture
description: The conventional wisdom about Chinese furniture could be a variant of Duke Ellington's 1932 song about swing: ''It don't mean a thing if it ain't got that Ming.'' Collectors have long focused on furniture of the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644) in two varieties of rosewood: huanghuali and zitan. The Chinese period room at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, for example, is the Ming Room, and it is full of such hardwoods.

title: STARR REPORT IS SAID TO CLAIM PERJURY AND ABUSE OF POWER BY PRESIDENT IN LEWINSKY CASE
description: The report sent to Congress by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, contends that evidence shows President Clinton committed perjury, obstructed justice, tampered with witnesses and abused the power of his office in trying to cover up an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, lawyers familiar with the report said today.

title: A British agency comes to New York seeking a car, an airline and fast-moving consumer goods.
description: AN upstart British agency with a reputation for quirky, cheeky work is making its long-awaited entry into the United States advertising market by opening an office in New York to be led by an Anglo-American executive team.

title: Excerpts from Apologies by Clinton
description: Since President Clinton's address to the nation last month, in which he acknowledged having had an inappropriate relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, he has spoken several times about his regrets and remorse. Following are excerpts from those statements.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Moscow Madness From the Inside; Investment Bank That Rode Boom Now Faces Bust
description: The gleaming marble and glass headquarters of MFK Renaissance, one of Russia's leading investment banks, stands as tangible evidence of the financial gold rush that briefly swept through here. Limousines still park by the firm's front doors, which abut the offices of Moscow's pre-eminent power broker, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov -- quite a change from just three years ago, when MFK Renaissance operated from the spare confines of a former hotel disco.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Teachers' Guide
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Guidelines Set For Random Drug Tests
description: The state Attorney General issued a set of guidelines yesterday allowing all law-enforcement officers to be tested at random for illegal drug use.

title: Way Out West, Whitman Says She's Content In New Jersey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is not asked the question very much these days at home. But here in California, where she is trying to help Republican candidates raise money and broaden their appeal to women and swing voters, the question about her own aspirations gets asked at every campaign stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBLUD, RUTH
description: WERBLUD-Ruth. On September 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Nathan Werblud. Loving mother of Maurice Werblud and Pauline Grubin. Also survived by four grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Reposing at Riverside Funeral Home, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City. Service will be held at noon Friday, September 11, 1998.

title: Diner's Journal
description: From the outside, La Fourchette does not look promising. The new restaurant occupies one of those anonymous new buildings that have taken root in Yorkville, and nothing about the facade prepares you for the luxurious elegance of the dining room.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the dismissal of a lawsuit against Intuit Inc. over software problems with the year 2000 misstated when the suit was filed. It was April, not late last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPATZ, DOROTHY (NEE STUART).
description: SPATZ-Dorothy (nee Stuart). On Sept. 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Loving mother of Stuart. Cherished grandmother of Steven, Christine, and Valerie. Great Grandmother of Cambrea. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Friday 7-9 and Saturday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Religious service on Sunday at 12 PM at the Funeral Home. Interment Christ Churchyard, Manhasset.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, GEORGE M.
description: SHAPIRO-George M. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family notes with sorrow the passing of our friend, George M. Shapiro. As past President of the Baron Edmond Rothschild Foundation, George was an important philanthropic supporter of the Medical Center. We will miss his encouragement and are grateful for his steadfast commitment to numerous innovative health care programs at Beth Israel. To his wife Rita, his daughter Karen, and all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D. Pres. and CEO.

title: Cinch It Here, Pouf It There: Still Draped in the 18th Century
description: If you think the 18th century is over, you're hopelessly out of date. Such has been the impact on fashion of the elegant, extravagant pre-industrial era in which aristocratic taste prevailed that it reverberates through the clothes of the 19th and 20th centuries and may never go away. That, at least, is the thesis of a scintillating new show, ''The Ceaseless Century: 300 Years of 18th-Century Costume,'' at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWLER, MARJORIE B.
description: LAWLER-Marjorie B. On June 16, 1998, age 85, of Newtown Square, PA, formerly of Lake San Marcos, CA, & Sleepy Hollow, NY, wife of the late Arthur P. Lawler, mother of Robert Lawler (Strafford, PA), Penny Lawler Dean (Toronto, Canada), Christopher Lawler (Oakland, N.J.), grandmother of Gretchen, Timothy, Elizabeth, Alison, Ben and Kate, sister of Eileen Orton and John Butler, both of Austin, TX, and sister-in-law of Martha Reynolds Lawler (NYC) & Nancy Butler (Long Island, NY). A memorial service & interment will take place at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, Rte. 9-A, Sleepy Hollow, NY, Saturday, Sept. 19, 10:30AM. Private reception will follow the burial. Memorial contributions to Metropolitan Opera Assn., Lincoln Center, New York, N.Y. 10023.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Apologize to the Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Is Proposed To Cap Tuition Rates
description: In an effort to curb rising tuition rates at state colleges and universities, the Senate minority leader, Richard J. Codey, proposed a bill yesterday that would cap annual increases in college operating costs at 3 percent or at the consumer price index, whichever is greater.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSMAN, MENDEL
description: WACHSMAN - Mendel. Lincoln Square Synagogue records with sorrow the passing of Mr. Mendel Wachsman, beloved father of our esteemed Board member and benefactor, Bernard Wachsman. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Adam Mintz, Rabbi Richard Kestenbaum, President

title: Gotti's Son and Co-Defendants Are Said to Reject Plea Deals
description: Federal prosecutors have offered plea-bargaining deals to John A. Gotti, the reputed Mafia leader, and his co-defendants in a major racketeering case, but the proposal has been rejected by Mr. Gotti, lawyers and investigators close to the case said yesterday.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 14.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Deficit Soars to Another Record
description: The nation's trade deficit in goods, services and investments widened to a record $56.525 billion in the second quarter, the Commerce Department said today. Net foreign purchases of Treasury securities increased as international investors shifted out of United States stocks.

title: X-ceed Acquires Mercury Seven
description: X-ceed Inc. in New York has acquired Mercury Seven Inc. in New York, a development and consulting company that specializes in on-line services for Internet industry professionals. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOTT, MATTHEW THOMPSON.
description: SCOTT-Matthew Thompson. The officers and staff of Banca Commerciale Italiana mourn the tragic passing of Matthew Scott. We are deeply saddened and much diminished by his loss, but so very grateful that he was a part of our lives. Giorgio Angelozzi Edward C. Bermant Claudio Marchiori

title: Malaysia Hires Salomon as Bank Adviser
description: The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, who has blamed foreigners for his nation's economic and financial troubles, unexpectedly named Salomon Smith Barney as a special adviser today to help repair the country's ailing banks.

title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Gerald Ford's Remark
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Bili Bidjocka, Los Carpinteros and Rivane Neuenschwander

title: Delacroix, That Skeptical Romantic
description: Visitors to Pere Lachaise Cemetery in Paris are sometimes struck that Delacroix's grave is a gray granite box of neo-classical design. The tomb of his friend Chopin, with its weepy muse and lyre, seems, more appropriately, Romantic by comparison, and it attracts a stream of admirers who leave flowers, candles and throat lozenges. No one hangs around Delacroix's grave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIDEL, CAROL H.
description: KRIDEL-Carol H., 78. September 8, at home. She was the widow of William J. Kridel. She is survived by her son, William J. Kridel, Jr, of London and New York, and by her daughter, Linda K. Smith, of Beloit, Wisconsin, and by three grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), Sunday, September 13 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Palliative Care Program, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029, or to The Collegiate School, 370 West End Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

title: Life Is a Carousel, a Dark One
description: For a few minutes on Wednesday night, I thought Jim Henson had come back to life. There were puppets onstage at the Public Theater with the irresistible combination of heart-tugging cuteness and everybody-dies edge. But the story's setting was some Weimar-like republic, newly ruled by a group called the Common Good, and the humor was an intertwining of the political and the sexual that evoked the dark essence of ''Cabaret.'' There were a lot of four-letter words. No Muppets need apply.

title: Shift in Cow Feed May Make Beef Safer
description: Microbiologists at Cornell University have found a way to virtually rid cattle of harmful strains of E. coli bacteria, including the bacteria that have caused scores of deaths and sickened thousands of consumers of undercooked hamburgers.

title: Thousands in Streets of Phnom Penh Cheer for Peace
description: In an extraordinary and largely spontaneous outpouring that took this battered city by surprise, thousands of people surged through the streets today clapping, cheering and chanting over and over, ''Hooray for peace!''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Sosa Gets 59th Homer But Milwaukee Wins
description: BREWERS 13, CUBS 11

title: Check Out These Birds: They're Not Winking
description: When is a pink lawn flamingo just a pink lawn flamingo?

title: A Flawed Achievement in Bosnia
description: The Dayton peace agreements nearly three years ago ended the savage killing in Bosnia. That was a proud achievement, but Dayton promised more than just a respite from violence. The United States and its European partners set out to promote a multiethnic democracy in Bosnia that could become a reliable foundation for lasting peace. As Bosnia's second round of postwar elections unfold this weekend, the results of that effort look disappointing.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Thirteen of Thirteen
description: XI. There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton's actions since January 17, 1998, regarding his relationship with Monica Lewinsky have been inconsistent with the President's constitutional duty to faithfully execute the laws. Before, during, and after his January 17, 1998, civil deposition, the President attempted to conceal the truth about his relationship with Ms. Lewinsky from the judicial process in the Jones case. Furthermore, the President has since lied under oath to the grand jury and facilitated the provision of false information to the grand jury by others.

title: Judge Tells 2 in Louima Case Of Lawyers' Possible Conflicts
description: A Federal judge yesterday warned two police officers accused of brutalizing Abner Louima at a Brooklyn station house in 1997 that there was a risk they might not get the best possible defense if they kept their lawyers because of ''actual or potential conflicts of interest'' that the lawyers have in the case.

title: A Bug Turns Up in U.S.-China Trade Relations
description: To halt the invasion of a devastating insect pest, the United States said today that it would ban the import of all Chinese goods shipped in raw wood packing material, a move that is likely to strain China's economy -- as well as United States-China relations.

title: After Just Missing Playoffs, Liberty Dismisses Its Coach
description: Three weeks after the Liberty lost its last regular-season game and thus failed to make the Women's National Basketball Association playoffs, its coach paid the price. Despite winning records of 17-11 and 18-12 in the league's two seasons, the Liberty dismissed Nancy Darsch yesterday.

title: The Gullible Groundskeeper
description: It's lucky for the National Baseball Hall of Fame that Mark McGwire's 62d home run didn't land in my lap. If it had, I'd have sold that thing to the highest bidder before the game was over.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Four of Thirteen
description: IV. April 1996: Ms. Lewinsky's Transfer to the Pentagon

title: Can Remediation Plan Save CUNY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Black Youth Rally Was Hardly a Riot; The Right to Speak
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bleak 'Tosca' Set In the Fascist 1930's
description: One of the primary goals of Paul Kellogg, the general and artistic director of the New York City Opera, is to give his company an identity distinct from that of his Lincoln Center neighbor, the Metropolitan Opera. And however one feels about the City Opera's new production of Puccini's ''Tosca,'' which opened the season on Thursday night, Mr. Kellogg has certainly achieved his goal.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Ten of Thirteen
description: A. There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton lied under oath when he testified that he could not specifically recall instances in which he was alone with Monica Lewinsky.

title: When Being a Newcomer Can Confuse the Opponents
description: Inexperienced players sometimes claim that the fact that they do not know what they are doing will confuse the opponents. This is rarely true, but it was, in a sense, on the diagramed deal played in a money game in May at the Regency Club, at 15 East 67th Street in Manhattan. None of the players were in the least inexperienced, but South was a newcomer in the game and had no idea how to respond when his partner overcalled one heart with one no-trump.

title: In Second Year, Charter Schools Continue to Gain in New Jersey
description: Nine months ago, Beth Mackin, a teacher at the new Gateway Charter School, did not know whether there would be a school to come back to after the Christmas break. The principal had just resigned. The only other teacher had been fired a month before. The school's part-time nurse and a computer consultant had decided to quit, too.

title: APPLIED EXTRUSION SHARES CLIMB ON SWEETENED BID
description: The shares of Applied Extrusion Technologies Inc. jumped yesterday after the Huntsman Packaging Corporation increased an earlier buyout offer for the plastics maker to $12.50 a share, or about $138 million. The shares rose $1.375, to $9.50, in Nasdaq trading. Applied Extrusion, the second-largest United States maker of plastics used for soda bottle labels and snack-food packages, last month rejected Huntsman's offer of $10.50 a share, or $117 million, saying it was in shareholders' best interest to stay independent. The new offer was announced after the close of United States trading on Thursday. Extrusion is based in Peabody, Mass.

title: Terrorism's New (and Very Old) Face; It's Not the Kind of War the West Fights Well
description: In some ways, Osama bin Laden is a thoroughly modern terrorist. He announces his intentions on CNN, directs his worldwide financial network by satellite telephone and sends messages to his supporters in Saudi Arabia via cassette tapes.

title: ELBIT MEDICAL IMAGING IS SELLING PIECES OF BUSINESS
description: Elbit Medical Imaging Ltd., a company based in Israel, said yesterday that it would sell pieces of its medical diagnostic imaging business to two buyers for about $375 million in cash. Elbit will sell its computed tomography division to Picker International Inc., a unit of the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain, for $275 million. Picker, based in Cleveland, said it was looking to expand its presence in CT scanning, which lets physicians look at cross sections of internal human anatomy, in several markets around the world. The medical systems unit of the General Electric Company of Fairfield, Conn., will buy Elbit's nuclear medicine and magnetic resonance imaging businesses for about $100 million to bolster its own product lines. The two General Electrics are not related.

title: The Primary for Attorney General
description: The race for the Democratic nomination for attorney general seems to have been conducted well below the public's radar screen, which is too bad. It is an important post, and New York has seldom seen as good a group of candidates, with such strong qualifications for the office they seek.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Party Battle Lines Begin to Emerge
description: Republicans and Democrats alike said today that while there was no single stunning revelation, they were deeply distressed by graphic and extensive details in the report by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Thugs Attack Demonstrators In Cambodia; One Shot Dead
description: A band of pro-Government thugs beat and shot at opposition demonstrators today and the military warned of stronger action, saying it could not allow what it called the ''worrying anarchy'' of the continuing opposition protests.

title: Mexico Drug Trafficker Slain; Major Figure Near U.S. Border
description: Rafael Munoz Talavera, who fought for control of a major drug cartel after he was freed from charges of being the master smuggler behind the largest cocaine seizure in history, was found slain on Thursday, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ENGLER, GEORGE J.
description: ENGLER-George J. Sept 12, 1910-Jan 1, 1992 Dearest DreadNaught Forever cherished

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Nine of Thirteen
description: GROUNDS

title: STARR FINDS A CASE FOR IMPEACHMENT IN PERJURY, OBSTRUCTION, TAMPERING
description: In a scathing report released today, the Whitewater independent counsel built a case for impeachment of President Clinton on an avalanche of salacious details of an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky and the Nixon-era concept of abuse of Presidential power in using aides to cover up the relationship.

title: AES ENDS DISCUSSIONS ON BID FOR HANWHA ENERGY UNIT
description: The AES Corporation, the biggest United States power plant developer, has broken off talks to buy the power business of the Hanwha Energy Company of South Korea because of a dispute over the terms of the $873 million investment, Hanwha officials said yesterday. If the investment is scrapped, it would set back Hanwha's attempt to pare debt and South Korea's efforts to attract foreign investment. Dennis Bakke, chief executive of AES, based in Arlington, Va., said the company had called off the investment ''for now.'' The transaction is foundering over conditions AES set in May for its $643.8 million payment for Hanwha's energy business with an additional $230 million investment to complete a power plant.

title: Black Youth Rally Was Hardly a Riot; Hatred, Not Unity
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALZ, HERMAN
description: SALZ-Herman. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Sr. Rabbi Geoffrey J. Colvin, Ch. of the Bd. Paul S. Schreiber, President

title: Corrections
description: An illustration in Circuits on Thursday with a column about a new computer game called Hedz was published in error. It came from the Web site for Gamespot, an Internet magazine; the image was not taken directly from the game.

title: State Gets $97 Million Welfare-to-Work Grant
description: The Federal Government announced yesterday that it was awarding a $96.9 million grant to New York State to help welfare recipients make the transition to regular jobs.

title: Ellis R. Kerley Is Dead at 74; A Forensic Sherlock Holmes
description: Dr. Ellis R. Kerley, a forensic anthropologist whose expertise was widely sought in identifying human remains, including those of the Nazi war criminal Josef Mengele and victims of the Jonestown suicides in Guyana, died on Sept. 3 at a hospice in San Diego. He was 74 and lived in Lake San Marcos, Calif.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Ten of Thirteen
description: A. There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton lied under oath when he testified that he could not specifically recall instances in which he was alone with Monica Lewinsky.
