description: XIV. January 17, 1998-Present: The Deposition and Afterward

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Sept. 4 about excursions to Sagamore Hill, the rambling Oyster Bay estate of Theodore Roosevelt on Long Island, misstated his relationship to Eleanor Roosevelt. She was his niece, not his cousin.

title: Mets Are Waiting for Olerud
description: The suspense is over for John Olerud, who became a first-time father Thursday night when his wife, Kelly, gave birth to a 9-pound, 4-ounce boy named Garrett John Olerud, the inverted form of the Met first baseman's given and middle names.

title: Clinton's Legacy: Nosy Media, Chaste Candidates; Lawyers Misjudged
description: To the Editor:

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Seven of Thirteen
description: XII. December 19, 1997 - January 4, 1998: The Subpoena

title: Observer; Mark In Paradise
description: In the course of being interviewed half-to-death this week, Mark McGwire began speculating on the next world. One of these days, he said, he hoped to meet Babe Ruth there and talk with him about hitting home runs.

title: Clinton's Legacy: Nosy Media, Chaste Candidates; Fact or Fiction?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ING GROUP, Amsterdam, a financial-services company, said it had an agreement to buy Clarion Partners L.L.C., New York, becoming the world's third-largest real estate asset manager.

title: Excerpts From White House Preliminary Response to Starr Report
description: Following are excerpts from the White House's preliminary response to the report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. It was issued today by President Clinton's lawyers before they received a copy of the report.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Thirteen of Thirteen
description: XI. There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton's actions since January 17, 1998, regarding his relationship with Monica Lewinsky have been inconsistent with the President's constitutional duty to faithfully execute the laws.

title: No. 2 Man Remains No. 1 Ally
description: At the moment of President Clinton's greatest peril in office, Al Gore was where he has always been these last six years. By the President's side.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Three of Thirteen
description: II. 1995: Initial Sexual Encounters

title: Driver Retires After 14 Seasons
description: Defenseman Bruce Driver retired, ending his 14-year career with the Rangers and Devils.

title: Was President Carrying On on the Line?
description: The report to Congress by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, contains testimony by Monica S. Lewinsky asserting that President Clinton had telephone conversations with three members of Congress and a former adviser during sexual encounters between herself and the President.

title: King David Inspires Plea For Pardon
description: In his confessional speech before a crowd of religious leaders at the White House this morning, President Clinton demonstrated his remarkable fluency with religious language.

title: Clinton Fund-Raiser Is Loyalty Test for Democratic Candidates
description: Despite anxiety among New York Democrats that President Clinton's difficulties may undermine hopes of unseating a Republican Governor and United States Senator this fall, the three major Democratic Senate candidates say they plan to appear at Mr. Clinton's side at a Manhattan fund-raiser on the eve of Tuesday's primary.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EXELBERT, MYRON
description: EXELBERT-Myron. The community of West End Synagogue grieves with the family of Myron Exelbert and extends its deepest condolences to his wife Joanne, sons Ethan, David and Jeremy, mother Esther Exelbert Weiss, and to all of his family and friends. May be his memory be for a blessing. Rabbi Avi Winokur Rabbi Yael B. Ridberg Donald Shapiro, President West End Synagogue

description: IX. October-November 1997: United Nations' Job Offer

description: V. There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton endeavored to obstruct justice by engaging in a pattern of activity to conceal evidence regarding his relationship with Monica Lewinsky from the judicial process in the Jones case. The pattern included:

title: The President, Facing Isaiah's Challenge
description: Now that the report of Kenneth Starr, the independent counsel, has been delivered to Congress, the big question is, What does the future hold for President Clinton? Will he finish his second term?

title: A Growth Spurt for Union Square Park
description: Having been transformed from a haven for drug dealers into a verdant jewel in a resurgent neighborhood, Union Square Park is about to undergo its next big transformation: a doubling of its size by turning adjacent pavement into parkland.

title: Clinton's Legacy: Nosy Media, Chaste Candidates; Prosecutors' Sacrifice
description: To the Editor:

title: Marco Rizo, 78, Cuban Pianist And Composer for 'I Love Lucy'
description: Marco Rizo, a Cuban pianist best known for composing for the ''I Love Lucy'' show, died on Tuesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Yeltsin's Choice Easily Ratified; A Shift to Left
description: Yevgeny M. Primakov handily won confirmation as Prime Minister from the Russian Parliament today, and signaled a sharp shift toward a more socialist economic model by endorsing two of the Communist Party's hand-picked candidates for top posts.

title: An Erratic Irabu Loses His Temper and the Game
description: Hideki Irabu came out of the passive funk he has been in last night, stirred to retaliate against Toronto for a perceived beanball by Roger Clemens. The tit-for-tat ignited a bench-clearing fight at Yankee Stadium, but Irabu's emotion could not solve his problems on the mound in a game the Yankees ended up losing, 5-4.

title: Armstead Vows to Play
description: Giants linebacker Jessie Armstead worked out lightly today and again insisted that he would try to play with a sprained ankle against the Oakland Raiders on Sunday, although he was aware of the risks.

title: Report Suggests Jordan Suspected Affair
description: Monica S. Lewinsky told investigators that Vernon E. Jordan Jr., a top Washington lawyer and a longtime confidant of President Clinton, directed her to destroy evidence of her relationship with Mr. Clinton, according to the Starr report made public today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISHNER, JOSEPH
description: WISHNER-Joseph. Age 101, on September 7th, 1998 in New York City. Born near Kiev, Russia, he emigrated to New York in 1906. He practiced as an orthopedic surgeon here for 70 years. A kindly and outstanding person, he will be missed. Predeceased by Rose his beloved wife of 68 years, he is survived by loving daughter June W. Snow of Portland, Maine, sister Laura Morse of Florida, four grandsons, 4 great grandchildren and cousins, nieces and nephews. Memorial service scheduled Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City, on Sunday, September 13 at 11:00 A.M.

title: Sports of The Times; Davenport's Special Skill Is Patience
description: LINDSAY DAVENPORT entered the post-match news conference last night half walking, half floating. This was in the wake of her greatest triumph and the eve of her greatest moment.

title: Gov. Weld's Successor in Massachusetts Battles for Own Term
description: Funny. Bill Weld made it look so easy.

title: UNITED DOMINION IS ADDING AMERICAN APARTMENT
description: United Dominion Realty Trust Inc. has agreed to acquire American Apartment Communities, a closely held San Francisco real estate investment trust, from a fund managed by Lazard Freres Real Estate Investors L.L.C. and other investors for about $336 million in cash and securities. The transaction, expected to close next month, will give United Dominion, a real estate trust based in Richmond, ownership of 86,000 apartments and a presence in 35 major United States markets. The purchase price consists of about 5.6 million operating partnership units, valued at $14.25 each; $200 million in convertible preferred stock, convertible into common stock at $16.25 a share, and $56 million in cash. It will also assume debt totaling $451 million.

title: Delay Is Expected in Start of Microsoft Case
description: Lawyers from the Microsoft Corporation and the Justice Department have tentatively agreed to push the date of the company's antitrust trial back to Oct. 15 from Sept. 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, IRVIN D.
description: GLUCK-Irvin D., 85. Died at home on September 10. Loving husband of Eleanor Soletsky Gluck. Father of Kathy Berkman and David Gluck. Father-in-law of Andrew Berkman and Mary Fessenden. Grandfather of Emily and Benjamin Berkman and Sofi Gluck. Brother of Midi Garth. Services on Sunday, September 13, 11:30 AM at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Contributions may be made to Hospice Care Network, 900 Merchants Concourse, Westbury, New York, 11590.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STIX, THOMAS L., JR.
description: STIX-Thomas L., Jr. BSI, ASH. Dear friend and benefactor, we will keep your memory green. The Adventuresses of Sherlock Holmes

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE PRICES FALL. Coffee futures dived 4.4 percent amid fears that Brazil will devalue its currency, prompting a wave of selling. In New York, coffee for December delivery fell 4.85 cents, to $1.0415 a pound.

title: Furtive Encounters, Recalled in Detail
description: She called him the Big Guy and smuggled presents and notes to him in the Oval Office. He told her that she made him feel young and that he loved her energy and smile.

title: In Manhattan, Third Suspect Is Held in Embassy Bombings
description: Federal authorities in Manhattan charged another suspect yesterday in a continuing investigation into terrorism in the wake of the bombings last month of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

title: Tangled Web Tangles Up the World Wide Web
description: The downloads were slow, the error messages were many, but in the first experiment in electronic communication between the United States Government and its citizens on a massive scale, millions of persevering Internet users were devouring the Starr report yesterday within hours of its release.

title: The Top Spot at Ford Is Returning to a Ford
description: One of the most storied families in American business reasserted its control over the world's second-largest company today as William Clay Ford Jr., a great-grandson of Henry Ford, was named the next chairman of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Across America, Crude Jokes and Somber Talk of Resignation
description: There were howls of laughter inside the Chicago Board of Trade, where stock traders and runners huddled around computer screens, some of them reacting to the lurid revelations as if it were mere entertainment.

title: Shame at the White House
description: Until it was measured by Kenneth Starr, no citizen -- indeed, perhaps no member of his own family -- could have grasped the completeness of President Clinton's mendacity or the magnitude of his recklessness. Whatever the outcome of the resignation and impeachment debates, the independent counsel report by Mr. Starr is devastating in one respect, and its historic mark will be permanent. A President who had hoped to be remembered for the grandeur of his social legislation will instead be remembered for the tawdriness of his tastes and conduct and for the disrespect with which he treated a dwelling that is a revered symbol of Presidential dignity.

title: Motozintla Journal; Nature's Fury Overwhelms a Mexican Backwater
description: Last Sunday afternoon, after four days of rains so relentless that even non-believers might imagine a biblical flood, the Las Canoas River abruptly rose from its bed and made for a new one.

title: Can Remediation Plan Save CUNY?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Protege of Starr, and an Established Nonfiction Writer
description: While the voluminous report released publicly today by Kenneth W. Starr is the product of many authors, much of the editing and writing was done by two lawyers, one of whom is a published author, according to the office of the independent counsel.

title: When Children Talk Crime
description: Last week Chicago prosecutors dropped charges against two boys, ages 7 and 8, who had supposedly confessed to murdering an 11-year-old girl. The confessions had been extracted by improper police interrogation, the boys' lawyers contended, and new evidence suggesting the killer was an adult seemed to back them up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, MARCELLA
description: WALDMAN-Marcella. On September 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, loving mother and mother-in-law of Grace and Jerome Schulman. Service Monday, 10:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Producer Price Index Declined 0.4% Last Month
description: Producer prices registered their largest drop in seven months during August, another indication that falling commodity prices are holding inflation at bay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNOV, ''TIPPI'' MILDRED MARSHALL CLARKE.
description: KRASNOV-''Tippi'' Mildred Marshall Clarke. Devoted and loyal wife of Robert. Loving mother of Jonathan. Died on Wednesday, September 9 in Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. She lived life to the fullest. She will be sorely missed by all those that loved her. Family will receive friends in the Harding Funeral Home, 210 Post Rd. East, Westport, Ct Friday from 7-9PM. Memorial Services will take place Saturday, 11AM in Norfield Congregational Church, 64 Norfield Rd., Weston, Ct. In lieu of flowers, please send Memorial Contributions to Weston Education Foundation, attention Liz Stokes, PO Box 1093, Weston, CT 06883.

title: Starr Puts Crimp in Coverage
description: Coverage of the independent counsel's report to Congress on President Clinton forced CBS yesterday to pre-empt the first two sets of Martina Hingis's semifinal victory over Jana Novotna at the United States Open.

title: Full Text of Findings Sent to Congress -- Part Five of Thirteen
description: VII. May 1997: Termination of Sexual Relationship

title: OFFICEMAX IS IN TALKS ABOUT A POSSIBLE COMBINATION
description: Officemax Inc., the third-largest United States retailer of office supplies, said yesterday that it was in talks about a possible combination. The company, whose stock is valued at $1.15 billion, said it stopped buying back its shares because of the preliminary discussions with the undisclosed party. That signals any transaction would probably be a pooling of interests, said Robert Willens, a Lehman Brothers accounting and tax specialist. Officemax's shares rose $2.0625, or 23 percent, to $11, as almost 5.4 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Officemax, based in Shaker Heights, Ohio, which operates 762 stores, gave no further details about the talks.

title: Starr's Aggressive Advocacy
description: The phrase runs like a grim mantra through Kenneth W. Starr's report to Congress: ''There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton . . .''

title: President Clinton's Address at the National Prayer Breakfast
description: Following is President Clinton's address today at the National Prayer Breakfast at the White House, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Rival Attacks Vallone Stand On the Right To Abortion
description: As the Democratic gubernatorial primary race entered its final weekend, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross stepped up her attacks on her major rival, Peter F. Vallone, while he drew the cloak of labor union support around him and tried to ignore the barrage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIDEL, CAROL H.
description: KRIDEL-Carol H., 78. September 8, at home. She was the widow of William J. Kridel. She is survived by her son, William J. Kridel, Jr, of London and New York, and by her daughter, Linda K. Smith, of Beloit, Wisconsin, and by three grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), Sunday, September 13 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Palliative Care Program, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029, or to The Collegiate School, 370 West End Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

title: Many Lands, One Culture
description: No, the spooky title, ''Curse on the Gypsies,'' is not meant as an unfashionable expletive. On the contrary, this two-hour documentary defends a much abused people against the bad reputation and harsh treatment they have endured in many lands over many centuries.

title: What's an Impeachable Offense? Past Is Fuzzy
description: With the House of Representatives considering whether to begin impeachment proceedings against a President for the first time in a generation, members of Congress are looking to legal and political history for standards to help them decide whether President Clinton's conduct amounted to impeachable offenses.

title: Language Is a Concern As TV Covers the Report
description: ''It's not going to get any prettier as the day goes on,'' Tom Brokaw said around 2:45 yesterday afternoon, a little more than an hour into NBC's marathon on-air coverage of details from Kenneth W. Starr's report to Congress.

title: Flight 111's Voice Recorder Is Recovered From Sea Floor
description: Navy deep sea divers recovered the cockpit voice recorder from Swissair Flight 111 today in about 180 feet of water not far from where the jet's other ''black box,'' the flight data recorder, was found on Sunday.

title: Clinton's Legacy: Nosy Media, Chaste Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Storm Drenches Texas, Flooding but Sparing Lives
description: Less than three weeks after the tropical storm Charley barged through South Texas, leaving 19 people dead from flooding, another tropical storm, Frances, swirled up the Texas Gulf Coast early today and dumped nearly a foot of rain here in the nation's fourth-largest city, turning it into a water theme park.

title: St. Patrick's Star Commits to Pirates
description: Samuel Dalembert, the 6-foot-11-inch senior center for the highly ranked St. Patrick's High School basketball team in Elizabeth, N.J., has given an oral commitment to attend Seton Hall next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, IRWIN
description: FRIEDMAN-Irwin. Beloved husband Betty. Devoted father of Marc and Sherrie, Ron and Shari, Jay and Andrea. Adored grandfather of Jodi, Jeffrey, Brandon and Remi. Services Sunday 10AM at ''Gutterman's'' (Parkside Building) 2576 Flatbush Avenue, near Avenue V, Bklyn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFENFELD, HARRY
description: LEFENFELD-Harry. Loving husband, father and grandfather whose kindness, love and humor filled the lives of those who shared life with him. An artist devoted to the joy of creation, he leaves behind a legacy of beauty and goodness. Services Sunday afternoon, Schwartz Brothers, Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORELICK, RUTH
description: GORELICK-Ruth. Of Coconut Creek, Florida, formerly Tamarac, Florida, Ellenville and Brooklyn, New York. Died on August 29th. Past President of Nachamah Group of Hadassah. Beloved wife of Murray. Loving mother of Norrie and Evan, and mother-in-law of Alis & the late Howard. Adoring grandmother of Jeremy and his wife Melissa, Michael & Stephen; and great grandmother of Carly. Dear friend, forever remembered and loved.

title: More Commuter Hassles for Brooklyn
description: The structural problems that have plagued the Williamsburg Bridge over the years will again inconvenience commuters starting in May, when city transportation officials are to suspend subway service across the bridge for roughly five months for a $150 million repair project.

title: David H. Holladay, 73, Expert in Air Safety
description: David H. Holladay, a specialist in aviation safety, died on Sept. 4 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. Mr. Holladay, a resident of Jamul, Calif., was 73.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: The New Season
description: The French call it la rentree. Americans talk of ''after Labor Day.'' In the worlds of art and entertainment it's simply the new season: a time to start afresh -- on stages and screens, in museums and music halls. A special issue of Arts & Leisure.

title: With Echoes of Watergate in the Air, House Members Take a Historic Vote
description: With memories of Watergate echoing through the chamber, the House voted today to make public the report of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, and to begin the process that could lead to the first impeachment proceedings against a President in 24 years.

title: Impeachment: The Process . . . and the History

title: Leonid Kinskey, 95, Bartender in 'Casablanca'
description: Leonid Kinskey, the Russian-born character actor best known for his portrayal of Sascha, the bartender in Rick's Cafe Americain in ''Casablanca,'' died on Tuesday in Fountain Hills, Ariz. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERMAN, ARON
description: SILBERMAN-Aron. Age 99, died September 10, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Anna Silberman; dear father of Paul and Maurice; father-in-law of Marion and Edna; loving grandfather of Joseph, Barbara and Steven, Nina, Jeremy and Alisa, Mark and Pamela; adored great grandfather of Eli, Anna, Noah and Nathaniel. He will be deeply missed. Funeral service Sunday, Sept 13, 11:30, Boulevard Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett.

title: Peacemakers in Bosnia Putting Hope in a Serb
description: It has gone pretty well for Ljubisa Savic in the six years since his paramilitary units helped take over this city in eastern Bosnia, where almost everyone who was not a Serb was terrorized, robbed, killed or expelled.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING'S OFFER FOR PRIME IS REVISED
description: The Homestake Mining Company and Prime Resources Group Inc. have agreed to a revised bid for Homestake to buy the 49.4 percent of Prime it does not own, increasing the transaction's value to $330 million. The new agreement raises the exchange ratio in the all-stock transaction to 0.74 Homestake share for each Prime share, from the 0.675 share that had been offered in May. The revised offer values each Prime share at $8.79.

title: For the Congress, the Capital and the Whole Nation, a Day for the Books
description: The day, as ominous as it was extraordinary, took a jagged tangent as the House finished its furiously partisan face-off on the question of impeaching the President. Instantly the city's focus, like the nation's, shifted to a long, salacious journey down the information highway.

title: About New York; Hard Fall Precedes Run In the Bronx
description: A YEAR and a half ago, Cynthia English's only home was the streets and subways of Brooklyn. The breakup of her 15-year marriage sent her into a depression that cost her her job, apartment and two children. When she had money, she had friends. She ate at soup kitchens, and slept in doorways or flopped at the home of a prostitute for whom she was sometimes a lookout. One night, despair was her sole possession.

title: Can Remediation Plan Save CUNY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGAN, DR. IRVING H.
description: KAGAN-Dr. Irving H., 75. Of Boca Raton, FL. & formerly of Huntington, LI, passed away September 8, 1998. Dr. Kagan was the beloved husband of Terry Kagan.

title: Mets Look Flat in Game They Needed
description: It seems that every time the Cubs win, the Mets win. So it was only natural that on a day when the Cubs lost at Wrigley Field, the Mets remained in step with their closest rival for the National League wild-card playoff spot by losing tonight to the Montreal Expos, 5-1.

title: Inquiry on Lobbying Delays Holbrooke U.N. Nomination
description: The nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as chief United States delegate to the United Nations has been delayed indefinitely while the Justice Department reviews his financial disclosure statements and investigates his contacts with former State Department colleagues after leaving the department two years ago for a job on Wall Street.

description: ALDRICH-Susan Cutler. We loved Aunt Susan and will miss her. Our sincere condolences to the family. Love, Patricia, Nick, and Maria

title: City Suspends Three Workers In Racial Float
description: City officials suspended two firefighters and a police officer without pay yesterday, saying the three men had admitted wearing blackface while riding a float at a Labor Day parade in Queens.

title: For Death of Its Diplomats, Iran Vows Blood for Blood
description: Iran vowed revenge today against the militant Taliban movement that controls most of neighboring Afghanistan, with the Revolutionary Guards saying that the Taliban should be given ''what they so richly deserve'' for killing at least nine Iranian diplomats.

title: Dodgers Name Orioles' Malone Their General Manager
description: Three years after walking away from his job in Montreal saying he wanted to build a team, not tear it apart, Kevin Malone yesterday became the general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, a team with lush resources.

title: Hamas Vows Revenge as Israel Kills 2 Militants
description: Islamic militants vowed today to avenge with bloodshed the killing by the Israeli Army of two of their key operatives on Thursday, threatening a new wave of violence after a year of refraining from deadly attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROTHSTEIN, ROGER MICHAEL.
description: ROTHSTEIN-Roger Michael. (August 31,1935-September 12, 1988). Dear Roger, your sweetness and generosity of spirit are still very much alive. We miss the fun of you. Thank you for the hearts you send us. Love always, Barbara, Carolyn, and Leslie

title: Tearful Clinton Tells Group Of Clerics, 'I Have Sinned'
description: With tears in his eyes, President Clinton told a roomful of clerics this morning that he had sinned, speaking just hours before the world was presented a painstaking account by prosecutors of when, where and how.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Goodbye World!; 2 Asian Economies Seek to Keep Global Markets at Bay
description: When Hong Kong and Malaysia placed curbs on their stock markets last week, the outcry from foreign investors was immediate and indignant. The governments were committing heresy, these critics said, by turning their backs on the free market in the search for a quick economic fix.

title: U.S. Eight Closes In On Repeat of Title
description: The United States men's heavyweight eight-oared crew yesterday qualified for the final of this year's world rowing championships in Cologne, Germany, in the second-fastest time of the regatta, 5 minutes 54.09 seconds. That was 84 hundredths of a second slower than Germany's eight, the winner of the other qualifying heat.

title: A Loyal Leader Goes For His 300th Victory
description: He is an Ivy league graduate with a thirst for books, mainly biographies. Numbers were never Joe Paterno's thing, although he has amassed enough to keep football-minded mathematicians searching for an algorithm to his success.

description: ROSEN-Leon. On September 10, 1998, Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Bethpage, N.Y. Beloved husband of Ruth for 54 years. Loving father of David, Mark and Hanora. Grandfather of Michael, John and Nicole. Father-in-law of Susan, Lynn and Ed. Service Sunday 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: INSIDE
description: Setback for U.N. Nominee

title: 'I Sinned,' He Says In Apology That Includes Lewinsky : Clinton Vows He Will Stay and Fight
description: WASHINGTON  President Bill Clinton declared somberly Friday that "I have sinned," in a speech so emotional and abject  including his first public apology to Monica Lewinsky and her family  that it brought a group of clergymen to their feet.

title: Panel Clears Overhaul Bill On Banking
description: The Senate Banking Committee approved sweeping legislation today to overturn Depression-era restrictions and allow American financial services companies to operate globally with far fewer limitations than under current law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIES, JULIUS
description: MARGULIES-Julius. Beloved husband of the late Nettie, devoted father of Karen and Peter, loving grandfather of Lesley, Abby, and Andy. Dear brother of Bea Leshinsky and Ruth Plagman. Services Sunday at 11:30AM at ''Parkside Chapel'' Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: 2 Jets Rookies Get a Shot on Special Teams
description: Suddenly faced with what he admitted was ''a sense of urgency'' approaching Sunday's game against the Baltimore Ravens, Jets Coach Bill Parcells will activate two rookies to try to jump-start his special teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOW, PETER (MEYER)
description: ARNOW-Peter (Meyer) died peacefully in his sleep on September 8, age 84 years. He was a poet, dreamer, and scientist who always loved to laugh. He was a devoted husband to Fran, loving father to Julie, and a playful, if sometimes forgetful, grandfather to Zoe, Sophia, and Navah. Graveside services were held at Newton Cemetery, Newton, MA., September 10. He will be dearly missed.

title: FREMONT GENERAL TO BUY PACIFICAMERICA MONEY CENTER
description: The Fremont General Corporation, the seventh-largest United States workers' compensation insurer, said yesterday that it would pay $55 million for PacificAmerica Money Center Inc., expanding its home loan business. Fremont, based in Santa Monica, Calif., will pay 75 percent of the purchase price in cash and the rest in its own stock. The transaction values PacificAmerica at $10 a share. The purchase gives Fremont a company that made $768 million in single-family home mortgages last year through offices in 45 states. PacificAmerica is based in Woodland Hills, Calif.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, RICHARD G.
description: LEONARD-Richard G. Of Philadelphia, on September 11, 1998. Husband of the late Patricia D. Leonard. Father of Hope Leonard Kirk. Also survived by two granddaughters, one great-grandson, and a sister Margaret Leonard Brown. Memorial service will be held from the Chapel of Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, Montgomery Avenue, Bryn Mawr on Monday, September 14 at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made in his name to the Wistar Institute, 36th & Spruce Streets, Philadelphia, PA. 19104.

title: Dow Gets a Lift Of Nearly 180 In Wide Rally
description: Technology and financial stocks led the market higher yesterday, as a few earnings bright spots showed through the fanfare over the release of the Whitewater independent counsel's report on President Clinton to Congress and concerns about the prospects for Mr. Clinton's impeachment.

title: New British Law Could Sabotage Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Roads to Final: Hingis Rallies, Davenport Breezes
description: Martina Hingis does not monopolize women's tennis at 17 the way she did so merrily at 16, but yesterday she proved she still has the gumption to grab the game by the jugular. Unlike Venus Williams, who fell a rung short of turning the United States Open women's finale into a repeat showdown, Hingis took control of her semifinal match at crunch time.

title: Mayor's Response to a Float Is Hailed by Black Leaders
description: Black political and religious leaders yesterday applauded Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's swift condemnation of a racially offensive float in a Labor Day parade in Queens. But they also continued to criticize the Mayor's support for the aggressive tactics used by the police at a Harlem youth rally last weekend.

title: Friend In the Lead After Two Rounds
description: The inner peace that Bob Friend first experienced in May in the Byron Nelson Classic returned yesterday in the Canadian Open as he handled tough wind and wicked pin placements for a five-under-par 67 and a one-stroke lead in Oakville, Ontario.

title: The 'New' New Left

title: Religion Journal; Homosexuals Reassured by Bishops
description: The Lambeth Conference, the once-a-decade meeting of the world's Anglican bishops that took place in England earlier this summer, had several themes, not least of which was the opportunity for bishops from places as far apart as Alaska and Zimbabwe to meet and confer.

description: Japanese Economy Continues to Shrink

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAASS, RICHARD
description: MAASS-Richard, 79. Of Purchase, New York, died September 10, of cancer. Mr. Maass was born May 20, 1919 in Baltimore, Maryland to Arthur Leopold Maass and Selma Rosenheim Maass. He is survived by his devoted wife of 55 years, Dolly Lederer Maass, a brother Arthur Aaron Maass of Boston, sons Douglas O. of Sleepy Hollow, NY and R. Andrew of Jackson, Mississippi, four grandchildren, Aaron, Ethan and Kern Maass and Annie Maass Halpin, one great grandson Michael Andrew Halpin. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY, Monday, September 14, 1 P.M. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Purchase College (SUNY) Foundation Scholarship Fund.

title: An American Drama Replete With Ironies
description: It was a surreal and unnerving spectacle sadly translated from the world of tabloid television to the world of governance: the White House issuing a press release yesterday about the nature of President Clinton's sexual activities, a reporter asking Michael McCurry whether the President suffered from ''satyriasis'' and the entire globe becoming privy, via the Internet, to Mr. Clinton's intimate, sexual proclivities -- the sort of things people do not know about their best friends, much less the most powerful man on the planet.

title: Democratic Candidates for Attorney General Still Struggling to Gain Attention
description: With only days before the primary, the four Democratic candidates for attorney general are blanketing towns and cities with letters and fliers, jamming the airwaves with television and radio advertisements and traveling the state in a last-ditch effort to draw attention to a race that has drawn little of it so far.

title: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES TO SELL PROPERTIES
description: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc., which is shedding assets in an effort to reduce debt, has agreed to sell oil and gas properties in South Texas to Collins & Ware Inc. for $148 million. Union Pacific Resources, based in Fort Worth, is an independent oil and gas exploration and production company. Collins & Ware, based in Midland, Tex., is a closely held oil company. The company has been selling nonstrategic blocks in the Gulf of Mexico off the Texas coast to reduce debt and improve its credit ratings. Last month, Union Pacific agreed to sell its 19 percent interest in the Matagorda Block 623 offshore natural gas field to the Enron Oil and Gas Company for $158 million.

title: Belmont's Big Fall Meeting Begins
description: New York racing switched downstate yesterday after a booming six-week run in Saratoga and opened a 33-day meeting at Belmont Park that features 40 stakes, the long-awaited ''race of the year'' in next Saturday's Woodward, the countdown to the Breeders' Cup, the divisional championships and the final hometown performances for Skip Away and Coronado's Quest.

title: Richard Maass, 79, Founder Of Conference on Soviet Jewry
description: Richard Maass, a self-employed investments manager whose concern for the deprived and the victims of discrimination led him to become the founding chairman of the National Conference on Soviet Jewry and president of the American Jewish Committee, died at his home in Purchase, N.Y., on Thursday. He was 79 years old.

title: Latin Grace and Drive Bonding With Jazz
description: Creolization is such a profound, unceasing force in the United States that it is often overlooked, the way a great vista becomes blank after time. It is to Jazz at Lincoln Center's credit that it opened its season at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night with a sold-out concert that was all about the endless bumpings, assimilations and transformations that the Spanish- and English-speaking worlds have caused each other, and it brought that aspect of the American experience to the front of the stage.

description: Offering new evidence that treating drug addicts works in the long term, a Government survey has reported that addicts who undergo treatment are considerably less likely to consume drugs or commit crimes to support their use, even after five years.

Cherished grandmother of Alan Pollack and Mimi and (Robert) Ellison. Great grandmother of Leora Ellison. Dear sister of Dorothy Weisblum and the late Leo and Abe Rosenberg. Services at graveside 2PM Sunday at Beth David Cemetery. For further information, call ''Boulevard Riverside'' 516-295-3100.

There is substantial and credible information that President Clinton endeavored to obstruct justice by helping Ms. Lewinsky obtain a job in New York at a time when she would have been a witness against him were she to tell the truth during the Jones case. The President had an incentive to keep Ms. Lewinsky from jeopardizing the secrecy of the relationship. That incentive grew once the Supreme Court unanimously decided in May 1997 that the case and discovery process were to go forward.

title: Gordon's Tires Pass Nascar's Test
description: It was Jeff Gordon's driving skill, not illegal tires as alleged by rival teams, that put him on victory lane last month at Loudon, N.H., Nascar concluded yesterday. Tests on Gordon's tires by an independent lab showed nothing abnormal.

title: White House Sex and Global Meltdown
description: In the science of chaos, the notion that little things can make all the difference is known as ''the butterfly effect.'' As the seminal chaos theorist Edward Lorenz once put it: Can a butterfly flapping its wings in Brazil cause a tornado in Texas? In Washington, people are starting to ask a similar question: Can an intern batting her eyelashes in the Oval Office cause a global recession?

title: Lewinsky Maintains a Low Profile

Starr's report, one notable exception was the woman whose story touched off the maelstrom: Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDWIN, M.D.
description: WEINSTEIN-Edwin, M.D. The Department of Neurology of the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine mourns the passing of our distinguished colleague, Dr. Edwin Weinstein, Professor Emeritus of Neurology. He was a gentleman and a scholar, a wonderful teacher and a gentle man who made a major contribution to communication disorders and authored many works including a major text on Woodrow Wilson. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTON, CHARLES NEWBERN,
description: BARTON-Charles Newbern, age 80, died Thursday, September 10th at home, 28 Formosa Drive, Charleston, South Carolina. Born: Douglaston, Long Island, New York on August 26, 1918. Parents: Walter E. Barton and Marion K. Barton. Schools: Deerfield Academy, Princeton University, and Harvard Business School. Career: He was President of the Charles B. Knight Insurance Agency, Inc., New York, General Manager for the Union Central Life Insurance Company which was the largest life insurance agency in the world, & was founded by his grandfather Charles Bennett Knight. He was CLU & a member of the National Association of Life Underwriters. He was a Navy Lieutenant during World War II and served for four years on a destroyer both in the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. He was President of the Douglaston Club and the Douglaston Manor Association. He is a member of the Douglaston Community Church and was Chairman of the Church Council. He was also an Associate member of The French Huguenot Church. He was a member of the Douglaston Yacht Squadron, the Carolina Yacht Club, a charter member of the Seabrook Island Club, & a member of the Princeton Club of New York. He is survived by his wife the former Norma Thatcher of Charleston, S.C. His children C. Knight Barton of Beaufort, NC, Salley Barton Davidson & Walter E. Barton both of Charleston, South Carolina, and four grandsons. The service will be held at 3:00 PM Sunday, September 13th at The French Huguenot Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice of Charleston, Inc., 3896 Leeds Avenue, North Charleston, South Carolina, 29405. For further information: J. Henry Stuhr, Inc. Downtown Chapel.

title: Former Justice Official Resigns After Conviction
description: The former deputy assistant director of the state's Division of Criminal Justice, who was found guilty last month of sexually harassing a female subordinate, resigned his job at the Division of Alcoholic Beverage Control yesterday.

Resting at Beecher Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, New York, where family will receive friends Sunday 6 to 8 P.M. Mass of The Resurrection on Monday at 10:30 A.M. Holy Innocents Church, Pleasantville. Entombment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

All he must do is find a way to attack Pete Sampras successfully this afternoon in the semifinals of Sampras's national championship.

description: In the starkest sign so far of the depth of Japan's recession, the Government said today that the economy contracted in the April-June quarter by an annual rate of 3.3 percent, nearly twice as steep a fall as most economists had expected.

Gammons performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head.

description: I LIKE to be in Montauk,'' proclaimed the artist Julian Schnabel. ''I like to paint near the ocean. I like to live near the ocean. I like to be in the water so much, whenever there're waves, I'm surfing.''

title: The Universe Stares Back
description: BLIZZARD OF ONE Poems. By Mark Strand. 55 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $21.

title: Culture Zone; Out of Order
description: Wandering around the Pierre Bonnard retrospective currently on view at the Museum of Modern Art in New York City, I found myself in search of lost time. MOMA's curators, in hanging the show's 82 paintings, rejected the cradle-to-grave chronology that typically anchors a career survey. Instead, Bonnard's luminous works were grouped thematically -- landscapes in one gallery, still lifes in another -- with a pointed disregard for dates. Youthful efforts from the 1920's were tossed together with canvases painted around 1947, the year of Bonnard's death. The Frenchman's last completed painting, a small, dappled image of a blossoming almond tree, was stuck into the center of the show. The result was an imaginative but odd survey, one in which innocence and experience commingled as one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALDRICH, SUSAN CUTLER
description: ALDRICH-Susan Cutler. Of Barrytown, NY, died at home at Rokeby, September 9, 1998, in her 85th year. Widow of Richard Chanler Aldrich, daughter of the late John Wilson and Rosalind Fish Cutler. Survived by her children Richard and John Winthrop Aldrich, both of Barrytown, NY, and Rosalind Michahelles of Cambridge, MA; five beloved granddaughters; her brother John Wilson Cutler; and her sisters Patricia Rosalind Warner and Judith Bayard Shinkle. The funeral will be held at the Church of St John the Evangelist, Barrytown, New York at twelve noon, on Monday, September 14th. In place of flowers please make donations to a local animal shelter or a charity of your choice.

title: The Stories and Tears Flow for Paterno's 300th
description: He had dodged the questions about the milestone all week. He ducked one cooler full of water as time ticked down, but not a second cooler. Still, Joe Paterno did not really get wet until after more than 96,000 people reverently chanted his name. Until his wife, Sue, his five children and three grandchildren swarmed him at the 50-yard line.

title: Security Analysis, Updated
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories and the Planes That Made Them
description: STANDING on the tarmac at Republic Airport, Raymond Young stared at the vintage B-17 Flying Fortress bomber that had just landed.

title: Commercial Property/Development Plans; Amid Stock Market's Volatility, an Air of Uncertainty
description: AS the stock market continues to dance like a cobra in a basket, some major players in real estate investment predict that while the biggest, most publicized development projects will probably continue to move forward, some of those in the planning stages may get caught in the turmoil. With the stock market's volatility, lenders are becoming more conservative, overheated land prices are starting to come down, and potential bidders for existing buildings are stepping back to reflect.

title: Minorities, Once Invisible in Environmental Struggles, Speak Up
description: Dorceta Taylor, who is the only black woman to obtain a doctorate in forestry from Yale University, remembers when a professor told her that ''blacks don't care about the environment.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Letter Perfect
description: Walker Evans's black-and-white photographs of shop signs, billboards, carnival posters, graffiti and electric light marquees are pictures of pictures in which an artist of stature pays homage to the work of scores of anonymous others. Recognizing unknown artisans may not have been his original intent, but Evans, who designed layouts for Fortune magazine and taught graphic design at Yale University, was fascinated by the way both professionally designed and primitively scrawled letter forms communicated to the public and left unique marks on the landscape. Evans understood typographic sophistication, but the typography and lettering that he chose to chronicle, as well as the hand-painted signs that he collected and exhibited, were the work of untutored sign makers for stores, restaurants, barber shops, sidewalk stands and churches -- the unheralded artifacts of popular culture that most passers-by take for granted. The photographs collected in a little gem of a book, SIGNS (J. Paul Getty Museum, $19.95), with an insightful essay by Andrei Codrescu, are consistent with Evans's better-known images of destitute Southerners in ''Let Us Now Praise Famous Men.'' Evans was a humanist, concerned with the masses, and these signs are made without pretense by and for common people. Steven Heller

title: Kathryn Metz, William Helm 3d
description: Kathryn Thornton Metz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Metz Jr. of Sharon, Conn., was married yesterday to William Lloyd Helm 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Helm of Wyndmoor, Pa. The Rev. Robert D. Cloney, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Hotchkiss School Chapel in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Miss Lewinsky: Are You Ready for Your Makeover Now?
description: Back when Monica Lewinsky was an anonymous Pentagon staff member rather than the (rumored) focus of a publishers' bidding war, she confided to a colleague that being President Clinton's fashion stylist would be her dream job. No longer. At her 25th birthday party in July, she told friends what she really wanted as a present: ''my life back.'' But what does that mean at this point? Based on analysis of past imbroglios, it seems that infamous women like Lewinsky have three basic options: they can disappear, they can marry well or they can try to stay famous for a while (writing, acting, etc.). What's obvious is that Lewinsky needs a whole new game. As a belated birthday gift, we asked several repackaging specialists how she might proceed.

title: A Sales Pitch Right Under Your Nose
description: SHOPPERS at the four Jordan's Furniture stores in Massachusetts and New Hampshire might be excused if they sense a hint of bubble gum in the children's room displays, or a whisper of pine in the country-style section.

title: Q&A/Michael R. Orsino; Arborist Who Also Climbs Trees for Fun
description: IF you thought tree climbing was just for children or adults rescuing cats, think again. Michael R. Orsino, 41, a certified arborist, has climbed a 120-foot tulip tree.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM; Five Sisters Alone Against Their World
description: THE past may have many interpretations, but everyone will agree that the Ireland in which I grew up during the 1940's and 50's was most definitely a different country.

title: Cultivating Everything From Tango To Classical
description: IT is a curious fact of ballet life that the best dancers tend to be the most generous, and Julio Bocca, a virtuoso once described by Rudolf Nureyev as a ''child of nature,'' has always been markedly generous to his partners and even to those who might be regarded as his competitors. That aspect of his spirit was responsible for the founding of his company, Ballet Argentino, which returns to City Center on Wednesday for a four-day engagement, during which it will present four works, including a sensually evocative tango and Roland Petit's passionately charged ''Le Jeune Homme et la Mort.''

title: Better, Not Bigger
description: To the Editor:

title: Laughter And Lane, Kid Stuff And Food
description: TIM REID

title: Dr. Gallagher And Judge Bartley
description: Dr. Tracy Ann Gallagher, a pediatrician, and Judge A. Kirke Bartley Jr. of Manhattan Criminal Court, were married yesterday by the Rev. Richard Gorman at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: Australia Has Three Reasons To Rejoice
description: Roy Emerson left Queens for Switzerland yesterday afternoon, with the fate of his record for Grand Slam singles titles in the hands of an Australian who plays the way Australians are still expected to play: with a swagger in his step, a yen for the net and no chip on his strong right shoulder.

title: Baseball, the Carnival
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: BOOKEND; Want to Buy a Rare Book? Click Here.
description: Book collecting. The money. The dust. Those harassing phone calls. ''We've found your Joyce.'' ''We have your Pynchon.'' As if your children had been kidnapped and the caller were demanding a ransom. Yet the goal is honorable. Book collecting is about creating a pantheon of writers whose creativity inspires your own. And there's the way you feel when a book's finally in your hands, something you've been looking for for years, the thing itself, an artifact retrieved from oblivion. . . .

title: The Searchers
description: THE VOYAGE OF

title: Pamela Tanowitz And Dan Siegler
description: Pamela Hope Tanowitz, a daughter of Rachel S. Tanowitz of Greenwich, Conn., and Dr. Herbert B. Tanowitz of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Dan Adam Siegler, a son of Dr. Ava L. Siegler and Robert Siegler of Manhattan. Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman is to officiate at Studio 450, a loft in Manhattan.

title: Crossing the Gap From English to American
description: EARLY one Sunday evening recently, the writer and director Peter Chelsom could be found on the back patio of his rented Bel-Air home, revealing a modest dream: ''One day, I would love to be sitting on an airplane, and someone will say, 'What do you do for a living?' And I'll go, 'Well, I'm a director,' and they'll go, 'Oh, anything I may have seen?' '' Then, Mr. Chelsom will list his credits and a look of recognition will creep over his seatmate's face. ''It would be nice,'' said Mr. Chelsom, 42, ending his reverie, ''to direct films that your average Joe would have seen.''

title: Abigail Marr And David Doft
description: Abigail Colvin Marr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Terrence Marr of Goldens Bridge, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to David Benjamin Doft, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Avrom I. Doft of New York. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at the home of the bridegroom's parents in Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, ADAM ZACHARY
description: HART-Adam Zachary. We cherish our beloved Adam who left more than he took. Nanelle, Elaine, Cha Cha

title: Little Industries Mean a Lot to Manhattan
description: WITH the Wall Street money machine suddenly in turmoil, New Yorkers might increasingly see their economic salvation in unfashionable places like Varick Street. Made up largely of older brick industrial buildings just three or four subway stops from the world's financial center, the area is a key part of the city's $3 billion printing industry.

title: Keelan Stern, Jonathan Bodow
description: Keelan Jennifer Stern, a daughter of Ann and Alvin Stern of Chatham, Mass., is to be married today to Jonathan Bradley Bodow, a son of Ellen and Warren Bodow of Waccabuc, N.Y. Rabbi Alan Flam is to officiate at Linden Place, a historic house in Bristol, R.I.

title: Reporter's Lawsuit
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispute Leaves Man Dead
description: One man was shot to death last night and another critically injured after a dispute with a third man on a Brooklyn street corner, the police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''As we judge the President, the people of America will also judge us.''

title: Umbria, Timeless and Enduring
description: We knew the landscape before we came here. We had seen it in London, Paris, New York. It is the world that opens beyond casement windows in Umbrian and Tuscan paintings of the early Renaissance, a background, never there for its own sake, never the center of interest, sometimes no more than an exercise in perspective, a world where those dreaming Madonnas and attendant saints could not really be imagined as ever setting foot, but intensely real to the imagination of the spectator, the walls and bell towers of some fortified town, the folded ranks of hills, with their dark, slender cypresses, as sharp and symmetrical as spear blades, and their steep terraces of olive and vine.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: September

title: School Days For Workers
description: Students of all ages are heading back to school this month. But in the workplace, a return to the classroom can come at any time of year, in the form of corporate training sessions. Whether it's learning about the new computer, the corporate culture, or how to unleash the salesman within, such classes can leave teacher and student alike wondering just how quick a study the other is. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Habitats/10th Street and Seventh Avenue South; A Place in the Village With Charm of the Marais
description: IT is easy to forget, when New York pulls you almost against your will, when you cannot imagine living anyplace else, that there are plenty of people who come here because they feel they must, without a passion for the place. They come for work, or for a spouse. They come thinking it is temporary, anticipating the day when they will live in a place that moves their soul.

title: Seeking Justice in the House
description: With heavy hearts and churning emotions, Americans are taking this weekend to digest Kenneth Starr's allegations of misconduct and abuse of power by President Clinton. The official judgment of Mr. Clinton's fitness to serve will be rendered by the Congress, which is as it should be. Wrangling over the role and rights of the independent counsel can now give way to procedures and powers established indisputably by the Constitution, and that is a healthy development.

title: Marian Bell, Nicholas Gilhool
description: Marian Whieldon Bell, the daughter of Linda and Frank Bell of New York, was married yesterday to Nicholas Kane Gilhool, the son of Gillian and Thomas Gilhool of Philadelphia. The Rev. Ruth Maedel performed the ceremony at Church of Christ, Congregational in Norfolk, Conn.

title: Anne Clarke And John Adams
description: Anne Megan Clarke, a daughter of Marylin and James Clarke of Old Lyme, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Hugh Adams, the son of Mrs. John A. Adams of New York and the late Mr. Adams. The Rev. Brian Schloth performed the ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church.

title: Where the Bodies Are Buried
description: AN AMERICAN KILLING

title: For Primakov, Now Comes the Hard Part: Finding a Plan That Will Save Russia
description: Winning approval from Russia's strident and stubborn Parliament on Friday turned out to be an easy day's work for Russia's new Prime Minister, Yevgeny M. Primakov, the savvy diplomat who has made a career of playing both ends against the middle.

title: In the Hunt For Perfect Spot On a Long Line
description: A start line almost a mile long has some of the best sailors in the world puzzled about where they are going to cross when racing begins today off Marblehead, Mass. It is liable to take 10 minutes to sail from one end of the line to the other in search of the best wind angle. Most of the skippers see that as a tactical nightmare.

title: Thriving on an Atmosphere of No Illusions
description: WITH enduring films like ''Days of Wine and Roses,'' ''The Manchurian Candidate,'' ''Birdman of Alcatraz,'' ''Seven Days in May'' and ''The Fixer'' to his credit, John Frankenheimer was one of the foremost directors of the 1960's. But he stumbled under the weight of personal problems and bad choices, and, starting in the 70's, his career went awry. For filmmakers and actors who have made wrong decisions, few places are as cruel as Hollywood.

title: Ms. Udolf, Mr. Schwartz
description: Nancy Udolf and Dr. Therodore H. Schwartz were married last evening by Rabbi Elliot Stevens at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: Vienna: A change of pace from chandeliers and Strauss
description: In a few discreet places, Vienna sheds its revered cloak of classical taste in music, fashion and food. The locals find these redoubts first and often secure them for themselves. The latest is Rhiz, a bar featuring electronic music (heavy on drums and bass) and disk jockeys who take turns as presenters.

title: A Season With Star Power on Many a Marquee
description: NAME-DROPPING is a game even serious theatergoers play. It is not what regional theater is about, but then if a star is sighted on the moors of Shakespeare or Sophocles, as the soothsayer says, it can't hurt. The new fall season in New Jersey professional theater is not altogether star driven -- though it is, more than ever, tuned into the value of names. At the same time attention is being paid to the importance of offering audiences a theatrical potpourri. Variety is, after all, the survival tool of all theaters.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: HOPE By Glen Duncan. Riverhead, $23.95.

title: The Nation: Out Of Control; After Starr's Report, Fallout Beyond Clinton
description: KENNETH W. STARR'S report became public so suddenly last week that Americans are still digesting its charges and tawdriness and weighing their significance.

title: Justices to Hear Census Case
description: The constitutional mandate to conduct a national headcount every 10 years sounds simple enough, and once it was. But a highly charged debate over how to run the census has reached the Supreme Court.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; For Affluent Elderly, an Array of Housing Choices

Diverse requirements for people aged 55 and older, in various states of physical and financial health, have produced a profitable alliance between developers and health service providers, and a bewildering array of choices for customers.

description: Outside the low Yankee Clipper Center office building, Joe DiMaggio and his lawyer, Morris Engelberg, were walking toward a white Dodge Caravan with the words ''The Yankee Clipper'' in navy blue above the rear window.

description: THE tiny office behind the displays of lamps, doorknobs and coffee grinders was crowded Tuesday morning. Natan Wekselbaum and three associates were plotting the expansion of his East Side housewares emporium Gracious Home to Broadway and 67th Street, where a branch is to open this month.

title: Tracy Fischetti and Trip Shepard
description: Tracy Marie Fischetti, the daughter of Teresa and John Fischetti of Thornwood, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Brown Shepard 3d, a son of Midge and Bill Shepard of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Raymond Daley performed the ceremony at Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARE, HELEN
description: LAZARE-Helen. On September 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Loving mother of Allan and Arlene. Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Marc and Amanda. Fuenral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROWENNA L.
description: WHITE-Rowenna L., at age 18. Victim of SwissAir Flight 111 crash on September 2. Beloved daughter of Nancy Wight of New York City and Paul R. White of Bronxville. Also survived by her stepmother Judith Lilleston White of Bronxville. Rowenna was on route to Geneva & Montreux, Switzerland to begin studies at Hotel Institute Montreux (HIM). She was a 1998 graduate of the Cascadilla School in Ithaca, N.Y. This summer she had been learning French at the Alliance Francaise and was employed by Nello's Restaurant in New York. Other immediate survivors include her grandparents Margaret and Joe White of Woodbridge, VA; 2 aunts and 2 uncles. Since she was an animal lover, contributions to the memory of Rowenna L. White may be made to the ASPA, 424 E. 92 Street, N.Y. 10128. A service in her honor will be held Saturday, September 19 at 12 noon at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave. at 71 Street, N.Y.

title: Where to Invest a Wealth of Talents?
description: ON a hazy August afternoon, Melissa Elliott -- singer, songwriter, rapper and producer -- sat before a mammoth stereo system in the offices of her record label, Elektra. She contemplated a pile of compact disks, digital audio tapes and promotional videos. Which would best demonstrate where this artist, whom the world knows by her deceptively girlish family nickname of Missy, is headed in the wake of her emergence, at 26, as a new ideal of womanly black power?

title: On the Prowl for Strays
description: This summer Ira Manhoff got tired of seeing cats cross his path on Manhattan Valley streets. ''I'd walk home at night and see all these strays coming out,'' Mr. Manhoff said. ''This summer, there have been just so many more cats than anyone has seen before.''

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Page Crosland; Keeping Spirits Up Courtside
description: THE fall social season is about to begin in Manhattan. To ease the transition from drinking southsides at the country club to Cristal at Le Cirque, the social set is tippling Evian bottled water at the luxury boxes at the United States Open, which runs through today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUSKIN, STELLA
description: GLUSKIN-Stella. September 3, 1998. Wife of the late Louis. Beloved mother of Marilyn Greenberg and Belle Waldner. Grandmother of four and great grandmother of two.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FANTINI, ALDO P.
description: FANTINI-Aldo P. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family notes with sadness the passing of Aldo P. Fantini, beloved father of our friend and colleague, Gary A. Fantini, M.D., attending physician in the Division of Vascular Surgery. To Gary, his mother Mary, his uncle Joseph and his aunt Flora, the entire Fantini family and all of his father's loved ones, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO Ruth E. Hennessey, Vice President Administration-Singer Division Michael Silane, M.D., Chief of Vascular Surgery

title: Shouts Of Rage At the Way We Are
description: AT a time when the news media are awash in the gory details of Presidential sexual hijinks, the public is supposedly beyond shock when it comes to revelations of bad behavior. Or is it? The acid test will come with the first public American screenings of Todd Solondz's pitch-black comedy ''Happiness,'' at the New York Film Festival. The film was shown at the Cannes Film Festival last spring and picked up for distribution by October Films, but October had to back out under pressure from its parent, Universal.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: NEW SERIES

title: Dana Rathkopf, Daniel Hunter
description: Dr. Dana Elizabeth Rathkopf, the daughter of Linda Rathkopf and Stephen M. Rathkopf of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Daniel Francis Hunter, a son of Margaret Hunter and Daniel J. Hunter of Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The Rev. Luigi Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Teach Your Children: It's All Luck
description: AS soon as the new school year has begun, we always hear a lot of snivelling, whining, ill-informed complaints about the failings of the education system. It's true that test scores are terrible and that 4 out of 10 New York high school graduates need remedial courses in college. Even the intellectual stars may think that ''ad infinitum'' is a rock group and that Ulysses is a kind of foot fungus.

title: Getting a Response Without Nagging
description: ON the whole, people like response: children who clean their room the first time they are asked, partners who share daily responsibilities without constant reminding, pets that come when called. In a perfect world there would be no interruption. Oddly enough, pets can be the most predictable.

title: U.S.S. New Jersey Will Have Berth in Bayonne
description: When the U.S.S. New Jersey returns to its namesake state, it should be moored in Bayonne, a state commission decided last week.

title: Affirmative Action Has Its Victims; Preparatory Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Male 'Swan Lake' to Bill T. Jones
description: PAUL TAYLOR

title: Russian Psychodramas Made of Movement
description: BORIS EIFMAN'S choreography, like his dancers, is passionate and intense: his Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg gave audiences a jolt when this 21-year-old Russian troupe made its New York debut in April with provocative psychodramas about Tchaikovsky and the ballerina Olga Spessivtseva.

title: Progress Toward Safer Beef
description: One way to avoid most deadly E. coli bacteria is to tinker with your diet -- by avoiding hamburgers. Now researchers at Cornell University have come up with another solution: first tinker with your diet's diet.

title: More Room for the State's Submarine Heritage
description: IN the 12 years since the Submarine Force Library and Museum opened in Groton, almost 4 million people have visited, making it the fourth most popular tourist attraction in the state.

title: Q and A
description: Sunny Art Classes

title: Cocktails
description: To the Editor: Thanks to William Grimes for explaining the Ramos gin fizz of New Orleans (''Charting the Globe on a Cocktail Napkin,'' Aug. 30). As an addendum, Lizabeth Scott in the movie ''Dead Reckoning'' (1947) is quite partial to it.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; The Latest Amenity: A High-Tech Friendly House
description: HOPING to gain a competitive advantage, some residential builders across the state are constructing homes with what they say is the amenity of the future -- a high-tech wiring system.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Upscale Rental Developments Continue to Grow
description: WHEN Connie and Michael Rocchio sold their four-bedroom West Babylon home to their son Michael, their reasoning was that his young family needed the big home they had outgrown.

title: It's Easier Being Gay
description: THE BEST LITTLE BOY IN THE WORLD GROWS UP

title: Lewinsky Was Familiar Face to Agents Near Clinton's Door
description: The Secret Service, it turns out, had seen a lot of Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANOLLI, ANGELO
description: ZANOLLI-Angelo. Died September 6, 1998. He will be greatly missed as he was a warm and very caring friend to many. He is survived by a sister, brother, nieces and nephews, all residing in Naples, Italy. Friends of Angelo

title: Julia Fayngold, Russell Covey
description: Julia Fayngold and Russell Dean Covey, both lawyers, were married on Monday at the Crystal Plaza, a caterer in Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Michael Paley officiated.

title: Comparing Two Very Different Versions of Clinton's Conduct
description: In his report to Congress, Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, accused President Clinton of committing perjury when he said under oath in the Paula Corbin Jones civil case and before a Federal grand jury that he had had no sexual relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Educator Is Named Board Chief
description: EVEN if students drag their feet at the thought of starting another school year, the newly appointed head of the Putnam-Northern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services cannot wait to start his job on Oct. 16.

title: Reverse Commuters Key to Region's Growth
description: AS Long Island's economy continues to grow and local companies scramble to find workers in a tight job market, economists say that businesses are being forced to rely more and more on workers from New York City.

title: Hope in Swissair Crash
description: In a case of deja vu, the United States Navy salvage ship Grapple is once again preparing to raise airplane parts from the ocean. It almost seems as if the crash of TWA Flight 800 off Long Island in July 1996 had repeated itself on Sept. 2 when Swissair Flight 111 crashed in the Atlantic Ocean off Nova Scotia, killing all 229 passengers.

title: Method to Pick Baby's Sex
description: For the first time in the millennia that humans have tried to select the sex of their baby, success may be at hand. Doctors at the Genetics & IVF Institute in Fairfax, Va., reported that they can sort sperm by exploiting the one difference between sperm that produce a male and those that produce a female: sperm that produce a male have 2.8 percent less DNA.

title: Barcelona: Underground show of an ancient heritage
description: For the best part of the 1990's, Barcelona has been busily making itself look new. Coinciding with the 1992 Summer Olympics, it spruced up the ornate buildings of the late 19th-century Modernista movement made famous by Antoni Gaudi and invited top-flight contemporary architects like Richard Meier, Norman Foster, Arata Isozaki and Santiago Calatrava to add daring new shapes to the city's profile.

title: White Plains Center
description: Tishman Speyer Properties has officially submitted its proposed plans for the development of the White Plains Town Center. Standing across from the former Macy's in downtown White Plains early this month, representatives of the development company presented plans to Mayor Joseph M. Delfino and other White Plains officials. The plans call for 540,000 square feet of retail, entertainment and restaurant space as well as 450 units of rental apartments and 2,350 parking spaces. As announced in February by Tishman Speyer, Mayor Delfino and Loews, a central feature of the Town Center will be a 24-screen, 5,200-seat megaplex theater operated by Loews Theaters, a Sony Retail Entertainment company.

title: Widely Respected Conservative Will Head Inquiry
description: On Henry J. Hyde's power wall in his Capitol Hill office are photographs of him with Dwight D. Eisenhower, Richard M. Nixon, Gerald R. Ford, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, George Bush, Mother Teresa, the Pope -- and Bill Clinton.

title: As Clinton Library Is Planned, Tough Questions Abound
description: Here on the south bank of the Arkansas River, on a site now strewn with weedy lots and aging warehouses, one version of Bill Clinton's history will be written some day.

title: James D'Alessio and Wendy Connor
description: Wendy Jill Connor, a daughter of Constance G. Connor and Donald K. Connor of Essex, Conn., was married last evening to James Alden D'Alessio, the son of Joan Rutland St. Pierre of Simsbury, Conn., and James G. D'Alessio of Rocky Hill, Conn. The Rev. Dr. George W. Peters, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated at Beechwood, a historic house in Newport, R.I.

title: Dr. Puskar, Dr. Culliford
description: Dr. Andrea Norika Puskar, a daughter of Erika G. Puskar of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Norman M. Puskar, was married yesterday in Lyme, Conn., to Dr. Alfred Thomas Culliford 4th, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Culliford 3d of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. David W. Good, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Lord Hill, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey W. Cooley, friends of the bride.

title: In Speech, Justice Thomas Talks of 'Backbone' and Beliefs
description: Alternately defiant and, at times close to tears, Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court exhorted a group of conservatives today to remain true to their beliefs even if they are subjected to personal attacks and unfair criticism.

title: Private Parts
description: THE ANATOMIST

title: Sandra Shaffer, Peter Tauckus 3d
description: Sandra Jeanette Shaffer, a daughter of Olga Shaffer and Dr. Russell Shaffer of Bethlehem, Pa., was married there yesterday to Peter Joseph Tauckus 3d, a son of Patricia and Peter Tauckus Jr. of Lynbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Andrew R. Baker, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Packer Memorial Church at Lehigh University. The Rev. David Sommers, a Moravian pastor, took part in the service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOREFF, HELEN
description: SOREFF-Helen. 72, died peacefully in her sleep at her home in New York on September 10, 1998. She was a wonderful artist, teacher, mother and friend to many. Helen was a provacative, lively and imaginative person. She was a devoted wife and mother to her husband Stephen, and her children, Alexander and Zachary. She will be missed by them, her students, and the art-world. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, at 1:15 PM, today.

title: The Blockbuster Script Factory
description: Reading Wolf's article, I couldn't help recalling the late Dwight Macdonald's oft-quoted essay ''A Theory of Mass Culture.'' ''Unity is essential in art,'' he declared. ''It cannot be achieved by a production line of specialists, however competent.'' That is why ''Manhattan'' is a great movie, and why ''Armageddon'' is the cinematic equivalent of a Big Mac -- one that has been under the heat lamps for 20 minutes.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Aug. 30 about the marriage of Vivian Balfour George and Tyler James Smith referred incorrectly to the home of the bridegroom's parents, Dr. and Mrs. David E. Smith. It is in Albany, Ore., not Albany, N.Y. The report also referred incorrectly to Dr. Smith's business. It is Geneva Gage Inc., not Geneva Gage Company; it is a distributor of precision measuring instruments, not a tool retailer, and it is in Albany, Ore., not Geneva, N.Y.

title: Scenes Behind the Scenes
description: IN a dark cabinet in my den, five years of travel tapes stand rank and file, labeled and piled neatly on top of an old VCR, listed by destination: Alaska. Senegal. Fiji. Holland. Northern Italy. Tasmania. Greece. Seven years ago, I was the host of ''Travel, Travel,'' a syndicated television show, during which time I learned how to pack efficiently in less than an hour, how much water to consume in order to stave off insufferable jet lag, how many camels I am apparently worth in marriage (10,000), and how to say goodbye in 11 languages.

title: Dr. Thompson And Dr. Proia
description: Dr. Lindsay Acheson Thompson, a daughter of Joan W. Thompson and Jonathan A. Thompson, both of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Robert Proia, the son of Marilyn Proia of Rochester and the late Dr. Richard Proia. The Rev. Brenda Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Food; Autumn Maize
description: Corn is a way of telling time. its different incarnations, from fresh to dried to ground, correspond not only to nature's imperative but to the seasonality of human appetite as well.

title: Eve Belfance, C. W. Colford
description: Eve Virginia Belfance and Christopher William Colford were married yesterday at the Church of the Annunciation in Akron, Ohio. The Rev. Jerry Hall performed the Greek Orthodox ceremony.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Taming It Down

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: What follows is a selective list; all opening dates are for New York and are subject to change.

title: Partnership Of Affinity That Defies Affiliations
description: BY their own admission, both are political mavericks. He, a longtime Westchester Democrat known for breaking the rules, won his first elected office as a County Legislator and became Supervisor of Greenburgh seven years ago. She, the Lieutenant Governor of New York and a former Republican, was the protegee of Gov. George E. Pataki before changing parties and seeking to unseat her mentor.

title: Oh Where Will the Elite Go to Cocoon?
description: ELAINE'S is too streetwise. Le Bilboquet is too French. Le Cirque 2000 might be fine for lunch, but at night, when it's filled with celebrities and out-of-towners toasting anniversaries, forget it. Up and down Park Avenue this week, among the crowd that passes for the 1990's version of the Social 400, a wail went up: Where will we eat now that Mortimer's is closed?

title: Following a Different Drumbeat
description: MOST musical visitors to Europe this fall will want to see the great opera houses and hear the outstanding orchestras -- the Vienna Philharmonic, the Berlin Philharmonic, the Royal Concertgebouw -- on home ground. But just as enticing are the opportunities to hear refreshingly adventurous performances.

title: London Revs Up
description: THANK goodness the fall is now upon us, for I seem to have spent the summer on the phone, frustrating and upsetting the customary influx of theaterphiliacs from America. Again and again the conversation has gone something like this. Caller: ''I can't wait to see Tom Stoppard's 'Invention of Love'.'' Me: ''Sorry, it's not on any more.'' Caller: Oh well, I hear 'The Weir' is terrific.'' Me: ''Afraid I've got bad news there too.'' Caller: ''So it looks as if I'll have to rely on the Royal Shakespeare Company.'' Me: ''No, they're out of town for the duration.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Praying to a Laughing God

title: Bird Habitats
description: To preserve bird habitats in Westchester and surrounding waterways, the county, along with the National Audubon Society, is establishing a program designating the sites Important Bird Areas.

title: Reno Announces Review Of Democrats' Campaign Ads
description: As if the White House did not have enough problems, Attorney General Janet Reno moved an important step closer to seeking an independent prosecutor to investigate whether President Clinton violated Federal election laws during his 1996 re-election campaign. Ms. Reno ordered a 90-day review of whether the $42 million the Democrats split among state party organizations for general advertising was actually an illegal scheme to finance an ad campaign for Mr. Clinton.

title: SOAPBOX; Struggling to Save Bryant Park
description: When Andrew Heiskell, the former publisher of Life magazine and former chairman of Time Inc., became chairman of the New York Public Library in 1981, he realized he had to drastically change its park grounds. This is an account of what it took, excerpted from Mr. Heiskell's privately published memoir, ''Outsider Insider,'' written with Ralph Graves, a former editorial director of Time Inc.
