title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; London
description: If ever my tawdry muse deserts me and absconds with all my tools of invention, I'll know exactly how to thwart the fickle strumpet.

title: SOAPBOX; njreps.sowhat.com
description: WHEN you come right down to it, Congressmen are interested in the Internet for three reasons: the opportunity to regulate it, the opportunity to tax it and, most importantly, the opportunity to have their very own personal Web sites. Eleven of New Jersey's 13 members of the House of Representatives have already immortalized themselves in Java code. What do they want you to know? To find out, fire up your favorite Web browser (try not to violate any antitrust laws while you're at it) and check out these postings on their Web sites. You can link to them from the House of Representatives Web site (http://www.house.gov).

title: Stacey Kahaner, Robert Marotta
description: Stacey Michele Kahaner, a daughter of Helen and Donald Kahaner of New York, is to be married today to Robert Marotta, a son of Rosemarie and Gus Marotta of Jericho, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Costa, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, N.Y. Cantor David Benedict took part in the ceremony.

title: Indianapolis: Basketball and Beyond
description: Indianapolis was invented from scratch. In 1821, five years after Indiana became a state, a committee of politicians selected some uninhabited bluffs overlooking the White River as the site for a capital. The river was shallow and behind the bluffs were swamps, but the vote was for a central location. It's the obvious logic of politicians. Metaphorically speaking, Indy pols have been trying to put Indianapolis at the center of things ever since.

title: Fresh Looks at Prints and a Town
description: 'An Inner Vision'

title: Definition of Violence
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Cadets Show Little Promise in a Close Loss to a Powerhouse
description: Army lost its opening game by a single point today to Miami of Ohio. Yet the score was no portent of a successful season for the Cadets.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: TUESDAY

title: Sensitivity Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Bus Shelters And Wind Direction
description: To the Editor:

title: Alaska Delegation Pushes Agenda of Development
description: Rarely has a small delegation from a singular state been as well placed as the three Republicans who represent Alaska in Congress to influence the development of their state's -- and the whole nation's -- natural resources.

title: In Paris, Finding the True Bistro a' Vin
description: I have long nurtured the fantasy of opening a restaurant. And, since my first visit to France, I have known that the restaurant would be a bistro a vin. To say it would be a casual place, a second home for its habitues, with a limited menu and lots of tasty country wines served by the glass, is not specific enough. I need to get down to cases, starting with my first love, Taverne Henri IV.

title: After a Lift, Cuban Church Has a Letdown
description: In cramped living rooms and quiet backyards across this Communist-ruled island, Roman Catholic faithful and curious newcomers are gathering to discuss the Bible, debate values, and talk a bit more openly about Cuba's future.

title: Safe to Drink the Water?
description: Do you drink water straight from the tap or do you use a filter or bottled water? Do you worry about your tap water?

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Volunteer: Now, That's An Order
description: THEY just don't make young people the way they used to. Nary a generation has looked upon its callow successors without finding them soft, spoiled and self-centered.

title: Maddie Corman and Jace Alexander
description: ALONG the country road leading to Jace Alexander and Maddie Corman's wedding on Sept. 6, there were hand-painted signs decorated with flowers, hearts, arrows and the couple's names in big bubble letters. They looked like signs from the back of an old Volkswagen bus.

title: Whose Land Is It?
description: WEATHERED

title: With Love and Squalor
description: At Home in the World

title: Iran Angered By a Promise That Proved To Be Hollow
description: Early last month, as the militant Islamic Taliban forces in Afghanistan advanced on an opposition enclave in the north, Iran's Foreign Ministry approached the Pakistani Embassy here to relay an urgent request.

title: Stratford Rethinks Its Base
description: THE past has taken on the nostalgic glow of the good old days in Stratford, when the military contractors and manufacturing provided prosperity and a stable tax base, and commerce thrived without the town government's help.

title: Miss Gould And Mr. Moss
description: Georgeanne Helen Gould, a daughter of Audrey S. Gould and Dr. Kenneth S. Gould of Princeton, N.J., is to be married there today to Peter Nathan Moss, the son of Carolyn B. Moss and Jason N. Moss of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Melvyn May is to officiate at the Nassau Inn.

title: Affirmative Action Has Its Victims; Do More for Students
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: UP AND COMING: Alessandro Nivola; From a Family of Painters, a Quick-Change Artist
description: FEW actors, however successful, can say that they have a museum in the family, but Alessandro Nivola can boast of two: one, devoted to his grandfather, the Italian sculptor Constantino Nivola, is situated in the artist's hometown in Sardinia, and a second, a far more modest and decidedly unofficial archive in Manhattan, is devoted to the actor himself.

title: Miss Watkins And Mr. Huber
description: Alexandra Moores Watkins, the daughter of Alexandra H. Watkins of Locust Valley, N.Y., and Ralph F. Watkins of Smithtown, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lamont Cochran Huber, a son of Lucille P. Whitely of New York and the late Richard R. Huber. The Rev. Dr. Charles R. Colwell, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y.

title: Rebecca Bond, Benjamin Brown
description: Rebecca Byfield Bond, a daughter of Alison Murray Bond and Prof. George C. Bond of Teaneck, N.J., is to be married today to Benjamin Doyle Brown, the son of Nancy Brown of Oshkosh, Wis., and Judge Richard Brown of Oconomowoc, Wis. Village Justice William Crosby of Tarrytown, N.Y., is to officiate at the headquarters of the American Booksellers Association there. The bridegroom's father, who sits on the Wisconsin Court of Appeals in Waukesha, will take part in the ceremony.

title: The Broncos' Shanahan Is Ruthless for a Reason
description: Kansas City quarterback Elvis Grbac remembered a story this past week that encapsulated Denver Coach Mike Shanahan, perhaps the smartest and most talented, yet most ruthless, head coach in the National Football League.

title: Dodge Foundation Names Its New Director
description: David Grant, a consultant for school districts on curriculum design and teacher training, has been named executive director of the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation in Morristown to succeed Scott McVay, director of the foundation since its inception in 1976. (Mr. VcVay was profiled in this section on March 29.) The appointment of Mr. Grant, 48, of Norwich, Vt., is effective Oct. 1. The foundation, established with a $60 million bequest in the will of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge of Madison, has made $164 million in grants to promote education, the arts and animal welfare. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REGEN, STUART
description: REGEN-Stuart. On Monday, September 14, 5 PM, The Auditorium, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, N.Y. 10023.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 6 comparing the economies of the former Soviet Union and Russia misstated the per capita gross domestic product. According to the World Bank, the G.D.P., in 1998 dollars, was $6,190 in 1988 and $4,269 in 1996.

title: Artist Takes an Idea And Turns It Into a Toy
description: EARTHLY S. GNOME is embarking on two journeys: one in the land of fiction, where the character created by a Rye resident, Mary Amy, leaves his parents and travels around the universe, gleaning knowledge and collecting five gems that represent peace, nature, wisdom, love and spirituality. The other is in a more practical realm, onto the shelves of book, gift and toy stores, including F.A.O. Schwarz's flagship store in Manhattan.

title: At This Stop, B and C Spell Walk
description: Starting today, subway riders who use the 81st Street station on Central Park West will have to walk four blocks south to 77th Street or five blocks north to 86th Street to get their B or C line trains.

title: In Landmark Settlement, a Question of Fees
description: FOUR years ago, some enterprising class-action lawyers filed a novel antitrust case accusing more than three dozen Wall Street brokerage houses of illegally fixing prices on stocks traded on the Nasdaq market. By last spring, against long odds, the lawyers had won settlements of more than $1 billion from the brokers, the largest such amount in antitrust history, and had helped push Nasdaq into a radical overhaul of its trading practices.

title: Candidate Is Assailed for Using 'Poll' to Get Support
description: The campaign ploy cost just $1,275.30, but it could prove politically expensive for a promising young candidate seeking to succeed a dynasty in the Connecticut House of Representatives.

title: No Headline
description: Rabbi Sender Deutsch, a leader of one of the largest Hasidic Jewish groups in the United States and the longtime chief editor and publisher of Der Yid, a Yiddish-language weekly newspaper, died on Sept. 2 at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 76 and a resident of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, where he had lived for about 45 years.

title: THE GUIDE
description: 45 Prendergasts on View

title: Even With Wells, Yankees Lack That Fighting Spirit
description: The Yankees needed the gregarious David Wells yesterday like a party needs music. Something to liven up the joint. A reason for everyone to find their groove.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALLOY, EDWIN A.
description: MALLOY-Edwin A. The Board of Trustees and staff at the Whitney Museum of American Art note with great sadness the passing of our beloved friend, Edwin A. Malloy. He will be warmly remembered for his steadfast support of American artists and his dedication to furthering the welfare and progress of American art. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Susan and family. Flora M. Biddle Honorary Chairman Leonard A. Lauder Chairman Joel S. Ehrenkranz President Maxwell L. Anderson Director

title: Miss Poole, Mr. Derbyshire
description: Sarah Smith Poole and Charles Edward Derbyshire 3d were married yesterday at the Freehold Christian Congregational Church in Freehold, N.Y. The Rev. Warren Beeman performed the ceremony.

title: Renewing Sponsor's Apartment
description: Q. I have rented from the owner and sponsor of a co-op for the last eight years. In April, the sponsor sent me a letter asking if I wished to renew my lease. In the past, he always sent a renewal lease, but this time, he only sent a letter asking if I wanted to renew. Since I was not aware whether the letter had any legal meaning, I ignored it and waited for the lease to arrive. The lease never came, and now the sponsor's lawyer has sent me a letter asking me to vacate the apartment. I have advised the sponsor that I am willing to renew my lease, plus any increase the sponsor is legally entitled to, but his reply is negative. My apartment is not rent-stabilized, but there must be some sort of protection for a tenant when a sponsor does not give proper notice. . . . Stewart Schulman, Manhasset, N.Y.

title: A Fast Ferry Speeds The Trip to Majorca
description: The ferry between Barcelona and Palma de Majorca in the Mediterranean was a state-run monopoly for 19 years until last summer, when a new private competitor, Buquebus, introduced a sleek catamaran that makes the trip in 3 hours and 25 minutes, one hour faster than the Government ferry. Yet both charge the same for a one-way ticket, $90 in first class, at 141 pesetas to the dollar, and $58 in tourist class.

title: INSIDE
description: Critical Election in Bosnia

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: UP AND COMING: Sam Rockwell; One-Man Gallery of Rogues, Crooks and Oddballs
description: SAM ROCKWELL is a master of the quick change. The 29-year-old actor showed his range in January at the Sundance Film Festival, where he was featured in not one but three films. He appeared as the romantic, James Dean-like outcast who mows lawns in John Duigan's ''Lawn Dogs,'' which opened in May; he slouched across the screen as a hilariously inept safecracker in John Hamburg's ''Safe Men,'' which opened in July, and he delivered a chilling performance as a car-salesman-turned-hitman in Saul Rubinek's dark comedy ''Jerry and Tom,'' which will also be shown this month at the Toronto Film Festival. ''Sam's got the juice,'' said Joe Mantegna, his co-star in ''Jerry and Tom.''

title: Pitching the Kitsch
description: WHEN your closets have gone from brimming to booby-trapped, and your meager rooms contain all the gimcrackery they can stand, a serious purchase has got to be followed by a serious purge.

title: At Last, A Town Will Get Its Own Address
description: Hillsborough Township is a postal patchwork quilt of no less than seven mailing addresses -- none called Hillsborough. The situation has caused confusion among people who can't find the 54-square-mile township on road maps, which often use postal zones to locate place names.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, RAYMOND
description: ROGERS-Raymond. Of Baldwin, L.I., on September 11, 1998. Veteran of World War II, retired printer for The New York Times. Beloved husband of Catharine (nee Burger) Rogers; devoted father of Marianne Rogers, Cathryn Pisano, Christine Rogers, the late Julia Rogers-Hiel, Joseph, Raymond, and Andrew Rogers. Loving grandfather of Margaret, John, Katie, Robert, James, Julianne, Christopher, Stephen, and Michael. Reposing at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave, Baldwin. Visiting hours Sunday and Monday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, at St. Christopher's R.C. Church, Baldwin. Interment following at St. Charles Cemetery.

title: High-Contrast
description: Two new musicals open this week in Atlanta, and for fans of asymmetrical experiences, it might be fun to attend both. On Thursday, Disney's ''Elaborate Lives: The Legend of Aida'' -- based on the Verdi opera, with music and lyrics by Elton John and Tim Rice -- previews at the Alliance Theater. The next night, ''Cannibal: The Musical,'' based on a film by the co-creator of ''South Park,'' Trey Parker, opens at Dad's Garage Theater. Here, a handy viewer's guide.

title: ART BY THE LOAD
description: * Please Take M.E., a ''materials exchange'' run by a group of Philadelphia artists, keeps a 2,000-item-plus inventory of ''rescued trash'' for sale to fellow artists. * Current offerings include an antique electrocardiograph and a flame-emblazoned personal sauna. * For the Philadelphia Fringe Festival (through Sept. 19), Please Take M.E. members are building floats made of (among much else) plastic bowling pins and mannequin parts. * The world's largest junk sculpture is called ''The Forevertron,'' a 315-ton ode to the cosmic powers of industry by a Wisconsin sculptor named Dr. Evermor. * Since 1977, the New York Department of Sanitation has had a resident artist, Mierle Laderman Ukeles. * Her masterwork, ''Flow City,'' features a mixed-media installation on the Hudson River, where garbage departs for the Fresh Kills landfill.

title: And the Winner Is (or Should Be)
description: ''Isn't she something?'' Gov. George C. Wallace (Gary Sinise) says proudly to an election-rally crowd, showing off his big-haired, honey-voiced young second wife, Cornelia. And she is. Angelina Jolie plays the First Lady of Alabama as a prim would-be Jackie Kennedy in public, as Tennessee Williams's Maggie the Cat in the bedroom and as Sammy Glick in moments of crisis. Her first reaction when she learns that her husband will be paralyzed after an assassination attempt is ''Well, we've got ourselves an F. D. R. candidate here.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Jungle Girl
description: Samantha Gillison's first novel, THE UNDISCOVERED COUNTRY (Grove, $23), is filled with vivid descriptions of the wondrous landscape of Papua New Guinea, but the journey at the center of this exceptional story is considerably less scenic -- and far more harrowing -- than any of her characters expect. Peter Campbell hasn't managed to secure official financing for his proposal to study the occurrence of a blood-borne parasite among the people of a remote village in the highlands, but he doesn't seem terribly grateful to his heiress wife, June, who pays for the trip both financially and emotionally. To make matters worse, when they settle down in the jungle community of Abini, it is not Peter or June but their 6-year-old daughter, Taylor, who learns the language and quickly eases into the local culture. Rather than smoothing her parents' way, the child's behavior causes a rift as Peter and June begin to fear her new ''savage'' habits. June, in particular, makes futile efforts to keep her daughter in check, but Taylor escapes more and more often into the rain forest, largely forgetting her Western upbringing. As the tension builds, Gillison deftly balances premonitions of doom with glimmers of hope, teasing readers with the possibility that the Campbells, despite a mounting array of physical and psychological dangers, may somehow find their way back to a world where their considerable flaws won't prove to be fatal. Elizabeth Gaffney

title: Gold Rush Trail
description: To the Editor: We enjoyed reading the articles in ''Reliving the Gold Rush'' (Aug. 16). My wife and I traveled the Gold Rush Trail in April and, like your correspondents, found it delightful. Let me suggest a few additional sites along the way:

title: The Beige And the Black
description: If the price blacks have to pay to have greater economic equality in America is to become beige, some of us might just want to forfeit the climb to financial bliss (''The Beige and the Black,'' by Michael Lind, Aug. 16). Strengthening the power of the black family to have access to greater social and economic opportunities should be the impetus for integration rather than for an end to race itself.

title: Daylami and Bailey Take The Man o' War Stakes
description: Ireland's Daylami, one of the best turf horses in Europe, made his debut in the United States yesterday by teaming up with the star American jockey Jerry Bailey to plant a victory flag at Belmont Park by winning the Man o' War Stakes by a length and a quarter.

title: Life in Albania Captured in Photographs
description: IN the late 1890's, H. N. Hutchinson, a Fellow of the Royal Geographic Society, produced ''The Living Races of Mankind,'' an illustrated book designed to popularize the study of ethnology. A Fellow of the Royal Geographic Society, Hutchinson believed that closer acquaintance with people in and outside the British Empire would enable the empire to ''maintain a lasting supremacy in trade'' while at the same time turning ''the half-clothed savage'' into what Sy Sims would call an ''educated consumer.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRIDEL, CAROL H.
description: KRIDEL-Carol H., 78. September 8, at home. She was the widow of William J. Kridel. She is survived by her son, William J. Kridel, Jr, of London and New York, and by her daughter, Linda K. Smith, of Beloit, Wisconsin, and by three grandchildren. Burial will be private. A memorial service will be held at Campbell's Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), Sunday, September 13 at 11:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Palliative Care Program, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, NY 10029, or to The Collegiate School, 370 West End Avenue, New York, NY 10024.

title: Sleuthing
description: To the Editor: Marilyn Stasio's essay about Seattle and its fictional detectives (''Gumshoes in the Great Outdoors,'' Aug. 23) was delightful. It was a mystery to me that during her snooping around she would find no clues that would lead her to discover that body of delicious seafood, i.e, fresh salmon, dungeness crab or halibut. Also I would like to suggest that her closing statement, that Seattle must be the best place in the country to curl up with a good book, be augmented with the phrase ''or somebody'' (or perhaps it should be ''some body'').

title: Michelle Lemay, Peter Wilhelm
description: Michelle Anne Nicole Lemay, the daughter of Dr. Helen Lemay East of Setauket, N.Y., and Dr. Richard Lemay of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Daniel Wilhelm, the son of Katharine and Ralph Wilhelm of Noblesville, Ind. Judge Louis J. Ohlig of Suffolk County Court in East Northport, N.Y., officiated with John H. Foote, the bridegroom's uncle, at the Harbor Hills Country Club in Belle Terre, N.Y.

title: Lawrence DiCapua, Brooke Smith
description: Brooke Jocelyn Smith and Lawrence Herrick DiCapua were married yesterday at Trinity-St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, N.Y. The Rev. Earle W. Pratt Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: Ms. Honeycutt, Mr. DeScherer
description: Amanda Ann Honeycutt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Honeycutt of Dunn, N.C., was married yesterday to Christopher Kaltman DeScherer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. DeScherer of New York. The Rev. Carl Butts, an uncle of the bride and a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Inn at Bingham School, a bed and breakfast in Mebane, N.C.

title: Chrysler, Owner In 70's
description: IT'S not often a man in his 70's is the same age as his car. ''Actually I was born in 1925,'' Charles J. Coulter of Southampton said. ''My car was made in 1928. So it's junior to me.''

title: The Dow Feels the Yo-Yo Effect
description: The stock market has given investors more than a few jolts lately, but some bumps aren't what they used to be.

title: Laurie Kalb, Mario Cosmo
description: Laurie Beth Kalb, the director of the New England Folklife Center, a museum in Lowell, Mass., is to be married today in North Truro, Mass., to Mario Lorenzo Cosmo, an astrophysicist at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics in Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Paul Levenson is to officiate at the home of the bride's cousin Barbara Baker and her husband, Graham Giese..

title: Aw, Rats!
description: To the Editor:

title: Road Rage Is A Media Invention
description: To the Editor:

title: The Swoon of the Swoosh
description: For some time now, the Nike swoosh has been showing up in the oddest of places, dropped like an inadvertent product plug amid the news of the day. Just before 39 members of the Heaven's Gate cult swallowed a suicide brew last year, they laced up their new black Nikes for a post-mortem chase of a spaceship they believed was trailing the Hale-Bopp comet. Benjamin Walker, a victim of the Springfield, Ore., school shooting in May, was so heavily swooshed in T-shirt and cap in the photo released by authorities that media outlets felt compelled to crop him to a tight facial mug. And then there's O.J. Simpson, the last athlete any company in the world wants to endorse its product, recently seen wearing a Nike cap.

title: Public Poise Reveals Little About Clintons
description: As America was logging on for some of the grubbier details of her husband's dalliance with a young employee, Hillary Rodham Clinton spent much of Friday alongside the President, smiling, soigne and apparently battle-ready.

title: At These Wells, No Buckets or Wishes, but Clean, Cold Water
description: On a recent afternoon, Noreen Tayler drove her black Volvo up the hill just past Clifton's City Hall and jumped out. At the back of what looked like a cement-chinked stone cottage, she turned on one of three faucets and began filling two large bottles with cool, soft water piped from a crack in the underground rock 300 feet below.

title: Style; Amazing Gres
description: Since its inception, fashion has been about the evolution of style and the pursuit of ''new.'' Yet one couturier dedicated her entire career to mastering something not only old, but ancient: the Grecian gown. For more than 50 years, Madame Gres wrapped and draped the world's most famous bodies in silk jersey and chiffon, precisely pleating the fabric by hand so it would caress a woman's curves and tumble to the floor like water flowing from an urn. There have been others -- Fortuny, Mary McFadden and Gianni Versace -- who have turned to classical Greece for inspiration, but their designs were of the moment. Madame Gres found the essential timelessness of the pleated gown, 100 of which will be auctioned at Christie's in London on Thursday. As Christian Dior noted, ''Each dress she creates is a masterpiece.''

title: Editorial Observer; As Team Prices Soar, Only Media Can Buy
description: The attention of American sports fans has been centered on the breaking of Roger Maris's home run record. But there is another record in the world of sports that is being broken by much greater margins than Mark McGwire or Sammy Sosa can hope to achieve. That is the record price for a sports franchise.

title: A Willing Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Cambodian Prince Offers Way to End Stalemate
description: An opposition leader signaled a possible way out of Cambodia's political impasse today as supporters of the two sides fought running battles in the streets with sticks, stones and slingshots.

title: Elizabeth Bylin, John Cook Jr.
description: Elizabeth Greenwood Bylin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Moore Bylin of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to John Folinsbee Cook Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Cook, also of Princeton. The Rev. Dr. Wallace Alston, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony in the Miller Chapel at the Presbyterian Theological Seminary in Princeton.

title: Camille Samuels, Travis Pearson
description: Camille Danielle Samuels, a daughter of Antoinette C. Samuels of New York and the late Howard J. Samuels, was married yesterday to Travis Ryan Pearson, the son of Diane and Ron Pearson of Plano, Tex. The Rev. T. J. Parlette performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: In Abstraction, Welcome Room for Discovery
description: NO official pronouncements ever come from the art world, but there is a widely held feeling that abstraction in its pure form, the driving force in western art for much of this century, is depleted.

title: An Epic That Defies the Disney Method
description: IN 1937, as Walt Disney put the finishing touches on his first animated feature, ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs,'' certain movie-industry figures, bankers and distributors mocked the film (sight unseen) as ''Disney's Folly.'' Audiences would never sit for over an hour watching silly cartoon characters chasing one another, said the Disney doubters.

title: WHITE HOUSE, IN REBUTTAL TO STARR, ASSAILS REPORT AS 'SMEAR CAMPAIGN'
description: Mounting a blistering counterattack to defend President Clinton from impeachment, the White House today rejected the independent counsel's charges of abuse of the Presidency as a ''hit-and-run smear campaign'' deliberately steeped in gratuitous ''pornographic specificity.''

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Germany
description: And then you make the only detour from the main road required anywhere on the trip,'' Fodor's 1966 guide to Germany orders, pleasantly enough. I was 21, on my honeymoon in Bavaria, on the Romantic Road near Steingaden. Obediently we detoured to see the Wieskirche (1746-54), having read Fodor's economical description: ''the exuberantly adorned church constituting the last and greatest masterpiece of Dominikus Zimmermann (he lies buried here), which is considered by connoisseurs to be the most beautiful rococo church is all of Germany.''

title: Splice Einstein and Sammy Glick. Add a Little Magellan.
description: It is a wonderful vicarious pleasure to see Craig Venter succeed with his research, despite funding refusals from overly conservative National Institutes of Health review panels. Nevertheless, a few items should be brought into perspective.

title: Judge Tries to Force Ex-Wife of a Terrorism Suspect to Testify
description: In an unusual move, an immigration judge handling the deportation case of a Palestinian accused of having links to terrorists has moved to force the man's former wife to disclose what she told the Federal Bureau of Investigation about him.

title: Still Living With '68
description: Ironically, a consequence of ''the 60's revolution'' has been the counterrevolution from the right. The fall of Lyndon Johnson led directly to the election of Richard Nixon. Reaction to student demonstrations led to the election of Ronald Reagan as Governor of California, thus providing him the platform from which he achieved the Presidency. Perhaps the most important consequence of the 60's was the change in the American mood from the optimism of youth to the cynicism and resignation of old age.

title: Correction
description: A chart on Aug. 30 listing the lowest air fares on popular routes omitted an available flight between New York and Milan. Alitalia too offers an unrestricted round-trip fare of $1,416.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPER, LINCOLN, M.D.
description: OPPER-Lincoln, M.D. Age 92, died quietly September 1, 1998, at home after a brief illness. He was born in New Haven, CT. After graduating from Yale University in 1927, he spent a year at the Sorbonne studying philosophy. He studied medicine at the University of Berlin and at the University of Munich, where he received his M.D. summa cum laude in 1933. He did his internship at Yale-New Haven Hospital where he was the first resident in neuropathology. He was an instructor in pathology at Yale University, assistant professor in the Department of Biochemistry at the University of Arkansas, pathologist at the Norwich State Hospital and the Backus Hospital in Norwich, CT, pathologist at the Charlotte Hungerford Hospital in Torrington, CT. For many years he was the forensic pathologist for the Connecticut State Police Department. In 1966 he took the position of director of laboratories and pathologist at the Camden Community and Knox County Hospitals in Maine, until his retirement coinciding with the opening of the new Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Rockport, ME. He is survived by one daughter, Carolyn Opper of New Haven, CT; two sons, William Opper and wife Anne of Wilton, CT, and Thomas Opper of Liberty, ME; daughter-in-law, Barbara Opper and granddaughter, Gretchen, both of Chevy Chase, MD; and a grandson Stephen of Albuquerque, NM. He was predeceased by his son Franz in 1991, and his beloved wife of 62 years, Charlotte, in 1996. A service was held September 12, 1998. The family requests that donations be made to Penobscot Bay Medical Center, 6 Glen Cove Drive, Rockport, ME 04856. For information call Laite & Pratt Funeral Home, Camden, ME.

title: Winning and Cohesion
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Men's Colorful Shirts And Offbeat Hours
description: Seeking to catch the eye of the young and hip during their nighttime perambulations, Juan Anon -- a new Lower East Side men's clothing store -- keeps unconventional hours. Situated at 193 Orchard Street (off East Houston) and nestled among a slew of trendy bars, Juan Anon is open from 8 P.M. to midnight on Thursday, Friday and Saturday. This is the first store for Wendy Juan, the owner and designer, a Texas native who has lived in New York for seven years.

title: Shots Fired Into Brooklyn Crowd, Killing One and Wounding 3
description: At least one unidentified gunman fired into a crowd early yesterday in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, killing a 33-year-old man and wounding three other people, one of them critically, the police said.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article comparing the economic environments of 1987 and 1998 misstated the middle name of a former president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York who said the world economy was now in a better position to withstand stress. He is E. Gerald Corrigan, not Daniel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, LAWRENCE
description: SINGER-Lawrence, 69. Remembered as an Innovative Teacher, Coach, Professor, dedicated Owner/Director, Camp Somerhill. Loving husband of Lynn Teper. Father of Debra and Bruce. Brother of Lois and Daniel. Supporter of the J. Jacobs Holocaust Remembrance, Friend. Missed greatly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSTER, BERTHA
description: FORSTER-Bertha. On September 12, 1998, at the age of 90. Beloved mother of Terry Seruya and Irwin and Fran Forster. Adored grandmother of Evan, Brian, Darren and Jonathan Forster; Mark and Heidi Seruya and Robin and Edgar Lampert. Great-grandmother of Jamie, Tara, Brian, Alexander, Jonathan and Emily. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: It's the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Settled, Survivor Relives Holocaust
description: IN the last few weeks, Vera Stein Werner relived the Holocaust.

title: Amsterdam: An Old Master's house adds masterly touches
description: The home of Rembrandt, where the painter worked, loved and taught for almost two decades, has gained a fine new wing, adding an entirely novel experience to one of Amsterdam's most beloved stopovers.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the musical ''Gypsy'' included one actress incorrectly in a list of those who have won Tony Awards for the role of Rose. Ethel Merman did not win; Angela Lansbury and Tyne Daly did.

title: Local Girls (Rarely) Make Good
description: THOUGH Miss New Jersey tends to finish in the top 10, only two have gone on to become Miss America, and one of those times was by accident.

title: Peer Pressure
description: THE NURTURE ASSUMPTION

title: Ms. Mazella, Mr. Rivera
description: Francesca Norton Mazella, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John S. Mazella of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married yesterday at her parents' house to Humberto Francisco Rivera, a son of Olga Castellanos of Teaneck, N.J., and Francisco Rivera of Manizales, Colombia. The Rev. Christian Iosso, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Word & Image; Snoops or Germs?
description: While deploring the loss of his own privacy this summer, President Clinton set out boldly to invade mine. His Administration promised me a healthier life if I would accept assignment of a computer code -- a number or thumb print or retina marker or other electronic gizmo to be called a U.H.I., a unique health identifier. It would instantly disclose my medical record to anyone needing to treat me anywhere, and also to those who labor to improve medical science with research.

title: Sleuthing
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed Marilyn Stasio's article linking Seattle and mysteries. But I've missed the earlier articles in the series. Since I'm a big fan of Ms. Stasio's columns about crime in the Book Review, I would like to read the earlier articles in the series.

title: F.Y.I.
description: A Piece of the Pie

title: Sticking to the Fundamentals of Scones
description: Blanca Sussman says she was only looking for a food she could bake simply, and what could be simpler than a scone? ''White flour, sugar, baking powder,'' she explained recently. ''The real trick is cutting in the butter, and you do that with a food processor. Add the fruit at the end. Bake.''

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 5/

title: John Holliman, 49, of CNN; Covered '91 Baghdad Attack
description: John Holliman, a CNN correspondent who distinguished himself by being one of only three journalists to broadcast live coverage of the 1991 bombing of Baghdad, died yesterday morning. He was 49.

title: A Friendship Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARVIS, ADRIAN A.
description: JARVIS-Adrian A. On September 10, 1998. Most wonderful loving husband of Maria (Coco), dearly beloved brother of Lelia D. Schlesinger. His lively spirit, and the love and caring that he brought to his family and friends will always be remembered. Services Monday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amersterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: September

title: Let There Be Light
description: Every day the widow Kate Walker loaded her two children in a boat and rowed them from Bayome to Staten Island, and back, so they could at tend school.

title: Response of President's Lawyers to Independent Counsel's Report
description: Following is the text of a response by President Clinton's lawyers to the report submitted by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, to the House of Representatives. The references to ''narrative at'' a given number are to specific points in Mr. Starr's report.

title: New at Brookhaven: Nuclear Security Lab
description: HEADLINES from Iraq, the former Soviet republics and Korea are a constant reminder of U.S. and international action to curb nuclear proliferation and terrorism involving nuclear, biological and chemical weapons of mass destruction.

title: A Hardy Heroine Gets Her Resolve Back
description: THERE'S no misery like misery in a beautiful setting. For Thomas Hardy, the final twist of the tragic knife relies on the old real estate maxim: location, location, location.

title: The Troubled Seas
description: As the naturalist Carl Safina observes in this month's Scientific American, it has always been hard to believe that humans might learn how to catch fish faster than the fish can reproduce -- that there are, in fact, finite limits to the bounty of a seemingly infinite sea. But that is what has happened. Highly mechanized fleets, huge government subsidies and the food needs of a growing world population have combined to put many of the world's fish stocks at risk.

title: Bombings Cast a Shadow On East African Tourism
description: THE bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania have frightened away travelers from East Africa just as Kenya was hoping for an end to a years-old slump in foreign tourism, and as Tanzania was finally beginning to reap the benefits from a major investment in the travel industry.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Aug. 30 about recordings of George Gershwin's music misspelled the surname of a singer. She was Sarah Vaughan, not Vaughn.

title: Inviting Wildlife To Dine
description: THE suburbs keep pushing deeper and deeper into land that was once wild and the habitat of many creatures. As a result, the wildlife population becomes increasingly stressed for food, shelter and living space.

title: Robin Alpert, Andrew Kaye
description: Robin Beth Alpert, a daughter of the late Belle and Julius Leonard Alpert, who lived in Brooklyn, was married last evening to Andrew Burnham Kaye, a son of Wendy Burnham Morris and Dr. Robert Edward Kaye, both of Manhattan. Rabbi David Lincoln performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: In Tourism Transit Disputes, Grenada Is the Little Guy
description: Small and vulnerable, Grenada is a typical Caribbean ministate that depends on tourism for budget revenues and jobs. So when American Airlines decided a few months ago that it would suspend daily jet service here unless the Government agreed to pay a $1.5 million annual subsidy to the airline, it was inevitable that a ruckus would ensue.

title: On the Hudson, a City Within Jersey City
description: PILE DRIVERS pound great beams of steel into the earth and cement trucks pour out their burdens as office and apartment towers keep rising on the Jersey City shore -- particularly on one vast, once-desolate tract called Newport that sparked the riverfront's rebirth.

title: Today's Lesson: What's a Bagel?; Austrians Fill a Need for Teachers and Learn the Lingo
description: Having shepherded his 33 freshmen into their first mathematics class of the school year, Richard Mesaric started his lesson, his voice loud but halting.

title: B. J. DeMeo, John Casey
description: Barbara Jeanne DeMeo, the daughter of Barbara A. Terry of New York and William R. DeMeo of Honolulu, was married last evening to John Edward Casey, a son of Charlotte F. Casey of Jamesburg, N.J., and the late Laurence J. Casey. The Rev. Donald J. Desmond performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WISHNER, JOSEPH, M.D.
description: WISHNER-Joseph, M.D. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute note with deep regret the passing of our good friend and collegue, Joseph Wishner, M.D. Dr. Wishner had the distinction of being the first orthopaedic surgery resident at HJD. He was a distinguished teacher and orthopaedic surgeon, a profession he fully retired from in his 80's. His lifetime of extraordinary dedication, enthusiasm and philanthropic support will be remembered and cherished. We grieve his passing as we celebrate his life and extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Wishner family. William A. Perlmuth Chairman of the Board John N. Kastanis, FACHE President and CEO Victor H. Frankel, M.D. President Emeritus Joseph D. Zuckerman, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief

title: The Autumn of the Revolutionary
description: I didn't need a four-page article to tell me that Daniel Ortega is history. The more interesting story, which Francisco Goldman didn't get to until the last few paragraphs of his article (''The Autumn of the Revolutionary,'' Aug. 23), concerns Zoilamerica Narvaez Murillo's charges against Ortega. When that story first broke, my question was, and still is, how did the patriarchal Latin American culture change in such a way as to make this event possible? That question remains unanswered.

title: Odette Cabrera, Raymond Duggan
description: Odette Diana Cabrera and Raymond Martin Duggan were married yesterday at St. Rosalie's Roman Catholic Church in Hampton Bays, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick Bergin performed the ceremony.

title: Vicki Porges, Joseph Eisner
description: Vicki Marlo Porges, a fourth-year medical student at New York University, was married last evening to Joseph Anthony Eisner, a New York architect and furniture designer. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the St. Regis in New York.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 13, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, LEON
description: ROSEN-Leon. On September 10, 1998, Delray Beach, FL. Formerly of Bethpage, N.Y. Beloved husband of Ruth for 54 years. Loving father of David, Mark and Hanora. Grandfather of Michael, John and Nicole. Father-in-law of Susan, Lynn and Ed. Service Sunday 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: An Offbeat Tete-a-Tete, But It's Classic Arliss
description: Responding to rumors that my favorite comedy show, ''Arliss,'' may be canceled by HBO, I called the creator and star, Robert Wuhl. He would confirm only that the show was on the endangered list. But, in his role as Arliss Michaels, the slippery sports agent, he was willing to entertain general questions about his business.

title: Congo Peace Talks End
description: A summit meeting of African leaders to negotiate a peace settlement for the Congo ended with little more than a joint statement endorsing peace as an ultimate goal. All the parties involved in the conflict got together, but they had little to show for their efforts.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Large Landscapes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, MARCELLA
description: WALDMAN-Marcella. On September 11, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Bernard, loving mother and mother-in-law of Grace and Jerome Schulman. Service Monday, 10:45 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Young Know Him
description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING IT; A Fund Manager In Kansas Keeps His Eye on Europe
description: MANAGING money for Waddell & Reed Investment Management in the rolling hills of Overland Park, Kan., Thomas A. Mengel is a long way from his European roots. Born in West Germany, he spent many of his school years in Milan, and he speaks four languages. And though he says he enjoys the ''very livable'' quality of life near Kansas City, he acknowledges missing Italy's Renaissance architecture as well as his relatives and friends on the Continent.

title: Amy Schimmel and Richard Tyroler
description: Amy Lynn Schimmel and Richard Mark Tyroler were married last evening at the Park Savoy, a catering business in Florham Park, N.J. Rabbi Gerald Heller performed the ceremony.

title: Designs for Students, Stars and Travelers
description: JOHN Naisbitt, the futurist, put it this way: When Asians like something, they call it modern. When they don't, they call it western. Since discouraging words are officially frowned upon in Singapore today, it is fair to predict that the new campus of Singapore's Nanyang Polytechnic will be received as modern through and through. It is also a safe bet that the crisp design of the campus will not soon be marred by unsightly wads of chewing gum.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about preparations for school openings misidentified the second-grade teacher unpacking at the J. Spencer Smith School in Tenafly. She was Kim Newman, not Judy Hanley.

title: Campaign Finance Bill Dies
description: The Senate effectively buried an overhaul of campaign finance laws for this year. Senators voted 52 to 48 to cut off debate and vote on a bill to ban unlimited, unregulated donations, called soft money, to political parties. But supporters failed to muster the 60 votes needed to end a Republican filibuster, so the bill was withdrawn.

title: In Papua New Guinea, Nature At Its Most Flamboyant
description: After a day of diving we put into a forested bay following a pod of spinner dolphins almost up to shore, where children were playing and a dugong was munching weeds, unconcerned by their racket. The village, half-concealed in the forest, seemed a sizable one for New Guinea, yet snorkeling in the shallows, I found numerous fish, two octopuses and a green mantis shrimp -- the first I had ever seen -- scurrying over the bottom, its strange E.T. eyes swiveling around on stalks. For a while I floated on my back in the warm green water watching a flight of white cockatoos overhead and listening to the raucous cries of parrots. On shore, smoke was going up from the thatched houses, and three small pigs were taking an evening constitutional. Back at the boat men in outrigger canoes were handing baskets of pumpkins up to the cook and gossiping with the crew.

title: Pollock and Monet: Distant Kinship
description: HE was dubbed the ''young man from Wyoming'' in the publicity for his first show 55 years ago. Never mind that he actually spent less than a year in Cody, a turn-of-the-century tract development cooked up by William (Buffalo Bill) Cody, or that he went to high school in Los Angeles until he dropped out to move to New York City.

title: Milan
description: Some Italian cities, like Naples or Palermo, have a hard time being sedate. Ask them to spin a pirouette or dance a tarantella, and they're in their element. But Milan is not a tarantella -- it's a slow tango, a cool, understated place with a measured step, where excitement can mean strolling to the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele, the glassed-in Beaux-Arts shopping concourse adjacent to the Duomo, to down a cappuccino or just to see and be seen.

title: It's a Guy Thing
description: REAL BOYS Rescuing Our Sons From the Myths of Boyhood. By William Pollack. 447 pp. New York: Random House. $24.

title: Atlantic City; At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Sneak Previews Or One-Time-Only
description: AMERICAN art lovers with a taste for the sneak preview will have a field day in Europe this fall. They can get a first look at several major exhibitions that promise to be highlights of the coming season in the United States. And they can savor shows that carry the particular cachet of not appearing outside of Europe at all.

title: A Sixth Branch In an Indian Restaurant Chain
description: Baluchi's, a chain of Indian restaurants owned by Rakesh Aggarwal and named after Baluchistan, a region that borders Iran and Pakistan, opened its latest branch last month at 63d Street and First Avenue. The first of the six sites was opened at 193 Spring Street (near Thompson Street) in January 1993.

title: Restore the Shell, Neighbors Say
description: Five years after a court ruling saved the Naumburg Band Shell from demolition, a plan for its restoration has gained broad local support. But community boards around the park say the Parks Department has not responded to requests to repair the 75-year-old band shell, which presides over Bethesda Mall just south of the 72d Street transverse.

title: Pass the Salt
description: EAT THE RICH

title: On the Front Lines
description: JANE RODNEY got back to work as director of the Breast Cancer Resource Center, for the first time since the end of May, at 7:30 the morning after Labor Day. It was earlier than her usual starting time, though the phone was ringing by 7:45. ''I just walked around here,'' she said later in the day. ''I felt so happy. I was home.''

title: Clinton's Legal Team Awaits the Public's Response to His Risky Political Gamble
description: President Clinton's closest advisers waited nervously today to see whether the most audacious political gamble of his career -- declaring last month that he told the truth when he swore he did not have a sexual relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky -- would cause the public to turn on his inquisitors rather than on him.

title: Mr. Miss America
description: Leonard Horn doesn't want to be remembered as the man who put singing, tap-dancing, piano-playing young women into two-piece bathing suits.

title: 4 Storm-Damaged Counties to Get Federal Aid
description: Four counties in central New York that were ravaged by a fierce Labor Day storm have been declared Federal disaster areas.

title: The Blockbuster Script Factory
description: 'The Blockbuster Script Factory'' shines bright light on the challenges of group creativity. It is appropriate that Robin Swicord makes the case against assembly-line movie making with her version of an old saying: ''A camel is an animal built by committee.''

title: Sosa Reaches Ruth's 60, And the Chase Isn't Over
description: CUBS 15, BREWERS 12

title: Frankfurt: Europe's hub gets better (but stop for the ballet)
description: Some cities are famous for their cultural life, others for history or night life. Frankfurt, perhaps unjustly, is famous primarily for its airport.

title: If It's Ghastly, Why Is Everyone Laughing?
description: IN a darkened Manhattan screening room, the disintegration of a family is unfolding, including incidents of everything from divorce to pedophilia. Seated in the audience, the director John Waters is laughing. So are the other viewers, although they are also shifting uncomfortably in their seats.

title: Ms. Limbardo And Mr. Macri
description: Michelle Marie Limbardo, the daughter of Electra and Antonio S. Limbardo of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Marcantonio Domenico Macri, a son of Maria J. Macri, also of Fort Lee, and the late Dominic Macri. Msgr. Joseph Manz performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany in Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Q&A/Dwight G. Smith; Tracking Birds for Insights on All of Nature
description: DWIGHT G. SMITH spends much of his time outdoors, observing birds. Dr. Smith, a professor of biology at Southern Connecticut State University, has published 10 books including the Connecticut Birding Guide (Thomson-Shore, 1996), written with Arnold (Buzz) Devine. His bird work extends to the western United States, Alaska, Siberia, southern Africa and Venezuela.

title: The Nation; Impeachment or Censure: Either Precedent's Ugly
description: IMPEACHMENT, censure or resignation? As far as the American Presidency goes, history offers one instance of each.

title: Composting for Mushrooms Moves Indoors
description: HAVING grown up in mushroom country, Charles Raskob Robinson remembers days when the stench wafting from nearby composting operations would take his breath away.

title: Hit-and-Run
description: Reservation Road

title: Shedding Its Skin
description: Those who use Westchester's Bee-Line bus system will find something missing next year. Some may yearn for the bright decorations, but others, like County Legislator Louis A. Mosiello, Republican of Yonkers, said recently, ''Good riddance!''

title: A Place for Casual Eating in Pawling
description: A FEW years ago we noticed that the decor at McKinney & Doyle's Fine Foods Cafe here, once so witty and charming, was becoming more commonplace and a few more tables had been added. That direction has not shifted. Now the old sign prohibiting whining is no longer quite so amusing, as we waited too long to be seated, as diners who were seated after us were attended to first, as on one evening the kitchen was out of quite a few items on the short menu -- calf's liver, trout, salmon. (Didn't anyone shop?)

title: A Veteran of Nixon's Fall Now Defends a President
description: Representative John Conyers Jr., the Michigan Democrat who is the ranking minority member on the House Judiciary Committee, probably knows more about impeachment procedures than most other members of Congress. He was on the committee in 1974, the year the committee -- with his strong approval -- voted to impeach Richard M. Nixon.

title: Trailing the Phantom Cat
description: Since the winter of 1995, reports of a shadowy creature with fangs and whiskers -- the much-rumored Eastern cougar -- have haunted yards and golf courses in suburban Philadelphia and Wilmington, Del. No one's managed a discernible photo, but pets have vanished and a Pennsylvanian named Lee Carlen swears he'll never return to the bike trail where a cougar supposedly chased his all-terrain-vehicle. The Eastern cougar was hunted to extinction long ago, so game experts figure the phantom is either a dog or collective delusion. But recent maulings in Canada have persuaded law-enforcement officials to assign a man to patrol the area -- just in case. Here's a look.

title: The View From/Somers; Whoops and Hollers: Must Be Fans of Bluegrass
description: IT was one of those moments when audience members and performers seemed completely attuned to one another. John Herald, singer, guitarist, top-notch showman, was introducing ''Foggy River'' to several hundred fans at a bluegrass festival at Muscoot Farm here.

title: A Family Apart
description: SHAME

title: Mets Fall Back in Wild-Card Bid
description: A lot of the moves Mets Manager Bobby Valentine has made this season have worked out, no matter how unusual they may have seemed at the time. But tonight, a couple of them backfired in a 5-3 loss to the Montreal Expos. And now the Mets are a game behind the Chicago Cubs in the National League wild-card race.

title: The Welcome Mat Is Back
description: IT is hardly news that 1998 has been a disaster for small-capitalization stock funds. The average such fund has lost 19.5 percent through Sept. 4, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher.

title: Manifest Destiny
description: WHAT AMERICA OWES THE WORLD

title: Philharmonic Personalizes Its Invitations
description: ON a sound financial footing for the first time ever, the Long Island Philharmonic is preparing for its 20th-anniversary season with one major hurdle to overcome: anonymity.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Tale of a Sky-Blue Dress

title: Bronx Assemblywoman Is Facing a Tough Challenge
description: Looking slightly wilted after an afternoon of door-to-door campaigning, Assemblywoman Gloria Davis paused among the tidy, suburban-looking homes in the Charlotte Gardens section of the Bronx to take stock of her re-election effort.

title: POSTINGS: New Englewood Cliffs Complex; 19 Homes On 4 Acres
description: A long-vacant patch of land less than a mile north of the George Washington Bridge in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., will be the site of a complex of 19 detached houses designed to blend in with the surrounding neighborhood.

title: Fashion Game, Set And Match
description: Except for Wimbledon, the days of all-white tennis gear are long gone. But at this year's United States Open, the women seemed to compete in a grand slam event of daring style. Monica Seles may have lost early to Martina Hingis, but she made it to the fashion finals in her lingerie-sheer, micro-mini black nylon dress by Nike, which reminded fashion editors of a Givenchy couture cocktail dress. Underneath, it had a form-fitting body suit made from Dri-Fit (a fabric that helps perspiration evaporate quickly), which let her change the dress right on court. Ms. Hingis wore her hair in a vertical ponytail, borrowing from Patrick Rafter, last year's men's champion. Mary Pierce added points to her fashion ranking with accessories: pearls and a tattoo peaking from the shoulder of her signature body-hugging Nike dresses (a look booed at the French Open). Anna Kournikova stopped short of the bikini-style outfits she's often photographed in, sporting instead sexy little skirts and dresses. Venus Williams aced the bra-top competition, wearing revealing halter, T-back tops from a line she helped design. ''Tennis isn't about country club dressing anymore,'' said David Crosland, a fashion editor at Out magazine and a hospitality coordinator at the Open. ''The women are more fit than they've ever been, and they want to show it.''

title: Chinese Checkers
description: EAST AND WEST

title: People Say Chickens Are Tough Neighbors
description: Ed Heins recalled a day last month when he had to take extra care getting into his car outside his Union Street home. ''I had to step over putrefied chicken guts,'' he said.

title: Hard Rock To Rap, The Trend Is to Blend
description: DAVE MATTHEWS

title: Zeneida Disla, Raymond Thorne
description: Zeneida Antonia Disla and Raymond Edward Thorne are to be married this afternoon by the Rev. Leonard Tuozzolo at St. Mark the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan.

title: Uncovering the Opera Within 'Streetcar'
description: ''WE'VE had this date with each other from the beginning.'' No, not Stanley and Blanche. Theater and music.

title: Basquiat Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Davenport Proves to Be Too Powerful for Hingis
description: Whether or not it is true that good things come to those who wait, Lindsay Davenport was tired of waiting. Yesterday, she did something extreme to erase her lingering case of bridesmaid syndrome at Grand Slam events: she used a slam-bang debut in a Grand Slam finale to capture the women's championship at the 1998 United States Open.

title: Rangers' Disaster Begets a Year of Reckoning
description: From his spacious corner office high above Madison Square Garden, Neil Smith of the Rangers can survey midtown Manhattan -- as well as the executive landscape of both his local sports market and the entire National Hockey League. Among the nine major professional teams in the New York area, only one other general manager has seniority over Smith: Lou Lamoriello of the Devils, who took his job in 1987, two years before Smith joined the Rangers for the 1989-90 season. Of the 26 other general managers in the N.H.L., only three have been with the same teams longer than Smith: Lamoriello, Glen Sather of Edmonton and Harry Sinden of Boston.

title: Clifford Grobstein, 82, Biologist Who Applied Ethics to Research
description: Dr. Clifford Grobstein, a scientist, university administrator and leading framer of the ethical questions raised by advances in developmental biology, died on Sept. 6 in La Jolla, Calif. He was 82 years old and lived in Rancho Santa Fe.

title: Going Green on Screen
description: In olden times -- say, before 1995 -- you had to go to a museum to visit its collection or to a garden to see its blossoms. Nowadays, of course, all that has changed; every cultural institution worth its salt has an Internet presence.

title: Melissa Gold, William Jelinek
description: Melissa Raff Gold, a vice president and assistant general counsel at Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, is to be married this afternoon to William Jelinek, a trademark lawyer at the Estee Lauder Companies in New York. Rabbi Elias J. Lieberman is to officiate at the Provincetown Inn in Provincetown, Mass.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Spin Cycle:

title: INVESTING IT; Trading in the Rumor Mill, An Entrepreneur Harvests The Market Grapevine
description: IT'S 9 A.M., and rumor central is abuzz.

title: Back to Vietnam, This Time to Build
description: THE last time Samuel F. Champi was in Vietnam, he was a 24-year-old Army engineer, building a 1,000-foot-long steel bridge across the Ban Thach River on the central coast. The bridge was to be a crucial link on the main north-south highway used by American military convoys, so he pulled round-the-clock shifts to complete it by early 1969.

title: Tanzania on Foot: A Stroll in the Serengeti
description: ''Not many people in the world have a chance to experience this,'' says our guide, Tim Corfield.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: Here is a selective guide to coming theatrical events in New York City and beyond. Unless indicated otherwise, all dates listed are for openings, all addresses are in Manhattan, and all telephone numbers have a 212 area code. The addresses and phone numbers of frequently mentioned theaters are on page 19.

title: Plugged In To Broadway
description: Break a leg, knock 'em in the aisles, stage-door Johnny, stage mother, stage-struck, twofer, understudy. . .much of the language of the theater has become the language of the street. But not all of it, and as the curtain raises on a new Broadway season -- check out today's Arts & Leisure section for previews -- it's a good chance to consider some of the most enlightening theatrical terms.

title: Duke Hopes Gateses' Gift Will Inspire New Genius
description: For nearly two decades, the MacArthur Foundation has rewarded genius by giving grants to creative individuals.

title: London: A new train to the plane is a traveler's dream
description: Heathrow Airport is not far from central London, but getting there and back has always been a traveler's nightmare. Faced with the miserable prospect of a traffic-choked and expensive taxi ride into town, many tourists choose instead to travel more cheaply on the London Underground, only to find that it quickly becomes uncomfortably crowded, has little space for luggage, makes dozens of irritating stops and, as subways do, suffers the occasional slowdown, evacuation or full-scale breakdown.

title: Buy New Plants and Tend the Old Ones
description: Scour nurseries for bargains on spring and summer flowering trees, shrubs and perennials. Look for Japanese apricot (Prunus mume) and witch hazels (Hamamelis species) to enliven winter landscapes with color and fragrance. Plant on an overcast day in the cool morning or late afternoon. Dig the hole as deep as the root ball and twice as wide. Be sure to untie and unwrap balled and burlaped trees.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HAIMES, MADELAINE
description: HAIMES-Madelaine. Your first birthday away from us. Mady dear, we remember you with sadness and love. Barbara, Ted and Alex

title: Finding a ticket to Europe's cultural cornucopia
description: Where to write or call for more information about the events mentioned by the critics.

title: Mystery Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Sensuous Empire
description: Lawrence Durrell

title: Put on That Tiara and Do the Electric Slide
description: THE SETTING: The Great Bridal Expo, a traveling exhibition of wares -- from colanders to contraceptives -- for the soon-to-be married, came to the Marriott Hotel on Adams Street Tuesday night. It was the first time in about 10 years that Brooklyn has been on the event's national itinerary, said Bill Heaton, president of Bridal Expos, which co-produces the event with Modern Bride magazine. More than 1,000 people came to view the displays, compete for door prizes and see the bridal fashion show.

title: Counting Deer, and Counting on Hunting to Cull Them
description: For the moment, New Jersey's huge population of white-tailed deer is foraging steadily through woods, farms and backyards, trying to put on weight before winter hits. The fawns, most about 4 months old now, are losing their spots, and the bucks are beginning to mark their territory, rubbing the velvet from their antlers onto branches and scraping up patches of dirt to urinate on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSLOW, FRANCES VIRGINIA WILLIAMS
description: COSLOW-Frances Virginia Williams. Of Studio City, CA, died August 7. A memorial service was held on August 11, in Studio City. Burial was in Enid, Oklahoma, where she was born and raised. She lived most of her adult life in Miami and New York, moving to California in 1995. Frances was a professional singer and entertainer, performing with The Noble & King singing group, known as The Royalty & Song. She appeared in London at a command performance for Princess Margaret and spent two years on USO tours. In 1953 she married Academy Award composer Samson Coslow, whose songs included ''Cocktails for Two'' and ''My Old Flame.'' Frances is survived by daughter Cara Louise Coslow, of Los Angeles, head of casting at Carsey-Werner Co.; two stepchildren, Jackie Coslow Eliopoulos of Katonah, NY, and Larry Coslow of Oklahoma; two brothers, Wayne I. Williams and John W. Williams, and one sister, Betty McCormick, all of Enid; six grandchildren and numerous nieces and nephews. Frances is beloved and deeply missed by family and friends.

title: It's Official: Trump Won't Get Atlantic City House
description: After five years, the question of whether Vera Coking had to sell her house in Atlantic City to Donald Trump so he could use it for a parking lot has been put to rest. The Casino Reinvestment Development Authority voted 10 to 0 last week not to appeal a Superior Court decision that said the authority could not take Ms. Coking's property and two nearby businesses by eminent domain because it did not have enough assurance from Mr. Trump the land would be used for the public good. The Trump organization agreed not to appeal the July 20 decision.

title: Gore Makes a Strong Statement Of His Support for the President
description: In his first extended remarks about the scandal enveloping President Clinton, Vice President Al Gore made a strong statement of support for him today, saying the independent counsel report issued on Friday provided insufficient grounds for impeachment.

title: Vibrant Choices at a Hamptons Spot
description: THE Laundry is the most un-Hamptons of Hampton restaurants. Its food is just as exciting as that at the most talked about newcomer, but its style, look and philosophy set it apart.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: MUSIC

title: Starr Report Recalls Outlook Of a Preacher in Rural Texas
description: Kenneth W. Starr, a deeply religious man, whose father, a fundamentalist minister, used to deliver sermons back home in Texas on the perils of women dressed in Bermuda shorts, has sent an impeachment report to Congress chock-full of explicit sex. And Wanda Cates of Crowell, Tex., is not surprised.

title: New or Old, Opera Steals The Show
description: MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS

title: In America; Still Doesn't Get It
description: David Maraniss, in his biography of Bill Clinton, ''First in His Class,'' writes about an ''intense relationship'' that Mr. Clinton had with a young woman who had volunteered to work in his first campaign for public office. Mr. Clinton was running for Congress and the woman was a student at the University of Arkansas.

title: The Blockbuster Script Factory
description: Jaime Wolf's article ''The Blockbuster Script Factory'' (Aug. 23) was hilarious. Just one question: Jaime and who else wrote it?

title: Many Editors Decide to Publish Details of the Report
description: The nation's newspaper editors, who often ride herd on themselves to keep intimate sexual material out of their pages, decided in large numbers on Friday that they had no choice but to publish some of the raunchiest details of a document that fused civic, legal and sexual issues into one seamless, X-rated package.

title: These Memories Are Made of Cash
description: COLLECTORS of sports memorabilia were already having a difficult time finding Mark McGwire mementos before Tuesday night, when the St. Louis slugger hit his 62d home run, surpassing Roger Maris's record for home runs in a season. After all, McGwire has turned down commercial ventures to sell his autograph, though he signs for fans before most games.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, VICTOR P.
description: MARTIN-Victor P. Suddenly on September 11, 1998. Retired Senior Administrator Assistant for the NYC Board of Education. Served with 1st Armed Division during WW II in North Africa and Italy. Trumpeter in the Black Hawk Band of the 1st Armed Division. Survived by two nieces, Patricia Fiust, Evelyn Muller. Also survived by seven great-nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends Sunday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30, Lang - Tobia - DiPalma Funeral Home, Inc., 406 Deer Park Ave., Babylon, LI. Religious services Monday, 10 AM, at funeral home. In lieu of flowers donations to Cancer Society. Cremation private.

title: Metaphysical Lure Of the Home Run
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Unbreakable Records
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Geneva: Choose your theater: one plush, one stark
description: The Grand Theatre, a beloved and prestigious Geneva institution, is about to reopen after a thorough overhaul that kept it closed for a year. The $13 million renovation project equipped the old house with state-of-the-art stage machinery and made other improvements, including the replacement of the nearly 1,500 seats with ones with in red velvet cushions.

title: A Step Toward Health
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Kiley and Mr. Mendrzycki
description: Jennifer Anne Kiley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kiley of Hawley, Pa., was married on Friday to Edward Casimir Mendrzycki Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mendrzycki of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Raymond P. Kiley officiated at Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in Hawley.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: UP AND COMING: Hope Davis; Lucky for Her, She Flunked the 'Nuprin' Audition
description: WITH her ethereal, makeup-free face, lank blond hair and an often winsome expression, Hope Davis would seem to be the epitome of the indie-film actress. In 1996, she broke through with two small but critically acclaimed movies, ''Daytrippers'' and ''The Myth of Fingerprints.'' Now she has three new films coming out, the first of them an independent called ''The Impostors,'' a comedy opening next month that reunites Ms. Davis with her ''Daytrippers'' co-star Stanley Tucci. The two others are bigger-budget studio films opening next year, the thriller ''Arlington Road,'' with Jeff Bridges, and a Lawrence Kasdan comedy, ''Mumford.''

title: A Cubist Vision of Theater as Sculpture in Motion
description: FROM Dali to David Hockney, Picasso to Howard Hodgkin, numerous artists this century have designed for the live arts, devising sets or costumes -- and sometimes both -- for theater, opera and ballet productions on both sides of the Atlantic. But even with that distinguished lineup, there's something startling about the dance and opera designs of Fernand Leger (1881-1955), the French cubist whose creative contribution to the performing arts in Paris on and off over some 30 years proceeded in tandem with the abstract geometric canvases for which he remains best known.

title: Soft Decor
description: Falling asleep in your clothes never seemed that appealing. But now Maxfield Parish, known for lavish leather and shearling jackets, is introducing a home collection to be carried by Henri Bendel that makes it seem redundant to dress in the first place. There are leather blankets (starting at $1,300), rabbit throws with cashmere backing ($1,400 to $5,000) and beanbag chairs in shearling (above), $2,400.

title: Tours Linking Bicycles And Black History
description: MOST people would not see a natural link between the Connecticut Bicycle Coalition and the Amistad Committee. The goal of the former is to promote bicycling for transportation and recreation; the goal of the latter is to promote the Connecticut Freedom Trail, with 78 sites of significance in African American history.

title: In London, New Home For Sadler's Wells
description: Sadler's Wells Theater will get a new home on its old site when it reopens on Oct. 12, with computerized stage flying machinery, state-of-the-art lighting and a glass facade that will act as a video screen. The theater, which dates to 1683, has been closed for two years for the $82 million construction project. Situated in Islington, about three miles from central London, Sadler's Wells is the second oldest working theater in London after Drury Lane. It is the city's main stage for touring dance companies and was the first home to the company that eventually became the Royal Ballet.

title: Grazing in Park And Thereabouts
description: FRED'S +

title: Sharpton-Led March Gets Warm Reception
description: Denouncing a Labor Day parade float that featured white men, including two firefighters and at least one police officer, wearing blackface in Queens, the Rev. Al Sharpton and more than 100 supporters marched peacefully into the tiny island community of Broad Channel, where some white residents welcomed them with lemonade, water and crumb cake.

title: Madrid Sticks With Classics
description: MADRID, as befits Spain's capital, pulsates with culinary activity and embraces restaurants of every description, from humble taverns featuring age-old Spanish regional dishes to world class establishments that are proud of their innovative cooking. Yet as scores of new restaurants open and others close forever, the city's finest restaurants are the very same ones that established their reputations 20, 30, even 50 years ago.

title: Aiming to Thwart Theft Behind the Counter
description: KELLY GREEN and Karri Carter spent a night late last month in McLean County Jail in Bloomington, Ill. Both were sales clerks from the nearby Wal-Mart, arrested in the store and charged with ringing up sales to phantom customers, recording bogus returns and then pocketing cash refunds of more than $300.

title: THE 1998 CAMPAIGN: After Fast Start, Ferraro's Race For the Senate Seems Listless
description: On that January afternoon when Geraldine A. Ferraro re-entered politics -- in a crowded and expectant hotel ballroom, with a CNN crew waiting for a live interview and an airplane waiting on the runway -- her victory seemed an almost foregone conclusion. Ms. Ferraro, the political celebrity and symbol of feminist achievement, appeared poised to seize what had been denied her six years ago: a chance to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Questions Abound As Camp Opens
description: For a second straight year, the Islanders will begin training camp with questions bigger than line combinations or who will be their starting goaltender. The embarrassing failed attempt by John Spano to buy the franchise haunted the team last year. Today, the day of this season's first practice, they do not have an arena to call home.

title: Volunteers Are Needed In Cleanup
description: VOLUNTEERS are needed next Saturday to clean up the shorelines of Long Island Sound and the Hudson River in the 1998 Annual Beach Cleanup, which is coordinated by the American Littoral Society, a coastal conservation organization. According to statistics compiled by the organization in last year's beach cleanup, more than 9,000 volunteers, including Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, civic organizations, environmental groups, dive clubs, corporations and interested individuals, removed debris from 310 sites on 287 miles of shoreline, documenting more than 176,000 pounds of garbage. One hundred and ninety-one divers cleaned 11 underwater sites.

title: Less Than a Country Club, but Much More
description: EVERYTHING has its season and now that the children are tucked away in school, we have finally re-entered the Season of Productivity.

title: Bosnian Elections Test Western Resolve
description: Bosnia is voting this weekend in elections that are the most tension-free since the war, and in many ways the most important.

title: Innocence and Experience
description: FOR KINGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONSHIK, JACOB, M.D.
description: DONSHIK-Jacob, M.D. Survived by his loving wife, Frieda; his children Sharon, Peter, Irwin, and Ellen, grandchildren Russell, Leigh, Dan, Adam, and great-granddaughter Mikayla. He will be deeply missed and always remembered.

title: Constitutional Law Scholars Say Public Will Be the Judge
description: Experts on constitutional law said yesterday that some of the scathing accusations in the report by the Whitewater independent counsel could, if proven, be appropriately defined as impeachable offenses within the meaning of the Constitution.

title: Fitting All the Pieces Of the Look Together
description: HUNDREDS of students heading back to school stopped by Neil Roberts School Uniform Outlet Store in Waterbury during the final days of summer vacation, all seeking the uniform to meet the requirements of the Waterbury Board of Education's new policy.

title: Jazz-Filled Gathering Of Neighbors
description: THE members of the local jazz dream team assembled for a concert today at the Montclair Art Museum may come from the same place geographically -- Montclair or nearby East Orange -- but musically, they are all over the map.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Feminist Difference

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARTZ, GERTRUDE SHULMAN
description: ARTZ-Gertrude Shulman. September 1, Charleston, West Va. Loving wife of the late Hy. Mother, grandmother, sister and Aunt.

title: Bungalows by the Bay Get Some Imposing Neighbors
description: Beaux-Arts and Broad Channel were two phrases rarely heard together -- until Charles Howard began building his stucco mansion next to a cluster of rickety bungalows on Channel Road. ''It's right out of the Gilded Age,'' Mr. Howard said of his three-story house, with its mahogany front doors, grand staircase, five fireplaces, 36-foot cathedral ceiling and large, round indoor pool.

title: The Democratic Candidates for Governor at a Glance
description: On Tuesday, Democratic voters will choose a candidate to face Gov. George E. Pataki from among four contenders: Charles J. Hynes, James L. Larocca, Betsy McCaughey Ross and Peter F. Vallone.

title: Ms. Burger, Mr. Gamper
description: Amy Lauren Burger, a daughter of Rosanne and Albert L. Burger Jr. of Wooster, Ohio, was married yesterday to Christopher Jordan Gamper, the son of Janice and Albert R. Gamper Jr. of Far Hills, N.J. The Rev. Evelyn N. Manzella performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Wooster.

title: A Jagged Voice Comes Back a Star
