description: THE aftershocks from Alanis Morissette's ''Jagged Little Pill'' haven't subsided since the album was released in 1995. In one pop-culture masterstroke, the album introduced a mainstream audience to what punks, post-punks, riot grrrls and alternative rockers had been shouting for more than a decade: that women were angry, intelligent, carnal, sick of being victims and ready to speak for themselves.

title: Solving the Mysteries of a Rising Sea
description: THE sea level is rising 2 millimeters a year, too little to notice year to year but enough to send the waves toward beach houses and sea walls over the next two generations.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: September

title: Seeking Platelet Donors For an Ailing Woman
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Where Are the Raging Hordes of Yesteryear?
description: FINALLY, this year's United States Open had a bit of bustle. All it took was a return of Super Saturday, an American woman winning the American tennis tournament and an American champion hobbling to a semifinal loss.

title: Ms. Neuhaus And Mr. Kilgore
description: Kimberly Sautelle Neuhaus, and Donald Edgar Kilgore 4th were married yesterday in the Tennis House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Lisel Burns, the leader of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: Forestalling Judgment On H.O.V. Lanes
description: None of the letters on H.O.V. lanes [Aug. 23] referred to the principal reason for construction of high-occupancy vehicle lanes on the Long Island Expressway.

title: From Colonel, to Boss, To Good Old Gehrig
description: In reminiscing about his life in baseball, Joe DiMaggio recalled moments with Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig and Yankee owners from Col. Jacob Ruppert to George Steinbrenner.

title: The Stresses of Distilling Drama From Life
description: ON the wintry, weedy grounds of an abandoned psychiatric hospital outside Boston, John Travolta and Robert Duvall locked bright blue gaze with pale blue gaze, breath steaming in the cold as they engaged in a verbal dogfight befitting the two lawyers they were playing in the film version of ''A Civil Action.''

title: Rafter Overcomes a Hobbled Sampras
description: A muscle in Pete Sampras's tightly wound body thwarted him yesterday, as did the man fast becoming the rival most people have wished for Sampras to have. Hampered by an injury to his left upper leg, Sampras succumbed to Patrick Rafter in a five-set match that had a greater sense of inevitability than a grand sense of climax.

title: Stupefaction in France, but Calls for Resignation in Britain
description: The Starr report on President Clinton dominated news reports in Europe on Friday night and today.

title: Are Full-Time Mothers a Threat?; Workplace Must Change
description: To the Editor:

title: For Giants' Gray, Growing Up Was a Lesson in History
description: Carlton Gray remembers when he was 8 years old and went on a business trip with his grandfather.

title: Evil's Humble Home
description: In a sense, it defeats architecture -- Theodore Kaczynski's house, viewed here where it now resides, prosaically almost prayerfully in Sacramento, preserved as ''evidence'' by a judge's order, in a warehouse, on an Air Force base, miles away from its proper, glenny setting in the forests of Montana. If architecture is the art of enclosing space for a purpose, Kaczynski's house warns us not to seek that space, not to go inside, not to be too curious for what is or was within. Ornament wastes resources, thought the architect Adolf Loos, who felt all ornamentation was a crime. But this is shelter tending more than usually in the direction of less, toward a cave, reminding us of those abodes where an elderly man is found to keep 200 cats or 80 years of The Bergen Record. Crime is just another form of banality.

title: His Debut as a Woman
description: David Buechner darts around his Upper West Side apartment consumed by that prosaic ritual known as spring cleaning. Few domestic chores carry as much metaphoric heft -- casting off winter's accumulated dust and detritus, embracing renewal and rebirth -- but for the 39-year-old classical pianist, the task has been especially symbolic. Strewn beneath the Steinway grand that fills the living room are piles of tailored Italian suits, unassuming cashmere sweaters and a lifetime's worth of ties, all bound for the Salvation Army. In a newly purged closet, arranged according to hue, hang the season's latest acquisitions: a summery frilled blouse, a plum chiffon dress, a black Chanel gown and dozens of off-the-rack dresses. ''I guess this is what they mean when they say 'coming out of the closet,' '' cracks Buechner with a weary smile.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THACHER, JOHN TABER
description: THACHER-John Taber. Formerly of Garden City, New York, died on September 11, 1998 in Exeter, NH. Born on December 20th, 1912 in Syracuse, NY, he attended Loomis School and graduated from Yale University in 1934. Husband of the late Mary Louise (nee Van Schaick) and father of Carol (Mrs Robert Weekes of Richmond, NH) and Mimi (Mrs. Edward Tate of Rye Beach, NH), 7 grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. He held executive positions with the National Association of Manufacturers, Employers Labor Relations Information Committee, and C.A.R.E., Inc, and worked independently as a management consultant. Mr. Thacher was an ardent fisherman and golfer. He was a long time member and former president of the Garden City Golf Club, and also served on various committees of the Metropolitan Golf Association. He was a member of the United States Seniors Golf Association, the 200 Club and other senior golf groups. In Exter, he resided at RiverWoods, a retirement community. A memorial service will be held at Christ Episcopal Church, in Exeter, Saturday, October 3 at 2 P.M., with interment in Indian Mound Cemetery in Moravia, New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Metropolitan Golf Association, 49 Knollwood Road, Elmsford, New York 10523 or The NH Chapter of the Nature Conservancy, 2-1/2 Beacon Street, Concord, N.H. 03301.

title: Doris Lee, Andreas Sohmen-Pao
description: Doris Susan Lee, a daughter of Young Sook Lee and Dr. Chol Lee of Grymes Hill, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Andreas Sohmen-Pao, a son of Anna Sohmen and Dr. Helmut Sohmen of Hong Kong. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan.

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: UP AND COMING: Monica Potter; An Early Lesson in Self-Confidence Pays Off
description: MONICA POTTER'S first brush with success happened half a lifetime ago in her hometown, Cleveland, when she was a 13-year-old actress in a local television commercial. With awestruck sincerity, she described the manifold uses of a silicon spray, a product that could shine, unstick or otherwise improve practically any household item. ''I played the daughter in a perfect family, but the ad had no budget, no wardrobe, nothing,'' recalled Ms. Potter, who made her small-screen debut wearing an outfit borrowed from friends. ''If I could find that tape, I think I'd die laughing.''

title: They Say He's Perfect for the Job Because He's Good With Figures
description: HE'S more than perfect for the job,'' Leonard Horn said of his replacement, Robert L. Beck. ''Not only doesn't he smoke cigars, he has no vices I can see.''

title: In Texas, a Laboratory Test on the Effects of Suing H.M.O.'s
description: TO hear lobbyists and lawmakers in Washington tell it, giving patients the right to sue insurers that refuse to approve medical treatment would be either the death of managed care or the salvation of patients.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the television season preview on page 34 of the Arts & Leisure section today about the TNT film ''A Dollar for the Dead'' misidentifies the director. He is Gene Quintano. (Sergio Leone died in 1989.)

title: Word for Word/Covert Action; All the President Had to Do Was Ask; The C.I.A. Took Aim at Allende
description: FROM 1970 to 1973, the United States sought to overthrow the Government of Chile and its democratically elected President, Salvador Allende, whom it deemed a Marxist threat to American interests. Under orders from President Richard M. Nixon, the Central Intelligence Agency mounted a full-tilt covert operation to keep Dr. Allende from taking office and, when that failed, undertook subtler efforts to undermine him. Those efforts ''never really ended,'' the C.I.A.'s director of operations at the time, Thomas Karamessines, later told Senate investigators.

title: Ellen Binder, Stephen Dubner
description: Ellen Binder and Stephen J. Dubner are to be married this morning by Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg at the Brotherhood Synagogue in New York.

title: Filming the Darkness Under a Hat
description: WHAT does an intellectual look like? Unfashionable clothes? A burning gaze? A beard? That's to presuppose the intellectual is a male, but then we often do. Can we at least assume a body formed by reading under the covers? Once we could point to Leon Trotsky's little round glasses, Virginia Woolf's living snood of frizz, even the physicist Richard Feynman's Hawaiian shirts. But intellectuals as a visual presence are hard to come by in the 1990's.

title: DIARY
description: STRIKES

title: Police in Brooklyn Seek Serial Rapist In Subway Assaults
description: The police said yesterday that a man who raped a woman on a G train in Brooklyn on Sept. 5 is a serial rapist who attacked a teen-age girl and at least one other woman in similar situations this month and raped another woman earlier this year.

title: Mozambique's Austerity Puts It on Brink of a Boom
description: Mozambique's monuments to faded eras are still pretty shabby. The bullring left from the days of Portuguese colonialism is a wreck. The grass around the memorials on the Avenue of Popular War goes untrimmed, and corn planted by starving urbanites still sprouts in parks.

title: Stay Home and See the World
description: Why bother to cross an ocean when the art and architecture, and even the landscape, of several continents are right here in the continental United States? (O.K., it's not the real Parthenon, but so what?)

title: Allen Middleton and Theodora Fried
description: Theodora Elizabeth Fried and Allen Russell Middleton were married yesterday at the Morristown Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Thomas C. Sheffield performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 30 about the artist Louis Comfort Tiffany referred imprecisely to the location of his mansion, Laurelton Hall. Though the site overlooks Cold Spring Harbor, it is in Laurel Hollow, not in the Village of Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Venice
description: Morning breaks like an egg and spills across the surface of the Grand Canal. Shimmering gold skims the top of darker depths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMANN, WILLIAM
description: FUHRMANN-William. The peaceful elegance of your life that was lost will forever leave a void in my heart. God gets to pick his angels, we are left with only memories. You will live on in my heart until we meet again. My love always, Joe

title: Playing Safe, Republicans Offer Silence
description: In a partisan call-to-arms last April, Speaker Newt Gingrich vowed to lead a drumbeat of attacks about scandal at the White House. ''I will never again, as long as I am Speaker, make a speech without commenting on this topic,'' Mr. Gingrich declared after firmly defending Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, BLANCA
description: ROSENBERG-Blanca. On September 11, 1998. Aged 84. Beloved mother of Alex and Mark. Grandmother of Eugene and Adrianne. Teacher, counselor, friend to all who knew her; full of wisdom, joy and understanding, courageous in the face of the Holocaust, ever hopeful and in love with life. Those she touched are poorer for her passing. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, 12:30 PM, Monday, September 14. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Museum of Jewish Heritage.

title: Ideas & Trends; How Schools Measure the Talent to Teach
description: JOHN SILBER, chairman of the Massachusetts Board of Education, recently berated deans of education schools for standards so low that nearly 6 of every 10 prospects who took the state's new basic skills exam for teachers failed it.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Infiniti G20; Reviving an Old Name To Tap a Hot Market For Low-Price Luxury
description: LUXURY automobiles used to be the domain of wealthy doctors, lawyers and business executives -- along with show-business celebrities and mob bosses.

title: Really Bad Shirts
description: Ugly shirts never looked so good. Witness the explosion of horrifying polyester in current movies. In ''Rounders,'' Edward Norton (far left) plays a poker hustler and ex-convict with a taste for out-of-date, perhaps never-in-fashion shirts. In ''There's Something About Mary,'' Matt Dillon's detective-stalker character (inset center) sports a loud Manilla shirt. And in Nicolas Cage's latest action movie, ''Snake Eyes,'' his shirt is a frightful brown and gold button-down (inset right).

title: Recharged for Fall: In France, They Call It La Rentree
description: IN the wonderfully strict cycles of life that make the French seem so predictable, la rentree first announces itself each year as a reason to postpone things. From early July, there is little that cannot await the return -- la rentree -- to Paris in September. But, take note, this is not a symptom of laziness. It is simply part of the French order of things. Parisians hold parties to say goodbye for the summer in the knowledge that social, cultural, political and business life will resume with a vengeance a la rentree.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: SEPTEMBER

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE ANSWER IS YES By Sara Lewis. Harcourt Brace, $23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIFFORD, ANN (TITEFSKY)
description: TIFFORD-Ann (Titefsky). Age 94. Beloved aunt and sister-in-law of four living generations. May the youngest of our family learn from your wisdom, strength, moxie and love. Words cannot desribe what you have meant to all of us. We will always remember you as someone who put your family first. Services at Schwartz Bros, Queens Blvd, 10 AM, Sunday.

title: A Loving Celebration of All That's Fosse
description: GWEN VERDON and Ann Reinking are two of the most respected performers to star on the American musical-comedy stage in modern times. And Bob Fosse, the choreographer and director, famously loved both women, as individuals and as artists, showcasing them indelibly onstage and on screen.

title: ON THE MAP; A House Where Miners' Widows Lived With Their Woes
description: The mid-19th century Bridget Smith house sits at a slight angle to Randolph Avenue in Mine Hill in Morris County, a small, unpainted wood-frame structure in a neighborhood of modern houses.

title: Big-Time Sports, Big-Time Bids
description: If you thought Mark McGwire set the only sports record by swatting his 62d home run Tuesday, you'd be wrong. The record price paid for a sports franchise tumbled twice in two days, making the $311 million paid by Rupert Murdoch for the Los Angeles Dodgers last January look like a Filene's Basement bargain.

title: Adventures, All in a Row
description: MANY of us in New York complain yearly about pandering repertory and incoherent programs, but solutions are arriving from every side. I hope the public responds, because music this season is being served with a sense of adventure unusual to the decade. The watchword is ''series,'' and there are a lot of them: coherent looks at either individuals or ideas.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 56 of the Arts & Leisure section today about the director John Frankenheimer credits him erroneously with one film. The film, ''Days of Wine and Roses,'' was directed by Blake Edwards.

title: Tax Refund
description: To the Editor: I spent three weeks in Santiago de Compostela, Spain, in July. I bought some silver and was told by the jeweler that I could receive a refund on the value added tax, about $75, at the Madrid airport. On Aug. 1, the guardia civil at the airport refused to stamp my tax forms. He told me that because my flight home went through London, I would have to ask for the tax refund there, in the last European Union country of my trip. I told him I had only a two-hour layover at Heathrow. I pointed out that the tax form said one could reclaim the tax refund in any European Union country; I saw no rule about doing this in the last country. I said I had bought the items in Spain, not England. He refused again and told me to move on. When I asked to speak to his boss, he became very rude and began to shout at me. He was also wearing a pistol. I left the line very much intimidated. Because I unexpectedly had to spend the night at Heathrow, I was able to collect my refund before leaving, but otherwise I would not have.

title: Honoring Tennessee Williams
description: IN a publicity-driven pre-millennial list mania -- compilations of best movies and best books, 100 of each, by committee rules -- much outcry has already been provoked.

title: George Rivera, Robin Stratton
description: Robin Alicia Stratton and George Rivera were married yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Eric Andrews performed the ceremony.

title: Writing in Light on the Tenement Walls
description: SHIMON ATTIE listens with the rapt, I-feel-your-pain concentration you pay a psychotherapist to give you. In fact, he was a psychotherapist once, in San Francisco, before he gave it all up and moved to Berlin seven years ago to become a full-time artist. He quickly attracted international attention there with his project ''The Writing on the Wall'': in an East Berlin neighborhood, he projected pre-Holocaust photographs of its onetime Jewish working-class inhabitants onto buildings that had withstood the ravages of World War II, the neglect of the Communist years and the real estate rush that followed reunification.

title: For Clinton, The Focus In an Address Is on Policy
description: Acknowledging that it had been an ''exhausting and difficult week,'' President Clinton tried today to move away from his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky and back to his policy agenda, announcing new grants to fight drugs and calling on Congress to support his economic priorities.

title: Victoria Colin, Stephen Wagenbach
description: Victoria Jane Colin and Stephen John Wagenbach were married yesterday at the Darien United Methodist Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Jeannette Bassinger-Ishii performed the ceremony.

title: The Magician
description: Collected Fictions By Jorge Luis Borges. Translated by Andrew Hurley. 565 pp. New York: Viking. $40.

title: Coming Soon: Three New Features
description: Money & Business will soon begin publishing a group of features that invite readers' participation.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Antique screen treasures lend luster to the lineup of movies on television this week: a horror classic, a Pulitzer Prize drama, a Pulitzer musical and a Hitchcock gem.

title: Shipboard Video Link For Medical Matters
description: A live two-way video link will allow passengers who are injured or become sick while traveling on the 109,000-ton Grand Princess, the world's newest and largest cruise ship, to get a second opinion.

title: Put Radium Test Results On Consumers' Water Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: A Career That Moved From Man to Machine
description: LEWIS WICKES HINE (1874-1940), one of the most influential photographers of the century, championed and fought for the causes of immigrants, laborers and child workers in the early 1900's. By the late 1930's he was just about out of work. Roy Stryker, head of the Farm Security Administration, thought he was difficult and past his prime and would not hire him. Assignments were scarce. In Hine's last couple of years he was so broke that he lost his house, stopped photographing and applied for welfare. He died as destitute as anyone who ever sat for his lens.

title: Comments on Clinton Are Consistently Guarded
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan stood at the Fifth Avenue starting line of a Labor Day parade in Manhattan yesterday, wrapped an arm around Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, and tried to drum up support for Mr. Vallone in Tuesday's New York Democratic primary for governor.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: September

title: Marisa Rosenberg, David Thalberg
description: Marisa Fay Rosenberg, the daughter of Marion Rosenberg of Beechhurst, Queens, and the late Harry J. Rosenberg, is to be married today to David Peter Thalberg, the son of Michale R. Thalberg of Woodbridge, Conn., and Kenneth B. Thalberg of Ridgefield, Conn. Rabbi Steven M . Graber is to perform the ceremony at West Park Wine Cellars, a vineyard in West Park-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Are Full-Time Mothers a Threat?; Not a Mother's Duty
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: PURE DRIVEL

title: A Little Dysfunctional Family Fun
description: ''MY brave spirit!'' is what Prospero calls the sprite Ariel in ''The Tempest.'' Not to get too Shakespearean, but a brave spirit is precisely the quality that gives a television show some promise. Of course, few television characters share Prospero's eloquence. In the ABC sitcom ''The Hughleys,'' a black man who has just moved his family into a white neighborhood wakes from a nap and embraces his children.

title: Old Invitation, New Twist
description: When the Conservative Synagogue of Jamaica Estates decided to try to add new faces to its Jewish High Holy Day services this year, it turned to the not-so-new face of a congregation member for help. The back of the rabbi's head also came in handy.

title: The Stations Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLOSSBERG, MICHAEL
description: SCHLOSSBERG-Michael. On September 9, 1998, at the age of 100. Beloved husband of the late Pauline. Dear brother of Phillip and Hyman Schlosberg and Mollie Orloff and of the late Irving, Charlie, George and Sam Schlosberg. Adored father of Elinor Amlen and Brenda Tepper. Precious uncle and great-uncle. Cherished grandfather of David and Jennifer Amlen, Jonathan and Elizabeth Tepper and father-in-law of Seymour Amlen and Jesse Tepper. Adored great-grandfather of Carly Amlen. A very thoughtful and generous man and wonderful friend. He will be deeply missed.

title: Birth of a Salesman: Andrew Spano, Live From China
description: LIVE from Xiamen, China, it's County Executive Andrew J. Spano. And so it was for about 80 minutes -- Monday night Westchester time, Tuesday morning Xiamen time -- as Mr. Spano, on a 12-day trip to China, was the host at a live video conference from there to here, aimed at promoting economic connections between Westchester and Chinese businesses.

title: Stepping Back From the Brink at Adelphi
description: THE trouble started in 1985, when a new president named Peter Diamandopoulos began floating grandiose ideas of turning Adelphi University, comfortably niched as a liberal arts and professional school geared toward commuters, into a ''little Ivy League'' school.

title: Casting an Eye On Artful Books And Asian Art
description: FORGET that books are endangered by the computer and that Asian art is collected mostly by Asians. Both are on the minds of the nation's curators, who have assembled some of the strongest and most diverse selections of such works ever shown in this country. And both have the power to inspire responses ranging from simmering excitement to deep serenity.

title: Jets' Offensive Line Will Put Bad Attitude to Good Use
description: It has been years -- maybe even a decade -- since the Jets suited up an offensive line with a nasty attitude. But look who's bad now.

title: Chasing the Last Atlantic Salmon of the Season
description: As my guide, Don Irvine, and I were getting into our canoe, Joseph Cullman 3d bellowed from the porch of Indian House Lodge on the Restigouche River: ''You've got to get him a salmon, Don. He hasn't taken one all season.''

title: Are You Mad, Doctor?
description: SCREAMS OF REASON

title: McNown Leads Bruins' Romp: No Heisman Contest Here
description: It was not 66-3, but it was enough for U.C.L.A. to make some history of its own.

title: Diane Fischer, Michael Hoffman
description: Diane Annette Fischer, a daughter of Barbara DeCote of Melville, N.Y., and the late Harry Fischer, was married yesterday to Michael Aaron Hoffman, a son of Elizabeth Hoffman of Rumson, N.J., and Jonathan Hoffman of New York. The Rev. Kathleen Hepler, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's mother's house.

title: Our Towns; From Streets To Salvation In the Suburbs
description: ANTHONY COLON'S hero is not a superstar athlete or a movie star. He is a neighbor on Wallace Street who comes home each night to tend his yard -- raking leaves, shoveling snow, watering the flower beds, depending on the season.

title: The Sunshine Hotel
description: ''THE ALABAMA HOTEL, the Comet, and the Uncle Sam House,'' recites a character in Joseph Mitchell's 1940 profile ''Mazie,'' in The New Yorker, ''the Dandy, the Defender, the Niagara, the Owl, the Victoria House and the Grand Windsor Hotel, the Houston, the Mascot, the Palace, the Progress, the Palma House and the White House Hotel, the Newport, the Crystal, the Lion and the Marathon. All flophouses. All on the Bowery. Each and all my home, sweet home.''

title: Rain From Tropical Storm Puts New Orleans in Flood Emergency
description: With more rain in the forecast, Mayor Marc Morial on Friday urged businesses and nonessential government agencies to send workers home early after as much as 10 inches of rain from tropical storm Frances fell here in 24 hours.

title: Raiders' Secondary a Perfect Fit for Woodson
description: Albert Lewis has a red book. Eric Allen has a black book. Both books are filled with numbers collected over several years.

title: Beyond the Familiar Toulouse-Lautrec
description: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC (1864-1901) is readily associated with the swirling petticoats of cancan dancers, but his art goes much deeper than that. This might seem a contradiction, because in an exhibition, ''The Pleasures of Paris: The Prints of Toulouse-Lautrec,'' at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, the curator, Richard S. Field emphasizes that Lautrec was concerned with surfaces.

title: The World: Politics and Business; The Chancellor's Game: Follow the Real Leaders
description: GERMANY'S most important election in decades will take place two weeks from today and the striking thing is this: Whoever wins will inherit a land where the pace has already been set for them, not so much by politicians as by the barons of big business.

title: Citing Unfairness, Black Caucus Stands Behind President
description: Even as many Democrats on Capitol Hill distance themselves from President Clinton in the wake of the independent counsel's report, members of the Congressional Black Caucus have emerged as Mr. Clinton's most ardent defenders.

title: Dining in Rome
description: To the Editor: As a former longtime resident of Rome, I must question Michael Mewshaw's recommendation of La Tana de Noantri (''Rome: In a Favorite Restaurant, a Meal Becomes a Ritual,'' Aug. 30).

title: Splice Einstein and Sammy Glick. Add a Little Magellan.
description: The ventures emanating from the Human Genome Project alarmingly illustrate the impending meltdown of the integrity of basic science. Patents issued for naturally occurring genetic code reflect a perverted relationship between science and industry. Any partnership between science and industry must be predicated on the distinction between a discovery and an invention. Complete and timely disclosure of genetic data not only is essential for a healthy and vibrant scientific community, but it also maximizes competition within the gene-related pharmaceutical market.

title: Chris Patten
description: Patten, the last Governor of Hong Kong, is the author of East and West:

title: Relief for North Korea
description: United States officials said they were readying a large humanitarian food shipment to North Korea. The move was part of an effort to keep the secretive country talking about its nuclear program, which includes a large underground site that American intelligence agencies believe could be part of a new nuclear complex.

title: A Wary Welcome for a Middle-Class Housing Plan
description: A proposal to build middle-income housing might not be noteworthy in many neighborhoods, but in Harlem this kind of overture by a developer is seen as a benediction.

title: Sosa Getting His Due
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: On Chester Green, Pops by Coast Guard Band
description: ROBBIE COLLOMORE was active in the restoration of the Chester Meeting House and, at his death, a music series there was named in his honor. Now the Robbie Collomore Concerts are ready to celebrate their 25th anniversary, and while the first of the ticketed concerts is still two weeks away (the Russian violinist Philip Quint gives the opening recital on Sept. 27), a concert this afternoon at 5 o'clock features the Coast Guard Band playing on the Town Green.

title: If the Yankees Had McGwire, Would McGwire Have the Record?
description: Put Mark McGwire in this season's Yankees lineup, and how many games do they win and how many home runs does he hit? Those are questions that will never be answered, but are tantalizing to ponder.

title: Dubrovnik, a Glorious Phoenix
description: First there is the drama of a climatic fault zone: a Gothic, wintry intimacy -- the work of dark oaks and cypresses -- set against a glittering, summery sea. Then, as one rounds another cliff wall, Dubrovnik appears, not merely as a medieval architectural masterpiece, but almost as a philosopher's ideal of beauty: a compass of mottled sienna roofs encased within monumental fortress walls that are, in turn, embraced by the sea on one side and by vast drifts of mountains on the other, while in the background lurk ranks of islands. The interplay of water and rock creates a misty image of dizzying depth.

title: The View From/New Haven; Suburbia in the City, Supermarket-Style
description: IT'S easy, once inside the clean, air-conditioned comfort of the new Shaw's supermarket in New Haven, to forget that one is in the heart of the city.

title: Ground for Burial or Play?
description: The large concrete wading pool at the Everett A. Martins Field playground is still bone dry. The paint on the swings is still chipped, the asphalt on the ground still cracked. And the graves of hundreds of blacks and Indians that were paved over to build the playground in 1936 are still unmarked.

title: Lisa Moskowitz, Eric Goldberg
description: Lisa Robyn Moskowitz, the daughter of Sandra F. Moskowitz of North Woodmere, N.Y., and the late Dr. Eli Moskowitz, was married last evening to Dr. Eric Robert Goldberg, the son of Joanne and Jay Goldberg of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Morris Friedman performed the ceremony at Temple Hillel in North Woodmere.

title: THE ANNOTATED LISTINGS
description: SEPTEMBER

title: Guess Who's Not Coming to Dinner
description: WHEN the annual limousine-and-sirens season opens at the United Nations on Sept. 21 with high-level speeches in the General Assembly, a lot of the world's bad boys won't be anywhere near the podium. They always stay home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EXELBERT, MYRON A.
description: EXELBERT-Myron A. Beloved husband of Joanne. Devoted father of Ethan, Jeremy and David. Cherished son of Esther Exelbert Weiss. Loving brother of Stephen and his wife Ellen. Dear son-in-law of Edwin and Rhoda Storch. Services Sunday 1 PM, at ''Riverside-'' Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Jill Litner, Benjamin Kaplan
description: Jill Susan Litner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Litner of Belmont, Mass., is to be married this evening to Benjamin Armand Kaplan, a son of Jeanette M. Schrag of New York and James L. Kaplan of Northampton, Mass. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler is to perform the ceremony at Congregation Or Zarua in New York.

title: Eugenia Burnett, Scott Tinsley
description: Martha Eugenia Burnett, a daughter of Mrs. Wingfield G. Burnett of Highlands, N.J., and the late Mr. Burnett, was married yesterday to David Scott Tinsley, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ellis A. Tinsley of Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Alan G. Gibson performed the Episcopal ceremony at All Saints' Memorial Church in Navesink, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends: Big-Bang Theory; A Blast From the Past Makes Baseball a Current Event
description: SHORTLY after Fox Television bought the broadcasting rights to Major League Baseball games three years ago, David Hill, the president of Fox Sports, issued a simple dictum to his newly assembled producers and announcers: ''I don't want to hear about dead guys.''

title: Three Men In a Boat Exploring Caribbean Costa Rica
description: We've sunk to our knees in warm mud, to our waists in gravy-brown water. Mike Geary walks ahead pulling a bowline, while Ricardo Vega and I hunch over the stern, pushing our 16-foot aluminum skiff. Trees and vines crowd the narrow banks and monkeys howl from the shadows, and it wasn't all that long ago we saw a crocodile. We push the boat past a clearing and a tiny wood-plank house on stilts. A round-faced boy, squatting in a glassless window, smiles and waves. We've been told the water is low because of El Nino, and I wonder if that's he.

title: Preparations for Working on Walls
description: WALLS are one of the basic structural elements of any dwelling. Most walls are framed with 2 by 4's but where extra-thick insulation is required, exterior walls may be framed with 2 by 6's.

title: Lexy Schmertz, John Nusbaum
description: Alexandra Maxine Schmertz, a daughter of Ida F. S. Schmertz and Herbert Schmertz, both of New York, was married last evening to John Myers Nusbaum, a son of Blanche and Charles Nusbaum of Norfolk, Va. Dr. Paul M. Steinberg, a rabbi, officiated at the Hannibal French House in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Bar Fight: End of Round 1
description: When Cynthia Mailman and Tom Delassandro look at Bay Street, where she lives and he owns a bar, both see an ailing commercial strip crying out for new businesses. But their solutions conflict sharply.

title: Visiting Rights, Even Invitations, for Wildlife
description: THE suburbs keep pushing deeper and deeper into land that was once wild and the habitat of many creatures. As a result, the wildlife population becomes increasingly stressed for food, shelter and living space.

title: Boat Licenses
description: Legislators Thomas J. Abinanti of Greenburgh, majority leader and chairman of the Health Committee of the Board of Legislators, and William J. Ryan of White Plains, chairman of the Public Safety and Criminal Justice Committee, are asking the county to study ways to prevent waterway accidents. They also want the state to license operators of pleasure boats, a practice many states follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, FANNIE
description: GREENBERG-Fannie. Of Boca Raton, FL, on September 11, 1998. Wife of the late Joseph Greenberg. Loving mother of Sylvia and Alan Ravitz. Beloved grandmother of Donna Ravitz and Nancy Ravitz. Graveside services, Monday, September 14, 1998, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A No-Nuance Bubbly

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: UP AND COMING: Reese Witherspoon; Commitment, Success and the Age of Ambivalence
description: DISCUSSING her career recently, the actress Reese Witherspoon felt compelled to make a confession. ''I use this threat, whenever I get disappointed with the movie business,'' she said, lowering her voice and narrowing her cornflower-blue eyes ominously. ''I say, 'This is it -- I'm going to med school!' I would love to be a pediatric surgeon.'' Chatting in a TriBeCa restaurant, Ms. Witherspoon veered from such pensive asides to moments in which she spoke giddily, even rhapsodically, about life as a fledgling 22-year-old movie star.

title: Crime
description: Watch for the explosive clash of colors when the hot pink and lime green Miami characters of James W. Hall's racy thriller BODY LANGUAGE (St. Martin's, $24.95) converge in Seaside. That pastel architectural confection is no place for the cultural barbarians who invade its placid shores in pursuit of the loot from an armored-car heist -- or for the serial killer known as the Bloody Rapist, who has taken a keen interest in their criminal activities.

title: Moscow: A cathedral razed by Stalin rises again
description: Even Muscovites, who by now have grown used to the giant gold onion dome on their horizon, still stop sometimes to marvel at the Cathedral of Christ the Saviour, the enormous church that has been built anew on the banks of the Moscow River near the Pushkin Museum for the Fine Arts. More than anything else in this fast-changing city, the vast cathedral -- whether or not you like its heavyset grandeur -- has come to symbolize Russia's attempt to undo the physical damage caused by the dead hand of Communism.

title: PULSE; Poker Face To Go
description: Women who want to turn back time and erase the frown lines in their foreheads aren't the only ones queuing up to have botulism toxins, or Botox, injected into their faces. Dermatologists are reporting an increasing number of men getting the shots, and not just to have a youthful mien. The procedure, which eliminates wrinkles by paralyzing some facial muscles, also minimizes facial expression. And now some male lawyers and investment bankers and executives see the lack of expression as an advantage in business dealings.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 6 about a re-edited version of Orson Welles's film ''Touch of Evil'' misidentified the star of the television show ''Peter Gunn.'' He was Craig Stevens, not Peter Graves.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Neigborhood Report last Sunday about the closing of the Fielday School in the Bronx appeared under an incorrect neighborhood heading. The school is in Riverdale, not Kingsbridge Heights.

title: Tough Times on the Children's Pageant Circuit
description: PICKING at a plate of fried chicken nuggets, Jackie O'Brien and her daughter, Shelby, 8, were busy discussing the notion of beauty at a Denny's in Timonium, Md., on the Saturday of Labor Day weekend. Mrs. O'Brien looked like a down-to-earth suburban mom: shoulder-length red hair, a little makeup, a T-shirt and pants.

title: Wendy Harris, Paul Campbell
description: Wendy Elizabeth Harris, a daughter of Leslie Peake Harris and Harold Harris of Ellenville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Barton Campbell, the son of the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell of New York and Paul B. Campbell of Cleveland. The bridegroom's mother, a Disciples of Christ minister and the general secretary of the National Council of Churches, performed the ceremony at the Stone Church in Cragsmoor, N.Y.

title: Easing the Passing of the Torch in Companies
description: MOST small-business owners are too busy with the day-to-day problems that come with running a business to plan for the future, and besides, none of us like to confront our own mortality,'' Andrew N. Karlen, chairman of the Small Business Committee of the Westchester Chamber of Commerce, said.

title: Sore Winner
description: I read with interest Jeffrey Goldberg's article ''Sore Winner,'' profiling Police Commissioner Howard Safir (Aug. 16). While I am, of course, pleased at the lowered crime rate in New York City, I was quite surprised that Goldberg wrote that there has been a spike in drug dealing in surrounding counties and that Safir was quoted as saying that city drug dealers had moved to New Jersey and Westchester and Nassau Counties. I cannot speak for other suburban areas, but I can for Nassau County.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEBEVOISE, WILLIAM E.
description: DeBEVOISE-William E. A resident of Floral Park and Shelter Island, died September 11, 1998. He was an enlisted WW II veteran, having served in the European theater of operations. Mr. DeBevoise, a graduate of St. John's Law School, was an associate of the law firm Shea & Gould. An active member in his community, he served as attorney for the Floral Park Bellerose School District. He is survived by his wife Patricia, daughters Susan Metalios, Kathy Syverson, Barbra DeBevoise, Carolyn Sullivan. Cherished grandfather of four. Friends may call Sunday 7-9:30 PM, and Monday 2-5 and 7-9:30 PM, at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, Inc, 29 Atlantic Aveue, Floral Park, NY (at RR Plaza). Religious service Monday evening. Funeral Tuesday 10 AM. Interment Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: Rally Organizers Miss With Youths in 2 Cities
description: The names Million Youth Movement and Million Youth March conjured up images of entire city blocks thronged with people, in a show of unity so strong, a gathering of voices so loud, that the issues of young black Americans could no longer be dismissed or ignored.

title: Designing Programming to Pack the House
description: ONCE upon a time, when suburban concert halls were almost exclusively devoted to classical music, filling the Tilles Center on the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville and the Staller Center at the State University at Stony Brook was a snap.

title: School Boards Find Ruling on Expulsion Is Troubling
description: WHEN the State Supreme Court issued a ruling this summer that students may be expelled for behavior off school grounds only if such behavior ''markedly interrupts or severely impedes the day-to-day operation of a school,'' educators said they feared it would be much tougher to keep even the most potentially violent students out of school.

title: Fires Posing Greater Risk As Amazon Grows Drier
description: A year after the Brazilian Government dismissed studies warning that parts of the Amazon rain forest were becoming so dry they could burn uncontrollably, fires have become a greater threat than ever to intact rain forest and to indigenous peoples, according to environmental groups that monitor the Amazon.

title: Flood, Mold And Mildew Damage
description: AFTER 65 years in the business of drying out wet houses, Max Gersh remembers one job more clearly than the rest. He calls it ''The Cube of Mold.''

title: About the Starr Text
description: Because of an editing error, a section of the independent counsel's report was printed twice yesterday in most copies. The affected section, appearing on pages B9 through B11, began with the heading ''There is Substantial and Credible Information That President Clinton Committed Acts That May Constitute Grounds for an Impeachment.'' It ended ''he could not supply responses in a consistent and credible manner,'' near the bottom of page B11, column 3. The repetition should not have occurred, but no material was omitted in its place.

title: The World; The Lawsuits Pile Up, Matching the List of Atrocities
description: FIFTY THREE years after it ended, the Second World War is spawning a new form of international justice that victims hail as long overdue. But some of its targets decry it as a dubious new legal cottage industry, in which some lawyers seize upon human rights abuses as the basis for emotionally charged class-action lawsuits.

title: Affirmative Action Has Its Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Roosevelt And Mr. Colon
description: Corinne Avery Roosevelt, the daughter of Priscilla and Kermit Roosevelt of Washington, was married yesterday to Michael Alexander Colon, the son of Maria M. Perez of Woodhaven, Queens, and the late Michael A. Colon. The Rev. Stanley Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass., on Nantucket Island.

title: Awaiting Kubrick, Malick, 'Mail'
description: ISMAIL MERCHANT

title: Penguins Say Jagr Will Stay
description: Roger Marino, co-owner of the Penguins, said today that although he could understand the Rangers' interest in Jaromir Jagr, he had no intention of trading the scoring champion.

title: Liberties; Pulp Nonfiction
description: The President must not lose his job.

title: From Bust to Boom: A Deeper, Stronger Economy
description: FOR a long view of the Long Island economy, there is Alan Fortunoff, patriarch of the Island's best-known retailing family, who made his oversized imprint on the suburban business landscape when he opened the huge Fortunoff store in Westbury in 1964.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, MALCOLM
description: FOSTER-Malcolm. September 10, 1998. Beloved husband of Helen. Devoted father of Malcolm Jr. and the late Barbara Hamilton. Contributions in his memory may be made to Princeton University, Class of 1932 or The American Red Cross in Greater New York. Funeral private.

title: Josiah Emery And Lee Rose
description: Lee Rose and John Josiah Emery were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Prouts Neck, Me. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: Mary Lou Ortiz And Ethan Robey
description: Mary Lou Dolendo Ortiz, a daughter of Estrellita D. Ortiz and Gualberto R. Ortiz of Tampa, Fla., is to be married today to Ethan Robey, a son of Barbara Robey of Manhattan and the late Dr. Richard C. Robey. Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx is to officiate at the Montauk Club in Brooklyn.

title: Most Consuming More, and the Rich Much More
description: Before the world slipped into a global financial crisis last year, consumption of goods and services was rising phenomenally in industrial and many developing nations, according to a United Nations report published this past week. The costs of public and private consumption, still rising despite economic setbacks, will top $24 trillion this year, twice the 1975 level and six times that of 1950, the report said.

title: Pamela Nigro, John Kern Jr.
description: Pamela Jean Nigro, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Anthony Nigro of Southampton, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Dwight Kern Jr., the son of Dr. and Mrs. Kern of Montchanin, Del. The Rev. Peter Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church.

title: Still Living With '68
description: Mark Lilla's essay ''Still Living With '68'' (Aug. 16), which pretends to be a comparison of the nature of the 1968 rebellions in Europe and the United States, turns out to be a somewhat smothered cry of complaint about the now commonplace bogeys of the right wing: the depredations of feminism, ethnic-identity politics and the so-called ''culture wars.'' He plays the usual game of blaming what he calls joylessly militant feminists for ''questioning the naturalness of the family'' and ''upsetting the psychologically delicate ritual of seduction.''

title: Home Sweet Home? Not With the Rats Out There
description: In an effort to draw middle-class live-in landlords to Harlem, a nonprofit group bought 49 abandoned buildings from the city for $1 each in 1986 and renovated them, turning them into multifamily homes. But buyers moving into the buildings, on 126th Street to 128th Street east of Fifth Avenue, say the blocks are overrun by rats.

title: TO DIAL FOR
description: Wagwear: 888-wag-wear or e-mail at wagwear@ibm.net

title: Sheri Saltzman, Robert Min
description: Dr. Sheri Ann Saltzman, a daughter of Patricia and Kenneth Saltzman of Liberty, N.Y., was married on Friday to Dr. Robert Min, a son of Dr. Sung Ja Kim and Dr. Chang Min of East Islip, N.Y. The Rev. Darrell Berger, a Unitarian-Universalist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Super Natural
description: Long, laid-back and luxe - that's the message for fall, and that's the magic.

title: Lives; Speaking in Tongues
description: Magnifique! summer a paris avec un appartement all to myself in the 10th arrondissement. No host family, no youth hostel. I would magically learn francais via the world-famous methode immersion! I would venture beyond the touristy parts and see the real City of Light! I would have the time of my life! Before setting off into my first Parisian night alone, the friend who had lent me her place told me, in richly accented English: ''Cheri, in Paris there's not guns, but there's a war of attitude. If you are too nice, they run you over.'' I laughed. I'm from Crooklyn. Who gon' mess wit me?

title: Rebecca Sherman, Javier Morcelo
description: Rebecca Ann Sherman, the daughter of Mary and Eugene J. Sherman of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Javier Morcelo, a son of Ana M. Morcelo of Bayamon, P.R., and Francisco Morcelo of Brooklyn.

title: Ain't Too Proud to Obsess, All Over Again
description: QUICK, think back to ''The Big Chill,'' Lawrence Kasdan's 1983 comic drama about baby-boomer friendship and dashed idealism, with the ghost of a Kevin Costner performance left on the cutting-room floor. What is the first scene that comes to mind? Of course: It's when the stars -- Glenn Close, Kevin Kline, Jeff Goldblum, William Hurt, JoBeth Williams, Mary Kay Place and Tom Berenger -- dance around the kitchen after a raucous meal of pasta and wine, doing Chuck Berry duckwalks and modified boogie-downs, washing dishes to the cranked-up sound of the Temptations' ''Ain't Too Proud to Beg.'' The scene encapsulates the spirit of the film: friendship forged in the footloose optimism of the 60's; camaraderie instantly regained through the nostalgic power of good pop music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELWIG, EDWARD P.
description: HELWIG-Edward P. Age 95. On August 30, 1998, at his home in Larchmont, NY. Columbia 1924, realtor with Cross and Brown. Mourned by wife, Christine, daughters Christa Patterson and Marymina Wallis, five grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren. Donations to Columbia College or Country Dance and Song Society.

title: A Small Drug Maker In a Low-Risk Niche
description: NEW drugs are long shots -- some 80 percent of experimental drugs fail before making it to market -- and so are most small drug companies. But one seems to have found a way to put the odds in its favor, at least for a while.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEXLER, MELISSA ANN
description: WEXLER-Melissa Ann 5/9/58 9/12/81 Missy, September, a time to remember, yet we think of and love you always. Mommy Arline Joachim, Eddie, Sheri and Larr

title: An Arena Takes Shape in Trenton Where Iron and Steel Once Ruled
description: STEEL rods are being anchored to mold reinforced concrete columns at a site that a century ago was part of one of the largest iron and steel manufacturing centers in the country. The project, the new $42 million Mercer County Arena, is expected to open in October 1999, providing a home for semi-professional hockey and basketball teams.

title: Bosnia Massacre Mars Do-Right Self-Image the Dutch Hold Dear
description: The Dutch like to think of themselves as model international citizens.

title: Concert Cycles Begin at Colleges
description: EACH year, it seems, the music season begins a little earlier. The Westchester Philharmonic opened its subscription series last night at Purchase College and will repeat the program today at 3 P.M. The Camerata of Westchester Community College begins its concert cycle today as well, also at 3 P.M. Victor Lionti conducts Haydn, Weber and Schubert in the Academic Arts Theater on the campus in Valhalla.

title: Redgrave Captures 8th Career Title
description: Steven Redgrave won a record eighth career title yesterday at the world championships in Cologne, Germany, taking the gold medal as part of England's coxless four. The crew, which included James Cracknell, Tim Foster and Matthew Pinsent, won over France in 5 minutes 48.06 seconds.

title: The Dangerous Road Clinton Must Navigate
description: As President Clinton starts down a fateful road with many forks, he will want to walk as slowly as he can.

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Copenhagen
description: I want to go back to Copenhagen, soon, and not just because there's an amusement park in the middle of town. Tivoli is a drawing card, of course. It has gardens, elegant restaurants, fireworks displays and a wooden roller coaster so old that no sane adult would board it unless he or she had had a few too many aquavits beforehand. (Of course, that sort of thing does happen.)

title: OPINION; Lowering the Gate on Paradise
description: I'M not a native East Ender, but like a lot of old-timers out here I've acquired a list of secret places -- idyllic skating ponds, hidden forest glens and secluded swimming spots -- whose precise whereabouts I'm loath to share with outsiders. Last Monday, though, I swallowed my scruples and joined nearly 100 fellow North Fork boaters in a loud, very public protest aimed at preserving access to what is perhaps the finest little paradise of them all. While a News Channel 12 helicopter hovered overhead we anchored our various craft and paddled, waded and swam ashore to lay claim to Long Beach, the narrow gravel bar that forms the extreme western end of Orient Beach State Park.

title: Felicia Allard And Erik Smith
description: Felicia Pratt Allard, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Allard of Durham, N.C., was married yesterday to Erik Antonio de Bulhoes Smith, the son of Myriam Silva de Bulhoes of Rio de Janiero and Lawrence G. Smith of New York. The Rev. Edmund M. O'Brien performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Lakeville, Conn.

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Bali
description: There is only one conceivable reason not to go back to Bali, a concern that a second visit could not possibly match the first. Bali's beaches are golden and its inland is emerald. Volcanos and terraced rice fields catch your eye at every turn. You wake up in a cottage to the smell of frangipani.

title: Fish Kills
description: As predicted by environmental groups, the summer's hot, humid weather has taken its toll on fish in Long Island Sound. Thousands of dead menhadens were found floating near the shoreline late last month, after the blooming of algae in the water, which reduced the amount of oxygen the fish needed, Mary Landrigan, a spokeswoman for the county's Health Department, said.

title: Taking an Opportunity For a Fall Preview
description: As autumn-like weather paid a brief visit on cue right after Labor Day, stylish women didn't miss the opportunity to preview their fall clothes. Cardigan sweaters were belted or buttoned, long jersey skirts were worn with turtleneck sweaters or leather jackets. The coat in both pictures at left showed an abstract style, in the manner of deconstruction, as if the tailor had halted halfway through the process of assembling the brown wool pieces over the canvas undercoat.

title: Political Aristocrats Seek Vote of Working Man
description: Each of them claims to be the true champion of the ordinary Joe and Jane. But the candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for governor of Minnesota have uncommon pedigrees: the field includes the sons of two former United States Vice Presidents, the son of a former Minnesota Governor and the son of a department store magnate.

title: One-of-a-Kind Guide To the City He Loves
description: THE New York City tour guide, writer and self-styled bon vivant Timothy (Speed) Levitch recalls a bus tour of international bankers he once led. ''It was on a fancy bus, with a bar, furniture and 20 Russians living large, but the microphone was minuscule,'' he said. ''It was weird to have such a fancy bus with a lousy amp system. So I was holding the mike against my chest, trying to figure out how I was going to work it. And suddenly there was this throbbing throughout the bus, this beautiful sound with a rhythm. And I realized it was my heartbeat.''

title: Acts of Mercy?
description: The Long Falling By Keith Ridgway. 305 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.

title: Overmatched Rutgers Routed by B.C. After a Fast Start
description: Maybe Rutgers, a Division I-A team, should stick to playing Division I-AA schools.

title: Corrections
description: A report on Aug. 30 about the marriage of Pamela Towen Lippe misstated the first name of the bridegroom. He is Guy Winston Morris, not Scott.

title: Streetscapes/50th Street from Broadway to Seventh Avenue; Once the Home of Horses, Now the Home of 'Cats'
description: BEFORE the old Times Tower or the Astor Hotel, before the theaters, the nightclubs or the peep shows, when it was not Times Square but Longacre Square, the area north of 42d Street was the horse center of New York City. Now, more than a century after it was built, the last vestiges of the American Horse Exchange, which became part of the Winter Garden Theater between 50th and 51st Street from Broadway to Seventh Avenue, may soon disappear.

title: The World: Gaining Currency; The Invisible Hand's New Strong Arm
description: LONG before the Asian economic crisis threatened a broader global meltdown, American officials saw a silver lining in all those plunging markets and dissolving currencies. The world, it said, was beginning to see the benefits of unfettered, American-style capitalism.

title: Delacroix To Degas, Hot Tubs To Fairies
description: SAMUEL SACHS 2D

title: The Brightening Touch of Favorite Vegetables in Golden Hues
description: VEGETABLES that were never thought of as yellow have, in the last few years, started casting a sunny glow over produce stands. Peppers, zucchini, tomatoes, potatoes, cucumbers and even beets have gone for the gold.

title: On Far Grand Slam Courts, Junior Players Carry On
description: Senior tennis is a relative term. If you are Pete Sampras or Patrick Rafter, it is the game being played by Jimmy Connors and his aging peer group. If you are Jelena Dokic or Fernando Gonzalez, it is the game being played by Sampras and Rafter.

title: Euro Translates Currency Babel
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Palazzos and Chalets Invite (Paying) Guests
description: Sometimes you don't have to be an aristocrat to live like one. An Italian bed-and-breakfast chain called Caffelletto, which began operating a few months ago, offers rooms in more than 60 homes -- some with noble lineage -- throughout Italy. The homes have been chosen for historic association, location and comfort. The hosts also have to meet hospitality standards.

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Aran Islands
description: A bowl of soup, a flatulent pony and us.

title: Bob Dixon, Broadcast Announcer and TV Cowboy, Dies at 87
description: Bob Dixon, a longtime broadcast announcer who had an unlikely star turn as a Connecticut-bred television cowboy and an even less likely run as Edward R. Murrow's best friend, died on Aug. 22 at a nursing home in Bethel, Conn. He was 87 and lived in Gaylordsville.

title: Beginning at the Ending at the Bates Motel
description: THERE'S a James Thurber story about a man named Charlie Deshler whose wife, Dorothy, feels compelled to finish sentences for people. ''Sometimes she finished them wrongly, which annoyed the person who was speaking,'' wrote Thurber, ''and sometimes she finished them correctly, which annoyed the speaker even more.''

title: High Hopes for Three Chameleons
description: BROADWAY seems to have chosen to dress like a wary, much-married bride this season. There's plenty of something old and something borrowed (from vintage movies and, of course, England) and very little of something new. (For something blue, there's always the salty-mouthed Sandra Bernhard, who is returning with her one-woman show ''I'm Still Here . . . Damn It!'')

title: Primary Race Leads G.O.P. to a Fork in the Road
description: On at least one big thing, Representative Linda Smith and Chris Bayley heartily agree. The time is ripe for a Republican challenge to Washington State's Democratic Senator, Patty Murray.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: TIVOLEM

title: For a Barnard Fixture, the End of the Story
description: Across a lane from several cases of bowling balls, including the flashy red Mustang 300, are several neatly arranged cases of books, including ''The Human Condition'' by Hannah Arendt.

title: Boys and Girls, Back to School In Uniform Style
description: AS thousands of children head back to school, there is the usual rush -- to buy notebooks and backpacks and, of course, just the right clothes. Anxious parents, two, three, four children in tow pack the stores, each child with his or her ''must buy'' list. In some towns, however, parents, administrators and school board members have agreed on a short list for wardrobes: uniforms. No more guesswork.

title: Laura Cadonati and Nicholas Darnton
description: Laura Cadonati and Nicholas Campbell Darnton, candidates for doctoral degrees in physics at Princeton University, were married there yesterday in the University Chapel. The Rev. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: A Thriving, Lively Port
description: IS the port still active, my wife, Brigitte, asked as we climbed into our cab for the drive to a waterfront restaurant in Hamburg.

title: Will a Queen Be Homeless?
description: If all had gone as planned, a 35-foot bronze statue of the 17th-century Queen Catherine would have been standing on public land along the Hunters Point riverfront next month. But while the artist, Audrey Flack, has sent her work to a foundry, a dispute has cast doubt on the statue's future.

title: Wish Lists And Cheers For Talent At Home
description: PAULA VOGEL

title: Death Merchant
description: THE GUN RUNNER'S DAUGHTER

title: THE NEW SEASON/FILM: UP AND COMING -- Jonathan Rhys Meyers; Earning an 'A' for Androgyny on the Screen
description: ONCE upon a time, the talk was of the It Girl. These days, Jonathan Rhys Meyers has filmmakers extolling what one might call the A Boy.

title: Is There Room on a Republican Ticket for Another Bush?
description: George Walker Bush was visiting his parents in the White House one day when the talk turned to religion, which is precisely the subject that some powerful factions in the Republican Party want their Presidential standard-bearer to talk about, forcefully, in 2000. But Bush, sitting one day recently on a sofa in the Governor's office at the Texas State Capitol, says he is ''cautious about wearing my religion on my sleeve in the political process.'' And he offers this particular story to explain why.

title: G.O.P. Details Tax-Cut Plan With Benefits For 3 Groups
description: Republicans unveiled the details of their proposed tax cuts today, laying out a package that they hope will overcome Democratic opposition by appealing to many married couples as well as to politically potent interest groups like farmers and small-business owners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY M.
description: KLEIN-Stanley M. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York are deeply saddened by the tragic death of Stanley M. Klein, longtime president of the Herman Goldman Foundation. The Foundation, for decades a staunch supporter and most devoted partner of UJA-Federation, had a positive impact upon thousands of lives under his exemplary leadership. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Carole; his son Alan; his son and daughter-in-law Abraham and Cheryl; his father, Harry; and all the members of the family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. VP

title: Debbie Freund, Marcus Schwartz
description: Debbie Freund, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sigmund Freund of Brooklyn, is to be married this evening to Marcus Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Schwartz of Monsey, N.Y. Rabbi Shmuel D. Halberstam is to perform the ceremony at the Rose Castle, a catering hall in Brooklyn.

title: Lucent on the Loose: Come October, It Can Swallow Bigger Fish
description: BILL VIQUEIRA is about to have one of the most interesting jobs in the telecommunications industry.

title: Misunderstandings Led to Melee at Rally in Harlem
description: From out of a cloudless blue sky came the police helicopter, flying low enough for the thousands gathered on a central Harlem thoroughfare to hear the chop-chop of its whirring propellers. What it represented depended on where you stood.

title: How Do You Keep Them in the Casino Once They've Seen the Cocoa Pit?
description: IT was time, Eileen Sverchek told her husband 14 years ago, to get a more respectable job. ''She was very instrumental in my giving up being a full-time blackjack player,'' Nicholas Sverchek 3d recalled during a moment stolen from his current office -- a clerk's booth near the cocoa futures pit at the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPF, GIBSON, NANCY
description: TOPF-GIBSON-Nancy. Born October 29, 1942. Died September 2, 1998. Nancy Topf-Gibson was a passenger on Swissair Flight 111 which was lost in the Atlantic Ocean with all passengers and crew while attempting an emergency landing near Halifax, Nova Scotia, Canada. Nancy was a master teacher, dancer, and choreographer. As the innovator of Topf Technique, she created a natural developmental approach to movement using kinetic imaging and release and alignment principles. Nancy's technique of neuromuscular education re-patterns inhibited movement, develops creative freedom and heals chronic injuries. Working with professional dancers and many students Nancy strove to center each person's emotional, spiritual, and physical body. Nancy taught throughout the United States and internationally, and was en route to teach in Geneva. Nancy is survived by her husband, composer/ musician Jon Gibson of New York City; her son, Jeremy Gibson, a college student; her mother, Celia Topf Straus of Lauderhill, FL; by her sisters and their husbands, Bobbi and Robert H. Straus, Peggy and Murray Schwartz, Margie J. Topf & Stuart Rose; and numerous nieces and nephews. A Memorial Concert is being planned for early December in New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a fund established in support of her surviving family and sent to: Nancy Topf Memorial Fund, C/O Lynne Linehan, Vice President, The Cambridge Trust Company, 494 Boston Post Road, Weston, MA. 02493.

title: Rivals in Labor Day Parade, But Pataki Gets Lead Role
description: Organized labor's traditional Labor Day parade moved in fits and starts up Fifth Avenue for five and a half hours yesterday, and the traditional hordes of politicians in search of support moved with it.

title: Paris: A new subway line for a new century
description: Almost exactly 100 years after Paris began construction of its famous Metro, the network's first high-speed and fully automated line will open in Oct. 15 after six years of construction.

title: Five Years of Surviving With Style
description: AS of yesterday, it's been five years lurking in this corner, trying to get a grip on everyday life in this city. Me, who can't even keep his room tidy, keep his papers off the floor, and dry. Which is why they gave me the job, I think, as my training therapy; as with most therapists, my elevator doesn't stop at every floor.

title: The Nation: Traditionalist vs. Modernizers; Two Dueling Sons of the South
description: HISTORIANS will, no doubt, analyze the blood feud between Bill Clinton and Kenneth W. Starr in many ways -- as a showdown over politics and law, of constitutional issues and human ones.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Zarafa

title: Can Clinton Find The Road Back?
description: With the release of Kenneth Starr's report, President Clinton's fortunes may be at their lowest point yet, and the nation is openly asking whether he can ever recover, politically or personally. Here, various people give their views on how Mr. Clinton might make a comeback.

title: Swissair Pilots Got Bad Data, Officials Say
description: Investigators hoping to unravel the mystery of what brought down Swissair Flight 111, killing all 229 people aboard, believe that the frantic pilots received false information from their instruments and computers just before the huge jet slammed into the Atlantic Ocean on Sept. 2.

title: Bedouin Minority Holds Key to Jordan's Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WACHSMAN, MENDEL
description: WACHSMAN-Mendel. Manhattan Day School/Yeshiva Ohr Torah records with profound sorrow the passing of Mendel Wachsman, father of our esteemed board member, Bernard Wachsman. May the entire family be comforted in this hour of their loss. Manhattan Day School/ Yeshiva Ohr Torah Rabbi David Kaminetsky Principal George Karasick President Elliott Gibber Chairman of the Board

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 30 about health care for the uninsured misspelled the surname of the director of the Maricopa, Ariz., County Health Department. He is Jonathan Weisbuch, not Weisbruch.

title: Seaside Dreams
description: IT'S 6:10 on a Wednesday evening, and the wait at Moonstruck, one of the most popular restaurants on the north Jersey Shore, is 40 minutes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAASS, RICHARD
description: MAASS-Richard, 79. Of Purchase, New York, died September 10, of cancer. Mr. Maass was born May 20, 1919 in Baltimore, Maryland to Arthur Leopold Maass and Selma Rosenheim Maass. He is survived by his devoted wife of 55 years, Dolly Lederer Maass, a brother Arthur Aaron Maass of Boston, sons Douglas O. of Sleepy Hollow, NY and R. Andrew of Jackson, Mississippi, four grandchildren, Aaron, Ethan and Kern Maass and Annie Maass Halpin, one great grandson Michael Andrew Halpin. A memorial service will be held at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY, Monday, September 14, 1 P.M. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Purchase College (SUNY) Foundation Scholarship Fund.

title: In Long Beach, Comfort Food And Prices to Match
description: EATING at TKOPS 180, the casual American bistro that is an offshoot of the impressive Kitchen Off Pine Street restaurant in Long Beach, is like buying the lowest-priced Mercedes Benz. The diner still benefits from the same know-how, skill and standards that are displayed at the more luxurious spot. Yet the dishes, which are American comfort food favorites, and the prices, which top out at $15 for entrees, are quite different. (So is a wine list with one-third of its selections in the $15 to $16 category.)

title: When Time Is Money: Catalogue Shopping
description: IF you live in New Rochelle, does the mailman deliver more mail-order catalogues there than in the more affluent Scarsdale?

title: Lost Historic Site
description: To the Editor: ''What's Doing in Casablanca'' on Aug. 23 overlooked a major disappointment facing American tourists: the Hotel Anfa on the outskirts of the city, where the famous Casablanca Conference was held in January 1943, has been torn down. What's left now are the two small bungalows where Churchill and F.D.R. stayed on this historic occasion. Visiting Casablanca this summer after a 50-year absence was heart-rending and left me in tears. It is now a totally different town from the one where I was born and raised.

title: Astaire's Rendering
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Full-Time Mothers a Threat?; Ignored by Politicians
description: To the Editor:

title: When Regents Testing Hurts Students
description: I was very disheartened with the state of affairs in our schools as reported in ''Schools '98: Bar's Raised and Space Is Precious'' [Sept. 6]. The new Regents testing program will go further toward discounting and disempowering students. How many more layers of distrust, competition and game-playing will these new tests add to our children's school cultures? How much profit will test makers and edu-bureaucrats make from this new stack of mindless paperwork? How many overachievers will lose focus on the important things in life in preparing for these academic exams? What will be the implications for the well-being of first-graders if principals, teachers and parents are beginning to stress over test preparation at the elementary level? How will our high school students learn responsibility and critical thinking skills if they are left out of important decisions and instead are forced to focus on the prefabricated tests of a huge educational bureaucracy? When will public schools wake up and remember that there job is not to provide good test scores, but to provide a good education for our children?

title: U.N. Extends Iraq Sanctions
description: After dithering for more than a month in the wake of Iraq's decision on Aug. 5 to stop weapons inspections, the United Nations Security Council pulled together in surprising strength and voted unanimously to deprive Baghdad of any chance of having sanctions lifted until the inspectors were allowed to resume their jobs.

title: Capital Trial to Begin for Man Accused of Killing for Jewelry
description: In May 1996, Brooklyn prosecutors say, Marvin McIntosh was standing in front of a girlfriend's home in East New York when two men and a teen-ager demanded his gold chain and large, eye-catching pendant, shaped like a bulldog's head.

title: Monet, With a Mint On the Pillow in Boston
description: Several Boston-area hotels and Amtrak are offering packages that include passes to the exhibition ''Monet in the 20th Century,'' at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. The show will run from Sunday through Dec. 27 before traveling to the Royal Academy of Arts in London. It will include more than 80 paintings produced by Claude Monet from 1900, when he was 60, until his death at 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRONGWATER, ROSLYN
description: STRONGWATER-Roslyn. Passed away peacefully with her loving family at her side. She is survived by her three married children, 12 grandchildren and 13 great-grandchildren. Her love of life and great optimistic spirit will live on in the hearts and memories of her family and loving friends. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, Tuesday, at 10 AM.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Atlantic Beach, L.I.; On a Barrier Island, a Family Aura
description: FOR Robert Kiss, what began 63 years ago as an annual summer visit to his grandparents' home on Atlantic Beach turned into a lifelong love affair with the oceanfront community.

title: Last Call for New Bars? Trendy Clothiers Move In
description: A cluster of trendy clothing and accessory shops are popping up in this neighborhood, in storefronts that once might have become that standard Lower East Side institution: the bar.

title: A German Leftist Who Loves To Count Beans
description: Any photographer assigned to shoot a portrait of Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, with his challenger, Gerhard Schroder, would face a nearly insurmountable problem. For a decent closeup, the photographer would have to choose between a picture of Kohl next to a patch of empty sky and the head of Schroder beside a massive shirtfront whose owner could be identified only by the overly broad knot of his tie. The esthetic dimension of an election should never be underestimated. People vote not only for the person they want to represent them but also for the person they want to be seen to represent them. In purely visual terms, the election of Schroder as Chancellor would signal a radical change -- a 10-inch height difference is by no means insignificant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KESTER, HOWARD SETH
description: KESTER-Howard Seth 1928-1989 Remembered with love. Mother

title: Affirmative Action Has Its Victims; Issue Is Fairness
description: To the Editor:

title: Openings
description: The social season begins at City Opera and at Saks, with a salute to British fashion.

title: Rock Stars
description: LOOKING FOR MO

title: The Splash Heard Round the World
description: THIS decade has produced the most powerful visual stimulation in history. A Japanese cartoon has sent children into seizures. Violence in movies can be so relentless that it inspires real-life copycats. And computer games can be so enticing that people lose themselves in them for days.

title: ALARM SCHOOL
description: In response to an overdose of false burglar-alarm calls in Phoenix -- 95 percent of the calls received are mistakes -- the Police Department has created the ''False Alarm Prevention Class'' to train Phoenicians to be more responsible users. For $10 and two hours in a classroom, citizens can waive the $74 fine that comes after the third false call. Instruction is. . .remedial, focusing on common bonehead plays. (Like: remember to tell your housesitter you have an alarm.) A surprising one, considering that these are homeowners who have paid good money to install alarms: unlocked doors that blow open in the wind.

title: Adventures in Indian Regional Cuisine
description: TANDOORI TASTE of India in Darien is amazing, terrific both in its stylish looks and in the fresh-tasting, inventive food served, with a repertory that is even more stimulating than the decor.

title: Marketing Stable Fund Returns to I.R.A. Holders
description: IS it plain old luck or smart market timing? As stocks continue to whipsaw their way through the summer, several mutual fund companies are lining up to sell so-called stable-value funds to holders of individual retirement accounts, the first time these super-safe funds have been offered to such investors.

title: Bound by the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; La Paz
description: In La Paz are entrances to many worlds. Beware, for doors that open also draw you in. I must return now, having promised to dance as a devil in next year's Gran Poder, a feast celebrating local miracles. It'll take weeks to get used to the two-and-a-half-mile altitude, so that when the archangel screams ''Vueltas!'' I can go whirling clockwise, then counterclockwise, full tilt down the steep streets, between walls of cheering Aymara: masked, unrecognizable inside 20 pounds of sequins, silver, satin, plaster, glue, elastic; roaring and laughing hellishly.

title: Second Sightings: Eight Wish Lists; Norway
description: After 12 days crossing the Atlantic on the liner Arosa Kulm with hundreds of other American Friends Service Committee high-school exchange students -- all of us deranged by alternating spasms of seasickness and lust -- I arrived in Alesund, Norway, a fishing town just below the Arctic Circle. It was 1957. The father of my new ''family'' was in the kleppfisk, or dried salt cod, business. The most exciting thing I could look forward to was to be taken down to the fish factory while Mr. Larsen caressed his salt cod, breathed in their rank essence and extolled their quality. We would then repair to the Chamber of Commerce where everyone but me would drink himself into oblivion.

Deborah Skell, the owner and designer, aims to stress classic clothing with a narrow silhouette that is ''spare and traditional but still dramatic.''

title: Syracuse Raises Its Profile By Quieting the Wolverines

title: Correction
