title: Splice Einstein and Sammy Glick. Add a Little Magellan.
description: I am writing in reference to Lisa Belkin's article regarding the work of J. Craig Venter (''Splice Einstein and Sammy Glick. Add a Little Magellan.'' Aug. 23). The mapping of the human genome is certainly a worthwhile undertaking, though the immediate value of such is far lower than what the general public has been led to believe. The term ''mapping,'' as used in this context, simply means the act of breaking up the long sequence of ''letters'' into the actual ''words'' that make up the total set of genes. It does not mean gaining an understanding of each of those words. It is more akin to having compiled a word list for a language for which our understanding remains rudimentary.

title: 10 Days in the White House: Public Acts, Private Moments
description: For Bill Clinton, as for all Presidents, the White House has been a stage, the symbol of national power and executive authority, its stately rooms reflecting America's noblest aspirations. In the Oval Office, he has met foreign leaders like Boris Yeltsin and Yitzhak Rabin and pondered domestic issues like health care and welfare. He has also used the elegant setting for less lofty purposes, as a political platform and as a place to charm the rich and powerful for campaign contributions or votes.

title: What Ken Starr Neglected to Tell Us
description: The striking feature of Kenneth Starr's report is its complete silence on the dispositive legal issue: Does the President's conduct amount to an impeachable offense? Mr. Starr's report contains thousands of words about sex, but not one word explains why the impeachment clause or the basic principles of the Constitution justify removing the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISITZKY, DOROTHY (ERTMAN)
description: SISITZKY-Dorothy (Ertman). Age 77, of Ironwood Lane, West Hartford, CT. Wife of Leonard H. Sisitzky, died suddenly at home on September 12, 1998. Born in Hartford, November 28, 1920, to Abraham and Lena (Eisenberg) Ertman, she lived in the Hartford area all of her life. She was a First Lieutenant in the Army Air Forces during World War II. Besides her husband, she is survived by a daughter, Nancy S. Alderman and her husband John of Scarsdale, NY, and a son Brian R. Sisitzky and his wife Laura M. of Winchester, MA. She will live through her grandchildren who she adored, Charlie E. Alderman and Alexa T. Sisitzky. She is also survived by a sister, Eva Katz of West Hartford, CT. Funeral services will be held today at 3 PM, in the Chapel of the Weinstein Mortuary, 640 Farmington Ave., Hartford, CT, with interment in the Emanuel Synagogue Cemetery, Wethersfield, CT. A memorial period will be observed at her home through Tuesday. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the National Parkinson's Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Ave., Bob Hope Rd., Miami, FL 33136.

As director of music at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, on Park Avenue, he created Sacred Music in a Sacred Space, a series that has not only added greatly to musical life in the city, especially on the impoverished early-music scene, but also put the church on the musical map to the extent that Lincoln Center and the Gotham Early Music Foundation have moved in as well.

title: The Paperless Society, Eh?; Threatened by Computers, An Industry Adopts Them
description: Picture a slurry, made of wood fiber and fillers like calcium carbonate or clay, swimming in a sea of water so vast that the pulp cannot form clumps. Mentally deposit it onto a wire mesh belt, through which the water drains out at huge pressures and speed. Feed that belt through a roller press to squeeze the rest of the moisture out.

title: As Lust and Honor Turn to Dust, Just Party On
description: In both message and structure, Kurt Weill's ''Seven Deadly Sins'' and Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana,'' which returned to the New York City Opera repertory in a double bill on Saturday, are ideal companions. Weill's work, with its satirical libretto by Brecht, follows a young girl from Louisiana through the full cycle of sins and skewers the pieties of her family, who warn her against these evils but happily accept the money she makes along the way. The Orff, using bawdy Latin texts based on a collection composed by medieval German monks, wonders fleetingly about mortality, concludes that it doesn't matter, and leaps blithely into a celebration of hedonism.

description: CANADIAN OPEN

title: Justice or Mercy for Bill Clinton?
description: So, after one of the most tumultuous weekends in modern political history, what is the future of the Clinton Presidency? There has been some public distress at Kenneth Starr's decision to include explicit sexual descriptions in the independent counsel's report to Congress. We are also seeing a broad Congressional and public repudiation of President Clinton's preposterous contention that he did not commit perjury in his sworn denials of a sexual relationship with Monica Lewinsky. There have emerged the outlines of a deal in which Congress might spring for censure rather than impeachment if Mr. Clinton would admit perjury on this key point. Either way, it is a virtual certainty that the House Judiciary Committee will hold hearings on whether impeachment proceedings are necessary.

Memorial services on September 17 and 18.

title: A Sly Musical Scrapbook Of Those Dreamy 1950's
description: If pop music offers a mirror image of its era, the 1950's were certainly the dreamiest and silliest decade in American history. And in ''Because of You,'' his sweeping musical survey of those officially happy days, the cabaret singer Jeff Harnar brings a perspective that is at once nostalgic and sweetly but relentlessly critical.

title: The Synergy of Live Music, And Tweaking in the Studio
description: Toward the end of a performance on Wednesday night, the singers Gilberto Santa Rosa and Victor Manuelle came out to perform a duet on one of Mr. Manuelle's songs. As so often happens when real excellence is paired with the normal, the relationship between those with inspiration and those with pretensions to talent became clear; the duet left the rest of the night's performers in the dust.

title: Can the House Deal Fairly With Starr's Report?; Grasp of Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Adds a Grim Tone to Congressman's 'Funday'
description: Chub Richards, whose cotton farm is not far from the Beth El Lutheran Church picnic grounds where he waited for a chance at the barbecue, fried chicken and hunks of watermelon, held out his hand with a wide grin when his Congressman, Charles W. Stenholm, passed by.

title: Lawsuits Depict a Police Culture of Sexual Harassment and Cover-Ups
description: Twelve years ago, Stacey G. Maher became a rookie New York City police officer despite warnings from a cousin who was a seasoned police supervisor.

title: Metro Matters; One Primary That's No Help To D'Amato
description: THOMAS A. DROLESKEY is not, he insists, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's enemy.

title: In Losing, Coaches Now Sound Prophetic
description: Every college coach utters a version of it early in the season. How his team has excellent potential, but don't make bowl reservations yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, MRS. HENRIETTA DANA SKINNER
description: RAYMOND-Mrs. Henrietta Dana Skinner. Historian, teacher and author, died at the Dunroven Health Care Center in Cresskill, NJ. She was 84 years old. Mrs. Raymond, known as Penny, earned her Master of Arts and Master of Philosophy degrees at Columbia University. She later published her thesis on Sophia Willard Dana Ripley, co-founder of Brook Farm. After teaching at Hunter and Rollins Colleges and the University of Southern Maine, she volunteered in VISTA, teaching Native Americans in Utah. She also volunteered at Jobs for Youth, preparing young adults for the workplace and at Saint Matthew's Learning Center in Manhattan, tutoring children with learning difficulties. She received awards from the City of New York and the N.A.A.C.P. for her volunteer efforts. A former resident of York Harbor, Maine, she was also an active member of the Colonial Dames of America where she served on the book awards committee. Mrs. Raymond was the widow of Professor Irving Woodworth Raymond who taught medieval history at Columbia College of Arts and Sciences and Brooklyn College. She is survived by five daughters: Henrietta Dana Raymond of Boynton Beach, FL; Dr. Elizabeth Bailey of Haddonfield, NJ; Mary Carrington Salpukas of Tenafly, NJ; Margaret Hill Foudy of Dumont, NJ; and Marion Woodworth Bestani of Charlestown, MA; a sister, Eleanora Carroll Calderon of Alexandria, VA; 13 grandchildren and 13 greatgrandchildren. Visitation will be at Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ on September 14 from 6-9 P.M. A funeral mass will take place on September 15 at 9:30 A.M. at St. Therese's Church, Madison Avenue, Cresskill, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Habitat for Humanity.

title: Voters Want Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: Vu Van Mau, Last Premier Of South Vietnam, Dies at 84
description: Vu Van Mau, who was briefly South Vietnam's Prime Minister -- and who called for all Americans to leave Saigon just before it fell to the Communist forces in 1975 -- died on Aug. 20 in a hospital in Paris. He was 84.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Sampling of Viewpoints From Nation's Newspapers
description: Charlotte Observer

title: Can the House Deal Fairly With Starr's Report?; Psalm's Other Meaning
description: To the Editor:

title: Painful Debate Over a Presidency
description: With the President's lawyers arguing today that even possible perjury by Mr. Clinton is not sufficient grounds for impeachment, the country began a painful debate over the future of his Presidency.

title: Watch what the Internet asks children, sponsors are warned, or see the government step in.
description: ADVERTISERS and agencies involved in aiming on-line sales pitches at children are being exhorted to toughen their policies for protecting privacy or suffer the consequences of growing demands from parents and government officials for restrictive regulation.

title: Can the House Deal Fairly With Starr's Report?; A Costly Potboiler
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets' Great Expectations in Pieces on the Ground
description: Now the Jets get to see what life is like when they are expected to win and don't.

title: Argentine Leader Vows to Retain Currency Peg to Dollar
description: It has become almost a daily ritual. President Carlos Saul Menem and his chief economic advisers take every opportunity to promise that they will not retreat from the Government's fixed exchange rate that pegs the value of the Argentine peso to the American dollar one to one.

title: Can the House Deal Fairly With Starr's Report?; Not Just About Sex
description: To the Editor:

title: There Is No There There for the Giants
description: You trot to the grocery store and there are 12 items you must buy. Got to have them all. You have $50. And the first thing you toss in the basket costs $47.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAJIM, RAYMOND P.
description: NAJIM-Raymond P. On September 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Marilyn (nee Notine). Beloved brother of Betty and Paul Najim and Marion Curka. Loving brother-in-law of Patricia Notine. Friends may call at the Williams Funeral Home, Inc., 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx on Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday in St. Gabriel's Church at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Patents; A technique to solve a broad array of computing problems with manipulation of DNA molecules.
description: FOUR years ago, Dr. Leonard Adleman raised the exciting possibility of DNA-powered supercomputers when he wrote in the journal Science that he had solved a computational problem essentially by stirring up some DNA in a test tube, using building blocks of DNA as computing symbols.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, BLANCA
description: ROSENBERG-Blanca. The Faculty Advisory Council Administration and Alumni Association of the Columbia University School of Social Work record with sadness the death of Blanca Rosenberg. A respected teacher and author, she will be remembered for her wise counsel, caring nature and courageous spirit. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her family. Ronald A. Feldman, Dean

title: Graduation Counts Most
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Europe Draws The Line
description: Does ''Bill and Monica'' play in Pisa? You bet, every night and every day. Lowbrow or high, glossy or dull, the media between Lisbon and Lodz are doing exactly the same as their counterparts in the United States. If the European newspapers and news shows don't feature the collapse of Russia or the slow death of Congo, Kenneth Starr's 36 boxes of evidence and the President's lip-biting apologies are sure to fill the space. Except that Le Monde or The Times of London doesn't devote 19,000 lines per week to the story.

title: A Magic Handel World Of Expressive Delirium
description: The New York City Opera's production of Handel's ''Partenope,'' which opened on Friday night fresh from Glimmerglass, is a treat. Six young singers give the firm impression that Handel wrote this music for them, so fluent are they in the vocal athletics and expressive delirium of their roles, and so youthfully fresh, enough to make the music sound fresh, too. By their voices they create a magic world, and a magic world is what the director, Francisco Negrin, and designers have created for them onstage.

title: Many Faces of Clinton
description: The Whitewater independent counsel's report on President Clinton reveals a man of high intelligence and magnetic personality whose propensity for self-destruction is balanced by a talent for self-preservation.

title: Sports of The Times; A Ringing Telephone Heralds a Champion
description: WHEN Mark McGwire (remember Mark McGwire?) hit his 62d home run (it was only six days ago, but it seems longer), somebody asked him if he ever went back to his room and looked at himself in the mirror and shouted, ''Yessss!''

title: In a First, Parties Settle a Year 2000 Suit
description: Produce Palace International, a grocer in Warren, Mich., has accepted $250,000 from Tec America Inc. of Atlanta, the manufacturer of its cash registers and credit card verification systems, in the first reported settlement of year 2000 computer litigation, according to Brian Parker, the plaintiff's attorney.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What we're saying, and saying very strongly, is that there is no hiding place for terrorists in this town.''

title: I. E. Segal, 79, Mathematician Who Disputed the Big Bang
description: Dr. Irving E. Segal, an influential mathematician at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who embraced many unpopular notions, including the view that there was no Big Bang at the dawn of the universe, died on Aug. 30 after he collapsed while walking near his home in Lexington, Mass. He was 79.

title: Market Place; Intel's positive forecast leads many analysts to think that technology stocks' worst may be past.
description: INVESTORS seized on some unexpected good news Friday from Intel, Oracle and National Semiconductor to drive technology shares higher.

title: A Newcomer Is Favored in Washington Mayoral Primary
description: For the first time in 20 years, Marion S. Barry Jr. will not be a candidate or a looming presence on Tuesday when Democratic voters in the District of Columbia choose their candidate for mayor.

title: Rangers Take Roll Call; The Absences Are Noted
description: Eric Cairns and Todd Harvey, restricted free agents, are not in the Rangers' training camp. The Rangers say they cannot attend until they sign contracts. Their absence bothers Coach John Muckler and, to a lesser extent, General Manager Neil Smith. Esa Tikkanen is a surprise arrival. That pleases Muckler and Tikkanen, too, while Smith seems willing to keep an open mind as the free-agent veteran tries to make the New York roster for the third time in his long and varied career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, EVA
description: HERMAN-Eva. 97. On Sunday, September 13. Beloved wife of the late Benedict. Devoted mother of Gladys Fleck and Harriet Charles. Adored grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of twelve.

title: Suspect Aided by French Intellectuals
description: For two decades, the police in Austria and Germany had searched for the accused terrorist Hans-Joachim Klein, who was arrested last week as he sipped beer at a cafe in the Norman village of Ste.-Honorine-la-Guillaume, where he had had been living for five years under an alias.

title: U.S. v. Microsoft: At Least They've Settled on Strategies
description: After nearly a year of testimony, acrimony and debate, the opposing parties in the antitrust suit against the Microsoft Corporation appear to have settled on strategies for the trial that begins in a few weeks.

title: Guidepost From Country's Pulpits: The Power to Judge Belongs to God
description: In historic Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d drew embarrassed titters from his congregation as he urged the men and women in the pews who may be having extramarital affairs to sidle up to their paramours on the sidewalk after services, end the relationship and ask for forgiveness.

title: World's Press Reflects Itself In Coverage of Clinton Affair
description: With a mixture of solemnity, worry and sometimes sheer glee at the crisis facing President Clinton, newspapers around the world continue to be dominated by news of how an official report about allegations of sex and lies has threatened to topple the most powerful man in the world.

title: Locking Up the Toothpaste, Staring at the Sublime
description: By now, summertime adventures are being put aside for more urbane cultural concerns, but for me that may be difficult. In my mind, I am still trudging up a jagged mountain path, sidestepping mule dung and negotiating slick rocks in the late summer heat. With every turn come vistas I doubt will be displaced in my mind by any music heard or art seen in coming months: massive granite contusions carved by ancient glaciers; sheer, glistening slopes of stone shining with cascades of water; glimpses of earth's supple musculature upon which one walks tentatively, humbly, struck dumb by its powers.

title: Ethnic Conflict in Caucasus Shows Its First Glimmer of Hope
description: In a week that saw the first high-level contact in years between Armenia and Azerbaijan, leaders of both countries said they were eager to resolve an ethnic conflict that threatens to ignite the Caucasus.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REEVES, MINNA
description: REEVES-Minna. My beloved mother's birthday and wedding anniversary are remembered today with love & gratitude, together with my esteemed father, who made everything good possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, JACK
description: FEDER-Jack. 83. Great-grandfather, grandfather, father of Dorothy, Sheila and Howard. Widower of Freida. Graveside service Tuesday, 1PM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale. Shiva Tuesday, at the Waxman home, Pt. Washington. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to SPSP (Society for Progressive Supranuclear Palsey), Woodholme Medical Building, Ste. 515, 1838 Greentree Rd., Baltimore, MD, 21208.

title: Youth Trying to Flee From Police Dies in Leap
description: A 15-year-old youth who was being chased by police officers on suspicion of narcotics possession fell to his death yesterday afternoon after trying to jump from a six-story Bronx building to a nearby building, officials said.

title: Can the House Deal Fairly With Starr's Report?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharp Divisions on Judiciary Panel
description: The name falls from their lips with uncharacteristic reverence, like ballplayers conjuring up Joe DiMaggio in Yankee Stadium.

title: Compressed Data; A Former Clinton Nominee Leads Technology Foundation
description: When the Markle Foundation, a nonprofit group devoted to issues involving communications technology and public policy, announced the appointment of two senior executives last week, just as noteworthy was the person doing the announcing -- Zoe Baird.

title: Few Wish To Impeach President
description: Perhaps Representative Rick White's constituents were in a forgiving mood this weekend because the Seattle area was bathed in sparkling late summer sunshine. Maybe it was because much of the Congressman's flesh-pressing today was done amid jovial fans assembled at a park-and-ride station for a trip to the Kingdome to watch the pro football Seahawks, whom many Seattleites think may make the playoffs this year.

title: Running Game Perturbs Fassel
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel and his offensive coordinator, Jim Skipper, spent time scolding the team's offensive line and running backs on the bench during yesterday's 20-17 loss to the Oakland Raiders. Fassel and Skipper were gesturing and pointing at the players, who said the coaches were agitated by the team's problems running the football.

title: People
description: * Tony Caccamo, vice president and creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Business Communications, Rochester, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., was promoted to executive vice president and executive creative director. He succeeds Ann Hayden, recently named chief executive.

title: Sosa Matches McGwire With Homers 61 and 62
description: Roger Maris's children were not in the stands today at Wrigley Field. The commissioner couldn't make it. The official National League baseballs bore no infrared markings. And the only nation with a live broadcast was the Dominican Republic.

title: Culture Of Reruns, And Pollsters At the Mall
description: What is happening in music today? MTV certainly doesn't know. That's why it has been replacing program directors and staff every few months. Recently, the channel told the thrash-rock band Korn not to bother making any videos for its new album. But last month, when Korn had a hit on the radio and it became clear that the band's album was going to be No. 1 on the pop charts, MTV called back. It wanted a video after all.

title: Compressed Data; The Gartner Group Adopts An Hourglass as Its Symbol
description: For its debut on the Big Board as an exemplar of the digital future, the Gartner Group has chosen a decidedly analog symbol: an hourglass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PADOW, EDWARD MARK, M.D.
description: PADOW-Edward Mark, M.D. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. The staff and friends at Primary Pediatrics, Laurel, MD, mourn the loss of their partner and mentor tragically September 10, 1998. Our hearts go out to his family, Rhoda, Jeremey, Victoria, Jackie, Chris, Nick and mother Sylvia. Dearest friend forever remembered and loved.

title: Can the House Deal Fairly With Starr's Report?; Decency on the Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox Drops Drama Based on Charge Against Justice Thomas
description: Fox Television has scrapped a television drama based on ''Strange Justice,'' a book about the sexual harassment charges against Clarence Thomas, after Rupert Murdoch, chairman of the News Corporation, Fox's owner, objected to the project, several people in the industry said.

title: Yankee Bullpen's Latest Collapse Costs Cone a Chance at His 20th Victory
description: The self-tortured David Cone had sidestepped peril all day as if playing matador on a freeway. But he could only take an isolated seat on the Yankee bench and chew the flavor out of a piece of sgum as he left his troubles to someone else yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: International Officials Say Elections in Bosnia Were a Success
description: Despite glitches that may leave voters in doubt about the legitimacy of elections this weekend, international officials in charge of the balloting today deemed it a success and a tribute to progress toward democracy.

title: A Call for Digital Surveillance Is Delayed
description: In a setback for the F.B.I., the Federal Communications Commission has given the telecommunications industry an additional 20 months to comply with a Federal law meant to bring law enforcement surveillance into the digital age.

title: Life Skills for Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: The Spaces And Echoes That Hint At Trouble
description: In psychiatry, grandeur and paranoia are two kinds of delusion. In the songs of Massive Attack, which performed on Saturday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom, they make a magnificent combination.

title: Statewide Candidates Ride on Local Coattails
description: In a suite of offices above a storefront in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the campaign headquarters of Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr. was buzzing yesterday afternoon. Teen-agers rushed to pick up campaign literature to hand out in the neighborhood, while another cluster of campaign volunteers worked the telephones, making sure that the 200 or so Election Day volunteers had their marching orders.

title: Starr's Report Paints A Many-Sided Portrait
description: From the pages of the Starr report, the many faces of Bill Clinton shine in succession.

title: An Incumbent Who Is Not Distancing Himself From the President
description: Most Democratic candidates cannot do enough to distance themselves from President Clinton. But not Jim McGovern. Last month the freshman Congressman from Massachusetts made national headlines -- and took what pundits and his Republican opponent called a big political risk -- when he welcomed President Clinton to his hometown just days after Mr. Clinton's grudging and ill-received admission of his involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Hacker Group Commandeers The New York Times Web Site
description: A group calling for the release of Kevin Mitnick, the imprisoned computer criminal, commandeered The New York Times site on the World Wide Web for several hours yesterday, forcing the newspaper's electronic edition to shut down at a time when traffic was particularly heavy because of the release on Friday of the independent counsel's report over the Internet.

title: Accounts
description: * Auction Universe, New York and Yalesville, Conn., an on-line auction Web site owned by the Times Mirror Co., named two agencies to handle accounts with combined billings estimated at $10 million. Romann Group, New York, will handle traditional advertising and Modem Media. Poppe Tyson, New York, part of True North Communications, will handle creative and media placement for on-line advertising. Also, R/GA Interactive, New York, another unit of True North, was named to handle Web site design.

title: A Sick Tradition
description: The scene evokes an ugly memory for many New Yorkers, harkening back to a dozen years ago when a black man was killed by a car after whites in Howard Beach chased him into a roadway. Now, from a community only a few miles away, comes raw videotape of the Broad Channel Labor Day parade, where one float was titled ''Black to the Future.'' On the truck bed were several white men in blackface. One participant held onto the back of the truck in a sickening parody of the murder of James Byrd Jr., who was dragged to his death last June by white racists in Jasper, Tex.

title: Texas Pipeline Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Take the Stage
description: To the Editor:

title: Staff Reorganized At Y.&R. Europe
description: Young & Rubicam Advertising has announced a reorganization at Y.& R. Europe in London after a decision by Fernan Montero, who has served as chairman and chief executive, to retire, effective tomorrow.

title: World News Briefs; Authorities in China Arrest Newspaper Editor
description: Security agents have arrested a newspaper editor who contributed to a recently published book on political reform, associates of the journalist said this weekend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, FLORENCE L.
description: MOSS-Florence L. On September 12, 1998. Beloved wife of Toby. Loving mother of Guy and Chet. Mother-in-law of Joyce and Ruth. Cherished grandmother of Jason, David and Jenna. Service Tuesday, September 15, 10 A.M. at Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROBERT
description: WOLF-Robert. 82. At home in Tucson, Arizona on September 12. Beloved husband of Peggy (Gluck). Devoted father of Dr. Thomas (Erica) and Nancy Harris (Paul). Cherished grandfather of six grandchildren. Mentor to many friends and clients. A graduate of Harvard College and Columbia Law School, he had an outstanding career beginning as a law clerk to the Hon. Bernard F. Sheintag. After serving as an officer in the Coast Guard during WW II, he joined the law firm of Hays, Wolf, Schwabacher, Sklar and Epstein (later Botein Hays and Sklar) where during the 1950's and 1960's he served as Managing Partner. When Botein Hays and Sklar closed its offices in 1990, he became Of Counsel to the law firm of Kronish Lieb Weiner and Hellman, a position he held until his death. He was a Past President of the Educational Alliance and the President of The New Land Foundation, a private charitable foundation. As President of The New Land Foundation, he was instrumental in establishing The Freud Museum in London. He was also an officer of the National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors. Services private. Donations may be made to the Educational Alliance or the Hospice at Tucson Medical Center.

title: At Least 30 Papers Call for Resignation
description: Scattershot anger and disgust at President Clinton, combined with pervasive anxiety about the potential use and misuse of constitutional impeachment powers, left many editorial pages groping to find analytic prescriptions to ease the dilemmas facing Congress and the President.

title: N.F.L. Week 2 -- YESTERDAY'S GAMES; Favre Backs Up Talk With Smart Passing
description: When Green Bay last played Tampa Bay, the Buccaneers' defensive lineman Warren Sapp was in the face of quarterback Brett Favre, and the two men weren't chatting about the Israeli peace process. Both are avid trash-talkers, and their outbursts during last season's conference title game marked the beginning of a furious rivalry between two of the game's best players.

title: A Growing Weariness Of Discussing a Scandal
description: By the time the food stalls and souvenir stands were up and running here this weekend for the annual Poolesville street fair, the contents of the Starr report were old news to residents of this suburban village 25 miles northwest of the White House.

title: Russian Musicians Find Playing Doesn't Pay, at Least Not in Money
description: Vladislav Bulakhov and his young 16-piece chamber orchestra were a big hit when they performed at the prestigious Moscow Conservatory this month.

title: Excerpts From Talks With Clinton Lawyers
description: Following are excerpts from an interview today with David E. Kendall, President Clinton's personal lawyer, on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' and from an interview with Charles F. C. Ruff, the White House counsel, on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press,'' as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Rafter Keeps Crown With Dash and Spirit
description: His signature sunscreen mask had already melted away, and his signature ponytail was flying at half-mast, but Patrick Rafter, who put his signature on the United States Open's trophy for the second consecutive year yesterday, was simply flying high. Dashing toward the net on a wing and a prayer, just the way he had done since he was 9 and used his sprints to beat eight siblings to the dinner table, the Australian acrobat completed a spirited and successful defense of his 1997 Open title at the National Tennis Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, CELIA
description: ZIMMERMAN - Celia. Devoted mother of Joan and Cappy Riemer, and Linda and Mel Radner. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZER, ERICH P.
description: HOLZER-Erich P. Husband of Eva, father of Vivian and Robert, grandfather of Susan, Robin, William, Gabriela and Jeffrey, fatherin-law of Gary Greenbaum and Viviana Holzer. Chairman of Chick Master Incubator Co. Funeral to be held Monday, September 14, at 11:30 AM, Temple Emanuel, 147 Tenafly Rd., Englewood, NJ. For information call Gutterman Musicant, 800-522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAPOLI, PHYLLIS (DE MARTINO)
description: NAPOLI-Phyllis (De Martino). Perished tragically on Swissair Flight 111 on Wednesday, September 2, 1998. She was the Product Development Manager for Klauber Bros. en route to a European trade fair. Phyllis was a very creative and highly respected merchandiser in the lace industry for over 25 years. Her family, friends and colleagues are devastated by her loss. She is survived by her devoted & loving mother Ann De Martino, beloved son Steven Napoli and his wife Michelle, adored brother Lenny De Martino and his wife Dianna, dearest nephew Jack De Martino and cherished grandchildren Vincent, Stephanie and Nicky. She was a special woman of uncommon grace and compassion. She dedicated her life to the love, support and well-being of family and friends. Her generosity of spirit and mind will live in our hearts forever. She will be sadly missed but never forgotten. Phyllis, you will always be our guiding light. A memorial service will be held Wednesday, September 16, at 7:30 P.M. at St. Andrews of Avellino Church in Flushing, New York at 35-60 158 Street (Northern Boulevard). In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the charity of your choice.

title: A Local Phone Company Aims High
description: Joseph P. Clayton, chief executive of the Frontier Corporation, wears his heart on his bumper.

title: Dancing, Chatting, Singing On Brooklyn's Waterfront
description: Martha Bowers fell in love with the raw beauty of the Pier 41 area on the Brooklyn waterfront in Red Hook and responded by creating outdoor dance spectacles there. ''Safe Harbor,'' seen on Saturday night, is about immigration. But the actual theme is the area itself, a deserted-looking dream landscape of squat industrial buildings that blend into a wash of pale, muted colors dotted with fantastic structures like a conical silver sugar factory and handsome red-brick Civil War depots.

title: Six to Enter Hall of Achievement
description: The American Advertising Federation will induct six men and women into its Hall of Achievement, which honors executives 40 and younger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, JEAN, PIERRE, MD
description: HARTMAN-Jean-Pierre, MD. On September 13, 1998. A medical doctor in Romania and then in the United States since 1963. He is survived by his beloved wife Eva. Friends may call Monday 6-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison at 81st Street. Services Tuesday 1 PM at the chapel. Entombment Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah.

title: The Facts About Affirmative Action
description: A new study of elite colleges provides striking confirmation of the success of affirmative action in opening opportunities and creating a whole generation of black professionals who are now leaders in their fields and their communities. No study of this magnitude has been attempted before. Its findings provide a strong rationale for opposing current efforts to demolish race-sensitive policies in colleges across the country.

title: The Real Internet Action Is Local
description: Forget all the talk about the global, freewheeling Internet. Nearly two years after the first on-line city guides appeared, many companies are still betting that the real action on the Internet is in such local on-line markets.

title: For a Scientific Team, a Case Goes Terribly Awry
description: THE BALTIMORE CASE

title: Town's Support Wanes, But Few Using 'I' Word
description: It was a glorious late-summer Sunday in this prosperous, largely Republican and now fed-up pocket of America. The soccer teams played at Memorial Park, the Sunday School of the Congregationalist Church posed for pictures, the line at Starbucks was long. And when the talk turned to President Clinton, as it usually did, parents asked their children to leave.

title: An Island That Sees No Racism; Enclave in Queens Defends a Float, and a Way of Life
description: Wearing blackface and Afro wigs, the men who piled into a pickup truck for the Labor Day parade in Broad Channel, Queens, were trying to win a trophy. For decades, parade organizers have awarded trophies for categories like ''cutest baby'' or ''most popular pet,'' and the men had won ''funniest float'' for nine straight years.

title: Dark Delight Returns From the Shadows
description: Isn't death romantic? For fans of Goth rock, it is. ''The passion of lovers is for death,'' Peter Murphy sang on Thursday night when the reunited Bauhaus, the pioneering Goth band, played the first of its two sold-out shows at the Hammerstein Ballroom. Bauhaus lasted from 1978 to 1983, but in that time it forged Goth's enduring traits, from hollow-eyed, portentous vocals to lyrics about maidens, decadence and madness. In Bauhaus's songs, Mr. Murphy can be a guide to the lower depths or a kind of coach; the band started its set with ''Double Dare,'' urging listeners to try ''the pangs of dark delight.''

title: Report Portrays Betty Currie as an Active Accomplice in the Clinton-Lewinsky Affair
description: She was presented to the world by President Clinton as the family ''role model'' of the White House, the upright, churchgoing secretary whose fear-stricken appearance before a grand jury in January generated several days of needed sympathy for an Administration under siege.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, SOPHIE
description: ROTH-Sophie. Born November 19, 1908 and died peacefully at home on September 12, 1998, two months and 1 week before her 90th birthday. Devoted mother of Rebecca Buch, cherished ''Grandma Sophie'' to Teri Ann and Philip Aron. Mamas like you were just like that.

title: I.B.M. Uses Existing Hardware To Sharpen Flat-Panel Image
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is planning to announce this week that it has achieved a much-sought-after breakthrough in computer monitor technology, a flat-panel screen that produces four times the resolution of typical desktop monitors yet is driven by off-the-shelf hardware and software components.

title: The MetroStars' Free Fall Won't Stop
description: To the MetroStars, it was a little like a ship with multiple leaks discovering there was yet another one. Diego Sonora aggravated a left-calf strain tonight and couldn't play in the second half, leaving Jim Rooney to fill in.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Emmys to 'Frasier'

title: Arnott May Miss the Opener
description: Jason Arnott has had bad luck with injuries since he was acquired from Edmonton in January. Today, the center was the only player under contract who failed to lace up his skates on opening day of the Devil's training camp at South Mountain Arena, which has undergone a $2 million renovation.

title: A Mighty Wind: Tracking Hurricane Information
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: TRANSMONTAIGNE PLANS TO ACQUIRE LOUIS DREYFUS ENERGY
description: Transmontaigne Inc. agreed yesterday to buy part of the Louis Dreyfus Corporation's energy division for about $161 million in cash and stock to expand its business in the Southern and Eastern United States. Transmontaigne, based in Denver, provides transportation, storage and marketing services to oil and chemical companies. It will pay about $113 million in cash, 4.5 million shares of its common stock and an undisclosed amount of working capital for closely held the Louis Dreyfus Energy, a petroleum products subsidiary of Louis Dreyfus, based in Wilton, Conn. Louis Dreyfus Energy, based in Atlanta, operates 24 refined petroleum products terminals and storage facilities.

title: By Design; Dusted With Beads
description: It may have started with Voyage, or possibly Narciso Rodriguez, this tendency to decorate a basic sweater, but by now it has taken hold at many price levels. The latest versions, which bear little relation to your mother's heavily beaded sweater from the 50's, have a tracing of beads around the neck or a delicate spattering down the front, so they can go out by day or night.

title: A Whirlwind of Energy For a Dissonant Master
description: I am not sure I have ever seen a group of musicians stride onto a concert platform so joyful and eager as were the 15 players who burst through the stage entrance door at Merkin Hall on Saturday night. And what were they to perform? Schoenberg.

title: Swissair Jet's Cargo Had Painting By Picasso and Other Valuables
description: The cargo hold of the Swissair jet that crashed off the coast here Sept. 2 held currency, diamonds and jewelry, along with a painting by Pablo Picasso that is believed to have been destroyed when the jet slammed into the water, Swissair officials said today.

title: Editors' Note
description: An obituary on Aug. 4 reported the death of Dr. Leroy E. Burney, who was Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service during the Eisenhower Administration. The obituary said his predecessor, Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, had resigned ''after a number of children developed polio from being injected with Salk Vaccine because of a manufacturing problem.''

title: WINBOND ELECTRIC TO BUY REST OF INFORMATION STORAGE
description: The Winbond Electronics Corporation of Taiwan has agreed to acquire the stake in Information Storage Devices Inc. it does not already own for $7.50 a share, or $63.8 million. Winbond makes integrated circuits for personal computers, consumer electronics, multimedia and other applications. It already owns 1.4 million, or 14 percent, of Information Storage's 9.9 million shares outstanding. Information Storage, based in San Jose, Calif., makes semiconductor voice recording and playback products. Shares of Information Storage rose 18.75 cents yesterday, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Sports of The Times; Homer Rivals Race for Unheard-Of Number
description: The day before the All-Star Game in Denver, Sammy Sosa was sitting with Ken Griffey Jr. in the interview area at Coors Field when he was asked whether he, Mark McGwire or Griffey had the best chance to break Roger Maris's record of 61 homers this season.

title: A Retired Robinson Remains the Center of Affection
description: Doug Williams sat quietly and listened as those speaking before him praised his predecessor, Eddie Robinson, at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENBERG, AL
description: LICHTENBERG-Al. On Sunday, September 13 at age 86. Husband of Friedel (nee Rothschild). Father of Judith and Frank. Father-in-law of David Luban and Michelle Sullivan. Grandfather of Daniel and Rachel Luban, and Andrew and Alec Lichtenberg. Brother of Trude Geismar. Memorial service Friday, September 18, 1 P.M. at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains, N.Y.

title: Holbrooke Discloses Gift of Free Lodging
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, the veteran diplomat whose nomination as chief American delegate to the United Nations has hit a snag, has amended his financial disclosure statements to reflect a gift worth more than $12,000 in lodgings from a former American Ambassador to Switzerland, Mr. Holbrooke's lawyer said today.

title: National News Briefs; Judge Reschedules Teamsters Election
description: A Federal judge in New York yesterday issued a ruling that pushed back a scheduled teamsters election by almost two months, ordering that the ballots be mailed out on Nov. 2 and returned by Dec. 3.

title: Sharing History, or Just Ruining It?
description: As the baseball Hall of Fame preserves history by stocking up on bats, balls, jerseys and other artifacts connected to Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa, one company is chopping history into tiny bits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAMBI, NICOLA
description: STRAMBI-Nicola. On September 11, 1998 after a long battle with lung cancer. He is survived by his wife, Barbara and daughter Nicole Struensee. Memorial service at a later date.

title: Officemax Ends Talks on a Possible Sale
description: Officemax Inc., the No. 3 United States retailer of office supplies, said today that it had broken off talks on a possible sale of the company because the terms were not in its best interests.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture of Patrick Rafter, the United States Open tennis champion, carried an erroneous credit yesterday. It was by Barton Silverman of The New York Times, not by Agence France-Presse.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Political Forgiveness?
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Details His Policy For Economic Growth

title: Sharp Rise Predicted in Health-Care Spending in Next Decade
description: After five years of relatively slow growth, total spending on health care in the United States will climb briskly over the next decade, doubling by 2007, Federal officials said today.

title: Seoul to Acquire 2 Ailing Banks
description: Moving to keep two of the country's biggest commercial banks afloat, the South Korean Government said today that it would acquire for $2.3 billion Commercial Bank of Korea and Hanil Bank, which agreed in July to merge.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Ruthless Partisanship
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Corn Silk

title: Iraq Assembly Threatens End To All Inspection Cooperation
description: The Iraqi Parliament, which diplomats often consider an advance-warning system on Baghdad's policy, threatened today to stop all remaining cooperation with a United Nations arms inspection system.

title: A Bill to Ban McGwire Drug
description: New Jersey would become the first state to ban sales to minors of androstenedione, the testosterone-boosting hormone used by Mark McGwire, under a bipartisan bill introduced today in the State Legislature.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTO, CAROLYN K.
description: ROBERTO-Carolyn K. Died on Friday, September 11, at age 86. Graduate of Pratt Institute, student of Gilbert Rohde's Design Laboratory, architectural draftsman and designer. She was employed by Bernard Rothzeid and William Hall. She and her husband, Supervising Architect for NYU Joseph J. Roberto (deceased), were instrumental in the saving and restoration of the Old Merchant's House Museum on East 4th St. She was also involved in the restoration of Stuyvesant Park, the Epiphany Library and numerous other landmark preservations. An inspiration to other community activists and a valued community member, she will be greatly missed. She is survived by her nieces Marilyn Hilly and Betty McCann, and her grand-nephew James McCann, among others. In lieu of flowers, Mrs. Roberto requested that donations be made to the Metropolitan Historic Structures Association, New York City. A memorial service will be held in November.

title: Microsoft's Trial Will Begin on Oct. 15
description: The trial in the Microsoft Corporation's antitrust fight with the Government will start Oct. 15, a Federal judge decided today. He also denied a request by the company to throw out the case.

title: Hold the Panic, Giants, But Plug Those Holes
description: The Raiders say the Giants arrived in Oakland, Calif., and expected the Raiders to fall flat on Sunday. After six straight losses, including this season's opener, the Raiders were a basket case. And not a good football team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREZZOLINO, JAMES AGAPITO
description: FREZZOLINO - James Agapito. Age 92 years of Ringwood, N.J., on Sunday, September 13th, 1998. Beloved husband of his wife of 62 years Lina (nee Poian), father of Jack Frezzolino of Hawthorne, Joan Crawford of Ringwood, Anna Marie Blimmel of West Hartford, CT, Sylvia Severance of Westerly, RI, brother of Mary D'Aloia of Mt Vernon, NY, grandfather of five and great grandfather of four. Funeral Wednesday 8:30 AM from the Browning-Forshay Funeral Home, 557 Lafayette Avenue, Hawthorne followed by a 9 AM mass at St. Anthony's RC Church. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. The family would appreciate memorial contributions to a charity of one's choice, the Ringwood Volunteer Ambulance Corp., or the Hospice of Visiting Nursing Services of Northern, New Jersey.

title: Magazine Set To Auction Art Collection
description: The financially troubled Reader's Digest Association, owner of an exceptional art collection, will be selling an estimated $100 million of Impressionist and 20th-century works by masters like Cezanne, Monet, Modigliani and Matisse at public auction in New York in November, several experts close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Remember Due Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, DAVID
description: PRICE-David. Devoted husband of Matilda. Loving father or Deena Aboodi. Brother of Rubin. Adoring grandfather of Michael and Debra.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Political Portent

title: Clinton's Speech on World Economies: '8 Months Later the Clouds Are Closer'
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech yesterday in New York to the Council on Foreign Relations, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Jumping the Gun
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHNIKIAN, JOSEPH M.
description: OHNIKIAN-Joseph M. Our beloved Joseph of Kingston, NY, passed away on September 4, 1998 in Houston, TX. He is survived by his wife Audrey, daughter Nancy (Pierre Tutunjian), daughter Janet Ohnikian, mother Mary, sister Annette, brother Arthur, and grandchildren Elizabeth and Christopher. Memorial services on September 17 and 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SETTE, EDWARD J.
description: SETTE-Edward J. The Officers, Board of Directors and Council of Trustees of United Seamen's Service mourn the death of Edward J. Sette, who served the agency for thirty-three years and retired as Executive Director in 1979. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends during this time of sadness. Talmage Simpkins, President Roger Korner, Executive Director

title: Monica Lewinsky, Career Woman
description: The most striking revelation of the Starr report is the lurid detail it goes into -- not about sex, but about jobs. Surprisingly large portions of the report are devoted to Monica Lewinsky's career pursuits. The public has known through rumor and leaks about the former White House intern's infatuation with the President, her fantasies of marriage, her sentimental notes and nicknames for a long time. But her savvy, ambitious streak did not emerge until the report was released on Friday.

title: Heard Takes Post As Pistons Assistant
description: Gar Heard, an assistant with the Philadelphia 76ers, is leaving the team to accept a similar position with the Detroit Pistons.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ENGLER, GEORGE J.
description: ENGLER-George J. Sept. 12, 1910-Jan. 14, 1992 Dearest DreadNaught Forever cherished

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Phillips Petroleum and Japanese In Big Kazakh Exploration Deal
description: American and Japanese companies signed oil- and gas-exploration deals today that could be worth several billion dollars to this former Soviet republic in Central Asia.

title: Holger W. Jannasch, 71, Dies; Keen Explorer of the Deep Sea
description: Holger W. Jannasch, who probed the dark recesses of the sea for the tiniest forms of life and helped discover how they constitute a hidden biosphere that dominates the planet and may be the place where life itself arose, died on Sept. 8 at his home in Woods Hole, Mass. He was 71.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; A Better Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Playoff Hopefuls Keep Pace
description: The Miami Fusion got an infusion of playoff fever Sunday after a 4-3 victory over D.C. United, but Tampa Bay and New England, which are fighting for the final playoff spot in Major League Soccer's Eastern Conference, also won, keeping their playoff hopes alive.

title: Indonesian Demonstrators Oppose Military's Role
description: Pressing the Government to take important powers away from the military, nearly 200 students staged a sit-in today at one of the Indonesian capital's busiest thoroughfares.

title: Foley Faces Trying Week As a Starter
description: Glenn Foley's numbers as a starter aren't pretty 1-6 in his career -- and the Jets have begun this season 0-2. Foley will start his third consecutive game on Sunday for the first time as a pro. This week will be a big test for Foley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNACK, WINIFRED
description: PASTERNACK - Winifred. With tremendous sorrow I note the untimely death of my valued and dedicated partner in the law firm of Halpern & Pasternack, a superb lawyer and staunch civil libertarian, and a close friend for over 30 years. Winnie loved poetry and had a passion for good literature. She was a beloved friend of my entire family, my wife Carol and our children Matt, Jane and Tom, and all of us will miss her terribly. We send our profound sympathy to her devoted daughters, Karen and Ellen, and her entire family. Jerry Halpern

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; A Higher Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Calls North Korean Rocket a Failed Satellite
description: The United States now believes that North Korea tried but failed to launch a small satellite into orbit when it fired a multistage rocket in an arc over Japan two weeks ago, Administration and defense officials said today.

title: Shell Shock on the Battlefields of a Messy Love Life
description: TOMCAT IN LOVE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEMAN, EMILY MORRIS
description: COLEMAN-Emily Morris, 84, of Charlottesville died of lung cancer on September 13, 1998. She was a music and dance critic of Newsweek from 1942 to 1964; and also wrote for The New York Times, Life, Opera News and numerous other publications. Born in San Antonio, Texas, she received a B.A. from American University in Washington, D.C. and an M.A. in Constitutional Law. There are no immediate survivors. Memorial contributions may be made to The Nature Conservancy, 1233 Cedars Court, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903.

title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK
description: DENVER

title: Response to Starr Report by Leading Democrats and White House
description: Following are statements today on the Whitewater independent counsel's report from the Democratic leaders in Congress, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and from a White House spokesman, James E. Kennedy:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GOLD FALLS. Gold retreated from a two-month high in response to the strength in the dollar and stocks, which reduced gold's appeal as an alternative. The December contract fell $3.40 an ounce, to $293.40.

title: Candidates In Final Push For Primaries
description: Scrambling for attention in the shadow of a Presidential visit, Democratic candidates for Senate and governor brought their primary campaigns to a quiet close yesterday, ending contests that were notably short on acrimony and appeared to stir little interest with the public.

title: Desktop Studio for Home Video Buffs
description: WITH a few notable exceptions like the stuff that ends up on ''America's Funniest Home Videos,'' most family movies and tapes are destined to the oblivion of those dresser drawers that collect the pressed flowers and love beads of our youth.

title: From a New Satellite, Radar Images of a High-Kicking Hurricane
description: A NEW earth satellite, launched last fall, captured radar images, shown above, of skyscraper-like thunderclouds rising more than 11 miles into the atmosphere from the center of Hurricane Bonnie on Aug. 22. So powerful were the forces producing the clouds that they punched through the upper boundary of the troposphere, the dense lower layer of the atmosphere, by one to three miles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, FRANCES (FROLICH)
description: LEWIN-Frances (Frolich). Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Member of the Hunter College Alumni Hall of Fame along with classmate Bella Abzug. For 20 years she was Commissioner of the Broadway show League giving entertainment each week to 400 members of the Broadway theatre community. After graduating from Hunter, class of 1942, she worked at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on various aircraft carriers. She is survived by her husband Richard (Dick), three children, Jill Chesler of CA., Richard E. Lewin II and Jay Lewin of New York and five granddaughters. Services will be private. Contributions may be made in her name to the Hunter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund.

title: Not Putting 'His Nation's Interests First'
description: USA Today yesterday joined a list of newspapers that have called for President Clinton to resign since the release of the Whitewater special counsel's report on Friday. Among them have been The New Orleans Times-Picayune, The Seattle Times, The Des Moines Sunday Register, The Philadelphia Inquirer, The San Jose Mercury-News, and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Following is an excerpt of the USA Today editorial:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WINIKOFF, ELLEN
description: WINIKOFF-Ellen. Ellen, darling, almost 26 years since your tragic accident. Today would have been your 50th. We love you and miss you. Stan, Marcia, Linda, Amy, Ken and Samanth

title: George Shapiro, 78, Counsel to Gov. Dewey
description: George M. Shapiro, who was counsel to Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and a managing partner at the Proskauer Rose law firm in New York, died Sept. 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Sulzberger to Retire As Museum Chairman
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for 11 years, will retire from that post by early next year, the museum has announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIHAILOVICH, MICHAEL
description: MIHAILOVICH - Michael. The Board of Managers, owners and residents of the Charles House Condominium and Wallack Management Company mourn the untimely passing of their Superintendent of the building for many years.

title: Stocks Rise as a Result of Guarded Optimism, Analysts Say
description: Stock prices posted strong, broadly based gains for the second consecutive session yesterday. Analysts and traders attributed the advance to some renewed optimism over corporate earnings and guarded hope that the industrialized economic powers would cooperate to overcome global economic problems that seemed so destabilizing a few weeks ago.

title: INSIDE
description: A Strong Rally on Wall St.

title: Teachers Scrap Lesson Plans To Grapple With Starr Report
description: With the Starr report very much on the minds and lips of her seniors at the Bronx High School of Science yesterday morning, Marilyn Reinhardt opened her fourth-period literature class by scribbling three one-word questions on the blackboard: ''Psycho? Devil? Victim?''

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Governing Is No Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Clergy Group Speaks Against Role for Police in the Schools
description: A group of clergymen led by the Rev. Al Sharpton urged city school officials last night to reconsider a plan to have the Police Department take over security in the city's public schools in light of the department's tactics at the Harlem youth rally on Sept. 5 and the suspension of an officer who rode a Labor Day parade float with racist depictions of blacks.

title: QWEST COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY ICON INTERNET SERVICE
description: Qwest Communications International Inc., which is building a nationwide network based on Internet technology, has agreed to acquire the Icon CMT Corporation, an Internet-service provider, for $185 million in stock. The shares of Icon soared 44 percent, gaining $3.25, to $10.50, in Nasdaq trading. Qwest's stock was unchanged at $28.8125. The acquisition of Icon will allow Qwest, based in Denver, to offer a broader menu of Internet-related services to large corporate clients. Qwest's fiber optic network is robust but lacks the heavy traffic volume of such rivals as MCI and AT&T. Icon, based in Weehawken, N.J., sells Internet access, Web hosting and network-management services to large businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARGAS, MINDY
description: VARGAS-Mindy. Age 47. Born March 31, 1951. The daughter of John and Shirley Vargas, last known to have resided in the New York City area. She died Monday, September 14, 1998 in the SUNY Health Science Center, Syracuse, NY. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please call the Rome DDSO collect at 315336-2300 with any special funeral arrangements.

title: Corrections
description: The obituary of former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama in some copies yesterday misidentified the spokeswoman for Jackson Hospital in Montgomery, where he died. The spokeswoman is Victoria Jones, not Dana Beyerly. The obituary is printed on page B10 today for readers who did not receive it.

title: Miscellany
description: * McKinlay & Partners, Avon, Conn., was renamed Martino & Binzer, to reflect its owners, David Martino and Gavin Binzer.

title: Top Democrats Call for Speedy Decisions And Warn Clinton Against Splitting Hairs
description: The two Democratic leaders of Congress sharply admonished the White House today to stop trying to make legal justifications for President Clinton's misleading testimony about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. But buoyed by polls showing the nation still reluctant to embark on impeachment, they also called for quick decisions to resolve the nation's constitutional crisis.

title: Garbage Truck Kills Woman Crossing Street
description: A 63-year-old woman was struck and killed by a city sanitation truck yesterday as she crossed a street on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: With McRae And Piazza, Mets Rally In the 13th
description: Try as he might, Mike Piazza cannot win the wild-card race by himself. And while it took more than eight innings tonight, the rest of Piazza's teammates finally chipped in, just when the Mets' post-season hopes seemed almost lost.

title: South African Official Freed From Prison in Mozambique
description: A South African Foreign Ministry official was released from a prison in Mozambique today, six months after he was arrested at a border town there and said to be carrying thousands of dollars and trying to buy a cache of assault weapons.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the two last lines of an article about the actor Tom Cruise are omitted today on page 6 of the Arts section. The complete quotation from Mr. Cruise should read: ''There are some things you don't do for money. I know that's hard to believe. To have a chance to work with Stanley Kubrick, that's worth it for me.''

title: From a Turtle Shell Grew First an Island And Then a World
description: With simple beauty, gentle humor, beguiling music and considerable ingenuity, imagination, wisdom and charm, the eternal mystery of creation is being explored by the gifted puppet master, designer and director Ralph Lee in a new production called ''The Woman Who Fell From the Sky.''

title: Contrition Doesn't Right All Wrongs
description: THE First Supplicant was back in town yesterday, and for the usual reason. He needed money.

title: Japan Bank Bailout Fails to Go Forward
description: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party failed to win support today from major opposition parties for a proposal to bail out troubled financial concerns.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Power of the People
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, DR. ABE
description: GOLDMAN-Dr. Abe. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, Dr. Abe Goldman. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Daniel Hiller, President Steven Wolinsky, Chairman of the Board

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATNICK, HILDA
description: PLATNICK-Hilda, on September 13, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Ray. Loving mother and motherin-law of Ellen and James Hochfelder and Barry and Jan Platnick. Adoring grandmother of Amy, Adam, Keri and Randy and greatgranddaughter, Samantha. Funeral services 10 o'clock, Tuesday, ''Boulevard - Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Netcom Expands in Baltic
description: Netcom Systems A.B. said today that it was buying stakes in mobile phone operators in Estonia and Lithuania from Millicom International Cellular S.A. Netcom paid $55 million for the 48 percent stake Millicom owned in Ritabell of Estonia. Netcom also agreed to acquire Millicom's 24.5 percent stake in the Lithuanian company Comliet UAB and Millicom's 35.8 percent holdings in Mobile Telecommunication of Lithuania. Terms of the transactions were not disclosed. Netcom, based in Stockholm, provides telephone and other telecommunications services. Millicom, based in Luxembourg, operates mobile phone systems.

title: Funny Columnist With a Melancholy Bent
description: THE front desk of the Regency Hotel, home of the Park Avenue power breakfast, is in full-throated warble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JENNINGS, JOHN J.
description: JENNINGS-John J. In loving memory of John J. Jennings, beloved father, grandfather and brother. Died September 13, 1998. Visitation from 2-4 and 6-9 P.M., on Wednesday, September 16 at the Tomlinson Homestead, 336 Main Street, Danbury, CT. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Edward the Confessor RC Church, Route 39, New Fairfield, CT., at 12 noon on Thursday, September 17th. Ar Dheis de Go Raibh a Anam.

title: 911 Operator Suspended After Hang-Up Claim
description: A 911 operator was suspended yesterday as the Police Department investigated allegations that she mishandled a call early Sunday morning reporting a sexual assault in progress on the Upper East Side, the police said.

title: Lewinsky's Journey From a Lover to a Danger
description: At some indeterminate moment in the affair between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky, the most powerful man in the world seems to have begun to fear his former intern and the emotional mess he had helped create.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Salacious Content
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Pharmacist Sentenced To 9 Years for Fraud
description: A former pharmacist received a nine-year prison sentence yesterday for defrauding the Federal Government of more than $2 million in a black-market prescription drug scheme, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, GERALD G.
description: GRIFFIN-Gerald G. President Cozzi and the New York City Technical College/CUNY community mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, hospitality educator and provost, Gerry Griffin. We will sorely miss his wit, integrity and professionalism, and extend heartfelt condolences to his loving wife, Charlene, his children and grandchildren. There will be a memorial service on Sunday September 20th at 2 PM at the Peddie Memorial Baptist Church, 572 Broad St. (corner of Fulton) Newark,NJ, (973) 642-2552.

title: Japan Real Estate Fund
description: A new real estate investment fund formed by Kennedy-Wilson International and Colony Capital Inc. has acquired a portfolio of 25 distressed Japanese properties and loans. Kennedy-Wilson, a real estate marketing and property management company, said yesterday that the venture paid less than 10 cents on the dollar for the properties, which have an original face value of more than $400 million. According to Kennedy-Wilson, the fund plans to buy up to $350 million in Japanese real estate and nonperforming loans by the end of the year. Colony Capital is a private company based in Los Angeles. Kennedy-Wilson, based in Santa Monica, Calif., has assets of $45.7 million.

title: Is Boston Repeating a Folding Act?
description: Twenty years ago today, the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox began a three-game series at Yankee Stadium that was well noted at the time but little remembered since.

title: Science Watch
description: Unhappy Marriage of Plants

title: Recession Is Good for the Soul
description: I hope a recession is coming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLK, LOIS
description: POLK-Lois on September 12, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Devoted mother of Patricia Polk, loving friend to many. Funeral services were held on Monday from Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY. Family requests donations to be made in Lois Polk's name to Temple Shalom Building Fund, 122 Kent Rd, New Milford, CT 06776

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; White House Workplace
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlantic City Drivers May See Higher Tolls
description: South Jersey Transportation Authority commissioners are to vote today on whether to increase tolls on the Atlantic City Expressway for the first time since 1968.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, BEVERLY (NEE BARD)
description: NEWMAN-Beverly (nee Bard). On Sept. 13, 1998. Beloved mother of Alan and Steven. Cherished sister of Gladys Winarick and the late Florence Wilson. Adoring grandmother of Zak & Zoe. Also survived by many nieces & nephews. Services 12:15 PM, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the Society for the Right to Die, NYC.

title: NASA's Learns That Faster And Cheaper Isn't Always So
description: THE National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been shifting its focus away from costly, large satellites and space probes, hailing a number of successes with smaller, less expensive craft that exemplify its new ''faster, better, cheaper'' philosophy of doing business.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TOBEY, SUSAN
description: TOBEY-Susan. Memorial services are being held at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55th St. at 10:00 am on September 18, 1998. Reception to follow.

title: Young, Hearst and Steamroller Offense Rout Washington
description: It was not just Trent Green versus Steve Young. No, that alone was not the problem for the Washington Redskins tonight.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Lieberman Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: BWAY TO ACQUIRE U.S. CAN'S METAL-SERVICES DIVISION
description: The Bway Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the metal-services subsidiary of the U.S. Can Corporation for an undisclosed price to expand its steel container making division. The U.S. Can unit had revenues of $116 million last year. Bway, based in Atlanta, will acquire U.S. Can's plants in Trenton; Brookfield, Ohio, and Chicago; and its nonoperating plant in Alsip, Ill. The unit provides metal coating, lithography, steel shearing and other services. The acquisition will help Bway increase sales of its metal services operation, which cuts, coats and imprints sheets of steel in preparation for can-making.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, MELVIN L.
description: ROGERS-Melvin L., of Bronxville, NY, on September 13, 1998. Beloved husband of Magdalena. Dear brother-in-law of Antonia Cancio. Loving uncle of Maritza Gonzalez. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, between the hrs of 12-2 PM Tues. Interment Rose Hills Memorial Cemetery.

title: Psychiatric Exam Ordered for Murder Suspect
description: A judge abruptly canceled a court hearing today for a suspect in the ambush and murder of two pizza deliverymen on a desolate country road in April 1997 and ordered him to undergo a psychiatric evaluation.

title: Con Gusto and One-Liners
description: The American Symphony Orchestra has approached the perennial problem of expanding its audience from several angles in the six years since Leon Botstein became its music director, and on Sunday afternoon at Cooper Union, Mr. Botstein initiated a series that he calls ''Classics Declassified.'' The idea is to introduce the uninitiated to the landmarks of the standard repertory by presenting the great works in an accessible format. With Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony as his subject, Mr. Botstein first lectured for about 45 minutes, using anecdotes to sugar-coat light analysis and illustrating his remarks with performance snippets. A complete performance followed, after which Mr. Botstein and the musicians answered questions from the audience.

title: Defending Record as Misunderstood, D'Amato Meets With Gay Groups
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato met privately today with leaders from several major gay organizations, some of which have been among his sharpest critics, to defend his positions on homosexual issues and to ask for their support in his campaign for re-election.

title: ROCKWELL TAKES $265 MILLION CHARGE AND CUTS 700 JOBS
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, the world's biggest maker of chips used in computer modems, said yesterday that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $265 million as it prepares to spin off its money-losing Semiconductor Systems division. The company, the former maker of the B-1 bomber, said $105 million of the charges were associated with closing its wafer fabrication plant in Colorado Springs and cutting about 700 jobs, or 10 percent, of the company's worldwide semiconductor work force. The job cuts come on top of 3,800 in layoffs announced in late June. The cost-cutting measures are intended to trim $200 million in pretax operating costs from the semiconductor unit, said Don H. Davis, Rockwell's chairman and chief executive. Rockwell's stock rose $2, to $40.5625.

title: Lead in Breast Milk
description: Mother's milk is generally best, but not always.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIESCHICK, KURT, W.
description: RIESCHICK-Kurt, W. Died suddenly September 13, 1998. Age 52. Adored son of Margaret and Walter. Beloved husband of Mary Lou. Loving father of Jacqueline and Kurt Jr. and step-father of Marissa Sappho. Beloved brother of Anne, Paul, Peter, Philip, John, and Tom. Fond uncle of Andrea, Alicia, Tiffany, Gregory, Andrew, Alex and Maria. Service at St. John's in the Village, 224 West 11th Street on Wednesday, September 16th at 1:00 p.m. No flowers. Donations may be made to City Mission of Schenectady, 425 Hamilton Street, Schenectady, NY 12305.

title: Precise Spanish Styling By an Ensemble of One
description: Pilar Rioja's programs of Spanish dance are solo concerts. Yet she often created the illusion that she was not dancing alone when she performed on Sunday night at Repertorio Espanol, at the Gramercy Arts Theater. By abruptly opening large fans in ''Cafe de Chinita,'' she appeared to be making pronouncements to a host of unseen people.

title: Transit Officials Lobby For Ellis I. Footbridge
description: Regional transportation officials in New Jersey voted yesterday to urge the National Park Service to complete a study on whether a footbridge linking Ellis Island to the mainland should be opened to the public.

title: Horrific Debt, Devastated Economy
description: Sometime next year, if it is unable to raise fresh money or delay payments, analysts expect that Russia will default on as much as $200 billion in foreign debt -- the largest default by any government in history.

title: What Is Freedom Without Privacy?
description: The furor surrounding the Starr report masks a real crisis, and its consequences may prove more lasting than those that could follow from the possible impeachment of President Clinton. I refer to the erosion of a fundamental element of our freedom -- our privacy -- implicit in the methods used by Kenneth Starr and, as we have come to learn, by so many of the nation's prosecutors. Our privacy is not simply a privilege derived from our freedom. Far more important, it is an integral element of our liberty, ''the most comprehensive of rights,'' as Justice Louis D. Brandeis recognized, ''and the right most valued by civilized man.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIEL, WILLIAM, JR.
description: PIEL-William, Jr., 89, September 13, 1998, of Tree House Farm, Sherman, CT. Beloved husband of Eleanor Green Piel, father of Michael, Anthony and Thomas, two brothers, five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Funeral Wednesday, September 16, 1998 at 11 AM in Holy Trinity Church, Sherman, CT. Interment in Coburn Cemetery, Sherman. Friends may call at the Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge St., New Milford, CT, Tuesday from 5-8 PM. Contributions in Mr. Piel's memory may be made to the Cancer Research Institute, 681 5th Avenue, NYC, NY, 10022-4209 or the New Milford Visiting Nurse Association, 68 Park Lane Road, New Milford, CT 06776

title: In Seattle, Civic Pride Builds Music a Home
description: Symphony orchestras in this country begin as civic gestures. If the Berlin or Czech Philharmonic defends a national culture (and is paid by a national government to do so), their American counterparts identify individual cities and report on their aspirations. Cities like this one, for example, maintain their orchestras in the same spirit that they pave streets, plant trees or open schools. European cities are old and work to keep their identities. American cities are young and are usually looking for one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZER, ERICH P.
description: HOLZER-Erich P. The Board of Directors and staff of The Jewish Community Center on the Palisades deeply mourn the loss of Erich Holzer, a long-time member of The Board of Directors, most recently serving as the Chair of The Board of Trustees. Erich was a beloved leader of the JCC, generously supporting the Center and its educational programs, particularly the nursery school, music school and Holocaust Education Institute. All at the JCC were indeed blessed to know Erich, a man whose character, committment, generosity and leadership defined our community and enriched the quality of all our lives. We offer our deepest sympathy to his wife Eva, son and fellow JCC board member Robert, daughter Vivian, and the entire Holzer family. May the Lord comfort them among all the mourners of Zion. Edward A. Grossmann, President Avi A. Lewinson, Exec Director

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Kennedy Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: An Angry Fassel Lowers the Boom on the Giants
description: The head coach was red-faced and angry, the offensive linemen were under siege again, jobs were being lost in the defensive secondary and the linebackers were all limping.

title: Hilton Says Its Earnings Will Fall Short
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings would fall short of analysts' expectations and figures a year earlier, in part because the Asian financial crisis had kept overseas travelers from its hotels in Hawaii and California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANTON, JERRY. (GERARD ANTHONY ANTONACHIO.)
description: ANTON-Jerry. (Gerard Anthony Antonachio.) On September 13, 1998. Beloved & respected photographers' & artists' representative for over 40 years. He is survived by his loving companion Robert Kosowski, brother William J. Anton, sister Barbara Noll, nieces Jenny Marrese, Maria P. Noll and Janeen S.
