Truman, and nephews Major John Peter Anton and Erik G. Noll. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, September 24 at 5:00 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory can be made to Gods Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, New York, New York 10013.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, WILLIAM H.
description: MEYER-William H. September 14, 1998 of Garden City, (owner of Meyer Chevrolet, Ridgewood, New York, and a Director of Maspeth Federal Savings Bank). Beloved husband of Sheila (nee McNulty). Devoted father of Danny. Cherished son of Betty Meyer Bruce & dear brother of Judy Hall and Lindy Prager. Visitng at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave & 12th St, Garden City, Wednesday & Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Mass St Joseph's Church, Friday, 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation, 420 Jericho Turnpike, Jericho, N.Y. 11501 would be appreciated.

title: Kramnik Wins TV Game Played at Moderate Speed
description: The prevalent view among organizers of chess as a television spectacle is that the rate of play should not be five minutes for each player for all moves because that's too speedy for the audience to take in. Also, it should not be the full tournament rate of 40 moves in 2 hours per player because that could add up to a four-hour session (and maybe an adjournment session), longer than the average viewer can devote to it.

title: Op-Art
Leader of Queens Crime Ring Pleads Guilty to 5 Murders
description: They were a violent gang of young men, a scourge of western Queens, who robbed banks and businesses, committed arson and extortion and murdered other gangsters in disputes and double-crosses, law enforcement officials say.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFFERTY, MICHAEL
description: RAFFERTY-Michael. New York Bus Service mourns the passing of its President, Michael Rafferty, a man whose wisdom, humility, patience, compassion and fairness knew no bounds. As a leader, mentor and friend, his loss is heartfelt by all who knew him. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Phyllis & beloved son, Scott in their time of sorrow. May he rest in peace and enjoy life everlasting. Reposing Tuesday and Wednesday 3-5PM and 7-9 PM at Raymond Funeral Home, 5 East Wall Street, Norwalk, Conn. Funeral mass Thursday 11AM, St. Matthew's Church, Scribner Avenue, Norwalk, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, the family request contributions be made to St. Jude's Childrens Research Hospital, 332 North Lauderdale Street, Memphis, Tenn. 38105.

title: League Suspends Strawberry
description: Darryl Strawberry was suspended for three games yesterday for his role in Friday's fight with the Toronto Blue Jays. Strawberry, also fined $1,000, intends to begin serving his sentence tomorrow, when the Yankees start a two-game series in Tampa Bay.

title: Yang Shangkun, 91, Ex-China Chief, Dies
description: Yang Shangkun, a former President of China and the military leader who orchestrated the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in 1989 on Tiananmen Square, died early today, the Chinese Government announced. He was 91.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BNY ESI & CO., New York, a unit of Bank of New York Company, agreed to acquire Alpha Management Inc., of San Francisco, a brokerage services firm, for undisclosed terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROBERT
description: WOLF-Robert. The Trustees and Staff of the Educational Alliance note with profound sadness the passing of Robert Wolf, our past president, honorary trustee and friend. Bob joined the Alliance's Board of Trustees in 1948 and served as President of the Alliance from 1958-1961. During this period he helped to define the modern role of the Alliance as a social group work agency serving all groups in the community with an unusually diverse range of programs and services. He continued to support our activities even after he left our Board to assume a leadership role in the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Peggy, children and grandchildren.

title: Once a Private Club, Prada Opens Its Doors
description: Patrizio Bertelli, the chairman of Prada, stood on Fifth Avenue before the smooth stone facade of his new store. His face was alight with the idea that the company he and his wife, the designer Miuccia Prada, had steered into the loftiest realms of fashion is reaching downward to one of the most populist venues -- Fifth Avenue -- where the dreams of a diamond Tiffany engagement ring and the reality of a Bugs Bunny T-shirt meet.

title: Iran Warns Afghan Rulers Use of Force Is 'Quite Near'
description: Iran today issued its strongest threat yet that it might use military force against Afghanistan unless the militant Taliban movement in power there made amends for ''past errors'' and adopted a more conciliatory course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, RABBI JONAS
description: GEWIRTZ-Rabbi Jonas. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved husband of Lola and father of Dorothy (and Rabbi Julius) Berman-Board members, respectively, of our Stern College for Women and the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminaryand Dr. William (and Debbie) Gewirtz. Rabbi and Mrs. Julius Berman are YU Guardians who, with their family, established RIETS' Rabbi Henoch and Sarah D. Berman Chair in Talmud at the Gruss Institute in Israel. Mrs. Berman dedicated a dormitory suite honoring Rabbi Jonas and Lola Gewirtz in SCW's Jerome and Geraldine Schottenstein Residence Hall. We extend heartfelt condolences as well to grandson Zev S. Berman, member of the Yeshiva College Board, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANCEL, CARLOS A.
description: CANCEL-Carlos A. Of Wading River, NY, on September 14th, 1998, age 64. Retired, Drexel, Burnham, Lambert, NY., NY. Beloved husband of Lucrecia. Dear son of Anna Molina and fond brother of Louis and Hector. Reposing 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Prayer service 10 AM, Wednesday, Alexander-Tuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Rt. 25A, Wading River. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELLER, GEORGE
description: BELLER-George. Congregation Beth Sholom records the passing of our esteemed member, George Beller. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Kenneth Hain Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, Rabbi Emeritus Daniel Hiller, President Steven Wolinsky, Chairman of the Board

title: Clinton Selects Clerics to Give Him Guidance
description: President Clinton has chosen a circle of two or three ministers to serve as a team of personal spiritual advisers who will meet and pray with him weekly and help him resist what one of the ministers calls ''the temptations that have conquered'' the President in the past.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANDERSON, PAUL J, MD
description: ANDERSON-Paul J, MD, On Thursday September 17, 2PM. The Auditorium, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St, NY

title: Hispanic Mothers Lagging As Others Leave Welfare
description: For years, Ramona Rosario could savor the English-speaking world only through the soap operas flickering on her battered television set. Her husband refused to let her work, study English or venture beyond their Hispanic neighborhood in the Bronx.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Whose Role to Impeach
description: To the Editor:

title: Packaging This President As Sinner but Not Perjurer
description: It is surely the strangest debate ever to transfix the nation's leaders: Does oral sex constitute sexual relations, and did President Clinton lie when he testified that it did not?

title: Lemaire, Back With Devils, Is Unsure What His Job Is
description: Jacques Lemaire, looking tanned and relaxed without skates and in civilian clothes, stopped by the Devils' training camp today as simply an employee of the organization without defined responsibilities.

title: G.M. Chairman Urges Rate Cut
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation publicly urged the Federal Reserve today to reduce interest rates, part of what is likely to be a series of such statements by top Midwestern manufacturing executives.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Shares Fall; Chief's Pay May Not
description: Until the recent market slump, chief executives had been hitting financial home runs like Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa. With compensation tied increasingly to the rising stock market, outfield walls were moving in every year -- so much so that many executives started betting they could hit the ball far beyond the fence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, HARRIS, M.D.
description: PECK-Harris, M.D. The Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University mourns the passing of our professor emeritus, a distinguished psychiatrist and educator who was associated with our medical school for four decades. A pioneer in social and community psychiatry, he inspired countless students by the example he set as a caring and socially-conscious physician. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire Peck family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. Dean, Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEEGAN, FRANCES L.
description: KEEGAN-Frances L. September 12th, 1998. Beloved mother of Frances A. Keegan, Edward A. Keegan and Roxanne K. Bethany. Vistors may call at McMahon Lyon Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains, New York, Tuesday, September 15, 2:00-4:00, 7:00-9:00 PM. Funeral mass 10:00 AM, Wednesday, September 16, St. Bernard's Church, Prospect Street and S. Lexington Avenue White Plains. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Covenant House 346 West 17th Street, New York, New York 10011 or Graymoor Sponsors, Box 731 Garrison, New York 10524.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, SAMUEL
description: SCHECHTER-Samuel. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun and its Sisterhood mourn the passing of the beloved father of their devoted member, Caryl Englander, and extend heartfelt condolences to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Primary Day in New York and in Connecticut
description: NEW YORK POLLING HOURS: 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: Quark Quits Its Quest for Adobe Systems
description: The graphic software publisher Quark Inc. today dropped its quirky bid to acquire the rival Adobe Systems Inc. Quark, which had never stated a price or how it intended to finance its unsolicited offer, said that Adobe had spurned its advances and that it did not want to pursue a hostile deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBOVITZ, JOAN (MOND)
description: LEBOVITZ-Joan (Mond). On September 13 of West Hartford, CT. Attorney and teacher. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Dear mother of Samuel of Brooklyn, Joseph of Columbus, OH and Alisa of West Hartford. Cherished grandmother of Robert, Kaitlin and Abigail. Proud graduate of Hunter College. First woman President of Emanuel Synagogue, West Hartford where services will take place Tuesday, September 15 at 12:00 noon. For information, contact Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, Newton, MA.

title: Brazilian Stocks Rebound, And Panic Eases Somewhat
description: The Brazilian stock market appeared to regain equilibrium after dizzying losses last week, shored up by higher interest rates, Government stock purchases and suggestions that the International Monetary Fund would step in to prevent disaster.

title: Democratic Primary Choices
description: New York and Connecticut will hold primary elections today for Democratic nominations for some statewide offices. There are primaries in both the Democratic and Republican parties for some district elections. The polls in New York will be open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M., and in Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. The following are our recommendations in some of these races. All the district contests involve Democrats in areas where nomination is tantamount to election.

title: Ricardo Ramirez, 67, Guatemala Rebel Chief
description: Ricardo Ramirez, the Guatemalan guerrilla commander turned peacemaker who was better known to his countrymen by his nom de guerre, Rolando Moran, died on Friday in a hospital in Guatemala City. He was 67 and had lived in the Guatemalan capital since a peace accord that ended the country's long civil war was signed in December 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVONDA, RICHARD P., M.D.
description: AVONDA-Richard P., M.D. On September 13th, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancy J. (Murtha) Avonda. Loving father of Kathleen Schneider, Jeanne Disador, Elizabeth Carbone, James, Robert, Peter, William, and Dr. Thomas Avonda. Grandfather of ten. Reposing at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, New York, Wednesday evening 7-9 P.M. Funeral mass Thursday 10AM at Our Lady of Sorrows R.C. Church, White Plains, New York.

title: American Leaving U.N. Development Post
description: The highest-ranking American in the United Nations system, James Gustave Speth, administrator of the United Nations Development Program, said today that he will be leaving the organization next summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTLER, ESTHER (MOLLIE)
description: CUTLER-Esther (Mollie). Congregation Orach Chaim extends heartfelt condolences to our devoted member Janet Fried, her husband Michael, a member of the Board of Trustees, and to the entire family on the loss of their beloved mother and grandmother. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Michael D. Shmidman, Rabbi Wolf Scheck, President

title: Sosa's West Coast Show Stays in the Ball Park
description: The great home run chase came to Qualcomm Stadium tonight in the form of Chicago Cubs right fielder Sammy Sosa, the newest member of the 62 home run club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREITROSE, MARK
description: BREITROSE-Mark. Beloved husband to Roberta. Loving father to Howard, Wendi, Melissa and Paul. Grandfather to Brynn and Jack. We will miss you always. Service Wednesday, Sept. 16, 1998 at 10 am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon.

title: An Ex-Leader In Legislature Pleads Guilty
description: Maxine Postal, the former leader of the Democratic minority in the Suffolk County Legislature, pleaded guilty today to charges that she attempted to divert $3,000 in campaign contributions illegally.

title: City on Life Support Tries to Rally; Camden, N.J., Seeks to Reverse Four Decades of Decline
description: It seemed that the troubles plaguing Camden for the last four decades had entered a strange new chapter when Mayor Milton Milan said in February that drug dealers had made him the target of a murder contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. Died tragically on Swissair Flight 111. Beloved husband to Carol, cherished father to Abraham and Cheryl, Alan and Odelia. Loving grandfather to Matthew, Daniel, Yonatan, Aliza Rachel and Nicole Rose. Devoted son to Harry and the late Rose, and brother to Steven and Anne. Caring, brilliant, vibrant and vital, his inspiration and legacy remain forever through the friends and loved ones he leaves behind.

title: For Intramurals in Chicago, the Prize Is a Theater
description: It is a conflict that has evoked pride and betrayal, pettiness and high-mindedness, calling up a fair bit of history and not a little money. Though neither side is evil, each claims to be wronged. As a drama it might be stageworthy if it didn't involve so much litigation. Indeed, Theodore Gross, president of Roosevelt University, one of the combatants, sized it up by invoking King Lear. ''Shakespeare said it better than I ever could,'' he said. ''It's a case of filial ingratitude.'' That would be one spin. The other is that Roosevelt is greedily overstepping its bounds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAAR, RUTH
description: KRAAR-Ruth. The Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee express deepest sympathy to our colleague Martin Kraar, Executive Vice President of ACWIS, on the passing of his beloved mother. Sincere condolences to Marty and his entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President Robert H. Asher, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, M.D., President

title: 10 People Are Charged With Spying for Cuba
description: Eight men and two women were charged today with spying for the Cuban Government by trying, sometimes successfully, to infiltrate American military sites and Cuban exile organizations.

title: Allied Signal Takeover Bid For AMP Gaining Support
description: Allied Signal Inc.'s hostile $9.8 billion takeover battle for AMP Inc. escalated yesterday as investors owning 72 percent of AMP stock agreed to sell their shares to Allied Signal.

title: Henry Spira, 71, Animal Rights Crusader
description: Henry Spira, the architect of the American animal rights movement's first successful campaigns to limit the use of animals in medical testing and a leading advocate of more humane treatment of farm animals, died early Saturday in his West Side apartment from esophageal cancer, according to Elinor Molbegott, his executor. He was 71.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't know if George Wallace is in heaven. The only thing I know is he's been in hell long enough.''

title: Chip Industry Acquisition
description: Newbridge Asia said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire P.T. Astra Microtronics Technology, a provider of subcontract-assembly and test services to the computer chip industry, from Astra Graphia-Information Technology Group for $90 million. P.T. Astra has offices in Pleasanton, Calif., and Batam Island, Indonesia. Newbridge, a private equity firm, is a unit of Texas Pacific Group and Richard C. Blum & Associates. Texas Pacific, based in Fort Worth, is an investment group.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Ulster Assembly Starts, With Debates on Flags and Languages
description: The new Northern Ireland Assembly held its first working session today. But instead of dealing with how to enact the provisions of the peace settlement reached in the spring, the Protestant and Roman Catholic members plunged into debates about flags, party labels, the use of Gaelic and Ulster Scots as official languages and whether it was proper to have a bar in the basement.

title: In Hour of Crisis, Kremlin Brings Gorbachev Economic Team Back
description: Summoned back from a decade of obscurity, a group of Gorbachev-era economists stood outside the gates of the Russian Government building today, awaiting their turn to give advice on how to rescue a floundering economy.

title: Hernandez Livens Yanks' Flat Staff
description: The Yankees won 100 games faster than any team in history because they were scared. They played hard because they feared what would happen if they did not play hard.

title: British-Borneo Petroleum Is Buying Hardy Oil
description: British-Borneo Petroleum Syndicate P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Hardy Oil and Gas P.L.C. in a deal valued at $:339 million ($566 million). British-Borneo, the fifth-largest independent British oil company, said it would exchange six of its new shares for every seven Hardy shares.

title: In Genome Race, Government Vows to Move Up Finish
description: SPURRED by competition from a commercial venture, the National Human Genome Research Institute said yesterday it would move up by two years, to 2003, its target for completing the sequence of the human genome.

title: Gingrich to Pay All of Fine Without Dole Loan
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that he did not need to borrow any money from former Senator Bob Dole after all to help pay the fine levied on him last year by the House of Representatives.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Reckless Senators
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: Martin Margiela for Men

title: The 1998 Emmy Winners
description: The 50th Annual Emmy Awards were given on Sunday at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. Here is a list of the winners.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Renouncing Pride
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, MALCOLM
description: FOSTER-Malcolm. The Board of Trustees, volunteers and employees of the American Red Cross in Greater New York are deeply saddened by the death of Malcolm Foster, a long-time Red Cross supporter. We extend our condolences to his beloved wife, Helen, who is a former vice chairman of the board and chairman of volunteers for the New York Chapter of the Red Cross.

title: 'Turandot' Bids Farewell To Beijing, the 'Home' It Awed and Perplexed
description: After eight performances actually seven and two-thirds, because one was halted by rain -- the much-anticipated production of ''Turandot'' in an ancient temple of the Forbidden City here closed on Sunday night to a lengthy standing ovation from a nearly full house approaching 3,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTON, ARNOLD JAFFA
description: MINTON-Arnold Jaffa. Died peacefully on September 14, 1998. Funeral today, 11:30 AM, at Garlick-Riverside Memorial Chapel, 1439 Unionport Rd, Bronx. Much beloved husband and father of Alma and Rachel Minton. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery Valhalla, N.Y.

title: George Wallace, Symbol of the Fight to Maintain Segregation, Dies at 79
description: Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, who built his political career on segregation and spent a tormented retirement arguing that he was not a racist in his heart, died Sunday night in Montgomery, Ala. He was 79 and lived in Montgomery.

title: Toasting (and Analyzing) Nabokov; Cornell Honors the Renaissance Man Who, oh Yes, Wrote 'Lolita'
description: On July 1, 1948, Vladimir Nabokov, a 49-year-old Russian emigre, arrived at Cornell University. For the next 11 years, his longest residence at any one place in the United States, he taught Russian literature and other courses. During that period he wrote his signature novel, ''Lolita,'' along with ''Pnin,'' about the comic misadventures of a Russian emigre to an American campus very much like Cornell. He also began to conceive ''Pale Fire,'' which many Nabokovians regard as the pivotal book in his considerable body of work.

title: Scientist at Work/Kary Mullis; After the 'Eureka,' a Nobelist Drops Out
description: KARY MULLIS, Nobel laureate in chemistry, is jumping up and down at the kitchen table of his cabin, a place in the woods several miles beyond where the paved road ends. His large head and wiry body shake as if in rage. From his lips comes an angry buzzing sound.

title: In Southwest, Doctor Meets Medicine Man
description: ELENA AVILA, a psychiatric nurse, donned a headband to join a ceremonial procession with Mayan healers in colorful embroidered dresses and Aztec dancers wearing brightly feathered headdresses.

title: Anxious Fans Come Out To See Home Run Derby
description: Cardinal fans are concerned that the spectacular home run race between Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa that was supposed to be finished is heating up again, and perhaps not entirely to their liking.

title: City Hall Gets First Plans for Governors I.
description: In the first round of proposals for reusing Governors Island, 20 developers, civic groups and advocates of open space have given City Hall plans for the island's future.

title: A Symbol of Alabama's Past, Indelible to Black and White
description: For 65-year-old James Harper, sitting on his tiny front porch in West Anniston with the day still brand new, the news that George C. Wallace was dead caused him to lower his eyes and catch his breath for a second, as if some last, dying chorus of ''Dixie'' had lodged in his throat.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS. The dollar rose against the yen, helped by gains in the stock market and expectations that President Clinton will not be forced out of office. In New York, the dollar cost 132.68 yen, up from 130.82 Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIEBOFF, JANET
description: LIEBOFF-Janet. Always loved and remembered, and forever in my heart and mind. Harry

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times last Tuesday about birds in New York Harbor misstated the population of the yellow-crowned night heron. A corrected version of the chart appears today on page F6.

title: Merger Talks by Makers Of Armored Vehicles
description: GKN P.L.C said yesterday that it was in talks to merge its armored- vehicles unit with Alvis P.L.C., to create a military company with annual sales of about $:300 million ($500 million). Alvis, based in London, makes the Scorpion armored vehicle and has a strong order book after its acquisition of Hagglunds Vehicles of Sweden last October. GKN, based in Redditch, England, makes the Desert Warrior.

title: Metro Business; Real Estate Giant Buys a British Firm
description: Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate company, has bought the British property brokerage firm Healey & Baker, officials with both companies said yesterday.

title: Dreyfus Chooses Grace & Rothschild
description: The Dreyfus Corporation unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had named Grace & Rothschild in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million. The account had been handled for three years by Citron Haligman Bedecarre in San Francisco, which parted ways with Dreyfus in April.

title: Correction
Cruise Talks but Cat Stays in the Bag
description: Perhaps the most anticipated studio film in years is Stanley Kubrick's long-delayed ''Eyes Wide Shut,'' made under almost military-style secrecy in England and starring Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman. Even top executives at Warner Brothers, which is tentatively set to release the movie in March, have little idea what the film is about.

title: In New York, Solace and Signs of Opposition for the Man of the Moment at the Moment
description: In a day of respite from the intense debate going on in Washington, President Clinton came to New York yesterday in pursuit of money and perhaps solace, and found some of both.

title: Familiar German Refrain: Can Kohl Do It Again?
description: OLDENBURG, Germany  GENERAL ELECTION in Germany

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; Frailties, Not Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Gretzky, 37, Likes Rangers' Youthful Enthusiasm
description: Twenty years ago, as a 17-year-old rookie with the Indianapolis Racers of the World Hockey Association, Wayne Gretzky reported to his first major league training camp.

title: Mexican Prices Feel the Squeeze of World Economic Trouble
description: The manager of a store selling imported kitchen utensils says many customers walk out when they see his prices.

title: Deadline Extended In Lockout Hearing
description: An arbitrator has extended to Friday the deadline for the National Basketball Association and its union to file post-hearing briefs in the case that will determine whether players with guaranteed contracts will be paid during the lockout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAASS, RICHARD
description: MAASS-Richard. The students, faculty, and administrators at New York University express deep sorrow on the loss of Richard Maass. His support and guidance will be deeply missed. The Richard Maass Collection of Westchester and New York State, now housed in NYU's Fales Library, will be a lasting reminder of his generosity and scholarship. Our condolences to Dolly and his entire family. Carlton C. Rochell Dean, NYU Libraries

title: Home Runs by the Bushel
description: During the recent series between the Cards and the Cubs, Mark McGwire suggested to Sammy Sosa how nice it would be if the two of them could both beat Roger Maris's record, and maybe end the season tied with the same number of home runs. That seemed unlikely at the time, with Sosa stuck at 58 home runs and McGwire on a tear. But beginning last Friday night, and continuing over the weekend, the hero of San Pedro de Macoris, in the Dominican Republic, pumped four home runs out of Chicago's Wrigley Field to draw even with McGwire at 62.

title: The Wallace Paradox
description: George Wallace's was a fate not to be wished on any man. He lived long enough to be a relic. In that regard, his passing invites our thoughts to stray to the Gothic era in Southern politics, a time when it was sometimes hard to draw a line between fact and fiction. The larger-than-life Huey Long begets the fictional Willie Stark, and then suddenly out of the Alabama outback springs this truculent little gamecock who seemed concocted of their best and worst parts. Like the Kingfish, Mr. Wallace believed in books and schools, but he had a dictator's heart that regarded his state's police and treasury as personal assets. Like the hero of ''All the King's Men,'' he believed that because he stood up for the downtrodden, the rules of political morality and personal loyalty did not apply to him.

title: Filling In the Portrait of Anne Frank's Mother
description: For a work that is treasured around the world for its glow of youthful honesty, Anne Frank's diary has turned out to have more than its share of contention, exploitation and evasion. Tonight's documentary, ''Anne Frank: The Missing Pages,'' based on a new biography by Melissa Muller, draws attention to five censored pages that Otto Frank, Anne's father and the keeper of her flame, entrusted privately to a friend because they cast an uncomfortable light on his relations with his wife, Edith.

title: Deere Expects Lower Earnings for Quarter
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment, expects to earn less in its fiscal fourth quarter than a year earlier because lower commodity prices are reducing demand for tractors and combines.

title: Teen-Agers and Sex: Younger and More at Risk
description: WHILE the nation remains focused on the sex scandal in the White House, the American public is ignoring what could be an even more serious sexual scandal -- the young ages at which boys and girls now engage in sexual intercourse, often risking pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases, including infection with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANDERSON, F. THAYER
description: SANDERSON-F. Thayer, 74. Of Old Lyme, CT, on September 12. He is survived by his wife Julie, daughters Katharine Heidlage and Terry Smith, son George Sanderson, and nine grandchildren. Memorial Service will be held at St. Ann's Church, Old Lyme, CT., at 11AM., Saturday, September 19. Memorial contributions may be made to the Phoebe Griffin Noyes Library, Old Lyme, CT. 06371.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES TO SELL SOME NATURAL GAS UNITS
description: Equitable Resources Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its natural gas midstream operations in Louisiana and Texas for $320 million in cash to the American Electric Power Company, an electric utility holding company based in Columbus, Ohio. Equitable said the operations included Louisiana Intrastate Gas, a 2,000-mile pipeline system; five natural gas processing plants; Jefferson Island Storage facilities, and an energy trading business. Equitable, an energy company based in Pittsburgh, had 1997 revenues of $2.15 billion.

title: BASEBALL: The Man Who Would Be McGwire; His Rival Is 'the Man,' but Sosa May Be the Home Run Champ
description: Relaxing at home in his 55th-floor condominium before a game, Sammy Sosa is the same as at the ball park: focused but funny, exuberant but reserved. He is in a strange country, conversing in two languages, but his every movement displays a combination of confidence and humility.

title: Composer's Birthday Tribute
description: Even if Joan Tower were inclined to conceal her age, her many friends would not let her.

title: Jericho Journal; Arafat's Gamble: A Casino for an Israeli Clientele
description: In the shimmering heat of the desert, a fancy new mirrored building, the Oasis, rises like a mirage on the highway between Jerusalem and the Dead Sea.

title: CLINTON PRESENTS STRATEGY TO QUELL ECONOMIC THREAT
description: President Clinton declared yesterday that the economic turmoil on three continents constituted ''the biggest financial challenge facing the world in a half-century.'' Without once discussing the calls for his censure or impeachment, he laid out for the first time a strategy to quell the trouble before it hits the American economy.

title: City Had Earlier Removed Girl Who Found Her Parents Dead
description: The 10-year-old girl who found both her parents dead in their Manhattan apartment on Saturday had been removed from the home last year by child welfare workers and then returned after the city investigated accusations that her parents had not been taking proper care of her, family members and city officials said yesterday.

title: 30-Year Treasuries Advance On Suggestions of a Rate Cut
description: The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose late yesterday as stocks declined from their intraday highs.

title: Phone Deal in Afghanistan Catches Many by Surprise
description: A privately owned telephone company in New Jersey has signed a $240 million contract to build a cellular telephone system for the Taliban, the Islamic fundamentalists who control most of Afghanistan and who the White House says are harboring Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind of the embassy bombings in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, last month.

title: Mrs. Murdoch Retires From News Corp. Board
description: Anna Murdoch, the estranged wife of Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, has retired from the board of the company, where she had served a director since 1990.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANIER, ROBERT S (ROBIN)
description: LANIER-Robert S (Robin). Died on September 9, 1998, in Sheffield, Mass., beloved husband of Madi Lanier and beloved father of Mary Day Wolleheim, Sabina Messenger, Christopher and Kate Lanier. We will miss him terribly.

title: Art Gallery Fire Is Ruled Arson, But No Political Agenda Is Seen
description: The fire at a Jersey City art gallery before the opening of a photography exhibition dealing with the effects of the violence in Northern Ireland was arson, officials said today, adding that they had not found any evidence of a political motive.

title: Let's Call the Whole Thing Off: Tellabs Drops Acquisition of Ciena
description: Tellabs Inc. called off its planned acquisition of the Ciena Corporation yesterday, after diminished financial prospects, scuttled sales and a steep drop in the share prices of both companies made the deal untenable.

title: Man With Stolen Shotgun Is Killed by Police
description: A 30-year-old man living with his mother in Buena Vista Township was shot to death by Dover Township police on Sunday after he had fired at them with a shotgun he had stolen from her, the Ocean County Prosecutor's office said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the nation's response to the release of the Starr report misidentified the Albuquerque newspaper that called President Clinton ''morally unfit to continue in office.'' It was The Journal; The Tribune has yet to take a position on whether Mr. Clinton should resign.

title: In Nurses' Lives, a Treasure Trove of Health Data
description: MORE than 20 years ago, a doctor who was curious about the effects of long-term oral contraceptive use sent questionnaires to 370,000 registered nurses. The answers he and colleagues received have turned into the largest and longest repeated follow-up study of a group of women, a fountain of information about health, in particular women's health.

title: Banana Republic, Discover Card, ABC, Kraft Foods and Sears start the fourth-quarter flood.
description: THE week after Labor Day always brings a torrent of advertising intended to stimulate consumers to step up their shopping during the important fourth quarter. True to form, several big advertisers in categories from retailing to media to packaged goods are beginning multimillion-dollar marketing blitzes.

title: F.B.I. Chief Cites C.I.A. Help In African Bombing Inquiry
description: The director of the F.B.I., Louis J. Freeh, said today that much of the progress made in the investigation of the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa had been a result of close cooperation between two usually rival agencies: the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The President's Day
description: President Clinton, mixing government and politics in New York, addressed the Council on Foreign Relations and three Democratic fund-raisers, one of them an evening performance of ''The Lion King.''

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., named Fran Barton chief financial officer and senior vice president to succeed Marvin Burkett, who left the company in March after 26 years. Mr. Barton had been executive vice president and chief financial officer at Amdahl Corp., Sunnyvale, a wholly owned subsidiary of Fujitsu Ltd.

title: Passports to Dignity For the Open Winners
description: When it came to the grand finales of this year's United States Open, anticlimactic was the word -- for all but two players, that is.

title: Abroad at Home; Muddying The Waters
description: The Clinton controversy puts two questions to the country. One is whether we are outraged by the President's personal behavior and public deceptions. The other is whether we believe he should be impeached and removed from office.

title: Festive Release of Butterflies Puts Trouble in the Air
description: BASKING in their first moments of nuptial bliss, brides and grooms around the country are exiting churches, showered not with rice or confetti, but surrounded instead by the fluttering gossamer wings of hundreds of butterflies. All but unheard of just a few years ago, butterfly releases are the latest fashion at weddings, not to mention at memorial services, grand openings, divorces and prison releases.

title: Box by Box, Lawyers Are Cramming for the Constitutional Test of a Lifetime
description: The room, H2-186 in the Gerald R. Ford House Office Building, has the crash-course ambiance of a law school study hall on the eve of the nation's ultimate examination on constitutional law.

title: Helen Soreff, 72, Painter and Professor
description: Helen Soreff, a painter of subtly inflected Minimalist abstractions, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 72.

title: I.B.M. CONFIRMS TALKS TO SELL GLOBAL NETWORK BUSINESS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was talking with telecommunications concerns and other companies about buying its Global Network business to focus on the software and services related to the computer network. The company said it had been talking with ''a number of interested parties, including major telecommunications companies.'' There have been rumors in recent weeks that I.B.M., the world's biggest computer maker, was looking to sell the network for $3 billion to $4 billion. I.B.M.'s shares rose $2.5625 each, to $129.125.

title: Dorsey Levens Breaks Leg
description: Dorsey Levens, the Packer halfback who parlayed his 44-day holdout into a $25 million contract, broke his right leg in Green Bay's 23-15 victory over Tampa Bay on Sunday. He could miss six weeks or more.

title: Is Truth of Starr Report the Ultimate Value?; A Lewinsky Apology
description: To the Editor:

title: Jingles Sell:  Advertisements as a Reflection of Society
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Radon More Dangerous in Air Than in Water
description: Radon in drinking water poses few human health risks by itself, but it increases people's overall risk from the toxic gas when it escapes into the air and is inhaled, a National Research Council committee said in a report released today.

title: Malhotra, 18, Impresses Rangers in Camp
description: The defenseman skated the puck to his blue line, where Manny Malhotra was waiting. Malhotra anticipated the pass, intercepted it with his shin pad, scooped up the puck on his stick and dashed in alone to score on a backhander to give his team a 1-0 lead during a scrimmage today at the University of Vermont.

title: The Candidate
description: I knew Bill Clinton before the world knew Bill Clinton. It was early 1974, and we were both at the University of Arkansas School of Law in Fayetteville: he was a young associate law professor and I was a third-year law student with Marxist views. Although I never took a class with him, I did meet him on several occasions to interview him for an article I wrote for The Grapevine, a local underground newspaper.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Last-Minute Switch

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, WILLIAM L.
description: REYNOLDS-William L. September 14, 1998. Devoted husband of Margaret Buck. Survived by his daughter Constance Bierkan and his granddaughters Elizabeth Welker and Laura Welker. Brother of Newlin Reynolds. Service on Friday, September 18, 1998, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASS, MAY
description: MASS-May. The leadership and Staff of The UAHC Greater New York Council of Reformed Synagogues, are profoundly saddened by the death of May Mass, our Past President and Administrator. After a short battle with acute leukemia, May died peacefully on Sept. 15th. She served the Reform Jewish Community of New York with distinction as the first female President of her Congregation, Temple Emanu-El, of Lynbrook, as President of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues, as Vice President of NFTS, District 3, as a member of the UAHC Board and Executive Committee, & most recently, as Adminstrator for the Regional Office of the UAHC. Our deepest condolences to her children, Michael and Linda, Mindy and Bob, Mark and Annette, and her three grandchildren, David, Kira, and Elizabeth. She joins her beloved Mack, to chastise all of us for going on too long. We were all blessed for having known her. Funeral services will be held on Friday 11 A.M. at Temple Emanu-El of Lynbrook. Ernest M. Grunebaum, President Rabbi Julie Spitzer, Director

title: Injuries Take Toll
description: The MetroStars will go into tonight's game at Giants Stadium against D.C. United with more injured players than ever at one time in their three years in Major League Soccer. The team has so many injuries that the thought of playing goalkeeper, Tony Meola, as a forward crossed Coach Alfonso Mondelo's mind.

title: Johnny Adams, 67, Vocalist; One of the Legends in Blues
description: Johnny Adams, one of the last of the great blues and ballad singers, died on Monday in Baton Rouge, La., where he lived. He was 67.

title: German Socialists Turn From Slogans to Jingles
description: Until recently, Detmar Karpinski's biggest accomplishment was advertising Lucky Strike cigarettes. Today, he is producing one of the slickest and most American-style political advertising campaigns that Germany has ever seen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLLETT, JOHN J.
description: FOLLETT-John J. Holland Lodge #

title: Great Balls Of Fire! A Yankee Secret Weapon
description: IN 1996, Mel Stottlemyre, the Yankee pitching coach, introduced a new snack to the team dugout -- Atomic Fireballs, red jawbreaker candies with the flavor of cinnamon and the burn of chilies.

title: H.M.O. Experiment Has Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTBALL: COLLEGE NOTEBOOK
description: SYRACUSE

title: The Latest Record: No. 63 for McGwire
description: Mark McGwire, pinch-hitting for the Cardinals, smacked his 63d home run last night in the first game of a doubleheader, extending the single-season record and breaking his latest tie with the Cubs' Sammy Sosa.

title: Panel Unveils Suggestions For Cutting Property Tax
description: A state commission charged with finding ways to lessen local property taxes in New Jersey offered 60 recommendations today, including a cap on annual increases in salaries of public employees, consolidation of some functions of local school districts and state financing of local prosecutors offices.

title: As the Running Game Sputters, Wheatley Gets Back in Huddle
description: From the beginning, they have been the most curious dance partners.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the filmmaker Milton Moses Ginsberg and how his movie ''Coming Apart'' affected his career misspelled his wife's surname. She is Nina Posnansky, not Polansky.

title: Rhone-Poulenc Unit Suspended
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said today that a United States plant of Centeon L.L.C., a joint venture with Hoechst A.G. of Germany, would suspend production after the United States Food and Drug Administration ordered a shutdown of the plant on safety concerns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DEA, THOMAS J. CUM DIO
description: O'DEA-Thomas J. Cum Dio, On September 13, 1998. Survived by six loving children: Noreen, Eileen, Brian, Kerry, Denise, Katie and the late Tod; five grandchildren and his sister Mary Drury. As per his request, no services were held. Donations to Meals on Wheels, 718-745-3660, or for his memorial garden, send to : O'Dea, P.O. Box 4, Hope, New Jersey 07844.

title: Sosa Aids Cubs Even Without Homer
description: The pressure was on the Chicago Cubs and Sammy Sosa tonight.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Thursday about the report sent to the House of Representatives by Kenneth W. Starr misstated the action taken by the House last year against Speaker Newt Gingrich. He was reprimanded, not censured, for ethics violations.

title: U.S. Court Upholds Aid for the Disabled On State Bar Exams
description: In the first ruling of its kind, a Federal appeals court in New York has ruled that a law school graduate claiming a reading disorder was entitled to extra time and other reasonable accommodations on the New York State bar examination -- even though an outside expert hired by the bar examiners said she had no disability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLAUGHLIN, MARYA
description: McLAUGHLIN-Marya. Monday, Sept. 14, 1998, of Washington, D.C. Miss McLaughlin is survived by her sister, Patricia McLaughlin Morgan of Bethesda, five nieces; Melissa Anne Morgan of Toronto, Canada, Marya Audrey Morgan of Cape May, NJ, Patricia Kearney Morgan of Rowayton, CT, Heather Morgan Hackett of Sterling, VA, Laura McLaughlin Morgan of Moscow, Russia, and 3 nephews; Byron Albert Morgan of Ashburn, Virginia, John Francis Morgan of Los Angeles and Peter McIntosh Morgan of San Francisco. Miss McLaughlin is also survived by five grand nieces and four grand nephews and close friend Eugene McCarthy. Friends may call at DeVol Funeral Home, 2222 Wisconsin Avenue, NW (parking adjacent) on Thursday from 6-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at St. Ann's Church, Wisconsin Avenue, NW at Yuma Street, NW, Washington, D.C. on Friday, September 18 at 10AM. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery, Woodville, VA. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Little Sisters of the Poor, 4200 Harewood Road NE, Washington, D.C. 20017.

title: PRESIDENT SENDS AIDES TO SOOTHE ANGRY DEMOCRATS
description: President Clinton hired a raft of fresh advisers today and dispatched his top aides to placate Congressional Democrats as members of the House Judiciary Committee bickered over whether to release a videotape of his grand jury testimony about his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS UP 9.2 PERCENT. Gulf of Mexico storms raised speculation that producers would face problems amassing winter supplies. The November contract rose 17.8 cents, to $2.123 for 1,000 cubic feet, a two-month high.

title: U.N. Rights Official, Back From China, Sees Better Attitude
description: At the end of what she called ''a successful but not always easy first visit to China,'' the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, said today that despite continuing human rights abuses, she had sensed among Chinese leaders a new willingness to discuss the country's rights record.

title: CHASE MANHATTAN TO BUY MELLON MORTGAGE NETWORK
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Mellon Mortgage Company's Western retail mortgage network, with 26 branches in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Nevada, Arizona and New Mexico. Chase Manhattan, a unit of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, said it expected the acquisition to add $750 million annually to its retail-originations franchise, doubling production in Oregon and Washington. Terms were not disclosed. Mellon Mortgage is a unit of the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: Political Scion, Hubert Humphrey 3d, Wins Nomination for Governor of Minnesota
description: Hubert H. Humphrey 3d, who bears this state's most revered political name, easily won the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party nomination for governor of Minnesota tonight.

title: As Energy Council Gathers, Oil Industry Seeks Answers
description: This week, Houston is throwing a party for more than 30 oil ministers and 8,000 other officials and executives from at least 82 countries. To make sure everyone attending the World Energy Council Congress feels sufficiently welcome, the city greeted them on Saturday night with a light show featuring 2 million watts of spotlights, 14 powerful lasers and 12 tons of explosives, enough to make car alarms wail all over downtown. Coming Thursday is what is being billed as the state's largest sit-down dinner ever, requiring a banquet hall also known as the Astrodome.

title: Democrats Pick Outsider in Washington Mayoral Race
description: In a striking break with the established political order, Anthony A. Williams, a government technocrat who moved to Washington less than three years ago to help lift the city out of its fiscal mess, won the Democratic nomination for mayor today over three opponents who are longtime City Council members.

title: Mayor Wins Chance to Take Storied Kennedy House Seat
description: Michael Capuano, the Mayor of the Boston suburb of Somerville, fought off nine rivals to inherit one of the most storied of political seats in the country tonight, winning the Democratic primary in the Eighth Congressional District, which sent a young John F. Kennedy to Washington more than half a century ago.

title: Begging for Bones: A New Craving for Marrow
description: IT is dinnertime at Judson Grill in midtown Manhattan, and typically, a good number of customers have ordered the grilled dry-aged sirloin with rosti potatoes, bone marrow, pea leaves and carrots. The marrow comes tucked inside a section of bone standing at attention alongside the steak, a tiny spoon at the ready.

title: Investors Not Told of Nuclear Plant Safety Issues, Group Says
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has kept quiet about its safety concerns over two uranium fuel processing plants in order to avoid embarrassment on the day after the plants were sold to the public, a nuclear watchdog group said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CMS ENERGY CORP., Dearborn, Mich., paid $90 million to buy the electricity company serving Margarita Island, Venezuela, in the first sale ever of a Venezuelan state-owned utility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAAR, RUTH
description: KRAAR-Ruth. The Boards and staff of United Jewish Appeal Federations of North America, a partnership of United Jewish Appeal, Council of Jewish Federations, and United Israel Appeal mourn the passing of Ruth Kraar, mother of Martin S. Kraar, who guided CJF as Executive Vice President for a decade. Married to the late Herbert, Mrs. Kraar was an aishes chail, a gracious touchstone and inspiration to her children, her grandchildren, and to all privileged to enjoy her ''Southern Hospitality.'' Our condolences to Martin, to his brothers Ronald and Louis, to their wives, Lynda, Jeannette, and Maureen, and to their families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Conrad L. Giles, M.D., President, CJF Jay Yoskowitz, Executive Vice President, CJF Richard L. Wexler, President, UJA Carole A. Solomon, National Chairman, UJA Bennett L. Aaron, Chairman, UIA Daniel R. Allen, Executive Vice Chairman, UIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDOLFO, DOLORES (DORI)
description: MANDOLFO-Dolores (Dori), August 28. The Far West 10th Street Block Association mourns the loss of our wonderful President. We extend our sympathy to her beloved husband Anthony and her family. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 17 at 10:30AM at St. Joseph's Church, 371 6th Avenue, N.Y.C.

title: Elite Mexican Drug Officers Said to Be Tied to Traffickers
description: An ambitious effort to overhaul Mexico's corrupt law-enforcement system has been thrown into turmoil by the disclosure that top investigators of an elite American-trained police unit may have ties to drug traffickers, American officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDEY, HELEN WINTHROP (KELLOGG), M.D.
description: EDEY-Helen Winthrop (Kellogg), M.D., 86, of Chilmark, MA., and New York City, widow of Maitland Armstrong Edey. September 15. Pioneer in issues of international population and family planning, founding board member of the Association for Voluntary Sterilization, later AVSC, International. Born in New York, she received her B.A. from Vassar College in 1934, and later her M.D. from New York University, while the mother of four children. She practiced psychiatry for many years before turning her incredible mind and great energy toward civic activitism and international affairs. Her many wide-ranging interests included arms control, setting up health clinics in underdeveloped countries, ornithology and travel. She is survived by her children, Maitland Edey Jr of West Tisbury, MA., Winthrop (Kelly) Edey of New York, Beatrice Phear, of Cambridge MA., and Marion Edey, of Silver Spring, MD, her son-in-law, Patrick Phear, her daughter-in-law Fausta Edey, thirteen grandchildren and four great grandchildren - all of whom she loved and who loved her.

title: Preventing World Recession
description: A quarter of a century ago when Washington was mired in scandal, the greatest challenge to global prosperity since the Great Depression presented itself in the form of an Arab oil embargo that promptly led to spiraling inflation, recession in the Western world and, within a few years, a third-world debt crisis that stifled development in Latin America for a generation. The largest economies were unable to respond to those challenges in a timely manner, and the world suffered.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Retail Sales Rise 0.2%, Below Expectations
description: Retail sales rose less than expected in August as gains in apparel and furniture were offset by a drop in automotive business.

title: Between a Whelp And a Windbag
description: It has been a good summer for Shaw's so-called ''plays pleasant.'' First, the Roundabout Theater mounted a sunny production of ''You Never Can Tell'' for those who could not get to the seashore. And now the Pearl Theater Company is offering an amusing and lighthearted revival of ''Candida.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARTH, PAMELA MARGARET
description: BARTH-Pamela Margaret. March 19, 1946 to September 16, 1991. In loving memory. Phyllis and Harris

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMERON, CLIFF
description: CAMERON-Cliff. On September 13, 1998 of Forest Hills, New York. Organist Emeritus First Church of Christ, Scientist, Forest Hills after forty years of service. The highlights of his 60 year career include: recognition as an original organist with NBC in the early days of television soap operas, as well as engagements in Atlanta, Georgia, The Hollywood Bowl, California & Radio City Music Hall, New York. He is survived by his sister Lucille Benash, Chicago, Illinois, and his nephew Carmon Hoppe, Oshkosh, Wisconsin. A memorial service will be planned.

title: Nominee for Treasurer Adds Diversity to the Democratic Slate
description: Connecticut Democrats assured that a minority candidate would be on their statewide ticket by nominating Denise L. Nappier for state treasurer today, much to the relief of party leaders who worried that they would wind up with an all-white slate in a year when the Republican ticket includes three minority candidates.

title: Harry Lumley, 71, Star Hockey Goalie
description: Harry Lumley, a Hall of Fame goalie who played for 16 seasons in the National Hockey League and was a star of the Detroit Red Wings' 1950 Stanley Cup title team, died on Sunday. He was 71.

title: McGwire Punches Up the Story
description: Mark McGwire had not hit a home run in six games, ever since he passed Roger Maris to set the major league single-season record amid a national furor. And to some, the sky was falling. A headline in a local newspaper today read, ''McGwire Stuck at 62.'' To add to the misery of McGwire's fans, Sammy Sosa, his once and future nemesis and, oddly enough, pal, had gone during the week from 58 home runs to 62, equaling McGwire's total.

title: 3 Charged in Shooting At Turnpike Rest Stop
description: Three men who were arrested following a shootout during an F.B.I. sting at a New Jersey Turnpike rest stop were indicted yesterday on charges of weapons possession and conspiracy to rob an armored car, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; New drugs offset some woes at American Home Products.
description: WOULD it be that the American Home Products Corporation has finally begun to change its luck?

title: Taming the Manhattan Cherry
description: THE maraschino cherry is a necessary evil in the world of cocktails. No one may actually want to eat it, but what is a manhattan without one?

title: China Military Chief Gives Pledges to U.S.
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen received pledges from China's senior military leader today that China will move ahead with modest joint military exercises and exchanges with the United States next year.

title: INSIDE
description: Major Gift to Lincoln Center

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARGAS, MINDY
description: VARGAS-Mindy. Age 47. Born March 31, 1951. The daughter of John and Shirley Vargas, last known to have resided in the New York City area. She died Monday, September 14, 1998 in the SUNY Health Science Center, Syracuse, NY. Would any kin or anyone knowing of any next of kin please call the Rome DDSO collect at 315336-2300 with any special funeral arrangements.

title: Bertelsmann Online Names Ogilvy One
description: Bertelsmann Online in New York, a unit of Bertelsmann A.G., said yesterday that it had named Ogilvy One Worldwide in New York as the first agency to handle advertising for BOL.com, its on-line bookselling venture. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPAS, LUCY G.
description: PAPPAS-Lucy G. September 15th. Beloved wife of the late George J. Pappas. Loving mother of Christo and John Pappas. Friends may call Thursday, September 17, 1998 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. Funeral Friday, September 18 at 10:30 A.m at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Hedge Fund And Banking Losses Pile Up
description: Tiger Management L.L.C., a well-known hedge fund, and the BankAmerica Corporation, one of the country's largest banks, reported huge losses yesterday in emerging-market investments, evidence that the economic havoc in Asia, Russia and Latin America is continuing to roil United States financial companies.

title: Rockefeller Center Plans Approved
description: Preservation officials approved a scaled-down plan yesterday to expand the windows of Rockefeller Center's boutique-size shopfronts, allowing a compromise that they believe will maintain the architectural spirit of the tourist magnet.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He's running the country well. He's just not running his life very well.''''

title: Principal's Pregnancy: Sex Education; Baby First, Then Marriage, But a Rural Area Is Able to Adjust
description: The flier mailed out this summer to scores of parents may have been anonymous, but it did not mince words.

title: Op-Art; Morality Test
Yankees on Way to 3 Million
description: Having broken their Yankee Stadium attendance record Monday night, and drawn another 43,218 fans last night, the Yankees need to average just under 40,000 a game for their last eight home games to reach three million for the first time.

title: An Artist and a Dog That Became a Cultural Icon
description: The Russians did not ask for a Blue Dog when George Rodrigue visited the Soviet Union with President Ronald Reagan a decade or so ago, but they thought a horse would be nice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, EVELYN
description: ADLER-Evelyn. Devoted mother of Herbert and Donald. Dear mother-in-law of Susan and loving grandmother of Lisa and Amy. Services were held September 15. Memorials may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 166 Avenue of the Americas, NY, NY 10013 or Friends In Deed, 594 Broadway, New York, New York 10012.

title: A Drug Memoir: In Hollywood, Who Could Tell?
description: As Jerry Stahl recounts in his blistering 1995 memoir, ''Permanent Midnight,'' drug addiction turned him into a skittish, distracted, hugely self-involved individual. And since he happened to be working in Hollywood, no one really noticed. While an addict, Mr. Stahl managed to pass for a plausible husband and employable television scriptwriter, even though drugs could render him capable of citing ''Nosferatu'' and ''The Patty Duke Show'' in the same sentence. What kept him afloat? ''I stood out, in short, as that most beloved of 80's entertainment commodities,'' he writes. ''Safe edge, the 'dark' guy who took a little explaining but got the job done.''

title: Islanders Have Arena Plan And Will Travel, if Needed
description: Should nothing come of Thursday's meeting between the Islanders and S.M.G., the company that operates Nassau Coliseum, the team plans to play its first 12 regular-season home games at several arenas around the region, an Islanders official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, CALLMAN
description: GOTTESMAN-Callman. Died September 13, 1998. Beloved father of Carol Siegel, beloved brother of Sydney, David, and Terry. Grandfather of Paul and Roger. Great grandfather of Eric. Services Thursday 12:00 noon at John Krtil, 1297 First Avenue at 70th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIFACH, IRA
description: ZWEIFACH-Ira. On September 14, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Ellen Fuller Zweifach. Loving father to Andrea Carroll and father-inlaw to Jerry Carroll. Dear brother to Shirley Zweifach. Services Thursday, 10:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIEL, WILLIAM
description: PIEL-William. Died September 13, peacefully at home in Sherman, Connecticut, age 88. Born New York City, son of the late William and Loretto Scott Piel; brother of the late Mary, Rita and John Piel & of Gerard & David Piel; husband of Eleanor Green Piel; father of Michael, Anthony and Thomas Piel. A.B., with honors Princeton University 1932; LL.B. cum laude Harvard Law School 1935. Served in Special Branch Military Intelligence, U.S. War Department, 1942-1945, Medal for Exceptional Civilian Service. In practice of law, Sullivan & Cromwell, 1935-1942, 1945-1981. Wake, 5 to 8 P.M., on Tuesday, September 15 at Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Ridge Street, New Milford, Connecticut. Mass of Christian Burial, at 11 A.M., on Wednesday, September 16, Holy Trinity Church, Sherman. In lieu of flowers, gifts please to The Cancer Research Institute, 681 Fifth Avenue, New York City 10022.

title: Cowboys Rallying Round Garrett
description: When Troy Aikman went down with a fractured left clavicle against Denver on Sunday, it looked as if the Dallas Cowboys' playoff hopes went with him. Aikman's scramble for extra yards knocked him out for at least four weeks and possibly as many as eight weeks.

title: Atlantic City Expressway To Have Higher Tolls
description: The commissioners of the South Jersey Transportation Authority voted unanimously yesterday to raise tolls on the Atlantic City Expressway.

title: Modestly Taking the Stage In a Cliffhanger; Todd Haimes Plays Knight For Troubled Livent
description: Todd Haimes used to be fat. He dropped 55 pounds several years ago, down to a trim 170 on a 5-foot-10-inch frame, resolving to live long enough to see his two children grow up. And though he looks like he has always been fit, Mr. Haimes has never been cavalier about conquering his weight problem. He keeps his fat pictures around to remind him not to overeat, worried that without absolute vigilance, the large man inside of him could easily emerge again.

title: Quick, Hide the Tools. Here Comes a Chef.
description: KENNETH JOHNSON, the chef at the Terrace restaurant at Columbia University, uses pantyhose to strain consomme.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRISTIN, IRVING
description: PRISTIN-Irving. On September 14, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Sina. Loving father of Ronald. Cherished grandfather to David & Steven. Dear brother of Seymour Pristin and Ann Buvitt. Services on Thursday at 12:15 P.M., at the ''Riverside'', 76th STreet and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: France and Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERELSON, SEYMOUR
description: PERELSON-Seymour. Devoted husband of Dorothy Elsinger Perelson and father to Lois Sacher. Grandfather of Randi and Peter Sacher. Great grandfather to Seth and Faith Chelsea. Services at Ferncliff Cemetery Chapel, Hartsdale, NY on Thursday at 12 noon.

title: Keep Clinton in Office, Most Say In Poll, but His Image Is Eroding
description: The public's view of President Clinton's moral character has sunk to the lowest level of his Presidency, but most Americans say they still believe he is a vigorous leader who should not be impeached or forced to resign, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: Kosovo's Crisis Is Bad, and Getting Worse
description: As evidence mounts of a human catastrophe in Kosovo, the United States is still far from a decision over whether to use military force to put an end to the Serbian assault that has forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their homes, senior Clinton Administration officials say.

title: Warning Against Intimidation
description: The chairman of the House committee that will weigh possible impeachment charges against President Clinton promised swift action today against any efforts to use smear tactics to intimidate committee members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, RABBI JONAS
description: GEWIRTZ-Rabbi Jonas. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Rabbi Jonas Gewirtz, cherished father, beloved husband, and renowned scholar, who enriched the lives of others through his gentleness and wisdom. He passed on a legacy of generosity to his family, longtime supporters of UJA-Federation and many communal activities. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his devoted wife, Lola; his daughter, Dorothy, president of Camp Mogen-Avraham, Heller, Sternberg, Inc., a UJA-Federation beneficiary, and her husband, Julius, a member of our Board of Directors; his son, William, and his wife, Debbie; his many grandchildren; and to the entire family. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGRIN, JOHN J.
description: VOGRIN-John J. Of East Norwich, New York, on September 14, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Madeline. Loving father of Jack F., and Daniel J. Cherished grandfather of Julia and Jeffrey. Visiting at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home Inc., 293 South St., Oyster Bay, Wednesday & Thursday 3-5, 7-9PM. Funeral Mass on Friday 9:30 AM, St. Dominic's R.C. Chapel. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: CUMMINS SEES REVENUE DROP AND SIZABLE CHARGE
description: The Cummins Engine Company, the world's top maker of high-power diesel engines, expects third-quarter revenue to fall as much as 10 percent below the second quarter's $1.64 billion because of weak demand in Asia. Cummins shares fell 17.5 percent yesterday, losing $7.50, to $35.25. The company also said it would take a pretax charge of $145 million in the quarter. About $110 million of the charge will pay for a previously announced reorganization and $35 million will cover a change in calculating engine warranty costs. Cummins, of Columbus, Ind., warned earlier this year of a ''significant'' charge to cut 1,000 jobs.

title: A Clutch Player: Gregory Bestor Craig
description: More than 25 years ago at Yale Law School, Gregory B. Craig was struck by a rare burst of pessimism from a fellow student, Bill Clinton, who argued in a seminar one day that corporate America had too much power and money to ever be tamed, even by the democratic institutions that the young man from Arkansas believed in and wanted to help lead.

title: Democrat Faces Daunting Battle In Governor's Race in New York
description: Trouncing his opponents in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, who has never won office outside his Queens district, propelled himself yesterday into a far more daunting struggle against Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Sunday about junior-level tennis misstated the location of a tennis academy operated by Dennis Van der Meer. It is in Hilton Head, S.C., not in Florida.

title: Isaac Stern: Eloquent in Word and Music
description: THE answer is, opening a jar of spaghetti sauce.

title: Players Union Enrolls N.F.L. Coaches Group
description: The three-year-old National Football League Coaches Association will now work under the auspices of the N.F.L. Players Association, the groups announced today.

title: Good Pay, Good Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANDERSON, PAUL J, MD
description: ANDERSON-Paul J, MD, On Thursday September 17, 2PM. The Auditorium, New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St, NY Reception will follow

title: BITS AND BYTES
description: In the Virtual Kitchen With Corporate Giants

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, EDWIN, MD
description: WEINSTEIN-Edwin, MD. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Insititute and Society note with profound sorrow the recent passing of one of their most acclaimed colleagues. Dr. Weinstein, a graduate of 50 years, was connected with White from its inception. A fine scholar, academician, diagnostician and clinician, Dr. Weinstein quickly rose to esteemed positions on the faculty, including those of training analyst, Fellow, and research chairman with a world-renowned expertise in neurological communication disorders. Despite the many demands by other organizations for his expertise, he continued to serve the Institute and Society in significant ways. Our condolences to his family and to his many friends and colleagues. Marylou Lionells, Ph.D., Dir. White Insititute Robert Watson, Ph.D., President White Society

title: Who Should Decide The Sex of a Baby?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; An Investment Firm Turns to Jersey City
description: Lord Abbett & Company, the investment management firm, announced on Monday that it had signed a lease for new offices in the Colgate Center at 90 Hudson Street on the Jersey City waterfront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIGER, MIRIAM
description: STEIGER-Miriam. On Sept. 14, 1998 at age 90. Beloved wife of the late Sol. Cherished mother of Joel J. and wife, Carole Ann, of Ridgewood, N.J., and Dr. Norman and wife, Nancy, of Mamaroneck, NY. Loving grandmother of Andrew, Adam and David Steiger, Deborah Schnur, Elizabeth Newman & Sue Ellen Gerber. She will be greatly missed by her thirteen greatgrandchildren. She is also survived by two sisters, Dinah Meyer and Rose Moskow. Graveside services at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, on Wednesday, September 16 at 1 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ROWENNA L.
description: WHITE-Rowenna L., at age 18. Victim of SwissAir Flight 111 crash on September 2. Beloved daughter of Nancy Wight of New York City and Paul R. White of Bronxville. Also survived by her stepmother Judith Lilleston White of Bronxville. Rowenna was en route to Geneva & Montreux, Switzerland to begin studies at Hotel Institute Montreux (HIM). She was a 1998 graduate of the Cascadilla School in Ithaca, N.Y. This summer she had been learning French at the Alliance Francaise and was employed by Nello's Restaurant in New York. Other immediate survivors include her grandparents Margaret and Joe White of Woodbridge, VA; 2 aunts and 2 uncles. Since she was an animal lover, contributions to the memory of Rowenna L. White may be made to the ASPCA, 424 E. 92 Street, N.Y. 10128. A service in her honor will be held Saturday, September 19 at 12 noon at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Ave. at 71 Street, N.Y.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in the Dining section on May 13 about Marco Pierre White, a British chef and restaurateur, described his climb to success. It said that in the past he had ''a well-publicized bout with drugs and alcohol.''

title: From Putts To Punts In 2 Days For Hansen
description: On Friday, Brian Hansen, his pro football career apparently a memory, was playing in a charity golf tournament in Sioux Falls, S.D. On Sunday, he was back at the old stand, punting for the Jets in their 24-10 loss to the Baltimore Ravens.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Aug. 27 about Web sites for mystery fans referred incorrectly to Jiro Kimura, who runs the Gumshoe site (www .nsknet.or.jp/jkimura). Jiro Kimu ra is a man, not a woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZER, ERICH
description: HOLZER-Erich. The Officers and members of the Boards of Governors of The Jewish Home and Rehabilitation Center & The Jewish Home at Rockleigh note with profound sorrow the passing of our fellow Board Member, dear friend and benefactor, Erich Holzer. An extraordinary man & gentle soul, we will miss him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife Eva, daughter Vivian and son Robert, and their families. May his name be for a blessing. Carl Epstein, President Charles P. Berkowitz, Executive Vice-President

title: It Wasn't Perjury When Clinton Lied
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIED, PEPI
description: FRIED-Pepi, Mrs. Lido Beach Synagogue extends condolences to our past president and Board member, Bert Fried and his entire family on the loss of his beloved mother, Mrs. Pepi Fried. Alex Berkovitch, President Rabbi Daniel Mehlman

title: Suffolk Sues, Alleging Power Authority Favors Nassau With 2-Tiered Rates
description: Suffolk County officials sued today to overturn the Long Island Power Authority's two-tiered billing rates and rebates, which they say favor electricity customers in Nassau County.

title: Princeton to Dedicate New Stadium
description: Tearing down venerable Palmer Stadium, where Princeton teams had performed since 1914, was an easy task. Steve Tosches, the football coach, was there watching the Mercer Wrecking Company's giant claws rip apart the grandstand and today he recalled those moments from December 1996.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Cable Concern Splits Canada Operations
description: Shaw Communications Inc., Canada's second-largest cable company, said today that it would split its media and cable operations into two separate companies.

title: Blame It on Wise Guys
description: Americans watch television in far bigger numbers and a lot more often than they go to the movies or listen to record albums; but that apparently does not translate into interest in seeing television stars pick up awards.

title: SCHUMER IS SENATE NOMINEE; VALLONE WILL FACE PATAKI
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, reaping the fruits of a decade of fund-raising and a campaign of ceaseless television advertising, won the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato last night, overwhelming Geraldine A. Ferraro in her second attempt to return to public office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRELL, RICHARD
description: MERRELL-Richard. Actor, television and film writer and designer, died Sunday, September 13 at his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, CT. The cause of death was heart failure. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Jan Miner, and two sisters, Sister Jeanne Merrell and Audrey Shepard. No services are planned at the request of the deceased. In lieu of flowers it was his wish and that of Jan Miner that those who choose make a contribution to Project ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease), 511 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 341, New York, New York 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, CATHERINE
description: WEBER-Catherine. Of New York City and Jewett, N.Y. Gently at the age of 89-1/2, beloved and loving wife of the late Frederic, mother of Cynthia Weber Freedman (Lewis) and Richard Weber (Twila), grandmother of Samuel Frederic.

title: Seeking a Middle Road on Impeachment, but Finding Only Roadblocks
description: Much of political Washington, especially the elders who have lived through all this once before, was searching today for a way out of the crisis into which President Clinton has plunged the nation's political system. But everywhere they looked they saw a roadblock.

title: Some Shrug Off Politics, Hold Noses and Just Vote
description: Jean Mandel describes herself as cynical about a lot of things, among them American politics in general and specifically the report by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, detailing President Clinton's alleged sexual peccadilloes.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: ALBERTA ENERGY BIDS CASH AND STOCK FOR AMBER ENERGY
description: The Alberta Energy Company, one of Canada's biggest oil concerns, offered to buy a struggling rival, Amber Energy Inc., for about $750 million (Canadian) in cash, stock and assumed debt. The bid consists of $7 a share in cash, or $446 million (Canadian). Amber shareholders may choose to receive 0.215 Alberta Energy share for each share, which were $7.25 at Monday's closing prices. Alberta Energy will also assume $304 million in debt. Amber said last week that it would produce less petroleum than expected through next year and slashed capital spending by 40 percent to conserve cash. Both companies are based in Calgary, Alberta. An acquisition would give Alberta Energy interests in oil land near its own holdings.

title: Sports of The Times; The Greatest Is Honored by The Diplomat
description: CAMERAS were clicking inside United Nation headquarters yesterday afternoon when the Secretary General Kofi Annan presented the Greatest, Muhammad Ali, with the Messenger of Peace honor. This was mostly a photo opportunity: the Secretary General presented Ali with a framed citation and a lapel pin in the form of a dove.
