Ali and his wife, Lonnie, presented the Secretary General with a pair of boxing gloves. This was a relationship filled with deep, longstanding mutual admiration.

title: Coming On Topical, Comical and Relevant
description: For some of us, daytime talk shows, with their celebrity puffery and soap-sister schmaltz, are as enticing as poison ivy. And the prospect of a talk show starring Roseanne seemed as unnatural as poison ivy with sound effects, notably a loud cackle. Never predict, because the show on Monday was surprisingly smart and winning, a mix of sharp topical conversation, occasional comedy sketches and social work without sentimentality.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets Continue to Rise As Dow Climbs 79 Points

title: Weiner Is Victor Over Katz In Bid to Replace Schumer
description: In a contentious, four-way race, Anthony D. Weiner, a 34-year-old City Councilman from Brooklyn, won the Democratic primary for the seat to succeed Representative Charles E. Schumer in Congress by a razor-thin margin this morning.

title: Who Should Decide The Sex of a Baby?
description: To the Editor:

title: Searching for a Life, He Found the Language
description: THE PROFESSOR AND THE MADMAN

title: Scott Mason, 50, Ex-Professor At Harvard's Business School
description: Scott P. Mason, a former chairman of the finance department at Harvard University's business school, died on Sept. 8 at his home in Wellesley, Mass. He was 50.

title: Both 'Black Boxes' Stopped Recording 6 Minutes Before Swissair Jet Crashed
description: Both ''black boxes'' recovered from the wreckage of Swissair Flight 111 stopped recording about six minutes before the jet crashed into the ocean, investigators said today.

title: Simple Italian Food, Untouched by 'Improvements'
description: FROM the name alone, you would assume that Pepe Rosso to Go is just a takeout place, like the original Pepe Rosso on Sullivan Street in SoHo and its cousin, Pepe Verde on Hudson Street in Greenwich Village. But by adding a dining room that can seat 50 while offering the same simple, inexpensive and first-rate Italian food as the others, the East Village Pepe Rosso to Go is for staying.

title: Democrats Nominate Spitzer To Confront G.O.P.'s Vacco
description: Eliot L. Spitzer, a wealthy Manhattan lawyer who spent millions of his own money to finance a campaign for state attorney general, won the Democratic primary nomination yesterday, and will take on the Republican incumbent, Dennis C. Vacco, in the November election.

title: It Wasn't Perjury When Clinton Lied
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FINKELSTEIN, SAMUEL
description: FINKELSTEIN-Samuel. 1906-1996. We no longer celebrate your birthday but continue to celebrate your life and cherish the memories. Mim, Berne, Billy, Barbara and all the children

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS FURTHER. The dollar rose for a second day against Japan's currency on gains in the United States stock market and a stock rally in Latin America. The dollar cost 133.90 yen in New York, up from 132.68.

title: Gauging a Bombardment of Opinions That Could Determine Clinton's Fate
description: For many liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans, getting a reading on what the folks back home think about President Clinton's behavior was not too tough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. We mourn the tragic loss on the Swissair 111 of our devoted friend, officer and supporter. A man of deep faith, his devotion to his people was legendary, yet he embraced all people who were in need. His deeds of humanity, charity and kindness will live on for posterity. Our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Carol, his sons Abraham and Alan and the entire family. Wall Street Synagogue Rabbi Meyer Hager

title: For Favre, the Game's the Thing
description: Brett Favre was heading toward the locker room after the Packers had dismantled Tampa Bay last Sunday, but instead of a hop in his step, there was a limp. Favre is the National Football League's most durable quarterback, but that doesn't mean he feels no pain.

title: New Era as Police Prepare to Run School Security
description: Bringing to a close a wrenching debate about the role of police officers in schools, the New York City Board of Education is prepared to vote today to turn over school security to the Police Department.

title: Forgiving George Wallace
description: Growing up in rural Alabama during the 1950's, it was hard not to know who George Wallace was. Mr. Wallace, first as a circuit judge and then as Governor, fought the civil rights movement with every fiber of his being. He was a demagogue whose words and actions created a climate that allowed for violent reprisals against those seeking to end racial discrimination.

title: Military Leaders Make Case To Clinton for More Money
description: Turning his attention to military issues amid the furor over his personal conduct, President Clinton met today with the nation's senior generals and admirals and received warnings that the armed forces were being stretched thin by increasing duties and decreasing budgets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PECK, HARRIS B., M.D.
description: PECK-Harris B., M.D. The Board of Trustees & staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Harris B. Peck, M.D., an esteemed member of our senior staff and a consultant to the agency for many years. A leading psychiatrist, Dr. Peck will long be remembered as a pioneer in the fields of community mental health and group therapy. JBFCS extends its deepest sympathy to his wife, Ilka; his children, Ann, Yoav, Jonathan, Joshua and Joel; and other members of his family. Joseph S. Kaplan, President Seymour R. Askin, Jr., Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President Robert Abramovitz, M.D., Chief Psychiatrist

title: Stocks in Brazil Rally, Buoying Latin Markets
description: Record gains by Brazilian stocks accelerated today, the third consecutive day of a rally that has driven up the market 45 percent. The strong gains were fueled by a growing sense among investors that developed nations would protect Latin American economies from the devastation that has crippled Asia and Russia.

title: Lincoln Center Gets Gift of $25 Million
description: A record $25 million has been given to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts by a new board member, Julian H. Robertson Jr., the hedge fund investor. Announcing the gift yesterday, Lincoln Center officials said the fountain plaza was being renamed in honor of Mr. Robertson's wife, Josie.

title: Denver Calls Old Airport Ground Zero for Growth
description: The luggage carousels and ticket counters have been sold to Peru and shipped to airports in the Andes.

title: Miscellany
description: * Snyder Communications Inc., Bethesda, Md., acquired MKM Marketing G.m.b.H., a pharmaceutical marketing agency in Lenggries, Germany, for $58 million in stock.

title: Business Travel; Singapore Airlines and Delta take different approaches to premium service for passengers.
description: SINGAPORE AIRLINES and Delta Air Lines announced two differing strategies to upgrade their long-haul in-flight service for business travelers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, SAMUEL
description: SCHECHTER-Samuel. The National Jewish Outreach Program mourns the passing of Samuel Schechter, beloved father of Caryl and Israel Englander, distinguished supporters of NJOP. Sin cere condolences to the family. Rabbi Ephraim Z. Buchwald, Dir.

title: The Concert Season as a Crucible, Not a Bouquet to the Past
description: Imagine that you've just been put in charge of a 680-seat concert hall that in recent years has presented a season balanced between new-music concerts and standard repertory recitals and chamber music. When you finish sketching out your first season of about 60 performances, you have a handful of concerts that cover the 14th through 18th centuries, virtually every flavor of 20th-century music, from Serialism and Minimalism to art-rock and 1960's vintage soul -- but not a single work by Bach, Mozart, Beethoven, Schubert, Chopin, Schumann, Liszt or Brahms.

title: Commercial Real Estate; General Foods' Old Office Is Repackaged for Multiple Tenants
description: With 14 acres of vacant office space wrapped like a red-brick embrace around a poplar-filled lawn, the former General Foods headquarters in White Plains is clearly more than any one potential tenant could digest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, MARILYN. (NEE QUARTNER)
description: KAPLAN-Marilyn. (nee Quartner). Died September 15, 1998 after a long, courageous battle. Much loved wife for 50 years of Bernard, cherished mother of Martin and Helene Kaplan and Shirley Kaplan and Hillel Marans. Adoring grandmother of Tamar, Aaron, Joshua, Ariella, Benjamin, Zachary and Elie. Funeral will be held Wednesday, September 16 at 9:30 AM, Boulevard Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. Charitable donations in lieu of flowers.

title: About New York; God And Swoosh At St. John's
description: WHEN James Keady took a course in Catholic social teaching last semester at St. John's University, his professor suggested that he look into sports and social justice for a term paper. It made sense to Mr. Keady, who was studying theology and working as a graduate assistant coach for the men's soccer team. He settled on a topic when he saw a newspaper article about allegations of unsafe conditions in the far-flung Asian factories making Nike products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLKER, ROSA (NEE JACOBSON)
description: KOLKER-Rosa (nee Jacobson). The Officers, members of the Board of Directors and Staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) deeply mourn the passing of Rosa Kolker (nee Jacobson), beloved mother of Jonathan W. Kolker, President of the JDC. She was an outstandiing woman and her presence will be greatly missed by all who knew her. We express our heartfelt sympathy to Jonathan, his wife, Judy, his sons, Alex and Robert, and his daughter, Frieda Hallock. Michael Schneider, Exec V.P. Amb. Milton A. Wolf, Ch of Brd

title: Yes, There Is Life After Chardonnay
description: THERE are tennis fans who so love the United States Open that they devote two full weeks each year to watching it. Not in the comfort of their homes but in the stands in Queens, day after day, broiling like lamb chops in the pitiless sun. I don't envy them, but I don't hate them for it. Nor do I harbor the slightest antipathy toward bungee jumpers, crossword puzzle addicts or people who enjoy Tex-Mex food. I don't care for any of those things, but I wish those who do only the best.

title: Panel Suggests Bank Changes For Canada
description: A national task force has endorsed mergers of large Canadian banks and has recommended easing rules for foreign banks to operate here as long as the public interest is protected.

title: Si, No Repeats
description: According to the Guinness Book of World Records, the longest-running television series in history without a single repeat episode is ''Sabado Gigante,'' the three-hour weekly variety show, which has been a fixture on Univision, the Spanish-language network, in the United States since the mid-1980's and in South America since 1961.

title: Iraqi Official Criticizes U.N. Chief Over Role in Arms Inspection
description: A senior Iraqi official close to President Saddam Hussein leveled an unusual direct attack on Secretary General Kofi Annan today, apparently trying to draw Mr. Annan into a growing confrontation over arms inspections.

title: ENERGEN TO BUY TOTAL MINATOME FOR $192 MILLION
description: The Energen Resources Corporation, a unit of the Energen Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., will acquire the Total Minatome Corporation, an oil and natural gas concern, from a unit of the French energy company Total S.A. for $192 million, then sell 31 percent of the acquired company to the closely held Westport Oil and Gas Company of Denver for about $60 million. Energen's net investment will be $110.4 million. It will also assume debt of $22 million. Total Minatome handles Total's non-deepwater oil and gas assets in North America. Shares of Energen rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $17.50.

title: De La Hoya Risking More Difficult Fights
description: Oscar De La Hoya, promoted as the Golden Boy, has felt for several years as if he has had to carry the tattered sport of boxing on his shoulders. Now, at the age of 25, another realization has struck him.

title: Intel Agreement Indicates a Rift With Microsoft
description: In an agreement to be announced on Wednesday, the Intel Corporation will license its advanced video compression software to Real Networks Inc., a Seattle-based developer of programs that deliver audio and video over the Internet.

title: Saga Acquisition Lags in Oil Production
description: Saga Petroleum A.S.A., Norway's third-largest oil company, said yesterday that it would take a one-time charge to its profits of 1.6 billion kroner ($212 million), mainly because it paid too much for Santa Fe Exploration (U.K.) Ltd., a North Sea oil production and exploration company. Saga's shares fell 9 kroner, or 11 percent, to 73.5 kroner, posting their biggest one-day percentage decline since 1990.

title: 7-Year-Old Is Linked To Drowning of Girl, 3
description: A 3-year-old girl who prosecutors say drowned in a backyard pool in Cherry Hill in May while her father took drugs inside was pushed into the pool by a 7-year-old, the Camden County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Dairy Deal by Dean Foods
description: The Dean Foods Company, the nation's biggest dairy concern, has agreed to acquire the closely held Berkeley Farms Inc., a leading processor and distributor of dairy products in California. Terms were not disclosed. Dean Foods, based in Franklin Park, has annual sales of $3.3 billion. Berkeley Farms, based in Hayward, Calif., processes and distributes milk, ice cream and other dairy products throughout Northern California. It had annual sales of more than $160 million.

title: Seductive Brandy Of Normandy's Eden
description: NORMANDY is so close to Paris that wise guys sometimes call it the 21st arrondissement. Which no doubt explains why, in the old days, Normandy's Calvados, or apple brandy, was the capital's favorite tipple. To a degree, it still is -- not so much in the grand hotels and the restaurants showered with stars, but in the bars, bistros and brasseries frequented by ordinary folk.

title: Political Outsider Wins in Washington
description: Washington voters chose Anthony A. Williams as the Democratic nominee to succeed Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. Gubernatorial nominees were selected in Minnesota and Massachusetts, where Democrats picked Michael Capuano to succeed Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d.

title: 3 Norwegian Banks Plan Giant Merger
description: Christiania Bank A.S.A., Fokus Bank A.S.A. and Postbanken agreed yesterday to merge to form Norway's largest bank, with assets of about $40 billion.

title: Good Pay, Good Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: TBS Banking On 'Seinfeld'
description: Might ''Seinfeld'' be the last great hit television show produced by the broadcast networks?

title: A Season for Hallah, by the Thousand . . . And a Season for Guides on How to Bake It
description: WITH Rosh ha-Shanah beginning on Sunday evening, the Israel Beigel Baking Company, like other classic Jewish bakeries in New York City, is in its high season for rugelach, honey cakes and traditional round New Year hallahs -- more than 10,000 of them.

title: Thyssen Halts Plan To Buy Steelmaker
description: Shares of Cockerill Sambre S.A. fell yesterday after Thyssen Krupp A.G. canceled plans to bid for a majority stake in the Belgian steelmaker. The government of Belgium's southern region of Wallonia, which owns more than 78 percent of Cockerill, is now relying on Usinor S.A., the only other interested party, to submit a bid by the deadline of next Monday. Thyssen's decision was disclosed by Walloon authorities late on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSTER, MALCOLM
description: FOSTER-Malcolm. The Board of Governors and members of Sunningdale Country Club are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed member, Malcolm Foster. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Helen and to the entire family. William Ettelson, President Michael Roth, Secretary

title: Metro Business; Office Building Venture
description: Reckson Service Industries Inc. of Melville, N.Y., has formed a $115 million joint venture to buy and develop office buildings used by the government and privately operated prisons, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

title: Man in Beating Case Told His Blood Was on Victim
description: Prosecutors have informed a defendant accused in what the police said was a racially motivated beating outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub that his blood has been found on the victim's shirt, lawyers said.

title: Writers' Consolation
description: To the Editor:

title: It Wasn't Perjury When Clinton Lied
description: To the Editor:

title: The Real Campaigns Begin
description: In winning New York's Democratic nominations for U.S. Senate and governor yesterday, Charles Schumer and Peter Vallone have accomplished only the easiest part of their political challenges. Mr. Schumer must now go on to compete against Senator Alfonse D'Amato, whose skills as a campaigner are legendary. Mr. Vallone must take on the popular Gov. George Pataki.

title: CALENDAR
description: Union Square Harvest

title: Woman Named To Head U.S.T.A.
description: Judy Levering of Stowe, Vt., will become the first female president in the 117-year history of the United States Tennis Association.

title: The Nearer the Tree, the Sweeter the Fruit
description: THERE is no better time than right now -- O.K., you could have started earlier in the summer -- to get into what nutritionists call the Five-a-Day habit: eating five servings of fruits and vegetables every day.

title: Rome Journal; Italy Is Speechless: Movies Lose Their Voices
description: For the first time in Italian history, Reva, the heroine of ''The Guiding Light,'' beat on the chest of her handsome shipwreck companion and raged this week in her native English. Tiny subtitles tried to keep up with the heaving dialogue, but most loyal television viewers were confused and outraged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERSON, ROBERT
description: MYERSON-Robert, 77 of New York passed away Monday, September 14th, 1998. He was the loving father of Laurel (Steven) Isicoff, Joseph (Michelle) Myerson; dear brother of Edward (Priscilla) Myerson and cherished grandfather of Joseph, Alison, Michael, Daniel, Andrew and Caitlyn. A memorial service will be scheduled in New York at a later time. Donations to Actor's Equity.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Pots, Pans and Food From Alain Ducasse

title: Critics Silent as McRae Emerges
description: It wasn't that long ago when Steve Phillips was still hearing criticism for his first major trade as general manager of the Mets. That was the one last season that brought reliever Mel Rojas to New York, where he has often pitched as miserably as he did for the Chicago Cubs.

title: Boeing's Rating May Be Lowered
description: The Boeing Company's credit rating may be lowered by Moody's Investors Service as production problems trouble the world's largest aircraft maker and Asia's economic crisis increases the risk that sales there will slow.

title: Nvest to Acquire Another Money Manager
description: Nvest L.P. has agreed to buy H. A. Schupf & Company, a New York-based money manager with about $550 million of assets, for an undisclosed amount of equity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRA, HENRY
description: SPIRA-Henry. Thank you, Henry, for being the powerful, articulate and sympathetic advocate you were. During our negotiations you helped me and my colleagues in senior management at Revlon understand that profits and humaneness are not mutually exclusive. You made Revlon employees and their family members feel better about themselves with your patience and your understanding of how corporations work. Yours was not a shrill voice, rather it was one of compassion and reason. Rest well my friend. You have earned it. Roger Shelley, Former V.P. Corporate Affairs and Investor Relations, Revlon, Inc.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Keep Sights on Events, Ready to Load Ammunition in Ads
description: Although overt efforts to drive President Clinton from office could backfire, several Republican operatives said today that many campaigns were on the verge of exploiting the President's troubles in commercials leading up to the Nov. 3 election. Several are conducting surveys to determine how forceful the advertisements should be.

title: Champs Ready For Garden Bout
description: The world champions Shane Mosley and Angel Manfredy made a joint appearance yesterday at Manhattan's Jekyll and Hyde Restaurant, holding their final news conference before defending their titles next Tuesday at Madison Square Garden.

title: Incumbents Across the City Fare Well in Gaining Democratic Nominations
description: In two of the most combative and turbulent local races in New York City this year, State Senator David Rosado and Assemblyman Ruben Diaz Jr., both of the South Bronx, survived strong, well-financed challenges last night from former State Senator Pedro Espada Jr., and his brother, Jose R. Espada, who ran for the Assembly seat.

title: Calvin Klein Chooses Wieden & Kennedy
description: Calvin Klein Inc. said yesterday that it had named an outside agency, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., to share advertising responsibilities for the CK One unisex fragrance with the company's in-house agency, CRK Advertising. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Iran's Top Leader Weighs In Against Afghans
description: Iran's supreme leader told the country's military and its top civilian officials today to be ready to carry out ''speedy, timely and forceful implementation'' of coming decisions in a crisis over Afghanistan.

title: Key Economic Reformer Said to Quit Primakov Government
description: An outspoken economic reformer has reportedly left the Russian Government, removing one of the last strong voices for free-market reform in the team being put together by Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMII, MOHAMMAD REZA
description: SAMII-Mohammad Reza, 42, architect. Beloved husband of Negar, and loving father of Guive, died in NY Hospital, August 26, 1998. Member of the American Institute of Architecture, his work in all three NY airports has been much admired. He was a loyal, sincere and extremely kind husband. He had the most beautiful relationship with his son, Guive, for he was the most caring and loving father. We thank all our friends and family whose help and support enabled us to pull through this extremely difficult time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, JULIUS
description: ROSEN-Julius. On September 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Robert and Emmett. Cherished grandfather of Eric. Dear brother of Gertrude. Graveside services Wednesday 1:30PM at Mt. Lebanon cemetery.

title: A Clinton Plea Bargain
description: The President cannot avoid impeachment hearings if his lawyers continue to insult the public by insisting that he did not lie under oath. That is the message that Senator Tom Daschle and Representative Richard Gephardt delivered Monday by denouncing the legal hairsplitting by White House lawyers. They were also serving notice that if impeachment hearings do come, the President's own party will not defend him under the deservedly ridiculed strategy devised by David Kendall.

title: New Rules for Children Testifying in Abuse Cases
description: Prosecutors in child abuse cases will no longer be able to tell juries what a child has said outside of court about an abuse case if the child is going to testify at the trial, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALE, THOMAS F.
description: HALE-Thomas F. Formerly of NYC and Westport, CT. Memorial mass September 19, 10 AM, in St. Luke's Church, Westport, CT.

title: A Season for Hallah, by the Thousand . . . And a Season for Guides on How to Bake It
description: FOR many Jewish families, the menu for Rosh ha-Shanah dinner, from the chicken soup to the honey cake, is set in stone, and has been for generations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDENSTEIN, CHARLES
description: SEIDENSTEIN-Charles. September 15, 1998. A truly special man, loving husband of Shirley, father of Richard and Robert, father-inlaw of Deborah and Marilyn, grandfather of Joshua, Dani and Julia. Funeral services at Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, N.Y., Thursday, September 17, 11:30AM. No flowers. Donations to Multiple Sclerosis Society of Westchester.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RONNER, GLADYS
description: RONNER-Gladys. 9/16/18-2/3/97. Lovingly remembered by all of us on your second birthday. Your very own family

title: It Wasn't Perjury When Clinton Lied
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, FLORENCE
description: MOSS-Florence. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heart-felt sympathies to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: F.C.C. Responds to Its Digital-TV Critics
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission today lashed back at critics in the telecommunications industry who have blamed his agency for the problems plaguing the introduction of digital-television services, scheduled to begin in just six weeks.

title: No Mercy for Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dow Extends Its Climb to a Third Consecutive Session
description: Stock prices rose again yesterday, the first time prices have risen for three straight sessions on Wall Street in more than a month.

title: Alvis to Acquire GKN Armored Car Unit
description: Alvis P.L.C. agreed yesterday to buy GKN P.L.C.'s armored car unit for $:67 million, or $106 million, in shares, creating Britain's largest armored vehicle manufacturer.

title: Viagra Now Legal in EU, but With Some Controls
description: BRUSSELS  The European Commission decided Tuesday to authorize the sale throughout the European Union of the oral drug Viagra to help men achieve erections.

title: Group Urges Strict Rules On Pajamas
description: Over the vehement opposition of the cotton industry, a coalition of consumer and fire prevention organizations is seeking to restore what it says are tougher Federal fire-protection standards for children's sleepwear.

title: ALLERGAN TO CUT 550 JOBS AND CLOSE FIVE PLANTS
description: Allergan Inc., the world's second-largest maker of contact lens care products, said yesterday that it planned to cut 550 jobs, or about 9 percent of its work force, over three years and to close five plants to improve its manufacturing efficiency. Allergan, which had revenue of $1.14 billion in its latest fiscal year, said it would take a pretax charge of about $103 million, or $1.12 a share after taxes, in the third quarter for costs of the restructuring and might take $10 million more in charges in the fourth quarter. The company, based in Irvine, Calif., will close the plants in Brazil, Puerto Rico, California, North Carolina and Massachusetts. Shares of Allergan fell $2.9375, to $56.125.

title: An Economic Taint South America Doesn't Deserve
description: Russia's economic crisis has rattled financial markets around the world. Last week it caused significant fluctuations in Brazil's stock index. But Brazil and other South American countries deserve better than to be tainted by someone else's troubles.

title: Renault Profit Tripled In Its First Half
description: Renault S.A. said yesterday that its first-half profit almost tripled, helped by cost reductions and rising demand for its Megane and Clio models in Europe.

title: Where Louis XIV Might Go for Dessert
description: THE men behind us light cigars as they emerge from the restaurant, congratulating one another upon the superb meal they have just shared. ''What food!'' they say, buoyed by the Williams Selyem zinfandel and the '66 Leoville-Poyferre they brought to drink with their dinner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, FLORENCE FRIEDBERG
description: HARRISON-Florence Friedberg. Age 92. Of Shamokin, PA on Sep 8, 1998. Beloved Mother of Robert H. Harrison, Scarsdale, NY, and cherished grandmother of Zachary & Alexander Harrison of Scarsdale. Beloved sister of Edith Friedberg Mesnick of Princeton, NJ, & loving wife of the late Maurice Harrison. Mrs. Harrison was a 1926 graduate of Bloomsburg State Teachers College and took post graduate courses at New York University and Penn State. She was a teacher in Berwick, PA, Junior High School for many years, became the first assistant librarian of the Shamokin-Coal Township Public Library & was an active member & officer of the Shamokin B'Nai Israel Synagogue Sisterhood and Hadassah. Burial was in B'Nai Israel Cemetery, Shamokin, PA. Contributions in her memory may be made to B'Nai Israel Synagogue, 52 East Independence Street, Shamokin, PA 17872. Shiva will be observed in Scarsdale, New York.

title: Home Run By Olerud Helps Mets Gain Split
description: As if there were not enough tension as their season dwindles to its final games, no day seems complete for the Mets without a late-innings comeback.

title: Liberties; The Wizard Of Is
description: The quintessential Bill Clinton moment can be found in footnote 109 of the Starr report.

title: Out of the Box From East London, Pop With Passion
description: ''All the way from the mystic East of London!'' said the bassist Dr. Das. He was introducing Asian Dub Foundation, a band of young Indians and Pakistanis who are, in fact, from East London, to its first New York audience at the Bowery Ballroom on Monday night.

title: Suspect to Act In Own Defense In Death Case
description: For the first time since capital punishment was reinstated in New York three years ago, a defendant facing the death penalty will be allowed to represent himself in court, a Queens judge ruled yesterday.

title: H.M.O. Experiment Has Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: Afghans Ask U.N. to Mediate With Iranians
description: The Taliban movement, aware of its isolation in the face of an Iranian military threat, asked the United Nations again today to establish a mediation process for defusing tensions with Teheran over the recent killings of Iranian diplomats in Afghanistan.

title: No-Sign Restaurants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFFERTY, MICHAEL
description: RAFFERTY-Michael. New York Bus Service mourns the passing of its President, Michael Rafferty, a man whose wisdom, humility, patience, compassion and fairness knew no bounds. As a leader, mentor and friend, his loss is heartfelt by all who knew him. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his beloved wife, Phyllis & beloved son, Scott in their time of sorrow. May he rest in peace and enjoy life everlasting. Reposing Tuesday and Wednesday 3-5PM and 7-9 PM at Raymond Funeral Home, 5 East Wall Street, Norwalk, Conn. Funeral mass Thursday 11 A.M., St. Matthew's Church, Scribner Avenue, Norwalk, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, the family request contributions be made to St. Jude's Childrens Research Hospital, 332 North Lauderdale Street, Memphis, Tenn. 38105.

title: Mets Accord Could Return Pro Baseball to Brooklyn
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to bring professional baseball back to Brooklyn moved forward yesterday with the announcement that the city had reached an agreement in principle with the New York Mets to move their Pittsfield, Mass., minor league team to a new ball park in Coney Island.

title: Judge Permits State Charges To Apply in Securities Trial
description: A New York State court ruled yesterday in support of the approach taken by Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, in prosecuting securities cases, allowing state insider-trading charges to proceed against four traders.

title: H.M.O. Experiment Has Failed
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasuries Decline Again as World Stock Markets Stabilize
description: United States bonds fell for the second time in three days yesterday as stock markets stabilized around the world, reducing demand for Treasury securities with long-term yields near record lows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, HAROLD
description: SCHECHTER-Harold. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Baby Talk, but Not the Sweet and Cuddly Kind
description: Doug and Susan Harris seem like a typical 40-ish yuppie couple, but they are having a sobering conversation in Susan's hospital room. Their first child has been born, almost three months premature and ''there's been a bleed,'' as one doctor tells them. Chances are the baby will be ''terribly damaged.'' Right now he's on life support.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN an Italian risotto maestro approaches the dish, it is almost always with the intention of producing a risotto that has a thick, creamy consistency. But some time back, I started experimenting with a looser, lighter version that requires less painstaking attention than the traditional approach.

title: Eating Purslane
description: To the Editor:

title: Argentina Seeks $8 Billion In Emergency Loan Reserves
description: In an attempt to ease any future economic tremors from neighboring Brazil, Argentina is negotiating loan packages totaling more than $8 billion with various international lenders to insure Government financing in case of a severe economic slowdown next year.

title: A former television executive enters a deal to provide content for Web-faring women.
description: IN a bow to advertisers marketing products to women, America Online said yesterday that it had agreed to sell three of its women-oriented services to a new venture formed by Geraldine B. Laybourne, the former head of cable television operations for the Walt Disney Company and ABC, who will develop them for the on-line service's new Women's Channel.

title: It Wasn't Perjury When Clinton Lied
description: To the Editor:

title: It Wasn't Perjury When Clinton Lied
description: To the Editor:

title: Dane Clark, Actor, 85, Dies; Starred in World War II Films
description: Dane Clark, the Brooklyn-born actor whose down-to-earth portrayals of tough but appealing soldiers, sailors and pilots in World War II films for Warner Brothers brought him stardom, died on Friday at St. John's Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 85 and lived in Brentwood.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Levers of Power Are Hard to Move

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Crisp Quiche Crusts

title: CTS TO BUY A UNIT FROM MOTOROLA FOR $240 MILLION
description: The CTS Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a wireless components business from Motorola Inc. for about $240 million, increasing CTS's market share in a fast-growing, high-volume business. The Motorola unit is going through a reorganization that will cut as many as 35 percent of its 5,200 workers, close a plant in Costa Rica and leave the unit with sales of $200 million a year. CTS, based in Elkhart, Ind., reported 1997 revenue of $415 million. The companies said a ''significant portion'' of the purchase price would be in the form of deferred payments that are contingent on the unit's operating results. Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., will continue to buy components produced by the unit.

title: THE MARKETS -- Asia's Tigers Lick Wounds And Worry; Long Lean Spell Brings Talk About a Depression
description: As statistics and despair pile up in the countries of Asia, it is becoming clear that the region's recession is deepening, along with the economic and social devastation it brings.

title: British Telecom Cites Pretax Profit From Sale
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C., Britain's largest telephone company, said yesterday that it would record a pretax profit of $:1 billion ($1.68 billion) in the quarter ending on Sept. 30 from the sale of its 20 percent stake in the MCI Communications Corporation to Worldcom Inc. British Telecom expects to receive $7 billion in cash from Worldcom imminently, said Ted Graham, the company's head of external communications. The $:1 billion in pretax profit equates to about $:690 million in net income.

title: Varitek's Home Runs Victimize Yankees
description: Jason Varitek, the young Boston catcher, lashed three bullets at Yankee Stadium last night. Two easily reached the right-field stands; the third traveled only 60 feet 6 inches. It was the third, though, that frightened some more hairs off the almost hairless head of the Yankees' manager, Joe Torre.

title: Union Will Steer Members to Rite Aid in Return for Promise Not to Fight Organizing Drives
description: New York City's largest union will announce an unusual agreement today with the Rite Aid pharmacy chain in which the union's health-care plan will steer tens of millions of dollars in business to Rite Aid and other unionized drug stores.

title: What a Little Cream Can Do
description: TAKE a soft, ripe fruit, and top it with creme anglaise (a thin custard), sabayon (a frothy egg-and-wine mixture) or another sweet sauce. Run the whole thing under the broiler, and you have a four-star dessert. The only problem is, luxurious sauces like these take a fair amount of time and attention to prepare.

title: Giuliani Faces Depositions Over Remarks After Parade
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani may be deposed by lawyers challenging the city's decision to suspend a police officer and two firemen who admitted wearing blackface during a Labor Day parade in Queens.

title: N.B.A. Puts Off Plans; Delayed Season Looms
description: The National Basketball Association indefinitely postponed its training camp for referees and its rookie orientation program yesterday, increasing the possibility that the season will not start on time.

title: Electronic Elections
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corrections
description: A list of this year's Emmy Awards on Tuesday and in some copies on Monday omitted one of those honored for writing for a drama series. Along with Nicholas Wootton and David Milch, Bill Clark received the Emmy for work on an episode of ''N.Y.P.D. Blue.''

title: Accounts
description: * Della Femina/Jeary & Partners, New York, owned by top executives and Omnicom Group, has been awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $13 million: MSG Metro Channel, New York, part of the Rainbow Media Holdings unit of the Cablevision Systems Corp., as first agency of record, and Jos. A. Bank Clothiers, Hampstead, Md., which had previously been handled by GVA Productions, Charlotte, N.C.

title: A Desert Prophet Wins New Disciples
description: ALBERT FREY hates waste. He sees no need for water-hungry lawns or spacious homes. He lives modestly in a 16-by-32-foot house made of low-maintenance materials that he built for himself 34 years ago. His principle in life and architecture, he explained, is to ''do the most with the least.''

title: Excerpts From Clinton's Grand Jury Testimony as Quoted in Starr's Report to Congress
description: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's grand jury testimony as quoted in the report sent to Congress last week by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel. The quotations are grouped by subject matter and are not necessarily in the sequence in which the answers were given in the President's testimony on Aug. 17. At the start of his testimony, the President read a statement outlining his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. At various times in the four-hour session, he refused to elaborate on certain matters and referred back to his statement.

title: Making Books; 40-Year Mark, In 2 Versions
description: This fall two of book publishing's editorial divi have very decisive career occurrences. Michael Korda celebrates his 40th year as an editor at Simon & Schuster and his 30th as editor in chief, and Jason Epstein more or less retires after 40 years at Random House. That is, he will edit only about 10 books a year, which is more than most editors starting out have to do.

title: Calling All Radio Buffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Venator to Close 570 Athletic Footwear Stores
description: Struggling to shed its former role as the discount retailer Woolworth and rebuild itself into a leaner athletic footwear, apparel and sporting goods chain, the Venator Group said yesterday that it would close its 570 Kinney and Footquarters shoe stores and take a $173 million third-quarter charge.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about President Clinton's choice of pastoral counselors referred incompletely to the views of the Rev. Tony Campolo, a Baptist preacher from Pennsylvania. He said that while he could be considered a liberal politically, he was not one theologically. And while he advocates Christian compassion and understanding for gay men and women, Mr. Campolo said, he finds homosexual behavior contrary to Scripture.

title: A Principal Problem
description: Students and teachers are back at their desks. New classrooms are open while older ones are mostly patched and painted. Now it is time to confront another crisis threatening New York City schools -- the one in the principal's office.

title: 2 MUTUAL INSURANCE HOLDING COMPANIES PLAN TO MERGE
description: The Acacia Mutual Holding Company and the Ameritas Mutual Insurance Holding Company said yesterday that they planned to merge to form a more diversified financial services company. The union would be the first between two mutual insurance holding companies. The new concern, the Ameritas Acacia Mutual Holding Company, will have about $6 billion in insurance assets, $21 billion in insurance policies and more than $750 million in revenue. It will also have about $11 billion in assets under management, mostly in mutual funds. Acacia is based in Bethesda, Md., and Ameritas in Lincoln, Neb.

title: INSIDE
description: Supplements Tied to Illness

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Long-Term Credit Bank Denies End to Alliance
description: Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd., one of Japan's 19 largest banks, denied a report yesterday that it planned to dissolve its alliance with UBS A.G. of Switzerland. The bank, whose fate hangs on a Government bailout and a merger with Sumitomo Trust and Banking Ltd., is negotiating with UBS and Sumitomo Trust about its future.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOVONI, KATHERINE RUDDEN.
description: GOVONI-Katherine Rudden. Of Rowayton, CT., on September 14, 1998. Wife of Stephen J. Govoni. Mother of Neil and Claire Govoni. Sister of Jane Rudden. Daughter of Mary Brady Rudden. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St Johns R.C. Church of Noroton, CT. on Friday, September 18, 1998 at 10:30AM. Interment Spring Grove Cemetery, Darien, CT. Friends may call Edward Lawrence Funeral Home, 2119 Post Road, Darien, CT on Thursday from 2-4 and from 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers memorials may be made to: Five Mile River Nursery School, 5 Pennoyer Street, Rowayton, CT 06853.

title: City Board Members Fault St. Barnabas Hospital Over Prison Care
description: Members of New York City's Board of Correction accused St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx yesterday of denying prisoners basic medical services since it took over a contract to provide health care in city jails in January. The hospital won the $342 million three-year contract, the largest prison health care contract in the country, by promising to reduce costs through managed care.

title: G.M. to Kill 2 Car Models
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would stop building the Buick Riviera and the Oldsmobile 88 cars this fall as part of an effort to consolidate its product lines and cut costs. While the consolidation unfolds, G.M.'s Orion Township assembly plant will operate on one shift for about six months, during which about half its 3,700 workers will be temporarily idled. The consolidation reflects G.M.'s decision to build its large front-wheel-drive cars off just one ''platform'' of powertrain and chassis components, instead of two. G.M., which this summer was hit by two crippling union strikes over productivity and job security issues, is the highest-cost auto maker in the nation and is taking steps to improve.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDHUSH, DR. ALVIN A.
description: GOLDHUSH-Dr. Alvin A. On September 16, 1998 after a long illness at the age of 79 of Nassau Pt., Cutchogue, formerly of Bayshore. Beloved husband of the late Viola Raybin Goldhush, MD. Devoted father of Susan Goldhush and Karen and Hank Kranichfeld. Loving grandfather of Bram, Oliver and Andrew; dear brother of the late Dr. Herbert Goldhush. He will live in our hearts forever. His gentle and knowing spirit, a strength to those who loved him. Reposing at the William F. Coster Funeral Home, Route 25, Cutchogue, New York, today from 5PM to 7PM. Funeral service, Friday, 11AM at Wellwood Cemetery. Memorials may be sent to East End Hospice, P.O. Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, New York 11978.

title: The Choices; Finding the Service Right for You
description: At first glance, the on-line personalized services might all look the same, but don't be fooled by the hypertext. They're not.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS TO BUY TELEDATA OF ISRAEL
description: The communications-systems maker ADC Telecommunications Inc. has agreed to acquire Teledata Communications Ltd., an Israeli telephone-network product company, for $15.75 a share, or a total of $200 million. Shares of Teledata rose $1 each, to $14.375, in Nasdaq trading, where shares of ADC gained $2, to $25.875. ADC, based in Minneapolis, makes equipment for telephone, cable television, Internet, wireless and private networks. Teledata supplies midsize digital loop carrier systems, enabling phone companies to serve greater numbers of subscribers with existing infrastructure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINEZ, JUANA
description: MARTINEZ-Juana. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, deeply mourn the passing of Juana Martinez, the devoted wife of our esteemed client and friend of many years, Eugene Martinez, Sr. Our heartfelt condolences to him, to his son, Eugene Jr, his daughter Juana Lynn, and to the entire family. Lipsky, Goodkin and Company, PC.

title: Injury Could Turn the Jets' Foley Into a Spectator
description: Glenn Foley, whose durability was an issue when Bill Parcells anointed him the Jets' starting quarterback, is suffering from a painful rib injury and has only a 50-50 chance to play Sunday against the Colts.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Saving Impatiens

title: In Toronto, Films Lounging on the Dark Side of Humanity
description: Drugs. Violence. Pedophilia. Dysfunctional families. And murder. Plenty of murder.

title: Two Hurt in Village When Shots Fired
description: Two men were wounded when shots were fired in the West Village last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERRELL, RICHARD
description: MERRELL-Richard. Actor, television and film writer and designer, died Sunday, September 13 at his home in Heritage Village, Southbury, CT. The cause of death was heart failure. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, Jan Miner, and two sisters, Sister Jeanne Merrell and Audrey Shepard. No services are planned at the request of the deceased. In lieu of flowers it was his wish and that of Jan Miner that those who choose make a contribution to Project ALS (Lou Gehrig's Disease), 511 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 341, New York, New York 10011.

title: Bayer Expected to Divest Itself of Sluggish Imaging Business
description: Bayer A.G., the big German chemical company, is expected to announce today that it will divest itself of Agfa-Gevaert, its imaging unit. Analysts expect it will spin Agfa off to Bayer shareholders.

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; Plea-Bargain Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesian Auto Maker Eliminates 25,000 Jobs
description: Astra International, Indonesia's biggest car maker, said yesterday that it had reduced its work force by 20 percent, or 25,000 workers, in the last several months to reduce costs. The cuts, which began last year, have come as Indonesia's first recession in 30 years has battered Astra's ability to repay $2 billion in debt.

title: Putting Less-Than-Super Computers on Pi's Trail
description: A 17-year-old Canadian college student has figured out pi -- the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter -- to the five-trillionth binary digit, and he did so without the help of a supercomputer. The student, Colin Percival at Simon Fraser University in Burnaby, British Columbia, beat the old record of one trillion digits, set last year, with the help of 25 people he found through the Internet who donated the use of their computers to complete the calculations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMINSKY, LOUIS C.C.
description: RASMINSKY-Louis C.C. Former Governor of the Bank of Canada. On September 15, 1998, lucidly and serenely in his 91st year at home in Ottawa, surrounded by the love of his children Michael and Lola, his daughter-in-law Judy, his grandchildren Sonya, Jonathan, Jeremy and Abigail, his special friend Jerry Grey and his longtime helper and friend Vicenta Pardo. Funeral is at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 1771 Cuba Avenue, Ottawa, Ontario on Thursday, September 17 at 2 PM.

title: Recount in Schumer's Old District to Wait a Week
description: The Board of Elections said yesterday that it would be at least a week before it begins recounting the ballots to certify the results of the close race in Tuesday's Democratic primary for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Fortis Ends Plans to Buy Stake in Malaysian Bank
description: Fortis, the third-biggest financial services company in the Benelux region, has abandoned plans to buy a 15 percent stake in AMMB Holdings of Malaysia, which owns Malaysia's seventh-largest banking company, dashing AMMB's hopes of raising $190 million in much-needed capital.

title: STOCK SLUMPS ON SALES OUTLOOK FOR THIRD QUARTER
description: Shares of the Gillette Company fell 10 percent yesterday as the company, the razor blade maker, said its third-quarter sales would be lower than a year earlier because of the economic problems in Asia and Latin America. Shares of Gillette dropped $4.8125, to $40.1875, in trading of almost 14.4 million shares. It was the stock's biggest one-day drop in 11 years. Gillette gets a third of its revenue outside the United States and Western Europe from sales of its razors, Duracell batteries, Papermate pens and other products. Third-quarter earnings will probably be lower than expected as international demand drops and falling currencies generate fewer dollars from local sales.

title: On-Line Place to Polish A College-Bound Image
description: In an interview for admission to college, it is best to begin by saying to the alumni representative:

title: Clinton's Front Line Turns Its Guns to the Rear
description: Mark Mellman, a leading Democratic pollster, has made the rounds on Capitol Hill in recent days, urging his clients not to stray from talking about issues and assuring them that, at least for now, the White House scandal is not likely to damage their own prospects in November. But they won't listen.

title: When Warmth Rises Above Hatred
description: The Lyons Dance Biennial, arguably Europe's most important dance festival, has started with a political bang and a hot-tempered debate on multiculturalism.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGSAM, EUGENE A.
description: LANGSAM-Eugene A. Adored and devoted husband to Myra. Cherished and loving father to his children, Nathania and Jennifer and David Kopelman. A compassionate and loyal man, ''Gene'' was a mentor to his family and friends. He touched the lives of all those who knew him. The family thanks all of our friends for their support during this very difficult time. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30 P.M., Friday.

title: A Piano Sounds Grand With a Digital Conductor
description: The Baldwin Piano and Organ Company is making it awfully easy to play a grand piano. You need not take piano lessons -- or even be in the same room as the piano -- but it may help to know how to use a disk drive.

title: U.S. and Iran, in Further Thaw, Will Join in U.N. Afghan Talks
description: The United States and Iran are facing the prospect of their highest-level diplomatic contact in nearly 20 years, with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright expected to attend a meeting at the United Nations next week that is likely to include her Iranian counterpart, Western diplomats said today.

title: Yankees, Beaten Again, Leave Torre Fuming
description: Manager Joe Torre usually contains his angry thoughts and waits a day before unleashing them in a more digestible form. But he did not bother waiting tonight, after fuming through the loss to the Tampa Bay Devil Rays.

title: N.F.L.: NOTEBOOK
description: WASHINGTON

title: Berenice Lipson-Gruzen, Concert Pianist, 73
description: Berenice Lipson-Gruzen, a pianist with a long international career, died on Sept. 3 in Bad Wiessee, Germany. She was 73 and lived in New York.

title: Film Set Magic: Childhood Revisited
description: ELECTRIC cables, television monitors, lighting and sound paraphernalia crowded the front hallway of the two-story saltbox house. Gingerly stepping over the wires, I crossed the foyer -- and the family home of my imagination came alive.

title: Weight Problem Is the Reason Wheatley Remains Sidelined for Giants
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel introduced a new twist to the tangled Tyrone Wheatley saga today, indicating that running back Wheatley didn't play last week because he was over a designated playing weight the team has set for him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, JEAN CONNOLLY.
description: YOUNG-Jean Connolly. Died at home on Sept. 15, 1998, surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of Joseph for fifty years. Loving mother to Megan Zwerner, Joseph Jr, Peter & Steven Young. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Emily, Anne, Blake, Colleen and Hunter. A caring, loving aunt. A kind hearted, helpful friend to many. A special woman, full of grace, spirit and a special quality for listening. Her compassionate words and deeds will always be remembered. Those of us who had the privilege of knowing and loving her understand we were blessed. Visiting hours Friday, September 18th, 1998, 2-4:30 and 7-9 P.M., at Chapey Funeral Home, West Islip, New York. a Memorial Service will be held 10:00 A.M., Saturday, September 19, 1998 at St. Patricks's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, N.Y. Contributions in her memory can be made to Good Samaritan Hospice, 655 Deer Park Avenue, Babylon, New York.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Her time had come and gone. But nobody I know, including myself, ever has the realistic view of what's happening when you're in the center of a hurricane.''

title: White House Plans H.M.O.-Medicare Rules
description: Taking unilateral action while Congress squabbles over legislation, President Clinton will announce new consumer protections on Thursday for more than 15 million Medicaid patients in health maintenance organizations.

title: U.S. Eases Encryption Software Export Bans
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it was relaxing export controls for encryption software used by several industries, including certain medical, insurance and on-line commerce companies.

title: Hyde Acknowledges 'Indiscretion' Following Report of an Affair
description: Republicans on Capitol Hill reacted with fury this evening after a political magazine on the Internet disclosed that Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who heads the committee that will review evidence against President Clinton, had an affair three decades ago with a married woman.

title: Risk of Lead to Infants
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMS, WILLIAM B.
description: ABRAMS-William B. The Editors and Staff of The Merck Manual of Geriatrics mourn the death of our great colleague and friend, William B. Abrams. The world is a better place for all he gave it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, HELEN ELIZABETH (TUCK).
description: SMITH-Helen Elizabeth (Tuck). Beloved wife of Donald A. Smith for 51 years. Devoted mother of Leslie E. Smith and grandmother to Haley Elizabeth and Gillian Ann Brocksmith. Also survived by her sister Claudia and brothers Scott, Walter and Emerson. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Yale School of Nursing Alumnae Fund (payable to Yale University), P.O. Box 1890, New Haven, CT 06508.

title: Power To the Flower
description: The renaissance of the dingbat, that flower-power symbol resembling an asterisk, is in full swing. It surfaced in the 1996 comeback issue of House & Garden, not far from Isaac Mizrahi's ear as he cavorted with a Miele vacuum cleaner, but was quickly identified with Wallpaper, the home magazine du jour. This month, Travel & Leisure took a spin with the ''Zaps'' dingbat (named for Herman Zaps). ''It's basically a 1960's emblem,'' said Dan Josephs, who designed the cover. ''We knew that Wallpaper had their own version with squared-off tips. These things are always going around. So what?'' For design aficionados, ''The Sixties,'' by Lesley Jackson (Phaidon, $59.95, due in October), records the inimitable look of the generation that inhaled -- paper furniture, inflatable houses, pop-top vests and, yes, the dingbat.

title: Aargh! You, Too, Can Play the Role of a Pro Wrestler
description: PROFESSIONAL wrestling is real -- if you play the video game version.

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: CLINTON PROPOSAL TO AID ECONOMIES MEETS OBSTACLES
description: President Clinton's push to quell the global financial turmoil ran into several obstacles today as Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, testified that the world's big economies had no plans for a coordinated reduction in interest rates.

title: You Can Surf Together But Who Gets to Drive?
description: Who's ready for a browser built for two?

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; Consider the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: CIRCON SHARES PLUNGE AS U.S. SURGICAL DROPS OFFER
description: The stock of the Circon Corporation fell 25 percent yesterday after the United States Surgical Corporation ended its two-year hostile takeover effort. U.S. Surgical said it had ended its $221 million offer, which expired Tuesday, because of its own proposed purchase by Tyco International Ltd. and because of Circon's recent announcement that it was looking for a friendly buyer. Shares of Circon, which is based in Santa Barbara, Calif., were down $3.375, to $9.875. Shares of U.S. Surgical slipped 6.25 cents, to $42.4375. U.S. Surgical, of Norwalk, Conn., sought to acquire Circon so it could compete better with Johnson & Johnson in the market for minimally invasive operating room gear.

title: Pet Sites to Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Holyfield Proves a Draw In a Hometown Defense
description: Evander Holyfield vaguely remembers when Muhammad Ali fought Jerry Quarry here at the Municipal Auditorium back in 1970. It was Ali's first bout after he was banned from boxing for refusing to join the military. Holyfield was 8 years old and had not yet become immersed in boxing.

title: High Court Razed Church-State Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: A Truly Special Senator
description: Alfonse D'Amato made his great leap from a well-deserved obscurity in 1980 when he mounted an improbable primary challenge against the highly regarded Republican Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPPAS, LUCY G.
description: PAPPAS-Lucy G. September 15th. Beloved wife of the late George J. Pappas. Loving mother of Christo and John Pappas. Friends may call Thursday, September 17, 1998 2-5 & 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st St. Funeral Friday, September 18 at 10:30 A.M, at Frank E. Campbell.

title: Computer Buyers' Ranks Keep Getting Broader
description: A new survey indicates that 1999 will bring a marked shift in who first-time home computer buyers will be. The study, by Forrester Research of Cambridge, Mass., found that low-income households, defined as those earning less than $35,000 a year, would become the leading source of first-time home computer purchasers.

title: T.W.A. Chairman Critical of 'Anti-Competitive' Airline Alliances
description: Sounding notes more often uttered by the airline industry's harshest critics, Gerald L. Gitner, the chairman and chief executive of Trans World Airlines, denounced proposals by the country's six largest carriers to pair off into three alliances as ''anti-competitive schemes'' that the Government should block.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Mix and Match? Close Enough
description: If fabrics were actresses, Lee Jofa's heavy cotton ''Vasi Cinesi,'' above, would be one of those slightly dotty grandes dames who flourish in Italian villas. Lee Jofa, a 175-year-old fabric house that usually sticks slavishly to historic sources, took an inspired leap in offsetting a damask-style background evocative of Italian frescoed walls with Ming vases adapted from an 18th-century English needlepoint pattern. Part of the Lyton Cay Collection, ''Vasi Cinesi'' costs $196 a yard. Information: (800) 453-3563.

title: Tequisquiapan Journal; Across the Land, Down the Years, 'Viva Mexico!'
description: Jose Antonio Mejia, who at 27 may be Mexico's youngest mayor and is still unaccustomed to public speaking, was feeling panic Tuesday night as the time drew near for him to preside over his first Independence Day celebration.

title: Alexander Wins Title in a Playoff
description: Carl Alexander, the assistant at Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y., captured the $70,000 Izod Club/Cadillac Met PGA Championship yesterday at Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y., in the first hole of a playoff against Heath Wassem, the assistant at Atlantic Golf Club in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Host Marriott Services Outlook
description: The Host Marriott Services Corporation said today that its third-quarter and full-year earnings will be disappointing, as fewer travelers from Asia and the pilots' strike at Northwest Airlines hurt its airport duty-free retail business.

title: Choreographing the Dance of Traffic Lights
description: IN commuter heaven, all traffic lights would magically switch to green for approaching drivers, forming strings of fiery green balls that went on for miles. Pedestrians in paradise would encounter ''Walk'' signs permanently aglow, and drivers would wait patiently as the walkers dawdled the day away crossing the street.

title: Universal Serial Bus Is Finally Picking Up Some Passengers
description: LOOK behind the back of that sleek new PC, and you'll find a rat's nest of cords, cables and wires. The mess is more than the computer's equivalent of a bad hair day -- it can make your PC darned hard to work with. Devices like your mouse, keyboard, monitor, speakers, printer and modem all plug into a bevy of connectors on the back of your PC.

title: Year of the Woman in Washington State
description: Two women will square off as major-party nominees for the United States Senate for just the third time in the nation's history, after a primary here in which Linda Smith, a conservative Republican Congresswoman, earned the right to challenge the Democratic incumbent, Patty Murray.

title: Sale Might Let Steinbrenner Run 3 Teams, Officials Say
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation, which owns the New York Knicks and the Rangers, has renewed its effort to buy the New York Yankees, sweetening the proposal by offering the Yankees' owner, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, a hand in running all three teams should he sell his ball club, associates of Mr. Steinbrenner say.

title: Now, Continuing Education for Lawyers
description: Seeking to keep lawyers up to date with a changing legal landscape and improve the public's perception of lawyers, the state's chief judges said yesterday that lawyers who practice in New York State would have to begin taking regular continuing-education courses.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANKBOSTON CORP. named Kevin Bryant European general manager.

title: In Clash With Mayor, Council Panel Backs Weekly Trash Recycling Pickups
description: As New York City moves toward closing the vast Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, a City Council committee passed a bill yesterday to mandate weekly recycling pickups, setting up a new confrontation with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on the issue.

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; A Political Process
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Beware Primakov
description: The man the Russian Parliament forced President Yeltsin to name Prime Minister is a former K.G.B. agent, a friend of dictators in Iraq and Serbia, and an enemy of the West.

title: There's Plenty of Room in the Tent For Those Who Are Tired of Canvas
description: From North African Bedouin tents to the Millennium Dome now under construction in Greenwich, England, tent architecture appeals because it embodies both ancient archetypes and future visions in one graceful sweep. When tensile architecture, with its fabric-inspired structures, emerged as a star in 1970's avant-garde design, the focus was on spanning great distances; now it's on the range and variety of materials that lend themselves to tensile design. ''Tensions in Architecture,'' an exhibit that opened yesterday, goes far beyond canvas awnings and polyester pup tents to explore the materials now in use, from Teflon glass, a tough, noncombustible material that came out of the space program, to the woven Teflon, as pliant as silk, in the photosensitive umbrella roof at the Prophet's Holy Mosque in Medina, Saudi Arabia, left. At Material Connexion, 4 Columbus Circle, through Jan. 5.

title: Republicans See Chance To Push Their Agenda
description: Eager to appear focused on the people's business and not just on President Clinton's, Republicans are pushing ahead with their agenda of economic and social issues in Congress. Today's message, laid out by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, was that projections of a big Federal budget surplus justified a tax cut.

title: AMBER REJECTS BID FROM ALBERTA AND EXPLORES OPTIONS
description: Amber Energy Inc., a Canadian oil producer, yesterday rejected the offer from the Alberta Energy Company of $750 million (Canadian), or $499 million (United States), and established a board committee to seek alternatives. The bid from Alberta Energy, which was made on Tuesday, included the assumption of $304 million (Canadian) in Amber debt. Alberta Energy, based in Calgary, made its offer less than a week after Amber's shares plunged on the news that Amber would not meet its oil production forecast. The bid, equal to $7 a share in cash, was 54 percent higher than the closing price of Amber's shares on Monday, but it was roughly a quarter of the 52-week high of $27.25. Amber's shares rose 5 cents yesterday, to $7.20, in Toronto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASS, MAY
description: MASS-May. Temple Emanu-el of Lynbrook mourns the death of our beloved Past President and extends our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Services at Temple Emanu-el of Lynbrook, 11AM Friday. Stuart Geller, Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein, Rabbi Emeritus Barbara Stern, President Rica Julie Timman, Cantor

title: Panel Recommends Approval of Drug for Rheumatoid Arthritis
description: A Government advisory panel yesterday recommended approval of the first drug created by genetic engineering to treat rheumatoid arthritis, opening a path to treating a disease for which there have been virtually no new medicines developed in years.

title: Mother Indicted in Death Of Son Who Took Heroin
description: A Gloucester County grand jury has indicted a Washington Township woman on aggravated manslaughter charges in the heroin overdose of her 13-year-old son, the County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Serbs in Bosnia Appear to Shun Favorite of U.S.
description: A key player in American strategy in Bosnia, the Bosnian Serb leader Biljana Plavsic, appears to have been voted out of office in the elections last weekend, according to international officials who are monitoring preliminary results.

title: For Ferraro, Early Promise, Lopsided Loss
description: ''Ger-RY! Ger-RY! Ger-RY!''

title: A Visual Artist Gives Form to Free Speech
description: IT'S not quite what he had in mind when he chose to become an artist, but Bradley McCallum insists he didn't mind measuring the sidewalks of Malcolm X Boulevard a few weeks ago.

title: First Stop: The Tutorial
description: WINDOWS 98 TUTORIAL

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., the largest natural-gas shipper in the United States, has agreed to buy a gasoline and diesel fuel terminal in Georgia from Phillips Petroleum Co., Bartlesville, Okla., for an undisclosed amount.

title: Work Ethic A Weapon For Pepper In Solheim
description: Even as a child, Dottie Pepper was a perfectionist. When Pepper was in kindergarten, her parents received a note from the teacher that said Pepper took herself too seriously. When Pepper started to play golf, she practiced so much that unless her parents made her leave the driving range, Pepper would often hit balls until her hands blistered.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors Shrug Off Talk of Global Rate Cut
description: American investors shrugged off yesterday's suggestion that no global interest rate cut was immediately in store to help the world's weak economies.

title: Whitman Proposes $100 Million Tax Rebate
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman embraced a host of recommendations today that she said would eventually reduce local property taxes by $1.2 billion, and then went on to propose an immediate rebate of $100 million in surplus state tax revenue to property owners.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER DROPS. Prices fell 1.2 percent on diminished hope for lower borrowing costs in the home building industry, the biggest user of copper. The December contract fell 0.95 cent a pound, to 76.15 cents.

title: Calling All Radio Buffs
description: To the Editor:

title: King Wants Tyson to Fight
description: The promoter Don King said that he believes the former heavyweight champion Mike Tyson should have his license reinstated by the Nevada State Athletic Commission, but he refused to say why.

title: After Major Study, Mysterious Force in Space Remains Mystery
description: For 19 years space scientists, astronomers and physicists have been scratching their heads for an explanation of a mysterious force that seems to be pulling spacecraft in the direction of the Sun. A team of investigators has now announced that after examining and ruling out most of the possibilities they could think of, the mystery remains.

title: Cutting Loose With Colors and Grace
description: By now, anyone who is at all interested in fashion surely knows that the New York shows for spring 1999 have splintered into Part 1, being held this week, and Part 2, scheduled for early November. The season has become like a fractured television miniseries whose final chapters run six weeks after the early ones, leaving the audience stumped to remember where they left off.

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; 'Dissing' the System
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILLETTE, NOETH, B.
description: GILLETTE-Noeth, B. 1925-1993. Happy Birthday Poppa. You taught me to enjoy life. I wish you were here to share it with me. Love, Lisa.

title: Pet Sites to Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting on the Web: Not Around the Corner, but on the Horizon
description: MARC STRASSMAN first began thinking about Internet voting in 1995. Mr. Strassman, a 50-year-old entrepreneur, political activist and occasional Congressional candidate, was in the process of starting a business, and he wanted to file a legal notice on line. He soon discovered that an Internet posting didn't satisfy the legal requirement, but the episode got him thinking about the role of the Internet in democracy.

title: Computer Use at Home Looks a Lot Like Work
description: With rich audio, video and multimedia capabilities, the home computer is marketed as a veritable home entertainment center. But a new survey says it is used more often for banal tasks like word processing than for saving the galaxy in colorful video games or setting up elaborate databases to keep track of expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, CARL LOEB.
description: KEMPNER-Carl Loeb. Of White Plains, New York on Sept. 15th, 1998. Husband of Doris Coleman Kempner. Son of Margaret Loeb Kempner & the late Alan Horace Kempner. Father of Kathryn Kempner Poteat, Margaret Adeline Kempner, Michael Coleman Kempner, & Carl Loeb Kempner, Jr. Father-in-law of Dr. George Howard Poteat. Brother of Alan Horace Kempner, Jr. and Thomas Lenox Kempner. Grandfather of Michael Kempner Poteat, Nicole Kathryn Poteat & Jason Kempner. Funeral service on Friday 12 noon at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Westchester Ave., Rye, N.Y. Interment is in Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers contributions to Purchase College Foundation Scholarship Fund, Purchase, New York 10577 or Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., New York 10021. The family will receive friends at their home on Thursday evening after 8 P.M. and Friday, 3-5 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: A calendar entry in the Westchester section on Sunday about a screening of the 1953 film ''Titanic'' on Saturday at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College was outdated. The showing has been canceled.

title: Swissair Jet Was Holding Museum Gem
description: At least one of the more than 200 diamond-encrusted cultural objects that were displayed at the American Museum of Natural History in New York until the end of last month was aboard the Swissair jet that crashed into the Atlantic near here on Sept. 2.

title: The Real Anne Frank
description: To the Editor:

title: Principals Veto Trading Tenure For Higher Pay
description: The Giuliani administration has offered a record raise of more than 30 percent over five years to New York City's public school principals -- in exchange for giving up their right to lifetime tenure and for working a 12-month year. Negotiators for the principals have rejected it.

title: Modern's Suave New Manner
description: DESIGN is serious. Decoration is superficial. Ask them.

title: Gee, It's Got Soup Cans? That Figures
description: Andy Warhol goes to hell. As a travelogue, you have to admit, it has potential: art's ultimate voyeur roaming through corridors of fire with his glazed stare and faux-naif demeanor, bumping into more celebrities than even he could have dreamed of and making observations like, ''Gee, I didn't know that Hitler was so short.''

title: Albert Lifts Ratings
description: For at least two nights, the MSG Network has been proven correct that hiring Marv Albert to host the revamped MSG SportsDesk would increase ratings.

title: Rewarding North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Save Worst For Last
description: Two penalty kicks and an ejection before the game was 14 minutes old decided the fate of the MetroStars in tonight's regular-season finale at Giants Stadium. Their sixth straight loss, by 5-0 to D.C. United, was their worst at Giants Stadium and established the longest losing streak in their brief history.

title: Instant Gratification For the Impulse Gambler
description: ONE night, while buying a quart of milk at a convenience store deep in the Catskills, I found myself standing in front of a glass display case holding perhaps 20 neat stacks of instant lottery tickets. Maybe it was the mountain air, or maybe it was the magnitude of the display, but suddenly I found these butterfly-bright slips of cardboard exotic and intriguing.

title: Pet Sites to Love
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Right Thing,' Clinton Says, Is for Him to Stay in Office
description: President Clinton today firmly defended his ability and intention to lead, saying it was ''the right thing'' for him to remain in office despite the furor over his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: U.S. Agency Faults Study On Exports Of Computers
description: When the Clinton Administration relaxed export controls on high-performance computers in 1996, it relied on a flawed report that did not study the national security implications and concluded with scant data that the computers were already easily available around the world, Government auditors said today.

title: Net Is Not Enough: Books on Starr Report, Too
description: BY midafternoon last Friday, modems and and laser printers were laboring mightily, dishing out the report by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, as quickly as the Web-using public could devour it.

title: $44 Million For Expanding Transit Service
description: With the boom in subway and bus ridership showing no signs of abating, transit officials said yesterday that they planned to spend $44 million to expand service over the course of 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LANE, SHIRLEY
description: LANE-Shirley. Sept. 17, 1997 We love you madly.

title: NBC Planning To Cut Jobs Across Board
description: NBC is planning to announce cutbacks today that will result in about 200 to 300 layoffs across all divisions of the network.

title: Relief Falls Short After Storms Ravage Mexican Villages
description: A fetid sand bank covers the place were 50 thatched-roof huts stood until the Pedregal River, swollen with rainfall, churned down from the mountains to bury them.

title: German Trade Surplus Reaches 10-Year High
description: Germany's trade surplus unexpectedly widened to a 10-year high of 14.2 billion marks, or $8.41 billion, in July amid a pickup in European demand and slowing Asian imports, the Government said yesterday. In the first seven months of the year, the surplus totaled 559.1 billion marks, or $331 billion, up 10.9 percent from the period a year earlier.

title: Coronado's Quest Hopes to Keep His Elders at a Distance
description: In the 44 years that the Woodward Stakes has been run at Belmont Park, only 11 winners have been 3 years old. But Shug McGaughey, who defeated older horses in the Woodward twice in the last decade with the 3-year-old stars Polish Navy and Easy Goer, thinks he has another good chance on Saturday with Coronado's Quest, a reformed head case who will face three of the best senior horses in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANK, HERBERT D.
description: BANK-Herbert D., 86. Of Cranbury, NJ died September 15, 1998. A graduate of St. John's College School of Pharmacy, he owned & operated Bank's Pharmacy in Brooklyn until 1970.
