He was a consultant to the Equitable Life Assurance Company & President of the Brooklyn Consolidated Retail Pharmacists, the NY City Pharmacy Council & Hadassah Associates of Brooklyn. He was Brooklyn Community Pharmacist of the Year in 1962. After retiring from retail pharmacy, Mr. Bank was a staff pharmacist for Blue CrossBlue Shield of New York, and Assistant to the Executive Secretary of the Pharmaceutical Society of the State of New York. He is survived by his wife, Georgia Levin Bank, daughters Cynthia Bank Schreihofer and Elin Bank Greenberg, sons in law Alan Schreihofer and Martin Greenberg, 5 grandchildren & 4 great grandchildren. Funeral Friday 11:00 am in Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Metro Business; Kenar Files for Chapter 11
description: Kenar Enterprises Ltd., the maker of Kenar women's clothing, is seeking Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after running out of cash to pay creditors.

title: Spain's Best Enter
description: Isaac Viciosa and Fermin Cacho, Spain's best milers, have entered the Donald J. Trump Fifth Avenue Mile Sept. 26. This will be the 18th annual running of the race, which has moved two blocks south, starting at 80th Street and ending at 60th Street.

title: Helping a Dissonant Psyche Sing
description: PROZAC DIARY

title: REPUBLICANS NEAR ACCORD ON RELEASE OF CLINTON TAPES
description: House Republicans closed ranks today and pushed closer toward releasing a videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony about his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, despite Democratic objections and private warnings from some lawmakers in their own party that the release of more sexually explicit material could backfire politically.

title: BAXTER TO TAKE CHARGES AND DISCONTINUE A PRODUCT
description: Baxter International Inc., the world's No. 2 medical technology company, said yesterday that it would take third-quarter charges of $293 million, mainly to settle breast-implant lawsuits, and would end production of the blood substitute Hemassist. It said it would continue to develop an experimental blood substitute acquired with its $188 million purchase of Somatogen Inc. in May. Baxter will take a $178 million charge for lawsuits, a $40 million charge to end joint ventures and a $75 million charge to end production of Hemassist. It will cut about 100 employees as it closes Hemassist operations. Shares of Baxter, based in Deerfield, Ill., rose 12.5 cents, to $60.9375.

title: Singapore's Senior Minister Angers Malaysians With First of 2 Volumes : Lee Kuan Yew's Controversial Memoirs
description: SINGAPORE  Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's senior minister, marked his 75th birthday on Wednesday with the launch of memoirs that have caused fresh tension in relations with Malaysia even before they appeared on sale in bookstores.

title: Latest Script: Hundley And Piazza Both Do It
description: After playing three games of ''can you top this?'' homer after homer, rally after rally -- the Mets tonight won the most dramatic game of their series against the Houston Astros.

title: Metro Matters; Are Voters Being Sexist Or Just Being Choosy?
description: IS it fair to bid farewell to Geraldine A. Ferraro and Betsy McCaughey Ross with the same fond adieu?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: U.N. Team Lays Most Blame in Algeria on Islamic 'Terrorists'
description: A panel of political leaders who visited Algeria to study the violence that has killed tens of thousands of people blamed terrorists today for most of the deaths and said the Algerian Government deserved the world's sympathy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. The Directors, Officers and Employees of Kahn Brothers & Co., Inc. note with deep sadness the passing of Stanley Klein, Senior Partner of Brauner Baron Rosenzweig & Klein. Stanley was a practical, vibrant and brilliant attorney whose wise counsel guided many. Our heartfelt condolences to his family and partners. Kahn Brothers & Co., Inc.

title: A Second Look at AOL, the Refurbished Ellis Island of the Net
description: EVERY society has its own class system, and so it is with the Internet. So, of course, the people who were first on line -- the early settlers who can reminisce about the good old days of the Arpanet -- get the most points for snob appeal. They are the on-line equivalent of those who claim that their ancestors were on the Mayflower.

title: So-sa! So-sa! Cub's Grand Slam Ties McGwire at 63
description: Right fielder Sammy Sosa of the Chicago Cubs was relaxed enough to hit his 63d home run tonight. It was simply a matter of when.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROBERT
description: SCHWARTZ-Robert. Beloved husband of Rosaline. Devoted father of Stuart and Felice and son-in-law Marty. Loving grandfather. Graveside services at New Montifore, Pinelawn, L.I., Friday 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHTER, VIVIAN
description: PACHTER-Vivian. Died Sept. 15, 1998. Beloved wife of Bernard. Mother of Lisa and David. Grandmother of Allison and Lindsey, & friend to many. Service Thursday, Sept. 17, 12 Noon, Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be sent to East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, N.Y. 11978.

title: Alcatel and Ascend May Form Alliance
description: Alcatel of France, one of the world's largest makers of communications equipment, plans to announce today a strategic partnership with Ascend Communications Inc., a leading maker of advanced data networking gear, according to executives close to the companies.

title: Robert Bierstedt, 85, Sociologist Interested in Constitutional Law
description: Robert Bierstedt, an author and emeritus professor of sociology at the University of Virginia, died on Sept. 8 in Martha Jefferson Hospital in Charlottesville, Va. He was 85 and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Gilbert and Sullivan: Information Galore
description: FOR many theater lovers, personal participation in show business reaches its pinnacle in a Gilbert and Sullivan operetta. Once bitten, one is likely to be forever entranced by the Victorian wit, period costumes and certainty that the cast will be happily paired off by the final curtain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDEY, HELEN WINTHROP (KELLOGG), M.D.
description: EDEY-Helen Winthrop (Kellogg), M.D., 86, of Chilmark, MA., and New York City, widow of Maitland Armstrong Edey. September 15. Pioneer in issues of international population and family planning, founding board member of the Association for Voluntary Sterilization, later AVSC, International. Born in New York, she received her B.A. from Vassar College in 1934, and later her M.D. from New York University, while the mother of four children. She practiced psychiatry for many years before turning her incredible mind and great energy toward civic activitism and international affairs. Her many wide-ranging interests included arms control, setting up health clinics in underdeveloped countries, ornithology and travel. She is survived by her children, Maitland Edey Jr of West Tisbury, MA., Winthrop (Kelly) Edey of New York, Beatrice Phear, of Cambridge MA., and Marion Edey, of Silver Spring, MD, her son-in-law, Patrick Phear, her daughter-in-law Fausta Edey, thirteen grandchildren and four great grandchildren - all of whom she loved and who loved her.

title: Sports of The Times; Cardinals Have Other Story Lines
description: HE'S a rookie, has been in the major leagues for all of one week, and already he has been booed vigorously. When he walked into the interview room after a pair of good games Tuesday night, virtually everyone in the crowd of reporters not only walked out, but also rushed out. ''I'll have no one to talk to,'' he said, fanned by the breeze of the swiftly departing.

title: When Things Go Wrong
description: WINDOWS 98 RESOURCE KIT

title: 7 Arrested After Melee That Left 5 Officers Hurt
description: Five police officers were injured and at least seven people were arrested last night following a melee that broke out near a funeral procession in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: World News Briefs; Indonesia to Question Suharto on Corruption
description: The Indonesian Government said today that it planned to question former President Suharto about allegations that he accumulated billions of dollars through corruption in his 32 years in power.

title: Hearst magazines 'get milk' to promote a literacy program aimed at children and mothers.
description: A MAJOR publisher is teaming up with the organization behind the ''milk mustache'' campaign for an elaborate marketing effort to encourage children to read -- and to encourage their mothers to buy a certain beverage that leaves an imprint on the upper lip.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Dining Notes

title: How Bars Lure Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Quietly, Alabama Troopers Escort Wallace for Last Time
description: The coffin, draped in the blood-red ''X'' on pure white that is Alabama's state flag, seemed almost too heavy to carry. Eight young, strong-looking Alabama state troopers bore the coffin foot by foot down the massive marble steps of the State Capitol, some of them having to place two hands on the rails of the coffin to steady it between them.

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; Crafty Republicans
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Moves 65.39 Higher in Its Fourth Straight Advance
description: A late surge lifted stocks to their fourth straight advance yesterday, the first since June, as traders and investors welcomed President Clinton's statement that he would not resign and shrugged off disappointment that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, offered no fresh hope of a cut in interest rates.

title: Deep, Deep, Deep, Er, Almost
description: If height were distance, Mark McGwire, the Cardinals' power hitter, would have had two more home runs tonight in Busch Stadium to add to his record-setting total of 63 for the season. Instead, his sky-high flyout to center field in the sixth inning and his space shot that seemed to have aged by about three weeks the Pittsburgh left-fielder, Turner Ward, as he waited for the ball to descend in the seventh inning, were simply outs.

title: Tape Release Challenges Secrecy of Grand Jury
description: The possibility that a videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony will be made public is expanding a debate about whether the investigation of the President may be eroding centuries-old rules guaranteeing secrecy and other protections for witnesses in grand jury proceedings.

title: Schumer and D'Amato Waste No Time in Attacking
description: The race for Senate took off at a furious pace today, as Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Democratic nominee, presented himself as a ''law-and-order Democrat'' with a tougher record on crime than Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. The Republican incumbent derided Mr. Schumer as ''a liberal Brooklyn Democrat'' and complained that he was already engaging in ''personal negative attacks.''

title: Thomas J. Murphy, 91, Dies; Led New York News Unions
description: Thomas J. Murphy, who led the Newspaper Guild of New York for 22 years, including during the bitter 114-day strike of 1962-63, died yesterday at Regency Park Nursing Home in Hazlet, N.J. He was 91.

title: Holmes, Newly Sharp, Is Thinking Playoffs
description: Darren Holmes had more than a month on the disabled list to think about why his curveball was not breaking sharply, why he had pitched ineffectively before it was determined that he had a bulging disk in his lower back.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about losses posted by American financial companies from investments in emerging markets misstated the BankAmerica Corporation's loans and investments in Latin America. They total $11.3 billion, not more than $33 billion.

title: Unequal Treatment Is Raised In Chase
description: The suggestion has not reached the proportions of a national debate, but talk about it has become part of the home run race that has commanded the nation's attention: Major League Baseball has slighted Sammy Sosa in its treatment of him and Mark McGwire, and race is the reason.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERKINS, JAMES A.
description: PERKINS-James A. A memorial service for James A. Perkins will be held on Sunday, October 4 at 2 PM at The Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, NJ. Dr. Perkins died August 20, 1998.

title: Plug-Ins Offer A Richer Slice Of the Internet
description: Q. When I try to look at a video clip with my Web browser, I get a message saying I need a particular plug-in. What is this, and what should I do?

title: Steps Planned By Magazine To Lift Profit
description: The Reader's Digest Association said yesterday that it would cut several hundred jobs, sell 39 paintings from its valuable collection and reduce its generous dividend by 75 percent to help improve a sagging performance.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Public Lives column on Tuesday about Donna Rice Hughes and her book ''Kids Online: Protecting Your Children in Cyberspace'' referred incorrectly to a passage on the disappearance of a 14-year-old girl who had met an older man in an Internet chat room. The passage referred to the sister of a woman named Tracey, not Mrs. Hughes's sister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLONE, HARRY
description: SLONE-Harry. The Board of Directors and membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member Harry Slone. Husband of our esteemed member Ruthe Slone. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Martin Scheman, President

title: Home-Grown Garnish For a Drop-Dead Party
description: DON'T take any happy homemaker tips from the film ''One True Thing,'' which opens tomorrow -- unless you want to poison your guests.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a United Nations official's comments about human rights in China misstated her whereabouts at the time. She was in Beijing, not ''back from China.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIEL, WILLIAM, JR.
description: PIEL-William, Jr. The Founder and Board of Trustees of the Cancer Research Institute mourn the loss of William Piel. Mr. Piel served as a CRI Trustee from 1956 until his death. His exceptional wisdom, vision and experience were indispensable in guiding the Institute through the years.

title: Articles Question Safety Of Dietary Supplements
description: People trying to treat their own ailments with remedies from health-food stores have become severely ill from pills and powders sold as ''dietary supplements,'' according to six reports being published today in the New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; Lying Is O.K.?
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Towns; Symbol of a Too-Hard, Too-Fast, Too-Short Life
description: MIKE MILLER lounged on a headstone at St. Peter's Cemetery, taking a cigarette break and watching from a distance as Catina L. Newmaster -- prostitute, drug addict, mother of five and murder victim -- was laid to rest.

title: Political Squabbling Snags a Financial Overhaul in Japan
description: Days before Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi leaves for a visit to the United States, hopes are dwindling for a passage this week of a landmark series of bills to stabilize Japan's financial system.

title: The Opponents Double, And Watch Tricks Vanish
description: The world championships, which ended in Lille, France, two weeks ago, were plagued by organizational problems. The worst occurred at the start of the final of the world open pairs, when it was discovered in mid-play that a badly designed movement would result in some players' meeting the same opponents twice. Many players had to sit out several rounds, in one case as many as six, and were given a score equal to the average of their correctly played boards. The problem recurred in the final session.

title: The Art Outside: Glowing Borders
description: It's all in the framing. Frames by Craig Ponzio for Larson-Juhl are handmade and water-gilded. The striated surface of Vermeer, inset, was burnished by hand. ''It's lovely but subtle,'' Mr. Ponzio said. ''It adds this line to the finish but brings your eye back inside to the artwork.'' The Vermeer and the embossed El Greco, below, are from one and eleven-sixteenths to four and a quarter inches wide, and $15 to $35 a foot; (800) 886-6126.

title: Another Humphrey Plans Populist Battle
description: At a time when Democratic politicians typically shrink from the populist ambitions of the Great Society era, Hubert H. Humphrey 3d is campaigning for governor here on a vow that government should flex its muscles for ordinary working people.

title: 2 Officers in Louima Case Can Keep Their Lawyers
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that two police officers charged with brutalizing Abner Louima could keep their lawyers even though the judge had found that the lawyers had ''actual or potential conflicts of interest'' in the case.

title: New Pataki Endorsements Upstage Vallone Upstate
description: A day after winning the Democratic gubernatorial primary, Peter F. Vallone took a victory lap of New York today to re-introduce himself to upstate voters, but he was upstaged when Buffalo's Democratic Mayor endorsed Gov. George E. Pataki for re-election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEIDENSTEIN, CHARLES
description: SEIDENSTEIN-Charles. Beth El Synagogue of New Rochelle records with sorrow the passing of long time Synagogue leader and Honorary Trustee. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Melvin N. Sirner, Rabbi Dorothy Fox, President

title: Meeting Today May Decide Isles' Home Ice
description: For the first time since the Islanders moved out of Nassau Coliseum last week and filed a $10 million lawsuit against the company that operates the arena, representatives of both sides will meet on Thursday in the hopes of reaching an agreement to have the team play its home games at the Coliseum this season.

title: Corrections
description: The Markets chart in Business Day yesterday with the daily stock market article, showing the performance of financial and commodities markets, carried outdated figures. They were from Monday, not Tuesday. Correct figures for yesterday's market performance appear in the chart today.

title: Economic Scene; The Fed can insulate the U.S. from much of the global crisis.
description: FIRST Asia. Then Russia. Now Latin America. There are days when it seems that America might soon be the only economy standing upright.

title: AUTO MAKER TO TRIPLE ITS STAKE IN SUZUKI MOTOR
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $315 million to triple its stake in the Suzuki Motor Corporation, the Japanese maker of compact cars and motorcycles. G.M. will raise its stake in Suzuki Motor to 10 percent from its current 3.3 percent. The move, part of an agreement to cooperate globally on the design and manufacture of vehicles, comes as the world's major auto makers are merging or forming alliances to improve competitiveness. G.M. is strong in North America, Latin America and Europe, but it does not have a big presence in Asia. It hopes to use Suzuki as a springboard to increase its presence there.

title: THE MARKETS: Shocks and Aftershocks; The Bear Is Rampant in the Markets for Riskier Bonds
description: The stock market's bear may have gone into hibernation, but the bond market variety is all too alive and well.

title: Political Foes and Opinion Polls Paint Him as a Has-Been, but Kohl Scoffs
description: Try telling Chancellor Helmut Kohl that he can't win the German elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, HILDA
description: MULLER-Hilda. In her 98th year. Beloved wife of William Muller. Former executive chef of the Metropolitan Opera Louis Sherry Restaurant in the old Metropolitan Opera House. She was a towering personality who operated Chalet Swiss in Warrensburg, New York for decades. Private funeral.

title: When Is a Sale No Bargain? City Seeks Ad Restrictions
description: The $300 gold earrings on sale last week at Macy's at 50 percent off, with an additional discount of 15 percent, may have seemed like a terrific deal. But customers were not getting any bargain because the so-called sale price of $127.50 was actually the fair market value of the item, city consumer protection officials said yesterday.

title: The Windowsills Are Lower (The Better to See the Murder)
description: When the remake of Alfred Hitchcock's mind-tingling ''Rear Window'' is broadcast on ABC-TV on Nov. 22, Christopher Reeve will appear in the Jimmy Stewart role of the house-bound bachelor riveted by the doings across the way; Daryl Hannah will do Grace Kelly without the pearls. Instead of a photographer, the lead is an architect; instead of having a broken leg, he's immobilized from the neck down, as is Mr. Reeve.

title: Shake-Up Set At Struggling Toys 'R' Us
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the toy retailer that has been struggling because of increased competition, said yesterday that it planned to revamp its business, close 90 stores, eliminate up to 3,000 jobs and take $495 million in after-tax charges.

title: Pet Sites to Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Shopper; All Dressed Up, Everywhere to Go
description: ''THIS might be the ultimate cross-dressing,'' said Kevin Roberts, a New York interior designer. Certainly, men's-wear fabrics are seeing some unusual crossover uses in home furnishings. Pinstripe flannel on chairs. Glen plaid draperies. Argyle-patterned rugs. Even herringbone tweed patterns on dinner plates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHERMAN, WILLIAM H.
description: SCHERMAN-William H., 85. VicePresident and Promotion Director of Newsweek on September 11, in Hanover, NH. Husband of Gerry (nee Germaine Ganteaume), father of Betsy Smith, Rowland, David, Daniel, Timothy, Thomas (deceased). Also survived by seven grandchildren, daughters-in-law Debra and Pamela and son-in-law Richard Smith. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to ''The William H. Scherman Fund at Dartmouth College'', c/o Alumni Office, 6068 Blunt Alumni Center, Hanover, NH 03755-3570 or a charity of your choice. Memorial service will be held at The United Church of Christ in Hanover at 12 noon, Sunday, September 20.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Remembering a Tyrannized Child and Her Dolls
description: Every day, it sometimes seems, newspapers carry grim articles about parents' battering their small children, scalding them, starving them, sexually abusing them, killing them. In a society in which so much is disposable, frighteningly large numbers of those who are least able to help themselves are being treated as the ultimate disposables.

title: Cutting the Cord
description: WHEN Susan Kubira, an interior designer in the Chicago area, decided to disconnect her home telephone to go completely cellular, she faced raised eyebrows from her friends, employees and, most of all, phone company.

title: Death of Man in Custody Leads to Suspension of 3
description: Three Atlantic City police officers have been suspended without pay for their part in an arrest that ended with the death of a man accused of stealing chips at the Trump Plaza Casino, Mayor James F. Whelan said yesterday.

title: Old Mountain Music (Black, No Sugar)
description: Gillian Welch and David Rawlings are a two-member austerity program. At Tramps on Monday night, their songs renounced four decades of pop to revive the Appalachian roots of country music, with concise melodies and stripped-down narratives that make no time for ornament or sentimentality.

title: Psychiatric Hospital Plan Causes Mayor to Protest
description: The state plans to build a psychiatric hospital in Woodbridge that could house convicted sex offenders who have completed their prison terms but remain unfit for release, officials said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: No Plans for Coordinated Interest Rate Reductions

title: Should Clinton Turn to Psychologists, as Well as Religious Healers?
description: As President Clinton pursues expiation before the nation, the historian Robert Dallek can only wonder why Mr. Clinton does not take the next step beyond his new cadre of fresh religious advisers and turn outright to psychotherapists and marriage counselors.

title: Excerpts From the President's News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference today at the State Department by President Clinton and President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Iran Versus Afghanistan
description: To American eyes, the clerical dictatorships of Iran and Afghanistan can seem variations on the same Islamic fundamentalist theme. But relations between the two neighboring countries are now at a flash point. Ethnic, political and religious tensions have been exacerbated by the recent killings of at least eight Iranian diplomats by Afghan Taliban fighters. Iran is now assembling some 250,000 troops along the Afghan border and threatens military action unless its demands for amends are met.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNIN, SUE DIANE.
description: BUNIN-Sue Diane. Beloved mother of Amy Eller, dear sister of Robert Goldberg, loving daughter of the late Sylvia and Sidney Goldberg. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, 7-9 P.M. on Thursday with funeral service at 11:30 A.M. on Friday. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Gynecology/Oncology Research Fund of New York University, C/O Dr. James Speyer, 160 East 32 St, NYC 10016.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: Army Marching on a Different Wavelength; Joining Conference USA Brings More Television Exposure and Revenue From Bowls
description: It has played football for 108 years, 1,011 games in all against teams from across the nation. It maintains a narrow edge over Navy in one of the oldest and most resonant rivalries in college sports. But the history of Army football takes a modern turn Saturday when a pair of teams without a victory square off at Michie Stadium.

title: Return of Paula Jones Suit Is Seen as Clinton Threat
description: The Paula Jones lawsuit, which is at the heart of the charges leveled against President Clinton by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, is re-emerging to pose new political and legal threats to the President, lawyers in and outside of the White House said today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, GLADYS
description: NEWMAN-Gladys. Darling, 21 years have past since you left us. You're unforgettable. Irving, Leslie and Keri

title: Philharmonic Plays It Safe: Stern and Beethoven
description: Season openers in the music world can be declarations of intent, bearers of subliminal messages or simple hellos. Applied to last night's New York Philharmonic concert, the first two options fit less well than the third.

title: Happy Birthday, Your Team Won, Your Stock Crashed
description: WEEKDAY mornings for Jessica Nierenberg, a 23-year-old research manager at a market research company in San Francisco, usually begin with a dash to her neighborhood bus stop for a 30-minute ride to her office in the city's financial district downtown. By 8:30 she is at her desk, pouring herself a bowl of breakfast cereal and firing up her computer for a glimpse at what the planet has wrought while she slept.

title: Pet Sites to Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Iraqis Affirm Threat to End Arms Checks
description: Iraq's ruling council today endorsed a threat to end all cooperation with United Nations arms inspectors if the Security Council did not restore regular reviews of its sanctions against the country.

title: Overreaching on Assisted Suicide
description: The House is poised to consider a misguided bill against assisted suicide that would intrude on the right of doctors to provide appropriate care at the end of a patient's life and the right of states to regulate the practice of medicine. The bill, sponsored by Representative Henry Hyde, Republican of Illinois, would allow the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration to investigate and punish any physician who prescribes lethal doses of drugs with the intent of assisting in a patient's suicide. Even the American Medical Association, which opposes physician-assisted suicide, is strongly opposed to this bill.

title: Gotti's Son to Be Released On Bail Ahead of Trial
description: Nine months after he was arrested on racketeering charges, John A. Gotti, the son of the imprisoned mob boss, was ordered released on bail today by a Federal judge who said adequate steps could be taken to insure that he was no threat to the public.

title: 2 Allied Domecq Accounts Change
description: There have been changes affecting the accounts of two Allied Domecq liquor brands.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIDEMAN, LAWRENCE & NANCY K.
description: SIDEMAN-Lawrence & Nancy K., 94 and 90. Married for 66 years. Died within 3 days of each other. Larry September 12 and Nancy Sept. 15. Amazing and beloved parents of Fredrica S. Levinson & Jacqueline and Howard Guttman. Proud grandparents of Elizabeth and Neil Henrichsen, Suzanne Levinson, Edward and Katherine Guttman & Marc Guttman. Joyous great-grandparents of Kayla and Jed Henrichsen. They were born and lived their entire lives in New York City. Private graveside service for Larry was held September 14. Funeral services for Nancy will be held Thursday, September 17 at 12 noon at Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home in Forest Hills. Those who wish may donate in Larry's memory to Parker Jewish Institute for Healthcare and Rehabilitation, New Hyde Park, New York and in Nancy's memory to Kew Gardens Hills Hadassah. As Nancy always said to Larry ''To life, to love, together''.

title: Fund-Raisers Say Scandal Has Not Had a Dampening Effect
description: The scandal in Washington had just begun to break last February when David Steiner had a few friends, and their checkbooks, over to his home for dinner with President Clinton.

title: An Internet Filter Is Eager To Zap the Starr Report
description: At least one software company is bragging that it can do a highly effective job of keeping the work of Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, from reaching your home computer.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOMBLE, CLEM
description: WOMBLE-Clem. March 3, 1920Septemper 17, 1988. We think of you always & miss you everyday. Memories of you remain forever in our hearts. Family & friends of Clem Wombl

title: Kennelly Got Running Mate She Wanted in the Primary
description: Barbara B. Kennelly, whose Democratic campaign for governor has never caught fire, caught a break in the primary on Tuesday when voters gave her a running mate who excites party members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C., 77. Redding, CT. On September 16. Survivors include his wife Elisabeth C., two sons David C. of Denver, CO and Henry C. of Bedford, NY, two daughters Sarah Dudley Plimpton, of NY and Jane Dudley of Seattle, Washington, & ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Please, no flowers, but if desired, contributions in his memory may be made to The Salvation Army, Highstead Foundation, PO Box 1097, Redding, CT 06875, or St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724.

title: Winner of Capital's Primary Appeals to Whites and Blacks
description: Anthony A. Williams, the government technocrat who swept to victory on Tuesday in the Democratic primary, began his campaign for mayor of Washington today by renewing his pledge to bring a sometimes racially divided city back together.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS FOR THIRD DAY. Japan's currency weakened as traders bought dollars on indications that no coordinated global interest rate reduction was being planned. The dollar rose to 134.90 yen in New York from 133.90.

title: A Russian Coal-Mine Region Producing Little but Misery
description: The Soviet Union leveled the conifers and birches of the west Siberian taiga and threw up this town 34 years ago for one reason only. The red-and-white sign at the outskirts, under the drawing of a coal-cutting tool emblazoned on a birch leaf, sums it up: ''City of Miners' Glory.''

title: Netscape and Qwest Plan To Announce Web Alliance
description: Forming perhaps the deepest alliance yet between a big Internet content provider and a long-distance company, the Netscape Communications Corporation and Qwest Communications International Inc. plan to announce a far-reaching strategic alliance today.

title: Havel, Repaying a Favor, Stands in Solidarity With a Friend Under Fire
description: It might not have been apparent to most Americans, but from the Czech perspective it was clear that by appearing at President Clinton's side at a news conference yesterday, President Vaclav Havel was not merely repaying a friend for bringing his country into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. A target of accusations of philandering himself, he was standing in solidarity with a fellow politician contending with a culture much more judgmental than his own.

title: Harvard, Joining Others, Raises Its Financial Aid for Students
description: As Princeton, Yale and other selective universities announced more generous financial aid plans for students last winter, Harvard was noticeably absent.

title: Stop Growing Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: A Bed No Child Will Be Able to Outgrow
description: Think of heirloom furnishings for children -- expensive pieces bought for one's progeny to love and lug through the years to adulthood -- as a mode of recycling for the trust-fund set. Discriminating tots can cut their collecting teeth on the Simon Horn cot, a convertible crib handmade in Devon, England, and recently imported to the United States. Its imposing silhouette, inspired by a Louis Philippe lit-bateau but built in accordance with Federal safety regulations, is sturdy enough to withstand the transformation from standard-size crib to bed to sofa (with the help of a few Simon Horn cushions to hide the slats). Harpers & Queen magazine declared the piece a must-have for chic nurseries. At $2,750, make that three heirlooms. Store locations: (205) 871-6222.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORSHEIM, JAMES
description: FLORSHEIM-James. On September 15, 1998. Beloved husband of Harriette. Devoted father of Henry and his wife Doe. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra and Sydney. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Thursday, September 17, 1998, 6-9 P.M. Graveside service Friday, September 18, 11 AM at Mount Judah Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Cabrini Development Council, 227 East 19th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERMAN, KENNY
description: HERMAN-Kenny. September 17, 1945-April 18, 1998. I will love you til the end of time. Susan

title: Board Votes to Give Police Control Over School Security
description: After a vociferous and emotional debate among concerned parents, teachers and community leaders, the Board of Education voted unanimously last night to transfer control of security in the city's public schools to the Police Department.

title: Filling Up Melodies While Awing The Fans
description: Joe Lovano played persuasively in his late set Tuesday night at Iridium, so much so that one fan, in a flush of awe, insisted afterward on having the saxophonist deface the back of the fan's cream-colored jacket.

title: High Court Razed Church-State Wall; What Jefferson Believed
description: To the Editor:

title: Fine-Tuning and Tweaking
description: WINDOWS 98 ANNOYANCES

title: Opposition Party Applies to Register in 3 Regions of China
description: In the last two weeks dissidents in three parts of China have applied to the Government to register local branches of an opposition organization, the China Democratic Party, human rights groups and the dissidents said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, WILLIAM L.
description: REYNOLDS-William L. September 14, 1998. Devoted husband of Margaret Buck. Survived by his daughter Constance Bierkan and his granddaughters Elizabeth Welker and Laura Welker. Brother of Newlin Reynolds. Service on Friday, September 18, 1998, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTZEN, MARVIN S.
description: KOTZEN-Marvin S. Of Larchmont, NY on September 16, 1998. Dearest husband and companion of Lynn (Andrews), wonderful father to Ellen and Jeff Spokes and Debby Kotzen, beloved grandfather of Joshua and Toby Spokes. He died as he lived, with dignity and without complaint. Funeral will be Friday, September 18 at 2 PM at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to Beth Emeth Synagogue, 2111 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont 10538 or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 237 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains 10605 or a charity of your choice.

title: Windows 98: After the Start Button
description: THREE years ago, David A. Karp, a Windows 95 beta tester, armed with a little spare time and his own Web site, started chronicling the things that bothered him in the new operating system.

title: Clinton Wasted His Chances to Deal; Report Isn't Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Making the Decision; Would You Pay a Price for Mobility?
description: ''IF you are looking to use a cellular phone as a land-line replacement, you have to look at what kinds of calls you make,'' said Ian Guillet, an analyst for the telecommunications group at International Data Corporation in Austin, Tex.

title: Justice Without a Circus
description: Is the nation doomed to endure lengthy Congressional hearings in which the tawdry facts of the Lewinsky affair and its legal ramifications are contested before television cameras and then decided by the House Judiciary Committee?

title: Fiercely Testifying for Banished Souls; Ghoulish and Gripping, Galas Makes Herself Heard
description: From devil to angel, beast to holy hero, Diamanda Galas has inspired a host of otherworldly associations. But the 46-year-old singer, pianist and composer scoffs at the simple-mindedness of those who brand her satanic or divinely touched. The metaphor she chooses to describe her work is fierce, but less familiar: a magical symbol of the rewards of dedication.

title: Campaign Reformer Under Attack
description: Hoping to capitalize on the distraction in Washington, Congressional Republicans are planning a new sneak attack on clean elections. The target, as before, is Lawrence Noble, general counsel of the Federal Election Commission and scourge of fund-raising violations. Republicans have tried repeatedly to oust Mr. Noble by attaching dismissal riders to various bills, only to back down. They are at it again this week, spreading word that a provision forcing out Mr. Noble will be attached to an unrelated spending bill that has already passed both the House and Senate. Proponents of campaign reform must speak out and block this move.

title: Twist for High Tech: Soft, Seductive Edges
description: A MOIRE pattern of shimmering light bounces off a grid of copper mesh -- not the usual sight one would expect in the stair hall of a grand old Brooklyn town house. The florid whorls of carved plaster moldings, maybe; the ample curve of a stolid wooden banister, of course. But a two-story wall of metal mesh layered on linen?

title: Tribute to a Neglected Composer
description: ''To make a prairie,'' in the words of Emily Dickinson, ''it takes a clover and one bee.'' The composer Ernst Bacon was a busy bee who, in his long life (he died at 92, in 1990), created a wide prairie of music, partly from the clover of Dickinson's poetry, which he set in more than a quarter of his 250 or so songs.

title: The Power of the Pen
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: When the Intern Has the Power; A Southern Showdown
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOL, MORRIS
description: SOKOL-Morris. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of its member Philip Sokol. May his entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EVANS, CARNOT WAGENER
description: EVANS-Carnot Wagener, 78. Of Kilmarnock, Virginia, formerly of Darien, CT. Died Wednesday, September 16, 1998. He was a retired investment banker and CEO of Clark, Dodge & Company of NY, NY. He is survived by his wife Jacquelyn P. Evans, a daughter, two sons, five grandchildren and a brother. Funeral services will be held 11AM, Saturday, Sept. 19 at Historic Christ Church, Irvington, VA. Memorial contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: ABITIBI TO BUY NEWSPRINT MILL FROM STONE CONTAINER
description: Abitibi-Consolidated Inc., the world's largest maker of newsprint, agreed yesterday to acquire the Stone Container Corporation's newsprint operation at Snowflake, Ariz., for $250 million. The Snowflake mill produces 287,000 metric tons a year of 70 percent recycled newsprint, Abitibi said, and the assets to be acquired include a 56-megawatt power plant, which provides the mill with 95 percent of its energy, and a 36-mile rail line. Stone is keeping an adjacent mill that produces paper used in cardboard boxes. Abitibi is based in Montreal. Stone Container, based in Chicago, is a pulp, paper and paper packaging company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIFACH, IRA
description: ZWEIFACH-Ira. The Collectors Club mourns the passing of its former president, past editor of ''The Collectors Club Philatelist'' and member of the Board of Governors for many years. His devotion to the Club and its functions will be gratefully remembered.

title: Statement on Tape By Clinton Lawyer
description: Following is a statement from President Clinton's personal lawyer, David E. Kendall, responding to efforts by the House Judiciary Committee to release videotaped testimony by Mr. Clinton, as provided today by the White House:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, ALLAN
description: KRAMER-Allan. On September 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Kevin and Kerri, cherished son of Gladys and the late Louis. Dear brother of Joel Kramer, Cheryl Yarmus and brother-in-law to Alan and Alice Rhein, and Scott Yarmus. Services Friday, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Leaders in House Act to Discourage the Spread of Embarrassing Stories
description: Capitol Hill was abuzz again today with talk about the personal lives of public people: specifically, who is spreading embarrassing stories about politicians, and what ought to be done about it.

title: After Some Politicking, Tyson Is Hardly Optimistic
description: Like a politician who is trailing in a campaign a few days before an election, Mike Tyson made a public appearance at a luncheon to honor Gov. Robert Miller of Nevada and Dr. Elias Ghanem, the chairman of the Nevada State Athletic Commission, at Caesars Palace today.

title: Woodward Stakes Has a Small, but Power-Packed, Field
description: Sonny Hine got the word yesterday that his Skip Away had been made the favorite to win the Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park tomorrow and repeated his old theme with new emphasis.

title: Lawmaker Seeks Vote on Contempt Resolution Against Reno
description: The chairman of a House investigating committee said today that he was seeking a vote of the full House on a contempt of Congress resolution against Attorney General Janet Reno, escalating a bitter dispute over the appointment of an independent prosecutor to examine possible campaign finance abuses.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSER, NATHANIEL
description: WEISSER-Nathaniel, 79. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Highly respected employer. A man of great integrity, generosity who will be sorely missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his wife Eleanor, his daughter Susan, son Robert, his daughter-inlaw Judith, his grandchildren Amanda and Jennifer. He took from no one and gave to many.

title: On My Mind; The Three Questions
description: President Clinton has forced the members of Congress to face three questions, whether or not the American people will like the answers:

title: When the Intern Has the Power; Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Is One Long Jubilee: Favorite Gershwin Recordings
description: Here are some favorite George Gershwin recordings of the classical music and pop and jazz critics of The Times. Compact disks range in price from $10 to $17 for a single disk; $25 to $35 for a two-disk set; $48 for a three-disk package and $68 for a four-disk collection. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: COMMERCE BANCORP IN DEAL FOR PRESTIGE FINANCIAL
description: Commerce Bancorp Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Prestige Financial Corporation for $16.25 a share in stock, or $75.2 million. Commerce, a multibank holding company based in Cherry Hill, N.J., has assets of about $4.6 billion. Prestige Financial is the holding company for Prestige State Bank, which has eight branches serving two New Jersey counties and assets of $310 million. Prestige Financial's shares rose 11 percent yesterday, gaining $1.50 each, to $14.50. Shares of Commerce Bancorp fell $1 each, to $38.9375. (Dow Jones)

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: SAMSUNG OPEN

title: China Detains Two Who Applied for New Party
description: Just days after dissidents in several parts of China met small but encouraging signals when they applied to register a political party, their counterparts in Beijing this week encountered a different fate.

title: Dow Declines by 216.01 as Part of a Global Downturn
description: Stock prices tumbled around the world yesterday after overseas investors digested word that central banks are planning no coordinated cut in interest rates to quell financial and economic turmoil in Asia, Latin America and Russia.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Television; Six Men Watching Their Lives Grind By
description: We meet George Crawford, a 22-year-old murderer, as he begins a life sentence at the maximum-security Louisiana State Penitentiary, a place where, the prisoners soon learn, ''Life means life.'' What the future holds for Mr. Crawford and 5,000 other inmates is the subject of ''The Farm'' (on A&E on Sunday night at 9), a grave two-hour look at the experiences of six men, five of whom seem fated to end their lives where they have already spent much of them.

title: Congress on Trial: Fate Of Parties May Be Issue
description: It is not just the Clinton Presidency that hangs in the balance in these fevered Washington days. Before the eyes of the nation, Congress itself is on trial.

title: Science and Poetry Face Death in a Hospital Room
description: ''Wit'' is the chilling chronicle of a professor dying an agonizing death in a teaching hospital. The instructor is an expert on the 17th-century poet John Donne, which proves entirely apt, because the performance at the center of the play is pure poetry.

title: Antiques; Furniture Packed With Surprises
description: The stars must be in an odd alignment. Normally, you would have to go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Louvre, the Victoria and Albert or the Hermitage to see a Roentgen antique. Now, for some reason, the firmament has released a few stellar examples.

title: CARE ONE AGREES TO BUY 49% of KUALA NURSING OPERATIONS
description: Kuala Healthcare Inc. of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., agreed yesterday to sell a 49 percent stake in its five nursing operations and all of its institutional pharmacy business to Care One L.L.C. for about $28 million in cash. The closely held Care One will also assume $39 million in debt. Through the agreement, Kuala, formerly Continental Health Affiliates, said it would be able to develop and acquire assisted living facilities. Care One will also have an option to acquire Kuala's remaining 51 percent stake in the nursing operations.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 2 about a National Labor Relations Board ruling involving a newspaper strike in Detroit misstated the former affiliation of Benjamin J. Burns. He was executive editor of The Detroit News, not The Detroit Free Press.

title: Two Kurd Groups Unite Against Baghdad in Pact Brokered by U.S.
description: The State Department announced today that it had brokered a settlement between two feuding factions of the Iraqi Kurds, uniting them against the Government of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Burmese Opposition Issues Risky Challenge to the Junta
description: In their riskiest challenge yet to the military rulers of Myanmar, a small group of opposition politicians said today that they would act as the country's legitimate parliament and declared all laws and proclamations issued by the ruling junta null and void.

title: Can Colleges Be Diverse and Fair?
description: To the Editor:

title: When the Intern Has the Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, HELEN. (BUDDY)
description: ALTMAN-Helen. (Buddy) nee Blackman, September 17, 1998, in her 95th year, left peacefully to join her beloved husband Bill. Cherished mother of Joy and Harry Henshel and Sam Altman. Adored Meema Buddy to Dayle, Patti, Diane and Judy, greatgrandmother to Artemis, Ariel and Jaron. Services at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, Friday, September 18th, at 1:30PM. Burial at Sharon Gardens.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Can America Rediscover Maserati?
description: ONCE-PROUD automotive name, Maserati, will be seen once again in the United States, if the company follows through on its plan to return to the American market in 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOBE, WILLIAM W.
description: KOBE-William W. Age 68 of Port Washington, Long Island, on September 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Janet. Loving father of Linda, James (Jayne) & Donna (Armando). Devoted grandfather of Julia and Alex. Visiting at home Friday 1:30-4 and 6:30 -9 P.M. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday September 19th at 1 P.M. at the United Methodist Church, Port Washington. Gifts may be made to the United Methodist Church Memorial Fund, 1515 Middle Neck Road, Port Washington, NY 11050.

title: In Zambia, the Abandoned Generation
description: It was only two weeks after their mother died from AIDS that their aunt took them to the bus station. She said she did not want to take care of them anymore. She told them to go to Lusaka, find a police station and ask for an orphanage.

title: Sustain the 'Partial Birth' Veto
description: A woman's right to abortion faces a critical test today in the Senate. The House has already voted to override President Clinton's principled veto last year of the latest Congressional attempt to ban so-called partial birth abortions. A Senate vote scheduled for this morning will determine whether this professedly narrow but actually far-reaching assault on abortion rights becomes the law of the land.

title: A Great Chinese Leap Into a New Sort of Cultural Revolution
description: China has changed more quickly and radically in the past few decades than at almost any time in its history. Video installations are being produced in cramped Beijing apartments. Gender-bending performances are taking place in out-of-the-way spots. Calligraphy, that most venerated art, is being put to perverse, absurdist ends. A brash Pop Art is tipping every sacred cow in sight, from Maoist ideology to Western market culture.

title: It's acquisition time: Just ask VSM Media, Marc USA, Bozell, Hadtke Associates and others.
description: SEVERAL agencies and agency companies are making acquisitions.

title: Report Faults Child Agency In Death Of 6-Year-Old
description: A state panel investigating the death of a 6-year-old New Haven boy last month harshly criticized Connecticut's child welfare department today, saying in a report that the agency failed to protect the abused child and repeated mistakes it had made in other cases.

title: M & C Saatchi Loses Two Top Executives
description: Two top executives at M & C Saatchi in New York -- Brent Bouchez, president, and David Page, executive creative director -- have left the agency after almost two years.

title: For Affluent Blacks, Harlem's Pull Is Strong
description: Howard Sanders had garnered the trappings of American success: a degree from Harvard Business School, a position with a high-powered Manhattan investment firm and an apartment on Central Park West.

title: Can Colleges Be Diverse and Fair?
description: To the Editor:

title: What Happened to Those Global Rate Cuts?
description: On Monday President Clinton declared that in the midst of the greatest economic turmoil in a half-century, ''the industrial world's chief priority today, plainly, is to spur growth.'' The markets soared, figuring that the combination of a Presidential call to arms and a statement issued the same day by the seven largest industrial economies meant coordinated action was on the way -- chiefly a cut in interest rates.

title: Accounts
description: * American Skandia, Shelton, Conn., a unit of Skandia Insurance Co. Ltd., to Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Farlow Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for the jazz guitarist Tal Farlow will be held at 7:30 P.M. on Sunday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Citicorp Center at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street. Mr. Farlow died on July 25.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS TO TAKE A CHARGE AND CUT JOBS
description: The American Greetings Corporation, the No. 2 greeting-card company, said yesterday that it would take a third-quarter pretax charge of between $10 million and $20 million as part of a ''pro-active'' move to cut costs and maintain growth. The charges come as part of a plan to review all operations at the company, which is based in Cleveland, and cut annual costs before taxes by $20 million to $30 million. Some of those savings will be achieved by early next year, the company said. The company's shares fell $3.875 yesterday, to $40.125. A spokesman said that 120 to 240 workers -- between 1 percent and 2 percent of the company's 12,000 full-time employees -- would be dismissed as part of the review of operations.

title: New York Hardest Hit by Census Flaws
description: A new study by a Democratic research group shows that the three worst undercounts in the 1990 census occurred in Congressional districts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx.

title: Clinton Issue Encroaches on Schumer's Senate Run
description: In Washington today, the House Judiciary Committee debated whether to release to the public videotapes of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the Monica Lewinsky case. Here in central New York, one of the committee's most prominent Democrats, Representative Charles E. Schumer, was touring a factory that makes cat litter, soberly noting the economic distress of this downtrodden region and proposing a series of measures to create jobs.

title: Former Archer Daniels Executives Are Found Guilty of Price Fixing
description: Three former executives with the Archer Daniels Midland Company -- including the son of its powerful chairman, Dwayne Andreas -- were found guilty yesterday of engaging in an international conspiracy to fix the prices of a widely used additive for animal feed.

title: Angst and Introspection In a Time of Transition
description: ''After Rabin: New Art From Israel'' at the Jewish Museum presents the work of 35 contemporary artists, established and emerging, who are said to be among the most visible and respected in Israel. Taken strictly as art, the show is not all that gripping. It's like a Whitney Biennial Lite, an entertaining but familiar mix of the traditional and the trendy, with a preponderance of photography and multimedia work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, DOROTHY MERRITT.
description: SCHWARTZ - Dorothy Merritt. Passed away on Septmeber 14, 1998. Beloved wife of Martin. Cherished daughter of Dorothy and the late John R. Merritt, and dearest sister of Harry, Robert, William, Grover, and Steve. She will be forever remembered and loved.

title: New Tests Dispute U.S. Finding of Iraq Nerve Gas
description: Swiss and French tests for a poison gas on Iraqi missile warheads appear to have reached results contrary to those from American tests that showed the presence of VX, a deadly nerve agent, diplomats said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSCARINIS, ROSA
description: FOSCARINIS-Rosa. Pediatrician, on August 24, 1998 in a tragic car accident in Athens, Greece. Donations in her memory to National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, 918 F Street N.W., Suite 412, Washington, D.C. 20004.

title: Alcatel Says Profit Will Be Disappointing
description: Alcatel S.A., the world's No. 4 telephone equipment maker, said yesterday that its profit would not meet forecasts this year. The announcement drove its stock sharply lower. Trading was halted seven times in Paris. Alcatel said its telecommunications unit would miss market expectations by at least $260 million as big European clients curb investment and recession in Asia erodes sales. That overshadowed a tenfold jump in first-half net to 15.2 billion francs ($2.7 billion), buoyed by asset sales.

title: Political Briefing; Clinton's Troubles Scuttle Beauty Contest
description: When 3,000 members of the Christian Coalition gather this weekend in Washington for their annual national conference, they will find that one major event on the schedule -- an Election 2000 Presidential straw poll -- has been canceled.

title: Rothko's Gloomy Elegance in Retrospect
description: With the Rothko retrospective now at the Whitney, a question arises: what has changed about our perception of him since the Guggenheim's big survey 20 years ago?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHUMER, RICHARD
description: SCHUMER-Richard. Always in our hearts. Doris, Jeff, Roshann, George, Jeanne, Leona, Howell & Familie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLSTERLI, ANDREW
description: BOLSTERLI-Andrew. The President, the Board of Directors, staff and members of United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, express our heartfelt condolences to John and Marianne Slade on the untimely death of their grandson, Andrew. John and Marianne Slade's generous support for UCP over many years has helped us to provide essential services to individuals with cerebral palsy and related disabilities. We share their grief and sorrow. Leo Hausman, President Edward R. Matthews, Exec. Dir. UCP/NYC

title: Carl Loeb Kempner, 74, Broker And Educational Philanthropist
description: Carl Loeb Kempner, the managing senior partner at the Wall Street firm of Hamershlag, Kempner & Company and a longtime supporter of education, died on Tuesday at his home in White Plains. He was 74 and had been battling prostate cancer for more than 20 years, according to his son Michael Kempner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINDLER, JULIUS
description: RINDLER-Julius on September 16 1998, 97. Devoted and loving father of Gerald and Peggy, beloved husband of the late Regina, dear brother of Erwin and uncle of Ronald, Joan, Judy and their spouses and children. Remembered with great love. Services were held September 16.

title: Life Is One Long Jubilee: Gershwin CD's
description: Was George Gershwin America's greatest composer? In the arts, such questions are futile and ultimately unimportant. What can be said, perhaps, is that Gershwin was the most American composer, in the democracy and eclecticism of his idiom, and in the brash energy and earthy imagination that boiled from his musical melting pot of pop, blues, jazz and classics.

title: Strict Bail Conditions Set For Release of Gotti's Son
description: Although he is expected to be released from jail in a few days, John A. Gotti, the son of the imprisoned Mafia boss, will be confined to virtual house arrest under bail restrictions set today. His phone calls will be monitored, visitors will be screened and a 24-hour guard will be posted outside his door.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Sol LeWitt

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: 3 Ex-Archer Executives Convicted of Fixing Prices

title: A Time to Hold, a Time to Go Home
description: When Meryl Streep first appears in ''One True Thing,'' she is clownishly dolled up to look like Dorothy from ''The Wizard of Oz,'' in a billowing blue-and-white-checked dress and ruby slippers, her hair knotted in pigtails strung with ribbons. Ms. Streep's character, Kate Gulden, the supermom to end all supermoms, is throwing a surprise costume birthday party for her husband, George (William Hurt), a college professor and author of some note. Entering this suburban Oz, Kate's daughter, Ellen (Renee Zellweger), an ambitious New York journalist, visibly winces when Mom entreats her to join the jolly carnival and dress up as something, anything.

title: The Inquirer's Editorials: Call to Quit and a Rebuttal
description: The Philadelphia Inquirer originally raised the issue of President Clinton's resignation in an editorial on Jan. 22, 1998:

title: Aggravation, but No Towels or Soap
description: Remember ''Grand Hotel''? Lewis Stone would sit in the plush lobby, saying: ''Always the same. People come, people go. Nothing ever happens.'' Well, the Sunshine Hotel is just like that, except that its guests are life's losers, its beds rent for as little as $4.50 a night, and the 4-by-6-foot rooms have chicken-wire ceilings.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''What's the next big trend in restaurants?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, EDWARD J.
description: DORAN-Edward J. Reposing at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, Bronx on Sunday 25PM and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10AM at St. Elizabeth's Church, 268 Wadsworth Ave. & 187th Street, NYC. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETTAS, ATHENA
description: PETTAS-Athena (9/18/73). Twenty-five years. Two and-a-half decades. A quarter of a century. Time runs. Memory abides. Your daughters

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Wednesday misidentified the Wieden & Kennedy advertising office named to share responsibilities with the in-house agency of Calvin Klein Inc. for the CK One unisex fragrance. It is the office in New York, not Portland, Ore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAKOW, HERMAN
description: KRAKOW-Herman. On September 14th, 1998 at age 77. Beloved husband to May. Devoted father to Robert & Carol. Loving brother to Rose. Cherished grandfather of Jarrad & Carly. Favorite relative & special friend. Services Friday, 11:30AM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza(opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Association for Children with Retarded Mental Development, 345 Hudson Street, New York, New York 10014.

title: CHANGE IN CONTROL OF SATELLITE SALES GAINS IN CONGRESS
description: In a major challenge to President Clinton's export policy, House and Senate negotiators agreed today to shift the control over exporting American satellites back to the State Department from the Commerce Department.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LECOMPTE, PHILIP M. M.D.
description: LeCOMPTE-Philip M. M.D., age 90, of Lexington, MA. formerly of Newton Centre, died Tuesday, September 15 at Brookhaven, 1010 Waltham Street, Lexington, MA. Born in Binghamton, New York, October 4, 1907. he was the son of Irville Charles LeCompte and Harriet Bernice Maclachlan. Magna Cum Laude graduate of the University of Minnesota and Phi Beta Kappa, he received his medical degree from Yale Medical School, 1936, where he was elected to two honorary medical societies, Alpha Omega Alpha and Sigma Xi. In 1939, he married Jean Sykes, of Conifer, New York at nearby Lake Massawepie. The LeCompte's have summered in the Adirondacks for many years. He then spent a year with Dr. Walter B. Cannon at his Harvard Physiology Laboratory. In 1940, he returned to teaching at Yale and also served as pathologist at Fairfield State Hospital. Dr. LeCompte was Chief of Pathology at the Faulkner Hospital for over thirty years until his retirement in 1974. The pathology laboratory at the new Faulker Hospital is known as ''The Doctor Philip M. LeCompte Laboratory''. He received international recognition for his research in diabetes mellitus and wrote numerous articles and chapters on the subject. In 1966, he co-authored the medical textbook, ''The Pathology of Diabetes Mellitus'' with Dr. Shields Warren and Dr. Merle Legg. After his retirement, he held a faculty appointment at Tuft's University School of Medicine and turned his attention to research and teaching in gastroenterology and co-authored several papers with young investigators. Dr. LeCompte loved medicine and was a role model for young physicians. He was a founding trustee of the Countway Medical Library and was a member of Physicians for Social Responsibility and Physicians Forum. Dr. LeCompte held strong opinions about politics and often shared his liberal views in Letters to the Editor. In 1947, he was elected the first Chairman of the Newton Chapter of Americans for Democratic Action. He is survived by his wife, Jean, his daughter, Anne LeCompte Fisher, his son, Andrew, Philip LeCompte and three grandchildren. The services will be private. Memorials in Dr. LeCompte's name may be made to the Faulkner Hospital, 1153 Centre St, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130 or to Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts at 1055 Commonwealth Ave, Boston, MA 02215.

title: Bayer Buying Chiron Unit and Stake in Seed Venture; Agfa Offering Set
description: Bayer A.G., the German drug and chemical giant that has been shedding assets to focus on life sciences, will buy the American diagnostics business of the Chiron Corporation and 50 percent of the farm seed subsidiary of the Crompton & Knowles Corporation.

title: Response by Starr to the President's Lawyer
description: Following is a response by the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr to David E. Kendall's statement on the videotaped testimony of President Clinton:

title: Malaysia Banks Plan to Merge
description: Bank Bumiputra Malaysia Bhd., a troubled state-owned bank, will merge with Commerce Asset Holdings Bhd., the two companies said today.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widens; Consumer Prices Up 0.2%
description: The trade deficit widened 2 percent in July as exports fell for the fourth consecutive month, while consumer prices changed little in August, Government figures released today showed.

title: Merchant-Ivory With Kristofferson
description: The tale of a young girl coming of age in the shadow of her literary-lion father is told in ''A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries.'' The film is adapted for the screen by James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala from the autobiographical novel by Kaylie Jones, the daughter of James Jones, author of ''From Here to Eternity'' and ''The Thin Red Line.'' It is the story of Americans in Paris -- like the Willis family in the movie, the Jones family lived in France -- and the maturing of Channe Willis (Leelee Sobieski) in the exotic expatriate world of her parents, played by Kris Kristofferson and Barbara Hershey.

title: Walker Evans Found the Poetry in Life's Unvarnished Details
description: Walker Evans might be called the Jackson Pollock of American photography. He took strands of American and European culture, discarded what he didn't want and braided the rest into an indelibly American art.

title: House Votes Small Fraction Of Money Sought for I.M.F.
description: The House tonight approved only a fraction of the nearly $18 billion that President Clinton is seeking for the International Monetary Fund.

title: Man Killed in Shootout With Agents in Brooklyn
description: Federal agents executing a search warrant at a Brooklyn house last night exchanged gunfire with five men, killing one before the other four surrendered early this morning, the police said.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Spending Bill Hurt by Bid on Foreign Farm Hands
description: A proposal to ease the hiring of foreigners at harvest time is clouding prospects for Congressional approval of a spending bill for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments.

title: France Blocks Coke's Bid For Orangina
description: The Coca-Cola Company's plan to take control of a leading French soft drink brand was blocked yesterday after the French Government rejected the acquisition, saying it would hurt consumers and give Coke too much dominance in the French market.

title: Mexico Promises Full Inquiry Into Tainted Elite Drug Unit
description: Mexico's Attorney General promised today to conduct a ''profound'' investigation into possible corruption of an elite American-trained police unit and insisted that antidrug cooperation with the United States should continue without interruption.

title: Testaverde Works Hard As Foley Nurses Injury
description: In the convoluted or is it Machiavellian? -- way that Bill Parcells often keeps people off balance, he said today that he would not know until Sunday morning whether Glenn Foley or Vinny Testaverde would start against the Colts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, CARL
description: KEMPNER-Carl. On behalf of the board of directors, professional advisory board, and staff of the National Center for Learning Disabilities (NCLD), we mourn the passing of our longtime board member and dear friend. Carl Kempner served on the board of directors of NCLD since its founding 21 years ago as the Foundation for Children with Learning Disabilities. His wisdom, commitment, & leadership as our former treasurer contributed enormously to the growth of our organization and we will miss him. We extend our condolences to Carl Kempner's family; his wife Doris; his mother Margaret Loeb Kempner; his brothers; and his children. Anne Ford, Chairman of the Board National Center for Learning Disabilities

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDE, JAY M.
description: LINDE-Jay M. September 15, 1998. Loving husband of Rosalie (nee Schlesing). Dear brother of Lee Spar. Very caring uncle to Franklin and Jeffrey Spar, Lisa Ziske & their respective families. Concerned cousin to Dr. Natalie Greenman. Graveside services at Old Mt. Carmel, corner of Cypress Avenue and Cypress Hills Street in Glendale, New York, on Sunday, September 20 at 11 AM.

title: Another Wallace Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Real Estate; A 48-Story Tower for a Low-Rise Neighborhood
description: A luxury rental apartment building that will be a commanding presence in its low-rise East Side neighborhood is now under construction and will eventually rise 48 stories above the pavement at 10 East 29th Street.

title: Political Briefing; Track Gets Slippery For Supposed Shoo-In
description: For months, the political presumption in South Carolina was that Gov. David Beasley would easily be re-elected. All he had to do win a second term, the reasoning went, was ride the strong Christian-right Republican tide that has been sweeping across the state throughout the 1990's.

title: Newcomers to Town Win 7 of 10 Committee Seats
description: A group of residents in the Ulster County town of Rosendale who had been stymied in their efforts to bring in rock concerts and experimental theater won election to 7 seats and tied for one other on the town's 10-member Democratic Committee in Tuesday's election.

title: A Not-So-Fond Cheerio to Hong Kong
description: EAST AND WEST

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, CAROL ELAINE.
description: HOCHBERG-Carol Elaine. Age 40. On Sept. 16, 1998 of breast cancer. She leaves her loving family, parents Herbert and Audrey Hochberg; sisters Brenda & Judith; their husbands David Dalgarno & Michael Mattis; grandmother Lea Hochberg, nieces & nephews and a warm circle of caring friends. She set an example of love and strength for those around her. Services will be at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, September 18, at 11:15 AM. Visitation at 7 Stonehouse Road, Scarsdale, NY, September 18, 4-8 PM and September 19, 2-7:30 PM and at 176 East 71st, Apt. 4E, NYC from noon to 6 PM, September 20. Donations in her memory may be made to SHARE, 1501 Broadway, Suite 1720, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Palestinian Youth Shot Dead As Jewish Settler Opens Fire
description: A Palestinian teen-ager was killed and another was wounded today in the West Bank when a Jewish settler fired at a group of Palestinian youths.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of the House & Home section yesterday about the revival of the 1960's typographical ornament known as a dingbat misspelled the name of a type designer and calligrapher. He is Hermann Zapf, not Herman Zaps.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Miles Coolidge

title: Corrections
description: An obituary headline on Wednesday about a Cuban comrade of Che Guevara misspelled the comrade's surname. He was Antonio Nunez Jimenez, not Nunes.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Betye Saar

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, SAMUEL
description: SCHECHTER-Samuel. The Mount Sinai Children's Center Foundation extends heartfelt condolences to our Board Members, Caryl and Israel Englander on the passing of Caryl's beloved father.

title: Too Long to Wait at the U.N.
description: Charges of mixing official and private business have held up President Clinton's nomination of Richard Holbrooke to be the chief United States representative at the United Nations. That would be a serious offense, but the merit of the charges has yet to be established. Formal State and Justice Department investigations are now under way.

title: M.R.I. Firm to Expand
description: HealthCare Imaging Services Inc. has agreed to buy five diagnostic imaging centers in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania for about $21 million in cash and stock to build its imaging business and expand into physician practice management.

title: Hundley Delivers Value And Power in a Pinch
description: Mike Piazza and Todd Hundley may never become ''the best catching tandem in the history of baseball.'' That was the line General Manager Steve Phillips used in jest when he said in mid-May that he was not interested in obtaining Piazza because the Mets already had Hundley on his way back from elbow surgery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADOOLMAN LYONS, JULIA.
description: NADOOLMAN LYONS-Julia. Age 40. Died Monday. She was born July 13, 1958 in Manhattan, New York. A certified public accountant, she was a 14 year resident of North Las Vegas. She is survived by her husband Keith of North Las Vegas, parents Jesse and Beatrice Nadoolman of New York City, and sister Joanna Nadoolman of Kerhonkson, NY. Memorial services will be 3:30PM Tuesday in Bunkers Eden Vale Mortuary. Memorial donations can be made to the American Heart Association or Vietnam Veterans of America, Chapter 17, Las Vegas, NV 89030.

title: Amid Falls in Profit, 5% of Hong Kong Is Jobless
description: Hong Kong's government reported today that unemployment rose to 5 percent of the labor force in August -- the highest level in 15 years -- from 4.8 percent in July.

title: In Democrat-Friendly Boston, Clinton Still Faces Harsh Words
description: Even here in one of the most Democratic states in the country and one of the most liberal cities, President Clinton has been unable to escape withering criticism for his sexual affair with a former White House intern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNOLDS, WILLIAM L.
description: REYNOLDS-William L. September 14, 1998. Devoted husband of Margaret Buck. Survived by his daughter Constance Bierkan and his granddaughters Elizabeth Welker and Laura Welker. Brother of Newlin Reynolds. Service on Friday, September 18, 1998, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 3
description: Game of the Week

title: Out of the Limelight, Griffey Hits His 53d
description: MARINERS 8, ATHLETICS 0

title: Resign or Not to Resign? Question That Weighs on Editorial Writers
description: Jane R. Eisner, the editorial page editor of The Philadelphia Inquirer, knew the jagged contours of the debate before it started. Long before the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report, it was clear that some colleagues believed, passionately, that President Clinton's deceit made him unfit to remain in office. An equal number felt just as passionately that his resignation now would weaken the nation's most cherished institutions.

title: Bergen Brunswig Purchase
description: The Bergen Brunswig Corporation, the third-largest wholesale-drug company in the United States, agreed today to acquire closely held Ransdell Surgical Inc. for an undisclosed price to expand its sales of medical and surgical products. Ransdell Surgical is based in Louisville, Ky.; it had revenue of $58 million last year.

title: Grunge Gets Religion, and It's Not Pretty
description: Grunge isn't dead: it just got religion. Creed, a band from Tallahassee, Fla., used the grunge basics when it played at Roseland on Tuesday night. Its singer, Scott Stapp, belted in a tormented baritone with his T-shirt hanging over his blue jeans; the band trudged through moody drones and then blasted power chords. But where old grunge bands used moodiness and muscle to suggest an agonized doubt, Creed answers its songs' troubles with certainty. ''We all live under the reign of the one king,'' Mr. Stapp sang, cuing the crowd to sing along. Other songs made it clear that the one king is Jesus.

title: INSIDE
description: Russia May Print Rubles

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the Manhattan District Attorney's prosecution of insider trading cases referred incompletely to a New York court ruling on state laws that apply. Besides endorsing prosecution under the general business laws, which include the Martin Act, the court found the penal law applicable.

title: Another Wallace Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Spending Takes a Break; Asia Crisis and Overcapacity Threaten Pillar of Growth
