description: Having just built one new factory and expanded another, the Chrysler Corporation is cutting back on capital investment. AT&T has also shaved its capital spending, but for a different reason: It purchased an existing phone network, rather than spending the money to build a new one. And Motorola Inc., its sales hurt by the Asian crisis, is postponing investments in new factories and machinery, even going so far as to halt construction of a huge $3 billion semiconductor plant in Virginia.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN REBOUNDS. Japan's currency snapped a three-day slide against the dollar, reflecting concern that Latin American economic weakness could hurt the United States. In New York, the dollar fell to 132.18 yen from 134.90.

title: Centennial Swing: Let the Drums Roll Out, Let the Trumpets Blare
description: Here is a listing of events in New York City in celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of George Gershwin:

title: A Daughter's Life of Reflected Glory and Pain
description: THE mother of Charles A. Lindbergh, his biographers have noted, was one of those omnipresent moms: Separated from Lindbergh's father when Lindbergh was 2, she accompanied her son to college, and hovered so close to him that at 25 the man who would be the world's most famous aviator had never had a date.

title: When the Intern Has the Power; Thackeray's Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the Venator Group to close 570 Kinney and Footquarters stores misstated their line of business. Kinney and Foot quarters sell shoes and sneakers, not athletic footwear.

title: 3 Teen-Agers Arrested In Ex-Policeman's Killing
description: Three teen-agers described as drifters were arrested yesterday in the investigation of the slaying of a former New York City police officer who was found strangled in a Sayreville motel room Monday afternoon, county prosecutors said.

title: Russia's New Leaders Plan to Pay Debt by Printing Money
description: Russia's new Communist-influenced Government indicated today that it plans to satisfy old debts and bail out old friends by printing billions of new rubles, a decision that drew a swift and strong reaction from President Boris N. Yeltsin's old capitalist allies.

title: Spanish Leaders Wary of Basque Rebels' Cease-Fire Declaration
description: The conservative Government and the opposition Socialist Party both reacted cautiously today to the first ''indefinite'' cease-fire announced by the Basque guerrilla group E.T.A. in its 30-year battle for an independent homeland.

title: House Panel Approves Republicans' $80 Billion Tax Cut Plan
description: The House Ways and Means Committee passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today, setting up a confrontation with President Clinton over how the nation should take advantage of its return to fiscal health.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LALL, ARTHUR
description: LALL-Arthur. The Fund for New Priorities in America mourns the passing of valued friend and member Arthur Lall on September 13, 1998 and extends our sympathy to his wife Betty and his family. A memorial service for the former Ambassador from India to the United Nations will be held on October 7 at 12:30 PM, UN Chapel, 777 UN Plaza.

title: Sosa Gets Routine 0-fer; Cubs Get Thrilling Victory
description: Millimeters. That's how close Sammy Sosa came to taking sole possession of the major league home run lead. And that's the difference between long home runs and routine fly balls.

title: $1 Billion Bombers? What Is Yanks' Value?
description: When Alfred Lerner bought the Cleveland Browns for $530 million last week, it was a record price for a sports team. A day later, Rupert Murdoch trumped Lerner by agreeing to pay $1 billion for the Manchester United soccer team.

title: Gingrich Dodges Spotlight, He Is in Charge
description: At a news conference on education legislation, the first question put to Speaker Newt Gingrich this morning involved the White House scandal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANAVI, MINA
description: ANAVI-Mina. September 16, 1998. Beloved wife of Albert. Devoted mother of Delia and Yasmine. Adored grandmother of Jake and Max. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Saturday, September 19th, 1998, 2-5PM. Funeral private.

title: New York Schools Are Already Policed; Legal Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANGSAM, EUGENE A.
description: LANGSAM-Eugene A. Adored and devoted husband to Myra. Cherished and loving father to his children, Nathania and Jennifer and David Kopelman. A compassionate and loyal man, ''Gene'' was a mentor to his family and friends. He touched the lives of all those who knew him. The family thanks all of our friends for their support during this very difficult time. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island, 12:30 P.M., Friday.

title: City's Jobless Rate Shrinks to 7.3%, Lowest Since 1990
description: With the booming economy creating more jobs than at any time since the 1950's, New York City's unemployment rate tumbled to 7.3 percent in August from 9.3 percent a year ago, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: Reynold Johnson, 92, Pioneer In Computer Hard Disk Drives
description: Reynold B. Johnson, a prolific inventor best known for creating the world's first commercial computer disk drive, died on Tuesday in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 92.

title: Iran Shuts Popular Newspaper That Questioned Hard Line on Taliban and Arrests Top Editors
description: In a new setback for political moderates, Iran has closed a leading daily newspaper and arrested its top editors for publishing articles deemed detrimental ''to the country's national interests and security.''

title: Rapid Transit Fast Becoming An Oxymoron
description: IF you ride the subway every day, the following will not come as a news flash: the trains move more slowly than they used to.

title: Ruling Gives Foster Parents Greater Rights
description: Some foster parents and children have the same constitutionally protected rights to their relationship as birth parents when the authorities try to remove children from a home, a Federal judge ruled in a decision released yesterday.

title: Kicks, Swivels and Wisecracks on Hollywood Boulevard
description: In the set of funny outtakes that end the Jackie Chan vehicle ''Rush Hour,'' Mr. Chan is seen delighting in the way Chris Tucker, who appears with him in this kick-happy buddy film, messes up his one line of Chinese dialogue. Ha! Now somebody else knows how it feels. Mr. Chan's own struggle with the language barrier has made him not only the current author least likely to have written his own English autobiography (''I am Jackie Chan'') but also a relatively silent partner in this film. Fortunately, being the Buster Keaton of martial arts, he makes a doleful expression and comedic physical grace take the place of small talk.

title: Dark Secrets Of Suburbia
description: Shortly after he finished the film ''Happiness'' Todd Solondz, its writer-director, got an unlisted telephone number for his New York apartment. ''I am nervous,'' the 38-year-old filmmaker said quietly. ''The film is unsettling. It's disturbing. There are crazy people out there. There are people who may have a strong reaction to it.''

title: Fearful Serb Is Journeying Almost Home In Bosnia
description: Not knowing what else to do, the elderly Bosnian Serb widow just sat down on a rock beside a green stagnant pool, in the middle of a field less than a mile from the home that once was hers.

title: New York Schools Are Already Policed; Forced to Volunteer
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunmen Kill 3 Families In Mexico Over Drugs
description: Gunmen dressed in black and carrying assault rifles pulled three families from their homes early this morning and shot at least 20 men, women and children against a wall in what the police described as a drug-related slaying.

title: New Restaurants
description: With autumn around the corner, it's an appropriate time to look back on this year's bumper harvest of new restaurants. Here are 11 of them. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: 2 New Suspects Linked by U.S. To Terror Case
description: Federal authorities charged yesterday that the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya last month was orchestrated by an Islamic extremist from the island nation of Comoros who reported directly to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile who is now the focus of the worldwide inquiry.

title: When Suspect Is Spiritual Guide; Rabbi's Arrest in Wife's Killing Is a Trial for the Faithful
description: Nearly four years have passed since Rabbi Fred J. Neulander returned from temple one autumn evening to find his wife bludgeoned to death in their Colonial home here. Yet the more time that passes, the more Rabbi Neulander seems to embody a wrenching test of faith for the 900 families who worship at the Congregation M'kor Shalom, the synagogue he founded more than 20 years ago.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: X-CEED INC., New York, a provider of corporate travel services and data to the health care industry, acquired the privately held Zabit & Associates Inc., Sausalito, Calif., an integrated communications company, for $28.2 million in cash and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSTER, SYBIL NEE PUTTERMAN.
description: RUSTER-Sybil nee Putterman. Beloved wife of the late Leon ''Rusty Ruster''. Loving mother of P.J. of Hollywood Fla and Richard ''Rusty Ruster'' of NYC. Grandmother of Evan Ruster. Graveside service Sunday 12:30 p.m. at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing NY.

title: House Faulted For Releasing All of Report
description: While most Americans approve of the way Congress is doing its job over all, they disagree with the decision of last week to release all of the independent counsel's main report, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Tikkanen Has Shot At First-Line Job
description: Esa Tikkanen, who has been without a contract all summer, has a chance to win a job on the Rangers' first line. In camp as a free-agent tryout, he practiced yesterday in Burlington, Vt., on Wayne Gretzky's left wing and is likely to get at least one audition there this weekend when the Rangers open their exhibition season with two games against Carolina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNIN, SUE DIANE.
description: BUNIN-Sue Diane. Beloved mother of Amy Eller, dear sister of Robert Goldberg, loving daughter of the late Sylvia and Sidney Goldberg. Funeral service 11:30 A.M. Friday at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Gynecology/Oncology Research Fund of New York University, C/O Dr. James Speyer, 160 East 32 St, NYC 10016.

title: Time for Central Bank Action
description: With the world economy growing at the slowest pace in decades -- and many countries in recession -- only the countries that are growing the fastest are in a good position to help the world economy before the problems engulf us all. But there is a great reluctance to act.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: B.C. OPEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C., 77. Redding, CT. On September 16. Survivors include his wife Elisabeth C., two sons David C. of Denver, CO and Henry C. of Bedford, NY, two daughters Sarah Dudley Plimpton, of NY and Jane Dudley of Seattle, Washington, & ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Please, no flowers, but if desired, contributions in his memory may be made to The Salvation Army, Highstead Foundation, PO Box 1097, Redding, CT 06875, or St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, DAVID E.
description: MORGAN-David E. September 17, 1998. Of Palm Beach and New York. Devoted companion of Sarita Server. Loving father of Leslie Solmonson, Alexandra Ciardi, Fern Lindsay & Nicholas Morgan. Cherished grandfather of twelve. Service Sunday, September 20, 1998, 10 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. He was a graduate of MIT in 1939. A respected geological engineer, he retired as the President of Peerless Precision Products in 1978, and was the Chairman of David E. Morgan Energy, Inc. He had also served as a Director of the Board of BancBoston-Florida and as a Trustee for Exodus House of New York.

title: In Self-Evaluation, Giuliani Finds Plenty to Crow About
description: Continuing one of his favorite traditions, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani produced a stack of charts yesterday that suggested the city is ever safer, its streets ever cleaner and its citizens ever healthier under his leadership.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Jayashree Chakravarty

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't have to live next to a white family. I effectively have integrated. I've gone to predominantly white schools. I work in a white firm, and I can live anywhere I want. It really is psychologically soothing for me to be in Harlem.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOTZEN, MARVIN S.
description: KOTZEN-Marvin S. Of Larchmont, NY on September 16, 1998. Dearest husband and companion of Lynn (Andrews), wonderful father to Ellen and Jeff Spokes and Debby Kotzen, beloved grandfather of Joshua and Toby Spokes. He died as he lived, with dignity and without complaint. Funeral will be Friday, September 18 at 2 PM at Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, contributions would be appreciated to Beth Emeth Synagogue, 2111 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont 10538 or the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation, 237 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains 10605 or a charity of your choice.

title: A Tenement Testament Laughs in the Shadows
description: Che, a gorgeous young revolutionary with a cell phone, is always being interrupted by calls from his mother. Graham, a truly talented actor and acting coach, is constantly being horrified by students who know nothing (''Have you ever done any Chekhov? Ibsen? Strindberg? O'Neill? Williams? Sam Shepard? Mamet? Neil Simon? Have you heard of these guys?''). Frankie, a determined but incompetent crook, tries to pull off a jewel heist but is persuaded to stop and deliver a baby. Lu Lu is a young virgin from China who is willing to marry just about anybody for a green card. Betty is a single white vegetarian who talks to teddy bears and screams a lot during sex. She appears to be a therapy patient but turns out to be the therapist. There are others.

title: Senators Plagued By Another Injury
description: Daniel Alfredsson, a right wing for the Ottawa Senators, is expected to be out eight weeks after tearing the medial collateral ligament in his left knee, the team said. The injury occurred during a training-camp scrimmage on Wednesday.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, CELIA
description: SCHWARZ-Celia. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to Amy Hirsch on the loss of her mother. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: A Merchant-Ivory Stroll Along a Young Life
description: ''I'm a writer's daughter,'' the young heroine of ''A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries'' finally insists, though her father, a World War II veteran, has always repeated the title phrase in times of trouble. ''It's okay then,'' he assures her. ''They cry all the time.''

title: Carpenter Remains A Fixture at 35
description: Five years ago, Bob Carpenter came into the Devils' training camp on a tryout basis, but he remains one of the team's key players, especially if Petr Sykora fails to sign a contract.

title: Man Accused of Attack Based on Race Gets Help
description: Ending a three-month effort to defend himself in his retrial for attempted murder, a Queens man accused of a racially motivated attack outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub asked for a court-appointed lawyer yesterday.

title: Home Video; Fall Zombies And Ghosts
description: Autumn sounds a klaxon in video circles: holidays, gifts, a raft of low-priced titles. In an era when videos of big action films and other so-called adult titles sometimes sell as well as they rent, this year's selection of movies-to-buy moves far afield from the fare parents traditionally scoop up for the littlest ones to watch over and over. How grown-up they are depends on one's definition, but this fall movies like ''The X-Files,'' ''Armageddon,'' ''Godzilla'' and ''The Mask of Zorro'' will all be officially priced from $15 to $23.

title: Police Add Patrols in Brooklyn After Clashes With Mourners
description: A day after a bottle-throwing melee in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, police officers were out in force last night to prevent a repetition of the violence, which erupted outside a local funeral home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, EDWARD G.
description: CLARK-Edward G. Age 74. Died suddenly on September 15th, at Saltaire, Fire Island. He was a former reporter and editor for the Associated Press. His longtime companion Suzanne Sames and his many, many friends in New York, Green Valley, AZ, and Madison, WI., treasured his wit and devoted friendship, and he will never be replaced in our hearts. Survived by his brother Robert and 11 nieces and nephews in Madison, WI. Funeral Mass and burial Monday, September 21 in Madison

title: A Woman Of Two Voices
description: The English pop-jazz contralto Cleo Laine has had to cope with an artistic crossroads that many singers would love to be facing. As the protegee, wife, and creative partner of the English clarinetist, saxophonist and band leader John Dankworth, she has developed a following as a jazz singer specializing in precision coloratura sound effects. When liberated from Mr. Dankworth's fussy notions of jazz singing she has also established herself as a gifted theatrical interpreter. Her 1988 album, ''Cleo Sings Sondheim'' (RCA), is a near-masterpiece of intense, refreshingly unornamented dramatic singing.

title: SMALL COLLEGE REPORT
description: COLUMBIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOT, ''WIN'' IRWIN.
description: ELLIOT-''Win'' Irwin. Age 83 of Westport and Weston, CT, died peacefully at Norwalk Hospital on Thursday, September 17, 1998. Born in Chelsea, MA, he was a graduate of Everett High School & the University of Michigan, '37. He served with the U.S. Maritime Service 1939-1941. During a 50 year career as a nationally recognized radio and television emcee, he broadcast virtually every major sporting event from boxing to New York Ranger Hockey. He is best known for his 18 year award winning broadcasts of Sports Central USA on the CBS Radio Network, horse racing's Triple Crown, Football's Superbowl & baseball's World Series. However when asked, he wished to be remembered as a ''Great Dad.'' He is survived by his wife of 47 years Rita Elliot of Weston, CT; four daughters, Sue Elliot-Bearce, Marilyn McDonough, Patti Elliot & Kathy Cobb; 5 sons, Richard Elliot, Peter Elliot, Michael Elliot, Robert Elliot and Douglas Elliot, one brother; Biff Elliot and seventeen grandchildren. He was predeceased by his youngest son, Chuck and brother Stanley Shalek. All he has touched are invited to call at Shaughnessey Funeral Home, 50 Reef Road, Fairfield, CT., on Sunday, September 20, 1998 from 48pm. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Luke's Church, Turkey Hill Road, Westport, CT on Monday at 10:00 AM. In lieu of flowers it would be appreciated if donations were made in his memory to: The Chuck Elliot Memorial Award at The Staples Tuition Grants Committee, 70 North Avenue, Westport, CT. 06880.

title: BASEBALL: Wild Card and Wild Games; It's Anybody's Race as Mets and Cubs Battle, Fields Apart, Down the Stretch
description: Bruce Bochy had to contend with Sammy Sosa the past four days, but the San Diego Padres manager had to admit that the Mets had his attention, too.

title: Inside Art; The Hermitage Gets Some Help
description: The State Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg is so beloved in this country that a group called the American Friends of the Hermitage is presenting the museum's director, Mikhail B. Piotrovsky, with a $100,000 gift when he comes to New York next week for the opening of ''Master Drawings From the Hermitage and Pushkin Museums,'' at the Morgan Library.

title: New Minister Joins Clinton's 2 Counselors
description: The Rev. J. Philip Wogaman, a Methodist pastor and Christian ethicist from Washington, is the third minister who will privately counsel President Clinton as part of a newly formed pastoral ''accountability group,'' said the Rev. Tony Campolo, a member of the group.

title: 7-Up Previews Super Bowl Ad Campaign For Its Bottlers
description: Seeking a fresher, younger image for the 7-Up soft drink, Dr Pepper/Seven Up Inc. unveiled a series of new television commercials today that will begin during the Super Bowl in January.

title: Blessings Of a City Beside The Sea
description: This is a hard city to squeeze into a sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RASMINSKY, DR. LOUIS.
description: RASMINSKY-Dr. Louis. Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a long time friend, former Governor of the Bank of Canada, and the first Canadian to receive an honorary degree from YU. He also served as honorary national chairman of YU's Bora Laskin Memorial Scholarship Fund. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Michael and Lola, daughter-in-law Judy, & to his grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Philippine Airlines Says It Will End Service
description: Philippine Airlines, Asia's first national flag carrier, said today that it would cease operations because of heavy losses. Years of labor turbulence, including a breakdown in an agreement with its largest union this week, led to the decision to close the 57-year-old carrier, it said. The closing of the airline is to take effect next Wednesday.

title: Family Fare; A Three-Ring Extravaganza
description: It may not be the greatest show on earth, but it is surely one of the greatest shows in Brooklyn. And city children are invited to star.

title: Stocks Resume Fall In a Global Selloff
description: Stock prices slumped around the world yesterday after overseas investors digested word from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that central banks were not planning a coordinated cut in interest rates to quell financial and economic turmoil in Asia, Latin America and Russia.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, LESLY
description: STERN-Lesly. To our beloved Lesly, your courage and strength will forever inspire us. The wonderful memories of our friendship and love will be in our hearts always. We will miss you. Cheryl and Ernie

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS 4.9 PERCENT. Prices for raw sugar plunged on rising exports from Brazil and weakening demand in Russia, the leading sugar importer. The October-delivery contract dropped 0.36 cent, to 6.95 cents a pound.

title: ROYAL AHOLD SAYS IT HAS FOUND BUYERS FOR 10 U.S. STORES
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the largest food retailer in the Netherlands, said yesterday that it had found buyers for 10 stores in the United States, meeting a Federal Trade Commission demand and bringing it one step closer to its planned $2.7 billion acquisition of Giant Food Inc., based in Landover, Md. F.T.C. staff members indicated that they would accept the sales agreements, Ahold said. Six of the stores are operated by Giant Food, and four others are Martin's stores operated by Giant Food Stores Inc., which Ahold acquired in 1981. All 10 are in Maryland and Pennsylvania. Ahold said it was optimistic that the move would lead to F.T.C. approval for its purchase.

title: Site of Earlier Scandal Frets Over Faded Luster
description: The 55-year-old President had intimate encounters with a 24-year-old campaign volunteer in a cloak closet off the Oval Office.

title: A Lyricist's Riposte to Red-Baiting
description: It's easy to envision the puckish lyricist E. Y. Harburg, whose sublime contributions ranged from ''Over the Rainbow'' to ''Lydia, the Tattooed Lady,'' snorting in delight over ''Flahooley,'' the iconoclastic 1951 musical he wrote with his ''Finian's Rainbow'' partner, Fred Saidy, and the composer Sammy Fain.

title: Serious Crimes Dip in Schools, but Total Incidents Rise
description: Assaults, robberies and other serious offenses reported in New York City schools declined slightly last year, but the total number of incidents from the most serious to the mundane showed a sharp increase, according to school officials, who attributed the rise to better reporting of incidents.

description: If and when the House of Representatives releases President Clinton's grand jury testimony on videotape, much of the nation will be able to see all four hours of it almost immediately.

title: Travelers and Citicorp Plan To Cut Jobs
description: In the first of what is expected to be major layoffs at financial companies, Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. -- which plan to merge into Citigroup Inc. -- confirmed yesterday that they would eliminate several thousand jobs, many in New York City.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Stephen Hendee

title: Treasury Prices Stage a Rally As Investors Seek Safe Havens
description: Treasury bond prices rallied yesterday as investors sold stocks and sought the safety of United States Government securities.

title: Sports of The Times; Islanders' Fans Taking Wild Ride
description: JUST when you thought you had seen every possible outrage for sports fans, along comes a new one. The Islanders moved their offices off Long Island and into New York City the other day, on the brink of the new training season. Involved in a dispute that is either about the safety of Nassau Coliseum or about how much money can be wrung out of this faded franchise, the new management is also threatening to seek other sites in the three-state region for regular-season games.

title: Pearle Vision Places Account in Review
description: McCann-Erickson New York and Pearle Vision Inc. in Dallas, the unit of the Cole National Corporation that operates the Pearle Vision Centers retail chain, have agreed to part ways on the Pearle Vision advertising and marketing account, effective at the end of the year. As a result, the account, with billings estimated at $15 million to $25 million, has been placed in review.

title: The Best Tip of All: Get a Different Job
description: It is 6 A.M. and 20 degrees below zero on a late December morning in the Windy City, and an unidentified cab driver (Paul Dillon) picks up his day's first passengers, a middle-class couple and their squirming young daughter who are on their way to church. Within minutes of entering his vehicle, the husband and wife begin prating about Jesus and pressuring the driver to worship with them. After nastily ordering their little girl to say how old she was when she was ''saved,'' the hostile child mumbles, ''4.''

title: Europe Turns Up Heat In Quest for Solheim Cup
description: Talking about the pressure of the Solheim Cup, which begins Friday morning, Laura Davies admitted she was nervous.

title: Nike's Profit Down by 35% in First Quarter
description: Nike Inc.'s fiscal first-quarter profits dropped 35 percent, the company announced today. Nike, the world's top seller of athletic footwear, attributed the decline to sluggish sales in Asia.

title: On the Day After, the Yankees Humor Mr. Torre
description: A handful of players checked on Joe Torre in his office this afternoon, under supposedly innocent pretenses. Tino Martinez dropped off some cigars, Derek Jeter grinned his funny grin and called his manager Mr. Torre, and Paul O'Neill stopped to say hi.

title: Junius Kellogg Is Dead at 71; Refused Bribe in 50's Scandal
description: Junius Kellogg, the Manhattan College player whose refusal to accept a bribe to fix the score of a 1951 game touched off the widest betting scandal in basketball history, died Wednesday in the Kingsbridge Veterans Affairs Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 71.

description: The issues raised by Kenneth Starr's report to the House Judiciary Committee are not legal but judgmental and value-related. That does not mean, however, that they cannot be dealt with rationally.

description: Former President Jimmy Carter, saying the credibility of the United States is on the line over the attack on a pharmaceutical factory in the Sudan that the Clinton Administration said was making an ingredient for nerve gas, called today for a technical investigation.

title: Spending Announced For European Network
description: Deutsche Telekom A.G. and France Telecom S.A. said yesterday that they planned to spend ''less than'' 1 billion marks ($594.1 million) to create a pan-European network capable of carrying high-speed data transmissions.

title: Clinton, Nixon and What It Means to Obstruct
description: Though many people take seriously Kenneth Starr's claim that President Clinton lied in depositions and before the grand jury about his sexual relationships with Monica Lewinsky, many lawyers who have publicly evaluated the Starr report do not take seriously his argument that the President obstructed justice. Certainly the President's own lawyers reject it. The law, they contend, requires that the obstructer be shown to have behaved ''corruptly'' in his efforts to influence a pending judicial proceeding.

description: In what could be the first step in removing car pool lanes from New Jersey's highways, the Senate Transportation Committee approved a bill yesterday that would force transportation officials to study some of the lanes.

description: Christy & Viener, a Manhattan law firm of about 70 lawyers, is merging with Salans Hertzfeld & Heilbronn, a European law firm, in the first trans-Atlantic law firm merger.

description: The nonpartisan, dignified review of the Monica Lewinsky case promised by Congressional leaders last week has quickly descended into political acrimony and the pursuit of tangential matters. The squabbling does not augur well for the hard work that lies ahead as the House considers whether to initiate impeachment proceedings.

title: Finding Poetry In Life's Details
description: Walker Evans might be called the Jackson Pollock of American photography. He took strands of American and European culture, discarded what he didn't want and braided the rest into an indelibly American art. His multifaceted achievement is examined in a small but thorough survey that opens on Sunday at the International Center of Photography.

title: The Man Who Moves, and Scares, Markets
description: When Alan Greenspan talks, the market listens. And most of the time it doesn't like what it hears.

title: VLASIC FOODS SAYS IT WILL SELL TWO BUSINESSES IN EUROPE
description: Vlasic Foods International said yesterday that it would sell its Kattus gourmet foods distribution business in Germany and its frozen baked goods plant in Britain and concentrate on its Vlasic and Swanson brands. The company, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., said it was negotiating with several parties to sell Kattus, which distributes gourmet specialty foods to German grocery chains. Kattus has 285 employees and has annual sales of about $70 million. Vlasic will also sell its plant in Peterlee, in northeast England, which makes fruit pies, desserts and doughnuts, to Hibernia Foods, a British food manufacturer, for an undisclosed amount. The Peterlee plant employs about 150.

title: Capturing the Extraordinary in Ordinary Days
description: ''Nearly all of my ideas happened in a very short time: those first two years,'' the photographer Harry Callahan, now 86, said in a 1977 interview, talking about the period of 1941 to 1943. ''I just keep going back to the same things. Some things work when I go back to them and some things don't.''

title: PARTISAN QUARREL IN PANEL DEBATING CLINTON VIDEOTAPE
description: Abandoning any pretense of bipartisanship, the House Judiciary Committee spent today wrangling over whether to release immediately a videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the Monica Lewinsky case and discussing how to edit reams of pages delivered by the Whitewater independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report yesterday about the suspensions of three Atlantic City police officers misstated the circumstances. The officers, Thomas DiLorenzo, William Warner and Keith Ferguson, have been relieved of duty while prosecutors investigate whether they used excessive force in breaking up a disturbance between security guards and a casino patron at the Trump Marina resort. They were not involved in a Sept. 8 incident at another hotel, the Trump Plaza, that resulted in the death of a patron, Hue Q. To. The authorities said no police officers were involved in that case.

title: The Murder Is One Mystery In a Tale of Cuba Revisited
description: A woman is murdered on the Havana waterfront just before the action of ''They Still Mambo in Havana'' begins. The search for the killer provides a loose framework for a series of encounters between Cubans and Cuban exiles visiting from Miami and New York that allow the playwright, Rogelio Martinez, to direct some pointed ridicule at the attitudes of both groups. But the search follows false leads and turns up no credible suspect, and that outcome is a telling comment on the play itself.

title: In Cincinnati, the President Makes a Most Abnormal Visit
description: On the surface, it was a perfectly normal Presidential visit, with all the symbols of power on display.

title: Clinton Panel on Race Urges Variety of Modest Measures
description: After 15 months of work, President Clinton's advisory board on race relations has produced a modest report whose chief recommendation is the creation of a permanent Presidential council on race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, STANLEY
description: KLEIN-Stanley. The directors, offices and employees of Encore Marketing International, Inc. mourn the death of our director, counselor and good friend, Stanley Klein, who perished on SwissAir Flight 111. Stanley's intelligence, love of life, good heart and generosity were and will continue to be a model for us all. Our deepest sympathy is extended to his wife Carol, his sons Abraham & Allen, his father Harry and his brother Stephen. No one can replace him in our hearts.

title: Reports of Anti-Gay Crimes Increase by 81 Percent
description: Reports of bias crimes against gay men and lesbians have risen 81 percent this year, the police said yesterday, even as overall crime has dropped sharply and other types of bias attacks have fallen slightly.

title: Assemblyman Asks State To Control City Schools
description: Prompted by recent corruption charges involving the Asbury Park Board of Education, a state assemblyman called on state officials yesterday to seize control of the city schools.

title: Judge Tells Islanders To Honor Arena Pact
description: A state court judge late this afternoon told the Islanders to honor their contract with Nassau County and to play all their exhibition and home games at the Nassau County Coliseum, despite a contention by the team's owners that the arena was unsafe.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: A Knack for Playing George and Martha, and Bad Timing
description: When Carol enters her childhood home, angry and having broken a window to get in, you half expect her to declare ''What a dump!'' When she and her brother Tom begin to trade insults in a well-worn routine of sibling hatred, there's more than a little George and Martha in them. ''The Weatherbox'' is no ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' but there are echoes.

title: Giants Plan to Bear Down, Aikman or No Aikman
description: The Giants have tried this week not to look past the absence of the injured Troy Aikman or to dismiss the skills of Jason Garrett. But saying that you respect Dallas's backup quarterback as much as its All-Pro passer and actually believing it can be hard to do.

title: The King of Madison Square Garden
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation, which owns the New York Knicks and the Rangers, has made George Steinbrenner an unprecedented offer. Sell us the Yankees, Cablevision has reportedly told him, and you can run all three teams.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Keep On Partying

title: Officials Try to Keep Region's Markets Open : U.S. Faces an Asian Wall
description: SEOUL  As the United States reported Thursday that its trade deficit had widened sharply again, its trade officials encountered a wall of resistance to American efforts to pry open key Asian markets, officials reported.

title: Of a Happening That Really Wasn't
description: What happened at the Roxy on Tuesday night was not a ''happening,'' at least not the kind staged by Al Hansen, the late Fluxus movement pioneer. He once wrote that his free-floating art events offered a chance ''to take part in spontaneous creation, constant opportunity to make choices.''

title: SEMPRA TO SELL A POWER PLANT TO PORT OF SAN DIEGO
description: The Sempra Energy Company, parent of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, agreed yesterday to sell a 693-megawatt power plant to the Port of San Diego for $112 million in cash. Sempra will also give the San Diego Unified Port District almost 200 acres around the plant, allowing the utility to take a tax deduction of about $50 million. The port said the state was requiring it to run the plant for 5 to 10 years. The port then plans to shut the plant down and convert the land into a shopping, recreation and entertainment area.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIER, MICHAEL
description: CURRIER-Michael. The Board of Trustees, on behalf of the entire Putney School community, deeply mourns the death of our friend and colleague Michael Currier. A Putney graduate, class of '79, and an active and long-time Trustee, Michael personified with passion and grace the values of the Putney School. We shall remember him with affection and gratitude, and we extend our most heartfelt condolences to his wife Karin and his family. Sarah Kerlin Gray, Board Chair Brian Morgan, Director

title: A Gift Evening Unravels, as Franco Pulls the String
description: The Mets will tease you with dramatic finishes against all odds, and make you feel like nothing is out of their reach, not the wild card, not even the World Series.

title: Beliefs
description: On Oct. 16, 1978, 20 years ago next month, Karol Cardinal Wojtyla, the Archbishop of Cracow, became Pope John Paul II. Evaluations of his event-studded pontificate -- already one of the longest in the history of the Roman Catholic Church -- and of his remarkable personality will soon be sprouting left and right (and no doubt reflecting different predispositions, left and right). Such evaluations will obviously require political insight, knowledge about Catholic teaching and a good deal of nuance.

title: Russia to Pump Huge Ruble Reserve Into Banks
description: In the latest example of a leaky ship bailing out sinking boats, the Russian central bank said today that the country's insolvent banks could use about $1.65 billion in precious ruble reserves to enable them to make good on customers' bills and debts that are going unpaid.

title: Ever More People, Ever Fewer Fish; Freedom for Butterflies?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, CAMILLA SEWALL EDGE
description: LEE-Camilla Sewall Edge, 74, of Elm St. and Small Point, Maine died Wednesday, Sept. 16, at the Mid Coast Hospital in Brunswick, Maine of respiratory failure. She was born in Ventnor, New Jersey, October 25, 1923, a daughter of the Hon. Walter E. Edge and Camilla Sewall Edge. Her father served as U.S. Senator and Governor of New Jersey as well as Ambassador to France. On her maternal side she was the great granddaughter of ship builder Arthur Sewall of Bath, Maine who was the vice presidental nominee of William Jennings Bryan. Camilla graduated from St. Timothy's School in Cattonville, MD. and attended Sarah Lawrence College. In 1944 she married E. Brooke Lee Jr. of Silver Spring, Maryland; a decendant of Richard Henry Lee. She inspired devotion from her large family & her many close friends. She will be remembered as a person of enormous character, humor, and dignity. She worked as a volunteer for the American Red Cross & conducted fundraising for the Maine Maritime Museum, as well as the American Cancer Society. She is survived by her six children, Camilla Lee Alexander, E. Brooke Lee III, Kaiulani Sewall Lee, Katie Blair Lee St. John, Richard Henry Lee, and Elizabeth Ashe Somerville Lee; fourteen grandchildren; and one great grandson. A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M. today at the Phippsburg Center Congregational Church. Memorial contributions may be made to Phippsburg Fire and Rescue Service, C/O James Totman, 27 Bog Lane, Phippsburg, Maine 04562. For further information the Demers-Desmond Funeral Home, 34 Cushing Street, Brunswick.

description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Her Big Trip To the State Of Serenity
description: A LOOKOUT posted outside Melvin Mister's house gave the doorbell two urgent rings, prompting him to scramble from the parlor to the sidewalk. He got outside in time to see his wife, Joan, drive up in her silver Volvo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHBERG, FRANCINE NEE SCHAMROTH.
description: HIRSHBERG - Francine nee Schamroth. On Friday, September 18. Loving and caring wife of Irwin and mother of Karen and Gary Hediger, William, Lesley and Craig Miller, and devoted and loving grandmother of Eric, Carl, Erin, Janine & Dana. Beloved daughter of the late Isidore and Regina Shamroth. Born in Antwerp, Belgium & came to New York in 1939. Graduated the Walden School and the University of Pennsylvania. Of complications of a spinal injury. Funeral at Wein and Wein, 129 Engle St., Englewood, New Jersey at 2 PM on Sunday, September 20. Family and friends will be received at the home of Francine and Irwin after the services and during the week.

title: British Petroleum Planning 'Firm' Cuts in Emissions
description: Setting a figure for the first time on its planned reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the British Petroleum Company announced today a ''firm overall target'' to cut emissions by 10 percent of their 1990 levels by 2010.

title: A Race Gets Rough in a New York Minute
description: To listen to Charles E. Schumer during these last 72 hours, Alfonse M. D'Amato is a liar: an untrustworthy, out-of-touch, Republican relic who is soft on crime and a promoter of higher taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHEL, PAULINE
description: FISCHEL-Pauline. Beloved wife of Edward. Cherished mother of Robert and Janet. Loving motherin-law of Shelley and of Russ Whitehurst. Devoted sister of Ethel, and sister-in-law of the late Alfred Raphael. Also cherished sister-in-law to Daniel and Maxine and the late Leon and Elaine. Dear grandmother of Joseph, Owen, Eliana, and Adam. Before retiring, she was a dedicated psychiatric social worker. Her guidance and caring lives on in her clients, friends, and family. Funeral service Sunday, September 20, 9:30AM, at I.J. Morris, Inc, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New Israel Fund or HIAS would be appreciated.

title: Summer of Trouble Still Doesn't Furrow Consumers' Brows
description: The financial and political blows of recent weeks have yet to shake Americans' basic faith in the United States economy or their own finances -- good news for the seven-and-a-half-year-old expansion and for the President.

description: SAX-Harry. On 9/17/98. Beloved husband of the late Anne. Devoted father of Carol (Tom) Neuman, Nancy (Steve) Dashefsky. Dear brother of the late Joseph Sax, Abraham Sax, Clara Weinberger (Sax) and Sarah Sacks (Sax). Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Jill, Lindsay and Kim. Loving uncle of many nieces and nephews. A genuinely wonderful man who was loved by everyone who knew him. Graveside services Sunday, 12:30PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Westwood, NJ.

title: In New Hampshire, Gore Looks More Presidential
description: Visits to New Hampshire have always been de rigueur for Presidential candidates, and Vice President Al Gore has made his share. Today, on his third trip to the state this year, he visited a health care seminar in Keene and a computer company here in Nashua.

The boy's status has not been released for privacy concerns; his doctor, Dr. Max Coppes, did not say he died.

title: Caste Hate, and Murder, Outlast Indian Reforms
