title: Man Admits to Killing 2 People During Robbery
description: A Camden man admitted yesterday in Federal court to killing two teen-age shoppers during a botched attempt to rob an armored car guard at the Deptford Mall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEADOW, CYRIL Z.
description: MEADOW-Cyril Z. Of New York City and Dummerston, Vermont, died on Friday, September 18, 1998 in Dummerston, Vermont. Mr. Meadow was 71 years old. He is survived by his wife Phyllis of New York City; his daughter Dena Reed of Brookline, MA.; and grandchildren Rebecca, Amanda and Zachary Reed of Brookline, MA; his sister Florence Bredhoff of New York City; his nieces Stacy Bredhoff of Washington, D.C. and Susan Cohen of Brookline, MA. A graveside service will be held at 3PM on Saturday, September 19, 1998 on his farm in Dummerston, VT. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies in New York City or the Boston Graduate School of Psychoanalysis in Brookline, MA. Center for Modern Psychoanalytic Studies

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, HELEN
description: ALTMAN - Helen. Board of Trustees of the Joseph Bulova School mourns the passing of the mother of our board Chair, Mrs. Joy Henshel, mother-in-law and grandmother to members Harry and Dayle Henshel. We extend our deepest sympathy to the entire Henshel family. Board of Trustees Joseph Bulova School

title: Ever More People, Ever Fewer Fish; Dredging Is a Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDREN, ANNE M.
description: CONDREN-Anne M., 93. Of Gristmill Lane, Plandome Mills, NY. On September 18, 1998. Wife of the late Edward I. Mother of William J., Professor Edward I., and Carol Carroll. Grandmother of Sloan Castleman, Sean, Ellen Crowley, Hillary, Colin, Elizabeth, Jennifer, and Mathew Carroll. Great-grandmother of Jack Crowley. Sister of the late Edna McKeever. Aunt of the late Rev. Paul E. McKeever & Sr. Edna McKeever. Mrs. Condren taught for many years in the New York City Public School System, mainly at PS 131 in Jamaica Estates, Queens, where she lived prior to moving to Plandome Mills in 1968, shortly after the death of her husband. A woman of great intelligence and character, she was the conscience and motivator of her family for four generations. There will be a wake on Sunday, September 20 at Fairchilds Sons, Inc. Funeral Home at 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset from 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's Church, Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Monday September 21 at 11:30 AM. Interment in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: Wayward Revelations of a Loner Reveling in Song
description: The centenary concert of Ernst Bacon's music at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday proved the truth for this composer of Thomas Carlyle's saying that ''All deep things are song.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C., 77. Redding, CT. On September 16. Survivors include his wife Elisabeth C., two sons David C. of Denver, CO and Henry C. of Bedford, NY, two daughters Sarah Dudley Plimpton, of NY and Jane Dudley of Seattle, Washington, & ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Please, no flowers, but if desired, contributions in his memory may be made to The Salvation Army, Highstead Foundation, PO Box 1097, Redding, CT 06875, or St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, New York 11724.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, THOMAS J.
description: MURPHY-Thomas J. The Newspaper Guild of New York mourns the passing of Thomas J. Murphy who served as Executive Vice President of our union from 1948 through 1970. His immense accomplishments will forever be remembered by our members. Barry F. Lipton, President Newspaper Guild of New York

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHBERG, CAROL
description: HOCHBERG-Carol. Carol was our friend and colleague for many years. Her courage is an inspiration to us all. She will be greatly missed. Arthur Rebell Mark Shapiro

title: In Tug-of-War Over a Toddler, a Cry of Politics
description: It sounds like a typical child welfare dispute: The foster parents who have reared a 2 1/2-year-old boy almost since birth want to adopt him. The boy's mother, who lost him because of addiction but has since stopped using drugs, wants him back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIFETZ, ELAINE FOX
description: HEIFETZ-Elaine Fox, on September 16, 1998, after a long illness. She is survived by her husband, Simon, and her daughter, Jeanne, both of NYC; and two brothers, Steve Fox of Los Angeles, CA, and Robert Fox of Fernandina Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at 1:30PM on October 4, 1998 at the Community Church of New York, 40 E. 35th St., New York, NY.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN EDGES DOWN. Japan's currency gave back some of its recent gains during a selloff of yen contracts. In New York, the yen traded at 132.60 to the dollar, compared with 132.18 on Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLOGG, JUNIUS
description: KELLOGG-Junius. The NYC Consortium for Independent Living is deeply saddened by the death of Junius Kellogg. As President of the Harlem Independent Living Center & in so many other capacities, he graced our lives with his kindness, wisdom, & vision. Junius Kellogg was a champion of equal opportunity for people with disabilities, the personification of dignity and integrity, and will always be a role model for us all. Our sincere condolences to his family.

title: Diabetes and Soda
description: To the Editor:

title: Punishing Americorps
description: Americorps is one of President Clinton's pet projects and thus a tempting target for Congressional Republicans looking for ways to humiliate Mr. Clinton and gain a bargaining chip in budget negotiations with the weakened White House. But G.O.P. lawmakers risk looking shabby if they persist in playing politics with the future of this worthy, four-year-old volunteer program.

title: Service Workers Union Re-elects President
description: Gus Bevona has been re-elected president of Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, the powerful local representing more than 55,000 cleaners, elevator operators and doormen in New York City's residential and office buildings, union officials announced yesterday.

title: A Pianist's Big Intentions
description: Sometimes music doesn't declare its intentions well, and the pianist Hank Jones's concert at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, part of Jazz at Lincoln Center, was at first unclear. Using a 32-piece orchestra of string and brass, along with a jazz rhythm section and Jazz at Lincoln Center's artistic director Wynton Marsalis on trumpet, Mr. Jones played two long halves of a concert made up mostly of his music.

title: De La Hoya Gets His Wish, as Chavez Concedes
description: Oscar De La Hoya came here tonight for respect. He wanted respect, finally, from Julio Cesar Chavez, perhaps the greatest fighter in Mexico's history.

title: PANEL SCHEDULES A MONDAY RELEASE OF CLINTON VIDEO
description: Giving a sharp partisan cast to deliberations over impeachment, the Republican-controlled House Judiciary Committee voted along party lines today to release the videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony, along with 2,800 pages of documents from the inquiry into his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: The Power Bar Is Raised
description: For the most part, the Milwaukee Brewers had been smart this season when facing Mark McGwire. They had pitched him low, high, inside, outside, whatever was necessary to avoid being bashed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLOW, MURRAY
description: MASLOW-Murray. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Devoted father of Richard, Mary Beth (Jeffrey) Davidson and Ilene (James) Robbins. Loving grandfather of Jessica, Leslie, Greg, Spencer and Jordanne. Services Temple Sharey Tefilo-Israel, 432 Scotland Rd., S. Orange, N.J., Sunday, 10 A.M. For info, Bernheim Apter Goldsticker, Maplewood, N.J., 1800-938-6372.

title: Rising Sales Lift Earnings at Nestle
description: Nestle S.A. said yesterday that its profit rose by 7.4 percent in the first half of 1998, buoyed by strong food sales in North America and lower commodity prices. Nestle, the world's biggest food company, said its first-half earnings rose to 2.029 billion Swiss francs ($1.46 billion) from 1.890 billion francs a year earlier. Sales rose by 5.6 percent, to 35.315 billion francs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBIN, DR. PAUL.
description: EBIN-Dr. Paul. Beloved son of Eva and Leonard Ebin. Father of Naomi, Menachem, Shimon, Rachel, Ilana, Yosef, Yehuda, Moshe and Shoshana. Brother of Jane Tuvia, Susan Thalheim and Amy Landesberg. Dear uncle, teacher and friend.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MONROE, SYLVIA (FOXTOW)
description: MONROE-Sylvia (Foxtow) My Lovely War Bride-How we danced with love lights in our eyes on the 55th year we were wed, under a star-lit sky. Love, Harol

title: Race Advisory Panel Gives Report to Clinton
description: President Clinton today focused his attention on an area where he has displayed comfort, as well as intellectual and political surefootedness: race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTELL, MATTHEW E.
description: MANTELL-Matthew E., 56, Barrytown, NY, Thursday, September 17, 1998. Son of the late Louis Stoloff and Lilian Mantell. Brother of Phyllis M. Klein. Funeral services will be held at 10:30AM, Sunday at Rokeby, River Road, Barrytown. Burial will be in New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York on Wednesday at 1 PM. For information call Burnett Rockefeller and Hand Funeral Home, 30 South Broadway, Red Hook, New York 914-758-5042.

title: Observer; The Great Media Meltdown
description: Later, in one of those comically solemn conclaves at which journalists ponder the philosophy of their trade and eat high on the expense account, the news industry will struggle to understand the Great Media Meltdown of 1998.

title: Living Your Politics, Not Fussing Over It
description: Anyone who cares to know about Hootie and the Blowfish is aware that the band honed its talents playing cover versions in fraternity houses in the South. This past was often excavated to denigrate the hit-makers, as if their early willingness to play what others wanted to hear proved not just a lack of originality but even a rejection of it. In a cover-studded set at Roseland on Wednesday night, scattering selections by KISS, Stone Temple Pilots, Tom Waits and Led Zeppelin among its own sing-alongs, Hootie and the Blowfish proudly displayed its belief in mainstream, and that proved to be the best thing about the group.

title: Lawyers Say Mega-Mansion In Hamptons Is Merely a Home
description: A man's home may be his castle, but lawyers and the public spent hours tonight debating whether the castle-size complex being built by Ira Rennert really is his home -- as defined by local zoning law -- or is actually a hotel, conference center or religious school in disguise.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina referred incorrectly to the office held by Alija Izetbegovic. He is one of the three members of the country's presidency, not the president of the Muslim-Croat Federation, a constituent part of Bosnia that is led by a prime minister.

title: U.S. Dismayed at Apparent Victory of Hard-Line Bosnian Serb
description: Clinton Administration officials said today that they were dismayed by projections that a hard-line nationalist would be the new president of the Bosnian Serbs, an outcome that would threaten to undo American efforts to reintegrate Bosnian Serbs, Croats and Muslims into a single nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, GEORGE EDWARD.
description: WOLF-George Edward. On September 16, 1998, of Great Neck, NY. Husband of Jane Molleson Wolf. Father of Pamela Wolf O'Callaghan. Grandfather of Kate O'Callaghan. Brother of the late Harry and W. Robert Wolf. Visiting in the Doyle B. Shaffer, Inc. Funeral Home, Little Neck Parkway and Northern Boulevard, Little Neck, NY on Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services are in the Little Neck Community Church on Monday at 11 AM. Interment in All Saints Cemetery, Great Neck, New York.

title: VORNADO REALTY TO SPIN OFF $100 MILLION UNIT
description: Vornado Realty Trust said yesterday that it would spin off a $100 million unit that will hold its non-real estate businesses on Oct. 16 to shareholders of record on Oct. 9. The unit, called the Vornado Operating Company, will be responsible for managing Vornado's cold storage business, trade show operations and its Hotel Pennsylvania in New York. The spinoff was necessary for Vornado to comply with rules governing real estate investment trusts. As a REIT, Vornado is exempt from corporate income taxes if it distributes at least 95 percent of net income to shareholders as a dividend. It must also generate at least 75 percent of its revenue from rents and mortgage interest. Shareholders of Vornado, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., will receive one share in the new company for every 20 shares owned.

title: Buyback by Estee Lauder
description: The Estee Lauder Companies said yesterday that it would buy back as many as four million class A common shares, or about 3.4 percent of its common stock outstanding, as it seeks to increase returns to shareholders. The cosmetics maker, which had $3.62 billion in revenue for the year ended on June 30, said the shares would be used for general purposes, including employee stock options. The shares rose $3.9375, to $54.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Running With the Alpacas?; A Modern-Day Golden Fleece at $5,000 a Head and Up
description: As an afternoon thunderstorm splashed their pasture, a small herd of alpacas trotted toward shelter under the overhanging roof of a nearby barn.

title: INSIDE
description: Union Ousts Longtime Chief

title: In Internet Age, Not Even President Has Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: BID FOR CELADON GROUP IS REPORTED STALLED
description: Celadon Group Inc., a trucking company based in Indianapolis, said yesterday that Odyssey Investment Partners Fund L.P., which is supposed to buy the company, had been told it was not getting the $125 million in bridge financing it needed to complete the transaction. In a statement, Celadon said the Bankers Trust Corporation notified had Odyssey that it was not obligated to provide the financing under current market conditions. But Bankers Trust said its commitment letter had not been terminated. If the conditions for financing are satisfied by Nov. 30, it will provide the money. Odyssey does not have to complete the merger if it cannot get the financing.

title: Some Welfare Rules Set Back Reforms
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Town and the Big Top; After Months of Traveling, Circus Settles in New Home
description: ''Here's the town the circus came to, when it came to town,'' said Darren Hernandez, the Village Manager of this postage stamp-size community straddling the Wallkill River in the Hudson Valley.

title: RESORTQUEST SET TO ACQUIRE ABBOTT RESORTS
description: Resortquest International Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Abbott Resorts Inc. for $34 million in cash and stock, plus assumed debt. In the deal, Resortquest will pay 80 percent of the purchase price in cash and 20 percent in stock. Abbott Resorts, based in Destin, Fla., is a property management and realty company active along Florida's Gulf Coast. It had revenue of $28.8 million in the year ended July 31. Resortquest, based in Memphis, provides vacation condominium and home rentals in resorts in the United States. It had revenue of $33.9 million in the six months ended June 30. The addition of Abbott's 2,400 rentals represents a 22 percent increase in Resortquest's property management and rental portfolio of roughly 11,000 vacation properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, EDWARD J.
description: DORAN-Edward J. Reposing at Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway, Bronx on Sunday 25PM and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10AM at St. Elizabeth's Church, 268 Wadsworth Ave. & 187th Street, NYC. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx.

title: JAPANESE PARTIES HAMMER OUT DEAL ON AIDING ECONOMY
description: Ending weeks of bitter deadlock, Japan's governing party said it had reached a landmark agreement tonight with the political opposition that could lay the groundwork for revamping the nation's teetering financial system and reviving the recessionary economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOROCHNICK, ROSE (HYMOWITZ)
description: MOROCHNICK-Rose (Hymowitz), of Riverdale, NY on Sept. 18, 1998. Beloved wife of the late William. Devoted Mother of Wilma & Norman Michaels, Iris and Ronald Maitland. Loving grandmother of Sheri and David, Stephanie and James, Pamela & Derek, Lori and Russell. Cherished great-grandmother of Amy, Jacqueline, Althea & Nina. Services Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York, Sunday at 10 AM. For more information please call ''Wien & Wien'' Englewood, NJ, 1-800-322-0533.

title: How the West Was Won, and Lost
description: While the American West has always held a special fascination for the public, scholars have often been immune to its pull. After World War II, many academics abandoned the subject and a number of universities stopped offering courses on it, assuming that this rural past was irrelevant to the modern world. But in recent years the history of the American West has once again captured historians' imagination. And next month will bring the publication of a new scholarly companion to those spaghetti westerns: The New Encyclopedia of the American West. Edited by Howard R. Lamar, the dean of historians of the West, this 1,320-page reference book (Yale University Press) was written with the help of 600 historians.

title: The Rural Life; Cattle Drive at Sunrise
description: The days shorten, the morning chill intensifies, and all across the Rockies cattle have been driven down from the high country. Recently a party of ranchers on horseback gathered before dawn at the mouth of a canyon along Clark's Fork of the Yellowstone River to drive 193 yearling steers and one Corriente bull down the highway to a set of corrals -- a trip of 13 miles -- where they would be weighed, given a clean bill of health and trucked to feedlots in Kansas. The night before, some of the cattle had moved down the highway on their own, only to follow the wind back up into the canyon in early morning. The herd was footsore.

title: Derailment in Bronx Delays Thousands
description: A double-decker car on a Conrail freight train slammed into a railway overpass in the Bronx early yesterday, causing a derailment that severely disrupted service on the Hudson line of the Metro-North commuter railway for much of the day and left thousands of commuters scrambling to get to work.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the singer, pianist and composer Diamanda Galas misstated the surname of the artistic director of a future collaborator, the Kronos Quartet. He is David Harrington, not Harrison.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FRUEHAUF TRAILER CORP., -- Indianapolis, a maker of truck trailers and parts, said it would distribute about $18 million in securities to secured bondholders and liquidate its remaining assets as part of a bankruptcy reorganization plan.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about three former executives found guilty of price fixing referred incorrectly in some copies to the full name of their company and the middle initial of one defendant. It is the Archer Daniels Midland Company, not Corporation; he is Terrance S. Wilson, not W.

title: S.E.C. HALTS AN INQUIRY ON ICN STOCK TRADING
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has dropped a three-year inquiry into accusations of insider trading by ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. and its chief executive, Milan Panic. But the S.E.C. will start an enforcement action against the company and Mr. Panic for failing to disclose adverse information about its viral drug, ribavirin, ICN said yesterday. The S.E.C. had investigated accusations that Mr. Panic sold $1.24 million of ICN stock in 1994 after he and ICN learned that the Government would not approve the sale of ribavirin as a stand-alone treatment for the liver ailment hepatitis C. The S.E.C. contended that the news was not disclosed to other shareholders. ICN, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., sells pharmaceuticals and biotechnology products.

title: George Danielson, 83; Urged Nixon's Removal
description: George E. Danielson, a California Congressman who urged the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon in 1974, died of heart failure on Sept. 12. He was 83 and lived in Monterey Park, Calif.

title: Baseball's Martyr
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Group Escapes Tax In Area Zoned For Business
description: An order of Roman Catholic priests is entitled to a religious tax exemption on its 265-acre conference and training center here despite town leaders' insistence that the property was ineligible because it was zoned for business only, a state judge has ruled in a decision announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEMPNER, CARL LOEB.
description: KEMPNER-Carl Loeb. Commandeur Carl Loeb Kempner, distinguished member of our august Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin. We shall miss his companionship at our table together with his knowledgeability and keen enjoyment. Our regrets extend to Commandeur Thomas Kempner and to other members of his family. William Zeckendorf, Jr., Grand Senechal de New York Edward H. Benenson, Grand Camerlingue Hon.

title: Success Is Often Short on Third Down
description: After two games, the 1-1 Giants are last in the National Football League in one statistical category: third-down efficiency.

title: In Internet Age, Not Even President Has Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: APACHE IS PLANNING ADDITIONAL ACQUISITIONS
description: The Apache Corporation wants to buy another oil and natural-gas exploration company or another company's fields within the next year while commodity prices are low, its president and chief operating officer, Steven Farris, said in an interview. ''We'd like to increase our size and critical mass in North America,'' Mr. Farris said. Crude oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed at $14.86 a barrel yesterday, almost $5 less than a year ago. An acquisition would resume Apache's strategy of growth through buying properties.

title: Veto Sustained On Bill to Ban Some Abortions
description: For the second time in two years, the Senate today failed to override President Clinton's veto of a ban on a late-term abortion procedure that opponents call partial birth. The vote was 64 to 36, three shy of the two-thirds needed to override.

title: From the Doomed, an Ode to Life And a Warning Not to Insult Death
description: In the 1940's and 50's, through the leadership of some visionary members of its theater and music departments, especially the composer Otto Luening, Columbia University became a center for new opera. Works like ''The Mother of Us All'' by Virgil Thomson and ''The Medium'' by Gian Carlo Menotti received their premieres there.

title: All's Well That Ends Ill
description: Scene: A Blasted Town Called Hope.

title: Jet Crash Divers Confront Deep Perils, and Emotions, in Grim Search
description: All those who have seen it fumble with words that seem inadequate to express the horror of the ocean floor where the wreckage of Swissair Flight 111 came to rest.

title: School Bus Collides With Truck, Injuring 7
description: A school bus and a three-ton dump truck loaded with topsoil collided at a busy intersection here this morning, critically injuring the driver of the bus and one of the six students aboard, the police said.

title: Sosa and Cubs Lack Punch in Loss to Reds
description: When Sammy Sosa and the Chicago Cubs left Wrigley Field last weekend for the West Coast, Sosa had just tied Mark McGwire in their home run race by belting four in the three-game series against Milwaukee, and the Cubs had staged two dramatic come-from-behind victories.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a $25 million gift to Lincoln Center misidentified one unit that will benefit. It is Great Performers, which presents classical music concerts, not ''Great Performances,'' a television series produced by WNET.

title: In Internet Age, Not Even President Has Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Rules Against Islanders
description: A Long Island judge yesterday denied a request by the Islanders to secure dates for home games at arenas other than Nassau Coliseum. Supreme Court Justice Burton Joseph directed the team to follow his ruling on Thursday that ordered the Islanders to play their exhibition and home games at the Coliseum.

title: Judge Sets Tentative Trial Date for Five Policemen in Louima Brutality Case
description: A Federal judge yesterday tentatively set a trial date of March 22 for four New York City police officers charged with brutalizing a Haitian immigrant, Abner Louima, in Brooklyn last year and for a sergeant accused of trying to cover up part of the assault.

title: Led by a Simms, Ramapo Starts Its Season
description: His team is the reigning North Jersey Group 3 champion, but Ramapo High School Coach Mike Miello isn't counting on last year's accomplishments to help him in the new season.

title: Schumer Sees 'Too Many Lies'
description: These are two 15-second commercials that the Schumer campaign began broadcasting Thursday night and yesterday morning.

title: A Mixed Verdict on Texas H.M.O. Law
description: A provision in a new Texas law allowing patients to sue health maintenance organizations and other insurers for malpractice was upheld today by a Federal judge.

title: Man Posing as Inspector Is Said to Bilk Restaurants
description: All points bulletin to restaurateurs: Beware the portly, middle-aged fellow in the greenish suit who flashes a silver badge and photo, identifies himself as an inspector from the New York City Health Department and asks to be paid -- on the spot -- for kitchen violations.

title: To Christians, G.O.P. Urges Punishment And Prayer
description: In the starkest display of contrasting Republican approaches to capitalize on the White House scandal, several speakers at the Christian Coalition's convention here expressed outrage today at President Clinton while others said only that he deserved their prayers.

title: Clinton Likely To Delay Trip To Pakistan And India
description: President Clinton will probably postpone traveling to India and Pakistan because both countries tested nuclear devices in May and have shown little inclination to defuse their arms race, officials with knowledge of plans for the trip said today.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, OSCAR V.
description: LYNCH-Oscar V. Died on Friday, September 18, 1998. Husband of Margaret B. Lynch. Father of Gregory M. Lynch and Kerry S. Lynch. Brother of Kevin Lynch and Alan Lynch. Mass will be celebrated Tuesday 10:30 AM at St. Edward's Church, Clifton Park, NY. Calling hours Monday 4-8 PM at the Gordon C. Emerick Funeral Home, Clifton Park, New York.

title: Managed Care Failure?
description: To the Editor:

title: Again, a World Title Eludes Berkowitz and Cohen at Lille
description: Ask the cognoscenti to name the best partnership that has never won a world title and there would be many votes for David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla. Two weeks ago, at the world championships in Lille, France, it seemed that they were about to lose their claim to this title, for they were leading into the final round of the Societe Generale World Open Pair Championship. But a surge by a little-known Polish pair, Michal Kwiecien and Jacek Pszczola, was successful.

title: Brooklyn Father Arrested After Girl, 9, Drowns
description: The father of a 9-year-old Brooklyn girl was arrested yesterday on suspicion that he drowned his young daughter late Thursday night because she was taking too long washing herself in the bathtub, the police said.

title: In Internet Age, Not Even President Has Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Muddled History of Impeachment
description: A small army of legal scholars is loose upon the land, exploring the origins of the phrase ''high crimes and misdemeanors,'' which sounds so odd to our ears because it links large offenses, like murder or treason, with trivial miscues, like jaywalking.

title: Some Welfare Rules Set Back Reforms; Programs Don't Help
description: To the Editor:

title: COMING SUNDAY: New Features in Money and Business
description: -- Private Sector, a page each Sunday on people in business.

title: Gerold Frank Is Dead at 91; Author of Celebrity Memoirs
description: Gerold Frank, a pioneer of the contemporary literary form of the as-told-to celebrity biography, died on Thursday at the Logan Square East Retirement Community in Philadelphia. He was 91.

title: Sybil Harrington, 89, Supporter Of Opera and Medical Charities
description: Sybil Harrington, a philanthropist from Amarillo, Tex., who besides supporting medical, education and arts charities was the largest individual donor to the Metropolitan Opera in the company's history, died on Thursday in Phoenix, where she kept a winter home. She was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, JOHN J.
description: HOPKINS-John J. Of Mt. Vernon, New York, on September 17, 1998. Husband of Joan Whittington Hopkins. Father of Richard, James, Edward, William, Robert, Eugene and Margaret Burns. Brother of Rose Kelly and Theresa Schwarz. Grandfather of 13. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Saturday and Sunday. Mass of Christian burial, St's. Peter & Paul Church, Fleetwood on Monday, September 21 at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Joseph's Seminary, Yonkers, NY 10704 or Nativity Mission Center, 204 Forsyth Street, New York, New York 10002.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday tracing cutbacks in capital investment misidentified one data source. It was the National Association of Purchasing Management, not Chesapeake Shared Services.

title: D'Amato Paints a 'Liberal'
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the D'Amato campaign began broadcasting on Wednesday.

title: The Change in Ms. Reno's Course
description: Attorney General Janet Reno's recent decision to review the advertising blitz orchestrated by President Clinton during his re-election campaign marks an important if belated turnaround. For two years, Ms. Reno has misread Federal campaign finance laws to justify her refusal to seek investigation by an independent counsel of the ''soft-money'' shenanigans by the President and the Republicans in the 1996 campaign. Her laissez-faire stance protected Mr. Clinton, but eviscerated restrictions on campaign spending and contributions designed to curb the buying of access and influence.

title: Biological Weapons, Literally Older Than Methuselah
description: Maybe it started with Moses. The biblical story of Exodus mentions 10 plagues God inflicted on the Egyptians for the Pharaoh's refusal to free the Jews from slavery: blood, frogs, vermin, flies, murrain, boils, hail, locusts, darkness and the slaying of the first-born.

title: Engineered Babies
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTBALL: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Rangers Divide Squad Into Two
description: As the Rangers broke training camp at the University of Vermont yesterday, they also broke their roster in half.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review and a cast listing on Wednesday for the Pearl Theater Company production of ''Candida'' misidentified the actor playing the role of the Rev. James Mavor Morell. He is Martin Kildare, not Dan Daily; Mr. Daily is to take over the part on Tuesday.

title: Wells Fills Ace's Role; Pettitte Is A Problem
description: David Wells was Manager Joe Torre's conundrum a year ago. With moods and habits Torre could not understand, he dropped Wells to the back of his rotation in the playoffs.

title: Mexico Rancher Tortured Before Mass Killing
description: The 38-year-old rancher who was the target of an apparent drug-related killing here on Thursday was tortured in his own living room before gunmen put him against a wall and shot him along with 18 relatives and neighbors, the authorities said today.

title: Fast Start by U.S. Team Has Europe Up the Creek
description: From today's first match at the Solheim Cup, the United States took command and left Europe playing catch-up.

title: MEDQUIST AGREES TO PURCHASE OF MRC GROUP
description: Medquist Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held MRC Group for $229.5 million in stock to expand its share of the $6.5 billion medical transcription market. Medquist, which had revenue of $84.6 million last year, said it would issue about 8.5 million shares to pay for the purchase. If Medquist's average price falls below $16.28, MRC will receive more shares. The deal was announced after Medquist closed at $27, up 31.25 cents. Medquist, based in Marlton, N.J., began negotiating with MRC this summer when the Cleveland-based MRC announced its plan for an initial public offering. If the purchase receives shareholder and regulatory approval, the combined company will have revenue of about $260 million.

title: Sports of The Times; Wild Card? More Like A Wild Ride
description: THE Mets' clubhouse doors opened yesterday afternoon and the reporters thundering in were greeted with a loud cheer from the players. The cheers weren't for the news media. They were for Reggie Sanders, whose home run had just given Cincinnati a one-run lead over the Chicago Cubs in their game at Wrigley Field.

title: The Day When the Book Is King
description: New York City reasserted its claim to literary pre-eminence yesterday, as tens of thousands of books and several hundred thousand of their devotees thronged onto a half-mile of Fifth Avenue and adjacent blocks for the 10th annual New York Is Book Country street festival. More than 160 publishers and booksellers displayed and sold their wares on the avenue, from 48th to 57th Streets, and four noted authors spoke at a literary brunch at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, DAVID E.
description: MORGAN-David E. September 17, 1998. Of Palm Beach and New York. Devoted companion of Sarita Server. Loving father of Leslie Solmonson, Alexandra Ciardi, Fern Lindsay & Nicholas Morgan. Cherished grandfather of twelve. Service Sunday, September 20, 1998, 10 AM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. He was a graduate of MIT in 1939. A respected geological engineer, he retired as the President of Peerless Precision Products in 1978, and was the Chairman of David E. Morgan Energy, Inc. He had also served as a Director of the Board of BancBoston-Florida and as a Trustee for Exodus House of New York.

title: Jones's Team to Seek Finding of Contempt
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones are planning to add to President Clinton's troubles next week by asking a Federal judge in Little Rock, Ark., to hold him in contempt of court.

title: Kennelly Struggles to Stop Slide In Connecticut Governor's Race
description: United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly held a solidarity lunch today to call attention to the novel presence of four women on the Democrats' statewide ticket, but wound up trying to explain her campaign's steep slide despite an ever-more-aggressive style.

title: Whitman Drops Plans To Change Food Services
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has dropped a plan to privatize food services at several state prisons and psychiatric centers after union leaders agreed to work with the state to cut operating costs at the institutions, state officials said yesterday.

title: Union Chief Is Accused Of Embezzling
description: The longtime president of the local representing 22,000 school cafeteria aides and crossing guards in New York City has been expelled from the union after an internal judicial panel concluded that he illegally received $1.7 million from the union, including $685,000 in fraudulent overtime expenses and $329,000 to pay his family's credit card bills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, SYBIL
description: HARRINGTON-Sybil. It is with profound sadness we mourn the death of Sybil Harrington, devoted member of our official family since 1967 and a Director of our Managing Board since 1980. One of the most generous Patrons in Metropolitan Opera history, in addition to her leadership gift to create the Metropolitan Opera's first endowment fund, Sybil underwrote 16 new Met productions, two gala concerts and 13 ''Metropolitan Opera Presents'' telecasts, including this season's telecasts of ''Samson et Dalila'' and ''La Cenerentola'' and the James Levine 25th Anniversary Gala. Her underwriting support for the current Met productions of ''Don Carlo,'' ''Manon Lescaut,'' ''La Boheme,'' ''Francesca da Rimini,'' ''Die Fledermaus,'' ''Turandot,'' ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Aida,'' ''Don Giovanni,'' ''La Fanciulla del West,'' ''Die Meistersinger von Nuernberg'' and ''Otello'' represent her passionate commitment to traditional productions of the core opera repertory. She took special pleasure in supporting the Met telecasts so that everyone throughout the country could be part of the Met audience. Sybil Harrington's philanthropy has left a legacy that will endure for generations to come. Each season's telecasts and productions supported by that legacy will help us recall with the fondest of memories her devoted love for the Met. The Opera House Auditorium bears Sybil Harrington's name in honor of the singular example she set for philanthropic commitment to the Metropolitan Opera. Metropolitan Opera Association Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear, Chairman Bruce Crawford, President

title: Ever More People, Ever Fewer Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Testaverde Knew This Might Happen
description: For months, Vinny Testaverde has believed that at some point this season he would become the Jets' starting quarterback -- either because of his ability or because of the real possibility that Glenn Foley would be injured. After all, almost a third of the National Football League's 30 starting quarterbacks have already missed some playing time.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL FUTURES SOAR. Oil futures rose sharply as a tropical depression in the Gulf of Mexico threatened to damage or shut down production. In New York,

title: Blacks Stand by a President Who 'Has Been There for Us'
description: While moving about his Congressional district here last weekend, just after the release of Kenneth W. Starr's report, Representative John Lewis was struck by the universality of support for President Clinton that he found among black Atlantans.

title: Excerpts From News Conference by Committee Members About Videotape
description: Following are excerpts from the remarks about the House Judiciary Committee's vote to make public a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. Participating in the news conference were Representatives Henry J. Hyde, the Republican who is the committee chairman; Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts; Asa Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas; Bill McCollum, Republican of Florida, and Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts. The remarks were recorded by Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: Of Mexico, Laughter And Tears
description: Maybe it's a fond backward glance as the end of the century approaches. Maybe it's a symbolic resistance to cultural homogenization. Maybe it's the graying of a generation of rockers. And maybe it's only a matter of musicians seizing a chance to record songs they love.

title: EARNINGS TO FALL BELOW ANALYSTS' ESTIMATES
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, based in Danbury, Conn., said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings would fall below analysts' estimates and as much as 35 percent from the previous three months because of tumbling chemical prices and lower revenue from Asia. Profit at the concern, the nation's seventh-largest chemical company, had been expected to fall to 64 cents a diluted share from 85 cents in the second quarter, or about 25 percent, according to the average estimate of 16 analysts polled by the First Call Corporation.

title: Countdown to Breeders' Cup Pits 20 Horses in 3 Big Races
description: Twenty of the best race horses in the country will gather at Belmont Park today for three races -- the Woodward Stakes, the Ruffian and the Jerome -- in a countdown to the Breeders' Cup that will match contenders against champions. And, in a sequel tomorrow, 11 star 2-year-olds will meet in two Grade I stakes -- the Matron and the Futurity -- that will cast long shadows into next year's Triple Crown.

title: A Palestinian Confronts Time; For Columbia Literary Critic, Cancer Is a Spur to Memory
description: Several years ago, Edward W. Said began writing a memoir mostly about his childhood in Palestine in the years before Israeli independence in 1948, before his family fled to Egypt, before he landed at Columbia University, before he became one of the most influential literary and cultural critics in the world.

title: Portrait of Nijinsky as a Crafty Victim
description: The career of Vaslav Nijinsky was short, a matter of about seven years altogether on the ballet stage early in the 20th century. But the legend of his life has inspired extraordinary attention long after his death in 1950. And one-man shows seem to be increasingly popular. The latest performer to hurl himself at that lemming cliff is Leonard Crofoot, whose ''Nijinsky Speaks'' may be seen for another five weeks at the Harold Clurman Theater at 412 West 42d Street in Clinton.

title: Broker Pleads Guilty in Trading Scheme
description: A brokerage employee who worked on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange pleaded guilty on Wednesday to conspiring with exchange floor brokers to cover up an illegal trading scheme.

title: Swiss Recount Key Drug Role Of Salinas Kin
description: After a nearly three-year inquiry into drug corruption in Mexico, Swiss police investigators have concluded that a brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari played a central role in Mexico's cocaine trade, raking in huge bribes to protect the flow of drugs into the United States.

title: Few Believe That Bean Will Dethrone Holyfield
description: The opponent weighed in at a less-than-svelte 231 on Thursday, 19 more pounds than he weighed for his last unsuccessful title shot. If Vaughn Bean were a puncher, this would be good. But his best attribute is said to be his lateral movement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIFACH, IRA
description: ZWEIFACH-Ira. The directors and members of the France & Colonies Philatelic Society mourn the passing of their longtime director, past president, and devoted program chairman, Ira Zweifach. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Richard M. Stevens, President Walter Parshall, Secretary Board of Directors of the France & Colonies Philatelic Society

title: Clinton Aides Say Taped Testimony Was Crucial Tradeoff
description: President Clinton's lawyers and advisers said today that they were forced to agree to the videotaping of his grand jury appearance last month in order to win other concessions the President wanted from Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel.

title: BELL MICROPRODUCTS IS ADDING ALMO DIVISION
description: The computer-product distributor Bell Microproducts Inc. has agreed to acquire the computer-products division of the Almo Corporation, in a move to bolster Bell's operations in the Eastern United States. Bell said it planned to use a combination of cash and a warrant to buy shares. Terms were not disclosed. Almo, based in Philadelphia, is a closely held value-added reseller. Its computer products division distributes disk drives, monitors, computers and other products to resellers and systems integrators. The division has annual sales of about $146 million. Bell is based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Court Backs Giuliani's Way Of Assigning Workfare Hours
description: A state appeals court has upheld the way New York City calculates the number of hours that welfare recipients must work in its workfare program to receive benefits.

title: Xiaogang Journal; Village of Small Farmers Marks Own Great Leap
description: Shooing away clouds of giant dragonflies, surrounded by lush fields of rice and platoons of clacking ducks, it is hard to imagine the parched and decrepit conditions of this little village 20 years ago that forced many of its residents to become itinerant beggars.

title: Starr Report Selling Well In Book Form
description: In the week since three publishers started selling sober-looking versions of that book -- the 400-plus-page report of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr -- the steamy chronicle of the relationship between President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky is selling at brisker rates than Tom Clancy's new novel about an elite antiterrorist squad.

title: Global Turmoil Leaves Europe Wondering How to Shield Economy
description: As dismal news accumulates around the globe, European economies are proving remarkably resilient. But evidence is multiplying that the Continent's two-year-old recovery is at risk, fueling debate about how to shield Europe from the effects of turmoil elsewhere.

title: Unregulated Dietary Supplements
description: There is mounting evidence that Congress should revisit its ill-advised decision in 1994 to insulate pills and powders sold as ''dietary supplements'' from Federal regulation. The latest warning appears in the New England Journal of Medicine, which on Thursday published six reports of people who had become ill after treating their ailments with remedies from health-food stores.

title: A New Argentine Look at an Anti-Chic Shocker
description: New Yorkers certainly know that Julio Bocca is an extraordinary dancer. As one of the stars of American Ballet Theater, he amazes audiences season after season with his technical brilliance and dramatic flair. But in his native Buenos Aires, he is regarded as a serious ballet director as well as a charismatic performer.

title: Bitter Struggle Behind Closed Doors
description: By midday, the principal legislators at the heart of the crisis left their debating chamber and eagerly strutted toward what threatens to be the dominant forum in their judgment of President Clinton: the television screens of America.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Black people simply are more willing to judge him by his stride than his

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japanese Parties Agree On Economic Strategy

title: UAL President, Pressured by Unions, Quits
description: John A. Edwardson, the president and chief operating officer of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, resigned today because unions at the company would not support his promotion to chief executive next year.

title: Will Germany Deny The Past?
description: With the German election a week away, Gerhard Schroder, the Social Democrat who is favored to defeat Chancellor Helmut Kohl, has been modeling his campaign on Bill Clinton's 1992 strategy of promising economic innovation and generational change.

title: Bond Prices Gain as Stocks Also Post Rise
description: Strange things happened on Wall Street yesterday. Prices of both bonds and stocks rose.

title: Vols' Martin Finding His Own Way
description: Peyton Manning has moved north to Indianapolis and the National Football League, leaving behind a bunch of passing records and a legend big enough that the Tennessee faithful named a street outside of Neyland Stadium in his honor. But one crack remains in Manning's remarkable legacy here, and it may be the opening Tee Martin needs to begin his own bit of road construction.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIBA, MAHMOUD
description: DIBA-Mahmoud. We mourn the sudden and tragic loss of Mahmoud Diba, beloved husband of Layla and father of Ahmad. The families Diba, Soudavar, Khosrowshahi, Khosravani, Hedayat, Afkham-Ebrahim, Zolfaghari, Vossough, Etezadi, Amir Ebrahim are united in grief.

title: Alcatel Considers Plan To Buy Back Shares
description: Seeking to contain the damage done by its warning on Thursday that its profit would not meet forecasts this year, Alcatel S.A. said yesterday that it would consider a significant share buyback program. Alcatel's stock plummeted 38 percent on Thursday after it said its full-year profit would fall short of estimates because slowing demand in Europe was compounding the effect of economic turmoil in Asia and Russia.

title: When Working With Copper Pipe
description: WHEN running water was introduced into American homes, the first pipes were made of lead. They were made by hammering lead sheets around a round form. The seams were melted together to form a watertight seal. Back then, lead was referred to by the Latin word ''plumbum,'' and the man who fashioned and installed the pipes was called a ''plumber.'' The lead pipes were, of course, toxic, and many homeowners died from drinking the water.

title: Language Schools Count More On Bonjour
description: USING pictures, pointing and pantomime, Margarita Gutierrez, an instructor at Berlitz International's language center on Rector Street, recently taught a visitor the Spanish words for ''ballpoint pen,'' ''briefcase'' and ''part-time job.'' But when the subject was computers, she had to violate Berlitz's policy of speaking only Spanish in a Spanish lesson. She used the English word ''Internet'' because it is used everywhere, she said.

title: OPINION; Lifting the Veil on 'English Only'
description: THIS fall, for the second time in three years, the Suffolk County Legislature will be debating the so-called ''English Only'' bill sponsored by Legislator Michael D'Andre, Republican of Smithtown. This resolution calls for Suffolk voters to cast their ballots in November 1999 on an initiative that gives lip service to making English ''the official language of Suffolk County'' while in reality both deceiving and dividing the public.

title: Stephen Foster's Old Hoboken Home
description: At Sixth and Bloomfield Streets in Hoboken is a four-story walk-up, its orange brick shaded by a large maple tree. It's a typical Hoboken row house in every way except for the small plaque next to the buzzer box: ''Stephen Collins Foster, composer of 'Old Folks at Home' and other immortal songs, lived in this house during the year 1854.''

title: After Dispute In Pakistan, Leader Leaves For U.S. Visit
description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif leaves for the United States today and could not have picked a better time for a getaway, with people here feeling he has just tried to eliminate democracy from the Constitution.

title: Cornering the Market on Creeps and Nerds
description: YOU think it's a romp being the world's 44th-funniest person? You spend half your time trying to make up ground on No. 43, and the rest looking over your shoulder at No. 45. Ben Stiller has faced this dilemma since last year, when Entertainment Weekly slotted him at 44 on its top-50 list of waggishness. What if some forgotten comic genius like, say, Aristophanes returns to vogue and pushes him down even lower in the rankings? Or if one of his riffs provokes only muted laughter -- laughter worthy of a 73, say, but not a 44 -- and he's overtaken by his father or his mother or, heaven forfend, his older sister? Seriously, folks: There's nothing funny about being 44th.

title: Proponent of an Ever-Potent Lodestone: Bad Taste
description: TWO of the cast members are small, with elaborate beards, pirate-style bandanas, enough leather to upholster a couch. One has a nose ring and a silver tooth up front. One wears jeans beneath leather pants strategically cut out to show off both his denimed bottom and his front.

title: Asbury Park's Stone Pony Rides Off Into the Sunset
description: The Stone Pony, an Asbury Park landmark for almost 25 years, is closing tonight and will reopen a week later as Vinyl, an adult dance club.

title: A Monument to Mothers and Lost Children
description: TERRY TITCOMB's son Al was murdered on Nov. 22, 1994. Sandy King lost two of her sons to murder, in 1986 and 1991. Both women are natives of Charlestown, a one-square-mile district on the north edge of Boston that has the highest rate of unsolved murders in the metropolitan area. Both are members of Charlestown After Murder, a group of mothers who try to make sense of their collective losses. ''It's not something we're going to get over, or we're going to get through,'' Ms. King said. ''Our lives stopped on the days our kids were murdered. I don't think I've looked forward once in the 12 years since my son was murdered.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Miss Ragnarsson, Mr. Zimmermann
description: Thorunn Lara Ragnarsson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Kristjan T. Ragnarsson of Larchmont, N.Y., was married on Martha's Vineyard yesterday to Benjamin Richard Zimmermann, the son of Barbara S. Smith and Jerry N. Zimmermann, both of Iowa City. The Rev. Thor Hauksson, a Lutheran minister and a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Beach Plum Inn in Chilmark, Mass.

title: The Unbearable Lightness of Being
description: BIRDS OF AMERICA

title: Ms. McManus and Mr. Macrone
description: Katherine Anne McManus and Dominic James Macrone were married yesterday at the Lamoreux Landing Winery in Lodi, N.Y., by Christine Springer, a Town Justice there.

title: Actors Pray: While Many Are Called, Few Are Cast
description: THE SETTING -- The Gothic sanctuary of St. Malachy's/Actors' Chapel on West 49th Street, where 240 worshipers gathered Monday evening to pray for the new season in a service called a ''Broadway blessing.''

title: New Head at Katonah Art Museum
description: THERE are those who create, those who confound and those with the gift to make sense of it all. Susan H. Edwards falls in the third category, an art scholar truly in love with her subject and not too refined to say so.

title: Never Mind the Starbucks. Please Pass the Carafe.
description: In a small dinner-table revolution, Americans are drinking more beer, wine and distilled spirits and less coffee, according to a new study of the nation's eating habits.

title: The Nation: Shadow Play -- Washington's Gears, Grinding; Surprise: Government's Not Necessarily Paralyzed
description: GIVEN the sheer volume of energy expended in weighing President Clinton's fate, given Washington's horrified fascination with every tawdry detail of his behavior, it would be easy to assume that the machinery of government and policy making has ground to a halt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICK, EDNA
description: EICK-Edna. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edna Eick, associated with The Times from 1966, until retiring in 1977.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Butterfly Retirement

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?; Carter's Wish
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Selected to Create Korean War Memorial
description: The sculptor who crafted the central bronze figures for the state's Vietnam Veterans' Memorial in Holmdel has been selected as one of two artists to create New Jersey's Korean War Veterans Memorial at Brighton Park in Atlantic City.

title: Brooke at Nite
description: If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, then Brooke Shields - star of stage, screen and 'Suddenly Susan' - offers her sisters in syndication this valentine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, DR. EVA (LICHTENFELD)
description: BERNSTEIN-Dr. Eva (Lichtenfeld). Sept 17, 1998. Survived by her nephews, Dr. Peter Lichtenfeld of Great Barrington, MA, Yoram Sadeh-Lichtenfeld of Israel; niece, Hanna Dubin of Westchester, NY; Sister-In-Law Leonia Field of NYC; several great nieces & nephews. Wife of the late Werner Bernstein. Dr. Bernstein was one of the first women Dentists in the U.S. and a supporter of the Arts. A memorial service and interment were held in Rochester, NY.

title: Q. & A.
description: A Deed In Lieu of Foreclosure

title: A Furnishings Store Opens A New Site Near Columbia
description: Liberty House, a West Side store since 1968 and currently on Broadway and 88th Street, opened a new store last month at 2878A Broadway, at 112th Street in Columbia University territory.

title: In America
description: A few months ago a guy said to me, ''If the economy is doing so great, how come I'm broke?''

title: Bookshelf
description: WHIRLIGIG. By Paul Fleischman. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 12 and up) This remarkably complex short novel is a contemporary American variation of a classical questing tale. The central character, Brent Bishop, a baffled and young 17-year-old, accepts the task of constructing four whirligigs -- wind toys -- to be named for and featuring a girl named Lea, whose death he accidentally caused. He is further charged with placing them at the corners of the continental United States to bring joy to people who would never meet her. The skilled and confident author is a Newbery medalist.

title: Single by Design
description: Hey Jennifer, where'd you get those pants? They may have come from Single, a Los Angeles-based line of body-conscious sportswear geared toward single women. The clothes have become a hit in wardrobe departments dressing young single women, like Jennifer Aniston's character on ''Friends.'' Debra McGuire, the show's costume designer, bought close to 20 pieces, including tight-fitting pants. ''The pants aren't for Courteney,'' she said, referring to Ms. Aniston's co-star Courteney Cox, ''but I'm going to try them on Jennifer. Jennifer is very thin right now.''

title: Symphony Orchestra's 74th Season
description: SHAKESPEARE said the ''silver-sweet sound by night,'' brings ''softest music to attending ears.'' Those who lend their ears to opening night of the Westchester Symphony Orchestra's 74th season next Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College will encounter two settings of ''Romeo and Juliet,'' the Overture-Fantasia by Tchaikovsky and a suite from Prokofiev's ballet, both conducted by the music director, Anthony Aibel. Then Hilary Hahn, the young violinist who at 18 can already look back on an Avery Fisher Career Grant, a Sony recording contract and appearances with the New York Philharmonic and the Pittsburgh Symphony, plays the Stravinsky Violin Concerto. William Bolcom's ''Commedia for (Almost) 18th-Century Orchestra'' rounds out the program. For a season brochure, call 631-4313.

title: BEST SELLERS: September 20, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Chipping Away at the Myths That Encrust a Blues Legend
description: ALTHOUGH the great blues singer and guitarist Robert Johnson died 60 years ago, swallowed up at 27 by the rural Mississippi demiworld of juke joints and barrelhouses that spawned him, he looms ever larger in America's imagination.

title: Archivists Sought
description: If you are a history buff, County Clerk Leonard N. Spano wants you. He is looking for residents interested in Westchester's history to volunteer for several hours a week this fall. The job entails retrieving and processing materials, researching information, entering data and answering reading room inquiries at the county's archives.

title: Reinventing the Box; Why the PC and the Television Never Shall Meet
description: Riddle: it has a big screen for displaying information and entertainment, speakers for lifelike sound and a thing you hold in your hand to click your way through various content sources. It reminds you to ''tune in often to see our latest updates!'' So which box are we talking about: the one with too many channels and nothing to watch, or the one that says, HTTP/1.1 Server Too Busy?

title: Orioles Will Discuss Ending Ripken's Streak
description: The Baltimore Orioles are on the verge of elimination, and after an extremely disappointing season, they are headed for a period of upheaval.

title: Returning to Normal At Northwest Airlines
description: Air service slowly began returning to isolated parts of the upper Midwest and South last week after pilots at Northwest Airlines ratified a new contract, ending their bitter 15-day strike against the nation's fourth-largest airline. About one quarter of Northwest's 1,700 daily passenger flights resumed on Wednesday; the airline said its full schedule would not be back in the air until Monday.

title: Ms. DiBartolo and Mr. Biasiol
description: Cynthia Denise DiBartolo, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony F. DiBartolo of Todt Hill, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Massimiliano Biasiol, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberto Biasiol of Monte Carlo, Monaco. Mayor Marcel Ardisson of Monte Carlo officiated at a civil ceremony in Monte Carlo's City Hall. Later in the day, Archbishop Joseph M. Sardou, the archbishop of Monaco, performed a Roman Catholic ceremony at Sante Devote Church in Monte Carlo.

title: Turkish Bath
description: To the Editor: Sherry Marker's article ''A Whirl Through Istanbul'' (Aug. 16) brought to mind an incident at a Turkish bath several years ago when my wife and I were visiting Istanbul. Since I had never been to a Turkish bath, I decided to treat myself.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SILVERMAN, ROBERT B.
description: SILVERMAN-Robert B. (7/17/20-9/20/83). Memories of love and devotion never die. Always alive in my heart. Your daughter

title: Amid the Lost Lives, Also a Loss to Art
description: A Canadian official who saw the wreckage of Swissair Flight 111 after it crashed into the ocean Sept. 2, killing all 229 people aboard, said it looked like a pane of glass that had shattered into a million pieces.

title: Bernstein's Gershwin
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YACCARINO, JOE
description: YACCARINO-Joe. 2/5/19-9/20/96. ''Parting is not goodbye. We'll be together again''. Nancy

title: Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Aug. 23 about Tiepolo frescoes in Paris referred incorrectly to the title of Henri III's host in one panel and misstated the location of the scene. Federico Contarini, whom the King was visiting, was not the Doge of Venice and in fact did not have a title. The setting was Mira, not Venice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, EDWARD G.
description: CLARK-Edward G. Age 74. Died suddenly on September 15th, at Saltaire, Fire Island. He was a former reporter and editor for the Associated Press. His longtime companion Suzanne Sames and his many, many friends in New York, Green Valley, AZ, and Madison, WI., treasured his wit and devoted friendship, and he will never be replaced in our hearts. Survived by his brother Robert and 11 nieces and nephews in Madison, WI. Funeral Mass and burial Monday, September 21 in Madison

title: Spreading Global Risk To American Taxpayers
description: AS gyrations in emerging markets -- from Asia to Latin America to Russia -- cause sleepless nights for many investors, one group of politically connected and well-heeled financiers with big bets in these shaky regions can sleep better, thanks to the American taxpayer.

title: New Coat for Debated Tower
description: Overriding months of vehement testimony by Todt Hill residents about a 90-foot radio tower they say is an illegally operated blight on their community, the Board of Standards and Appeals voted last week to grant the business a 10-year special permit for continued operation.

title: Ms. Lippman, Mr. Bettencourt
description: Jessica Marie Lippman, a daughter of Sidney and Thomas W. Lippman of Washington, was married yesterday to Christopher Taylor Bettencourt, a son of Carlin Taylor Eliot and Peter O. Bettencourt, both of Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Robert D. Edmunds performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, on Martha's Vineyard.

title: Buddy System
description: NEVER AT WAR

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: My Favorite Show; David Sedaris on 'Cops'
description: There is an America we envision while reciting the Pledge of Allegiance, and there is the America reflected on ''Cops,'' the half-hour true-crime documentary on Fox. Each week a camera crew accompanies police officers as they make their rounds, different cities every time. We might be in, say, Kansas City, where an elderly man is caught n the back seat of his company car with a middle-aged hooker. The camera observes the broken, humiliated suspect as he phones his wife.

title: Two Towns, Sad Legacy From the Old Ivory Trade
description: IN the last half of the 19th century and the first half of this century, two towns near the mouth of the Connecticut River were famed for an industry that brought them great prosperity. Today that industry would provoke screams of rage from human rights and animal rights activists for the dead bodies, thousands upon thousands of them, human and animal, that the industry left in its wake.

title: A Touch of Clash
description: No color or clash of patterns is too daring for these men, who are annihilating the corporate look. Searing splashes of color are worn for daytime leisure and evening parties. For others, summer pastel suits are giving way to autumnal rust colors. Above, men in a line are wrapped in cat-burglar suits for a film.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, JANET APPEL
description: LEVY-Janet Appel. Devoted wife of the late Herman A. Levy. Beloved mother to Robert and Deborah. Loving grandmother to Alexandra and Robin and loving mother-in-law to Suzanne. Janet will always be remembered for her strength, generosity and warmth. She was also a former president of the East Meadow Hadassah. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, September 20 at Gutterman's in Rockville Centre. Call (516) 764-9400 for time.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: JACOB'S HANDS

title: A Year-Round Tan for the Asking
description: FOR the innocent Long Islander, one of the many hazards of midtown Manhattan is the cast of strange characters who lurk on every city block, distributing free literature. As a spectator sport, it's quite entertaining to watch the dance duets of the touts and the pedestrians who are trying to avoid them. But personally, being a polite suburban person and an avid reader, I find it hard to say no to anything in print. The result is that, within a few blocks, I become a walking scarecrow bulging with scraps of multicolored paper. This makes me a magnet for every other street person with a message.

title: Magnet School, in Suburbia And Aiming for a Profit
description: CONNECTICUT has its first Edison Project school -- a public/ private for-profit partnership run by Edison, aNew York-based company now having almost 50 schools in 25 cities under its direction.

title: Sosa (0 for 4) and Cubs Are Stymied Again
description: For their last homestand of the season, the Chicago Cubs planned a full weekend of festivities to honor Sammy Sosa, culminating in a ceremony before Sunday's game that the Cubs promised would rival the gift-showering in St. Louis on Sept. 8 after Mark McGwire's 62d home run.

title: Megan Liberman, Edward Lewine
description: Margaret Rose Liberman and Edward Lewine were married last evening by Rabbi David Gelfand at the Farmhouse, a restaurant in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Opening 18 Doors To a Glorious Past
description: Hoop-skirted hostesses will welcome visitors into 18 of Natchez's pre-Civil War mansions when the homes open for guided tours during the Natchez Fall Pilgrimage Oct. 2 to 25. The pilgrimage is one of two each year; the spring event in 1999 will be March 10 to April 10, when 31 houses will open for tours.

title: Spellbound
description: Having gone through life with the name Hara Person, I felt compelled to respond to Natalie Angier's On Language column (Aug. 30). We are a family of unusual names. My husband is Yigal (strange here but common in his native Israel), and our children are Liya (different in Hebrew from the biblical Leah) and Yonatan (Hebrew for Jonathan). Unusual, yes; hard to spell, yes. But unusual names and atypical spellings (if they are used for a reason other than pure novelty) can transmit family history, heritage and values, make for great storytelling and create character.

title: Supers Trade Tips and Tales of Woe
description: PERHAPS no other profession touches so many New Yorkers' lives but is as unregulated as that of building superintendent. Many trades have exams and licenses, but the only hint in New York City law that supers even exist is a requirement that buildings with 16 or more units have a janitor on or within 200 feet of the premises 24 hours a day. The law doesn't specify what skills, if any, this individual must have.

title: The Science Police
description: The Baltimore CaseA Trial of Politics, Science, and Character.By Daniel J. Kevles.Illustrated. 509 pp. New York:W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: At Sayville High School, Books and a Breathalyzer
description: SOME schools on Long Island have new computers; others have new courses.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Promise of Justice

title: Lisa Markowitz and Jeffrey Grand
description: Lisa Lynne Markowitz and Jeffrey Scott Grand were married yesterday by Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz at Bridgewaters, a Manhattan caterer.

title: Snakes Are Fine, but Oh Those Toads on Ice
description: FOR some time now, I've been scouring the state for the perfect pet for Abby, the household 1-year-old. Here are some of the things I've learned:

title: Bette Midler Softens the Edges
description: BETTE MIDLER's up-and-down recording career has always been about juggling personas to create a portrait of an entertainer (and woman) of many (often contradictory) parts. And ''Bathhouse Betty,'' her first album for Warner Brothers after more than two decades on Atlantic, is arguably her most multifaceted collection since her 1972 debut recording, ''The Divine Miss M.''

title: GURU: Bill Fischer; Reservationist To the Stars
description: EAGER for an invitation to a private party at Le Cirque 2000?

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'No Boys Allowed'
description: This show takes over where the ''girls only'' hygiene films of junior high school left off, giving young ladies the real truth about what it means to be a woman. Feminist icons will give solid, needed advice -- things they've learned, things they'd like to have known, things that held them back, things that made them great. ''No Boys Allowed,'' a half-hour-long talk show with me as host and taped before a live studio audience, will be on weekdays right after school. Featuring no beauty tips, no bull and definitely no boys, the show will go something like this:

title: Francesca Hunt, Fletcher Jewett
description: Frances Randall Hunt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Pratt Hunt of Washington, was married yesterday to Fletcher Maddox Jewett, a son of Dr. Leslie S. Jewett of Washington and Eugene A. Jewett of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. James L. Ulrich performed the Episcopal ceremony at Little Moose Lodge on Little Moose Lake in Old Forge, N.Y.

title: A Show of Paintings Where East and West Meet in Harmony
description: ROBERT MARTIN'S Blue Hill Plaza here can still be counted on for a full schedule of shows, thanks to the efforts of its art consultant, Carolyn DeLisser. But business is booming in this corporate enclave, and while the exhibition space is as generous as ever there are signs of cost-cutting times -- plastic plants in the lobbies, for example.

title: Yankees Look for a Silver Lining After Cone Loses
description: His voice congested and nasal, David Cone said all week that he was recovering from the flu. Cone treats illness the way he pitches: just find a way to survive.

title: Rebecca Friedman, Adam Lichstein
description: Rebecca Anne Friedman, the daughter of Vivian and Edward Friedman of South Orange, N.J., was married there last evening to Adam Robert Lichstein, the son of Marilyn Lichstein and Dr. Edgar Lichstein of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Helene S. Reps performed the ceremony at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: The Nation
description: TO: Kenneth W. Starr

title: So Long, Ebullience, Hello, Cutbacks
description: Telltale droplets of blood began appearing on the forehead of corporate America.

title: Sports of The Times; The Home Run Seesaw Is Rocking Hard on I-94
description: IT'S always better when there are two, especially when each needs to do more because of the other. It was this way with Ali and Frazier, with Palmer and Nicklaus, with Russell and Chamberlain, with Evert and Navratilova, with Affirmed and Alydar. And now it's this way with Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa.

title: My Favorite Show; Daniel Menaker on 'The Weather Channel'
description: I've seen the Local Forecast three times now, so I'll just mute it for a minute or two. The 24-hour programming on the Weather Channel has a wonderful narcotic effect. Not only is its focus so narrow as to exclude 98 percent of all human excitements, but we've spent an entire evolution trying to insure our safety from the elements. So what could be more soothing than the contemplation of huge climatic events reduced to a pixeled 19-inch image, rendered in cartoon symbols and schematic maps and narrated by preoccupied ''weather hosts,'' as I like to think of them? It's all out there, and I'm in here, before my electronic hearth, in my hi-flr, prewar, 24 hr drmn fullsvce cave.

title: Vacation Is Over for Houseplants, Too
description: Begin preparing houseplants that spent summer outdoors for winter indoors. Move sun lovers to progressively shadier spots outside to ease their transition to significantly reduced indoor light.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOFTNESS, LEONA GOLDEN
description: SOFTNESS-Leona Golden. 66, of Manhattan and Coconut Grove, FL, passed away September 18, 1998. Mrs. Softness is survived by her beloved husband John, to whom she was married 44 years; devoted children Barney (Betsy) Softness, Randy (Michele) Softness, Danny (Ellen) Softness; brothers Jerry Golden, Robert Golden; and adored grandchildren Ben, Melissa, Sara, Kenny, Alex, Nicki and Bailey. Funeral services will be held 11 AM, Sunday, September 20, 1998, in Miami, FL. Donations in memory may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society. For information, contact Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1-800759-1151.

title: Liberties; Power of Attorney
description: It was inevitable, of course, that lawyers would destroy civilization.

title: Melbourne
description: Forged with gold-rush money at the height of the Victorian era, Melbourne is graced with grand public buildings, tree-lined boulevards and decorous parks. While it may be the most British of Australian cities, it also has one of the world's largest Greek cities, a sizable Vietnamese quarter, neighborhood markets that rival those in Paris, and a palm-fringed waterfront akin to Venice Beach, Calif. Decades ago, Italian immigrants brought espresso to its cafes. Today its restaurants are sophisticated and multiethnic, drawing from the rich surrounding farmlands, vineyards and coastal waters.

title: Win Elliot, Who Broadcast Sports With Flair, Dies at 83
description: Win Elliot, whose affable broadcasting style colored his calls of Rangers hockey games and whose sports reports were marked by sophisticated writing, died on Thursday at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 83. The cause of death was not available.

title: POSTINGS: Afterthoughts at New Rochelle Center; Adding Hotel And Offices To Complex
description: Last January construction began on the 400,000-square-foot New Rochelle Center, a retail/entertainment complex in the heart of downtown. Just two months into construction, plans for the center were revised in order to top the center's seven-level parking garage with a four-story extended-stay hotel and an office building.

title: Cadets Rally To Win Debut In a Conference
description: Army began a new chapter in its storied football history today when the Cadets made their debut in the 3-year-old Conference USA.

title: Miss Sullivan And Mr. Carter
description: Margaret Rose Sullivan, a daughter of Thomas V. Sullivan of Stamford, Conn., and the late Sheila E. Sullivan, was married yesterday to Peter Murphy Carter, a son of Florence and Forrest Carter of Eastport, N.Y. Msgr. Roger Watts performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Cecilia in Stamford.

title: Border Crossing; Speaking Double
description: Remember those three ravishing private eyes who always managed to shoot straight, even as they raced across gravel in strappy four-inch sandals? How about that mysterious boss whose calling card was a velvety baritone? Or the lovable go-between who never, ever sneaked a lustful glance at his crime-busting colleagues?

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, JANICE M.
description: FREEMAN-Janice M. Passed away Wednesday, September 16, 1998, after a courageous, dignified battle. One of the early women stockbrokers on Wall Street, who later was Senior Vice President at Manufacturer's Hanover Trust, she was the beloved mother of Douglas S. Freeman II and the cherished sister of Helen M. Dunn & Harold F. Miller, Jr. A memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Ave., (71 St.) NYC, Sun., September 27, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers donations should be sent to The American Cancer Society New York Chapter.

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kosovo's Refugee Emergency
description: A potentially deadly season of cold and starvation is rapidly closing in on Kosovo's Albanian refugees. The Clinton Administration must marshal American diplomatic and military resources to persuade Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, to stop terrorizing Kosovo's ethnic Albanian population. Washington must also help protect and assist those already displaced until they can return to their original homes.

title: When a Rose Is a Rose Is a Rose Indeed
description: WHEN the conductor Edward Strauss strikes up the big Paper Mill pit band for the ''Gypsy'' overture, it isn't too hasty to feel that everything is already coming up roses. Some precious times, it all goes right, from the very start. One of the musical theater's signature orchestrations, as recognizable from its first rocket-like blare as the chords of Beethoven's fifth, is in the best of hands, and there's no doubt that you're in for a real good time.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday in the theater listings for the coming season misspelled the given name of an actress in ''The Old Settler,'' which is to open next month at Primary Stages. She is Lynda Gravatt, not Linda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNIETTI, TINO
description: CUNIETTI-Tino. Died peacefully September 16, 1998. Dear nephew of the late Eleanora Garnett and Luciano Riggio. Much loved father of Eleanora and Jennifer, grandfather to Jack and Isabel.
