description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region/Long Island; For Housing Industry, Growl of the Bears Is Faint
description: ON Sept. 1, the day after the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 512.61 points, Robert L. Muchnick, a Blue Point developer, made purchase offers on three land parcels at what he said were better terms than he would have asked for the week before.

title: Now Is Indeed the Time to Think of Bulbs
description: THE time has come to start thinking about spring-flowering bulbs. One of the most delightful ways to welcome the season is to see a lawn bursting with color from early bulbs, the first, even before the grass, to respond to the returning sun.

title: Specialty Market
description: ALL adaptive equipment for people with disabilities is considered specialty equipment, but within this category are the specialty's specialties. If most automotive adaptive equipment helps people get into and drive vehicles, these devices help make that experience more pleasant.

title: Making Schools A Thriving Environment
description: What should we be doing in the schools to provide safer environments and, at the same time, fulfill our responsibilities in preventing future horror stories [''Dealing with Bullies Before They Can Erupt,'' Sept. 6]? Clearly, the recent school shootings in Arkansas, Pennsylvania and Oregon could happen in New York, and on Long Island. Suburban parents are disturbed by the recognition that these three recent incidents occurred in schools that are very similar to our own, not troubled inner-city schools.

title: 'Porgy' Panned
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mother Speaks
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amato Sees 'Character Assassination'
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato accused his Democratic opponent, Charles E. Schumer, of ''character assassination'' yesterday, asserting that he was running a campaign based on personal attacks and predicting that it would fail by Election Day.

title: McGwire Is Now Chasing Normality
description: In the third inning of tonight's game between the St. Louis Cardinals and Milwaukee Brewers, everything was pointing toward another history-making home run by Mark McGwire.

title: Carried Away
description: I couldn't help smiling through most of Kummer's article, and bought my New York Times with companion purchases of Evian water and Yoplait yogurt, cultural hangovers from trips to France to visit a high-school pen pal. Sadly, the smile disappeared from my face when Kummer told us he used his bare hands to drink water from Panna's source -- without regard for the consequences. Was his ''audacity'' worth the possibility of contamination?

title: LP's to CD's: High Fidelity Madeleines
description: GOING back to the neighborhood of one's youth and finding familiar objects smaller than remembered is an experience shared by most of us. I had the same feeling, not long ago, picking up a CD of Ravel's piano music and finding on its cover the shrunken image of an LP record I knew some 45 years ago.

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?; A President Hounded
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Fighting a Superstore With Wine, Web and Book Club
description: When Barnes & Noble opened in Park Slope last September, the 27-year-old Community Bookstore, 10 blocks away, was empty for the first hour of business. The sales staff looked at one another nervously. Was it the rain? Or was it the end?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARKAN, JOSEPH
description: BARKAN-Joseph. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Survived by present wife Toby. Dear father of Steven and Barbara and daughter-in-law Janice. Cherished brother of Samuel, Elaine Canepa, and Shirley Haken. Adored grandfather of Aron and Risa. Past President of the New York City Board of Education. Vice President of Busch Terminal Lines, and Executive Vice President of Prudential Steamship Lines. Funeral services Sunday 12:45 at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: In Land of Home Rule, An Uncommon Merger
description: In this densely populated town in northern Hudson County, where municipalities bunch up like boxcars in a train wreck, Dan McEldowney would often sit outside Engine Company No. 1, where he works, and watch the fire trucks from adjacent North Bergen barreling by toward fires on that town's eastern end.

title: Sports of The Times; Mets' Old Warrior Survives a Brutal Night
description: THERE were handmade signs around Shea Stadium yesterday, nominating this pitcher or that pitcher as the new closer. John Franco showed up for work angry, and it was not just the traffic on the bridge, either. He was disgusted with himself for blowing a game on Friday night, and he accepted the yowls from the pack.

title: Between Consenting Co-Workers
description: NOT a day has gone by in the last month when I haven't read in the paper, received an E-mail or heard in conversation that any corporate chief executive who was caught having a consensual relationship with a young intern or staff member would be given the heave-ho.

title: A Humbled Yeltsin Is Fading Away
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin made a rare appearance in public last Wednesday evening at a gala concert at Moscow's Conservatory. At least, he was there for the start of a performance by the Russian cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and Seiji Ozawa, the Boston Symphony's conductor.

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?; Censure Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilians Fret as Economic Threat Moves Closer
description: Until recently, it seemed that Augusta Aparecida Pettinari's fortunes and the country's economic reform plan ran on parallel tracks, like twin locomotives taking the young receptionist and the modern currency toward a steadily more promising future.

title: Melissa LaBarre And Thor Thors
description: Melissa Hunt LaBarre, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis W. LaBarre of New York and Cleveland, was married yesterday to Thor Philip Thors, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thor H. Thors Jr. of New York. The Rev. Nicholas B. White performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: Shelby Fleck, Scott Slayton
description: Shelby Ann Fleck and Scott Thompson Slayton were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Gregory Cootsona at the College Hill Presbyterian Church in Easton, Pa.

description: Amanda Slater La Forge, a daughter of Elizabeth Porter Steisel and Thomas J. La Forge, both of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Mark Baird Denbo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Denbo of Bethesda, Md. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: PULSE
description: Barneys: (212) 826-8900, or (800) 777-0087 outside New York City.

title: INVESTING WITH/James H. Gipson; Clipper Fund
description: AS stock indexes climbed to record highs during the first half of the year, many managers of stock mutual funds were throwing most every dollar they had into the market. Not James H. Gipson, founder and lead manager of the Clipper Fund. By mid-July, he had a fat 44 percent of his portfolio in cash and Treasury bonds, with the balance in just 17 stocks.

title: Artisans Beat a Path to Lyndhurst and the Craft Show
description: FROM bread-dough ornaments to textured paper boxes to fine-art pottery, everyone seems to be making something. More often than not, the work is meant for display and, the maker hopes, for sale, whether at a school or church bazaar, at a gallery or one of the many craft fairs from spring through fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLECHMAN, SYLVIA
description: BLECHMAN-Sylvia. Died at her home on September 10, 1998 in her 89th year. Beloved widow of Nathan O. Blechman and supporter of numerous New York charities.

title: Con Edison Taken to Task Over PCB's
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized Consolidated Edison yesterday for its delay in notifying the Fire Department that firefighters who battled a blaze at a generating plant on Staten Island Sept. 7 may have been exposed to extremely high levels of toxic chemicals.

title: Sheila Lennon, Eugene O'Shea Jr.
description: Sheila Lockwood Lennon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul T. Lennon of Larchmont, N.Y., and Eugene Kevin O'Shea Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Shea of Bedford Hills, N.Y., were married yesterday at SS. John and Paul Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont. The Rev. Charles J. Beirne performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Drug Chief Seeks Overhaul of Strategy to Stop Illegal Flow From Mexico
description: United States border inspectors searched slightly more than a million commercial trucks and railway cars entering the United States from Mexico last year. They found cocaine stashed in cargo compartments on only six occasions, said Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House director of drug control policy.

title: Ghosts and Ruins Along the Mississippi
description: I WAS invited to dinner in Natchez, Miss., this spring. The architecture of the dining room -- or front parlor, in local nomenclature -- was Federal, the decoration Victorian, the palette blue and white all over, like a piece of painted Chinese porcelain. Candles flickered, the flames in the gaslight chandelier fluttered. There were multiple courses, wine glasses incised with star bursts , a formidable array of silver.

title: Island's Quietest Corner Gets a Bit Bigger
description: ON any nice weekend day, dozens of canoeists and kayakers paddle along the serpentine bends of the Carmans River from just below Sunrise Highway in Brookhaven to where it joins Great South Bay.

title: Some Want Village, Not Mall
description: Local residents are voicing a bundle of worries about a proposed development plan for the site of the former Washburn Wire factory.

title: Ms. Burghardt, Lieut. McDavit
description: Danielle Clare Burghardt, a daughter of Celeste and Joseph J. Burghardt of Sparta, N.J., was married there yesterday to Lieut. (j.g.) Jonas Reale McDavit, the son of Mary Anne and Jared L. McDavit of Andover, N.J. The Rev. Walter J. Burghardt, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church.

title: Rhonda Warren, Robert Banker
description: Rhonda Darlene Warren, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elzie R. Warren of Jasper, Ala., was married last evening to Robert Vernon Banker, the son of Ritchey F. Goodwin of New York and Vincent C. Banker of Locust Valley, N.Y. The Rev. Peter M. Larsen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: Carried Away
description: Bottled water! Compact, portable and usually squirtable (with a sports cap), it sure beats standing hunched over the water fountain or carrying around paper cups, especially outdoors or at the gym. Has anyone made a study of how many times these bottles are refilled with tap water before being lost or tossed? I think it might be more than the bottlers would appreciate.

title: Twist on Ratatouille: Grilled Vegetables
description: AS summer turns into fall, produce in farmers' markets is at its peak. To use up the glut of summer vegetables, many cooks make ratatouille, often with less than happy results. Who wants to see all those bright, glossy zucchini, eggplant, peppers and tomatoes reduced to mush?

title: Inyourface the Nation
description: It's 3 P.M., Monday, Aug. 17. President Clinton is in the White House Map Room, testifying, and Chris Matthews, the flaxen-haired, pink-faced, know-it-all and occasionally unhinged host of ''Hardball With Chris Matthews,'' is sitting in his office in the Washington quarters of CNBC, scarfing a basket of Wendy's fried chicken. For Matthews, this is the Day of Days -- to be equaled later, of course, by Sept. 11, the day of the Starr report's release -- and in his excitement he's spraying bits of biscuit on his tie. ''Hardball'' is one of a half-dozen shows, mostly on cable, that for the past seven months have been Monicamonicamonica. There's ''Rivera Live,'' also on CNBC; ''The Big Show'' and ''The News With Brian Williams'' on MSNBC, and ''Hannity & Colmes'' and ''The Crier Report'' on Fox News.

title: Six Scientists Whose Discoveries Helped to Combat Cancer Are Honored
description: Six scientists who made discoveries dating to 1960 that identified the genetic basis of cancer and improved the diagnosis and treatment of certain types of the disease will receive this year's Albert Lasker awards.

title: My Favorite Show; Richard Ford on 'Mister Rogers' Neighborhood'
description: I know. I'm 54. No longer . . .what? Six? The truth is, Mr. Rogers gets into me. As soon as Fred clears the door and heads toward the closet for the cardigan, singing ''Won't you be my neighbor?'' I am his neighbor. And what neighborliness means is the lowering of my spiritual guard, the advent of the sort of post-Kierkegaardian relief I otherwise never feel. Relief born of irony's absence, the promise that some advice (it's good when you say ''thank you'') can be imparted and accepted unvetted, the trust that everything Fred does and says for the next 30 minutes will have useful lessons lodged within (always peek out the window before you open the front door; always look at whom you're speaking to, even if it's Mr. McFeely). Plus, in the neighborhood there's evidence that many acts have but one meaning and a good consequence (feeding the fish), that all formality and decorum isn't hollow and underwritten by despair and that your shoes will always be where you left them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, HILDA ANN NEE REICH
description: JACOBS-Hilda Ann nee Reich. Beloved widow of Isidore. Mother of Selma and Bernard. Mother-in-law of Joan Jacobs and Harold Coyne. Grandmother of David, Gail, Charles and Gordon. Great grandmother of Molly and Erica. Services at Gutterman's Funeral Home ''Parkside Building,'' 2576 Flatbush Avenue at 10:30 AM Sunday, September 20, 1998. Member of Eastern Star, Helada Sunshine Club.

title: Alix Ogden, Evan Matthews
description: Alix Roberts Ogden, a daughter of Patricia P. McGrath and Alfred T. Ogden 2d, both of New York, was married yesterday to Evan Howard Matthews, the son of Penelope Matthews and Howard Matthews Jr. of Wickford, R.I. The Rev. Hope Eakins performed the ceremony at Anguillia, the farm of the bride's grandfather Alfred Ogden in Stonington, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAIRD, W. FREDERICK
description: LAIRD-W. Frederick. Retired Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., died Tuesday, Sept. 15, at Christiana Hospital in Wilmington, DE after a brief illness. He was 79. Survivors include his wife of 55 years, Jane, two sons, Frederick W. of Plainfield, NJ and John W. of NYC, & four grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at Westminster Presbyterian Church, Pennsylvania Ave. at Rodney St. in Wilmington at 11 AM, Monday, September 21. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Delaware Hospice, 3515 Silverside Rd., Wilmington, DE. 19810 or Westminster Presbyterian Church, 1502 W. 13th Street, Wilmington, DE. 19806.

title: In Capital Murder Trial, 2 Versions of Encounter
description: In the Brooklyn neighborhood where he lived, Jermaine Page called himself the ''main man,'' prosecutors say. They are happy to call him that, though not for a reason that makes Mr. Page happy.

title: Record Briefs
description: ULTIMATE BROADWAY

title: U.S. on the Short End Of Vacation Benefits
description: As summer ends, that vacation taken just weeks ago is already a distant memory, with credit card bills the only real souvenirs. It may not help to know that workers in other parts of the world are given more paid-vacation allowances than their peers in the United States get -- sometimes triple the amount. Hewitt Associates, the management consulting firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., notes many nations set minimum vacation lengths by law. At left is a sampling of what some countries require for employees with a year on the job.

title: Bracing for Mortgage Losses
description: Investors are still reeling from the news that trading losses, mostly in emerging markets, will erase a lot of earnings from the books of leading financial services companies in the United States this quarter. Merrill Lynch said it lost $135 million trading bonds in July and August, cutting earnings to one-fourth their level during those months in 1997. Citicorp's losses will slice $200 million from third-quarter profits.

title: Haywire
description: IN DARK WATER

title: Political Briefing; Lack of Green Alters The Tint of This Race
description: If a Green Party candidate had not siphoned off dissident Democratic votes four years ago in New Mexico's Governor's race, the Republican candidate, Gary E. Johnson, might still be running a big construction company instead of running for re-election. But this time around there is no Green on the ballot and Democrats are confident that their candidate, Martin Chavez, a former Albuquerque Mayor, has a real shot at taking Mr. Johnson.

title: Karen Kemp, Thomas Glover
description: Karen Louise Kemp and Thomas Shircliff Glover were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket. The Rev. George E. Andrews 2d performed the ceremony.

title: Through Customs In 15 to 20 Seconds
description: The quick passage through immigration control that is now used by business travelers at six airports may soon be open to leisure travelers who re-enter the country at least three times a year. The electronic recognition system gives the green light to an enrolled passenger in 15 to 20 seconds; 70,000 business travelers are enrolled now.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Pamela Paul, Bret Stephens
description: Pamela Lindsey Paul, the daughter of Carole Paul and Jerome D. Paul, both of New York, was married yesterday to Bret Louis Stephens, a son of Xenia and Charles Stephens of Somers, N.Y. John E. Parker, a town justice in Hurley, N.Y., officiated at the Peterson House, a reception hall in Bearsville, N.Y.

title: Self Styling
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books; Over the Bright Blue Geriatric Sea
description: Old women, giant waves, washtub boats and surfing dogs make up the wacky, whimsical universes of two delightfully different books. In Quentin Blake's MRS. ARMITAGE AND THE BIG WAVE (Harcourt Brace, $15; ages 4 to 8) the clamdigger-and-halter-top-clad beachgoer and her trusty canine sidekick, Breakspear, hop a banana yellow surfboard over a blue-green sea to wait out the big wave.

title: Twilight at Raffles
description: To the Editor: In ''Charting the Globe on a Cocktail Napkin'' (Aug. 30), William Grimes wrote that ''the right drink takes you somewhere.'' How right he is. The mere mention of a Singapore Sling takes me back to Raffles, where I once lived for 10 days. At the end of each day I repaired to the Palm Court with a book of short stories by Conrad or Maugham in one hand and a tall frosted glass in the other. There, as streaks of pink and turquoise arced above the palms, I read stories written when the authors stayed there, too. The heady concoction I sipped was created by the same barman who cleverly hid Raffles's silver as the Japanese were marching into Singapore, where enemy officers would convert Raffles into their headquarters.

title: Happy Birthdays
description: Philharmonic's 157th, Le Cirque's 25th, Jewish Center's not-yet-first.

title: SOAPBOX; No Direction Home
description: A Federal report this summer on the quality of care in the nation's nursing homes was followed by a deluge of advice and information in the press. However, in New Jersey there has been virtual silence from the state Department of Health and Senior Services, which licenses and monitors these facilities, as well as from the state Ombudsman for the Institutionalized Elderly who advocates for the 50,000 residents of the state's nursing homes.

title: Scents and Sensibility
description: For years, Mike Burian, who works in Manhattan for Soccer U.S.A., used whatever fragrance anyone gave him. But after turning 40, Burian decided it was time to find his own scent.

title: 'Moonstruck' Bakery Eclipsed
description: Marlene Hochman and her three children pressed their faces against the glass door of the Cammareri Brothers Bakery one evening last week. The place was dark, its shelves empty.

title: From Parcels To Passengers
description: THE Cinderella tale is always fun, even when the transformation takes place in the predawn dark at Philadelphia International Airport. The pumpkin -- in this case, a United Parcel Service Airlines 727 with ''UPS'' on the tail and a brown stripe down the fuselage, emptied of packages flown from Raleigh-Durham, N.C., -- was sitting with its wide left-side cargo door flung up, clamshell-style.

title: Welfare Fraud
description: The state's crackdown on welfare fraud has netted more than $440 million since January 1995, according to figures released this month by Gov. George E. Pataki.

title: School Construction Reflects Needs
description: FOR many of the county's schoolchildren, the sounds of construction are as familiar as the more conventional sounds of instruction.

title: Beneath the Surface
description: Not modernists exactly, not post-modernists for sure, not minimalists per se -- Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron defy the taxonomical categories we use to sort most architects and their work. With restrained forms executed in materials that are extraordinary, often beautiful and surprising, Herzog and de Meuron have forged a style that is both cerebral and sensual, appealing to mind and body together, captivating a large audience.

title: Flight Pattern Test Ends at Newark Airport
description: A six-month experiment in which half of the planes departing Newark International Airport were routed over an industrial swath of Carteret and Rahway ended at 7 A.M. Tuesday, but it will take the Federal Aviation Administration at least another six months to study the results and determine if the changes should be permanent, Arlene Salac, a spokeswoman for the aviation agency, said last week.

title: The View From/Rye; It's Back to School and the Basic Values Beyond the Three R's
description: THE banner in the lobby says it all ''Welcome back to school.'' Brightly colored cardboard letters form the words, which surround a big, three-dimensional paper apple. Also in the display case: a lacrosse stick, a globe, a football and copies of ''Heidi,'' ''Tom Sawyer'' and ''Frankenstein.''

title: Carried Away
description: You said nothing about the impact that all those plastic containers must have on our landfills. It may no longer be politically correct to serve tap water as a beverage, but we need to stem the tide against a flood of throwaways.

title: Urban Renewal
description: Essential outerwear offers the warmest feel and the hottest look of the season. Duffles, peacoats and hooded parkas -- in newly resurgent wools and high-tech fabrics -- look best with cargo pants and substantial sweaters.

title: Jeanine Behr, Robert Getz
description: Jeanine Michelle Behr and Robert Hinman Getz were married yesterday in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: Athena Foley, Christopher Hooper
description: Athena F. Foley and Christopher S. Hooper, associates at New York law firms, were married yesterday at the Wyckoff (N.J.) Reformed Church. The Rev. David Bach performed the ceremony.

title: The Uninvited
description: To the Editor: Since when has an adult passenger been permitted to sleep on the floor of a plane during a trans-Atlantic flight?

title: A Fabric Maker's Tapestry for Success
description: WHAT could Larry A. Liebenow have been thinking in 1989 when he decided to buy the Quaker Fabric Corporation, an ailing, 43-year-old business in this struggling mill town?

title: BOOKS: Dante From Italian to English, Baby Given Up and Baby Wanted; Keeping the Spirit Of Dante Alighieri
description: A professor of English and humanities at Dowling College has produced a book from hell. ''Inferno'' (Pantheon) is Elio Zappulla's English translation of the first of three canticles of Dante Alighieri's 14th-century epic poem, ''The Divine Comedy.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONNER, ROBERT D.
description: BONNER-Robert D. On September 16, 1998. He is survived by his wife, Tricia, his daughter, Bissie, his mother, Marie, brothers Mark and Paul and nieces and nephews. Private services were held. Donations in his memory can be made to the National Brain Tumor Foundation, 785 Market St, Suite 1600, San Francisco, CA. 94103.

title: Culture Zone; Deep Impact
description: When I became a television critic a couple of years ago, I never dreamed I would also become an object of pity. What could be better than a job that combines art, pop culture and sociology? But now I have grown accustomed to the sympathetic glance and the well-meaning tone people assume when they say, ''Poor you, you have to watch television,'' as if I have tumbled to the bottom of some cultural mine shaft. They must imagine me toiling in the dark (I have to watch Roseanne!), hoping for a whiff of air (are there any Jane Austen novels left to adapt?), waiting for the song of some canary that will signal the suffocating end of civilization (Rosie O'Donnell anchors the news).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDREN, ANNE M.
description: CONDREN-Anne M., 93. Of Gristmill Lane, Plandome Mills, NY. On September 18, 1998. Wife of the late Edward I. Mother of William J., Professor Edward I., and Carol Carroll. Grandmother of Sloan Castleman, Sean, Ellen Crowley, Hillary, Colin, Elizabeth, Jennifer, and Mathew Carroll. Great-grandmother of Jack Crowley. Sister of the late Edna McKeever. Aunt of the late Rev. Paul E. McKeever & Sr. Edna McKeever. Mrs. Condren taught for many years in the New York City Public School System, mainly at PS 131 in Jamaica Estates, Queens, where she lived prior to moving to Plandome Mills in 1968, shortly after the death of her husband. A woman of great intelligence and character, she was the conscience and motivator of her family for four generations. There will be a wake on Sunday, September 20 at Fairchilds Sons, Inc. Funeral Home at 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset from 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Mary's Church, Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Monday September 21 at 11:30 AM. Interment in St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: A New Way to Read The Law at Home
description: Beginning next month, students will be able to earn a law degree entirely on line.

title: The Nation: Shadow Play -- Washington's Gears, Grinding; Behind the Scenes, There Are No Wise Men Anymore
description: WHEN Speaker Newt Gingrich was hitting rock bottom in facing the House's ethics reprimand last year, he resorted to a time-honored insider technique: He reached out privately to one of the capital's political ''wise men'' -- to an elder of the rival Democrats known to offer stricken combatants confidential advice beyond the bounds of partisanship.

title: Help Wanted: Fourth Singer, Able to Make a Singular Sound
description: ANONYMOUS 4 has just released its eighth recording, and it will not be surprising if this CD, ''A Lammas Ladymass,'' sails to the top of the classical charts as most of the group's earlier efforts have. But this new album of chant and polyphony for the Roman Catholic feast of the Assumption, which celebrates the Virgin Mary's passage into heaven, is itself a rite of passage.

title: Into Dante's Phantasmagorical Vision of Hell
description: Abandon all hope, you who enter here.'' This motto, inscribed on Hell's front door in Dante Alighieri's ''Divine Comedy,'' might also serve as a warning to ambitious thespians transferring the 14th-century masterpiece to the stage.

title: Taking Arms Against Stage Fright
description: PICTURE audience members in their underwear. That's an old trick. Makes them less intimidating.

title: As Great as Bach? Well, at Least He's Getting a Hearing
description: WHEN the French composer Jean Barraque died in 1973, at 45, he left behind a tiny body of work and an enormous reputation. According to the version of 20th-century musical history put forward by Andre Hodeir in his book ''Since Debussy,'' in 1961, Barraque, though he had written just four works at the time, delivered the promises that had been only partly fulfilled by Schoenberg, Stravinsky, Messiaen and Pierre Boulez.

title: County's Diversity
description: The percentage of residents of Asian descent in Westchester jumped 43 percent from 1990 to 1997, according to the latest United States Census figures released by the County Planning Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBIN, DR. PAUL
description: EBIN-Dr. Paul. He was taken too soon, too young and at his prime. Heartfelt sympathy to his devoted parents, his family and the children he loved. The Law Firm and Staff of Rudnick Sheps

title: Q&A/Patricia Reilly Giff; Writing for Children, in Monumental Scale
description: THE Newbery Medal is awarded by the American Library Association for the most distinguished children's book of the year. Newbery Honor Book awards also go out, and this year ''Lily's Crossing,'' by Patricia Reilly Giff of Weston, was one of the three books so honored.

title: Structural Integrity
description: In clothing, as in architecture, structural integrity can be achieved in unexpected ways. At the Dominus Estate winery in California's Napa Valley, a sensual exterior wall of loose gray stone does not support the building, but rather insulates it and lends texture to the surface, while concealing the true structure within. Similarly, in men's wear, as surface effects become more important and fabrics grow softer, easy tailoring must supply the structure. Fortunately, this can be accomplished with a minimum of construction for a maximum of comfort and style.

title: Turning Tides Sink A Big Technology Deal
description: Tellabs called off its planned $7.1 billion acquisition of Ciena, the top maker of equipment for building the capacity of phone networks, because shareholder approval was unlikely, thanks mainly to a near free fall in Ciena's business outlook after the deal was announced on June 3. Since then, Ciena has warned that its third-quarter profit would be less than half of what analysts expected, said it had failed to land two important contracts, and seen its stock tumble 81 percent -- abetted by the general late-summer slide in the markets, of course -- while Tellabs fell 37 percent.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Travel Advisory column on page 3 of the Travel section today, about speeding the passage of travelers through American airports, refers incorrectly to the agency involved. It is Immigration, not Customs.

title: Cuban Contributions
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art That Washes In
description: Last weekend at Cafe Verboten, an ''underground'' coffeehouse and gallery in the basement of a St. George office building, two women stood on a temporary indoor beach of trucked-in sand and gazed down on a found-object sculpture by Douglas Schwartz. Oyster shells, shark egg casings and all manner of tide-tossed bivalves lay on the sand in an artful asteroid belt of beach debris.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Pop Art in Ridgefield

title: In the Region/Westchester; Armonk Shopping Center's Developer Avoids Chains
description: A THIRD-GENERATION Westchester development company now building a 20,050-square-foot shopping center near the downtown of this affluent hamlet has resisted the overtures of national chain stores interested in leasing space in favor of an exclusively local approach.

title: Boy Is Healthy Without Drug For H.I.V., Mother Says
description: As 4-year-old Nikolas Emerson ran across the grass in a public park here today, he spun like a top and shrieked with glee. Watching him, his mother, Valerie Emerson, said that Nikolas, who is infected with H.I.V., has never been happier or healthier.

title: World of the Bayou And the Plantation
description: ''MA'AM, if I'd been born any further to the South, I'd be a sof' shell crab right now,'' a Baton Rouge resident once said to a Virginia woman who was confused by the regional accent, in an encounter described by Harnett T. Kane in ''The Bayous of Louisiana'' (1944). She was apparently unaware of the speaker's heritage, for, as a product of the bayou, his blood was a commingling of Creole, Cajun, Isleno from the Canary Islands and Houmas Indian, typical of the lower Mississippi.

title: A Study Finds Problems In Converting Closed-End Funds
description: Investors who hope to make a tidy bundle if their closed-end fund converts to open-end status may be in for a rude awakening, according to a new study by CDA/Weisenberger, a fund tracking service in Rockville, Md. The study, which looked at 10 closed-end funds that became open in 1997 and 1998, concludes that long-term investors in converted funds suffered, and for several reasons.

title: Where Foods of Spain and Mexico Meet
description: VIVA LA VIDA, a newly opened storefront in Huntington, features the food of Spain and Mexico. While this pairing is frequently seen on Long Island, the cuisines have little in common. Mexico's is New World and corn-centered while Spain's is closer to its European neighbors than to its former colonies.

title: Tracy Morelli, John Pramenko
description: Tracy Susan Morelli, a daughter of Marianne and Robert A. Morelli of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. John Matthew Pramenko, a son of Karen and George R. Pramenko of Arvada, Colo. The Rev. Dr. Walter J. Smith performed the ceremony at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: SOAPBOX; When Keeping Company Is Therapy
description: SOMEONE calls for a doctor, and I approach to find a man sobbing. He is curled up, crying, inconsolable. I could be in the intensive-care waiting room, or approaching a rape victim, or telling a father he has lost his son to AIDS. But this is nothing like any of those daily routines of doctoring, because I am on a plane bound for Halifax, Nova Scotia, with the families of those who died on Swissair Flight 111. The cabin is full of tear-filled memories and pain.

title: Backtalk; Responsible Youths Grow on a Dusty Field
description: In October 1995, after returning to New York City from the Million Man March, two former college athletes named Chris Legree and Ervin C. Roberson vowed to transport the march's spirit of racial responsibility to their home neighborhood of Brownsville. Since both men had used scholarships to attain college degrees, they decided to use sports as their vehicle for change and brought Pop Warner Little Scholars football to a dusty patch of field underneath the No. 3 train tracks.

title: Painting for Sale
description: For more than 50 years, an Impressionistic-style painting of Central Park in Manhattan was a fixture at the Bronxville Public Library, a gift from a wealthy resident. Although it was a popular painting and well liked by library users, it was not considered a valuable piece.

title: 'Dubious' Assertions On Weather Are Challenged
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. McGovern, Mr. Gambuzza
description: Ellen Marie McGovern, a daughter of Mary Ann and Philip McGovern of Beverly, Mass., and Norbert Michael Gambuzza, a son of Marie and Norbert Gambuzza of Lincroft, N.J., were married yesterday at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Eugene O'Brien, the president of the Pontifical Gregorian University Foundation in New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Stock and Bond Issuance Falls to a Low for the Year
description: It's tough trying to peddle securities in these whipsawed times. Even so, last week was especially dismal for new issues. The Securities Data Company, a Newark research firm, reported that debt and equity issuance for the week fell to a spectacular low for the year, with just over $14 billion of new securities sold, based on preliminary totals. That is in contrast to $16 billion the previous week, and a high of $56.5 billion during the week beginning March 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN VALKENBURGH, MILDRED ARLENE
description: VAN VALKENBURGH-Mildred Arlene. On September 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Pierre. Loving sister of Gladys Shockley and Gertrude Knight and aunt of many. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, September 22, 2-6 PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Lung Association of New York, Inc., 432 Park Ave. So., NY NY 10016.

title: Editorial Observer; African-American Progress in the New South
description: After a rocky and sometimes violent start, American colleges were

title: Breaking the Mold Downtown
description: BOND STREET **

title: Space Is Tight, Office Markets Robust
description: WITH vacancy rates declining, rents rising and some tenants opting to move either to the suburbs or to parts of Manhattan that were once avoided, the fundamentals of the commercial real estate market in the New York area have been robust in the first nine months of the year.

title: Football on Many Screens And Bond's Favorite Martini
description: Sean Corrigan, Brad Sakele and Hugh Preece didn't intend to open a sports bar. At least that's what Mr. Corrigan said of the Lincoln Park Grill. But they installed nine television sets that seem to pull in almost every college and professional football game played in the United States.

title: The World; China's Fine Art: Linguistic Survival
description: ALTHOUGH the world has focused its attention on the one-sided battle between the Chinese Communist Government and the political dissidents who press for radical change, there is also a large population here of intellectuals, many of them scholars or former officials, who work openly to nudge the system in a more democratic direction.

title: The Hole Grows Deeper for the Europeans
description: For the United States at the Solheim Cup, it was another day of steady play under pressure, with many players making important contributions. For Europe, it was another day of missed opportunities, missed putts and deflating defeats.

title: Habitats/Park Slope, Brooklyn; Making a Home and a Life With Her Own Hands
description: FOR a while, Ellen Liburt lived in a house in Maine that was built over rocks on the edge of the sea. There were huge glass blocks in the floor, so you could look down and see the ocean flowing through, its sound the voice of the house. She lived there with her fiancee, who had made a lot of money in the roofing business and built his dream house.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, excerpts yesterday from remarks by members of the House Judiciary Committee following the vote to release President Clinton's grand jury testimony omitted an attribution at one point in some editions. The remarks were by Henry J. Hyde, the Republican chairman of the panel, not by Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts. A corrected excerpt appears on page 36.

title: In Silicon Valley, Talent in Reserve
description: IN 1994, Michael Bowles was skulking outside his office at Hughes Electronics in El Segundo, Calif., whispering on public telephones to potential investors and pleading for financing to start his own cable modem company.

title: Power to the People
description: THE BILL OF RIGHTSCreation and Reconstruction.By Akhil Reed Amar.411 pp. New Haven:Yale University Press. $30.

title: Avon Votes for Leashed Dogs
description: WHILE walking her dog in Fisher Meadows Park in Avon in early May, C. J. Hauss, a town resident and Literacy Volunteers executive, met a friend who told her the town council, in meeting the night before, had decided to rescind its rule allowing unleashed pets in a portion of the park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EBIN, YAAKOV
description: EBIN-Yaakov. We mourn the untimely passing of the brother of our esteemed member, Susan Thalheim and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANGER, ADELE WILSON
description: SANGER-Adele Wilson, 86. Of Dover, MA, peacefully on August 1, 1998. Formerly of Rye, Cold Spring Harbor and Syosset, NY. Survived by three daughters, Joan Griffin of Baltimore, MD, Kathleen Yorke of Sibford Gower, England and Aileen Chase of South Salem, New York. Also survived by four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 17 at 2:30PM at the Dover Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Chapin School, 100 East End Avenue, New York, N.Y., Rye Country Day School, Cedar St, NY, NY 10580 or the Boston Symphony Orchestra would be appreciated.

title: Ms. Lindsey, Mr. Hauptman
description: Michelle Renee Lindsey, a daughter of Patricia A. Lindsey of West Chester, Pa., and the late Richard W. Lindsey, was married yesterday at her family's house in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., to William Hauptman, a son of Betty and Michael Hauptman of Greenwich, Conn.

title: High Holy Day Services Broadcast
description: WHEN Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, begins today at sundown, many observers will be in synagogues. Some, though, may not be able to get there in person: the elderly, the ill, the disabled. For them there will be radio broadcasts of the services being held at Temple Israel in New Rochelle. They can turn to WRTN-FM, 93.5, or WVOX-AM, 1460, and hear not only prayers and music but also a commentary on the actions of the rabbi and cantor.

title: This Is Larry King. Next Up: The Babe.
description: After a long silence, Babe Ruth has emerged for a rare interview on tonight's ''Larry King Live.''

title: Detail Oriented
description: Accessories this fall have one thing in common: all look good with gray, the ultimate neutral and this season's color of choice. Standout favorites include modern belts with brushed metal buckles, elegant silver-gray ties and stainless steel watches.

title: Gimmickry Amid the Dishes in Irvington
description: FUFFI GRILL runs on showmanship, and run it does. Noise, clutter, shtick -- all add up to a lot of fun, if you are in the mood. A miscellany of movie posters and photographs covers the walls. Rummage-sale neckties are draped on a plastic hanger and knotted wittily around the neck of some columns. The comedy-routine badinage from the bustling wait staff is almost nonstop. And, of course, there is the ''fuffi'' gimmick, the word a secret ''until you've visited here three times and the cafe three more times.'' Even then you might not get a straight answer.

title: New in Money and Business
description: Money & Business introduces a group of new features today and reorganizes its pages to reflect the variety of economic and financial life.

title: Making Sure Organic Really Means Organic
description: THE pungent aroma of freshly picked basil filled the air around Tobacco Road Farm in Lebanon. Bending over an outdoor sink, Bryan O'Hara, owner of the farm, washed bunches of the herb in cold water. Mr. O'Hara pulls the plants from his garden by the roots, early in the morning before the sun is high, and prepares them for sale at a local market. After the picking, washing and drying, the basil is stored in trays of water in a cool, dark, humid root cellar. At the market, the fragrant plants are sold from the tray, like cut flowers. ''You have to take your time and treat them delicately,'' Mr. O'Hara said. ''That's good farming.''

title: A Fount of Poetic Inspiration
description: A BUNCH of tourists from various parts of the world stand at the edge of a shallow circular pool and stare into the water that is so clear they can see the pebbles on the bottom. Swans and ducks lazily paddle around and every now and then land on small grassy islands. The breeze rustles the poplars and weeping willows, and the birds twitter.

title: Noted, Not 'Notorious'
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fast-Food Strategy for a High-End Menu
description: ALLEN J. BERNSTEIN of Manhasset got his first taste of the restaurant business in the 60's at Roslyn High School where, one season, the teen-ager sold enough hot dogs to pay for new uniforms for the school's entire cheerleading squad.

title: BOOKS: Dante From Italian to English, Baby Given Up and Baby Wanted; Of Infertility, Grief And Hard Choices
description: DEBBY PEOPLES and Harriette Rovner Ferguson faced difficult struggles with infertility; now that they've made it to the other side they've written a book to help others through the battle.

title: It's a Race for the Record, but Is It Also About Race?
description: All across the country, Americans are talking baseball and home runs. Or more specifically, Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa. Take a seat at the bar in Denver, or at a hamburger joint in Los Angeles. The questions are simple: Who are you rooting for in the home run race? And why?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, LOUIS S.
description: PETERSON-Louis S. Playwright, screenwriter and professor. On April 28, 1998 after a long illness. Survived by many loving friends. Memorial service to be held at the Actor's Studio Inc., 432 W. 44 St., New York, N.Y. on Friday, September 25, 1998 at 2:30 P.M.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Marc Jacobs; Even Steamier Than Paris
description: IT was cold Tuesday morning in Paris when Marc Jacobs left to fly to the opening of the new Louis Vuitton store in Manhattan. At 7 P.M. he entered the store, a virtual cashmere-lined steam bath, where photographers stood on antique Louis Vuitton trunks to get his picture, and 800 guests -- all seeming to be 26 and employed as accessories editors -- reached toward him. Mr. Jacobs, 35, the perpetual boy-wonder designer who created Vuitton's first sportswear collection this year, pulled out a black stocking and improvised a headband to keep his hair off his sweat-drenched forehead.

title: THE GUIDE
description: An Exhibition About Plastics

title: Bosnia's Serbs Reject A Leader the West Liked
description: As Bosnia conducted elections under the watchful eyes of the United States and other countries with peacekeeping forces in the land, the West's diplomatic strategy was clear: isolate the hard-line Serb nationalists and support those moderates who appeared most likely to support reconciliation of Bosnia's Serbs and Muslims.

title: Remembering a Swim Club That May Disappear
description: To the Editor:

title: That Delicate Balance: What About the Dads?
description: To the Editor:

title: Is the Other Brick About to Drop on Construction?
description: DO construction executives know something the rest of us don't?

title: Extreme Watches
description: Humvees rumble over suburban streets; industrial stoves fire up a single burger. These days, extreme utility equals status. The newest in the ranks of the unnecessarily powerful is the Bell & Ross Hydro Challenger watch, designed to take a 34,000-foot undersea dipping and keep on ticking. Bell & Ross maintains that the Hydro's depth tolerance comes from the high-grade cosmetology silicone (the same grade used in breast implants, it says) that fills the watch case. ''The silicone also eliminates light refraction in the water, so it's readable from any angle,'' said Lee Polin, a maritime security consultant and former Navy search-and-rescue diver who owns two Hydros.

title: Hyperion Using World's Largest Mainsail
description: The largest mainsail ever made flew from New York to Amsterdam last week, a staggering 1,040 pounds of high-tech monster strapped to two pallets in an airplane cargo hold. It is the mainsail for Hyperion, the $30 million, 155-foot vessel built for the founder of Silicon Graphics and co-founder of Netscape, Jim Clark.

title: Plan for Tribal Casino Backfires On a Fading Jersey Shore Town
description: In 1995, the Mayor and business leaders of Wildwood, a struggling resort on the Jersey Shore, were certain that the path to prosperity ran through this parched corner of western Oklahoma. The idea seemed inspired: Take a bit of city land -- a two-acre parking lot, actually -- and give it back to Oklahoma's Delaware Indians, whose ancestors were pushed out of New Jersey in the 1830's. The Indians would open a casino, and Wildwood would finally tap into the river of dollars flowing to the mighty resort casinos of Atlantic City, 30 miles up the shore.

title: Ms. Friedman, Mr. Wallerstein
description: Diana Karen Friedman, a daughter of Geraldine and Edward A. Friedman of New York, was married last evening to Andrew J. Wallerstein, the son of Betty Cooper Wallerstein and David Wallerstein of New York. The Rev. Betty Zimmer, an interfaith minister, officiated at the New-York Historical Society.

title: Sevanne Kassarjian, Paul Griffin
description: Sevanne Margaret Kassarjian, the daughter of Dr. Mary Catherine Bateson and Dr. J. Barkev Kassarjian of Hancock, N.H., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Paul Gerard Griffin, a son of Eileen H. Griffin of Chicago and the late James T. Griffin. The Rev. Douglas J. Hennessy, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMBERS, ROBERT MITCHELL
description: CHAMBERS-Robert Mitchell, age 60, of Palm Beach, FL, passed away suddenly September 15, 1998, at his home. Mr. Chambers was born June 13, 1938, in Queens, NY. He was a graduate of St. John's University. He served with the 1st Squadron 101st Calvary U.S. Army. Mr. Chambers was a top sales executive for the ABC Radio Network for 35 years, retiring in 1992. He was a former member of the Pelham Country Club and a member of the PGA National Golf Club and president of the Bristol Club Board of Directors. He was an avid golfer, world traveler and a kindred soul. Mr. Chambers leaves to cherish his loving memory his beloved wife, Chicki Chambers and his devoted children Robert Chambers, Susan Haldeman and husband Scott, Carolyn McKenna and husband Mark, and his adored grandchildren Matthew Scott Haldeman, Kaitlin Moore McKenna and Brooke Mitchell McKenna. A private memorial service is being held in honor of Mr. Chambers. All donations are being accepted at Yale Children's Hospital, New Haven in honor of Brooke Mitchell McKenna.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: The View From/Hartford; The History of Insanity, Shameful to Treatable
description: ABOUT three years ago, Lee Monroe, public relations director for the Institute of Living in Hartford, wanted to come up with a unusual way to celebrate the 175th anniversary of the psychiatric hospital, Connecticut's first and the country's third. Its storage rooms and offices boasted a wealth of artifacts. As the institute's director, Dr. Harold I. Schwartz, put it, ''We have the history of psychiatry in the basement.'' So, with a gift from Glaxo Wellcome Pharmaceuticals and a grant from the Connecticut Humanities Council, a museum was born. ''Myths, Minds and Medicine'' is that unusual celebration -- and a whole lot more.

title: The ABC's of Getting Ahead
description: IF mobility is the core of the American dream, then there can be no better expression of the dream than A Better Chance, an educational program that celebrates its 35th anniversary this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARNACK, SHIRLEY
description: SHARNACK - Shirley. Beloved mother of Charlotte Rosenzweig and Beverly and Jerry Levitan. Devoted grandmother of Karen, Mark and Tania, Roy and Pam, Peter, Kathi and Ira, and Nancy and eight great grandchildren. Loving sister of Ida Gross. Always in our hearts. Services will be private.

title: Last Taunts in Pittsburgh Go to Lions
description: Joe Paterno might not have stuck around for 301 victories if they all came like this.

description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVENDER, ANDREW
description: LAVENDER-Andrew. Died September 17, 1998. Beloved by wife Bruria, family, friends, students and cats. You will be dearly remembered and deeply missed. Private ceremony.

title: My Favorite Show; Ellen Gilchrist on 'E.R.'
description: It is a sign of how hard times are for fiction writers that I have agreed, for money, to admit that I stay up until 10 o'clock central standard time on Thursday nights to watch ''E.R.'' The part I like is when they roll in the accident victims and the doctors, who have been lolling around the nurses' station flirting with one another, go into high gear and start stuffing a plastic tube down the victim's throat, telling him not to worry, even though he's been shot several times or fallen from a roof. Occasionally they even close some of the wounds as the camera zooms in on the blood.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'Full Moon Downtown'
description: In 1955 my father, Pat Weaver, then head of NBC, had Milton Berle step out on the stage of ''Producers' Showcase'' and tell a few jokes. But instead of introducing the usual variety acts, Uncle Miltie brought out the prima ballerina Margot Fonteyn. They chatted about tutus, and within moments Fonteyn and the Royal Ballet were performing ''Sleeping Beauty'' from beginning to end. Millions of people tuned in. Dad still believes that people will watch ''culture'' on TV, but that they need some ''enticement.''

title: Russia's Cultural Revolution
description: RUSSIA IN THE AGE OF PETER THE GREAT

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: All Over But the Shoutin'

title: A la Commode
description: It's a toilet, it's a sink, it's a fountain for your dog. An accessory-fixe in France, the bidet in America elicits embarrassed giggles. Maybe not for long. ''Bathrooms are getting bigger, and bidets are popular in the upscale house,'' said Gopal Ahlwalia, the director for research of the National Association of Home Builders.

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?; No Plea Bargain
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There is no government here. Mobil is the only visible entity. They are making a lot of money here, and we've been left like monkeys out here in the swamp.''

title: Sprucing Up For Holidays: It's a Mitzvah
description: SEPTEMBER is the month when my mailbox is jammed with fall fashion catalogues and glatt kosher caterers have signs in their windows urging, ''Place your holiday orders now.'' For me, the coincidence of these two rituals inspires a single unifying drive -- to select a wardrobe for Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur.

title: Entering a Time Machine via Photography
description: The Life Shoot

title: A Coming-Out Party for Grand Central
description: Until recently, habitues of Grand Central Terminal had to think hard to recall a time when the place wasn't a mess, first from neglect, more recently as a construction site. But as the 500,000 people who pass through daily may have noticed, the vast two-year project to restore and modernize the 85-year-old station is just about over at last.

title: Sarah Kim And Eugene Kim
description: Sarah Eunjung Kim, a daughter of Po Young Kim and Dr. Sang Hie Kim of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Eugene Hyunwook Kim, a son of Sam Hee Kim and Dr. Sang Hoon Kim of Morganville, N.J. The Rev. Chan Hie Kim, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Christ Church United Methodist in Manhattan.

title: The Lost Tribe of Natchez
description: MY 8-year-old son, Sam, and I are sitting on either side of Marty Nathanson, in the last row of Temple B'nai Israel, in Natchez, Miss. Since the mid-1970's, the 86-year-old Mr. Nathanson, the unofficial historian of Jewish Natchez, has conducted Friday night services here -- sometimes to a congregation of no more than two or three souls.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, ROSE SCHULMAN
description: COHEN-Rose Schulman. 8/12/21-9/21/94. I'll be loving you-always. Judie

title: Dining Abroad
description: To the Editor: As Patricia Volk says, you are where you eat (Aug. 30). Often the novelties of the regional food are the most apparent evidence that one is not at home: yogurt overlaid with honey in Greece, cherries braided to look like bunches of large grapes on the roadside in Czechoslovakia, trays of fresh cucumbers on the street in Istanbul, fresh herring sandwiches in The Netherlands.

title: Marcelle Bichotte, Ricardo Dunner
description: Marcelle Berda Bichotte, a speech and language pathologist, and Dr. Ricardo Orlando Dunner, a primary care physician, are to be married today in Woodbury, N.Y. The Rev. Alexandre Valme, a Pentecostal minister, is to officiate at Fox Hollow, a catering concern.

title: Political Briefing; An Intern, an Affair And a State Senator
description: Bill Clinton, Dan Burton, Helen Chenoweth, Henry Hyde -- from the halls of the White House to the halls of Congress, the list of lofty elected officials who have admitted engaging in extramarital affairs grows ever longer.

title: Metro-North Line Reopens
description: All Metro-North commuter trains were running on schedule yesterday, a day after a double-decker car on a Conrail freight train crashed into a railway overpass just south of Yankee Stadium in the Bronx and derailed, disrupting service on the Hudson line of the Metro-North commuter railway for most of the day.

title: Access to Clinton Data Aids E Pluribus Unum in the 90's
description: Tim Ericson was not one of the millions of Americans scrolling through the report by the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr in cyberspace last week. He read it in his local paper. Nor does he plan to waste bandwidth downloading the video of President Clinton's testimony when it is made available this week.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

Hunter Walton Jr. of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday to Jon Eric Karlen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sven Bernhard Karlen Jr. of Woodstock, Conn. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Prouts Neck, Me.

title: Fear and Loathing at a Growth-Stock Gathering
description: ANYONE wondering what was on the minds of money managers attending the Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities investment conference last week got their answer Monday afternoon at a presentation by Judith Estrin, chief technology officer at Cisco Systems.

description: KING LEOPOLD'S GHOST

title: More on Truckers And the Highways
description: The letter writer, Mr. Lowenstein, couldn't be more on target. I co-own major property on the ''clouded,'' yet fabled Route 7 corridor between Danbury and Ridgefield.

title: South Africa Learns That Tourism Is Fragile
description: THE bomb that went off in the Planet Hollywood restaurant in Cape Town on Aug. 25, killing two people, has hurt tourism in South Africa's prettiest city, but no one agrees how much.

title: Fearful of the Fumes and Dubious About the Fine Print
description: Back in 1997, neighborhood residents were sure they had finally won a long battle against a medical waste incinerator that had regularly polluted the air around them. Under pressure from Gov. George E. Pataki and Borough President Fernando Ferrer, Browning-Ferris Industries agreed to shut its incinerator down rather than continue trying to fix it.

description: An anonymous poison-pen letter has left the United States waiting for a chief delegate at the United Nations.

title: Children's Books
description: CHERRY PIES AND LULLABIES

title: OIL RICH, OIL POOR: A special report.; High Claims in Spill Betray Depth of Nigerian Poverty
description: Denny Sansom of Mobil Oil has the ocean behind him, seven million restive Nigerians of the Niger River Delta in front of him, huge reserves of oil beneath him and hundreds of thousands of angry complaints against his corporation threatening to sink him.

title: Better Schools Is Battle Cry for Fall Elections
description: The Democratic candidate for governor in South Carolina, Jim Hodges, has chosen as his logo a drawing of the back of a school bus and the slogan ''It's all about our schools.''

title: If You're Thinking of Living In /Woodhaven, Queens; Diversity in a Cohesive Community
description: TO a visitor, 97th Street south of Jamaica Avenue looks as though it is holding a Fourth of July celebration in September, with American flags hanging in front of almost every house.

title: Klezmer to Pops for the New Haven Symphony
description: THOUGH the New Haven Symphony doesn't begin its subscription season for another month, a benefit gala for the orchestra offers the audience an opportunity to hear Jewish folk music from Eastern Europe at Woolsey Hall on Thursday at 8. Itzhak Perlman and four backup bands -- the Klezmatics, Brave Old World, the Klezmer Conservatory Band and the Andy Statman Klezmer Orchestra -- are the performers of what is known as klezmer music.

title: All-Spanish Final At Bournemouth
description: SAMSUNG OPEN

title: To Cablevision, It's All About Entertainment
description: IF any company on Long Island has generated its share of double takes lately, it's been the Cablevision Systems Corporation.

title: Minneapolis Celebrates Enlarged Art Museum
description: After 10 years of renovation and expansion, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts plans to make merry next Sunday with live bands, food, street performers and carriage rides on its premises and in the adjacent park.

title: Escape to New York
description: I Can't Wait on God

title: A Hollywood Satire That Refuses to Stay Down
description: THE return of ''The Dying Gaul'' to the Vineyard Theater, where it closed in June, conjures up titles befitting a parody of a bad movie sequel -- ''The Gaul That Would Not Die,'' perhaps, or ''The Dying Gaul: Resurrection.'' And on one level, that's fine with the author, Craig Lucas.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'Like, Duh'
description: One of the centerpieces of my four years at the Federal Communications Commission was the fight to require every television station to broadcast at least three hours per week of children's educational programming. We won that fight, but now the question is: What to broadcast? Here's my modest proposal.

title: Parcells Motivates Team With the 'Same Old Jets' Warning
description: It was the most hated phrase any of them knew: ''Same Old Jets.'' You remember, those three little words that fans, announcers and headline writers paraded out at one of those customary Jets moments -- failure when victory was expected, and bizarre failure, at that.

title: Backtalk; A Uniform Drug Policy Needed for All Sports
description: Like one of his Herculean home runs, the drug controversy around Mark McGwire seems to be going, going, gone.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'Le Theatre de la Reine'
description: Saturday-morning children's television would benefit this fall from ''Le Theatre de la Reine,'' a repertory television theater founded by three retired queens from France (Marie Antoinette, Marie de Medici and Maria Theresa) ostensibly for the purpose of entertaining and educating their grandchildren and various young Unicef friends. Every week these three grande dames, incarnated as puppets, will perform in an hour one of the great classics of the theater. Their repertory consists, in the premiere season, exclusively of revenge tragedies, chosen specifically to teach toddlers the values of hubris, demented vengeance and crying out to the gods.

title: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; Job Moves: They're Not Just For Sluggish Economies
description: In a weak economy, people often relocate to find jobs. But a strong economy can also feed the urge to move.

title: Jobless Rate in New Jersey Drops to 4.8 Percent
description: New Jersey's unemployment rate fell a tenth of a percentage point to 4.8 percent in August, but remained above the national average of 4.5 percent even though the number of jobs reached a record high, the State Department of Labor reported on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACHTER, VIVIAN
description: PACHTER-Vivian. Like a sister, an aunt and a very special friend, we will always remember you with your warm smile. You'll always be greatly missed. We love you, Amy, Shelly, Cori, Kenny, Trish and Todd

title: The Staff of Life
description: Bread for the DepartedBy Bogdan Wojdowski.Translated by Madeline G. Levine.402 pp. Evanston, Ill.:Northwestern University Press. $19.95.

title: Putting An Office In the Home
description: AS telecommuting and home-based businesses become increasingly common, the traditional home office -- the card table in the corner of the family room or the kitchen table cleared after dinner -- has become a thing of the past. These days, home-based-business consultants say, establishing an efficient home office generally entails carving out a dedicated space -- a whole room or part of one -- and adapting it to suit the business's needs.

title: Carried Away
description: Corby Kummer gives many perfectly plausible theories to explain how designer water got to be a ubiquitous prop of the 90's (''Carried Away,'' Aug 30). However, I think he missed its connection to another prop of the 90's: Prozac. Everyone's in a better mood, but, you know, that dry mouth can be so annoying.

title: Tennessee Beats Florida to End Long Waiting Game
description: They had waited a long time to tear their goal posts down. Six years. But after four quarters of helmet-rattling football and 10 overtime plays, Tennessee exorcised the demons of Florida, outlasting the Gators by 20-17 to snap a five-year losing streak.

title: Text of Statement to Jury
description: Following is the text of the statement read by President Clinton at his Aug. 17 appearance before the grand jury investigating the Lewinsky matter, as provided to The New York Times by lawyers familiar with the testimony.

title: Face in the Painting
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Critically Wounded In Central Park Stabbing
description: The police were combing Central Park last night for an assailant carrying a knife after a man was found lying in a pool of blood with two stab wounds to the chest.

title: Point, Click and Play
description: Looking for a museum with displays about bugs? A martial arts school near home? A place your child can study violin? These and a raft of other activities and programs for children have been published twice a year since 1994 in the ''Kids' Guide,'' aimed mainly at parents in Essex, Somerset, Union and Morris Counties. To get the information, you had to pick up the free booklet at preschools, pediatricians' offices and similar places. Now you need to no farther than your computer and you get updates every two weeks or so. When you get on the site, http://www.kidsguide.com, the right side of the screen lists openings of sites and listing of events. On the left is a table of contents, including Places of History, Zoos, Great Outdoors, Theater, Music and Dance, New York, and Pennsylvania. Click on one, and you get the same listings as in the booklet; click on the name of say, a museum, and you get the museum's Web site. Maybe your child can show you how to do it.

title: Paradores On the Plain
description: CASTLES in Spain rate high on that country's list of travel attractions. Reality justifies the emphasis. As many as 2,200 castles embellish the Spanish landscape, counting those in various states of crumbling disintegration. The idea of spending a night in a 15th- or 16th-century castle appealed to my unwarranted sense of myself as an adventurer. I set up an itinerary to visit five of them this past May, all within driving distance of Madrid.

title: Congregants Uprooted by Fire Find Home for Holy Days
description: It was only three weeks ago that flames engulfed Central Synagogue in midtown Manhattan, badly damaging the 126-year-old architectural landmark.

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?; Don't Trust Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Country Flair In the Hudson Valley
description: DESCRIBING the Hudson River Valley as the East's answer to Sonoma County -- as some boosters do -- may seem a bit of hyperbole to those who haven't been up the river lately. No, the wine is not in the same league as Sonoma's superb offerings, but the valley's scenery is just as spectacular and in many ways much more romantic. And the Hudson Valley has some excellent restaurants that specialize in fine local ingredients.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'Bill and Bill'
description: In ''Bill and Bill,'' I play a postman and I have a talking dog. The irony, which is so important to me in my work, is that the postman's nemesis is, ordinarily, the dog, but in this story, the dog is the postman's lover and confidante. The lover part would ordinarily mean this series would have to be on cable, but what I mean by ''lover''is I give an occasional pat on the head, scratch on the belly and then a soft, gentle caress -- maybe this does have to be on cable.

title: More on Truckers And the Highways
description: I was bothered by the letter from Richard A. Lowenstein (''Truck Accidents, Another View,'' Aug. 30) and I want to come to the defense of truck drivers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SPANOPOLOU, EUGENIA, PH.D. AND HODTSEV, ANDREW, PH.D.
description: SPANOPOLOU-Eugenia, Ph.D. and Hodtsev, Andrew, Ph.D. A Memorial Service will be held at Mount Sinai School of Medicine to mark the tragic, untimely passing of our esteemed colleagues Eugenia Spanopolou, Ph.D, and her beloved husband Andrew Hodtsev, Ph.D., along with their 16 month old son Platon, in the crash of Swissair Flight 111 in Nova Scotia. Trustees, Faculty, Staff, Students and friends are invited to attend at 4 P.M., Wednesday, September 23 in the Goldwurm Auditorium, East Building, 1425 Madison Avenue at 98th Street.

title: Olivia Bingham And Scott English
description: Olivia Tiffany Bingham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram A. Bingham of Greenwich, Conn., and James Scott English, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James English 3d of New Haven, were married yesterday in Greenwich. The Rev. Jeffrey Walker performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHEL, PAULINE
description: FISCHEL-Pauline. Beloved wife of Edward. Cherished mother of Robert and Janet. Loving motherin-law of Shelley and of Russ Whitehurst. Devoted sister of Ethel, and sister-in-law of the late Alfred Raphael. Also cherished sister-in-law to Daniel and Maxine and the late Leon and Elaine. Dear grandmother of Joseph, Owen, Eliana, and Adam. Before retiring, she was a dedicated psychiatric social worker. Her guidance and caring lives on in her clients, friends, and family. Funeral service Sunday, September 20, 9:30AM, at I.J. Morris, Inc, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New Israel Fund or HIAS would be appreciated.

title: City to Close Several Streets Near the U.N.
description: In addition to several dozen heads of state, this year's annual debate at the United Nations General Assembly will bring even tighter security -- and more traffic detours -- than usual in the wake of the American Embassy bombings in Africa.

title: Record Briefs
description: 'THE CELLO AND THE KING OF PRUSSIA'

title: At Summer's End, These Two Still Shine
description: EATING at summery spots in the fall has it all, be they picturesque waterfront restaurants or Hamptons hangouts. Once the Labor Day weekend passes, most of us mentally write off these destinations, even though the glare of the sun has cooled and the vacationers have returned to their desks, resulting in ideal weather and plenty of seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDNER, JAMES ROBERT
description: BRUDNER-James Robert. On September 18, 1998. Beloved son of Harriet and Sheldon, loving brother of the late Eric, dear nephew, cousin and friend. Service Sunday 10AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Rosemary Spano, Aaron Stern
description: Rosemary C. Spano and Aaron Stern were married yesterday in the gardens of the Boscobel Restoration, a historic house in Garrison, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. William A. Weisenbach, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Housing Grants Awarded
description: MORE than $8 million in Federal block grants has been awarded to 37 communities in Westchester County, with the goal of building affordable housing, preventing the growth of homelessness and improving parks and open spaces.

title: What the Tube Is For
description: TV is good.''

title: Jets Might Help Initiate Leaguewide Program to Aid Players Off the Field
description: The Jets are among seven teams considering taking part in an experimental program aimed at keeping National Football League players out of trouble off the field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GODIN, MICHEL R.
description: GODIN-Michel R. Of Avranche, France. Passed away August 30, 1998. Former Captain at Le Cirque. He was survived by his daughter Astrid Godin. Memorial services will be held in his country of birth.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVITT, STACY
description: LEVITT-Stacy. It's ten years since we parted in the dentist's office. We'll always miss you, Sweetie. Love, Mommy and Michael

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
