description: To the Editor:

title: Breathe Deeply, and Start Saving
description: IN ''Down and Out in Paris and London,'' George Orwell wrote that ''poverty annihilates the future.'' In a way, he was right. There is something liberating in being down to your last centimes and surviving, especially if you're George Orwell.

title: From the Closet of History
description: THE OTHER SIDE OF SILENCE

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'The 20th Century: Good or Bad?'
description: Picture if you will a group of playwrights, young and attractive, middle-aged and sour, old and sibylline. They've been hired to write a series in which the entirety of the 20th century is to be dramatized over the course of five seasons, one or two years of the world's history per one-hour episode. It isn't merely the sheer infinite abundance of recorded events that's unmanageable; it's also the exquisitely vexed question of historical interpretation. Was this century, finally, a good or a bad thing?

title: VOWS; Cyril Christo, Marie Wilkinson
description: SIMPLY put, Cyril Christo is not a 9-to-5 guy. He is a poet, photographer and filmmaker who swears he will never work a regular job because he doesn't want to ''lose the wonder of existence.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURRIER, MICHAEL STEPHEN
description: CURRIER-Michael Stephen. On September 16th, after an accident, in Sante Fe, New Mexico. Beloved and devoted husband and father, he was an investor, philanthropist and supporter of the Dalai Lama. He will be missed immeasurably by his family and friends. A private memorial service will be held. In lieu of flowers, the family encourages that contributions of any size be made to the Sante Fe Community Foundation, P.O. Box 1827, Santa Fe, New Mexico, 87504, earmarked for a newly established fund in memory of Michael Currier.

title: In Debate Over Earth and Water, There's Fire in the Air
description: THERE'S the huge house going up in Sagaponack, and the long dock proposed for North Haven. But some East End environmentalists say their most pressing concern is a proposal for a golf course located in a natural intake area for the aquifer that provides most Long Islanders with their tap water.

title: Reserved Celebration of a Century of Golf
description: SITTING in a rocking chair on what used to be the men's porch at the New Haven Country Club, Joe Goldshinsky recalled the Rolls-Royces, Packards and LaSalles that once took up much of the space in the club's parking lot while their well-to-do owners played golf and cards and had lunch in the men's grill.

title: Clinton's Monica Problems Cast Shadow on 2 Freshmen
description: This is a tale of two freshmen whose fates may have become oddly intertwined because of one President and his relationship with an intern.

title: Judith Rader, Robin Richardson
description: Judith Anne Rader, a daughter of William D. Rader of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Joan Sperry Rader, was married yesterday to Robin Gordon Richardson, a son of Susan Merrill Richardson and Gordon Richardson of Boston. The Rev. Richard Lanz performed the ceremony at the Harbor Baptist Church on Block Island in Rhode Island.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on page 41 of the Arts & Leisure Section today about a new recording misspells the singer's surname in some copies. She is Bette Midler, not Middler.

title: No Easy Ride for Disabled
description: Left virtually crippled at 48 by a hip infection, Susana Lopez-Lira has come to rely on a city service that provides door-to-door transportation for the disabled. Yet booking a ride on that service can be a stressful ordeal that sometimes leaves her stranded.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'Mr. President, Private Eye'
description: President Jack Camden is the elected leader of the free world. He's also a crime buff, and whenever his official duties take him within 50 feet of a jewel theft, murder or art forgery, Camden can't help turning amateur sleuth. No crime is too small for this Commander in Chief's attention, and important business of state is often jeopardized to corner racehorse smugglers and opera-star blackmailers.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Watermelon

title: In the Stock Market, a Tenuous Recovery
description: For most of last week it looked as if storm clouds had lifted, as the stock market began recovering from the mauling it had taken in recent weeks -- even managing to climb for four consecutive days for the first time since June.

title: Devils' Young Defenders Getting a Look
description: The longer Scott Niedermayer continues to demand a $4 million-a-year contract to join the Devils, the better the chances are for several promising players to take a spot on the defense that was second best in the National Hockey League last season.

title: In Church, Changing of the Guard
description: BESET by rising costs and shrinking congregations, traditional Protestant churches that were once community mainstays in dozens of Long Island towns and villages are struggling to stay afloat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIMON, LEONARD
description: LIMON-Leonard. 76, of Cranford, NJ, on September 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Sybil (Cohen) Limon. Devoted father of Lynn of Richmond, VA, and Keith of Eastampton, NJ. Also survived by a grandson, Joshua.

title: Swiss Hills Are Alive With Sound of Diesels
description: At 4:45 A.M. sharp, the Alpine stillness here is broken by the roar of dozens of trucks. Having parked outside the St. Gotthard Tunnel to observe the Swiss ban on overnight truck traffic, the drivers now start their engines, and the noise echoes down the narrow Reuss Valley.

title: Commercial Property/UBS Center in Stamford, Conn.; A Swiss Bank's Industrial-Strength Trading Center
description: IF investment banking has always seemed tradition-bound, presenting a reassuring solidity through hushed, dark-paneled quarters swaddled in deep carpets and soft leathers, a 960,000 square-foot complex in Stamford, Conn., offers a revisionist view. Within the ruddy granite-like precast-concrete exterior, the Warburg Dillon Read Center works more like an industrial plant than a brass-lamped men's club.

title: Nostalgia Vies With Modernity In Monet
description: Not so long ago, 20 or 25 years maybe, Monet wasn't the immensely popular figure that he is now. If you go back yet another 25 years, people were actually talking about the need to reconsider his career, or part of it: in the early 1950's, American critics looking for antecedents to what the Abstract Expressionists were doing latched onto Monet's late works, like the Water Lilies, which had been mostly disregarded for a quarter century. To the critics, Monet suddenly justified Pollock, and vice versa.

title: English Manor In the Heartland
description: IN the early 20th century, few American industrialists were harder at work spending their vast fortunes to create a history for themselves than Frank A. Seiberling. Cofounder of the Goodyear rubber empire in Akron, Ohio, Seiberling built the largest private house in Ohio, Stan Hywet Hall, and surrounded it with one of the most splendid landscape gardens in the Midwest.

title: Invasion of the Land Snatchers
description: The transmutation of Nantucket from quaint redoubt of East Coast Wasps to summer playroom of the famously rich continues apace with a new round of eyebrow-elevating real estate transactions.

title: A Correction
description: Excerpts from remarks by members of the House Judiciary Committee following the vote to release President Clinton's grand jury testimony omitted an attribution at one point. The remarks were by the Republican chairman of the panel, Henry J. Hyde, not by Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts. A corrected version follows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, GERALD
description: FELDMAN-Gerald. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Gerald Feldman, associated with The Times from 1990.

title: Trenton Takes On Impact Fees, Licenses and Little League
description: Lawmakers returned to Trenton on Monday after a six-week summer recess to consider a new round of bills. Here are some highlights:

title: Our Towns; College Hunt Is Earlier And Trickier
description: LIKE the proverbial tourist who knows he's in Belgium because it's Tuesday, Philip Lutgendorf scratched his head to reconstruct where he and his daughter Claire had been the last week.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season
description: What if there were no ratings? What if time slots didn't matter? What if television could cross boundaries, mix genres, break all the rules? We asked a few good minds from the theater, movies, government and, yes, even television to create the shows they wish they could watch. On the following pages, a portfolio of what their lineup would look like.

title: Poetic and Surreal, Georgian Cinema Is True to Life
description: THIS small nation nestled under the towering Caucasus Mountains, which has a history stretching back several millennia but which emerged from the debris of the Soviet Union only seven years ago, has a rich creative tradition based on the mixture of fantasy and reality.

title: Censorship in the Age of Anything Goes; Where Have You Gone, Standards and Practices?
description: LAST week, Fox ran an on-air promotion for a pair of sitcoms, ''Living in Captivity'' and ''Getting Personal.'' To make the point that the shows were sassy and sexy compared with tamer Friday night programming on other channels, the commercial depicted a man being chased as a voice-over announced, ''We ran the censors off, and boy, does it show!''

title: BENEFITS
description: Happy Birthday, George

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, J. MICHAEL
description: HAMMER-J. Michael. September 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Samantha and J. Michael, Jr. Brother of George A., Patrick, Ernest H., and Jane Dwyer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, September 21, 1998, 5-9 PM. Service Tuesday, September 22, 1998, 11 AM, University Church at Fordham, 441 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY.

title: Katharine Ijams, Clement Butt

title: Giving An Old College Try The Star Treatment
description: THE world of dance did not pause in its erratic spin when a young Belgian dancer named Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker presented what amounted to her first choreography in 1981 at a festival in Westchester County. A solo set to Steve Reich's ''Violin Phase,'' the dance was uncompromisingly formal and repetitious. Though it was recognizably influenced by the post-modernist dance minimalism of the time, unexpected undercurrents of emotion set the solo apart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, SYBIL
description: HARRINGTON-Sybil. It is with profound sadness we mourn the death of Sybil Harrington, devoted member of our official family since 1967 and a Director of our Managing Board since 1980. One of the most generous Patrons in Metropolitan Opera history, in addition to her leadership gift to create the Metropolitan Opera's first endowment fund, Sybil underwrote 16 new Met productions, two gala concerts and 13 ''Metropolitan Opera Presents'' telecasts, including this season's telecasts of ''Samson et Dalila'' and ''La Cenerentola'' and the James Levine 25th Anniversary Gala. Her underwriting support for the current Met productions of ''Don Carlo,'' ''Manon Lescaut,'' ''La Boheme,'' ''Francesca da Rimini,'' ''Die Fledermaus,'' ''Turandot,'' ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Aida,'' ''Don Giovanni,'' ''La Fanciulla del West,'' ''Die Meistersinger von Nuernberg'' and ''Otello'' represent her passionate commitment to traditional productions of the core opera repertory. She took special pleasure in supporting the Met telecasts so that everyone throughout the country could be part of the Met audience. Sybil Harrington's philanthropy has left a legacy that will endure for generations to come. Each season's telecasts and productions supported by that legacy will help us recall with the fondest of memories her devoted love for the Met. The Opera House Auditorium bears Sybil Harrington's name in honor of the singular example she set for philanthropic commitment to the Metropolitan Opera. Metropolitan Opera Association Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear, Chairman Bruce Crawford, President

title: Talking the Tawk; New Yorkers Are Sounding More Like Everybody Else. Is It Curtains for the Accent People Love to Hate?
description: IT'S loud, it's fast and when some of its more famous speakers -- like Fran Drescher (''The Nanny'') and Joe Pesci (''My Cousin Vinny'') use it, you know exactly where they're coming from. It's New York ese, the mother tongue of millions of city dwellers and of expatriates who have taken it to Long Island, New Jersey and beyond.

title: For Yahoo, the Growth Mantra Goes On and On and On
description: Investors searching for signs of life in the stock market, and for the technology sector in particular, need look no further than their Internet search engine. While thousands of stocks are trading at 25 percent or more below their recent highs, shares of Yahoo, which closed at $90.4375 on Friday, are up 430 percent from their one-year low and off just 12.8 percent from their high on July 7.

title: Dressing the Help In Designer Wear
description: A CENTURY ago, butlers often wore mismatched trousers with their evening tail coats, to make sure no one ever mistook them for dinner guests. Today, having a staff that's decked out as stylishly as the guests is precisely the point for many hotels and restaurants, which are hiring designers like Isaac Mizrahi and Dolce & Gabbana to create uniforms. If the staff looks even sweller than the patrons, so much the better in the age of hipper than thou.

title: Clinton and Starr, a Mutual Admonition Society
description: On Aug. 3, in the White House Map Room, President Clinton rolled up his shirt sleeve in the presence of an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and a prosecutor from the office of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The White House physician, Dr. E. Connie Mariano, drew a vial of the President's blood.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: The trouble with traveling on the World Wide Web is that after a while you may crave a home there, a place where you pick up your mail, chat with friends, trade gossip and information or just hang out. On the Web, you can wander from site to site, searching for rooms and restaurants, booking air fares, seeking sights to see and places to play. But it is like staying in a different hotel every night of a vacation; eventually you forget where you are, and you never talk to anyone. Consequently, a dozen or so Web sites have gotten more homey lately.

title: Taking Charge In Interviews
description: Q. Next week I have a job interview. I really want the job, but I know there will be many other candidates. Some people seem to glide effortlessly through interviews and get offers every time they apply. But for me, the process is a stressful ordeal, and though I am often told I've made the short list, I rarely get an offer. How can I make myself stand out from the crowd this time?

title: Censorship in the Age of Anything Goes; For Artistic Freedom, It's Not the Worst of Times
description: Three years ago, Amy Lippman and Christopher Keyser joined the legions of writers exploring once taboo subjects when they wrote a script for the Fox drama ''Party of Five,'' in which Julia, a principal character, got pregnant from her first sexual encounter and had an abortion. But, in a sign of the times, Ms. Lippman and Mr. Keyser, the executive producers of the highly regarded television show for young people, were persuaded that the story was too racy and rewrote it so that Julia (Neve Campbell) had a miscarriage before going in for the abortion.

title: Cambodia: A New Try
description: Wars, elections, coups and riots come and go in Cambodia, but the unhappy entanglement of the Prince and the former Communist, it seems, is never-ending.

title: Remembering a Mentor Who Sought Perfection
description: THERE was no one quite like James Truitte. Lean and craggy faced, intense yet calm, Truitte brought a quietly dramatic, powerful presence and maturity to bear on Alvin Ailey's earliest dances. He had come to Ailey after dancing with Joseph Rickard's Hollywood Negro Ballet and with Lester Horton, the West Coast modern-dance pioneer, in the late 1940's and early 1950's. After retirement from the stage, Truitte became an active and passionate disseminator of the little-known Horton technique and repertory in dance companies and schools across the nation. An old-school gentleman, Truitte looked back with remarkable detachment -- and wry wit -- on a creative life circumscribed by racial bigotry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALCHON, BERNARD FORBES
description: ALCHON-Bernard Forbes 83, an Orphan Train rider. Born November 1914 in NYC to Grace Forbes, father unknown, at 1 1 /2 ''Henry Forbes'' was sent by the Children's Aid Society (CAS) to Osage, IA, where adoption by Maude and Guy Alchon ''transformed a throwaway into a son.'' To honor their memory, and that of CAS founder Charles Loring Brace, Mr. Alchon recently established a college scholarship for children of the CAS. The first award will be made in 1999. A 1936 graduate of the University of Iowa, a businessman, and a resident of Highland Park, IL, Mr. Alchon was married to the late Marion Gargan Alchon of New Orleans. He is survived by a son, Guy, and a granddaughter, Lilla. Another son, Fred, died in 1974. Contributions may be made to the ''Alchon Scholarship Fund'' of the CAS, 105 East 22nd St., New York, NY 10010, or the Orphan Train Heritage Society, 614 East Emma Ave., Springdale, AR 72764.

title: Where Kennedys Once Played
description: The oil billionaire DAVID KOCH took the wraps off his newly redecorated Fifth Avenue apartment, formerly owned by JACKIE ONASSIS. And, the guest of honor was -- GEORGE BUSH . In rooms where CAROLINE and JOHN JR. once played, Wall Streeters and former Republican officials sipped Chateau Margaux and dined Friday on gold-leaf china to honor one of Mr. Bush's favorite charities, the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. Tanned and fit, Mr. Bush asked: ''What do you do when you used to be President with the rest of your life?'' His answer: ''Plug my causes,'' including charities where ''I'm a big deal now.'' JOHN HENNESSY , chairman of CS First Boston, and LIZ TILBERIS , editor of Harper's Bazaar, attended the event as did BOB MOSBACHER , a former Commerce Secretary; WALTER CURLEY , a former Ambassador to France, and JOSEPH ZAPPALA , a former Ambassador to Spain. Mr. Koch, who paid $9.5 million for the apartment and spent three years redecorating it, quipped: ''If I knew what Jackie's possessions would fetch at Sotheby's, I would have taken the place furnished.''

title: Of Prints, Propriety and Property
description: DAVE WILLIAMS , chairman of Alliance Capital, and his wife, REBA, are adding 18th century work by the Peale family of Philadelphia to their 6,000-piece collection of early American prints. The couple paid just under $50,000 for a Charles Wilson Peale museum ticket and the plate from which it was made. . . . RICHARD BRANSON , the billionaire owner of the Virgin business empire, is now marketing a stripped-down version of himself. In the past, he has appeared in outlandish costumes, including a wedding dress, to peddle his products. Now, he is appearing in ads in British newspapers in the buff, except for a strategically placed newspaper, to promote ''Losing My Virginity -- the Autobiography.'' . . . MOSSIMO GIANNULLI , the California designer whose net worth has declined by a half-billion dollars or so as his company's stock price nose-dived, has been unloading property in California, including his curved-concrete Laguna Beach bluff home to a New Jersey trust last month for close to $3.5 million and an undeveloped five-acre site near Newport Beach for nearly $12 million, a local real estate agent said. . . . RUPERT MURDOCH , the News Corporation chairman who is divorcing his wife ANNA , has put his Beverly Hills estate on the block for $19.5 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, JOHN J.
description: HOPKINS-John J. On behalf of the Boards of Directors, Administration & staff of Calvary Hospital, Inc, and Calvary Fund, Inc, we mourn the passing of our longtime board member and dear friend. John Hopkins served on the hospital Board of Directors since 1982. He gave generously of his time, as First Vice-Chairman of the Board, Chairman of the Planning Committee, member of the Executive, Finance and Nominating Committees of the hospital board and Treasurer of the Calvary Fund Board. His wisdom, commitment and leadership contributed enormously to the growth and success of the hospital program of care and to the efforts of the Calvary Fund. We will miss John, both as a dedicated board member and as a true friend. We extend our condolences to his wife Joan; his children; his grandchildren and other members of his family. Thomas J. Fahey, Jr., MD Chairman of the Calvary Hospital Board of Directors Dennis E. Berberich, Chairman of the Calvary Fund Board of Directors Frank A. Calamari, President-Executive Director Michael J. Brescia, MD, Medical Director James E. Cimino, MD Director of Calvary Palliative Care Institute, Richard J. Kutilek, Chief Operating Officer Roy Clary, Executive Vice-President, Calvary Fund

title: Should the Mississippi Files Have Been Reopened?
description: 'Should the Mississippi Files Have Been Reopened'' (by David Oshinsky and Richard Rubin, Aug. 30)? Yes, yes, yes. In the fall of 1964, my family and I (I was 15) moved from New Rochelle, N.Y., to Greenwood, Miss. I had recently attended a summer camp in upstate New York run by Quakers (where Andrew Goodman had been a counselor the summer before and where Bonnie Raitt had been a fellow camper). When news came of the three killings, I was terrified because I knew that my family and I were going to move to Greenwood when the summer ended.

title: Should the Mississippi Files Have Been Reopened?
description: The situation in Greenwood today, which Richard Rubin calls ''a separate peace'' and (I suspect euphemistically) ''separate but equal'' is not the best we can achieve. The proud old bigots he interviewed, the nearly all-black inmate population at the local prison, the segregated schools, these don't add up to a utopian status quo to be protected at the cost of suppressing the truth about the past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSHBERG, FRANCINE NEE SCHAMROTH
description: HIRSHBERG - Francine nee Schamroth. On Friday, September 18. Loving and caring wife of Irwin and mother of Karen and Gary Hediger, William, Lesley and Craig Miller, and devoted and loving grandmother of Eric, Carl, Erin, Janine & Dana. Beloved daughter of the late Isidore and Regina Shamroth. Born in Antwerp, Belgium & came to New York in 1939. Graduated the Walden School and the University of Pennsylvania. Of complications of a spinal injury. Funeral at Wein and Wein, 129 Engle St., Englewood, New Jersey at 2 PM on Sunday, September 20. Family and friends will be received at the home of Francine and Irwin after the services and during the week.

title: Operation Cover-Up
description: There are cosmetic lines tailored to all skin types: oily, dry, sensitive, combination -- and now, post-op skin. After years of working with plastic surgery patients, Kamara Ahnert, the owner of a makeup studio on Madison Avenue, has designed a kit of makeup to help camouflage the unattractive aftereffects of laser procedures, face lifts, rhinoplasty and so on. The $235 kit's main attraction is a corrector palette, which holds five hues of base concealer: mint and amber to temper redness, mauve for dark bruising, neutral yellow for lines. Also included are powder and fan brushes to help set makeup on freshly resurfaced or tightened skin, and extra-mild makeup removal pads with chamomile and aloe vera. The products contain PABA-free sunscreen and are hypoallergenic.

description: BURKE-Cathleen. In memory of Cathleen Houlihan Burke, who died on the 20th of September, 1994. She was gallant, brilliant, beautiful and loved.

title: Where a Hindu Temple in Flushing Sits Next to a Dutch Farmhouse in Flatlands
description: David Goldfarb's virtual neighborhood, a Hindu temple in Flushing, Queens, sits next to a 1720 Dutch farmhouse in Flatlands, Brooklyn, and the Friends of Terra Cotta hang with a fervid cabal of New York City gargoyle enthusiasts. You can wander around this historically dense and perpetually threatened zone at Preserve and Protect, a Web site Mr. Goldfarb started two years ago as an Internet crossroads for nonprofit preservation groups, mostly in the city, and people who appreciate the places they protect.

title: My Favorite Show; Stanley Crouch on 'Oz'
description: When I came upon the premiere of ''Oz'' on HBO in the summer of 1997, I was startled. By the last of the first eight episodes of this prison drama, I was sure it had set another standard for realism and expanded the dramatic territory of cable television. To my delight, it had a fully integrated cast, with a range of characters who ''looked like America'' and were conceived with impressively realistic ethnic nuances, from the administrators all the way down to the very lowest criminal. In every respect, ''Oz'' went beyond the vast majority of our celebrated contemporary fiction, where the idea of trying to achieve expression across lines of race, class and religion is truly a minority effort.

title: Down on the Farm, Where Anxiety Grows
description: When the weather turns disastrous, or a Presidential campaign goes on the road, television news programs deliver the now-familiar images of America's agricultural heartland: wheat fields, tractors and two-lane blacktop. This week, ''The Farmer's Wife,'' on the PBS series ''Frontline,'' goes beyond those comforting vistas and inside the lives of a young Nebraska farm couple who struggle to keep their finances in order as they fight to save their marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLONE, HARRY
description: SLONE-Harry. Beloved husband of Ruthe. Loving father of Richard and Merry. Adored grandfather of Tara & Wayne Goldstein, Ondine and Michael Miranda, Lauren and David Leighton. Cherished great grandfather of Zachary, Joshua, Daniel and Max. He will be in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORTIMER, JOHN AND HILDA
description: MORTIMER-John and Hilda. On Tuesday, September 29 at 2PM at the First Congregational Church, Sound Beach Ave., Old Greenwich, CT. Reception to follow.

title: Texans Call Terror Suspect Apolitical
description: By the accounts of those who worked for him at a ramshackle Fort Worth tire shop and lived near him in a rundown apartment block on a dead-end street here in Arlington, about a mile from the stately mosque where he prayed every Friday, Wadih el Hage was even-tempered, devout and utterly apolitical.

title: Maury Hanigan, Brian Edwards
description: Maurelia A. Hanigan and Brian George Edwards were married yesterday at the English-Speaking Union in Manhattan by Judge Marian C. Doherty of Housing Court in the Bronx.

title: Amy Brunski, Thomas Hudson
description: Amy Lynn Brunski, a daughter of Jill and David Brunski of Shrewsbury, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Hudson, a son of Marilyn Hudson of Oklahoma City and the late Jim Hudson. The Rev. C. David McKirachan performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church.

title: Gubernatorial Candidate Hires Ex-Aide to Weicker
description: A former chief of staff to Lowell P. Weicker Jr. will be the chief strategist for New York's Independence Party gubernatorial candidate, B. Thomas Golisano.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUTSTEIN, LEONARD R
description: RUTSTEIN-Leonard R. Dec. 15, 1924-Sept. 18, 1988. In Loving Memory.

title: Princeton Christens Its New Stadium Appropriately
description: The home team scored on its first two drives in its new home today, and went on to dedicate Princeton Stadium with a 6-0 victory over Cornell.

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'Love and Death on the High C's'
description: The upcoming television season should feature a soap opera that is truly an opera. Every scene will be sung and every character be played by a male or female diva. Background music will be a full orchestra with a conductor who has long hair. Here is the first installment:

title: Amy Gambrill, William Vincent
description: Amy Johanne Gambrill, a daughter of Johanne N. Gambrill of Tenafly, N.J., and James H. Gambrill of York, Me., was married yesterday to William Sullivan Vincent, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Vincent of Asheville, N.C. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington.

title: Familiar Faces Return to Moscow
description: Ten years ago, when Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet President, was tinkering with an ossified Communist economy, he sought the advice of a group of then-liberal economists who advocated such notions as a ''regulated market economy.''

title: Ruling Party In Panama Is Profiting From Canal
description: As Minister of Housing for the last four years, Francisco Sanchez Cardenas was supposed to improve other people's living conditions, not his own. But with the United States turning hundreds of homes of departing military officers over to Panama as stipulated by treaty, he and other leaders of the governing party have got the best residences for themselves.

title: What a Difference a Week Can Make: Bellport Rights Itself
description: Long Island

title: Beverly Brown, Thomas O'Toole
description: Beverly Lisa Brown, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan J. Brown of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Thomas Patrick O'Toole, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Toole of Franklin, Pa. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at Windows on the World in New York. The Rev. R. John Nelson took part in the ceremony.

title: Brooklyn Man Dies In Street Shooting
description: A 19-year-old man was shot to death on a busy commercial street near his home in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, on Friday afternoon in an attack by at least four other young men. The police would not say whether the killing was gang-related.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, RAYMOND F.
description: YOUNG-Raymond F. September 18, 1998, of Chappaqua, NY. Loving husband of Carol. Devoted father of Jessica, Kelsey and Alexandra. Dear brother of Steve Young and Melissa Wilkinson. Cherished son of Robert and the late Bernice Young and step-son of Joyce Young. Funeral service at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Sunday, September 20 at 1:30 PM. Interment Temple Israel Cemetery. Ray loved life and lived it to the fullest, and we will miss and love him forever.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: MUSIC

title: Earth's 911
description: Are you seeking information on the Household Chemical Clean-Up Day Program or disposal instructions for special materials? The county's Recycling Office has joined the ''Earth's 911,'' a nationwide environmental hot line and a free public-private partnership enabling county residents to get access to recycling and waste reduction facts and data. The hot line -- a public service sponsored by businesses, including the Bank of America, Edison International, America West Airlines, Microsoft, Home Depot and Sprint -- originated as a regional source of information but is now available in all 50 states and parts of Canada.

title: Political Briefing; Wilson's Love-Him, Love-Him-Not Polls
description: Pete Wilson has fought a lot of tough battles in almost eight years as Governor of California. But his toughest fight has always been with the polls.

title: Why Not Let The Show Go On, Then Rebut It?
description: CENSORSHIP is the tribute paid by established political and religious groups to the power of art. By seeking to suppress a poem, a play, a painting, a photograph, the leaders of such groups signal their fear of its message. But they also pay the work the compliment of taking it seriously, which puts artists and their supporters in something of a bind. There is nothing we want more than to be taken seriously. Even to be noticed amid the cacophony of the contemporary media circus is an achievement. To be singled out and thought worthy of frontal attack is a signal honor.

title: The Have-Nots, at Least, Have Shelter in a Storm
description: INCOME inequality is taking on a new dimension these days. Not only have people's weekly earnings grown more disparate than in the past; what they possess -- their accumulated wealth -- has also grown more unequal lately. The haves and the have-nots, or more precisely those who have prospered and those who have stood still, are becoming easier to tell apart. Now the have-nots might get a break.

title: The Pace of Justice
description: As the nation uneasily ponders the prospect of impeachment, Americans should be grateful that the Constitution was conceived when weighty decisions of state were not expected to be made overnight. There are no time lines or deadlines in the impeachment provisions, and the Congress would be wise not to bend the procedures to fit the era of instant communication and lightning news cycles. The constitutional blueprint will work if it is followed faithfully and with due regard for the welfare of the nation rather than that of a political party or any individual.

title: New York's Baby Picture
description: HOW has New York's appearance changed since 1650? A lot, as New Yorkers will confirm when a watercolor believed to be the oldest surviving visual representation of New York returns for the first time since the 17th century. The drawing, ''The City of New Amsterdam Located on the Island of Manhattan in New Netherland,'' will be the centerpiece of the exhibition ''New York Begins,'' opening on Saturday at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Ideas & Trends; Newfangled Econ 101: Throw Caution to the Winds
description: THE Japanese are well versed in the art of fending off American accusations, including the perpetual hyperventilating over Japan's protectionist trade policies. But nothing from the past could have prepared the Japanese for the latest salvo by several prominent American economists who say the Japanese Government has been insufficiently reckless.

title: Reinventing the Box
description: They rage against Materialism, as they call it, forgetting that there has been no material improvement that has not spiritualized the world.'' So wrote Oscar Wilde, right as usual. Wilde would have doted on high-definition television (HDTV), a material improvement that is strictly esthetic in purpose and, yes, spiritualizing in its probable effects. I've seen it, twice -- in promotional demonstrations given this summer in New York City. And here's my impression: for better or worse, HDTV is going to change us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, FRANCES (FROLICH)
description: LEWIN-Frances (Frolich). Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Member of the Hunter College Alumni Hall of Fame along with classmate Bella Abzug. For 20 years she was Commissioner of the Broadway show League giving entertainment each week to 400 members of the Broadway theatre community. After graduating from Hunter, class of 1942, she worked at the Brooklyn Navy Yard on various aircraft carriers. She is survived by her husband Richard (Dick), three children, Jill Chesler of CA., Richard E. Lewin II and Jay Lewin of New York and five granddaughters. Services will be private. Contributions may be made in her name to the Hunter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund.

title: Making Schools A Thriving Environment
description: Child Abuse Prevention Services shares the experience of the Suffolk County Organization for the Promotion of Education, which has been deluged with requests for presentations on violence in schools. Last year, the CAPS Child Safety Institute presented more than 700 sessions with students on topics ranging from bully prevention and sexual harassment to child abuse and date rape.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Shrinking Violet

title: Sex, Race and Peking Man
description: LOST IN TRANSLATION

title: On Language; Broken Records
description: In 1965, Gordon E. Moore, co-founder of Intel, boldly predicted that the power of computer chips would double every 18 months. Moore's Law has turned out to be remarkably prescient -- about the content of computers. It is no guide, however, to the content of communication. There are no automatic upgrades, updates or new releases for language. English is studded with fossils of techno-terminology, and how we use them tells much about how language does change.

title: What They Do Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Ashley Goodale, C. J. Muse Jr.
description: Ashley Krissel Goodale, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Goodale of New York, was married last evening to Christopher James Muse Jr., the son of J. Christine Whalen of Northampton, Mass., and Mr. Muse of Boston. The Rev. Diana W. Phillips, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Pierre in New York.

title: Unchained
description: RESCUING PROMETHEUS

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with a listing of entertainment at casinos in Atlantic City was published in error. The picture showed Buddy Greco, not the Second Story Guys.

title: Streetscapes/The Langham, Central Park West and 73d Street; Tall and Sophisticated, and Just North of the Dakota
description: THE 1907 Langham apartment house at 73d Street and Central Park West is tall and sophisticated, cosmopolitan compared to the brooding, scrunched-down Victorian design of the Dakota, on which it looks down across the street. Indeed, the builders of the Dakota unsuccessfully tried to keep the Langham lower than their own structure. Now work crews are making the 13-story Langham a few feet taller, as the owner restores its giant mansard roof.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: FLUSHING MEADOWS

title: Negative Ads in Governor's Race
description: And then there was the race for governor.

title: Staten Island Teacher Accused of Raping Girl
description: A teacher at Tottenville High School on Staten Island was arrested Friday night and charged with raping and sodomizing a 15-year-old girl in a school building on several occasions during May and June.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A Hollywood drama, a Broadway classic, a caustic western and a Swedish milestone highlight the week's movie meny.

title: With Arrests, a Breakthrough in the Case of the Purloined Best Sellers
description: For years, people in the book industry have assumed that the best sellers available from New York City street vendors at bargain prices were stolen. But publishers and booksellers said they had no idea how these books made their way onto the sidewalk tables.

title: Just a Moral Lapse, or an Impeachable Offense?; Public Needs the Facts
description: To the Editor:

title: Over-Long School Day Winds Up at the Police Station
description: If it's 4:30, parents of pupils in School District 18 know where their children are: at a local police station, where school officials regularly deliver students who have not been picked up within 90 minutes after the 3 P.M. dismissal bell.

title: Trial by Style
description: Courtrooms and their casts of characters may look like this only in the movies; think film noir or, more recently, ''L.A. Confidential.'' But any man, regardless of profession, can dress in the elegant style of the celluloid drama presented here. And this season offers plenty of choices for those who prefer suits with style. Look for vests, matched and unmatched, and for peaked lapels on single-breasted jackets, as well as ticket pockets, side vents and hand-finished details, like decorative stitching on lapels. Suits can also be found in offbeat colors, including mocha brown, royal blue and pearl gray, a standout in this predominantly gray season. Patterns play their part, too, from bold chalkstripes and jaunty pinstripes to English-flavored windowpanes. Weigh all the evidence, and choose your style for fall.

title: This Slightly Tarnished Hero, Bert Parks, Finally Returns
description: Eighteen years after he was dismissed for being ''too old'' at the age of 63, Bert Parks, the grinning, Georgia-born pitchman who had a 25-year run as the Miss America pageant's master of ceremonies, returned to the city that made him famous -- as a statue.

title: Familiar Names In Minnesota Too
description: In a race among men with famous Minnesota names, victory in the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party's primary for governor went to the state's most revered one: Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: Acheson's Cold War
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Love Among the Orientals

title: Endpaper
description: I always loved the 'Queen for a Day' concept - the perfect blend of complaint, confession and consumerism - but I'd like to update it for the 90's.

title: Russia Crisis Leaves Yeltsin Pushed Aside
description: As Russia's new Prime Minister struggled to patch together a coalition Cabinet last week, Boris N. Yeltsin seemed to fade into the background, adding to the growing impression that the country's crisis has left the once-powerful President with a largely ceremonial role.

title: IN MY BRIEFCASE/JEFFREY D. SACHS
description: Jeffrey D. Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development, spends roughly one-third of his life on the road, giving lectures and troubleshooting the institute's economic development projects from Indonesia to southern Africa. This day, he packed light for the flight back to Boston from Jacksonville, Fla., but included a lot of reading material in his briefcase, ''in case we get stuck on the runway.''

title: Lisa Friedman, Matthew Shevach
description: Lisa Iris Friedman, the daughter of Diane Friedman and Dr. Alan J. Friedman of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Alan Shevach, a son of Ruth Shevach and Dr. Ethan M. Shevach of Rockville, Md. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated at the Essex House in New York.

title: Loving A Stock, Not Wisely But Too Well
description: THE tip arrived at the rustic New Hampshire farmhouse of George A. Schrader Jr. in a large manila envelope, postmarked Boston and stuffed with the hopeful prospect of future riches.

title: What's a Network to Do?
description: The telephone is ringing in the Veranda suite of the Regent Beverly Wilshire. ''I'm sure it's for the network guy,'' says Fred Silverman knowingly. Silverman, who is 61, now produces ''Diagnosis: Murder,'' but in a past incarnation, during the heyday of network television in the 70's and early 80's, he was the only person to oversee the programming of all three major networks. At CBS, in the early 70's, he reinforced the Tiffany network's high-toned image by scheduling ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and ''All in the Family'' and its many offspring (''Maude,'' ''The Jeffersons''); at ABC, in the mid- and late 70's, he was known for a mix of ''jiggle shows'' (''Charlie's Angels,'' ''Three's Company'') and prestige mini-series (''Roots''). And, at NBC in 1980, he began the laborious process of turning around that network, which was then dead last in the ratings, with shows like ''Hill Street Blues.''

title: A Fantasy Fall Season; 'This, That And the Other'
description: It seems to me that the promise of television has not been kept. The promise that, for the first time, in the privacy of your own home, you could see what was going on, as it was going on, with a drink in your hand.

title: A Casino in Wildwood?
description: Should an Indian-run casino be allowed in Wildwood on a municipal parking lot that would be transferred to the Delaware tribe?

title: Carried Away
description: As a dentist, I have noticed a considerable increase in dental caries among my pediatric patients whose parents have chosen bottled water as their primary source of drinking water. I have done research over the Internet to find the fluoride content of some bottled waters and have noted that the most commonly used one, Poland Spring, does not contain adequate amounts of fluoride to prevent dental caries in developing teeth. In fact, you would have to drink 10 liters of Poland Spring per day to achieve the recommended allowance. I am an advocate of bottled water and filtered water, when used with caution. However, it is disturbing to perform dental services on a 5-year-old with eight cavities.

title: A Man Nobody Knew
description: To the students of my generation at Columbia in the late 1950's and early 60's, a decade after ''The Liberal Imagination'' had made him famous, Lionel Trilling was already a legendary figure, the intellectual conscience of the English department, the entrepreneur of distinguished book clubs, a link to the turbulent world of the New York intellectuals, above all a teacher and critic dangerous to emulate and virtually impossible to please.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSETT, JEROLD I.
description: ROSETT-Jerold I. Beloved husband of Mildred, adored father of Stephanie and Jonathan Westphal, Barry and Susan Rosett, Leslie and Barrie Borr, cherished Grammydad of Alexander, Sophia, Thomas, Lucy, Casey, Molly, Joanna and Jacob, devoted brother-in-law of Eugene Ogush, loving brother of Jacqueline Dack.

title: On Mediation In Divorce Cases
description: In her comments on divorce in Connecticut (''Q&A: Marriage, and Divorce, as 50-50 Propositions,'' Aug. 30), Lorna J. Wendt laments that too often each spouse's contribution is not fairly valued in divorce settlements.

title: Aphids, Scourge of the Garden
description: THE first sign of trouble is an oddly shaped leaf. It's twisted, and puckered like seersucker, and I know before lifting it to check the underside what I'm going to find there. Aphids.

title: The Thursday-Night Massacre
description: On Christmas Eve in Aspen, Colo., Don Ohlmeyer got a telephone call that realigned all the planets in his professional world.

title: POSTINGS: Westbury on Madison Is Being Converted; Westbury on Madison Is Being Converted
description: An English real estate company is transforming a grand old 238-room hotel, the 71-year-old Westbury on Madison Avenue between 69th and 70th Streets, into only 47 -- perhaps even grander -- condominium apartments.

title: Margo Heher, Sebastian Hill
description: Margaret Warne Heher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Heher of Hopewell Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Sebastian Martin Coote Hill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin P. Hill of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Richard A. Kunz performed the ceremony at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Princeton.

title: A New Irish Restaurant With a Big Irish Breakfast
description: Bagatelle, a first-venture Celtic-inspired restaurant and bar owned by Lee-Ann Durcan, opened three weeks ago at 12 St. Marks Place (between Second and Third Avenues) in the East Village. Ms. Durcan, raised on Long Island, named her place after a contemporary rock band popular in Ireland.

title: Magazine Has Ideas for Post-Clinton Democrats, and Gore Looms Large
description: As the debate intensifies over President Clinton's political future, a new magazine will be introduced next week that is devoted to the post-Clinton era in American politics -- and, apparently, to the election of Vice President Al Gore in 2000.

title: Record Briefs
description: MENDELSSOHN: STRING QUARTETS

title: Judy With Punch
description: Like a cooling, delectable lemonade, MEET ME IN ST. LOUIS (1944) suffuses the screen with a homey musical glow - an ideal showcase for the young Judy Garland (above, with Tom Drake) as the focus of a winning Missouri clan during a World's Fair. Vincente Minnelli smoothingly pilots the vignettes of family upset and young love based on Sally Benson's New Yorker magazine stories with a fine cast that includes Leon Ames, Mary Astor, Lucille Bremer and Harry Davenport. the Martin-Blane songs are delightful, and a Halloween sequence with little Margaret O'Brien is enchanting. There are few sweet movies; this is one of them. Small wonder that Minnelli and his star later married - WEDNESDAY at 10:30 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies.

title: A Flash in Time Is Buried in Alabama
description: People did not throng the streets of Montgomery to see the white hearse roll slowly by, at least not as many people as might have been expected. Maybe, some political experts surmised, it was because George C. Wallace had already passed into history.

title: Skip Away Runs Away From All-Star Field to Win the Woodward Stakes
description: Skip Away raced into thoroughbred history yesterday when he won the 45th Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park against an all-star field. With the victory, his ninth straight, he drew ever closer to the stature and the money record of the great Cigar.

title: Children's Books
description: SOMEONE LIKE YOU

title: Solange Brown, John Reppas
description: Solange Stephanie Pezon Brown and John Basil Reppas, students in the M.D.-Ph.D. program at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., were married yesterday at the Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, Ill. The Rev. George Councell performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: A Place to Mourn and Share 'the Silent Loss'
description: SHE had no birth certificate, no death certificate. But there was, ever so briefly, a human being. All that was left, after nine months of pregnancy, were memories. A fluttering in the belly, an elbow or a foot kicking to the side. Hopes and dreams for a life that ended almost before it began.

title: A Street Seeks a Detour for Heavyweights on 18 Wheels
description: When Delphine Faison, 47, moved back to her native Harlem four years ago, she observed a distinct change in the neighborhood.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: UNCOMMON PEOPLE

title: Mine! Mine! All Mine!
description: THE NOBLEST TRIUMPHProperty and Prosperity Through the Ages.By Tom Bethell.378 pp. New York:St. Martin's Press. $29.95.

title: City Panel Rejects Sale of Building to Kingdom of Bhutan
description: A little-known city panel has voted to kill the sale of a $2.3 million city-owned building to the Kingdom of Bhutan. In rejecting the deal Thursday by a 9-to-2 vote, the panel -- the Manhattan Borough Board -- cited reports of Bhutan's ''extremely poor human rights record.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGILL, J. THURSTON
description: MAGILL-J. Thurston. Memorial service Sunday, September 27, 1 PM, at Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th St., NYC. Contributions may be made to the Church, attention: John Haynes Holmes Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDEY, HELEN, DR.
description: EDEY-Helen, Dr. The Directors and Staff of The Scherman Foundation are saddened by the loss of our dear collegue Dr. Helen Edey. Helen was a passionate advocate for the environment, an indefatigable fighter for women's reproductive rights and a strong voice for human rights and liberties. Her feistiness and thoughtful contributions to our deliberations will be missed. Our condolences to her children and grandchildren. Axel Rosin, Chair Emeritus Karen R. Sollins, Chair Sandra Silverman, President

title: Conduct Unbecoming
description: The Death of Outrage

title: Welcome, Friend. Wanna Bet?
description: In a brilliantly cynical venture, the Palestinian Authority unveiled last week the first large, for-profit international investment in Yasir Arafat's territory: a casino catering to Israelis.

title: Hard to Tell, But It Seems As if Swedes Are Voting
description: Sweden this weekend is staging its quadrennial political fete, a national election, and the exercise is uneventful and unimpassioned, indeed, barely detectable.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Laura Linney; Actress Plays Eliza To Designer's Higgins
description: IN ''The Truman Show,'' Laura Linney plays Jim Carrey's wife, an actress pretending to be a real person. In life, Ms. Linney is an actress struggling to project a movie star, now that ''The Truman Show'' has brought her the widest attention yet during a career built on theater and television.

title: A Historic Homestead Awaits a Shift of Position
description: Looking at Alexander Hamilton's home today, crammed between St. Luke's Episcopal Church and a brick housing complex, it is difficult to imagine the place as his 30-acre country estate. Visited by busloads of tourists, the Hamilton Grange National Monument on Convent Avenue between 141st and 142d Streets is one of Manhattan's historical treasures. But though the Grange is supposed to be moved a few blocks away into St. Nicholas Park, the National Park Service, which owns the building, says it is waiting for the city to act.

title: BASEBALL -- Narrow Escape Pulls the Mets Into a Tie; This Time, Franco Wriggles Out of Bases-Loaded Jam in the Ninth
description: Beneath the noise and tension and pressure, John Franco emerged as more of a survivor than a closer yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: Out of the Minds of Poets and Into the Hearts of Poetry Lovers
description: SOME artists express themselves with oil paints or pastels; some use bronze or clay; some use musical notes. For the 100 or so poets reading their work next weekend at the seventh Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival, the medium is words.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: IMPOSSIBLE SAINTSBy Michele Roberts.Ecco, $24.

title: BUSINESS: DIARY
description: Consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August, the same as in July. . . . Fewer foreign cars and cheaper oil meant that the nation's imports fell in July. But exports fell faster, reflecting soft demand in troubled Asian countries. So the trade deficit widened to $13.92 billion. . . . Sluggish sales in Asia hammered Nike, whose profits fell 35 percent in the latest quarter. . . . Three former executives of Archer Daniels Midland, including the chairman's son, were found guilty of conspiring to fix prices of lysine, the animal feed additive.

title: Those Topsy-Turvy Bonds
description: THESE are strange times in bond land.

title: Reinventing the Box; How Cable Captured the Mini-Series -- and the High Ground
description: As the father of the recent trend of producing classics like ''The Odyssey'' for television, Robert Halmi Sr. was notably irritated recently over a fight he had with NBC. He wanted to advertise his forthcoming version of ''Crime and Punishment'' as not just a psychological thriller but also as a production of the famous novel by Fyodor Dostoyevsky. NBC was eager to garner the prestige from broadcasting a classic. But the network was also, by its own admission, deeply reluctant to display the author's name too prominently, for fear it would make the program appear taxing, a dose of the cod-liver oil of education rather than the cotton candy of pure entertainment its target audience of younger viewers so desires.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE COLOR BIND

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Black and White in the Yellow Nineties
description: ''Wierdsley Daubery,'' as Aubrey Beardsley's critics called him, personified the esthetic ideal of the decadent 1890's despite the brevity of his career. In 1892 he was earning enough by his illustrations to escape his day job, but five years later, at the age of 25, he espoused Roman Catholicism and renounced his erotic drawings before dying from consumption. In AUBREY BEARDSLEY (Abrams, $39.95), a judicious and handsome critical study, Stephen Calloway, a curator at the Victoria and Albert Museum, suggests that the identification of Beardsley (1872-98) with the Wildean excesses of the decade was part myth from the start. It was a misrepresentation that was to injure Beardsley as well as to advance him. His work as art editor for the notorious ''Yellow Book,'' for example, recalled Japanese prints and French ''lubricity,'' carrying a whiff of vice to a journal of only occasionally risque art and writing from the likes of Henry James and Max Beerbohm. But the moral backlash provoked by Oscar Wilde's trial for gross indecency led to Beardsley's being fired, and while his best work was yet to come, he was never again as financially or professionally secure. Beardsley always used imitation as a spur to innovation, and Calloway magnificently elucidates his influences -- among them, his mentor Burne-Jones, his enemy William Morris, Mantegna, Charles Ricketts and James McNeill Whistler. To each he owed a not inconsiderable debt, yet Calloway is persuasive in his assertion of Beardsley's distinct artistic genius. Sarah Harrison Smith

title: Carey Voigt, Timothy Dearnley
description: Carey Elizabeth Voigt, a daughter of Patricia and Frederick Voigt of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Timothy Klevan Dearnley, a son of Margaret and Richard Dearnley of Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. John Francis performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

title: Backtalk; A Radio Get-Together, In Two Languages
description: IN a glorious home-run summer that owes almost as much to Sammy Sosa's ebullient salsa as Mark McGwire's meaty decency, Julio Pabon's eight-year campaign to ''raise the visibility of positive Latino role models'' seems to be reaching a peak.

title: Genes 'R' Us

title: Annabelle Irwin, 82, Co-Author of Novels for Young Teen-Agers

title: TELEVISION; He's Gay, She's Straight, They're a Trend
description: ONE theory holds that if Monica had had a gay man for a confidant --someone reliable, empathetic and capable of keeping certain secrets safely locked in a closet where they belong -- her sex life would never have been splashed across the headlines. If only she'd had a pal like Will Truman, half of television's latest odd couple in ''Will and Grace,'' a series that has its premiere on NBC tomorrow night at 9:30. Like all male homosexuals -- you didn't know? -- Will is good-looking, witty, has lots of disposable income and knows how to dress. Despite his many attributes, he's currently unattached, leaving him available for help with a multitude of late-night crises. (And emergency trips to the dry cleaner?) What more could any woman desire in a best friend than a man who can offer a sturdy shoulder to cry on and knows his way around a loose interpretation of penis envy? Based on the evidence of the first two episodes, he doesn't even own a tape recorder.

title: A September Selloff? Yes, if History Is a Guide
description: If investors think it may be time to test the stock market again, they may be overlooking one issue: seasonality. September, it seems, in the last half-century or so, has been the single worst month for the stock market. According to The Wall Street Companion, a New York-based market newsletter, the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen in 30 of the 47 Septembers since 1950, by an average of roughly 1 percent.

Samuel Intrator, an animated young rabbi, was teaching them to perform an ancient blessing recited on Rosh ha-Shanah and other Jewish holy days, a responsibility reserved for those descended from the high priests of Judaism, the Kohanim and the Levim.

After all, Harvard overran the Lions, 45-7, in last year's opener and went on to a 9-1 record and the Ivy championship. The Crimson had won seven straight games, and quarterback Rich Linden and tailback Chris Menick, the big guns, were back.

title: My Favorite Show; Robert Pinsky on 'The Simpsons'
description: Why do I like ''The Simpsons'' so much? Because the show is funny, brilliantly written for masterful vocal actors. But also, I think there is something about ''The Simpsons'' that penetrates to the nature of television itself. The most powerful televisionof my lifetime has been broadcast live, what the book industry would call ''nonfiction'': sports events, trials, assassinations, funerals, wars, missions into space. What all of these spectacles have in common is that they are unpredictable. Even a one-sided World Series game or a carefully planned state funeral might suddenly erupt into surprise, some spontaneous marvel of passion or comedy, as large as a bombing or as small as some unanticipated facial expression. Television has a unique power to bring the dynamic, potentially startling event into the viewer's private, intimate space, immediately. Perhaps television's greatest artist, Sid Caesar, by genius and historical circumstance, had it both ways. his carefully written, disruptive comic sketches were performed live.

title: BOOKS: Dante From Italian to English, Baby Given Up and Baby Wanted; First, a Dead Body, Then Come the Whys

Sure enough, at the outset of ''God Bless the Child,'' her 13th book, comes the news of a ''poor girl lying in a pool of blood'' fallen, jumped or pushed from the upstairs deck of an East Hampton home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSCARINIS, ROSA, MD.
description: FOSCARINIS-Rosa, MD. The Faculty and Staff of New York University School of Medicine deeply mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague, Rosa Foscarinis, MD, Clinical Associate Professor of Pediatrics. Dr. Foscarinis died in a car accident in Athens, Greece on August 21, 1998. She was 82. Dr. Foscarinis was affiliated with NYU for about 4 decades. After earning her MD degree from the School of Medicine of the National University of Athens in 1940, she came to the US to pursue specialty training. She completed a residency in pediatrics at Gouverneur Hospital in 1950 and at NYU's University Hospital (formerly called New York Post-Graduate Hospital) in 1951. Dr. Foscarinis served as a dedicated, compassionate assisting attending in pediatrics at both the NYU Medical Center and Bellevue Hospital. She was also an attending in pediatric allergy at Gouverneur Hospital. We extend our sympathies to Dr. Foscarinis' husband Nicolas, her daughter Maria and all the members of the Foscarinis family. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate contributions to the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, 918 F Street N.W., Suite 412, Washington, DC, 20004. Wade P. Parks, PhD, MD Pat & John Rosenwald Professor of Pediatrics and Chairman of The Department, NYU School of Medicine

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Smile When You Call It Pulp, Stranger
description: Before he became known for wonderfully quirky crime novels like ''Get Shorty'' and ''Out of Sight,'' Elmore Leonard was a master of the pulp western. THE TONTO WOMAN (Delacorte, $23.95), a collection of stories published in various magazines from the 1950's to the 1980's, is a perfect introduction to this work. Like almost all westerns, these are essentially morality tales, but in Leonard's world the triumph of good over evil often comes with an unexpected twist. In ''The Tonto Woman,'' we also see the genesis of his economical prose style and his ability to sketch distinct, multifaceted characters. Leonard doesn't dither; every word counts. In ''You Never See Apaches . . . ,'' the first sentence -- ''By nature Angsman was a cautious man'' -- is the perfect setup for a violent adventure in which a scout is hired by three lowlifes to lead them in search of a gold mine that happens to be on Apache land. Leonard's stories are driven not so much by events as by character. In the title story, the wife of a wealthy rancher is kidnapped, sold into slavery to the Mojave tribe and branded on her face so that ''when she died the spirits would know she was Mojave and not drag her soul down into a rathole.'' Returning in shame to her husband, she is forced to live alone on a secluded ranch, where she encounters an outlaw, Ruben Vega, who will reintroduce her into polite society. We shouldn't be surprised. After all, here's how Leonard introduces Vega: ''A time would come, within a few years, when Ruben Vega would go to the church . . . and say to the priest, 'Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. It has been 37 years since my last confession. . . . Since then I have fornicated with many women, maybe 800. No, not that many, considering my work. Maybe 600 only.' And the priest would say, 'Do you mean bad women or good women?' And Ruben Vega would say, 'They are all good, Father.' '' Charles Salzberg

They are a young Nebraska farm couple, parents of three, whose ordeal of dry weather with its crop of economic and emotional troubles is the subject of ''The Farmer's Wife.''

title: Martin Repeats at Dover
description: If Mark Martin is going to challenge Jeff Gordon for this season's Winston Cup championship, his Ford Taurus will have to be as dominant as it was yesterday in Dover, Del.

title: On a Roof, Vignettes That Get Around
description: The weirdest part was the tour guide's role. The audience was rounded up in the fifth-floor cafeteria of Seward Park High School on Grand Street and divided into three groups, each with a separate guide. Ours introduced herself as Padee Yang and began telling us, in a chirpy, tourist-friendly voice, that her father had been poisoned in a Laotian prison camp and that her mother, who had brought the family to the Lower East Side of Manhattan, had just disappeared one day.

title: High-Stakes Battle for Momentum
description: For network programming executives, the start of a new television season is always intense because the stakes are so so high. But to hear them tell it, the debuts of 36 new series this season has become something akin to the landing on Omaha Beach.

title: Jazz at the White House: A Metaphor for Democracy (and a Help to the Boss)
description: It was everywhere, rustling through conversations the way a breeze moves through trees, in the smirks and jokes of some, in the extended, slightly nervous ovation the President and Mrs. Clinton received as they walked into the East Room of the White House on Friday night for a Millennium lecture on jazz. It was the President's Problem, and it colored the event. The musicians onstage spent much of their time, as did the audience, analyzing the way the President and his wife interacted, how they played their public roles, how, in the middle of a Greek tragedy, they were doing.

title: Television in Review
description: 'L.A. Doctors'

title: Brazilian Shatters World Record by Running 2:06:05
description: A Brazilian named Ronaldo accomplished in marathon running yesterday what his counterpart in soccer could not do at this summer's World Cup -- prove that he was indisputably the best on the planet in his sport.

title: Papa Told Manning About Days Like This
description: Peyton Manning and his father, Archie, stood in a tunnel leading out of Giants Stadium today and spoke quietly for a few minutes. Peyton wiped a towel across his face between words, and when enough was said, he left with a hug from his father. Quietly, Archie implored him, ''Head up.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I think the time is right.''

title: Tennessee Defense Shakes Up the Poll
description: The scoreboard displayed: Tennessee 20, Florida 17. And thousands in the school-record crowd of 107,653 were rolling onto the field at Neyland Stadium to pound on the goal posts. In the middle of them, Al Wilson stood his ground as he had for four quarters and a thrilling overtime finish against the Gators.

title: Dolphins Shut Down Steelers' Offense
description: This game was billed as a slugfest, two teams that had barely been able to throw the ball and loved to run it. So on its first two offensive plays, Miami hurled bombs. Both fell incomplete. Pittsburgh, on its first two offensive plays, tossed a short pass and then a deep one. One gained 2 yards and the other was incomplete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMER, J. MICHAEL
description: HAMMER-J. Michael. September 18, 1998. Beloved husband of Barbara, loving father of Samantha and J. Michael, Jr. Brother of George A., Patrick, Ernest H., and Jane Dwyer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Monday, September 21, 1998, 5-9 PM. Service Tuesday, September 22, 1998, 11 AM, University Church at Fordham, 441 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY.

title: Immigrants Settle Lawsuit Over Jail Beatings for $1.5 Million
description: More than three years after a group of immigrants seeking political asylum in the United States were beaten and tortured by guards at a jail in Elizabeth, N.J., county officials there have agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle a Federal civil rights lawsuit brought by 21 of the immigrants, lawyers said yesterday.

title: Recycling the Trash Issue
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has long wondered whether recycling will live up to its environmental notices. He has suggested more than once that recycling at some point becomes more trouble than it is worth. But with New York City's Fresh Kills dump on Staten Island scheduled to close by 2002, recycling must certainly be a big part of the mix. Under present plans, recycling will increase from 1,800 tons a day to 4,250 tons by the year 2001.

title: Jets Heed Coach's Warnings and Wallop Colts
description: Before the Jets obliterated the hapless Indianapolis Colts today, 44-6, there was a week of practice that was terrible by all accounts, one that some Jets players say they will never forget.

title: Treasury Will Offer Two Bills and a Note At Sales This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a two-year note being auctioned Wednesday.

title: U.S. Hesitates on Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN VALKENBURGH, MILDRED ARLENE
description: VAN VALKENBURGH-Mildred Arlene. On September 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Pierre. Loving sister of Gladys Shockley and Gertrude Knight and aunt of many. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday, September 22, 2-6 PM. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Lung Association of New York, Inc., 432 Park Ave. So., NY NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GERSON, IVAN D
description: GERSON-Ivan D. ''A unique man.'' It's five years. Unbelievable! We love you and miss you so much. Rest peacefully our dear Ivan. Hugs and kisses, Mom, Dad and Adrienne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEL, GARY
description: TURKEL-Gary, 58. Longtime resident of Chatham Towers in Lower Manhattan, passed away on Saturday morning, September 19. He leaves his wife Toby, son Avi, twin brother Michael, and sister Barbara, three nieces and four nephews in Israel, and three nieces and two nephews locally. For 26 years, he worked as a butcher at Turkel Kosher Meats at Essex Street Market alongside his father, Frank. After closing the store, he worked with his brother at Sobel Construction. A Boy Scout in his youth, he attended Ten-Mile Scout Camp. Later, he was a Civil War buff and Pavarotti fan, an expert sport and fly fisherman, and a gourmet cook. An unfailingly supportive husband and father, he helped his wife attain her goals, and he was very proud of his son's achievements. He contributed his talents and energy unstintingly and with great dedication at Civic Center Synagogue for many years. A generous, soulful, and selfless individual, he helped friends and strangers alike. If desired, contributions in his memory can be made to ''Gary's Kitchen Fund'' at Civic Center Synagogue, 49 White St., NYC 10013.

title: Public Clamor Puts Focus on 'Clusters' In Cancer Research
description: Linda Gillick began her quest convinced that science and a little common sense could explain why in one ordinary patch of New Jersey seashore, an unusual number of children, her son Michael among them, have similar types of cancers.

title: Editorial Observer; Is the Global Capitalist System Collapsing?
description: Last week, the world's best-known money manager, George Soros, warned that the global capitalist system ''is coming apart at the seams.''

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Year 2000 Compromise Bill Is Opposed by Trial Lawyers
description: A compromise effort by Congress and the Clinton Administration to promote candid information about year 2000 problems in the nation's computers is being assailed by trial lawyers because a cornerstone of the plan would grant computer and chip makers immunity from liability suits.

title: Industry View; The stock market's gyrations are causing anxiety among Silicon Alley start-ups that are planning to go public.
description: IN contrast to politics, in the world of entrepreneurs, going public has fabulously positive connotations. Many founders of start-ups set their sights on taking their companies public before even filing their incorporation papers.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Tattoo Artists Bare a Lot (but Not All) at Their Ball
description: No one dons black tie for the annual Inkslingers Ball. That would be in bad taste. A tux would cover up too much skin.

title: Essay; Impeachment Election
description: In six weeks, a minority of the nation's eligible voters will decide whether the President is to be impeached by the House and removed from office by the Senate.

title: McGwire Hits No. 65 And Has Near-Miss
description: In Milwaukee, Mark McGwire hit one ball into the bleachers for his 65th home run and one into the hands of a fan who was called for interference, a ruling that erased what might have been McGwire's 66th homer. On Sammy Sosa day in Chicago, Sosa stayed stuck at 63, going 0 for 5 in a Cubs loss that dropped them a game behind the Mets in the race for a wild-card playoff berth.

title: An Immediate Broadcast Of All 4 Hours by Some
description: Videotape of President Clinton's Aug. 17 grand jury testimony will begin rolling on the major all-news cable television networks as soon as it is released to them this morning, but the three major broadcast networks planned to use only parts of the video at first, incorporated into live reports beginning at 9 A.M. or as soon as the tape is released.

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Family Feud Touches Down in Newburgh
description: One after another, the cars pulled up to the chain-link fence at Stewart International Airport. One after another, curiosity seekers squinted through the fence at the turf-green-and-white Airbus A300 wide-body jet sitting on the tarmac, silent and still except for the fabric covers on its engines flapping in the breeze.

title: Citing New Year, Some Rabbis Ask for Delay
description: Several rabbis in the Washington area have asked the House Judiciary Committee to postpone releasing the videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony until after the Jewish holiday of Rosh ha-Shanah, which began last night.

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEWMAN, NORMAN
description: NEWMAN-Norman, age 45. Of Lawrence, New York. Winston & Strawn remembers and remains saddened by the untimely passing of their partner & friend, Norman Newman. Mr. Newman served as chairperson of the firm's employee benefits and compensation practice, was a frequent lecturer and writer in his field, and was a highly respected member of the legal community. His devotion to the practice of law and steadfast dedication to clients will be remembered with great admiration. He is deeply missed personally and professionally by all who worked with him. We extend our sincere and heartfelt sympathy to his family.

title: Television in Review
description: 'Will and Grace'

title: F.T.C. Surfs the Web and Gears Up to Demand Privacy Protection
description: After more than a year of heated debate within the Government, the Federal Trade Commission has all but decided it will part company with the Clinton Administration over the contention that business can regulate itself when it comes to Internet privacy.

title: The Story of a Failed Merger Proves to Be a Page Turner
description: It wasn't uncommon for Michael J. Birck, chief executive of Tellabs Inc. to arrive early at his headquarters office in Lisle, Ill. But on Friday, Aug. 21, he was earlier than usual. The company's shareholders were set to vote on the much-awaited merger with the Ciena Corporation, a telecommunications equipment maker, and he had a few slides to go over before his 10 A.M. presentation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, JOHN J.
description: HOPKINS-John J. The Board of Trustees and the Priests, Religious, Lay Staff and Volunteers of The Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York mourn the death of our devoted trustee and admired friend. We cherish the memories of his wisdom, his gentle encouragement and his open-hearted generosity and loving kindness. We extend our warm sympathy to his beloved wife Joan, and his family. May our Gracious God reward him abundantly and grant him the fullness of love and peace forever. John Cardinal O'Connor, President The Board of Trustess of The Catholic Charities of The Archdiocese of New York

title: As Russia Teeters, the Rest of Us Should Worry
description: To the Editor:

title: McGwire Gets One But Loses Another
description: The greatest home run spectacle in history spawned an outrageous subplot today when Mark McGwire belted what many are calling home run No. 65 1/2 at County Stadium.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Swedish Party Pledging Expanded Welfare Gains Slim Victory
description: The governing Social Democrats rode a pledge to expand Sweden's huge welfare programs to a thin victory tonight in a national election that signaled a shift to the left.

title: Demonstration Was Largest in the Capital's History : Malaysia Police Seize Anwar After Anti-Mahathir Protest
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysian policemen wearing black ski masks and carrying submachine guns smashed their way into the house of Anwar Ibrahim, the country's former deputy prime minister, late Sunday night and arrested him, just hours after he had led the largest political demonstration in this city's history.

title: Japan Sees Itself as a Scapegoat Of Washington in the Asia Crisis
description: Japan is often seen these days as an insouciant bumbler, fiddling while much of the world's economy burns. But Government officials here, grimly plodding the corridors of power, see things rather differently.

title: Union's Chief Is Challenged On Corruption
description: A fast-growing dissident movement at District Council 37, the giant union representing 120,000 New York City public employees, is mounting a major challenge to Stanley Hill, the union's executive director, demanding that he act decisively to stop the corruption that has rocked the union.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: G.O.P. Needs 8 Seats To Take Texas House
description: It is a warm, cricket-loud Friday night in West Texas, which means the parking lot is jammed next to the high school football field, big enough to hold much of the town, which it does.

title: Safer Diets for Cows
description: Microbiologists at Cornell University have found that what cattle eat can affect the safety of hamburgers, opening a whole new path to controlling food-borne illnesses. Strains of E. coli bacteria have caused illness and death in humans who have eaten undercooked ground beef, lettuce and unpasteurized fruit juice. Thus far most efforts to control the spread of E. coli have focused on improving safety in slaughtering and food-handling practices.
