But the new research shows that the E. coli problem can also be managed by changing the diet of cattle.

title: Bergen and Sprint Part Company
description: Candice Bergen's eight-year run as the spokeswoman for the Sprint Corporation is ending by mutual agreement, the actress and the company have announced.

title: Media Talk; A Gamble on 'E.R.' Paid Off for NBC
description: After agreeing to pay $13 million an episode for ''E.R.,'' which returns for a new season Thursday night, NBC may be feeling like one of the patients on a gurney in the series. But it shouldn't.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: NATO Stance Is Said to Hurt Both Alliance and Kosovo
description: NATO indecision about whether to act against a three-month-old military offensive in Kosovo by President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia has severely threatened the credibility of the alliance and almost insured a winter-long human catastrophe, Western diplomats said today.

title: Going After Republican on Gun Control
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer fiercely criticized Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's voting record on gun control yesterday, saying the Senator was more interested in collecting donations from the National Rifle Association than protecting the lives of New Yorkers.

title: Edwin A. Weinstein, 89, Neuropsychiatrist Who Studied President Wilson
description: Dr. Edwin A. Weinstein, a former neuropsychiatrist at Mount Sinai Medical School in Manhattan who maintained that people, even Presidents, go to extraordinary lengths to hide their illnesses, died on Sept. 7 at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 89.

title: China Intensifies Crackdown On Applicants for New Party
description: Chinese authorities have stepped up their crackdown on dissidents' efforts to form a political party, sending a clear signal that despite liberalization in many areas of Chinese life they would not allow such organized dissent.

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: * Champion Jogbra, Burlington, Vt., a division of the Sara Lee Corp., to Earle Palmer Brown, New York, to handle women's sports products advertising, which had been handled by Gearon Hoffman, Boston. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $4 million.

title: Film Industry Is Confronting Likely Change In Accounting
description: The nation's accounting rule makers have tentatively approved new financial reporting standards for the film industry that could cost some Hollywood studios hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Proud and Stubborn And Oh So Classical
description: Exhausted and emotionally drained, Cal Ripken fell into a deep slump in the days after breaking Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game record of 2,130 on Sept. 6, 1995. Ripken was a national icon, a living symbol of dedication to excellence who graced magazine covers and television screens, but that did not help him when he was trying to hit fastballs.

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Media; An author questions the existence of Deep Throat, Watergate's man in the shadows.
description: THE man known as Deep Throat is a singular figure in American culture, credited with being the source of explosive articles written by the reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein as they unraveled the Nixon Administration's abuses of power. Named for a pornographic movie, this furtive truth-teller may be the first pseudonymous American hero not conceived in a comic book.

title: In Primary, Being Liberal Meant Less Than Being Rich
description: For the last generation, the most liberal candidate has always been a good bet to win a statewide Democratic primary in New York.

title: Media Talk; A Forbes List Maker Makes the List
description: Take a look at Forbes ASAP's annual listing of the 100 wealthiest people in technology, which will be published today, and you will learn some of the secrets of getting rich quick these days. They include selling technology for the Internet and selling things on the Internet.

title: Stressing Governor's Ties to D'Amato and Budget Cuts
description: This 30-second ad for the campaign of Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, began broadcasting yesterday.

title: A Day To Pay Old Debts
description: During President Clinton's visit to the United Nations General Assembly today, he will almost certainly try to gloss over one important fact: with one stroke of his pen, he can pay the American ''arrears'' to the United Nations -- today.

title: Bonn  Says Sudanese Faces U.S. Extradition
description: German officials said today that they were preparing to extradite to the United States a Sudanese suspect arrested this week in connection with the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi.

title: Media Talk; Globe's Ex-Columnist Defends His Work
description: Mike Barnicle, the former Boston Globe columnist, said Friday he hoped to buy a full-page ad in tomorrow's Globe to defend the authenticity, if not the accuracy, of the 1995 column that led to his forced resignation last month.

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Goings-On Behind the Television Anchors' Smiles
description: We seem minutes away from an all-''Dateline'' channel, and show-business gossip is a growth industry; no wonder two of the season's most likable sitcoms are set behind the scenes of fictional quasi-news programs and take a shrewd look at television itself. The sharply written ''Sports Night'' (beginning tomorrow) and the goofy ''Brian Benben Show'' (which has its premiere tonight) have radically different styles, but share a media-savvy attitude. The freshness of their comic approaches can be measured by how far they have come from ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' still the godmother of all sitcoms that find humor in an associate producer's job.

title: True North's new unit aims to reach ethnic households, which have money to spend.
description: A GIANT agency company is stepping up its efforts in multicultural marketing, forming a unit devoted to encouraging advertisers to keep pace with the changing face of consumers by increasing sales pitches aimed at ethnic groups.

title: Bean Dents Holyfield's Armor
description: Evander Holyfield absorbed several big blows late in his fight against Vaughn Bean on Saturday night, going 12 rounds against an opponent who many observers thought might last three. The champion was not awful, but he was not awesome, either.

title: Mr. Clinton's Strange Power
description: The Lewinsky scandal has weakened Bill Clinton's grasp on his office, but it may have given him a peculiar new weapon in the budget wars. Only a few weeks from adjournment, Congress is engaged in the annual autumn ritual of confronting the White House over taxes and spending, just when Mr. Clinton is braving the impeachment firestorm on an island of his own contradictions. But in that weakness lies a paradoxical kind of strength. The more feeble the President seems, the more seriously Congress takes his demands. The last thing Congressional Republicans want is to distract the public from Mr. Clinton's troubles and provoke a searching look at the G.O.P. budget priorities.

title: Schroder the Invulnerable? Look at His Record
description: He went to the opera in Vienna with the chairman of Volkswagen. He took a spin on the Boeing yacht in Seattle last year. He has visited with Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft.

title: Fumbles Forgotten
description: The day began as a nightmare for Jets running back Curtis Martin. In the beginning of the Jets' 44-6 victory over Indianapolis, the Jets were on their own 25-yard line. Seconds after getting the handoff, Martin fumbled when safety Jason Belser poked the ball loose. Luckily, quarterback Vinny Testaverde pounced on it.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: DECISION TO STRIKE FACTORY IN SUDAN BASED ON SURMISE INFERRED FROM EVIDENCE
description: Shortly after investigators linked Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile, to the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa, six of President Clinton's most senior advisers convened in the White House situation room to plot a counterattack with cruise missiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GERTRUDE LIBNER
description: FRANK-Gertrude Libner. On September 19, 1998. Best friend and beloved wife of David. Devoted daughter of Beatrix Libner. Cherished and loving mother of Vicky Frank, and Betsy and Alan Leinwand. Unforgettable ''Dusty'' to grandchildren Alexander and Alyssa Leinwand. Her strength, courage and love will be remembered always. Gifts may be sent to the Gertrude Frank Fund for Pediatric Cancer Care, Sloan-Kettering Memorial Hospital, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

title: Compressed Data; A Combined Phone-Palm Pilot Impresses the Techno-Elite
description: Mixing technical and political evangelism, the annual Telecosm conference, sponsored by George Gilder and his libertarian friends from Forbes magazine, is one of the highest-powered gatherings of technology experts in the nation.

title: Sports of The Times; Testaverde's Arm and Jets' Season Are Both Revived
description: VINNY TESTAVERDE had no feeling from his shoulder to his fingers, but inside his helmet he was fine. He was not thinking about his own misfortune, but about the two quarterbacks on the sideline.

title: Heroin Use Seen Declining Among Young Suspected Offenders in Manhattan
description: Heroin use and the injection of drugs have declined sharply among young people who were arrested in Manhattan and some other urban centers, according to a survey of their drug habits.

title: Puerto Rico and Nearby Islands Brace for Big Hurricane
description: With Hurricane Georges, the most powerful storm of the season, bearing down on them today with 115-mile-per-hour winds, Puerto Rico and a dozen smaller Caribbean islands south and east of here braced for what authorities warned could become a disaster.

title: Top Opposition Leader in Malaysia Is Jailed in Sex Case
description: After a day of lurid headlines and protests by thousands, the rising star of Malaysian politics, Anwar Ibrahim, was jailed tonight after a long, bitter struggle against his one-time mentor, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.

title: Changing the Way Music Is Marketed
description: With revenue of $12.36 billion in 1997, profits in the music business have been essentially flat for the last few years. So, lured by an on-line music market that the research firm Jupiter Communications predicts will reach $2.8 billion a year by 2002, the record industry, from producers to retailers, has struggled with how to take advantage of Internet technologies to realize better margins.

title: Farewell, Fusty Glamour; Hello, Efficiency; Sleek and High-Tech, the New British Library Wins Over Critics
description: ''As far as history, there is no history here,'' said Doris Fletcher, speaking of the new British Library, the sparkling, soaring building that recently opened near King's Cross to replace the old library, which oozed tradition in the heart of Bloomsbury. ''We are starting from scratch.''

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sosa Draws The Collar As Cubs Slip Behind
description: As Sammy Sosa goes, so go the Cubs, and today Sosa failed for the fourth straight game to hit a home run, going 0 for 5 in a 7-3 loss to the Cincinnati Reds on a day dedicated to celebrating his season.

title: Pursuing The Soul Of 'Streetcar' In Opera
description: ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' is so operatic as a play that one wonders why more than 50 years have passed since its Broadway opening with no opera of note being made of it. A dressed-to-the-nines crowd, including some 140 journalists and critics from around the world, seemed to be wondering the same thing on Saturday night at the San Francisco Opera. The new setting of Tennessee Williams's play, with music by Andre Previn and a libretto by Philip Littell, answered a few questions and asked others.

title: Giants' Measuring Stick Is Playing the Cowboys
description: In the modern era of the National Football League, no team has helped define the success or failure of any Giants season quite like the Dallas Cowboys. Year after year, how the Giants have fared against the Cowboys has tended to mark the team's season -- positively or negatively.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Calvados, the French apple brandy, misspelled the given name of the author who wrote about it in his book ''The Food of France.'' He was Waverley Root, not Waverly.

title: REVISIONS
description: I went to the Museum of Modern Art to see the work of the Russian artist Aleksandr Rodchenko for two reasons. I certainly wanted to see first-rate art. But I also wanted to see what a first-rate artist committed to being an honorable citizen did when faced not with second-rate political scandals but with life-and-death upheavals: a revolution that was changing everything, from the way people worked to the way they thought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, SALLIE B.
description: JOHNSON-Sallie B. Age 74. A world class bridge champion and instructor at the Regency Whist Club for over 20 years in New York City died peacefully on September 14, 1998 at her home in Lake Placid, NY. She is survived by three daughters, Wendy, Sally B., and Deborah Johnson and by her brother, Patrick Cummings.

title: As Russia Teeters, the Rest of Us Should Worry
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; It might not do for Captain Kirk, but a sensor could help rescuers save victims of disasters.
description: FANS of the television show ''Star Trek'' know that one of the wonders of the science-fiction future is the starship sensor. With it, crew members can detect the exact location of living bodies on a planet they are orbiting. If mankind does someday develop those fantastic sensors, they might have their roots in inventions of today.

title: What Is the Virtue of Releasing Clinton Tape?
description: To the Editor:

title: Troubled Nations May Look at Clinton at the U.N. and See... Trouble
description: If President Clinton wants a sense of how dangerous a place the world has become in the midst of a scandal over his personal conduct, he could study the grim faces in the audience when he rises on Monday at the green marble podium of the United Nations General Assembly in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday about a method of duplicating DNA misstated the composition of the substance. Its two intertwining chains are composed of units known as nucleotides; amino acids are not a component.

title: A Hit From the 70's Is Fading in the 90's; ABC's 'Good Morning America' Has Seen Better Days
description: In early-morning television, Katie and Matt don't need surnames. As co-hosts of the enormously popular ''Today'' show on NBC, Katie Couric and Matt Lauer are not only familiar companions in more than five million American homes each morning, they are also well known to movers and shakers from Washington to New York to Hollywood.

title: Denver Has Plenty In Reserve to Win
description: Not even John Elway's exit could change the fortunes of the Oakland Raiders today.

title: As Russia Teeters, the Rest of Us Should Worry
description: To the Editor:

title: 24 Injured When Bus Runs Off the Parkway
description: A bus going from Manhattan to Atlantic City went off the road on the Garden State Parkway early yesterday and crashed into a tree, resulting in minor injuries to 24 passengers, the authorities said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Arthur Lall, 87, Indian Diplomat and Scholar
description: Arthur S. Lall, an Indian diplomat of the Jawaharlal Nehru generation who helped secure his newly independent country a place near the center of world affairs in the 1950's and 60's, died on Sept. 13 in New York. He was 87.

title: Before Public, Armor Is Showing No Cracks
description: At the dedication of the new Peace Corps headquarters last week, Hillary Rodham Clinton cut a long red ribbon with two-foot-long scissors and nearly signed up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIMARCO, MICHAEL V.
description: DIMARCO-Michael V. Of Clifton Park, died Friday, September 18, 1998. Husband of Rosemarie DiMarco. Father of Joanne Speck of Malta and Vincent M. DiMarco of Harrison, NY. Son of Mary DiMarco. Funeral Monday, 10 AM at St. Edward's Church. Contributions American Cancer Society or the P.J. O'Donnell Memorial Fund, c/o Siena College, Loudonville, NY.

title: Youth Charged in Killing Of Brooklyn Man, 16
description: A 16-year-old youth has been arrested in the fatal shooting of a 19-year-old man on a busy commercial street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: In Upstate Swing, D'Amato Attacks Schumer on His Voting Record
description: In his first major swing of the general election campaign, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato barnstormed across the Republican-friendly reaches of northern New York State today, repeatedly accusing his Democratic opponent, Representative Charles E. Schumer from Brooklyn, of being blithely indifferent to the needs of upstate residents.

title: Sports of The Times; 'That's Why Mark's The Man,' Sosa Says
description: TROTTING past Wrigley Field's ivy-covered brick outfield wall after the ceremonies, Sammy Sosa was waving his blue Cubs cap at the adoring applause from the bleachers when the word suddenly arrived at Wrigley Field. Some 90 miles to the north in Milwaukee, Mark McGwire had just hit another homer -- his 65th.

title: Lockheed to Buy Comsat, Satellite Access Seller, for $2.7 Billion
description: Moving away from the military business and toward global telecommunications, the Lockheed Martin Corporation announced yesterday a $2.7 billion acquisition of the Comsat Corporation, a communications satellite company created by the Government more than three decades ago.

title: Florida's Split: Will It Play in the Panhandle?
description: Wade Jackson, a farmer near this Panhandle city, remembers traveling to Punta Gorda in the southwestern part of the state some 15 years ago to visit a nephew. That was as far south as he has ever gone in Florida.

title: Television in Review
description: 'Conrad Bloom'

title: Television in Review
description: 'The King of Queens'

title: The Stripper's Mother: Ambition Rampant and Ugly
description: What may be the scariest song in musicals doesn't come from ''Jekyll and Hyde,'' ''Phantom of the Opera'' or even the bloody ''Sweeney Todd.'' It has an infectiously upbeat tune you surely know and gets played a lot as an optimistic anthem at pageants and conventions. In the context of its show, though, it's a shocker, and when Betty Buckley sings it in a production of the 1959 musical ''Gypsy,'' now at the Paper Mill Playhouse here, you'll find it impossible not to recoil and feel, at least fleetingly, stone cold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRINGTON, SYBIL
description: HARRINGTON-Sybil. It is with profound sadness we mourn the death of Sybil Harrington, devoted member of our official family since 1967 and a Director of our Managing Board since 1980. One of the most generous Patrons in Metropolitan Opera history, in addition to her leadership gift to create the Metropolitan Opera's first endowment fund, Sybil underwrote 16 new Met productions, two gala concerts and 13 ''Metropolitan Opera Presents'' telecasts, including this season's telecasts of ''Samson et Dalila'' and ''La Cenerentola'' and the James Levine 25th Anniversary Gala. Her underwriting support for the current Met productions of ''Don Carlo,'' ''Manon Lescaut,'' ''La Boheme,'' ''Francesca da Rimini,'' ''Die Fledermaus,'' ''Turandot,'' ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Aida,'' ''Don Giovanni,'' ''La Fanciulla del West,'' ''Die Meistersinger von Nuernberg'' and ''Otello'' represent her passionate commitment to traditional productions of the core opera repertory. She took special pleasure in supporting the Met telecasts so that everyone throughout the country could be part of the Met audience. Sybil Harrington's philanthropy has left a legacy that will endure for generations to come. Each season's telecasts and productions supported by that legacy will help us recall with the fondest of memories her devoted love for the Met. The Opera House Auditorium bears Sybil Harrington's name in honor of the singular example she set for philanthropic commitment to the Metropolitan Opera. Metropolitan Opera Association Mrs. Gilbert W. Humphrey, Honorary Chairman James W. Kinnear, Chairman Bruce Crawford, President

title: President Is Urged to Speak To Congress About Affair
description: The day before President Clinton's grand jury testimony beams into television sets across the nation, White House officials stepped up their accusations that Republicans are conducting a smear attack against Mr. Clinton, while a leading Democrat suggested the President should personally visit Congress to answer its questions.

title: Report Calls for Higher Education Reform
description: A new report by the State Comptroller criticizes higher education policy making as haphazard and often politically influenced, and calls on the state to establish a higher education coordinating board to replace or supplement the Board of Regents, the panel that is responsible for education planning in the state.

title: INSIDE
description: Caribbean Braces for Storm

title: An Era of Friction In U.S. Ties to U.N.
description: This is viewed by both United Nations supporters and detractors as a low point in its relations with the United States. When President Clinton speaks at the United Nations today, he will face an organization that is likely to strip the United States of its General Assembly vote for nonpayment of dues.

title: Studies Differ on Internet's Impact on TV
description: So, are eyes starting to wander?

title: Americans Dig Deep, And Cup Stays Put
description: Disappointed in their performance, desperate for points and angry at Dottie Pepper, Europe's players had ample motivation for today's final round of the Solheim Cup.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: After 2,632 Games in a Row, Orioles' Ripken Sits One Out
description: Cal Ripken, who had not missed a game since 1982, removed himself from the Baltimore Orioles' lineup here tonight after playing in 2,632 consecutive games.

title: Muriel Humphrey Brown, Senator, Dies at 86
description: Muriel Humphrey Brown, who grew from a shy girl from South Dakota into a confident woman during political campaigns for her first husband, Hubert H. Humphrey, and then was named to fill his seat in the Senate at his death in 1978, died today at Abbott Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. She was 86 and lived in Plymouth, Minn.

title: Bronner Slosberg Opens New Agency
description: Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston has opened a stand-alone agency in San Francisco, Sansome Group, that will service two important accounts, Charles Schwab & Company and L.A. Cellular.

title: Compressed Data; Microsoft Word as Pundit: Software Maker Says It Isn't So
description: The Internet has been buzzing with all sorts of pranks and trivia related to President Clinton's troubles. But an E-mail tip that was widely circulated last week made the programmers of Microsoft Word, the word-processing software, seem predictive.

title: Mandela Offers Praise for a Clergyman and a Cathedral
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem sang in Xhosa yesterday. ''Bayethe Mandela,'' they shouted, in a rousing rendition of the South African anti-apartheid anthem. ''Hail Mandela. Warrior of Warriors. King of Kings.''

title: The Work Must Go On
description: I had lunch with President Clinton last week. Well, not quite. I was at the counter of a pizza parlor next door to my office, wolfing down a slice to the accompaniment of the restaurant's television set, which was tuned to cable news. Mr. Clinton was on the screen, but his voice was inaudible in the bedlam of the restaurant. He was addressing the National Farmers' Union and saying something about providing emergency financing to farmers.

title: Indian Reservations Bank on Authenticity to Draw Tourists
description: The mercury had pushed over the 100-degree mark again here in the high desert, but the tourists from Germany were undeterred, looking for clues to life in the American West before every small town had an espresso bar.

title: Ford Tries to Improve Its Marketing Efforts
description: The Ford Motor Company has agreed to buy multiyear, multimedia advertising packages from Time Inc. and Hachette Filipacchi Magazines as part of an ambitious drive to improve its marketing efforts by sponsoring elaborate sales pitches coordinated with media giants.

title: He'll Bend Your Ear, He'll Bend Your Bats
description: Al Leiter slipped into the chauffeured car on the Upper East Side yesterday with a cup of coffee and a bagel and immediately bombarded John Olerud, his Met teammate and fellow passenger, with his game plan for pitching against the awful Marlins. Leiter, who is as effusive as a radio talk-show host, discussed strategy while Olerud, who is as taciturn as a mannequin, simply listened.

title: Compressed Data; What's in a Web Name? Sometimes, Mistaken Identity
description: Jeff Woods, the owner of an Internet service provider to Raleigh and Durham, N.C., has discovered that using an address, or domain name, that people associate with a well-known company may not be worth the free publicity that comes with mistaken identity. He owns delta.com, a domain name he chose in 1993 for his company, Deltacomm Internet Services.

title: A Steamy Report Aids a Publisher's Debut
description: By rather brief tradition, the literature of choice at the year-old Public Affairs publishing house started by the Random House refugee Peter Osnos is intelligent and reflective -- serious nonfiction scorned by conglomerates seeking best-seller profits.

title: A Week of Street Closings in Manhattan
description: A visit by President Clinton and the annual debate at the United Nations General Assembly, which will draw several dozen heads of state, will cause street closings -- and traffic jams -- around Manhattan starting today and continuing until next Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCOY, LILLIAN (ELIZABETH
description: McCOY-Lillian (Elizabeth), 101. Formerly of New York City. Wife of the late James R. Beloved mother of Rose Dickinson (Jay Morgan, Sr.) of Aurora, OH, and the late Marguerite M. Seidell (Herbert). Grandmother of James R., Martin A., Herbert A, Jr., Christopher T., and Patrick M. Seidell. Sister of William McDonald. Great-grandmother of 14. Funeral Mass 10:30 AM, Wednesday, September 23, at St. Joan of Arc Church, 496 East Washington St., Chagrin Falls, OH. Visitation 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday, at StroudLawrence Funeral Home, 95 South Franklin St., Chagrin Falls.

title: Death, Terror and Writer's Block
description: BAG OF BONES

title: Metro Matters; In This Race, It's L-Words On Both Sides
description: MANY races begin with policy debate and end with name-calling. In this one, the candidates have apparently decided to skip the preliminaries.

title: Rescue at Sea
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Sports of The Times; Death at 38: Reviewing a Vibrant Life
description: LATE yesterday afternoon, Bob Kersee and his wife, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, had touched down in Los Angeles and were headed down the freeway, headed toward the home that Jackie's brother, Al, shared with his wife, Florence Griffith Joyner, and their 7-year-old daughter, Mary.

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Staring Straight Into Camera, President Reveals Many Sides
description: Bill Clinton has always loved nothing better than a tough audience and, in the end, that is how he treated Kenneth W. Starr's grand jury, starting shakily, then warming to his task, unspooling every thread of wounded dignity, controlled anger and confident elaboration at his command in a performance filled with trademark touches.

title: Almost in Awe, Physicists Ponder 'Ultimate' Theory
description: WHEN many science fans last tuned in, physicists in search of the universe's deepest secrets were pinning their hopes on a dazzlingly beautiful and bewildering invention called superstring theory. The ultimate explanation of nature would finally come together, it was promised, if one thought of the hundreds of subatomic particles as musical notes produced by incredibly tiny strings vibrating in a realm made of 10 dimensions. Never mind that the universe seems to be made of only four dimensions (counting time). The other six were said to be conveniently curled up into vanishingly tiny balls, out of sight and mind.

title: Puerto Rico Struck By Strong Hurricane
description: Hurricane Georges roared into Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands, causing extensive damage after leaving destruction in smaller Caribbean islands. Half of Puerto Rico was without water, and there were reports of five deaths there and one on St. Kitts.

title: Some Poison Arrows Marked 'Return to Sender'
description: SIR VIDIA'S SHADOW

title: Iranian President Paints a Picture of Peace and Moderation
description: Introducing himself as ''a man of the East'' from ''a great and renowned nation,'' President Mohammad Khatami of Iran tried to woo his global audience today with talk of how freedom-loving and law-abiding Iran is these days and asked for help in resolving the crisis in neighboring Afghanistan.

title: Dietary Supplements May Test Consumers' Health
description: GROWING numbers of Americans are stepping daily into a potential minefield of substances loosely referred to as dietary supplements, many of which have little or nothing to do with the components of foods people normally consume. And increasingly these pill poppers are getting into trouble, suffering toxic reactions to deliberate or accidental components of these products or sacrificing the chance to be helped by conventional medicine.

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: How Cruel The Close-Up
description: Public response to the videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony may hinge on a question of film grammar. Does an audience empathize more readily with an off-screen prosecutorial voice or with a witness sweating it out in tight close-up? If the dynamics of ''Les Miserables'' and ''The Fugitive'' are relevant, then the President may yet have a chance against the Javerts and Lieutenant Gerards of the special prosecutor's office and the House Judiciary Committee.

title: The President's Testimony: Part One of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: America's Pro and Con To All That Q. & A.
description: Seventy-eight-year-old Margaret Watkins does not like Bill Clinton, never voted for him and is angry that the leader of the free world ''basically let his libido get the best of him.'' And yet, as she sat transfixed before the television this morning, Mrs. Watkins found herself doing something she had never done before in her life: she was cheering Bill Clinton on.

title: Montgomery Chief Quits in Dispute With Nationsbank Parent
description: Thomas Weisel, one of the best-known investment bankers on the West Coast, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities L.L.C. after months of bitter quarreling with his new bosses in Charlotte, N.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCOPP, DR. IRWIN W.
description: SCOPP-Dr. Irwin W. On September 20, 1998. Beloved husband of Edith, cherished father of Alfred, loving father-in-law of Fredrika, dear grandfather of David. Also devoted brother-in-law of Pearl and Natalie, cherished brother of the late Clara, Harry and Rose. His distinguished career includes positions as Clinical Professor, Periodontics and Director of Continuing Dental Education, New York University College of Dentistry; Chief, Dental Services, New York Department of Veteran's Affairs Medical Center. Also author of textbooks and scientific research articles. Biographical listings include: Who's Who in America, Who's Who in the World, Who's Who in Science and Engineering, Who's Who in the East, Who's Who in Medicine and Healthcare. Funeral service, Tuesday, September 22, 1:30PM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARONSON, HAROLD M.
description: ARONSON-Harold M. Age 94. Formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. and Englewood, N.J. Died September 20, 1998 peacefully at home in Delray Beach, Fl. Beloved husband of Muriel. Beloved father of Paul and Deborah. Beloved grandfather of Daniel, and Julie and Steven Kronowitz. Graveside ceremony 10:30 A.M. Tuesday, September 22, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, N.J.

title: Florence Griffith Joyner, 38, Champion Sprinter, Is Dead
description: Florence Griffith Joyner, the three-time gold medalist at the 1988 Summer Olympics who revolutionized women's sprinting with her searing speed and flamboyant fashion sense, died yesterday at her home in Mission Viejo, Calif. She was 38.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDEY, HELEN WINTHROP, M.D.
description: EDEY-Helen Winthrop, M.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute is grieved at the loss of an extraordinary colleague. After graduating in 1962, Dr. Edey distinguished herself in many areas & became a member of the Institute's Board of Trustees in 1969. Her implacable social consciousness and the depth and breadth of her devotion to the betterment of humankind lit our way. Of those who will miss her and of those who will remember her, we are among the countless. Profound condolences to her beloved family. Charles C. Harrington, Ph.D. President, Board of Trustees Marylou Lionells, PhD, Director, White Institute

title: 1,200 Are Evacuated After Break in Gas Line
description: About 500 students and 700 workers were evacuated from an elementary school and an office building in Jersey City yesterday after a city contractor ruptured a four-inch gas main, officials said.

title: Suitors in U.S. Deal Make Offer to Europe
description: The American Home Products Corporation and the Monsanto Company offered today to scale down the proposed $37.8 billion merger of their companies in an effort to overcome European Union antitrust hurdles, Monsanto said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAYON, ABRAM MIKO
description: FAYON-Abram Miko. Born on April 1, 1920, died at his home in Pelham, NY on September 20, 1998 at age 78. He was the beloved, cherished, honored husband of Shoshana (nee Schmeltzer-Pilcer) and dear father of David, Philip, and Annia. He remains to all who knew him, a wonderful, caring companion and friend. A graduate with a B.S. in Chemical Engineering from the Univ. of Istanbul, Turkey in 1947; an M.A. degree from Johns Hopkins Univ. in 1952; a Ph.D. from NYU in 1959. Abram Miko was a project manager with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency from 1987 to 1998; an Adj./ Assoc. Professor at Manhattan College, New York City, 1984 to 1988; an engineering associate at Mobil Corp. in N.Y.C. and Houston, 1967 to 1984; a chemical engineer at American Cyanamid, 1954 to 1960; & a lecturer Assist. Professor at NYU, 1952 to 1954. In addition to being a member of Sigma Xi and Tau Beta, Miko contributed articles for publication to professional journals in Men's Chemical Engineering. He was chairman of the Men's Club of the Pelham, NY Jewish Center, 1969 to 1971, a very skilled and accomplished pianist who loved and appreciated music, & an avid reader who appreciated fine literature. He was also an aware spectator of current world and local affairs. It is with tears, with deep sorrow, with profound feelings of loss, that we who knew him and cherish him must let him go. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St., Mt Vernon, NY, 914664-6800 on Sept. 23 at 10 AM.

title: Westminster Abbey Elevates 10 Foreigners
description: Life-size statues of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero and other 20th-century figures who died for their beliefs now fill the 10 niches above Westminster Abbey's main entrance that had remained empty for 500 years.

title: Russians Vow To End Crisis, But Key Posts Go Unfilled
description: Russia's leaders offered more assurances today that the country's fiscal crisis could be tamed without provoking high inflation or social unrest. But with key positions in the new Government unfilled, few people seemed to accord the promises much weight.

title: Tanzania Charges Two in Bombing of American Embassy
description: Tanzania charged two men today with 11 counts of murder in connection with the bombing of the United States Embassy there on Aug. 7.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIKLER, BARBARA (PETE)
description: SHIKLER-Barbara (Pete). On September 21, 1998. A wondrous woman. Survived by her husband of 51 years Aaron, daughter Cathy, son Clifford, son-in-law Armand and granddaughter Isabella. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Malaysian Police Break Up Protests on Arrest
description: Acting to quell the biggest show of dissent faced by Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad in his 17 years in office, riot police officers fired tear gas and water cannons today to disperse thousands of people protesting the arrest of his former deputy.

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Put Conditions On Check to U.N.; Silencing Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Singer Is Returning to a Stage Where It All Began
description: Like most beginnings, it was not predictable. Herman C. Krannert, a wealthy cardboard box maker, suddenly agreed to endow a performing arts center at the University of Illinois, far from either bright lights or big city.

title: Clinton Video Provides Evidence to Back Every Viewpoint
description: President Clinton's belatedly televised grand jury testimony -- breathlessly advertised as explosive in its content, but much less so in reality -- is unlikely to change many minds.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Finding a Fort: the Basics

title: Film Festival Prizes Its Paradoxical Niche
description: It began 35 years ago, pre-cable, pre-Internet, back when the current glut of culture and quasi-culture, had it been foreseen, might have made its mission seem particularly daunting.

title: By Design; Winter (and Fall) White
description: Did you grow up hearing you should never wear white after Labor Day? Well, forget it. Chanel and Prada featured white shoes, boots and bags for fall, reminding the fashion world of the white go-go boots Courreges showed with his space age clothes in the 1960's. And with the millennium approaching, white looks ultramodern again.

title: New Dimension in Dance: Thinking Man's Macarena
description: AT the Strings '98 conference this summer in Santa Barbara, Calif., physicists were so excited about a recent paper by Dr. Juan Maldacena, a Harvard theorist, that they danced in celebration. The lyrics, written by Dr. Jeffrey Harvey, a physicist at the University of Chicago, are a take-off on the 14-step version of the popular Spanish dance called the Macarena.

title: Candie's Is Seeking Additional Agency
description: Candie's Inc. said yesterday that it was searching for an additional agency to join its roster as the trendy footwear marketer expands into the jeans and fragrance categories.

title: A View That Starr's Report Doesn't Have All the Facts
description: Monica S. Lewinsky told Federal grand jurors that ''no one ever asked me to lie, and I was never promised a job for my silence,'' according to testimony released today.

title: Patterns
description: Jewelry From a Model

title: MacLean Is Hoping He'll Fit In With Rangers
description: John MacLean and Bruce Driver began their National Hockey League careers in 1983-84, and for more than a decade grew to prominence with a New Jersey Devils franchise that became a league power and won the Stanley Cup in 1995.

title: Japanese Bank Compromise Frays Already
description: A broad-based banking compromise measure that Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi had hailed as the foundation for Japan's economic recovery began to fray today, just as Mr. Obuchi prepared to meet with President Clinton in the United States on Tuesday.

title: Customer Shoots 3 in Crowded Restaurant
description: A customer at a Red Lobster restaurant in Queens who had gotten into an argument with other patrons fired several shots in the crowded dining room last night, critically injuring one man and grazing two other diners, the police said.

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; Real to Bold and Vice Versa
description: As brain transplants go, the one that seems to have taken place between Donna Karan and Helmut Lang is a most startling swap. Ms. Karan, evidently, has become the bold experimenter and Mr. Lang, the comforting, hard-nosed realist.

title: For Crack Babies, a Future Less Bleak
description: When the first babies were born to crack addicts in the mid-1980's, images of trembling infants with tubes up their noses led to fears that such children were irreversibly damaged and doomed to grow into violent misfits.

title: For the Poor, a Shortage of Primary-Care Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Kohl's Unified Germany
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers on Both Sides Showed Mutual Distrust
description: After spending more than a month in a fruitless effort to win agreement for President Clinton to testify voluntarily before the Federal grand jury, Robert J. Bittman, one of Kenneth W. Starr's deputies, was fed up with what prosecutors had come to view as stalling tactics by the White House.

title: Metro Business; Bradley Airport Busy
description: Passenger and cargo traffic at Bradley International Airport this summer have surpassed last summer's levels, the State Department of Transportation reported yesterday.

title: Channel Tunnel Posts Sharply Reduced Loss
description: Eurotunnel S.A., the operator of the Channel Tunnel linking France and Britain, said yesterday that its first-half loss from operations shrank by more than half, helped by booming traffic and lower interest charges. Excluding one-time items, Eurotunnel lost 1.25 billion francs ($220.7 million) in the first half, compared with 3.1 billion francs a year earlier. Including a one-time gain of 2.79 billion francs, linked to the revamping of its debt, Euortunnel posted its first net profit -- 1.55 billion francs ($273 million).

title: The British Are Coming, and Going; Many Retailers Come Up Short in the Trans-Atlantic Leap
description: If it is true, as everyone from Adam Smith to Disraeli and Napoleon has said, that the British are a nation of shopkeepers, why can't they keep shop more successfully in America?

title: Where Raunch Met Excess; Demise of Art Deco Temple of Less-Than-High Art
description: At the Rialto Theater, ''Romper Room'' and ''Liquid Lips'' were neighbors.

title: HIGH NOTES AND LOW: A special report.; A Jazz Success Story With a Tinge of the Blues: At Lincoln Center, Defining the Canon Draws Fire
description: The scene at the Supper Club on West 47th Street seemed to evoke the glory days of jazz -- an ebullient swing band playing classic Ellington tunes as dancers in period costumes rocketed around the dance floor.

title: New Respect for Foster Parents
description: A Federal district judge in New York City has taken an important step toward recognizing the special relationship that exists between long-term foster parents and children they are seeking to adopt. The case stemmed from a caseworker's abrupt removal of a 4-year-old boy from the Bronx home of a foster mother who had cared for him since he was a month old, and who was in the final stages of the adoption process. The adoption was eventually approved, but the foster mother sued anyway, arguing that her due process rights had been violated when the city denied her a prompt hearing as well as visitation rights.

title: Gulko Wins Hawaii Event As a Prologue to the Open
description: Before Boris Gulko won the United States Open Championship jointly with Judit Polgar, he warmed up for the tourney by winning the Saitek United States Masters Tournament in Honolulu, July 21 to 29.

title: Kosovo Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Tape Shows Nation a Clinton Irate and Sad
description: In an extraordinary and grueling display, President Clinton's grand jury testimony was broadcast to the nation today as a centerpiece in his possible impeachment trial, with Mr. Clinton alternately argumentative and contrite, furious and crestfallen as he dueled with criminal prosecutors over accusations of perjury in the White House scandal.

title: America West Airlines Gets a Contract
description: The America West Holdings Corporation's America West Airlines Inc. unit reached a tentative five-year contract with its teamsters' union today, alleviating some labor tension the airline said hurt its third-quarter profit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Japan's Prime Minister Cites Others' Costly Errors

title: Metro Business; Building Workers Needed
description: Connecticut economists and industry experts say the exodus of construction workers during the state's recession, combined with a crackdown on unlicensed laborers and a lack of young people entering the field, is increasing construction prices and delaying home repairs.

title: The President's Testimony: Part Four of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: Top Executive Joins Tiger
description: Phil Duff, the chief financial officer of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, who played a key role in the merger that created the company last year, is resigning to take a position with Tiger Management L.L.C., the hedge fund. Mr. Duff, 41, spent 14 years at Morgan Stanley. He will join Tiger next week and will be senior managing director. Mr. Duff will become chief operating officer when Michael Bills leaves the firm earlier next year to return to teaching.

title: Racial Motive Is Seen in Beating of Indian-American Man in Queens
description: Offering fresh details about what they described as a bias attack, law enforcement officials said yesterday that a 19-year-old man who was severely beaten Sunday evening in South Ozone Park, Queens, had been singled out by residents who wanted to beat up an Indian.

title: Colorado Republicans Get a Queasy Feeling
description: At the headquarters of the Colorado Republican Party today, the television was not working, so some staffers listened to President Clinton's grand jury deposition on the radio. Others got a different kind of earful over the phone.

title: Remodel World Bank And I.M.F., Blair Urges
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain yesterday urged a revamping of the way the world's financial institutions deal with global economic turmoil, and said the procedures of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank had to be updated.

title: The President's Testimony: Part Three of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: Michael Currier, 37, Philanthropic Rancher Who Helped Tibetans
description: Michael Stephen Currier, a rancher and philanthropist who was the manager of the Economic Development Fund for the Tibetan Community in Exile, died on Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 37, and lived in Santa Fe.

title: Driver in Bus Crash Was Drunk, Police Say
description: The driver of a bus that ran off the Garden State Parkway and hit a tree Sunday morning, injuring himself and 23 passengers, was legally drunk, the State Police said yesterday.

title: Canadian Holdings Sold By Big Dutch Concern
description: Eureko B.V., the Netherlands-based holding company for a European alliance of financial services companies, said yesterday that it was selling its Canadian business to concentrate on Europe. Eureko said it had sold Seaboard North American Holdings Inc. for $265 million (Canadian), or $174 million (United States), in cash to Industrial Alliance, a Canadian life insurance company.

title: Among the nation's schoolchildren, there is a booming and puzzling market for key chains.
description: PARENTS shopping this month for pencils, notebooks, crayons and backpacks can add a new item to the school supplies list -- key chains, and lots of them. Dangling from the backpacks of the country's schoolchildren, they signify a booming market that barely existed two school years ago.

title: Boeing Wins Plane Maintenance Contract
description: The Boeing Company and the Hill Air Force Base in Odgen, Utah, said today that they had won a nine-year Air Force contract worth $1.1 billion to perform depot maintenance on a wide range of Air Force planes, including ground attack aircraft, the Air Force said.

title: Tape's Release Disgusts Kohl, But German TV Will Show It
description: Two of Germany's national television networks said today that they would not broadcast the most sordid sections of President Clinton's videotaped testimony, while Chancellor Helmut Kohl said the release of the tapes ''makes me vomit.''

title: Ripken Finally Sits One Out
description: No matter how many home runs Mark McGwire or Sammy Sosa hits this year, that record is going to be easier to match than Cal Ripken's. On Sunday, Baltimore's indestructible infielder finally scratched his name from the lineup after playing in 2,632 consecutive games, ending a streak that began early in Ronald Reagan's first term, survived eight Oriole managers and continued longer than most baseball careers.

title: Politicians Are Quick to Offer Hurricane Relief to Puerto Rico
description: It did not matter that Hurricane Georges was more than 1,500 miles from New York. As the powerful storm moved closer to Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands early yesterday, three of the state's most prominent politicians jockeyed for the title of Best Disaster Relief Coordinator, each saying he had a top-notch plan ready to go.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Gerhard Schroder, the challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in the German national election, misstated the date of the recent state election in Bavaria. It was Sept. 13, not Sept. 12.

title: Kosovo Dilemma
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MONY GROUP INC., New York, the holding company for Mutual Life Insurance Co., filed to sell common stock through an initial public offering, hoping to raise at least $100 million.

title: U.S. and Allies Increase Pressure on Serbs
description: The United States and NATO allies stepped up pressure on President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia today to end his military crackdown against separatists in Kosovo. And officials in Washington and Europe warned that the worsening plight of refugees in the province was increasing the possibility of NATO intervention.

title: Essay; Science Squints at a Future Fogged by Chaotic Uncertainty
description: BACK during China's Shang dynasty, around 3,500 years ago, sages foretold the future by casting oracle bones -- the clairvoyant equivalent of crap shooting.

title: Cowboys Have Excuses, but the Giants Need Them
description: The Dallas Cowboys played the entire game without their usual starting quarterback, Troy Aikman, who was out with a broken collarbone. They played the second half without their best running back, Emmitt Smith, who had a groin injury.

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Muriel Humphrey Brown, 86; Finished Husband's Senate Term
description: Muriel Humphrey Brown, who grew from a shy girl from South Dakota into a confident woman in the political campaigns for her first husband, Hubert H. Humphrey, and then was named to fill his seat in the Senate at his death in 1978, died on Sunday at Abbott Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. She was 86 and lived in Plymouth, Minn.

title: Abroad at Home; To the Stake!
description: Which of us could bear to be questioned relentlessly by hostile prosecutors about our sexual practices, our sins? That is what I thought as I watched the videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony.

title: A Memo to Pittsburgh: Let Stewart Be Slash
description: Kordell Stewart did not field questions after Pittsburgh was dusted by Miami, 21-0, here on Sunday. He made a statement about how his team was not at its best, how the offense did not click, how his team got socked, how it is early in the season and how changes need to be made. But no questions, please.

title: The President's Testimony: Part Six of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS. The dollar rose against Japan's currency, helped by a late rebound in United States stocks and by cracks in Japan's banking overhaul plan. In New York, the dollar settled at 134.49 yen, up from 132.60 on Friday.

title: Specialists See Hope For Crack Babies
description: After fears that babies born to crack addicts in the mid-1980's were irreversibly damaged failed to materialize, a new conclusion was reached in the early 1990's: that cocaine causes no lingering effects on children born to drug-addicted mothers. Now many pediatricians and child development specialists believe that the complex truth lies in between.

title: Questions on Health Care In Jails Raised After Death
description: Late last month, Jose Ubano, an inmate on Rikers Island, checked into a jail clinic with high fever and abdominal pains. City officials say Mr. Ubano, 29, was hallucinating and seemed suicidal.

title: These Trees, and 8,000 More, Struggle for Survival
description: EARLIER this year, the World Conservation Union, a nongovernmental organization based in Switzerland, added nearly 34,000 kinds of plants to its Red List of endangered species. That amounts to at least 1 in every 8 plant species in the world. Among those, it was recently announced, are at least 8,750 tree species -- about 1 in 10.

title: Clinton Urges World Action on Terror
description: President Clinton told world leaders today that the fight against terrorism was ''at the top of the U.S. agenda'' and proposed steps for better international cooperation to prevent and punish attacks.

title: FOUR MEDIA BUYS MSCL FOR $68.6 MILLION FOR EXPANSION
description: The Four Media Company, a film and television post-production services concern, said yesterday that it had bought the closely held MSCL Inc. production-services company for about $68.6 million to expand into the commercial editorial business. Four Media, based in Burbank, Calif., said it paid $66.1 million in cash and debt, plus 486,486 shares of Four Media stock for MSCL, which is based in Hollywood. MSCL's Encore and Filmcore operating units provide editing and other production services for commercials and television shows like ''Ally McBeal,'' ''The X-Files'' and ''NYPD Blue.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGUR, ELEANOR C.
description: SEGUR-Eleanor C. On September 20, 1998. Water color artist and art teacher. Beloved sister of Constance Duncan and also survived by several nieces, nephews, grand nieces and grand nephews. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced.

title: BREED TECHNOLOGIES PLANS HIGHER WRITE-DOWNS
description: Breed Technologies Inc., the world's No. 3 maker of automobile air bags, said yesterday that it planned to report increased write-downs and higher operating income in its restated fiscal second-quarter earnings. The company said its write-down of good will would rise to $81.9 million from the previously reported $77.6 million in the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1997. The write-down for long-lived assets related to affected production and other equipment would rise to $74.1 million, from $62.9 million. The company, which is based in Lakeland, Fla., settled a dispute with the Securities and Exchange Commission over its method of accounting for good will and asset write-downs in the second quarter, which included $349.9 million in revamping and other charges. Shares of Breed fell 25 cents, to $6.625.

title: Big Man on Campus? It Isn't the Witness
description: It might have been from emotion or it might have been the color control on the itty-bitty television set, but President Clinton's face shone a bright pink through much of his videotaped grand jury testimony.

title: Japan's Paralysis
description: A political deal on how to close insolvent Japanese banks appears to be unraveling rapidly, raising the specter of continued inaction on the financial crisis facing the world's second-largest economy. That would constitute an abdication of responsibility not only to the Japanese people but to the global economy that needs a healthy Japan.

title: With Puppets, Stravinsky's Tale
description: A new season at the New Victory Theater is off to an entrancing start with ''The Firebird.'' Combining puppetry, shadow play, colorful and imaginative lighting, dance movement and, of course, Stravinsky's potent musical telling of a Russian folk tale, this 50-minute show consistently captivates the eye and ear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITNEY, DON F.
description: WHITNEY-Don F. Of Furlong, PA on Sunday, September 20, 1998 at his home, Meetinghouse Ford. Son of the late Fay & Hazel Johnson Whitney. Brother of Morton J. Whitney and William D. Whitney, both of West Bend, Wisconsin. Longtime companion of James F. Paccioretti. Uncle of three nieces and three nephews. Relatives, friends & members of the Central Bucks Chamber of Commerce are invited to his memorial service on Thursday, Sept. 24, 1998 at 11:00 AM at Doylestown Presbyterian Church, 127 East Court Street, Doylestown. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Don's name may be made to Business Cares, a charity of the Central Bucks Chamber of Commerce, 115 West Court Street, First Union Bank Building, Doylestown, PA. 18901. For further information, Reed & Steinbach Funeral Home, Inc., Doylestown, PA.

title: Motor Vehicles Workers Receive Layoff Warning
description: The State Department of Transportation notified 3,800 of its workers yesterday that some of them could be laid off in November after the state turns over the operation of 35 motor vehicle inspection stations to a private company.

title: Jobs Going Begging, Companies in Florida Adapt
description: BellSouth Telecommunications of Miami, a unit of the BellSouth Corporation, says it has taken more than six months to fill 500 newly created jobs in Florida. Even more surpisingly, it went through 10,000 applicants before getting the people it wanted.

title: German Bank Forming Venture With Insurer
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's third-largest bank, and Allianz A.G., Europe's second-largest insurer, said yesterday that they would form an asset management venture in an effort to cut costs. By combining the maintenance and development of their information technology systems and sharing investment costs abroad, Dresdner and Allianz said they each expected to save at least 10 million marks ($6 million) a year.

title: Avian Intercourse
description: Q. How do birds have sexual intercourse?

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the United States' relationship with the United Nations referred incorrectly to the nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke as the United States' chief representative. The Clinton Administration has not submitted nomination papers to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; the process is being delayed while the State Department and the Justice Department investigate Mr. Holbrooke's financial disclosure forms and his contacts with State Department employees after he left the department two years ago. The nomination is not being blocked by Republicans.

title: DISNEY AND INFOSEEK TO CREATE NEW INTERNET DIRECTORY
description: The Walt Disney Company and the Infoseek Corporation said yesterday that they were developing a new Internet directory called Go Network, to be introduced later this year, as the world's No. 2 entertainment company looks to reach a bigger on-line audience. The move, reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal, follows Disney's agreement in June to buy a 43 percent stake in Infoseek, which has the fourth-largest Internet search and directory service. The companies said the new site would build on Infoseek's current service. Shares of Infoseek rose 81.25 cents, to $21.3125; Disney fell 43.75 cents, to $25.125.

title: Is It Artistry or Wishful Thinking?
description: In pretty much the same way that Shoeless Joe Jackson and Roger Maris have fans who are passionately devoted to getting their heroes into the Baseball Hall of Fame, Amy Beach has advocates who are lobbying to place her in the pantheon of great composers. Respected musicians have rallied to her cause: a few seasons ago, Ransom Wilson conducted her chamber opera, ''Cabildo,'' at Lincoln Center, and Dennis Russell Davies led the Brooklyn Philharmonic in her titanic ''Gaelic'' Symphony. There have been several recent recordings of her Grand Mass. And Joanne Polk, who is currently recording all of Beach's piano music, offered highlights at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday and Saturday evenings.

title: Malaysia-Singapore Rift Imperils Accord : 5-Power Defense Pact Is Caught in Crossfire
description: SINGAPORE  Malaysia's economic difficulties and political tensions with neighboring Singapore have cast a cloud over the future of Southeast Asia's only multilateral defense cooperation agreement, analysts said Monday.

title: Weighing Shame and Sympathy, A Weary People Watch Clinton
description: Finally the anchors and pundits fell silent, the tape rolled, a fuzzy image of President Clinton came on the screens, and . . .

title: Grand Jury Sympathized With Distraught Lewinsky
description: Three days after the President spoke to the country about his affair with Monica S. Lewinsky, the former White House intern told grand jurors that she had been in love with him right up until the minute he went on television and told the world that their involvement was purely sexual. And where, she wondered, was his apology to her?

title: Are Clinton's Aides So Innocent?
description: To the Editor:

title: N.Y.U. Relishes Visit From Clinton on High-Profile Day
description: L. Jay Oliva, the president of New York University, likes to describe the school as a reflection of the city: a world compressed into a village that is at once neighborly, multicultural and second to none when it comes to self-promotion.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: WHEAT ADVANCES. Wheat futures surged as expectations grew that Pakistan, Jordan and other countries would buy American wheat this week. Wheat for December delivery rose 4.75 cents, to $2.7075 a bushel.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a proposed tax on heavy trucks in Switzerland misidentified a retired Swiss postal worker. He is Urban Camenzind, the husband of Brigitte Camenzind. He is not the husband of Lori Epp-Zgreggen. A centuries-old farmhouse mentioned in the article belongs to Mrs. Epp-Zgreggen, not to the

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEINMEL, SIDNEY
description: FEINMEL-Sidney. 9/22/97. Missing your brotherly counsel more and more each day. Mycha

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLNER, HILLIE
description: WILLNER-Hillie. Beloved wife of Bruce, devoted mother of Alan & Steven Rosenthal. Loving sister of Emanuel and Marvin Frieman and Peppe Vilinsky. Also survived by four grandchildren. Services are on Wednesday, at 12 noon, at ''Riverside-Nassau North'' Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Phillips-Harris Laugh-In Brings Lift to Met Spirits
description: For all that they have given the Mets on the field, the biggest contribution Lenny Harris and Tony Phillips have made this season may be the smile they have helped put on Mike Piazza's face. And on the faces of most of the other Mets, as well.

title: 5 Airlines in Marketing Pact to Rival Star Alliance
description: Frustrated by regulatory delays as the airline industry forms global alliances, British Airways P.L.C., American Airlines and three other carriers announced a new marketing linkup today that is intended to challenge the Star Alliance spearheaded by Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. and the UAL Corporation's United Airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUMPER, WILLIAM J.
description: DUMPER-William J. Age 94. Of Southbury, Conn. formerly of Freeport, NY. Died September 20, 1998. Retired from the Investment Departament of Harris Trust and Savings Bank. Beloved husband of the late Frances. Dear father of Nancy Koch of Huntington, NY and Sally Wiseman of Wilton, Conn. Also eight grandchildren and one great-grandson.

title: The President's Testimony: Part Five of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: High-End Speaker Systems Bring Quality Sound to Home Computers
description: WHEN shopping for a computer system, the last features that buyers typically consider, if they consider them at all, are the audio speakers. Most multimedia computers are equipped with a pathetic pair of plastic-encased speakers of a fidelity about equal to a clock radio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONNELLON, MARY CORNELIA
description: DONNELLON-Mary Cornelia. On Monday, September 21, 1998 of New York City. Beloved wife of William McGuire; loving Stepmother of Laurie, Jennifer and Kimberly McGuire; sister of Frances Federici, Kathleen, Samuel R. Jr., Timothy and the late Richard Donnellon (1964); devoted daughter of Samuel R. Sr. and Cornelia Donnellon. Funeral services will be held Friday 9:15 am from the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Road, Wayne, NJ, then to Immaculate Heart of Mary RC Church, Wayne, NJ for a 10 am funeral Mass. Friends may call Wednesday 79pm and Thursday 2-4, 7-9 pm. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to the Susan B. Korman Breast Cancer Foundation, 5005 L.B.J. Freeway, Suite 370, Dallas, Texas 75244 would be appreciated.

title: People
description: * Tom Cotton was named to the new positions of president for global business and executive vice president and global business director for the Merrill Lynch & Co. account at J. Walter Thompson New York, a unit of WPP Group P.L.C. He had been executive vice president and worldwide account director for the AT&T Corp. account at Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, part of True North Communications.

title: The President's Testimony: Part Eight of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, MILTON
description: LEEDS-Milton. Of 366D Heritage Village, Southbury, CT. Died Monday September 21. Born November 14, 1909 in East Orange NJ, son of the late Louis and Blanche Schuhl. He went directly into the securities business after graduating high school, and for forty years worked at Pershing & Co. Stockbrokers on Wall Street, retiring in 1971 as a partner. He was Past President of the Association of Customers Brokers and also served as President of the National Association of Investment Brokers. He is survived by a couson, Judy Hertzberg of PA. Memorial service to be held at a later date. Burial in the Laurel Hill Cemetery in Brookfield, CT.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Consolidation Among Medical-Device Makers
description: A note to shareholders of all medical-device manufacturers: This is only the beginning.

title: A Success Story Defends His Lightweight Title
description: Shane Mosley, the International Boxing Federation lightweight champion, is the antithesis of everything that is wrong with boxing. He is a superbly talented boxer who fights all comers. He gets along great with his father, Jack, who is also his manager and trainer. And he is a good citizen whose name does not end up on a police blotter once a month.

title: A Fast Start Is Important
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel likes to divide the 16-game National Football League season into quarters, as if each was a four-game season. It is the way Fassel motivates his team and keeps it centered on immediate goals.

title: Razzle-Dazzle in the Playbook, Ineptness on the Field
description: For the last week, Giants players say, Coach Jim Fassel seemed tired. Not physically -- he has the energy of 10 men -- but tired of how his team has played on offense this season. He was tired of the lack of a running game. He was tired of his offense being ranked 29th. He was tired of the Giants converting just 11 percent of their third downs, last in the National Football League. He was just tired.

title: W. R. GRACE PLANS TO PURCHASE CROSFIELD DELAYED AGAIN
description: The W. R. Grace & Company's proposed $445 million purchase of the Crosfield Group, a subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. has been delayed for a second time because a review into whether the acquisition would hurt competition was taking longer than expected. When the transaction was announced on April 2, Grace, a specialty-chemicals producer with $1.5 billion in 1997 sales, said that it planned to complete the purchase of the maker of chemicals used in toothpaste and detergent by midyear. No new closing date was announced. Crosfield is a division of the British-based ICI Group.

title: Jefferson on Religion
description: To the Editor:

title: With Nation Glued to Television, Clinton Sticks With His Peers
description: On a day of high-minded indifference to the disclosure of his grand-jury testimony, President Clinton passed his time yesterday in the consoling company of admiring fellow world leaders, contemplating terrorism, Social Security, the degradation of the oceans and the social safety net in the Netherlands.

title: A Struggling Petitte Fails to Make His Case for the Playoffs
description: For a while, Andy Pettitte appeared to have found a relaxation technique last night. He was as loose as Jell-O as he settled into an easy rhythm, looking like a pitcher without a care in the world.

title: An Ace Beats A Jack Any Day
description: Two weeks ago, Democrats nominated John Cox, a former professor and management consultant, to take on Representative Matt Salmon, the two-term Republican who represents Arizona's First District in Washington. But it was not to be.

title: Enyokeni Royal Residence Journal; Zulu Virgins Celebrate Their Bodies, Themselves
description: To Western eyes, it may seem odd that 2,000 girls who are here to be sternly lectured about virginity are also heavily pressured to strip off almost every stitch of their clothing.

title: Next Step for Congress: Impeachment Decision
description: Even as the nation watched President Clinton on videotape today, many members of Congress on both sides of the aisle had already decided that he lied under oath. Now the question, which Congress is already starting to debate, is whether that is grounds for impeachment. Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, certainly seemed to think so. In his report to Congress, he held that perjury and obstruction of justice by any citizen ''are profoundly serious matters'' and that ''when such acts are committed by the President of the United States, we believe these acts 'may constitute grounds for an impeachment.' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMP, ALIDA DONNELL MILLIKEN.
description: CAMP-Alida Donnell Milliken. 89. At home in East Bluehill, Maine on September 19. Wife of the late Frederic E. Camp. Daughter of the late Seth M. Milliken and Alida K. Leese. Mother of Nicholas R. Camp (Carmel, ME), Susan C. Schewe (Lecanto, FL), Donnell McK Camp (South Londonderry, VT), Catharine C. Lund (Groton, MA), and William M. Boardman (Woodstock, VT). Grandmother to 14, great grandmother to 9 with a 10th expected in November. Sister of Minot K. Milliken (NYC) and John F. Milliken (Pittsboro, NC). She was a founding member of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Maine chapter of the MS Society; a longtime Trustee of Colby College; and a founding Trustee of the College of the Atlantic. She graduated from Smith College in 1930, after attending the Brearley School and Milton Academy. Honorary degrees: Doctor of Humane Letters from Colby and Bachelor of Arts in Human Ecology from College of the Atlantic. She was also a founding member of the Blue Hill Troup. She raced sailboats competitively from her childhood until 1958 when she took to cruising the coast in her Concordia yall named Thistledown. Memorial service at the Blue Hill Congregational Church, 2 PM, Friday, September 25. Memorial contributions to National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 Third Ave, NYC 10017-3288.

title: A Russian Spectrum, From Lamentation To Fiery Exuberance
description: Saturday night's concert by the New Juilliard Ensemble, with Joel Sachs conducting, presented five recent compositions in two categories. Either the music was slow and based on a minimum of ideas (essentially one in the case of Tigran Mansurian's ''Because I Do Not Hope'' and none in that of Otto Ketting's ''Arrival'') or else it zipped by, spilling diversity.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: HARNISCHFEGER ABANDONS SALE OF ITS BELOIT SUBSIDIARY
description: Harnischfeger Industries Inc., the world's No. 2 manufacturer of paper-making equipment, said yesterday that slowing economic growth worldwide had forced it to suspend efforts to sell its Beloit pulp- and paper-making machinery subsidiary. Harnischfeger, based in Milwaukee, also said it had strengthened its anti-takeover plan by lowering the threshold at which shareholders could buy additional shares, making a takeover prohibitively expensive. Shares of Harnischfeger fell 68.75 cents, to $11.875, their lowest level this decade.

title: Today's Sections
description: Metropolitan News begins on page D1 today, and SportsTuesday on page D9. Fashion news is on page A28.

title: A Story Told With Evil Intent
description: First the best-selling book; now the movie. Millions of Americans are still engrossed in reading ''The Starr Report,'' particularly the 121-page section called simply ''Narrative.''

title: Americans Continue Dominance
description: The United States national women's team will go into a two-month hiatus on a high note, having captured the Nike U.S. Cup with shutout victories over Mexico, Russia and Brazil.

title: Executive Changes
description: EMC CORP., Hopkinton, Mass., the maker of corporate computer-storage systems, said John Egan, its executive vice president for products and offerings, would leave the company after 15 years to pursue other interests. Paul Noble Jr. was named to succeed Mr. Egan, who is the son of the company co-founder Richard Egan.

title: The President's Testimony: Part Seven of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: Tokyo Leader Blames Many for Banks' Crisis
description: Japan's Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, today blamed his predecessor, Japan's powerful Finance Ministry and the heads of the country's huge financial institutions for wasting years before facing up to the crippling banking crisis as well as a deep recession that is worsening the world's economic turmoil.

title: Hesitantly, TV Executives Decide Show Must Go On
description: Much like television viewers, network executives were unsure what to expect when the videocassettes of President Clinton's grand jury appearance were popped into tape machines in Washington yesterday morning, and equally unsure how much of the sometimes salacious testimony they wanted the country to see.

title: Potassium-Rich Diet Linked to Lower Stroke Risk
description: A STUDY that tracked nearly 44,000 men over eight years has found that those whose diets included large amounts of potassium had one-third fewer strokes than those who did not. The benefits appeared to be greatest for men with high blood pressure.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROBERTSON, LEON C. JR.
description: ROBERTSON-Leon C. Jr. Memorial service Saturday, September 26th, at 12 Noon at the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, 281 Park Avenue South at 22nd Street.

title: Where Y2K Is Nothing But 3 Keys
description: YOU have probably already read, and you can expect to read a lot more in coming months, about something called Y2K. Sounds like the secret ingredient for a miracle hair restorer. Actually, it is a problem that is supposed to leave all us moderns quaking in our Nikes, but has to bring a smile to anyone with mild Luddite tendencies.

title: Don't Put Conditions On Check to U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: For a Son, 'Deliverance' Through a Memoir
description: WHEN James Dickey -- the hard-drinking, hard-living Southern poet and novelist -- died of liver disease in 1997, his son Christopher forgot everything he had ever known about his father.

title: A Fourth Day of Price Gains Lowers 30-Year Yield to 5.12%
description: Treasury yields declined yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, with no significant economic reports to move the market.

title: Corrections
