description: Headlines yesterday with a front-page article about the United States' attack on a pharmaceutical factory in Sudan on Aug. 20 referred incompletely to senior officials' account of the decision to act. As noted in the article, they attributed the choice of a target to evidence as well as inference. They did not say it was based on surmise.

title: Du Pont Relative Accused in Death of Heir's Girlfriend
description: For the second time in two years, a relative of the du Ponts, Delaware's first family, has been charged in a killing.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Conrail derailment that caused delays for commuters on Metro-North referred incorrectly to the Marble Hill Station. It is in Manhattan, not the Bronx. The neighborhood was joined to Manhattan until the digging of the Harlem Ship Canal in 1895.

title: Lazard in Talks on Los Angeles Transit Suit
description: Lazard Freres & Company and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of Los Angeles County are in talks to end almost two and a half years of litigation concerning overcharging on bonds, or yield-burning, a lawyer for the authority said.

title: EMI Shares Drop 15% On Weak Profit Outlook
description: EMI Group P.L.C.'s shares fell 15 percent yesterday to their lowest level in six years after the company, Britain's largest music concern, warned that problems in its major markets would push first-half operating profit down about 20 percent. The shares fell 61 pence, to 335 pence ($5.66), the lowest since Nov. 23, 1992.

title: One Family's Regal Airs, Another's Upward Mobility
description: Most sitcoms about families pretend to be connected to real life, though the link is tenuous. Two brash new comedies competing head to head tonight position themselves on either side of that big, banal middle ground where most series live.

title: Holyfield on the Outside Looking In
description: For one night, Evander Holyfield is trying a new profession: fight analyst.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise To a Record on the Big Board
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange rose 2.6 percent last month, to a record 4.21 billion shares, the exchange said yesterday. On the smaller American Stock Exchange, uncovered shart sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 204.28 million shares.

title: Drug Price-Fixing Suit Goes Before Jury
description: Lawyers for thousands of United States pharmacists go before a jury this week with their price-fixing lawsuit against Johnson & Johnson, Novartis A.G., Forest Laboratories, the Monsanto Corporation's G. D. Searle unit and the nation's largest drug wholesalers.

title: Lewinsky's Testimony on Love, Friend and Family
description: Following are excerpts of from testimony of Monica S. Lewinsky, who appeared before the grand jury convened by the independent counsel on Aug. 6 and Aug. 20, the second time three days after President Clinton had testified.

title: Parcells Says Foley Is the Starter, but Must Prove Himself
description: Late last week, as the Jets prepared for their meeting with the Indianapolis Colts, Bill Parcells sneaked up behind Glenn Foley and delivered a blow to the quarterback's torn rib cartilage. It was not a hard shot, just barely a touch, but Foley said he nearly collapsed.

title: Political Notes; Latest Chapter Brings Bronx Political Feud Full Circle
description: The feud between the Bronx Democratic Party and the Espada family has become so bitter that it has arguably achieved the status of Bronx political legend.

title: The Shrinking Power of Lies
description: The sound was buzzy, the picture less than crisp and the man at the center looked somehow smaller or at least more ordinary. Eyes blinking, his mouth set in a taut line, President Clinton looked like an ordinary man defending the ordinary lies he had concocted to hide an ordinary affair. The political bottom line was obvious. The four-hour tape of his Aug. 17 grand jury testimony will not destroy Mr. Clinton straightaway, and as an exercise in boil-lancing, it may help him. A contrarian might even argue that this performance, while indisputably one of the most low-rent moments in White House history, will do him less harm than the disastrous speech that he delivered later that same day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRUDNER, JIM
description: BRUDNER-Jim. The Board and Staff of the Treatment Action Group (TAG) mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Jim Brudner. Jim valiantly fought AIDS, both personally and professionally, for many years, and his struggle deeply inspired us. We will miss him. Mark Harrington, Senior Policy Director

title: On the Attack With an Army of Rhymes, Egotism and Music
description: ''Battle is my favorite hobby, that's why you despise me,'' snapped Canibus during his set at Tramps. But the rapper's pugnacious streak wasn't the main reason the audience might have resented him at the night's end. In a 30-minute set that demonstrated little beyond hostility, Canibus aided the backlash that hit him nearly as soon as he stepped into hip-hop's combat zone.

title: A Leader Comes Off The Bench
description: Troy Aikman was holding a clipboard. Emmitt Smith limped to the locker room early with a strained groin and did not return. And in between spectacular touchdowns in the second and fourth quarters, Deion Sanders spent nearly an hour in the locker room receiving fluids intravenously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONSTON, MILTON R.
description: BRONSTON-Milton R. Age 92. Husband of Beatrice. Father of Joan Traub & Kenneth Bronston. Grandfather of Anne, Margaret, Mary and Duncan. USLTA Tennis Umpire and tennis pro. International bridge lecturer and director. Services at Schwartz Brothers, Forest Hills Wednesday 1 P.M.

title: Cellstar Expects Weaker 2d-Half Earnings
description: The Cellstar Corporation, a wireless phone retailer, said today that earnings for the second half of 1998 would not meet expectations because of weakened demand in Asia and Latin America, as well as losses from its investment in Topp Telecom Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, FRANCES K.
description: WEINSTOCK-Frances K., 103. On September 20, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George J., devoted mother of Blossom Landsman, Arthur Weinstock, his wife Betty, & the late Rita Weinstock. Loving grandmother of Peggy Kerner & Carol Landsman. Also survived by great granddaughters Erica and Julie. Nieces and nephews all of whom she loved and who loved her. A special woman of caring, concern, wisdom and generosity. Services on Wednesday, at 1:00 P.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: CENTRAL PARKING TO BUY ALLRIGHT FOR $585 MILLION
description: The Central Parking Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to merge with Allright Holdings, the Houston-based parking services company, in a transaction valued at $585 million. Under terms of the agreement, Central Parking will issue about 7.6 million shares to Allright's shareholders, as well as assume debt. The company said Allright, which has 2,275 locations and does business as Allright Parking, had revenues of $216 million for the fiscal year ended June 30. Ownership of Allright is controlled by Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund II L.P., which is led by William L. Mack, and AEW Partners L.P., an investment partnership managed by AEW Capital Management L.P.

title: Clinton's Role of Lifetime Breaks Cinema's Rules
description: It was political theater of the purest sort, adapted for the age of video. And there was little doubt, watching Bill Clinton's grand jury testimony, that he knew he was making a movie. Refusing to provide sexually explicit details, he said, ''I am right to answer all the questions about perjury, but not to say things which will be forever in the historical annals of the United States because of this unprecedented videotape, and may be leaked at any time.''

title: Iranian Fails to Appear at the Afghan Talks Attended by Albright
description: What was expected to be the first high-level meeting in two decades between Iran and the United States did not occur today because Iran's Foreign Minister did not show up for a conference on Afghanistan attended by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.

title: Philips Electronics Sees a Drop in Profit
description: Shares of Royal Philips Electronics fell 17 percent here today after the company warned that third-quarter profit would significantly decline and that full-year profit from operations would be about the same as last year.

title: Selloff Abroad Is Deflected By Wall St.
description: Stocks weathered a sharp selloff on European markets yesterday and finished modestly higher, led by strong gains among bellwether technology issues.

title: NASA Wants Money to Save Russia Partner
description: Worried that trouble in Moscow is threatening its own dreams, NASA wants to spend up to $660 million over five years to bail out its Russian partner in building a planned international space station, agency officials said yesterday.

title: Meter Official Is Accused Of Coin Theft
description: The official in charge of collecting quarters from the city's 65,000 parking meters stands accused of pocketing thousands of the coins himself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZEN, LILA
description: KATZEN-Lila. On September 20, 1998. Renowned sculptor, beloved wife of Philip, loving mother of Denize and Hal, cherished grandmother of Donna and Matthew, dear sister of Leonard Pell and the late Murray Pell. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM at the Chapel in Trinity Cemetery, NYC.

title: Starr's Team Hammered Hard to Catch the President in Lies
description: Although the camera never once showed even a glimpse of Kenneth W. Starr or his team of inquisitors, the prosecutors' mission remained clear throughout President Clinton's grand jury testimony: to prove that the President of the United States was a liar.

title: For the Poor, a Shortage of Primary-Care Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspicion and Resentment in Letters From Lawyers
description: Following are excerpts from documents released today by the House that show a thinly veiled animosity between the lawyers for the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, and President Clinton over testimony by Mr. Clinton and his aides. They clashed over executive privilege, leaks to reporters, the White House willingness to provide information, the President's schedule and the independent counsel's tactics and the request by his office for a blood sample from the President for DNA testing.

title: INSIDE
description: Down Payment on Security

title: Doctors Report Rise in Elective Caesareans
description: THE Manhattan woman was in the first trimester of pregnancy with her first child when she decided how she wanted the baby delivered. She had read about childbirth in pregnancy books, heard war stories from friends and relatives and feared that she could not endure whatever labor pain she might have before the epidural kicked in. She told her doctor that when her pregnancy was full term, she wanted a Caesarean section.

title: IMPERIAL CREDIT REJECTS A RIVAL'S BID
description: The Imperial Credit Commercial Mortgage Investment Corporation yesterday rejected an unsolicited bid from a rival mortgage real estate investment trust, Wilshire Real Estate Investment Trust Inc. The ''proposal is inadequate and does not reflect the inherent value'' of Imperial Credit and ''its portfolio of assets,'' the Los Angeles-based company said in a statement. In addition, Imperial Credit, based in Los Angeles, adopted a poison pill plan designed to make a takeover more expensive for a would-be acquirer, and increased its quarterly dividend 18 percent. It also announced plans to buy back up to six million shares of common stock, or about 17.4 percent of its shares.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Murder Charges Dropped Against Homeless Parolee
description: The police arrested a homeless parolee yesterday morning and accused him of killing a man in Central Park on Saturday night, but the Manhattan District Attorney's office determined last night that the man could not have committed the murder and dropped the charges against him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, GEORGE
description: HOROWITZ - George. Beloved husband of the late Rose. Devoted daddy to Laura and Jay Wexler and Roberta Horowitz. Loving grandpa to Stacey, Lisa & Joshua. Always in our hearts. Will deeply be missed. Services Wednesday, 9:15AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: After Watching the Testimony Whitman Urges Resignation
description: After watching the videotape of President Clinton's grand jury testimony on television today, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey called for him to resign, saying ''his disdain for the truth is a national disgrace.''

title: The President's Testimony: Part Two of Eight
description: Following is a transcript of President Clinton's grand jury testimony in the investigation conducted by the independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. The testimony took place at the White House on Aug. 17. It was transcribed for the House Judiciary Committee by Deposition Services, a private transcription firm.

title: Ahab's Wife Dreams, and the Whale Speaks
description: Who was the wife of Captain Ahab, mentioned only fleetingly in Herman Melville's ''Moby-Dick''? That is the question at the heart of ''Ahab's Wife, or The Whale,'' performed on Sunday afternoon at the handsomely renovated Music Hall at Snug Harbor, on Staten Island.

title: Italian Growth Rate Met 2d-Quarter Expectations
description: Italy reported yesterday that second-quarter gross domestic product growth rose in line with expectations, but economists said they expected to revise their full-year forecasts down from the Government's 2 percent target. The G.D.P. rose a real, or inflation-adjusted, four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter from the first quarter, and was up 1.1 percent from the second quarter of 1997.

title: Dreamworks and Developer Agree to Terms for Movie Studio
description: Ending contentious negotiations that appeared doomed as recently as last month, the fledgling movie studio Dreamworks SKG and a real estate development company backed by New York investment houses reached an agreement today for the studio to build its new home in a coastal development heralded as the future of urban planning.

title: Administration to Ask $1.8 Billion for Embassy Security
description: The Clinton Administration will ask Congress this week for $1.8 billion for emergency security improvements at most of the 260 embassies and consulates worldwide, a down payment on protecting American missions against terrorism.

title: In North Carolina, The Name Game
description: What's in a name?

title: STOCK OF HARVEY ENTERTAINMENT RISES AS IT WEIGHS SALE
description: The stock of the merchandising and film concern Harvey Entertainment Company jumped 24 percent yesterday after the company said that it had hired a financial adviser to explore ways to raise cash or increase revenues. Harvey, based in Los Angeles, owns the rights to ''Casper the Friendly Ghost'' and ''Richie Rich.'' The company said it had retained Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, the New York investment firm, to advise it on the possible sale, merger, consolidation, recapitalization or spinoff of its business.

title: Satellite System Used In Landing at Newark
description: In a step that aviation officials say will improve safety and on-time arrivals and reduce noise, a commercial airliner yesterday touched down for the first time at Newark International Airport using a satellite-guided landing system.

title: French Bank Expanding In Australian Securities
description: The Australian brokerage subsidiary of Banque Nationale de Paris agreed yesterday to buy most of the brokerage business of Prudential-Bache Securities Australia Ltd. No purchase price was disclosed. Banque Nationale said the agreement was part of its ''worldwide expansion strategy into equities markets.''

title: Metro Business; G.E. Filing on Taxes Draws Senator's Fire
description: The General Electric Company failed to disclose its New York State and local tax payments properly in a report to the Federal Government, says a state senator who questioned whether the company had paid any New York taxes at all.

title: Hurricane Buffets Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands
description: Hurricane Georges roared into Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands today, causing extensive damage after leaving a trail of destruction in the smaller islands of the northeastern Caribbean.

title: High-Seas Hunter Pleads for Preservation of Fish
description: DR. CARL SAFINA was edgy, drumming his fingers, glaring at the sea through dark glasses. His boat rolled in the low waves. Seawater sloshed and gurgled through a chum bucket, forming a trail of chopped-up fish and an oily slick behind the boat.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm so disgusted with Republicans and Democrats that I'm going to vote for a third party next time. We've got no leader. We're the laughingstock of the whole world.''

title: Milutinovic Will Coach MetroStars In Playoffs
description: Bora Milutinovic, the soccer miracle-worker who has taken four different countries to the second round of the World Cup finals, was hired yesterday to coach the slumping MetroStars as they enter their own tournament, the Major League Soccer playoffs.

title: Doctors' Qualms About CPR
description: More than half of the doctors at a New York hospital said they would not give mouth-to-mouth resuscitation to a cardiac arrest patient, even in the face of low risk of infection and high likelihood of success.

title: An Uphill Climb, With Ankle Weights
description: Senator Barbara Boxer of California has known almost from the day she took office that winning a second term would not be easy. As one of the most liberal Democrats on Capitol Hill, she is a polarizing figure who attracts critics more easily than most politicians do, and her resulting ''negatives'' in the polls have always been high.

title: In Peru, Evidence of an Early Human Maritime Culture
description: ABOUT 12,000 years ago, people living in what is now southern Peru camped on the Pacific shore and feasted on fish, seabirds and shellfish. The remains of stone tools, hearths and butchered bird bones found at two Peruvian sites are the earliest known evidence of maritime-based cultures in the New World, scientists reported last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, K. BERTRAM
description: FRIEDMAN-K. Bertram. Beloved husband for 60 years of Patience (Patty). Devoted father of Thomas and David. Cherished grandfather of Michele, Marc, Jeremy, Jason & Benny. Loving brother of Helen Levy and Edith Garfunkel. Services Wednesday 1:15PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck. Contributions may be made to the Samuel Field Y, 58-20 Little Neck Parkway, Little Neck, NY.

title: Pearle Selects Barkley Evergreen
description: Pearle Vision Inc. in Dallas, the unit of the Cole National Corporation that operates the Pearle Vision Centers retail chain, said yesterday that it had named Barkley Evergreen & Partners in Kansas City, Mo., to handle its advertising and marketing account, with billings estimated at $40 million. The account had been handled by McCann-Erickson New York, part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising division of McCann-Erickson World Group, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, until that agency and the company agreed to part ways last week.

title: Unlikely Setting for Rosh ha-Shanah
description: At 2 A.M. Sunday, just 17 hours before the start of the Jewish High Holy Days, volunteers from Central Synagogue entered the vast, bleak space of the empty Seventh Regiment Armory on the Upper East Side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVENSON, JAMES H.
description: LAVENSON-James H. He asked so little, yet gave so much. Sail on sweet captain. Kris and Jerry Becker

title: C.B.A. To Spot In History
description: Ryan Minor was in the Baltimore Orioles' dugout about 15 minutes before Sunday night's game when Manager Ray Miller summoned him into a side room. ''You're in there at third base,'' Miller told him. Minor's eyes widened. ''Does he know?'' Minor responded.

title: MORE ON THE INQUIRY
description: Still in Boxes: Evidence That Could Help Clinton

title: Suffolk County Makes A Pitch for Islanders
description: If the Islanders are unhappy with Nassau Coliseum, they are welcome to seek a new arena in neighboring Suffolk County, leaders of the Suffolk Legislature and town officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARRELL, SR. AGNES, R.S.M.
description: PARRELL-Sr. Agnes, R.S.M. on September 20, 1998. Dear sister of Ann Lynch. Caring aunt of Mary Dinneen and Thomas Lynch. Mass of the Resurrection Thursday 4pm, Church of the Sacred Heart Dobbs Ferry. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9 pm. EdwardsDowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Wake service Wednesday 7:30 pm. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Memorials to Sisters of Mercy Retirement Fund appreciated.

title: Lockheed Stock Falls Over Comsat Bid
description: Shares of the Lockheed Martin Corporation fell 4.9 percent amid concern that the world's largest military-supply company was putting earnings at risk with its $2.7 billion bid for the Comsat Corporation, a provider of satellite services.

title: Oriole Officials Yielded To Cal Ripken's Streak
description: Not long after Cal Ripken surpassed Lou Gehrig's consecutive-game record on Sept. 6, 1995, a consensus began building among the Baltimore Orioles' staff and front office officials that the team would be better off if the streak ended. The goal was simple: to restore the normal hierarchy that governs a sports team.

description: Magazine Appears On Lewinsky List

title: Texan Charged With Bin Laden Link
description: A Texan was indicted yesterday on new charges that he lied about his knowledge of the activities of Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected in the bombings of the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last month.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

description: Following is an excerpt from remarks made at the General Assembly today by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa, as part of what he termed a valedictory address.

description: After a tense standoff outside an Upper Manhattan apartment yesterday, police officers fatally shot a man who they said had stabbed an acquaintance and then brandished a kitchen knife at the officers.

description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

description: PAPAGEORGE-Kay. On September 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Petros. Loving mother of Bess Nicholas. Cherished grandmother of Angela & Louis Clarke. title: Sybase Creates A New Division
description: Sybase Inc., the No. 4 data base software maker, said today that it had created a new division to focus on laptop and electronic-device users so it could focus on a growing area of its market.

description: At the End of the Rainbow, A Pot of Pastel Mushrooms

title: D'Amato Ad Seeks to Exploit Upstate Resentment of New York City
description: Playing directly to upstate voters' longstanding antagonism toward New York City, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato began broadcasting a television advertisement yesterday asserting that his Democratic challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, had written off upstate New York with statements and votes throughout his career.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Two Political Leaders Ask I.R.A. to Disarm
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland and David Trimble, the First Minister of the new Northern Ireland Assembly, called on the Irish Republican Army tonight to agree to begin a phased disarmament to allow the Northern peace effort to advance.

title: Test Kitchen; Light Bulbs to Playing Cards: Home Secrets Divulged
description: WHO knew that electric light bulbs could be used to mold chocolate cups? Or that hotel shower caps can be used to cover bowls in the refrigerator?

title: Congressman Plans Bill On Railway Hazards
description: Prompted by complaints that freight trains carrying jet fuel and other hazardous materials are often left idling for hours near homes in Carteret, United States Representative Robert Menendez said yesterday that he would seek Federal regulations to protect residential areas from railway hazards.

title: 'New' Germans Find Escape From Tainted Past
description: They have grappled with their nation's history and understand its shame. They see their future with a self-confidence their parents lacked.

title: What Will Mom and Dad Dream Up Next
description: With cup holders sprouting in every corner and nook of American cars (there are seven in a Dodge Caravan), it was only a matter of time before someone came up with the Stroll'r Hold'r, an ingeniously simple cup holder that snaps on to the handle of a baby stroller.

title: Shower of Bricks Pinpoints Flaws In New York Building Inspections
description: In the summer of 1996, an engineer using binoculars and a high-powered camera inspected the brick facade of a 44-story office building in midtown Manhattan and declared it safe, satisfying the requirements of a city law intended to guard against crumbling masonry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIKLER, BARBARA (PETE)
description: SHIKLER-Barbara (Pete). On September 21, 1998. A wondrous woman. Survived by her husband of 51 years Aaron, daughter Cathy, son Clifford, son-in-law Armand and granddaughter Isabella. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Thursday 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Clinton's Legalisms Evade the Real Issue: Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: $2 Million to School District in Manhattan
description: School District 2 in Manhattan is one of 20 school districts in 17 states to receive grants from the Federal Government to train teachers in the use of new technology, the Clinton Administration announced yesterday.

title: Clinton Is Seeking More Money for Military Readiness
description: A week after the nation's military commanders warned him about growing fiscal strains on the armed services, President Clinton today proposed giving the Pentagon an immediate new infusion of cash and opened the door to a much larger increase in military spending in 2000.

title: Mandela, at White House, Says World Backs Clinton
description: Nelson Mandela, the President of South Africa and among the planet's foremost moral authorities, gave President Clinton the kind of emotional endorsement tonight that he has trouble getting these days from members of his own party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARSHAW, JOANNE (EPPS)
description: WARSHAW-Joanne (Epps). Of NYC, on September 20, 1998. Beloved wife of Jules. Loving mother to Bruce, Matthew and Jacqueline Michaels. Loving grandmother to Zachary, Samuel, Daniel, Jack and Luke. Loving mother-in-law to Blake, Gigi and Debbe.

title: U.S. Aide Drives to Valley of Kosovo Refugees
description: The Clinton Administration's special envoy for Kosovo drove into a valley filled with about 20,000 ethnic Albanian refugees today, many of whom sleep in the fields, to refute the Yugoslav President's assertions that there was no human crisis in the province.

title: A Wine Country Grows in Manhattan
description: ON the sixth day, New Yorkers do not rest. Saturday, supposedly set aside for leisure, is the day for picking up the dry cleaning, dropping off shoes for new soles, buying groceries and taking the cat to the vet. It is a workday.

title: Hurricane Sets Off Alarm Among Millions in New York With Ties to Caribbean
description: As Hurricane Georges continued on its destructive path through the northeastern Caribbean yesterday, the storm also roared to life for millions of people in New York City who have relatives living in its path.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORTIMER, JOHN AND HILDA
description: MORTIMER-John and Hilda. On Tuesday, September 29 at 2PM at the First Congregational Church, Sound Beach Ave., Old Greenwich, CT. Reception to follow.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: United Airlines' Parent Picks Insider as President

title: Corrections
description: A music listing in the Arts & Leisure section on Sunday for concerts tomorrow and Friday titled ''New Encounters 1'' misstated the site. The concerts, by the New Music Consort of the Manhattan School of Music and the Elsner String Quartet, will be at the Taipei Theater, 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 49th Street, not at the Manhattan School of Music, which is a sponsor of the event.

title: TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO ADD MEDICAL PRODUCTS MAKER
description: Tyco International Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy the Graphic Controls Corporation, a maker of disposable medical and surgical products, from the New York investment group Bessemer Holdings L.P. for $460 million in cash to augment its medical unit. The Buffalo-based Graphic Controls makes disposable medical monitoring products and has sales of about $280 million, Tyco said. Tyco, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, has been on an acquisition spree, spending more than $11 billion to buy companies since July 1997. In May, it agreed to buy the United States Surgical Corporation for about $3.9 billion in stock and assumed debt. Tyco shares rose $1.6875, to $54.

title: A Greek Savory That's No Pastry-Come-Lately
description: WITH any luck, the wrap fad is fading and ingredients that do not belong inside dough -- like chewy stalks of broccoli and drippy sauces -- will be left where they belong.

title: $25 and Under; Casual Japanese Dining, Right on the Beaten Track
description: I FIRST heard about Marumi on the Internet, at www.chow hound.com, a food lovers' site where the message boards offer a wealth of information about New York City restaurants. In an exchange about sushi, one correspondent mentioned one of his favorites, Marumi, a small restaurant I had never heard of, on one of the touristy blocks near New York University that I generally avoid.

title: Crisscrossing The Cultural Boundaries; Vernon Reid Likes Forging Unlikely Artistic Alliances
description: There's a Victorian house on a cul-de-sac in Staten Island that looks a little different from its neighbors. Flanking the walkway to the front porch are two eyeballs the size of cantaloupes, and where a picket fence used to be, there is a sculptural gateway of rusted iron, a dangling wooden sphere and a shiny aluminum circle. ''Welcome to the Abstract Ranch,'' said Vernon Reid, the guitarist and composer who lives and works there.

title: Advertisers are graded on how they depict women, and a pitch for a burrito gets an F.
description: AN organization of women in advertising is again grading efforts by Madison Avenue to portray their sex in sales pitches for products.

title: A Rape and Beating, Later 3 Murders And Then the Twist
description: The young women whom Brandon Teena dated all agree about one thing. Brandon, a fresh-faced 21-year-old Nebraskan who was raped and beaten by two acquaintances on Christmas Eve in 1993, then shot to death with two others by the same pair a week later, knew how to treat a woman. He was courtly and sent flowers and was an excellent kisser. Growing up, the star he most idolized was Cher.

title: Suharto Wealth Under Inquiry
description: The Indonesian Government has questioned former President Suharto about his personal wealth and accusations that he had billions of dollars in overseas bank accounts, officials said today.

title: Old Admirer Becomes McGwire's Foe for Day
description: Randy Johnson was the awkward one of the two, a tall campus curiosity with a slingshot of an arm but the aim of a water gun. Fastballs spraying everywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, EVELYN
description: SCHWARTZ-Evelyn. 87. Of Pompano Beach, Florida, formerly of Jamaica, New York passed away September 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Sol, loving mother of Lucille Greene (Ronald), Jill Schwartz (Burton), Jack Schwartz (Lynne), cherished grandmother of six, adored greatgrandmother of four. Services Thursday, noon, at Beth David Cemetery in Hollywood, Florida.

title: Mosley Stops Morales in a Bout of Unbeatens at Garden
description: Giving a brilliant performance in his New York debut, Shane Mosley kept pounding Eduardo Morales of Argentina until Morales sagged into the corner and had to be saved by the referee in the fifth round last night at the Theater in Madison Square Garden.

title: Itochu Sells 40% Of Time Warner Stake
description: The Itochu Corporation, one of the world's largest companies by sales, said yesterday that it sold almost half its stake in Time Warner Inc. for $420 million. Itochu said it sold 2.3 million shares, or 40 percent of its stake in Time Warner. The company, based in Osaka, Japan, said it earned a profit of 27 billion yen ($199.6 million) on the investment.

title: Putting a Funky Face on Wall Street
description: TWO men in ponytails and a woman with a bleached-blond crew cut were hanging out in their sparsely decorated Internet consulting firm at 11 Broadway in lower Manhattan. Their upstairs neighbor, the president of an Internet company had just stopped by. He had sideburns to his chin.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Out of Job, Out of Stock

title: Journal; Pig Vs. Prig
description: It's not only our President who has a certain genius for, as the Starr report puts it, refusing to achieve ''completion'' in sex. Look at the media. From the moment the All Monica bell went off in January -- with Sam Donaldson's immortal prediction that ''If he's not telling the truth, I think his Presidency is numbered in days'' -- the press has been promising a national orgasm in the form of the resignation, impeachment or tarring-and-feathering of Bill Clinton. But, in the eternal Groundhog Day that is Monicagate, the consummation, however devoutly wished, never arrives.

title: William Albright, 53, Composer Of Ragtime Music for the Organ
description: William Albright, a composer, organist and pianist, died on Sept. 17 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 53.

title: Cause Elusive In Death of Griffith Joyner
description: Authorities continued performing an autopsy yesterday to try to determine the cause of death of the 1988 Olympic sprint champion, Florence Griffith Joyner, who did not wake from her sleep on Monday morning at her home in Mission Viejo, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An essay in Science Times yesterday about predictions misstated the time elapsed since the suicide of Socrates, who relied on oracles. It was 2,397 years ago, not 1,398.

title: 2 Top Family Business Groups Cede Large Stakes to Indonesia
description: Indonesia said today that the Salim and Gajah Tunggal groups had agreed to settle $7 billion in debts at failed banks they controlled by ceding to the Government shares in almost all their global investments.

title: MetroStars Are Upbeat as Milutinovic Parachutes In
description: Nothing has changed about Bora Milutinovic. He still philosophizes and he still confuses his interviewers the way he has since at least 1986 as the coach of four different national teams in the World Cup finals.

title: Where the Future May Be a Table Away
description: JOHN SHOCH, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, scans the room at Bucks, a folksy cafe in this affluent bedroom community, and notes that he recognizes about half the financiers, hardware engineers and software hackers who are seated, eating breakfast.

Betten was a native or Norway and a memorial is planned in Sandefjord, Norway. Donations in her memory may be made to the Norwegian Seamen's Church, 317 East 52 St, NY, NY 10022. Phone number 212-319-0370.

title: Teen-Ager Is Killed and Woman Is Hurt by Gunmen on Bicycles
description: Two men on bicycles shot a teen-ager to death outside a Brooklyn grocery store yesterday and wounded a young woman nearby, the police said.

title: Needed: A Fed for the World
description: Even as emerging markets sink into depression and stocks plunge from Montreal to Melbourne, a global economy is slowly emerging, albeit in a tortuous and painful way. But governments seem paralyzed, unable to deal with both the crisis and the opportunity.

title: Homecoming at Absarokee
description: At halftime in Absarokee, Mont., last Friday night, the candidates for homecoming queen of Absarokee High School stood at midfield, young women shivering in bright backless gowns as though they were creatures just uncocooned. Beside each queen candidate stood a king candidate who was also a football player with helmet-matted hair, a running back or tight end or linebacker carapaced in black and orange, the colors of the Absarokee Huskies. The rest of the Huskies had just trampled off the field, and the king candidates looked impatient to follow, detained only by feminine hands laid lightly upon their arms. The Huskies were trouncing the Lodge Grass Indians, from the Crow Reservation, and the mood was high, for this would be the Huskies' first victory of the season, 42-8.

title: Seagram in Polygram Deal
description: The commission of the European Union has granted regulatory approval for the Seagram Company's proposed acquisition of Royal Philips Electronics N.V.'s 75 percent stake in Polygram N.V. The commission did not impose any conditions on its approval of the proposed transaction, the companies said on Monday. The tender offer is expected to begin in October and to be completed in the fourth quarter of this year. Seagram, which also owns Universal Studios, has already said it will sell off Polygram's film division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNER, CHUCK
description: HORNER-Chuck. TV comedy writer & playwright, died September 15 in New York City. He was born 86 years ago in Delphos, Ohio. He graduated with high honor from Ohio Wesleyan University. During the 30's he and his first wife Katie worked as puppeteers for the Tatterman Marionettes and Bil Baird. From 1941 to 1945 he was a defense worker for Westinghouse in Ohio. In 1946 he came to New York and began writing for radio and TV. Arthur Godfrey hired him as head writer for ''Arthur Godfrey Time,'' the ''Talent Scout Show'' and ''Arthur Godfrey and Friends'' (8 years). He said that as head writer, he often had the dubious distinction of watching a written joke crumpled and thrown from the window of the 26th floor. He went on to write for Garry Moore, jack Paar, the ''Today Show'', game show creator Bob Stewart, CBS's ''All American Thanksgiving Day Parade'' (12 years), and ''The Tournament of Roses Parade'' (10 years). As Charles Horine playwright, he wrote ''Me and Thee'', ''Home is the Place'', Undying Love'', ''A Spot of Shade'', '' A Virgin at Nick's.'' He leaves his wife Denise Lor, his daughter Marie Axton, two grandchildren Myles and Lucy, two great grandchildren, Laurie and Evelyn.

title: Universities Finding a Sharp Rise in Computer-Aided Cheating
description: In a troubling reminder of technology's darker side, Virginia Tech, the state's largest university, has acknowledged that computer-aided cheating by students is growing rapidly.

title: Why the Wasabi-Lime Was the Right Move
description: MARTHA FURST, 36, and her sister, Susan Furst, 32, returned to their hometown of Freeport in rural Illinois to open a business. Martha had been an investment banker with Morgan Stanley. Susan was a professional chef with a resume that included the Four Seasons in Chicago and the Flying Fish restaurant in Seattle. Backed by money from an agricultural-feed company founded by their great-grandfather, the sisters started Terrapin Ridge, a line of gourmet mustards. In early 1997, they unveiled the mustards at a fancy-foods show in San Francisco. A year and a half later, the sisters now have about 1,000 accounts, according to Martha, and expect sales of about $400,000 this year.

title: 'Corpus Christi' Has a Preview, and Protesters
description: The theatergoers for the first preview performance of Terrence McNally's ''Corpus Christi,'' which has outraged religious and other groups by depicting a gay Christ-like figure and 12 gay apostles, had to make their way through a group of protesters and unusually tight security last night before they could take their seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AYE, DENNIS S.
description: AYE-Dennis S. A sweet, gentle man died Sunday, September 20, 1998 after a long illness. Survived by his adored mother, Kin Hla Kittee Toon Aye, his beloved children, Morgan and Gareth, his wife Terry, his sisters and brothers-inlaw Lei and Scott Ennis, Doris and Dominick Celiberti, Daisy and Glen Murison. Prayer service 10AM, Wednesday, September 23 at Burr Davis Sharpe, 584 Gramatan Avenue, Mount Vernon. Graveside service 3PM Wednesday, September 23 at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, ESTELLE (GOLDFINGER)
description: UNGER-Estelle (Goldfinger). Of Amherst, MA, died Sept 20th at the Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, MA. Born in Brooklyn she lived in Midwood Park and Stockbridge, MA. Husband J. Sam Unger died in 1989. Survived by son Jon Unger, daughter Lisa (Unger) Baskin, son-in-law Leonard Baskin, grandchildren Tobias Baskin, Laura Green, Hosea Baskin, Sarah Buttenwieser, Lucretia Baskin, 3 great grandchildren. A graveside service will be held at 11 AM Wednesday, the 23rd at the Mt. Judah Cemetery in New York. Contributions to Blue Feather AHRC, 558 16th St, Bklyn, NY 11215

title: Clinton's Legalisms Evade the Real Issue: Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERMAN, PHILIP E.
description: GERMAN-Philip E. On September 21, 1998. Our beloved Phil was too soon snatched from us by a bunch of bees. He died of anaphylactic shock due to multiple beestings. Phil was born in the Bronx, was a World War II veteran, and lived very happily in Princeton, NJ, for the past 24 years. He had a strong, brave heart that was intolerant of discrimination, injustice and hypocrisy. He was vibrant, loving, generous, compassionate, loyal, honest and funny. He had a deep, searching intelligence and sometimes despaired of the unfairness and dishonesty in this wicked world. He was truly a progressive and wonderful person who adored Shakespeare and Bach and hugely relished good food and drink. He leaves behind devastated Elaine, Ted, Matthew, and Laura. He was a ''oner''-and will be terribly missed. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the ACLU or Planned Parenthood.

title: Waging War Against the Cultural Status Quo
description: Some nasty fun is to be had watching Simon Geist (Dan Zukovic), a bogus journalist, colossal misanthrope and art snob, make fools of the publicity-hungry show business hopefuls he interviews for a nonexistent Los Angeles magazine in ''The Last Big Thing.''

title: Executive Quits at Saks
description: Saks Inc., the sixth-largest United States department store operator, said today that Jeanne B. Daniel, 42, had resigned as executive vice president of merchandising for its flagship Saks Fifth Avenue stores to pursue ''independent opportunities.'' Philip B. Miller, the chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue, will take over her responsibilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMPSON, HENRY A., M.D.
description: SAMPSON-Henry A., M.D. Beloved husband of Tania Jurtshuk, devoted father of Barbara. Funeral services private.

title: A Museum In Mexico Suddenly Shuts Down
description: With no fanfare and surprisingly little mourning, a museum that critics had extolled as Mexico's finest forum for modern art was closed on Sunday, a victim of cost slashing at the leading television network, Televisa.

title: Dubious Decisions on the Sudan
description: Almost immediately after American missiles destroyed the Shifa pharmaceutical plant in the Sudan last month, serious questions arose about whether the Clinton Administration had targeted the right factory. The Administration insisted that the factory was producing nerve gas for terrorists. But a report in Monday's Times by Tim Weiner and James Risen reveals that the decision to attack the plant was based in part on incomplete information and inference.

title: Adelphi Enrollment Rises After 12 Years of Decline
description: Adelphi University, whose enrollment plunged 62 percent during the turbulent 12-year administration of Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, released figures today showing that it is starting this academic term with a surge of new students on campus.

title: Yeltsin Creates Inner Cabinet Of Primakov and 6 Deputies
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin gave shape to Russia's new Cabinet today with a decree that created an inner cabinet, or presidium, made up of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov and his six top deputies. The decree also offered a greater voice to regional leaders.

title: Safer in the Rapids Than by the Shore
description: AS a teen-ager, Bill Kimpton was fired from the Clift Hotel in San Francisco. Later, he was rejected for admission to Cornell University's School of Hotel Administration. But in 1981 Mr. Kimpton finally became a hotelier when he left investment banking and took over the Hotel Bedford, a rundown tourist flop on Union Square in San Francisco.

title: COLLEGE NOTEBOOK
description: MIAMI

title: The Solution: (with apologies to Bertolt Brecht)
description: A voice,Jetting over the wilderness,Broadcasts the triste nouvelle:Outrage is dead,Gomorrah is swinging,The handbasket roasts in hell.Impeach?Perhaps. But if, perchance,It's we who have been infected?Say Dr. BennettAnd Reverend Pat,A new nation must be elected.

title: Uplifting Lessons in a Sweet, Tumbledown World
description: More than half a century after the full employment during World War II put an end to the Great Depression, that agonizing era is serving a new generation as a fount of wisdom: Hard times teach hard but useful lessons.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN HURT BY THREAT TO BANK REFORM. Political squabbling in Japan over measures to strengthen banks weakened the yen for a second day against the dollar. In New York, the dollar settled at 135.43 yen, up from 134.49.

title: Clinton Way: Ever Elusive
description: He began with careful answers about his understanding of ''the whole truth.'' He ended by saying he wished he had even more time to answer grand jurors' questions. Throughout his four hours of sworn testimony broadcast on Monday, President Clinton dodged and weaved, feinted and bobbed.

title: Rising Costs in Health Care
description: A report by economists at the Department of Health and Human Services predicts that growth in health-care spending will increase substantially over the next 10 years. Total health expenditures are expected to rise from $1 trillion in 1996 to $2.1 trillion by 2007, jumping from 13.6 percent of gross domestic product to 16.6 percent. That is likely to translate into much higher health insurance premium increases than has been the case in recent years. These numbers are discouraging, particularly since the projections do not even reach the years when baby boomers will begin utilizing health care intensively in their late 60's and 70's.

title: Home Worker Sentenced In Slaying of Woman, 74
description: A home health-care worker was sentenced to at least 40 years in prison yesterday for robbing and killing a 74-year-old woman in his care. A jury that had convicted him of capital murder in 1997 was dismissed before the trial's penalty phase.

title: Bomb's Birthplace Gets Down to Business
description: THIS city of 28,000 accepted long ago that its claim to fame was as a birthplace of the atomic bomb, which also brought a modicum of fortune.

title: To Go; Dessert as a Sweet Distraction
description: IT's been an up-and-down year for Thierry Cabigeos, the owner of Pitchoune, a small Provencal bistro at Third Avenue and 19th Street. Last winter, he and Pitchoune's chef, David McKenty, triumphantly opened Cote Sud on the Upper East Side. But then differences with Mr. McKenty caused Mr. Cabigeos to sell his interest in Cote Sud and retreat back to Pitchoune and to a new triumph, the opening of MUSETTE .

title: Vandals Deface 40 Graves at Jewish Cemetery
description: As Jews around the world celebrated the second night of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, one or more vandals painted 33 orange swastikas and other anti-Semitic and racist graffiti on 40 gravestones at a Jewish cemetery here.

title: COOPER CAMERON WARNS ON EARNINGS AND PLANS LAYOFFS
description: The Cooper Cameron Corporation, a maker of oil and natural gas equipment, warned yesterday that earnings would fall below estimates in the third and fourth quarters and that the company would cut about 500 jobs as Asian economic troubles reduce sales. The Houston-based company said lower-than-expected sales would cut third-quarter earnings to about 70 cents a share, below the 84-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call Corporation. Cooper said fourth-quarter earnings would be about 75 cents a share, below the 93-cent estimate. To cut costs, Cooper will lay off 5 percent of its work force in the next 60 days and will close a production plant in Missouri City, Tex. The shares fell $5, to $29.25.

title: Report Faults 'Soft Dollars' Use by Brokers
description: Imagine placing your hard-earned nest egg with an investment adviser who, in trading for your portfolio, uses a brokerage firm that pays his rent, gives him vouchers for rental cars, travel or theater tickets or buys new carpet for his office.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PETERSON, LOUIS S.
description: PETERSON-Louis S. 1923-1998. Friends of Lou Peterson will gather for a celebration of his life Friday, September 25, 1998, 2:30 PM, The Actors Studio Inc., 432 W. 44 Street, NY, NY. Please join us.

title: Ingredients for Success: Ground Pigments and Linseed Oil
description: CARL PLANSKY holds the strange distinction of being a prospering entrepreneur who has yet to acquire a tie or a jacket. He owns Williamsburg Art Supplies, a tiny shop on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that specializes in homemade oil paints. In an age when most paint is mass-produced, and when even much of the art in the galleries has a manufactured sheen (think video monitors), Mr. Plansky has earned a loyal following for his Old Worldish ways. ''I don't want to boast,'' he said on a recent afternoon, ''but all the schmeary painters buy from me.''

title: House Panel Edits 16 Boxes, Hoping to Forestall Pandora
description: The House Judiciary Committee today continued to pick through the 16 remaining boxes of evidence turned over by the independent counsel, flagging portions that may be too private, too embarrassing or irrelevant for public viewing.

title: Start-Ups Are Catching Fire in Poland
description: WHEN Communism collapsed in Poland, there were high expectations for a boom in small business. The Poles were known as canny traders, and anyone who visited dreary Warsaw in 1990 could see a thousand opportunities in a consumer- and service-starved populace. But few imagined the explosion in small-business start-ups: if England was known in the 19th century as a country of small shopkeepers, then Poland might well go down as a mecca for small businesses at the end of the 20th.

title: Iberia to Buy 11 Airbus Aircraft
description: Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana S.A., the Spanish national airline, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to buy 11 Airbus Industrie aircraft for 200 billion pesetas ($1.4 billion). The new aircraft, which will be delivered between 1999 and 2003, will replace existing DC-10 planes made by the Boeing Company's McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The Government plans to sell 5 percent stakes in Iberia to British Airways P.L.C. and to the AMR Corporation's American Airlines. A 30 percent stake will be offered to Spanish companies and the rest will be offered to the public.

title: New York Fed Chief Suggests He Leans to Interest-Rate Cut
description: Slowing growth now poses more of a danger to the United States economy than inflation, the president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, William J. McDonough, said yesterday, suggesting that he had become more open in recent days to the idea of a cut in interest rates.

title: Their Businesses May Be Small, But Their Ambitions Rarely Are
description: EVEN as children, many of them spotted a business angle nobody else did, and milked it for all it was worth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, DONALD R.
description: SCHOEN-Donald R. The Governors and staff of Lawrence Hospital are deeply saddened by the death of our long time Governor, Don Schoen. He was a respected business and community leader and loved as a dear friend of the Hospital. His commitment to quality patient care and his contributions to strategic planning were deeply valued and he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. George E. Austin, Chairman of the Board Roger G. Dvorak, President

title: 3Com Earnings Top Estimates But Sales Are Down by 12%
description: The 3Com Corporation reported earnings today that exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates for the second consecutive quarter. But the computer networking company's sales declined 12 percent from a year ago.

title: For Indie Films, 1979's Lark Turns Into This Year's Institution
description: When Sandra Schulberg rented a screening room in Manhattan in 1979 to show 20 new films to producers and distributors, she felt as if she was doing something radical. ''The intention was to try to create an alternate film economy,'' said Ms. Schulberg, a filmmaker herself. ''I did not see it becoming an institution.''

title: Failure May Not Be So Bad After All
description: TED KNEIDL founded West End Soda in 1992. His product, an all-natural, carbonated beverage of brewed fruit (raspberries and kiwis, among others) was, by most accounts, a mighty thirst-quenching treat. The tiny St. Louis firm grew to over $11 million in just three years. Then, in 1995, Mr. Kneidl and West End confronted what venture capitalists and bankers commonly refer to as ''market forces,'' a benign term for total destruction.

title: Bus and Subway Use Increased in July
description: Bus and subway ridership increased sharply in July, the first month that unlimited-ride Metrocard passes were sold, compared with the same month a year earlier, according to Metropolitan Transportation Authority figures, but the increase was not greater than the pace at which ridership has been growing for almost two years.

title: Using a Sexual Slur, Malaysian Calls Ex-Deputy Unacceptable
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today that he once had high hopes that his former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim, would be his successor. But he said that ''I cannot accept a man who is a sodomist as leader of the country.''

title: One Patch of Russia's Economic Crazy Quilt
description: With the rugged stoicism that typifies this vast Siberian territory, Nina V. Popova thought she could ride out Russia's economic storm.

title: First, There Are the Doughnuts
description: PREPARING frostings and deep-fried foods are two of my least favorite culinary tasks. But thanks to ''The Cupcake Cafe Cookbook'' by Ann Warren and Joan Lilly (Doubleday, $25), there I was, first heating and eventually discarding pounds of shortening to make two batches of doughnuts, then up to my elbows in masses of soft butter for buttercream.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times yesterday with an article about advances in the theory of superstrings misstated the given name of the astronomer who discovered the expansion of the universe. He was Edwin Hubble, not Edmund.

title: Treasury Prices Dip, in Unusual Tandem With Wall Street
description: Prices of United States Treasury securities fell for the first time in five days yesterday despite weakness in stocks.

title: Stories With Good Spirits and Bad
description: The inventiveness of the storytelling in Ping Chong's ''Kwaidan,'' along with the extravagant art and artfulness of its set and the unfailing precision of four puppeteers manipulating scores of elaborately contrived and painted figures, bring cheering audiences to their feet at LaMama's large Annex, where it is being presented as part of the International Festival of Puppet Theater.

title: Excerpts From Congressman Hyde's News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference with Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, after today's committee meeting, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription service:

title: Berlin Memorial Isn't a Fit Tribute; Germans Won't Forget
description: To the Editor:

title: Gore on the Tapes: 'Much Ado About Not Much New'
description: Like millions of other Americans on Monday, Vice President Al Gore watched parts of President Clinton's videotaped testimony before the grand jury that heard evidence in the Lewinsky matter.

title: Fuengirola Journal; Britons Pine in Exile, Ever Faithful to Their Dogs
description: Like many of the British expatriates scattered around southern Spain, Cecilia Riber and her husband moved to this coastal town when they retired, drawn to its warm climate and relaxed way of life. But Mr. Riber died 6 years ago, and now, after 15 years away from home, Mrs. Riber is ready to go back.

title: Unsafe Supplements?
description: To the Editor:

title: Tape Jordan, Lewinsky Says She Was Told
description: Contradicting investigators for the Whitewater independent counsel, Monica S. Lewinsky told a grand jury in August that they had asked her to wear a wire to secretly record Vernon E. Jordan Jr. and possibly President Clinton, according to a transcript of her testimony released by the House on Monday.

title: PURCHASE PLANS AND TOP APPOINTMENTS ARE ANNOUNCED
description: The Bank of New York Company's BNY Capital Markets Inc. unit agreed yesterday to buy the Patricof & Company Capital Corporation, a New York investment bank, which will be integrated into BNY Capital. Terms were not disclosed. Separately, the Bank of New York made some high-level executive appointments. Thomas J. Perna, Bruce W. Van Saun and Joseph M. Velli were named to the new positions of senior executive vice president and Thomas P. Gibbons to executive vice president; Robert J. Mueller will head the new asset based lending sector; Leslie V. Godridge was named head of corporate banking, and Harold F. Dietz will be chief credit policy officer and head of the credit policy sector.

title: ALBERTSON'S GAINS F.T.C. APPROVAL TO BUY BUTTREY FOOD
description: Albertson's Inc. won United States antitrust approval yesterday to complete its $169 million purchase of the Buttrey Food and Drug Stores Company after it agreed to sell 15 supermarkets in Montana and Wyoming. The Federal Trade Commission unanimously approved a proposal by Albertson's to sell the stores to resolve concerns that the combination would hamper competition in some regions. Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc. agreed to buy 13 of the stores and Supervalu Inc. the other two. On completion of its planned purchase of American Stores for about $12.7 billion in stock and debt, Albertson's, based in Boise, Idaho, will be the nation's biggest supermarket chain.

title: It's Her Label and She'll Sign Who She Wants To
description: WHEN Bettina Richards was an artist-and-repertory executive for big recording companies, she didn't like the way they treated musicians. Her favorite bands were ignored if they weren't best sellers; one lead singer, who went on to make a gold album, was told he shouldn't be singing at all.

title: Three Media Investors Seek A Stake in Germany's Kirch
description: Rupert Murdoch; Prince Walid bin Talal, from Saudi Arabia, and Mediaset S.p.A. plan to buy as much as 25 percent of the Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, for about $2 billion, the prince's adviser and Mediaset executives said.

title: Chardonnay: Pure Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: CABLETRON SEES PROFITS SLUMP 75% IN 2D QUARTER
description: Cabletron Systems Inc., the No. 3 computer-networking company, reported yesterday that second-quarter profit tumbled 75 percent on slower sales of older equipment. Its earnings fell for the fourth quarter in a row as companies bought faster equipment from rivals like Cisco Systems and 3Com. Net income for the quarter ended Aug. 30 fell to $14.6 million, or 9 cents a diluted share, from $57.6 million, or 36 cents, a year earlier. Cabletron, of Rochester, N.H., was expected to earn 8 cents a share, based on a survey by the First Call Corporation. The shares dropped 62.5 cents, to $10.375. The stock has lost about a third of its value this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNN, VIVIENNE H.
description: DUNN-Vivienne H. On September 22nd. Phi Beta Kappa, Woodrow Wilson Fellow, Columbia University, Johns Hopkins. Original TimeLife ''Gypsy of Sixth Avenue'' with IBM over 20 years. Joyously retired with her animals to Stone Ridge, NY. Survived by daughters Lynda and Eve, brother Richard, great aunt Wanda, grandchildren Rebecca and Daniel, her beloved animals, and many many true friends. Contributions to the Humane Society (HSUS), PO Box 97049, Wash., DC 20077. Memorial in Stone Ridge to follow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, JOSEPH H.
description: SCHINDLER-Joseph H. On September 22, 1998. Of Delray Beach Fl and New York City. Retired attorney. Beloved husband of Norma; father of Dale Kotick and Bruce Schindler; grandfather and great grandfather; brother of Rose Thomas. Services private.

title: 2 Agencies Make Acquisitions
description: Two agencies made acquisitions in health care and in public relations.

title: Students at B-Schools Flock to the E-Courses
description: AS the sun begins its pink descent behind the neo-Gothic spire of Deering Library, two barefoot students lazily toss a Frisbee across a great expanse of lawn. Backpack-toting undergraduates saunter by. Four flights up, in Northwestern University's Leverone Hall, 18 students and a professor are gathered around a classroom table dotted with water bottles and cups of iced coffee. Pens are filling notebooks.

title: Food Chain
description: Leveling a Layer Cake

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAUMAN, CALEB
description: CAUMAN-Caleb. On Sept. 21, 1998 at St. Albans Veterans Hospital. Beloved husband of Rebecca Lowenstein Cauman, devoted father of Ann Cauman and Martin White and Richard Cauman and Catherine Hoffmeier Cauman of Washington, D.C. Adored grandfather of Sam and Seth Cauman and Jason and Charles CaumanWhite. Born January 1, 1909. Caleb was a graduate of Boston Latin School and Harvard University-'29. He was a Lt. Col. in the United States Army, joining in 1941 and serving overseas in the China-Burma-India Theater from 1943-1946. His surviving sister is Hannah Cauman Levin of Canton, Massachusetts, and Sarasota, Florida. Memorial services at St. Thomas More Rectory, 65 East 89 Street, NYC at 1:30 PM, Thursday, September 24. Please omit flowers. Contributions may be sent to Veteran's Hospital Primary-Based Homecare or charity of choice.

title: U.S., Minus Stars, Coping With Substitute Squad
description: This Davis Cup crew continues to be a team defined more by the who's who of stars missing from its midst, a list led by Pete Sampras and Andre Agassi, than by the sum of its actual parts. But the four players selected to represent the United States in the semifinal against Italy this weekend in Milwaukee are coping with the slight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CB RICHARD ELLIS, Los Angeles, a real estate service company, bought the 73 percent of CB Commercial Real Estate Group Canada that it did not already own. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 7 about a libel suit filed against The Philadelphia Inquirer by a reporter for the paper, Ralph Cipriano, omitted three words in a comment made to The Washington Post by Robert J. Rosenthal, the newspaper's editor. He said, ''There were things we didn't publish that Ralph wrote that we didn't think were truthful.''

title: Senate Votes Down a Higher Minimum Wage, Citing Squeeze
description: Senate Republicans today killed any chance of increasing the minimum wage this year, voting down a bill they said would hurt small businesses because it would extract too much too soon after the wage increase of 1996.

title: A Science and a Business, a Saver and a Killer
description: BLOOD

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WENDELS, MAY E.
description: WENDELS-May E. On Friday, Sept. 25, at 11 A.M., a graveside service will be held at Lutheran Cemetery, 67-29 Metropolitan Ave., Middle Village, New York. May died Friday, August 28

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUDICINA, PAT
description: LAUDICINA-Pat, 52. Suddenly on September 20, 1998 of Malverne. Beloved brother of Vivian Huber. Loving uncle of Michael and Andrea. Fond cousin of Tony Danza. Funeral entrusted to the Malverne Funeral Home (Anthony J. Walsh & Son), 330 Hempstead Ave, exit 17 South, S.S. Parkway, Malverne, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:45AM Our Lady of Lourdes RC Church. Interment St Charles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPSCHUTZ, BERTHA
description: LIPSCHUTZ-Bertha. On September 22. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Rosalind Berkowitz and the late Phyllis Lefkowitz-Hark. Dear grandmother of Cheryl Prosky, Ellen Kamzan, Gary Lefkowitz, Shari Berkowitz, Gail Berger and Mark Berkowitz. Also survived by six great grandchildren. Graveside service today, 11 AM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHALFI, EVELYN
description: SHALFI-Evelyn. We will never know a kinder soul. Love, David, Evelyn, Evan and Jesse Bauer

title: About New York; An 'Invisible' Life Remains So in Death
description: JOSE SORIANO loved walking around the city. It was a welcome stress-buster from his routine of working long shifts at a Brooklyn clothing factory. Some days he sauntered through Central Park to his railroad flat in El Barrio, taking in the sights of the city he adopted eight years ago when he moved here from Mexico. His wife, Fausta, worried about him, but he shrugged off her concerns. There's always light, he reassured her. And people look out, too.

title: Critic's Notebook; Murals That Evoke the 'Chagallization' of a Theater
description: Among the major works of 20th-century art, none have traveled more widely in the 1990's than the panoramic murals that were painted by Marc Chagall in January 1920 for the new Jewish Theater in Moscow. Like that theater itself, and like many of those who had worked for it, they had been proscribed, suppressed and quite possibly destroyed in the Soviet Union. If Stalin could order the murder of Salomon Mikhoels, the Jewish Theater's greatest actor, what hope was there for the paintings?

title: Off the Menu
description: In the Giraffe's House

title: Clinton Holds Mostly Steady In the Polls
description: The release of President Clinton's videotaped grand jury testimony produced no dramatic shifts in public opinion about Mr. Clinton or the issues surrounding his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, according to several polls conducted just after the tape was televised on Monday.

title: U.S. Trade Official Says China Market Is Closed Tighter
description: A senior American trade official today criticized what he called China's unwillingness to open its markets to foreign companies, and accused the Chinese of tightening some restrictions on foreign businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OWEN, RICHARD D.
description: OWEN-Richard D. Of Wading River, NY. Suddenly on September 22, 1998, age 60. Beloved fiancee of Ann Carlile. Loving father of Ned. Fond brother of David Owen and Nancy Strong. Dear stepfather of Helen and John. Long time employee of Waldbaum's, boxing promoter of All Star Boxing, supporter of Special Olympics and Make-a-Wish. Friend to the famous and not so famous. Reposing from 2-4, 7-9 PM on Thursday, Alexander-Tuthill Funeral Home, 6447 Route 25A, Wading River. Funeral Service, Friday, 10am St. Anselm's Episcopal Church, Shoreham. Cremation, private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BENJAMIN
description: COHEN-Benjamin. Died peacefully after 90 full years on Sept 21, 1998. He was an avid golfer, artist extraordinaire, and bridge player. Father of Arthur Cohen & Dorothy Schrager, grandfather to Eric Cohen & David Schrager. Graveside services on Wednesday 2 P.M. at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Bill Cratty, 47, Choreographer and Dancer
description: Bill Cratty, a choreographer and dancer with the Jose Limon Dance Company, died on Sept. 9 at his home in London. He was 47.

title: NBC Makes Deal For New Auto Race
description: NBC Sports, which no longer has pro football in the fall, announced a three-year deal yesterday to carry a new Nascar Winston Cup race, the Jiffy Lube Miami 400, from the Homestead Miami Speedway, starting in November 1999.

title: Keeping Asia Liquid
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dow Declines by 36.05 as Other Gauges Post Gains
description: Stocks were generally higher yesterday, but the market's most closely watched indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, ended with a small loss.

title: Liberties; Legacy of Lust
description: He couldn't stop thinking about the thong underwear. He couldn't believe Monica had pulled up her jacket to show it off. It so inflamed his imagination. At meetings, at briefings, at the most unlikely times, his mind suddenly reverted to the image of those straps, quickening his pulse, making him catch his breath.

title: Can Players Maintain Resolve of September?
description: Many of his peers were in Atlanta last Saturday to watch Evander Holyfield defend his heavyweight title and to play pick-up basketball at a downtown athletic club. Dikembe Mutombo attended the bout, but he declined an invitation to get a decent workout.

title: 'You Don't Know Me, but . . .'
description: The race between Alfonse D'Amato and Charles Schumer for the United States Senate hit the rancor level so fast that Mr. D'Amato's ''Two Mayors'' television commercial -- in which Rudolph Giuliani and Edward Koch vie for the right to say that Al D'Amato is ''the best Senator New York has ever had'' -- may be as good-humored as this campaign is going to get. Never before have Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Koch looked like the most cuddly people in town.

title: The Upstate-Downstate Game
description: This is a new 30-second commercial that the D'Amato campaign began broadcasting in markets in upstate New York yesterday morning.

title: One-Woman Fashion Show
description: ELAINE KIM opened a designer clothing store on soon-to-be-hip Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles in 1986. It was successful, but she wanted ''to get my hands dirty.'' So in 1992, she created her own label, Product, a line of urban fashions for women. She opened a boutique in Los Angeles, then moved her studio to SoHo in New York and opened a store there in 1994. Two years later, her designs were featured in fashion magazines and sold in Bloomingdale's and Barneys New York.

title: SALES IN ASIA WILL BE LOWER THAN EXPECTED, COMPAQ SAYS
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that sales of its personal computers in Asia would be lower than expected this year because of the region's economic crisis. The Houston-based company said that the number of computers it sells in Asia would be little changed from a year earlier and that overall sales for the region would fall short of earlier targets. It declined to disclose the targets or last year's sales. Compaq is cutting prices to shed its leftover models and is reining in costs at Digital Equipment, which it acquired in June for more than $9 billion. The shares rose 25 cents, to $31.875.

title: City's Principals Had No Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZEN, LILA
description: KATZEN-Lila. On September 20, 1998. Renowned sculptor, beloved wife of Philip, loving mother of Denize and Hal, cherished grandmother of Donna and Matthew, dear sister of Leonard Pell and the late Murray Pell. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM at the Chapel in Trinity Cemetery, NYC.

title: With 4 Games to Play, Sosa Concedes but Cubs Do Not
description: Sammy Sosa conceded the home run race today, saying Mark McGwire ''will finish a little bit higher.'' But the Chicago Cubs have not conceded the race that Sosa says really matters.

title: KAUFMAN AND BROAD REPORTS 85% INCREASE IN PROFIT
description: The Kaufman and Broad Home Corporation, the largest United States home builder in the West, said yesterday that fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 85 percent, aided by improved profit margins from its home building operations. Net income for the three months ended Aug. 31 rose to $28.1 million, or 68 cents a diluted share, from $15.2 million, or 38 cents, in the comparable period a year earlier. Revenue for the company, which is based in Los Angeles, rose to $659 million from $469 million. Results were above expectations of 60 cents a diluted share, according to a survey by the First Call Corporation. Nevertheless, the shares fell $1.50, to $20.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, ALAN
description: WECHSLER-Alan, 66, on September 17, in Phoenix, Arizona of a heart attack. A longtime resident of New York, he is survived by, and will be very much missed by his daughter, Bettye Connolly and son, Stephen Wechsler, both of Charlotte, N.C. and his brother and sister-in-law, Lawrence and Jan Wechsler, both of New York.

title: Kennelly Press Secretary Quits Governor's Race
description: The press secretary for United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly's gubernatorial campaign announced her resignation yesterday.

title: West Reaches Agreement With Russia On Kosovo
description: Western diplomats said tonight that they had reached agreement with Russia on a Security Council resolution that could be interpreted as allowing the use of force to stop the fighting in the Serbian province of Kosovo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITAY, VICTOR
description: KITAY-Victor. Beloved husband of Betti, adored father of Arlene & Robert Kaplan, Madeline & Monte Wolfson, cherished grandfather of Marc, Wendy, Ricky, David, and Jessica. He will always be remembered as the most loving, giving, caring, and sharing human being. A man to emulate and admire. Services will be held Wednesday, September 23, at 11:30 A.M. at Boulevard - Riverside Chapels, Hewlett, New York.

title: Rotation Full of Ifs, Ands, Buts
description: The Mets are guarding their weekend starting rotation as if it were a state secret. But Rick Reed has been told he will start in Atlanta on Friday against the rookie left-hander Bruce Chen. That means Reed would most likely start the first game of the division series next Wednesday if the Mets win the National League wild-card berth.

title: Clinton and Obuchi Break Ice but Solve No Economic Problems
description: President Clinton and Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi of Japan met for the first time yesterday and struggled to reassure the markets that they agree on a common strategy to pull the world's second-largest economy out of a recession that is fueling economic turmoil on three continents.

title: 22.5 Million Saw Broadcast of Testimony
description: About 22.5 million people watched the videotape of President Clinton's Aug. 17 grand jury testimony when it was broadcast on Monday on the three major broadcast networks and three all-news cable networks, according to Nielsen Media Research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, ELLEN
description: GROSSMAN-Ellen, an attorney known as Ellen Unger. Beloved wife of Mark. Devoted mother of Sean Unger, Michelle Davolio and Meryl Grossman. Loving daughter of Solomon and Jean Cohen. Dear sister of Neil Cohen. Services Wednesday, 10:45 AM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York.

title: Expos Nudge Mets Back Into a Tie With the Cubs
description: John Olerud tied a National League record by reaching base safely in 15 consecutive plate appearances. Turk Wendell established a Mets record for pitchers by appearing in his eighth straight game.

title: His Dream Is That We'll All Hear Little Voices
description: DRIVE west from Manhattan, through the Lincoln Tunnel and into the thick of one of the many commercial bloodstreams that feeds the suburban beast engulfing New York City. Go about 20 miles from the Hudson River, past the Tick Tock Diner and the all-night A&P, to a nondescript office building that overlooks a 14-theater multiplex and a warehouse-size Costco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWECK, JACK
description: DWECK-Jack. Everyone at Group Sales Box Office extends sincere condolences to Doris, Suzie and Robby on the untimely passing of their beloved husband and father.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLACK, SOL
description: KOLACK-Sol. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the death of Sol Kolack, retired Director of ADL's Regional Office in Boston. From 1947 to 1983 Sol led the fight against anti-Semitism, racism and bigotry in New England and implemented educational programs to promote tolerance and understanding. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Shirley, his children Richard and Nancy, and the family. Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: REPUBLICANS VOW TO PRESS INQUIRY ON THE PRESIDENT
description: Republicans in Congress vowed today to press ahead with consideration of an impeachment inquiry even though the broadcast of President Clinton's grand jury testimony did nothing to increase the public's appetite for him to leave office.

title: When a Big Company Hatches a Lot of Little Ideas
description: CHRYSTAL SOFTWARE'S document-processing products were born at the Xerox Corporation, but they sure did not fit there. Xerox can take years to develop a line of copiers; software goes stale in months. And Xerox thinks in terms of billion-dollar businesses. Even R. Steven Kiser, Chrystal's president, concedes that if Chrystal is wildly successful this year, its sales will not top $15 million. ''We're not even a blip on Xerox's radar screen,'' Mr. Kiser said. ''If we were still part of Xerox, we'd be killed off.''

title: The Minimalist; Fresh Figs Are to Relish, Or to Make Into One
description: I CAN'T say this about too many foods, but I can vividly remember my first taste of a fresh fig. This is because I grew up at a time when this plump, succulent fruit was sold almost exclusively in its dried form. It took me 20-plus years of life to encounter a fresh fig, and that was in Rome. In both appearance and taste it was unexpected and spectacular.

title: Fed by the Hand That Bites
description: FIFTY years ago, Lou Witzeman watched as a neighbor's house in an unincorporated area of Phoenix burned to the ground. A reporter at the time, Mr. Witzeman wrote the story for The Arizona Times, but he found a personal angle. He discovered that he, too, had no fire protection.

title: Street Closings
description: Because of the annual debate at the United Nations, today through Monday there will be intermittent closings of First Avenue between 41st and 48th Streets; the 42d Street exit of the Franklin D.
