Roosevelt Drive, and streets around the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at Park Avenue and 50th Street. Other street closings and detours are also possible elsewhere in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Clinton's Legalisms Evade the Real Issue: Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMP, ALIDA DONNELL MILLIKEN
description: CAMP-Alida Donnell Milliken. 89. At home in East Bluehill, Maine on September 19. Wife of the late Frederic E. Camp. Daughter of the late Seth M. Milliken and Alida K. Leese. Mother of Nicholas R. Camp (Carmel, ME), Susan C. Schewe (Lecanto, FL), Donnell McK Camp (South Londonderry, VT), Catharine C. Lund (Groton, MA), and William M. Boardman (Woodstock, VT). Grandmother to 14, great grandmother to 9 with a 10th expected in November. Sister of Minot K. Milliken (NYC) and John F. Milliken (Pittsboro, NC). She was a founding member of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Maine chapter of the MS Society; a longtime Trustee of Colby College; and a founding Trustee of the College of the Atlantic. She graduated from Smith College in 1930, after attending the Brearley School and Milton Academy. Honorary degrees: Doctor of Humane Letters from Colby and Bachelor of Arts in Human Ecology from College of the Atlantic. She was also a founding member of the Blue Hill Troupe. She raced sailboats competitively from her childhood until 1958 when she took to cruising the coast in her Concordia yall named Thistledown. Memorial service at the Blue Hill Congregational Church, 2 PM, Friday, September 25. Memorial contributions to National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 Third Avenue, NYC 10017-3288.

title: Police Defend Handling of Arrest in Central Park Killing
description: The homeless man who was wrongly arrested on charges that he had killed a man in Central Park told investigators that he confessed to the slaying because he thought doing so would help him avoid going to jail for a parole violation, a law-enforcement official said yesterday.

title: Fireballs in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Heeding the Siren Call to Do Your Own Thing
description: MY father told the story over and over. He was a young and energetic broker employed by a big textile company, an immigrant's son prospering for the first time, when his boss summoned him one day and said that because of corporate setbacks, my father would have to accept a wage cut.

title: Giants Push Neither Foes Nor the Panic Button
description: A day after being humbled by the Dallas Cowboys, the Giants found themselves in a most unwanted position: leaning on past adversity for present optimism.

title: Corrections
description: A table of the top-rated television programs in Business Day on Monday, under the heading ''Most Wanted,'' misstated the number of households represented by one rating point. It is 994,000, not 980,000.

title: Vive la Pizza: Simple, Rustic and, Yes, French
description: EVEN though the French influence is everywhere in New York's culinary world, a few foods that are common in France have managed to escape the city's dragnet and remain almost unknown here. The French pizza is one stunning example. Yes, pizza. Although it is most often known as a pissaladiere, it is what it is: a round, flat bread, crisp on the bottom, simply garnished on top, rustic and yet urbane.

title: For Martin, the Pressure Is a Self-Made Condition
description: Times had been tough for Curtis Martin, and he wanted to make up for it. After sub-par performances in his first two games as a Jet, he wanted to make something happen last Sunday against the Indianapolis Colts, which probably had something to do with his fumbling the ball on his second and third carries of the game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, RUTH
description: MARKS-Ruth. Of Margate, FL, formerly of Yonkers, NY, wife of the late Jack Geiger and Arnold Marks, devoted mother of Joyce Geiger Rosenbaum (Harold). Dear sister of Stanley, Leonard, Gilda and the late Irving Cohen, cherished nana of Jason and Jordana Mendelowitz, Gregory and Monica Drew. Services 11:30Am Thurs Sept 24th at the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, Union, NJ. Shiva family residence 53 Lenape Lane, Montville, NJ Thurs-Sun. She fought a courageous battle with cancer. Her spirit was there till the end. She died at home with her daughter and grandchildren. You are our inspiration. You meant so much to our family and always will.

title: Executive Fallout From a Merger Accord
description: One morning last November, as leaders of Worldcom Inc. and the MCI Communications Corporation held a news conference in Manhattan to announce their companies' $37 billion merger deal, an executive close to Worldcom who sat in the audience subtly gestured at the stage and an extremely subdued Gerald H. Taylor, MCI's chief executive.

title: Letter to Panel Leaders From Clinton Lawyers
description: Following is the letter sent today to Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, and Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the ranking Democrat on the committee, from President Clinton's lawyers, Charles F. C. Ruff and David E. Kendall, and released by Mr. Kendall:

title: In Chard, The Glory Lies in The Green
description: SWISS CHARD has a secret: it really is a type of beet. But while the stars of the beet family -- the red beet and the red-and-white Chioggia beet -- are valued primarily for their bulbous roots, chard's glory is its magnificent greenery. In fact, every inch of its stems, ribs and leaves can be used in dishes that seem just right for fall and winter nights.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Federal Express to Put Up Big Center in West Village
description: Signs on the former Atlas paper recycling plant on Greenwich Street in lower Manhattan suggest that a caller might find the property available for sale or lease. The building is vacant. But one of the two phone numbers on the sign is disconnected and the other brings an abrupt ''no comment'' from a voice that will identify itself only as a representative of the owner.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Starwood Has Lost Some Wall St. Luster
description: Over the past few years, Barry S. Sternlicht, chairman and chief executive of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc., has dazzled analysts with his financial acumen, transforming what had been a sleepy real estate investment trust into the world's largest hotel company.

title: Clinton Lawyers Say Starr Distorted Facts in the Report
description: The White House and President Clinton's lawyers complained to Congress today that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, had distorted facts and omitted exculpatory evidence in his impeachment report against the President.

title: New Unit for National City
description: The National City Corporation said today that it had created a new unit, National City Investment Management, which would focus on asset management for institutional investors. National City said the new unit, which would also serve as investment adviser for the Armada and Parkstone fund families, had assets under management of about $22 billion.

title: Restaurants; Italian Fare That's Earthy and Reliable
description: THERE must be thousands of Italian restaurants in New York City. Why are so few of them good?

title: Business Travel; Philippine Airlines may shut down operations tonight, a victim of the Asian economic crisis.
description: BARRING a last-minute rescue, Philippine Airlines, Asia's oldest scheduled carrier, will shut down at midnight tonight. This means passengers who until now have flown the airline's daily nonstop flight between Los Angeles and Manila, or the thrice-weekly nonstop flights between San Francisco and Manila, will have to make other arrangements. But no other arrangements from the United States will include nonstops.

title: UBS to Increase Control in Japan Ventures
description: UBS A.G. of Switzerland, one of the world's largest banks, said today that it was assuming greater control of its joint ventures with the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan, moving further away from the troubled Japanese lender.

title: SPECIAL TODAY: Entrepreneurs
description: The individual striking out alone has always been a part of America's business tradition. Now Everyone is trying to get into the act. Even big companies are trying to catch the restless spirit. With profiles, tips from those who have succeeded, reports from the hot spots and more. SECTION G.

title: Drum Roll, Please, for the 1995 Bordeaux
description: IF you plan to buy wine in the next few weeks, and you probably do, as more wine is sold in the fourth quarter of the year than at any other time, there is no question about what you should buy: 1995 Bordeaux. It is one of the better vintages of the waning century.

title: Security Left Out One Detail: The Boss
description: When it came to security for parking-meter collections, New York City officials believed they had finally built the better mousetrap.

title: Pataki's Stance on Yankees: 'They Belong in the Bronx'
description: Gov. George E. Pataki made his most emphatic statement so far in the fight over the future home of the Yankees, declaring yesterday that ''They belong in the Bronx, period.''

title: 6 Men in Mob Group Charged With Extortion
description: Six men identified as members of the Bruno-Scarfo organized crime family were arrested yesterday morning on charges of extortion, loan-sharking, conspiracy and racketeering, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, K. BERTRAM
description: FRIEDMAN-K. Bertram. The Board and staff of the Samuel Field YM-YWHA are profoundly saddened by the passing of K. Bertram Friedman, a valued past president and devoted board member. Mr. Friedman was a unique & multi-talented individual whose love for his family, zest for life and commitment to the wellbeing of others was extraordinary. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his beloved wife Patty, his children Thomas and David, and to his entire family. Mr. Friedman was a very special person who will be deeply missed by all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAFFNEY, RICHARD W.
description: GAFFNEY-Richard W. Of Brooklyn, New York, and Rehoboth Beach, Delaware. Died suddenly at home Sept. 22, 1998. An artist, educator & sportsman, he was the husband of Ann Walker Gaffney, the father of Walker Gaffney of St. Louis, and Elizabeth Gaffney of Brooklyn, & grandfather of Rynier Forrester Gaffney. A memorial service will be at 11 AM on Friday, September 25 at Grace Church Brooklyn Heights, 254 Hicks Street, Brooklyn, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Richard Gaffney Memorial Fund at Wagner College, One Campus Road, Staten Island, New York 10301.

title: UAL Names New President In Wake of Unions' Actions
description: United Airlines' parent company, the UAL Corporation, named James E. Goodwin, a longtime senior executive, as its new president and chief operating officer yesterday, only a few days after his predecessor was forced out by the carrier's powerful unions.

title: That's a Wrap: A Fad's Fade-Out
description: JUST last summer, Wrap-a-Rama was a bustling, happy little food shop on lower Second Avenue in Manhattan, serving up yummy meals with names like ''Tikka Break'' and drinks like strawberry-banana smoothies. Regulars crowded in for the wraps -- burrito style sandwiches filled with foods from around the world, like Indian chicken or Greek salad -- and to sit at painted tables and watch the East Village go by.

title: HURRICANE DAMAGE EXCEEDS $1 BILLION
description: Battered overnight by the strongest storm to hit this Caribbean island in 70 years, Puerto Rico struggled today to begin repairing at least a billion dollars in damage from Hurricane Georges, which continued its slow march west to the Dominican Republic and Haiti.

title: When the Suits Can Save Your Shirt
description: DEBORAH L. JACOBS, lawyer-turned-writer, gave a heartfelt compliment to the young man who arrived with his helper to clean her house in Brooklyn recently: the name of his service was awfully clever. But she wasn't going to leave it at that. ''Have you trademarked it?'' she asked.

title: Irabu and Spencer Make Their Cases for Playoffs
description: Even when they are on the verge of tying the American League record for victories, the Yankees still manage to muster a bit of intrigue.

title: City's Principals Had No Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- Scrambling for Lifeboat Seats; Indonesia's Troubles Swamp Even the Well-Run Banks
description: When Indonesia's economy began collapsing in August 1997, Rudy Ramli, president of Indonesia's fourth-largest private bank, gathered his top lieutenants for a pep talk. ''If everybody is going to die,'' Mr. Ramli said, ''we want to be the last ones to die.''

title: Legislating Suicide
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTROW, MEYER H.
description: OSTROW-Meyer H. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Wonderful father of Joseph and Francine, Rita and Arnold Rubin. Cherished grandfather of Sandy Fein, David Rubin, Elizabeth Buchsbaum, Peter and William Ostrow. Greatgrandfather of Barrie, Daniel, James and Matthew. A man for all seasons. Services today 10:30AM at Washington cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Convicted Killer Arrested Again in France
description: Ira Einhorn, an anti-establishment leader who has spent the last 17 years in Europe as a fugitive from justice in the murder of his girlfriend in Philadelphia in 1977, has been arrested again in France and faces possible extradition to the United States, a Government official said today.

title: Berlin Memorial Isn't a Fit Tribute
description: To the Editor:

title: City's Principals Had No Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Louis P. Martini, 79, Leader in Wine Industry
description: Louis P. Martini, a leading figure in the California wine business and chairman of the Louis M. Martini Winery in Napa Valley, died Monday at his home in St. Helena, Calif. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOUCHER, THOMAS O'NEIL
description: BOUCHER-Thomas O'Neil a longtime resident of Delray Beach Florida and Manchester Vermont, died Sunday, September 13 at the Vermont Respite House located in Williston, VT. after a brief illness. He was 85 years old. Mr. Boucher was born May 18, 1913 in Hartford, Connecticut. He graduated from Yale College in 1934 and Yale Law School in 1937. Mr. Boucher practiced law in New York City following graduation. He served in the Navy from 1942 until 1946 and was discharged with the rank of Lieutenant Commander. Following the war he joined the legal staff of Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick, New Jersey becoming a Director and a member of the Executive Committee. In 1966 he joined Ciba Corporation as President and served as Chairman of the merged Ciba-Giegy Corporation until his retirement in 1974. Following his retirement he continued on as a director of several different corporations and nonprofit enterprises with which he had long been involved. Surviving him are his wife, Dorothea, three children, Katherine Beug, Thomas O. Boucher, Jr., and Dr. Elizabeth Miquel; two stepchildren, Dale Leoffler and John C. Rodenburg; and 12 grandchildren. The family requests that in lieu of flowers donations be sent to the Vermont Respite House, 50 Allen Brook Road, Williston, VT. 05495.

title: Quarter Profit At Goldman Declines 25%
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it earned $754 million before taxes in its fiscal third quarter, a drop of about one-fourth from the second quarter, as global market turmoil took a toll on profit and cast doubts on Goldman's own planned public offering of stock.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ORANGE JUICE RISES 2.5 PERCENT. Prices rose for the first time in a week on speculation that Hurricane Georges would damage the orange crop in Florida. The November contract gained 2.55 cents, to $1.0585 a pound.

title: Settling the Score With Dragon Lady
description: At first, she looks a little clownish, forlornly wandering the crumbling ruins in an oversize coat, with sleeves too long and a fraying hem that sweeps the dirt covering the stage of the McCarter Theater. But it soon becomes apparent that there is nothing whimsical about her at all: Electra, played by the extraordinary Zoe Wanamaker, is wearing her murdered father's coat.

title: Brokers Admit Rigging Bids In Foreclosures
description: The bidding could not have been more public: foreclosed houses auctioned off by a court-appointed referee on the very steps of the State Supreme Courthouse in Queens.

title: Russia and U.S. Plan to Guard Atom Secrets
description: Russian and American officials agreed today on a program to discourage Russia's nuclear scientists from leaving for Iraq, Iran or other aspiring nuclear powers.

title: TV Notes
description: Measuring The Premieres

title: Meditating for Fun and Profit
description: LOCALS call this town, tucked in the rolling hills of southeastern Iowa, Silicorn Valley. And while the landscape is covered with cornfields, the economy in this valley of 10,000 thrives largely on its abundance of start-up companies, many of them high-tech.

title: Sports of The Times; Valentine Still Seeks His Program
description: BOBBY VALENTINE says that he doesn't believe in turning points, but then he keeps ticking off some turning points of this season and he gets to six or eight without even mentioning John Franco's life-flashes-before-your-eyes strikeout last Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Making a Good Idea Her Own
description: HONEYMOONING on the beaches of Ibiza, an island off the southeastern coast of Spain, Dalia Almanza-Smith had what she calls an epiphany: the germ of an idea for a business that changed her life and helped to introduce postcards as a new form of advertising in America.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNGER, ESTELLE G.
description: UNGER-Estelle G. The members of the Brooklyn Museum of Art Community Committee are deeply saddened by the sudden death of Estelle G. Unger, a devoted member and dear friend. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. Celia Quinones, President Community Committee

title: INSIDE
description: Wage Increase Defeated

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAFIELD, CHARLES B.
description: DELAFIELD-Charles B. The North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System was deeply saddened by the passing of Charles B. Delafield, a long-time President of the former Community Hospital at Glen Cove. Mr. Delafield served our community with skill and compassion. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Saul B. Katz, Chairman Board of Trustess John S. T. Gallagher, Chief Executive Officer David R. Dantzker, MD., President North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANDA, RAJIV KRISHAN
description: NANDA-Rajiv Krishan. On September 18, 1998, beloved husband of Rema, father of Arjun Scott, son of Sudershan and Satyender and brother of Vikram and Sandip. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, September 25 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service at the funeral home 9:45AM Saturday September 26th. Contributions in Rajiv's memory may be made to the U.S. Committee for UNICEF, Tribute Card Program for Rajiv Nanda, 333 East 38th Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Boy, 6, and Family Robbed at Knifepoint
description: A man held a 6-year-old Bronx boy at knifepoint in Central Park on Sunday night as he robbed the boy's family of cash and jewelry before escaping, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, PEARL
description: FELDMAN-Pearl. Age 96. Formerly of Brooklyn, New York, and Santa Monica, California. Died on Sept. 20th, 1998 at Maine Medical Center in Portland, Maine, after suffering a heart attack. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Dorothy Schwartz (Elliott) of South Freeport, ME., the late Shirley Horowitz (the late Mike), the late Jerry (Helen Bartwink); cherished grandmother of Steven Horowitz (Debby), Shari Epstein (Norman), Joy Horowitz (Brock Walsh), Scott, Richard (Michelle), Peggy Horowitz (Alan Alhades), Sue Desimone (Wayne), Nina Schwartz and Jonathan (Liz) Schwartz; also 14 great grandchildren and aunt of Beatrice Schofield. She remains to all who knew her an inspiration and loving forcethe French toast maven, crochet fanatic & Dancing Doll celebrated in ''Tessie and Pearlie: a Granddaughter's Story'' by Joy Horowitz. A homemaker, she volunteered her secretarial, culinary and artisitic services to the Peninsula Hospital in Far Rockaway, Temple Beth-El in Manhattan Beach, Santa Monica Hospital, Crossroads School, the Early Years School and countless retirement homes in Santa Monica. Graveside service will be held on Thursday, September 24, at 2 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, Long Island.

title: WATSON PHARMACEUTICALS TO BUY U.S. RIGHTS TO 3 DRUGS
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the United States rights to three lines of birth control drugs produced by G. D. Searle & Company, the Monsanto Company's pharmaceutical unit, for $120 million in cash. It is buying the rights for Tri-Norinyl, Norinyl and Brevicon. Watson, based in Corona, Calif., said the purchase would expand its health care product offerings for women. Shares of Watson rose $1.5625, to $49.25. Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, rose $2.125, to $60.

title: 2 in a Wisconsin Race Put Limits on Coffers
description: With spending on most American political campaigns seemingly headed toward Pluto, the contest for United States senator in Wisconsin is remarkable for its restraint, including the almost quaint notion that most of the financial donors in a Wisconsin election should actually live in Wisconsin.

title: BASEBALL: Sports of The Times; Baseball Is 'Lucky' to Have Had McGwire and Sosa This Season
description: WHEN the baseball commissioner's office was in New York, the former commissioners, from Ford Frick to Fay Vincent, had lunch in their favorite fancy restaurants. But yesterday Allan H. (Bud) Selig, the new commissioner, drove over to where he has had lunch for more than three decades: Gilles drive-in with a neon ''Frozen Custard'' sign on the roof.

title: A Meltingly Tasty Soup From Butternut Squash
description: JUST how many squash soups can one city serve?

title: IRANIAN DISMISSES ALL HOPE FOR NOW OF POLITICAL THAW
description: President Mohammad Khatami of Iran said yesterday that Iran has no intention of opening an official political dialogue with the United States until Washington takes concrete steps to change its attitude toward his country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, PAUL RUNDIO
description: STEWART-Paul Rundio. On September 19, 1998. Beloved husband of Vivienne, loving father of Colin, Caitlin, Tamsyn, Campbell and Christopher, loving father-in-law of Robert and Grace and devoted grandfather of Jackson and Madeleine. His distinguished career in direct marketing included senior executive positions at Time Life Books, Time Life Music, Time Life Entertainment in Alexandria, VA, Warner Music Enterprises, in New York and founding partner of PKM Direct Marketing. Visitation, Wednesday, September 23, 6:009:00PM at Horn & Thomes Funeral Home, 83 E. Main Street, Pawling, NY. Funeral service, Thursday, September 24, at 11:00AM at Christ Church on Quaker Hill, 1 Church Road, Pawling, N.Y. Memorial contributions may be made to the Nature Conservancy, Nags Head Woods Preserve, 701 W. Ocean Acres Drive, Kill Devil Hills, NC 27948 or Paul R. Stewart Scholarship Fund C/O Key Bank, 3 West Main Street, Pawling, NY 12564.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, CHARLES S.
description: WINTER-Charles S. Died September 17, 1998. Survived by his loving wife, Esther Libbin, father Jackson Beck, brother Dorn Leslie, nieces and nephews. A kind, sweet and loving man. We will always miss you.

title: Eyes for the Mouse, Wheels for the Joystick
description: Two prominent Internet pioneers have founded a company to create a way of navigating the Internet with maps that portray the relationships between computers and information as three-dimensional space.

title: From Architectural Showman to Yale Dean
description: NOT so many years ago, Robert A. M. Stern, the architect, was peacefully reading behind the privet hedge of his modest East Hampton ranch house -- his architect friends refer to it as the ranchburger -- which Mr. Stern bought after his divorce, when he overheard a few people passing by his sign out front. ''My God, he doesn't really live here, does he?'' Mr. Stern heard someone say.

title: Big in Small Business, Straining to Grow
description: THERE is an old joke told by statistics professors about a fellow who has his feet in the oven and his head in the freezer: on average, he feels fine.

title: For Russian New York, A 'Suburb' Next Door; Many View Brighton Beach as the 'City,' And Manhattan Beach Is Now Home
description: Viktor Angurov lives on a leafy street in the affluent Brooklyn neighborhood of Manhattan Beach, about one mile from his mother's apartment in Brighton Beach. It is the same one-bedroom apartment they shared after arriving from Moscow in 1979 with two suitcases and $90.

title: No Chief Chosen Yet at Broken Hill
description: The chairman of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, Jerry Ellis, said today that he expected to appoint a chief executive soon to help guide the company, Australia's largest resources concern, through times ''that have never been tougher.''

title: Barclaycard to Cut 1,100 Jobs in 3 Years
description: Barclaycard, the credit card business of Barclays P.L.C., said yesterday that it would cut about a quarter of its staff and increase spending in technology as it strove to retain its market leadership in Britain.

title: Democrats Making a Case For Some Form of Censure
description: The White House and prominent Democrats say they have opened an aggressive behind-the-scenes campaign to save President Clinton from impeachment hearings by seeking to build support among politicians of both parties for the President to be harshly rebuked by Congress and perhaps pay a large fine.

title: N.F.L. NOTEBOOK
description: CHICAGO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTOCK, FRANCES K.
description: WEINSTOCK-Frances K., 103. On September 20, 1998. Beloved wife of the late George J., devoted mother of Blossom Landsman, Arthur Weinstock, his wife Betty, & the late Rita Weinstock. Loving grandmother of Peggy Kerner & Carol Landsman. Also survived by great granddaughters Erica and Julie. Nieces and nephews all of whom she loved and who loved her. A special woman of caring, concern, wisdom and generosity. Services on Wednesday, at 1:00 P.M., at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Want Some Million-Dollar Ideas? I Got a Million of 'Em
description: WHENEVER I look at my bank statement, I think of Ken Hakuta, a.k.a. Dr. Fad. Best known as the inventor of the Wacky Wall Walker, he made some $20 million from slime-covered plastic creatures that ooze down vertical surfaces. The beauty of it is that Mr. Hakuta didn't even come up with the idea: all he did was license the toy from Japan for a fraction of the amount he made. Now he's a millionaire and a prominent figure on the lecture and convention circuits. With one simple idea he achieved the American dream: money and fame.

title: Malaysia Unrest: 'We Are Prepared to Handle It'
description: Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad of Malaysia has led his country down an unorthodox road in his quest for economic recovery, shutting his country off from global currency markets. He also dismissed his anointed successor, Anwar Ibrahim, leading to a large-scale street demonstrations. Mr. Mahathir spoke with Thomas Fuller of the International Herald Tribune on Tuesday.

title: The Chef
description: I GREW up on a dairy farm in central New York, and the first cold snap still makes me yearn for the hearty, soulful foods of my childhood. My mom had a stick-to-your-ribs approach to cooking -- which was fine by me and my six brothers and sisters -- and her braised pork chops with mashed potatoes and cream gravy was one of our favorite fall meals.

title: Tiny Neighbor Gives South African Army Rude Surprise
description: South African troops rolled into this tiny mountainous kingdom early this morning to put a quick end to political turmoil that had brought the Government to a standstill. Instead, the invading force met surprisingly fierce resistance from Lesotho soldiers who are rebelling against the Government. They took to the hills and brought relentless fire on the South Africans.

title: Unsafe Supplements?
description: To the Editor:

title: Unsafe Supplements?
description: To the Editor:

title: Terence McEwen Dies at 69; Directed San Francisco Opera
description: Terence A. McEwen, a former executive with London Records, a general director of the San Francisco Opera during the 1980's and a witty frequent panelist on the ''Texaco Opera Quiz,'' the intermission feature of the Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts, died on Sept. 14 at his home in Honolulu. He was 69.

title: Rebuiding Houses of Worship
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Owner and Union Can't Agree on Saving Carrier : 'Everything Is Over,' as Philippine Airlines Shuts Down
description: Philippine Airlines, the oldest carrier in Asia, went out of business at midnight Wednesday after 11th-hour talks mediated by the government failed to resolve differences between the Philippines' richest man and its toughest labor union.

title: Seeing a Fund as Too Big to Fail, New York Fed Assists Its Bailout
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has helped organize the rescue of a large and prominent speculative fund, indicating that regulators recognize that the failure of such a fund would damage already fragile world markets.

title: Trenton Debates Requiring Guns That Sense Owners
description: Eight years after New Jersey enacted one of the nation's strictest bans on assault weapons, gun control advocates and the National Rifle Association have turned the State Legislature into a testing ground in the newest battle over gun control, the push for high-tech personalized handguns that are designed to fire only if the owner personally pulls the trigger.

title: With No. 110, Torre's Team Matches '27 Yanks
description: Miller Huggins, manager of the 1927 Yankees, weighed 140 pounds, small enough for Babe Ruth to dangle him from a moving train. Huggins had been an average player, an average hitter who relied on his speed. Joe Torre, manager of the 1998 Yankees, is thickly built, a former Gold Glove catcher and winner of a most valuable player award in 1971.

title: A Master Steeped in The Core Works
description: The nine Beethoven symphonies are colossal works of seminal importance to the classical repertory. No one worth paying attention to disputes this.

title: A Centrist Shifts to Left To Attract German Votes
description: The banner above his head read ''The New Center,'' but Gerhard Schrod er's oratory today was somewhat to the left of that as he lambasted tax-evading millionaires, praised solar energy and the welfare state, and vowed to attack growing economic inequality in Germany.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Quick Moral Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: Essay; Beyond Monica
description: Forget the Hot Stove League blather about extraconstitutional deals, of censures and fines, or of a quickie impeachment vote. And let's cut the hand-wringing about how awful all this is, too much for the children to take, etc.

title: Second Home of Fish From Dinosaur Age Is Found
description: The coelacanth, a very rare fish with a pedigree older than the dinosaurs, has delighted biologists by turning up in Indonesia. Two of these ugly but fascinating fish have been discovered nearly 6,000 miles from the coast of southern Africa, the only place in the world where coelacanths had hitherto been found.

title: Lagardere Profit Increases 17.5%
description: Lagardere S.C.A., a maker of missiles and publisher of Elle magazine, said today that first-half net rose 17.5 percent, helped by military export contracts and strong sales of the Espace mini-van it builds with Renault.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Questions on Coca-Cola in Market Turmoil Abroad
description: Coca-Cola Company executives have summoned Wall Street analysts for a hastily scheduled meeting tomorrow morning in New York, suggesting that the leading soft-drink company is about to deliver ominous news about earnings.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'Brother's Keeper'

title: Splinter Group Seeking More Influence on Tour
description: A new generation of professional golfers, saying that it wants greater accountability from the PGA Tour, has created a players association in order to reassert direction over its own tour.

title: Defying Warnings, Serbs Press Attacks on Kosovo Albanians
description: Scoffing at warnings by the West that force might be used to end the fighting in Kosovo, the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, pressed ahead with a tank and artillery offensive today that chased about 10,000 ethnic Albanian civilians into the hills and left many of their homes on fire.

title: MacLean Salutes Some Old Friends by Scoring on Them
description: For a game with just one goal, the appropriate player scored it.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: GREENSPAN HELPS MARK. Germany's currency rose against the dollar after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, hinted at lower U.S. interest rates. In New York, the dollar settled at 1.6783 marks, down from 1.6824.

title: A Cornucopia of Native Foie Gras; Partners' Efforts Produce Menu Delicacy in Abundance
description: Not long ago, a sumptuous slice of fresh foie gras, cut from the fat-rich liver of a force-fed duck or goose, was a rarity on American menus. Even as French restaurants flourished in the 1980's, desperate chefs usually had to settle for canned pates. Those willing to defy Federal restrictions on imports of raw poultry even had the delicacy smuggled from France inside fish bellies.

title: FIRST SECURITY TO BUY VAN KASPER FOR $100 MILLION
description: The First Security Corporation, a bank holding company with operations across the West, agreed yesterday to acquire Van Kasper & Company, the closely held brokerage and investment-banking firm in San Francisco, for $100 million. First Security, based in Salt Lake City, has assets of $849.2 million and offers mortgage, insurance, leasing, investment management and securities brokerage services. It will acquire all of the diluted shares of Van Kasper, paying $18 to $22 a Van Kasper share, under a floating exchange ratio. If the company meets certain earnings targets, First Security will pay $10 million in cash over four years to key Van Kasper employees and shareholders.

title: Clinton Crosscurrents
description: The chaotic events in Washington have finally resolved themselves into two main debates -- one having to do with President Clinton's political future and the other with Kenneth Starr's legal competence and fairness.

title: Our Towns; A Tradition Of Firefighting Put to the Test
description: THE grizzled men rocking on the porch of the Firemen's Home here can pinpoint the location of a blaze from the sequence of blasts on the air horn that summons volunteer firefighters.

title: Organic Dog Food
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennelly Criticizes State's Role in Child's Death
description: The Democratic candidate for governor, Barbara B. Kennelly, criticized Gov. John G. Rowland and his administration today for failing to prevent the death of a child under state supervision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEMINGWAY, DAVID S.
description: HEMINGWAY-David S., 84. Of Riverside, CT on September 17, 1998. Husband of the late Lucy Truesdale Hemingway; son of the late Roy Willet and Mary Booth Hemingway; father of D. Stuart, Jr. (Riverside, Conn), Margaret Hemingway (Washington D.C.), Timothy Truesdale Hemingway (Holland, MI), Barbara Hemingway (Arlington, VA), and Samuel Scott Hemingway (Seattle, WA); brother of Booth Hemingway (Exeter, NH), Harvey W. Hemingway (Woodstock, GA), and Margaret H. Harrington (Rye, NH); also survived by four grandchildren. Graduate of Hotchkiss School in 1932 and Princeton University in 1936. Memorial service to be held at later date. Contributions may be made to Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT, 06830.

title: Portable Music Player Uses No Tape or Disk -- Just RAM
description: A popular way to buy, trade and download music on the Internet may now become even more popular. The Rio PMP 300, created by Diamond Multimedia Systems of San Jose, Calif., is a portable music player that is about the size of a pager and does a lot more than beep. A departure from Walkman-like music players that use cassette tapes, compact disks or mini-disks, the Rio can store up to 60 minutes of digital-quality music directly into its 32 megabytes of memory. Because it can handle only music that is compressed in the MP3 format -- used to record and play music distributed on the Internet -- the Rio comes with software that also permits users to convert music on CD's into the MP3 format.

title: Medicine's Frontier: Training Doctors to Treat the Elderly
description: Dr. Michael Westerman, 29, a resident in internal medicine at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center, was catching up with one of his patients, 72-year-old John Foltz. Mr. Foltz, who has emphysema and heart disease, told the doctor he had not had a cigarette in a month and was breathing better, though climbing the stairs to his apartment was still a trial.

title: A Street-Smart 'Godot' In a Cultural Wasteland
description: If ever a pair of Beckett clowns were made for each other, it would have to be the Vladimir and Estragon who run amok in Joy Zinoman's hip new staging of ''Waiting for Godot.''

title: Swing Vote in East Worries Germans
description: Karl Roost listened today as Chancellor Helmut Kohl denounced the evils of the old East German Government, and by the end of the speech his blood was boiling.

title: LIBRARY/LEARNING SPANISH; An Emphasis On Practice
description: SELF-STUDY SPANISH(Syracuse Language Systems; $79; Windows 95.)

title: A Global Gag Rule on Abortion
description: Republicans are inviting President Clinton's vetoes by attaching odious gag rules on international family-planning groups to various bills. For his part, the embattled Mr. Clinton would probably welcome the opportunity to remind most Americans that he stands closer to their views on reproductive rights than do his political opponents.

title: Acquisitions Set By a Pair of Agencies
description: Two acquisitions were made yesterday for undisclosed terms.

title: A Hands-On Definition Of, Well, an Autodidact
description: ROADSTER

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Environmentalists Vow To Fight Referendum
description: A coalition of environmental groups pledged yesterday to oppose passage of a referendum asking taxpayers to bail out counties for debts incurred in the building of incinerators because, the coalition said, location of the trash burners in low-income neighborhoods amounts to environmental racism.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH TELLS OF STOCK SPLIT AND NEW CHAIRMAN
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, encouraged by an expected 20 percent jump in earnings for 1998, said that it would split its stock 2 for 1. In addition, the giant pharmaceutical company, which is based in Madison, N.J., named Richard Jay Kogan its chairman, replacing Robert P. Luciano, who is retiring. Mr. Kogan will maintain his position as chief executive but resign as president. Raul E. Cesan will become president and chief operating officer. Analysts have put the company's 1998 earnings at $2.34 a diluted share, up from $1.95 last year. Shares of Schering-Plough rose $3.4375, to $105.0625.

title: LIBRARY/LEARNING SPANISH; Easy Tutor At Low Cost
description: SWIFT MULTIMEDIA SPANISH(The Cosmi Corporation; $14.95; Windows 95.)

title: The Purple Moon Store
description: Purple Moon, the software company whose ''friendship adventures'' cater to pre-teen-age girls, is getting ready to entice budding shoppers into getting adventurous with their weekly allowance.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'Buddy Faro'

title: LIBRARY/LEARNING SPANISH; Sophisticated but Easy to Use
description: LEARN TO SPEAK SPANISH, VERSION 7.0(The Learning Company; $79.95; Windows 95 and Macintosh.)

title: Covering the Territory; On the Web, Titans Battle for Turf
description: WHILE there are thousands of real estate sites on the Internet, a battle appears to be shaping up between two titans: Home Advisor, run by Microsoft, the mogul of cyberspace, and Realtor.com, which is operated by Real Select for the National Association of Realtors and is the leader in home listings on the Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, MURRAY, 80, AND FLORENCE, 79
description: WHITE-Murray, 80, and Florence, 79, also known in the theater as Wyman and White, and Murray, a successful C.L.U. and agency director for several insurance companies, are survived by their three children, four grandchildren, one great-grandson, and Murray's three brothers. Funeral services will be held at the Levitt-Weinstein Memorial Chapel, Tamarac, FL., at 11 A.M., Sunday, September 27.

title: San Giovanni Rotondo Journal; Saint or No, an Old-Time Monk Mesmerizes Italy
description: In 1959 a celebrated Capuchin monk and mystic named Padre Pio was shown the new brick church that was added to the monastery to accommodate his many followers. ''What are you building, a matchbox?'' he told his fellow monks. ''Make it bigger.''

title: This Time, McGwire Can Offer No Reply
description: An unassuming shuttle bus driver poked his head into the hotel lobby this afternoon and quickly morphed into a town crier: Sosa's got two, Sosa's got two.

title: Intel Gives $6 Million To Whitney for a Show
description: The Intel Corporation has contributed $6 million to the Whitney Museum of American Art to stage its mammoth overview of 20th century art and culture, which is scheduled to open next April.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Forgetting Forgiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: ST. LOUIS

title: 3 Killed as a Commuter Van Crashes on I-80
description: A commuter van carrying nine workers to a cosmetics-packaging company rolled over several times, killing the driver and two passengers and injuring the other six, in busy rush hour traffic this morning on Interstate 80, apparently after a tire blew out.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: A Weed by Any Other Name

title: Land Lines for Data
description: To the Editor:

title: A Timely, Timeless Lesson in Repentance
description: FEW of the nation's rabbis will be able to resist the allusive New Year's gift President Clinton offered to them this month. Every fall, as they stand before overflowing congregations on Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur, most pulpit rabbis struggle to devise a new variation on the theme of repentance, the nature of sin, the snare of old habits. The perils of annual repetition are well known to worshipers, but this year, rabbis can simply clip their object lesson from the newspapers.

title: An Agreement To Increase Special Visas
description: The White House and Congressional leaders agreed today on legislation to increase the number of foreign workers who can get visas allowing them to fill high-tech jobs in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANDA, RAJIV KRISHAN
description: NANDA-Rajiv Krishan. On September 18, 1998, beloved husband of Rema, father of Arjun Scott, son of Sudershan and Satyender and brother of Vikram and Sandip. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, September 25 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service at the funeral home 9:45 AM, Saturday, September 26th. Contributions in Rajiv's memory may be made to the U.S. Committee for UNICEF, Tribute Card Program for Rajiv Nanda, 333 East 38th Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Scholarships Provide Laptops Instead of Money
description: A NEW scholarship program at a California state college is one of the first in the nation to give students computers instead of financial aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMP, ALIDA MILLIKEN
description: CAMP-Alida Milliken. The Members of the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd. are profoundly saddened by the loss of Alida Milliken Camp, our Honorary Chairman. Her spirit, indefatigable energy, and love of life and music will be sorely missed by all of us. We send our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Emily K. Rafferty, President and the Board of Directors Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd.

title: A new public service campaign from the Ad Council will ask people to 'Give a kid a hand.'
description: THE Ad Council is joining forces with the International Advertising Association to distribute a new public service campaign from the international group to encourage adults to do volunteer work with children.

title: Historic Houses On the Hudson
description: STUYVESANT LANDING is where Henry Hudson turned back in 1609, seeing no future in the Hudson River as a great passage to the Pacific. But for the town of Stuyvesant, nearby in Columbia County, N.Y., three centuries of growth lay ahead.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: First Novel Draws A Pre-emptive Jab

title: Web Shopping? Not for the Picky
description: ON days when life is under control in our household, either my husband or I will take the baby to shop at a friendly family-owned grocery. We all benefit from such leisurely outings. Clementine always gets a cookie (iced) from the owner, who also remembers to ask us how our older daughters are liking school so far this year. We bask in the amazing luxury of checkout clerks who cheerfully insist on bagging all the groceries.

title: World Trade Center May Go on Market
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to vote today to put the World Trade Center, its flagship property and the largest office complex in the country, on the market. Gov. George E. Pataki of New York said he was confident that the plan, under which developers would bid for a 99-year lease on the vast complex, would be adopted.

title: Rapper Takes the Eclectic Road
description: A photograph in the CD booklet for ''Whitey Ford Sings the Blues,'' the new CD by Everlast, pictures the rapper-musician striding down some train tracks, an acoustic guitar slung over one shoulder and a boombox in his other hand. He did that image one better at Coney Island High on Tuesday night, surrounding himself with a band that included a hip-hop DJ, a Moog keyboardist, a stand-up bassist, a drummer and a guitarist who played both standard electric and pedal steel.

title: Honeycombs in Flight: Office of Tomorrow?
description: ANYONE who works in a cubicle knows that its shroudlike isolation bears no resemblance to real privacy. But it may come as a surprise that the people who design today's office systems agree that cubicles are long overdue for a makeover.

title: PAKISTAN PLEDGES A-BOMB TEST BAN IF SANCTIONS END
description: Pakistan's Prime Minister said today that he would sign a treaty banning nuclear testing within the next year, putting the onus on India to follow suit or be left with North Korea as the only nations refusing to curb their nuclear weapons.

title: James C. Dudley, 77, Investment Adviser
description: James Chittenden Dudley, an investor and geologist who was also active in education, died Sept. 16 in Danbury Hospital in Danbury, Conn. He was 77 and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: Security Council Tells Serbs To Stop Kosovo Offensive
description: The Security Council sent a warning to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia today to stop Serbian attacks on civilians in the ethnically Albanian Kosovo region or face international intervention.

title: Lockout Hits Preseason
description: The National Basketball Association will announce today the indefinite postponement of training camps and the cancellation of the first week of the preseason, a league official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOTTEL, BERTHA
description: MOTTEL-Bertha. 8 years, still missing you. Love, Ger

title: Musical Damage In Starr Report
description: This month contemporary pop music received two major setbacks. First came the MTV Video Music Awards, which collected some of the biggest singers of the moment to illuminate a very derivative, infertile period in music. Then came the Starr report, which may have done even more musical damage, helping to prove that the generation gap in musical taste is disappearing.

title: Bus Drivers Slash Each Other Over Picking Up Passengers
description: The sight of two city buses pulling up to the first stop on the B17 line in Brooklyn on Tuesday evening should have raised riders' hopes for a quick trip along their route.

title: Bertelsmann Income Rose 9.8% in 1998
description: Bertelsmann A.G., the world's third-largest media company, said yesterday that fiscal year 1998 net income rose 9.8 percent as strong United States sales more than offset lagging profit at its European book clubs.

title: 72 Schools Adopt Plan To Improve Performance
description: In what was viewed as a surprising show of enthusiasm for the latest effort to improve education in New Jersey's 28 poorest school systems, the state said yesterday that 72 schools are implementing so-called whole school reform this year, far more than anticipated.

title: A Familiar Terror Clothed in New Software
description: SENTINEL RETURNS is a game about surveillance. Based on a 1985 strategy game for eight-bit microcomputers like the Spectrum, the Amiga and the Atari ST, Sentinel retains the terrifying elegance of the original. Imagine playing king of the hill on a lunar landscape under panoptic surveillance. Starting at the lowest point on a honeycomb of rocks and cliffs, the player must reach the summit and destroy the Sentinel, who turns slowly, like a malevolent lighthouse at the pinnacle, neutralizing any threat in his field of vision.

title: Texaco Gets Kazakh Field
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it had taken a 65 percent stake in the undeveloped north Buzachi oilfield in western Kazakhstan from the state-owned Saudi Arabian oil company, the Nimir Petroleum Company, which will keep the remaining 35 percent stake in the field. The oilfield has an estimated 1 billion to 1.5 billion barrels of crude oil. Texaco said it would test the field to see if it was commercially viable and that production could start within two to four years. The company said the terms of the agreement between itself and Nimir remained confidential.

title: Britain Arrests 7 Suspected Of Links To Bin Laden
description: The British police arrested seven people today in a coordinated raid apparently aimed at associates of Osama bin Laden, the exiled Saudi financier accused of carrying out the bombings of the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRODIN, ADAM J.
description: GRODIN-Adam J. On September 21, 1998 of Plandome, New York. Beloved husband of Yvonne. Dear father of Mary Jane Freeland and the late John. Loving grandfather of 5. Funeral Mass Thursday at St. Mary's RC Church at 9:45AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD., Brampton, Ontario, a telecommunication provider, said it had received a $155 million network expansion contract from Sunday, a Hong Kong mobile-phone network operator.

title: Displays of Crafts, Art and Furniture
description: Craft Exhibitions

title: Two Executives Switch Agencies
description: Two executives who headed the branding unit at Ogilvy & Mather in New York have left that agency to form another branding unit at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications in New York, part of MacManus Group.

title: Alou, the Prophet, Says Cubs Have Gone Clank
description: The Milwaukee Brewers had just wiped out more than half of the Chicago Cubs' 7-0 lead and had runners at first and second with only one out. Felipe Alou, the Montreal Expos' manager, sat in the visiting manager's office at Shea Stadium and didn't take his eyes off the small television set.

title: Visit by Gore Buoys Spirits of Michigan Democrats
description: Some Democrats around the country worry that President Clinton's problems could affect the midterm elections, but Michigan Democrats have an extra concern: Geoffrey Fieger, their party's nominee for governor, whose background and language have alienated many voters.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; 'Crime' of Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUSRIN, CECELIA
description: PUSRIN-Cecelia. Widow of Aaron Pusrin. Beloved sister and best friend of Elsie Young. Dear aunt, great aunt and great great aunt. Passed away August 26, 1998 and services held August 30, 1998.

title: When Clues in the Bidding Rescue a Shaky Contract
description: The Daily Bulletins published at National Championships were enlivened for many years by the contributions of Ron Andersen. Under the pseudonym The Hog, a character with a vast appetite for food and life, he offered entertaining predictions of the results of major matches about to be played. Since his death, his place has been taken by The Bull, a pseudonym for Chris Compton of Austin, Tex.

title: Bayer to Pay $96.6 Million For Stake in Millennium
description: Bayer A.G., the German drug and chemical company, said yesterday that it would pay $96.6 million to buy a 14 percent equity stake in Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc., a genomics company in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Innovation in Renovation: A Manager in Your Court
description: AS the sun sneaked down through a cobwebby skylight onto centuries-old mahogany and rosewood planks in an antiques warehouse in Chelsea, Randy Polumbo pulled out one dusty board after another, hefting a couple of them onto a table and wetting them down with alcohol to see their true color.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Impeachment Muddle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDMONDS, EDWARD DANA
description: EDMONDS - Edward Dana. Passed away untimely on Sept. 20. A resident of Boca Raton, Florida, Edward was a Lt. (j.g.) in the U.S. Navy having retired from the service after an automobile accident in 1982. A graduate of the University of South Carolina, Edward was an active participant in the Paralyzed Veterans of America, and an avid supporter of continuing spinal chord research everywhere. His father L. Scott Edmonds, Captain U.S. Navy (Ret.) of Jacksonville, Florida, died four years ago. Edward is survived by his mother, Mary Elizabeth Edmonds, his brother Robert Scott Edmonds, and innumerable saddened friends. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Bart's Episcopal Church, 50th and Park Avenue on Friday, September 25 at 2PM. Contributions may be made in his name to the Miami Project to Cure Paralysis, P.O. Box 016960 (R. 48), Miami, Florida 33101.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANBERY, E. CARLETON
description: GRANBERY-E. Carleton. Of Old Quarry Road, Guilford, Conn. Died September 22, 1998 at his home. Husband of Diana Allyn Granbery. Father of Carleton A. Granbery of Stony Creek, CT, Joya G. Llano of Newport, RI, & Pamela Granbery of Borrego Springs, CA, brother of John Granbery of Salisbury, CT. Predeceased by two sisters, Elise G. Becket and Mary W. Granbery. Funeral service Saturday, 2PM, at Christ Episcopal Church, Park Street, Guilford, Connecticut. Contributions in memory of Mr. Granbery may be made to the National Academy, 1083 5th Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10128. Information contact Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church Street, Guilford, CT.

title: Albright and Netanyahu Report Progress on Stalled Peace Talks
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel reported some progress here today toward ending the stalemate in peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians. But they agreed that a settlement was still not imminent.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; A Moralistic Assault
description: To the Editor:

title: Home Prices Hit A Snag
description: PEGGY FITZPATRICK was asking $899,000 for her 2,500-square-foot loft at the corner of Broadway and Washington Place. Since she had just listed it in mid-August, she wouldn't -- in an ordinary season -- be thinking of marking it down yet.

title: Sports of The Times; Brewers Do Part in Sosa's Season
description: THERE was a time when the familiar slogan in this bratwurst burg bragged about ''the beer that made Milwaukee famous.'' But in baseball's year of the Great Home Run Race, Milwaukee is now known for the pitching staff that made Sammy Sosa famous.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Poor Nixon Comparison
description: To the Editor:

title: China Plans to Spend $1 Trillion on Big Public Projects
description: Chinese leaders expect to weather the Asian economic crisis by spending so much money on public works that they reverse slowing growth, deter unemployment and reverse the fall in exports, a senior official said today.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'Two of a Kind'

title: Terms Not Yet Set for Release of Gotti's Son
description: As his imprisoned father braced for throat cancer surgery, John A. Gotti and his lawyers struggled today to cobble together an agreement with the United States Attorney's office over restrictions on his freedom that would permit his release on bail.

title: LIBRARY/LEARNING SPANISH; Spanish Classes Where You're in Control
description: FOR English speakers, Spanish is among the easiest foreign languages to learn. But can a software program alone help you achieve fluency? The answer depends not just on the quality of the program, the amount of time you spend on it or your natural affinity for the language. It also has to do with the kind of student you are.

title: Kelly Kip Bringing Streak Into a Sprinting Showdown
description: New York's countdown to the Breeders' Cup passes another milestone Saturday when a full field of sprinters is expected to compete in the $250,000 Vosburgh, which will serve as the final dress rehearsal for several of the country's best sprinters aiming for the $1 million Breeders' Cup Sprint six weeks later.

title: Malaysia Police Question Wife of Jailed Dissident
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Malaysian police Wednesday questioned the wife of the ousted deputy prime minister and tightened restrictions on the country's month-old opposition movement, banning further political rallies.

title: Court Backs The Pentagon On Gay Rights
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the military's longstanding ban on homosexual activity and its more recent ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy, saying that the rules do not violate any constitutional rights because of the special circumstances of the military.

title: Air France-American Express Card Plans
description: Air France and the American Express Company said today that they planned to offer a co-branded charge card aimed at strengthening customer loyalty at the airline and allowing the United States company to expand its network in the world's biggest tourist destination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEPERT FRIEDMAN, HEDDY
description: LOEPERT FRIEDMAN-Heddy. On Sept. 22, in her 102nd year. Mother of Helga Rosenberger (Hugo), Margit Simon (Peter C.). Grandmother of Lynn Edelstein, Peter C. Simon Jr. Great-grandmother of Mark, Eric, Gary and Julie. Great-great grandmother of five. Funeral services in Charlotte, North Carolina.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Sometimes doctors will call me, embarrassed, late at night to ask for help with their own mothers.''

title: DELL, AT&T AND OTHERS OFFER INTERNET PACKAGE
description: The Dell Computer Corporation teamed with the AT&T Corporation, Excite Inc. and SBC Communications Inc. yesterday to offer a package of Internet hookups intended to attract the growing number of people who buy personal computers mostly to get on line. Terms were not disclosed. Buyers of Dell computers will be offered Internet service through AT&T and then will be taken directly to an Excite site on the Web. The move by Dell, the No. 1 direct seller of PC's, follows similar offerings from the Compaq Computer Corporation and Gateway Inc. SBC Communications said that starting early next year it would offer Dell users faster A.D.S.L. technology, which speeds the delivery of Internet content over regular phone lines.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR FALLS 1.3 PERCENT. Fears of global economic weakness hurt prices, blunting a rally the day before. The October contract fell 0.09 cent, to 7.10 cents a pound. Raw sugar prices have fallen 35 percent in the last year.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Fiction vs. Journalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Chet Hoff, 107, Oldest Former Major Leaguer
description: Chet Hoff, who was born a decade before the American League was founded and pitched for the Yankees when they were known as the Highlanders, died last Thursday at a nursing home in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 107 and had lived longer than anyone else who ever played major league baseball.

title: New $20 Bill Going Public
description: The redesigned $20 bill easier to read and harder to counterfeit -- goes into circulation on Thursday. The new bill has security features intended to discourage counterfeiting, including a larger portrait of Andrew Jackson, the seventh president, moved off-center to leave more space for a watermark; a security thread that glows green when exposed to ultraviolet light, and color-shifting ink. The new note will be phased into circulation over several years.

title: INSIDE
description: Changing Bankruptcy

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Voices of Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL 4.0 (and Lots of It) All on CD-ROM
description: America Online, the world's largest Internet and on-line service provider, wants to get its software into the computers of as many consumers as possible, and in trying to do so it has sometimes been accused of carpet-bombing the country with millions of 3.5-inch diskettes. No longer.

title: On Bad Day for Cubs, Sosa Ties McGwire at 65
description: The summer of the home run headed toward a final glorious chapter today after Sammy Sosa hit home runs No. 64 and No. 65 against the Milwaukee Brewers and once again tied Mark McGwire in a battle that may go down to the last swing.

title: DEAN FOODS' EARNINGS OFF 5.7% ON HIGHER INTEREST COSTS
description: The Dean Foods Company of Franklin Park, Ill., said its fiscal first-quarter earnings fell 5.7 percent as interest expense more than doubled. Dean, which makes Milk Chug and other dairy products, said profit from continuing operations fell to $22.9 million, or 56 cents a diluted share, from $24.3 million, or 59 cents, a year earlier. That still beat analysts' 55-cent average estimate. The company's interest costs rose because of its acquisition in the last year of 12 dairy companies, which increased revenue by about a third, to $825.1 million from $619.9 million. The costs of integrating the acquired companies also reduced profit, the company said. Its shares rose $2.50, to $45.8125.

title: Legal Gamesmanship May Take Toll
description: In the Watergate era, the misdeeds of lawyers provoked a national discussion about whether ''legal ethics'' was an oxymoron.

title: V.A. Coopersmith, An Entrepreneur Of Apparel, 51
description: Victor A. Coopersmith, a fashion entrepreneur who in July closed the company that made women's wool suits and other clothes designed by his wife, Andrea Jovine, drowned Sept. 9 while swimming in Lake Powell near Page, Ariz., the United States Park Service said. He was 51.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Meeting Fails to Reach a Compromise on Disarming the I.R.A.
description: Prime Minister Bertie Ahern of Ireland and Mo Mowlam, the highest British official in Northern Ireland, tried but failed today to devise a compromise in the growing dispute over disarming the Irish Republican Army.

title: Farrior Is Inching Closer To Return After Injury
description: The moment finally came today when James Farrior could return to football -- but in a limited way. He started football-related drills but will not practice.

title: Soccer Fans Find New Ways To Root for Faraway Favorites
description: ONE of the first purchases Jim McGinn's father made after the family moved from Glasgow to New York in 1956 was a shortwave radio.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Violations of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: A Life's Warp and Weft
description: JACK LENOR LARSEN was ready for his close-up.

title: Clinton's Letters to 'Andy'
description: While working at the White House, Monica S. Lewinsky made copies of two letters written by President Clinton -- one to a Congressman, the other to a military official -- and sent them to a former boyfriend as a joke, the boyfriend said today.

title: Upper Madison Is Suddenly Homey
description: IN retailing, the young, the trendy and the new have tended to go downtown, to TriBeCa, SoHo and Chelsea. So, it's nice to see new life appearing this season on Madison Avenue, especially that stretch between 72d and 86th Streets.

title: Land Lines for Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp's Merger Approved by Fed
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday approved the merger of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc., a combination that would create the world's largest financial services company, subject to the divestiture of some key insurance activities within five years.

title: Letter to Judiciary Panel From Starr's Deputy
description: Following is the letter sent on Tuesday to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, and Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, the committee's ranking Democrat, from Robert J. Bittman, the deputy Whitewater independent counsel. The letter, released by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater counsel, was in response to one to the panel on Tuesday from President Clinton's lawyers complaining about what they said were omissions in Mr. Starr's report to Congress.

title: Dress Rehearsals for the Playoff Rotation
description: Joe Torre has not officially unveiled his rotation for the division playoff series that starts Tuesday. But the final dress rehearsals in the next few days give deep insight into what the Yankees' manager is thinking.

title: Our Lost Best Chance
description: I spent the day The Videotape was released inside the bubble of New York University Law School's symposium on globalization. And a very pleasant bubble it was, with the First Lady and scholars and bankers and United Nations officials earnestly, even a bit piously, mapping a ''third way'' between laissez-faire capitalism and the welfare state.

title: Hamed Opens Up With Pair Of Jabs
description: Naseem means gentle breeze in Arabic, but Prince Naseem Hamed blew through New York yesterday with all the sound and fury of a hurricane. In several hours at a news conference in midtown Manhattan, the bombastic World Boxing Organization featherweight champion managed to demean Wayne McCullough, his opponent for an Oct. 31 bout in Atlantic City; proclaim himself a legend in the making, and paint his trainer, Brendan Ingle, as a traitor.

title: Sports of The Times; Keeping One Eye On the TV
description: LATE in the afternoon, long before a spare outfielder named Brant Brown made a bid to initial Bill Buckner's legacy, Al Leiter didn't see the point in wasting time with the Cubs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTIT, JUSTIN
description: PETTIT-Justin. Beloved son of Bruce and Cathy, grandson of Joseph and Ruth Sheldon, nephew of Jay and Randy Raubvogel, Craig & Mariko Sheldon. Services 9:45 A.M. Friday at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Destroyed German Synagogues Return to Life on a Web Page
description: HISTORY repeats itself. Haunted by that prophecy, Marc Grellert, a professor at Darmstadt Technical University in Germany, started a project that is bringing back to virtual life German synagogues that were destroyed during World War II.

title: Carnegie Starts Season by Celebrating Gershwin
description: We don't often think of George Gershwin as revolutionary or prophet. There has always been enough in the Schubertian grace of the songs, the fascinating rhythm and the ambiguous harmonies to keep us happy. Yet Gershwin's ability to disrupt the boundaries between high and low culture may end up as his most important gift to us.

title: G.O.P. Resists Speedy Action On President
description: With Speaker Newt Gingrich brushing aside talk of a deal with President Clinton on a censure, Democrats today called for a quick resolution of House impeachment proceedings while Republicans held out for a slow and deliberate investigation.

title: Brazil's Leader Calls for Reforms, Heartening Investors
description: In a move to counter international uncertainty about his Government's answer to growing deficits, the Brazilian President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, opened the door today to raising taxes if he is re-elected, and vowed to push through congressional votes on restructuring social security and the Civil Service.

title: Fed Chairman Renews Hopes For a Rate Cut
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested today that the central bank would seriously consider cutting interest rates next week because of the deepening world financial crisis.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Suggests Fed May Cut Rates

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, REYNOLD
description: BENNETT-Reynold, of New York City. He died while on vacation in Paris, at age 80, on July 29, 1998. Survived by loving wife Cynthia Bennett, as well as by Leigh and Reynold Kane Bennett, both children from a previous marriage. Also survived by sister Marjorie Bennett and niece Colby Bennett. After receiving his degree from Harvard in 1940, he served as an army captain in the Pacific Theatre during World War II. He earned his LLB from Georgetown Law School in 1948 and was awarded a diploma in international law in 1949 from Cambridge University, England. He was vice president for public relations of the National Association of Manufacturers (NAM) for many years, and for work he did on its behalf, he received the Silver Anvil Award for Excellence in International Relations from the Public Relations Society of America. For ten years he served as in-house counsel for Mitsubishi Trust. He also edited a book on futurism called ''Living Tomorrow Today''. He is interred at the Crematorium Park, Cambridge, England. Memorial services will be held Thursday, October 1 at 6PM at The Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street, New York City.

title: Identity Evolution: The Mutant Logo
description: CORPORATE logos are supposed to be universal and unchanging, their color, size and placement spelled out in corporate-image policy books. From I.B.M. to Federal Express, the power to imprint everything from a headquarters building to business cards has been a sign of efficiency, implying a power and dependability customers could trust.

title: MCDONALD'S EXPECTS 13% TO 14% RISE IN SALES ABROAD
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it expected third-quarter sales outside the United States to rise 13 percent to 14 percent before adjusting for the strong dollar. That kind of growth, even in the face of economic instability in some regions, would exceed most analysts' expectations. The international outlook follows promises last month by McDonald's new chief executive, Jack Greenberg, that per-share earnings would continue to rise 10 percent to 15 percent annually for the next five years. McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., has more than 23,500 fast-food restaurants in 113 countries. Its shares closed unchanged at $56.50 in trading of 3 million.

title: Lazard Is Said To Settle Suit On Bond Sales
description: Lazard Freres & Company has agreed to settle accusations that in the early 1990's, the brokerage firm grossly overcharged a municipal agency in Los Angeles in a bond transaction, attorneys close to the case said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLUSS, HELENE
description: FLUSS - Helene. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Helene Fluss. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: The Lure of the Underground
description: THE lure of secret and mysterious underground places has always had a hold on some people. For all the on-line Indiana Joneses out there, the Web offers plenty of places, from ancient to modern, to poke around in without getting too grimy or chased by angry guards.

title: How to Crack The File Code
description: Q. Can you tell me what some of those three-letter abbreviations mean on the end of file names in Windows? I would be less afraid of the system if I knew what some of these cryptic things meant.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Turning Their Backs
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Testimony for Sale (Real Cheap) on DVD
description: If you are one of the dozens of Americans who cannot get enough of the Clinton-Lewinsky saga, a California company called Netflix has just the thing for you: President Clinton's four-hour grand-jury testimony is now available on a DVD disk.

title: Economic Scene; As Placebo Or Real Cure, Fed Rate Cut Seems Closer
description: Everybody seems to want the Federal Reserve policy makers to cut interest rates when they meet Tuesday. And why not? With financial chaos sweeping through Asia, Russia and now Latin America, a rate cut would seem a smart inoculation against recession for the domestic economy. That is certainly the view of the Business Roundtable, a group of corporate leaders, as it vigorously lobbies for the Fed to cut the cost of borrowing for American businesses. Lower rates would also help individual debtors and foreign countries saddled with loans that must be repaid in dollars.

title: To a Southerner, a Belle and a Butterfly Are Different
description: Witnessing Andre Previn and Colin Graham struggle with the Southern mind on Saturday night at the San Francisco Opera was like getting transmissions from some distant moon exploration. Mr. Previn was the composer for a brand new operatic setting of ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' Tennessee Williams's notorious take on New Orleans life. Mr. Graham was the director.

title: NEWS WATCH; Even Smaller Notebooks Coming to Market
description: Notebook computers are getting even smaller, by Jove. On Oct. 12, at the annual Microsoft Professional Developer Conference, at least eight personal computer makers are planning to exhibit their new ''Jupiter-class'' mini-notebook computers. Jupiter is the code name for Windows CE 3.0, the latest version of the consumer electronics operating system that Microsoft is to introduce that day. It is also the generic term for the new generation of portables that are smaller than conventional subnotebook computers but larger than the palm-size computers like the 3COM Corporation's popular Palm Pilot III.

title: Artest Has Surgery On His Left Thumb
description: Ron Artest, St. John's sophomore power forward, underwent minor surgery yesterday to repair the torn ulnar collateral ligament in his left thumb. Artest, who shoots right-handed, is expected to be ready for the season opener Nov. 16 against North Carolina-Asheville in the Chase Preseason National Invitation Tournament.

title: MILLIPORE SAYS ELECTRONICS SLUMP WILL RESULT IN A LOSS
description: The Millipore Corporation, the maker of filters used to purify liquids and gases, said it would report a third-quarter loss on Oct. 15 because of weak demand from its electronics industry customers and the strong United States dollar. The company, based in Bedford, Mass., said it expected a loss of 7 to 12 cents a share before charges. Analysts expected Millipore to earn 12 cents a share. Shares of Millipore rose $1.9375, to $20.75. Millipore, which generated about $759 million last year on sales of products such as purification systems used in making computer chips, said a worldwide slump in the semiconductor market accounted for most of the expected shortfall.

title: Judge Orders Nassau Coliseum Inspection
description: A state judge today ordered a team of engineers to conduct an expedited safety inspection of Nassau Coliseum, where the Islanders are scheduled to play their opening exhibition game Friday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUM, MARVIN
description: BLUM - Marvin. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, and extends condolences to the entire family. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: Dole Is Busy Taking Aim At President
description: Bob Dole takes care to assure audiences that he is not on ''an 'I told you so' tour.'' But there is at least a whiff of vindication in the air.

title: McCall Says Pension Fund Is to Invest in Small Concerns
description: A month after he warned that New York City's economy is too dependent on the financial giants on Wall Street, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall announced that the state employees' pension fund would invest $100 million in a program that makes loans to small businesses in the city and around the state.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Lucio Battisti, 55, Italian Pop Performer
description: Lucio Battisti, a singer and songwriter who was the voice of Italians who came of age in the late 1960's and early 70's, died on Sept. 9 at a hospital in Milan. He was 55.

title: McDonald's Heir Gives $80 Million to Salvation Army
description: Joan Kroc, widow of the man who turned McDonald's into a billion-dollar corporation, today donated $80 million to the San Diego chapter of the Salvation Army.

title: Business Group Fails to Mollify Giuliani
description: Determined to clamp down on the business group that oversees sanitation, security and other services in the Grand Central Terminal area, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the group must do more than change its leadership to stay in operation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUDICINA, PAT
description: LAUDICINA-Pat, 52. Suddenly on September 20, 1998 of Malverne. Beloved brother of Vivian Huber. Loving uncle of Michael and Andrea. Fond cousin of Tony Danza. Funeral entrusted to the Malverne Funeral Home (Anthony J. Walsh & Son), 330 Hempstead Ave, exit 17 South, S.S. Parkway, Malverne, Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:45AM Our Lady of Lourdes RC Church. Interment St Charles.

title: Browsing in a Herd
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KITAY, VICTOR
