description: KITAY-Victor. The Hewlett-East Rockaway Jewish Centre mourns the loss of its esteemed member, Victor Kitay, and extends heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Betti, and the entire family. Rabbi Stanley Platek Dr. Norman Doctor, President

title: Two Hospitals on the Same Block In Brooklyn Discuss Partnership
description: The state-run University Hospital of Brooklyn and the city-run Kings County Hospital Center, which face each other from opposite sides of Clarkson Avenue in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, have agreed to begin talks aimed at creating a partnership.

title: City Could Sharply Reduce Cost of Lawsuits, Study Says
description: New York City could sharply reduce the cost of settling claims against it by hiring more lawyers, rooting out fraud more aggressively and settling more quickly, a study released yesterday found.

title: G.O.P. Bets Scandal Will Help at Polls
description: While Congressional Republicans say President Clinton's own conduct forces them to march ahead past Election Day down the road toward impeachment, they are also motivated by a sense that the White House scandal is beginning to exact a toll from Democratic candidates.

title: LIBRARY/LEARNING SPANISH; A Serious Package With Gaps
description: WEBSTER'S NEW WORLD SPANISH TUTOR(Macmillan Digital Publishing; $49.95; Windows 95.)

title: Giddy Outbursts of Energy
description: The autumn season at the Joyce Theater got off to a fine start on Tuesday night with a rousing performance by the Dayton Contemporary Dance Company. Since Jeraldyne Blunden, its director, founded it 30 years ago, it has grown steadily in skill and assurance. It now lives confidently in the present and looks proudly back on dance's past.

title: Haitian-Americans Worry About Kin
description: Dr. Jean Claude Compas did not sleep well Tuesday night. Like other Haitian-Americans in New York, he stayed up phoning relatives and friends in Haiti to monitor Hurricane Georges's destructive path and to make sure loved ones were spared.

title: Tractor Fans on Line
description: IT looks like an ugly hunk of iron. Its machinery shares space with wasps' nests and an occasional skunk. It has more rust than the Titanic. But it's the same model your father drove, or the same one you supported your family with. Or maybe it's just one you've always heard about. And what keeps you working on it through the cuts and bruises is the knowledge that -- unlike the family car -- its parts are usually designed to be fixed easily.

title: Hurricane Leaves 110 Dead; Florida Put on Alert
description: Hurricane Georges, which left at least 110 dead and widespread destruction in the Caribbean, swept into Cuba today and took aim at South Florida, where the 80,000 residents of the Florida Keys began evacuating their vulnerable island chain.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the President of Iran misstated the timing of the Iranian Foreign Minister's scheduled speech in New York. It is Monday, not today.

title: CONAGRA BLAMES LOWER BEEF PRICES FOR LOWER EARNINGS
description: Conagra Inc. said yesterday that earnings fell 8 percent in its fiscal first quarter because of lower beef prices. The company, which makes Butterball turkeys and Slim Jim meat snacks, said net income fell to $109.3 million, or 23 cents a diluted share, from $118.3 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier. Even so, the earnings beat analysts' 22-cent average estimate. Conagra, based in Omaha, blamed lower selling prices and overproduction of meat in the United States for a 29 percent decline in profit from its refrigerated foods unit, where it gets about half its profit. The company said it hoped to cut costs and increase sales in the second half of the fiscal year. Conagra rose 43.75 cents, to $28.1875.

title: Street Closings
description: Because of the annual debate at the United Nations, through Monday there will be intermittent closings of First Avenue between 41st and 48th Streets; the 42d Street exit of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, and streets around the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at Park Avenue and 50th Street. Other street closings and detours are also possible elsewhere in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Antiques, Crafts and Ceramics
description: Benefit Auction

title: Lehman Brothers Holdings Posts 23.4% Earnings Drop
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings reported yesterday a 23.4 percent decline in third-quarter earnings from a year ago, saying that worldwide financial turmoil had buffeted its bottom line. But executives said that that the investment bank was still operating profitably amid some of the most turbulent market conditions in a decade.

title: Senate Votes to Curb Bankruptcy Abuse by Consumers
description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to overhaul the bankruptcy system and make it more difficult for consumers to walk away from debts.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; A Nation of Enablers
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans See Hope In a Staten Island Race
description: For the last 16 years, Assemblyman Eric N. Vitaliano has been a fixture in Staten Island politics. Known for his moderate views in a moderate-to-conservative district, Mr. Vitaliano has survived in eight successive elections as a Democrat on a largely Republican terrain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREWES, WILLIAM
description: DREWES-William. Died at the age of 72, after a brief illness. Bill, a graduate of Columbia College and Cambridge University, went on to an illustrious career as a management consultant, lecturing and publishing two books on the subject. His true passion, however, was in pursuing the mystery of Catholicism. He wrote the children's book, ''Discovering God.'' He loved and was loved by his wife, Jean, two children, Bill and Margaret, seven grandchildren, and his devoted cousin Frederick. He was a distinctive individual with a sharp intelligence, and an idosyncratic manner, a great sense of humor and a huge capacity for the enjoyment of life. The wake will be Thursday and Friday at Doyle B. Shaffer, Little Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to your charity of choice.

title: Metro Business; Tax Break Helps Sales
description: New York's fourth sales-tax-exemption week, held earlier this month, resulted in increased sales of 71 percent compared with a typical week in September at stores surveyed in the city, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said on Tuesday.

title: Starr Report Survey Shows Power of Tracking
description: It's hardly surprising that when the Starr report went on-line earlier this month, most readers skipped the legalese and made a bee-line for the more salacious sections. But the extent to which people's on-line reading habits can be dissected became clear when Net Ratings, a Web audience measurement company, released figures last week.

title: 150 Million Jobless, Global Study Says
description: At least 150 million people worldwide are jobless, and this number is expected to rise by millions before the end of the year, the International Labor Organization said today.

title: A Foil for Those Who Fool Caller ID
description: In the battle for dinnertime, technology has favored the telemarketers lately, with computerized dialers and more sophisticated databases making it easier for telephone solicitors to reach unsuspecting consumers. Caller ID is a big help in figuring out who is on the other end of the ring, but many times the display shows an unhelpful message like ''blocked'' or ''out of range.'' If a person picks up the telephone to figure out who it is, the caller sometimes turns out to be a telemarketer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, HELEN
description: ALTMAN-Helen. On behalf of the Board of Directors and staff of the New York Association for New Americans, Inc., (NYANA) we extend sincere condolences to our esteemed Board Member, Joy Henshel and to her family on the passing of her mother, Helen Altman. Our thoughts and prayers are with you in this time of sorrow. Laura G. Ross, President Mark Handelman, Executive V.P.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Democratic Partisans
description: To the Editor:

title: Power to the Polls
description: Republicans these days don't seem to think much of public opinion polls. With a strong majority of Americans still opposed to the impeachment of President Clinton, some prominent Republicans are arguing that Congress should do what it thinks is right, not what the polls say.

title: U.S. Urging NATO to Step Up Plans to Act Against Yugoslavia
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that NATO had to be prepared to act to prevent a humanitarian disaster in Kosovo or the alliance would rightly face ''severe criticism'' for issuing empty threats.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Albany as Party Town
description: A lobbyist's life is easier in New York State than in most places around the country. Armed with a cause and a checking account, the lobbyist operates in an environment that seems designed for his convenience. By day, the company or union representative can attend legislative sessions and roam the Gothic hallways in Albany peddling a well-honed message for a tax loophole or a special exemption. By night, the same lobbyist dutifully attends legislators' fund-raisers, often located within walking distance of the Capitol building.

title: How Laser Shows Get Their Dazzle
description: AS rockers lean back to gaze at a planetarium's dome, they see a glowing image pulsing in time with the drumbeat of the music. A figure of a hippie wearing neon red bell-bottoms and playing a quivering electric guitar disintegrates in a loud crash of cymbals and is replaced by a fluorescent wash of abstract designs that coalesce into luminous rising steps.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; What Founders Meant
description: To the Editor:

title: Audit Finds Many Failures In City Renovation Program
description: A multimillion-dollar city program that renovates tax-delinquent apartment buildings and gives ownership to the tenants has allowed many of the buildings to slide back into debt and disrepair, an audit by the City Comptroller has found.

title: HARSCO SHARES IN STEEP DROP AFTER EARNINGS WARNING
description: Shares of the Harsco Corporation, the steel-mill services company based in Camp Hill, Pa., plummeted 35 percent yesterday after it said that profits in the third and fourth quarters would not meet estimates as business slowed in Asia, Russia and South America. The company said after the markets closed that profit from continuing operations would be $2.35 a share for the year, 32 cents lower than analysts' estimate of $2.67. Harsco expects to report third-quarter results on Oct. 16. Its shares tumbled $12.9375, to $24.3125, in trading of 2.26 million, wiping out more than $590 million in market capitalization. Harsco's board authorized the repurchase of 2 million shares, in addition to the 400,000 shares remaining from previous buyback plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUM, FRANCIS
description: DRUM-Francis. Age 93, of River Edge, New Jersey, on September 22nd, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Margaret (nee Clarke). Loving father of Francis P. Riley of River Edge, Peggi Drum of NYC, and Bernadette Drum of Newton, MA. Dear brother of the late Mary Ellen, Katherine, James, Patrick, and Anne. Adored grandfather of Christopher and Keith Riley. Funeral mass is on Saturday 10AM at St. Peter the Apostle R.C. Church in River Edge. Family will receive friends at the Beaugard Funeral Home, 869 Kinderkamack Road, River Edge, NJ., on Thursday and Friday 2-4, 7-9PM

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Gerhard Schroder, the challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in Germany's national election, misidentified the sea to which a shipbuilder in Mr. Schroder's state delivers luxury liners. It is the North Sea, not the Baltic.

title: Leaf Seeks Turnabout Following Tantrum
description: Life in the National Football League turned a bit stormy for San Diego's Ryan Leaf in the third week of his rookie season.

title: Discovering a Cool Esthetic for Burning Issues
description: Social protest and conceptual cool have come to the fore in ''Mediterranea,'' the 1998 presentation of the Lyons Dance Biennial.

title: Brazil Makes Fast Recovery From Brink of Economic Collapse
description: Only two weeks ago Brazil's stock market was crashing and its banking system was leaking currency reserves at a rate of more than $2 billion a day. Financial collapse or a crushing devaluation looked almost inevitable.

title: On-Line Petition Solicits Outrage at Congress
description: Just how powerful is the Net as a grass-roots political tool? Joan Blades and Wes Boyd plan to find out. On Tuesday, the two founders of Berkeley Systems, known for its best-selling After Dark screen savers, posted a petition on the Web (www.moveon.org) inviting fellow citizens to express collective disgust at Washington's protracted preoccuption with President Clinton's relationship with Monica Lewinsky and to urge Congress to turn its attention to more important matters. The petition calls for Congress to ''immediately censure President Clinton and move on to pressing issues facing the country.'' Once a visitor to the site endorses the petition, it is automatically transmitted to ''key members of Congress'' and the President.

title: New Guidelines Urged On Money Laundering
description: Seeking to address weaknesses in the state's ability to fight money laundering, Attorney General Peter G. Verniero yesterday recommended tougher penalties for offenders and stricter reporting requirements for financial institutions to help investigate suspicious transactions.

title: And to All a Good Night Light
description: PARENTS buy children's lamps to create a fanciful, even zany, world that will excite imaginations,'' said Merin Wexler, a short-story writer in New York and the mother of 19-month-old Liana Spiro (pictured above giving Lumibear a big smoochy bearhug). ''Kids' lamps,'' she added, ''are really accessories to delight.''

title: Excerpts From Greenspan's Congressional Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the Senate Budget Committee and an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Judd Gregg, Republican of New Hampshire and a committee member, in a question-and-answer session following the testimony:

title: Cubs Offer a Gift, but Mets Say 'No Thanks'
description: Out of left field, the Mets were handed a gift-wrapped opportunity yesterday. And then the Mets turned around and handed it right back.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Student's Tip Helps to Find New Planets Beyond Sun
description: A university sophomore in England, corresponding by E-mail, volunteered some carefully considered advice to the two American astronomers with a knack for finding planets around other stars beyond the solar system: focus their planet search on 30 overlooked Sun-like stars and they just might score more discoveries.

title: House Hunting With Cursor and Click
description: SHOPPING for an apartment in New York City while living in the Netherlands could be difficult -- particularly in a hot market in which properties often sell as soon as they come on the market, sometimes for more than the asking price. But Gary Ensana and David Vickrey found a way to bridge the intercontinental divide.

title: Clinton Is Talk Radio's Only Topic
description: There are other things to talk about, Dori Monson, the host of a popular talk-radio program on KIRO-AM here in Seattle, told his listeners the other day. There is a big tobacco lawsuit going on in Washington State. There is the controversial case of a Seattle lad who, under a ''zero tolerance'' policy, was kicked out of school the other day for carrying a water pistol to class.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Censure Is Inadequate
description: To the Editor:

title: Accountants' Rules Approved
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved new legal standards for accountants' conduct.

title: Plan to Lease Trade Center Is Near a Vote
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to vote today to put the World Trade Center -- its flagship property and the largest office complex in the country -- on the market, officials said yesterday.

title: Philippine Airlines Ends Operations
description: A last-ditch attempt to save Asia's oldest airline failed yesterday after management and unions of Philippine Airlines were unable to reach agreement on a rescue plan for the ailing carrier.

title: Anniversaries Marked at Agencies
description: Three agencies are celebrating milestone anniversaries.

title: Sign of the Times (Square) -- PC's for Visitors
description: Raphael Kobi (left) and Mohamed Kone (right), two students from Abidjan, Ivory Coast, use a new Internet surfing station in the Times Square Visitors Center in Manhattan. The six computer terminals were installed by the Times Square Business Improvement District in conjunction with Yahoo, which designed a specific homepage for the machines (timessquare.yahoo.com). Mr. Kobi and Mr. Kone used them to send photographs of themselves to friends through E-mail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAFIELD, CHARLES BARBER
description: DELAFIELD-Charles Barber. At the age of 93. On September 22, 1998. Husband of the late Helen Q. Thorndike. Father of Eleanor Everett and Harriet Smith. Grandfather of John O. Everett and Charles MacLachlan, and has two great - grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Saturday September 26, 1998, 12 noon at St John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove.

title: In Capital Case, Witness Describes a Shooting
description: In New York City's second death penalty trial since the state revived capital punishment three years ago, a Brooklyn woman testified yesterday that she saw the defendant shoot a man down the block from her apartment and then fire four or five more shots after a second assailant ripped a gold chain and pendant from the victim's neck.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'Jesse'

title: Bacteria Blamed for Illness of 203 in California
description: As many as 203 people who ate at five restaurants in this Northern California town may have contracted a highly contagious bacterial infection, one that is rare in the United States but more common in developing countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MURRAY ARTHUR
description: GOLD-Murray Arthur. Beloved husband of Syd Gold, honored father of Judith Stitzel and Ivan Gold, admired by many, lover of life, avid reader of the New York Times. Services at 201 East Broadway, NYC at noon today.

title: Kick-Starting (Kapow!) a TV Series; CBS Broke All the Rules to Fling an Action Show at Young Men
description: The broadcast networks have spent 50 years perfecting one of the most regimented and costly creative processes in the arts, producing new fall series. Script ideas are pitched en masse by October, 11 months before the new season; some 300 full scripts are then delivered by Christmas. In January, 100 or so are selected for filming as pilots, usually in March; the pilots are delivered by May 1, and in mid-May maybe 35 shows win coveted spots on the new schedule, presumably the best of the best.

title: Stocks Surge As Fed Offers Hint on Rates
description: Blue-chip stocks surged 3.26 percent yesterday, as Federal Reserve officials hinted strongly at an interest-rate cut, perhaps next Tuesday, to arrest a global economic skid that is threatening to turn into a worldwide recession.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; A Bully, Not a Lawyer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, RUTH PAZEN
description: BURGER-Ruth Pazen. Wife of the late Irving Burger. Mother of John and Arthur Burger. Grandmother of Scott, Russel and Katie Burger. Sister of the late Rose Pazen and Anne Gotthardt. Retired from the Research Institute of America where she was Directing Editor of Executive Programs. Former Executive Director of the Association of Professional Art Advisors and volunteer docent of The Lighthouse. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Lighthouse, 111 E. 59 St., NY 10022. There will be a prayer meeting at her home at Noon, October 10.

title: The Great Conciliator at the Capitol
description: In the shadow of Nelson Mandela's visit to the Capitol, the word ''forgiveness'' was being uttered most gingerly today, as if it were the latest in the endless string of lurid notions that has been resounding daily in the sex-and-mendacity investigation of President Clinton.

title: James Fletcher, 63, a Banker In Poor Chicago Areas, Dies
description: James Fletcher, chairman of the South Shore Bank, a pioneering lender to some of the poorer neighborhoods in Chicago, died of complications of lymphoma on Sept. 16 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Chicago. He was 63 and a lifelong resident of the city.

title: Downloading on AOL
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; A Dreadful Game
description: The Republicans didn't know how to play their hand. They had the videotape, which was the equivalent of, say, two pairs, or maybe three of a kind. But they got all excited and bet as if they had four aces.

title: Both Sides Skirmish Over Lewinsky Testimony
description: As the central witness in Congress's consideration of impeachment proceedings, Monica S. Lewinsky has provided an account of her affair with President Clinton that, paradoxically, both Whitewater prosecutors and White House lawyers have seized upon to support elements of their cases.

title: Texan Tied to Bin Laden Held Without Bail
description: A Texan who worked as a close aide to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected in the embassy bombings last month in Africa, was ordered held without bond yesterday after the authorities accused him of buying firearms for a defendant convicted in the World Trade Center bombing in 1993.

title: FIRST LADY ASSAILS VOTES BY D'AMATO
description: With Representative Charles E. Schumer at her side, Hillary Rodham Clinton started a three-day national campaign tour yesterday by lacerating Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato as a ''Jesse Helms clone'' who had repeatedly voted to keep women ''down and back'' during his 18 years in Washington.

title: Calipari Foresees A Benefit for Nets
description: The coach who runs up and down the sideline during games, living and dying with every play, is supposed to be going crazy right now, searching desperately for ways to occupy his time.

title: Politics as Usual: No Weird Sex
description: Will it be possible for the virtuosos who write political novels to top the gaminess and authenticity of the Starr report? Or create as juicy and mingy characters, and become rich in the doing? After all we've seen and heard, could a novelist conjure a pair at least as outrageous as President Clinton and Kenneth W. Starr, even if they are sort of the Duke and the Dauphin of American politics?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIKLER, BARBARA (PETE)
description: SHIKLER-Barbara (Pete). Our special friend. For years we basked in the loving warmth of your stylish hospitality. Together we laughed till we cried. You will live and laugh and love forever in our hearts. Susan, Melinda and Ted

title: Traveler's Notebook; Have Adapter, Will Travel
description: IN the old days, travel meant getting away. Now it means going, but not getting away. To explore the third world may still mean lugging a backpack, but inside it you can have a trove of high-tech devices that tether you as securely to the first world as a ball and chain.

title: 'Mouthing Off' as Art, To Say Nothing of Song
description: ''At this moment, I'm surgically uncorrected,'' Cybill Shepherd boasted from the stage at Tuesday's opening night show of her two-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars. ''Who knows? In five years, I could have my whole self done.'' The blond 48-year-old star also boasted about her new multimillion-dollar contract with Revlon representing Ultima 2 and delivered an impromptu sales pitch. She rattled on cheerily about her years of bad reviews, especially for her singing, and bragged about the companies that went out of business after she recorded for them.

title: FIRST INITIAL STOCK SALE IN 4 WEEKS RAISES $63 MILLION
description: Ebay Inc., operator of an Internet auction site, raised $63 million yesterday in the first initial stock sale in four weeks. The company, in San Jose, Calif., sold 3.5 million shares at $18 each, the top of the $16-to-$18 range set by the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Company. The initial offering gave the three-year-old company a market capitalization of $715.3 million and its 31-year-old founder and chairman, Pierre M. Omidyar, a stake worth about $274.1 million. Ebay shares are expected to do well as they begin trading today, analysts said, even though the initial offerings market has been battered for months.

title: Land Lines for Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHOEN, DONALD R.
description: SCHOEN-Donald R. The Board of Trustees and the President of Westchester Community College join the Board of Directors of Westchester Community College Foundation in remembering the outstanding contributions and thoughtful manner of Donald R. Schoen as a Director of the Foundation Board. The College will miss him. Our sincerest condolences go out to the members of his family.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; G.O.P.'s Hostile Signal
description: To the Editor:

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Case Of the Contested Coins; A Modern-Day Battle Over Ancient Objects
description: William I. Koch once dreamed about owning an ancient coin collection so magnificent it might be called the hoard of the century. Now he does and he can't stand it.

title: W. W. Ballard, 92, Scholar With Wide Interests
description: William Whitney Ballard, professor emeritus of biology at Dartmouth College, died on Sept. 14 at his home in Norwich, Vt., in the same bed in which he was born 92 years earlier in Griswoldville, Mass.

title: Sales at J. C. Penney Are Below Forecasts
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the fourth-largest United States retailer, said today that September sales at stores open at least a year were falling short of expectations, prompting several analysts to cut fiscal third-quarter earnings estimates. Warm weather and consumer concerns about the decline in United States stock markets hurt sales of clothes, notebooks and other back-to- school products, retailer analysts said. J. C. Penney's same-store sales may decline as much as 5 percent this month, they said. The company's goal was to increase sales as much as 4 percent.

title: Has the President Been Too Much of a Lawyer?; Aides' Loyalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHINDLER, JOSEPH H.
description: SCHINDLER-Joseph H. The Officers, Directors, Trustees and staff of The Jewish Guild for the Blind, note with sorrow the passing of Joseph Schindler, husband of Guild Trustee, Norma. We extend our deepest sympathies to Norma and the family. James M. Dubin, Chairman Alan R. Morse, President

title: European Court Orders Britain to Restrict Beatings by Parents
description: In a sharp rebuke, the European Court of Human Rights ruled today that Britain had failed to protect adequately a 9-year-old boy who was repeatedly struck with a bamboo garden stake by his stepfather.

title: Every Picture Tells a Story
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Uncovered Short Positions Are 0.8% Higher on Nasdaq
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq stock market rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market, reported yesterday.

title: MATTEL SAYS IT EXPECTS LITTLE GROWTH IN THIRD QUARTER
description: Mattel Inc., the world's biggest toy maker, said yesterday that it would show little growth in third-quarter earnings because of lower orders from Toys ''R'' Us, its largest customer, and said it would more than double its stock buyback. Mattel said full-year earnings would also be disappointing because of the cutbacks by Toys ''R'' Us, the No. 1 toy retailer. Mattel said its sales to Toys ''R'' Us could be down as much as $200 million for the year. Mattel expects third-quarter earnings of 75 cents a diluted share, up from 73 cents a year earlier, but less than the average estimate of 79 cents by analysts. Mattel will buy back 15 million shares, up from 6.5 million. Mattel shares rose 50 cents, to $29.25.

title: McGwire-Sosa TV Plans Made
description: Local viewers following the home-run quests of Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa can watch Sosa at 8 o'clock tonight when ESPN carries the Cubs-Astros game. When McGwire comes to bat in the Expos-Cardinals game, ESPN will switch live.

title: Accounts
description: * Round Table Franchise Corp., Walnut Creek, Calif., to Wieden & Kennedy, Portland, Ore., to handle advertising for the pizza chain, which had been handled by Butler, Shine & Stern, Sausalito, Calif. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $9 million.

title: Republicans Hint at Widening Clinton Inquiry
description: Republican leaders suggested today that the Judiciary Committee would consider information from other House investigations into the White House and Democrats if it helped the panel establish a pattern of obstruction of justice by President Clinton.

title: Iran Drops Rushdie Death Threat, And Britain Renews Teheran Ties
description: The Iranian Foreign Minister publicly divorced his Government today from the death threat imposed on the British author Salman Rushdie in 1989 by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, and Britain responded by restoring full diplomatic relations.

title: Morgan Stanley Reports 5% Drop in Income
description: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company reported a 5 percent drop in net income for its third fiscal quarter yesterday, but it beat analysts' expectations and turned in a stronger performance than either Goldman, Sachs & Company or Lehman Inc., the two other Wall Street firms that reported quarterly results this week.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Russia Warns It Might Default if Western Aid Is Withheld
description: As the Russian Government today laid out ways to spend its way out of a roiling economic crisis, it also took a harsh line with its international creditors, warning them of a potential default on its long-term debt if more Western aid is not delivered.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture grouping on Wednesday in the special Entrepreneurs section, about baby products devised by parents, included an incorrect phone number for Well-Fed Baby, the maker of one such product, frozen kosher baby food. The number, toll free, is (888) 935-5333.

title: Hyde Vows He Will Preside Over Clinton Inquiry
description: Seeking to repair political missteps, Representative Henry J. Hyde said today that it was he, not Speaker Newt Gingrich, who would preside over impeachment deliberations, and Mr. Hyde played down suggestions that Republicans were seeking to broaden the inquiry beyond Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Mary Frann, 55, Bemused Wife on 'Newhart'
description: Mary Frann, an actress best known for playing the wife of the comedian Bob Newhart in his second successful CBS series, ''Newhart,'' died on Wednesday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 55.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Clintons Call Lawmakers to Gauge Support and Seek Comfort
description: President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, have been contacting members of Congress as they seek support and comfort during the President's predicament, White House and Congressional aides said today.

title: CIRRUS LOGIC PLANS LAYOFFS AND A $500 MILLION CHARGE
description: Cirrus Logic Inc., once a dominant maker of semiconductors for computer graphics, said yesterday that it would lay off as much as 28 percent of its work force and take a $500 million charge to get rid of its weakest businesses. Cirrus will cut 400 to 500 of its roughly 1,800 employees as part of a plan to stop making chips for graphics, personal-computer modems and Internet-access equipment. The company will focus instead on its more profitable chips for computer disk drives, audio equipment and industrial devices. The revamping was announced after shares closed at $7.28125, down 40.625 cents.

title: Sarah Lucas
description: 'The Old In Out'

title: Aer Lingus Names Chief
description: Aer Lingus, Ireland's national airline, named Gary Cullen chief executive today. The appointment, effective Oct. 1, was widely expected. Mr. Cullen, currently the airline's chief operating officer, has been with Aer Lingus for more than 20 years. He takes over from Gary McGann, who left Aer Lingus to join the Jefferson Smurfit Group two months ago.

title: The Guy Who Looks Like Freddy Krueger? Nah, Too Obvious
description: You know you're in trouble when you get to college to find that your folklore professor is Freddy Krueger, the dean is the Well-Manicured Man from ''The X-Files,'' and it's the 25th anniversary of a dormitory massacre.

title: Peggy's Cove Journal; On Nova Scotia's Shore, Will Sadness Be Forever?
description: Perhaps it is the endlessly swelling sea with its lacy waves that lend this place its timelessness. Or the granite boulders, shoved to the edge of cliffs by a retreating glacier 10,000 years ago.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD PLANS TO CUT JOBS AND REDUCE COSTS
description: The chairman of the Atlantic Richfield Company warned employees last week that the company would eliminate an unspecified number of jobs and reduce other costs as depressed oil prices cut its profits and threaten its existence as an independent company. The chairman, Michael R. Bowlin, sent an E-mail message to workers saying that the Asian economic recession was spreading, keeping energy demand sluggish and oil prices down. Atlantic Richfield, known as ARCO, is the seventh-largest United States oil company and has about 20,000 employees. It must cut expenses to lift sagging returns from oil sales and avoid being swallowed up, Mr. Bowlin said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELIAS, JOHANNA
description: ELIAS-Johanna. On September 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Loving sister of Ilsa. Services on Sunday, 11 A.M. at The Hebrew Tabernacle, 551 Fort Washington Ave. Interment Cedar Park Cemetery, New Jersey.

title: Mortgage Rate Hits a Low
description: The benchmark United States mortgage rate dropped this week to the lowest level in more than three decades, Freddie Mac said today. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell to 6.64 percent in the week ending Friday, from the previous week's 6.66 percent, according to a weekly survey by Freddie Mac. This week's rate is the lowest since 1967, when the rate was 6.38 percent, Freddie Mac said, citing figures from the Federal Housing Finance Board.

title: Sports of The Times; Sept. 23, 90 Years Apart
description: IN their clubhouse, the Cubs were getting dressed like zombies, still in silent shock from Brant Brown's blunder. But upstairs in County Stadium in Milwaukee late Wednesday afternoon, a voice with a Chicago persuasion put the Cubs' sudden loss in historical perspective.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT SAYS ITS EARNINGS ARE UP 27%
description: Countrywide Credit Industries, the largest independent home mortgage company, said yesterday that fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 27 percent, as low interest rates prompted a boom in home buying. Countrywide said net income rose to $95.1 million, or 81 cents a diluted share, from $74.7 million, or 67 cents a share, before a one-time gain from the sale of a subsidiary, in the quarter ended Aug. 31. It was in line with the 80 cents average forecast by analysts. Countrywide's income from new loans more than doubled, to $157 million. Countrywide made $22.9 billion of new loans in the fiscal second quarter, up from $10.6 billion for the quarter a year earlier. It shares fell $2.6875, to $41.9375.

title: Meanwhile, Half-Crazed At the Local Pool Hall...
description: With his wounded baby doe eyes and oddly curled-up lips, Joaquin Phoenix often resembles an overgrown little boy who has only recently stopped sucking his thumb. It is this look more than anything that has led to his being typecast as a lost, sweetly bumbling perpetual adolescent, part fragile innocent, part credulous patsy. And in David Dobkin's smart, spiffily photographed genre spoof, ''Clay Pigeons,'' Mr. Phoenix is snugly cast as a naive young cowboy whose very niceness threatens to be his downfall.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, HOWARD K.
description: WEISBERG-Howard K., M.D. On September 23, 1998. Attending physician at St. Lukes-Roosevelt & New York University Hospitals. Husband of Isot Maria Weisberg, father of Michael van Biema. Grandfather of Fiamma & Tristan. Interment private. A memorial service to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOOLEY, EDWARD WILLIAM, SR.
description: DOOLEY-Edward William, Sr. 82. Retired advertising executive and Special Agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Milwaukee, Boston and New York, died September 17, 1998, following a heart attack at his home in Malibu, CA. He was VP, advertising and marketing, Citibank, N.A., from 1975-1983 when he joined the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Foundation. He played a key role in raising $400 Million in contributions to refurbish the two national historic landmarks. Former Executive V.P. of J. Walter Thompson; V.P. at SSC&B and Economics Laboratory, St. Paul, MN. He joined the FBI in 1940 following graduation from Marquette Law School. Survivors: two sons, Edward W. Jr. nd Patrick W. two daughters Lynn Vinnedge and Kathleen Nolan, two brothers Father William Dooley, S.J., and Dr. John Dooley; eight grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Funeral Mass at noon, Saturday, Sept. 26th, Our Lady Star of the Sea Church, Stamford, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Marquette University, P.O. Box 1881, Milwaukee, WI 53201 and the Jesuit Partnership, 3400 W. Wisconsin Ave., Milwaukee, WI. 53208.

title: I.M.F. Resists 'Blackmail' by Russia and U.S.
description: A senior official of the International Monetary Fund warned today that he would neither submit to ''the blackmail'' of Russian leaders who threatened national default if they are denied billions of dollars in aid, nor let Congress ''impose conditions'' on the fund in return for $18 billion in new contributions from the United States.

title: Home Video; Director Limns Women's Lives
description: Viewed one by one on tape, a director's films usually follow a gradual progression. In the case of Marleen Gorris, however, the oeuvre sprints right up to the brink of oblivion before taking a prodigious leap into the ranks of the acclaimed.

title: William Piel Jr., 88, Ex-Corporate Lawyer
description: William Piel Jr., a leading corporate lawyer of his time, died Sept. 13 at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 88.

title: John Morris
description: D'Amelio Terras

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKACH, MARION LONG
description: LUKACH-Marion Long. Died on Sept. 24th, 1998 at the of age 98. Wife of the late Arthur S. Lukach. Mother of Ellin L. Perlmutter and Arthur S. Lukach Jr. and the late Ann L. Thron. Sister of the late Louis Long Jr. and the late John E. Long. Cherished grandmother of 8 and great grandmother of four. She was a devoted volunteer and Secretary of the Board of Directors of The Visiting Nurse Service of New York, member of the Sisterhood of Central Synagogue and active in Interfaith Neighbors. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70th Street, New York City, 10021. For funeral information call Frank E. Campbell at 212-288-3500.

title: Home Video
description: Chinese Box

title: CITING GLOBAL SLOWDOWN, UCAR WILL CLOSE THREE PLANTS
description: UCAR International Inc., a maker of graphite and carbon electrodes for the steel industry, said yesterday that it was closing plants in Ontario, Germany and Russia, eliminating 950 jobs as part of a worldwide bid to cut costs. UCAR, which is based in Danbury, Conn., attributed the cuts to the continued slowdown in the global economy, which has eroded demand for steel and graphite electrodes. The cuts will save $24 million next year, and $33 million a year starting in 2000, the company said. Costs associated with the revamping will lower third-quarter earnings by $150 million before taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENICK, MARGEN RILEY
description: PENICK-Margen Riley. Wife of the late Dr. S.B. Penick, beloved mother of Elizabeth Romanaux, Barksdale Penick and Julia Garry, beloved sister of Dr. Fenwick Riley, Nancy Newhouse Iovenko, Mary Riley Smith and William Terence Riley. The funeral service will be 1 PM, Monday at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Friends of Princeton Open Space, POB 374, Princeton, New Jersey 08542.

title: Facing Suit, School Ends Drug Testing Of Athletes
description: The school board in Ridgefield Park, N.J., has decided to end its policy of random drug testing of student athletes rather than engage in a long and costly court fight over whether the policy is legal under the New Jersey Constitution.

title: QUARTERLY EARNINGS RISE 31% AT BED, BATH AND BEYOND
description: Bed, Bath and Beyond Inc., the third-largest United States home-furnishings chain, said yesterday that fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 31 percent, as low interest rates spurred consumers to spend money on their homes. Net income in the quarter ended Aug. 29 rose to $25.5 million, or 18 cents a diluted share, from $19.4 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts expected the retailer to earn 17 cents. The per-share comparison is adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on July 31. Revenue rose 29 percent, to $344.9 million from $266.9 million. Shares of Bed, Bath and Beyond, based in Union, N.J., rose $2.1875, or 9.8 percent, to $24.5625.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANDA, RAJIV KRISHAN
description: NANDA-Rajiv Krishan. On September 18, 1998, beloved husband of Rema, father of Arjun Scott, son of Sudershan and Satyender and brother of Vikram and Sandip. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday, September 25 from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service at the funeral home 9:45 AM, Saturday, September 26th. Contributions in Rajiv's memory may be made to the U.S. Committee for UNICEF, Tribute Card Program for Rajiv Nanda, 333 East 38th Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Spencer Makes His Case as Yanks Set a Record
description: An American League scout lounged in the stands at Yankee Stadium last night, in his second week of trailing the Yankees for a potential playoff opponent. The scout feels he knows how to pitch Chuck Knoblauch effectively, how to beat Orlando Hernandez. But he acknowledged he knows almost nothing about Shane Spencer, the late-season call-up who continued his rampage by bashing a grand slam in the Yankees' 5-2 victory over Tampa Bay.

title: AT&T Changes Some Fees
description: The AT&T Corporation, the nation's top phone company, is offering residential customers long-distance calls within the United States for 5 cents a minute on weekends, in a bid to add more customers and stem defections. The discount rate is available for six months to customers who sign up for the company's One Rate Plus plan, which charges 10 cents a minute on other days plus a $4.95 monthly fee. The new plan comes a year after a rival, MCI Worldcom Inc., began charging consumers 5 cents a minute for long-distance calls on Sundays. AT&T wants to sign up consumers who spend more time on the phone and more money each month on phone services.

title: Not All Hedge Funds Have Suffered Like Long-Term Capital
description: Not all hedge funds have suffered the losses of Long-Term Capital Management, which is accepting a cash infusion of $3.5 billion just to stay afloat.

title: Ex-Head of Suspect's School Won't Testify in '75 Murder Case
description: The director of a school for troubled youth where a suspect in the murder of a Greenwich teen-ager almost 23 years ago spent nearly two years receiving treatment, refused to testify today during grand jury proceedings into the crime.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MANSFIELD, JOSEPH ANTON
description: MANSFIELD-Joseph Anton. (February 11, 1946-September 25, 1973). Golden boy, 25 years gone. Forever loved and missed.

title: Lewis Aims to Retain Title And Keep Unification Bid
description: Lennox Lewis was one of the more interested parties watching the Evander Holyfield-Vaughn Bean heavyweight championship fight last Saturday night. Lewis has a vested interest in Holyfield's remaining healthy and a champion, because Lewis's future financial well being and place in boxing history rest in Holyfield's hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, SAMUEL H.
description: BAUM-Samuel H. Beloved husband of Essie; loving father of Barbara Lerner (and her husband Arthur) and the late Sheila Baum; loving grandfather of Scot and Stefanie Lerner and Stacy Hochfelder (and her husband Peter); great-grandfather of Jake, Harrison and Charles Hochfelder; and brother of the late Dorothy Steinman. Mr. Baum was an honored World War II veteran, an active member of B'nai Brith for fifty years, and a supporter of the UJA, the Men's Club of Midchester Jewish Center in Westchester and Golden Lakes Synagogue in West Palm Beach.

title: In the Village, Halloween Parade Is Under Fire as Too Unruly
description: Like the neighborhood in which it is set, the Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, a milelong train of 20,000 marchers outfitted in elaborate, often naughty costumes, has long celebrated creativity, eccentricity and the liberating power of bending the rules.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: GOLF: YESTERDAY
description: BETSY KING CLASSIC

title: Who Is to Blame for Mr. Starr's Witch Hunt?; Medieval Political Mood
description: To the Editor:

title: ABC Losing Its Hold On Monday Ratings
description: What's ailing ABC's ''Monday Night Football''?

title: A Racial Gap at Southern Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies; Shandling Keeps Busy
description: Garry Shandling finished the last season of his television hit, ''The Larry Sanders Show,'' in high style. He was not only co-writer of a finale that many critics described as perhaps the best episode in the series (in contrast to the last episodes of ''Seinfeld'' or ''Ellen''), but he also won his first Emmy in the process. Even as he held the coveted award that evening, he was being asked what would come next.

title: Meciar Turns Out the Stars to Get Votes
description: BRATISLAVA, Slovakia  As Prime Minister Vladimir Meciar of Slovakia cut the ribbon on a short stretch of highway near here last week, the German supermodel Claudia Schiffer flashed her million-dollar smile and said Slovakia was a beautiful country.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS UP 2.3 PERCENT. Prices rose as Hurricane Georges swept toward rigs in the Gulf of Mexico that produce 25 percent of the United States supply. The October contract rose 4.8 cents, to $2.179 for 1,000 cubic feet.

title: Appealing to the Senses And to Higher Powers
description: A program called ''Indrani: Dancers and Musicians From India'' offered a generous sampling of Indian dance styles on Wednesday night at the Kaye Playhouse. Like many presentations of Indian dance, this one, arranged by Indrani, an Indian dancer who teaches at the Juilliard School, was lovely to behold.

title: Robbers Posing as Utility Workers Prey on Elderly in Brooklyn
description: It begins with frantic knocking and doorbell-ringing, and the elderly Brooklynites who answer are met by men in hard hats and fluorescent-orange vests, carrying crackling walkie-talkies. The men claim to be from ''the water company'' and warn of a nearby water main break and the possibility of flooding, broken gas lines and contaminated tap water. They ask, in urgent tones, to come inside to check the pipes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENFELD, RON
description: ROSENFELD-Ron. In memory of my sole mate, Ron Rosenfeld. I'm missing you. You're missing my gefilte fish. Happy Holidays where ever you are. Love Toni.

title: S.E.C. Charges 41 With Fraud In Suits Filed Over Sales of Stock
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged 41 defendants, including International Automated Systems Inc. and Global Casinos Inc., with defrauding investors of $25 million in the sale of low-priced stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHMONES, THELMA
description: SCHMONES-Thelma. On September 23, 1998. Beloved mother of Leslie Goldschmid and Jeffrey Schmones. Cherished grandmother to Jennifer, Emily, Robyn, Jamie. Services Friday, 12PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Fast Aid Is Essential In Highway First Aid
description: MANY highway accident victims who are pronounced dead on arrival at emergency rooms have injuries doctors find to be surprisingly small.

title: Senate Panel Approves Minimum-Wage Increase
description: Nearly 30,000 state residents who earn a minimum wage of $5.05 an hour would be eligible for a 10-cent raise under a bill approved yesterday by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: Cargill to Produce Sara Lee Turkey Meat
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said today that it had hired Cargill Inc. to produce and process turkeys for its packaged-meat unit, the world's largest.

title: TV Weekend; From the Bolsheviks to the Berlin Wall
description: A history of the cold war, which ran for close to half a century and was played out on several continents, is no small undertaking. In recognition of the subject's scope, CNN's new series allows it 24 episodes, one a week beginning on Sunday with an introduction to Soviet-American relations and concluding next spring with the fall of the Berlin wall. It's an ambitiously conceived, intelligently executed project.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: CENDANT SAYS IT WILL SELL SOME UNITS AND BUY BACK STOCK
description: The Cendant Corporation's chairman, Henry R. Silverman, said yesterday that he expected the company's earnings to grow 20 percent annually starting next year, bolstered by sales of noncore businesses. Mr. Silverman said the company planned to use the proceeds of sales to buy back stock, which is down 60 percent this year after the company disclosed accounting irregularities in mid-April. Shares of Cendant fell 87.50 cents yesterday, to $13.50. The company, based in Parsippany, N.J., has been offered as much as 14 times earnings for some of its units. Cendant stock is trading at about five times earnings.

title: From Europe to Japan, 25 Film Programs
description: The 36th New York Film Festival opens tonight and closes on Oct. 11. The festival, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, includes 25 programs representing 16 countries. All films are shown at Alice Tully Hall with the exception of the late show tonight and the closing night film, which are at Avery Fisher Hall. Several special screenings and series are planned at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. Sergei Eisenstein's 1924 film ''Strike'' will be shown with live musical accompaniment on Thursday at 7 and 9:30 P.M. ''In the Presence of a Clown,'' Ingmar Bergman's 1997 work for Swedish television, will be shown on Oct. 3 at 6:15 and 8:30 P.M. and Oct. 4 at 1 and 3:20 P.M. (the 3:20 P.M. is sold out). ''Views From the Avant-Garde'' will be screened at various times on Oct. 10 and 11. And a film series devoted to the Egyptian auteur Youssef Chahine will run through Oct. 24. All screenings at the Walter Reade are $8.50; $5 for Film Society members; $4.50 for the elderly at weekday matinees. Box office: (212) 875-5600. Many festival screenings are sold out, although a few returned tickets may be available. Tickets are $8 to $30 and available at the Tully Hall box office, (212) 875-5050. Unless otherwise noted, the films were made this year. Some are already scheduled to be released commercially in New York City, and those dates are noted. Here is the festival schedule:

title: On Stage and Off; Swinging Again At Studio 54
description: For ''Cabaret,'' it's auf Wiedersehen to the Kit Kat Klub on West 43d Street.

title: Vallone Backed by 133,000-Member Teachers' Union
description: In payback for Gov. George E. Pataki's budget vetoes last spring, the New York City teachers' union -- one of the state's most potent political operations -- endorsed his Democratic opponent, Peter F. Vallone, yesterday.

title: A Case Study In Instability Hurts Stocks
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday on intensified fears about world financial instability, which has so badly infected a large American investment fund that the Federal Reserve helped organize a $3.5 billion emergency rescue.

title: Can a Laundryman Be Taken to the Cleaners?
description: Creating a comedy is like making a souffle. Two chefs can work with the same ingredients and follow the same recipe, yet one result will be airy and delightful; the other, heavy and flat.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about advances in the theory of superstrings misspelled the names of four scientists. The physicist who helped revive string theory in the 1980's is Dr. John Schwarz, not Schwartz. Those who helped rid quantum electrodynamics theory of troublesome infinities include Dr. Julian Schwinger, not Schwiger, and Dr. Shinichiro Tomo naga, not Tomanaga. The physicist who discovered quasars is Dr. Maarten Schmidt, not Marten.

title: Street Closings
description: Because of the annual debate at the United Nations, through Monday there will be intermittent closings of First Avenue between 41st and 48th Streets; the 42d Street exit of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, and streets around the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at Park Avenue and 50th Street. Other street closings and detours are also possible elsewhere in Manhattan, the police said.

title: FOOTBALL: EASTERN COLLEGE NOTEBOOK
description: GENEVA

title: Giuliani Steps Up Criticism of Drug Czar Over Methadone Care
description: Several months ago, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wrote to Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, the White House drug policy director, in part to express pride that New York City's drug policy was consistent with the national strategy. The Mayor closed with, ''I look forward to an opportunity to discuss these issues in person.''

title: Real Tough Guys, Real Derring-Do
description: A crew of tough customers assembles at the start of John Frankenheimer's top-notch thriller, ''Ronin.'' Each of them is seasoned and shrewd, but they've got nothing on the man behind the camera when it comes to gritty professionalism. Directing like a world-weary Hitchcock with a taste for the breathtaking car chase, Mr. Frankenheimer propels this tale of intrigue through its tightly plotted paces with such conviction that he even makes an action hero out of Robert De Niro.

title: Who Is to Blame for Mr. Starr's Witch Hunt?
description: To the Editor:

title: Trajectory of a Brief Career Hints at What Might Have Been
description: The American painter Bob Thompson lived hard and died young, in 1966, just short of his 29th birthday, after years of substance abuse. He painted at a fairly brisk pace, too.

title: Kohl, Seeking 5th Term, Plays on Germans' Fears
description: Battling to win an unprecedented fifth term as Chancellor in national elections on Sunday, Helmut Kohl today chose a simple theme: fear.

title: On My Mind; Listen to the Man
description: It's been a pretty fine vacation for Americans, hasn't it, a vacation from the whole world for the better part of a year.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 4
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Ernst Rudolph Jaakson, 93, Estonian Diplomat-in-Exile
description: Ernst Rudolph Jaakson, the Ambassador from Estonia who maintained a consulate in New York after the Soviet Union absorbed the country, died on Sept. 4 in New York, the Estonian Consulate said. He was 93, and had been a diplomat for 75 years -- the longest-serving diplomat in the world, according to the State Department.

title: Anguish, Freeze-Dried and Served With Precision
description: Two years ago, the National Theater of Greece came to New York with a whirling, incantatory ''Electra'' so throbbingly alive you could hear its heartbeat. The company has returned to town, and this time has cooled things off considerably, importing a severe new version of ''Medea'' that puts much more stock in a display of style than the delivery of substance.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAFTON, ALFRED G.
description: TRAFTON-Alfred G. (Kipp) III. March 21, 1953 to September 25, 1988. Always remembered deep in the heart of Texas

title: Gritty Pals Who Prefer Car Thefts To a Job
description: A group of pals in Charlestown, a dingy Irish-American enclave of Boston, are sitting around one night smoking cigarettes, downing beers, sniffing cocaine and shooting the breeze. At one point, their rough-and-tumble conversation turns to movie star breasts (real ones versus silicone), the Hollywood brat pack (this is the mid-1980's) and the physical attributes of celebrity dream girls. When the macho banter hits a lull, one of the friends wearily allows that even if they were the last men on earth, their fantasy lovers would still never give them the time of day.

title: The Wild Wild-Card Race
description: For the last month, while the Yankees have been marking time, the New York Mets have been playing the most exciting baseball in the City of New York. Besides reawakening the interest of many fans who deserted them earlier in the decade, they have raised the possibility, however faint, that two New York teams could meet in the World Series for the first time since the Dodgers-Yankees series of 1956. But first the Mets have to win a spot in the playoffs, which in turn means disengaging themselves from the Chicago Cubs, with whom they have been locked in an energetic if slightly bizarre tango for the last seven weeks.

title: An Unsolicited Suitor Bids for Filofax
description: No yuppie was seen without one. No master or mistress of the universe ventured forth unadorned by this particular accessory: For much of the 1980's, the Filofax -- the black leather ring-binder whose girth was a measure of power-lunch dates and contacts in high places -- was de rigueur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYBAUM, RHODA H.
description: MAYBAUM-Rhoda H. Beloved wife of the late Harry and good friend of Mr. Nathan Cooper. Services were held.

title: Sharon Horvath
description: 'Rome Series and Other Works'

title: N.B.A. Training Camps Off
description: The National Basketball Association made it official yesterday, postponing training camp for players and canceling the first week of the exhibition season. ''Unfortunately, it is now clear there will not be enough time to fill their rosters, go through a necessary period of conditioning and be ready to play preseason games by mid-October,'' Russ Granik, the league deputy commissioner, said in a statement.

title: Lawyer Says U.S. Inquiry On Holbrooke Is Near End
description: The lawyer for Richard C. Holbrooke, whose nomination as the American representative at the United Nations has been sidetracked by a Federal ethics investigation, said today that the inquiry was nearly over and that investigators had found nothing that should stop the nomination from proceeding.

title: A Cold War Relic Is a Literary Hot Spot; New Authors Hope Someone Important Is Listening to Them at Bar's Readings
description: ''Mothers bathed their babies in the sinks,'' Helen Schulman was saying softly. She was reading from a book on a battered lectern placed before a ratty framed picture of paraders in Red Square. ''Hershleder could believe this,'' she continued.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Mexico Jails 2 Drug Agents, and U.S. Officials See Graft
description: In a new case raising friction between American and Mexican law enforcement officials, two Mexican drug enforcement agents are in jail here on kidnapping charges that appear to have been trumped up by corrupt police officers working with traffickers.

title: Courier on Davis Cup Bench; Fast-Rising Gambill Is In
description: When the time came to unveil the identity of the United States Davis Cup squadron that will battle Italy in the semifinal here this weekend, the hot hand won out over the old hand during a chilly outdoor draw ceremony a few blocks from the designated battlefield, a semi-sluggish indoor hardcourt at the Milwaukee Arena.

title: Snapping Away but Eating Like a Bird
description: Finding hilarity in John Waters's latest movie title is the basic pre requisite for enjoying the goofy ingenuity of his new film. Remember that Mr. Waters proudly establishes himself as perhaps the first filmmaker to accompany his directorial credit with a shot of rats mating, and you'll be nicely attuned to ''Pecker'' and its ebulliently trashy fun.

title: Kosovo Refugees Trapped by Two Fears
description: In the sullen silence of a makeshift camp in the hills above the still smoldering villages of central Kosovo, Fehmi Geshi, a 21-year-old student, stared blankly ahead today, barely able to comprehend that he is once again a refugee.

title: American Bombs Won't Help Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigeria's New President Visits U.S. and Wins Support for Regime
description: Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, who became President of Nigeria in June by an accident of fate, came to the United States this week determined to persuade skeptics that his Government will be short-lived, open and incorruptible, and that the country had finally turned the corner to democracy after years of military rule.

title: Real Reform Versus Mayoral Expediency
description: The rumbling from New York's City Hall suggests that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is ready to veto an excellent campaign finance reform package passed last month by the City Council. The Council can easily override the Mayor's veto, but Mayor Giuliani would send a far more worthy signal to New Yorkers if he would simply let these reforms pass, either by signing the three bills or stepping aside and letting them become law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOAS, RUTH
description: BOAS-Ruth. Aged 98. On September 23, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Benjamin, loving mother of Muriel & her husband Sol Cantor, and the late Robert and daughterin-law Marjorie Levins; adored grandmother of five; great-grandmother of fifteen. Funeral private. ''She walks in beauty like the night of cloudless climes and starry skies, and all that's best of dark and bright meet in her aspect and her eyes.''

title: Troubled President Turns to the Mideast
description: Even as concern grows abroad that Bill Clinton's troubles at home will distract him from matters of foreign policy, American officials said the President would meet separately with the Israeli and Palestinian leaders at the White House next week in the hope of reviving moribund peace talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, LEO
description: ROSEN-Leo. The Jewish Center of Atlantic Beach records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Mr. Leo Rosen, father of Meryl Hoffman and David Rosen. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and know no further sorrow. Dr. Basil Herring, Rabbi Arthur Udell, President Armand Lindenbaum, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Who Is to Blame for Mr. Starr's Witch Hunt?; Lewinsky Was Pilloried
description: To the Editor:

title: No Time For Partisans
description: The news of the last few weeks involving President Clinton has had a juggernaut quality, with events rushing at such a pace that Congress seems to be heading inevitably toward an extended, full-scale impeachment proceeding. We believe that it need not be so, that there are several steps along the way at which reasonable men and women in Congress could consider alternatives less damaging to the nation.

title: Mel Chin, Arlan Huang, Bing Lee
description: China 2000 Fine Art

title: Clinton Scandal Is Benefiting Fund-Raising for Both Parties
description: The scandal involving President Clinton and a former White House intern has spurred a sharp increase in Republican campaign contributions for the November elections, a senior party official said today.

title: Inside Art
description: Ellsworth Kelly On the Wall

title: A Once-Thankless Task Is Now a Chance to Shine
description: Replacement actors, once seen as pale shadows of the performers in the original cast, are no longer playing second fiddle to their predecessors. Substitute casts are now charged with star power, as evinced by a string of new lighted names on theater marquees, from Jennifer Jason Leigh and Blair Brown arriving in ''Cabaret'' to Christian Slater segueing into ''Side Man'' to Richard Benjamin and Paula Prentiss moving into ''Power Plays.'' The shift away from scrubs among the subs to first-string quality is driven by producers' needs to satisfy ticket buyers' demands for known quantities, abetted by the desire of screen and stage actors, from Hollywood and London, to work in New York theater. The results can be exciting, as demonstrated by Lillias White's energizing ''Dinah Was,'' the biographical drama of Dinah Washington. Ms. White, who won a Tony for her role as a hooker in ''The Life,'' performs a brace of Washington hits, grabbing hold of the audience and not letting go. Over at the Royale Theater, Brian Cox, Henry Goodman and David Haig have taken over from Alan Alda, Alfred Molina and Victor Garber in ''Art,'' and it is Mr. Cox, and his wonderfully blustery portrayal of Marc, the bombastic neocon, who now sets the rhythm of the play.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you're so used to getting hard news -- and by that I mean bad news -- then news like this is almost unbelievable. It's like being told the cancer is gone. Well, the cancer's gone.''

title: Hustlers With Chickens? Wait, There's Fantasy, Too
description: Ghislaine sounds pretty casual when she calls a client to say, ''I'm going to have to cancel your afternoon beating.'' The same is true when she explains to someone else that a client used a branding iron on poor Robby, and when she reports, ''One of my chickens got kidnapped or something.''

title: What, Play Linebacker? Giants' Phillips Can Do It
description: Last Monday night, Ryan Phillips made his first professional start, stepping in at strong-side linebacker for the Giants before a nationwide television audience. It was a far cry from where he was just two years ago, playing on the defensive line at the University of Idaho.

title: Giving Icons Real Life and Humans a Paradise
description: Welcome to heaven. Or more accurately, to heaven on earth. That's the terrain mapped out in crisp, luminous detail in ''From van Eyck to Bruegel: Early Netherlandish Painting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.''

title: Wave of Laws Aimed at People With H.I.V.
description: Reflecting a growing frustration and fear about AIDS, legislators around the country are passing an increasing number of laws intended to protect the public. This latest wave of legislation shifts the focus from earlier laws that protected the civil liberties of H.I.V.-infected people to laws that seek to identify certain people with the virus, notify partners and in some cases punish those who intentionally place others at risk of contracting the virus.

title: Jason Martin
description: Robert Miller Gallery

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets Decline as Fears Of Additional Losses Grow

title: Fans, Poll Says, Are Back, Back, Back
description: The two-way home run race that fans don't want to end, the one that has catapulted baseball to new heights of interest, enters its last stage tonight. So does the three-way race for the National League wild-card spot. But both races could be extended beyond Sunday, the final day of the regular-season schedule, creating an even more frantic finish to one of the most scintillating seasons ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWLING, JEANNE
description: DOWLING-Jeanne of NYC and Moriches on September 24, 1998. Beloved mother of Deborah Paul, Jeannine Dowling Twomey, and William Dowling, dear sister of Rosemary Hammel and Thurston Millett, beloved grandmother of Michael, Kristin, and Caitlin. Reposing Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the Follett & Werner Funeral Home, 60 Mill Rd., Westhampton Beach. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Monday 11 AM at the Church of the Immaculate Conception, Westhampton Beach. In lieu of flowers contributions to Mrs. Dowling's favorite charity, The Gladney Fund, 2300 Hemp Hill, Fort Worth, TX 76110 would be appreciated by the family.

title: NEW DELHI PLEDGES TO SIGN WORLD BAN ON NUCLEAR TESTS
description: India joined Pakistan today in announcing that it is prepared to sign the international treaty banning nuclear testing within the next year, but said it is still discussing details with Washington.

title: Op-Art
Francelia Butler Is Dead at 85; Children's Literature Champion
description: Francelia Butler, a late-blooming academic of such passionate, unorthodox ways that she has been credited with almost single-handedly transforming the study of children's literature from a stepchild of library science into a recognized academic discipline, died last Friday at a nursing home in Windham, Conn. A resident of Mansfield Hollow, Conn., she was 85 and had been a professor at the University of Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C. There will be a memorial service held Saturday, October 24, at 1PM, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

title: Littlest League: Boy, 3, Shuns Old Bawl Game And Goes a Full 9
description: You take a 3-year-old to a ball game at your peril. That's what I heard. I had waited until my daughter was 5 before escorting her to her first game. But with second children, things always feel accelerated. My son had seen Eddie Murphy in ''Dr. Dolittle.'' He laughed at the questionable jokes.

title: Swiss Bank Foresees a Loss Of $721 Million This Quarter
description: UBS A.G., Europe's biggest bank, announced today that it expected to report a third-quarter loss as high as one billion Swiss francs -- currently $721.6 million -- related to losses in emerging markets, equities and the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the American hedge fund.

title: Survey Finds an Upsurge In Theatergoers Under 20
description: The proportion of Broadway theatergoers younger than 20 has nearly tripled in the last 30 years, and most of these young people attend musicals rather than plays, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Sudan Needs TB Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling With Love, but No Torch Songs
description: THERE are high notes Barbara Cook no longer tries to hit, and at 70 the voice is changed -- richer and more interesting, actually, since she was Marian the Librarian in ''The Music Man'' 40 years ago, with a lyric soprano that was just like every other ingenue's lyric soprano, except hers was better.

title: Reporter Pleads Guilty in Theft Of Voice Mail
description: The Cincinnati Enquirer's lead reporter on an expose that was later retracted by the newspaper pleaded guilty yesterday to two felony charges that he stole internal voice mail messages from the Chiquita banana company, which he had been investigating.

title: Kentucky's Quarterback: Born for the Big Time
description: There is a gold chain hanging from his neck and the lore of a mountain hero weighing him down. Folks from the hollows of Thousand Sticks and Hell For Certain watched him grow up and throw touchdowns in neighboring Hyden -- at 357 people, a big place by eastern Kentucky's standards.

title: Allies Inch Toward Action Against Serbs
description: NATO asked its military commanders today to take the next step to prepare for air strikes against Yugoslavia if it does not stop attacks on ethnic Albanian civilians in Kosovo, the province in southern Serbia.

title: Vital Lesson For Students Is Workaday
description: FEW eyebrows should have been raised, and most likely few were, when a recent survey showed that New York business leaders have meager faith in the city's public schools. Even so, it was hard to keep shoulders from sagging after the late-August release of the study, commissioned by the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce.

title: Santi Moix
description: Paul Kasmin Gallery

title: Blood Test Is Said to Link Man to Student's Slaying
description: Blood on a knife found in the apartment of a 22-year-old man charged with killing a Columbia Law School student in March matches the blood of the victim, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: No Homers, No Relief For a Silent McGwire
description: Maybe it's the claustrophobia in Mark McGwire that has turned him into a man who seems to be desperately searching for an air pocket as everything closes in on him: the season, Sammy Sosa, the news media, zealous fans, everything.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OCHITILL, SAMUEL J.
description: OCHITILL-Samuel J. Born on November 12, 1909 in NYC, passed away on September 21, 1998 after the final stages of an acute illness. He was the cherished husband of Gertrude Lerner and the dearly loved father of Karyn and Herbert. He is also survived by his three grandchildren, Jackie, Sarah and Emily. Services will be held in San Diego. Contributions in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Jim Hodges
description: CRG Gallery

title: Somebody Else's Role Can Now Be a Star Turn
description: Once, it was a job for the also-ran: the former television star on the downhill leg of the career track, the hopeful understudy promoted from the waiting room to the dressing room, the Broadway journeyman lugging his battered makeup kit from one tired chestnut to the next.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Sitting in that big, spare, masculine room looking at Madison Square Garden hunkered down just across the street you think: ''Of course! What this neighborhood needed was a steakhouse!''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Russian immigrants in the Brooklyn community of Manhattan Beach misstated the position of Harold Weinberg, a local resident who was involved in amending zoning laws to let some homeowners enlarge their houses. He is a member of the local community board, not the City Council.

title: Iran's Diplomatic Offensive
description: Iranian Government leaders consolidated several days of effective public diplomacy at the United Nations yesterday by formally repudiating their country's death threat against Salman Rushdie, the British writer. Though the announcement by Foreign Minister Kamal Kharrazi does not entirely eliminate the danger to Mr. Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' it would appear to end any Government role in trying to kill him. Rejection of the assassination threat removes one of the primary obstacles to improved relations between the United States and Teheran.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAPLES, ELIZABETH ANN
description: STAPLES-Elizabeth Ann. Age 30, of New York City, formerly of Haymarket, VA and Tequesta, FL, died Thursday, September 24, 1998 at University Medical Center in Stony Brook, NY from injuries sustained in an automobile accident. She was a 1990 graduate of Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY having received a B.A. degree in Fine Arts and had worked as an artist-metal sculptor in New York City since graduation. Survivors include her parents, Charles and Margaret Ann Staples, of Tequesta, FL. and Haymarket, VA, one sister & brother-in-law, Kimberly and Kenneth Thornton, niece Kendra and nephew Kurtis all of Gainesville, VA., one brother, Whit Staples, of Tequesta, FL., her grandparents, Ernest T. Painter, of Pulaski, VA, Mr. and Mrs. Bob Lane, of Portsmouth, VA, and Mr. and Mrs. Griffin Staples, of Cocoa Beach, FL, great grandmother, Rochelle Norton, of Cunton, NC. Also surviving are maternal aunts and uncles, Ella Price, Shawsville, VA, Charles Painter of Warrenton, VA, Debra Socha, of Rockville, MD, cousins, Chad Price, Emily Beaver, Matt Painter, Jenny Socha and Teddy Socha, fraternal uncles, Jimmy Staples, of Portsmouth, VA, Billy Staples, of Vero Beach, FL, cousin, Jason Staples and friends ''head to toe around the world.'' Family will receive friends from 7-9 PM, Friday, September 25, 1998 at Price Funeral Home, 9609 Center St., Manassas, Virginia where funeral services will be held 10:00 AM, Saturday, September 26, 1998. Interment will take place at 3:00 PM, Sunday, September 27, 1998 at Drapers Valley Presbyterian Church Cemetery, in Draper, VA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARATH, PETER
description: SARATH-Peter. It is with deep sorrow that we record the untimely passing of our esteemed member, Peter Sarath, and extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Denise and children Brian and Lindsay. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President Robert Fensterman, Secretary

title: Critic's Choice/ Film; Moved to a Large Screen, 'Lolita' in All Its Detail
description: At long last, Adrian Lyne's trouble-plagued ''Lolita'' can be seen in the large-screen format it richly deserves. Mr. Lyne's deeply felt, subtle adaptation of the Nabokov masterpiece is the best work of his career, and for its detail alone it shines theatrically in ways that weren't fully possible on Showtime.

title: In Videotape, Ousted Deputy Blasts Mahathir For Corruption
description: KUALA LUMPUR  In a videotape that was recorded before his arrest and broadcast throughout East Asia on Thursday, Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's ousted deputy prime minister, leveled broad allegations of corruption against Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad.

title: Money to Burn at the Pentagon
description: Ever since the Republicans took control of Congress in 1995, they have added money to the defense budget, over and above the Clinton Administration's requests. In 1995 and 1996, they raised the proposed level of defense spending by $20 billion. In 1997, as part of the balanced budget agreement, the Pentagon's five-year plan received an additional $17 billion boost. And because of lower than expected inflation, the Pentagon will have another $35 billion in purchasing power from 1999 to 2003.

title: It's a Leonardo? It's a Corot? Well, No, It's Chocolate Syrup
description: Here's the art history quiz for the day: What connects Leonardo da Vinci to Bosco chocolate syrup?
