Answer: Vik Muniz, an artist who specializes in unlikely means of not quite fooling the eye and calls the results ''photographic delusions.'' Mr. Muniz has copied Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' in chocolate syrup. This is probably a first.

title: Texas Songs That Dwell On Yesterday
description: Texas couldn't secede from the United States, but its songwriters broke free. Texas musicians have always been an independent bunch, and they haven't yielded to pop trends from the outside. Texas rockers freely mix blues, country, mariachi, swing and Tex-Mex norteno music with rock, and the more introspective songwriters are always aware of the wide-open landscape and its mythic drifters and cowboys.

title: Fancy Goods With an Aura Of a Better Life
description: Social betterment may be a universal impulse, but Americans have always taken the pursuit to a new level. Even in the 1750's, the colonists eking out a living in Deerfield, Mass., were also busily trying to improve themselves morally, intellectually and materially -- between Indian raids and harvests, that is. We see this in ''Pursuing Refinement in Rural New England: 1750-1850,'' an exhibition at the Flynt Center of Early New England Life, a new museum run by Historic Deerfield that opens to the public tomorrow.

title: Hedge Fund Bailout Rattles Investors and Markets
description: The $3.5 billion rescue of a big, risky investment fund verging on collapse unnerved markets around the world yesterday, raised a clamor for a Government investigation and created fear that other enormous hidden losses might become evident in the weeks and months ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRAFTON, KIPP
description: TRAFTON-Kipp. March 20, 1953 to Sept. 25, 1988. Ten years. We're lucky for the love, the memories, the images and the friends you left behind. Especially the love. Todd

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETIT, JUSTIN
description: PETIT-Justin. Your strength, dignity and fortitude in the face of adversity have touched all that knew you. The legacy you leave will inspire all of us. To the family, we offer our love and support. Ruth & Seymour Raubvogel Lisa & Jeff Hammerman & family

title: Wallace's 'Conversion'
description: To the Editor:

title: The Holders of Russian Debt Begin Blocking Overseas Assets
description: As foreign holders of Russian debt struggle to recover some of their billions in losses, they have begun blocking Russian bank accounts and other assets overseas, resorting to the courts to unravel a tangled skein of loan, bond and currency-contract defaults.

title: Residential Real Estate; A New Tower for Young Professionals
description: Containing mostly studios and one-bedroom apartments, the 26-story Longacre House in the Clinton section of Manhattan was designed with an eye toward attracting young professionals.

title: Lawyers for Jones and Clinton Are Seeking to Settle Lawsuit
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones and President Clinton said today that they were engaged in serious discussions about reaching a financial settlement to end her sexual-misconduct lawsuit, which set off the events that led to the possible impeachment action against Mr. Clinton that is now before Congress.

title: Metro Business; Costs of Renting Compared
description: Midtown Manhattan is the most expensive commercial real estate market in the nation, at an average of $48.25 a year per square foot, but it is ranked only 15th in the world, according to Global Market Rents, published by CB Richard Ellis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, ROBERT LEE
description: GILL-Robert Lee. Age 87, died on Thursday, September 24, 1998, in New York City, from complications of a stroke. Survivors include his wife, Melanie Gill, and from his first marriage, a son, Peter T. Gill of Bronxville, NY, and a stepson, John D. Chapman of Fort Pierce, Fla., and two sisters, Barbara Betts of West Hampton Beach, NY, and Mary Roby of Rochester, NY; grandchildren, Caroline and Elizabeth Gill, John, David and Steven Chapman, and seven step great-grandchildren. Born in South Orange, NJ, October 10, 1911. Married Caroline Townsend Chapman in 1939, who died in 1984. Member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 40 years. Past president of the NYSE Luncheon Club, member of the NY Racquet and Tennis Club. Distinguished and well-known collector of fine American art and antiques. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum, DE 19735. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Sunday, 2-5 PM, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Service private.

title: Too Many Caesareans
description: To the Editor:

title: A Racial Gap at Southern Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: World Trade Center Goes Up for Lease
description: The Port Authority board voted unanimously yesterday to put the World Trade Center up for long-term lease, and several major real estate figures have already expressed interest in becoming the new landlord of one of the world's most prominent properties.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about remarks on Wednesday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, referred incorrectly to the 257.21-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average that day. It was not the strongest advance since Aug. 31; the strongest was 380.53 points on Sept. 8. Wednesday's close of 8,154.41 was the Dow's highest close since Aug. 31.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELAFIELD, CHARLES BARBER
description: DELAFIELD-Charles Barber. At the age of 93. On September 22, 1998. Husband of the late Helen Q. Thorndike. Father of Eleanor Everett and Harriet Smith. Grandfather of John O. Everett and Charles MacLachlan, and has two great - grandchildren. Memorial service will be held on Saturday September 26, 1998, 12 noon at St John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about Pakistan's offer to sign the treaty banning nuclear weapons tests referred incorrectly to the status of the treaty in the United States. President Clinton has indeed sent it to the Senate for ratification.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: HEDGE FUND PROBLEMS HELP YEN. Japan's currency rose on concern about foreign-currency positions held by hedge funds after the bailout of Long-Term Capital Management. The dollar eased to 135.10 yen from 135.75 yen.

title: Southern Specialties
description: Of all the American regional cuisines, Southern cooking has over the years made the greatest impression on New Yorkers, with more restaurants offering specialties of the South than of any other region. Here are 12 of them. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Islanders And Devils Await Site Inspection
description: The managers of Nassau Coliseum said today that the arena was ready for the Islanders' opening home exhibition game against the Devils on Friday night, but lawyers continued to argue in court this afternoon over whether the arena was safe for the players and fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATSON, MADELEINE STILES DICKERSON
description: WATSON-Madeleine Stiles Dickerson (Leine), age 55, very peacefully in the Royal Brompton Hospital in London. Darling wife of Simon C.H. Watson and much loved sister of Helen Dickerson Millar of Hyde Park, NY, Allen E. Whitman of Berwyn, PA, and Johnston de F. Whitman of Laurel Hollow, LI. She will be missed by her many friends. Thanksgiving Service on Monday, October 5, at 5PM at Holy Trinity Brompton, London, SW7. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to GUCH Fund, c/o Dr. Jane Somerville, Royal Brompton Hospital, London, SW3 6NP. Memorial service will be held in NYC at a later date.

title: Boy, 14, Is Charged With Raping a Girl, 14
description: A 14-year-old boy was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 14-year-old girl in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: A Racial Gap at Southern Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Life and Literature Intertwined in a City That Speaks Volumes
description: This weekend New York, our big, noisy, contentious, world-engaging town, is being celebrated as Book Country. For most people, that's Manhattan. But once, my New York City was the Bronx. It was a small place (I thought). It was enlarging itself, slowly moving east on little bridges over narrow streams and north on Robert Moses's highways in order to sell its fancier citizens to the suburbs. Not me.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Who Is to Blame for Mr. Starr's Witch Hunt?; Media Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: American Bombs Won't Help Kosovo
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Ordered to Halt Cleanup at Cemetery
description: Concerned that city bulldozers would disturb some 18,000 untended graves, a Superior Court judge ordered Newark officials yesterday to suspend their cleanup efforts at a former cemetery the city has been using as a garbage dump.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: ALBERT V. MANISCALCO, 90, a Staten Island Leader
description: Albert V. Maniscalco, who was the Borough President of Staten Island during its dizzying shift from rural to urban borough, died on Sept. 2 at the Sisters of Charity Medical Center there. He was 90.

title: Spaniard Goes For Fourth Straight
description: To Isaac Viciosa, the best-known athletes in Spain are the tennis players Arantxa Sanchez Vicario and Carlos Moya. Viciosa would rate himself in the top 10.

title: Defenseman Sent To Hartford
description: Brent Thompson, a Rangers defenseman, was sent down to the Hartford farm club yesterday, reducing the roster to 32 players. Before they cut down to 23 for opening night on Oct. 9, the Rangers will play six more exhibition games, including one against the Devils tomorrow night in New Jersey.

title: Publicis Says Profit Rose 72% in Half
description: Publicis S.A., Europe's second-largest advertising company, said yesterday that first-half profit rose 72 percent, helped by acquisitions. The company earned 160 million francs ($28 million), up from 93 million francs in the first six months of 1997. In August, the company said sales rose 41 percent, to 17.41 billion francs ($2.9 billion).

title: John Ahearn
description: 'Sculpture From East 100th Street'

title: Audi's New Coupe Gets Neiman's Blessing
description: The new Audi TT coupe is the automobile featured in this year's Neiman Marcus Christmas catalogue, which came out this month. A hundred limited edition and numbered TT coupes will be available on a first-ordered basis for delivery late next spring.

title: Recession Produces More Orphans, but Nation Resists Giving Offspring to Foreigners : Koreans Agonize Over Child Adoptions
description: SEOUL  The young mother was in tears as she and her landlady walked into the Seoul Children's Counseling Center, both of them tugging at her six-year-old daughter.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; The debut of an on-line auction house reminds investors of the glories of initial offerings gone by.
description: NOW we know what it takes to shake Wall Street's I.P.O. blues: Beanie Babies and lots of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, JOAN L.
description: LEONARD-Joan L. On September 21st, 1998. Mother of Jason Scaramucci and Nicole Leonard. Cherished daughter of Ruth and the late Louis Leonard. Services Friday 1pm at the ''Community Synagogue'', 150 Middleneck Road, Sands Point, N.Y.

title: 'High C'
description: Collages by Irwin Kremen

title: Nissan to Sell Its Tokyo Headquarters
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation, Japan's No. 2 car manufacturer, is selling its headquarters building in the tony Ginza district here, making another small step toward paring its mammoth debts.

title: Several top executives at Young & Rubicam are shifted 'to put people in the right positions.'
description: A CADRE of top executives at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York is being redeployed as the huge agency company seeks to build on the momentum gained from recent high-profile account assignments.

title: POLL FINDS CLINTON IN STRONG REBOUND SINCE VIDEO AIRING
description: President Clinton's standing with Americans has rebounded broadly in the days since the release of his videotaped testimony before a grand jury and, in fact, there are stirrings of a backlash against the Republican-controlled Congress and the House Judiciary Committee itself as it presses forward with an impeachment inquiry, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: AT&T-Yahoo Partnership
description: The AT&T Corporation has expanded its marketing partnership with Yahoo Inc., the No. 1 Internet search directory, to create a co-branded Internet service. AT&T had agreed with Yahoo in May to market its phone services on Yahoo's directory. The new service will be called Yahoo Online, powered by AT&T Worldnet Service. The Yahoo Online service will be available at an introductory subscription for $14.95 a month, the companies said.

title: Tie for McGwire and Sosa Seems the People's Choice
description: Sammy Sosa's two home runs Wednesday, matching Mark McGwire's total of 65, no doubt pleased the many Americans who would like to see this year's pursuit of the home run title end in a tie. According to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, 26 percent of adults would like to see McGwire hold the record for most home runs at the end of the season, 15 percent would prefer Sosa end up with the most, and 42 percent would rather they finish in a tie.

title: G.E. Agrees to Clean Part of Tainted River in Massachusetts
description: The General Electric Company has agreed to spend $150 million to $200 million to clean up a contaminated stretch of river in western Massachusetts in a settlement that Federal regulators described today as a significant victory for the environment and a city.

title: TBWA Chiat/Day Wins Top Obie Award
description: TBWA Chiat/Day in Playa del Rey, Calif., took top honors, winning Best of Show at the 56th annual Obie Awards for creative excellence sponsored by the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Ex-Officer of Blue Cross Is Sentenced to Jail
description: The former chief financial officer of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield was sentenced in Federal District Court yesterday to 18 months in jail after being convicted of trying to block a Senate investigation into the insurance company's financial problems, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan announced.

title: Wry Transformations In Doodles and Blankets
description: While Joseph Beuys (1921-1986) is widely revered in Europe, his cult remains mystifying to many people on this side of the Atlantic. An exhibition of drawings and large-scale sculpture from the 1970's, now at the Dia Center for the Arts in Chelsea, shows what it is about the influential German sculptor, performance artist, Conceptualist and grass-roots politician that makes him at once so annoying (his portentous theatricality) and compelling (the undeniable formal power of his best sculpture.)

title: Schumer and D'Amato Try to Out-Tough Each Other on Crime
description: Just two weeks old but already rancorous, the race for the Senate has become in large part an acid debate over crime, with Representative Charles E. Schumer and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato trading accusations almost daily that the other is soft on criminals.

title: Mets Make Playoff Bid In Atlanta
description: After six months and 159 games, the Mets' soap opera of a season now comes down to three days in Atlanta. It is there, beginning tonight, that they will have to try to beat the best team in the National League perhaps once, or twice, or maybe three straight times in order to capture the National League wild-card race outright or simply stay alive for a one- or two-game playoff on Monday and Tuesday.

title: With More Than 250 Dead in Caribbean, Storm Nears the Florida Keys
description: As the death toll from Hurricane Georges's rampage through the Caribbean rose to at least 250, the storm crossed Cuba today, turned northward and took aim at southern Florida, where a million people were advised to evacuate mobile homes and low-lying coastal areas.

title: 'Oprah' Staying At King World
description: Oprah Winfrey will keep King World Productions Inc. as the exclusive distributor of her top-rated talk show through 2002, a mixed blessing for King World, which gets most of its revenue from the program, though it will receive significantly less under the new agreement.

title: INSIDE
description: Joint Drive on Terrorism

title: Hoechst Announces Sale Of a Drug Subsidiary
description: Hoechst A.G. said yesterday that it had sold its generic drug subsidiary, Cox Japan Ltd., to Germany's Hexal A.G., effective retroactively to Aug. 1. Financial details of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Rowland's Opponent, Trailing In Polls, Begins TV Campaign
description: Trying to reignite her flagging campaign to unseat Gov. John G. Rowland, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly began her long-delayed television campaign today as the two met in the first of a series of back-to-back, head-to-head appearances.

title: Changes in Accounts Made by 3 Companies
description: Three marketers made changes yesterday on their accounts.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a film review of ''Shadrach'' on Wednesday misidentified the characters played by Andie MacDowell and Deborah Hedwall. It is Ms. MacDowell who plays ''the beer-swilling, warmhearted mother,'' Trixie Dabney. Ms. Hedwall, whose character is referred to as Mother in the film, plays the mother of another character, 10-year-old Paul Whitehurst.

title: Belgium Halts Expulsions After Police Kill a Refugee
description: BRUSSELS  The Belgian government said Thursday that it was suspending forced repatriations during an inquiry into the death of a 20-year-old refugee who was killed while being forcibly sent back to her native Nigeria.

title: Too Many Caesareans
description: To the Editor:

title: FALLEN STAR: THE MANAGERS -- An Alchemist Who Turned Gold Into Lead; Financial Wizard Done In By His Smoke and Mirrors
description: When Salomon Brothers, the swashbuckling Wall Street firm of the 1980's, was raking in the money -- hundreds of millions, even billions, of dollars -- investors would grin at one another and say, ''J. M.'s done it again.''

title: Uncomfortable Landings For That Guy in the Sky
description: LINDBERGH

title: Clinton to See Netanyahu And Arafat Next Week
description: President Clinton will meet separately with Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, at the White House next week in the hope of reviving peace talks in the Middle East, White House and State Department officials said today.

title: Where the World's Traditional Music Has Evolved Into a Local Tradition
description: Back in 1968, a folk-dance researcher and enthusiast, Martin Koenig, started the Balkan Arts Center to present concerts and dances with musicians from Crete and Romania. ''He would go and do his research overseas,'' said Ethel Raim, who joined him as a co-director of the center in 1975, ''and people would say, 'Hey, can you look up my cousin in New York?' And when he did, he would find musicians.''

title: 3 Luxury-Goods Makers Fall Victim to Asia
description: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., the Gucci Group N.V. and Diageo P.L.C., Europe's leading producers of luxury fashion goods and liquor, reported falling profits yesterday as consumers in Asia, caught up in recessions, lost their appetites for high-priced imports.

title: U.S. Directs International Drive on Bin Laden Networks
description: The United States is coordinating an effort with European and African nations to roll up the terrorist networks of Osama bin Laden, the suspected mastermind of the bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa, as fears mount that he will strike again, officials have said.

title: Bill Jensen and Leonardo Drew
description: Mary Boone Gallery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODRIGUEZ MOURELO, RAMON
description: RODRIGUEZ MOURELO-Ramon Died on September 23, 1998 from complications of cancer. Mr. Rodriguez, a native of O Incio in Galicia, Spain, was a businessman and civic leader in New York's Hispanic community. He came to New York in 1937 as a refugee of the Spanish civil war. He & his sister, Eva, were forced to flee Spain after their father was killed by fascist forces in Galicia. In the United States, he served honorably in the Army during World War II, participating in the Normandy invasion. He returned to military service during the Korean war when he joined the Navy and was assigned to the USS Yosemite. Mr. Rodriguez was a founder of the Desfile de la Raza and President of the Casa Galicia. He was also a past master of the Masonic lodge No. 751. He is survived by his wife, Stella Rodriguez, two sons-Ramon and Tomas from his previous marriage to Maria Iglesias, and his sister, Eva Portillo. He had four grandchildren, Tomas, Gabriel, Isabella and Julian. The wake will be at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home 117 West 72nd Street, and, today from 2 until 9 PM. A funeral service will be held at the Holy Name Church, 96 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Saturday, September 26, 1998, at 11:00 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Union Settlement Adult Education Program (212) 828-6015 or the Puerto Rican Hurricane Relief Fund at any branch of Banco Popular.

title: Surgeons in France Try Hand Transplant
description: Surgeons in France announced yesterday that they had attached the right hand and forearm of an anonymous donor to the arm of a 48-year-old Australian man whose own hand was amputated after a logging accident in 1989.

title: Island Nation Loses a Bridge As Philippine Airlines Fails
description: What happens when a sprawling island nation suddenly loses its national airline?

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Six Arrested In Drug Raid Near Times Sq.
description: Police officers last night raided a building near Times Square that had been transformed into a haven offering services and shelter for the poor, arresting six residents on charges that they had sold or possessed crack cocaine.

title: Movement to, and Beyond, the Rhythms of Jazz
description: Donald Byrd's choreography operates on an inventive level of sly wit that is both private and public. Hence, the double sense of mystery and accessibility in his dance pieces.

title: A Hedge Fund Crashes
description: The concept of ''too big to fail'' has now been extended to a huge hedge fund that was run by people thought to be financial wizards. The bailout of the fund by a consortium of the country's leading financial institutions is a reminder of how fragile the world's financial markets now are, and of the risks of making big bets that markets will act in predictable ways.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, DAVID
description: KATZ-David, Dr. 72. Of West Orange, NJ, Wednesday, Sept. 23rd, 1998. Beloved husband of Sarah. Devoted father of Lynn Galatt of West Orange, NJ, Eli of Santa Barbara, CA, Bert of Bedminster, NJ & Ira of Far Hills, NJ. Cherished father-in-law of Beth, Gale and Andrea. Dear brother of Harry of West Orange, NJ, the late Sidney & Faye. He is also survived by 7 grandchildren. Services were held on Thursday, September 24, 1998 at Ahavas Achim Bnai Jacob & David Synagogue, West Orange, NJ. Interment at King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. Contributions can be made to Ahavas Achim Bnai Jacob & David Synagogue and Solomon Schector Day School, West Orange, NJ. For further information contact Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, New Jersey, (973) 763-3505.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURGER, RUTH PAZEN
description: BURGER-Ruth Pazen. Wife of the late Irving Burger. Mother of John and Arthur Burger. Grandmother of Scott, Russel and Katie Burger. Sister of the late Rose Pazen and Anne Gotthardt. Retired from the Research Institute of America where she was Directing Editor of Executive Programs. Former Executive Director of the Association of Professional Art Advisors and volunteer docent of The Lighthouse. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Lighthouse, 111 E. 59 St., NY 10022. There will be a prayer meeting at her home at Noon, October 10.

title: View From Abroad: U.S. Policy Sapped by Scandal
description: Ask in Foggy Bottom, ask in Whitehall, ask on the Quai d'Orsay, ask at the Kremlin, and you get the same deeply discreet answer: No, of course, Bill Clinton's personal and political troubles have not impaired the capacity of the United States to conduct foreign policy. But scratch a little deeper, push a little harder, and you discover that diplomats and politicians in most of the world's major nations are worried sick by the spectacle of a distracted President in Washington at a moment when, in their view at least, bold American leadership is all but indispensable.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PFIZER INC., New York, the nation's No. 4 drug maker, said it would buy back as much as $5 billion of its common shares.

title: TV Networks Failing to Give Content Alerts
description: One year after the television networks revised their movie-style ratings code to add labels alerting parents to sexual or violent content in shows, a study has found that the networks are not regularly adding the labels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUSTON, HOWARD E.
description: HOUSTON-Howard E., 87. Of Bloomfield, died on Monday, September 21st, 1998 at Duncaster. Husband of the late Frances (Crawford) Houston, he was born in Ryan, Iowa, and was a graduate of Columbia University. In Connecticut, Mr. Houston served from 1935-54 as the builder and first Executive Director of the Bradley Home in Meriden. He was elected and served three terms as Mayor of Meriden from 1948-51 and 196263. Governor John Davis Lodge appointed him Commissioner of Welfare from 1953-54. Concurrently his brother, Raymond Houston, was the Welfare Commissioner for the state of New York. In 1992, Mr. Houston was inducted into the Meriden Hall of Fame. With the U.S. State Department, Mr. Houston served the U.S. Agency for International Development in India, Korea and Peru under the Ambassadorships of John Sherman Cooper, Ellsworth Bunker, Kenneth Keating and Daniel P. Moynihan. Among his awards were the Mugunghwa Medal, Order of Civil Merit from President Park Chung Hee of Korea and the Superior Honor Award of the Agency for International Development, U.S. Department of State. He is survived by a son, Attorney Frederick W Houston, his wife, Eileen, and their children, Clay K. and Justin C. Houston of Newfane, VT. He is also survived by a daughter, Molly H. Savard, her husband, Edward and their sons, Nicholas H. and Turner H. Savard. A Service to honor the memories of both Mr. Houston ahd his wife will be held Monday, October 19, 1998, 11:00am at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, 20 Catlin St, Meriden. Burial will be at the convenience of the family. There will be no visiting hours. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Bradley Home, 320 Colony Street, Meriden, Connecticut 06451 or to a charity of the donor's choice. The Dillon-Baxter Funeral Home, Wethersfield for information.

title: Officials Assess Impact Of a Fed-Brokered Deal
description: The Clinton Administration played down today the potential risks to the financial system from Long-Term Capital Management L.P.'s brush with collapse, but the fund's fall raised questions in Congress about whether regulators can keep up with the increasing complexity and speed of the markets.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: The Hard Life Of a Herd

title: A Racial Gap at Southern Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Orders Cleaner Air In 22 States
description: In a step meant to control the windblown smog that drifts across state lines toward the Northeast, the Environmental Protection Agency today ordered 22 states to significantly reduce emissions of nitrogen oxides, the main pollutant that causes smog.

title: Jostling and Stumbling Toward a Fateful 15 Minutes
description: At the opening of this year's New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center tonight, the scene will be one of quintessential, flashbulb-popping New York life in the fast lane -- and some of that may even be off screen. But the main attraction is a look at Manhattan's brand of specious fame through Woody Allen's not unexpectedly jaundiced eye in ''Celebrity.''

title: British Current Account Shows Surplus in Quarter
description: Britain said yesterday that its current account showed a surplus of $:600 million ($1 billion) in the second quarter as economic growth slowed to a pace that economists said was more sustainable than before. The surplus compares with a deficit of $:497 million in the first quarter, as less money was paid to the European Union during the quarter. It reflects a rising surplus on trade in services and a smaller deficit in trade in goods, confounding market forecasts of a $:2 billion deficit.

title: Presenting News in a Time of Scandal Becomes a Delicate Balancing Act
description: It has been an unequal contest. Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico versus the possibility of impeachment proceedings. International economic breakdowns versus an unprecedented video of President Clinton defending himself during questioning about intimate sex acts with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Hermes Had 16% Profit Gain in First Half
description: Hermes International, France's third-biggest luxury good maker, said first-half profit increased 16 percent as revenue from leather goods helped offset a decline for luxury silks.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Blood on Bronze

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASS, MORRIS I.
description: HASS-Morris I., Esq. Beloved husband of Sheila. Loving father of Jeffrey and Nancy, and Stephen and Margaret. Loving grandfather of Erin, Debra, Sarah and Samuel. Beloved brother of Helen Breger. A prince amongst men. Services ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 B'way, Hewlett, L.I., 2PM, Friday.

title: Too Many Caesareans
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Try to Shift Scandal's Glare to G.O.P.
description: When the report of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, landed like a bombshell on Capitol Hill, the devastating questions all concerned President Clinton's behavior. But in the weeks since then, Democrats have done everything they can to refocus the spotlight onto Congressional Republicans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, WILL
description: KAPLAN-Will. Died on September 23 after a two and a half month struggle following heart surgery on July 10. He was 89 years of age. Survivors include his wife of almost 20 years, Evelyn Rypins Kaplan and his nieces and nephews: Connie and Jules Kay, Charlotte and Paul Schwartz, Gladys and Leonard Davitch, Rosalind and Marty Rodman, Sara and Don Nelson. We are all very sad. At Will's request he will cremated and the memorial will be in the hearts of his survivors.

title: Who Is to Blame for Mr. Starr's Witch Hunt?; Another Show Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUGASTRY, SARAH
description: ZUGASTRY-Sarah. Beloved wife of the late Izrael. Loving mother of Evelyn (Sidney) Willig and Lila Porges. Devoted grandmother of five. Great-grandmother of nine.

title: Black and Hispanic Poverty Falls, Reducing Overall Rate for Nation
description: The proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, mostly because of reductions in poverty among black and Hispanic families, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: A City Officer And 3 Others Are Shot Dead
description: A New York City police officer, a woman believed to be his girlfriend and her two small children were found shot to death last night at her home in Orange County, N.Y., in what the police said was an apparent murder-suicide.

title: New Jersey Turnpike Link Dealt Setback by E.P.A.
description: In the latest setback for New Jersey's longest-pending highway project, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it was opposed to a $300 million, high-speed, limited-access highway that would connect the New Jersey Turnpike with the thriving business corridor along Route 1 in the central part of the state.

title: QUAKER FABRIC SHARES DECLINE TO A 52-WEEK LOW
description: Shares of the Quaker Fabric Corporation fell 44 percent yesterday to a 52-week low after it said fiscal third- and fourth-quarter earnings would be significantly below expectations because of problems related to a computer-system update. Quaker Fabric stock fell $4.03125, to $4.96875, on trading of 3 million shares. The manufacturer of woven fabrics for home furnishings said it expected earnings of 3 cents to 5 cents a share for the third quarter, which ends Oct. 3, and 20 cents to 25 cents for the fourth quarter. Analysts surveyed by First Call had predicted earnings of 31 cents a share in the third quarter and 35 cents a share in the fourth.

title: Regulating Supplements Might Rob Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Gain in South Asia
description: Four months after shocking the world with their nuclear tests, India and Pakistan have declared their intention to sign a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty. The announcement could reduce tensions in one of the most volatile parts of the world. But before the United States can lift economic sanctions imposed in response to the nuclear blasts last May, it should press India and Pakistan to reach additional curbs on the production of weapons-grade nuclear material and the development and deployment of missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.

title: Soros in Venezuelan Deal
description: George Soros has increased his stake in the Venezuelan real estate company Fondo de Valores Inmobiliarios SACA, picking up an additional 20 percent in the company for $20 million earlier this month, the newspaper El Nacional reported today. The latest purchase puts Mr. Soros's share at about 34.5 percent. Mr. Soros also owns shares in Banco Provincial S.A., Banco Caracas S.A., Nacional Telefonos de Venezuela and C.A. Electricidad de Caracas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, SAMUEL
description: BAUM-Samuel. To our dear friends Barbara and Arthur Lerner, we express our deepest sympathy on the loss of your beloved father. Lee and Jeffrey Feil

title: Street Closings
description: Because of the annual debate at the United Nations, through Monday there will be intermittent closings of First Avenue between 41st and 48th Streets; the 42d Street exit of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, and streets around the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at Park Avenue and 50th Street. Other street closings and detours are also possible elsewhere in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Filofax Accepts A Takeover Bid
description: Filofax Group P.L.C. agreed today to accept Day Runner Inc.'s $:50.3 million ($84 million) revised takeover bid just one day after the United States company made its unsolicited offer.

title: Journal; More Joy of Sex
description: Don't listen to the Clinton lackeys' bitter gripes about Henry Hyde's impending impeachment show. It's hard to imagine what Judiciary Committee investigating this President could be more qualified -- and bipartisan -- than this one. Both Mr. Hyde, its chairman, and Barney Frank, its ranking Democrat, have had their own embarrassing sexual adventures exposed for all the world to see. Who better than these guys to render justice on Mr. Clinton's seemingly perjurious efforts to parse the sex out of oral sex?

title: James Lavenson, 79, Marketer Who Once Headed the Plaza Hotel
description: James H. Lavenson, an advertising and marketing expert known for public speeches that were both hilarious and instructive, died Sept. 19 at Penobscot Bay Medical Center in Rockport, Me., following a stroke, his wife, Susan, said. He was 79.

title: Corrections
description: The Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday misidentified the singer in one role for the performance of ''The Barber of Seville'' by the New York City Opera at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow at the New York State Theater. Daniel Mobbs, not Shon Sims, will play Figaro.

title: Plan B Turns Into 2-0 Hole For U.S.
description: On a slow hard court that gobbled up the hosts like quicksand and became a magic carpet for the visitors, the United States Davis Cup team stumbled into a double ambush today in its semifinal against Italy. An unanticipated home-court disaster left the favorites dangling one match from elimination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRENNER, SIDNEY
description: PRENNER-Sidney. 88. Passed away on Thursday September 10th after a long illness. He leaves his beloved wife Martha, three children and eight grandchildren, each of whom he was so very loving, caring and proud. He will be remembered in the hearts of his survivors.

title: Santa Catarina Journal; Drug Gangs' Deadly Toll: Indian Villagers in Baja
description: After five centuries of killing and pestilence that began with the Spanish conquest, only a few hundred of Baja California's indigenous people are left alive. And now they are being hunted down and killed by drug traffickers.

title: Father's Conviction Dismissed in Recanted Case of Sex Abuse
description: Six months after a young woman recanted graphic accusations of sexual abuse against her father, a judge threw out the father's conviction today and said it was unlikely that a retrial would succeed.

title: Washington's Passing Concerns Nebraska
description: Three games, three quarterbacks, three victories. It appears that the Frank Solich era at Nebraska has picked up where Tom Osborne left off. But it has not been as easy as 1-2-3. Nebraska's injured list has looked like a Big 12 all-conference team.

title: Queens Student Sued Over McGwire Ball
description: A Queens high school student was sued yesterday over the ball that Mark McGwire hit last Sunday for what some fans thought was his 66th home run of the season.

title: About New York; Gone West, And Pickin' Up Bad Vibrations
description: I RECENTLY moved to Silicon Valley, and I am constantly homesick for all aspects of New York life,'' Rosemary Shashoua wrote in a recent E-mail. ''Please write a column regarding this feeling.''

title: Obsession and Obliquity in Gay Hollywood
description: ''Gods and Monsters'' is an unalloyed success at the New York Film Festival, with a performance by Ian McKellen that richly deserves to be remembered at the end of the year. Like John Hurt in ''Love and Death on Long Island'' (giving a similarly splendid performance, though in a narrower role), he works wonders with the character of a marvelously urbane English homosexual who becomes obsessed with an Adonis from a wildly different world. In this case it's Brendan Fraser, also impressive, as the hunk who mows the lawn.

title: Those Glorious Pre-Detente Days
description: Announcing the

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSHKIN, PHILIP
description: GRUSHKIN-Philip. Of Englewood, NJ on September 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Jean (nee Glasser). Devoted father of Dena Florczyk, Paul and Jonas Grushkin. Dear brother of Stanley and Daniel. Cherished nephew of Frances Sharpe. Loving grandfather of Jessica, Jordan, Aaron, Colin, Jack and Rebecca. Services Temple Emanu-El, 147 Tenafly Rd., Englewood, NJ on Sunday, September 27, 1998 at 9:00 AM. Contributions to Hackensack University Medical Center Cardiac Unit would be appreciated. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: Backlash at Republicans Raises Hopes
description: After months of enduring withering attacks for President Clinton's relationship with a White House intern, Democrats are turning the Republican zeal to punish him into a rallying cry.

title: COMING ON SUNDAY: WINNING IS THE ONLY THING
description: George Steinbrenner is still a control freak, but he has learned to control himself. His team responded in historic fashion. But what will make him happy? A report by Buster Olney, plus a 1998 Yankee portfolio by Joyce Tenneson. The Mahazine.

title: INTERNATIONAL HOME FOODS PLANS EARNINGS CHARGE
description: International Home Foods Inc. said yesterday that it would take $119 million in pretax charges against third-quarter earnings to close two factories, dismiss about 525 workers and write down the value of its Campfire snack bar and Polaner fruit spread businesses. Shares in the maker of Chef Boyardee pasta and Bumble Bee tuna fell $1.375, to $14.625. The company said $41 million of the charge would be used to close its factories in Vacaville, Calif., and Clearfield, Utah, and $78 million would be used to reduce the value of the Polaner and Campfire snack bar businesses.

title: Charges of Research Fraud Arise at a Cornell AIDS Lab
description: Cornell University officials say they are investigating allegations of scientific misconduct against the head of one of the university's largest immunology and AIDS-related research labs, who is a recipient of more than $2 million in Federal money.

title: Sports of the Times; Run to the Wire, Chase to the End
description: SAMMY SOSA is the symbol of a great baseball season coming to a close.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTNAM, PETER BROCK.
description: PUTNAM-Peter Brock. Died peacefully in his sleep at his Princeton, N.J. home September 23, after a two year battle with lymphoma. The noted blind lecturer, author, teacher and fundraiser for non-profit organizations was 78 years old. He was born June 11, 1920, in Fort Oglethorpe, Georgia, the son of Brock and Marguerite Faber Putnam. He is survived by his wife Durinda Dobbins Putnam, his children, Brock, Barbara and John Gerry and two grandchildren Benjamin Brock Hamlet Putnam and Emma Berson Putnam and a sister, Theodora Downing of Annapolis, Maryland. A memorial service will be held Sunday, October 4 at 4PM at the Princeton Unitarian Church. Memorial contributions may be made to Recording for the Blind & Dyslexic, 12A Hibben Rd, Princeton, N.J. 08540.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTMAN, IRVING
description: LITTMAN-Irving. Beloved husband of the late Minnie, father of Madelyn, father-in-law of Frank Wagner, and companion of Eleanor Dorf. Adored grandfather of Emily and Molly Wagner. Brother of Sadie Frieser and Shirley Silberstein. Died September 24, 1998. Services Sunday 1:30 PM at The Larchmont Temple, 75 Larchmont Avenue. For further information, contact John J. Fox Funeral home: 914-834-0144

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRISALLI, JOSEPH P.
description: CRISALLI-Joseph P. Devoted husband of Josephine, beloved brother of the late Anthony (Ninny), fond uncle and dear friend. In Repose Raccuglia & Son 321-323 Court Street, Bklyn. 718-855-7737. Visitation 2 PM-9 PM Saturday.

title: Boys' Release In a Murder Doesn't End A City's Pain
description: Chicago remains rattled over the case of an 11-year-old girl who was sexually molested and killed this summer in a patch of weeds in a poor South Side neighborhood. Two months after her death, the case has taken extraordinary twists and turns.

title: Crew Moves to Increase Monitoring of Principals
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is stepping up the monitoring of New York City's 1,100 principals and setting the stage to begin ousting principals for ''educational failure.''

title: FINGERHUT TO TERMINATE DIVIDEND TO BUY ITS STOCK
description: The Fingerhut Companies said yesterday that it would terminate payment of quarterly dividends of 4 cents and use those funds instead to immediately begin repurchasing stock.The company, a data base marketing concern, said it would take a third-quarter charge of $31 million to position it for growth as it completes its tax-free spinoff of its 83 percent-owned financial services unit, Metris Companies. Fingerhut will also take a third-quarter noncash charge to write down its distribution center in Utah. And it will incur an additional third-quarter charge as part of its internal cost-reduction program. Also, an extraordinary charge will be incurred to refinance its $120 million in privately placed senior notes.

title: The Name's Mavrovic, and He's Out to Stop Lewis
description: It is not easy being Zeljko Mavrovic. Virtually ignored as he prepares to take on Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, in a title bout Saturday night, his name is mangled so much that he simply wants to be referred to as ''Zed.''

title: Celebrities Call Starr a Fanatic And Inquisitor
description: A letter protesting Kenneth W. Starr's investigation of President Clinton, presented in Thursday in Paris, has been signed by an international roster of writers, scholars and actors, including Bishop Desmond Tutu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner from South Africa; Gabriel Garcia Marquez and William Styron, Pulitzer-Prize winning authors; the actresses Emma Thompson and Lauren Bacall and the singer Jessye Norman.

title: Killer Hurricane Slams Into Keys
description: After leaving nearly 300 people dead in a five-day rampage across the Caribbean, Hurricane Georges slammed into the Florida Keys today with winds of over 100 miles per hour, causing widespread flooding and extensive damage to buildings, roads and harbors but apparently no deaths.

title: Author Banned By British Air
description: British Airways said today that it would not permit the writer Salman Rushdie to fly on its planes, despite Iran's assurances that it would not carry out its death sentence against Mr. Rushdie.

title: A Campaign Secret:The Emergence of Right-Wing Extremism
description: DRESDEN  Throughout their campaigns, Helmut Kohl and Gerhard Schroeder kept clear of the issue of emerging right-wing extremism with an agility they usually reserved for avoiding specifics on how they would create new jobs, save money and sustain Germany's enormous social welfare system all at the same time.

title: Tolerance and the Generation Gap
description: Some young women say: Let she who is free of all Monica-style sin cast the first stone. Others say: Blame the powerful man who cheats, not the weak woman who helps him. Still others say: She was wrong. But Lord, the punishment of having every desperate, lovelorn detail bared to the entire country!

title: No Letup in Home Run Race: 66 and 66, Just Minutes Apart
description: In a remarkable bit of long-distance theater, Sammy Sosa and Mark McGwire exchanged home runs 45 minutes apart last night, enhancing a home run duel that had already captivated the attention of fans and nonfans everywhere.

title: Vague, Yes, But Schroder Could Unseat Chancellor
description: With a promise to restore ''social justice to Germany'' and with a flash of his winning smile, Gerhard Schroder today wound up his campaign to replace Helmut Kohl as Chancellor in elections on Sunday.

title: Outcry in Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Sosa Fires First Shot In the Fourth
description: Truman defeats Dewey. David knocks out Goliath. Sosa beats McGwire? The underdog scenario has had two hours of life during the Great Home Run Race of 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEHLIN, ROSALIE (NEE BREEN).
description: STEHLIN-Rosalie (nee Breen). Beloved wife of the late Charles V. Stehlin on September 16, 1998. Devoted mother of Elizabeth. Loving grandmother of Bronwen, Lee & Merrick. Cherished great-grandmother of Ethan. Survived by her dearest sister, Pat, and dear ''Auntie Lee'' to her many devoted nieces and nephews. Governor Emeritus The Arthritis Foundation, NY Chapter. Past President Manhattanville College Alumnae Association. Past Chairman United Hospital Fund Nursing Home, long term care. Member of Women's Auxiliary of Lenox Hill Hospital. Services will be held at 9:15 AM, on Tuesday, September 29, at St. Joachim RC Church, 614 Central Ave, Cedarhurst, L.I. Interment private, family only. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Arthritis Foundation, NY Chapter, would be deeply appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANN, EDITH, DR.
description: GANN-Edith, Dr. 1905-1998, psychologist & educator. She was the youngest principal in NJ. She received her doctorate from Columbia University. Dr. Gann was active in the alumni association where she received an award for her devoted service. Her book on Reading Difficulty & Personality Organization was used in many schools as a text book. She also wrote other books. Dr. Gann is the beloved aunt of Robin, Carla, Victor, Erik & Cory. Her family & friends will miss her. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Jewish Community Foundation of Metro West, NJ in her memory. A graveside service will be held on Sunday 9/27/98 at noon at Oheb Sholom Cemetery, 1321 No. Broad St, Hillside, NJ. In the near future a memorial service will be held at Columbia University. For further information call Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Funeral Home at 973-763-3505.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RADL, DR. LUCIA
description: RADL-Dr. Lucia, born in Odessa, Russia in 1900, passed away on September 20, 1998 at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City. A physician and psychiatrist, Dr. Radl was trained in Europe and in the United States. Professionally active for many decades, she was on the staffs of the Joint Diseases Hospital and Lenox Hill, and served as a Senior Analyst and Faculty Superviser at the Alfred Adler Institute of New York. She was an emeritus member of the American Medical Association & belonged to the North American Society of Adlerian Psychology. Dr. Radl was also the author of numerous articles & professional manuals. She will be missed by family, friends and colleagues. Funeral was private. A memorial gathering will be held for her on November 1, 1998 from 2-4PM at the Olcott Hotel, 27 West 72 St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, please donate to the charity of your choice.

title: Peanut Butter as a Health Threat
description: Reports of some schools adopting peanut-free zones in lunchrooms and even total peanut butter bans may sound like a freakish health fad, but there have been rare cases where children who were severely allergic to peanuts have died after coming into contact with peanuts in school. With increased reports of food allergies among children, the impetus to protect the susceptible is understandable.

title: Milking Fantasies of Desire
description: Suppress that wish, buddy. You might have it hurled back into your gut until you understand what an idiot you were to dream it in the first place.

title: Yeltsin Plugs a Hole in His Kremlin Team, but Then Two New Ones Appear
description: Ending an agonizing deliberation that held world financial markets and national politics in its thrall, President Boris N. Yeltsin finally chose a Finance Minister for Russia's new Government today.

title: Kingfisher Agrees To Castorama Deal
description: The British retailer Kingfisher P.L.C. agreed yesterday to merge B&Q, its home-improvement business, with Castorama Dubois Investissements of France. Under the terms of the proposed deal, Kingfisher would exchange 100 percent of B&Q for a 54.6 percent stake in the fully diluted equity of an enlarged Castorama, worth $4 billion. The deal calls for Castorama to issue 22 million new shares in payment to Kingfisher.

title: Lawmaker Uses Own Experience to Urge Measured Approach
description: As a lawyer and former Federal judge, Representative Alcee L. Hastings has more than a passing familiarity with the Constitution. And his reading tells him that Congress is badly mishandling the impeachment process.

title: Rushdie, Free of Threat, Revels in 'Spontaneity'
description: What he longed for most of all, Salman Rushdie said today, describing nine years of living under a death sentence that clouded his every thought, was the simple freedom to open his door and stroll casually down the street.

title: House Rejects Expanded Trade Power for President
description: The House today rejected legislation to give expanded trade negotiating authority to President Clinton.

title: Mayor Vetoes Bill to Tighten Limits on Campaign Giving
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani vetoed a bill yesterday that seeks to curb the influence of money in municipal elections, but the move was largely symbolic because the leadership of the City Council has pledged a speedy override.

title: Air France Revenue Fell in Latest Quarter
description: Air France said yesterday that first-quarter revenue fell 4.7 percent, hurt by a 10-day pilot strike that disrupted France's plans for a 4 billion franc ($712 million) public offering of shares in the airline. Revenue in the three months ended June 30 fell to 13.85 billion francs ($2.47 billion).

title: Slipping In and Out of Phase With Steve Reich
description: We may all be taught that form follows function, but for the ever-brilliant Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, form generates meaning.

title: Second Setback for Advocates of Census Sampling
description: Federal judges in Virginia have dealt another setback to the Clinton Administration's plans to use statistical sampling in the 2000 census, agreeing with judges in Washington that use of the technique would be illegal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANDA, RAJIV KRISHAN.
description: NANDA-Rajiv Krishan. On September 18, 1998, beloved husband of Rema, father of Arjun Scott, son of Sudershan and Satyender and brother of Vikram and Sandip. Funeral services Saturday, Sept. 26th, 9:45AM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Contributions in Rajiv's memory may be made to the U.S. Committee for UNICEF, Tribute Card Program for Rajiv Nanda, 333 East 38th Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: McGwire Responds In the Fifth
description: Somewhere along this mesmerizing chase, Mark McGwire fixed his Windex blue eyes on the world around him and discovered the effect of his marvelous journey with Sammy Sosa.

title: Clinton Casts The Congress As Do-Nothing
description: Cheered by polls that appear to show the beginnings of a backlash against Congressional Republicans for a seeming preoccupation with the Lewinsky scandal, President Clinton today criticized them for a lack of action on spending bills and other legislation.

title: Coke Expects Flat Earnings This Quarter
description: Painting a bleaker picture than many analysts had foreseen, the Coca-Cola Company disclosed yesterday that its short-term business results had been severely battered by global economic upheaval.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about bans on peanut butter in some schools misattributed its invention. While George Washington Carver developed many uses for peanuts and helped popularize peanut butter, its precise origins have long been debated. Dr. John H. Kellogg received a patent in 1897 for a process to produce ''nutmeal,'' a substance like peanut butter.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Face-Off Looms as Deadline Nears on Spending Bills
description: With nine working days until the deadline for approving money to keep the Government running, President Clinton is facing the first real test of his power in dealing with the Republican-controlled Congress since the effort to impeach him engulfed the Capitol.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUECK, RHETA
description: GLUECK-Rheta. On September 23rd. Daughter of Ella and David. A medical writer, she served overseas with the American Red Cross. Dear cousin to many. Graveside service Sunday, 11AM, at the Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale, New York.

title: Congress Should Ignore the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Detour in Brazil; Global Crisis Pushes Car Makers Into the Slow Lane
description: The Volkswagen factory here was built for better days. Thanks to aggressive streamlining over the last four years, the plant's 2,304 shift workers, 137 robots and miles of machinery send another boxy Gol subcompact or Parati station wagon into the world every 90 seconds.

title: Divining the Impact of Georges
description: There are many ways to measure the force of a storm -- by rainfall, tide height and wind speed, by the number of utility customers inconvenienced or residents displaced, by the damage in dollars or human lives. But none of these measures the profound psychological force of a storm like Hurricane Georges, which has devastated the Caribbean and southern Florida over the last few days.

title: Observer; Rube Goes to Town
description: I spent four days in New York. It was swell.

title: Victory Establishes A.L. Mark
description: Joe Torre made his way through the clubhouse shaking hands last night, the first manager in the 98 years of the American League to congratulate his players on 112 victories.

title: Troubled Investment Fund's Bets Now Estimated at $1.25 Trillion
description: The speculative investment fund rescued by a consortium of Wall Street banks this week made complex bets on international financial markets with a total value drastically higher than previously estimated, financiers who studied its books said yesterday.

title: New Voices Take On Evergreen Rossini
description: One of the unwritten mandates of the New York City Opera is presentable productions of the standard repertory offered at affordable prices. Thursday night's return of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' checked out nicely. It also gave us a look at some interesting young singers.

title: Jeffrey Moss, 56, Writer and Father of Cookie Monster, Dies
description: Jeffrey A. Moss, a writer and composer whose accomplishments included dreaming up the ''Sesame Street'' characters Cookie Monster and Oscar the Grouch, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 56.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKACH, MARION L.
description: LUKACH-Marion L. The Board of Directors, clinical and administrative staff and volunteers of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of Marion L. Lukach, a beloved Director for more than 30 years, life-long volunteer and benefactor of the agency's home care and public health services. Her interest in nursing education and patient care, especially maternal and child health care, improved the health and well-being of countless New Yorkers. Her unwavering support of the agency for more than 50 years and commitment to high quality, compassionate healthcare will be remembered always. We extend our profound sympathy to her son, Arthur Lukach, a member of our Board of Directors, her daughter, Ellen Perlmutter, and to her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Douglas D. Broadwater Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO

title: Sports of The Times; Bumpy Air On Flight To Playoffs
description: BOBBY COX knows how to handle the last weekend of the season.

title: Go West, Young Men, to Snap Slide
description: When the dates for the 1998 National Football League schedule arrived in the Giants' offices earlier this year, three games stood out: at Oakland, at San Diego, at San Francisco.

title: Dow Ends With Small Gain on Expectation of a Rate Cut
description: Stocks recovered from sharp morning losses yesterday to end the session and the week with gains.

title: Albright Hopes for Progress in Mideast Talks
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is preparing to open a round of shuttle diplomacy on American soil, traveling between Washington and the United Nations in New York in the hope of securing progress in talks between Israel and the Palestinians, Administration officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fallen Hedge Fund's Bets Are Put at $1.25 Trillion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PENICK, MARGEN RILEY.
description: PENICK-Margen Riley. Wife of the late Dr. S.B. Penick, beloved mother of Elizabeth Romanaux, Barksdale Penick and Julia Garry, beloved sister of Dr. Fenwick Riley, Nancy Newhouse Iovenko, Mary Riley Smith and William Terence Riley. The funeral service will be 1 PM, Monday at Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton NJ. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Friends of Princeton Open Space, POB 374, Princeton, New Jersey 08542.

title: AMERICANS LACKING HEALTH INSURANCE PUT AT 16 PERCENT
description: Despite the booming economy, the number of people without health insurance rose sharply last year, to 43.4 million, and the proportion of Americans lacking coverage reached the highest level in a decade, 16.1 percent, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Bosnia Results Confirm Serb Hard-Liner's Victory, and Gains by Moderates
description: Election results released today by international officials confirmed the victory of the extreme nationalist candidate, Nikola Poplasen, as president of the Bosnian Serb portion of this country.

title: Fiscal Stones, Glass Houses: Bailout Points Finger at U.S.
description: If there has been a single refrain as economic shock waves rolled around the world for the last year, it is the importance of spotting and addressing financial risks before they get out of control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YABLOKOFF, JACK
description: YABLOKOFF-Jack. Most beloved husband and best friend of Helen Schraub Yablokoff. Cherished and loving father and fatherin-law of Randy, Susan and Michael Minoff, Robin and Larry Kaufman. Adored grandfather of Matthew, Meredith, Erica, Amanda and Jared. Founder of Yablokoff's Kingsway Memorial Chapel, Juilliard educated cellist and proud member of the Brooklyn Trio, in addition to many other chamber music groups. He was well loved, well respected, and the legacy he leaves will inspire us all. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at the Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel, 1978 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, (SEFF) VIOLA,
description: GOLDBERG-(Seff) Viola, at 92. Beloved wife of the late Henry Goldberg and the late Manny Seff. Devoted mother of Kate & Gerry Beswick, of London, and Vicki Winteringham. Loving grandmother of Kefi Beswick, affectionate stepmother of Dr. William Ruberman and the late Janet Ruberman. Step-grandmother of Dr. Louise and Arie Buckheister and Daniel and Ann Ruberman. Survived by five great step-grandchildren. A woman of great charm, intelligence and beauty, she devoted her time and energy to relationships with family and friends, the pursuit of art and learning & an intense involvement in philanthropic causes. She was a member of the Board of Trustees of Beth Israel Hospital where she was actively involved in developing innovative programs in hospice care & in the hospital nursing school. Funeral services will be held on Monday, September 28 at 9:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: Ex-Police Officer Sentenced in Shooting
description: A former New York City police officer who shot his former wife's boyfriend was sentenced to five years' probation yesterday, the Bronx District Attorney's office said.

title: Analysts See Positive Signs In Latin American Turmoil
description: With increasing signs that world lenders are preparing to rescue Brazil from a potential financial meltdown, Wall Street analysts say that outflows of capital are slowing from stock markets from Mexico City to Buenos Aires.

title: TRIARC EXPECTS TO REPORT 3D-QUARTER INCOME DROP
description: The Triarc Companies said yesterday that it expected to report lower third-quarter earnings because of higher taxes, losses from equity interest in a company and other unusual or nonoperating factors. Triarc said it expected a significant increase in third-quarter cash flow on strong results from its Snapple beverage and Arby's restaurants. A First Call Corporation survey of five analysts put the company's third-quarter earnings at 37 cents a share. The company expects an increase in its premium beverage cash flow, led by a more than 10 percent volume increase for Snapple.

title: Pirandello In a Spirit Of Elegance And Gloom
description: A Pirandellian spirit of intricate despair governs the Taviani brothers' ''You're Laughing,'' though in visual terms these filmmakers are never far from life-affirming beauty. Their latest film is an odd composite, moving from the dark confinement of an accountant's office to the gloriously rugged hills of Sicily in search of the unifying vision that it never truly finds.

title: Congress Should Ignore the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Replace H.M.O.'s With Universal Care; End the Link
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC OFFER FILING FOR PCS GROUP IS SET
description: The Sprint Corporation yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of $603.75 million of common shares for its PCS Group. Sprint, based in Kansas City, Mo., is a diversified telecommunications company. PCS Group, to be formed on completion of the offering, will consist of Sprint's domestic wireless telephone and personal communications businesses. It will include the operations of Sprint Spectrum Holdings, Phillieco and Sprintcom.

title: In SoHo, Consumerism Is an Art; High-End Stores Help Re-create Madison Ave. Downtown
description: A uniformed security guard stands by the door of the imposing new Louis Vuitton store on Greene Street. Inside, fashionably dressed couples, many from Europe or Japan, eye the rich leather bags arranged one to a shelf like exemplars of a rare type of ancient pottery. Downstairs, clothes are displayed with a studied casualness -- a long skirt here, a jacket there. A steamer trunk with a price tag of $25,000 rests on the highly polished floor.

title: Mets Drop a Big One, and It's a 3-Ring Circus
description: The year of the home runs is quickly becoming the season of rookie mistakes, as well.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: About Life, Death and the Pause That Separates Them
description: In Margaret Edson's new play ''Wit,'' Kathleen Chalfant plays Vivian Bearing, a literature professor whose speciality is the 17th-century poet John Donne. The 50-year-old teacher, who wrote her thesis on Donne's sonnet ''Death be not proud'' -- with special consideration given to the punctuation -- now finds herself in a hospital ward, dying of cancer. In this scene, Vivian flashes back to her graduate school days.

title: Replace H.M.O.'s With Universal Care; Home Inspections
description: To the Editor:

title: Yeltsin Tries to Turn Back Tide of Vodka
description: Reining in Russia's boundless thirst for illicit, untaxed and therefore cheap vodka is easy. President Boris N. Yeltsin's Government has already done it dozens of times.

title: Replace H.M.O.'s With Universal Care
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says Bin Laden Aide Tried to Get Nuclear Material
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that a man they described as a senior deputy to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile suspected in last month's bombings of two United States Embassies in Africa, tried on behalf of the bin Laden group in 1993 to obtain materials that could be used to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Congress Should Ignore the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulating Supplements Might Rob Consumers
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Sign Harvey for Line
description: By signing Todd Harvey yesterday, the Rangers bolstered their strength at right wing and cut their missing persons list to one.

title: POLITICS IS DRIVING JONES SETTLEMENT
description: In an effort to give President Clinton a stronger position as Congress considers impeachment proceedings, his lawyers are in the final stages of reaching a settlement with Paula Corbin Jones in her sexual misconduct lawsuit, advisers to both parties said today.

title: Home Resales Down but Still Remain High
description: Home resales declined last month but remained near a record level, while consumer spending rebounded, a sign of the economy's stamina.

title: Rivals Have Found Little to Fight Over In German Election
description: As a hard-fought German election campaign comes to a vote on Sunday, one of the most striking features is that the two leading parties are fighting about very little.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about an appeals court ruling supporting the Pentagon's policy on homosexuals in the military misstated the basis of the decision. The court ruled in favor of the ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy because of what it considered the special circumstances of the military, not because it found the policy nondiscriminatory.

title: Profits of Hedge Fund Insiders Appear to Be Off but Still Big
description: Despite the huge losses and shattered reputations that have resulted from the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the firm's 16 partners still appear to be sitting on gains in their original investments in the hedge fund they managed.

title: Replace H.M.O.'s With Universal Care; Success at Rikers
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are less vulnerable than any other nation in the world by a huge margin. But we are nonetheless vulnerable.''

title: In Five Years, a Nobody Becomes Somebody
description: In 1993, only one person in America could possibly have foreseen the day when Conan O'Brien would be so popular on late-night television that NBC would hand him an hour of prime time to celebrate his fifth anniversary on the air:

title: Hampton May Upstage Williams
description: All the hoopla will surround Doug Williams, the coach with the National Football League background, Super Bowl ring and legacy to follow. But at the conclusion of the 28th annual New York Urban League Football Classic today, Coach Joe Taylor and his Hampton University Pirates are very likely to be the ones in the spotlight.

title: Beauvoir Emerges From Sartre's Shadow; Some Even Dare to Call Her a . . . Philosopher
description: ''I don't consider myself a philosopher,'' Simone de Beauvoir wrote in the second volume of her autobiography. For decades, most philosophers have agreed with her.

title: A $3.44 BILLION CONTRACT WITH NASA IS AWARDED
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the nation's second-biggest military and aerospace company, said yesterday that it had won a $3.44 billion, 10-year contract to run NASA's space operations, beating its rival the Boeing Company. Allied Signal Inc., as a member of the Lockheed Martin team, said it had been awarded a $1 billion contract. Shares of Lockheed rose $3.5625, to $102.625. Boeing shares rose 18.75 cents, to $34.6875. Lockheed's initial contract is valued at $1.9 billion over five years, with options for another five years totaling $1.54 billion. The contract runs from October to December 2008. Lockheed Martin will manage all of NASA's data collection.

title: Owners Deliver Proposal
description: The move could be construed as either immediate progress or a mound of propaganda. In any case, the National Basketball Association's owners delivered a new proposal to the players yesterday in hopes of salvaging the start of the season on Nov. 3 and ending the three-month-old lockout.

title: Congress Should Ignore the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Officers Back on Duty After Scuffle at Casino
description: Two of three Atlantic City police officers who were suspended this month after scuffling with a casino patron returned to active duty yesterday after a hearing determined they were not a risk to the public.

title: The Half-Life of Presidential Scandals
description: Presidential scandals have always made for grand, or at least gaudy, public theater. For well over a century, Americans have been captivated by tales of the powerful brought low by their basest appetites -- for money, sex or absolute domination. But do these imbroglios help the opposing party win elections? Do they alter the course of our political life?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRIGON HEALTHCARE INC., Richmond, a managed care company, said it had halted its share-buyback program as it worked with the Internal Revenue Service to resolve some tax issues.

title: A Game of Mental Mirrors
description: Where does self-delusion end and lying begin? And how much do our deepest feelings correspond to old songs we retain that pop into our minds at the oddest moments? These and other less-than-burning questions are contemplated in Alain Resnais's buoyant film ''Same Old Song,'' a contemporary musical comedy about real estate, agoraphobia, hypochondria and Parisian tourist landmarks, among other topics.

title: Like Sex Acts, Lawyer's Job Is a Matter Of Definition
description: In a recent cascade of contrition, President Clinton has almost greedily accepted responsibility for his present predicament. But when blame for the Monica Lewinsky matter is apportioned, the finger-pointing goes in another direction: toward Mr. Clinton's lawyers.

title: Editorial Observer; What Monica Has Wrought in the Opinion Biz
description: Perhaps it was inevitable, or at least handy, that a new kind of Presidential scandal would turn up as a test case for what the new media age would do to the workings of politics and public opinion. Right off, we have seen that this scandal is not like Watergate, when the commentators and Congressional sages served as instructors in the necessary level of public outrage. This White House saga has been available in excruciating detail in the people's media -- in particular, the new cable talk channels and the World Wide Web.

title: Despite Figures on Falling Crime, Fear in Part of the Bronx
description: Joseph Torres, 27, moved into a new two-family house in the East Tremont section of the Bronx two weeks ago. A few nights later, he heard gunfire for the first time.

title: A Hard One to Watch, Even Harder to Live
description: Which of us hasn't at one time or another felt at least a twinge of the despair, fury and misanthropy that engulf the unlucky protagonist of Gaspar Noe's devastating film, ''I Stand Alone''? The story of an unemployed 50-year-old Parisian butcher (Philippe Nahon), whose disgruntled bitterness accumulates into a sustained psychotic rage, suggests a darker sequel to ''Taxi Driver,'' filtered through Dostoyevsky by way of Godard with an added touch of ''Hard Copy.''

title: Golda Meir's Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDPARTNERS EXPLORING THE POSSIBLE SALE OF UNIT
description: Medpartners Inc., a health care company, said yesterday that it had hired the investment bank, Bowles Hollowell Conner & Company, to assist in exploring the possible sale of its Government Services unit. The unit is the remaining portion of Medpartners' Contract Services Group, which provides managed health care services to state, county and local correctional and military facilities. Government Services became part of the company as a result of its June 1997 acquisition of Inphynet Medical Management. Government Services currently generates revenues of $150 million on an annualized basis. In the year ended Dec. 31, Medpartners had revenues of $6.33 billion.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN WEAKENS ON BANK-REFORM DELAY. Japan's currency fell as lawmakers argued over a bank-reform package, delaying passage of a measure viewed as critical to economic revival. The dollar rose to 136.25 yen from 135.10.

title: INSIDE
description: Officer and 3 Others Shot

title: The Indies Go to Market
description: It used to be a simpler world for Warrington Hudlin and other young filmmakers who gathered in New York for the first Independent Feature Film Market. ''There were no expectations then,'' he said on Thursday at a lunch to celebrate the market's 20th anniversary. ''Camaraderie was incredible because you'd made a choice not to make a Hollywood movie. You had to reassure yourself that you weren't crazy, and the mutual support kept you going.''

title: Congress Should Ignore the Polls
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders' Dispute Halts Game
description: Legal skirmishing over the structural safety of Nassau Coliseum forced cancellation of tonight's scheduled exhibition game between the Islanders and the Devils.

title: Daisy Anderson, 97, Widow of Former Slave and Union Soldier
description: Daisy Anderson, an old man's darling who kept the flame of her own youthful love and her husband's searing slave memories burning for more three quarters of a century, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Denver. She was 97, and, as the oldest of the nation's three known surviving Civil War widows, may also have been the last widow of a Southern slave.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Religion Journal; Sin and Atonement Transcend Words
description: With the nation's political leaders and the press preoccupied by the scandal involving President Clinton, words like sin, repentance and forgiveness have flowed freely in newscasts and political debate for weeks.

title: Body Slams Illumined by Aphorisms
description: If, as soldiers say, war consists of endless boredom punctuated by moments of stark terror, ''Martial Law'' boils down to an hour of tedium punctuated by frenzied bouts of kung fu fighting.

title: Remy Cointreau to Sell Venoge to LVMH Unit
description: Remy Cointreau S.A. signed a letter of intent yesterday to sell its Venoge Champagne brand to the Moet & Chandon unit of the luxury goods and spirits group LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton for an undisclosed sum. Remy Cointreau said the sale of the Venoge Champagne brand was part of its program to shed 1 billion francs ($178 million) worth of assets by March 31, 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DUDLEY, JAMES C.
description: DUDLEY-James C. There will be a memorial service held Saturday, October 24, at 1PM, at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the investigation of Richard C. Holbrooke, President Clinton's choice for representative at the United Nations, misstated what Mr. Holbrooke's lawyer said about the inquiry. The lawyer, Richard I. Beattie, said he was told by the Justice Department that it had found no evidence to support an allegation that while Mr. Holbrooke was at the State Department he improperly helped Credit Suisse First Boston, the company that hired him when he left the Government. Mr. Beattie did not say that the Justice Department told him it had found nothing to stop Mr. Holbrooke's nomination from proceeding.

title: Tomorrows Cat Wins by 3 Lengths
