description: Tomorrows Cat was chasing Rock and Roll again tonight in the $500,000 Grade II Buick Pegasus Handicap at the Meadowlands Race Track in East Rutherford, N.J. In the last start, Rock and Roll held on to capture the Pennsylvania Derby. But this time, Tomorrows Cat caught Rock and Roll as the horses headed into the home stretch and pulled away to win by three lengths in 1:46.4. the third-fastest time ever in the race.

title: F.B.I. Focusing Bomb Search on House Near Nairobi
description: As F.B.I. agents continue their investigation into the bombing of the American Embassy in Kenya last month, they have returned to a fashionable, two-story white house with a red tile roof in this Nairobi suburb, which they combed over after the first suspects were captured.

title: Donald Pious, 68, Researcher Who Explored Immune System
description: Dr. Donald A. Pious, a University of Washington immunologist who advanced understanding of the immune system's responses to transplants and infection, died on Sept. 6 at his home in Seattle. He was 68.

title: Compromise Revives Bill On Religious Rights Abroad
description: After its sponsors had almost given up the issue for dead, a compromise version of a bill that would require the Government to punish any foreign country that persecutes its citizens for their religious beliefs is likely to become law this year.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: TEXAS OPEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECHSLER, ALAN
description: WECHSLER-Alan. Passed away September 17, 1998. Alan, you were the best and the funniest. You will be missed. Woody and the boys

title: Corrections
description: A Spare Times listing in Weekend yesterday misstated the information number for the Little Red Lighthouse Festival, which is being held today from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. at Fort Washington Park in Manhattan. It is (888) 697-2757.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: ENERGY FUTURES FALL. Prices retreated on forecasts that Hurricane Georges would bypass key Gulf of Mexico producing areas. Crude oil fell 23 cents a barrel, to $15.75; natural gas ended little changed, losing an early gain.

title: 9 Dominican Stowaways Found in Chinese Vessel
description: The police and customs inspectors today captured nine stowaways from the Dominican Republic who had spent five days on rough seas in the hull of a Chinese container ship.

title: Brooklyn Teacher Convicted For Affair With Student, 16
description: A Brooklyn high school teacher was convicted yesterday of statutory rape and other charges for having a sexual relationship with a student who was under 17, the legal age of consent.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Committee Approves Release of Tapes Tripp Made of Talks With Lewinsky
description: The House Judiciary Committee today approved the release of thousands more pages of documents that had been delivered by the Whitewater independent counsel, finding near unanimity this time on particularly sensitive information to be kept from public view.

title: Replace H.M.O.'s With Universal Care; Children at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Haitian Immigrants Disagree on Lag in Hurricane Relief
description: Haitian immigrants in New York City are scrambling to put together a relief effort for Haiti in the aftermath of Hurricane Georges, and some have expressed dismay at what they see as the slow response of the Giuliani administration to the devastation there.

title: Official Sees Racism in a Traffic Stop
description: Patricia A. Hurt, the Essex County prosecutor and one of the top black law-enforcement officials in New Jersey, has complained that a state trooper used racial profiling when he pulled over her official government sedan for driving erratically on the Garden State Parkway earlier this month.

title: Boat Racers' Eyes on Weather
description: Rough seas and high winds are part and parcel of a solo round-the-world racer's expectations. But officials of Around Alone, the single-handed yacht race scheduled to begin here on Saturday, do not want their fleet of 16 sailboats to start out that way.

title: Olympics Chief Backs Bridge For Entry as a Winter Sport
description: An important statement about the future of bridge was made this month by Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee. ''Bridge,'' he said at the opening of the Olympic Committee Grand Prix in Lausanne, Switzerland, ''is a sport, and as such your place is here with all other sports.''

title: Q&A/Anthony deGuzman; Going One-on-One With the Very Young
description: IT all began in New Haven in 1993 with two students at Yale University, Aaron Lieberman and Rebecca Weintraub. It's called Jumpstart, a one-on-one mentoring system for preschoolers that is now a member of the Americorps National Service Network with programs in Manhattan; Washington, D.C., and Boston, the head office.

title: Airborne
description: To the Editor: Michael Finkel's article brings to mind an adventure in Poland. I was a much older part of a college chorale, singing one summer in Polish schools and churches. One very hot day, traveling between performance towns, our bus driver felt ill and we stopped near a field. One student had a Frisbee and we all gladly left the bus and had great noisy fun.

title: Familiar Sights, Freshly Portrayed
description: THE Members Gallery of the New Jersey Center for the Visual Arts here does not afford the most advantageous exhibition space, since it is essentially a long, narrow corridor opening out into a lobby. But it suits Valeri Larko very well. She is showing oil drawings on her constant theme, the industrial landscape of New Jersey, and drawing is a medium that encourages viewers to get up close.

title: In the Region / New Jersey; Elizabeth Is Razing Its Time-Worn Public Housing
description: WYNONA ANCRUM is looking forward to the day when she and her family will be able to move out of her time-worn public-housing complex in the Elizabethport section of Elizabeth into a new town-house-style apartment with a yard and front porch.

title: Teardowns, Trophies And Angry Neighbors
description: IN some wealthy New York suburbs, the tearing down of older homes to make way for massive new luxury houses has moved beyond the curiosity phase. As the pattern has picked up speed, several towns have begun to look at ways of scaling back the size of what some irritated neighbors call ''McMansions.'' And many longtime residents who associate the older, smaller homes being knocked down with their town's very character are speaking out against houses they say are out of sync with their community.

title: Taking the Long View Of What Makes a Winner
description: Every election has a loser, but in politics as in boxing, losing a bout can be a step toward victory later on. In the race in New Jersey's 13th Congressional District, Theresa de Leon is widely being described as the designated loser in an impossible campaign.

title: A Fresh Coat
description: This winter, lay it on thick, in something short and sleek or long and daring.

title: How Did Pretoria Err? Lesotho Counts the Ways
description: Probably the biggest blunder South Africa made in invading the tiny kingdom of Lesotho on Tuesday was a military one -- sending fewer than half the soldiers it ultimately needed. But it is hard to say; the list of blunders is so long.

title: Seafood Restaurant Offers a New Deal
description: Designed to look like a beach, Go Fish, a new Upper East Side restaurant, is a spot that has also tapped into part of the neighborhood's ethos. ''It's like going to the Hamptons,'' said John Hawkins, an owner.

title: BASEBALL: Another Loss Pushes Mets to the Brink of the Off Season; No Runs, and Not Much Hope
description: Over the last five days, the Mets could at least feel that they were in control of their post-season hopes. That is definitely not the case anymore.

title: Archie M. Smith, 78, Winemaker Who Fulfilled a Jefferson Dream
description: Archie M. Smith Jr., a Virginia winemaker who had the rare distinction of succeeding in a field where Thomas Jefferson failed, died on Sept. 19 at his home in Middleburg, Va. He was 78.

title: After Fighting Its Own Battles, a Vietnam Museum Opens
description: Like the war it depicts, the new Vietnam Era Educational Center in Holmdel generated controversy that pitted those who served there against those who were part of the anti-war movement at home. But after months of wrangling, the display that opens to the public today is a compromise, and all sides say they are proud of the results.

title: Still a Good Day for Sosa As Cubs Avoid Disaster
description: The moment was ready to be pasted into the Scrapbook of Frustration, the one kept on the shelf of memory by Chicago Cubs fans everywhere.

title: Alexandra Rhodie and Samuel Kimball
description: IN 1994, after years of dating physical trainers, actors and stand-up comics, Alexandra Rhodie started wearing a St. Jude necklace and praying for a miracle -- that she would meet and fall in love with a businessman who wore a suit to work.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: Where She Has Gone By Nino Ricci. Picador USA, $25.

title: A Discarded King's Sad Lesson in Love
description: ENTER Harris Yulin, wearing a crown, his sole allusion to regality in ''King Lear'' at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival here.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GILLMAN, BENJAMIN
description: GILLMAN-Benjamin. Always in our hearts, 32 years, miss you. Edith, Larry and Marion

title: BENEFITS
description: An Infernal Evening

title: Editors' Note
description: The Practical Traveler column on Sept. 13 about the euro, the standardized European currency, included an outdated reference to the notes that will circulate starting Jan. 1, 2002. On Sept. 11, after the section went to press, the governing council of the European Central Bank decided against allowing each country using the euro to print a distinguishing national motif on the notes. Each country will, however, be allowed to place such a motif on euro coins that it mints.

title: Editorial Observer; The Fed Should Do More Than Cut Rates
description: Alan Greenspan wants to cut interest rates, which means the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee is likely to do just that when it meets Tuesday. But the meeting may still be contentious because there are two very different worlds that will be affected.

title: Applause For Paper Mill
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: Uninvited Guest at Opening
description: Days before the opening of its fall exhibition, Socrates Sculpture Park informed Bruno Hadjadj that his ''Mister Dream'' -- a 15-foot fiberglass statue of what he calls ''a sweet, yet terrifying drug dealer'' -- would not be among the sculptures on display.

title: Cure Could Be Harmful
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Kibbutz, Dirty Hands at Last
description: The first thing I saw when I drove through the gates of Kibbutz Haogen on a hot Saturday afternoon this summer was a homemade sign: ''This way to the sheets and bedding bazaar.'' One of Israel's most prominent kibbutzim was selling linens. And more than that, it was selling them on the Sabbath.

title: Diane Emanuel, Charles Sammons
description: Dr. Diane Makela Emanuel and Charles David Sammons were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Richard E. Murdoch at the Rye Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIRER, RAE
description: GIRER-Rae. 93. On September 23, 1998. Beloved wife of Sol. Devoted mother to Sheila, Mel, Barbara & Larry Krevans, David & Judy. Cherished grandmother to Jodi, Mara & Donald, Scott & Deena, Glenn & Bonnie, Robin & Jason & Lisa. Loving great-grandmother to Jason, Erica, Juliana & Sam. Sister to Thelma. She will always be with us in our hearts.

title: Columbia's Momentum Fades Against Bucknell
description: All the momentum that Columbia carried from its upset victory over Harvard last week dissolved in one minute today at Bucknell. An interception that led to a Bucknell touchdown late in the first half and a 93-yard kickoff return for a touchdown to begin the second half helped turn Columbia's 14-3 lead into a 27-20 defeat.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: APPLES

title: For Richer, for Poorer
description: Myron S. Scholes, the economics guru who helped invent index funds and was co-designer of the Black-Scholes model for pricing stock options, may have lost a bit of face as well as a lot of money last week in the collapse of Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn. But consolation awaits.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: PEARL Poems by Vincent Katz. Paintings by Tabboo!

title: The Simple Pleasures of Serifos
description: IN his 1978 book ''The Greek Islands,'' about a tour of the Cycladic Islands, Lawrence Durrell wrote: ''Iron-stained Serifos speaks of poverty and silence, and drear reaches of rock induce a mood very different from the heart-lifting ones induced by Rhodes or Mykonos. Livadi is a trim little port to lie in for a summer, if you have a private yacht; if not, the place is more likely to suit novelists, or suicides of other kinds.''

title: Can a Generation Learn to Share?
description: ON graduation day, during that walk to the auditorium to return our caps and gowns, giddy about the future, were we ever so confident as to imagine that we'd be where we are now? That we'd have lucrative jobs, full retirement accounts and nice homes soaring in value?

title: Yellow Stripe Mystery Solved
description: How did that yellow stripe appear on the curb around a local fire hydrant? The answer sounds like something out of the game of Clue: It was Eric Rochow with a paint roller on President Street.

title: Tracing a Long Voyage Into the Mainstream
description: IN her Canal Street studio, Laurie Anderson is pulling together half-formed fragments from a work in progress, an electronic ghost story for the stage. In front of her is a one-eighth-scale mock-up of a set draped with black and white gauze. Behind a desk banked high with Macintosh computers and digital video projectors, Ms. Anderson is furiously punching keys. Images begin to flood the set. ''I build these in the computer,'' she says, ''and then animate them.'' Snowflakes descend in shivering waves down the gauze. Two stick figures meet and tussle; one head rolls off and bounces away. A yellow map projection writhes on a white globe like a world seen through the eyes of a very disoriented explorer.

title: An Inspector Calls. Uh-Oh.
description: WHILE waiting for Mr. Livestock last week, I felt the anger rise in my throat like mercury in a thermometer. I have bigger problems these days, so it helped to fixate on a small one like Mr. Livestock's inspection of my building for a new insurance policy. As the co-op board president, I had arranged the inspection, but I also had a more personal stake; the old policy did not cover sewer or flood damage, both of which I have suffered lately. I assumed Mr. Livestock would find faults in the building, write it off as 12 units of self-mismanagement, a ship of fools whose elected captain, me, couldn't steer a shopping cart into a checkout lane.

title: Hear Ye! Hear Ye! See Ye, Too!
description: The new Federal courthouse that opened for business on a spectacular waterfront site here this week is in many ways the first of its kind in modern judicial architecture: a building designed to welcome rather than intimidate, to invite the public to stop by for a meal, an art exhibit, a film festival, a chamber music concert or a stroll through the new two-acre ''harbor park'' that surrounds the building. There is even a floating boat dock, although the only boat tied up there during Friday's opening ceremony was a Boston Police cruiser named the Due Process.

title: Public Face of Terror Suspect: Low-Key Family Man
description: His business card said he was the director of Africa Help, a nongovernmental relief organization, and he told friends that he supplemented his income by trading in precious stones. He lived unspectacularly in a close-knit middle-class housing development. A father of six, he sent the oldest to a primary school, where his wife was active in the Parent Teachers Association.

title: Vissi d'Arte
description: CINDERELLA & COMPANY

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Conservative Vote
description: The Conservative Party leader, Vincent Natrella, appears to be in a position to retain power in his party, despite efforts by a group of disgruntled party members to topple him.

title: The Young White Sox Seek to Prove That Second-Half Surge Is No Mirage
description: Don't look for the Chicago White Sox in the playoffs this week. They won't be there. But then, they aren't where anyone thought they would be, based on their performance in the first half of the season.

title: Lives; The Quarter-Acre Universe
description: Ever since we married, my husband and I have lived in old houses filled with even older things -- battered tavern tables and tattered quilts, rickety crofter's cabinets and threadbare rugs. After 12 years, we've grown used to the faded tones of 19th-century dyes and the low sheen of worn woodwork.

title: Why Pink? Why Now? It's Simple. Sort Of.
description: THE best clothes on the runway that Friday morning were pale yellow -- a muted marigold -- and shadowy gray. But the line of fashionistas waiting at the Chelsea Piers taxi stand after Mark Eisen's show told another color story entirely.

title: A Role Model for Us All
description: At the July 1 celebration of PricewaterhouseCooper's first day as a merged firm, Rocco Maggiotto, the global leader of its financial services practice, received thunderous applause from the roughly 4,500 people assembled. But they were not cheering Mr. Maggiotto because he was host of the event, a breakfast at Tavern on the Green in Manhattan, but because he had chosen to skip it. As he explained in a telephone call broadcast to the crowd that morning, he had to drive his 12-year-old son to summer camp.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, JEFFREY
description: MOSS-Jeffrey. We are devastated by the loss of our friend, colleague and mentor Jeff Moss. For 30 years his creativity, talent and integrity have been at the heart of Sesame Street. We take comfort in knowing that his spirit, his characters, his silliness and his songs will continue to delight, educate and nuture millions of children around the world for generations to come. Long live Rubber Duckie! The Writers of Sesame Street

title: The Nation: Just Tell Us Which Sin
description: WHEN he went before religious leaders at the White House two weeks ago, President Clinton admitted to having sinned in his relationship with the former White House intern Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: Miss MacKenzie-Childs, Mr. Chaplet
description: Heather Taylor MacKenzie-Childs, the daughter of Victoria and Richard L. MacKenzie-Childs of New York, was married yesterday to J. Nils Chaplet, a son of Kersti and Pierre H. Chaplet of Neauphle-le-Chateau, France. Mayor Michel Faure of Neauphle-le-Chateau officiated at the Town Hall there.

title: How the Knee Became the Back
description: I read Cynthia Gorney's article (Sept. 6) with great interest. I, too, tore my anterior cruciate ligament when I lost my footing on my basement stairs. An avid runner, I was shocked to learn, after talking to a knee surgeon, that my options were either reconstructive surgery like Gorney had or pretty much giving up my active life style.

title: Black and White and Seen All Over
description: Stephen Galluccio, who grew up in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, doesn't remember the first photograph he took as a teen-ager, but he does remember the first photo that mattered to him. It was at CBGB's, the downtown Manhattan club, and the punk-rock group the Ramones were playing.

title: Indulging a Passion for Marching Bands
description: IT was early August and high school students were out under the hot sun, loaded down with equipment, muscles aching and stamina being tested. Coaches on the sidelines held clipboards and yelled commands. They spent hours each day preparing for a season of competition that would dominate their nights and weekends through Thanksgiving.

title: September 20-26; Not-So-Quick-Change Artist
description: Kenneth F. Ginter was stuffing handfuls of quarters into a coin redemption machine in a Waldbaum's supermarket in Queens. In fact, the authorities said, he had put 1,086 quarters into the machine and had 295 more quarters in his pockets when the police emerged from the aisles to arrest him. The quarters, they said, came from the city's parking meters. Worse, Mr. Ginter was the city official in charge of collecting the change. All told, Mr. Ginter was accused of stealing as many 14,400 bent or damaged quarters on a total of 12 occasions. JOHN KIFNER

title: Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on July 12 about the African-American Civil War Memorial in Washington included an erroneous title supplied by its sponsors for the memorial's designer. A fax dated Aug. 21 points out that Edward Dunson was the architect, not the landscape architect, on the project. (Paul S. Devrouax was the architect of record and asked Mr. Dunson to join in designing the memorial.) This correction was delayed through an editing oversight.

title: Nameplates Reduced to Memories
description: GENERAL MOTORS is continuing to thin its herd, recently announcing plans to discontinue the Oldsmobile Eighty Eight and the Buick Riviera.

title: Kristin Peterson, Matthew Edwards
description: Kristin Ann Peterson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lloyd J. Peterson of Greensboro, N.C., was married last evening to Matthew Stephen Edwards, the son of Dr. and Mrs. E. Stephen Edwards of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. Timothy J. Patterson performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Greensboro.

title: Ms. Williams and Mr. Labrecque
description: Christine Joyce Williams, the daughter of Margaret and Morgan Lloyd Williams of Plandome, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Goulet Labrecque Jr., a son of Sheila Labrecque and Mr. Labrecque of Fair Haven, N.J. The Very Rev. Jerome A. Carosella, the chancellor of the Diocese of Venice, Fla., performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, N.Y.

title: Macao Astir Over Troops In Handover To Beijing
description: For years, the looming reversion of this Portuguese colony to China has been little remarked on and largely forgotten -- a bit of colonial housekeeping lost in the wake of Hong Kong's momentous handover from Britain.

title: BUSINESS: DIARY
description: The Senate passed a bankruptcy bill that will make it substantially harder for consumers to walk away from debts. . . . Philippine Airlines shut down after last-ditch efforts to resolve a bitter labor dispute collapsed. The carrier handled 80 percent of domestic air passenger and cargo traffic in the island nation; the Government and smaller carriers scrambled to fill the void. . . . Morgan Stanley Dean Witter reported a drop in profits of only 5 percent for the third quarter, much less than expected, but the cheery report got lost in the hedge-fund bailout flap and Morgan's stock slipped on the day. Earlier in the week, Lehman Brothers Holdings said profits fell 23 percent in the quarter; it, too, was reckoned to have escaped much damage, and its shares bounced on the news. . . . Orders for durable goods jumped 1.6 percent in August, pointing to continued economic strength; G.D.P. growth in the second quarter was revised upward, to an annual rate of 1.8 percent. . . . The huge Citicorp-Travelers merger cleared its last regulatory hurdle, winning Federal Reserve approval contingent on selling some businesses.

title: Inger Dewey, David Golob 2d
description: Inger Cecilia Dewey and David Richard Golob 2d were married yesterday at the Memorial Church of Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Wendel W. Meyer, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the ceremony, in which the Rev. Walter H. Cuenin, a Roman Catholic priest, took part.

title: Melissa Filides, E. N. Cutler
description: Melissa Filides, a daughter of Irene K. Wiedman of Boston and the late Michael C. Filides, was married yesterday to Earle Newton Cutler 4th, a son of Schuyler W. Field of New Canaan, Conn., and Mr. Cutler 3d of Barrington, R.I. The Rev. Richard C. Martin, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: Jennifer Lupo, Jose Ibietatorremendia
description: Jennifer Lupo and Jose Ibietatorremendia, both lawyers, were married yesterday in Sea Cliff, N.Y. The Rev. George E. Lutz, a Lutheran minister, officiated at Sans Souci of Sea Cliff, a caterer.

title: ON LANGUAGE; Playing With A Full Deck
description: My son, Howard, and daughter Annie live and move and have their beings in that windowless, clockless pleasure dome known as Las Vegas. I'm pleased to report that in May, in a packed room at Binion's Horseshoe Casino in downtown Vegas, they placed sixth and seventh in the seven-card stud competition, the only sibling pair ever to reach the finals in the World Series of Poker in the same game. Annie and Howard have also won national tournaments with exotic names like the Diamond Jim Brady Texas Hold'Em Shootout and the Hall of Fame Classic Deuce-to-Seven Lowball Draw No-Limit. If you can't already tell, I'm proud of my kids, especially because they possess such passion for what they do.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: September 27, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Court Monitor Criticizes Hotel Union On Finances
description: A court-appointed monitor has found widespread financial wrongdoing in the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union, one that has long been linked to organized crime, attacking its former president in particular for using union money for personal activities, like flying his wife to Palm Springs, Calif.

title: New York Debut for Doug Williams Starts Out Badly but Winds Up Being Respectable
description: Hampton had recorded the victory in its ledger, and many of the 54,564 fans at the Meadowlands had retired to the parking lot for more tailgating. The 28th Annual New York Urban League Classic, Doug Williams's first as Grambling's coach, had become a rout, with Hampton dominating every facet of play.

title: OUTDOORS; A Question for Chincoteague: Can Wild Ponies and Wildfowl Coexist?
description: Some 50 feet away, the palomino stared me down and, seeing nothing in my hands to mooch, she walked off through the salt marsh toward the sand dunes in Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge, with water spraying at each hoof step. The white cattle egret on her back rode quietly along since these semiwild horses are a buffet table for bug-eating birds.

title: Mau-Mauing the Fact Checkers
description: Recent fact-oriented scandals involving Stephen Glass (The New Republic), Patricia Smith (The Boston Globe) and Mike Barnicle (ditto) have created. . .nervousness in journalism. Recently, the American Society of Magazine Editors -- the trade association for the magazine biz -- reacted to this ''summer of media introspection'' (as Barnicle put it) by holding a ''hands on'' seminar about fact-checking, a tough job that, at most magazines, is performed by younger employees. Part of the ASME Seminar Series for Juniors, the event was held at ASME's midtown office on a Wednesday night, giving it the feel of after-school detention. Here's a look.

title: Gladstone's Hobby
description: To the Editor:

title: The Good Leader; In Presidents, Virtues Can Be Flaws (and Vice Versa)
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON's admitted immoral behavior has thrust to the forefront a fundamental question about the meaning of the American Presidency: Should the President be a moral leader? And if so, what is a moral leader?

title: MetroStars Win in Milutinovic's Debut as Coach
description: Bora Milutinovic was so excited about coaching his first game for the MetroStars tonight that he arrived at Foxboro Stadium having left his clipboard full of diagrams back at the team hotel.

title: Lightening Up
description: TIME was I'd never leave for a trip to the beach without the shish kebab skewers. No matter how carefully I wrapped them up, inevitably they'd poke a hole through a canvas suitcase or stab me when I unpacked. But year after year I dragged them as part of what I considered essential vacation apparatus, from the back of the closests into the overstuffed car and out to a rented summer cottage.

title: Perfecting the Art of the Spiel
description: WHEN Candace Bushnell got up to contribute a tale to an evening of storytelling on the theme of ''Scary Wedding Stories,'' she found out it was harder than it seemed to enthrall an audience without a written text. Ms. Bushnell, the author of ''Sex and the City,'' loped through a sprawling saga of sex, drugs and matrimony, weaving in mentions of Hugh Grant, a pair of ruined shoes, several continents and various men.

title: Noble Pronouncements, Meet Wary Legislators
description: LIKE mom and apple pie, New Jersey's efforts at cost-cutting and greater efficiency have long produced reverent and pious pronouncements of devotion from state and local officials. Who, after all, would not want to save money?

title: Backtalk; An Athlete to Remember, For a Variety of Reasons
description: It wouldn't be a total surprise if the world's fastest woman died of heart failure. Her heart, like her performances, was larger than life.

title: Stone Walls, Clues to a Very Deep Past
description: PEOPLE love the old stone walls that cross the New England landscape, but they often miss what's in those walls, say Robert and Kristine Thorson. ''There are secrets in the walls, and in the stones in the walls,'' said Robert Thorson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARATH, PETER
description: SARATH-Peter. Beloved husband of Denise. Devoted father of Brian and Lindsay. Adored son of Howard and Rosilyn. Loving brother of Maureen. Funeral service Sunday September 27, 1998, 10 AM. Dix Hills Chapels, of I.J. Morris Inc., 21 East Deer Park Rd., Dix Hills NY.

title: Weld Thing
description: It starts the moment bill weld steps from the car and seems as if it will never stop: the craned necks, the raised thumbs, the exuberant hellos. As he makes his way into and then through Fenway Park, there is a new fan at every step, another outstretched hand at every turn. On this mid-July night in the heart of Boston, the approbation is as thick as the humidity. ''Can I get a picture of you with my nephew?'' asks one man, maneuvering the little boy into position.

title: A Town of Guinea Pigs Celebrates Its Contribution to Longer Life
description: If all the Americans who owe some of the length or quality of their lives to the Framingham Heart Study were to express their gratitude by attending its 50th anniversary gala on Sunday afternoon, the auditorium would need millions upon millions of folding chairs.

title: In Kosovo Death Chronicles, Serb Tactic Revealed
description: The last time Hava Bislimi saw her eldest son, Rexhap, his face was battered with bruises. He was being pushed by security police officers into the family's front garden, where he was handed a shovel and ordered to dig for weapons.

title: Afghanistan's Opium Output Drops Sharply, U.N. Survey Shows
description: Bad weather and tensions with neighboring Iran have slashed the opium production of Afghanistan and hampered its opium exports for European heroin markets, according to a new United Nations survey.

title: The Cult of Joyce Maynard
description: I am sure it's true that Joyce Maynard's memoir would not get nearly so much press had she omitted her affair with J. D. Salinger, and the opportunity of a peek into his private life. So I will buy her book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANG, JOSEPH
description: LANG-Joseph. On September 16. Precious husband of Charlotte, father of Elliot and Fred. Brother of Richard Lang. Grandfather of Durijah and Helena. Memorial Service at I.J. Morris in Dix Hills, NY on Friday, October 2 at 2 PM.

title: Kristy Gallagher, Jason Bauer
description: Kristy Michele Gallagher, the daughter of Lucy and James P. Gallagher of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Jason Gerard Bauer, a son of Kathleen and C. Roger Bauer, also of Upper Saddle River. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: No Room for the Living
description: THE FARMING OF BONES

title: September 20-26; Poverty Rates Fall
description: In a welcome bit of good news for the Clinton Administration, the Census Bureau reported that the proportion of Americans living in poverty declined last year, a drop largely attributed to progress made by black and Hispanic families.

title: Residents of Florida Keys Assess Damage After Windy, Wet Night
description: Thousands of residents woke to a sultry sea breeze and a giant mess today after Hurricane Georges blasted the southern Florida Keys on Friday.

title: Libraries Using the Net to Lure the Public
description: WHILE attending the East Northport Festival earlier this month, Aviva Guttmann and her son, Benjamin, 9, decided to stop for some cool drinks. But instead of heading for a deli or ice cream parlor, they stepped into the public library on Larkfield Road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MURRAY A.
description: GOLD-Murray A. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Murray A. Gold, beloved brother of our devoted members Hermine and Chairman of the Board, Julius H. Gewirtz, founders and benefactors of our Synagogue and Day School. May they find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Goldman's Faltering Profits May Delay an Offering
description: After debating fitfully about it for years, the 189 partners of Goldman, Sachs & Company finally voted in June to go public, and look what's happened since: Currencies have collapsed, emerging markets melted, stock markets swooned, bond yields sunk, merger deals unraveled, and new equity offerings all but vanished. Somehow Goldman still made a profit of $754 million in its fiscal third quarter, the company said on Tuesday, but the falloff from earlier in the year was sharp enough to cast doubt on Goldman's plan for a November debut for its stock.

title: Hemingway On the Mat With Life
description: ERNEST HEMINGWAY lived a helluva life: Pulitzer Prize author, big-game hunter and deep-sea fisherman, war hero and foreign correspondent, lion of the literati, lover of women, alpha male among men, friend, drinker, suicide.

title: Survivor of Many Tribulations, Including Stardom
description: FILMING the movie ''Shadrach'' was both thrilling and rough for John Franklin Sawyer, the octogenarian who has the title role. This is a first for a man who survived the cruel apartheid and violence of this city's past.

title: Commercial Property / Real Estate Services; The Trend to International Expansion Is Growing
description: THE Sept. 15 announcement by the real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield that it is merging with the London-based firm of Healey & Baker will create a company that, by real estate standards, is huge, with annual revenues of over $700 million and more than 7,700 employees.

title: Joe Miller, Who Did His Part For Baseball, Is Dead at 95
description: Joe Miller's pal was born to play soccer, and he played it with such flair that 80 years later Mr. Miller could raise the hairs on a listener's neck simply by describing his friend's powerful kick.

title: School Days For Workers
description: Students of all ages are heading back to school this month. But in the workplace, a return to the classroom can come at any time of year, in the form of corporate training sessions. Whether it's learning about the new computer, the corporate culture, or how to unleash the salesman within, such classes can leave teacher and student alike wondering just how quick a study the other is. Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: When Management Shoots for the Moon
description: MANAGEMENT theorists, who have created clunky terms like ''co-opetition,'' are generally not known for their elegance with language. That's not likely to change anytime soon, considering the buzzword now sweeping through corner offices around the country: BHAG's, for ''big, hairy, audacious goals.''

title: Compost: The Secrets Of Success
description: ALL too soon the leaves start to turn and drop. This change should signal to all good gardeners that the time for composting has arrived.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Amelia Earhart's Daughters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDEN, BERNARD
description: HOLDEN-Bernard. Pased away on September 22, 1998. Husband of Mickey. Father of Stuart and Leslie, grandfather of Jason and Greg. Brother of Estelle. We will always remember you. Estelle and Leon Port and family

title: A Charmer Returns to the Scene of the Seduction
description: IN addition to being a playwright, an actor and a director who ran his own theater company for 20 years, Charles Ludlam was something of a cultural shoplifter. As Ludlam himself divulged, his sources for ''The Mystery of Irma Vep'' included ''Rebecca,'' ''Wuthering Heights,'' ''Gaslight,'' ''Nosferatu,'' ''Romance of the Mummy'' (a 19th-century French novel by Theophile Gautier) and ''She Who Sleeps'' (by Saxe Rohmer, author of the Fu Manchu series). The dialogue is also sprinkled with references to Ibsen: when he was working on ''Irma Vep'' in the spring of 1984, Ludlam knew he would be portraying Hedda Gabler in Pittsburgh that summer.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: Harper Lee's hero sought the truth, but not at the cost of killing a mockingbird. Ken Starr may reply that the President is no Boo, but the bird he wounds more deeply than Mr. Clinton does is the American eagle. He has no right to overturn the will of the electorate.

title: BILLIONS UPON BILLIONS: A special report.; Fault Lines of Risk Appear As Market Hero Stumbles
description: Wall Street, often hard-nosed and cynical, was utterly dazzled by John W. Meriwether. He was viewed as a bond trader with a Midas touch, a mathematician of genius who found gold nuggets in markets where others saw only sand.

title: Brendan M. Jones, Former New York Times Reporter, 85
description: Brendan M. Jones, who was a former reporter for The New York Times, died Sept. 18 at Western Queens Community Hospital. Mr. Jones, a resident of Jackson Heights, was 85.

title: Policy Means Nothing If the Shelves Are Bare
description: ANYONE who thinks all this global market turmoil is mostly about devalued currencies, deflation and doomsday scenarios should try to check in with Anwar Ibrahim. He's a bit hard to reach these days.

title: A Town Debates Golf vs. Open Space
description: A PROPOSAL to build a public golf course and housing on reservoir property in New Milford has stirred a growing number of residents to fight to preserve the pristine land as open space instead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLWOOD, RALPH W.
description: ELLWOOD-Ralph W. On September 26, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Johanna. Loving father of Brenda Reale, Robert John, Marie Alice Sanderson and the late Ralph, Jr. Devoted brother of William, Marion Cuite and the late Catherine. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd., Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, 10 AM, St. Edward's R.C. Church. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Loose Threads
description: BRIDGE ACROSS BROKEN TIME

title: September 20-26; Iran Drops Rushdie Threat
description: Does Salman Rushdie really feel safe now that the Government of Iran has officially canceled its nearly decade-old death sentence against the British author? He says he does. ''It's over,'' he insisted. ''It's done.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Love Germ By Jill Neville. Verso, paper, $12

title: Khrushchev, Kennedy, Mao, Nixon . . .  Can the Cast on Today's Stage Compare?
description: Nearly a decade since the fall of the Berlin wall, is it time to grow nostalgic for that captivating era of world tension known as the cold war? Not that we live in boring times, but they seem so disorganized, so bereft of the focus that the East-versus-West confrontation guaranteed. The Soviet Union has disintegrated, Russia is in turmoil, China balances capitalism and Communism, and we're worried that Islamabad, not Moscow, has the bomb.

title: Advice, Not Ratings, On Nursing Homes
description: To the Editor:

title: Armstrong Is Pedaling Back Up the Ladder
description: Lance Arm strong has a new philosophy finish what you start -- and, he reports happily, it's working like a charm.

title: Riverside Dog Lovers Are a Step Nearer to a Real Run
description: Late last winter, when the cold had driven neighborhood children indoors, Aisha N. Smith and some friends took their dogs to the fenced-in Riverside Park playground at 143d Street to let their pets stretch their legs. Because there are no dog runs from West 105th to West 183d Streets, the place seemed ideal, at least until the weather got warmer.

title: Nanette Ambroze, Logan Chandler
description: Nanette Ambroze and Logan Munroe Chandler were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Susannah R. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: Photographers Move Forward Into the Past
description: THE photographer Jerry Spagnoli remembers the first daguerreotype he bought, in a flea market. The image of two girls seemed to hover over the tarnished silver plate, and the play of surfaces seemed to capture the vitality of the living subject. An antiquated process revealed expressive possibilities he hadn't imagined. He has spent two decades since then exploring them.

title: The Nation; 'Enabling' Is Now a Political Disease
description: ''A NATION of Clinton Enablers?'' a headline in The New York Post queried. ''We have all been enablers for Bill Clinton,'' declared Time magazine. Last week, an editorial in this newspaper spoke of Mr. Clinton's ''documentably dysfunctional personality'' and warned that ''we must not become a nation of enablers.'' In a recent speech, the television evangelist (and sometime Clinton counselor) Robert Schuller asserted that ''we all share part of the shame'' for stubbornly high public approval ratings that have enabled President Clinton so far to avoid confronting the problem of his sexual behavior.

title: On Traffic: Have I Got Some Ideas
description: WE'VE all seen and cheerfully ignored those public service announcements on Channel 21.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOMINGUEZ, NICHOLAS
description: DOMINGUEZ-Nicholas. If ever the Mets could use your help, it's now! Please pull some strings up there. Love always, Angela

title: Opposition And Leaders In Japan Save Bank Rescue
description: Japan's governing party and the opposition patched up a basic agreement today on legislation to revive the banking system. The latest agreement, if it sticks, may dispel concerns that Japan's political paralysis will continue to hobble its economy.

title: Them and Us
description: It's sometimes said that the average London cabbie is familiar with three Manhattan streets. . .and that the average New York cabbie knows only those same three streets. The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission isn't amused, which is why it wants to revamp the current licensing requirements.

title: Three-Story Lounge With a Downtown Attitude
description: It's a lounge created by a varied collection of professionals. Greg Cimino was a lawyer practicing in Boston when he negotiated a lease for what has become the Front, a spacious three-story TriBeCa lounge that is to open on Friday.

title: A 'Musical Event' That's Bucking For, Yes, a Profit
description: THE first sing-through of ''The Civil War,'' the musical extravaganza that opened to enthusiastic audiences and positive, if qualified, reviews at the Alley Theater here on Sept. 16, took place in the Alley's only rehearsal space, a windowless room beneath the stage. It is a space more suitable for a chamber group than for the 28 singers and 9 musicians who crammed it that day in late August, belting out the sentimental ballads and calculated, 11-o'clock show stoppers that are the specialty of the composer, Frank Wildhorn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GITTLER, ADELE WATKIN
description: GITTLER-Adele Watkin. September 27, 1978. Twenty years have passed. You are still in our hearts & minds each day. We remember you & cherish your memory today and in all the years ahead. Lovingly, Amy Jo, Marshall, Harvey, and all the others.

title: INSIDE
description: Economic Accord in Japan

title: Not Like a Priest
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Kaufman, Melvin Goodes
description: Nancy E. Kaufman, a former sales executive with Nazareth-Century Mills, a children's wear maker in New York, and Melvin R. Goodes, the chairman and chief executive of the Warner-Lambert Company, the pharmaceuticals and consumer products concern in Morris Plains, N.J., were married yesterday at their home in Mendham Township N.J. Judge Bernard F. Conway of the Chancery Division of the Superior Court of New Jersey in Morristown officiated.

title: Root, Root, Root For the Home Run
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Nation: In Finance, Bitter Pills Are for Others to Take
description: DO as I say, not as I do.

title: More Flee Hurricane
description: By tomorrow afternoon, the center of Hurricane Georges is expected to reach the mouth of the Mississippi River, about 75 miles southeast of New Orleans. Yesterday, 1.5 million people were ordered or urged to leave the city and coastal parishes.

title: Harvard's Endowment Has A Flow of Crimson Ink
description: Harvard University's endowment, the world's largest university nest egg, has been decimated over the past 10 weeks, as $1.3 billion was shaved off its $13 billion portfolio, the school's investment arm said in its fiscal year-end letter.

title: In Athens, A Trove of Antiquities
description: MANY people recognize the ancient marble figurines known as Cycladic as sources of inspiration for modern artists like Brancusi and Henry Moore. At the Goulandris Museum in Athens, Cycladic art can be enjoyed for what it really is: a major manifestation of the time, 5,000 years ago, when stone was being replaced by bronze as humankind's most useful material.

title: Enough Power To the People?
description: IT is often said that New Jersey's struggle for identity arises from its proximity to Philadelphia and New York City, which influences how its residents perceive themselves. But a major factor may also be its fragmented nature.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Tea With God
description: Leo Polishook's grandfather, a Jewish gangster known as the Pasha of Allen Street, was a bootlegger who made gin in his bathtub while he was bathing (because, he claimed, his bodily fluids gave the liquor a distinctive taste) -- until, so one story went, a rival gangster tossed a match into the tub. After growing to manhood in a Lithuanian town called Plissa, Moses Polishook transformed himself into a dapper American gangster. Half of the remarkable stories his grandson tells in David Black's semiautobiographical novel, AN IMPOSSIBLE LIFE (Moyer Bell, $18.95), take place here in the early part of this century and focus on the exploits of the resilient and resourceful Moses. The other half take place back in Lithuania sometime in the last several centuries. Then again, perhaps none of the stories ever took place anywhere, for each of them is described as a bobeh myseh, an old wives' tale. In Plissa, the stories focus on Leo's grandmother, Bella, who lived through pogroms, rapes, murder and cholera and who tells of Heschel the Newcomer and his freckled, redheaded wife, Miriam. Other stories include a wildly mixed cast of seducers, con artists, fools, fakes, faithless wives and beautiful daughters. Golems, dybbuks, demons, angels and talking beasts have what seem to be sensible parts in the action, as do Adam and Eve, Noah, Moses, Abraham, Joseph and Sarah. Even God visits to answer questions and drink tea at the kitchen table. Some of the tales are told with vaudeville rhythms, some with the inflection and diction of the shtetl. All are impossible, wonderful, irresistible. If, as Black suggests in a note at the end of the book, this narrative is something of a family legacy, then he has inherited untold wealth. Barbara Fisher

title: Time for a Favorite Food Of Autumn: Baked Apples
description: THE autumn apple season calls for turning on the oven. No other fruit inspires baking like apples.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Jackson Hole Fancies Up With a New Hotel
description: In a case of East goes West, Amanresorts, the Hong Kong-based chain of elegant retreats, is opening its first American resort, in Jackson Hole, Wyo., on Thursday. And like many elements of the company, the resort's name, Amangani, is a cultural mix -- ''Aman'' is Sanskrit for ''peaceful'' and ''gani'' is Shoshone for ''home.''

title: MEAN CABBAGE
description: A Philadelphia spiritualist was recently acquitted of bilking an elderly invalid of her life's savings because, the judge ruled, the demons claimed to have been exorcised may really exist. ''I don't find intent to deceive because there's no way to prove whether the spirits were there or not,'' said Judge Richard J. Hodgson as he dismissed charges against Joy Jadusingh, a voodoo healer. Jadusingh convinced a wheelchair-bound client that ''murderous cabbages'' were invading her home, and that the only defense was ''mystical water'' from Atlantic City. The victim shelled out more than $90,000. But since she and Jadusingh had arranged a service contract, the defense attorney, J. Michael Farrell, successfully argued, What's the crime? The prosecutor, Henry S. Hilles 3d, calls the judgment a license to steal: ''Proving that demons don't exist is tough, which makes a predator like Joy Jadusingh very hard to convict.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, ROBERT LEE
description: GILL-Robert Lee. Age 87, died on Thursday, September 24, 1998, in New York City, from complications of a stroke. Survivors include his wife, Melanie Gill, and from his first marriage, a son, Peter T. Gill of Bronxville, NY, and a stepson, John D. Chapman of Fort Pierce, Fla., and two sisters, Barbara Betts of West Hampton Beach, NY, and Mary Roby of Rochester, NY; grandchildren, Caroline and Elizabeth Gill, John, David and Steven Chapman, and seven step great-grandchildren. Born in South Orange, NJ, October 10, 1911. Married Caroline Townsend Chapman in 1939, who died in 1984. Member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 40 years. Past president of the NYSE Luncheon Club, member of the NY Racquet and Tennis Club. Distinguished and well-known collector of fine American art and antiques. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum, DE 19735. Family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Sunday, 2-5 PM, and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM with services on Tuesday, September 29 at 4:30PM.

title: 2,000 Recall Griffith Joyner, Track Star With Commitment

title: It Hasn't Been This Good Since Jimmy Carter's Day
description: Hiring in the final quarter of the year will be the highest for any fourth quarter since 1977, according to Manpower Inc. In its Employment Outlook Survey for the quarter, Manpower found that 29 percent of companies would add to their work forces, 60 percent would remain at present levels, 7 percent planned to cut back and the remaining 4 percent did not yet know their plans. Demand was especially strong in wholesale and retail trades and in construction.

title: Macho Yankees Hit the Tissues as Cone Wins 20th
description: David Cone's eyes were still moist and pink 30 minutes after he throttled the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, 3-1, to win his 20th game yesterday. The Yankees wondered if he would be able to contribute seriously this season following right-shoulder surgery last October. Cone wound up giving the team more than any other pitcher.

title: Bay Area Bookstores for the Purist
description: MANY people take vacations in and around San Francisco to see such physical landmarks as the Golden Gate Bridge, Coit Tower, Alcatraz, Nob Hill or the bumps and grinds at the famous bars on Broadway. But another type of vacationer visits the Bay area to seek out intellectual landmarks such as the novels of Mark Twain, first editions by Jack Kerouac, collectible comics by R. Crumb, scholarly volumes, detective novels, biographies, autobiographies -- books about everything from cabbages to kings.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 14 of the Travel section today with the What's Doing column, about New York, misspells the surname of the painter whose works will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art starting Nov. 1. It is Jackson Pollock, not Pollack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARSON, INEZ
description: GARSON-Inez. Artist, art historian, died in Seattle, September 17. 83. Beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother. Born in New York City, she is survived by her three children, Rachel Garson of Seattle, Adam Perl of Ithaca, NY, Joshua Perl of New York City; five grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. She worked at the Museum of Modern Art, directed the White Art Museum at Cornell, and was curator at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington. Gifts may be made to Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, Patient Care Program, P.O. Box 19024, Seattle, Washington 98104.

title: Covering the Ink With Pancake
description: DAVID REMNICK, once a rumpled writer for The New Yorker, appeared on ''The Charlie Rose Show'' on Sept. 13 to discuss his appointment as editor of the magazine. Gone were the oversize horn-rimmed glasses readers saw on the jacket of his Pulitzer Prize-winning book, ''Lenin's Tomb,'' and Mr. Remnick appeared to have treated himself to an $80 haircut, a stylish, windowpane-check suit and a plump silk tie.

title: Reducing Russian Nuclear Dangers
description: Russia's idle nuclear weapons complexes are dangerously short of money, leaving thousands of skilled scientists and workers unpaid or unemployed. Some may be tempted to sell their expertise to countries like North Korea, Iran and Iraq that are trying to develop nuclear weapons of their own. But the Russians could put their skills to work for their own country's commercial and social benefit, if funds were provided to train and employ them.

description: BY now, virtually no one in the capital contends that President Clinton shouldn't be punished for his deceptions in the Lewinsky affair. But what to call the punishment?

title: Sir, Your Room Is Not Quite Ready
description: Top executives of Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, based in White Plains, appear to have rather fickle taste in housing. When the chairman, Barry S. Sternlicht, moved to Greenwich, Conn., several years ago, he and his wife built a house, abandoned the project and then bought an existing house that ''unfortunately had to be practically rebuilt,'' he wrote in the Harvard Business School's 10-year reunion book from the class of 1986. Now, his newly appointed chief executive and close friend from business school, Richard D. Nanula, has bought a house in Greenwich for $6 million, but is renting elsewhere until it is renovated. Juergen Bartels, another Starwood executive, also bought a big house recently in the same neighborhood, and he, too, is renting until the contractors are finished with a makeover. ADAM BRYANT

Adored grandfather of Matthew, Meredith, Erica, Amanda and Jared. Founder of Yablokoff's Kingsway Memorial Chapel, Juilliard educated cellist and proud member of the Brooklyn Trio, in addition to many other chamber music groups. He was well loved, well respected, and the legacy he leaves will inspire us all. Services today, 12 noon, at the Yablokoff Kingsway Memorial Chapel, 1978 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

Only half the young players who gather for daily pickup games on the blacktop diamond wear mitts. Home plate is a discolored patch of cement, and the sidelines of a nearby basketball court serve as foul lines.

title: Cash Low, H.M.O. Goes Under State Supervision
description: The Health Insurance Plan of New Jersey, the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, has come under the supervision of state insurance regulators. The State Department of Banking and Insurance announced that it had issued an order of administrative supervision on Sept. 8, after the nonprofit company fell $9.5 million short of a required cash reserve of $15.4 million, the amount it would theoretically cost to pay claims for all its 195,000 New Jersey members, said Winnie Comfort, a spokeswoman for the department.

title: To Deal or to Fight?
description: Encouraged by public impatience with the Monica Lewinsky case, some of Bill Clinton's aides have devised a political battle plan they believe can save his Presidency. It is essentially the same strategy the White House used in earlier confrontations with the Republican majority in Congress, namely paint the opposition as parochial, partisan and indifferent to the national interest. These tactics have worked in budget and policy conflicts. But when transferred to the legal arena by hatchet-swingers like James Carville, Lanny Davis and the White House lawyers, such attacks have steadily weakened personal respect for President Clinton, his grip on his office and his negotiating options.

title: Private Group Says City Overrates Park Conditions
description: Conditions in New York City's parks are considerably poorer than city officials say, partly because most of the more than 27,000 acres of parkland are never inspected, a private parks group says in a report to be issued tomorrow. In checks of 10 parks, the group found benches collapsing, paths a shambles, landscape overrun by weeds and almost no drinking fountains working.

title: Recognizing When Fruit Is Ripe for the Picking
description: I GROW a kind of strawberry -- a white alpine -- whose flavor, when it is fully ripe, is an ambrosial melding of strawberry and pineapple. But if it is even slightly underripe, it tastes like sour cotton. How do I know when to pick the white berries? One way is with my nose, by the delectable aroma of a fully ripe fruit.

title: Honk if Offended
description: Kevin Dimmick, a 41-year-old h.i.v.-positive man from Kensington, Calif., wants a personalized license plate that says hiv pos, but the California Department of Motor Vehicles doesn't want him to have it, deeming the message ''offensive.'' Earlier this summer, a Federal court said that Dimmick -- who tested positive in 1991 -- should have his plate, noting that California has already issued disease-specific plates like end hiv, addictd and schizzo. The state is deciding whether to appeal, but for now it isn't coughing up the plate.

title: . . . Especially to the Budget-Minded Diner
description: UNLIKELY as it seems, passengers in an airliner and patrons in a restaurant have a lot in common. They are both sequestered in one place for a specific purpose, and the people in each group are paying very different amounts for what they are receiving. Just as airline passengers, sitting next to each other in the same class, buy tickets for a wide range of prices (low season and senior discounts, 7-, 14- and 21-day advance excursion fares, consolidators' tickets, etc.), so too do diners who are eating the same dish at the same time in the same restaurant pay varying sums as a result of early-bird, two-for-one, fixed-price and early-week dinners, bar menus, discount coupons, etc.

A chance meeting there led to a new temple in Short Hills, according to ''Generations and Reflections,'' a history of the congregation compiled for this year's 150th anniversary.

title: Lightweight Tennis
description: The way tennis technology is headed, soon the racquet could be lighter than the ball. First there was wood, then aluminum, graphite, titanium and now Hyper Carbon. A material primarily known to the aerospace industry, it's being used to produce the lightest racquet ever, Wilson's Hyper Sledge Hammer. Weighing a mere 8.3 ounces, it promises to blast past titanium models and become the power racquet for weekend hackers. ''The Hyper Sledge Hammer is now the lightest racquet on the market,'' said Bill Gray, equipment editor at Tennis magazine, which has play-tested the racquet against other new models. Jim Baugh, the president of Wilson, said the featherweight racquet is too stiff for most pros, but perfect for the player with a short, compact swing or an older player looking for a little more zip. Available in sports shops next month, the Hyper Carbon, $350, is designed to give a player a lot more power. ''It's definitely not for a pro, who already has that,'' Mr. Baugh said. Mr. Gray said: ''If Pete Sampras got hold of this racket, he'd probably burn a hole through the back fence. But I recently had a senior player test it, and he compared it to Viagra.''

title: Angelica Torn, Timothy Williams

title: Borne With a Silver Spoon
description: Mousse-filled cherry tomato cups and other hors d'oeuvre delivery systems don't cut the honey mustard anymore. At chic catered affairs around town, people prefer to be spoon-fed. Instead of reaching for the salmon tartare on, say, an endive leaf, they swallow bite-size morsels served on silver spoons passed on a tray -- then return the spoon to an awaiting linen envelope. ''Because there is no base, like a tartlet shell or a cucumber slice, it becomes an hors d'oeuvre in its purest form,'' said Carla Ruben, owner of Creative Edge Parties, who started the uncanapes last spring. At parties at the New York Public Library and the Whitney Museum, her signature hors d'oeuvres have become so popular that Ms. Ruben now has a spoon menu. Clients choose from lemon aioli and sevruga caviar, foie gras and Granny Smith apples, Maine lobster with artichokes and other former phyllo fillers. ''People love it because you're not holding anything, carrying anything, dipping anything,'' she said. ''It's very clean.'' Phone: (212) 741-3000.

title: Word & Image; The Facts of Media Life
description: The roster of fallen journalists grows apace: Stephen Glass, Mike Barnicle, Patricia Smith, James Hirsch, a whole team of CNN investigators. But the year's toll is proof not that many reporters often lie; it bespeaks a heroic battle by the news media to preserve the meaning of fact and the sanctity of quotation marks. Reporters have been losing their jobs for committing fiction, a crime that is no crime at all in too many other media venues, notably film and television docudramas.
