description: FOR an outstanding athlete to die at age 38, her world records still unbroken, as Florence Griffith Joyner did last week, is a blunt reminder that fine physical condition is no guarantee of longevity.

title: September 20-26; NASA Seeks a Russian Bailout
description: The biggest science project of all time, a sprawling outpost for astronauts, is to start being hauled piecemeal into orbit in two months. But the plan is shaky because a key Russian player has been crippled by the nation's economic chaos.

title: Banging the Drum for Hong Kong
description: THIS former British colony has neither an army nor an air force. But these days, it does have a general -- a career civil servant with a Chinese name, a British knighthood and a warrior's determination to crush the foreign speculators whom he accuses of preying on Hong Kong's economy.

title: Taliesin West Offers Special Look at Wright
description: The documentarian Ken Burns, whose PBS series have dissected topics as all-American as baseball and the Civil War, will now tackle another native subject: Frank Lloyd Wright, whom Mr. Burns calls America's greatest architect.

title: Higher Ground for Freeport's Nautical Mile
description: SINCE Mary Klotsche moved into her South Freeport home 35 years ago, flooding from nor'easters and hurricanes have ruined more oil burners and car exhaust systems than she can count, and her 18 prized azalea bushes are lifeless after repeated soakings in salt water.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: Has it occurred to Abner Mikva, the former White House counsel, that perhaps Hillary Clinton was caught lying to the special prosecutor during one of those discreet, pleasant and cooperative Saturday sessions at her residence? Maybe that is why she was summoned to appear before the grand jury by way of the front door.

title: Mary Jane Grows Up
description: This fall, women seem afflicted with a Lolita syndrome, wearing Mary Janes, the little girls' party shoes associated with frilly white ankle socks. ''I wear them,'' said Elizabeth Kiester, senior fashion editor of Jane magazine. ''It's ironic to wear them with below-the-knee pleated skirts. I feel like I'm back in parochial school.'' Updated for a more mature, fashionable foot, this year's styles come in everything from flannel to velvet, with pointy or square toes and artfully shaped or traditionally flat heels. The only must seems to be the girlish instep strap. Prada and Miu Miu did a rubber-sole sport Mary Jane with a Velcro closure, $230 to $250, which was seen at the September fashion shows. They also have a harlequin style in black and white and red and white (top row) for $340. ''That shoe is so graphic and modern,'' said Lauren duPont, accessories director of Vogue, who suggested pairing them with a simple slip dress. For NoLIta Lolitas, Sigerson & Morrison, 242 Mott Street, offers Mary Janes with a heel and sling backs for $228 (bottom left). Barneys made a witchy-looking Jane (bottom center) for $195. Diego Dolcini for Trend Les Copains (807 Madison Avenue, near 67th Street) showed a version for $290 (bottom right) on the fall runway with a skinny, midcalf tweed skirt. And D & G has created a flat Mary Jane in wool and velvet for $260 (434 West Broadway). ''It's about looking pretty and sweet, instead of hot and sexy,'' Ms. Kiester said. ELIZABETH HAYT

title: A Tax-Free Benefit And a Ticket to Ride
description: Who wouldn't like to cut their taxes by $300 or $400 a year? Such savings are available to commuters whose employers set up a transit voucher program to take advantage of provisions of the Federal transportation law enacted in July.

title: Culture Zone; A Money Tree Grows In the Bronx
description: Don't be surprised if, a year or two from now, you receive in the mail a catalogue filled with glossy photographs of stainless-steel trowels, floral wrapping paper, children's science kits, handblown vases, cucumber-scented face cream, leaf-embossed tablecloths, berry jams and gardener's smocks -- all carrying the stamp of the New York Botanical Garden. The consultant Bonnie Trust Dahan, a veteran of the Smith & Hawken garden retail company, is developing a strategic plan that would make the Botanical Garden a brand name to reckon with in the horticultural world.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Dominique Swain; The Age of Insouciance
description: ON her first visit to a New York nightclub, Dominique Swain said she had more in common with the title character in ''Pecker'' than the one for which she is known. That is ''Lolita,'' of course.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, MURRAY AND FLORENCE
description: WHITE-Murray and Florence. You lived a beautiful life together, always, even in song. Now you are together in peace. Memories of you both have always been treasured by Margie and me. Rest well my dear friends. Phil Stein and family

title: Book Publisher Fosters a Strong Point of View on Health Care
description: TUCKED away in a converted furniture warehouse in Garden City Park, the Avery Publishing Group doesn't look like much of a business. After all, how many copies could its alternative health titles like ''The Green Tea Book,'' ''Chromium Picolinate: Everything You Need to Know'' and ''Prescription for Nutritional Healing'' possibly sell?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, TILLY
description: BARON-Tilly. On September 26, 1998. Beloved sister of the late Louis, Abner, Theodore, Harry and Morton Baron, Adeline Feinblatt, Belle Baron and Libby Coleman. Survived by many nieces and nephews and great-nieces and greatnephews. Interment private.

title: Forbes: Not Loved In Arizona Anymore?
description: Back during the 1996 Presidential campaign, Steve Forbes, the publishing magnate, spent the better part of $4 million, much of it from his personal fortune, to win a surprise victory in Arizona's Republican primary. Since then, his eye now fixed on the Election 2000 primary, he has returned often to the Grand Canyon State to meet and greet and to preach his special brand of conservative economics.

title: Willy Moves to Iceland, A Little Freer
description: The world's most famous killer whale may be gone, but Newport, Ore., hopes tourists will keep coming.

title: The World; In Turkey, at Least, the Dogs of War Still Howl
description: FEW spectacles in recent decades have been as breathtaking as the historic handshakes between government leaders and chieftains of insurgent groups. From Central America to Israel and from South Africa to Northern Ireland, these scenes, which for years or decades were unthinkable, have shattered old assumptions and opened up new futures for long-suffering groups of people.

title: David Noah, Melissa Goldstein
description: Melissa Ann Goldstein, a daughter of Hana Goldstein and Dr. Gideon Goldstein of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday evening to David Harold Michael Noah, a son of Helen Noah and Dr. Harold Noah of Amenia, N.Y. Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court in Brooklyn officiated at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS: JAMES E. GOODWIN of UAL; Taking Over And Already In the Know
description: PLUCKED from relative obscurity, James E. Goodwin became president and chief operating officer last week of the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, the country's largest airline and largest employee-owned company. He succeeded John A. Edwardson, who resigned after United's two biggest unions made it clear they would block his becoming chief executive when Gerald Greenwald retires next year. United's board has hired a search firm to find a successor for Mr. Greenwald.

title: Lisa Miller, Deric Angelettie
description: Lisa Michelle Miller, the daughter of Barbara V. Miller and Walter J. Miller, both of Philadelphia, was married last evening to Deric Michael Angelettie, the son of Noemi Angelettie Wallace of St. Albans, Queens, and Eric Angelettie of Orlando, Fla. The Rev. James Simmons, an African Methodist Episcopal minister, officiated at the Mansion, a caterer in Voorhees, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, DAVID
description: FISHER-David, whose maxims were published as ''The Human Relations Factor'' in 1990 and served as the themes for Waterways: Poetry in the Mainstream (1989-1990), will be missed by his publishers, BardPress and the Waterways Project of Ten Penny Players, Inc.

title: Inflated Pay Awaits Deflated Executive Egos
description: Golden parachutes are billowing, thanks to the addition of so-called gross-up features for executives who face tax liabilities when companies change control and the executives lose their jobs.

title: Going Beyond 12 Ideas; Why Not a Cellar Market Or an E-Z Metrocard?
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Boss Changed His Stripes
description: The phone will ring, inevitably. The Boss will call. If the Yankees are losing or if they are winning -- and, until a late-summer skid, they were winning almost uniformly this season -- the Boss will call, demanding, cajoling, fretting, questioning. Brian Cashman, the Yankees' 31-year-old general manager, wants to be ready. He's trying, like an anticipating matador, to guess what the Boss will ask next.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, (SEFF) VIOLA
description: GOLDBERG-(Seff) Viola, at 92. Beloved wife of the late Henry Goldberg and the late Manny Seff. Devoted mother of Kate & Gerry Beswick, of London, and Vicki Winteringham. Loving grandmother of Kefi Beswick, affectionate stepmother of Dr. William Ruberman and the late Janet Ruberman. Step-grandmother of Dr. Louise and Arie Buckheister and Daniel and Ann Ruberman. Survived by five great step-grandchildren. A woman of great charm, intelligence and beauty, she devoted her time and energy to relationships with family and friends, the pursuit of art and learning & an intense involvement in philanthropic causes. She was a member of the Board of Trustees of Beth Israel Hospital where she was actively involved in developing innovative programs in hospice care & in the hospital nursing school. Funeral services will be held on Monday, September 28 at 9:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: Jews in Germany
description: To the Editor: Since my husband and I traveled to Germany in 1996 and again recently, I was interested to read ''Conceding the Grim Past, Germany Invites Jews'' (Aug. 2). On this trip we had the pamphlet you mentioned, ''Germany for the Jewish Traveler.'' We felt that it was important to bear witness.

title: September 20-26; Smut? Not in This Man's Army!
description: Military stores at bases around the world began pulling from their shelves more than 150 magazines that the Pentagon decided are sexually explicit.

title: Spano Cabinet Changes
description: Two of County Executive Andrew J. Spano's department heads will now collectively run four departments. Mr. Spano, a Democrat, announced recently that Anthony M. Landi, the Commissioner of Public Works, will also serve as Acting Commissioner of Environmental Facilities, and that Rocco A. Pozzi, the Commissioner of Probation, will serve in the dual role of Acting Corrections Commissioner. Both are holdover appointees from the administration of former County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.

title: Coltrane for All Generations
description: THE SETTING -- Aaron Davis Hall, City College's sleek, acoustically pleasing fine-arts center at 135th Street and Convent Avenue. Mind-Builders Creative Arts Center, a school that provides music, dance and theater classes for children from Williamsbridge in the Bronx, is celebrating its 20th anniversary, with a concert of jazz artists last Wednesday performing the music of John Coltrane, the tenor saxophonist and jazz icon who was born Sept. 23, 1926, in Hamlet, N.C., but gained his greatest fame playing in the city's jazz clubs like Birdland and the Village Vanguard.

title: Suit Against Auto Insurer Could Affect Nearly All Drivers
description: When Mark E. Covington drives his 1992 Chevy Cavalier at night, the beam of the left headlight wobbles across the road, and in daylight, the red paint on the hood shows an odd ridge on the left side.

title: Greeting And Giving
description: Warming up September.

title: 4 Accused of Invading Homes And Torturing People for Cash
description: After several incidents this month in which armed men in masks burst into homes in Queens and tortured the people living there until they gave up their cash and valuables, the police charged four men Friday with the well-planned robberies.

title: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Kohl and His Story: New Chapter, or History?
description: Change is not lightly accepted in a country where stability is paramount, and as Germany prepares to vote Sunday in national elections it appears gripped by last-minute doubts over whether the time has come to end the era of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: Lisa Heilbrunn, David Rattray
description: Lisa Ann Heilbrunn and David Edwards Rattray were married yesterday in East Hampton, N.Y., by Shirley Fingerhood, a retired acting justice of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: For New York City, Garbage Is a Resource
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMP, ALIDA DONNELL MILLIKEN
description: CAMP-Alida Donnell Milliken, 89. At home in East Bluehill, Maine on September 19. Wife of the late Frederic E. Camp. Daughter of the late Seth M. Milliken and Alida K. Leese. Mother of Nicholas R. Camp (Carmel, ME.), Susan C. Schewe (Lecanto, FL.), Donnell McK Camp (South Londonderry, VT), Catharine C. Lund (Groton, MA.), and William M. Boardman (Woodstock, VT). Grandmother to 14, great grandmother to 9 with a 10th expected in November. Sister of Minot K. Milliken (NYC) and John F. Milliken (Pittsboro, NC). She was a founding member of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society and the Maine chapter of the MS Society; a longtime Trustee of Colby College; and a founding Trustee of the College of the Atlantic. She graduated from Smith College in 1930, after attending the Brearley School and Milton Academy. Honorary degrees: Doctor of Humane Letters from Colby and Bachelor of Arts in Human Ecology from College of the Atlantic. She was also a founding member of the Blue Hill Troupe. She raced sailboats competitively from her childhood until 1958 when she took to cruising the coast in her Concordia yall named Thistledown. Memorial contributions to National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 733 Third Avenue, New York City 10017-3288.

title: A Passion in College For a Master of Pulp Finally Bears Fruit
description: ''I'M basically drawn to defeated, injured, hurt, barely walking characters,'' said Steven Shainberg, the director of ''Hit Me.'' Little wonder, then, that he would choose a bleak, gritty Jim Thompson novel, ''A Swell-Looking Babe,'' for his first feature film. Indeed, though decidedly cheerful during an interview, Mr. Shainberg has regarded Thompson as something of a soul mate ever since college.

title: Ironman Triathlon Grows; It's Now 20 and Still Bragging
description: On that February morning in 1978, only 15 sets of footprints dotted the shores of Waikiki. To every man fit and brave enough to take the challenge went three sheets of paper listing a few rules and a course description.

title: Looking Inward on Holy Days
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: More Troubling Signs For a Governor
description: More re-election problems for Gov. David Beasley of South Carolina . . .

title: Prices in Bali
description: To the Editor: I read Daisann McLane's Frugal Traveler article ''In Bali, $3 Goes a Long Way,'' (Aug. 2). I just returned from four weeks of travel in Bali. It was a good article, but I want to point out that only an American would say, as Ms. McLane's acquaintance did, ''I told my landlady that she had to raise the price of her guesthouse -- it was only $4 a night!''

title: Miss America as Role Model
description: Does the Miss America Pageant provide a suitable role model for girls and young women?

title: In the Region / Long Island; Making Garden City's Franklin Ave. Bloom Again
description: DRY leaves of late summer tumble down the broad and largely deserted sidewalks of Franklin Avenue, the main north to south artery of this comfortable village. In recent years the thoroughfare, once known as Long Island's Fifth Avenue, has been plagued by empty stores, especially along a three-block stretch extending from 11th Street to Stewart Avenue.

title: Our Towns; Business Hotel Makes Room For Toddlers
description: AT this week's staff meeting, Cathy Hart will ask the employees at the Marriott Residence Inn here how to make Halloween a festive occasion for the hotel's guests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTSCHULER, DR. STANLEY
description: ALTSCHULER-Dr. Stanley, 86. Died on September 17th, 1998 in Sun City West, Arizona. Beloved husband for fifty years of Edith, cherished father of Judy Altschuler Goldstein and Ellen Altschuler Kirchner. He practiced medicine in Elmhurst, Queens. His kindness and generous spirit will be missed by many.

title: Airborne
description: To the Editor: Like Michael Finkel, author of ''Hands-On Diplomacy'' (Sept. 6), we are seized with an urge to take a Frisbee with us. The only other times we play with it are when our grandchildren visit.

title: Latest Offspring Of a Clothing Store
description: On the verge of creating something of a neighborhood clothing empire, Christiane Celle struck again three weeks ago when she opened Calypso Enfants at 284 Mulberry Street (between Prince and Houston Streets) in the neighborhood that has become known as Nolita (north of Little Italy).

title: State Begins Complex Task Of Evaluating All Colleges
description: With its ratings of primary and secondary schools well established, the New York State Department of Education is embarking on an effort to assess the state's colleges and universities, both public and private.

title: Street Closings
description: Because of the annual debate at the United Nations, today and tomorrow there will be intermittent closings of First Avenue between 41st and 48th Streets; the 42d Street exit of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, and streets around the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, at Park Avenue and 50th Street. Other street closings and detours are also possible elsewhere in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Never Far From Vitebsk
description: Henry Miller said it best when he described the artist Marc Chagall as ''a poet with the wings of a painter.'' In his MARC CHAGALL: 1887-1985 (Taschen, $39.99), Jacob Baal-Teshuva focuses on Chagall's adroit use of mystical and free-floating images to create canvases that are poetic pictorials. Born in 1887 in the dismal town of Vitebsk (now in Belarus), near the Lithuanian border, Chagall never saw a painting until 1906, when he spied a fellow student copying a book illustration. Baal-Teshuva, a longtime friend of Chagall's whose warm feelings of friendship ripple throughout his text, follows the artist's career through Vitebsk, St. Petersburg, Paris, the United States and back to France. Concentrating primarily on Chagall's refusal to embrace artistic trends, Baal-Teshuva identifies the painter's strict adherence to Jewish tradition and his affinity for Vitebsk as the unifying themes of his work. Vitebsk, Chagall once said, ''was the soil that nurtured the roots of my art''; of his religion he commented, ''Were I not a Jew, I would not have become an artist.'' From Chagall's prolific career, Baal-Teshuva cites one constant: his use of dreamlike fantasy images combined with vivid memories of his childhood, both of which maintain a constant dialogue between the artist, his origins and his religion. Amy Todd

title: Race Goes On for Pair Who Nearly Lost Their Lives
description: The sideburns on Josh Hall's brush-cut are graying now. And the smile lines in the corner of Isabelle Autissier's blue eyes are etched a little deeper. But the same tenacity that allowed them to overcome losing their sailboats at sea, and nearly their lives, in a round-the-world race four years ago, has brought them back to the starting line again.

title: Style; Shoppers' Ed
description: How many times can you make the choo-choo go around the tracks? And what inoffensive game can you play with a purple dinosaur that hasn't been played before? Let the good-natured and imaginative baby-sit for children at home; when I'm in charge of my little nephew, we go shopping.

title: A Change in Course Toward Dances for the People
description: ''I'M no longer interested in spectacle. I now want my pieces to deal with what is going on today,'' Maguy Marin, the experimental French choreographer, said recently over lunch near Lyons.

title: Migrant Workers Tie Peekskill to Mexico
description: NEW YORK, Washington, Geneva, Paris, Peekskill. Somehow the official diplomatic circuit does not usually include that modest upcounty Hudson River city. Recently, however, Peekskill was the host to a delegation of Mexican governmental health officials from the state of Puebla as part of the United States/Mexico Binational Health Professional Exchange.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: As a lawyer and former Second Circuit law clerk who's been impressed with the analysis in several of Ken Starr's judicial opinions, I believe the real misfortune is that he was not appointed to the Supreme Court (Michael Winerip, Sept. 6). With all the bitterness the Lewinsky scandal already has caused, his chances of a future appointment to the Court are probably about as good as a renomination of Judge Bork. I think Starr's integrity, intelligence, temperament, fortitude in the face of unpopularity and capacity for hard work would have made him a fine Justice.

title: SHOPPING WITH/Saul Williams; Downtown to Stardom in One Leap
description: SAUL WILLIAMS walked into the Antique Boutique in Greenwich Village as though it were his old neighborhood. He had the same comfortable, long-limbed stride his poet-rapper character in ''Slam,'' this year's Sundance grand prize winner, used while walking around the projects in Washington. Brushing past rows of sweaters and pants in all the New York colors -- black, charcoal, gray -- he stopped in the middle of the floor, at a rack he seemed to know well.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In / Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.; A Caring Community, Rich in Parkland
description: SINCE the founding of the Village of Croton-on-Hudson a century ago, says its Mayor, Robert Elliot, it ''has improved immensely.''

title: Food; The Upper Crust
description: Crustiness is a culinary come-on. Its latest incarnation may have begun with blackened and grilled food, though its reputation was sealed the moment the word crusty became the only acceptable modifier for the word bread.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Make Room for the Big Guns of Autumn: Baked Apples
description: THE autumn apple season calls for turning on the oven. No other fruit inspires baking like apples.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Four screen enhancements of stage works highlight the movie attractions this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELBERGER, JACK (JACOB)
description: ELBERGER-Jack (Jacob) age 84. Passed away on September 15, 1998 in Delray Beach FL. Beloved husband, father and grandfather.

title: MARKET WATCH
description: What is the lesson from the rescue of Long-Term Capital Management, the hedge fund based in Greenwich, Conn., that's run by John W. Meriwether and a band of Wall Street's savviest traders? That it helps to be big, to be bold and to know the right people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMP, WINIFRED MARY KNAPP
description: KAMP-Winifred Mary Knapp. On Friday, September, 18, 1998, age 73, born on October 22, 1924 in Middletown, NY, daughter of the late Clarence J. and Lillian M. Cady Knapp. Beloved mother of Leo Charles Kamp, Jr., Ronald James Kamp, Lawrence Paul Kamp, Karen Marie Small and Anna Marie Culbreth. Also surviving are five grandchildren and one great grandchild. Services will be private. Condolences may be sent to Anna M. Culbreth, 226 Asbury Road, Winchester, VA 22602.

title: New York
description: The runners of the New York Marathon may be masochistic, but they are not stupid: They run in the fall. After all, if you are going to see the five boroughs as a blur while gasping for breath, you might as well do it when the colors are crisp and the air brisk. Attitudes are brisk, too: when the heat leaves, the locals return, their hunger to master the universe recharged.

title: Opposing Camps But Shared Opinions
description: EVERY two years, since Naomi C. Matusow, a Democrat, did the unexpected in 1992 and beat a supposedly entrenched Republican for a seat in the State Assembly, the Republicans target Mrs. Matusow's seat as the one they will reclaim. In 1994 and 1996, the Republican candidate went down to defeat.

title: Bushwick to Bensonhurst, When the Boards Meet
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Greenpoint, Williamsburg; meeting usually held on second Tuesday of month; but next meeting is on Wednesday, Oct. 14, 7 P.M.; 211 Ainslee Street, corner of Manhattan Avenue; Community board chairman: Vincent V. Abate; District manager: Gerald Esposito; (718) 389-0009. Agenda: To be announced.

title: Look, Up in the Air!
description: IT was just after noon on Tuesday. Steve Bow had been zipped into his blue flight suit for hours, waiting calmly with the other crew members among the wafting medicinal vapors on the top floor of University Hospital, in Newark. He knew -- they all knew -- that it was only a matter of time.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: Your article states that Ken Starr avoided military service because of psoriasis. I am at least a second-generation sufferer of that irritating condition and, in my dotage, am now enjoying the pleasures of psoriatic arthritis. Once, in the service when it was bothering me, I went to sick call and was told by the doctor, ''Yeah, it sure does look like hell.'' He prescribed some ineffective salve. End of treatment.

title: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Horseman, Pass By!
description: GHOST TOWN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYD, GEORGE JR.
description: BOYD-George Jr. Of Darien, CT on September 23, 1998. Husband of Esther (Terry) Boyd. Father of Bonnie Boyd Kraig and James G. Boyd. Brother of Meta B. Stroupe. Grandfather of four. Great grandfather of one. Memorial Services were held St. Luke's Episcopal Church Darien, CT. yesterday. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to: Darien Library, 35 Leroy Avenue, Darien, Connecticut 06820 or St. Luke's Episcopal Church (Book of Remembrance) P.O. Box 3128 Darien, CT. 06820.

title: ON MY ... WALL: THOMAS GALVIN
description: He is, he joked, ''probably the only strategist on the Street who's bankrupt,'' Thomas Galvin, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities, was referring to an erroneous letter he received in July from American Express, telling him it was canceling his charge card because ''of our receiving notification of your filing bankruptcy.'' The letter -- a result of a computer error at American Express -- now hangs on his wall, in full view of his clients.

title: Julie Damgard, Thomas Frist 3d
description: Julie Mead Damgard, the daughter of Darcy Mead Leeds of New York and John Michael Damgard of Washington, was married yesterday to Thomas Fearn Frist 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Frist Jr. of Nashville. The Rev. Charles H. Clark, the rector emeritus of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Dune Church in Southampton, N.Y.

title: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Safety Regulations For Lobbies
description: WHEN a co-op or condominium decides to redecorate a lobby, questions of design usually take precedence. Safety issues, such as the flammability of carpeting, draperies and other furnishings, are sometimes neglected. But co-op and condo lawyers say that a careful consideration of those issues is not only advisable but is required by law.

title: Democrats in Connecticut See Trouble in November
description: Unnerved by their gubernatorial candidate's dismal poll ratings and President Clinton's political troubles, the 11 Connecticut Democrats running for statewide and Federal office held an emergency meeting called by Senator Christopher J. Dodd today to discuss how the party can avoid a disaster in the November elections.

title: April Torrey, Patrick Perry
description: April Elizabeth Torrey and Patrick Lawrence Perry were married yesterday by the Rev. Ray Kehew at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church in New Shoreham, R.I.

title: Some New Maps Worth Unfolding
description: MUCH has been made lately of mapping features on the Web. They have their advantages, including the ability to customize the cartography. But I've found that maps taken from the Web do not help me much on the road unless they are printed on a color printer, and even then, they are pretty dinky at 8 1/2 by 11. So, as a map-dependent, I continue to linger by the racks in bookstores, comparing legibility and manageability -- how the map folds.

title: Rohit Bhalla, Lisa Calabria
description: Lisa Mary Calabria and Dr. Rohit Bhalla were married yesterday at the Surf Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Nikhil Trivedi, a Hindu priest, performed the Vedic ceremony.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: I found your articles on Joyce Maynard and Kenneth Starr an interesting juxtaposition. One deals with a woman who, as a 19-year-old college student, had an affair with a 53-year-old writer. The second deals with a prosecutor pursuing a public figure who, at age 50, had an affair with a 21-year-old intern.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Money Into Art

title: Despite Vote, Three Cities Still Battle to Berth the U.S.S. New Jersey
description: Since it was commissioned on May 23, 1943, the U.S.S. New Jersey has served in World War II and conflicts in Korea, Vietnam and Lebanon. Now, after being decommissioned in 1991, the battleship is involved in a civil war of sorts among Bayonne, Camden and Jersey City for the right to berth the 45,000-ton, 887-foot vessel as a tourist attraction.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAUM, SAMUEL H.
description: BAUM-Samuel H. The partners of Newmark & Company Real Estate note with deepest sorrow the passing of Samuel Baum, beloved father of Barbara Lerner and fatherin-law of our friend and fellow partner, Arthur Lerner. Our heartfelt sympathies to Mr. Baum's entire family. Jeffrey Gural Barry M. Gosin James D. Kuhn Arthur Rosenbloom Ronald Goldberger William G. Cohen Marlene R. Post

title: A Middle-Income Housing Program Gathers Steam
description: RELAXED on a park bench a few days ago, Joseph Scarpinito looked across the street at the nearly complete apartment house he is building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn and speculated on what might have happened on the site, but didn't.

title: McGwire Reaches 68; Mets Are a Game Out
description: Responding royally once again to the persistent challenge of Sammy Sosa, Mark McGwire snatched back the lead in the home run race yesterday. McGwire had slugged a homer the night before to tie the race at 66 after Sosa had taken a rare lead; yesterday, McGwire hit Nos. 67 and 68, right, against Montreal in St. Louis to take the lead again by two home runs.

title: Life at the Beach With Wild Parakeets
description: AT 7:30 A.M., as the mist rises over Long Island Sound at Compo Beach in Westport, distant chirps and trills break the silence. It's a form of bird song too musical to be attributed to sea gulls. ''They'll be here soon,'' says Angelo Veno, 70 years old , and a retired developer. ''In the winter sometimes, we get 150 to 200 parrots.''

title: Cottage-Like Space in Bedford Village
description: IN a village with few convenient snacking spots, this place could not be better situated. Meetinghouse is next door to the Bedford Playhouse and the village green is a stone's throw down the block. If it is to pass for more than a place for a snack or a drink, location is not enough.

title: Postings: Assisted-Living Rentals in Kew Gardens; Apartments For the Elderly
description: Leasing began last month at an eight-story, hotel-like rental building for the elderly in Kew Gardens, Queens, which is scheduled to open Jan. 1.

title: In Paris, a Wall Street Veteran Argues the Case for Laissez-Faire
description: FRANCE has been governed by the Socialists for the entire year that Felix G. Rohatyn has been the United States Ambassador in Paris. So Mr. Rohatyn, the former Lazard Freres partner who oversaw the rescue of New York City from the brink of bankruptcy in the 1970's, has spent a lot of time trying to explain American ''popular capitalism'' to the French.

title: Corrections
description: The Favorite Funds table on the Data Bank page last Sunday misstated the basis for selecting the funds. They were the stock mutual funds with the most assets under management, not the funds held by the largest number of accounts. The table also omitted the source of the data. It was Morningstar Inc.

title: Persian Gulf Cruises To Call at Iranian Port
description: In another effort by Iran to show greater hospitality toward the United States, Americans will be able to visit Iran by ship for the first time in more than 20 years.

title: Programs Reflect Countries
description: AN international spirit brings a number of events into focus next weekend, including Sicilian dances in Valhalla, Irish songs in Mamaroneck and most unlikely of all, perhaps, a Scarsdale concert titled ''Musical Connection in Leipzig: the Schumanns, Mendelssohn and Japanese Composers.''

title: Congress Fears Medicare Will Miss Deadlines for Change
description: Just three months before a new era in the history of Medicare is to begin, members of Congress and health policy experts are expressing alarm that the Federal Medicare agency cannot meet statutory deadlines for many of the changes scheduled to take effect over the next two years.

title: Asleep in the Cockpit? Automation's Nightmare
description: NEW passenger jets are so automated that two pilots do the work that used to be performed by three, yet they have lighter workloads. The newer planes also make longer trips, across more time zones. While technology has increased airline safety in many ways, it can also make for sleepy pilots.

title: Daniel Scheulov, Christine Cave
description: Christine Elizabeth Cave, the daughter of Mrs. Gilbert L. Nelson of New Brunswick, N.J., and Dr. Alfred E. Cave of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Daniel Igorevich Scheulov, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Igor Scheulov of Moscow.

title: Unsung Heroine
description: Forget the pro-Clinton backlash. Isn't it past time for a pro-Monica backlash?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We can't look at the face of Kohl any more. It's a physical thing, a psychological thing, just as the British tired of Mrs. Thatcher. But at the same time, this is such an awkward choice. I do not know if I can trust the Social Democrats.''

title: Krista Clancy, Matthew Annenberg
description: Krista Michele Clancy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon A. Clancy of Ridgewood, N.J., was married last evening at the Harvard Club in New York to Matthew Douglas Annenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ted M. Annenberg of New York. Judge Donna Mills of New York Civil Court officiated.

title: Dear Mr. Carver. This Is a Cease and Desist Order.
description: TIMES do change. A century ago, peanut butter was considered a health food. Of course, in those days Coca-Cola was rumored to contain a secret ingredient that many Southerners still suspect was cocaine. Now a growing number of nutritionists say the easy-to-make staple of the lunch-box set, the peanut butter and jelly sandwich, should come with a warning that says it can be hazardous to your health. And not because of the jelly or the bread.

title: Monitor Group Keeps an Eye on State's Courts
description: The defendant stood before the judge in Suffolk County Court in Riverhead. This was the man's third arrest for drunken driving, and he had agreed to allow the judge to hear his case.

title: Babylon Revisited
description: Model Behavior

description: Paula Michelle Carr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ambrose A. Carr Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Alexander Bedford Cummings, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Cummings of Washington. The Rev. McLean A. Cummings, the bridegroom's brother and a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Going Beyond 12 Ideas; Why Not a Cellar Market Or an E-Z Metrocard?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Graying Of Autumn
description: Fall, the time for changing colors, has quickly seen women replacing black clothes with gray outfits. And there is nothing dull about fashion's spectrum of gray, which ranges from a banker's flannel to platinum sequin skirts. Many women are mixing several shades of the color in one outfit. Top far left, black is reduced to an accessory -- a shoulder bag -- and a cell phone. Bottom far left, the surprise of a sequin skirt worn with a gray twin set.

title: Atlantic Crossing
description: In the late 19th century, adventurers and explorers were celebrities, hauling in big speaking fees. George Harbo and Frank Samuelson, immi grants from Norway living in the Atlantic Highlands, were making a meager living hauling in claims at Nauvoo (now Sea Bright) and Sandy Hook Bay. So they decided to become adventurers themselves. In 1896, they became the first men to row across the Atlantic, making the voy age of 3,000 miles from New York City to the Scilly Islands in 55 days - no one has bettered that time in a number of attempts since - then on to Le Havre, France, and Paris. De spite a heroic tale of facing storms, fatigue and hunger in a an 18-foot boat with no sail, the two did not achieve fame and riches. David W. Shaw, who lives in Westfield, has put the story of their voyage in a book, ''Daring the Sea,'' published by Car of Publishing Group in Secaucus ($19.95). Mr. Shaw has also written a book about his own four-year voyage through the waterways of the North east.

title: Katherine Friedman and John Hickey
description: Dr. Katherine Frank Friedman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome T. Friedman of Manhattan, was married yesterday to John Timothy Hickey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Hickey of Greenwich, Conn. Judge Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at Le Cirque 2000 in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOAS, RUTH
description: BOAS-Ruth. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University notes with profound regret the passing of the beloved mother of Muriel and Sol Cantor. Mr. Cantor is a long-time member of our Board of Overseers. For many years, the Cantor and Boas families have been devoted friends of our medical school and respected members of our Society of Founders. To the entire family, we extend our sincere condolences. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Board of Overseers Albert Einstein College of Medicine Dr. Dominick P. Purpura, Dean

title: From Eugene O'Neill At the Schoolhouse
description: LONG Day's Journey Into Night'' may be the theater's most rightful claim to classical tragedy, American style, in this century. While Tennessee Williams's Blanche DuBois and Arthur Miller's Willy Loman unravel in classic style, their descent, his in particular, is as much a social tragedy as an individual's.

title: Friendly Persuasion
description: A World Transformed

title: Going Beyond 12 Ideas; Why Not a Cellar Market Or an E-Z Metrocard?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Initial Offerings, 1998 Is a Year to Forget
description: Investors who bought into one or more initial public offerings this year might prefer not to be reminded of them. The average initial offering was down 13.9 percent through last Thursday, according to Commscan, a New York company that tracked 333 such deals. And the Bloomberg I.P.O. index, which tracks stocks for 12 months after their debuts, was down 30.2 percent from its April 22 high.

title: Corrections
description: A review in the Book Review last Sunday about ''The Baltimore Case: A Trial of Politics, Science, and Character,'' by Daniel J. Kevles, misstated the surname of the Harvard Medical School scientist who remarked, in the course of a Congressional investigation of possible fraud in science, that the incidence of fraud among recipients of grants from the National Institutes of Health was ''way below 1 percent,'' and went on to say, ''I'm not sure that the number of crooks in Congress is less than 1 percent.'' He was Bernard Davis, not Harris.

title: Affirmed Success Clears Hurdle And Aims for the Breeders' Cup
description: In five starts this year, Affirmed Success had done everything his trainer, Richard Schosberg, had asked of him -- except beat Kelly Kip.

title: A Tenor Who Knows No Bounds
description: AS weeks go in the life of the ubiquitous Placido Domingo, the next two, though cram-packed by the standards of mere mortal performers, are not that punishing.

description: Christine McKendry, the daughter of Claire Moylan of Langhorne, Pa., was married yesterday to Eduardo Nils Tarto Andrade, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose E. Andrade of New York. The Rev. Paul L. Hebert performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Most Holy Trinity Church in Pomfret, Conn.

title: How to Cut Wood, Tile and Masonry
description: MOST household cutting jobs consist of slicing through paper, cloth or wood. Do-it-yourselfers can easily handle these cutting chores although sometimes cutting lumber to size can present problems.

description: Sara Michael Armstrong, a daughter of Nancy and Jack Armstrong of Sea Girt, N.J., is to be married this morning to Peter Gannon Crumlish, a son of Gabrielle and Arthur Crumlish of New York. The Rev. Gerard McCrane, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Allaire Chapel in Allaire, N.J.

title: Renee Ramirez And Justin Herz
description: Renee Anne Ramirez and Justin David Herz were married yesterday at the Bird and Bottle Inn in Garrison, N.Y. Judge Loretta A. Preska of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, HAZEL HORN
description: DAVIS-Hazel Horn. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Daughter of the late Ray and Benjamin Horn. Much loved cousin and aunt. Graveside services Sunday, September 27, 12 noon at Union Fields Cemetery, Glendale, Queens, NY.

title: Kari Ginsberg, Robert Nesbit
description: Kari Margit Ginsberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sandy Ginsberg of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Robert Wilson Nesbit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Nesbit of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Georgia Ann Snell, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church on Nantucket Island.

title: In Hartford, Landscapes From Two New Worlds
description: Two hundred years ago, as the new United States and the new British colony in Australia confronted their vast wildernesses, expanses never imagined in their mother country, what kind of landscape art did they produce? How was it similar, how different? ''New Worlds From Old: 19th-Century Australian and American Landscapes,'' which opened at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford this month, offers some answers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, EDNA (NEE MARCUS)
description: LEDERMAN-Edna (nee Marcus). Died September 25, 1998. A true woman of valor. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Dear mother of Arnold and Fran and Saul and Betty. Adored grandma of Diane Sharon, Nancy and Michael Cohen, Steven and Kenneth. Great-grandma to Samantha and Thalia. Devoted sister of Lee Elkins, Alex and Seymour and the late Harold Marcus. Graveside services Sunday, September 27 at 3 PM, New Montifiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Amid All the Confusion, The Mets Hit the Bottom
description: AFTER the final weekend of a compelling baseball season, the Mets are going home -- but not the way they wanted.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Allison Read, Stephen Walk
description: Allison Read, the daughter of Vice Adm. and Mrs. William L. Read of Easton, Md., and Stephen Germond Winans Walk, a son of Mrs. Everett G. Walk of Reading, Pa., and the late Mr. Walk, were married yesterday in Newport, R.I. The bridegroom's brother, the Rev. Everett P. Walk, performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: For Printers, an Eviction Notice; Landlords Are Seeking Cleaner, High-Paying Tenants
description: Harold Russell has to yell to be heard above the roar of the Miehle Roland presses churning out 25,000 brochures for an insurance company. The pungent smell of ink envelops the shop floor like a thick cloud.

title: The Cult of Joyce Maynard
description: You let us know (between the lines, of course) that Maynard, a working writer, is little more than a hack, living out her days with an unsightly dog, some kids and a ''laugh with a hysterical edge to it.'' Maynard has survived a great deal, including Salinger's frozen-peas-for-breakfast regime. Let's hope she can survive your less-than-kind treatment.

title: Kickoff
description: VISIBLE WORLDS

title: A New Birth for American Opera
description: OPERA has for too long, by too many people, been defined as works of the past by composers long dead, with the emphasis less on the operas themselves than on the divas and divos singing them. For operas by American composers, the situation has been even worse: American opera has been ignored by opera companies, audiences and American singers -- an orphan on opera's doorstep.

title: Their Art Survived Them
description: FORTY watercolors selected from nearly 4,000 drawings created by children who faced deportation to Nazi death camps are being shown in a collection, ''I Have Not Seen a Butterfly Around Here,'' on display at the Czech Center. The children were held in the Terezin Ghetto, which was maintained by the Nazis from 1941 to 1945, in an old fortress town about 50 miles from Prague. The exhibition's title comes from a poem written by Pavel Friedmann, a young Terezin inmate who died in Auschwitz.

title: September 20-26; Reading Tea Leaves
description: Alan Greenspan and Keizo Obuchi have almost nothing in common. Except that the Federal Reserve chairman and the new Japanese Prime Minister both enjoy reputations for making public comments that leave investors puzzled.

title: Crime
description: If Robert B. Parker doesn't blow it, in the new series he set up in ''Night Passage'' and continues with TROUBLE IN PARADISE (Putnam, $22.95), he could go places and take the kind of risks that wouldn't be seemly in his popular Spenser stories. His protagonist, a former Los Angeles cop named Jesse Stone, has promise; but does he have resolve? A man prone to drink and bruised by marital betrayal, Jesse tries to salvage his life by becoming Chief of Police of the coastal town of Paradise, Mass. Driving around his little patch in the dead of night and hanging out with the natives in the Gray Gull bar, he is just starting to get a feel for small-town crime (catch the great station house scene in which he goes toe-to-toe with the parents of two teen-age arsonists) when a big-time gang of crooks invades Paradise with a daring scheme to clean out Stiles Island, the high-money end of the community.

title: Lauren Braddock, James Havey Jr.
description: Lauren Anese Braddock was married yesterday to James M. Havey Jr. at the Union Station Hotel in Nashville. The Rev. Terry Dearmore of the First Church Unity officiated.

title: Con Ed Bid Rejected
description: Round No. 1 in Consolidated Edison's effort to lower property taxes on its Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor went to the town of Cortlandt.

title: At Bakery, Homes May Rise
description: Maritta Dunn, chairwoman of Community Board 9, still relishes the sweet aroma that once wafted from the Taystee Cake Bakery in western Harlem, even though it closed 20 years ago.

title: Nicole Tillinghast, Francis Jenkins 3d
description: Nicole Fuller Tillinghast, the daughter of J. J. Tillinghast and George L. Tillinghast, both of West Hartford, Conn., was married last evening to Francis Plummer Jenkins 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jenkins Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y. The Rev. Karin Fowler performed the ceremony at Asylum Hill Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: Putting Children First In Education
description: It is unrealistic to expect all students to pass five Regents exams [''Schools '98: Bar's Raised and Space Is Precious,'' Sept. 6]. Lowering passing grades and making the tests easier is not the honest way to reform education and raise standards.

title: A Crucial Week for a Frayed Global Safety Net
description: FOR the world's central bankers and finance ministers, this is the week to put up or shut up.

title: Evans Makes Spectacular Return for the Cornhuskers
description: One play, one pitch to DeAngelo Evans was all Bobby Newcombe was wishing for against the Washington Huskies today. The Nebraska quarterback had sat out the past two games with a torn knee ligament. Evans, the I-back in the ground-gobbling Cornhusker option, had been out for 21 months trying to overcome a medical chart worth of injuries.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 16 about the potential sale of the Cleveland Browns football team included an outdated reference to Max W. Jacobs, a member of a family that operates sports franchises and is among the bidders. Although he was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in a 1972 Las Vegas case against a family company, the Emprise Corporation, involving casino operations, Mr. Jacobs's name was legally expunged from the indictment in 1980.

title: September 20-26; Russia and I.M.F. Square Off
description: Russia and the International Monetary Fund have never liked each other, but now neither side is hiding it. The new Russian Government declared that unless it got more aid from the I.M.F. it might default on its international obligations. The I.M.F. said that it wouldn't tolerate ''blackmail,'' and that if Russia wants loans, it might think about collecting some taxes and turning off the printing presses that are spitting out rubles and creating hyperinflation.

title: OPINION; Finding Many Doors to the Temple
description: WITH the regularity of ritual, as reliable as the sounding of the shofar whose piercing ram's horn blasts usher in the Jewish New Year, my son Jacob, now 10, asks the perennial September question: ''Do I have to go to Hebrew school?''

title: Even a Hedge Fund Can Be 'Too Big to Fail'
description: Long-Term Capital Management was every inch a hedge fund. For a big-money client list, the fund's big-name managers took big chances with even bigger leverage in pursuit of really big returns. Lately the fund had bought risky emerging-markets bonds and hedged by selling Treasuries short, a strategy that got it in big trouble when Russia devalued, setting off a market stampede to safety that made both those moves big losers and nearly wiped out the fund's capital.

title: It's Never Too Early to Think Spring
description: Order spring bulbs. In addition to showy hybrid tulips, try species tulips like Tulipa batalinii Apricot Jewel. Add these diminutive charmers to the front of borders, rock gardens and raised beds, where they are closer to eye level. Unlike hybrids, which diminish in vigor after several years, these set seed and will multiply happily.

title: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy

Service Monday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Dune Grows in Margate, Thanks to Christmas Trees
description: Last winter this section reported on a fourth-grade class at the Union Avenue School in Margate that ''planted'' 120 discarded Christmas trees on the beach to protect the sand from erosion. The three rows of trees that were stood upright along 100 feet of beachfront are now buried under seven to eight feet of sand. City officials bought 3,500 plugs of dune grass that the children planted along the mound and then fenced the area. KAREN DeMASTERS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAYNE, NEIL
description: SHAYNE-Neil. We love you. You will always be in our hearts. Sheila and Fred Abrams Elaine and Len Marcus

title: U.S. Envoy Issues a Stern Warning on Kosovo
description: The American envoy leading efforts to resolve the conflict in Kosovo said today that the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, had ''no justification'' for pressing his campaign against insurgents and warned that he faced a devastating blow if he refused to stop.

In 1978, when he was 26, he immigrated to the United States and settled in Stamford, where several of his schoolmates had also moved. One of the first things he did when he got there was to help form the Stamford Cricket Club.

title: He's Here for Eternity, but Don't Ask Where
description: A recent tour of the Friends Cemetery in Prospect Park ended as all such tours do: visitors asked to see the spot where Montgomery Clift is buried, and the guides refused.

description: While some fans held hands and closed their eyes like participants in a seance, and others gnawed straws to tatters, Mark McGwire stepped into the batter's box at Busch Stadium today as if it were an isolation booth.

description: Like a love-struck intern parsing the boss's neckwear for a secret sign that the feeling is mutual, world markets hunted obsessively last week for reasons to believe that the Federal Open Market Committee would cut interest rates at its meeting on Tuesday.

description: SOMETIMES things just click into place. Like a flight of stairs in which one step simply follows the other; like a plot so tightly constructed no other story line seems possible; a relationship can start, progress and find permanence with the ease of something preordained.

title: The Prodigal Team Player
description: Q. I am part of a small team that creates product marketing materials for our manufacturing company. One member of our team chews up much more than her share of our group budget, overpaying for necessities and wasting money on frills. Should the rest of us keep pinching pennies, even though the quality of the work suffers, or should we spend what we think we need, knowing that it will call down the wrath of the bean counters on the whole team?

title: Fourth Straight in the Fifth for a Cagey Viciosa of Spain
description: In the 1970's, the Oakland A's won three straight World Series, but not four. In the 1980's, Ivan Lendl won three straight United States Open tennis titles, but not four. Early in the 1990's, the Chicago Bulls won three straight National Basketball Association titles, but not four.

title: In the Region / Connecticut; Avalon Expected to Nearly Triple Stamford Rentals
description: WHEN Avalon Bay Communities completes two rental apartment projects under construction in Stamford -- and if it wins expected approvals on a third -- it will add 1,132 units to the total of 638 rental units it has already built in the city at Avalon Glen and Avalon Grove.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1999 Oldsmobile Alero; A Key Piece in a Survival Blueprint
description: OLDSMOBILE is the nation's longest-running auto maker and General Motors' oldest division, but for a decade it has been struggling to remake itself and remain relevant to consumers who don't put much stock in history.

description: A picture caption last Sunday about the Paper Mill Playhouse misidentified the woman seen with the actress Betty Buckley, who is starring in ''Gypsy.'' She is Laura Bell Bundy, not Deborah Gibson.

title: Greens Abandon One of Their Own
description: There is no state where the Green Party is stronger or more active than New Mexico. In recent years, Green candidates, with their appeal to environmentalists, hard-left liberals and counter-culturists, have helped put several New Mexican Republicans in office by stealing away the votes of dissident Democrats concerned about the ideological purity of Democratic standard-bearers.

description: THE 516 area code, long a numeric emblem for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, may soon be augmented by a second area code because of exploding demand for telephone numbers, telephone company executives and regulators said last week.

title: Tara Rowe, Samuel Hawley
description: Tara Hansen Rowe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Ackley Rowe 3d of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Samuel Roberts Hawley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Waller Hawley Jr., also of Fairfield. The Rev. Thomas M. Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Vision of a Child's Inner World
description: ALL children grow up. They all know they will grow up. They all know after they're two. Two is the beginning of the end.''

title: Hollywood Loves Writers (If They Suffer)
description: JAMES IVORY boasts about the fact that in the many movies he has made about authors, he has almost never shown one writing. ''I never even for one second thought of him writing,'' said Mr. Ivory of his latest character, the novelist James Jones, in the new film ''A Soldier's Daughter Never Cries.'' The image of the miserable outsider, an alcoholic tormented by writer's block, facing a forbidding black Remington portable in a seedy hotel room, is a commonplace of films about writers, and Mr. Ivory has always strived to avoid it.

title: Edward Whitmont, 85, Leader In Teaching Jungian Psychology
description: Dr. Edward Christopher Whitmont, a Jungian psychoanalyst and homeopathic physician who introduced many Americans to the fundamentals of Jungian psychology through his writing and teaching, died on Monday at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 85.

title: Habitats; A Mill House That's Grist for His Passion
description: A FEW years ago Pat Glynn built a two-story house with cathedral ceilings on the side of a mountain, overlooking a lake. The house had everything he and his wife, Evelyn, could want.

title: The Last Course: It's Time to Say Goodbye to a Job Worth Savoring
description: SURELY the hardest part of my job as a restaurant reviewer is quitting. For three and a half years, I've had the luxury of pursuing two beloved pastimes, eating and writing about eating, at someone else's expense. I hate cooking. I hate spending (my own) money. Why quit?

Smith of St. Louis. The Rev. Mark E. Grimes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Georgetown, Conn.

description: SMOKING

title: Despite Lack of Seasoning, Lewis Retains W.B.C. Title
description: After Vaughn Bean lasted 12 rounds against Evander Holyfield in their heavyweight championship fight last week, Lennox Lewis complained that Holyfield looked like a has-been.

title: Sports of The Times; For the Giants, 'the Best Offense' Is a Matter of Perspective
description: SO I am watching the Giants play the Cowboys last Monday night, trailing by 10 points deep in the third quarter, and I am thinking, no doubt about it, they are about to score a touchdown any second now, put themselves right back in the football game.

title: Maybe Pepsi Has a Job For a Dogged Coke Critic
description: Albert J. Meyer, a mild-mannered accountant, gained fame in 1995 for leading investigators to the New Era Philanthropy fraud in Philadelphia that cost investors of tens of millions of dollars. His doggedness in uncovering that scam helped win him a job at Martin Capital Management in Elkhart, Ind.

title: Toddler Resort
description: To the Editor: We too have had the plasure of staying at the Four Seasons Aviara in Carlsbad, Calif. (''In California, Two Resorts Fit for Toddlers,'' Aug. 2) It not only caters to toddlers and adults but also wins over the hearts of older children and, yes, adolescents.

title: The Garden Sundial, Not Just an Ornament
description: FOR more than 5,000 years, humankind has traced the rhythms of life and anchored itself in the shadows of the natural world with a scientific device now consigned to graves, gardens and college campuses. The sundial has been relegated to the ranks of the inconsequential, deemed inconvenient and incorrect.

title: The Selling of 'Felicity' (in a 70-Channel Universe)
description: FOCUS groups swooned over the pilot of the WB's ''Felicity.'' Industry analysts -- even executives at rival networks -- declared ''Felicity,'' a new hourlong drama, the only sure hit of an otherwise unpredictable fall season. Spotting their latest It Girl, magazine and newspaper editors rushed to give the kiss-and-hug treatment to the show's star, Keri Russell, a 22-year-old former Mouseketeer with an innocently open gaze and angelically backlit blond curls who seems incapable of taking a bad photograph. The WB couldn't have bought better insider buzz.

title: Off-Season Pleasures of Eleuthera
description: SOMEWHERE around Cape Hatteras the sky turned from light blue to steel gray, with an ominous band of black that slashed across the horizon. A half-dozen thunderheads rose against this gloomy backdrop -- some spun upward like plumes from an enormous forest fire, others spread at the top like nuclear mushrooms. If weather were a movie, this would be a Spielberg, I thought, pressing my nose closer to the window of the plane for a better look. I felt lucky to be witnessing nature's own late-summer blockbuster from a front-row seat -- but that was about the only positive note I could squeeze from the moment. For the raging storm to the southeast was Hurricane Bonnie, and my friend Karrie and I were on the way to what we had envisioned as an uninterrupted week of snorkeling, beach and sun in the Bahamas.

title: Opening Nights
description: COMING UP ROSES

title: Joyce Campbell, Robert Giuffra Jr.
description: Joyce Diane Campbell and Robert Joseph Giuffra Jr. were married yesterday at the Georgetown Presbyterian Church in Washington. The Rev. Campbell Gillon officiated, and the Rev. Paul Hartmann, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEACH, ALAN
description: LEACH-Alan. On Friday, October 2, at 6:15 P.M., Church of the Epiphany, 2nd Avenue at 22 Street, New York, New York.

title: September 20-26; Gift for Salvation Army
description: McDonald's, it's safe to say, has changed the world, imprinting cookie-cutter standardization on the global psyche. Now Joan Kroc, the widow of Ray Kroc, who made McDonald's into a golden-arched juggernaut, is using a few of her millions to try to change one corner of the world, donating $80 million to the Salvation Army for a community center in inner-city San Diego.

title: Lisa Lee, Robert Smith 3d
description: Lisa Hyun-Ji Lee, the daughter of Ha Yung Lee and the late Theresa K. Lee was married last evening to Robert Angus Kermode Smith 3d, the son of Katherine Southworgh Smith and Mr. Smith Jr. of Edwards, Colo. The Rev. Charles Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Ken Starr Would Not Be Denied
description: First, I stopped listening to the news. Then I stopped talking about it. Because the Starr investigation, which started out as a comedy (with a cast of characters that includes a dogged investigator, a maligned wife, a star-struck ingenue) is turning into a national tragedy.

title: Dianne Lewis, Maurice Batista
description: Dianne Morrow Lewis, a daughter of Carol Kelley Lewis of Water Mill, N.Y., and the late William E. Lewis, was married yesterday to Maurice Batista, a son of the late Maria and Emanuel Batista, who lived in Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Thomas Reese performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: 'Liberal' as Jab May Fail D'Amato This Time
description: In the very first sentence of a commercial that he unveiled on the very first day of his general-election campaign, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato signaled his plan of attack on his challenger, Representative Charles E. Schumer. To anyone who had followed Mr. D'Amato's previous campaigns, or the candidacies of a dozen Republicans across the nation who read from the same strategic playbook, it was anything but a surprise.

title: Italy Eliminates the U.S. With a Five-Set Victory
description: Strange things have been happening in the Davis Cup ever since it began in 1900. Patriotic pipsqueaks have scrambled past powerhouse shoo-ins, insurmountable deficits have inspired miraculous comebacks, and nationalistic fans have thrown everything but kitchen sinks at players they viewed as visiting villains.

title: Chase Boyer, Josh Ferrer
description: Elizabeth Chase Boyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Morrison Boyer of Hickory, N.C., was married yesterday to Jose Maria Ferrer 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferrer 3d of New York. The Rev. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Hickory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IGEL, PERY
description: IGEL-Pery. In Sao Paulo, Brazil, on September 24. Husband of Ana Maria, father of Rogerio, Joyce, Marcia, the late Ernesto and Fabio. Beloved friend of Henry Schneider. A man of vision, vast accomplishiments and above all a great heart. He helped shape our lives with his love and caring. Jacqueline, Jean and Michael Schneider Robert, James, Max and Ethan

title: Amy Frohling and Benjamin Curcio
description: Amy Mary Frohling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucien O. Frohling of North Caldwell, N.J., was married there yesterday to Benjamin Charles Curcio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Curcio of Chatham, Mass. Msgr. Edward J. Ciuba performed the ceremony at Notre Dame Church.

title: Stylish Neapolitan Newcomer Pleases . . .
description: IF the words Neapolitan restaurant bring images of red-and-white checked tablecloths, candles in Chianti bottles and vats of tomato sauce in the kitchen, think again. Naples 25, the younger brother of Naples 45 in Manhattan, recently opened in the Americana shopping center in Manhasset. It is as sleek and stylish as any of the Tuscan beauties that dot the Island.

title: G.O.P. Says It Ignores Critical Polls On Inquiry
description: Republicans in Congress insist that they will not be deterred in their investigation of President Clinton by polls this week showing the public's disapproval.

title: Back With a Bang After Three Quiet Years
description: THE British singer and guitarist Polly Jean Harvey is without question the most critically lauded rock-and-roller of the 90's, and the hosannas are sure to continue with ''Is This Desire?'' Like every P. J. Harvey album since her 1992 release, ''Dry,'' announced her as a force to be reckoned with, her new one is intense, imaginative and certain of its own significance. Once again yoking the indubitably traditional to the overtly experimental, it opens new vistas of thwarted fulfillment in a sonic quest that doesn't sacrifice emotional resonance to avant-garde posturing. To any reasonably open-minded fan who takes the trouble to listen, it leaves no doubt that it's an Important Record.

title: More Dominicans Are Feared Dead as Waters Recede
description: Four days after Hurricane Georges clobbered the Dominican Republic with shattering force, and as help arrives from around the world, this Caribbean country is still counting its dead.

title: Bag of Bones
description: On a very hot day in August of 1994, my wife told me she was going down to the Derry Rite Aid to pick up a refill on her sinus medicine prescription -- this is stuff you can buy over the counter these days, I believe. I'd finished my writing for the day and offered to pick it up for her. She said thanks, but she wanted to get a piece of fish at the supermarket next door anyway; two birds with one stone and all of that. She blew a kiss at me off the palm of her hand and went out. The next time I saw her, she was on TV. That's how you identify the dead here in Derry -- no walking down a subterranean corridor with green tiles on the walls and long fluorescent bars overhead, no naked body rolling out of a chilly drawer on casters; you just go into an office marked PRIVATE and look at a TV screen and say yep or nope.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Boces Becomes a Technology Services Force
description: IN 1948, when the State Legislature created the Board of Cooperative Educational Services, its goal was to allow local school districts to pool resources so they could save money and provide more services. The agency, known throughout the state as Boces, allowed districts to offer services like special education and vocational education that they could not afford individually.

title: Love Among the Ruins
description: WHEN you sail toward the island of Naxos, your eye is caught by a monument that not only looks strange and distinctive but is as much a symbol or trademark of the island as the Statue of Liberty is of New York. It's a giant portal, 21 feet high and 16 feet across, that stands at the end of a natural causeway running out of the port city of Chora. The Portara, as it's called, was put in place around 520 B.C. by a tyrant named Lygdamis, and was to be a suitably grand entrance to the greatest temple to Apollo in all Greece. But Lygdamis was overthrown in 506, the temple was left unfinished, and 2,000 years later it was still being plundered for its marble. Today you can wander through the remnants of the place, maybe musing on the pride of princes, the hubris of tyrants.

title: Hero Appeal
description: Now that reruns of HERCULES: THE LEGENDARY JOURNEYS and XENA: WARIOR PRINCESS are appearing weekdays on the USA Network, even the most devout fans may be tiring of the same draconian monsters and ungodly gods. Fear not. New evil is in sight, as the stars of the syndicated hits begin the season far from their home sod. In tonight's premiere episodes, on Channel 11, the son of Zeus (Kevin Sorbo) journeys to the castle of Gilgamesh in Sumeria with a wary Iolaus (Michael Hurst), who is shocked at discovering a strange and unusual set of deities, while Xena (Lucy Lawless) ventures even farther afield, encountering a Siberian warrior on her way, not to Hades, but an all-new Land of the Dead - SATURDAY at 8 P.M. (XENA) and 9 P.M. (HERCULES)

title: Snake Oil? Never
description: TOM FILLIUS wants to correct some misperceptions of Chief Two Moon Meridas, who once sold patent medicines on the Boardwalk.

title: Trying -- Again -- to Derail Rumor About Veterans Benefits
description: For veterans, keeping track of their entitlements is a chore. Legislators have repeatedly reduced the generous benefits that a grateful nation established after World War II, and the federal Department of Veterans Affairs, like other governmental agencies, has constraints on its advertising budget.

title: Rallying to Increase Aid for Cancer Research
description: Thousands of people who have cancer, who have overcome it, who have lost friends and relatives to the disease or are working in laboratories to conquer it marched in the nation's capital today to seek more money for research.

title: A Bet? Yes. A Loss? Maybe.
description: To the Editor:

title: W.P.A. Murals, Aging With Grace and Growing in Value
description: MURALS made for various relief agencies during the Depression were considered a form of workfare, and not valuable art. This attitude led to gross negligence, and tales abound of ambitious work being painted over or thrown away in the course of a building renovation.

title: Not a Horn of Plenty
description: LIKE thousands of Mexican immigrants before him, Miguel Lopez made his way to New York last fall hoping to find work that might pay more than the $15 he made each week as a bricklayer in Puebla, his home state. With six relatives depending on his meager income, Mr. Lopez, 22, says it was getting harder and harder to keep everyone's stomach full. ''I didn't want to leave home, but if I stayed, my family would go hungry,'' he said.

title: Spreading The Risks Of Hedging
description: HEDGE funds lost their luster in a big way last week when Long-Term Capital Management, once the brain-trust darling of Wall Street, came within a hair's breadth of bankruptcy and investors were said to be left with 20 percent or less of their stakes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBIN, LILLIAN
description: RUBIN-Lillian. One year, September 26, 1997. Not a day goes by that I don't think of you, Mom. We all miss you and love you in our hearts and our minds.

title: Democrats Push New Theme Of 'Lost Way' Republicans
description: Picking up where President Clinton left off on Friday, three past or future Presidential aspirants today attacked the Republican-led Congress for focusing on the White House scandal at the expense of passing a budget bill and other important legislation.

title: An Efficient Testaverde Finds 'Right Spot' for Jets
description: Vinny Testaverde is surrounded by the trappings of his youth, when he could steamroller Sewanhaka High to victory by force of will. But now, at age 34, playing for the team whose legendary quarterback's picture used to adorn his bedroom wall, Testaverde is happy being a smart veteran -- and just being happy.

title: Full-Time Mothers Meet Part-Time Jobs
description: ON a typical school day in Mill Valley, Calif., Paula Reynolds rises at 5:30 A.M., gets her two oldest children out the door by 7:45 and hops into the car to follow her youngest as he navigates his bike down the hill to school. Then she commutes to work to San Francisco, 45 minutes away. Five hectic hours later, she heads back home in time to greet her children -- Peter, 12; Julia, 9, and Charlie, 6 -- at the door at 3 P.M.

title: Truth Is Elusive in Vallone's Statements About Pataki in Governor's Race
description: On the night Peter F. Vallone won the Democratic primary to run against Gov. George E. Pataki, he told supporters in a speech broadcast statewide that Mr. Pataki ''wrote the Republican Party's anti-choice platform in 1990.''

title: DATABANK: September 21-25; Stocks' Gains Mask Traders' Anxieties
description: The market's numbers for the past week look better than its shaky performance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose a respectable 133.11 points to close at 8,028.77, and the Nasdaq composite advanced nearly 80 points to close at 1,743.59. Even the small-capitalization Russell 2000, which has been battered this year, climbed nearly 6 points to 369.02.

title: September 20-26; Pentagon's Gay Policy Upheld
description: The Supreme Court has declined so far to take up the constitutionality of the military's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy. But the Court may get another opportunity after a ruling by a Federal appeals court, which said the policy does not violate homosexuals' rights.

title: Lives of the Judges
description: The gift shop on the ground floor of the Supreme Court building offers for sale, in addition to postcards, miniature gavels and brass scales of justice, judicial biographies by the dozen. Perhaps not many visitors to the Court, which opens its new term next week, are drawn to the life of David J. Brewer, who spent 20 years as a Justice at the turn of the century, or of Stephen J. Field, who served 33 years after the death of Abraham Lincoln, the President who appointed him.

title: Designing Women
description: At Ian Schrager's office-warming party last week at 475 10th Avenue, his love of minimalist chic appeared in more than the furniture. Matching the elegant curves of his Eames chairs were the nine women on his design staff -- all tall and wearing the same form-hugging dress. They call themselves Anda's Angels, after Anda Andrei, the design director of Mr. Schrager's hotel empire and lead Angel. They wore a tube dress with attached stockings created by Phillipe Starcke, the design guru who created the looks of Mr. Schrager's hotels, including the Royalton and Delano. Though the length and neckline of the dress (called the ''Stark naked'') can be transformed, the Angels wore it long and strapless. Talking shop with hotel V.I.P.'s, they looked like particularly glamorous Stepford wives. The Stark suits are being introduced this month by Wolford and were overnighted as a special gift for the Angels from Mr. Starcke. ''Whenever he designs anything funny and great, he shares it with his friends,'' Ms. Andrei said. Along with two male designers, the Angels do everything from choosing coasters to hurricane disaster preparations. ''If it means washing windows to open a space on time, we'll do it,'' Ms. Andrei said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, ARDITH FULLER
description: ROTH-Ardith Fuller. On September 20 in Jacksonville, FL. She was preceded in death by husband Emil J. Roth of NYC, parents Phyllis Warner Pollitz of NYC, Arthur Dodd Fuller of Pacific Palisades, CA and Jane Fuller Stern of NYC. She is survived by brother Clinton W. Fuller and nephew Clinton W. Fuller, Jr. of Shreveport, LA. Services on Tuesday, September 29, at 11 A.M., at Hardage-Giddens Funeral Home, Jacksonville, FL.

title: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: The 'Third Way' Is No Route to Paradise
description: Each age has its cliche. Ours is the ''third way.'' Hardly a week passes without a public figure in Britain, Germany or the United States hailing the coming of the third way: the new, ''post-ideological'' approach to politics and policy making. Sociologists theorize about it, policy seminars promote it, Presidents and prime ministers bask in the reflected glory of its modest ambitions. No reasonable person can dissent; the bad old days of big projects, of left and right, are gone for good. The political goals of the third way are small goals -- and in the cliche of an earlier age, small is beautiful.

title: Jews in Germany
description: To the Editor: More to the letter on Germany's past (Sept. 6) and the Q & A ''Portrait of Tubingen'' (Sept. 6): On the outer wall of the late Gothic church in the center of the Old City of Tubingen, facing the street, are two modest plaques side by side that are probably among the most brutally honest memorials to the victims of the Third Reich.

title: Moody's Raises Ratings On Some State Bonds
description: Moody's Investors Service has upgraded ratings for New Jersey's $7.45 billion appropriation debt, bonds that must be reauthorized by the Legislature each year, saying a strong economy and a reliance on the bonds for important capital projects make the state less likely to default, state officials announced last week.

title: Family Feuds
description: THE SOCIOLOGY OF PHILOSOPHIES A Global Theory of Intellectual Change. By Randall Collins. 1,098 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $49.95.

title: With Higher Speed Limit, State Joins the Nation
