description: OPINIONS are divided over what will happen when the speed limit on about half Connecticut's highways goes up to 65 miles an hour on Thursday. Either it will only legalize the speed nearly all drivers are already driving, or it will encourage more motorists to drive at 75 or 80.

title: Susan Baldomar, Ethan Gussow
description: Susan Baldomar and Ethan Meredith Gussow were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. J. Barrie Shepherd performed the ceremony.

title: Assistant Coaches Are Seeking Better Treatment From N.F.L. Owners
description: Just over a year ago, officials from the National Football League Coaches Association, angry at what they thought was unfair treatment by the owners, met with Jeffrey Kessler, perhaps the most renowned sports antitrust lawyer in the country, in a hotel ballroom in Indianapolis. The topic of conversation? The N.F.L. assistant coaches were considering suing the league for antitrust violations.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, ELSIE
description: SHAPIRO-Elsie. September 27, 1992. Remembered with love

title: A Tenant Overpays On a Sublet
description: Q. My daughter has been subletting a rent-satbilized apartment in New York City for the last two years. She pays the rent to the tenant that had the apartment previous to her and not to the landlord.She believes that the real rent is approximately $500, however she pays $600. She has just been told that the rent would be increased to $1,000 or she must move. What rights does she have, if any? Can she contact the landlord and deal directly with him? ... Eli- nor Geller, Kendall Park, N.J.

title: Hyla Ames, Boris Bauer
description: Hyla Lincoln Ames, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Ames of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Boris Bauer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerhard Bauer of Wachtberg-Pech, Germany. The Rev. Richard S. DenUyl Jr. performed the ceremony at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUGLESTAD, ARNE
description: FUGLESTAD-Arne, 81. Died on September 13, 1998, in Sarasota, Florida. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Arne Fuglestad grew up in Staten Island, NY, and was graduated from Bucknell University in 1939. Entering the U.S. Navy in 1940, he remained for five years, serving in the Atlantic and Pacific theaters during World War II and was discharged in 1945 as a Lieutenant Commander. After the War, he went to work on Wall Street, specializing in Investment Banking. Many of Arne's fondest memories were of his business associations and friends. A devoted family man, he is survived by Alma, his wife of 55 years, two sons, a daughter, and five grandchildren. He was buried at sea by his family. Memorial donations may be made to University Relations, Bucknell University, Cooley Hall, Lewisburg, PA. 17837.

title: The Secrets of a Successful Compost Pile
description: ALL too soon the leaves start to turn and drop. This change should signal to all good gardeners that the time for composting has arrived.

title: Comsewogue Turns Runaway Into a Nail-Biter, 28-27
description: Long Island

title: Chief Investment Strategist: Paine Webber Inc.
description: EDWARD M. KERSCHNER has seven television sets in his Long Island home. His refrigerator is stocked with Snapple, Coca-Cola and Hellmann's mayonnaise. And he brushes his teeth with Crest.

title: Intrigue in Fiorello's Shadow
description: In the long chronicle of bare-knuckle neighborhood conflicts in New York, this one, involving a small park near New York University that contains a particularly vivid statue of Mayor Fiorello La Guardia, is velvet glove.

title: Excuse My Heaving Chest
description: Harlequin, the world's leading publisher of romance potboilers, claims that 59 percent of the genre's readers have attended college. Now Harlequin is hitting campus. This month, the Duke University Museum of Art in Durham, N.C., is displaying 21 oils for Harlequin covers by the late Danny Crouse, who painted dozens of Harlequin covers in the 80's. Most of the paintings -- like ''Drastic Measures'' (pictured) -- fall into one of three categories: adventure, middle-aged romance and, naturally enough, lust.

title: Victoria Tomlinson, John Herrmann 2d
description: Victoria Alexandra Tomlinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Tomlinson of New York, was married yesterday to John Martin Herrmann 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. Herrmann of State College, Pa. The Rev. J. Kevin Fox, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Memorial Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Lucky for Welles
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OHTA, YOSHI (TINY)
description: OHTA-Yoshi (Tiny). Of NYC and Tokyo passed away on September 13, 1998. The devoted wife of the late Teruo Ohta. An inspirational mother to Yasuteru and Akiko Ohta and Mme. Hiroko Yukawa and exceptional mother-in-law to Chie Ohta. Also loving grandmother of Motoyasu and Motoyoshi Yukawa and Teruo and Hikari Ohta. She was a patron of the Arts and an especially devoted fan of The Metropolitan Opera and The St. Petersburg Opera. She lived with love and compassion until the very last of her life. We will miss her presence forever. A private service will be held at a later date in Tokyo.

title: Arithmetic of the Avenues
description: Hunting for an address on an avenue in Manhattan without knowing the cross street does not have to be difficult. Drop the last figure, divide by 2 and add or subtract as indicated below. The answer is the nearest numbered cross street. This key does not apply to Broadway below Eighth Street because of the many streets with names instead of numbers.

title: Miss Tuck and Mr. Serena di Lapigio
description: Charlotte Emily Tuck and Ottavio Serena di Lapigio were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert Gilmore at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Reading, Jamaica.

title: 'Auto Choice' Forgets Some Basic Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, BRENDAN M.
description: JONES-Brendan M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Brendan M. Jones, associated with The Times from 1947, until retiring in 1983.

title: Black or White, They're Birds of a Feather
description: PALE chests gleaming, eyes and foreheads smudged black, a gang of feral creatures huddle together, eyeing the outsider who has stumbled into their midst. In the traditional ''Swan Lake,'' Odette, the swan queen, protects her flock of pen-maidens (female swans) from the threat of human danger; in Matthew Bourne's alternative version, which started previews at the Neil Simon Theater yesterday, the swans' male leader rescues the prince from the hostile birds.

title: Kimberly Nguyen, Ronald Sturm
description: Kimberly H. Nguyen, a daughter of Linda and Khuyen Nguyen of Asbury Park, N.J., is to be married this evening to Ronald Marc Sturm, a son of Ellen and Irving Sturm of New York. Dr. Michael Rosen, a rabbi, is to officiate at the Roslyn Country Club in Roslyn Heights, N.Y.

title: Bad Tennis Players at the Top of Their Game
description: SWINGING her racquet like a fly swatter, Denise Orlando of Medford bent her knees and leaned forward, poised to attack.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Life With Father Divine

title: From Classics to Klezmer, All in One Week
description: QUESTIONS for the concertgoer buying tickets for the Tilles Center this week: Classical music or klezmer? The pianist who won the eminent Van Cliburn Competition, or a sovereign among violinists letting his hair down? Are concerts supposed to be for silent listening to Beethoven's ''Emperor'' piano concerto, or clapping to a combo and dancing in the aisles?

title: Setting Trends On the East Side
description: ASIA DE CUBA *

title: Orchestral Seasons Opening Once Again
description: WITH autumn the symphonic scene begins to flourish again: three orchestras offer their season openers today, and another does so over the weekend.

title: SPLINTERED HOUSE APPROVES TAX CUT WORTH $80 BILLION
description: Brushing aside a veto threat from President Clinton, the House passed an $80 billion Republican tax cut today that would be paid for by projected Federal budget surpluses.

title: Now Starting at Safety, a Man Who Wants to Stay in the Lineup
description: He calls his father the hardest-working man in America.

title: Avoiding the Spruce-Up Craze
description: To Sunday Styles:

title: Airborne
description: To the Editor: Michael Finkel's article reminded me of my trip to the Galapagos in July. It was a 60th birthday present. One among our five was my 26-year-old son, who was captain of his college's Ultimate Frisbee team and now spends most of his weekends traveling the Los Angeles area playing in tournaments. We of course took along a Frisbee. On a beautiful beach, with sea lions on shore and in the water, we tossed the disk around, and were joined after a few minutes by our 65-year-old Ecuadorian naturalist guide.

title: Is Safety the Issue?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Four Doomed Souls, Without a Chance
description: EUGENE O'NEILL'S ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' may be the theater's most rightful claim to classical tragedy, American style, in this century. While Blanche DuBois in Tennessee Williams's ''Streetcar Named Desire'' and Willy Loman in Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman'' unravel in classic style, the descent of DuBois and of Loman -- his in particular -- is as much a social tragedy as an individual's.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: THE HEART IS ITS OWN REASON

title: Elections Needed For LIPA Board
description: The Long Island Power Authority Board must be replaced by an elected board of trustees.

title: With Buses Rerouted, a Plaza Can Now Grow Green
description: After more than two years of what was, even by New York standards, noisy and sharp-elbowed community politics, the Battle of Dag Hammarskjold Park has come to a quiet, if costly, conclusion.

title: Ship of Suspects
description: Agatha Christie's mystery puzzle DEATH ON THE NILE (1978) gets a handsome, full-rigged screen treatment in a highly atmospheric location near Luxor and aboard a deluxe cruise ship as one question hovers over a starry cast and challenges a hefty Poirot (Peter Ustinov, above right, with David Niven): whodunit? He and a tense Mia Farrow have the ripest footage, and, under John Guillermin's deft direction, they make the most of it, as do Bette Davis, Maggie Smith and Angela Lansbury. An ominous musical score heats things up. The clever plot virtually duplicates another Christie movie a while back. But why spoil the fun? Suffice to say, the other picture was shot on Majorca. This one also keeps you guessing - THURSDAY AT 7:30 A.M. on Showtime.

title: Going Beyond 12 Ideas; Backyard Dispute Is Over an 'Abomination'
description: To the Editor:

title: Burton Engel and Susan Meadow
description: Susan Ellen Meadow and Burton Engel were married on Friday by Justice Samuel G. Fredman of State Supreme Court in his chambers in White Plains.

title: FAILING GRADES
description: * Los Angeles County restaurants are in a tizzy over a tough new system of beefed-up inspections and letter grades that must be posted (A, B and C, which correspond to grades in the 90's, 80's and 70's). * One impetus was a stomach-turning 1997 report by a local TV station that showed a restaurant cook deboning chicken with his teeth. * Major infractions include: Raw beef stored on the floor, food and dirt encrusted on walls, telltale marks of rodent infestation. * Spago in West Hollywood, where the Uberchef Wolfgang Puck shot to fame, bombed its first report -- scoring a 42. (More recently it made an 80.) * It cost Nate 'n Al, the legendary Beverly Hills deli, $200,000 to get up to code. (It went from a 47 to a 92.) * Fatburger No. 117, in Santa Monica, and 41 concession stands at Dodger Stadium racked up A's, with scores from 91 to 100.

title: A Killing Refocuses War on Abuse
description: HILDA UGUNA has become yet another grim statistic. She is one of 1,300 women a year in the United States killed by abusive partners.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Telling the Other Side of a Very Old Story
description: I AM not a cruel woman,'' asserts Clytemnestra, the original queen of mean, who took a lover, beguiled him into conspiring to kill her husband and then put her own father-loving daughter out with the dogs. Now, who's going to believe her?

title: Portland Treats
description: To the Editor: We read ''An Oregon Trail of Portland Treats'' (June 28) with great anticipation, for one of our favorite restaurants is in Portland. But how could you have missed such a culinary treat as Couvron?

title: September 20-26; Pakistan and India Make Nuclear Test Pledge
description: The United States wants to see signatures on this and other nuclear control agreements before lifting the sanctions that were imposed after the two countries set off nuclear explosions in May. BARBARA CROSSETTE

title: POP/JAZZ; His Songs Were A Soundtrack For the Jazz Age
description: ''So many smart men go to pieces nowadays.'' - Nicole Diver in F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Tender is the Night''

title: Crabgrass Gothic
description: 'Do you want to feel the bump?'' A man in a gray suit, an entertainment lawyer named John Sloss, is holding up his right leg for Todd Solondz to feel. Solondz's controversial new movie, ''Happiness,'' which he wrote and directed, opens next week at the New York Film Festival, but tonight he is standing near the bar at a crowded premiere party for another film, ''Next Stop Wonderland.'' Solondz, whose last film was ''Welcome to the Dollhouse,'' is slight and is wearing an untucked checked shirt, tan pants, and a maroon jacket, all of which are too big -- not stylishly so, but rather as if the clothes had been bought to be grown into. He has a pale, beamy, childlike face framed by sprouts of brown hair and enormous glasses, and stands out in this sleek crowd -- which, consciously or not, works to his advantage. As he makes his way through the party, there is a constant murmur. ''That's Todd Solondz,'' go the whispers. ''He made that movie.''

title: Moonlighting?
description: DARK ALLIANCE The CIA, the Contras, and the Crack Cocaine Explosion. By Gary Webb. Illustrated. 548 pp. New York: Seven Stories Press. $24.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASS, MORRIS I., ESQ.
description: HASS-Morris I., Esq. Beloved husband of Sheila. Loving father of Jeffrey and Nancy, and Stephen and Margaret. Loving grandfather of Erin, Debra, Sarah and Samuel. Beloved brother of Helen Breger. A prince amongst men.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Private Sector page last Sunday about an executive compensation plan at Computer Associates referred incorrectly to a grant received by Charles B. Wang, the chief executive, and two aides. As the article noted, they were given $1.1 billion in shares of the company, not options.

title: The I.M.F. Can Calm a Roiling Global Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: With the West Pushing, Leipzig Enters a New Era
description: THE last time this city's Gewandhaus Orchestra made international headlines was in 1989, when the players' union and the chief conductor, Kurt Masur, dared to speak out publicly during the vast popular unrest that was ultimately to topple East Germany's Communist regime, calling for peaceful dialogue and thus helping to avert violence.

title: KOFI ANNAN'S Astonishing Facts!
description: Every year, the United Nations Human Development Report looks for a new way to measure the lives of people. Putting aside faceless statistics like per capita gross domestic product or export-import figures, the report burrows into the facts about what children eat, who goes to school, whether there is clean water to drink, how women share in the economy or who doesn't get vaccinations against diseases that go on killing even though they are preventable. This year, the report takes its first look at what people have -- from simple toilets to family cars -- and what proportion of the world's goods and services are consumed, comparatively, by the rich and by the poor. The pie is huge -- the world's consumption bill is $24 trillion a year -- but some servings are very small indeed. BARBARA CROSSETTE

title: BEST SELLERS: September 27, 1998
description: Weeks

title: Kirsten Botts, James Ward
description: Kirsten Mary Botts and James Cameron Ward were married yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket. The Rev. Dr. Katharine Black, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and the Rev. Charles O'Bryne, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Inspirations for a Time of Renewal
description: IN the mid-19th century, Courbet proclaimed, ''Show me an angel, and I will paint one.'' His bold statement turned artistic interest away from religious subject matter, which had so long dominated European art. Painters then began to depict scenes from the real world rather than rely on religious images. In the recent past, artists have returned to their spiritual roots to create works of personal introspection, and it has again become acceptable for the postmodern painter to deal with religious issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKACH, MARION L.
description: LUKACH-Marion L. The Board of Directors, clinical and administrative staff and volunteers of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of Marion L. Lukach, a beloved Director for more than 30 years, life-long volunteer and benefactor of the agency's home care and public health services. Her interest in nursing education and patient care, especially maternal and child health care, improved the health and well-being of countless New Yorkers. Her unwavering support of the agency for more than 50 years and commitment to high quality, compassionate healthcare will be remembered always. We extend our profound sympathy to her son, Arthur Lukach, a member of our Board of Directors, her daughter, Ellen Perlmutter, and to her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Douglas D. Broadwater Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO

title: A New Day, A New Urge To Refinance
description: EARLIER this year, it seemed that stock prices would never stop going up. Now, it seems that mortgage rates will never stop going down.

title: 'Arm Candy': One-Night Stun
description: THE other night at Saks Fifth Avenue, Jonathan Farkas, the Alexander's department store heir, was escorting Darah Sowell, a sometime model, at a glittery party for British designers. Mr. Farkas, who is a private investor in Manhattan, has a steady girlfriend, but she wasn't available. He wasn't looking to two-time his steady. He wanted Ms. Sowell along for another purpose.

title: Before Dying, Daughter Tells 911 of Policeman's Rampage
description: On a typical Friday, Officer Patrick J. Fitzgerald would leave the 34th Precinct station house in Manhattan, drive 90 minutes home to Orange County, and take his 7-year-old daughter, Ashley, to flag football practice. He was the coach, and she was the only girl on the team.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE

title: Denise Monte, Anthony Szema
description: Dr. Denise Christine Monte and Dr. Anthony Ming Szema were married yesterday in East Setauket, N.Y. The Rev. John Fitzgerald performed the ceremony at St. James Roman Catholic Church.

title: Commuter Vans Caught in a Bind
description: Laurie Dolinger's morning subway trip from the Upper East Side to a Wall Street law firm takes more than an hour. But for the last year and a half she has cut her commuting time to about 20 minutes by riding a convenient, inexpensive van.

title: If It's Tuesday, This Must Be Brandon: Juggling 16 Sets of Children
description: IF Taty Sena were not a real person, someone would invent her for a hip, urban American sequel to ''Mary Poppins.''

title: Hard Times for Strong-Minded Women
description: IF transmissions of the new fall television shows were intercepted by a galaxy far, far away, here is the chillingly clear picture that extraterrestrials would get of the human female at the dawn of the new millennium. She is young, perennially confused, perpetually underemployed and adorably confounded by men. In her teens and early 20's, she is smart and spunky, but approaching 30 she is mysteriously stricken with an unnamed disease that renders her increasingly incompetent. Miraculously, her cuteness is left intact.

title: Festival Salutes The River
description: ANYONE with high energy, a love for the Hudson River and an appetite for things autumnal should like next Saturday's Hudson Heritage Festival.

title: Q&A/Peter A. Young; Archeologists as Fact Finders of History
description: INDIANA JONES, as portrayed in ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and its sequels, was an archeologist who led a James Bond-like life, beating the bad guys and getting the girl. While not entirely accurate, the movies did more to promote archeology than almost anything else, Peter A. Young, editor in chief of Archaeology magazine in Manhattan, said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FURMAN, DON
description: FURMAN-Don. You are loved and missed more than you know today and always. Love, Mom, Rikki, Allison & Fred

title: Fantasies in Glass Awash in Color
description: TOOTS ZYNSKY produces fantasy forms in glass that look as fragile and festive as crepe-paper objects -- ruffled, puckered, pinched and drenched with color. She uses a revolutionary technique to create the multicolored tuliplike works: instead of blowing or casting these pieces, she fuses thousands of glass threads into entire vessels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, DANE
description: CLARK-Dane. Geraldine Clark announces a special Memorial Service & Reception for her cherished and loved husband, Dane Clark Sunday, October 4 at 3:00PM at the Self Realization Fellowship at Lake Shrine, 17080 Sunset Blvd, Pacific Palisades, Los Angeles. Dane Clarke passed away on September 11, 1998.

title: One Lawmaker's Ideas on Peeling Away Layers of Redundant Services
description: In her quest for consolidation of municipal services, Governor Whitman may find an unexpected ally in a prominent Democrat who once sought his party's nomination for governor.

title: Rutgers Takes a Big Step At Army's Expense
description: Somehow, somewhere Rutgers found the skill and will to play a commendable game of football tonight. After being trounced by Syracuse, 70-14, last Saturday and humbled by Boston College, 41-14, the week before, the Scarlet Knights defeated Army, 27-15, before a Homecoming crowd of 31,879.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIBEL, PEARL
description: LEIBEL-Pearl. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Adored aunt, great - aunt, great - great - aunt. Graveside service today, 1:45 PM, Beth David, Elmont, LI.

title: Companies Are Busy Helping Those Who Are Busier
description: LOUISE BIJESSE is busy.

title: World Consumption:  Unequal Slices of the Pie
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Treasury's Auction Is Confined to Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is limited to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Sharks in the Senate Race
description: Alfonse D'Amato, who represents New York in the United States Senate, appears to be planning a re-election campaign aimed at increasing the tensions and distrust between its residents. That is a remarkable conception of what it means to be a statewide elected official.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Essay; Woodrow Wilson Lives
description: After World War I, President Woodrow Wilson had an idealistic notion called ''the self-determination of nations'': national boundaries should be drawn around peoples who have a common language and cultural heritage. A generation later, in the face of Nazi aggression, Churchill and Roosevelt made ''self-determination'' a part of the Atlantic Charter.

title: Yankees' Glittering Regular Season Is a Mere Prelude
description: Videotaped memories from the 1996 World Series filled the refrigerator-sized television screen in the players' lounge yesterday morning at Yankee Stadium: Jim Leyritz hitting the pivotal home run, the large dark eyes of Yankees Manager Joe Torre glazed with tears after the final out. Two years later, the Yankees will pursue another World Series title, which would be the organization's 24th.

title: Mocking Doubters With Teasing Vamps
description: There's a story that Sam Cooke, at the height of his gospel-singing career, could make a crowd detonate simply by choosing the perfect moment to smile. In some rarefied chamber beyond professionalism, a musician can transmit power with the merest gesture. A performer is lucky to find this magic zone every once in a while.

title: A Menace, Be It Smooth or Chunky; The Real Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Novel TV Deal Could Rein In Program Costs
description: In a case of the right talent meeting the right need at the right time, Ed Zwick and Marshall Herskovitz, the creators of the 1980's ABC hit show ''Thirtysomething,'' have concluded a complicated new television series deal that several participants say may be the first step in a radically changed approach to controlling escalating program costs.

title: Bronx Offers Stadium Plan for Keeping Team
description: Hoping to place the Bronx back at the center of the debate over a home for the Yankees, the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, plans to offer a proposal today to renovate Yankee Stadium, install 120 luxury boxes, ease traffic congestion and redevelop the neighborhood with a waterfront park, a Yankee Hall of Fame and sports-related stores.

title: Europeans Congratulate Both Winner And Loser
description: European leaders congratulated both Gerhard Schroder and the man he defeated today in Germany's elections, Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: A SEASON TOO ENTERTAINING TO END
description: METS COLLAPSE -- The Mets missed the wild-card playoff, losing their fifth straight game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILBANE, PAUL L.
description: KILBANE-Paul L. Left us suddenly and peacefully on September 26, 1998, after a courageous and dignified fight with cancer. He was 64. Loving father of Hilary Allinson (and her husband Edward) and Tara Dixon (and her husband Peter). Grandfather of Carter E. Allinson and Miles J. Dixon. Former husband of Ginger Kilbane. He also leaves his close friend Carolyn Albert. He was Vice President of Marketing at E.T. Browne Drug Company and a former Senior Vice President at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Inc. A true gentleman with charm, wit, style, and grace. He will be missed by many. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WITTNER, HENRY W.
description: WITTNER-Henry W. September 28, 1994. My Henry, I always miss you. Love, Mir

title: The Year of the Hitter
description: The baseball playoffs begin tomorrow, which leaves far too little time to savor the manifold pleasures of a regular season that seems disinclined to leave the stage. The season will not, in fact, officially end until tonight, when the Cubs and Giants play an extra game to determine the National League's wild-card team. The Yankee manager, Joe Torre, called it ''the best year I've been involved with, and it was at the proper time'' -- by which he meant that this summer's heroics may finally have restored the game of baseball to its rightful place at or near the top of the American sporting pyramid, and laid to rest the sullen memories of the strike-ridden seasons of 1994 and 1995.

title: Glancing At the 50's, Romantically If Flippantly
description: Now in his fourth season as music director of the San Francisco Symphony, Michael Tilson Thomas has unquestionably made his mark as an assembler of fresh and often surprising programs. By revisiting neglected scores, finding new works that he can make a case for without seeming doctrinaire, and giving these nearly equal time with big works from the standard canon, he has persuaded his listeners to trust him. His season programs, like those of Esa-Pekka Salonen, in Los Angeles, have become models of how modern symphony orchestras can inhabit the present without neglecting the past. Not coincidentally, his programming has become a truncheon that critics can use to beat up on Mr. Thomas's less adventurous colleagues.

title: Time Now Running Out On Holyfield and Lewis
description: Lennox Lewis survived to score a 12-round unanimous decision here Saturday night over Zeljko Mavrovic, the 27-year-old Croat with the granite head. And if there is a theme song for the heavyweight division these days, it is the Bee Gees' ''Stayin' Alive,'' because survival is the only thing that matters.

title: Democrats' Spin Is Not Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Real Networks in Pact With America Online
description: It seemed a risky step when Rob Glaser, chairman of Real Networks Inc., appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee in July, joining a chorus of Microsoft bashers. He complained that some of the Microsoft Corporation's latest software refused to work properly with his company's so-called streaming programs, which deliver audio and video over the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARDLE, THOMAS F.
description: McCARDLE-Thomas F. September 26, age 66. CEO of Kolene Corporation. Beloved husband of Marilyn. Dear father of Michael and Dennis McCardle (Pamela), and Mary ''Missy'' Cole (John). Dear brother of Margaret and John McCardle. Aslo survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral at Vasu Rodgers and Connell Chapel of A. J. Desmond and Sons, 32515 Woodward (between 13-14 Mile Rd.), Royal Oak, MI (248-549-0500), Wednesday, 9:15 AM, to St. Thomas More Church, 4580 Adams, Troy, MI, at 10 AM. Family will receive friends Monday, 6-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at funeral home. Rosary Tuesday evening. Right of Committal, Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Southfield, MI. Family suggests memorials to the St. Thomas More Building Fund or the American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDEN, BERNARD
description: HOLDEN-Bernard. Passed away on September 22, 1998. Husband of Mickey. Father of Stuart and Leslie, grandfather of Jason and Gregg. Brother of Estelle. We will always remember you. Estelle and Leon Port and family

title: CPR, the Safe Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, (SEFF) VIOLA
description: GOLDBERG-(Seff) Viola, at 92. Beloved wife of the late Henry Goldberg and the late Manny Seff. Devoted mother of Kate & Gerry Beswick, of London, and Vicki Winteringham. Loving grandmother of Kefi Beswick, affectionate stepmother of Dr. William Ruberman and the late Janet Ruberman. Step-grandmother of Dr. Louise and Arie Buckheister and Daniel and Ann Ruberman. Survived by five great step-grandchildren. A woman of great charm, intelligence and beauty, she devoted her time and energy to relationships with family and friends, the pursuit of art and learning & an intense involvement in philanthropic causes. She was a member of the Board of Trustees of Beth Israel Hospital where she was actively involved in developing innovative programs in hospice care & in the hospital nursing school. Funeral services will be held on Monday, September 28 at 9:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: Alienation on an Iceberg Where Anger Is Warmth
description: ''Marco Polo Sings a Solo'' begins with an astronaut adrift among the stars, which is as apt a metaphor as any for this hyperbolic satire from the pen of John Guare. Like a space capsule on the fritz, the play gets stuck in perpetual orbit, floating somewhere out there, high above our heads.

title: After the False Alarms, Haitians Fail to Prepare
description: When it became clear last Monday that Hurricane Georges would hit Haiti, Jean-Claude Delice, a development official here in the Artibonite Valley, went on the radio begging residents to evacuate their homes and sent a team of his people with bullhorns to do the same thing.

title: Go Punt, Football; Baseball Is On Throne
description: Somewhere on television yesterday, football existed. But it hardly mattered -- no, not even on a day when New Orleans won its third straight game -- on a dizzying baseball afternoon when the Mets lost and were eliminated from playoff contention, the Cubs and Giants lost but will meet tonight in a playoff and Mark McGwire slugged his 69th and 70th home runs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, HOKE S.
description: SIMPSON-Hoke S. On September 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Suzanne (nee Memminger). Loving father of Drayton Jenkins Gerety, Hoke S. Jr., and Willis M. Caring grandfather of Hoke III, Sheryl, Michael, Christopher, Katie, and David. Memorial service at St. John's Episcopal Church, Fountain Square, Larchmont, NY, on Tuesday at 11 AM. Reception will follow at the Larchmont Yacht Club. For further information, contact John J. Fox Funeral Home 914834-0144.

title: Carol Kay, Scholar And Professor, 51
description: Carol Kay, a professor of 18th-century literature and culture at the University of Pittsburgh, died on Sept. 12 at Montefiore Hospital in Pittsburgh. She was 51.

title: Hillary Clinton, Smile in Place, Hits Fund-Raisers
description: Is she a national role model as First Lady? The President's top crisis manager determined to rescue his legacy? Or a traumatized victim deserving of America's embrace?

title: Potentially Big Security Flaw Found in Netscape Software
description: A potentially serious security flaw has been discovered in the programming language used in the Navigator and Communicator software of the Netscape Communications Corporation, with the defect possibly allowing an outsider to read information on a personal computer user's hard disk.

title: Germany Turns the Page
description: A German politician once said of Chancellor Helmut Kohl that if he had been the Titanic, the iceberg would have sunk. So it seemed for 16 years as Mr. Kohl barreled over one opponent after another to lead Germany for longer than any man since Otto von Bismarck a century ago. But the Kohl winning streak was broken yesterday, and with it ended one of the most eventful and fateful periods in postwar German and European history.

title: Three Veteran Politicians See No Deal Now Between Congress and President
description: As Democrats and the White House, buoyed by polls, sharpened their attacks against Republicans today, three veteran politicians said that there would be no deal between President Clinton and Congress until after the Nov. 3 elections.

title: President and Allies Want To Look Into Starr's Inquiry
description: Broadening its counterattack against possible impeachment proceedings, the White House has coordinated a strategy with Congressional Democrats to turn the tables and investigate the investigators by examining how Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, came to look into the Lewinsky matter, Clinton advisers said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBITZKY, SIMCHA (MOTRO)
description: DUBITZKY-Simcha (Motro). Of Miami Beach, FL. Widow of Aaron Dubitzky. Died September 25, 1998. She was born in Israel and had lived most of her life in the United States. She leaves a son, Theodore Dubitzky and his wife Deborah in Israel; two daughters, Ann Cope and her husband Bernard of West Hartford, CT, and Aviva Budd and her husband Martin of Stamford, CT; two brothers and two sisters; eight grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. The burial was Monday in Beth El Temple Cemetery, Avon, CT.

title: Calculated Risk: U.S. and I.M.F. Lead Push for Brazil Bailout Plan
description: With the Clinton Administration and the International Monetary Fund taking the lead, a package of loans for Brazil, likely to total more than $30 billion, is gradually being put together to limit the damage to Latin America's biggest economy from the Asian crisis. But the bailout plan is a calculated risk: rather than save Brazil, it could sink the country into deep recession.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on the Automobiles page on Sept. 11 about the 1999 Ford Mustang referred incorrectly to the styling of the original Mustang. It did not have a prominent hood scoop and triangular side scoops.

title: A Menace, Be It Smooth or Chunky
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENZI, MATLEA
description: MENZI-Matlea. In my heart and soul every day. Your light shines in us all. Love, Sharon Lauer-Wolf

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLONTZ, FRANZ J.
description: CLONTZ-Franz J. Monday, September 21, 1998. Dearest father of Neil (Jeannine), Keith (Deborah) Clontz, Susan (Steve) Bolhafner, James Clontz and the late Patricia Clontz, dear grandfather of Nicole Gutierrez, Mary Beth Sziglti and Elizabeth Bolhafner, our dear cousin and friend. Member of Typographical Union #

title: Mets Lay Their Final Egg, And It Tastes Awful
description: The final indignity of the Mets' 1998 season did not come when Mike Piazza popped out to short right-center field for the last out of a 7-2 defeat to the Atlanta Braves in what might have been the All-Star catcher's final game as a Met.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLOWITZ, JOEL
description: KAPLOWITZ-Joel. We will sorely miss the love, warmth and friendship you gave to us. We will cherish the memories always. Our hearts go out to Bonnie, Rachel, Jenna, Eleanor, Michael, Patti and family. Tina and Rick Blank, Michael, Scott and Adam

title: Sports of The Times; For Yanks, Only 125 Victories Will Do
description: IN their spectacular season of 114 victories, the Yankees were so talented, so deep, so much better than any other American League team, it was as if they were on cruise control.

title: The Thomas Lesson
description: Even before President Clinton referred to the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearing in his grand jury testimony, comparisons between the Monica Lewinsky scandal and my testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee were being made. The comparisons usually come in the form of a question to Democrats: ''How do the current accusations differ from those raised during the Thomas hearing''?

title: U.S. Is Right to Demand Changes at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Betty Carter, Innovative Jazz Vocalist, Is Dead at 69
description: Betty Carter, one of jazz's great singers and a composer and arranger whose groups were virtual schools for generations of jazz musicians, died at home in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn on Saturday. She was 69.

title: Metro Matters; In This Vote, You Can Take Manhattan
description: WOULD a ''real mensch'' trash Manhattan to curry favor in Munnsville?

title: GERMAN VOTERS END AN ERA, REJECT KOHL AFTER 16 YEARS AND PICK A SOCIAL DEMOCRAT
description: Gerhard Schroder, a Social Democrat, defeated Helmut Kohl today in the race to become Chancellor, ending an era in Germany and opening a new one in Europe where center-left governments now dominate the continent's politics.

title: U.S. Looks for Lessons In Davis Cup Drubbing
description: Already beaten before they had even stepped onto the court, the United States Davis Cup team and the United States Tennis Association officials who ran this star-crossed event went through the motions of completing their demoralizing semifinal against Italy. After all, the cheapest seats in the house had sold at $90 for a three-day package, and today their occupants were owed a pair of singles matches, meaningless or not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKACH, MARION L.
description: LUKACH-Marion L. The Board of Directors, clinical and administrative staff and volunteers of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of Marion L. Lukach, a beloved Director for more than 30 years, life-long volunteer and benefactor of the agency's home care and public health services. Her interest in nursing education and patient care, especially maternal and child health care, improved the health and well-being of countless New Yorkers. Her unwavering support of the agency for more than 50 years and commitment to high quality, compassionate healthcare will be remembered always. We extend our profound sympathy to her son, Arthur Lukach, a member of our Board of Directors, her daughter, Ellen Perlmutter, and to her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Douglas D. Broadwater Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO

title: Albright Meets With Netanyahu And Arafat for Joint Talks
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright pushed today for agreement on key details of a long-stalled peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, meeting jointly for the first time in nearly a year with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Circuits on Thursday with an article about the Privacy Manager technology for telephone service was published in error. It showed the Rio PMP 300 portable music player, the subject of a separate article.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUTSCHE, ERHART F.
description: KUTSCHE-Erhart F. With profound sorrow, we mourn the passing on September 25 of Fred after a short illness, a devoted employee, colleague and friend for over 40 years. He will be greatly missed. Sincere condolences to Marie, his wife, who also is a colleague and dear friend. David Minkin Esther Schneidman Patricia and Howard Lester The Briger Family The Thall Family

title: A Top Lender in Japan Files for Bankruptcy
description: The Japan Leasing Corporation, Japan's second-largest leasing company and an affiliate of troubled Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd., filed for court protection on Sunday night, becoming the country's biggest postwar bankruptcy.

title: McGwire Shifts Focus to His Tan
description: Two police officers poked their heads out of a side door to the Cardinals' clubhouse. All clear. A hulkish redhead ducked into the dank corridor beneath Busch Stadium and began to run.

title: Sosa Will Play Another Day As Cubs and Giants Are Tied
description: Sammy Sosa and the Chicago Cubs walked off the indoor carpet, slump-shouldered losers in the home run race and the wild-card race. They had blown a lead again, losing by 4-3 in the 11th inning of the 162d game of their overachieving season. The only home runs in the Astrodome had been on video, with Mark McGwire hitting Nos. 69 and 70 on the giant video screen above Sosa's head in right field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAYNE, NEIL
description: SHAYNE-Neil. We mourn the passing of the father of our esteemed member Mark Shayne and pray that the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Young Israel of Great Neck

title: Clinton Aides Paving Way for a Jones Settlement
description: A senior aide to President Clinton sought today to prepare the public for a possible settlement of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit, saying that it should not be taken as an admission by the President that Ms. Jones's accusations are true.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Aug. 25 about a performance of Jawole Willa Jo Zollar's ''Hands Singing Song'' at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival misstated the date of the work's premiere. The dance was commissioned by the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., where it had its world premiere in June and received the festival's Doris Duke Award for New Work. The Jacob's Pillow performance was the Northeastern premiere. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Market Place; Why Sprint Goes It Alone and What May Change That
description: The Sprint Corporation has not followed the script.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLIGAN, ANABEL A.
description: MULLIGAN-Anabel A. On September 26, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. A. Loving mother of Ann Gloria Mulligan, Patricia Maffei, Marita Conron and the late Thomas J. Mulligan. Cherished grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of two. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Joseph's R.C. Church, 404 East 87th Street, Wednesday, 11 AM.

title: U.S. Is Right to Demand Changes at the U.N.
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate May Vote on Financial Services Bill
description: For nearly two decades, efforts to lift Depression-era regulations on the nation's financial services industry have come to no avail. But that may end this week, as a measure to modernize the industry, one long written off as dead, is showing remarkable signs of life in the Senate.

title: Op-Art
Democrats' Spin Is Not Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: In Defeat, the Unifier of Germany Claims Yet Another Political First
description: It was characteristic that even when Helmut Kohl was finally ousted in Germany's national elections, he scored a first -- this time as the first postwar German Chancellor to be voted out of office.

title: Democrats' Spin Is Not Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: Satellites Guiding Industries on the Move
description: Moving millions of tons of earth around the Black Thunder coal mine in Wright, Wyo., has come to resemble playing a video game, except that the score is kept by military satellites high overhead.

title: After the Hedge Fund Bailout, Tighter Restrictions Are Seen
description: Last week's $3.5 billion bailout of the hedge fund Long-Term Capital Management L.P. could bring closer scrutiny and tighter restrictions on such funds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINS, AARON (ARCHIE)
description: WILKINS-Aaron (Archie). Beloved husband of Iris. Devoted and loving father of Fern and Lowell Kwiat, and Stuart and Laurie Wilkins. Cherished grandfather of Greg, Russell, Adam, Cory, Brian and Alyssa. Dear brother of Celia Mitchel. Services were held on Sunday, September 27, 1998. Interment followed at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Pursuing a Different Vision At The Los Angeles Times
description: The Los Angeles Times, which in the last decade has experimented with a variety of strategies for covering the sprawling megalopolis around the city, is swiftly moving toward a major reorganization. The move is likely to give the newspaper a higher national profile and significantly alter its signature regional coverage.

title: Making Do With Supplies, Dominican Republic Struggles to Rebuild
description: Under a blazing Caribbean sun that made him squint as he worked, Rafael Dennis began trying to rebuild his mother's little wood-frame house this morning.

title: New Delhi Journal; In City Slums, Amateur 'Doctors' Thrive on Trust
description: As dusk falls on Jhuggi Jhonpri Colony No. 8, a teeming slum that sprawls along the Yamuna River, a barefooted parade of fish peddlers, maidservants and rickshaw pullers line up at the storefront offices of their neighborhood ''doctors.''

title: Democrats' Spin Is Not Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: All in Bosnia Must Do More to Fulfill Peace Accords, Cohen Says
description: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today that the national elections here created ''some room for optimism'' for the future of Bosnia's shattered society, but he warned that Bosnian leaders had to make more progress or risk losing international support.

title: The Weather Is Bad, but Life Is Worse
description: Winter is never-ending in Aleksei Guerman's impenetrable film ''Khroustaliov, My Car!,'' a nearly two-and-a-half hour absurdist nightmare of life in the Soviet Union during the final days of Stalin's rule. Snow falls in almost every scene of this starkly grim, black-and-white movie, which follows the triumph, fall from grace and hasty rehabilitation of a hulking Red Army general and brain surgeon named Yuri Glinshi (Yuri Tsourilo). Processions of black government vehicles are forever materializing like ominous phantoms through the curtains of snow that drift over a dilapidated town decorated with gleaming white statues of the beady-eyed, mustached Soviet dictator.

title: Fairness for Haitian Refugees
description: The Senate has included in its Treasury-Postal appropriations bill a provision to allow 40,000 Haitian refugees who have been in this country since 1995 to stay permanently. The House, which has not included similar language in its bill, should accept this measure when the conference committee meets to produce a compromise bill this week.

title: Sports of The Times; Kanell Is No Leaf, And Leaf's No Kanell
description: IT is all about relativity in the National Football League, a week-to-week proposition, the ongoing search for someone in a more vulnerable position than yourself. All things considered yesterday, Danny Kanell could have been Ryan Leaf.

title: A Menace, Be It Smooth or Chunky; Unseen Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Role Reversal in a Queens Assembly Race
description: When they faced each other two years ago, Douglas Prescott was a seasoned, senior Republican member of the State Assembly and Ann Margaret E. Carrozza was a young lawyer and novice Democratic politician.

title: Young at Heart and Considering Ailments of the Liver
description: ''Dr. Akagi'' is an eclectic footnote to the career of Shohei Imamura, the septuagenarian Japanese filmmaker whose quirky daring is currently best represented by ''The Eel.'' That film's novel conception of a man who reserves his greatest confidences for a pet eel seems relatively mainstream compared with this. Based on a novel called ''Dr. Liver'' by Ango Sakaguchi (who was frank about his drinking and drug use), and set during World War II, ''Dr. Akagi'' is a bawdy gallows comedy centering on the treatment of hepatitis. The filmmaker has described this as an homage to his father, who was a doctor.

title: 2 Are Slain Outside Brooklyn Baptismal Party
description: Two men were killed outside a Brooklyn baptismal celebration on Saturday night when an 18-year-old man was shot to death and his uncle was fatally stabbed while intervening in hopes of saving him, the police said yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm in awe of myself right now.''

title: Sports of The Times; McGwire and Sosa Just Kept Going
description: SEVENTY is such an awesome number. Just awesome. The idea that anybody could club his way past Babe Ruth, past Roger Maris, past the pressures, past any reasonable expectation, is just staggering.

title: Friend of Rabin's Assassin Is Sentenced
description: A friend of Yigal Amir, the assassin who gunned down Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin three years ago, was sentenced today to nine months in prison for failing to prevent the slaying.

title: 13 Years and Counting For a Reagan Biography; A High-Profile Project Meets Another Delay
description: The question stings for the estimated 726th billionth time.

title: For G.O.P., Rare Hope in Boulder
description: Could Boulder, the liberal lighthouse of the Rockies, send to Congress -- a Republican?

title: Batting Title for Williams, With Free Agency Ahead
description: Bernie Williams came into the season fearful that his impending free agency might be a distraction. It appears to have been more of a motivation. Williams went 2 for 2 yesterday, improved his batting average to .339 and won the American League batting title.

title: The Post-Lewinsky Winner Is the Web
description: Longtime users of the Internet often laugh when mainstream media talk about ''defining moments for the Net.'' To them, it was defined long ago.

title: Icelandic Violinist Wins the Indianapolis Competition
description: The International Violin Competition of Indianapolis yesterday named Judith Ingolfsson the winner of its fifth contest. Ms. Ingolfsson, 25, from Iceland, has studied at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia and the Cleveland Institute of Music, and has won awards at other competitions, including the Concert Artists Guild Competition this year.

title: A Match That Wouldn't End Finally Does, After 4 Months
description: Matches in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Double Knockout Team Championship normally consist of about 27 deals and are completed in less than 4 hours. But one in a late stage of the 1998 event obstinately refused to conform to this pattern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, MARY JANE REGAN
description: GOLDFARB-Mary Jane Regan, 52. On September 25, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Jack. Cherished daughter of Wilma Regan. Loving mother of Carolyn Goldfarb and Candice Goldfarb Posner. Beloved sister of Jacqueline McSwiggan. Her family will miss her strength, warmth and keen sense of humor. A memorial service will be held at Central Presbyterian Church, 593 Park Ave. at 64th St., New York City, Tuesday, September 29, at 2:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation or American Cancer Society.

title: Schumer Tours Upstate to Counter Attacks by D'Amato
description: After a week of being assailed in television advertising as a ''liberal Brooklyn Congressman'' hostile to upstate interests, Charles E. Schumer campaigned across western and central New York today, ticking off the names of relatives who had lived there and blaming Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato for the economic decline that has gripped this region.

title: Reno Taken to Hospital After Fainting at Church
description: Attorney General Janet Reno fainted this morning during a church service in suburban Maryland and was hospitalized at Georgetown University Medical Center, where she will be held overnight for observation, Justice Department officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENTHAL, NAT
description: LINDENTHAL-Nat. Beloved husband of Dottie. Loving father and father-in-law of Sharon and Jeff, Rhonda and Joseph. Dear brother of Eva and Murray. Cherished grandfather of Elana, Michele, Michael and Genna. Services today, 10:15 AM, ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expy., Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: BASEBALL; Nen Gets Relief After Losing In Relief
description: The distraught San Francisco Giants closer Robb Nen thought his season was over as he walked off Coors Field this afternoon after serving up a game-losing home run to the Colorado Rockies.

title: Former Stronghold Turns Frustrations Against Kohl in Voting Booth
description: Most of the nightmarish chemical refineries in this eastern German city have been bulldozed since the fall of the Berlin wall, along with most of the jobs there.

title: Sprint, looking for help in broadening its image, moves from Thompson to McCann-Erickson.
description: THE Sprint Corporation has unexpectedly dismissed J. Walter Thompson San Francisco after 17 years and moved most duties for consumer advertising, with billings estimated at $150 million, to McCann-Erickson New York.

title: Parade Ground Wins Again on Turf
description: Parade Ground, sixth in the Kentucky Derby and fourth in the Belmont, continued to flourish since being switched to the grass, winning yesterday's $125,000 Lawrence Realization at Belmont for his third victory in four starts on the turf.

title: Using Pain and Mayhem as a New Lost Generation's Cries for Help
description: At the Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., on Friday night, boys yelped and roared as they ran from the mothers they left in the parking lot. Girls trying hard to be fierce pulled their just-purchased Korn shirts over their tank tops. The Family Values Tour had arrived, and New Jersey was ready for some organized extremity.

title: W. Frederick Laird, Gas Company Executive, 79
description: W. Frederick Laird, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Columbia Gas System, died of cancer Sept. 15 at Christiana Hospital in Newark, Del. Mr. Laird, who lived in Greenville, Del., was 79.

title: Albany Lobbying Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the German election misstated the number of years between the defeat of the Nazi regime and 1999, when the Reichstag building in Berlin will again house the German Parliament. It is 54 years, not 44.

title: Brooklyn Doctor Charged With Abuse of Patient
description: A Brooklyn doctor has been charged with sexual abuse after a patient at Wyckoff Heights Medical Center accused him of fondling her, the police said yesterday.

title: Standout Showings Amid the Muddle
description: One by one, the Nebraska players stepped to the lectern to characterize Saturday's dominating performance against the Washington Huskies as a ''statement game.'' In political parlance, they stayed ''on message.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVAL, JEANNE
description: KOVAL-Jeanne. Beloved mother of Shirley, Ruth and Stanley. Adored grandmother and greatgrandmother. Services 10 AM, Tuesday, September 29, at Riverside-Boulevard Chapel, 312 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY.

title: For Sale: Free Software; Backers of Linux Say System Is Basis For Revolutionizing Computer Business
description: In an experiment that is half business model and half populist movement, a small company called Red Hat Software is charging $50 for an operating system called Linux that anyone can get free on the Internet, and it is paying programmers decent wages to write code that it will give away.

title: Tokyo Politician Raises Hope for Real Opposition
description: Obscured by the mountains of bad debts, by the battles in Parliament, by the growing international frustration at Japan's tardiness in confronting its economic problems, something remarkable is bubbling up in Japan.

title: Digital Commerce; A slow-motion train wreck in setting technology standards for a forthcoming era of television.
description: ONE of the most ominous trends in Washington is a growing belief that private industry, particularly any technology-based industry, is better suited to serving the public interest than are elected lawmakers and Government agencies.

title: County's Battle to Avoid Paying Benefits in Fire Chief's Death Angers Volunteer Firefighters
description: Volunteer firefighters here are angry that Tioga County has been waging a legal battle for two years to avoid paying death benefits to the widow of a former Newark Valley fire chief who collapsed and died at a house fire.

title: A Menace, Be It Smooth or Chunky; Sent to the Streets
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Catholic Leader In North Faults I.R.A.
description: The highest-ranking Roman Catholic in the Northern Ireland Assembly today accused Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, of impeding the peace effort in the British province.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: JAZZ
description: Piano Solos Brimming With Emotion

title: Defense Buys Stewart Time to Shake Off Slump
description: A new cottage industry has broken out here; call it the psychoanalysis of Kordell Stewart. Talk-show callers fill the airwaves with advice for the Pittsburgh quarterback on how to break out of his terrible slump. Forests have been decimated because of the massive amount of newspaper copy that has documented his troubles. Kordell needs to throw downfield more. Kordell needs to run more. Kordell needs to be Kordell.

title: In Yankee Bleachers, Triumph and Troubles; Rabid Fans Could Miss Playoffs, or Worse, See Them From Box Seats
description: ''Mom is drunk!'' they screamed. ''Mom is drunk!''

title: Peter Putnam, 78; Scholar Wrote of His Blindness
description: Peter Brock Putnam, a blind historian who spoke in public and wrote about blindness and was active in nonprofit organizations, died on Wednesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 78.

title: Israeli Arabs And the Police Clash in North On Land Plan
description: In a disturbance reminiscent of scenes from the Palestinian uprising in the West Bank and Gaza, Israeli riot police officers clashed with Israeli Arabs in northern Israel today, wounding scores with tear gas and rubber-coated bullets as youths hurled rocks and set road blocks on fire.

title: Compressed Data; Coming This Week: A Web Hair Transplant
description: From the company that brought the first live broadcasts of childbirth and open-heart surgery to the World Wide Web comes the latest opportunity for medical rubbernecking: a live Webcast of a hair-transplant operation.

title: Democrats' Spin Is Not Relevant
description: To the Editor:

title: A Menace, Be It Smooth or Chunky; Not Supporting Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Kosovo Village, Burned Down by Serbs
description: First the warning artillery rattled across the valley about 8:40 on Friday morning, sending a message that the Gashi clan instantly understood. They gathered their children, and by the account of Haziz Gashi, who was collecting milk at the time, everyone ran for the forest.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW: ROCK
description: Two Left Behind Make the Most of It

title: Culture Rears Its Head in the Public-Private Debate
description: The image last week was too painful to watch, the President, shrunken by the camera's high-aimed frame, his forehead pocked with sweat, responding to questions one wished one hadn't heard. Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, anticipating the broadcast, said, ''It makes me vomit.'' ''We are all German Chancellors now,'' wrote a columnist in Le Monde, ''All of this is worthy of vomiting.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAEB, MARINA
description: STRAEB-Marina. On September 26, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late William Straeb and Marie Panarello. Mass of Christian Burial 11 AM, Tuesday, at St. Vincent Ferrer Church. In lieu of flowers donations can be made in her memory to the Cancer Care Program, the Cabrini Hospice Program and the American Cancer Society. For information call the John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Ave, NYC.

title: News and Young Minds
description: Children's ears and eyes have not been shielded from coverage of the scandal enveloping President Clinton. And many parents cringe at the questions the coverage may have raised in their youngsters' minds.

title: Tearing Down the House At a Jazz Competition
description: Musicians call it ''getting house,'' working the audience into a frenzy, and on Friday night at Baird Auditorium at the Smithsonian Institution here, the 63-year-old singer Teri Thornton, competing in the Thelonious Monk International Jazz Vocals Competition, not only got house but large building, zip code and city. Ms. Thornton, who last released a recording in 1963 and now lives in the actors' retirement home in Englewood, N.J., won first prize in one of the best fields of competitors that the Monk Institute has seen in years. She did it by singing well and by digging into some of the best aspects of black entertainment culture, the parts that make audience members and performers join in the same experience.

title: When an Audience Is Asked to Listen in a Different Way
description: In the late 1960's, the Texas-born composer Pauline Oliveros earned a small cult following among college students for her eclectic mixed-media performances of her free-form compositions, involving musicians, dancers, exotic instruments and a sense of ritual. These works were more like events, hushed collective sonic mediations, usually performed in large reverberant spaces, which were essential to the effect.

title: Patents; A blow by blow of how the inventor of windsurfing found his place in the sun.
description: A 70-year-old retired sign painter, S. Newman Darby, might still be living in obscurity in Jacksonville, Fla., if an odd couple of sorts -- a windsurfing industrial engineer and an archivist at the Smithsonian Institution -- had not decided to champion his cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELLASALA, ANNE
description: DELLASALA-Anne. On September 26, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Gerald L. Beloved mother of Gerald J. Also survived by two grandchildren, James and April. Mass Tuesday, St. Bernadette R.C. Church, 9:30 AM. Reposing at Ralph Aievoli & Son, 1275 65th St., Brooklyn, NY, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Sunday Styles on Sept. 6 about the design magazine Wallpaper and the consumers influenced by its emphasis on midcentury modernism misstated the age of Re-Generation, a furniture store in downtown Manhattan that specializes in industrial design. It opened in 1993, not in the last year and a half.

description: A Debut From Japan, By Way of France

title: A Question Of Safety
description: If Sam Garnes cannot play next week against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, the Giants could use the rookie Shaun Williams, or they could move Percy Ellsworth to strong safety if free safety Tito Wooten's hamstring has healed sufficiently and the Giants favor that combination.

title: INSIDE
description: White House Strategy

title: One Life Abandoned, Another Embraced
description: On Saturday, Judith Boneski said her final farewell to couture clothes and gold jewelry, to strong perfumes and trips to Paris, to evenings with friends in little bistros, to family.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: A Plan Without A Goal In Kosovo
description: For the first time since Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia began a brutal crackdown against the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo, there is a real chance that NATO may intervene militarily. After the United Nations Security Council passed a resolution last week demanding that Mr. Milosevic withdraw his forces, NATO commanders prepared plans for air strikes. The question is, What earthly purpose would such an action serve, however momentarily satisfying it might be?

title: Democrats Fear Worst Loss of Assembly Power in Decades
description: ''Mostly, I lean toward Democrats, but there are times you just need a Republican,'' Myrtle Several said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMEE, ELIZABETH THERESA
description: McNAMEE-Elizabeth Theresa. Of West Islip, L.I. and New York City. On September 25, 1998. Beloved daughter of Maria and Frank. Loving sister of William. Cherished godmother of Jaclyn and adored niece and cousin of many. Graduate of West Islip High School, Harvard University and in the final year of New York University Law School. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of Robert Moses Cswy.). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10 AM, at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Bay Shore, L.I. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations be made in memory of Elizabeth to the Hospice of Good Samaritan, 655 Deer Park Ave., Babylon, L.I. 11702. Visiting Tuesday, 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: McGwire's Grand Finale Makes It 70
description: His seasonlong performance so surpassed any individual performance major league baseball has ever seen that Mark McGwire said, ''I'm in awe of myself right now.''

description: TWO CITIES

title: Valentine Angst, 5 Times Over
description: The Mets' last stand in 1998 was no stand at all. It was a pathetic conclusion to what could, and should, have been something much more memorable. The final week of the season deteriorated, from the Mets standing above the wild-card world six days ago to the Mets stumbling, sitting, kneeling and finally expiring yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Dining Section on Wednesday about free tastings at Manhattan wine stores misspelled the name of an Italian winery. It is Mionetto, not Mionetta.

title: Corrections
description: A roll-call listing yesterday showing the House vote on a Republican-sponsored tax cut misstated the votes for two states. For Connecticut, the vote was: Republicans -- Johnson, Y; Shays, Y. Democrats -- DeLauro, N; Gejdenson, N; Kennelly, Y; Maloney, Y. For West Virginia, the vote was: Democrats -- Mollohan, N; Rahall, N; Wise, N.

title: DiMaggio's Series Rings Replaced
description: To recordings of Paul Simon singing, ''Joltin' Joe has left and gone away,'' and Bonnie Baker singing, ''Joe, Joe DiMaggio, we want you on our side,'' the 83-year-old DiMaggio rode around the Yankee Stadium outfield in a white '56 Thunderbird yesterday, waving to the thousands who were waving back and cheering.

title: Spotlight on Reporters and Sources in Lawsuit Against '60 Minutes'
description: It is shortly before the end of a tough ''60 Minutes'' report on the United States Customs Service in San Diego, and a memo flashes on the screen, with telling phrases highlighted. The document seems to support the report's basic thrust: the southwestern border is a sieve through which huge drug cargoes pass with impunity.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Recharged Hurricane Batters Gulf Coast With 105 M.P.H. Winds
description: Hurricane Georges, rampaging again after earlier devastating islands in the Caribbean and the Florida Keys, slammed into the seaside cities and resorts of the Gulf Coast tonight with rain-packed winds of up to 105 miles per hour and a sea surge of 10 feet or more.

title: Blanca Rosenberg, Who Fled Nazis, Dies at 85
description: They were the Thelma and Louise of Nazi Poland, and if Hollywood hasn't tumbled to their story, it may be because Blanca Rosenberg and Maria Rosenbloom had too many hair-raising escapes, too many improbable rescues -- and far too much unremitting horror in between -- for a single script to handle.

title: Donors Offer Cash and Compassion to Clinton
description: Outside, the signs were savage for President Clinton in the six cities he visited over the weekend to raise money for Democrats.

description: Goldman, Sachs & Company is likely to announce this week that it will not go public this year, according to people who work at the Wall Street investment bank.

title: A Passion for Doing the Right Thing (and Gambling)
description: Character and conversation outweigh momentum and suspense in ''Phoenix,'' but a gifted cast, led by Ray Liotta, who was a co-producer of this story of corrupt police detectives in Arizona, splashes alluring color across its familiar noir.

title: Doak Walker, 71, Standout In College and Pro Football
description: Doak Walker, the 1948 Heisman Trophy winner and one of college football's legendary heroes, died yesterday at Routt Hospital in Steamboat Springs, Colo. He was 71.

description: Activision Inc., the video game maker, is going Hollywood.

title: Media Talk; Gannett to Merge Papers In Suburban New York
description: Gannett Suburban Newspapers is planning to merge its 11 papers in Rockland, Westchester and Putnam counties in New York into one newspaper later this fall, to be named The Journal News.

title: Giants Relentlessly Regain Their Strut
description: The formula is not new to these Giants, and they knew where they were headed today when they saw the rattled rookie Ryan Leaf throwing the football into their formations without much thought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERMAN, EDNA (NEE MARCUS)
description: LEDERMAN-Edna (nee Marcus). Died September 25, 1998. A true woman of valor. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Dear mother of Arnold and Fran and Saul and Betty. Adored grandma of Diane Sharon, Nancy and Michael Cohen, Steven and Kenneth. Great-grandma to Samantha and Thalia. Devoted sister of Lee Elkins, Alex and Seymour and the late Harold Marcus. Graveside services Sunday, September 27, at 3 PM, New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

description: FARMER-Margaret H. On September 26, 1998, in Doylestown, PA. Beloved wife of the late James A. Farmer. Devoted stepmother of James A. Farmer, Jr., of Champaign, IL, and Sylvia F. Hultkrans of Madison, WI. Loving grandmother of James S. Farmer, Paul A. Farmer, Jean B. Hultkrans, and David J. Hultkrans. Also survived by a brother, Orville L. Hankins, Sun City, AZ, and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, ARLYNE L.
description: STEINER-Arlyne L. On September 25th, 1998. Beloved wife of Leonard Steiner. Loving mother of Robin & Kathy Steiner, Ellyn and Michael Greenspan, Beth & Timothy Sinatro. Exceptional ''Grammy'' of Erin, Sammy, Darren, Allie, Lulu and Alec. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. In lieu of flowers contributions in her honor may be made to The Gynecological Cancer Research Fund at NYU Medical Center or Dickstein Cancer Treatment Center at White Plains Hospital Center.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, DAVID
description: FISHER-David. Devoted husband of the late Bettie Lou is survived by his children Barbara, Jane, David, Timothy, Padraic, Andrew; five grandchildren; and devoted companions Mitchell Grossman, Nora Knowles, and Ramzi Pio. He was 87. A well-respected attorney for over 65 years, he represented many famous clients including The Steinway Corporation, The New York Yankees, and many celebrities and served as general counsel for U.S. Surgical Corporation from 1968 to 1995. A voracious collector and accomplished bookman, his 35,000 volume library is among the most extensive private collections in the country. A prolific writer in his retirement, his works include ''The Human Relations Factor'' 1990, and the unpublished ''Journey to the Sun'' and his epic celebration of Native Americans, ''Red Eminence.'' In his professional career as a leading authority in securities law, the Fordham University graduate authored many of New York State's securities law statutes. Services will be held Tuesday, September 29, 1998 at 12 noon at the Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memoriam to the American Indian College Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALY, CHRISTINE (NEE KAVANAGH)
description: DALY-Christine (nee Kavanagh). Of Ridgewood, NJ, and Southold, LI, NY, passed away September 25. Beloved wife of Austin J. Loving mother of Christopher Daly, M.D., of Pittsburgh, PA, Patricia Nappi of Manhattan, NY, and Anne Barabas of Allendale, NJ. Adored grandmother of Austin, Matthew and Jonathan Daly, James, Amy and Daniel Barabas. The family received their relatives and friends Sunday, from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Feeney Funeral Home, Inc., 232 Franklin Ave., Ridgewood. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated today, 11 AM, at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Ridgewood. Interment Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions made to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, JOSEPH
description: FEINBERG-Joseph. On September 27, 1998. Beloved husband of Belle for 61 years. Loving father of Marty and Phyllis Feinberg. Cherished grandfather of Jack and Kallie. Loved, cherished and admired by all who knew him. Services Monday, 11 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: BRONCOS 38

title: Media Talk; A New Business Post For Magazine Publisher
description: Joe Armstrong, publishing director and senior partner at Meigher Communications, is joining Capital Publishing in the new post of senior vice president, group publisher.

title: Bartle Bogle Gets A Reebok Account
description: Reebok International Ltd. has given the new American office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty in New York its first assignment, naming it to handle worldwide advertising for the Reebok Classic line. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: Is Anybody Out There?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Quietly, 4 Try to Steer a Center Course
description: They are an unlikely quartet, two House Republicans and two House Democrats who are waging a quiet campaign to take the partisan sting out of the House impeachment deliberations.

title: Review/Fashion; In London, Indulging in a Bit of Creativity
description: In a funny way, Alexander McQueen best represents the attitude of the collections seem so far in London for spring and summer 1999. His show on Sunday night was a combination of feminine and brassy, of sexy and fragile. No other designer succeeded so well in getting this dual message across.

title: New German Leader to Seek Coalition With the Greens
description: Gerhard Schroder, Germany's Chancellor-elect, said today that he would seek to form a coalition government with the environmentalist Green Party, opening the way for the first ''Red-Green'' government in the 49-year history of the postwar republic.

title: A Top Iranian Aide Rejects U.S. Overture on New Ties
description: Iran's Foreign Minister, Kamal Kharrazi, yesterday rebuffed the offer by the United States to draw up a ''road map'' to re-establish relations between the two countries, accusing the Clinton Administration of an outdated policy of hostility toward his country.

title: When Scientific Predictions Are So Good They're Bad
description: NOAH had it easy. He got his prediction straight from the horse's mouth and was left in no doubt about what to do.

title: ARTS IN AMERICA: Where Stars Came Out to Play; Broadway's Rural Refuge, With Lunt and Fontanne
description: The seven sheets of undated stationery from a Toronto hotel are addressed to ''Beloved Celestials'' and folded carefully into a similarly yellowing envelope bearing the hotel's crest. It was lonely and late at night, the letter said, after a grueling performance, and Canada was asleep. ''God, how glorious to be even thinking of seeing you,'' it said, and was signed ''Larry.''

title: $1.07 Billion Offer for Access Health
description: HBO & Company said today that it would buy Access Health Inc. for as much as $1.07 billion in stock to expand the information services that HBO offers to the health care industry.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COOPER INDUSTRIES, Houston, dropped out of the bidding yesterday for TLG P.L.C., a British lighting company. TLG recommended that its shareholders now accept the offer from Wassall P.L.C.

title: Accounts
description: * Rocket Science Creative Ltd., New York, was awarded three accounts with combined billings estimated at $3.5 million: HomeDelivery.com, New York, an on-line shopping service; Robert Burton Associates, West Caldwell, N.J., for East Coast advertising for Joker brand cigarette rolling paper, and Sandellas, Georgetown, Conn., as the first agency for Sandellas Wrap Cafes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYERT, MURRAY
description: HEYERT-Murray, age 86, died unexpectedly on September 8, 1998 in the company of his beloved wife Florence of almost 65 years. He is also mourned by his daughter Elizabeth Heyert and her husband Douglas Elliott, his brother Arthur Heyert, and his brother inlaw Edwin Horen and his wife Myra. Memorial service was held in his honor in Tamarac, Florida. His family and friends will miss him greatly.

title: Sports of The Times; Stottlemyres Display No Emotion This Time
description: TONIGHT the father and son will be on opposite sides in a short series that will leave one of them disappointed. Literature is full of parents and children who must eventually confront each other as adults. This is neither the Civil War nor Tolstoy. This is a case of two professionals, proud of each other. Todd Stottlemyre is a pitcher with the Texas Rangers; his father, Mel, is the pitching coach with the Yankees.
