title: GILAT SATELLITE TO BUY GE SPACENET UNIT FOR $227 MILLION
description: Gilat Satellite Networks Ltd., an Israeli maker of satellite earth stations, has agreed to buy GE Capital Spacenet Services Inc., a provider of global communications network and services, for $227.5 million in stock. Gilat, a primary provider of products to GE Spacenet, will pay five million newly issued shares. The deal will make GE Spacenet's parent, GE American Communications, Gilat's largest shareholder, with a 30 percent interest. Gilat, based in Petah Tikva, Israel, makes satellite earth stations called very small aperture terminals, or V.S.A.T.'s. GE American Communications is a unit of the General Electric Company. The Spacenet Services unit is based in McLean, Va.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, IRVING
description: MANN-Irving. Dad/Irving, You were a most special father and devoted grandfather. You taught us all to be strong, independent, and hard-working, but also how to laugh and enjoy life. You and Mom/Nanni showed us the true meaning of love. During your fiftynine years together, your unending devotion to each other warmed our hearts. We will never forget you. Your words of wisdom, encouragement and advice will follow us all through our lives. Rest peacefully and know how much you were loved. Meryl, Michael, Betsy and Adam

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOGAN, DORIS DOLL
description: LOGAN-Doris Doll. Of Rumson, New Jersey. Formerly of NYC. On September 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Howard S. Logan and mother of the late Peter F. Logan. Loving mother of Diana L. Boyd. Also surviving are 3 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Graveside services on Saturday, October 3 at 11 A.M., at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55 Street, NYC 10019.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, DOROTHY
description: BROWN-Dorothy. The Young Israel of Scarsdale regretfully records the passing of its longtime member, Dorothy Brown, and extends heartfelt condolences to her husband, Edward, and the entire family. Jacob Rubenstein, Rabbi Joshua Klapper, President

title: Two Wars at Once?
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Tribute For Griffith Joyner
description: Florence Griffith Joyner, who died Sept. 21 at age 38, will be honored with a special tribute and posthumous award on Feb. 11 at the Jesse Owens International Trophy Award annual dinner in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHINELANDER, PHYLLIS M.
description: RHINELANDER - Phyllis M. Daughter of the late Philip Kip Rhinelander & Helen G. Rhinelander passed away at her home on Sunday, Sept. 27 after a long illness. Involved in several charities, she was a member of the Colonial Dames Of America, Society Of Daughters Of The Cincinatti, and Daughters Of The American Revolution. She leaves a sister, Helen Rhinelander Schreuer & a cousin, Mrs. Robert M. Donaldson. In lieu of flowers, please send to: Save The Children, Westport Connecticut 06880. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue and 81 Street, visiting hours 9:00 AM-9:00 PM Tuesday, September 29th. Funeral service Wednesday, September 30th at 11:00 AM at Christian Community, 309 West 74th Street. Memorial service at a later date at the Church of the Holy Trinity.

title: Deadline Deal Energizes Johnson and the Astros
description: There was something ornery and iffy about the pitching star stuck in a funk earlier this year. Still, this was the coveted Randy Johnson, a pitcher up to his mustache in power and the potential to swing the balance in a playoff series.

title: A Victory for Cleaner Air
description: After two decades of delay and political debate, the Environmental Protection Agency has now moved decisively to deal with windblown pollution that originates mainly in the Midwest and drifts eastward to poison the air over New York and other Northeastern states. Last Thursday Carol Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, ordered 22 states to sharply reduce emissions of smog-producing nitrogen oxides. Her ruling represents a triumph of science and common sense over a sustained lobbying campaign by the Midwestern governors and the coal-fired electric utilities that will bear most of the cost of the new program.

title: Lazard to Pay $9 Million in Yield-Burning Suit
description: Lazard Freres & Company, the Wall Street investment bank, has agreed to pay $9 million to settle a civil lawsuit brought by the Los Angeles Metropolitan Transportation Agency accusing Lazard of grossly overcharging the agency in a 1993 bond transaction, participants in the settlement said yesterday.

title: The Right-Leftist on Top: Gerhard Schroder
description: Gerhard Schroder, who will soon become Germany's first new Chancellor in 16 years, is a practical man with a gift for the modern news media; his biggest challenge will be to define just who he really is.

title: Thomas Hearings' Flaw
description: To the Editor:

title: D'Amato and Schumer Intensify Clash Over Crime Issue
description: Wrestling over two issues that have become central to the Senate campaign, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato lined up today the endorsements of a half-dozen police union leaders in an effort to underscore his crime-fighting credentials, as Representative Charles E. Schumer assailed him as ''the most anti-education senator in the history of New York.''

title: Germany's Shift East
description: With an astonishing boldness, Germans have ushered in a new phase in their political life, one their newly elected leader, Gerhard Schroder, today called the ''Berlin republic.''

title: Jerusalem Journal; Aged Rabbi at Center of an Unholy War of Words
description: The rabbi doesn't look like a political football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHER, DAVID
description: FISHER-David. Devoted husband of the late Bettie Lou is survived by his children Barbara, Jane, David, Timothy, Padraic, Andrew; five grandchildren; and devoted companions Mitchell Grossman, Nora Knowles, and Ramzi Pio. He was 87. A well-respected attorney for over 65 years, he represented many famous clients including The Steinway Corporation, The New York Yankees, and many celebrities and served as general counsel for U.S. Surgical Corporation from 1968 to 1995. A voracious collector and accomplished bookman, his 35,000 volume library is among the most extensive private collections in the country. A prolific writer in his retirement, his works include ''The Human Relations Factor'' 1990, and the unpublished ''Journey to the Sun'' and his epic celebration of Native Americans, ''Red Eminence.'' In his professional career as a leading authority in securities law, the Fordham University graduate authored many of New York State's securities law statutes. Services will be held Tuesday, September 29, 1998 at 12 noon at the Waterbury & Kelly Funeral Home, Briarcliff Manor, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memoriam to the American Indian College Fund.

title: No Signs of Rejection in Transplanted Forearm
description: THE Australian man who received a transplanted hand and forearm in France last Wednesday is recovering uneventfully without any signs of graft rejection, his doctors said yesterday.

title: 'Trick' Accounting Draws Levitt Criticism
description: Scolding America's companies and their accountants for using ''accounting hocus-pocus,'' Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that his staff would crack down on businesses that used certain controversial accounting methods to manipulate the numbers reported to shareholders.

title: State Offers Savings Plan For College
description: Joining a growing number of states that give tax breaks for college savings, New York inaugurated a program yesterday that allows parents to save thousands of dollars in state taxes as they put aside money for a child's college education.

title: In Dominican Republic, Isolated Areas Get Food
description: A small plane chartered by the United States began airdropping parcels of food and water today to beleaguered people in villages and small towns that have been isolated for nearly a week by flood waters and broken bridges resulting from the hurricane that struck on Tuesday.

title: Older People Enjoy Sex, Survey Says
description: Many older Americans maintain an interest in sex, with nearly half of those over age 60 engaging in sexual activity at least once a month, according to a survey released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHNER, HARRY
description: SCHECHNER-Harry. On Sept. 27, 1998, of Lakewood, N.J., due to a long illness. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Survived by wife Florence, brothers Bill and Stanley Schechner, son Dr. Richard Schechner and grandchildren. Services will be held at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, Long Island, New York 10:30AM, Tuesday, Sept. 29. In lieu of flowers donations to Original Leisure Village Foundation, 19 Buckingham Drive, Lakewood, N.J. 08701.

title: This Race Was for the National League Mild Card
description: The second most exciting race of the season was decided here last night. That doesn't say much for the competitive part of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAMS, ISAAC (BILL)
description: BRAMS-Isaac (Bill). On September 28. Of West Bloomfield, MI. & formerly of NY. Beloved husband of Audrey, devoted father of Leonard (Susan), adoring grandfather of Jennifer, dear brother of Stanley (Gloria), brother-in-law of Robert & Hazel Reichard. Services on Thursday, at 1 P.M. at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Trying Times Test a G.O.P. Congresswoman's Moderation
description: It's dessert night with the candidates at the Elks Lodge, and Representative Nancy L. Johnson, a Republican, finds herself defending her party's drawn-out handling of President Clinton's fate. Back in Washington, she was on the other side, rankling party leaders with sharp criticism over the release of X-rated evidence against the President.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, VIOLA
description: GOLDBERG-Viola. The Trustees of the Archives of American Art wish to extend our sincere sympathy to the family of Viola Goldberg. As a fellow Trustee Viola will be eulogized in our memory as one of our own and as a friend. Frank Martucci, Pres. Richard Wattenmaker, Director

title: U.S. Hedge Fund Bailout Raises Asian Eyebrows
description: In Asia, which has been scolded and sermonized by the United States over its economic policies, there is a sense of grim satisfaction at the near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management L.P., and at its $3.65 billion rescue by a team of banks and brokerage firms.

title: Indians Count On Ramirez Continuing His Power Surge
description: The problem with a historic baseball season is that there are casualties. Those with the marvelous performances receive the lion's share of recognition while those with the lesser, though still notable, achievements are dwarfed, relegated to doing great things in virtual anonymity.

title: John F. Prudden, 78, Surgeon and Researcher
description: Dr. John F. Prudden, a surgeon and researcher who used medicines made from the cartilage of sharks, reptiles and cows as well as the chitin of lobster or shrimp shells to help heal wounds and treat a range of diseases, died on Sept. 12 at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 78 and lived in Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: A Colleague, Fan and Daughter
description: Ravi Shankar's most attentive audience member was onstage with him when he performed at Carnegie Hall on Friday night. That listener was his 17-year-old daughter, Anoushka, who is also one of his sitar students and who was playing by his side. She followed his every phrase with the concentration of a disciple, eventually joining in on melodies and taking a flashy solo of her own. But the center of attention was Mr. Shankar, who at the age of 78 is showing his audiences a broad sweep of Indian classical traditions, from ancient repertory to his own innovations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, GUSSIE
description: SCHNEIDER-Gussie. Temple Hillel, No. Woodmere, L.I. records with profound sorrow the passing of their Congregant, Gussie Schneider, beloved mother of our Board of Trustees Member, Gloria Schlussel, and son, Milton, motherin-law, grandmother and great grandmother, and extends sincere condolences to the entire family. Dr. Alan F. Lavin, Rabbi Arthur Singer, President Morris S. Friedman Rabbi Emeritus

title: CARGILL TO SELL SEED BUSINESS TO A GERMAN COMPANY
description: Hoechst Schering Agrevo G.m.b.H. agreed yesterday to acquire most of the North American seed businesses of Cargill Inc. for $650 million. Agrevo, a joint venture of the German chemical maker Hoechst A.G. and the drug maker Schering A.G., said it would buy Cargill Hybrid Seeds North America to try to expand its market share in North America. Cargill Hybrid Seeds, which had sales of $106 million in the year that ended on May 31, is a leading producer of high-performance hybrid seed in the United States and Canada. The company has a 4 percent share of the United States corn seed market and is also a major producer of sunflower seeds. The acquisition includes 14 research and production facilities in the United States and one in Canada.

title: Sam Locke, Writer for Radio, TV and Theater, Is Dead at 81
description: Sam Locke, a writer of plays, books, theater sketches and television scripts whose roots hark back to the golden days of radio, died on Sept. 18 at a convalescent center in San Diego. He was 81.

title: Bank Reform, Not Bankruptcy, Is the Big Talk in Tokyo
description: Financial markets today virtually ignored the financial fallout of Japan's largest postwar bankruptcy, rallying instead on progress in a bank-reform plan viewed as an important step toward overcoming a severe recession.

title: Editorial Notebook; Confessions of a Foul-Weather Mets Fan
description: While the rest of the country has been consumed this summer with the Mark McGwire-Sammy Sosa duel, the home run most precious to me took place in Houston on Sept. 15. The hitter was Mets shortstop Rey Ordonez, a fielding genius but no slugger. The shot brought his home run total for the year to one, tying his personal best, and that is where it stayed.

title: Leon Johnson: Special In Many Ways for Jets
description: Forget the fact that Leon Johnson averages 13.2 yards every time he touches the football for the Jets. Or his spectacular 82-yard, catch-and-run touchdown on Sept. 20 against the Indianapolis Colts. Or that he is one of the few players of the 1990's to have scored touchdowns running, receiving and returning punts and kickoffs. He will not get more plays.

title: Metro Business; Company Gets New Home
description: CCH Legal Information Services has signed a long-term lease for approximately 147,000 square feet of space at 111 Eighth Avenue, between 15th and 16th Streets in Manhattan.

title: School for Scandal, 1998 Version
description: It was my excellent good fortune to arrive in Paris the day after the broadcast of President Clinton's deposition. In the course of a three-day visit, I was required to explain to a number of bewildered French how we have managed to arrive at the present situation and why we are now satellite-feeding the world the minutest details of Presidential indiscretions.

title: Advanswers Renames New York Office
description: Advanswers in St. Louis, the media services company owned by Omnicom Group, has renamed its New York office, formerly known as the Paul Schulman Company, as Schulman/Advanswers N.Y. Tom DeCabia, senior vice president for network television and account supervisor at Schulman, was promoted to the new position of executive vice president and general manager at Schulman/Advanswers N.Y. Mr. DeCabia, 44, reports to Paul Schulman, 58, president.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Accents, Adulation And Spirit Of Salsa
description: Marc Anthony made some noise at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night, but it wasn't as much noise as his fans made.

title: Among Hollywood Democrats, President Is Supported as One of Their Own
description: Madonna dropped in at a Democratic fund-raiser in Beverly Hills honoring President Clinton. Barbra Streisand defended Mr. Clinton the other day and said many of the greatest Presidents seemed to have had affairs, too. And David Geffen and other moguls said Mr. Clinton's personal life was his own business.

title: GLOBAL MOTORSPORT ENDS PACT WITH FREMONT PARTNERS
description: Global Motorsport Group Inc., the top independent parts-distributor for Harley-Davidson motorcycles, said yesterday that it had ended its agreement to sell a majority stake to Fremont Partners L.P. for $104.8 million, as Global Motorsport said it was not happy with the transaction's financing conditions and would seek other opportunities. Fremont is an equity fund based in San Francisco. Global Motorsport, based in Morgan Hill, Calif., is the parent organization for an international group of motorcycle-parts makers, including Custom Chrome Inc. Global Motorsport's stock rose $1.75 a share, to $15.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Patterns
description: A Secondary Line for Jacobs

title: Feud at Top Is Disrupting Mutual Fund
description: A fight for control of a formerly highly regarded mutual fund is brewing between its manager and independent directors. If the battle follows the pattern of several similar recent battles, shareholders could be the biggest losers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRMAN, RITA MARIE
description: MURRMAN-Rita Marie (nee Honeck). Beloved wife of the late Edward. Devoted mother of Marita K. Murrman Baronowski, Joanne Murrman and the late Marianne Culhane. Loving grandmother of Katherine Anne, J.B. and Edward. Funeral Mass was Monday, 10:30 AM, at the Catholic Center of NYU. Burial following in Arlington, MASS.

title: Spencer to Watch
description: Even as Shane Spencer went on a power binge in the season's final week, Manager Joe Torre never wavered about whether the Yankee rookie might start in the playoffs.

title: Making a Sad Time Touching and Funny
description: Frank's lover, Ben, is dying. Friends, neighbors and family swarm like interfering gnats. Terri, a young upstairs neighbor, has installed himself as the household's tireless organizer of activities and emotions. A hyperactive little transvestite named Imelda breezes in and out. Becky, a ''lesbian mom,'' visits with her little son, Willis. Ben's cruelly homophobic sister Joyce arrives.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHECHNER, KENNETH STEVEN
description: SCHECHNER-Kenneth Steven. G-d blessed me deep and profound for 38 years I had a brother around. He showed me much of how a boy could live-he taught me everything of how a man does die. AI

title: Fighting a Stronger and Meaner Strain of Malaria
description: YOU may wonder why I would write a Personal Health column about malaria when there is no malaria in the United States. Well, that is only partly true. Malaria is not endemic in this country or to Canada or Europe. But one-third of the world's population lives where the malaria parasite and its carrier mosquitoes thrive, and every year more than one million Americans travel to those areas for business or pleasure. Malaria, it seems, is gaining ground annually as control efforts become more costly and cumbersome.

title: Federal Proposal Would Provide Methadone to More Drug Addicts
description: The White House's top drug official is to announce today a policy to expand the availability of methadone to all those who need it, despite Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's criticism of the drug as simply exchanging one addiction for another.

title: The Orchestra Walks Out, As the Composer Ordered
description: Sunday afternoon's Carnegie Hall concert by the American Composers Orchestra, with Paul Lustig Dunkel conducting, provided a rare opportunity to see and hear George Crumb's ''Echoes of Time and the River'' -- a work that certainly needs to be seen as well as heard. Writing this work in 1967, Mr. Crumb went further than any other composer in exploring the possibilities of the walking orchestra.

title: Committee's Partisanship Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: A Blast at Secrecy in Kennedy Killing
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Bill Would Reverse Welfare Family Cap
description: A state law that cuts off supplementary welfare benefits to recipients who have additional children would be repealed under a bipartisan bill introduced yesterday.

title: City's Renewal Plan Includes an Amusement Park Ride
description: For years, the city leaders here have considered how to rebuild a deteriorating downtown to attract businesses and tax dollars. First, they looked to retail, but the threat of competition from nearby suburban shopping meccas quickly scuttled that idea.

title: Gillette to Cut Jobs by 11% As Results Lag
description: Warning that its third-quarter results would be dismal, the Gillette Company said yesterday that it would cut 4,700 jobs, or 11 percent of its worldwide work force, as it reorganized its business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMPSON, HOKE S.
description: SIMPSON-Hoke S. On September 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Suzanne (nee Memminger). Loving father of Drayton Jenkins Gerety, Hoke S. Jr., and Willis M. Caring grandfather of Hoke III, Sheryl, Michael, Christopher, Katie, and David. Memorial service at St. John's Episcopal Church, Fountain Square, Larchmont, New York, on Tuesday at 11 AM. Reception will follow at the Larchmont Yacht Club. For further information, contact John J. Fox Funeral Home 914-834-0144.

title: The Relativist-in-Chief
description: The Clinton crisis is as much about the rigidity of the past and flexibility of the present as it is about right and wrong, true or false. It's about sex, morality and the law -- but as seen from two different generations, perspectives and sets of values.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWERLING, LOUIS
description: ZWERLING-Louis. At age 88, painter, poet, world-traveler, on September 25, 1998. He will be grievously missed by his wife, Harriet, and son, Milo, and mourned by his brother, Jeff Corey of Malibu, California, sister, Edith Siegel of New York City and many friends. Our love goes with you into your dream.

title: Committee's Partisanship Shows; An Issues Vacuum
description: To the Editor:

title: Struggling to Bolster Minorities in Medicine
description: MEDICAL authorities, educators and civil-rights lawyers, concerned about a sudden drop in minority enrollment in the nation's medical schools, are striking back at moves to fight affirmative action that they believe threaten the future health of minority communities.

title: This Year Just Isn't Next Year For Bonds
description: As the Cubs took victory laps and sprayed Champagne on Wrigley Field, the former Cub Shawon Dunston stayed on the top step of the San Francisco dugout, watching his former mates. Pitcher Julian Tavarez slapped a photographer with his glove. Barry Bonds sat quietly in the clubhouse.

title: Time Warner Sponsors School Program for Computer Careers
description: Time Warner announced yesterday that it would sponsor a program to prepare students for careers in computer technology.

title: Restaurant Manager Is Fatally Stabbed
description: The manager of a Wendy's restaurant in East Orange was stabbed to death yesterday morning, apparently the victim of a robbery, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, ARLYNE
description: STEINER-Arlyne. We mourn the loss of Arlyne, generous supporter together with beloved husband Leonard and mother of Robin and Kathy Steiner, Ellyn and Michael Greenspan, Beth and Timothy Sinatro. May the memories of their loving and fulfilling life sustain the family during this difficult time. Michael R. Stoler, Chairman Lay Advisory Board Franco M. Muggia, MD Director Kaplan Comprehensive Cancer Center NYU School of Medicine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SERING, CLARITO B.
description: SERING-Clarito B. Age 61, on September 27th, 1998. He is survived by his wife, Maria Jerlin; a son, Clarito Jr., and two daughters, Claribelle and Candice, brother and sisters. The family will receive friends on Thursday and Friday, October 1st and 2nd, at 2-5PM and 7-10PM at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Boulevard, Flushing, NY. A memorial service will be held at St. Andrews Avellino Catholic Church, 157th St and Northern Boulevard, Flushing, New York.

title: Astronomers Revive Scan of the Heavens for Signs of Life
description: ''SORRY guys,'' Jill C. Tarter said, cutting off chitchat around the control panel, eager to hunt for alien civilizations. ''We have the telescope.''

title: Building a Bridge, a Theater Troupe From the U.S. Is Embraced by Havana
description: The veteran actors from Repertorio Espanol had performed the play ''Broken Eggs'' dozens of times before, in New York City, but on Sunday they took the stage here with the nervousness of beginners. One feared that she would become so emotional she would lose her concentration. Another said he was terrified that he would open his mouth and nothing would come out.

title: Yankees' Mantra: Concentrate and Play Hard
description: Joe Torre intends to stand in the middle of the Yankees' clubhouse at the Stadium today and remind his players to continue playing as they have all year. Concentrate, play hard. Keep everything the same, ignore the changing circumstances.

title: When a Spirited Teen-Ager Faced the Unimaginable
description: ANNE FRANK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, LIA A.
description: JOHNSON-Lia A. Dear Lia, we will always remember you for your gentle and kind ways. Your beauty will remain with us forever. Rest in peace, dear friend. Leslie and Cliff Spelke

title: Liberal Group Says It Is Preparing Ad Campaign Defending Clinton
description: A liberal political group plans to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on an advertising campaign that extols the accomplishments of President Clinton and attacks Republicans for neglecting everyday issues while chasing the Lewinsky scandal.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Dr. Helen Winthrop Edey, 86, Philanthropist and Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Helen Winthrop Edey, a philanthropist and psychiatrist who was active in the field of women's reproductive health and rights, died on Sept. 15 at the Martha's Vineyard Hospital in Massachusetts. She was 86 and lived on Martha's Vineyard and in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZBARD, SHIMSHON
description: SCHWARTZBARD - Shimshon. Sept. 24. Beloved husband of the late Miriam. Father of Abe & Ada. Father-in-law of Lorraine and Jack. Grandfather of Amy, Ari, Adam, Debra, Jonathan, Rachel and Dana. Brother of Lola Altman, Hinda Eisenberg, Harry & Barry .

title: Upon Further Review, Mets Look to the Future
description: On the morning after the biggest collapse in franchise history, the Mets began to look to the future. They had no other choice.

title: Illuminating Chinese Art With Western Styles And Mysterious Effects
description: Friday night's concert at the Taipei Theater was a joint venture between that institution and the Manhattan School of Music. From the school came the performers -- the Elsner Quartet, an exceptional ensemble undergoing final training there, and the New Music Consort -- while the theater, as an outpost of Taiwan, provided the composers.

title: Kremlin Ousts Its Most Outspoken Reformer
description: The Russian Government's most outspoken reformer was ousted from his post today, leaving policy in the hands of a unlikely coalition of Communists, regional leaders and Yeltsin holdovers.

title: U.S., Israel and Arafat Inch Toward Pact
description: After more than 18 months of squabbling and stalemate, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat have agreed on the essentials of an Israeli withdrawal from another 13 percent of the West Bank, senior American and Israeli officials said today.

title: Victories And Virtue In the Bronx
description: THIS baseball fan's one and only encounter with Joe DiMaggio is as fresh as an autumn breeze in memory, even after 19 years. Some New York business types were giving the great DiMaggio an award: a chance, rest assured, for them to bask in his glory and not the other way around. It was also an opportunity, too good to miss, for an unabashedly starry-eyed reporter to meet a legend.

title: Unpredictable in Serenity and Chaos
description: For all the agonizing one still hears about that state of contemporary musical language, the generation of composers who grew up in the 1960's and 70's has sorted things out efficiently. Osvaldo Golijov, a 38-year old composer who was born in Argentina, studied in Israel and now lives in the United States, solved the language problem by skirting easy definitions. His music, with its shifting, cloudy harmonies, is not really consonant, but its dissonances are so fleeting and ethereal that the music cannot be called dissonant either. Because Mr. Golijov often quotes or alludes to existing material -- Hebrew prayers and chant melodies, for example -- sections of his works seem tonal. Yet these melodies are typically enveloped in accompaniments that elude key centers.

title: Committee's Partisanship Shows; Citizens, Not Enablers
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Jeffrey A. Moss, a writer and composer who contributed characters and songs to ''Sesame Street,'' omitted two survivors. They are his mother, Stella Moss of Manhattan, and a sister, Andrea Moss End of Westchester County.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Kosovo Refugees, a Grim Augur of Winter
description: Heavy rain and winds slashed the makeshift ethnic Albanian refugee camps in Kosovo today, and many inhabitants, who have been living outdoors for months, were left cold, wet and encrusted in mud.

title: Corrections
description: A schedule of New York Film Festival screenings in Weekend on Friday misidentified the director of ''The Apple,'' an Iranian and French film being shown at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow and on Sunday. She is Samira Makhmalbaf; Mohsen Makhmalbaf wrote the screenplay and is her father.

title: Bighorn Sheep Losing Ground, and Lives, to an Old Foe
description: NOT long after settlers began streaming into the West in the mid-1800's, bighorn sheep began disappearing. Unregulated hunting took its toll, as did diseases spread by domestic sheep.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDERMAN, RUTH
description: FEDERMAN-Ruth (nee Korman) 84, on Sept 27, 1998. Beloved wife, Loving mother to Hank Federman and Fern Black, Devoted grandmother, sister and aunt. Lovingly remembered now and forever.

title: (Loosely) Managed Care Is in Demand; Provider Plans Zooming Over Restrictive H.M.O.'s
description: Some of the hottest, fastest-growing managed health care plans are turning out to be the ones that are hardly managed at all.

title: Q & A
description: Rayon

title: Met Opera Begins Effort To Raise $200 Million
description: With 26 donors already giving or pledging at least $1 million each, and one as much as $25 million, the Metropolitan Opera has opened its largest endowment campaign ever, aimed at more than doubling its nest egg to $400 million over the next three seasons.

title: Cure for a Crush: Be Sincere and Earnest
description: ''Felicity'' is set in motion by one of life's archetypal experiences: the hopeless, dumbstruck, high-school crush. On graduation day, the shy, smart Felicity asks the handsome, popular Ben to sign her yearbook. ''I've watched you for four years, always wondered what you were like,'' he writes. He signs it, ''Love, Ben,'' and walks away. Felicity chucks her parents' stifling plan for her to go to nearby Stanford premedical school and follows Ben to the fictional University of New York (New York University in all but name).

title: Builder Pleads Guilty in Death of Girl, 16
description: A Bronx construction company pleaded guilty yesterday to manslaughter and will pay a $10,000 fine in the death of a 16-year-old girl who was injured last January when a brick fell from the roof of a Brooklyn elementary school that was undergoing repairs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DWYER, VIRGINIA
description: DWYER-Virginia. The past year has been so much less without you. The Family

title: Drug Maker Set To Cut 350 Jobs
description: Schein Pharmaceutical Inc. said today that it would cut 350 jobs at its Steris Laboratories generic-drug plant in Phoenix.

title: Islanders' Engineer Calls Coliseum Repairs 'No Big Deal'
description: Nassau Coliseum can be easily and safely repaired without closing the arena, a structural engineer called by the Islanders testified in court today, apparently undercutting the team's case.

title: Teacher, Pupil and Now Rival Closers
description: Mariano Rivera was casually answering questions as he sat at Yankee Stadium last Saturday, deflecting the idea that he would be adversely affected by one pitch to the Indians' Sandy Alomar Jr. in the 1997 American League Division Series and saying that he was a superior pitcher now compared with last season. His demeanor was stoic, not bombastic.

title: Trials Halted, Danish Drug Stock Falls
description: Shares in Novo Nordisk, the world's No. 1 diabetes-care company, fell 12 percent here today after Novo abandoned an osteoporosis drug it was developing to reduce its reliance on diabetes treatments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUTH, BARBARA
description: BLUTH-Barbara. Beloved wife of Ira. Dear mother of Mark and Doris, and Neil and Hedy. Adored grandmother of Scott, Brian, and Jessica. Dear sister of Jerome Kletter. Services on Tuesday, at 11:30 AM at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park).

title: Prudential of Britain Cutting Sales Offices
description: The Prudential Corporation P.L.C., Britain's largest life insurer, is planning to close one-third of its branches and reduce the commission that its sales force is paid, John Elbourne, chief executive of Prudential Retail Finance Services, said yesterday. The company plans to shut 34 of its 113 sales support offices, eliminating more than 300 jobs.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT AGREES TO SELL ASSETS TO REPUBLIC
description: Waste Management Inc. agreed yesterday to sell landfills and other assets to Republic Services Inc. for about $500 million in cash and properties. Waste Management, based in Houston, hauls trash for municipal, commercial and residential customers. Republic, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., operates nonhazardous waste collection and disposal services in 28 states. The sale will fulfill the terms of a consent decree that antitrust regulators required before permitting Waste Management Inc. to merge with USA Waste Services Inc. last July.

title: Lamar Crowson, 72, Pianist for Chamber Music
description: Lamar Crowson, an American pianist who, though little known in the United States, was regarded by many colleagues as one of the finest chamber musicians of his time, died on Aug. 25 in Johannesburg, where he lived. He was 72.

title: Using elements of fashion and hints of humor, two Cognac campaigns aim for younger drinkers.
description: IN recent years, advertising for Cognac has assiduously played down references to heritage and pedigree because younger consumers seemed to perceive all those designations of V.S., V.S.O.P. and XO as spelling out F-O-R-O-L-D-F-O-L-K-S. That trend continues in two campaigns, now being introduced at the same time, for two leading Cognac brands.

title: 2 Democrats Hope Support for Lottery Will Help Break G.O.P. Grip on South
description: A red-bearded Bubba, outfitted in a baseball cap and a Georgia Bulldogs T-shirt, grins devilishly from behind the counter of his convenience store and explains to South Carolina voters why it is that ''here in Georgia, we looooove David Beasley.''

title: S.E.C. Crackdown on Technology Write-Offs
description: It is upgrade time at America Online.

title: KLM Foresees a Drop In Fiscal-Year Profit
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines N.V. has forecast lower earnings for its current fiscal year as a strike by a United States partner, Northwest Airlines, and a slump in Asian traffic cut into ticket sales. KLM's shares closed at 54.2 guilders ($28.59), down 1 guilder, after the carrier, Europe's fourth-largest airline, said on Friday that it expected earnings per share to be 6.5 to 7 guilders for the year that ends in March, compared with 8.10 guilders in the previous year.

title: Trading Is on Hold Pending Rate News
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as traders and investors awaited an announcement, expected this afternoon, that the Federal Reserve policy makers have decided to lower short-term interest rates.

title: AIDS Laws Reflect Gap in Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Good Intentions Going Horribly Awry
description: ''Frontline'' offers a tour de force tonight. Short on pictures of the October 1993 firefight in the Somali capital, ''Ambush in Mogadishu'' provides a compelling account through the memories of United States Army Rangers who found themselves pinned down for 17 hours. Eighteen Americans were killed -- the most memorable picture was of a body being dragged through the streets -- and scores more wounded, with enduring consequences for American foreign policy.

title: ALLSTATE SELLS OFF REAL ESTATE TO WESTBROOK
description: The Allstate Corporation, the insurance holding company based in Northbrook, Ill., has sold what remained of its real estate portfolio to the closely held investment fund Westbrook Partners L.L.C. for about $965 million. The portfolio, which includes more than 10 million square feet of space in about 95 offices, ends Allstate's liquidation of its once-giant real estate holdings, aside from some of its own offices. Westbrook, based in New York, raises money to buy real estate. It is the first time in recent years that a big portfolio of office properties has been sold to a closely held buyer instead of to a publicly traded real estate invesment trust. Allstate will retain a $150 million interest in the portfolio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAYNE, NEIL
description: SHAYNE-Neil. Dear Grandpa, we love you and will always miss you. Lizzie, Dena, Dani, Stephanie and Matthew

title: Abroad at Home; The Piper and the Tune
description: One political force is more determined than any other to drive President Clinton from office for his behavior, and the same force would be the big political gainer if he is removed. That is the Christian right.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about foreigners' concern that the Monica Lewinsky scandal is impairing American foreign policy misstated the title of a Brazilian official, Luiz Felipe Lampreia. He is Foreign Minister, not Finance Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, ARLYNE L.
description: STEINER-Arlyne L. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of the beloved wife of Leonard Steiner and the adored mother of Robin (Kathy) Steiner, Ellyn (Michael) Greenspan, and Beth (Timothy) Sinatro. With her husband and with Robin and Kathy, Mrs. Steiner was a long-time friend of our medical school and a respected member of our Society of Founders. Robin serves as secretary of our Young Men's Division; Leonard is a Guardian of our University. To them and to the entire family, we offer our deepest sympathy. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Burton P. Resnick, Chairperson Board of Overseers Albert Einstein College of Medicine Dr. Dominick P. Purpura, Dean Stephen R. Karafiol, Chairman Young Men's Division

title: Goldman Plan To Sell Stock Is Canceled
description: Blue-chip clients around the world pay Goldman, Sachs & Company to divine the most auspicious time to raise money on stock markets, so many will surely heed its latest insight: not now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKACH, MARION L.
description: LUKACH-Marion L. The Board of Directors, clinical and administrative staff and volunteers of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York mourn the loss of Marion L. Lukach, a beloved Director for more than 30 years, life-long volunteer and benefactor of the agency's home care and public health services. Her interest in nursing education and patient care, especially maternal and child health care, improved the health and well-being of countless New Yorkers. Her unwavering support of the agency for more than 50 years and commitment to high quality, compassionate healthcare will be remembered always. We extend our profound sympathy to her son, Arthur Lukach, a member of our Board of Directors, her daughter, Ellen Perlmutter, and to her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Douglas D. Broadwater Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO

title: Medical Privacy Breach
description: To the Editor:

title: Feller and '54 Indians Won 111, Rue 4 Losses
description: The Yankees matched the American League record of 111 victories set by the 1954 Cleveland Indians last Thursday. By Friday, Bob Feller was hurling verbal heat.

title: DuPont Approves a Stock Issue for Conoco
description: The DuPont Company's board approved a plan today to sell up to 20 percent of Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company, in an initial public offering.

title: Caesarean Births; A Woman's Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA JOINING EARLY-BIRD STATES FOR CAMPAIGN 2000
description: In a bid to give the nation's most populous state more clout in selecting Presidential nominees, Gov. Pete Wilson today signed a bill that moves all statewide primaries here to the first Tuesday in March, putting California in the company of New York and at least four other Eastern states for what would amount to a giant national primary on a single day.

title: Vallone Links Starr Report To Campaign In New York
description: After weeks of treading cautiously around President Clinton's troubles, Peter F. Vallone attacked Republicans' handling of the situation today and tried to link Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato to Mr. Clinton's adversaries in Washington.

title: The Real Policy Makers
description: American democracy is upside down. While Congress, the President, talk radio and yell television are obsessed with sex and scandal, the big decisions affecting our lives are hidden from view and made by people largely unaccountable to democratic processes.

title: Ketchum Takes The Grand Prize
description: Ketchum Advertising in Pittsburgh took top honors, winning the $100,000 grand prize, in the Athena Awards competition sponsored by the Newspaper Association of America for creative advertising in newspapers.

title: A Beneficent Opera Fan
description: ''I'm one of those crazy music people,'' said Alberto W. Vilar, by way of explaining how he came to give or pledge close to $40 million in recent years to the Metropolitan Opera for new productions, developing artists and its endowment campaign.

title: Additional Aid for Farmers Is Rejected in Conference on the Agriculture Bill
description: Setting up a confrontation with President Clinton, Congressional Republicans tonight rejected a Democratic request for $3.5 billion in additional emergency aid to farmers. But they approved millions of dollars for individual agricultural projects.

title: Stealth Assault on Juvenile Justice
description: Republican Congressional leaders have been quietly maneuvering to gain passage for a misguided juvenile crime package. The vehicle for this mischief is an otherwise uncontroversial measure to renew funding for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, which the Senate approved in June.

title: U.S.G.A. Debates With Club Makers
description: In a forum at United States Golf Association headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J., equipment manufacturers argued yesterday that that the U.S.G.A. should not place limitations on golf clubs that could limit innovation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IGEL, PERY
description: IGEL-Pery. In Sao Paulo, Brazil, on September 24. Husband of Ana Maria, father of Rogerio, Joyce, Marcia, the late Ernesto and Fabio. Beloved friend of Henry Schneider. A man of vision, vast accomplishments and above all a great heart. He helped shape our lives with his love and caring. Jacqueline, Jean and Michael Schneider Robert, James, Max and Ethan

title: New Regents Standards Will Hurt Weak Students, Study Says
description: A science teacher predicts that if tough new state standards are implemented, the weakest students will be ''thrown to the wolves.'' A principal laments that ''many teachers can't write,'' let alone teach challenging material. Another administrator warns that immigrant students cannot be expected to know, say, that George Washington was the first President of the United States.

title: NATIONWIDE IN TALKS TO BUY BAXTER UNIT OF UNITED ASSET
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its Pilgrim Baxter & Associates Ltd. fund-management unit to Nationwide Financial Services Inc. United Asset Management is seeking as much as $600 million for Pilgrim Baxter. Pilgrim Baxter executives want to own a stake in the firm if a sale occurs, they said. Pilgrim Baxter and Nationwide have been in talks for months. In that time the performance of Pilgrim Baxter's funds has lagged and the firm's assets have declined to $12.4 billion from $16.6 billion in the last year.

title: Former Basketball Star Is Convicted in the Slaying of a Teen-Age Girl
description: Richie Adams, a former high school, playground and college basketball star whose repeated declines into drug use and crime cost him his chances for a professional career, was convicted on Saturday of killing a 15-year-old girl in a South Bronx housing project in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLOWITZ, JOEL
description: KAPLOWITZ-Joel. We are heartbroken at the loss of a lifelong friend. Your courage and dignity will never be forgotten. Love to Bonnie, Rachel, Jenna, Eleanor, Michael, Patti and family. Bob and Linda Futterman Allie and Lauren, Fred and Lisa Futterman Joan and David Bergman Nathan and Harriet Futterman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID
description: MILLER-David. On September 27. Beloved husband of Sarah (Sally). Devoted father of sons Donald and Arthur, Frances and Robert Pildes. Loving grandfather of Gregory, Stefan and Elizabeth. Dear brother of Henry. Service today 11:30AM at ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn (near Avenue V).

title: Committee's Partisanship Shows; Measure 'Sentiment'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arafat, at U.N., Urges Backing for Statehood
description: Yasir Arafat, speaking today for the first time in the annual debate among leaders of governments and major international organizations, asked a largely sympathetic audience for help in bringing independence to the Palestinians by May.

title: Unlikely Season Of Dreams For Cubs
description: Harry Caray, the Cubs broadcaster who had a bit of a problem with names, liked to call Sammy Sosa ''Salsa.'' Sosa didn't mind. Since Caray died at the start of spring training, Sosa has honored him with a ''V'' sign after every home run this season, along with his heart thumps and kisses for the Sosa family.

title: Hurricane Falters After Thrashing Coast
description: From the eastern reaches of New Orleans to Pensacola, Fla., Hurricane Georges pounded the Gulf Coast today with destructive winds and even more destructive rains, then slowly lost much of its punch as it drifted along the coast.

title: Discovering Who's Buried in Halvdan's Tomb
description: SOMETHING is moving inside a Viking burial mound said to be the ninth-century tomb of King Halvdan the Black. But some archeologists are loath to enter, warning that whatever is in there could dissolve the spell of enchantment that helped make Norway a nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, STANLEY
description: STRAUSS-Stanley. Beloved husband of Audrey. Devoted father of Wendy and Gary Pomerantz, Mark and Susan and Jill. Loving grandfather of Shari, Amanda and Lee. Services 9:45AM, Thursday, October 1 at Beth El Synagogue, North Avenue and Northfield Road, New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Eight Employees Sue F. A. O. Schwarz, Claiming Racial Bias
description: Two current and six former employees of F. A. O. Schwarz filed a lawsuit against the company yesterday, accusing a former general manager of the specialty toy retailer's flagship store on Fifth Avenue of creating a hostile and racist environment by speaking baldly about the need to ''lighten'' the complexion of the work force.

title: INSIDE
description: Russian Reformer Ousted

title: Judge Approves Suit By Immigrant Detainees
description: A Federal judge in Newark has approved a class-action suit against the private company that ran an immigration detention center in Elizabeth where detainees rioted in June 1995 to protest what they said was inhumane treatment.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO BUY BACK $3.28 BILLION IN SHARES
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it would repurchase an additional 40 million shares, or $3.28 billion in stock, expanding a four-year buyback program. The New York-based company said the new repurchases represented about 9 percent of its 456.8 million shares outstanding. Under the existing 100-million-share buyback program, begun in September 1994, American Express has repurchased 89.5 million shares. The New York-based company, which has assets of about $120 billion, said it would use the repurchased shares to ''offset share issuances under employee compensation plans and to increase economic value for shareholders.'' Shares of American Express rose $2.50 each, to $83, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, MARILYN
description: GREENBERG-Marilyn. 1935-1998. Author of ''The Rabbi's Life Contract'', Doubleday, 1989. Beloved wife of Rabbi David Greenberg and his partner in all things, including the building, in Scarsdale, of the Westchester Reform Temple and the Scarsdale Synagogue (1955-1980) and, in Easthampton, L.I., the Jewish Center of the Hamptons (1981-1994). Beloved mother of Rachel Leah Levenberg and Ruth, Ethan, Adam and Susannah Greenberg. Caring mother-in-law of Joel Levenberg, Ed Gogel and Robert Schechter. Doting grandmother of Ruth, Aaron and Julia Levenberg and Hannah and Benjamin Gogel. She was a great writer. Contributions to the Therapeutic Nursery of the JCC of the Palisades, 411 East Clinton, Tenafly, New Jersey 07670.

title: By Design; A Little Light Warmth
description: With all those sleeveless shifts and tank tops in fall collections leaving the arms exposed to cold, it was time for a revival of the albreviated coverup known as a shrug. Designers have responded enthusiastically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONAHUE, GEORGE R.
description: DONAHUE-George R. On September 27, 1998. Devoted husband of the late Margaret M. (nee McGarry). Beloved father of George M. and Carmen, John Colson and Anne, Anne Marie and Charles Murnin, Elizabeth M. and Edward Holst, and the late Mary Jane Donahue. Loving grandfather of Jennifer, Sarah, Michael, John, Eddie, Mary, Katherine and Sean. Dear great grandfather of Matthew and James. Funeral Wednesday, 9:00 AM from The McManus Funeral Home, 2001 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial 9:45 AM, St. Thomas Aquinas Church. Interment St. Charles' Cemetery. In Memoriams to Brooklyn Catholic Charities, 191 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201, would be appreciated. Visiting hours Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABORN, NORMAN
description: ABORN-Norman. The Directors and Staff of the Tanenbaum Center for Interreligious Understanding extend heartfelt sympathy to our esteemed Board Member, Richard Aborn, and his family upon the death of his father, Norman. Georgette F. Bennett, Ph.D President

title: Gonzalez Shuns Any Talk About the 1996 Playoffs
description: Juan Gonzalez did not want to discuss recent history. In the 1996 American League Division Series, he hit five home runs and helped the Texas Rangers scare a Yankee team that went on to win the World Series. But to Gonzalez, those four games are memories.

title: Encore for a Memorable Season
description: NEW YORK -- 114-48, A.L. East champion

title: DuPont Unit to Cut Jobs
description: DuPont Photomasks Inc., a maker of computer-chip templates, said today that it would dismiss 3 percent of its work force, or 40 people, and temporarily trim the salaries of top executives by 15 percent because of slowing demand for semiconductors. DuPont Photomasks, which is majority-owned by DuPont, has already consolidated its suppliers, cut overtime and delayed construction of a plant in Gresham, Ore., to reduce costs.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If voters were home runs, California would be Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa put together. But the current primary process treats us like we can't hit our weight.''

title: Skip Away Steps Briskly Toward the Gold Cup
description: Nine days after his sweeping score in the Woodward Stakes for his ninth straight victory, Skip Away went back to work yesterday morning and was up to his old tricks. He breezed half a mile at Belmont Park in a snappy 46 3/5 seconds in his first workout for his next performance, in the Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: Worldwide Rebound Seen in Chip Sales
description: Worldwide sales of computer chips are expected to rise 12 percent in 1999, rebounding from a decline of 6 percent this year, according to a market research group.

title: Amateur Lawyers' Poor Record; History Is Discouraging for Suspect in a Capital Case
description: The murder trial of James Allen Gordon just under way in a third-floor courtroom in Queens looks much like any other criminal case. Two court-appointed lawyers, Chris Renfroe and Russell Morea, interrogate a parade of potential jurors. The defendant, unshackled each morning as he is brought into the courtroom, sits quietly off to one side, occasionally scribbling notes on a yellow legal pad.

title: Garnes Out for Giants' Tough Test in Tampa
description: It was an efficient victory in San Diego, one that made the Giants feel self-assured. But injuries and the formidable nature of their next assignment have impinged on the sense of conquest.

title: Compact Disk Pictures Offered By Kodak and Intel Partnership
description: In the first tangible result of a marketing partnership they announced in April, the Eastman Kodak Company and the Intel Corporation yesterday introduced a compact disk for pictures.

title: People
description: * Richard Monturo, senior vice president and strategic planner at Lowe & Partners/SMS, New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was promoted to executive vice president and strategic planning director. He succeeds Stephani Cook, who becomes a consultant to the agency.

title: Westchester Legislature Rejects a Tax-Free Week
description: The Westchester County Legislature voted tonight against participating in the state's next tax-free shopping week, scheduled for January, concluding that although it would help the county's merchants, it would do so at the cost of a property tax increase for homeowners.

title: Technology Puts DNA to Work to Fight Disease-Causing Genes
description: OF all the emerging technologies in the biotech firmament, few have been so controversial as antisense, in which small snippets of DNA can serve as drugs by blocking the action of specific genes. With the Food and Drug Administration's approval last month of the world's first antisense drug, this technology took a big step forward in critical acceptance and therapeutic significance.

title: F.C.C. Blocks Two Bells On Long-Distance Entry
description: There are two basic sets of telecommunications regulations in the United States: one that applies to the local Bell phone companies, and another that applies to everyone else.

title: Yankees Start Over After Record Season
description: Their 114 victories gave the Yankees an American League record, but no guarantees in baseball's post-season, which begins tonight with the Yankees playing host to Texas, Boston at Cleveland and Houston playing host to San Diego. Tomorrow night Atlanta will face the Chicago Cubs, who defeated the San Francisco Giants last night, 5-3, in the one-game wild-card playoff that ended an exhilarating regular season. Sammy Sosa, given one extra game to add to his home run total, hit two singles and finished with 66 homers, 4 behind Mark McGwire.

title: Hellzapoppin' With Dante And Friends
description: The burly performer, isolated by a hot spotlight, sits hunched over a watermelon. He lodges it between his legs and devours it ravenously. ''I was Count Ugolino,'' he says, casting his eyes over his meal. ''This was Archbishop Ruggieri.''

title: Report on Effort to Aid Poor Fathers Offers Discouraging News
description: As the age of limited benefits descends on welfare families, policymakers have shown a keen new interest in absent fathers, especially the undereducated, underemployed, often streetwise men, who go months, if not years, without seeing their children.

title: AIDS Laws Reflect Gap in Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES, Sunnyvale, Calif., a supplier of integrated circuits for computer and communications markets, named Randy Burdick to the new position of chief information officer. He will oversee the company's information technology and business systems organizations.

title: Two Wars at Once?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ewing Pessimistic On Labor Talks
description: Patrick Ewing of the Knicks said yesterday that there was no progress between the owners and players toward ending their labor dispute, which enhanced the possibility of a regular-season work stoppage.

title: AMP Steps Up Efforts to Fend Off Allied Signal Takeover
description: Fighting a hostile takeover bid of $44.50 a share from Allied Signal Inc., AMP Inc. announced a plan yesterday to buy back as many as 30 million shares of its common stock for $55 a share.

title: Mayor Calls Bronx Stadium Plan a Rerun
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani scoffed yesterday at a proposal by the Bronx Borough President to renovate Yankee Stadium, calling it a ''warmed over'' version of a plan drawn up for the city four years ago.

title: Iraq Says It Won't Let U.N. Resume Spot Arms Checks
description: Iraq will not withdraw its ban on spot arms inspections, Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz said today after a meeting with Secretary General Kofi Annan.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Arrow to Close Plant
description: Arrow Automotive Industries said today that it would close its Spartanburg plant on Nov. 27 and cut 423 jobs. The company, a remanufacturer of auto parts, said the decision followed unsuccessful efforts to sell the business. Arrow said it would continue to seek a buyer for the property. Last week, the company agreed to sell certain assets, including its electrical parts division and its clutch and crankshaft remanufacturing division, for an undisclosed amount to a rival, Motorcar Parts and Accessories Inc.

title: Investors Fear Trouble at Another Hedge Fund
description: A consortium of big Wall Street banks completed a huge-scale rescue package for Long-Term Capital Management last night, but investors' anxiety rose about a second hedge fund in possible trouble because of bad bets in turbulent markets.

title: Agency Says Two Computer Stores Cheated Customers
description: Two electronics stores in New York City have repeatedly bilked customers by passing off used computers as new ones, misrepresenting products in advertising and sales pitches and attracting customers through bait-and-switch tactics, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; One Night To Celebrate The Cubs
description: HALF past three yesterday afternoon, they pulled up the gates at the intersection of Clark and Addison and rolled out the old kiosks from which the Wrigley Field programs are hawked at a modern-day miracle price of 75 cents. There was one last ball game in a remarkable baseball season, and no team was more entitled to this prime-time slot than the Cubs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, ROBERT LEE
description: GILL-Robert Lee. Age 87, died on Thursday, September 24, 1998, in New York City, from complications of a stroke. Survivors include his wife, Melanie Gill, and from his first marriage, a son, Peter T. Gill of Bronxville, NY, and a stepson, John D. Chapman of Fort Pierce, Fla., and two sisters, Barbara Betts of West Hampton Beach, NY, and Mary Roby of Rochester, NY; grandchildren, Caroline and Elizabeth Gill, John, David and Steven Chapman, and seven step great-grandchildren. Born in South Orange, NJ, October 10, 1911. Married Caroline Townsend Chapman in 1939, who died in 1984. Member of the New York Stock Exchange for over 40 years. Past president of the NYSE Luncheon Club, member of the NY Racquet and Tennis Club. Distinguished and well-known collector of fine American art and antiques. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum, DE. 19735. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Tuesday, September 29th, at 4:30 P.M.

title: U.S. Asks British to Deliver Suspected Bin Laden Aide
description: A British court ordered a suspect held yesterday pending extradition to the United States as part of the broadening investigation into Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile who is being investigated in connection with the embassy bombings last month in Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILBANE, PAUL L.
description: KILBANE-Paul L. Holland Lodge #

title: The Rustle of Mideast Diplomacy
description: After more than a year of slumber, the Middle East peace effort is stirring. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, are talking with one another again, and yesterday President Clinton invited them to Washington next month for intensive talks to complete a long-stalled round of negotiations with his assistance. With time rapidly running out on the negotiating clock established under the Oslo accords, the two sides can afford no further delay.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINS, ARCHIE
description: WILKINS-Archie. We are so saddened by the recent death of Archie Wilkins, most loved father of our dear friends, Fern and Lowell Kwiat & Laurie and Stuart Wilkins. We will never forget that twinkle in his eye, his incredible generosity, and his neverending sense of humor. We know that his gentle spirit & love of life will be a legacy to his children and grandchildren. We send our most sincere condolences and love to Iris and the rest of this special family. Susan, Steven, Logan and Cameron Levkoff

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GAIN IN COFFEE. Coffee rose on worries that flooding from Hurricane Georges could ruin beans in New Orleans, where coffee for contracts traded in New York is stored. December coffee rose 3.7 cents, to $1.0835 a pound.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Sibling Rivalry, Social and Literary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, BERNARD
description: SIEGFRIED-Bernard. On September 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Robert and Jonathan. Dear grandfather of Amanda, David, Jeremy, Matthew and Rachel. Services at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th Street, Thursday, October 1, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers a contribution in his memory to a heart or cancer association of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Caesarean Births
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 in Holdup Suspected In Earlier Robberies
description: A trio of young men involved in the robbery of a T.G.I. Friday's restaurant early Friday morning may have committed a recent series of armed holdups in Monmouth, Ocean and Burlington counties, prosecutors said yesterday. One of the men apparently took his own life during a chase by two police officers after the Friday robbery.

title: Corrections
description: The Pop Life column on Thursday, about the shared musical interests of President Clinton and Monica S. Lewinsky, misidentified a song to which Ms. Lewinsky alluded in a computer message to the President. (Ms. Lewinsky referred to it in her message as ''song No. 5.'') It is Sarah McLachlan's ''Do What You Have to Do''; ''Surfacing'' is the McLachlan CD on which the song appears.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANGAN, JOSEPH F.
description: MANGAN-Joseph F. (President of Truck Drivers Local #

title: The Business of Persuasion Thrives in Nation's Capital
description: ''I haven't thought about Monica Lewinsky all day,'' mused Wright Andrews, a Washington lobbyist.

title: It's Not Easy, but the Cubs Find Their Way Into the Post-Season
description: Sammy Sosa did not hit four home runs to share the record with Mark McGwire. Steve Trachsel did not pitch a no-hitter. But the Chicago Cubs did gain a chance to win their first post-season series since 1908.

title: Hasbro to Buy Galoob Toys
description: Hasbro Inc., the nation's second-largest toy maker, said today that it would buy the struggling Galoob Toys Inc. for $220 million in cash, or $12 a share, giving it control of all ''Star Wars'' toys licenses just months before the new movie trilogy will be released.

title: Minoru Niizuma, 67, Sculptor and Teacher
description: Minoru Niizuma, a sculptor and educator who taught at the Brooklyn Museum Art School and Columbia University, died on Sept. 5 at the University Hospital and Medical Center of Stony Brook on Long Island. He was 67 and lived in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: How Thwarting One Evil Can Summon Up Another
description: Sometimes there is nowhere to go: for the sake of escaping the perils of the opponent's middlegame attack, you rush to get the queens off and into an ending. That's standard strategy -- reduce the enemy's firepower -- and it cannot be faulted. But every once in a while, the ending turns out to be thornier than you had bargained for. That's what happened in a fourth-round game between the Manhattan grandmaster Nick DeFirmian and Emanuel Berg of Sweden in the Stockholm International Tournament in August.

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article yesterday about the German election misstated the number of years between Hitler's defeat and the return of the German capital to Berlin next year. It is 54, not 44.

title: Hyde Bows to Democrats on Some Inquiry Issues
description: The Republican chairman of the House Judiciary Committee acceded to an array of Democratic demands today, saying he wanted to eliminate contentious side issues and keep his committee focused on whether President Clinton should be impeached.

title: BEA SYSTEMS TO BUY WEBLOGIC FOR $192.5 MILLION IN STOCK
description: BEA Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Weblogic Inc. for $192.5 million in stock, based on Friday's closing price, giving the corporate software maker Weblogic's Internet technology to add to its product line. BEA will issue 7.7 million shares to buy the San Francisco-based company. BEA, based in San Jose, Calif., said it would include Weblogic's software in its own products, which let companies process such transactions as airline reservations over different types of computers in a network. Weblogic's Internet technology will let BEA's customers also handle transactions over the Web, the companies said.

title: Giving Out Millions While Losing Billions
description: THERE are bad weeks, and then there are really bad weeks. Take the case of Julian H. Robertson Jr., the chairman of Tiger Management, the world's biggest hedge fund. On Sept. 15, Lincoln Center officials announced that Mr. Robertson had given the center $25 million -- the same day that Mr. Robertson's fund announced August losses of $600 million.

title: To Actresses, Greek Tragedy Offers Many Happy Endings
description: Pat Carroll was attracted to the role of the Chorus of Mycenae in Sophocles' ''Electra'' because of its spareness, its necessity, its raw and relentless candor. ''There is no subtext,'' Ms. Carroll said. ''What is said is what is meant.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKMAN, LUCILLE
description: GLUCKMAN - Lucille. Beloved wife of Sol, devoted mother of Barrie Miller and Miles Gluckman. Cherished grandmother of Lloyd & Rona Miller. Services Thursday, 1:30 PM at ''Riverside NassauNorth'', Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Elder Care Is Inadequate
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTERPRISE FEDERAL STOCK SOARS ON MERGER AGREEMENT
description: The stock of Enterprise Federal Bancorp rose 37 percent yesterday after it had agreed to be bought by Fifth Third Bancorp for $92.8 million. Enterprise, parent of Enterprise Federal Savings Bank, jumped $10.50 a share, to $39.25, after its agreement to be acquired by Fifth Third, Ohio's third-largest bank by deposits, was announced late on Friday. The shares of Fifth Third fell $2.375 each, to $61.25. Shareholders of Enterprise, which is based in West Chester, Ohio, will receive 0.68516 share of Fifth Third common stock for each Enterprise share. Cincinnati-based Fifth Third, has $29 billion in assets.

title: Tiny New Chip Could Pit Protection of Property Against Right of Privacy
description: TOM ROWLEY seems uncomfortable in the role of braggart. A sheepish look comes over his face when he tells you, ''We're going to change the way people live.''

title: Possible Reprieve At Philippine Air
description: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines said today that Government mediators had negotiated an agreement to resume operations at Philippine Airlines, but it was not clear whether the plan had sufficient support from union members.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AMP Buying Shares to Stop Takeover by Allied Signal

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Jay Remembers When

title: Good Maternal Behavior Is Linked to the Genes of a Father
description: HOW do mother mice know how to look after their babies when there is no one to tell them what to do? By instinct, meaning that their maternal behavior is in some way programmed into their genes.

title: Baseball Steals The Show
description: National Football League overnight ratings fell Sunday, victimized most likely by viewer interest in the final day of the baseball season. The games on Fox and CBS combined for 31.6 Nielsen rating points, down from 35.0 last year.

title: AIDS Laws Reflect Gap in Knowledge
description: To the Editor:

title: Cub Fans Savor Decisive Game
description: Before the game, the old and the young were in old Weeghman Park, all giddy with anticipation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: RUBIN'S REMARKS HELP YEN. Japan's currency rose after Robert E. Rubin, the United States Treasury Secretary, said the United States was concerned about its weakness. The dollar fell to 135.85 yen in New York from 136.25.

title: Vacco Questions Rival's Honesty on Finances
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco's re-election campaign sought yesterday to put his Democratic challenger, Eliot L. Spitzer, on the defensive about finances, saying Mr. Spitzer had failed to explain how he was paying for his campaign.

title: MetroStars May Have The Edge
description: MetroStars (15-17) vs. Columbus (15-17): This is the closest matchup of the four series in the M.L.S. playoffs, which will start tomorrow and end with the championship game on Oct. 25 in the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. Along with identical records, the teams had awful finishes in the regular season going into the two-of-three-game series.

title: Dissidents Delicately Democratize
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Judge Refuses to Quit Lawsuit Against Mobster
description: Rejecting a challenge to his impartiality, a Federal judge has declined to disqualify himself from a case in which Salvatore Gravano, the mobster turned Government witness, is being sued by relatives of several of his murder victims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENSTEIN, IRVING
description: BORENSTEIN-Irving. Our deepest sympathy to Thelma and the entire family on the loss of a true gentleman. We've all lost a friend and devoted colleague. William A. Schwarz & Sons

title: But Does Oscar Like It?
description: Instead of being brought to you by the letter K or the number 3, starting soon ''Sesame Street'' will be brought to you by Discovery Zone indoor playgrounds.

title: Going From Hero to Heroine
description: The new patient at Watertown State Hospital really doesn't want to be given a bath. As everyone soon realizes, that's because the patient, Private Albert D. J. Cashier, a Civil War hero now in his 60's, is really a woman. Oh, Cashier (Mikel Sarah Lambert) fought with the 95th Illinois Infantry, all right; he-she has been living as a man since adolescence.

title: Taliban's Man in Queens Wants the U.N. to Listen
description: Somebody from the delegation with the sign that says ''Afghanistan'' made a speech in the General Assembly today. But he wasn't a representative of the people who run the country.

title: Working to Prevent the Rain on Her Parade
description: ''PART of the reason the parade can continue is I live in a place where we have the facilities to build giant puppets,'' Jeanne Fleming, the director of the Greenwich Village Halloween Parade, is saying. ''A big estate, near Rhinebeck. You've got to come up to this place. It's a magical place.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANNISTER, ELIZABETH HOUSTON
description: BANNISTER-Elizabeth Houston. 79, passed president of Bellevue Hospital Auxiliary, died September 26, 1998 after a brief illness. Wife of the late Walter Scholl and the late Lemuel Bannister, Jr., beloved sister of William Houston and beloved mother of Thomas Bishop, Jr., and five Scholl children, Anthony, Peter, Nicholas, Jaye, and Alexandra. Memorial service at 11:30 AM, Saturday, October 3rd, St. Luke's, Darien, CT. Contributions may be made to Bellevue or Notre Dame Convalescent Center, 76 W. Rocks Road, Norwalk, CT 06851.

title: Airport Rail Link's Cost Increases to $415 Million
description: The cost of a link between New Jersey Transit tracks and the monorail system at Newark International Airport has increased 66 percent, to $415 million, with the addition of a baggage handling system and the conversion of a transfer station into a gateway to the airport, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKOW, MONROE
description: LAKOW-Monroe. October 18, 1899-September 26, 1998. Survived by his wife Ruth Cedar Lakow, his daughter Ellen Lakow Georgiou and granddaughter Alexis. Services were held September 28th, Gramercy Park Chapel.

title: For Pakistan And India, Atom Pact Is Hard Sell
description: For the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan to follow through on their stated willingness to sign the nuclear test-ban treaty, both men will need to convince their restive publics that they got something substantial in return.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, JEFF
description: MOSS-Jeff. The entire Browning School community mourns the loss of Jeff Moss, class of '59 alumnus trustee and friend. He was always the star performer at our school assemblies. ''Rubber Ducky, you're the one.'' Stephen M. Clement, III Headmaster Allan L. Gropper President, Board of Trustees Tricia S. Langton President, Parents Association

title: Playing Roulette With the Global Economy
description: Derivatives, those risky financial contracts that rocked the markets with billion-dollar losses in the mid-1990's, are coming back to haunt us. And the sequel may be far more terrifying for the average investor.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'To Have and to Hold'

title: With 7 R.B.I., Vaughn Lets Bat Do the Exorcising for Red Sox
description: The talk was of curses and ghosts and failures, of Babe Ruth and Bill Buckner, of 0 for 14 and 13 consecutive losses. All the Boston Red Sox heard about was doom as they prepared for their American League division series with the Cleveland Indians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGIONE, GIOVANNI
description: FORGIONE-Giovanni. On September 28, 1998. We will meet you on the hilltop in Frigento always. Joan, Barrie, Marie-Teresa, Angelina and family

title: The Impeachment Picture
description: The decisions by the House Judiciary Committee chairman, Henry Hyde, to insure greater fairness and openness in the examination of evidence in the Monica Lewinsky affair are sound on the merits. But they have a larger importance as encouraging signs that the debate over President Clinton's future can be kept moving toward some reasonably prompt resolution. Time magazine found that 35 percent of its polling sample wanted Mr. Clinton out of office, 29 percent favored censure and 34 percent favored no punishment. You do not need a poll, however, to sense that citizens do not want this to drag out indefinitely. Barring the emergence of explosive new evidence, there is no reason that it should.

title: Grubbing For Grades
description: First report cards for network television this season: some solid grades for new series, a lot of gentleman's C's, a few perilous scores that could point to early failure, but mainly more lessons for every network in the new competitive field of six networks plus cable, which leaves them hard pressed to find an A.

title: A New Form of Lobbying Puts Public Face on Private Interest
description: From the nondescript headquarters of his Houston construction firm, Leo E. Linbeck Jr., a lanky, bow-tied executive with a drawl, is masterminding a crusade to overturn the nation's tax system.

title: Tom Bradley, Mayor in Era Of Los Angeles Growth, Dies
description: Tom Bradley, the sharecropper's son who became Mayor of Los Angeles and presided over the city for two decades of explosive growth and change, died yesterday at the Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in West Los Angeles. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORGIONE, JOHN L.
description: FORGIONE-John L. On Sept. 28, 1998, at age 75, of Astoria, Queens, after a courageous battle with cancer. Accomplished painter, sculptor, film maker, photographer & swimmer. John will always be known for his generous nature, vigorous life style, and someone that ''spoke his mind.'' As a graduate of The Maryland Institute of Fine Arts, and a lifetime member of The Art Students League of New York, John shared his joy of art with many people including his loving brother and four sisters and friends. His paintings and sculptures were drawn and sculpted in New York and throughout Italy. In addition to his immediate family, he leaves behind a large number of aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, and cousins. His spirit will always be with us. Reposing at The Moore Funeral Home, 54 West Jamaica Avenue, Valley Stream, New York. Visitation Thursday from 3-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial offered Friday, October 2, 1998 at 11 A.M. at Holy Name of Mary R.C. Church, Valley Stream, New York. Interment to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Details in Killings by Officer

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
