description: Fed Lowers Interest Rates To Ease Effects of Turmoil

title: Let Yanks Stay, Many Fans Say
description: Some Yankee fans are already looking past this season's performance to reflect on whether the team should play in the Bronx, in Manhattan or in New Jersey.

title: Government By Automatic Pilot
description: Puritans usually wreak more havoc than sinners. Cromwell did far more damage than any English king. Reformers did more harm to American cities earlier in this century than the supposedly corrupt political bosses did. And the postal system based on patronage worked better than the one that allegedly runs on ''merit.''

title: Computers Help Math Learning, Study Finds
description: The first large-scale examination of how computers affect the learning of mathematics in American classrooms found that when used selectively by trained teachers in middle schools they can significantly enhance academic performance.

title: King Is Sued Over a Fighter's Contract
description: Cedric Kushner has filed a lawsuit against Don King, alleging that King interfered with Kushner's contract with the heavyweight title contender Hasim Rahman and coerced Rahman to pull out of a scheduled bout against David Tua last week by having Rahman fake a hand injury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCKMAN, LUCILLE
description: GLUCKMAN - Lucille. Beloved wife of Sol, devoted mother of Barrie Miller and Miles Gluckman. Cherished grandmother of Lloyd & Rona Miller. Services Thursday, 10AM at ''Riverside NassauNorth'', Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York.

title: Woman Sues Over Lab Test That Prompted Abortion
description: A woman who had an abortion after a test showed that her female fetus had a serious disease and would not survive infancy is suing Lenox Hill Hospital and a laboratory over the diagnosis, saying an autopsy found the fetus was male and perfectly normal.

title: Starting All Over, With Mom
description: In one of the most backward-looking, unpromising of mini-trends, television producers seem determined to prove that you can, too, go home again. WB's dismissable new drama, ''Hyperion Bay,'' sends a computer whiz and businessman back to his hometown in the Northwest. NBC has shipped Nathan Lane back to the family vineyard in ''Encore! Encore!'' and plans a midseason replacement called ''Providence,'' named after the hometown that lures a cosmetic surgeon back from Beverly Hills. And tonight there is CBS's pleasantly watchable but uninspired ''Maggie Winters,'' in which Faith Ford trades in her ditsy but likable Corky Sherwood character from ''Murphy Brown'' for the role of a floundering woman in her 30's fresh out of a bad marriage. Apparently never having held a job (how quaint!), Maggie returns to her small Indiana hometown to live with her mother and start over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ELAINE BENSON
description: KAUFMAN-Elaine Benson. Of Bridgehampton, NY, on September 28, 1998. Beloved sister of Steven Klebanoff. A life of fulfillment long to be remembered by his family, Joy, Peter, Jennifer, and William Lerner.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TUBY, DR. ROBERT
description: TUBY-Dr. Robert. Our wonderful husband and daddy, loved, adored, respected and missed terribly. All our love forever, Evelyn, Joan, and Family

title: Oprah Winfrey Calls Off Lewinsky Interview Talks
description: Negotiations over the rights to Monica S. Lewinsky's account of her relationship with President Clinton took an unusual turn yesterday when Oprah Winfrey, the talk show host, announced on television and in a press release that she would not pursue an interview with Ms. Lewinsky.

title: Revelry Onstage and Off at the Met
description: Opening night at the Metropolitan Opera is one of those times in the performing arts when the audience commands as much attention as the event being witnessed onstage. With the house bulging with gowned and tuxedoed patrons and with a banquet awaiting some of them on the upper levels, the Met made a shrewd choice of repertory on Monday night.

title: The Most Reliable Dinner Mate: German Riesling
description: THE Burg Landshut, a ruined castle high above medieval Bernkastel, the best known of the Mosel wine towns of Germany, offers one of the most spectacular views of vines in Europe. The vineyards sweep southward toward Brauneberg and west past Graach and Wehlen to Zeltigen, all of them legendary German wine villages, too. The view is never more stunning than a few weeks from now when summer is truly past, the leaves are turning and the river's steep banks are carpeted a bright yellow gold.

title: Wells Gives Yankees A Victory in Game 1
description: The Yankees, behind eight dominating innings by pitcher David Wells, began the playoffs with a 2-0 victory over Texas in the first game of the division series. Game 2 is tonight at Yankee Stadium.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RISES ON REPORT OF G-7 PLAN. -- Japan's currency gained after Kyodo News said the Group of Seven nations would agree on ways to strengthen the yen at a meeting this weekend. The dollar fell to 134.45 yen, from 135.85.

title: QUARTERLY DIVIDENDS TO GIVE WAY TO ANNUAL PAYMENTS
description: The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that its board had decided to pay dividends to shareholders on an annual basis instead of quarterly, beginning next year, as a way to cut costs. Disney also said that because a large number of its investors own 10 or fewer shares, the company was spending more on processing and postage than the actual dividend payments to those stockholders were worth. Disney will make the annual payments in November of each year. The company, which is based in Burbank, Calif., has been looking for ways to cut costs and recently warned that its fourth-quarter profit would fall because of reduced demand for some of its products in Asia and weakness in its film business. The shares fell 25 cents, to $26.

title: Like Old Times for Terreri
description: The Devils tried with little success to find the ideal backup to goaltender Martin Brodeur after they traded Chris Terreri three years ago. But after three seasons of searching, they realized that Terreri was their man.

title: Big, Brash and Bent on Change; Chief of Local Sees Corruption in City Workers' Union
description: First, he said, came the threat to break his legs. Next came the telephoned death threats.

title: F.D.A. Issues Warning on a 60's Health Food, Alfalfa Sprouts
description: PEOPLE with weakened or developing immune systems -- those for whom food-borne diseases pose a severe health risk -- now have something else to worry about. And it is something normally billed as a health food: alfalfa sprouts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, ARLYNE
description: STEINER-Arlyne. A beautiful, brave, noble woman passed our way. We are all richer for her being. Gloria, Sidney and Family

title: Treading a Path of Self-Inflicted Ruin
description: THE STILLEST DAY

title: Indonesia in Warning To Its Troubled Banks
description: Indonesia said yesterday that it would take over all banks that cannot meet new capital standards within 30 days as part of its latest move to fix the country's crippled banking industry. The threat ratchets up pressure on Indonesia's more than 200 banks, most of which are buried under a flood of bad loans caused by the currency's 70 percent collapse against the dollar in a year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENSON, ALBERT
description: LEVENSON-Albert. On September 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Geneva M. (nee Taylor). Loving father of Patricia. Funeral service will be Thursday 10 A.M., at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC.

title: People
description: Tom Quarton was named to the new position of president for the Western region of Landor Associates and managing director of the San Francisco office. In the San Francisco post, he succeeds Craig Branigan, now regional president for Landor Europe and managing director of the London office. Mr. Quarton had been president and chief operating officer at the Cirque Corp., Salt Lake City. Landor is part of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: In Dominican Republic, Sun Dries Much, but Not All Tears
description: A week of bright sunshine and clear skies has done wonders for the Dominican Republic.

title: New Peace Diplomacy Gets Mostly Shrugs in Israel
description: In a land where skepticism is a national sport, there were neither hallelujahs nor boos today following President Clinton's intervention in the stalemated peace talks between the Israelis and the Palestinians -- an indication that few believed there had been a diplomatic breakthrough worth celebrating or condemning.

title: Brown Strikes Out 16 and Outduels Johnson
description: All the attention, all the focus, all the hype before the game belonged to Randy Johnson. But that all changed when Kevin Brown pitched a Randy Johnson-type game today, striking out 16 Houston batters in a 2-1 victory for San Diego. And now Johnson's Astros are down one game to none in their National League division series with Brown's Padres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, IRVING
description: MANN-Irving. To our dear friends Meryl and Michael and their children Betsy and Adam, we extend our most heartfelt sympathy on the loss of your beloved father and grandfather. May the strength of your love for him be a source of comfort to you all. Diane, Frank, Danni and Ricki Lederman

title: A Three-Star Peasant Dish
description: CHICKEN with vinegar is one of the great poultry dishes from the area around Lyons, France, where the chickens are considered by many to be the best in the world. The story is that the dish was first popularized at La Mere Brazier, one of the Lyons restaurants known as ''les bonnes meres.''

title: On Eve of Playoffs, Color Campos Gone
description: On the day before the Major League Soccer playoffs were to begin, conversation around the league was dominated by a departure and an arrival: the departure of Chicago's Jorge Campos yesterday for his native Mexico and the recent arrival of Bora Milutinovic to coach the MetroStars.

title: Aides to Clinton Step Back From an Ally's Plans for 'War' Against Gingrich
description: Trying to reassure Congressional Democrats that President Clinton feels more contrite than belligerent about his affair, the White House distanced him today from a declaration of ''war'' on Speaker Newt Gingrich by James Carville, the President's longtime political lieutenant.

title: Amtrak Unveils $185 Million Plan for Faster Service Upstate
description: Amtrak officials and Gov. George E. Pataki announced a five-year plan yesterday to upgrade the tracks between New York City and Albany and rebuild trains used on the route to shave at least 20 minutes off the trip, allowing riders to cover the distance in less than two hours.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE LOWERS KEY RATE BY QUARTER-POINT
description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point today in an attempt to keep the financial turmoil afflicting much of the world from derailing the domestic economy.

title: Dimac Is Merging Four Units Into One
description: The Dimac Corporation has consolidated its four direct-response operations and spun them off into a single agency named DMW Worldwide.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Ex-Clinton Aide Is Stalked Again

title: Why Save Risky Hedge Fund?
description: To the Editor:

title: Before Death, Officer's Wife May Have Told Police of His Abuse
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Glimpses of a Secret World
description: The dances that Nadine Helstroffer presented on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio seldom hurried, and their choreographic tone was never insistent. These were introspective little pieces, and there were moments when Ms. Helstroffer appeared to be lost in a private world totally closed to her audience. Yet if one watched intently, these meticulously detailed works did give up some of their secrets.

title: Student Says Catholic College Censored Her Published Poem
description: Iona College, a small Roman Catholic school in New Rochelle, N.Y., is caught up in a swirl of controversy for distributing a censored version of the student literary magazine that had been suppressed four months earlier because it included expletives and sexually explicit langauge.

title: Medically Uninsured Still Cost Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill and Monica and Georges
description: After the wind and the seemingly endless deluge subsided, we stepped out of our houses yesterday to survey the hurricane damage -- flooded houses, torn-up shorelines, boats ripped from their moorings and set down among pines. As with Washington's current political scandal, we'd tracked the maelstrom from far off as it approached; it gradually crowded out everything else on television; it made us weary, edgy and anxious from anticipation. Then it engulfed us.

title: Clinton Presses Terrorism Issue in 2d Meeting With Arafat
description: President Clinton met today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and emphasized the work that the Palestinians need to do to combat terrorism as the Israelis withdraw from an additional 13 percent of the West Bank, senior American officials said.

title: Doctors Praise New Methadone Effort
description: Doctors and other addiction specialists yesterday generally welcomed the Federal Government's plan to make methadone more accessible, saying the drug has proved effective in reducing dependence on heroin.

title: O'Neill's Gamut at the Plate: Perfection or Rage
description: Jose Cardenal tries not to laugh, and he turns away if he can't help himself, his body shaking. Cardenal, the Yankees' first-base coach, not only hears Paul O'Neill's self-indictments after the All-Star right fielder makes an out, he also all but feels the heat from O'Neill's explosions.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Metropolitan Opera's $200 million endowment campaign misidentified an earlier donor. She was Martha Baird Rockefeller, the second wife of John D. Rockefeller Jr., not his first wife, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RHINELANDER, PHYLLIS M.
description: RHINELANDER-Phyllis M. On September 27, 1998. Memorial service will be held Saturday, October 3, 11 A.M. at Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88 St, NYC.

title: Braves Enter Playoffs Healthy and Cautious
description: For the Atlanta Braves, everything appears to be in order.

title: Hedge Fund Debacle Offers A View of a Secret World
description: The near-collapse of Long-Term Capital Management has provided a rare chance to pull back the curtain on John W. Meriwether's cloistered financial brain trust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REDWOOD, BRUCE
description: REDWOOD-Bruce, 49, September 24, 1998. Born and raised NYC. Cols, OH resident since 1985. Beloved husband of Carolyn; son of Claude & Rita; brother of Claudia; & uncle of Ilyse & Meryl. Former executive of Chase Manhattan Bank, NY; co-owner Redwood Travel, Cols, OH. Graduate Villanova and St. John's Universities.

title: Gulf Coast Feeling Lucky Hurricane Wasn't Worse
description: Sometimes, Reola Jones said, a tree just knows which way to fall.

title: A Settlement Ends Strike By Stagehands At the Apollo
description: A strike that shut down the Apollo Theater in Harlem for five weeks ended yesterday after management signed a one-year contract with the newly formed bargaining unit that represents the theater's stagehands.

title: New Evidence Said to Have No Bombshell
description: Republican investigators said today that grand jury evidence to be made public on Friday would bolster charges that the White House tried to cover up President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: 2 Shops Eliminated In Kellogg Review
description: The Kellogg Company has narrowed a review that may result in adding an agency to the roster of shops handling its American cereal account.

title: Editorial Observer; Post-Season Thoughts on McGwire's Pills
description: Mark McGwire's prodigious home-run production this year has been just the right tonic to resuscitate baseball as the national pastime and to divert a public weary of scandal and global crises. The sight of this gentle, earnest giant handling the pressure of the home-run chase with grace and humility has made an entire nation feel better about itself. But all the euphoria about his truly astounding accomplishment in hitting 70 home runs should not obscure the troubling questions raised by his use of the testosterone-boosting drug androstenedione (pronounced andro-STEEN-die-own).

title: Michael Jordan, Grand Central's New Player
description: THE hamburger is absurd.

title: A Basque Pepper Filled With an Earthy Crunch
description: IN Spain, the piquillo pepper is a hero of the Basque country. Roasted over a wood fire and skinned, it becomes a soft, sweetly piquant purse that's filled with garlicky cod puree or with a sardine paste. Mariano Aznar, the new chef at Solera Restaurant and a native of Barcelona, spins the piquillo in a new direction, stuffing it with a rabbit-pistachio mixture and painting the plate with a tangy vizcaina sauce.

title: Maris Set Standard
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Save Risky Hedge Fund?
description: To the Editor:

title: What the Well-Dressed Knight Wore Is Shining Anew
description: Past the dead buildings and the smart new town houses, past the sprawling Cleveland Clinic complex, in a court at the Cleveland Museum of Art, one of the city's most beloved attractions has come back to life.

title: Philip F. Cohen, 87, Founder Of Legal Publishing Company
description: Philip F. Cohen, the founder and former president of Oceana Publications Inc., a publishing house that specializes in international law, died on Aug. 29 at Dobbs Ferry Community Hospital in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 87 and lived in Dobbs Ferry.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 2.6 PERCENT. -- Prices lost most of Monday's gain, as Hurricane Georges missed storage warehouses and traders refocused on abundant supplies. The December contract fell 2.8 cents, to $1.0555 a pound.

title: Phyllis M. Rhinelander, 77, Kin of Mayors
description: Phyllis M. Rhinelander, a lineal descendant of two early mayors of New York City and of the Kip family, who gave their name to the Kips Bay region, died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77.

title: A Police Sergeant Is Accused Of Impersonating a Reporter
description: When Police Officer Joseph Locurto held a news conference in his lawyer's office this month to apologize for appearing in blackface at a Queens parade and to plead for the right to continue serving on the force, there was a mole among the reporters: a police sergeant investigating his case who sat among the journalists and took notes.

title: Jones Lawyers Press Case Despite Talk Of Settlement
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones asked a Federal appeals court in St. Paul today to reinstate her sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton because, they said, he lied under oath when he testified that he had not engaged in sexual relations with Monica S. Lewinsky.

title: When Cognac Sings Solo
description: THE name Le Peu means nothing to Cognac drinkers. Yet, most Cognac drinkers know it very well -- sort of.

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'The Secret Lives of Men'

title: Judge, Finding Coliseum Safe, Says Islanders Must Play in It
description: Ending at least for now a bitter battle between the Nassau County Executive and the New York Islanders, a state judge declared today that Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum was safe and that the Islanders must play all their scheduled home and exhibition games at the arena.

title: Metro Business; Union Camp Plans To Eliminate Jobs
description: The Union Camp Corporation of Wayne, N.J., a maker of paper, packaging, chemicals and wood products, said yesterday that it will eliminate 540 jobs in a reorganization it hopes will cut annual costs by $42 million.

title: Beethoven as Scapegoat in a Programming Debate
description: The New York Philharmonic's Beethoven Symphony cycle has become a peculiar kind of straw man.

title: Gonzalez, Who Hit Mightily in '96, Is Kept Silent
description: A slippery changeup got away from David Wells and sailed right into the sight line of Juan Gonzalez like a deer standing before a hunter. Gonzalez pulled the trigger, swung with might and fouled off the 2-2 pitch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, KAUFMAN, ELAINE
description: BENSON-KAUFMAN-Elaine, 74, Bridgehampton, NY of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, September 28, peacefully at home. Widow of Emanuel M. Benson and of Joseph F. X. Kaufman. Survived by children Bill (Betsy, Kenny) Goff, Ginny (Les) Green, Neal (Rene, Daniel, Teddy) Goff and Kimberly Goff; step-son Frank (Diane, Elizabeth) Kaufman; and brother Steven (Joy) Klebanoff. Kimberly Goff will continue to operate the Elaine Benson Gallery. A memorial service will be announced. Donations to Southampton Hospital in lieu of flowers.

title: Massacres by Serbian Forces in 3 Kosovo Villages
description: The bodies of 15 women, children and elderly members of the Deliaj clan lay slumped among the rocks and streams of the gorge below their village in Kosovo Province today, shot in the head at close range and in some cases mutilated, as they tried to escape advancing Serbian forces.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGFRIED, BERNARD
description: SIEGFRIED-Bernard. On September 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Robert and Jonathan. Dear grandfather of Amanda, David, Jeremy, Matthew and Rachel. Services at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th Street, Thursday, October 1, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers a contribution in his memory to a heart or cancer association of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKINS, ARCHIE
description: WILKINS-Archie. With great sympathy on the loss of your father and grandfather, to the Kwiat and Wilkin families. Karyn, Steve, Emily, Gabe and Julie Rotter

title: New TV Season in Review
description: 'Vengeance Unlimited'

title: Merrill Said to Consider Bond Unit Layoffs
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, which is considering layoffs because of the recent turbulence in financial markets, may cut as many as 15 percent, or about 350, of the more than 2,500 people it employs in its bond businesses, officials at the firm who declined to be identified said yesterday.

title: Team Finds Success in Simplicity
description: At halftime of the Giants game in San Diego on Sunday, some youngsters played a brief Pop Warner league football game. Before the snap of most plays, a young offensive player, jogging along in his set of cumbersome pads, would go in motion behind the line of scrimmage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHIN, EDWARD M.
description: CASHIN-Edward M. On September 29, 1998. Beloved brother of Sr. M. Genevieve, O.P. and Luke A. and the late William T. Loving uncle of Grace and Joseph. Reposing at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue (near Kimball Avenue), Yonkers. Visiting hours are on Wednesday and Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass Friday, 9:45 A.M. St. Barnabas Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: MGM to Record Loss in Quarter
description: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. said on Monday that it expected a significant third-quarter loss after it takes about $33 million in charges for movies that did not do well and for the cost of cutting jobs.

title: Chinese Dissidents Issue a Sharp Challenge to the Government
description: A small group of dissident intellectuals here has issued a sharp challenge to the Government, circulating two manifestoes on freedom and social justice that reject many hallowed tenets of the Communist Party.

title: Accident Site Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, JOAN
description: MURPHY-Joan (nee Drutman). On September 29, 1998. Beloved wife of Bob, devoted mother of Rachel Judith, dear sister of Amy Drutman, loving daughter of Mae & Jack Drutman. Good and loyal friend to many. Long time devotee of Camp Roosevelt. Services Thursday, 10:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: MODTECH BUYING SPI MANUFACTURING FOR $109 MILLION
description: Modtech Inc., a maker of modular school buildings, agreed yesterday to acquire SPI Manufacturing Inc., a designer of commercial and light industrial modular buildings, for about $109 million. Modtech will pay $8 million in cash and about 5 million common shares. Based on Modtech's closing price on Monday, the stock portion is worth $100.6 million. Modtech will also refinance about $32 million of SPI debt. SPI, a closely held company, had sales of about $80 million for the year ended March 31. Modtech, based in Perris, Calif., had sales of $134 million in 1997. Its shares fell $1.90625, to $18.21875.

title: Bell Atlantic Is Planning a Revamping
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation, the largest United States local phone company, said yesterday that it would create a new office of the chairman and reorganize its business units to adjust for rapid changes in the communications marketplace.

title: Cendant's Profit Becomes a Loss
description: The Cendant Corporation, a marketer and franchiser whose stock plunged after it disclosed accounting irregularities said yesterday that it lost $217.2 million last year, instead of earning net income of $55.5 million reported earlier, after restating its earnings.

title: THE CHEF
description: MY sister and her husband run an old-fashioned cider mill in Fly Creek, N.Y., just outside Cooperstown. The mill's 1889 press, powered by a thumping water wheel, makes a rich and delicious apple cider that has become a fixture on our fall table.

title: Giuliani Going South to Raise Funds for Party
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will leave this afternoon for Florida, where he will spend two days raising money for the Republican Party and meeting with local politicians, his spokeswoman said last night.

title: Gonzalez Center Stage
description: Perhaps people around Arlington, Tex., understood exactly how mighty Juan Gonzalez was before 1996. It took the Yankees and their televised division series against the Rangers in 1996 to help the rest of the nation open their eyes to the power Gonzalez possessed.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: France Worries as New German Leader Stresses Ties to Britain
description: Faced with the prospect of a German Chancellor who believes that his country's relations with London will be at least as important as its ties with Paris, France is filled with anxiety about being taken seriously enough by its powerful eastern neighbor.

title: When Lending Money Just Isn't Enough; Critics Seek a New Role for the I.M.F. As Recent Bailout Programs Fall Short
description: The world looks to the International Monetary Fund to stop financial crises. Yet its best efforts are failing. Even apart from the spectacular collapses in Asia last year and in Russia this year, there has been a ''boom in busts'' -- an explosion in the number of countries whose economies have been devastated by simultaneous runs on their currencies and banks.

title: Why Save Risky Hedge Fund?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cost of Rampant Mental Health Care Fraud Soars in Medicare
description: Federal officials said today that they were expelling 80 community mental health centers from Medicare after finding that the program to provide psychiatric services to the elderly was riddled with fraud.

title: A campaign promotes the funny, sort of Folgers-coffee-like skies of Delta Express airline.
description: HUMOR is not a common element in airline advertising. Maybe that is because so many travelers these days find nothing funny about flying. Nonetheless, Delta Air Lines is using humor as the central element in the first television campaign for its low-fare airline, Delta Express.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLL, ASHLEY ANN
description: NICHOLL-Ashley Ann (Nickii). Of NYC & Southampton, Long Island, formerly of Montclair, N.J., on Sept. 25th, 1998. Survived by her loving mother, Dale of NYC and Southampton, L.I.; brother Maynard C. III of NYC; grandmother Helen G. Kulik of NYC; father Maynard C. Jr. of Maryland; half brother J. Christopher of Canton, MI, & half sister Charring Carlson of Inverness, FL. Nickii attended the Chapin School in NYC, St. Mark's in Southborough, MA, and State University of New York at Albany. Private graveside services were held in the Southampton Cemetery, Southampton, NY on Sept. 29, 1998. Memorial services will be held at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at 55th Street and 5th Avenue (entrance on 55th Street) on October 3, 1998 at 2:00 PM. Memorial contributions in Ashley's name to Bide-A-Wee, 410 E. 38th St, NYC, NY 10006 or the animal rights league of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, JEFFREY
description: MOSS-Jeffrey. We are devastated by the loss of our friend, colleague and mentor Jeff Moss. For 30 years his creativity, talent and integrity have been at the heart of Sesame Street. We take comfort in knowing that his spirit, his characters, his silliness and his songs will continue to delight, educate and nurture millions of children around the world for generations to come. Long live Rubber Duckie! The Writers of Sesame Street

title: Why Save Risky Hedge Fund?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RAINES, BARBARA
description: RAINES-Barbara. In loving memory of my sister, Barbara on her 90th birthday. Mimi

title: THREE THERMO ELECTRON SUBSIDIARIES TO CUT JOBS
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation said yesterday that three of its units would cut at least 750 jobs in a revamping that is expected to produce savings of $30 million next year. As a result of the reorganization, the units will incur combined pretax charges of $53 million in the third quarter, which ends Saturday. Thermo Electron, of Waltham, Mass., operates a complex structure of businesses in various industries. It has annual sales of about $3.6 billion. The company's Thermo Instrument Systems unit will reduce its own work force and those of its seven subsidiaries by a combined 7 percent, or 750 to 800 jobs. The number of workers affected at the other two units, Thermotrex and Thermo Terratech, was not immediately available.

title: Foley Says He's Fit, And Ready To Play
description: Two weeks ago, Glenn Foley's chances of playing through his rib cartilage injury were ruined when Bill Parcells sneaked up behind him and squeezed. Foley tried to hide the pain, which he said nearly caused him to collapse, but he winced. That was enough to persuade Parcells to hand the ball to Vinny Testaverde.

title: Programs That Make Leadership Their Goal
description: Are leaders born or bred? Can students be taught how to set a course that others will follow?

title: Democratic Primary Winner Is Certified in Schumer's Old District
description: The Board of Elections certified City Councilman Anthony D. Weiner yesterday as the winner of the Sept. 15 Democratic primary for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Charles E. Schumer.

title: Sports of The Times; Bottom Puts Yanks On Top
description: DURING a Yankees batting practice over the weekend, Joe Torre glanced out at the scoreboard, which had third baseman Scott Brosius's name and statistics in lights.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Yeshiva Adds 2 Towers For Women in Midtown
description: Seeking to develop a midtown campus for its undergraduate women's colleges, Yeshiva University has acquired control of two attached office buildings at 205-215 Lexington Avenue between 32d and 33d Streets.

title: FOOD STUFF
description: Abbondanza in a Jar: Pasta Sauces With a Twist

title: MCI Will Cut Its Write-Off On Acquisition
description: MCI Worldcom Inc. plans to write off $3.1 billion of Worldcom's $37 billion purchase price of MCI Communications as research and development costs -- half of what the company estimated last month.

title: District Attorney Reviewing Medical Care at City's Jails
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has begun a preliminary investigation into possible problems with the medical care provided to more than a dozen inmates in city jails this year, including at least four who died, city officials with knowledge of the investigation said yesterday.

title: No Opinion On Clinton For Now, D'Amato Says
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato firmly removed himself from the thorny debate over President Clinton's future today, saying he would absolutely not take a position on impeachment and removal unless the issue came before the Senate -- which would not happen until well after the November elections, if ever.

title: RJR Nabisco Braces for Drop In Russian Sales
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the latest United States company to be buffeted by economic crisis from abroad, warned yesterday that ''depressed market conditions'' in Russia would reduce its third-quarter earnings well below earlier expectations.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We would rather be

title: Livent Says Suit by Drabinsky Adds to Woes of Shareholders
description: Livent Inc., the Broadway theater producer, is arguing in a Canadian court that a lawsuit filed by its founder threatens to prolong the pain of the company's shareholders who have been unable to trade their shares since early August because of an accounting investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLEN, LOUIS M.
description: COLEN-Louis M. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Adored father of Mitchell & Valerie, Barry, and Arthur. Cherished grandfather of Beth, Julia, Cynthia, Michelle, and David, and great-grandfather of Jennifer, Alyssa and Michael. Services on Thursday, 11:30 A.M., at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'', 312 Coney Island Avenue (at Prospect Park).

title: Journal; The Gasbag Gang
description: Everyone knows that something big happened, but what? ''It's as if a boil was lanced and the fever has broken,'' said Ed Markey, a Massachusetts Congressman, after the Bill Clinton grand jury video. Yes, the country's mood about-faced that Monday -- but why?

title: Corrections
description: The main front-page article Monday about the German election misstated the percentage of Germans who are unemployed. It is 10.6 percent of the workforce, not 10.6 percent of the population.

title: Fiamma Ferragamo, 57, Dies; Shoe Designer for the Elegant
description: Fiamma di San Giuliano Ferragamo, a designer who helped develop one of the most famous shoe labels in fashion, died on Monday at her home in Florence. She was 57. She died of cancer, said Ferrucio Ferragamo, her brother and chief executive officer of Salvatore Ferragamo Italia.

title: The Libido and Literature as Inspiration
description: Angela Jones presented a program of almost unbridled choreographic exuberance on Sunday night at the Joyce SoHo.

title: Most Borrowers in U.S. Can Expect to Benefit
description: The Federal Reserve's decision yesterday to lower interest rates for the first time since January 1996 should translate into lower borrowing rates on many consumer loans and keep mortgage rates for home purchases and refinancings below 7 percent at least through the end of the year, economists said.

title: Why Save Risky Hedge Fund?
description: To the Editor:

title: Joint Chiefs Tell Lawmakers Pet Projects Impair Defense
description: In a sharp exchange with senators, the Joint Chiefs of Staff said today that pet projects sought by Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and Congress's refusal to close unnecessary bases are weakening the nation's defense.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: Salt's Kosher Question

title: Blair Sheds a New Layer of Old Labor
description: Blackpool and the British Labor Party have been as compatible as fish and chips for years, but the delegates to this week's convention are having their last fling with the slatternly old resort.

title: It Is Third-and-Fun For Johnson's Dolphins
description: Jimmy Johnson replaced Tom Landry as head coach in Dallas.

title: Why Save Risky Hedge Fund?
description: To the Editor:

title: Expert for Microsoft Helps Fight One of Its Subpoenas
description: The software industry is a notoriously fast, fluid business, with today's friend becoming tomorrow's foe. So too, it seems, for the industry's most famous defendant, the Microsoft Corporation, in its pretrial preparations.

title: COLLEGES: NOTEBOOK
description: WISCONSIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMEE, ELIZABETH T.
description: McNAMEE-Elizabeth T. The entire NYU Law School Community mourns the sudden loss of a magnificent third year student and emerging young lawyer, Elizabeth. Our hearts and prayers go out to her family. Dean John Sexton NYU School of Law

title: Fed's Rate Cut Has Little Impact as Dow Falls by 28.32
description: The first interest rate cut since January 1996 failed to impress stock investors yesterday, and the major market indexes were narrowly mixed at the end of a fairly active session.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NEWMONT MINING CORP., -- Denver, the gold producer, will buy the 6.25 percent of the Newmont Gold Co. that it does not already own for $253 million in stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRONIN, CAROLINE M.
description: CRONIN-Caroline M. (Gallow) of Madison, CT. Survived by four sons, Kevin, Brian, Paul and David V. Cronin, Jr. Two daughters, Caroline Lockyer and Laurie Ann Fornel-Cronin. Three brothers, Colonel Arthur Gallow, George and Robert Gallow. A Mass of Christian Burial, Friday 9am in St. Margaret Church, Madison, CT. Burial Services Friday 12:30 pm Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting hours, Thursday 5-8 pm at the Swan Funeral Home, 825 Boston Post Rd, Madison, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONS, BETSY
description: SIMONS-Betsy of Franklin Lakes, NJ, passed away peacefully on Sept. 28, 1998 at NYU Medical Center, after a courageous & dignified fight with cancer. Beloved wife of Jeffrey and a devoted and loving mother of Andrew and Jennifer. Mrs. Simons graduated Magna Cum Laude from William Paterson University in 1995. She was a graduate student, a student teacher, & an active founding member of Temple Beth Rishon. Her unwavering compassionate support of her family and friends earn her a special place in all of our hearts. In her own words she said, I have no regrets no woulda's, shoulda's, coulda's, every day take a step toward making your dream a reality, no road blocks, just stepping blocks. Services are on Thursday, 12 Noon at the Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: Toni House, 55, an Ex-Journalist And Press Officer for High Court
description: Toni House, an author and a longtime Washington journalist who spent the last 16 years as the Supreme Court's public information officer, died here today of lung cancer, the Court announced. She was 55.

title: Extradition Is Halted In Disappearance Case
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge agreed yesterday to allow prosecutors in Manhattan and Utah to temporarily halt extradition proceedings against the the mother and son who are suspected in the disappearance of an Upper East Side millionaire.

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Two Years Later; Bellwether's Rank and File Strongly Support Clinton
description: In 1996, Canton's newspaper, The Repository, endorsed Bill Clinton for President. It was not an easy call for editorial board members. For much of its history, The Repository has had a Republican slant. At the endorsement meeting, while editors praised the President's economic and welfare overhaul policies and called him courageous for standing up to the gun and tobacco lobbies, they also fretted over ''the character issue,'' ''the womanizer,'' ''the guy involved in Whitewater.''

title: High Court Will Add to Sex Harassment Rulings, Taking Up Case of Offense by Student
description: Adding a dozen cases to the calendar for its new term, the Supreme Court today expanded its review of sexual harassment law and also agreed to decide whether states can impose special welfare limits on new residents.

title: Playoff a Bonanza for ESPN
description: ESPN drew its most viewers for a baseball game Monday night when the Cubs' 5-3 victory over the Giants put Chicago in the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAGE, SEYMOUR
description: SAGE-Seymour. Loving & devoted husband for 58 years of Myra, father of Diane Miltenberg and Carol Rudoltz, grandfather of Andrew Miltenberg, Alissa Miltenberg-Vertes, Stephen Rothandler & Lisa Ullman, great-grandfather of Isabel and Jacob Miltenberg, Zachary and Jacob Ullman. A true gentleman, your love & laughter, courage and strength will echo in our hearts forever. We love and miss you. Myra, Diane, Carol, Andrew, Alissa, Stephen, Lisa, Isabel, Jacob, Zachary, and Jacob

title: The Early Jitters Sank Rangers' Stottlemyre
description: The early jitters that rippled through Rangers starter Todd Stottlemyre dissolved, and the composed right-hander emerged to shut down the Yankees. The transformation occurred too late for Texas last night.

title: Medically Uninsured Still Cost Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; An Internet buying service is planning to book hotel rooms for guests at prices they propose.
description: PRICELINE.COM, the Internet buying service that tries to book flights for travelers at prices they propose, is planning to do the same thing with hotels starting next month.

title: Liberties; Maladroit Du Seigneur
description: When women finally came into power in Washington, they were in the mood to collect some scalps.

title: Nissan Predicts Loss From Stock Holdings
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, said yesterday that its profit for the half year through today would probably fall short of expectations because of a stock valuation loss of 60 billion yen ($446 million). Nissan predicted in May that it would break even in the period, compared with net income of 38.5 billion yen in the corresponding period last year.

title: Congress Can't Turn to Polls on Impeachment; Rewriting History
description: To the Editor:

title: Paying Back College Loans May Be Easier
description: College students who take out Federal loans will pay the lowest interest rate in decades, saving hundreds of dollars each, while grants to poorer students will increase by thousands of dollars under a bill that won final passage in the Senate today and is sure to become law.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Investors View Rate Cut By the Fed as Too Timid
description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates yesterday. Almost nobody cheered.

title: Philips to Help Build Chip Factory in Asia
description: Royal Philips Electronics N.V., the Dutch consumer electronics company, said yesterday that it planned to join with the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company and EDB Investments of Singapore to build a $1.2 billion semiconductor plant in Singapore. Philips will own 48 percent of the venture, with Taiwan Semiconductor owning 32 percent and EDB Investments, a unit of Singapore's Economic Development Board, owning 20 percent.

title: Woman, 85, Dies After Van Hits Her
description: An 85-year-old woman was fatally wounded by a hit-and-run driver whose van struck her as she tried to cross a midtown Manhattan street yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Schumer Presses D'Amato on Abortion
description: Spotlighting one of the clearest points of division between the candidates for Senate, Representative Charles E. Schumer attacked Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday over his opposition to abortion rights, describing him as an ''extremist'' whose votes in Congress had restricted the rights of women.

title: Rangers Ship 5 to Minors
description: With fewer than two weeks remaining before opening night, the Rangers demoted several players, including one who was expected to skate against the Philadelphia Flyers on Oct. 9.

title: Ribs Show Off Their Tender Side
description: WHY is it that some of the fanciest chefs in town positively dote on short ribs?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILL, JESSIE LEONARD
description: HILL-Jessie Leonard. On September 23, 1998. Wife of the late Ray R. Hill and mother of Samuel Ray Hill. Sister of Charles R. Leonard, Jr., Laura Leonard Ault, the late Emelyn Leonard Righter and the late W.A. Hazard Leonard. Also survived by many nieces, nephews, great-nieces and great nephews. Memorial service to be held Nov. 16 at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York City at 11:00 AM. Donations may be sent to the Islesboro Health Center, PO Box 137, Islesboro, ME 04848 or to The American Red Cross, 150 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY 10023.

title: DAVEL BOARD VOTES TO END DEAL TO ACQUIRE PHONETEL
description: Davel Communications Group Inc. said yesterday that its board had voted to end its agreement to buy the pay phone operator Phonetel Technologies Inc. of Cleveland for $51 million in stock. The company did not elaborate. The agreement, announced in June, would have combined Davel's 40,000 pay phones in 36 states and the District of Columbia with Phonetel's 45,000 pay phones in 42 states. Separately, Davel, based in Tampa, Fla., reaffirmed its commitment to join with the Peoples Telephone Company of Miami. The deal, announced in July, would create the nation's largest independent pay phone provider, with more than 83,000 installed phones.

title: Germany's Greens: Can They Put 'Chaos' Behind Them?
description: It has been a roller-coaster year for Germany's environmentalist Greens. They have zigzagged on German troop deployment in Bosnia, called for a near-tripling of gasoline prices, only to shelve the idea, gone back and forth on what to do about NATO and finally found themselves a likely member of Germany's new government.

title: The Sitcom Siren Song
description: Susan Harris, one of television's most successful and prolific comedy writers, has told the world for five years that she was permanently retired after a career in which she wrote the first 70 episodes of the 1970's hit ''Soap'' and created other hits like ''Golden Girls,'' ''Benson'' and ''Empty Nest.''

title: VFB Stuttgart Storms Back
description: VFB Stuttgart made one of the great comebacks in UEFA Cup history yesterday, scoring a 3-0 victory over Feyenoord in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, to overturn the Dutch club's 3-1 first-leg lead.

title: New Season Starts Now
description: Texas Manager Johnny Oates seemingly stopped pondering the notion of opposing a team that won 114 games during the regular season when he said: ''Yesterday, we were 26 games behind the Yankees in the loss column. Today, we're dead even.'' JACK CURRY

title: Two Children of the Pizza Renaissance
description: PIZZA rests on the trinity of tomatoes, mozzarella and dough. Yet as basic as these ingredients are, the results can vary tremendously because the components can be treated in so many ways. What kind of tomatoes are used, and should they be chopped, sliced or pureed? How much moisture, fat and salt should the cheese contain? Should it be sliced or grated? And bakers can go on for hours about what makes their dough distinctive and special.

title: Apropos of the Fall, the Mysterious Fig
description: WHETHER a luscious purple or a pearly light green, figs are always a special treat. To me, they bring to mind pleasant Mediterranean dinners, when figs, cut open to reveal their fleshy pink insides, accompany salty slices of translucent ham at the start of the meal. Often a basket lined with dark green, shiny fig leaves and piled high with purple figs is served for dessert on a warm night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZBAUM, RENEE
description: SCHWARZBAUM-Renee. On September 28, 1998. Of Guttenberg, N.J. Beloved wife of Zvi. Devoted mother, grandmother and dearest friend to many. Services Thursday, 10AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 West Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey.SCHWARZBAUM - Renee. The Partners and the staff of the New York office of our firm mourn the loss of our longtime devoted Office Manager and a good friend. We offer our sincere condolences to her family on the occasion of this sad loss. We will remember her always as a vivacious and helpful colleague. Egon Zehnder International Inc.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a speech in New York by the Iranian Foreign Minister, Kamal Kharrazi, misstated the American policy with which he is displeased. It is the policy toward Iran, not toward Iraq.

title: All Stars, All Ladies, All Glitter, All Night
description: All-star benefit concerts are often poorly organized, long-winded affairs in which the talent is pulled out of a grab bag and a restless audience longs for a director's blue pencil. That's why ''My Favorite Broadway: The Leading Ladies,'' a first-class industrial show (for Continental Airlines) at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening that also raised $50,000 for two AIDS charities, came as a happy (and occasionally thrilling) surprise.

title: Putting Down the Drink to Drown in Reality
description: The title of Ken Loach's new film, ''My Name Is Joe,'' is intentionally incomplete, with Joe Kavanaugh's ''. . . and I'm an alcoholic'' left to the imagination. In the same deliberate way, Mr. Loach keeps a major part of Joe's life under wraps. First heard speaking fervently at a meeting of Alcoholics Anonymous, Joe is determined to put his hard-drinking past behind him. He has been sober for 10 months as the film begins, and has thrown himself furiously into the job of reinventing his life.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Food's Ambassador to Washington; Michel Richard is so creative his mission may well succeed.
description: Michel Richard strode into his kitchen one morning last week and announced, ''I want to make French toast.'' Just French toast?

title: China Applies Brakes on Move Toward Market Economy
description: China's leaders have slipped back into a defensive stance on a range of finance and trade issues, apparently worried that the effects of Asian financial crises will eventually swamp their economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, VICTOR CHARLES
description: KAUFMAN-Victor Charles, 82. Retired Detective/Lieutenant NYPD. Former Com. Officer, Brooklyn South Homicide Squad. USMC, WWII, serving Pacific area and China. Saint John's University Law School, received an LLB. Founder and President of NY Lie Detection Labs. Charter Member of American Polygraph Association, honored with Lifetime Membership Award. On behalf of his profession, he gave many TV interviews. Surviving are his beloved wife, Beverly Hosier Draffin, his son Alfred Kaufman, daughter, Claudette Randazzo, grandsons, John and Robert Randazzo, and step daughters, Rayne Mayer, and Dawne Hentrich. Reposing at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn. Visiting from 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Wednesday and Thursday. Service to be held Thursday evening 7:30 P.M. with the Reverend Niles Blatz, of Grace Church, Brooklyn Heights, in attendance. Interment in the Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: A Cautious Rate Cut
description: By choosing to lower interest rates by only a small amount, the Federal Reserve has opted for a gradual and measured response to the growing problems affecting the world economy.

title: CALENDAR
description: Exploring Mushrooms

title: Newspapers Plan to Fight Ruling on Reporters' Notes
description: At least five major newspapers are preparing to join NBC in challenging a recent Federal appeals court ruling that would make it easier, in some circumstances, to subpoena reporters' notes, videotapes that were not broadcast and other unpublished material in Federal lawsuits.

title: Conviction Is Appealed In Murder of Officer
description: Lawyers for Robert Simon, who was sentenced to death in April for the murder of a Franklin Township police officer, appealed his conviction yesterday in the State Supreme Court, contending his confession was coerced by a co-defendant.

title: White House Considers New Uses for Sampling
description: Having lost two decisions in the lower courts, Clinton Administration officials and advocates of statistical sampling in the 2000 census have begun to think about ways to use a modified form of the methodology even if they do not prevail in the Supreme Court.

title: Saveur With a Truly American Savor
description: SAVEUR magazine, now three years old, has had a notable impact, helping to make grass-roots American cooking fashionable again. It's stylish, knowledgeable, chatty, sometimes quirky and full of gorgeous, you-are-there photographs of food and cooks. Most of all, it explores the connections between people and places and the food they produce.

title: Judge Fines City $19,800 for Ignoring Orders
description: A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that officials of the New York City Police and Correction Departments had shown such ''utter disregard and apparent disdain'' for his orders in defending a civil rights suit that he ordered the city to pay $19,800 in sanctions.

title: About New York; Where Voices Stake a Claim To History
description: SOMETIMES, Mary Marshall Clark hears voices while working in her office atop Butler Library at Columbia University. She doesn't shame them into silence with a shush. They're reassuring, even if they are in her head.

title: Medically Uninsured Still Cost Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: Forbidden Fruit: Freedom and Happiness
description: Potent symbolism linked to a bizarre story rooted in fact, set in Iran and laden with political, social and generational overtones makes ''The Apple'' one of the more intriguingly resonant features of the 36th New York Film Festival.

title: No Longer a Problem, Boomer Is the Solution
description: David Wells was so calm last night that he paused before facing the second Ranger of the game to wave to the rowdy fans chanting his name in the bleachers. It was typical Wells. Why be overly concerned about Roberto Kelly at the plate or Mark McLemore creeping off first base? Just motion toward right field, as always, and then get back to throwing.

title: Executive Changes
description: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL CORP., Dallas, said its president and chief operating officer, Harold D. Marshall, would resign next year.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Yasir Arafat's speech at the United Nations omitted a passage in a quotation. The quotation should have said: ''I would like to call upon all of you, from this place, the source of international legitimacy and peacemaking, the guardian of freedom, security and stability, and the source for the achievement of justice and prosperity for humankind, to stand by our people, especially as the five-year transitional period provided for in the Palestinian-Israeli agreements will end on 4 May 1999 and our people demand of us to shoulder our responsibilities, and they wait the establishment of their independent state.''

title: Heavens Send Earth An Enormous Surge Of Stellar Radiation
description: A powerful blast of stellar radiation briefly penetrated Earth's upper atmosphere one night last month. While it never reached the ground and posed no health hazard, scientists say, the radiation stripped atoms of their electrons and disrupted the quiet of the high night sky with electrical conditions that severely limited the range of radio transmissions. It rocked delicate instruments on at least seven spacecraft, causing temporary shutdowns.

title: Magazine's Bureau Chief Is Forced to Resign
description: The Washington bureau chief of the on-line magazine Salon, who urged his editors not to reveal the 30-year-old affair of Henry J. Hyde, the House Judiciary Committee's chairman, was forced to resign after he publicly questioned the journalistic merits of the decision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WATTENBERG, REGINA CHARITON
description: WATTENBERG-Regina Chariton. Beloved mother of Gaby Brill and Lily Kaplan. Loving grandmother of Lori, Leonard, Todd, Marc Solondz, Michele Kaplan Green, Andrew and David Kaplan. Adoring great grandmother. Service Thursday, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSTWICK, G.H.
description: BOSTWICK-G.H. ''Dolly'', 77. Of 525 Laurens Street, Aiken, SC, entered into rest, Sunday, September 27, 1998, at her residence. Loving mother of Dolly Bostwick, Aiken, SC, Sissy Armstrong, Indian Town, FL, Charles S. Bostwick, Aiken, SC and Richard S. Bostwick, Aiken, S.C. Other survivors include eight grandchildren, Taylor Bostwick, Charles Armstrong, Henrietta Armstrong, Riccardo Armstrong, Tara Gail Bostwick, Elenor Bostwick, Charles Bostwick & Francis Bostwick, 2 sisters, Nannie Steele von Stade Ward, Beaufort, SC and Mrs. John H. Krumpe, Brookeville, NY, and three brothers, Frederick H. von Stade, Del Ray, FL, Philip R. von Stade, Locust Valley, NY and John T. von Stade, Far Hills, New Jersey. Memorial services will be held Thursday, October 1, 1998, at 11:00AM at St. Thaddeus Episcopal Church with Rev. Father Richard Crozier officiating. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be directed to the Hitchcock Foundation, P.O. Box 1702, Aiken, S.C. 29802. Shellhouse Funeral Home, Inc, 924 Hayne Ave, Aiken, SC, phone 803-642-3456.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Cafe Boulud Opens

title: Death in the Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Rally's Hamburgers in 2 Acquisitions
description: Rally's Hamburgers Inc. agreed on Monday to acquire two restaurant companies, Giant Group Ltd. and Checkers Drive-In Restaurants Inc., for $64.7 million in stock.

title: Wells Gives His All, and It's All Yanks Need
description: Joe Torre jogged to the mound in the eighth inning last night and invaded the personal space of David Wells, going chest to chest. Wells stepped backed uncomfortably, but Torre, the Yankee manager, moved forward, looking the pitcher directly in the eyes, and asked, ''How are you feeling?''

title: City Government Lawyer Is Accused of Scalping
description: A Corporation Counsel lawyer was among 64 people arrested last night on charges of trying to scalp tickets for the Yankees-Rangers playoff game, the police said.

title: Julian Allen, 55, Illustrator; Worked for Many Periodicals
description: Julian Allen, an illustrator best known for realistic visual essays on contemporary subjects like the Watergate scandal, the Israeli raid to free hostages at the airport in Entebbe, Uganda, and the gangs of the South Bronx, died on Monday at a hospice in Baltimore. He was 55 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, MARY R.
description: WALSH-Mary R. Formerly of Hartsdale, NY. on September 27, 1998. Mass of Christian Burial, Sacred Heart Church, Hartsdale, Friday, 10:00AM. For information contact Bennett Funeral Home.

title: Ousted Malaysian, in Court, Denies Sex and Graft Charges
description: Visibly bruised and asserting that he had been beaten by his jailers, Malaysia's ousted Deputy Prime Minister, Anwar Ibrahim, denied in court today charges of corruption and sexual misconduct.

title: EATON TO SHUT PLANT IN TEXAS AND LAY OFF 475 WORKERS
description: The Eaton Corporation said yesterday that it would close its ion equipment plant in Austin, Tex., and lay off a total of 475 workers as it continues a reorganization in an effort to return to profitability. Eaton said that about 200 of the 239 workers at its Austin plant would be laid off and that the remaining workers would be offered positions at the company's plant in Beverly, Mass. The additional 275 layoffs, Eaton said, will be in the company's worldwide semiconductor equipment operations. The company also said that the reorganization would result in costs of $42 million, or 38 cents a share, to be recorded in the third quarter, which ends today. Eaton, based in Cleveland, plans to record more costs related to the revamping in the fourth quarter and in the first quarter of 1999.

title: Gordon Parks Donates 227 Works to Corcoran
description: Gordon Parks was so pleased by the way the Corcoran Gallery of Art put together an exhibition of his photographs that he has given 227 of them, practically every one in the show, to the museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRAGAMO, FIAMMA
description: FERRAGAMO-Fiamma, Marchesa Paterno di San Giuliano. September 28, Florence, Italy. Beloved and dearest friend, I will miss you forever. My deepest sympathy to Giuseppe, Diego, Giulia, Maria and to Wanda, Giovanna, Ferruccio, Fulvia, Leonardo, Massimo, and all the family. Love, Gioconda Crivelli

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOLLETT, JOHN J.
description: FOLLETT-John J. Holland Lodge #

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about European leaders' reaction to the German election misidentified the major European country governed by conservative parties. It is Spain, not Italy.

title: Congress Can't Turn to Polls on Impeachment
description: To the Editor:
